title: HOW ONE LADDER CAME TO COST $1,676
description: The AA Ladder and Supply Company of 2305 Rhode Island Avenue, N.E., sells its sturdiest 10-foot aluminum ladder with hooks for $160.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: The latest qr and 9 mos net increased by 3 cents a shr and 11 cents a shr, respectively, on reduction of certain inventory levels accounted for under the LIFO method

title: ARMY REPLACING STEEL HELMET
description: After 40 years and three wars, the Army is trading in its metal helmet for a new, stronger, fiberglass model that looks a little like the headgear worn by the Germans in World War II.

title: AN MX 'DENSE PACK' WOULD NEED ABM'S, BOTH PERILING SECURITY
description: President Reagan's proposal to deploy MX missiles in Wyoming in a tight configuration occupying barely 14 square miles, aptly labeled ''dense pack,'' ends a five-year quest for a basing mode that would protect this new intercontinental ballistic missile from Soviet attack. Yet the dense pack would be vulnerable, even to inaccurate and unreliable Soviet missiles. The only way to protect it would be to build an antiballistic missile system - a costly and, under treaty obligations, illegal move.

title: Smith Defends Record On Civil Rights Issues
description: Attorney General William French Smith defended the Justice Department's record on civil rights today and said he believed criticism of the agency's actions had been politically motivated.

title: U.S. SUES CHICAGO PARK DISTRICT, CHARGING RACIAL BIAS IN PROGRAMS
description: The Federal Government filed a civil rights suit today against the Chicago Park District, charging the district with a broad range of discrimination in the programs and facilities it provides for black and Hispanic neighborhoods.

title: Moving Day In Mexico
description: Mexico gets a new President every 6 years and a new generation every 15 years. This, as usual, is the problem facing Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado as he takes responsibility for governing this fabulous and beautiful country: how to deal with both its faltering economy and its spectacular fertility.

title: SEARCH IS UNDER WAY TO FILL KUHN'S JOB
description: While many of the 26 club owners explore the talent available in the free-agent market, six of them have begun exploring the talent available in the commissioner market.

title: ABORTION RESTRICTION CASES ARGUED BEFORE HIGH COURT
description: The abortion issue returned to the Supreme Court today. For three hours, the Justices heard arguments on the constitutionality of various obstacles that state and local governments have placed in the path of women seeking abortions in the nearly 10 years since the Court declared that the Constitution protects the right to have an abortion.

title: FLOWER TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 INCUMBENTS IN GEORGIA WIN RE-ELECTION TO SEATS IN HOUSE
description: Representative Elliott H. Levitas and Representative Wyche Fowler Jr., Democratic incumbents, won reelection today in the nation's last midterm Congressional races.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in July 1982

title: 4 OFFICERS AMONG 10 SEIZED IN GAMBLING TIP-OFF SCHEME
description: Four members of the New York City Police Department and a former officer were among 10 men arrested yesterday in connection with a scheme to warn owners of illegal gambling operations in Manhattan of impending police raids.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AFTER cocktails and hors d'oeuvres of marinated mushrooms, cheese tidbits and pate came a sumptuous dinner: French onion soup, rolls and butter, roast beef and gravy, baked potato and sour cream, fried zucchini, wine, salad with a garlic-and-vinegar dressing, chocolate cake, coffee, a cigarette and a handful of mints on the way out the door. Hardly an unusual meal for an American eating out.

title: FOOD GIFTS FOR YOUR CHRISTMAS LIST
description: HERE is no one for whom it is easier to find a Christmas gift than a cook -with the exception, perhaps, of a small child. Cooks always have long wish lists. If they do not covet the newest in food processors, they yearn for a year-round source of fresh herbs. If they do not seek equipment to make their small kitchens more efficient, they are extolling the virtues of a new kind of vinegar.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: U.N. Pays Off Its Mortgage

title: DOW SOARS BY 36.43, TO 1,039.28
description: Buoyed by heavy buying from pension funds and other large institutions, the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday soared 36.43 points, its fourth-biggest one-day gain in history.

title: ON ALLOWING A PATIENT TO DIE
description: To the Editor:

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 16
News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1982
description: International President Reagan arrived in Brazil to put his personal endorsement on improved ties between the United States and Latin America's largest country. Brasilia is the first stop on Mr. Reagan's five-day, four-nation Latin American journey. (Page A1, Col. 5.) Moderate policies in Spain were pledged by Felipe Gonzales, who said his new Cabinet would pursue a domestic policy of austerity and would review military ties to the United States and NATO. In a 70-minute address to Parliament, Mr. Gonzalez outlined a posture as cautious as the men he has carefully picked for the first Socialist Cabinet since the Spanish Civil War. (A10:3-4.)

title: CINDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Andropov's Son Speaks At East-West Session
description: Igor Y. Andropov, son of the new Soviet Communist Party leader, today told a session of the East-West conference on European security that the West had ignored important issues when making up a package of human rights amendments.

title: U.S. Court Denies Black-Duck Plea
description: Judge Joyce Hens Green of Federal District Court denied today a request by the Humane Society of the United States that the Fish and Wildlife Service close this year's hunting season for the black duck.

title: TORREY MAY SHOP A BIT
description: Bill Torrey is a man of habit. Take his bow tie, for example. Only once in many years has he been seen in public without some form of bow tie between his chest and his chin.

title: SPAIN'S NEW LEADER OUTLINES CAUTIOUS PLANS TO PARLIAMENT
description: Felipe Gonzalez said today that his new Cabinet would pursue a domestic policy of austerity and would review its military ties to the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: U.S. LIFTING BAN ON PROCESSING OF CANADIAN TRUCKING APPLICATIONS
description: The Reagan Administration today lifted a moratorium on the processing of applications by Canadian trucking companies to operate across the border, serving points in the United States.

title: Second Prison Drinker Dies
description: A second prisoner who drank cleaning fluid taken from the Oregon State Penitentiary paint shop died today. Donald Fisher, 47 years old, who had been in critical condition, died at a hospial, the state police said. Thomas Dillon, 26, died Sunday afternoon after the drinking incident Friday night.

title: HOUSE VOTES BACK I.R.S. SCHOOL RULE
description: The House this evening rejected two proposed appropriations riders that would have restricted the power of the Internal Revenue Service to act against private schools that discriminate on the ground of race.

title: Navy Reserve to Start
description: Gary Tranquill, the Navy coach, said he would start a third-string sophomore quarterback against Army Saturday. He said that Ricky Williamson would start the game at Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium because the No. 1 quarterback, Marco Pagnanelli, had a broken leg and the No. 2 man, Tom Tarquinio, had an injured shoulder.

title: MISS O'NEILL, ACTRESS, AND HUSBAND FACING CHARGES ON REVOLVER
description: The actress Jennifer O'Neill and her husband, John Lederer, have been indicted on criminal charges of possessing an unlicensed gun, the Westchester County District Attorney announced today.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan conceded he has given up any hope of persuading Congress to advance next July's 10 percent income tax cut. Before leaving on his five-day Latin-American trip, Mr. Reagan listed his priorities for the special session of Congress now under way. He said he still favors moving up the tax cut, but will probably have to work to keep Congress from repealing it. (Page A1.)

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Nov 20
description: Shr earns reflect a 5 percent stock divd to be paid Dec 15

title: MEXICO TO INSTALL NEW CHIEF TODAY
description: Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado begins a sixyear term as President of Mexico Wednesday, assuming the double challenge of lifting the country out of its worst economic recession in 40 years and preserving political stability at a time of growing hardship for most Mexicans.

title: DANCE: LIMON OPENS WITH SOKOLOW WORK
description: NOT all the works in the current repertory of the Jose Limon Dance Company, which opened last night at the Joyce Theater, are by Limon. But they are, 10 years after Limon's death, clearly related to the principles of dance in which he so firmly believed.

title: PEARCE URSTADT MAYER & GREER reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $330,000 or 39 cents a shr for the latest yr and $213,000 or 21 cents a shr for the previous yr

title: SOME PRACTICAL HOLIDAY GIFTS FOR WELL-EQUIPPED KITCHENS
description: ANEIGHBOR of mine once told me that there are two kinds of gift givers in this world, the romantic and the practical. If that is true, then I undoubtedly fall into the latter category.

title: Nebraska Minister Jailed For Defying School Ban
description: The Rev. Everett Sileven, director of the Faith Christian School, was arrested early today and returned to jail for defying a judge's order to keep his uncertified church school closed.

title: LEADING INDICATORS POST SLIGHT RISE
description: The index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to forecast trends in the economy, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Itel Securities Suits Tentatively Settled
description: The Itel Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a tentative settlement with plaintiffs in several class-action securities suits. The agreement would provide for payment of up to $40 million to people who had purchased securities from May 25, 1977, to Dec. 5, 1979.

title: AILEY DANCERS OPEN SEASON TONIGHT
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will open a three-week season tonight at 8 at the City Center with the company premiere of Hans van Manen's ''Songs Without Words'' and recent popular successes by Louis Johnson and Billy Wilson.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for 12 weeks to Oct 16
description: B-Including tax credits of $11,472,000 for the 12 weeks and $12,640,000 for the28 weeks

title: ENS BIO LOGICAL (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including interest income of $365,236 for the qr and $1,483,309 for the 9 mos, a foreign currency translation loss of $496,522 for the qr and a foreign currency translation gain of $519,241 for the 9 mos...C-Including interest income of $758,510 for the qr and $1,361,610 fora the 9 mos and foreign currency translation gains of $173,088 for the qr and $219,489 for the 9 mos

title: Chrysler Plant Starts Doing Canadians' Work
description: Under orders from the United Automobile Workers today, employees at a Chrysler Corporation plant in Kokomo, Ind., began producing parts previously made by striking union members in Canada.

title: DUTCH BALLET OPENING
description: No, the Dutch National Ballet is not the ''nude ballet'' company of Holland. New York might be forgiven for confusing the troupe with the Netherlands Dance Theater, a far more frequent visitor to the city and one that performed a memorable ballet in the nude in 1970. But the Dutch National, which opens tonight for a two-week season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, will doubtless cause shock waves of its own with a repertory that is decidedly about something more than dance: old age, death, war and free-floating anxiety.

title: SENATOR CITES BAD MEMORY ON BRIBERY DEFENDANTS
description: Senator Howard W. Cannon completed his testimony today in the conspiracy case in which the Government contends he was the target of attempted bribery.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: BANK OF MONTREAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Cutting the Cord
description: Being a football player on a team coached by your father is no fun at all, especially when it's a losing team, said Tim Salem, the backup quarterback for the University of Minnesota and the son of the Gophers' coach, Joe Salem.

title: Fannie Mae Sets Loan Plan
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association plans to make $192 million in home loan money available to prospective house buyers through a new arrangement worked out with a large home builders group, officials said.

title: PANEL RECOMMENDS 6 LANES ON THE HUTCHINSON PARKWAY
description: The Westchester Parkway Commission today recommended a $73 million reconstruction of the Hutchinson River Parkway that would widen it to six lanes from the present four lanes for a distance of 7.4 miles, from Eastchester to Harrison.

title: RIBLET PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN'S DEPARTURE SPEECH
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's statement at the White House yesterday before his departure for Latin America, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: CARROLL E. FRENCH
description: Carroll E. French, a labor relations adviser to major American corporations, died Monday at his home in Andover, Mass. He was 87 years old.

title: Farmers' Prices Up By 0.9%
description: Prices farmers get for raw products rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in November but did not make up ground lost in a sharp decline the month before, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Brazil; Geography
description: Brazil, which covers nearly half of South America, is bounded on the east by the Atlantic Ocean and borders on every country except Ecuador and Chile. Much of the north and northwest is a humid, tropical region drained by the Amazon.

title: Mubarak Flies to India
description: President Hosni Mubarak flew to India today for a two-day visit and talks with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on promoting the role of the nations that profess nonalignment. Officials said Mr. Mubarak was eager to revive cooperation between Egypt, India and Yugoslavia, the three countries that are the founders of the nonaligned movement.

title: HLH PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; revs for the latest 6 mos includes a gain of $2,738,601 on the sale of oil and gas properties

title: A SIGNAL TO THE LATINS
description: President Reagan's visit to Brazil, Colombia and Costa Rica sends a long overdue signal that the United States and Latin America continue to share strategic interests and must close ranks.

title: Comex Barred On S.& P. Use
description: The Standard and Poor's Corporation, the credit rating agency, said yesterday that a Federal District Court had granted a permanent injunction prohibiting the Commodity Exchange from trading or advertising futures contracts based on the S.& P. 500 stock price index.

title: Bridge: Reisinger Winners Showed They Hadn't Lost Stamina
description: The East Coast foursome that captured the prestigious Reisinger Team title in Minneapolis Sunday was easily the oldest team in the final. But the winners' stamina did not fail in a grueling test that called for roughly 64 deals of board-a-match play, the toughest form of competition, for three straight days.

title: PATTI CATALANO STARTING BACK
description: This past year was one in which Patti Catalano set no records, broke no tapes at finish lines and won no races. But it was the year that Patti Catalano defeated the depression that had almost ended her running career.

title: THROUGH BARS, A TEARFUL REUNION OF PENTACOSTALS
description: Kneeling on the sill of the barred basement window of the United States Embassy, Avgustina Vashchenko saw her two youngest children today for the first time in four and a half years.

title: Mental Health Is Not a Jobs Program
description: Each year New York State spends in excess of $700 million on a network of aging state mental hospitals whose functions are increasingly obsolete. After years of discharging mental patients to the ''least restrictive environment'' - a policy encouraged by the availability of new drugs, changes in treatment philosophy and the courts - the hospitals are drastically underpopulated. For better or worse, most people who now need mental health services in New York State live in urban communities, straining local budgets for community programs and aid to the homeless.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said the rate on its auction of $200 million of 91-day paper rose to 9.199 percent, from 8.964 percent last week.

title: US SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Pursue the Poisoners
description: Toxic waste is no longer just a byproduct of industry; it's an industry itself, subject to alarming temptations to maximize profit at the expense of public safety.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After a loss of $87,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $710,000 on sale of discontinued operations...C-Net income after a loss of $45,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a gain of $27,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $710,000 from sale of discontinued operations...E-Net income after a gain of $277,000 from discontinued operations

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 1, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: AKRON'S 1978 RULES WERE ENJOINED ALMOST AT START
description: After several young rock fans were suffocated by the crush at a Cincinnati rock concert several years ago, the Akron City Council adopted a crowd-control ordinance.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: One View of Rehabilitation

title: N.F.L. Is Studying Film of Blinka Foul
description: Art McNally, the National Football League's supervisor of officials, said today that a film study was being made of the blow that Stan Blinka of the Jets delivered to the jaw of John Jefferson, the Packers' wide receiver, knocking him out of last Sunday's game.

title: COLUMBIA PICTURES, CBS AND HBO PLAN STUDIO
description: Columbia Pictures Industries, CBS Inc. and Home Box Office announced plans yesterday to create a motion picture company that they hope will blossom into one of Hollywood's major studios.

title: Judge Brian O'Neill, 44, Of Hartford State Court
description: Judge Brian E. O'Neill, who had been handling the state's corruption cases against former Transportation Commissioner Arthur B. Powers and seven others, died today at Hartford Hospital after a brief illness. He was 44 years old and lived in Wethersfield, Conn.

title: AMERICAN MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DANKER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
KURT LORE, EXPERT ON PROPERTY LAW
description: Kurt W. Lore, a partner in the Wall Street law firm of Thacher, Proffitt & Wood and a specialist in real estate, died Nov. 23 at a nursing home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 68 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: G.P.U. Wins Round in Court
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation said the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania had denied the Government's motion to dismiss G.P.U.'s suit against it.

title: RUTGERS SETS BACK PRINCETON BY 60-55
description: Coach Pete Carril, the master of the patient game, wanted to see if his Princeton basketball team was really guilty of holding the ball too much and slowing games, something it has been accused of in recent years. So he agreed to meet Rutgers on its own terms tonight - a 40-second shot clock and a 19-foot-9-inch, 3-point circle at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: Y.& R. USA Names Vice President, Director
description: E. William Munsel, 57, has been named an executive vice president and a director of Young & Rubicam USA. He became part of the Y.& R. organization when his agency, Creswell, Munsell, Schubert & Zirbel, of which he now becomes chairman, was acquired in 1974. C.M.F.& Z.'s new president and chief executive will be Richard Meyocks.

title: Massachusetts Begins Plan To Help Poor Insulate Homes
description: Massachusetts officials today presented the first rebate checks to help poor people insulate their homes. Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, president of the Citizens Conservation Corporation, which is administering the program, said there were two goals: giving tenants an incentive to conserve fuel, and preventing the waste of Government-subsidized fuel in poorly insulated buildings.

title: BRIEFING
description: Nursing Loan Defaults

title: Follett Asset Sale
description: Esquire Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the assets of Follett Publishing Company, a division of the closely held Follett Corporation of Chicago.

title: ON LEBANESE FRONT WITH WINTER NEAR, THE ISRAELIS SETTLE IN
description: Israeli soldiers who hold front-line positions near here, 400 yards from Syrian troops, are preparing for winter. Underground bunkhouses accommodating an infantry squad have been built. Heavy clothing has been issued.

title: The Incide Dopes
description: The boys didn't like the rumors going around. ''You can speak Megatongue,'' they told me. ''Ask them at headquarters what's going on.'' Megatongue is the language of the nuclear thinkers, and I don't understand it any better than most other missiles do. ''Look, I'm just a plain-spoken old MX missile like the rest of you,'' I objected. ''If headquarters hits me with one of those 20-megatongue words I'll look like a fool.''

title: Rider Ban Upheld
description: An Illinois appeals court today upheld the lifetime suspension of the jockey Ben Feliciano for possession of a battery device used to stimulate horses during races. The device was discovered in Feliciano's car at Arlington Park June 16, 1981, after an anonymous tip. Feliciano's lawyers argued that the search of his car was illegal but the police said Feliciano had signed a consent form allowing the search.

title: AMERICAN SHIPBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. TO SELL MORE ARMS TO TAIWAN
description: The Pentagon said today that it planned to sell Taiwan $97 million worth of army vehicles, the first such deal since shortly after a United States-Chinese statement on limiting arms sales to Taiwan.

title: KENNEDY REPORTED DECLINING TO SEEK PRESIDENCY IN 1984
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy told close advisers tonight that he would not run for the Presidency in 1984. Larry Horowitz, administrative assistant to the Massachusetts Democrat, said late tonight that the Senator would hold a news conference on Capitol Hill Wednesday ''to discuss his plans for 1984.''

title: Santa Fe Accord
description: The United States Department of Energy said that the Santa Fe Energy Company, a subsidiary of Santa Fe Industries, had signed a $2.7 million proposed settlement of all Government allegations that Santa Fe Energy overcharged for crude oil between September 1973 and January 1981. Under terms of the pact, Santa Fe did not admit to any violation or noncompliance with Federal oil pricing regulations.

title: Union Board To Vote Today
description: The chief negotiators for the National Football League players and owners met yesterday in Washington to make final the language of the new five-year collective bargaining agreement that will be voted on Friday by the league's 1,500 players.

title: BRITAIN TO INCREASE ULSTER FORCES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government will add 800 men to Northern Ireland's police forces and will increase security spending by $20 million a year in the province, Britain's Cabinet Minister for Northern Ireland announced today.

title: Bank Merger
description: A proposed $100 million merger between the CBT Corporation and State National Bank of Connecticut has received final approval from Federal banking regulators, following the banks' agreement to sell five branch offices. The approval, granted by the United States Comptroller of the Currency, hinged on the combined banks' divestiture of about $30 million in deposits and as many as six offices. The banks also need approval from the United States Department of Justice.

title: Pirates Arrange Pay-TV Contract
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates have signed a five-year contract with Warner Amex Cable, operators of the city's cable-TV system, to televise at least 60 games a season on an allsports pay channel to be started in 1983.

title: Utah Doctors Pick Man To Get Artificial Heart
description: The first human recipient of an artificial heart developed at the University of Utah has been selected, and surgery is scheduled for early Thursday, the school said today.

title: Erdos & Morgan
description: Arthur J. Morgan, 70, executive vice president of Erdos & Morgan, the marketing research firm that he and Paul Erdos founded in 1947, has resigned. Mr. Morgan will continue to act as counsel and remain a member of the board.

title: Stock Index Plan Approved
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has approved a plan by the New York Futures Exchange to trade futures on the New York Stock Exchange's composite index, an agency spokesman said today.

title: JUDGE QUESTIONS WITNESS ON NUCLEAR ACCIDENT
description: The first day of redirect examination of a key witness in the Three Mile Island trial was taken over yesterday by the judge, who tore into the witness's statement that he had ''refreshed his memory'' on contradictory testimony given earlier.

title: Mitterrand Winds Up His Stay in India
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France toured central and southern India today at the end of a four-day visit that officials say has succeeded in establishing special ties between India and France.

title: BBDO International
description: The board of directors of BBDO International has voted to recommend an increase in the number of shares the corporation is authorized to issue, from 4.5 million, to 10 million shares, and split the the outstanding stock 2 for 1 in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend, payable to stockholders of record on Jan. 24. But first, the authorization must be approved by stockholders at a special meeting on Jan. 19.

title: Tar Heels Win In 3 Overtimes
description: Michael Jordan's 3-point play with 1:48 left in the third overtime tonight led North Carolina, last season's national champions, to a 70-68 victory over Tulane as the Tar Heels (1-2) snapped a two-game losing streak.

title: Redistricting Overturned In Washington State
description: Washington's newly drawn Congressional districts were rejected today by a three-judge Federal panel, and the Legislature was ordered to produce a better plan.

title: Careers; Ruling's Impact on Dismissals
description: THE name Walton Lewis Weiner raises a red flag for company personnel directors. The New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, handed down a decision on Nov. 18 (case No.485), upholding Mr. Weiner's right to sue McGraw-Hill Inc. because he was discharged by the publishing company.

title: Marathon Man
description: At the age of 50, Fred Lebow directs marathons in New York and advises foreign countries on staging their own marathons. And, more often than not, he then gets into his running shoes and runs the marathon himself.

title: A COURT DATE AFTER ALL
description: Can a judge hold courtroom spectators in contempt for refusing on the ground of religion to stand up when the bailiff commands ''All rise!'' as the judge enters or leaves the courtoom?

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Edison Professorship Set Up
description: Columbia University has established a Thomas Alva Edison professorship with the aid of a $1 million grant from the Consolidated Edison Company. The professorial chair, which will deal with energy-related subjects, is the first in the country named for the inventor, Fred Knubel, a university spokesman, said yesterday.

title: A Nobel Winner Assesses Reagan
description: Friedrich A. von Hayek, winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, says that ''on the whole'' he approves of the economic policy of the Reagan Administration.

title: 'BUBBLE' CHILD REPORTED CURED
description: Doctors say they have successfully treated a baby girl who was born without resistance to disease and thus had been required to live in a germ-free plastic bubble.

title: MET OPERA: EVA MARTON
description: THE arrival on the scene of a fully matured Wagnerian singer is always good news, however long we must wait between dispatches from the front. The news today is that Eva Marton has arrived. The Hungarian artist, portraying Elisabeth for the first time with the Metropolitan Opera in Monday night's ''Tannhauser,'' showed that she has the vocal and temperamental qualities to become the opera world's next important dramatic soprano. She may, in fact, already be there. The timbre is right, the sheer staying power is impressive and the instincts are those of a born actress.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe Defeats Borg, 6-3, 2-6, 6-4

title: Pistons 123, Celtics 116
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Isiah Thomas scored 29 points as Detroit ended Boston's eight-game winning streak.

title: POLICE LINK IT TO CRIME FAMILY
description: A bookmaking operation that is believed to have been mob-connected and to have handled more than $25 million a year in illegal sports bets was broken up Monday night with police raids on six of the ring's facilities in three New York City boroughs, the authorities said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HALL MARKS

title: I.B.M. SUIT ON SECRETS IS SETTLED
description: Two former I.B.M. engineers sued by the company for stealing corporate secrets consented yesterday to a permanent injunction and final judgment against them, ending the suit.

title: Champion Wins
description: Hilario Zapata of Panama retained his World Boxing Council junior-flyweight championship tonight with an eighthround knockout of Tadashi Tomori of Japan. Tomori, who was battered in the later rounds, was saved by the bell after he was knocked down at the end of the seventh.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: EDWIN NEWMAN notes that at Blimpie's, on 42d Street east of Fifth Avenue, ''it is now possible to buy kiche, in three varieties. So, at any rate, a sign in the window proclaims.''

title: Connecticut Killer Gets Life in Prison
description: The first person to be sentenced under Connecticut's revised capital punishment law was spared the death penalty today and sentenced instead to life in prison. A threejudge Superior Court panel unanimously sentenced the convicted killer, John McGann, for the murder for hire of a man in 1981.

title: Calling for Cornstarch
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Market Place; Earnings Buoy Smucker Price
description: IN early November, shares of the J.M. Smucker Company, the nation's biggest producer of jams and jellies, were selling on the New York Stock Exchange at around $53; by yesterday they had risen to $70.25. But unlike numerous instances where a company's stock has shown a big gain, Smucker is not a takeover target. Its market price has been gaining on the basis of strong earnings.

title: OTIS ELEVATOR TO LEAVE BIRTHPLACE
description: The Otis Elevator Company plant in Yonkers, where the safety elevator was invented, is to be closed by mid-1983, officials of the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford, its parent company, announced today. They cited technological changes in the building industry.

title: HELIONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains

title: 1. Make a Baptism Dress
description: The tradition of dressing a baby in a long christening dress is a charming one, but anyone who has shopped for an embroidered dress knows that prices usually run well over three figures. However, if the infant has a godmother or relative who is handy with her needle, a dress, cap and petticoat can be made from a kit for $18.95. The kit, put together by a company called the Patchmakers, includes precut white batiste, lace, embroidery thread and patterns for the embroidery. It makes a copy of a 19th-century dress that is in the collection of the Brooklyn Museum and can be bought at the museum shop at Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue, or at its Manhattan branch in the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street.

title: WINE TALK
description: COMPARISON tastings of Champagne are rare. The quality of Champagne in general is very high and the differences evident to unskilled palates are subtle. Moreover, Champagne is expensive, which can be a deterrent to anyone considering tasting a half-dozen or more brands.

title: Economic Scene; GATT Talks: 3 Score Cards
description: WAS the trade negotiation in Geneva a partial success or an ominous failure? The judges at ringside have scored the fight differently. Lawrence B. Krause, the top international economist of the Brookings Institution, says the ministerial conference accomplished all that ''any sophisticated person could have expected it to do - made a beginning toward the negotiation of some key issues in the next few years.''

title: YANKEES, BAYLOR IN ACCORD
description: Activity in the free-agent market has lagged since the Nov.10 draft, but the Yankees will bring some life to it today with an announcement that they have reached agreement with Don Baylor.

title: Wine for Sale
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In the Wine Talk column of Sept. 29, Robert B. Beleson, president of Remy Martin Amerique, is quoted as saying: ''We're now looking into California table wines. As you know, everything out there is for sale.''

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
1,000 Attend Rites For Slain Student
description: About 1,000 family members, friends and schoolmates of 18-year-old Amie Hoffman, who was found fatally stabbed on Thanksgiving Day, attended a memorial service for her here today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Richfield, Ohio. The Knicks did not lose a game in six meetings with the Cavaliers last season, and this is their first meeting this season. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M.) Nets vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md. In their last meeting, also in Landover, Jeff Ruland, the former Iona star, scored 21 points and grabbed 13 rebounds as the Bullets gave the Nets their worst defeat this season, 104-85. (Radio - WVNJ, 620 AM, 8 P.M.) College: Notre Dame vs. Kentucky, at South Bend, Ind. (Television - ESPN Cable, 8 P.M.) St. John's vs. Columbia, at Levien Gymnasium, Broadway and West 119th Street, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WNYE, 91.5-FM; 7:25 P.M. WKCR, 89.9 FM, 7:25 P.M. and WGBB, 1240 AM.) Syracuse vs. St. Bonaventure, at Syracuse Carrier Dome, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WNYE, 91.5 FM, after St. John's-Columbia game.) Seton Hall vs. Fordham, at Rose Hill Gymnasium, the Bronx. (Radio - WFUV, 90.7-FM; 7:45 P.M.) Other games, all 8 P.M.: Concordia at Brooklyn; Wagner at Iona; Stony Brook at City; Baruch at John Jay; Merchant Marine at C.W. Post; Hunter at York; Kean at New Jersey Tech; Vassar at Lehman; Pace at Pratt; New York Tech at Stevens Tech.

title: BUDGET 'WORRIES' M.A.C.
description: Members of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday called on Governor Carey, Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders to put aside the partisan ''pressures'' of political life and work together to solve the budget deficits of the state, the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Plan to Put Nuclear Missiles In Sicily Assailed by Bishops
description: Two leading Italian bishops have spoken out against plans to install nuclear missiles in Sicily and sided with American bishops condemning the nuclear arms race.

title: 21-Month-Old Boy Falls To Death From Window
description: A 21-month-old boy fell to his death last night from a seventhfloor apartment window in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: THE FEINT THAT FOOLED DOLPHINS
description: For Neal Colzie, who grew up fantasizing that he was running back interceptions in the Orange Bowl for the Miami Dolphins, it was a sort of sweet reality. After a neat fake, he wound up in a spot where he was not supposed to be, or so the Miami quarterback, Don Strock, apparently thought. Then Colzie made the interception and a 51-yard return that helped his team, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, beat the Dolphins Monday night, 23-17.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Plan Corp., Woodbury, N.Y., has elected Abe Jay Lieber chairman and president and Robert C. Hall vice chairman.

title: APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains from discontinued operations of $128,000 for the qr and $370,000 for the yr...C-Including gains from discontinued operations of $128,000 for the qr and $10.3 million for the yr

title: BLOCK, H & R, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CORECTIONS
description: A picture caption in some copies of Business Day Monday, with an article about Music Television, incorrectly identified people shown in an interview. Alan Hunter of MTV was interviewing Brian O'Neil of the Bus Boys.

title: 2 LOTTERIES PROVIDE $13.6 MILLION WORTH OF DREAMS
description: If living well is indeed the best revenge, then across New Jersey this week there are thousands of people who harbor dreams of getting even.

title: EASIER NATO STANCE ON MISSILES HINTED
description: Officials of the Atlantic alliance gave signs today of increased readiness to seek a compromise solution in negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union about intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Reassigned Marv F oley, catcher; Keith Desjarlais, Juan A gosto, pitchers, and Rusty Kuntz, out- f ielder, to Denver farm. CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Ferguson J enkins, pitcher, to two-year contract.

title: RECESSION CUTS BOARDING SCHOOL ROLE
description: An unusually large number of students who accepted admission at private secondary schools last spring backed out at the last minute this fall because of economic fears, admissions officers nationwide report.

title: PRESIDENTIALLY BELITTLED MILITARY BUILDUP
description: To the Editor:

title: Search Fails at Missile Site
description: Divers groped through inky water at the bottom of a test cell for two hours today but found no trace of two of four technicians killed Saturday in a flash fire at the Arnold Engineering Development Center. The first body was found Sunday and the second Monday night. The four technicians were working in the bottom of the shaft to recover 30,000 pounds of MX missile fuel and were killed when the fuel ignited.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Eleanor Roosevelt Remembered

title: Space Center Said to Find Cause of Suit Problems
description: Engineers at the Johnson Space Center have tentatively decided what caused the failure of two spacesuits during the fifth flight of the space shuttle Columbia, an informed source said today.

title: 2 Italians Die in Avalanche
description: Two Italian skiers died in an avalanche on slopes in the Alps Sunday, the police said today. The bodies of the skiers, ages 17 and 28, were found Monday by rescue workers.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $230,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary tax credit of $1,430,000...C-Net loss; yr-ago results are unconsolidated and reflect operations prior to the acquisitions of April-Marcus Inc and Apparel Inc on Oct 29, 1981

title: Index; International
description: Pentecostals in Moscow in tear- ful sidewalk meeting A2 Walesa and aides pray for guid- ance A3 NATO officials hint at easier stance on missiles A3 One injured by letter bomb sent to Mrs. Thatcher A4 Disputes delay Fanfani an- nouncement of Cabinet A8 Around the World A9 Britain to strengthen Ulster's se- curity forces A11 Mexico to install new leader today A13 Administration fights Congres- sional cut in money for NATO A15 Government/Politics Two Georgia incumbents win re- election in House races A18 New York-area officials want more transit aid B2 Akron abortion ordinance was en- joined at beginning B4 Washington Talk Briefing B8 Congress: Key votes coming up on leadership posts B8 How some aluminum ladders came to cost $1,676 each B8 Command to ''all rise'' for the judge is taken to court B8 General Around the Nation A17 Senator's memory fails on talks with bribery defendants A24 Judge questions key witness in Three Mile Island trial A26 Figure in Tylenol case surren- ders A28 Historic Otis Elevator plant in Yonkers to close B2 Concern is accused of negligence in handling city insurance B3 Miss O'Neill, the actress, and husband indicted in gun case B3 Texas defendant continues to deny he killed a Federal judge B5 The Living Section Food Food gifts for Christmas C1

title: WASTE PLANT: DEFEAT FROM VICTORY'S JAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Interest Rates Increase a Bit; Demand Is Called Weak
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday in quiet trading as market participants reported weak investor demand, with little followthrough after Monday's sharp drop in prices.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an item in the Business People column on Nov. 18 misstated the way in which Richard T. Gralton, the new president and chief operating officer of the Savin Corporation, was recruited. Savin initiated an executive search.

title: A.T.& T. Issue Priced at $60
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's recently announced public offering of 16.5 million common shares was priced yesterday at $60 a share by Morgan Stanley & Company, the underwriters.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bert Jones, the Los Angeles Rams' quarterback, will miss tomorrow night's game against San Francisco because of a pinched nerve in his neck that is causing numbness in his left. hand and arm. Vince Ferragamo will replace him. ... Al Chesley, the linebacker who demanded that the Philadelphia Eagles ''play me or trade me'' after he was dropped from the starting lineup 10 days ago, has been released on waivers. ... David Thompson, the guard for the Seattle SuperSonics who has been sidelined because of swelling and fluid in his right knee, has received a favorable medical report.

title: Warriors 110, Suns 98
description: Golden State, led by Purvis Short's 40 points, snapped a seven-game losing streak. The Warriors had lost 11 of 12 games after opening the season with three straight victories.

title: PIPELINE RATE POLICY REVAMPED
description: The Government, which has been regulating pipelines that carry crude oil and gasoline since the heyday of John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil empire, today declared a new hands-off approach to the industry.

title: HUNGER ARTICLES WIN PRIZES
description: Seven reporters for The New York Times have shared one of the first World Hunger Media Awards for their work on a series of 17 articles on hunger throughout the world.

title: Jersey Court Test To Permit Cameras
description: The State Supreme Court today approved an experiment to allow still-camera, television and radio coverage in municipal courts in Bergen, Mercer and Camden Counties.

title: Tird article of a series appearing periodically on current world economic problems
description: A host of social arrangements have softened the impact of the recession in Western Europe, but Europe's economic troubles are widely regarded as more difficult to resolve than the recession in the rest of the industrialized world.

title: FRUITCAKE FROM THE HEART OF TEXAS
description: CORSICANA, Tex. WHEN Tine Holm of Kolbotn, Norway, decided three years ago to send a fruitcake to her grandmother 140 miles away in Eidsvoll, she knew just what to do. She wrote out her order and put it in the mail addressed only to ''Fruitcakes, Texas.'' The letter quickly found its way to the Collin Street Bakery in this central Texas town, and before too long, Miss Holm's grandmother, Kari Orbech, received her fruitcake.

title: PEKING PRESENTS A 5-YEAR PLAN
description: China presented an overdue five-year plan today that sets cautious goals for economic growth while allocating substantial investment funds for chronic problem areas such as energy and transportation.

title: AIDE AT 10 DOWNING STREET IS HURT BY A BOMB SENT TO MRS. THATCHER
description: A package addressed to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher containing an incendiary device ignited this afternoon inside her official residence at 10 Downing Street, slightly injuring an official who checks all suspicious mail.

title: Bid for Dan River Is Extended
description: Carl C. Icahn and three companies he controls again extended their $16.50-a-share tender offer for up to 2 million shares of Dan River Inc., a bid the textile company opposes.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PAPERS OF ULYSSES S. GRANT. Vols. 9 and 10. Edited by John Y. Simon. Vol. 9, 700 pages; Vol. 10, 618 pages. Southern Illinois University Press, Car- bondale, Ill. Each volume, $40. ULYSSES S. GRANT: Essays and Docu- ments. Edited by David L. Wilson and John Y. Simon. 145 pages. Southern Illi- nois University Press. $13.95.

title: Gibson Leaves Tulane
description: Last Saturday's 31-28 victory by Tulane over Louisiana State, which is headed for the Orange Bowl, was a grand season closing for Coach Vince Gibson, but not enough to save his job in light of a 4-7 record.

title: Real Estate; British Methods in Manhattan
description: IT was the fall of 1980, the commercial real estate market was booming and Brian Rainbow bought the first piece of Manhattan property for his company, Royco Development. Mr. Rainbow, president of Royco, was one of many new foreigners in a hot market. Royco was founded in Britain in the 1960's by Roy Strudwick, and the company does both commercial and residential development.

title: USAir Buying Jets
description: USAir Inc. said it was buying five new Boeing Company jetliners.

title: Advertising; Discover Magazine's Attraction
description: ''O NE reason for our success,'' R. Timothy Leedy, Discover magazine's advertising sales director, said the other day, ''is that we tell it like it is.'' And indeed, there is an unglamorous quality to much of the Time Inc.-owned monthly's contents. The December issue, for instance, features pictures of such subjects as ''an array of Cuban tree snails,'' ''Crossed tusks, trait of female elephants,'' and ''Edward O. Wilson with a cherished possession: an ant.''

title: Reagan Statement and Tax Replies
description: Following is a statement made today by President Reagan after a meeting with Republican leaders of Congress and his replies to tax-cut questions: We've just finished a very warm and constructive meeting on the final session, and I want to report to you on the results.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Stronger Than Ever, 'Falconer' Returns Home

title: THE POP LIFE
description: MANY musicians are nomads, perpetually in transit from one continent to the next in search of new musical experiences, new scenery, better working conditions and more money. But Don Cherry, the 46-year-old trumpet player who first attracted attention as a member of Ornette Coleman's original quartet, is probably modern music's champion wanderer.

title: BUDGET OFFICE URGING SHARP CUTS IN SCOPE OF PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
description: The Office of Management and Budget is trying to eliminate the authority of the Government's top health official in a cost-cutting reorganization plan that would reduce the size of the Public Health Service.

title: SENATE OPENS DEBATE ON PRICE-FIXING LIABILITY
description: Under threat of filibuster, the Senate today began debate on legislation that would change the rules for apportioning liability in price-fixing suits, and apply those changes retroactively. Sources gave the measure little chance of passage in the current session.

title: COSTA-GAVRAS PLANS TO MAKE FILM IN ISRAEL
description: Despite initial jitters in the Israeli Government, the Paris-based film maker Costa-Gavras is planning to film his next movie in Israel. Given the political character of many of Costa-Gavras's films, the proposed movie, which will chronicle a love affair between an Israeli woman lawyer and a Palestinian refugee, may well grate against Israeli sensitivities and spark controversy when it is made.

title: South Dakota Places Creche In Capitol, Arousing A.C.L.U.
description: A Nativity scene has again been set up in the state Capitol rotunda, causing the American Civil Liberties Union to charge violation of the United States Constitution's provision on separation of church and state.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The kid who puts graffiti on a wall ought to be the kid who's taking it off.'' - Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola. (A1:2.)

title: CITY'S SCHOOLS TOLD TO SET UP CODES OF DISCIPLINE NEXT FALL
description: Every New York City public school will be required by next September to establish a disciplinary code to list what the school considers to be misbehavior and how it should be punished.

title: Hawks 111, 76ers 97
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Eddie Johnson scored 27 points and Dominique Wilkins 26, including 15 in the fourth quarter, to lead Atlanta to its third straight victory.

title: Big Pact for Whitaker
description: Lou Whitaker of the Detroit Tigers has signed a five-year contract worth more than $3 million, making him one of the highest-paid second basemen.

title: Subway Incidents Snarl Rush Hour
description: In three subway incidents that caused evening rush-hour delays yesterday, one man was electrocuted, another lost a leg and a subway station was evacuated after it became filled with smoke.

title: GUMPTION AND CASH PUT LYNN BACK ON ITS FEET A YEAR AFTER FIRE
description: There is an empty spot where the Benson Shoe Factory stood here. But Elsie Tucker, who lost her job to the fire that collapsed the factory last November, has made the transition. After 35 years making women's shoes, she has retrained to be a nurse's aide. She cares for patients in a nursing home.

title: Edibles
description: A tasteful and stylish gift is a holiday dinner at home for two - without the usual work involved. To begin, roasted red yellow and green peppers with baby eggplant, followed by a flavorful but not greasy Muscovy duck stuffed with chestnut-and-raisin dressing and served with burgundy sauce. An excellent puree of celery root is served in orange halves, and brocoletti, peeled broccoli stems, are steamed and sauteed in garlic and oil. For dessert something light: floating island with caramel glaze. The meal has been attractively arranged in a basket and is packed in containers that go directly into the oven for heating. All you need is a bottle of wine. The basket, at $75, must be ordered at least two days in advance from Balducci's.

title: Nastase Takes On The Computer
description: Ilie Nastase is back, this time as the director of a tennis tournament, and so is his temper. And don't think that the man who often harangued people as a tennis player is about to be intimidated in his new role by a mere computer.

title: Olympic Coins Net $10 Million
description: The Treasury Department turned over $10 million to Olympic officials today as the first installment in a series of payments made possible by the contributions of purchasers of commemorative gold and silver coins for the 1984 Olympic Games. The money is being generated by surcharges on advance sales of special Olympic-motif silver dollars and $10 gold pieces.

title: A TASTE OF EGYPT AT THE HOLIDAYS
description: THERE are countless legends about food, and the less plausible they are the better I like them. For instance, I enjoy the thought that chicken Marengo was first prepared by Napoleon's chef, who, after the smoke of battle at Marengo had cleared, gathered all the ingredients he could find and whipped up a dish for the Emperor. The ingredients included olive oil, chicken, tomatoes, crayfish and eggs.

title: SCOUTING
description: Maxwell Gluck, the master of the Elmendorf Farm, knows all about speed on the race track. His farm has produced some of the sport's best thoroughbreds, and Gluck spends most of the year on the West Coast, where speed is a way of racing life.

title: VIOLINS TOO EXQUISITE TO BE HEARD
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Dietary Guidelines Panel

title: Ketchum Advertising Adds Post of President
description: Ketchum Communications has named Donald G. Sullivan, 41 years old, president of Ketchum Advertising/US, a newly created position at the company. Mr. Sullivan was executive vice president of Ketchum/US and president of Ketchum's San Francisco office.

title: SUSPECT IN U.S. JUDGE'S DEATH SAYS LAWYER BROKE PLEA DEAL
description: Charles V. Harrelson said today he would have pleaded guilty in the shooting death of Federal District Judge John H. Wood if a lawyer, Joe Chagra, had kept a promise to send $300,000 to Mr. Harrelson's sons.

title: MINDS THAT DRUGS RESTORE, NOT ALTER
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Panel Asks Study On Chemical Warfare
description: The General Assembly's Political Committee has overwhelmingly approved a resolution calling on Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to investigate the illegal use of chemical weapons in warfare.

title: A.M.C. Offering Dealer Incentives
description: The American Motors Corporation announced a cash-incentive program for dealers of $600 a car on 1982 and 1983 Spirits and Concords delivered between Nov. 29 and Dec. 31.

title: No More Cricket
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Your piece on the chirping smoke detector (Metropolitan Diary, Oct. 27) saved me from going buggy.

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a gain of $550,000 for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $19,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net loss afterlosses from discontinued operations of $844,000 for the qr and $979,000 for the6 mos

title: SOVIET PAYMENT CITED IN TRIAL
description: A Canadian professor charged with passing economic secrets to the Soviet Union admitted to investigators that he had been paid $6,000 for his services, the prosecution in a British spy trial said today.

title: NETS WIN
description: Nineteen seconds into the third period last night, Trent Tucker of the Knicks hit on a jumper from the right corner. Twenty-seven seconds later Tucker scored on a jumper from the left corner. By the time the quarter was over, Tucker, making his second start as a professional, had missed only once in eight attempts from the field for the period and the Knicks were on their way to a 124-93 rout of the Utah Jazz at Madison Square Garden.

title: TV: 'MISSING CHILDREN,' MOTHER'S TALE OF FRAUD
description: TONIGHT'S television-movie problem, being displayed on CBS at 9, is described in the title: ''Missing Children.'' If that doesn't grab you, try the subtitle: ''A Mother's Story.'' As Al Capp's Li'l Abner might say, ''Gosh! Gasp! Sob!''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An item in the Sports People column yesterday incorrectly identified the Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur player of the year for 1981. He was Peter Van Ingen.

title: HIGH ON AGENDA ARE THREE LEADERSHIP FIGHTS
description: How will the 19 Republican Senators who are facing re-election prepare the groundwork for their campaign? What will the Democratic leadership in the House do to exert more discipline over its troops? Who will run the subcommittees that deal with military spending?

title: L.I.R.R. Averts Threatened Strike
description: A threatened strike that could have stopped Long Island Rail Road operations was averted early yesterday when officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority signed an agreement with Local 808 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: REAGAN CONCEDES THAT HE CAN'T WIN A TAX-CUT SPEEDUP
description: President Reagan conceded today that he would be unable to win advancement of the 10 percent income tax cut scheduled for July and would, instead, have to devote his efforts to preventing Congressional opponents from repealing it.

title: Chronological Age
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Enid Nemy's article on chronological age (''New Yorkers, etc.,'' Nov. 10) was interesting. I have had the same results when discussing this subject with friends, relatives and acquaintances.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ABORTION APPEALS BEING HEARD BY HIGH COURT
description: Following are summaries of the abortion cases that were argued before the Supreme Court today: SIMOPOULOS v. VIRGINIA -Principal question for the Court: the constitutionality of a state law requiring that all abortions after the first three months of pregnancy be performed in hospitals. The case is a criminal appeal by a gynecologist who was convicted of violating the law.

title: FLAGG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RAINSTORMS LEAVE 10 DEAD ON COAST
description: A storm carrying rain and snow driven by 80-mile-an-hour winds killed at least 10 people in California yesterday and led to the explosion of a chemical storage tank that forced the evacuation of thousands of people.

title: ISLANDERS TRIUMPH ON GOAL BY POTVIN
description: Denis Potvin broke a 2-2 tie in the second period tonight to lead the Islanders to a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues in the Checkerdome. It was the Islanders' first victory in their last eight road games.

title: NEW DATA ON CANCER AND RACE ARE GIVEN BY A FEDERAL AGENCY
description: Statistics compiled by a Government cancer surveillance program show that 47 percent of white patients and 35 percent of blacks survive the disease for at least five years. Such survival is considered an indicator of a likely cure for many types of cancers.

title: Professor Is Appointed Stanford Business Dean
description: Robert K. Jaedicke, a professor of accounting, was named yesterday as dean of the Stanford Graduate School of Business effective Jan. 1. Mr. Jaedicke, 53, succeeds Rene C. McPherson, 58, who announced his intention to resign in June, citing health and personal reasons. Mr. Jaedicke, who will be the sixth dean of the school and the first elected from its faculty in 25 years, had served as acting dean from 1979 to 1980 and as associate dean for academic affairs from 1969 to 1981. He holds the endowed William R. Kimball professorship of acounting.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
EXPERTS TELL OF ACID RAIN AT CON ED HEARING
description: The burning of coal instead of oil at electricity generating plants in Queens and Staten Island would intensify the already severe problem of acid rain in the Adirondack Mountains, a scientist said yesterday at a hearing in Manhattan.

title: Agent Testifies In Race-Fix Case
description: A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, testifying in the race-fixing trial of the harness driver Ben Webster, told a Federal court today that he watched two co-defendants place bets before four races specified in charges against the men.

title: Aren't Four Tanks Better Than One?
description: The program manager of the Army's new M-1 tank, Maj. Gen. Duard Ball, said in a recent letter on this page that the tank costs only 28 percent more than its predecessor, the M-60, but is greatly superior. Since the tank's problems are common to many of the Defense Department's other weapon systems, General Ball's case bears a closer look.

title: BANKRUPTCY RULING BY HIGH COURT
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a key provision of the 1978 bankruptcy code, designed to protect consumers in their dealings with finance companies, does not offer retroactive protection to consumers who incurred their debts before the new law was passed.

title: CBS NEWS REDUCING STAFF
description: In a move that reflects the financial troubles of its parent network, CBS News has dismissed 25 employees and outlined plans to close its full-time bureaus in Bonn and Hong Kong.

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Carpenter Expects to Be Ready Sunday
description: Rob Carpenter is back. The 27-year-old running back, an unsigned free agent until Monday, rejoined the Giants today and started preparing for Sunday's game against the Houston Oilers at Giants Stadium.

title: 22 Are Feared Dead In Colombia Air Crash
description: A twin-engine domestic airliner carrying 22 people crashed in mountainous terrain during a rainstorm on Monday and all aboard were believed killed, Colombian aviation officials said today.

title: Athlete's Ordeal
description: Being a scholarship athlete isn't all that easy, not when your sister gets married on the same day you make your debut on the varsity. Ask Susan Nangle, an 18-year-old freshman guard on the women's basketball team at Manhattan College.

title: CHROMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a special gain of $124,000 for the qr and a special loss of $153,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income including special gains of $238,000 for the qr and $1,160,000 for the 9 mos

title: NU-WEST IN DEBT TALKS
description: The Nu-West Group Ltd., which is based in Toronto, said yesterday that it had begun talks with its banks to reschedule its payments on interest and principal. Nu-West added that its big loss for the latest nine months was the result of high interest and carrying costs and a severe slump in the real estate market.

title: A SELF-PORTRAIT OF SARTRE
description: ''SARTRE PAR LUI-MEME (Sartre by Himself),'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is a 3-hour, 10-minute film usually described as a ''talking heads'' movie. That's exactly what ''Sartre par Lui-Meme'' is, and when the talking heads belong to Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir and a small circle of friends, you can't do much better. However, because the talk in the film is entirely in French, ''Sartre par Lui-Meme'' also is an exercise in the reading of subtitles.

title: REAGAN BEGINS HIS LATIN TOUR IN CORDIAL BRAZIL
description: President Reagan arrived in Brazil tonight to put his personal endorsement on improved relations between the United States and Latin America's largest country.

title: Casinos Are Assessed $4.2 Million by Panel
description: Atlantic City's nine casino-hotels, required by law to finance the operations of the Casino Control Commission, were given a multimillion-dollar special assessment today to pay off the panel's deficit.

title: AN MX 'DENSE PACK' WOULD NEED ABM'S, BOTH PERILING SECURITY
description: In a major reversal of defense policy, the Administration is moving in a direction that may require not only deployment of an antiballistic missile system but also revision - or cancellation - of the 1972 ABM treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union. This prospective threat to national security arises from President Reagan's proposal for ''dense pack'' deployment in Wyoming of 100 MX intercontinental missiles whose survival in a nuclear war might require ABM's.

title: HEARNS IS ANGERED BY FIGHT PAY CUT
description: Since first fighting for a championship in August 1980, Thomas Hearns has learned that there is more to being a fighter than getting into the ring. When he came here three weeks ago, it was to help promote his bout against Wilfred Benitez, the World Boxing Council superwelterweight champion. The fight, scheduled for Friday night, figured to be exciting, but it was not doing well at the box office.

title: BATTLING FOR CHOCK FULL O'NUTS
description: It has all the earmarks of a bruising political campaign: Two wealthy men with big egos trade charges that focus more on personalities than issues.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT would be capricious to say that one flavor or seasoning works best with quickly made dishes, yet I think it is time to pay tribute to one of the most versatile of herbs and seasonings, the shallot. For me it has special merit where any fine French cooking is concerned.

title: PACESETTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Seven-Up Accuses Pepsico on Ads
description: The Seven-Up Company accused Pepsico of using ''false, misleading and deceptive'' advertising for its new Pepsi-Free soft drink.

title: ENVIRONMENT UNIT DEDICATED BY KEAN
description: A $5.2 million environmental study center and office building was dedicated today on the slope of old garbage dumps in the Hackensack Meadowlands. It is the focal piece of a broad project designed to create a 2,000-acre state park from a wasteland of landfills and polluted creeks.

title: Hoechst Asbestos Alternative
description: Hoechst, a West German chemical company, said it had developed chemical fibers that could take over some of the industrial uses of asbestos, which has been linked to lung cancer.

title: Harley-Davidson Asks Import Curb
description: The last United States motorcycle maker, Harley-Davidson, is asking the Government for protection from Japanese competition that it says threatens to drive it out of business. It said it has laid off 40 percent of its work force because of losses for which it blames Japanese competition.

title: HOME CREAM MAKER
description: ANYONE who cooks often with cream, especially when making desserts, knows the importance of a top-quality product with high butterfat content. Some of the ultrapasteurized heavy creams on the market may be disappointing in certain recipes.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; results include discontinued operations

title: WAS PICKERING IN 'MY FAIR LADY'
description: Robert Coote, the veteran British actor who won acclaim on Broadway more than two decades ago when he created the role of the spluttering, Blimpish Colonel Pickering in the hit musical ''My Fair Lady,'' died in his sleep last Thursday at the New York Athletic Club.

title: INSURANCE CONCERN TEMRED NEGLIGENT
description: A brokerage concern that specialized in insurance for antipoverty programs was accused yesterday of negligence that kept New York City from collecting more than $1.3 million.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings reflect 5 percent stock divds in Jan 1982 and July 1982

title: Drought Watch Ordered for City
description: New York City entered a drought watch yesterday, with its reservoirs almost 22 percent below normal levels.

title: NEW YORK AREA OFFICIALS SEE FAULTS IN REAGAN TRANSIT BILL
description: Officials of New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut said today that the Reagan Administration's proposal to aid mass transit through an increase in the Federal gasoline tax would do little more than offset its proposed cuts in operating assistance.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Hunter's Moon

title: FOR ERSKINE CALDWELL, 50 YEARS OF SUCCESSES
description: FIFTY years ago they emerged from the backwoods of Georgia, shiftless and uneducated poor whites bearing such unfamiliar names as Jeeter, Ellie May, Sister Bessie, Ty Ty and Darling Jill. Underfed and oversexed, their public passions, petty jealousies and frequent fits of anger stunned an American public that had barely been aware of their existence.

title: WALESA AND STAFF PRAY FOR GUIDANCE
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the outlawed Solidarity union, came to the ancient manastery here today to pray for guidance on his future course of action.

title: MAN WANTED BY ILLINOIS OFFICIALS IN TYLENOL CASE TURNS HIMSELF IN
description: Police officials said today that a 35-yearold mechanic wanted for questioning in connection with the cyanide murders of seven people in Illinois had turned himself in here Monday and was under arrest on a drug charge unrelated to the murders.

title: Help-Wanted Ads Up
description: The Conference Board's help-wanted advertising index rose in October, the first monthly upturn in a year.

title: U.S. Farmer Who Underwent 2 Lung Transplants Dies at 31
description: James Franzen, the first person to receive two transplanted lungs from different donors, died this afternoon at Toronto General Hospital, five days after suffering a massive stroke, officials reported.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In a book dealing with life in the Caribbean I ran across the term ''sour sop.'' I am not certain if this is a fruit or a baked dessert. Can you tell me?

title: A NEW FLORIDA AIR FARE WAR
description: Airline fare wars on the hotly contested Florida route have become as much a part of the holiday season as Christmas shopping. And 1982 appears to be no exception.

title: DISCORD IS DELAYING FANFANI IN FORMING AN ITALIAN CABINET
description: Prime Minister-designate Amintore Fanfani formally notified President Sandro Pertini today that he was prepared to form a four-party coalition. But continued disputes between members of his Christian Democratic Party and their Socialist coalition partners apparently prevented him from announcing his Cabinet.

title: City's First Case Of Flu for Season
description: The season's first case of influenza in New York City has been discovered at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx, according to Dr. David J. Sencer, the City Health Commissioner.

title: TRICKLE-DOWN A LA 30's
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Enters Plea
description: H. Edward Tickel, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, pleaded not guilty Monday to charges of transporting stolen property and tax evasion. Federal District Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. set trial for Jan. 31. A separate trial is scheduled Jan. 24 on charges that Mr. Tickel entered credit union offices at F.B.I. headquarters with intent to steal.

title: Bucks 88, Cavaliers 78
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Junior Bridgeman scored 17 of his 20 points in the second half, and Sidney Moncrief added 17 to lead Milwaukee.

title: SHOULD U.S. CUT FUNDS FOR CHILD NUTRITION?
description: The first serious legislative test of President Reagan's ''new federalism'' initiative involves child nutrition programs.

title: REAGAN AIDE FIGHTS CONGRESSIONAL CUTS IN NATO
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the adoption by Congress of pending legislation to reduce the American role in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would be a blow to United States and allied security.

title: THE HONORED GUESTS WERE JEWELS
description: tie golden anniversary party on Monday night for itself and some 1,200 friends and customers, none of whom mispronounced the word as ''jools.'' The setting was the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Engelhard Court, whose sculptures were the only figures not dressed to the teeth.

title: Lakers 137, Spurs 132
description: SAN ANTONIO (AP) - Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 27 points, including 6 of his team's last 8 points in the second overtime period, to give Los Angeles the victory.

title: MID-AMERICA PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
RANGERS WIN WITH 4 GOALS IN 3RD PERIOD
description: After two periods last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers led the struggling Hartford Whalers by only 2-1. After three periods, the Rangers had a 6-1 victory.

title: INDIA'S ASSAM CALDRON BUBBLES DANGEROUSLY AGAIN
description: A student-led movement has called for a new confrontation with the Indian Government in its campaign for the expulsion from Assam, a northeastern state, of hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants.

title: Santa Fe Industries Plans for Successor
description: John J. Schmidt, the president of Santa Fe Industries, has the inside track to become chairman and chief executive officer of the Chicago-based transportation and energy concern. He was recommended yesterday for the position by John S. Reed, the 65-year-old chairman and chief executive who will retire after the annual meeting next April.

title: ASTROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
BULGARIA IS SAID TO WARN ITALY OF CRISIS IN RELATIONS
description: Bulgaria was reported today to have warned Italy that it had provoked a crisis in their relations with the arrest of a Bulgarian airline representative last Thursday on suspicion of complicity in the 1981 attempt to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: Hanna Shutdown
description: The Hanna Mining Company said it planned to close its Groveland iron-ore pellet project near Iron Mountain, Mich., because of depressed conditions in the steel industry and an imbalance between domestic iron-ore pellet capacity and projected demand. Robert F. Anderson, chairman and president of the Cleveland-based natural resources company, said Hanna would take a $35 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to account for the shutdown.

title: Argentine President Promises Elections in '83
description: President Reynaldo Bignone announced today that elections would be held in Argentina next year, probably in the fourth quarter.

title: DiGregorio a Coach
description: Finally resigned to giving up his playing career, Ernie DiGregorio has become basketball coach at the Rhode Island School for the Deaf, whose students are mostly of high school age.

title: HOME BEAT
description: EUROPEAN influence in the area of bed linens is pretty well established these days. Duvets and square pillows are two contributions from abroad that have been adopted by American manufacturers.

title: Newmont in Deal For Copper Unit
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Cities Service Company's Miami copper operations in Arizona for $75 million in cash.

title: TELETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $145,300 from the sale of a subsidiary and a loss of $12,900 from discontinued operations

title: Citicorp in Futures Role
description: The Federal Reserve Board said today that Citicorp could trade futures through the Citicorp Futures Corporation, with contracts in bullion, foreign exchange, Government securities and money market instruments.

title: IN CHINA, THE HIGH COST OF MODERNIZATION
description: Despite a promising economic future, China is still not generating enough revenue to keep up with the demands of its modernization program, Finance Minister Wang Bingqian said today.

title: Tokyo Stock Market Gains
description: The Tokyo stock market average rose 71.15 today, to 7,966.77, its highest point this year, in active trading that reflected expectations of a lower interest rates soon, dealers said.

title: Fire at G.I. Site in Germany
description: A fire set by an arsonist Tuesday night extensively damaged the underground garage of an apartment building where many American servicemen live, the police said today.

title: CALENDAR: HOUSES BY CANDLELIGHT
description: Christmas in Odessa, Winterthur Mu- seum at Odessa, Del.; 302-378-4069.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: BASKETBALL Suns vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Phoenix. Both teams are coming off upset defeats Tuesday night, the Suns to Golden State, 110-98, and the 76ers to the Atlanta Hawks, 111-97.

title: 2 Sisters, Cash Nearby, Die of Cold in Pittsfield
description: Two elderly sisters and their cat died of exposure and illnesses in their heatless home, surrounded by thousands of dollars in cash and gold pieces, officials said today.

title: AMQUEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
YANKS SIGN BAYLOR FOR FOUR YEARS
description: George Steinbrenner, a grandmaster of the free-agent game, made his first conquest in this year's market yesterday, signing Don Baylor to be the kind of ''take-charge leader'' he felt the Yankees lacked last season.

title: FILM ON GANDHI OPENS IN LAND HE HELPED FREE
description: ''I wept through most of the film, I was so moved, '' said the business executive. ''I'm not ashamed to admit it and I could see that many others were similarly moved.''

title: Required Reading 'The Outer Limit'
description: Excerpt from ''The Reagan Presidency at Mid-Term: an Introduction to Four Analyses of Administration Policies and Policymaking, '' by Fred I. Greenstein. Prepared for a mid-November conference on the Reagan Presidency sponsored by the Garfield Foundation and the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University:

title: A Successful Journey From Print to NBC-TV
description: The commercials that the NBC-TV Network has been running to promote its new season, and which have been complimented for their creativity, are the work of Steve Sohmer, who may be remembered in the New York area as the former creative director of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.

title: A TEST FOR CLASS ACTION SUITS
description: All Steven Miner wanted from the Gillette Company was what the 1978 advertisement offered - a free Accent table cigarette lighter, retail value $7.95. As required, Mr. Miner sent off 50 cents for postage and handling and proof of purchase of two of Gillette's Cricket disposable cigarette lighters.

title: Deaths of 11 Russians In Lebanon Disclosed
description: Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard N. Perle has disclosed that several Russians were killed in Lebanon last spring when Israeli jets destroyed a downed reconnaissance plane to prevent secret electronic equipment from falling into Soviet hands. A Pentagon spokesman declined to confirm the account.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Witkowski Cited
description: John Witkowski, Columbia's record-breaking quarterback, was named yesterday as winner of the Asa A. Bushnell Cup as Ivy League football player of the year.

title: Technology; Supermarkets For Computers
description: FROM Alpha Microsystems to Zenith Data Systems, an enormous number of companies are making computer equipment. The exhibit guide for Comdex, a computer trade show taking place this week in Las Vegas, lists 142 vendors of microcomputers, 81 suppliers of printers, 54 makers of word processing equipment, 114 sellers of software for particular applications - more than 1,000 exhibitors altogether.

title: FRESH PAINT ON LANE DIVIDERS BETRAYS SECRET REAGAN ROUTE
description: One of the many precautions taken to protect President Reagan here was to take him in a side entrance to the presidential Palacio Planalto today rather than up the ceremonial ramp flanked by dragoons in plumed helmets.

title: Massey Expansion
description: Massey-Ferguson Holdings of Britain said it would spend about $17.6 million over the next three years to improve efficiency at its Coventry tractor plant.
