The company, a wholly owned unit of Canada's Massey-Ferguson Ltd., said the program is intended to improve productivity at the plant, which now produces just over 46,000 units a year.

title: NATIONAL TRUST CO (TORONTO, ONT) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BLINKA DEFENDED BY MICHAELS
description: The Stan Blinka-John Jefferson matter failed to go away today at the Jets' training center. Walt Michaels, the coach, and Greg Buttle, the team's defensive captain, came to the defense of Blinka, the middle linebacker who hit Jefferson with a blow to the face last Sunday at Shea Stadium.

title: Miss Holtzman Fights Subpoena
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn formally moved yesterday to quash a subpoena requiring her to testify at a hearing concerning possible prosecutorial misconduct in her office. Oral arguments are expected tomorrow.

title: TV: 'CANCER CONFRONTATION' OFFERS HOPE BY EXAMPLE
description: ''The Cancer Confrontation,'' which can be seen on Metromedia, is not as aggressive a program as the title might suggest. It is, in fact, a softhearted, determinedly upbeat effort to offer hope by example.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to give pro forma effect to a stock distribution effected in the form of a 100 percent stock divd payable Dec 3, 1982

title: IC Industries Asks For F.T.C. Review
description: IC Industries, a highly diversified conglomerate with major interests in railroads, manufacturing and consumer products, said it had asked the Federal Trade Commission to alter a 1973 order that prohibits its Midas muffler unit from purchasing replacement parts from IC's Abex manufacturing subsidiary, or any of Abex's suppliers.

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Strong Reaction
description: W est Virginia's Secretary of State, A. James Manchin, said yesterday that ''you people up in the Big Apple'' are trampling all over ''my burning love for the Statue of Liberty.'' He has fired off a demand that the Ideal Toy Company - and its parent, CBS Toys Inc. - ''cease and desist'' using a television commercial that shows a toy, Rubik's Cube, ''spinning at the top of the statue's torch instead of the flame of liberty.''

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
REAGAN READY TO WORK WITH CONGRESS ON JOB BILL
description: The Reagan Administration today showed a willingness to work with Congress to modify the President's proposed five-year $32.9 billion highway and mass transit program that would be financed by a 5-cent increase in the Federal gasoline tax.

title: NETS HALT STREAK OF BULLETS
description: With Otis Birdsong, the Nets' guard who is their leading scorer, out of the lineup again with the flu, and Foots Walker, a point guard, suffering with a swollen left hand, Coach Larry Brown was desperate. So at the begining of the final period tonight against the Washington Bullets, he selected Albert King, a forward, for his first backcourt duty of the season.

title: SPENDING UP 1.1% FOR CONSTRUCTION
description: Builders stepped up spending on new construction projects by 1.1 percent in October, the Government reported today. The gain, helped by governmental construction, was the biggest since June.

title: VISA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-There are no comparable yr-ago results because the company commenced operations on Apr 1

title: Bridge: The Half-a-Loaf Principle; Applied in an Unusual Way
description: Many years ago the great English player-writer Skid Simon made a very important point: Half a loaf at the bridge table is better than no bread -one should try for the best result possible, and not the best possible result.

title: LOOKING FOR GIFTS AT AREA CRAFTS FAIRS
description: Whether you're looking for a decorative piece of porcelain for the mantel or a soft sculpture toy for a nephew, there are many crafts fairs in the area this season likely to have just the thing. Here is a sampling. WBAI Holiday Crafts Fair, Ferris Booth Hall, Columbia University, Booth Hall, Columbia University, 115th Street and Broadway, 212-857- 3918.

title: Roy White Turns To World of Art
description: When Roy White was majoring in art 20 years ago at Compton College in California, he wanted to be a baseball player. Now, after 14 years with the Yankees and three with the Tokyo Giants, he wants to be an importer of art. And he is doing just that.

title: BRIBE TRIAL JURORS GET 'CRANK' CALLS
description: A man described in court as ''a crank'' telephoned five jurors today in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters' union, forcing the judge to sequester the jury.

title: Build the White Street Jail
description: The decrepit Rikers Island House of Detention for Men is the bad boy of New York City's jail system, and the city has promised, under court pressure, to replace it. The refurbished Manhattan Tombs, closed by court order in 1975, will accommodate a third of the inmates. For most of the rest, the city proposes a new jail on White Street, next to the Tombs. The Board of Estimate votes on the plan today.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1982; International
description: President Reagan said the U.S. will allow Brazil $1.2 billion in short-term loans to help it meet its debt crisis. On the first day of his Latin American trip, the President urged lenders around the world to aid indebted developing nations and he praised Brazil's austerity measures. In New York, Brazilian bank officials were seeking a $2.4 billion loan from commercial banks. (Page A1.)

title: INVESTORS SNAP UP BELL STOCK
description: An underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley & Company yesterday sold 16.5 million shares of common stock in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for $990 million.

title: NUCLEAR SUPPORT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MEXICO'S HARVARD MAN
description: When Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado was first chosen to be Mexico's new President, politicians immediately worried whether this genial Harvard-educated economic planner had the inner steel to dominate a country long accustomed to strong government.

title: Connecticut Loses Air Pollution Case
description: Connecticut lost a court battle yesterday to prevent some Long Island power plants from continuing to burn fuel with 2.8 percent sulfur for two more years.

title: 500 FISH HANDLERS CALL STRIKE AT FULTON MARKET
description: The usually bustling Fulton Fish Market, a huge barnlike structure in lower Manhattan, was stilled yesterday as a strike by 500 fish handlers prevented millions of pounds of fresh fish normally processed there from reaching metropolitan area restaurants, hotels, hospitals and retail outlets.

title: Union Camp Appoints A New Vice Chairman
description: William T. Bess Jr., who started as a salesman at the Union Camp Corporation after answering a help-wanted ad, has been named vice chairman.

title: Miss Boston Held In Contempt
description: Cynthia Boston, who is also known as Fulani Sunni Ali, was held in contempt of court yesterday for refusing to provide samples of her handwriting and hair to a Federal grand jury investigating the 1981 Brink's robbery in Rockland County.

title: CHURCH CRITICISM FROM WAY OFF CENTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Books: Rich Heritage
description: LIVE & BE WELL. By Richard F. Shepard and Vicki Gold Levi. 192 pages. Balan- tine. Hard-cover $20, paperback $9.95.

title: THE RIGHT STUFF
description: Edward Kennedy's decision to stay out in 1984 leaves one big gainer among Democratic politicians and one man with new problems. The gainer is Mr. Kennedy himself. The man in trouble is Walter Mondale.

title: 'CENTRIST' POSITION FOR G.O.P. IS URGED
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the highestranking Republican state official in New York, called today on Republicans to adopt a ''centrist'' position.

title: Moore Shipping
description: Moore McCormack Resources Inc. said it was negotiating the sale of its shipping line subsidiary to McLean Securities Inc., the parent company of United States Lines Inc. Terms under discussion were not disclosed.

title: Venezuela Aids Bank
description: The Venezuelan Government has authorized cash injections totaling $230 million for the Banco de los Trabajadores de Venezuela as a first stage in its rescue of the nation's largest bank, financial sources said today. The central bank first freed some $115 million it held as the bank's reserves, and later it authorized the transfer of a similar amount from Venezuela's social security institute pension fund, which is managed by the central bank. The Government intervened Monday to rescue the bank after it ran into severe liquidity problems.

title: Books Of The Times
description: TICES. By Lawrence Durrell. 393 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After charges and writedowns of $833,000...C-Net income; results for the latest 6 mos reflect restated first qr results

title: UNION WAITS IMPATIENTLY FOR NEW WAGE OFFER FROM CHRYSLER
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers are waiting with increasing impatience for the Chrysler Corporation to place a wage proposal on the negotiating table, now that most noneconomic issues have been resolved.

title: HELOISE'S BORIC ACID ROACH EXTERMINATING FORMULA
description: 8 ounces powdered boric acid 1/2 cup flour 1/8 cup sugar 1/2 small onion, chopped (optional) 1/4 cup shortening or bacon drippings Water to form soft dough.

title: Federated-J.M.B. Realty Talks
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the country's largest department store chain, is negotiating to form a joint venture with the J.M.B. Realty Corporation that would build urban stores, offices and apartments, industry sources reported yesterday.

title: A Rediscovery In the Underground
description: T he Empire State Building's management went into the underground yesterday to begin a campaign to get New Yorkers, as well as tourists, to visit the building's observation decks.

title: CHANNEL 13 IS MEETING ITS FINANCIAL CHALLENGES
description: To the Editor:

title: BUYER BE DAMNED...
description: A powerful labor lobby, the United Automobile Workers union, is threatening the right of American consumers to purchase foreign cars.

title: 'HORSEBURGERS' ON PUSHCART MENU
description: New York City's Health Department announced yesterday that it had issued a permit allowing a Connecticut company to sell ''horseburgers'' and horse-steak sandwiches from pushcarts in midtown Manhattan.

title: French Outlook Weak
description: French industrial production is likely to fall slightly in the next three months in all sectors except cars, the Government's statistics institute said today. It noted a slowdown in production since September. Only the car industry managed a slight rise, it added.

title: Redmen on Radio
description: St. John's probably has the best basketball team in the New York area, but it had the devil of a time finding a way to broadcast its games by radio. No station would handle the team, no sponsor would put up the money.

title: Brazil's Debt and Promise
description: Good for President Reagan for giving Brazil pride of place in his hemisphere foray. His three nights there are a vote of confidence in a big country churning with promise. A lot rides on how Brazil manages its tricky midpassage out of debt and dictatorship - and a lot depends on the right kind of encouragement from normally inattentive Washington.

title: The Coaches' Corner
description: After six years as head football coach at the University of Connecticut, and a 24-39-2 record, Walt Nadzak has resigned. ... Blaming a lack of support from the athletic department, Monte Kiffin resigned as football coach at North Carolina State. In three years, his teams won 16 games and lost 17.

title: David Apter, Publicist For Civil Rights Groups
description: David Apter, a public relations executive who specialized in work for civil rights and civic organizations, died of a heart attack on Nov. 29 at the home of his son, Marc, in Rockville, Md. He was 67 years old and lived in Washington.

title: American Can
description: The American Can Company said it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire Penncorp Financial Inc. Under terms of the merger, American Can will exchange $262 million in $13.75-a-share preferred stock and principal amount of notes for Penncorp's outstanding stock. The two companies also plan to acquire an outstanding warrant to buy Penncorp stock for $31.4 million in cash, they said.

title: Exxon Price Cuts
description: Exxon U.S.A. announced additional price cuts for barge-load quantities of heating oil in New York Harbor, effective immediately.

title: PHOTON SOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WITNESS GIVES ALIBI FOR FRIEND CHARGED WITH SLAYING JUDGE
description: An unexpected witness told a jury today that he knocked on a Dallas apartment door less than an hour after Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. was assassinated and that the man accused of killing him, Charles V. Harrelson, answered.

title: Justice Brennan's Wife Dies
description: Marjorie Leonard Brennan, the wife of Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr., died today.

title: France Will Sign U.N. Sea-Bed Treaty
description: France will sign the United Nations Law of the Sea Treaty when the international convention is open for signature at Kingston, Jamaica, next week, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Queens College to Offer Gluck Opera Premiere
description: The American premiere of Gluck's opera ''Paris and Helen'' will be presented in a new English translation at Queens College Dec. 9 to 12 by the Queens College Opera Studio directed by Hugo Weisgall.

title: HOUSE APPROVES $85.5 BILLION BILL FOR SOCIAL PROGRAMS
description: The House of Representatives easily passed legislation today that would provide $85.5 billion for health, education and related social programs in the fiscal year 1983.

title: REALEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3

HELPFUL HARDWARE;
MAKING IT EASIER TO PUT UP THE TREE
description: IF you are thinking ahead about decorations for the holiday season, some new products and catalogues can make setting up the Christmas tree easier.

title: Terms Explained in Race-Fix Case
description: A racing official called by the prosecution as an expert witness in the race-fixing trial of the harness driver Ben Webster today explained terms used in wiretaps placed on Mr. Webster's home telephone.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JOYCEAN

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Washington Bullets have reactivated Kevin Grevey, who has been out since the season started with a torn abdominal muscle, and placed another guard, Billy Ray Bates, on waivers. ... The New York Racing and Wagering Board held a two-hour hearing to consider the appeal by Angel Cordero of his seven-day suspension, but no decision is expected until later in the week. Guy Lafleur of the Montreal Canadians has recovered from a broken toe he suffered on his left foot Nov. 9 and is expected to return to action Saturday in Montreal against the Boston Bruins.

title: Ex-Iranian Hostages Are Married in Utah
description: Two Government employees who were among the Americans taken hostage in Iran three years ago were married in a private ceremony last weekend.

title: OVERDUE CONTRIBUTOR TO SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: IMAGE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: With Senator Edward M. Kennedy out of the 1984 Presidential race, the chances of all other Democratic hopefuls obviously improved yesterday. But the clearest gains were not for any individual Democrats, but for organized labor.

title: MOST FARES RAISED 5% BY AIRLINES
description: Most of the nation's major airlines quietly put into effect yesterday a 5 percent increase in fares on most of their domestic routes in hopes of increasing profitability.

title: 2 Consent At Muir
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has settled its case against two of the defendants charged with securities fraud in connection with John Muir & Company's underwriting of $6 million of securities for the Cayman Islands Reinsurance Corporation.

title: L.I. Boy Charged In Mother's Death
description: A 13-year-old boy shot his mother to death today because she insisted he go to school, the Nassau County police said.

title: CITY PUSHES LAWSUIT TO COMPEL YANKEES TO OPEN IN STADIUM
description: Talks between New York City and the Yankees have broken off, and the city said yesterday that it would proceed with its lawsuit to prevent the baseball team from playing its first three scheduled home games in Denver next spring.

title: MUSHROOM FARMERS ARE HURT AS IMPORTS FROM CHINA SURGE
description: Peter Collins lifted a knee-high barrel covered with Chinese writing onto his porch. The barrel, filled with mushrooms from China, represents ''what's killing the mushroom farmer,'' he said.

title: FLARE AND FANTASY FOR TABLE SETTING
description: SOME believe that if forks go on the left, knives on the right and plates in between, there isn't much more to be said about setting a table. It's a point of view not without merit, especially if the table is being made ready for such gourmet delights as canned salmon dumped on a bed of potato chips, with an apple and marshmallow salad.

title: ON MATINEE DAY, ALL OF MIDTOWN'S STAGE
description: On any Wednesday, just around lunch time, the area of Manhattan bounded roughly by Broadway and Eighth Avenue and 42d and 50th Streets is thick with normalcy.

title: Envoy's Son Arrested But Charge Is Dropped
description: The son of Brazil's ambassador to the United States was charged with shooting an employee of a topless bar but the charge was dropped because the son has diplomatic immunity, the United States Attorney's office said today.

title: CITY PICKS 10 AGENCIES TO ASSIST HOMELESS
description: New York City has picked 10 private agencies to help shelter up to 500 homeless men and women in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Florence Herman, 82, Lawyer Active in Feminist Movement
description: Florence Rogatz Herman, a lawyer who had been active in the feminist movement since the 1920's, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 82 years old.

title: REDMEN RAISE RECORD TO 4-0
description: Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach, had cause for concern during the first five minutes of last night's game at Columbia. ''I was worried 'cause Columbia was putting the ball in the refrigerator at the start,'' Carnesecca said. The Lions built a 6-0 lead and kept the ball from the Redmen, working deliberately for their shots. But after St. John's got its first basket at 5:30, the Redmen went on to tie the score at 10-10, build a 32-22 lead at the half, and go on to win, 72-45, before a crowd of 2,350 at Levien Gym.

title: STORMY VOTING SESSION FOR CHOCK FULL O' NUTS
description: The battle for control of Chock Full o'Nuts was waged in the ballroom of a midtown Manhattan hotel yesterday, and those who think annual meetings are dull missed entertainment that often seemed more fitting for ball park bleachers or a neighborhood bar.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1982
description: International American loans to Brazil totaling $1.2 billion were announced by President Reagan. Amid a round of talks in Brasilia, Mr. Reagan said Washington would provide the emergency short-term loans to help Brazil overcome its huge debt problem, and he praised Brazil's leaders for taking austerity measures. (Page A1, Column 6.) Austerity moves in Mexico were announced by Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado at his swearing-in as President. His program calls for budget cuts, new taxes, price increases, postponement of public works projects, higher interest rates and eased foreign exchange controls. (A1:5-6.)

title: Jersey Legislator To Seek Pay Cuts
description: Assemblyman Robert D. Franks said today he would introduce a concurrent resolution on Monday calling upon state employees to take voluntary 7 percent pay reductions to save the state $21 million and help solve New Jersey's looming budget deficit.

title: CHANNEL 13 IS MEETING ITS FINANCIAL CHALLENGES
description: To the Editor:

title: CARESSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: Needed: New Name

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Brands Inc. has elected to its board of directors Catherine May Bedell, a special consultant to the White House and first woman to serve as chairman of the U.S. International Trade Comission.

title: SPANISH PARLIAMENT ELECTS SOCIALIST PRIME MINISTER
description: Felipe Gonzalez, the leader of the Spanish Socialist Workers Party, was elected Prime Minister of Spain this morning.

title: E.E.C.-U.S.  Accord Urged
description: Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen of Denmark, the current Common Market chairman, said today that he hoped the upcoming meeting of European leaders here would contribute to improved trade relations with the United States.

title: Oil Data Delayed
description: The weekly figures on gasoline and crude oil stocks prepared by the American Petroleum Institute were unavailable yesterday because the compilation was delayed by the Thanksgiving holiday. The figures will appear tomorrow.

title: Miners' Chief Sets Inaugural
description: Departing with tradition so outof-work coal miners will not have far to travel for the event, the United Mine Workers union will hold the inauguration of its president, Rich Trumka, in Charleston on Dec. 22.

title: JOHN C. CAIRNS
description: John C. Cairns, retired president and board chairman of the Stanley Works of New Britain, Conn., manufacturer of builders' hardware and electrical equipment, died of congestive heart failure last Friday at Florida Hospital in Orlando. He was 82 years old and a resident of Winter Park, Fla.

title: EVEN A BEGINNER CAN GROW WINDOWSILL ORCHIDS
description: THEY may be considered weeds in Central America, but around here an orchid in flower is a cause celebre. Too few city gardeners experience these delightful blooms in their homes because of overblown myths of how difficult they are to tend, and overblown prices at florists. But orchids will thrive on any bright windowsill, and a flowering-size plant can be had for under $30 from an orchid specialist.

title: News Analysis
description: In retrospect, the most predictable aspect of the transition after Leonid I. Brezhnev's death should have been the puzzles and mysteries surrounding the new leader. The Soviet Union has always been compulsive about secrecy, and Yuri V. Andropov had come in from 15 years in the state security service.

title: U.S. Fines A-Plant In Jersey $40,000
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday fined the operators of a New Jersey nuclear plant $40,000 for having failed to determine that two safety-related valves were not in working order.

title: DEVILS TRIUMPH BY 7-3
description: The Devils broke out with three goals in a span of 1 minute 50 seconds in the second period tonight and defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7-3, for their first victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena since Oct. 18.

title: Tenace Joins Pirates
description: In a move to bolster their bench strength, the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday signed Gene Tenace, a free-agent catcher-first baseman, to a multiyear contract. Tenace, 36 years old, best known as the slugging catcher on the Oakland A's three world championship teams in the early 1970's, played for the world-champion St. Louis Cardinals last season.

title: GREAT SOUTHWEST INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Carteret in Accord On 4 Florida Units
description: The Carteret Savings and Loan Association of Morristown, N.J., said it had agreed to acquire four branch offices of the Florida-based Freedom Savings and Loan Association.

title: Masco in Offer For Brass-Craft
description: The Masco Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Brass-Craft Manufacturing Company for $26 a share in cash, or about $68.9 million.

title: WE HAD A RIGHT, PHALANGIST SAYS OF MASSACRE
description: The leader of a Lebanese Phalangist Christian faction said today that the killings of Palestinian civilians in two refugee camps in September were ''a Lebanese reaction from the relatives and parents of our martyrs.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anchor Hocking Corp. said it had acquired 800,700 shares, or 16.6 percent, of Towle Manufacturing Co.'s common stock; 750,000 of the shares were acquired from Towle at $22.50 a share.

title: Prices Steady in Listless Day; Treasury Sale Is Awaited
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed yesterday after a listless trading session in which both investors and speculators showed little inclination to participate.

title: DOW OFF 8.19 TRADING HEAVY
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.19 points yesterday, to 1,031.09, in another day of heavy trading. But despite the drop in the market's key average, most stocks held on to big gains made Tuesday.

title: Connecticut Faces $7.8 Million Deficit
description: Connecticut's state government, which already faces a budget deficit of nearly $300 million in the fiscal year starting July 1, now has a projected deficit of $7.8 million in the current fiscal year, State Comptroller J. Edward Caldwell reported today.

title: DENVER SUIT LOOMING AS THREAT TO WAY CITIES AWARD CABLE TV FRANCHISES
description: In October, a conservative public interest group here filed a lawsuit challenging Denver's decision to award a single company the right to wire the city for cable television.

title: POLLOCK TELEPHONE PAD MOVES TO COFFEE TABLE
description: GIVEN the repro-mania that has seized the art world, and our heroworship of Jackson Pollock, it's inevitable that such an attractive fetish object as Pollock's telephone scratch pad should be reproduced as a multiple. Put out in an edition of 500 by the Johnson Reprint Corporation, a subsidiary of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich that specializes in overrefined texts at investment prices, it's solemnly titled ''Jackson Pollock: The Last Sketchbook.'' Packed in a solander box, the cloth-covered kind in which rare manuscripts are kept, the book is even more solemnly priced at $500.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My 20-year-old house is well built. In recent years I have added insulation, caulking and weatherstripping. I even added plastic foam sealers to all the electrical outlets on outside walls recently. As a result, my heating bills are the envy of all my neighbors. However, when I started to think about how airtight I had made my house I started to become alarmed. Can a house be so well sealed that the amount of oxygen is diminished to a dangerous level?

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Headline
description: KENTUCKY DEFEATS NOTRE DAME, 58-45

title: Paging Walter Mitty
description: A dozen members of the 2,500-man Corps of Cadets at Texas A&M will receive an opportunity next season to do more for the football team than just stand and cheer throughout the game. Jackie Sherrill, the first-year coach, has decided to select 12 of the best athletes in the corps and let them play on the defensive kickoff team at each home game.

title: BALLET: DUTCH TROUPE PRESENTS THREE WORKS
description: THE Dutch National Ballet is the best-known of the six European companies in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Ballet International'' series and last night it opened its run, through Dec. 12, with two New York premieres and the familiar ''Four Last Songs'' by Rudi van Dantzig, the troupe's artistic director.

title: Triton Bid Revised
description: The Triton Group Ltd., New York-based holding company, and the Tony Lama Company, the nation's leading manufacturer of Western boots, said they had agreed in principle for Triton to revise its offer for Lama. Under the proposed new terms, Triton would still pay $35 a share for each of Tony Lama's 2,325,115 outstanding shares, or $81 million, but the breakdown of cash and debt would be changed. Each share of Tony Lama would be exchangeable for $16.50 in cash and $18.50 of 12-year floating rate subordinated notes, the companies said.

title: ARTWORKS TO SIZE: 3-BY-5 FIBER SHOW
description: Owners of art galleries have long had to deal with customers searching for ''something blue for over the sofa.'' While such a request may raise dealers' eyebrows, it is routinely heard. Frequently sought, too, is ''something 3 by 5,'' referring to a size regarded by many in the art world as the ideal proportions.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH a wood-burning fireplace is not the most efficient source of heat - and, indeed, will usually waste more than it generates - those who have a fireplace still enjoy a crackling fire on a chilly night.

title: CABARET: BOSTON QUARTET IN 'SWING'S THE THING'
description: WERE ''Swing's the Thing'' as funny as its performers apparently think it is, it would be a cross between Sid Caesar and ''Saturday Night Live.'' The problem is it's not funny at all.

title: McEnroe Booed in Loss
description: Europe won the $600,000 Tennis Challenge from the Americas tonight, with the last match of the three-day tournament marked by controversy concerning John McEnroe.

title: STEVENS, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1.5 million...C-Net loss including a tax credit of$38 million

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Fundamentalist Minister Free After Pact to Shut His School
description: The Rev. Everett Sileven, jailed when he defied a court order to close his Faith Christian School was freed again today after agreeing to keep the unaccredited school closed until Monday.

title: TURKISH OFFICIAL'S SOVIET VISIT SAID TO MARK A NORMALIZATION
description: Foreign Minister Ilter Turkmen's current visit to the Soviet Union was described by officials here as marking a normalization of relations, which were said to have cooled somewhat since the military came to power here in 1980.

title: Baylor: 'Pencil My Name In'
description: W ith that big Yankee top-hat banner behind him, Don Baylor stood behind the microphones yesterday at Yankee Stadium in the same dining room where Ken Griffey and Dave Collins had stood when each joined the Yankees about a year ago. And when he was asked if he would like to be more than merely the designated hitter he was with the California Angels last season, Don Baylor smiled.

title: Coast Company Charged With Illegal Dumping
description: A nationally known water service company was charged today with dumping hazardous wastes, including a carcinogen, into the city's sewer system.

title: A SLIMMER CADILLAC FAIRVIEW
description: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation drew attention in the 1970's by putting together dramatic real estate deals that changed skylines from Calgary to California. In these less buoyant times, it is attracting even more attention through a strategy of becoming stronger by becoming smaller.

title: PRACTICING AT HOME, PIANISSIMO
description: IN concert halls around the world, performances by the pianist Emanuel Ax find many supporters. But in his own building, Mr. Ax's playing has prompted some harsh criticism from his next-door neighbors.

title: ECONOMY WORRIES OFFICIALS OF CITIES
description: The recession and Federal spending cuts seemed to be the main concerns among almost 4,000 local officials from around the country who ended a four-day convention today, although they were placated somewhat by a few words from President Reagan.

title: MARY JOSEPHINA KENNEY
description: Sister Mary Josephina Kenney, retired president of Xavier University, died Monday after a long illness. She was 80 years old.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 2, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Auto Outlook in Europe
description: The General Motors Corporation expects the West European market to grow from 10 million cars a year to 11.5 million by 1985 and to 13 million by 1990, Howard Kehrl, G.M.'s vice chairman, said in a speech here today.

title: AMERICAN ACADEMY SELECTS FOUR MEMBERS
description: Four vacant chairs will be filled tomorrow in the 50-member American Academy of Arts and Letters, in its classic building on Audubon Terrace overlooking the Hudson in northern Manhattan. If this were London, the four new academy members would be knighted and called Sirs; here, they'll simply be cited for their literary stature, clink glasses and leave after lunch as they arrived, still Misters.

title: SAN ANTONIO
description: THE curve is a sweeping left-hander leading onto the freeway, and Ponce Kiah Marchelle Heloise Cruse Evans deftly downshifts her chocolate brown Porsche Turbo Carrera and slips easily into the turn, steady as a rock as she whips into the outside lane, her long silver hair rippling in the wind.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOUSE VOTE WOULD END F.T.C. RULES FOR DOCTORS
description: The House voted today to exempt medical and all other state-licensed professionals from the Federal Trade Commission's consumer protection and antitrust laws.

title: DRUSE CHIEF HURT IN BEIRUT BOMBING
description: A Druse leader escaped a powerful car bomb in the heart of Moslem West Beirut today with only minor injuries.

title: PLAN TO ABOLISH ENERGY DEPT. FADING
description: Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel indicated today that the Reagan Administration's proposal to abolish the Department of Energy and move its activities to other agencies was probably dead. The proposal has aroused wide opposition in Congress and elsewhere.

title: KING'S 25 BOLSTER KNICKS
description: The tone of the Knicks' 101-84 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight was described in the opening seconds when a spectator in the sparse turnout of 2,114 at the 19,548-seat Richfield Coliseum yelled, ''Boring.''

title: U.S. PUTS AN 'IF' ON MORE TROOPS FOR LEBANON
description: The Administration said today that it had received a Lebanese request to double the number of peacekeeping forces in Lebanon but would agree only if there was an end to the deadlock over the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization troops from that country.

title: A Penn State Star
description: Remember Art Mahaffey, who used to pitch for the Philadelphia Phillies and who had such a good pickoff move? Well, he spends a lot of time these days watching college women playing field hockey, especially one: Judy Mahaffey, his 21-year-old daughter, who is carrying the family's involvement with sports into a new dimension.

title: COUSIN HELD
description: The body of a 10-year-old girl was found at a construction site in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday morning, and hours later detectives charged her 28-year-old cousin with the murder after rescuing him from a group of enraged relatives, the police said.

title: Market Place; Market Shifts For Levi Jeans
description: LEVI STRAUSS & COMPANY has announced the closing of a jeans plant in Hobbs, N.M., and plants in Clovis, N.M., and Plainview, Tex. that make jeans and other garments. Last April it closed a jeans plant in Laredo, Tex.

title: JUDY'S FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ESTIMATE BOARD VOTING STRUCTURE UPHELD
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the voting structure of the New York City Board of Estimate did not violate the United States Constitution.

title: Queens Man Guilty Of Killing Parents
description: A 24-year-old Queens man was convicted yesterday of murdering his parents in a attack set off by a reprimand from his mother. A jury of 10 women and two men returned a guilty verdict in State Supreme Court in Queens against Alan Kinitsky of Bayside for the March 22, 1981, killings of Julius Kinitsky, 52, and Marilyn Kinitsky, 49.

title: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO GIVE BRAZILIANS A $1.2 BILLION LOAN
description: President Reagan said today that the United States would provide $1.2 billion in emergency short-term loans to Brazil, and he appealed to lenders around the world to help Brazil and other countries through their financial crises.

title: PLAN TO CURB DAIRY SURPLUS GOES INTO EFFECT
description: Dairy farmers today began paying a special assessment they believe will neither help reduce the mountainous surplus of dairy products nor lower the prices that consumers pay for them.

title: U.S. SLASHES FUNDS FOR STUDY ON UTILITIES' ROLE IN ACID RAIN
description: The Reagan Administration, which has insisted that more research is needed before it undertakes a costly regulatory program to control acid rain, today sharply reduced a major research program on air pollution by electric utilities.

title: Index; International
description: Assam caldron bubbles dangerously again A2 China's revenue can't keep pace with modernization demands A3 Poland dissolves actors union over boycott of TV shows A4 Around the World A5 Druse leader escapes serious injury in Beirut bombing A8 U.S. says it won't increase troops in Lebanon until talks begin A9 Fresh paint on lane markers betrays Reagan's secret route A12 Spanish Parliament elects Socialist as Prime Minister A13 Turk's visit to Moscow said to mark normalization in ties A14 Bulgaria said to warn Italy of crisis in ties A15 Government/Politics Concern about the economy is voiced by city officials A21 Farmers begin paying special assessment on dairy products A27 Administration ready to work with Congress on job bill B15 Regan urges New York G.O.P. to take ''centrist'' position D23 Washington Talk Briefing B14 Interagency cooperation urged in the battle against drugs B14 Working Profile: Gerald P. Carmen of the G.S.A. B14 General Around the Nation A18 Bribery trial jury sequestered after receiving phone calls A19 Houston transit officials forced to change plans A22 City picks 10 private agencies to help with homeless B7 Industry/Labor Union is impatient for Chrysler wage offer A26 Gulf Oil to pull out of upstate New York next year B8 The Home Section Home The art of giving gifts for the home C1

title: A COMPOSER'S DELAYED REACTION TO NAZISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Hawks 4, Penguins 2
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Darryl Sutter scored two goals and Murray Bannerman made 44 saves to held Chicago extend its winning streak to six games.

title: CONCERT: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC GROUP
description: THE Group for Contemporary Music mounted a particularly wellchosen memorial program at Symphony Space on Tuesday night to the pianist Robert Miller on the first anniversary of his death. Mr. Miller's death at the age of 50 was felt as a particular loss, since he had played such a vital role in support of the sober, dissonant, complex music that dominated composition in the northeastern United States during the decades after World War II. His contributions were twofold: He was a technically commanding, conscientious interpreter, and as a lawyer he assisted composers and contemporary music in legal matters.

title: One DePaul Player Carries Big Burden
description: CHICAGO W alter Downing smiled at the memory of the last basketball game he played that included players from U.C.L.A., a pickup game in Los Angeles more than seven months ago. There were about 16,000 fewer people watching than there will be tonight when Downing and DePaul oppose the Bruins at the Rosemont Horizon.

title: United Brands Cutback
description: The United Brands Company said yesterday that it would omit a cash dividend this quarter because of its $15.8 million loss in the fiscal first quarter, ended Sept. 30. The company distributed 5 cents a share in October.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
EX-FEDERAL AIDE PICKED BY CUOMO TO BE COUNSEL
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo yesterday named Alice G. Daniel, a former assistant United States attorney general, to be his counsel. Mr. Cuomo said Mrs. Daniel would be the first woman ever to serve as counsel to a Governor of New York. ''I'm delighted with that and I think it's significant,'' he said.

title: British Steel Narrows Loss
description: The British Steel Corporation said today that it had an operating loss, after interest, of 154 million, equivalent to $247 million, in the six months ended Oct. 2.

title: Flyers 4, Oilers 2
description: Bill Barber, playing in his 800th game, scored twice for Philadelphia.

title: 'Superwomen's' Guilt
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: What Nan Robertson's article (''Job vs. Baby: A Dilemma Persists,'' Nov. 18) omitted is a discussion of the heart-wrenching guilt that we ''Superwomen'' feel when we have finally made the decision to work and leave our baby with the babysitter. Like many of the women whom Miss Robertson is writing about, I thought I could do it all - and on the surface, I did.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $651,000

title: Heileman Returns Pabst Certificates
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company said it was returning by registered mail all certificates for Pabst Brewing Company stock submitted under a now-terminated tender offer. Under a new, $225 million agreement announced last Friday, Heileman, the nation's fourth-largest brewer, said it would offer $29 a share in cash, or about $162.4 million, for up to 5.6 million Pabst shares, and would issue notes for the rest in a second step.

title: CONCERT: GUARNERI QUARTET
description: WHEN Dvorak was not attempting to be a classical master or a Wagnerian disciple his music was remarkably intoxicating, a Bohemian mixture of quirky tensions and melodic invention. That charm was celebrated Monday by the Guarneri Quartet at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think it's any mystery that I would like to be President.

title: DELAY ASSAILED IN FILLING POSTS ON STATE COURT
description: The Chief Judge of New York State said yesterday that a dispute blocking the appointment of 19 new Court of Claims judges could have ''catastrophic'' consequences for the court system, and could require the transfer of eight upstate judges to New York City next year.

title: Advertising; Scali Going Into Direct Marketing
description: year-old, highly creative advertising agency, will establish a subsidiary direct-marketing agency next month. That comes as no major surprise since there is a trend among large general agencies to set up such units.

title: LaRouche Campaign To Pay $15,000 Fine
description: The 1980 Presidential campaign of Lyndon LaRouche has agreed to pay a $15,000 fine for violating Federal election laws, the Federal Election Commission said Tuesday.

title: Swedish Defense Chief Gives Up His Job
description: Defense Minister Borje Andersson resigned today from the Social Democratic Government of Prime Minister Olof Palme. Mr. Andersson said he wanted to spend more time with his family.

title: MEXICAN PRESIDENT, TAKING OFFICE, LAYS OUT STRICT AUSTERITY PROGRAM
description: Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado was sworn in as President of Mexico today and immediately announced sweeping austerity measures aimed at dealing with the country's worst economic crisis in four decades.

title: Poachers in South Africa Kill 137 Elephants
description: Poachers have shot and killed 137 elephants in the Kruger National Park in the last 18 months, park officials said today. The park is 250 miles northeast of here.

title: ...WORKER BE SAVED
description: While the American and world economies are undergoing structural transformations more profound than any since the late 19th century, Established Wisdom has responded with a 167-year-old idyll called free trade. In the process, it has been discovered that the proposed domestic-content bill in Congress - legislation that requires auto producers to employ American workers in proportion to the number of vehicles they sell in the American market - contradicts that hoary utopian vision.

title: FREEZE FRINGE
description: To the Editor:

title: New Phone Link Planned by MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it would sharply increase the capacity of its long-distance telephone network between New York and Washington, D.C., by installing a fiberoptics link between the two cities.

title: PRESIDENCY
description: Following is a transcript of a statement in Washington yesterday by Senator Edward M. Kennedy in which he announced that he would not seek the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1984 and his answers to questions from reporters, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Pick Judges, Not Fights
description: State Senator Warren Anderson threatens to block confirmation of anyone nominated for 19 much-needed New York judicial posts. Why? Because Governor Carey won't nominate some of the Senator's favored candidates. As majority leader of a Republican-controlled Senate, Mr. Anderson has the power to insist, but not the right to wield it so pettily, and with such severe consequences.

title: BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Announced that a f ree agent, Terry Forster, relief pitcher, h ad agreed to terms for a three-year con- t ract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed a free a gent, Gene Tenace, catcher-first base- m an, to a multiyear contract.

title: SUMMONS TO SOMEDAY
description: Be charitable: grant that a concern for his children's worry about assassination was surely one factor in Ted Kennedy's decision not to run for President in 1984.

title: SYMPHONY NATIONAL ORCHESTRA
description: IT makes sense that the National Symphony Orchestra should be taking a prominent part in the ''Scandinavia Today'' festivities that are being observed throughout the country this season. The orchestra is, after all, the resident ensemble of Washington, and ought to take the lead in certain diplomatic responsibilities. And it does. Last night's concert at Carnegie Hall by the National Symphony was an all-Scandinavian program under the baton of its music director, Mstislav Rostropovich.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
POLAND DISSOLVES UNION OF ACTORS OVER A PROTEST AGAINST ARMY RULE
description: The Polish authorities today dissolved the actors union, which has been boycotting television to protest martial law. The abolition of the union was carried out under the same 1932 statute used to dissolve the journalists union in March. The boycott had turned television, often a showcase for original drama, into a dreary series of panel discussions and official speeches, sometimes enlivened by athletic events and old Russian movies.

title: Coast Fraud Indictment
description: A Federal grand jury here indicted a fugitive businessman today on 35 counts of fraud. Joel D. Nelson, who has not been seen since last New Year's Eve, is accused of having run a scheme since 1968 in which investors lost as much as $18 million.

title: Dow Will Abandon Big Saudi Venture
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would withdraw from a $1.5 billion joint-venture agreement with the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation to build a huge petrochemical complex in Jubail.

title: FLORIDA GULF REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CODY SENTENCED TO 5-YEAR TERM AS A RACKETEER
description: John A. Cody, one of the New York metropolitan area's most influential labor leaders, was sentenced today in Federal District Court to five years in prison for labor racketeering and tax evasion.

title: HOUSTON REJECTS A CENTRAL ELEVATED RAIL LINE
description: In the face of stiff protest, transit officials here have given up on their plans to build an elevated rail line through downtown Houston and have begun to look for the additional money needed to put part of the line underground.

title: Study Finds No Proof That a Diet Pill Works
description: No persuasive evidence has been found that starch blockers, which were being sold in great numbers as diet aids earlier this year, can in fact cause weight loss without dieting or exercise, a team of doctors said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Nov. 24 incorrectly attributed a company's first-half loss. Ketchum Laboratories Inc., a subsidiary of Ketchum & Company, suffered the loss.

title: Bert Jones Is Ailing
description: Bert Jones, the starting quarterback for the Los Angeles Rams, has a pinched nerve in his neck and is not expected to see any action in tonight's game against San Francisco. He will be replaced by Vince Ferragamo. For the 49ers, Pete Kugler will start at nose guard in place of John Harty, who will move to defensive end. ... One day after he was put on waivers by Philadelphia, Al Chesley, the 6-3, 240-pound linebacker, has been acquired by the Chicago Bears.

title: CITY BALLET: A SALUTE TO BROOKLYN BRIDGE
description: IT'S not every day that a ballet company honors a bridge. But that's what happened Tuesday night when the New York City Ballet came to the Brooklyn Academy of Music for the first time in its history to offer ''A Star-Spangled Salute to Brooklyn.'' And all proceeds went to the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Financial Network's Advertising Adviser
description: Richard L. Gilbert, who over the past year has made the transition from agency president to cable-TV consultant, has been retained by the Financial News Network as ''senior adviser'' in the areas of advertising and marketing strategies.

title: Israeli Professors Strike
description: Israel's state-owned universities were closed today as the professors' union began its third two-day strike in a month to demand salary increases.

title: French Nationalization Blamed in Divorce Case
description: In French business circles, it is the divorce of the year. Halfkiddingly, she blames the Socialist Government's nationalization program. Not kidding at all, his spokesman says it's a private matter.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART IMPLANT IS BEGUN IN SALT LAKE
description: A retired Seattle dentist suffering from inoperable heart disease underwent surgery late tonight for what was to be the first transplant of a permanent artificial heart.

title: Japan's Premier to Visit U.S.
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone today accepted an invitation from President Reagan to confer in Washington on Jan. 18, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said today.

title: DRIVE TO REVAMP IMMIGRATION LAW IS GAINING
description: Members of Congress appear increasingly eager to pass a comprehensive immigration bill this year, but there is growing support for efforts to delete a proposed amnesty for illegal aliens.

title: THE ART OF BUYING GIFTS FOR THE HOME
description: The Home Section's Christmas gift roundup was compiled by Suzanne Slesin, Carol Vogel and Mary Smith and was written by Miss Slesin. BUYING a gift for someone's home can be a difficult task. Will the item fit the recipient's decor or style of living? Is it useful and practical? Accepting that this Christmas season may be a more sober affair than usual, we may be spurred toward a streak of creativity, choosing items that are appropriately useful yet still imaginative. Many department stores and specialty shops seem to be encouraging such an approach, emphasizing merchandise that is more practical than whimsical. So it makes sense to think carefully about what to buy and for whom, before setting out to shop.

title: Modern Grandma
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: You cannot be up to your elbows in cranberry sauce (''Thoroughly Modern Grandma,'' Nov. 25). In stuffing, perhaps, or in turkey or mincemeat or even pumpkins, but not cranberry sauce. Next year when Betty Friedan's new grandson is able to help, he may be up to his elbows or even his eyebrows in cranberry sauce, but I'm quite sure a feminist grandmother will be able to handle a feminist's grandson. ANNA MARY WELLS Hightstown, N.J.

title: KENNEDY, BARRING '84 RACE, CITES DUTY TO CHILDREN
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that he would not run for President in 1984 because he did not want to expose his children to the pressures of another campaign.

title: LORIMAR PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Chevron Venture
description: Chevron U.S.A. and Arco Alaska Inc. plan to drill exploratory wells in Alaskan waters, spokesmen for the two companies said.

title: THEATER: 'YELLOW FEVER' BY THE PAN ASIAN REP
description: STANDING in a back alley, with his hat shadowing his face, the raincoated figure lights a cigarette, and, in carefully clipped dialogue, he begins to tell us about his latest and toughest crime caper. The man is not Sam Spade, but Sam Shikaze, private eye, and the story is not ''The Maltese Falcon'' but R.A. Shiomi's ''Yellow Fever.''

title: KEY TO THE BATTLE ON DRUGS: A DOUBLING OF TROOPS
description: In the past year President Reagan has made combating narcotics trafficking one of his major causes, escalating the struggle to its highest level in at least a decade.

title: LFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: B-After a loss of $215,000 for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: LOANS IN LATIN AMERICA MAY HURT U.S. BANKS
description: Many American banks may show smaller profits and major increases in problem loans for the fourth quarter of 1982 as a result of loans they have made to private companies and individuals in Mexico and Argentina.

title: MOVE TO AFFECT 485 GAS STATIONS
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, citing its small share of the gasoline market and declining gasoline prices, said yesterday that it would withdraw from upstate New York next year, leaving 485 stations looking for new suppliers of gasoline.

title: Manning Accepts Role As a Temporary Starter
description: Since 1971, Archie Manning had been one of the National Football League's premier quarterbacks. Then came a surprising trade early this season from his beloved New Orleans Saints to the Houston Oilers, where he is starting all over again.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday incorrectly identified Michael Slosberg. He is executive vice president and executive creative director at Marsteller New York, the New York office of Marsteller Inc.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Consumer Saturday column on Nov. 13 about the cost of insuring small cars incorrectly reported the rate of collision claims affecting two models. The 1980 Oldsmobile Cutlass compact wagon, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, had far fewer loss claims than the 1980 Chevrolet Corvette.

title: Hong Kong Quotas Cut
description: After six months of tough negotiations, the European Economic Community signed an agreement with Hong Kong Wednesday cutting quotas for imports of cheap textiles from the British crown colony.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: Tylenol Figure Ordered Back to Illinois by Judge
description: Kevin John Masterson, sought for questioning in the Tylenol poisoning case, was ordered back to Illinois today after he waived extradition.

title: BROWN WARNS MX PLAN NEEDS FAR MORE SILOS
description: Former Secretary of Defense Harold Brown today asserted that President Reagan's proposed base for MX missiles could not survive nuclear attack and urged Congress to change it by adding silos to deceive Soviet war planners.

title: Creamer Inc. Losing The Wella Account
description: Donald E. Creamer, president of Creamer Inc., will be losing the Wella Corporation, whose products include Wella Balsam Conditioner, Wella Balsam Shampoo and Kolestral, all hair-care products, with billings of around $3.5 million.

title: Court Backs Fraud Verdict
description: Multimillion-dollar fraud damage awards were upheld today against C. Arnholt Smith, his wife, daughter and an associate as a result of the collapse of his financial empire in 1973.

title: HERS
description: WORD having gotten around that I was at work on a novel about abortion, I was continually surprised by women who volunteered information about themselves. They, too, they felt I should know, had had abortions. It was never lightly said - always gravely, as if imparting a trust, yet always surprisingly, spontaneously, the pentup information sought its own way toward release.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $16,000 for the qr and yr...C-Net loss

title: Rocket Coach's Problem
description: The ethical problems of his situation have caused Del Harris to offer to step down as coach of the Houston Rockets, but the club owners have assured him they understand the situation.

title: OPEC Sales Fell Last Year
description: Oil sales by the 13 members of OPEC fell 9 percent last year as a steep decline in production more than offset an increase in prices, the group said today.

title: FLAGG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Grant Wood Exhibition Planned by the Whitney
description: A retrospective of works by Grant Wood (1891-1942), said to be the largest ever assembled, will open June 16 at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: A COMPOSER'S DELAYED REACTION TO NAZISM
description: To the Editor:

title: PINTOR AND GOMEZ KNOW THE HAZARDS
description: He wandered to the table where Wilfredo Gomez was being interviewed and rested his hand on the champion's shoulder for the benefit of photographers. Lupe Pintor fashioned a broad smile that has become his calling card this week and there was not even a hint of malice between the two.

title: After Kennedy, and Before
description: During the tormented 1968 Democratic convention in Chicago, bereaved Robert Kennedy staff members huddled in a pipe-and-drape booth on the mezzanine waiting for a sign that Edward Kennedy would make a dramatic bid for the Presidential nomination. The signal never came.

title: Partial Walls of Yore
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: While partial walls may be a new, innovative idea of today's architects (''Partial Walls: New Ways to Shape Space,'' Nov. 18), for those of us who lived in small apartments some 30 to 50 years ago, partial walls or their equivalent were a necessity. In the 1930's through to the 1950's we - my parents, sisters, aunt and uncle -lived in a Williamburg tenement.

title: THEATER: 'KNIGHTS ERRANT,' ON NIXON
description: JUST as Richard Nixon arouses violent feelings, so do those performers who seek to portray him. Was the comedian David Frye's jocular Nixon too soft? Was Rip Torn's hilariously lunatic Nixon, seen on television's ''Blind Ambition,'' too extreme? Other illustrious stage and screen Nixon impersonators over the last decade or so have been as diverse as Jason Robards, George S. Irving and Robert Brustein. They all have their fierce partisans and detractors, for Richard Nixon is a role subject to as many interpretations as just about any protagonist in classical drama.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Allied Stores Corporation filed a shelf registration with the S.E.C. for $200 million of debt securities, to be offered occasionally with terms set at the time of sale.

title: GOVERNMENT LANDLORD'S FRUGAL STYLE
description: Gerald P. Carmen's introduction to the wondr@ous ways of the Federal bureaucracy came on his first day as administrator of the General Services Administration when he was handed a swatch of expensive upholstery materials.

title: DAY BY DAY
description: A Warm Welcome For the First Lady

title: People
description: * Daniel E. Cohen has been promoted to executive vice president at the Marschalk Company.

title: FEARN CUTLER THURLOW
description: Fearn Cutler Thurlow, curator of painting and sculpture at the Newark Museum, died yesterday in Mendham, N.J. She was 58 years old.

title: CHINA TO GET NEW CONSTITUTION TOMORROW, ITS 4th SINCE 1949
description: During a discussion at the current session of the National People's Congress, an army political commissar named Xiao Hua ventured that the elimination of the ''freedom to strike'' from the new constitution was a good idea.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''To all those doom criers, and they are worldwide, we have a message.

title: IN LITCHFIELD HUE AND CRY FOR 'TRADITION'
description: On occasion, residents of this little community in the Berkshire foothills will look up to find tourists standing in their front hallways and living rooms.

title: TOKYO EMBRACES 'BEST FIVE' DESIGNERS
description: Valentino, the Italian fashion designer, was besieged by admirers after showing his collection here. They demanded that he autograph their shirts, dresses and jackets, and they ''received me like a king,'' he said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co. said it and Penncorp Financial Inc. will each hold special shareholder meetings on Jan. 11 to vote on American's proposed acquisition of Penncorp.

title: Heisman Winners Who Played Line
description: Leon Hart and Larry Kelley admit it. Every season they scan the newspapers and the television for a massive brute of a lineman who cannot be denied the Heisman Trophy, given to the outstanding college football player.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ultimate Sacrifice

title: KEEPING TROOPS IN EUROPE
description: Among the many cracks endangering the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's political and military cohesion is a small fissure that, if allowed to widen unchecked, could destroy the alliance. For the first time in a decade, Congress is contemplating pulling United States troops out of Europe.

title: A dollhouse of collectibles.
description: NOSTALGIA always runs high in pre-Christmas sales of such collectibles as the dolls, toys, music boxes, mechanical banks, fur coats, costumes, Oriental robes, lace goods, fans and novelties that were found under Christmas trees a generation or more ago.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bank of New England Corp.'s 540,000 depository preferred shares were priced at $50 each, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: SUFFOLK COUNTY OFFERS PLAN FOR DEALING WITH NUCLEAR PLANT ACCIDENTS
description: Suffolk County today presented its plan for dealing with accidents at the Long Island Lighting Company's $3 billion Shoreham nuclear power station and recommended evacuating residents in a zone twice as large as the one mapped out by the utility.

title: Market Place; Hospital Care: Rapid Growth
description: ''I love it; it's a terrific stock,'' declares Carl Sherman, hospital management analyst for Prudential-Bache. ''I've recommended it for years,'' says John F. Hindelong, who holds the same position at Warburg Becker Paribas. Both are praising the same company, National Medical Enterprises, the big Los Angeles-based owner and operator of hospitals and nursing homes.

title: General Re Corp.
description: The General Re Corporation, parent of the General Reinsurance Group, the largest property-casualty reinsurer in the country, said that preliminary estimates indicated that it would incur a loss of about $10 million from its reinsurance coverage of two recent catastrophes, a fire at the Northwestern Bank building in Minneapolis, Minn., and damage from the hurricane in the Hawaiian Islands. The $10 million loss, the Greenwich, Conn., company said, could cause a 12-cent-a-share decline in operating income in the fourth quarter of this year. ''Despite these events, I believe fourth-quarter 1982 earnings will exceed those reported for the fourth quarter of 1981,'' said Harold J. Hudson, chairman of General Re.

title: 40,000 MEN IS THE ULTIMATE GOAL
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it had agreed to rebuild and train the Lebanese Army over the next year so that it can eventually maintain the internal security of the country with some 28,000 light infantry forces and another 12,000 troops in support.

title: SANITATION DEPT. ACCUSES WORKERS OF A JOB ACTION
description: The Sanitation Department said yesterday that 400 truckloads of refuse had gone uncollected in New York City on Wednesday and Thursday because of a sudden increase in truck safety inspections and ''a slowdown in work performance'' by sanitation workers.

title: GONZALEZ INSTALLED AS SPAIN'S PREMIER
description: Felipe Gonzalez was sworn in today as the first Socialist Prime Minister of Spain since the 1930's. At a brief ceremony at the palace of King Juan Carlos on the outskirts of Madrid, the 40-year-old Mr. Gonzalez placed his hands on a Bible and, facing a cruficix, took the oath to the Constitution, using the secular word ''promise'' rather than the religiously laden ''swear'' used by his predecessors. Mr. Gonzalez, the youngest Prime Minister in Europe, is a nonpracticing Roman Catholic.

title: A WEALTH OF GOVERNMENT INFORMATION AT THE PUBLIC'S FINGER TIPS
description: To the Editor:

title: HEROIC LUTHERANS
description: To the Editor:

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
French Videotex Group Plans Marketing in U.S.
description: Bernard E. Joseph has been named chairman and chief executive of a newly formed group of French companies that plans an assault on the United States market for teletext and videotex.

title: JERSEY URGED TO STEP UP CASINOS' AID PAYMENTS
description: New Jersey's Casino Control Commission, saying that legalized gambling had failed to lead to the renewal of Atlantic City, today asked for legislation requiring casinos to invest millions of dollars in housing and other projects there.

title: Bull Moose Bid
description: The Bull Moose Tube Company, the St. Louis-based subsidiary of the National Steel Corporation, announced that it has signed a letter of intent for the purchase of all the outstanding stock of the Vulcan Tube and Metals Company of Chicago for an undisclosed amount of cash. Bull Moose produces mechanical, structural, sprinkler and pressure tubing.

title: PAUL E. WILLHIDE
description: Paul E. Willhide, vice president of personnel and industrial relations for the Pratt & Whitney Group of United Technologies, East Hartford, Conn., died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Savannah, Ga., during a business trip.

title: Fast Skating Helps Ranger To a Goal
description: Skating speed in hockey is often overstressed, according to Rob McClanahan, the forward for the Rangers who can skate very fast. ''Sometimes I go too fast,'' said McClanahan. ''I overskate the puck or break too early. I'm trying to slow down a little bit.''

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1982
description: International Ways to avert an accidental war proposed by President Reagan and made public in his Nov. 22 speech have evoked interest on the part of the Soviet leadership, according to Administration officials. They said the Kremlin had sent Mr. Reagan a message asking where the United States wanted to discuss the proposals in detail and were told that the Administration wished to pursue the subject at the arms control talks in Geneva. (Page A1, Column 4.) American aid for Lebanon's Army over the next year has been pledged by the Reagan Administration. United States officials said that American forces would train and help rebuild the Lebanese Army so that it could eventually maintain the country's internal security. (A12:3-4.)

title: JOBLESS BENEFIT ROLLS SURGE FOR THE NATION TO 4.84 MILLION PEAK
description: A record 4.84 million Americans are drawing unemployment checks, the Labor Department reported today. Analysts said the statistic reflected substantial rises in the number of people insured against loss of work.

title: Pacer Half-Share Costs $3.6 Million
description: Lana Lobell Farms has paid $3.6 million for a half-interest in the 2-year-old pacer Fortune Teller, who amassed more money in earnings this year than any other race horse.

title: A PAIR OF SKILLED HANDS TO GUIDE AN ARTIFICIAL HEART: ROBERT KIFFLER JARVIK
description: Dr. Robert Koffler Jarvik, who was the principal designer of the polyurethane Jarvik-7 artificial heart that was implanted in Barney B. Clark's body yesterday, had a strong motivation to invent such a machine: His father died of heart disease after open-heart surgery a decade earlier. Today Dr. Jarvik says that event led him down the newly opened path of artificial-heart research in the early 1970's.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: The latest qr includes a nonrecurring charge of $1,154,000 from a one-time labor contract payment; Fiscal 1982 figures include a charge of $1,910,000 related to company's changes in product distribution plus a gain of $1,359,000 from divestiture of broiler operations

title: Teamster Official On L.I. Indicted
description: The president of a Long Island-based local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was indicted yesterday on a charge of extorting $7,000 from the head of a company that employed members of the local.

title: A RACE WITHOUT KENNEDY
description: Edward Kennedy's withdrawal from the 1984 Presidential campaign makes an open race for the Democratic nomination even more open -not necessarily a good thing. Beyond that, in an era of television and primary politics, speculation becomes a guessing game.

title: NATO BACKS U.S. OPERATIONS IN MIDEAST
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization offered moderate new support today for possible American military operations in places outside the alliance's geographical area such as the Middle East and the Persian Gulf.

title: FOR TERESA BREWER, GROWING UP HAS BROUGHT JAZZ
description: LOTS of things have changed since 1949, when an 18-year-old Teresa Brewer belted her way to singing stardom by urging listeners to ''put another nickel in, in the nickelodeon'' and get ''Music, Music, Music.'' But not everything.

title: AMERICAN METALS SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
McDermott Inc.
description: McDermott Inc. announced that it and Brown & Root Inc., a subsidiary of the Halliburton Company, had executed tentative agreements in the settlement of claims by 25 plaintiffs in 14 of the 65 consolidated private antitrust actions currently pending in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana. The settlement, which is subject to the approval of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, provides for a total payment of about $27.5 million, of which McDermott would pay about $13 million to the plaintiffs, which are natural gas transmission companies.

title: Mrs. King Gains, With Mrs. Lloyd
description: Billie Jean King defeated Barbara Potter, 6-4, 6-2, today to gain a berth in the quarterfinals of the $350,000 Marlboro Australian Open tennis tournament against Chris Evert Lloyd.

title: PROBLEMS IN SPACESUIT TRACED TO MISTAKE AND FAULTY SENSOR
description: Space agency engineers have traced the source of the spacesuit failures in last month's flight of the space shuttle Columbia. One was caused by human oversight in manufacturing.

title: Union Talks Extended At Boston Newspaper
description: Negotiations between the publisher Rupert Murdoch and 11 Boston Herald American unions continued past a midnight deadline in efforts to reach an agreement to keep the newspaper from folding.

title: French cuisine in theater district.
description: CONSIDERING the demand for good, pleasant, moderate-price restaurants in the theater district, La Vieille Auberge should develop a loyal following. Opened just six months ago on Restaurant Row - 46th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues - the simple, comfortable bistro is a family affair. The owner and overseer of the dining room is Marcel Riou, formerly a waiter at the ''21'' Club. He is aided by his wife, Marie Louise, and on weekends, their son pitches in as a waiter. The chef, Jean Le Cras, cooked at Restaurant Raphael when it first opened, and he is adding stylish nouvelle cuisine touches to the sort of menu that has become standard at French restaurants on this block.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Carpenter and Woolfolk Work Together
description: Although the return of Rob Carpenter this week seemed sure to lift the Giants' offense, it also raised questions.

title: Advertising; Greeting Travelers With Ads
description: WHAT could be more fitting in an official ''Welcome to the United States'' brochure than something that Americans get more of than anyone - advertising.

title: ART: A SHOW THAT PAIRS MONDRAIN AND BRANCUSI
description: IF they had nothing else in common, the painter Piet Mondrian (1872-1944) and the sculptor Constantin Brancusi (1876-1957) shared a powerful esthetic impulse: to pare redundant nature down to pure, intrinsic form. And what each did -Mondrian geometrically reordering the world through reductive grids of vertical and horizontal lines; Brancusi with his soaring shafts and ovoid forms refining fleshly substance to spiritual essence - reverberates through 20th-century art.

title: SIMS SAYS JETS' RAY HAS ONE ADVANTAGE
description: Billy Sims's friend and former teammate at Oklahoma, Darrol Ray, knows how to stop the irrepressible Sims, who enters this week's games as the leading rusher in the National Football Conference.

title: Economic Scene; The Timing Of Stimulants
description: BEFORE he left for Brazil, President Reagan dropped the idea of moving next year's scheduled 10 percent cut in personal income taxes up from July to January. But his earlier support for the move - and his reasons for dropping it - are worth examining for the light they shed on economic policy and how it is made.

title: SALARY INCREASES CALLED ESSENTIAL FOR STATE JUDGES
description: Asserting that inadequate salaries discourage able candidates from seeking state judicial posts and sitting judges from remaining in them, particularly in New York City, a special commission is recommending judicial pay increases amounting to $20.2 million.

title: Some verdicts by Charlotte Rampling.
description: IN the elegant East Side restaurant, the usually composed maitre d'hotel takes one look at Charlotte Rampling and cries, ''You're gorgeous.'' ''And you,'' Miss Rampling says, ''must be Italian.''

title: POP: BOB DOROUGH, VOCALIST
description: BOB DOROUGH has a ''country boy'' singing style that, in a general sense, is somewhat similar to the mannerisms of Johnny Mercer, Hoagy Carmichael, Dave Frishberg and, from an earlier day, Pinky Tomlin. But unlike those other singers, who are laid back, relaxed, happy and somewhat naive, Mr. Dorough is hip and has such a fiercely intense approach that he seems to be baring his fangs as he sings.

title: BLACK HAWKS ENJOYING A RESURGENCE
description: The team with the best record in the National Hockey League at present is not the Islanders, nor the Montreal Canadiens. It is neither the Boston Bruins nor the Edmonton Oilers nor the Minnesota North Stars.

title: The Pinch of a Strike
description: The 57-day strike of the National Football League Players Association had bitter financial consequences for many people, but Harvey Martin of the Dallas Cowboys appears to be one of the hardest hit. The defensive end has filed for court protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Steel Quotas Cut by E.E.C.
description: The European Economic Community today announced steep cuts in its steel production quotas for the first quarter of 1983 and said it foresaw no improvement in demand before next summer.

title: IT'S DANCE, DANCE, DANCE ALL OVER TOWN
description: All over the city, from the Theater of the Riverside Church on West 120th Street to the White Dog Studio in TriBeCa, someone will be dancing this weekend. A number of major choreographers and performers are involved, as well as an unusual number of new works.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Surprise $500,000 Gift

title: More Chemical Smoke in Asia
description: The United States has come up with new evidence pointing to Soviet chemical warfare in Asia. If the case is still inconclusive, it is stronger. It cannot be shrugged off by the Russians. Properly, the United Nations this week ordered further inquiry into the thickening smoke. Any use of toxic chemical weapons violates a 1972 convention signed by, among others, the Soviet Union.

title: DEBATE ON MISSILE MAY FOCUS ON NEED
description: A number of Congressional aides and Reagan Administration officials believe that the debate over the MX intercontinental missile could focus on the need for the missile itself rather than on the ''dense pack'' system for basing the missile.

title: IAN SMITH'S PASSPORT CONFISCATED AFTER U.S. TRIP THAT CAUSED FUROR
description: The Zimbabwean authorities today seized the passport of Ian D. Smith, who was Prime Minister when the country was called Rhodesia and ruled by whites.

title: L.I. BOY, 13, AWAITS TRIAL FOR MOTHER'S SLAYING
description: A 13-year-old Long Island boy who fatally shot his mother Wednesday was being held yesterday in the Nassau County Children's Shelter in Westbury, awaiting trial as an adult for second-degree murder.

title: Money Fund Assets Increase
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $306 million in the week ended Wednesday, to a record of $231.46 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Series Star Finds Reality at Home
description: John Stuper, the rookie who pitched a critical victory for the St. Louis Cardinals in the World Series, said he became acutely aware of two things when he got back home to Butler, in western Pennsylvania: ''A lot of things had been going my way, and a lot of my friends were struggling without jobs.''

title: 'FIDELIO' BEFORE THE REWRITE
description: Ludwig von Beethoven wrote nine symphonies, 32 piano sonatas, a goodly amount of chamber music and many songs and smaller pieces. But he wrote only one opera, ''Fidelio,'' and it has had a checkered career from the beginning.

title: Republic Air Debt
description: Republic Airlines announced that it had reached an agreement with its major lenders to restructure its debt of $395.5 million under which the maturity schedule has been extended from 1989 to 1992. The company added that payments due in 1983 and 1984 had also been reduced from a total of $108 million, to $45 million.

title: 2 BIG REFINERS CUT PRICES PAID FOR OIL
description: Two large oil companies, the Cities Service Company and Ashland Oil Inc., announced yesterday that they were cutting a dollar a barrel from the prices they would pay for crude oil purchased in the United States.

title: ECONOMIC POLICY WITHOUT PITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SALVADOR NAMES 7 TO RIGHTS PANEL
description: Alvaro Magana, the provisional President, today named the director of the national police, a Roman Catholic priest, a young peasant leader, an engineer and three lawyers to form the Government's Commission on Human Rights.

title: Actors Plan 5 Benefits To Build Nursing Home
description: Alexander H. Cohen, the producer, announced yesterday a series of five annual benefits for the Actors Fund of America that will take place at the Palace Theater and will be taped for later broadcast on ABC television. The first benefit is scheduled for April 25.
