title: DANCE: AILEY OPENS WITH VAN MANEN
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater breezed into the City Center on Wednesday with one of the most joyous opening nights in many a season. It was partly a matter of the program, which represented the company at its sunniest and funniest. The high-powered performing had a good deal to do with it, too. And the Ailey troupe has a new hit on its hands.

title: Bank Rule Moved Up
description: The Federal Reserve Board said yesterday that the phase-in period for new reserve requirements under the Monetary Control Act of 1980 would end on Feb.2, 1984, instead of a month later as had been planned. Reserve accounting rules also would take effect on Feb.2.

title: NOT FOR CHILDREN OF AMERICA'S POOR
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE Countess of Avon is in New York from England this week, serving as guest of honor at a series o f dinner parties for the benefit of Ben-Gurion University of the N egev in Israel.

title: PUZZLE OF THE 'STRUCTURAL DEFICIT' PENNED BY REAGAN
description: Nothing can quite excite the curiosity and anxiety of Reagan Administration strategists as word that the President himself has performed a ''yellow-pad job'' and personally taken pen and legal pad in hand to write a speech passage on some major subject.

title: SANJI ABE
description: Sanji Abe, interned in World War II after becoming the first American of Japanese ancestry elected to Hawaii's Territorial Senate, is dead at the age of 87.

title: Mormon Head Shuffles Ruling Church Group
description: Spencer W. Kimball, president of the Mormon Church, today announced a reorganization of the faith's ruling First Presidency in the wake of the death of N. Eldon Tanner, a counselor to four church presidents.

title: PSYCHOLOGICAL OUTLOOK A KEY IN NAMING OF HEART RECIPIENT
description: Barney B. Clark, the man selected to receive the first permanent artificial heart to be implanted in a human, had both the medical and psychological characteristics that doctors considered essential for a successful operation.

title: Cartoon History of U.S.  On View in Brooklyn
description: ''A Cartoon History of United States Policy, 1776-1976,'' an exhibition of more than 50 political cartoons, will be on view through Dec. 21 at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University, DeKalb and Flatbush Avenues.

title: Cuban Defects to U.S.  And Asks for Asylum
description: A Cuban civil servant has defected to the United States and is seeking political asylum, according to the Mayor of Hialeah, Fla., who said he helped arrange the defection.

title: East Orange Man Slain In a Times Sq. Theater
description: A 25-year-old New Jersey man was stabbed to death in a Times Square movie theater at 7 P.M. yesterday.

title: REAGAN, IN BRAZIL, WARNS ON TRADE
description: President Reagan warned an audience of United States and Brazilian business leaders today that the global trend toward trade barriers and protectionism would lead to ''economic contraction and eventually dangerous instability'' in the Western Hemisphere and the developing world.

title: Cosell Bars Boxing
description: Howard Cosell says he will never work another professional boxing match on television. And John Martin, the vice president of programming for ABC Sports, replied yesterday, ''I'll only say it would be his prerogative if he doesn't want to.

title: Benitez Eager to Fight Hearns
description: Those searching for signs thought they had spotted one in the ring where Wilfred Benitez was resting only 30 seconds between rounds of a sparring session and was keeping rather busy during the rounds themselves. A fighter is supposed to taper off during the final days of training, but it looked as if Benitez - his hair matted and beard dripping with sweat - was just getting down to serious work.

title: GREEK MUSIC BEYOND THE BOUZOUKI
description: There will be a concert of Greek music and dance tomorrow night at 8 at Hunter College that, its organizers say, could be matched only by a journey through the mountains, plains and islands of Greece.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Raid and an Apology

title: WARNING ON 'GENDER GAP' FROM THE WHITE HOUSE
description: The latest capital study on the ''gender gap'' says that the unhappiness of single women with the Reagan Administration involves ''astute self-interest.'' It also says that the differing views of the sexes on President Reagan's handling of unemployment will not go away until he makes ''progress toward less unemployment.'' And it says that separated and divorced women find the President and his policies ''personally threatening.''

title: BROKERS AGLOW AT MEETING
description: Good cheer and conviviality mark the annual convention here of the nation's brokers and securities analysts, who are basking in the bright south Florida sun and the glow of prosperity from the richest quarter in their history.

title: 'LA FEMME ENFANT' WITH KLAUS KINSKI
description: KLAUS KINSKI has done a lot of strange things on screen, but he may never before have lain smiling as his face was whipped with colored petticoats or have ministered to a constipated cow. These are some memorable moments from Raphaele Billetdoux's ''La Femme Enfant,'' a film that is otherwise on the dull side. It depicts a half-formed love affair between an 11-year-old French girl and a mute, middleaged peasant gardener. And it follows a predictable pattern, even if its emphasis is distinctly on the strange.

title: Orchids and Plants For Holidays Featured
description: A trip to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden this weekend will yield visitors a wealth of information about orchids and holiday plants.

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1982; The Economy
description: The Ways and Means Committee approved a bill to raise taxes on gasoline by 5 cents a gallon to help finance President Reagan's $32.9 billion highway improvement program. The panel, with both parties behind the new tax, cleared the bill with unusual speed. It could reach the floor on Monday. (Page A1.)

title: GODDARD COLLEGE NO LONGER FACES POSSIBLE LOSS OF ITS ACCREDITATION
description: Goddard College, an avant-garde school once thought to be insolvent, received a major vote of confidence today when a higher-education association removed it from its list of schools threatened with loss of accreditation.

title: Further Issue Of Bell Stock
description: The largest offering of common stock in history was completed yesterday, when an additional 1.2 million shares of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were sold by an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Over two days, 17.7 million new Bell shares were sold at $60 each, raising a total of $1.062 billion.

title: DIPLOMATIC IMMUNITY: ANOTHER FUROR
description: The Ambassador from Brazil, Antonio F. Azeredo da Silveira, left Washington Sunday night to join in his country's diplomatic preparations for President Reagan's visit to Brasilia. The next day his son, Antonio F. Azeredo da Silveira Jr., was arrested for shooting a bouncer three times following an argument at a Washington bar called The Godfather.

title: 1,200 Bodies in Beirut Increase Toll to 6,775
description: About 1,200 more bodies have been found here in recent weeks, some in mass graves dug by Palestinian guerrillas for their dead, raising the tally of deaths during the Israeli siege to 6,775, police officials say.

title: SCREEN: 'INTO THE VOID,' A COMEDY ON SUICIDE
description: ''LEAP INTO THE VOID,'' Marco Bellocchio's very fine Italian film, may be the first genuine comedy about suicide ever made. When I call it a comedy, I don't mean the kind of movie that has laugh lines and breezily irreverent situations, in which the hero, as in Burt Reynolds's ''The End,'' spends most of the movie failing in his attempts to end it all.

title: JACKPOT $11 MILLION IN JERSEY LOTTERY DRAWING
description: With lottery fever gripping New Jersey, state officials today increased the top prize in the Pick-6 contest shortly before the winning numbers were drawn, letting the jackpot climb to more than $11 million.

title: 25 Years of Work Led To the Artificial Heart
description: Scientists worked 25 years to develop the artificial heart implanted in a retired Seattle dentist Thursday. In 1952, a mechanical heart developed by F.D. Dodrill of the General Motors Corporation drew considerable notice when it was used to bypass the heart of a patient for 50 minutes during surgery.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
New P.S.A. Effort By Braniff Pilots
description: Former Braniff Airways pilots met to see if they could come up with further concessions that might enable the bankrupt carrier to again approach Pacific Southwest Airlines and revive a proposal for P.S.A. to operate part of Braniff's fleet and rehire about 1,500 workers.

title: U.S. Drug Agent Is Slain In a Gun Battle in Florida
description: An agent of the special Presidential task force on crime in southern Florida was killed and another was wounded this afternoon in a motel room gun battle after an undercover attempt to buy drugs ''went sour,'' the police said.

title: DEBATE CONTINUES TO RAGE ON CITY'S J-51 TAX POLICY
description: In September, New York City's J-51 tax benefit program, offering tax abatements and exemptions to owners who undertook to renovate their property moderately or substantially, lapsed because the Legislature adjourned without voting to extend it.

title: Turkey's No. 2 Daily Is Shut in Crackdown
description: The daily newspaper with the second largest circulation in Turkey has been banned for an ''unlimited time'' by the Istanbul martial law commander.

title: TRADE AND SECURITY
description: Mounting protectionism and the failing efforts to keep international trade lines open are adding to effects of the world crisis. It is, of course, a reaction to unemployment but it is one that will impede recovery.

title: Old Holiday Cards
description: Holiday greeting cards from the late 19th century are on view through Jan. 25 at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 76th Street.

title: Stocks Mixed; Dow Up by 2.02
description: The stock market finished mixed yesterday and trading volume declined. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, ended with a gain of 2.02 points, to 1,033.11. However, in the overall market, stocks that declined on the New York Stock Exchange outscored advancing issues by 819 to 736.

title: Ira Levin following 'Deathtrap' with his 'Footsteps.'
description: IRA LEVIN'S hair-raising imagination, which produced the longrunning hit ''Deathtrap,'' has come up with yet another thriller for the theater. It is called ''Footsteps,'' and is to open on Broadway in April.

title: Verna Fields, 64, Film Editor Who Won an Oscar for 'Jaws'
description: Verna Fields, a film editor who began as an apprentice to Fritz Lang and won an Oscar for her work on ''Jaws,'' died of cancer Tuesday at Encino Hospital.

title: AT LINCOLN CENTER, BIG APPLE MEANS A ONE-RING CIRCUS
description: THE SMALL TOP comes to town today. The outrageously blue tent of the Big Apple Circus will inhabit Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center until the day after New Year, imparting a clowny bluish tinge to the white travertine walls of its neighbors, the New York State Theater and the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Moffett Said to Get Post
description: Kenneth E. Moffett, the mediator who helped resolve last year's 50-day baseball strike, is expected to be named next week to succeed Marvin Miller as executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, according to some of the individuals involved in the decision.

title: Judge to Allow Vote at Itel
description: The Itel Corporation said that a bankruptcy court judge had given a ''99 percent approval'' to a disclosure statement by Itel that would allow Itel's creditors to vote on the company's proposed reorganization hearings. A final approval that would allow the statement to be mailed must await a hearing - scheduled for next Wednesday - on a disclosure item raised by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The yr-ago shr earnings results were restated for effect of the 5 percent stockdivd distributed Jan 21, 1982

title: HOUSE APPROVES BILL ON DISPOSAL OF NUCLEAR WASTE
description: The House of Representatives today approved, by voice vote, legislation that would establish the first national policy for the storage and disposal of nuclear waste.

title: HMW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $33,000 for the qr and $45,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $5,000 for the qr and $16,000 for the 9 mos; the latest qr and 9 mos operating net includes the estimated loss on the sale of consumer fastener business of $210,000

title: RISE IN GASOLINE TAX
description: With a rare spirit of bipartisan cooperation, the House Ways and Means Committee today formally adopted legislation to raise gasoline taxes by 5 cents a gallon, effective April 1.

title: B.P. Net Up 4.9% in Period
description: The British Petroleum Company, one of the world's biggest oil concerns and a 53 percent owner of the United States-based Standard Oil Company (Ohio), said today that its thirdquarter profit rose 4.9 percent from the similar 1981 period.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs Hawks, at Atlanta. This is the Nets' first game against Dominique Wilkins, the outstanding rookie from Georgia. Otis Birdsong is expected to return for New Jersey after missing two games with flu. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620 AM; 7:30 P.M.) Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md., 8:05 P.M. Knicks are seeking third straight victory of the week. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Boxing Wilfred Benitez, (43-1-1, 26 knockouts) champion, vs. Thomas Hearns, (34-1, 32 knockouts), 15 rounds, for the W.B.C. superwelterweight championship. Both boxers suffered their only career defeats to the same man, Sugar Ray Leonard. Wilfredo Gomez (36-1-1, 36 knockouts), champion, vs. Lupe Pintor, (49-5-1), 15 rounds for W.B.C. superbantamweight title, at Superdome, New Orleans. (Television - In theaters and closed-circuit arenas only. The Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden is sold out. Other sites: Roseland, 239 West 52d Street; the Beacon Theatre, 74th Street and Broadway; the Palladium, 126 East 14th Street; the Kingsbridge Armory, Jerome Avenue and Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx; Brooklyn College, at Bedford Avenue and Avenue H, and Ridgewood Grove, 345 St. Nicholas Avenue in Queens).

title: Dramatis Personae; The Bloc
description: The annual U.N. vote urging an immediate Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan may be an empty exercise, but it has the value of truly defining the Soviet bloc of wholly dominated, dependent or mesmerized nations. The vote in favor this week was 114.

title: Rates Dip on Modest Demand; Fed's Buying Helps Prices
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday as modest demand by investors was supplemented by Federal Reserve purchases on behalf of its customers.

title: MOSCOW WELCOMES REAGAN PROPOSALS ON REDUCING RISKS
description: The Soviet leadership has sent President Reagan a message expressing interest in his recent proposals for measures aimed at reducing dangers of accidental war, Administration officials said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LONGEST WAR. Israel in Lebanon. By Jacobo Timerman. Translated from the Spanish by Miguel Acoca. 167 pages. Knopf. $11.95.

title: 49ers OVERTAKE RAMS, 30-24
description: Joe Montana passed for more than 300 yards for the fourth consecutive game to lead the San Francisco 49ers to a 30-24 victory over the Los Angeles Rams tonight.

title: Scali, McCabe, Sloves Gets an Airline Account
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves in New York, for about five years the agency for Texas International Airlines, has been named agency for both passenger and cargo advertising at Continental Air Lines, Los Angeles, which was combined with Texas International Oct. 31. Both operations are owned by the Texas Air Corporation.

title: Price-Fixing Bill Fails
description: Senate Republican leaders withdrew from floor consideration today a bill to alter the liability of companies that engage in price collusion. Earlier in the day, the Senate had decisively turned down attempts to limit debate on the legislation, indicating that the bill's supporters were unlikely to prevail.

title: PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FLICKINGER, S M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
CONCERT: LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC
description: IF you were the ordinary famous conductor, intent on nurturing your reputation as a god of the podium, you probably would not think it wise to open your annual series at Carnegie Hall with a program consisting of two stern and solemn works of Brahms. Carlo Maria Giulini, however, is not your ordinary symphonic deity, so he had no compunction about having his Los Angeles Philharmonic entertain the audience last night with the ''Tragic'' Overture and ''A German Requiem.'' Actually, it was not much of a gamble, for the Requiem can make a tremendous impression in the right hands and Mr. Giulini is certainly one of the most accomplished and most inspiring leaders of choral music to be found anywhere in music today.

title: Photographic Fair
description: A walk through the lower-level concourse of Grand Central Terminal on Sunday will transport visitors to the early days of photography, with the 29th fair of the Photographic Historical Society of New York.

title: SOME HANDLERS TO END STRIKE AT FISH MARKET
description: A leader of the striking fish handlers at the Fulton Fish Market in lower Manhattan said yesterday that 21 of the smaller companies among the 62 struck had signed interim agreements with Local 359 of the United Seafood Workers.

title: Help for Morris Family
description: With Mercury Morris in jail, facing a minimum sentence of 15 years without parole for drug trafficking, his wife and three children are in dire financial straits. ''You want to talk about money, we have none,'' said Bobbie Morris in Miami this week.

title: Mechanic Freed on Bond After Tylenol Questions
description: Levin Masterson, a 35-year-old mechanic, was questioned for more than two hours today by the authorities investigating the deaths of seven people who took Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules laced with cyanide.

title: Newark Preparing Drive on Scofflaws
description: With more than $14 million worth of unpaid traffic tickets, this city will soon have the authority to suspend immediately the driving licenses of scofflaws, Judge Betty J. Lester, presiding judge of the Municipal Courts, announced today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Coast Brewer Bids For 50% of Pabst
description: Paul Kalmanovitz, a California millionaire and brewery owner, announced yesterday a tender offer of $32 a share for 4.15 million shares, or just over 50 percent, of the outstanding stock of the Pabst Brewing Company.

title: Feldstein Warning On Budget Deficit
description: Large budget deficits facing the Government could delay recovery from the recession, Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said this evening.

title: A Whitney for midtown.
description: IN the best of all possible worlds, perhaps all people interested in art would go to museums and involve themselves in what is there. A decade ago, the Whitney Museum of American Art decided such a world was not about to exist and began building small satellite museums: If interested people would not go to museums, very well, the museums would go to the people. The Whitney is about to complete this decentralization plan with the opening of a third exhibition center, in the 6,650-square-foot ground-floor public-access area of the new Philip Morris building at 120 Park Avenue, just opposite Grand Central Terminal.

title: Memorial for Sarah Churchill
description: A memorial for Sarah Churchill, the 67-year-old British actress who died in London on Sept. 24, will be held at 6:30 P.M. on Tuesday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the ''Little Church Around the Corner'') 1 East 29th Street. Miss Churchill, who lived in the United States for more than 20 years, was a daughter of Sir Winston Churchill. Her sister, Mary, Lady Soames, survives.

title: PACKWOOD LOSES PARTY JOB IN SENATE
description: With the active support of the White House, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana today was chosen to head the National Republican Senatorial Committee in a vote in which he defeated the incumbent, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon.

title: CORRECTION
description: A recipe for Egyptian holiday cookies in Wednesday's Living Section gave an incorrect amount of unsalted butter for the dough. The correct amount is 2 1/4 cups.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
G.E. of Britain Lifts Profit 18%
description: The General Electric Company of Britain, one of the nation's largest corporations, reported today that after-tax profits had jumped 18 percent in the six months ended Sept. 30.

title: Bronze Horses
description: The horse, fashioned in marble by the masters and in oil by Frederic Remington, is enjoying a revival in the arts. And one reason may be the dramatic success of Triple Crown champions in the last decade, starting with Secretariat.

title: ELLMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEAN VETOS BILL ON SILENT PERIOD IN PUBLIC SCHOOL
description: Governor Kean today vetoed a bill requiring a one-minute period of silence at the start of each school day in the state's public school system. The Legislature is expected to attempt to override the veto.

title: THEATER: DIANE VENORA STARS IN PAPP'S 'HAMLET'
description: SO why did Joseph Papp choose a young, virtually unknown actress named Diane Venora to star in his new revival of ''Hamlet''? As it turns out, there is some, if not enough, method to the seeming madness. Miss Venora possesses many of the skills necessary to sustain a major Shakespearean role. Her voice is a clear, versatile instrument, full of light and shadows and totally at home with the verse. Her lithe, athletic body is balletic in its grace, whether Hamlet is darting antically about Polonius or lurching dangerously at Laertes in the final duel. And, yes, Miss Venora also has that intangible quality of magnetism: Even when she's not center stage, you find that your eyes are irresistibly drawn to her.

title: COURT OFFICER HELD IN SHOOTING
description: A court officer assigned to the Civil Term of Manhattan Supreme Court was arrested on charges of shooting his estranged wife and her sister-in-law and attacking an off-duty police sergeant during a dispute in Jackson Heights, Queens, last night, the police said.

title: NORTHWEST ENERGY: A TIGHTROPE DEAL DOUBLES ITS SIZE
description: In its eight-year history, the Northwest Energy Company has repeatedly displayed an appetite for projects and acquisitions larger than itself.

title: Why Break the Immigration Clock?
description: There's a bargain built into the immigration reform bill inching through the House. On the one hand, the bill would make it much harder for illegal workers to enter the country. On the other, it would provide limited amnesty for those already here, living with a fear of discovery that subjects them to exploitation. It's a humane bargain - and also a practical one. The Simpson-Mazzoli reform bill, as delicately balanced as a clock, could never have gotten so far without it.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: NEW YORK CITY has not been kind to its jazz landmarks. The ''home of happy feet,'' the Savoy Ballroom, has disappeared into a housing project at 596 Lenox Avenue, near 140th Street, along with the Cotton Club, which was three blocks north at 644 Lenox Avenue. ''Swing Street,'' West 52d Street, now holds office buildings rather than jazz clubs. Birdland, 1678 Broadway, is now Casa Blanca, a Latin music club, and the Five Spot, at 2 St. Mark's Place, gave way to a used-clothing store.

title: A HOST WHO SHALL HAVE MUSIC WHEREVER HE GOES
description: They sipped, they munched, they chatted, but mostly they listened. For music is the main attraction of the soirees of Joseph Machlis, professor, writer, pianist and music lover. Mr. Machlis has built his life around music - teaching it, writing about it, playing and listening to it.

title: E.P.A.'s Chief Is Cited For Contempt by Panel
description: A House subcommittee voted today to cite Anne M. Gorsuch, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, for contempt of Congress for witholding documents on President Reagan's orders.

title: BANK BUILDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
JAIL NEAR CHINATOWN IS APPROVED BY 7 TO 4 BY BOARD OF ESTIMATE
description: Construction of a 500-cell jail on the outskirts of Manhattan's Chinatown was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate as some residents of the neighborhood filled the board's chamber at City Hall with shouts, jeers and threats of political retribution.

title: MET CELEBRATES HOUSES WRIGHT BUILT
description: IF there is anything that marks the work of a truly great artist, it is its ability to resist looking tired. It may be based on ideas that are no longer fresh, and it may even look a bit quaint, but it never seems wilted or exhausted.

title: FRANCES FARMER PLAYED BY JESSICA LANGE
description: ''FRANCES'' is based on the sad, profoundly troubled life of Frances Farmer, the golden-bright Seattle high-school girl who had some measure of Hollywood fame in the 1930's, in such films as ''Rhythm on the Range'' and ''Come and Get It,'' and one Broadway triumph in the Group Theater's production of Clifford Odets's ''Golden Boy.''

title: NCNB CORP. BID
description: The NCNB Corporation said it had received regulatory approval for its acquisition of Exchange Bancorp of Tampa and Downtown National Bank of Miami.

title: Los Angeles Gets Olympic Trials
description: Los Angeles was chosen without opposition today as the site for the United States Olympic Games trials in track and field in 1984, and Buffalo was named as the site for the men's marathon trials.

title: Black Rail Porters Win $6 Million From Union
description: About $6 million in back wages should be paid to 71 former train porters who were victims of discrimination by their union, a Federal district court has ruled.

title: U.C.L.A WINS IN OVERTIME
description: For all of his team's mistakes, which he recited one by one, Ray Meyer was still smiling at the result. DePaul's 73-70 overtime loss to U.C.L.A. tonight could be traced to the errors of his inexperienced players. But the comeback from a 12-point first-half deficit, and a near miss against the sixth-ranked Bruins, were inspired by those same players.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The seven-day suspension of the jockey Eddie Maple for careless riding at Belmont Park Aug. 1 was upheld yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Alexander Vitale in Mineola, L.I. The justice said the State Racing and Wagering Board had had ''a rational basis'' for imposing the suspension after stewards found Maple guilty . ... Roberto Duran (W.B.C.) and Pipino Cuevas (W.B.A.), welterweight champions at the same time two years ago, will finally meet, in a bout with a 150-pound limit in Los Angeles Jan. 29, the day before the Super Bowl in nearby Pasadena. ... Alan Ashby, the catcher selected by three teams in the free-agent re-entry draft last month, was retained by the Houston Astros, who signed him to a three-year contract worth $1.2 million with an option for a fourth year. ... Steve Kasper, the Boston Bruins' center voted the league's top defensive forward last season, will undergo surgery on his left shoulder next Tuesday and miss three months. ... Don Nehlen, the football coach at the University of West Virginia, says he will remain at the school. Michigan State officials had asked West Virginia for permission to discuss their vacant job with Nehlen. ... Dennis Green of Northwestern has been named Big Ten football coach of the year by The Associated Press.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bridge: Size Isn't the Best Measure Of a Tournament's Success
description: The recent Fall Nationals in Minneapolis were the smallest in 11 years, totaling 7,465 tables. A much smaller tournament was going on there at the same time, and, although its count was a mere 100 tables, it was adjudged a success.

title: A LAND FULL OF MX BASING EXPERTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Man, 77, Is Given 5-Year Term In Fraud that Swindled Priest
description: A 77-year-old Manhattan man was sentenced to five years in prison and fined $73,000 here yesterday for his part in a stock fraud that bilked several investors, including a Roman Catholic priest who was cheated out of $100,000 with promises of helping Indians in New Mexico.

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $51,078,000 for the qr and $42,133,000 for the yr...C-Net income which included income from discontinued operations of $2,177,000 for the qr and $7,487,000 for the yr

title: CANDIDLY SPEAKING
description: Manners of speaking, according to linguistic scholars, tell us something important about a society. Consistent use of honorific titles, polite expressions and profanity, for instance, reflect self-images as well as roles that people perform in their community. Lately, I've been wondering about certain words and phrases that give out disturbing signals.

title: SRI LANKA IS SEEKING THE RECALL OF A U.S. DIPLOMAT
description: Sri Lanka said today that it had asked the United States to recall the first secretary of the American Embassy here for statements that he was said to have made about the Sri Lanka President.

title: President of Cable Unit At Westinghouse Quits
description: M. Christopher Derick, president and chief operating officer of Group W Cable Inc., one of the nation's big cable television operations, has resigned over what the company called ''philosophical differences.'' It has named Burton B. Staniar, a senior vice president, to the post.

title: Defense Rests for Two In Judge's Slaying
description: Defense lawyers rested their cases today for two of the three people on trial in connection with the murder of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. in 1979.

title: BRIEFING
description: New Role for Kennedy

title: NORTH AMERICAN ROYALTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CONCERT: THE CONCORD
description: IN the final moments of the third movement of Beethoven's String Quartet in A minor (Op. 132) at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night, the Concord String Quartet provided a glimpse of what Beethoven had in mind when he inscribed the movement: ''Holy song of thanks to the Godhead from a convalescent.'' With the intimacy called for in the score, the rocking syncopations and sustained half notes suggested a sense of healing, the opening up of new possibilities.

title: STEINBERG INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Oct 23
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: Aiming at Record
description: It has been 19 years since a world indoor best time for the mile was set in the New York area. In fact, the last five indoor-mile records have been set in California, chiefly because San Diego has one of the fastest tracks in the world.

title: SCHEIB, EARL, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORD RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
General Tire Gets Harvester Alumnus
description: Warren J. Hayford, who resigned abruptly in March as president and chief operating officer of the International Harvester Company, has been named to the same posts at the General Tire and Rubber Company in Akron, Ohio.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM IN SQUEEZE
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Company was hardly bothered by the sharp rise in energy prices that shook the nation in the late 1970's. The company used a fortuitous mix of hydroelectric power and pricecontrolled natural gas that sheltered it from the brunt of the oil crisis.

title: Defeated Poland
description: The bitter news from Poland is that General Jaruzelski has beaten Solidarity. The union's underground, which only months ago convulsed the country with massive protest, can no longer do so. The Roman Catholic Church, which in late summer was condemning the military regime, now concedes the success of ''normalization'' by rescheduling the visit of Pope John Paul II. The economic indicators, after a long free-fall caused by mismanagement, strikes and alienation, are turning around.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RCA to Make Stock Offering
description: The RCA Corporation said it would make a public offering of 5 million shares of its common stock. The stock sale, to be managed by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb and Lazard Freres & Company, would raise $115 million at yesterday's closing price of $23 a share.

title: LUNCH CART ON LEXINGTON AVE. REPORTS RUN ON HORSEBURGER
description: Free samples of horseburgers and horsemeat steaks were dispensed yesterday from an unprepossessing yellow and white striped cart on Lexington Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets.

title: 3.9% DROP IN FACTORY ORDERS
description: Orders to factories for manufactured goods fell 3.9 percent in October, the biggest decline in a year, the Commerce Department reported today. The sharp drop, which had been expected, was another sign of the persistence of the 16-monthlong recession.

title: ART: LOUISE BOURGEOIS CLOSES HER OWN DOSSIER
description: UNTIL quite recently, Louise Bourgeois's name was more familiar than her art. That is to say, a reasonably well-informed observer of the scene would certainly know of the artist, but might have more trouble in defining the character of her work than, say, David Smith's. Partly, this is because Miss Bourgeois, though a participant in group shows almost annually since she turned from painting to sculpture in 1949, has seldom had a solo show. But it also has to do with the work itself, which, if invariably distinctive, has always seemed somehow phaseless and unpredictable.

title: News Analysis
description: ''Brazil and the United States: Finally Partners,'' was the headline today in Brasilia's Correio Braziliense, a newspaper traditionally contentious toward American interests.

title: Friday; MARTHA GRAHAM BAZAAR
description: For $250,000, you can have the Noguchi sculpture-spider dress costume worn in Martha Graham's ''Cave of the Heart.'' For $3, you can plant a bulb in the garden outside the Graham town-house studio at 315 East 63d Street. They are the most and the least expensive offerings at a bazaar in the studio today (5 to 9 P.M.) to help support the creation of new works for the company and for scholarships for Graham students. Items include Miro posters from the 1975 Graham season ($10), a dance of your choice performed by the Graham Company ($50,000), a sewing machine, a car, autographed photographs of Miss Graham and jade pendants. You can also get a private coaching sesssion in Graham technique by Jeanne Ruddy ($100). Admission is free. Information: 832-9166. MET IN HOLIDAY GARB

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE ON MX FUNDS
description: Following is the roll-call vote today by which the House Appropriations Committee defeated an attempt by Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, to delete $988 million in MX missile production funds from a military spending bill. Representatives William Lehman, Democrat of Florida; William H. Natcher, Democrat of Kentucky; and John Edward Porter, Republican of Illinois, did not vote.

title: A LAND FULL OF MX BASING EXPERTS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGAL AID EXECUTIVE QUITS, CITING DIFFERENCES WITH REAGAN'S BOARD
description: The battle over the direction of the Legal Services Corporation intensified today as its acting president, Clinton Lyons, announced his resignation.

title: DENTIST, CLOSE TO DEATH, RECEIVES FIRST PERMANENT ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: For the first time in history, surgeons early today implanted a permanent artificial heart to replace a dying human heart.

title: BRITISH SAID TO OUST A RUSSIAN
description: The Government will expel the Soviet naval attache in London for ''inadmissible activities,'' the domestic news agency Press Association reported tonight.

title: MODERNIZED JEKYLL AND HYDE
description: THE makers of ''Jekyll & Hyde - Together Again'' have thoughtfully included a closing shot of Robert Louis Stevenson turning over in his grave, which spares anyone else the trouble of overstating the obvious. Surely Mr. Stevenson is spinning.

title: A GUIDE HELPS IN WATERFOWL HUNTING
description: Now that November's Indian Summer has come and gone, New York State's waterfowlers, particularly those who hunt on Long Island, can become serious about this season's endeavors.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A for Arroz, B for Bagel ...

title: POPE INSISTS PRIESTS QUIT SANDINIST POSTS OR HE WILL NOT VISIT
description: Pope John Paul II has demanded that Roman Catholic priests resign from positions they hold in the Nicaraguan Government as a condition for his visiting Nicaragua early next year, church officials here said.

title: JOHNSON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'IT'S ONLY THUNDER'
description: THERE'S a very good, overlooked Vietnam movie at the Thalia this weekend, Peter Werner's ''Don't Cry, It's Only Thunder,'' which takes an unexpectedly homespun approach to its subject. The setting is a Saigon military hospital, the year is 1967 and the hero is Brian Anderson (Dennis Christopher), a disaffected medic who's very nearly at his wits' end. While capturing an unusually keen sense of day-to-day life in Saigon, the movie also traces Brian's transformation from weary, frightened, cynical soldier to someone whose sense of purpose transcends the wretchedness of his situation.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES TO BLOCK SALE OF OIL LEASES OFF COAST
description: The House Appropriations Committee voted unanimously today to block Interior Secretary James G. Watt from selling oil and gas leases off the central and northern coast of California.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 20
Amarex Petition
description: Amarex Inc. said its creditors had filed a Chapter 7 involuntary bankruptcy petition against it in Oklahoma's bankruptcy court. The company said it had authorized a motion to transfer the case to Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, which would make it a debtor in possession and require it to file a plan of reorganization.

title: CAVANAUGH'S JOB IN PERIL AT ARMY
description: Ed Cavanaugh, Army's 29th head football coach, is in jeopardy of being dismissed within a day or two after the Army-Navy football game in Philadelphia tomorrow. But any decision on Cavanaugh's future will not depend solely upon the outcome of that annual service game, according to Lieut. Gen. Willard W. Scott Jr., superintendent of the United States Military Academy.

title: GUINEA IS SLOWLY BREAKING OUT OF ITS TIGHT COCOON
description: The story of Guinean independence is one of many strands: of repressions and purges, and economic collapse coupled with the rising of national pride and what an official called ''dignity in rags.''

title: TOPPLING MANAGUA'S REGIME
description: The ostensible purpose of President Reagan's trip to Honduras tomorrow is to lend American support to the democratic experiment now underway there. But its real significance lies in the fact that Honduras has become the front line in one of Washington's most ambitious attempts to bring down a foreign government since the Kennedys unleashed the Central Intelligence Agency against Fidel Castro. This time, the target is the Sandinist Government of Nicaragua, and today, as in the 1960's, Washington may find that by creating a secret army of exiles it has set in motion something that very possibly cannot be halted.

title: MX MISSILE FUNDS SURVIVE IN TIE VOTE BY A HOUSE PANEL
description: The Reagan Administration's MX missile program survived a critical test today when the House Appropriations Committee tied, 26 to 26, in a vote on a proposal to kill it.

title: ELECTRONIC MODULES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 2
description: The shr earnings and the shrs outstdng adjusted for the 100 percent stock divd paid in July 1982

title: CUOMO FILLS 3 MORE HIGH POSTS IN ADMINISTRATION
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo yesterday formally announced three appointments to the inner circle of his government in formation. The three are Michael J. Del Giudice as secretary, Michael Finnerty as Budget Director and Fabian Palomino as special counsel to the Governor. All three had been previously disclosed by Mr. Cuomo himself or his aides.

title: C.&N.W. Railroad To Lay Off 1,000
description: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company said that it would lay off about 1,000 workers, or 10 percent of its current work force, because of the weak economy and poor rail traffic, including declining grain and coal shipments. The pre-Christmas layoffs, which have already began, include about 110 employees at the railroad company's Chicago headquarters.

title: Hussein Is in Moscow; Received by Andropov
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, today conferred here with King Hussein of Jordan, who arrived at the head of a seven-member Arab League group.

title: BURL IVES IS ENDING A 20-YEAR NEW YORK ABSENCE
description: To almost anyone who was living in the America of the 1940's and 50's the fact that Burl Ives will be performing a solo folk-song recital Sunday afternoon at Lehman College might not seem very remarkable. Mr. Ives, after all, has long been a familiar image in American popular life, with his avuncular figure, gray-white beard and twinkly blue eyes.

title: 3 MILE ISLAND PLANT SUPERVISOR SAYS HE WAS POORLY TRAINED
description: A shift supervisor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant concluded more than two weeks of testimony in Federal District Court in New York City yesterday still insisting that his training had not prepared him to handle the March 1979 crisis at the plant.

title: IN BRAZIL, 'DEMOCRATIC SOCIAL' IS NOT INVERTIBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: SPECULUM MUSICAE
description: SPECULUM MUSICAE'S first Alice Tully Hall concert of the season Wednesday night was serious to the point of grimness. Still, serious music hardly means bad music, and indeed there were several pieces on Wednesday's program that gave pleasure.

title: F.C.C. Seeks New Tax Rule For Minorities
description: The Federal Communications Commission decided today to seek broader authority to use tax concessions as a means of encouraging minority ownership of television and radio stations.

title: DRAMATIS PERSONAE; In Line
description: A friend of ours hustled to the theater district early Monday morning for tickets to Eva Le Galliene's revival of ''Alice in Wonderland.'' All seats for the first preview performance were $1.50 - the same as for Miss Le Galliene's first production of the fantasy in 1932 - and the line was already very long.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Iran Says It Downed An Iraqi MIG-25

title: BROOKLYN YOUTH SHOT BY ROBBERS AT A HIGH SCHOOL
description: A 16-year-old student who refused to give up his gold chain was shot and seriously wounded yesterday by two other students outside the cafeteria of Eastern District High School in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: BANKERS CHEER MEXICO'S AUSTERITY PLAN
description: Foreign bankers struggling with Mexico's huge debt problem reacted optimistically today to the Cabinet appointments and austerity measures announced by the country's new President, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado.

title: Adding Clark Helps Surprising Saints
description: When Bruce Clark left the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League after two seasons to sign last spring with the New Orleans Saints of the National Football League, he was surprised by the reaction of some of the Saints' fans.

title: German Jobless Rate Up
description: The number of unemployed in West Germany surged in November to 2.04 million, or 8.4 percent of the labor force, the federal Labor Office reported today.

title: HOLIDAY-SEASON BAZAARS UNWRAP THEIR WARES
description: This is the time of year when almost everyone is out hunting for presents. It is no coincidence, therefore, that this weekend begins the season of crafts fairs, festivals and bazaars designed to tempt holiday shoppers with such handmade goods as feather-trimmed shawls, carved wooden toys and homemade jam.

title: RUTGERS AND ST. PETER'S STAY UNBEATEN
description: Rutgers scored 12 consecutive points midway through the second half and went on to defeat Jacksonville, 71-65, in the second game of a doubleheader at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight. In the first game, St. Peter's trounced George Washington, 68-47.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO SUPPORT I.M.F. RISE
description: The United States and four other major industrial nations have tentatively agreed to a 50 percent increase in the basic lending resources of the International Monetary Fund, European monetary officials said today.

title: Index; International
description: Guinea is slowly breaking out of its tight cocoon A2 NATO backs U.S. military operations in areas such as Mideast A3 Gonzalez installed as Prime Minister of Spain A3 Sri Lanka is seeking the recall of a U.S. diplomat A3 Zimbabwe seizes Ian Smith's passport A4 Around the World A5 Pakistan seeking new nuclear reactor from West A6 Chinese legislature to approve new constitution A14 Government/Politics Mayor Byrne adopts new look in re-election bid A16 Senate Republicans oust Bob Packwood from key position A19 Debate over MX may focus on need for the missile itself A20 Kean vetoes bill on period of silence in schools B2 Suffolk offers plan for dealing with nuclear power accidents B2 Cuomo fills three more posts B3 Legislative leaders to meet with members on M.T.A. deficit B3 Washington Talk Briefing A26 Aides ponder the meaning of a new phrase penned by Reagan A26 White House report issues warning on ''gender gap'' A26 Shooting rekindles questions on diplomatic immunity A26 General Around the Nation A16 Horseburgers move briskly on Lexington Avenue B3 Health/Science Psychological health a key attribute for heart patient A24 Industry/Labor U.A.W. offers new deal on Chrysler accord A16 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Big Apple Circus at Lincoln Center C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: Zaire Buys $8 Million Of Arms From Israel
description: Zaire has bought $8 million worth of military equipment from Israel to outfit its presidential guard, President Mobutu Sese Seko said in an interview with the newspaper Maariv published today.

title: A LAND FULL OF MX BASING EXPERTS
description: To the Editor: In ''1984,'' George Orwell described the ''war is peace'' thesis in which the superpowers pretended to their people that they were at war and constructed vast amounts of military equipment which, among other things, they sank in mid-ocean. The constant state of war allowed each to keep its populace under control and to maintain a war economy. I wonder if Orwell would not have found burying the equipment in the desert equally satisfactory. ASA P. RUSKIN Brooklyn, Nov. 26, 1982

title: UNION MAKES NEW OFFER TO CHRYSLER IN BID TO END DEADLOCK ON PACT
description: The United Automobile Workers today told the Chrysler Corporation it would be willing to double the length of a new contract if the company would grant an immediate pay increase rather than one tied to profits.

title: NEW HOME SALES DROP A SLIM 0.4%
description: Sales of new single-family houses declined a slight four-tenths of 1 percent in October, leveling off after soaring 28 percent the previous month, the Government reported today.

title: WAS TOP EXECUTIVE AT FORD
description: John S. Bugas, a retired vice president of the Ford Motor Company and one of Henry Ford 2d's closest friends and aides, died today at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: C. ROBERT FINE
description: C. Robert Fine, an inventor and consultant in sound recording for films and television, died of a heart ailment in Boston on Wednesday.

title: Jersey School Shut
description: The Board of Education has closed the Euclid Elementary School indefinitely after nearly a third of the school's 300 pupils complained of dizziness and dry throats.

title: MICROBIOLOGICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CALUMET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LATE RETIREMENT PUNISHES OLD AND YOUNG
description: To the Editor:

title: PAKISTAN SEEKING 2D ATOM REACTOR
description: Pakistan has begun soliciting bids for the purchase of a new nuclear reactor from the West. The move, made on Wednesday, was described by American officials today as likely to complicate American efforts to block the sale of nuclear technology to Pakistan.

title: Tribune Co. Net Slides
description: The Tribune Company, the privately held communications concern that owns The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York, reported today that its net income in the third quarter of 1982 declined 86.4 percent, to $2.6 million, compared with $19.1 million for the similar period a year earlier.

title: LEGISLATORS TO HOLD MEETINGS IN ALBANY ON M.T.A. DEFICIT
description: The leaders of the New York State Legislature agreed yesterday to take their members back to Albany on Monday for private meetings on plans to reduce or eliminate the need for increases in bus, subway and commuter rail fares.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: The yr-ago shr earnings results were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective Nov 12

title: LIVELY 'WITNESS FOR THE PROSECUTION'
description: PROVING its remarkable durability, ''Witness for the Prosecution'' is back again, this time as a television movie that can be seen tomorrow night at 9 on CBS. This Norman Rosemont Production is being offered as a ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' presentation.

title: Thunderbird Dancers
description: A free performance of American Indian dances will be given by the Thunderbird American Indian Dancers tonight at 8 o'clock in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, Third Avenue and Seventh Street. The ensemble directed by Louis Mofsie will perform dances of the Winnebago, Seneca, Iroquois, Hopi and Sioux. Information: 254-6300.

title: SHELTER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Post for Publisher
description: Elven Grubbs, publisher of The Ledger in Lakeland, Fla., has been named publisher of The Herald-Tribune in Sarasota, Fla. The appointment was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of The New York Times Company, which this week completed its acquisition of The Herald-Tribune from Lindsay Newspapers Inc., a family-owned concern in Sarasota. Lynn O. Matthews will replace Mr. Grubbs as publisher of The Ledger, which was acquired by the Times Company in 1977.

title: House Schedule Announced
description: President Reagan will deliver his State of the Union Message to Congress on Jan. 25, Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the House majority leader, said today, and will submit his budget for the fiscal year 1984 on Jan. 18. Mr. Wright disclosed the dates when he announced the proposed 1983 schedule for the House to members on the floor. He said the new session of Congress would convene on Jan. 3, meet for a week to organize, then take a two-week recess.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has elected Stephen P. Norman secretary.

title: A Voice Against Football
description: Cherry Creek High School will play Saturday for the Colorado Class 4A state football championship. But the school's principal says he would like to do away with prep football altogether.

title: OCEANIC EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: A play review yesterday for the Pan Asian Repertory production of ''Yellow Fever'' gave the name and address of the theater incorrectly. The play is at the 28th Street Playhouse, 120 West 28th Street.

title: Help for the Palace of Minos
description: Culture Minister Melina Mercouri announced today that Greece would spend $550,000 to shore up the crumbling 3,500-year-old Palace of Minos at Cnossos on the island of Crete.

title: PUBLISHING: 'AEROBICS' SCORES AGAIN
description: ABOUT 15 years ago an acquaintance of Herb Katz, editor in chief of M. Evans & Company, told him that an Air Force physician had developed a cardiovascular program to insure that astronauts would be physically fit before going into orbit. The acquaintance said that a friend of his, Kevin Brown, had written a newspaper article about the program, and eventually Mr. Brown introduced Mr. Katz to Dr. Kenneth H. Cooper.

title: S.E.C. Disclosure Plan
description: In the face of stiff protests from big business, the Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today to scale back a proposed rule that would have required public disclosure of transactions between officers of a publicly held company and some members of their families.

title: Lillian Carter Is Hospitalized
description: Lillian Carter, the mother of former President Jimmy Carter, was admitted to Emory University Hospital here tonight, a hospital spokesman said. The spokesman would say only that Mrs. Carter, who is 83 years old, was in ''satisfactory condition.'' It was the third time this year that Mrs. Carter has been admitted to the hospital.

title: Warsaw Police Arrest 5 Solidarity Activists
description: The police have arrested five leaders of a Solidarity underground group in Warsaw that campaigned against the martial law authorities, the official press agency reported today.

title: NEW BID BRINGS NEW LOOK IN CHICAGO
description: The flashy Noriko outfits and other accouterments of flamboyancy have disappeared, giving Mayor Jane M. Byrne a new, understated look that apparently symbolizes the temperate public image she has assumed in her bid for re-election.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Beetle Battle (Conclusion?)

title: National Patent Settles a Suit
description: The National Patent Development Corporation and its NPD Development Corporation subsidiary said that they had settled patent infringement litigation against the American Optical Corporation, a unit of the Warner Lambert Company, the Morris Plains, N.J., chemical and pharmaceutical concern. The patents deal with the manufacture of soft contact lenses but the settlement does not cover soft lenses produced by American Optical under the trademark Softcon.

title: Abducted Girl, 4, Is Found Dead
description: The body of a missing 4-year-old girl, abducted from her Union City home earlier today, was found tonight in an abandoned lot in this Hudson County community, the police said.

title: Doctor Is Arrested In Sale of Drugs
description: A 58-year-old physician has been arrested on a narcotics charge. The suspect, Dr. James E. Wesley, was accused of ''selling thousands of false prescriptions to narcotics traffickers'' for resale to drug addicts.

title: KOCH WARNS SANITATIONMEN OF 'SLOWDOWN' LEGAL ACTION
description: Mayor Koch warned yesterday of possible legal action to stop a slowdown by sanitation workers that the city said had continued for a third day.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE CLIMBS TO 10.8%, A POSTWAR RECORD
description: Nearly 12 million people were out of work in November as the nation's unemployment rate shot up four-tenths of a percentage point to 10.8 percent, setting another postwar record, the Labor Department reported today.

title: FOR BRITISH AT CHRISTMAS: E.T. AND AN ALIEN SANTA
description: Prince Andrew has switched on the Christmas decorations in Regent Street. Harrods is dressed, as ever, in its seasonal costume of shimmering white lights. In a few days, the Norwegian Government's annual gift of thanks to the British people for their support during World War II, a towering fir tree, will be illuminated in Trafalgar Square.

title: WILL BUY BOSTON PAPER
description: Rupert Murdoch announced today that he had reached labor agreements enabling him to buy the ailing Boston Herald American from the Hearst Corporation and keep it on the newsstands.

title: Tests Are Ordered For Boy in Slaying
description: A psychiatric examination was ordered today for a 13-year-old boy accused of shooting his mother to death Wednesday when she insisted he go to school.

title: No Headline
description: Leo (Dutch) Meyer, 84, Dies; Coached at Texas Christian

title: OF GOAT CHEESE KNOWN AND LOVED
description: My first taste of goat cheese made a lasting impression. Though it must have been almost 25 years ago, memories still linger of that overaged, pungent and what I now realize was a moldy cheese. Such is not the best way to be introduced to goat cheese, or chevre, but I had naive faith in the Frenchman who owned the little French market where I often shopped and collected what I thought was irrefutable Gallic wisdom about food.

title: AD INCREASE BUCKS TREND
description: After a year and a half of managerial turbulence, calm has returned to the offices here high above Lake Michigan where, among fica trees and pieces of African art, John H. Johnson runs his publishing empire.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 34. 1. He was the head of a completely reclusive community of Old Believers in deepest Siberia. The remark, his first to an outsider since the 1930's. was to the geologists who first sighted his home from the air in 1978.

title: OIL CITY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including income of $89,248 for the qr ...C-After a loss of $38,313 for the qr and yr from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: WALL ST.'S TURN TO HELP
description: That the city's fiscal bind is urgent seems to be seeping in. One sign of this collective acknowledgment is that Mayor Koch is proposing to revive the recently phased-out stock transfer tax and, more revealing, that this time the financial community is not threatening, in knee-jerk outrage, to move en masse to New Jersey.

title: CITY CONSTRUCTION AT INFLATED COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHANGE IN STATE DRINKING AGE STIRS NEW CONCERN AT COLLEGES
description: At 12:01 this morning, New York State's minimum drinking age was raised from 18 - where it has been since Prohibition was repealed in 1933 - to 19, a change that poses a particular problem for college administrators.

title: AIDES STUDYING OMENS FOR RE-ELECTING REAGAN
description: Fresh after Senator Edward M. Kennedy's withdrawal from the 1984 Presidential race, some of President Reagan's political associates are working to nudge the President into an early decision to run for re-election.

title: FLORIDA BABY SITTER PLEADS GUILTY TO MURDERING THREE IN HER CARE
description: Christine Falling pleaded guilty today to charges of murdering three children in her care and was sentenced to life in prison. She will be eligibile for parole in 25 years.

title: A PATIENT WITH LEADING CREDENTIALS
description: A few months ago Barney B. Clark liked to joke that maybe he would prefer to be the 100th recipient of medicine's first permanent artificial heart, rather than the first. He was still laughing Wednesday night, even as he lay dying, as he said to his wife, ''Well, come to think about it, there's nothing to be nervous about. I'm ready.''

title: UNESCO AGREES ON ITS PLAN FOR FUTURE
description: Delegates from 158 member nations of Unesco wound up a two-week special conference here tonight by adopting a plan for the organization's future activities that included a divisive chapter on information and mass communications and another on collective rights as distinct from human rights.

title: U.S. to Weigh a Freer Bank Account
description: Just after authorizing banks and savings institutions to offer consumers an insured account to compete with the money market funds, Federal banking regulators will meet on Monday to consider an even less restricted version.

title: ADMINISTRATION DRAFTING NEW POLICY ON REGULATING CANCER-CAUSING A GENTS
description: The Reagan Administration is drafting a new, Government-wide policy that would change the way Federal regulatory agencies protect the public from cancer-causing substances.

title: Federated Stores In Joint Venture
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., based in Cincinnati, said it had reached an agreement in principle for a joint venture with J.M.B. Realty Corporation of Chicago to develop shopping center properties. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ARTS GROUP SEEKS NEW STRATEGIES AS THEY VIE FOR SHRINKING FUNDS
description: New York's major cultural institutions have started to apply new strategies to deal with growing financial strains in a worsening economy.

title: Delta Workers Are Buying Jet
description: Almost half of the employees of Delta Air Lines have made pledges to help buy their employer what may be the world's largest Christmas present - a new $30 million Boeing 767 jet.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Nov 13
Court Supports Merrill on Fees
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York yesterday upheld the dismissal of a stockholder suit charging affiliates of Merrill Lynch & Company with levying excessive management fees on its popular Ready Assets money market fund.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My husband said, 'This week let's go for a dream.' '' - Amelia Rowbotham. (1:5.)

title: Maxwell Sackheim, 92, Book Club Co-founder
description: Maxwell Sackheim, a founder of the Book-of-the-Month Club and an advertising executive, died Thursday night at his home in Largo, Fla. He was 92 years old.

title: HERALD SQUARE NEEDS AN UNDERGROUND MALL
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Efficient Collection Of Energy From Sun
description: A stationary device to track the position of the sun throughout the day has been invented for the Dow Corning Corporation, Midland, Mich. The purpose is to increase knowledge of energy obtainable from the sun without requiring excessive power to compensate for cloud obscurity.

title: DR. MAXON H. EDDY
description: Dr. Maxon H. Eddy, former chief of surgery at Bridgeport (Conn.)

title: UNCERTAINTIES FACE ARMY
description: The future of Army's football coach, Ed Cavanaugh, and the future of Philadelphia as the annual site of the Army-Navy game were in doubt on the eve of the 83d meeting between the teams. The game will begin Saturday at 12:30 P.M. at Veterans Memorial Stadium.

title: WEST EUROPE RE-EVALUATES SOVIET POLICY
description: The leaders of the Common Market nations began two days of meetings here today to try to unify their positions on East-West matters and on protectionism before important discussions next week with American officials.

title: Exocet Sale Said to Spur A British-French Brawl
description: Four British sailors from the aircraft carrier Hermes suffered minor injuries in a brawl with French civilians that broke out after an argument over France's arms sales to Argentina, police sources said.

title: JURY HEARS OF THREATS BY CHAGRA
description: Elizabeth Chagra, charged with conspiring to kill Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., told a jury today that her husband, Jamiel (Jimmy) Chagra, had a volatile temper and often made idle threats that he would kill people.

title: 'LITTLE FLOWER' WAS A THORN IN BIGGIES' SIDES
description: When Fiorello H. La Guardia railed against ''them'' on the radio, we knew who they were. If Mayor La Guardia went up against a big guy, he did it directly. ''Well, lo and behold, you did not have long to wait, did you, Western Union?'' And, ''Now, remember, butchers, I think I warned you last week.''

title: Pollack to Leave Post At Fairleigh Dickinson
description: The president of Fairleigh Dickinson University is stepping down at the end of the current academic year after nine years in the post.

title: BRIEFING
description: Outlook at State

title: RULE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest qr and yr earnings include a nonrecurring gain of $433,000 from settlement of litigation and charge of $325,000 from relocation of the company's California operations to Massachusetts

title: SPECIAL TOYS FOR THE DISABLED
description: Anne Mele and Donna Pettick are occupational therapists who left the world of hospitals and clinics to open a toy store. ''We found we couldn't get to the child or the parent,'' Miss Pettick said. ''It was too impersonal. We decided we wanted to reach the community, to do something positive for parent and child.''

title: IN TOKYO, STOCKS ARE STRONG
description: The Tokyo stock market is surging, driven by a stronger yen and the prospect of lower interest rates. The Nikkei-Dow Jones average hit a record high of 8,027.16 this morning, before retreating to close at 7,991.65, down 9.42 for the day. Since the beginning of October, the value of the 225 issues in the index has increased 16.7 percent, with nearly 10 percent of the advance since Oct. 28.

title: Moscow Said to Test New Strategic Missile
description: The Soviet Union has flight-tested a new land-based intercontinental ballistic missile, a United States Government source disclosed tonight.

title: Gonzalez Cabinet Installed in Spain
description: The Cabinet of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez was sworn in today at the Zarzuela Palace in the presence of King Juan Carlos.

title: AUTO CLUBS VIE TO AID MOTORISTS IN TROUBLE
description: The first motorists' club in the United States, the American Automobile Association, was founded in 1902, and for long it had the road pretty much to itself. But since the mid-1960's, a period that has seen the curtailment of service at gasoline stations if not their closing, dozens of national and regional auto clubs have appeared. Today nearly 35 million of the almost 150 million registered drivers belong to the clubs, most of which operate on a system of reimbursement.

title: The Test at Journey's End
description: The closer home he gets from Brazil, the harder becomes President Reagan's Latin voyage. Colombia got a bit sticky yesterday over American policy in Central America, where this weekend he meets four Presidents: two elected (Costa Rica and Honduras), one provisional (El Salvador) and one self-enthroned (Guatemala). It is that last encounter, in Honduras today, that will truly test Mr. Reagan's toasts to democracy all along the trail.

title: SOVIET GETS WESTERN GAS BIDS
description: Three Western companies, from West Germany, France and Canada, have submitted detailed bids for contracts to develop large natural gas fields in southern regions of the Soviet Union, industry officials said today.

title: LIMITED ARRAIGNMENTS ARE LEGAL AND PROTECT DEFENDENTS' RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
SATURDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1982
description: International A cool reception in Colombia was given to President Reagan by its President and the people in the street. In contrast to the smooth exchanges that had marked the President's Latin American tour since he left Washington for Brazil on Tuesday, President Belisario Betancur used luncheon toasts to air differences over Central American insurgencies, aid, trade and narcotics. Mr. Reagan was also jeered by crowds in the streets. (Page 1, Column 1.) Covert activities in Central America begun by the United States a year ago with limited aims have become the most ambitious paramilitary and political action operation prepared by the Central Intelligence Agency in nearly a decade, intelligence officials say. The C.I.A. has devoted a large proportion of its special operations staff to the Central American effort. It has more than 150 agents based in Honduras and dozens more in neighboring countries, according to intelligence sources. (1:2.)

title: SOLIDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $60,000...C-Net income

title: HARTFORD VOTES ON BONDS TO FIX AXLES ON CONRAIL
description: Connecticut approved the sale of $3.5 million in state bonds today as the first step to replace rail car axles that have caused delays on Conrail's New Haven line.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Battling Gentrification

title: REAGAN CRITICIZED BY COLOMBIA CHIEF ON VISIT TO BOGOTA
description: President Reagan encountered sharp public criticism of his Administration's policies today from Colombia's President and jeers from crowds on the street after flying to that country from Brazil for a five-hour visit.

title: CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $108,000 from the reversal of a tax credit...C-Net income including a tax credit of $37,000...D-Including a tax credit of $28,000...E-Including a tax credit of $157,000

title:
PATENTS;
Identification by Laser
description: Army inventors have patented a laser system to identify personnel in the field as friend or enemy.

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a gain of $33,000 for the qr and 6 mos from a return of premium forworkers compensation...C-Net income

title: by Fiorello H La Guardia
description: Too often life in New York is merely a squalid succession of days; whereas in fact it can be a great, living, thrilling adventure. The reason, I think, is plain. The government of the City of New York, with unparalleled opportunities, simply has not seen its opportunities; and when it has seen them, has not been able to make use of them. We need imagination at City Hall -imagination for the other fellow; and hitherto all we have had has been astuteness to find personal advantage. I have been accused of being an idealist in this matter; I propose to go right on with my idealism. Further, I know that now our ideals can be brought to reality.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: TOOTH AND MAN
description: News is made up of a curious variety of events. For example: 1. The rare event: ''Man bites dog'' is often wrongly cited as the definition of news. Actually, it is the tiniest fraction of the tons of news we consume annually; to wit, a rare event.

title: ONE GOALIE'S WORST ENEMY
description: W hen Gilles Gilbert saw the blisters again in September, he knew what that meant. The blisters formed little bubbles, the way skin peels after a sunburn. New blisters formed, and his skin itched more. Gilbert would scratch, and the rash would spread. His skin bled, and clung to his clothes during the day and the bedsheets at night.

title: Chrysler Sets Deadline On Canadian Strike
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, told the United Automobile Workers today that striking Canadian employees of the concern must be back at work by Dec. 13 or the company would recess contract talks in the United States and Canada until January.

title: TO EAT, SMOKE OR BOTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: On New Jersey's Budget; The Popular Way to Raise Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Library Gets $168,500
description: The Performing Arts Research Center of the New York Public Library has been awarded $168,500 by the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Weinberger Holds Talks With the Yugoslavs
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger landed this morning in Dubrovnik instead of Belgrade on his oneday official visit to Yugoslavia.

title: The Safety Net Comes Apart
description: This morning's front pages tell only part of the bad news: 10.8 percent unemployment, 12 million Americans looking for jobs and more than a million others so discouraged they have given up looking. The rest of the story was in yesterday's paper -more than half of those 13 million are not getting benefits from unemployment insurance.

title: House Unit Backs U.S. Aid to School
description: The House Appropriations Committee has approved a spending bill that would give $200,000 in aid to the Highland Falls School District to help cover the costs of educating children of military personnel who live or work at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.

title: RADIO CITY TRANSPORTS HOLIDAY SHOW TO COAST
description: Radio City Music Hall has moved a New York City tradition across the continent: for the first time, it is staging its annual Christmas show outside New York.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co.'s Western Electric Co. will increase the overall level of prices of its manufactured products by 4 percent, starting Jan.1.

title: 3 GUNMEN INVADE 8 HOMES AND BEAT AND ROB VICTIMS
description: In a three-hour spree of robbery, violence and death threats, three gunmen kicked in the doors of eight homes in Queens and Brooklyn, staged three street holdups and escaped in a pair of stolen cars early yesterday after eluding the police in two wild auto chases.

title: Landaluce Burial
description: Landaluce, who died from blood clots last week, will be buried Dec. 12 in the infield at Hollywood Park. The burial will take place before the day's first race. A permanent grave marker has been commissioned.

title: NETS RALLY TO WIN
description: In more than eight relatively obscure seasons of professional basketball, Foots Walker has learned something about resiliency, the ability to bounce back.

title: Aftermath of a Tragedy
description: The fiancee of Duk Koo Kim will receive 60 percent of his earnings, according to a South Korean newspaper. Kim died from brain injuries suffered in his Nov. 13 lightweight title fight with Ray Mancini.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: In New York City, places become institutions faster than you can say, ''Studio 54.'' One week, a nice little restaurant is only a nice little restaurant; then suddenly it becomes the only place to eat pasta with pesto and to see whomever it is anyone would want to see. A club in lower Manhattan is just a hole in the wall with a bar and a sound system, and then it is the club to end all clubs, at least for a few weeks.

title: Article 075378 -- No Title
description: The New York City Opera's 1983 production of Puccini's ''La Rondine'' will be financed through a $175,000 gift from the Gramma Fisher Foundation of Marshalltown, Iowa.

title: Regan Deputy to Join Cuomo Budget Office
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo yesterday reached into the office of the State Comptroller, a Republican, to find a first deputy budget director.

title: DANGEROUS GAMES THAT PEOPLE PLAY
description: L ast Sunday, a linebacker for the Jets smashed a wide receiver for the Packers, running a pass pattern, with a forearm and elbow in the face. On Thanksgiving Day a lineman for the Lions cracked into a punt returner for the Giants who, unguarded as a naked bather, was looking into the air to catch the ball.

title: Braniff Set Back
description: The attempt to get part of Braniff Airways flying again was set back, as its pilots refused to give further concessions to form a joint venture with PSA Inc. Richard L. Goduti, an official in the Airline Pilots Association who heads the New York area council of Braniff pilots, said a straw vote of members showed that they were unwilling to give up their seniority for a joint venture with Pacific Southwest Airlines. When the pilots refused to give on the seniority issue last week, PSA broke off talks on the venture.

title: CAREY NOMINATES 11 FOR CLAIMS COURT
description: Governor Carey yesterday nominated 11 people for newly created seats on the State Court of Claims, but their confirmations were in jeopardy because of a dispute between Mr. Carey and the Senate's majority leader.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MARTY FELDMAN, FILM COMIC, VICTIM OF HEART ATTACK AT 48
description: Marty Feldman, the wild-eyed British comedian who became known to American moviegoers for his antic performances in such films as ''Young Frankenstein,'' ''The Adventure of Sherlock Holmes's Smarter Brother'' and ''Silent Movie,'' died Thursday in his hotel room in Mexico City. He was 48 years old. The cause of death was ''a massive heart attack,'' according to his manager, Michael Maslansky.

title: WINNERS OF GAMBLE ON SMALL COMPUTER
description: Many of the 50,000 people here for Comdex, a major computer trade show, came seeking the riches, occasional celebrity and independence that the rapidly expanding personal computer business has provided for a few.

title: TARIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the loss for the latest 9 mos reflects unusual expenses charged to earnings of $75 million for the cost of restructuring the New York Daily News

title: Bus Service to Stay In Federal Control
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission has refused to consider New York State's contention that the state has authority over a new commuter bus service between northern Westchester County and New York City.

title: 2 BODIES FOUND AT MX SITE
description: Firefighters equipped with the last 2 bodies who were killed in a flash fire Saturday night in an MX missile test shaft.

title: Indictment Is Dismissed In Libya Equipment Sale
description: A judge today dismissed an indictment against a former Canadian businessman, Robert A. Manina, after a Federal prosecutor said the charges were technically flawed. The charges were related to the investigation into the affairs of a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, Edwin P. Wilson.

title: FINGER LAKES' HECTOR AREA: NO SALE,
description: PLEASETo the Editor:

title: STARCH BLOCKERS: BAN DEFIED
description: SIX months after the Food and Drug Administration ordered that the sale of starch blockers c ease, the pills, which have been advertised as aids in weight r eduction by preventing starch intake, are still on the shelves of m any pharmacies and health-food stores in the New York area.

title: Britain Gives a Warning After Expelling Russian
description: Britain expelled a Soviet naval attache today, reportedly for spying, and warned the Russians not to retaliate against British diplomats in Moscow.

title: AUTO SALES ROSE 25.1% LAST MONTH
description: Sales of new cars by the nation's Big Three auto manufacturers jumped 25.1 percent in November, strengthening growing hopes in the industry that its three-year sales slump is coming to an end.

title: REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
After-Death Tax Planning
description: ESTATE planning does not have to end with the death of an individual. His or her executor, as well the beneficiaries, can often undertake a number of steps that might also reduce taxes.

title: Bell & Howell To Sell 2 Units
description: The Bell & Howell Company, an information systems concern with interests in specialized business equipment and learning materials, said it was negotiating to sell its domestic professional equipment and electronic systems products divisions as part of a plan to redeploy its assets.

title: Michigan State Coach
