description: George Perles, the architect of the Pittsburgh Steelers' Steel Curtain defense, was named yesterday as coach of Michigan State with a five-year contract at $95,000 a year. Perles, who was to coach the Philadelphia Stars of the new United States Football League, succeeds Muddy Waters, who was dismissed Nov. 14 after a 2-9 season, his third straight losing season. ... The Big Eight coach of the year in 1981, Don Fambrough, was dismissed as football coach at the University of Kansas.

title: Houston's Epic
description: The University of Houston made the Final Four in college basketball last season, and it wants the public to know about it: In 320 pages, with 122 photographs and with profiles of almost everybody from the chancellor to the school's pet cougar.

title: TAMBELLINI LEADS DEVILS, 5 TO 4
description: With Steve Tambellini scoring three goals and two other former New York Islanders, Yvan Vautour and Hector Marini, getting the other ones, the New Jersey Devils registered a 5-4 victory over the Hartford Whalers tonight.

title: U.S. Criticizes Offer by Banks
description: The Federal Government advised three New York savings institutions yesterday to eliminate one element in the promotional schemes they have been using to attract depositors to their new money market accounts.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART TURNING PATIENT SHARPLY BETTER
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark's new artificial heart has beaten about 200,000 times since it was implanted and his doctors said today that it had dramatically improved his condition.

title: Sleeping Banned in Tent City
description: Protesters may erect tent communities near the White House and the Capitol but may not sleep in them, a Federal district judge said today.

title: Smith's Winning Touch
description: Dean Smith, whose North Carolina basketball team, the 1981-82 collegiate champions, plays Louisiana State today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, has the best winning percentage among the top 20 coaches who have accumulated the most victories at four-year schools.

title: MOYNIHAN SEES HIS ROLE AS SPOKESMAN FOR PARTY
description: As he looks toward the start of his second term in the Senate, Daniel Patrick Moynihan says that he is not a Presidential contender, but that he believes he has a role to play as a national spokesman for the Democratic Party.

title: WEBSTER DOES WELL
description: In August 1978, the Knicks signed Marvin Webster to a five-year contract at $600,000 a year to solve their problems at center. Instead, in the more than four seasons that followed, Webster has been injured and often ineffective.

title: Nora Laing, 91, a Journalist For Foreign Press on Coast
description: Nora Laing, a journalist who during her 50-year career helped to found the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and to create the Golden Globe awards for excellence in motion pictures, died Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Burbank. She was 91 years old.

title: Padres Pursue Garvey
description: The San Diego Padres have convinced Jerry Kapstein, the agent for the free-agent first baseman Steve Garvey, that they are serious about signing the former Los Angeles Dodger star. Garvey has been asking for a five-year contract worth about $1.5 million a year and Kapstein said the Padres' offer was serious. Ballard Smith, the Padres' president, said after meeting with Kapstein and Garvey that ''basically, they are waiting for one more proposal.''

title: Group Details Contributions To Opponents of Medical Bill
description: The 208 House members who voted Wednesday to deny the Federal Trade Commission jusisdiction over statelicensed professionals got an average of $10,875 each from political action committees representing doctors and dentists, more than twice as much as the 195 members who supported the bill, Common Cause reported today.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes $1.3 million from adjustment for cumulative effect of change in accounting

title: 2D BULGARIAN REPORTEDLY SOUGHT IN POPE SHOOTING
description: The Italian police confirmed today that they had issued an arrest warrant for a former Bulgarian Embassy staff member in connection with the shooting of Pope John Paul II, the Italian news agency Ansa reported.

title: WOODLAWN AVE. BOYS VS. THE WARTIME AXIS
description: The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor came as a great surprise to those of us Chicagoans who were members of the Woodlawn Avenue Rough Riders.

title: Kimberly-Clark Sets Georgia Plant
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said today that it planned to build a $100 million nonwoven fabrics plant in LaGrange, Ga. The plant, which will employ about 200 people, will take about two years to build, with construction beginning in April.

title: No Headline
description: Princeton Overtime Winner

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tales of the City

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Question of 'Territory'

title: THE NEW L.I.R.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: West German stock prices soared today to their highest levels of the year after a larger-than-expected cut in interest rates yesterday by the Bundesbank, the nation's central bank.

title: Watercolor by Homer Brings Record $561,000
description: Winslow Homer's 1903 ''Sponge Boats, Key West'' sold yesterday for $561,000, the highest price ever paid at auction for an American watercolor.

title: SLUGGISH JAGUAR BOUNCES BACK
description: Jaguar, the renowned British car maker that appeared to be foundering in recent years, with heavy losses, demoralized management and a growing reputation for sloppy workmanship, is positioning itself once again as a force in the luxury car market.

title: NEW HELMSMAN OF G.O.P. SENATORIAL FORTUNES
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, has come a long way. In just a decade, he has gone from being Richard M. Nixon's favorite mayor to becoming one of President Reagan's favorite senators.

title: AMERICAN HELIOTHERMAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: A LIMON CELEBRATION
description: Three generations of the Jose Limon Dance Company were reunited Thursday at the Joyce Theater in a 35th-anniversary celebration that left many in the audience moist-eyed and meditative, between the cheers.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7 P.M. and 1 A.M., tape Radio -WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) College: L.S.U. vs. North Carolina, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J. North Carolina, defending national champions, lost its first two games before winning in double overtime last Tuesday. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Villanova at Kentucky (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.). U.C.L.A. at Notre Dame (Television - ESPN Cable 8 P.M.) Wendy's Classic final: Georgetown is the favorite in this four-team tournament. (Television - ESPN Cable, 10 P.M.) St. John's at Providence, 8 P.M. (Radio -WGBB, 1240 after Islanders game, approximately 10:45 P.M. Fordham vs. Columbia, at Levien Gymnasium, 119th Street and Broadway, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WFUV, 90.7 FM; 7:15 P.M. WKCR, 89.9 FM; 7:30 P.M.). Brown at Manhattan, Draddy Gymnasium, 242d and Broadway, the Bronx, 3 P.M. Football College: Arkansas vs. Texas at Memorial Stadium, Austin, Tex., (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.); Army vs. Navy, at Veterans Stadium, Philadelphia (Television - Channel 2, 12:30 P.M.).

title: Race-Fixing Case Dismissed by Judge
description: Declaring it the ''thinnest'' case he has ever tried, a Federal judge dismissed tonight the race-fixing charges against the harness driver Ben Webster and two other defendants involving four races at the Meadowlands race track in July and August 1981.

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COLOMBIAN PRESIDENT WINS WITH MAVERICK TOUCH
description: Belisario Betancur, the Colombian President who gave President Reagan an unexpectedly blunt welcome today, has in four months in office brought a markedly new style to the tradition-bound public life of this country.

title: A New-Old Cuomo Team
description: Governor-elect Cuomo's top appointments consist mainly of familiar Albany faces. Since his new secretary, Michael Del Giudice, and his new Budget Director, Michael Finnerty, held similar posts in the present administration, it may seem that Mr. Cuomo intends to stay the Carey course.

title: THE DUAL PURPOSE OF SENIOR DISCOUNTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Promotes Malara
description: Anthony C. Malara was named president of the CBS Television Network yesterday. His promotion fills a position vacant since James H. Rosenfield was named executive vice president of the CBS Broadcast Group in November 1981. Mr. Malara was then appointed vice president and general manager of the television network.

title: POLAND'S LEADER, IN BITTER SPEECH, THREATENS TO RESTRICT TIES TO U.S.
description: Poland's martial-law ruler, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, delivered a bitter and emotional attack on the United States tonight and threatened to restrict relations between the two countries.

title: A GOTHIC EXISTENCE
description: ISAK DINESEN: The Life of a Storyteller, by Judith Thurman. Illustrated. 495 pages. St. Martin's Press. $19.95. Baroness Karen Blixen, better known as Isak Dinesen, was everything a biographer could wish for: an extraordinary writer and an even more extraordinary woman who behaved as if she were a character in one of her own Gothic tales. Her life was a rejection of what she called Danish ''homeliness,'' which is better rendered in English by ''hominess.'' The opposite of hominess, according to Freud, is the uncanny, and it would not be too much to say that this is what Karen Blixen proposed for herself: an uncanny existence.

title: U.N. CHIEF CHALLENGES THE LEGALITY OF ASSEMBLY DRAFT ON PALESTINIANS
description: In an unusual move, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today challenged the legality and feasibility of a General Assembly draft resolution that calls on him to insure the protection of Palestinian refugees in Israeli-occupied territory.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bridge: Pre-emptive Bidding Holds A Big Threat for the User
description: As the experts know very well, pre-emptive bidding is a two-edged sword. It will quite often succeed in its primary aim of making it difficult for the opponents to find their best contract. But almost as often it will provide the enemy with a valuable clue, in the bidding or the play.

title: HEARNS DETHRONES BENITEZ IN A 15-ROUND DECISION
description: For the entire fight, he was content to be the boxer, to circle and jab as if he were poking fun at Wilfred Benitez. Perhaps Thomas Hearns wanted to prove he had the stamina to go 15 rounds. Perhaps he wanted to show he did not have to rely on a knockout to win. Hearns made his point tonight, enough of them, in fact, to win a majority decision and capture the World Boxing Council super-welterweight championship.

title: Buffalo Savings
description: The Buffalo Savings Bank announced that it had reached an agreement in principle with the United National Corporation, a real estate investment and management company, for the acquisition of United. United will merge with a subsidiary of Buffalo Savings. Under terms of the deal, each of the outstanding common shares of United will be exchanged for newly authorized nonvoting cumulative $23 preferred shares of United National, with a total value of about $83 million.

title: Massachusetts Moves To Allow Sunday Sales
description: A bill that would repeal the colonial Puritans' Blue Law against Sunday retail sales passed the Massachusetts Senate today.

title: ROAD BILL BENEFITS VIEWED AS NARROW
description: The road repair and construction bill being considered by Congress would provide hardly any special assistance to those industries and regions with the worst unemployment, economists said today.

title: Stolen Baby Is Recovered
description: The police have recovered an infant who was stolen from a hospital by a woman who offered to hold the child while the mother filled out medical forms. Charlene Barnhart, who officers say suffered a miscarriage two weeks ago, was arrested Thursday as she waited with the baby in her arms at the county jail. An anonymous informer had told detectives that Miss Barnhart regularly visited an inmate there.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Freed Poet Says Cuba Won't Let Relatives Go
description: Armando Valladares, the Cuban poet who has lived in Paris since he was freed two months ago after spending 22 years in a Cuban prison, said today that his mother and his sister had been refused permission to leave Cuba and join him in France.

title: CHICAGO BANKER NAMED HEAD OF ST. LOUIS FED
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, long the symbol of the monetarist school of economics, yesterday named Theodore H. Roberts, a banker rather than a monetarist economist, as its new president.

title: PROSPERITY OF SOUTH SLIPS AWAY AS SLUMP GOES NATIONWIDE
description: The nation's long economic slump is reversing many of the economic gains the South realized over the last two decades from the movement of industry and jobs to the Sun Belt.

title: TV: 'THE FORGOTTEN HELL,' DOCUMENTARY ON BATAAN
description: Why make a documentary now on the American defeat in the Philippines 40 years ago? If that's your question, be assured that ''Bataan, the Forgotten Hell'' is its own justification.

title: MARK C. CANDEE SR.
description: Mark C. Candee Sr., a corporate lawyer and former president of the American Partition Company, died Tuesday of a heart attack at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Mendham, N.J.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Monday incorrectly described the ownership of the Scandinavian Airlines System. The Swedish, Danish and Norwegian Governments own 50 percent of the stock, with the rest publicly held.

title: Giants to Start Carpenter
description: The Giants today activated Rob Carpenter, the former free agent, and Coach Ray Perkins said that the running back would start Sunday against the Houston Oilers at Giants Stadium.

title: REPORT QUESTIONS LILLY ROLE ON DRUG
description: Eli Lilly & Company did not disclose reports of 26 British deaths linked to Oraflex when it sought Government approval to market the antiarthritis drug, according to investigators for the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Dates Are Set For Soviet Tour
description: The National Hockey League and the players association announced today the dates and starting times for a series of games between six N.H.L. teams and the Soviet Union all-stars.

title: THREE CHARGED WITH MURDER OF A FEDERAL AGENT IN FLORIDA
description: Three men were charged today with murdering a Federal agent from New Haven, Conn., and wounding another agent from New York City in a shootout Thursday.

title: A GOOD COURT SYSTEM THAT WILL GET BETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: SEATTLE (AL) - Assigned Dave V alle, catcher, to Salt Lake City of Pacific C oast League. COLLEGES KANSAS - Announced the dismissal of D on Fambrough as head football coach.

title: Joseph Dixon Gets Merger Offer
description: The Joseph Dixon Crucible Company of Jersey City said it had received a merger offer from the Bryn Mawr Corporation of Vero Beach, Fla. It said the offer consisted of $29 in cash, 0.28 share of Bryn Mawr common and one Bryn Mawr $13.75 principal amount 12 percent subordinated sinking fund debenture due Dec.1, 1992, for each Dixon share.

title: SEISCOM DELTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COFFEE YIELD DOWN 15%
description: - World coffee production in 1982-83 is expected to yield 82.5 million bags, down more than 15 percent from last year's record harvest of 97.7 million bags, according to new Agriculture Department estimates released today.

title: 2 DOCTORS WIN $50,000 EACH FOR WORK ON A CANCER DRUG
description: Armand Hammer, chairman and chief executive officer of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, awarded two cancer researchers $50,000 each today for their pioneering work with a drug derived from a cancer victim's own immunological system.

title: Modern-Day Cost For an Old Game
description: Baseball teams are getting defensive about their ticket prices, which are generally going up. Sometimes, they act defensive when the prices don't go up.

title: Borg Triumphs In Belgian Event
description: Bjorn Borg, John McEnroe, Ivan Lendl and Mats Wilander reached the semifinals of the $700,000 European Champions' Championship today.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1982; The Economy
description: The unemployment rate rose four-tenths of a percentage point in November, to 10.8 percent, another postwar high, the Labor Department reported. The increase from October's rate of 10.4 percent was sharper than many economists had expected. In Congress, Democrats called for immediate action on job-creating programs. (Page 1.) According to economists, however, the highway repair and mass transit bill now under consideration would do virtually nothing for the jobless. (46.) The unemployment rate in New York State and in New Jersey rose to 9.9 percent. (46.)

title: JOBLESSNESS IN NEW YORK AND JERSEY AT 5-YEAR HIGH
description: Unemployment in New York State and New Jersey in November reached its highest level in more than five years, although the figure in both states, 9.9 percent, remained significantly below the national rate.

title:
PATENTS;
Inventor of the Year
description: Sven H. Dodington, a scientist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for more than 41 years, was cited this week by the New York Patent Law Association as its Inventor of the Year.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO BAR OIL LEASES
description: The House today approved a $7.4 billion appropriation bill containing a provision that bars Interior Secretary James G. Watt from approving oil and gas leasing off the northern two-thirds of the California coastline.

title: XRG INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

PATENTS;
Improving the Timing Of Satellite Signals
description: The Army got a patent this week for a satellite communications system.

title: JETS, PACED BY WATTERS, DEFEAT ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders, struggling both on offense and defense, lost to the Winnipeg Jets, 4-2, tonight in Winnipeg Arena. Tim Watters, a defenseman, scored two of the Jets' goals, including one in the third period that put the game out of reach of the Islanders.

title:
Patents;
Alarm Net Employs TV Cable
description: BASED home security system that can be operated with the widely used two-way television cables was patented this week for a New York company. Heat, smoke, fire and intrusions can be detected, and medical emergencies can be signaled.

title: FALCON OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Agency Warns Airline to Stop Advertising Caribbean Flights
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board has ordered Sea and Sun Airlines of Manhattan to stop advertising flights to St. Maartens, Netherlands Antilles because it has no authorization to make the flights.

title: 1 Pabst, Heileman Sue Rival Bidder
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company and the Pabst Brewing Company said they had brought suit in Federal District Court in Delaware in an attempt to block a tender offer for Pabst by Paul Kalmanovitz, a West Coast brewery owner.

title: C.I.A. IS MAKING A SPECIAL TARGET OF LATIN REGION
description: United States covert activities in Central America, which began a year ago with limited aims, have become the most ambitious paramilitary and political action operation mounted by the Central Intelligence Agency in nearly a decade, according to intelligence officials.

title: The Tight Legal Market
description: When Joseph Tock, a third-year student at the St. John's University Law School, walked into the Bronx District Attorney's office last week for his second job interview, his heart sank. ''There were 45 people in the waiting room,'' he said.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RAGAN, BRAD, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Stocks Fall Slightly; Dow Declines by 1.75; Late Profit Taking Cited
description: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday despite some renewed optimism that interest rates will soon decline. At the final bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 1.75 points, to 1,031.36. For the week, the blue-chip barometer advanced 24 points mainly because of a 36.43 point rise on Tuesday.

title: RATES DECLINE ON JOBLESS NEWS
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined yesterday as credit market participants grew more confident that a weak economy and rising unemployment would lead the Federal Reserve to encourage lower interest rates in coming weeks.

title: 4 TICKETS SPLIT $11 MILLION JERSEY LOTTERY PRIZE
description: A roofer, a clothing fitter, a supervisor of messengers and the owner of a maintenance company were among the holders announced today of the four winning tickets in the largest lottery prize in the nation, and they came to the State Capitol to collect their shares of $11,141,892.

title: Errico's Bid Rejected
description: A Federal Parole Board turned down the request for early parole by Con Errico, the former jockey who was sentenced to five years for racketeering connected to race-fixing at thoroughbred tracks.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 37.

title: Regal Treatment
description: Lefty Gomez, the blithe spirit of the Yankees half a century ago, has just returned from a sentimental visit to the scene of one of his early triumphs: Japan.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: YOUNG AND OLD

title: Lillian Carter Is Treated
description: Lillian Carter, mother of former President Jimmy Carter, was released today from Emory University Hospital. Mrs. Carter, 83 years old, was admitted to the hospital Thursday, but officials declined to disclose what treatment she received. Mrs. Carter underwent a modified radical mastectomy for cancer in the summer of 1981.

title: THE THEATER: 'ANDREA'S GOT TWO BOYFRIENDS'
description: The three title characters in ''Andrea's Got Two Boyfriends'' (at La Mama) have been abandoned by their families and pigeonholed by society. In the words of the play, they are ''exiles from their own homes.'' These are seriously retarded adults, apparently unable to cope with a life outside of an institution, in this case, a former resort in the Catskills.

title: DANCE: GALA AT THE AILEY WITH PREMIERE TO MATCH
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has always given the best galas in town, and Thursday's benefit for the company at the City Center was no exception. It had a terrific world premiere by Talley Beatty titled ''The Stack-Up'' and a guest headliner, the pop singer Peter Allen.

title: INMATES SEEK MINISTRY BEHIND PRISON'S WALLS
description: James Douglas began serving his sentence on a murder conviction in 1970, and eight years ago he underwent what he calls ''a deep personal conversion.'' He is now studying for the ministry here at the state prison, in a graduate seminary program believed to be the only one of its kind in the nation.

title: MERCANTILE BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
'FAMILY' HOUSING PROPOSED
description: TRENTON LEGISLATION that would enable elderly parents to live independently of their adult children under the same roof, so to speak, has been approved by the State Assembly by a vote of 70 to 1.

title: THEISMANN HAS ONE GOAL TO COMPLETE
description: WASHINGTON THE talent was always there. He has the arm, the mobility, the desire. Especially the desire. ''I've never seen a guy who wanted to be the best more than him,'' Bobby Beathard, the Washington Redskins' general manager, said about Joe Theismann, the Redskins' quarterback. ''I mean, this guy is here all the time, running, working out in the weight room, looking for someone to throw balls to. He'll throw to a little kid if that's all he could find to throw to.

title: FOR THE FUN OF THEM
description: In counting my blessings at Christmas, I like to think of the books I read this past year that encouraged me to feel that the world, for all its vicissitudes, is still a very rich place. Whatever we may think about economics or politics or the moral temper of our time, men and women continue to write good, even wonderful books. While our proud technology often appears to be ineffectual, it's ironical to see our literature, which is so delicate and handmade, doing its job so well.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY AGEEES ON CONVICTION DISMISSAL
description: The United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York has agreed that a Long Island man's indictment and conviction for racketeering should be dismissed because, the official said, the ''grand jury may have been misled'' by the prosecutor on whether a key witness was available to testify before it.

title: VETERENS DESCRIBE BATTLES OF BUDGET
description: The officials responsible for policing New York City, cleaning its streets, educating its schoolchildren play a budgetary game with the Mayor's staff in City Hall.

title: CONNECTICUT REPORTS CONTINUED DROP IN FACTORY JOBS
description: The number of jobs in manufacturing continued to drop in Connecticut while nonmanufacturing employment increased, the State Labor Department said in its report for October.

title: BEDFORD DEBATES DEVELOPMENT PLAN
description: THE specter of a four-lane highway along the edge of their 300-year-old village green, giant office buildings dotting the woodlands and hundreds of new office workers filling the town has roused and angered the residents of Bedford Village.

title: AT 22, A COMPOSER OF NOTE
description: HUNTINGTON RONALD CALTABIANO, a composer whose music has been performed by the Guggenheim Concert Band and commissioned by the Emerson String Quartet, can list just eight pieces in his musical catalogue. ''It's so few that I can still remember them all,'' he said.

title: WITH A LITTLE HELP FROM OTHERS, A FAMILY MANAGES TO GET BY
description: THERE was no Thanksgiving turkey for the H family and the only Christmas cheer may be that the family will be able to keep a roof over its head.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO LAG ON PLEDGE TO FOOD AGENCY
description: The head of a United Nations agency that seeks to increase food production in impoverished countries says his organization may be in jeopardy because Washington is refusing to fulfill a financial pledge.

title: ADVOCATES OF ARMS CONTROL PONDER SOME NEW MOVES
description: Leading proponents of a freeze in Soviet and American nuclear arsenals assembled this weekend in San Francisco to debate the future of their movement. While a mid-life crisis might seem premature, the freeze movement seems to be having one.

title: Team Representatives To Be Polled on Pact
description: The National Football League Players Association will delay until Sunday the polling of team representatives on whether to recommend ratification of the proposed contract with the owners.

title: MAKING ROOM FOR WRIGHT
description: By Faithfully recreating a living room from one of Frank Lloyd Wright's prairie houses, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has installed the first room of true architectural significance in its American Wing.

title: HATS OFF TO DANBURY
description: GREECE, Rome and the Far East have nothing on Connecticut as far as being the innovators of the hat. Perhaps it took the state a little longer, but once Danbury got started, it became one of the leading manufacturers of hats; not only in Connecticut, but in the world.

title:
GARDENING;
SAFE HANDLING OF CHRISTMAS GREENERY
description: DRIED out Christmas greens are unsightly and may create a fire hazard. Discrimination in selection and proper care will go a long way toward preventing these problems.

title: 2 A.M. BAR CLOSINGS WEIGHED FOR COUNTY
description: WHITE PLAINS VILLAGE efforts to control late-night rowdyism closing bars earlier have reached the county level and may force public hearings on the issue.

title: RANCHER IN PLEA TO HIGH COURT OF TORTURED MEXICANS
description: Patrick Hanigan, the Arizona rancher found guilty of charges based on the torture of three Mexicans in August 1976, has appealed his conviction to the United States Supreme Court.

title: REBEL LEADER WAGES WAR ON TWO FRONTS, AT LEAST
description: The Reagan Administration has been seeking to use the long-stymied plan for the independence of Namibia, or South-West Africa, as a lever to dislodge Cuban forces from neighboring Angola. In the package deal Washington seeks, South Africa would remove its forces from Namibia, which it has controlled since World War I, and Cuba would simultaneously withdraw its troops from Angola, where they have operated since 1975. A would-be key player in the game, but one who has yet to be formally included in the many-sided negotiation, is Jonas Savimbi, the insurgent leader of the Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita. His organization has been pitted against the Luanda-based Government of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, known by its Portuguese initials as the M.P.L.A.

title: AN OLD ANARCHIST RETURNS
description: Sometimes they can be trying to live through, but revolutionary periods do make the best reading. Take the second and third decades of this century, which were a time of musical upheaval without parallel in recorded history, a time that still holds tremendous fascination for us today. It was a time when ''bad boys of music'' vied with one another for the honor of giving the bourgeoisie the loudest slap, the hottest hotfoot. Revolutionaries, real and wouldbe, threw their bombs and damp squibs everywhere. Half a century later, as we crouch among the debris and patiently wait for the dust of revolution to settle, we amuse ourselves with guessing games: in another 100 years, who will be perceived as the Robespierre of that era's music? Who the Washington, the Tom Paine, the Lenin, the Trotsky? More specifically, who will the future honor more, Schoenberg or Debussy, Bartok or Stravinsky? What about Henry Cowell, Charles Ives, Leo Ornstein?

title: What's New in Consumer Research; THE EYES HAVE IT
description: Eye-tracking research, which shows marketers what consumers read or don't read when they view a print ad, has labored under a cloud of suspicion since it was first introduced on Madison Avenue some two decades ago.

title: BURIED THORIUM ALARMS COMMUNITY
description: MAYWOOD KARIN MITCHELL keeps her 9-month-old son out of the backyard as much as possible, and her neighbor, Frances Cielo, has been advised by government officials to spend as little time as possible in her bedroom.

title: REAGAN AIDES URGE TAXING EMPLOYEES ON HEALTH BENEFIT
description: Senior Administration officials have urged President Reagan to propose that employees pay a tax on part of the health insurance benefits they receive from their employers.

title: Protests Over Building a Church
description: The recent article ''Neighbors Protest New Church'' draws an inaccurate picture of the situation in Our Lady Queen of Martyrs parish.

title: EUROPEANS PRESS MOSCOW ON 2 ISSUES
description: The leaders of the 10 Common Market countries called on the Soviet Government today for initiatives on Afghanistan and disarmament and said such steps would meet with a positive response in Western Europe.

title: WHALER'S 3 IN 3D BEAT RANGERS
description: The Hartford Whalers got even tonight for their 6-1 loss to the Rangers last Wednesday in Madison Square Garden. Here at the Civic Center Arena, they scored three goals in the third period and won, 5-2.

title: NETS' FLOYD FEELS FRUSTRATION
description: His palms and brow were damp, and Eric Floyd was moving nervously in his seat. The date was June 29. The place was the Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden. And the time was moments before the all-America guard from Georgetown was to be drafted into the National Basketball Association.

title: NEW JACK RABBIT DRIVE LIKELY
description: The clubbing to death of thousands of jack rabbits, vehemently protested by wildlife groups a year ago, may be repeated this winter.

title: DANCE
description: David Gordon describes "Trying Times," a new, full-evening dance to be performed at the Bessie Schonberg Theater Friday through Dec. 20, as looking "simple and not very stylish." "It has visual devices by Power Boothe," Mr. Gordon said.

title: Ex-Attorney General Named Overseer of Teamsters' Fund
description: Former Attorney General William B. Saxbe was named Friday as special counsel to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' biggest pension fund, the Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund.

title: DR. JANE DOYLE TO WED DR. J.A. DAY JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Doyle of New York and Roxbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Jane Marie Doyle, to Dr. John Anthony Day Jr., son of John A. Day of Lafayette Hill, Pa., and the late Marcia O'Brien Day.

title: Headliners; Grounded in Zimbabwe
description: Instead of globetrotting, former Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith will be running in place from now on. Officials of what is now black-ruled Zimbabwe lifted Mr. Smith's passport last week, saying that during a recent trip to the United States he had urged the withdrawal of Western aid to Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's government. Mr. Smith, whose white minority regime canceled the passports of hundreds of blacks in the 1960's and 1970's, said the Government's action would backfire because ''the average person is fair-minded and against unjust persecution.'' Enough for Everybody

title: A SYRACUSE COUPLE WIN FIGHT TO BRING COMATOSE SON HOME
description: After more than eight months of living in a furnished room in San Diego so they could be with their comatose and brain-damaged son, Carl and Mary Hucko are finally taking him home to Syracuse. The New York State Medicaid program has broken a stalemate with California and agreed to pay his future hospital and medical bills.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE WAR OVER PENTAGON SPENDING
description: AS a nation, we are waging a war among ourselves over our ability tow age war. On Nov. 22, the President fired off a salvo with one of h is typically effective television speeches. He spoke of the need to s pend more on defense so we can cajole the Russians into mutual r eductions in defense spending in the future. In opposition, others a rgue that the Russians will not be impressed with increases in U nited States defense spending if they are inefficient and that therei s no way that the huge increases sought by the President can be i mplemented efficiently. Still others - though a notable minority - d o not see the Russians as much of a threat at all.

title: Unifying Help To Pro Athlete
description: To the Sports Editor: I am writing in response to Peter Alfano's article on athletes in business (''After the Games Are Over: Athletes in the Work Force,'' The New York Times, Nov. 28).

title: HAMBURG: BUSTLING PORT AND CIVIL CITY
description: FLETCHER KNEBEL is the author of ''Crossing in Berlin'' and other books; his latest, ''Poker Game,'' a novel about computer espionage, is forthcoming from Doubleday.

title: Union Tops Montclair for Title
description: Keith Peace scored a touchdown in the second quarter that gave Union a 14-7 victory over Montclair yesterday for the championship of North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 before 7,500 fans at Woodman Field in Montclair.

title: STUDY FINDS SUPREME COURTS IN BRONX HEAR CASES HALF A DAY
description: State Supreme Court justices who handle criminal cases in the Bronx spend on average slightly more than half of each court day hearing cases, according to a citizens group.

title: STUFFED HAM WITH A KICK
description: Its not true, as some tasteless cynics say, that it takes at least a 12th-generation southern Marylander to love southern Maryland stuffed ham. Occasionally one hears of a newcomer - a visitor, even - whose sensitive palate quivers with delight at the first piquant bite. Piquant, in the sense of being pleasantly disturbing.

title: A BIG BERLIN SHOW THAT MISSES THE MARK
description: The ''international exhibition of modern art'' in West Berlin called ''Zeitgeist'' is in more ways than one a very funny business, but there is no doubt that its opening was the event of the fall season in Europe. Upward of four thousand people forced their way into the Martin Gropius Building, where the show can be seen through Jan. 16, 1983. They included artists, collectors, curators, dealers and critics both from the United States and from all over Europe. The firemen had fits, the police didn't care for it at all, but nobody fell through the ceiling.

title: CHINESE PARLIAMENT APPROVES A NEW CONSTITUTION
description: China's Parliament ratified a new state Constitution today that restores the post of president and obliges the people to practice birth control.

title: Soviet Sets Dec. 21 Meeting Of Parliament and Party Body
description: The Kremlin announced today that it would hold a meeting of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal parliament, and the Communist Party Central Committee on Dec. 21 to mark the Soviet Union's 60th anniversary.

title: LETTERS
description: What's Wrong With the Military? In ''What's Wrong With Our Defense Establishment?'' (Nov. 7), Gen. David C. Jones begins by criticizing World War II military organization (''fought along service lines ... split authority''), but ends by seeking to help ''the Eisenhowers, the Nimitzes, the MacArthurs of the future.'' He cannot have it both ways.

title: SUBVERSION TRIAL OF 280 OPENS IN EGYPT
description: A group of 280 people defiantly waving copies of the Koran from steel courtroom cages went on trial here today on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: 'THE LAST WORD' OFTEN DOESN'T SAY MUCH
description: The first word about ''The Last Word,'' ABC's new hour-long midnight entry, is, it's a magazine show. But what sort of magazine? Partisan Review? Vogue? Country Life? A hint is provided by the Art Deco frame of the title, which calls to mind some minor magazines that were published between the declining years of Art Deco and the surging years of television. One of the more popular of them was Coronet, a pocket-sized effort to attract readers who found the Reader's Digest too demanding. In basic ways, the late-night television show is the incarnation for our time of the late magazine.

title: LAST MINUTE TAX MOVES FOR 1982
description: PEOPLE who operate their own businesses, have large amounts of d ividend and interest income or hold incentive stock options may be a ble to cut their 1982 tax bill substantially if they act now. B ecause of changes in the tax law that will go into effect in J anuary, there are only a few weeks left to make the most of certain l oopholes that are about to be closed.

title: Illinois Governor Given Budget-Cutting Power
description: An emergency plan giving the Governor extraordinary one-time powers over the state's purse strings was approved Friday night by the General Assembly.

title: THE BEST WAYS TO REPAIR A WIND-WHIPPED STORM DOOR
description: ON very windy days - which have been plentiful in this area in the last month or two - a sudden gust will sometimes catch the outside storm door with such violence as people enter or leave that it rips the door handle out of a person's hand. The door then swings open so fast that it tears out the wood screws that held the door-closer (hydraulic or pneumatic) fastened in place against the door jamb (frame).

title: NEW PROBLEMS SEEN FOR MULTI-TOWN
description: AFTER five years of planning and the spending of nearly $7 million, the Multi-Town Waste Management Authority, which was created to oversee the construction and operation of a resource recovery plant, may be facing some new problems.

title: Fellowship in History Of Art to Be Granted
description: The Art Dealers Association of America has started accepting applications for its second annual $20,000 fellowship in art history.

title: No Headline
description: COLGATE OUSTED BY DELAWARE

title: PENELOPE COPE AFFIANCED TO ROBERT E. O'SULLIVAN JR.
description: Penelope Bass Cope and Robert Emmett O'Sullivan Jr. plan to be married in February in Newark, Del. Libby G. Bass of St. Louis, Mo., has announced the engagement of her daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. O'Sullivan of Newark, Del.

title: What's New in Consumer Research; THE NECKTIE APPEAL
description: You are what you eat, the counterculture motto of the 1960's, may well be replaced this decade with a Madison Avenue tag: You are what you buy. According to Lewis G. Pringle, executive vice president and director of research at Batten, Barton, Durstine, Osborne Inc., people subconsciously buy what he calls ''necktie brands'' to make a statement about themselves and to impress others.

title: Former Cabinet Officers Back Limit on Presidential Terms
description: A group led by former White House advisers has announced it will press for a constitutional amendment limiting Presidents to one six-year term in office.

title:
ANTIQUES;
GEMS OF THE TOY BOAT MAKER'S ART
description: STARTING today, one can see a flotilla of ocean liners, warships, riverboats, submarines and pleasure boats at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences here.

title: CHASE
description: Joan Harriet Gregory, daughter of Mrs. Eleanor Gregory of Springfield, Vt., and Harry K. Gregory of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Edward Thornton Chase, son of Edward Tinsley Chase of New York and Mrs. Lawrence Widdoes of New York. Justice Murray Mogel of the Criminal Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title: No Headline
description: The use of such terms as ''Miss'' or ''Mrs.'' is an archaic device, an atavism from the days when the identity of a woman was defined solely through her husband.

title: Forests Pay Off to States
description: Checks totaling about $133 million have been mailed to eligible states as their share of national forest income for the year that ended Sept. 30, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. An interim payment of $99 million was made to the 40 eligible states and Puerto Rico on Oct. 1, and the final checks were sent out this week, officials said.

title:
GARDENING;
SAFE HANDLING OF CHRISTMAS GREENERY
description: DRIED out Christmas greens are unsightly and may create a fire hazard. Discrimination in selection and proper care will go a long way toward preventing these problems.

title: MERCURY HITS 72, NEW HIGH FOR DECEMBER
description: New York City and much of the East basked in springlike weather yesterday as the temperature rose to 72 degrees in Central Park at 2:15 P.M. - a record not just for the date but also for the month of December as well.

title: CHURCH MAKES NOVEL DEAL WITH DEVELOPER
description: A Brooklyn church has found a way to ease its financial problems through a novel arrangement with a Queens developer that allows it to keep a room in the rear of its building for worship services while the developer converts the main sanctuary into luxury apartments and medical offices.

title: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT SHOOTS UP TO 10.8%
description: The nation's jobless rate soared to a post-Depression record of 10.8 percent in November. Economists expect the employment situation to worsen in December despite an expected Christmas shopping surge. With 440,000 people joining the jobless rolls last month, a total of 12 million Americans were out of work. Democratic leaders cited the increase as evidence that Congress should go further in its effort to create jobs. Earlier in the week, Martin S. Feldstein, the President's chief economic advisor, said the unemployment rate could remain above 6 or 7 percent for as long as five or six year.

title: Dr. Clark's Residence Ransacked, Son Says
description: The home of Dr. Barney B. Clark was ransacked while he was in Salt Lake City undergoing surgery to receive the first permanent artificial heart, his son said today.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: SALES of the Connecticut Turnpike token surpassed the five million mark last week, which means that more than half of the 10 million tokens minted for the program are now in circulation.

title: Jersey Township Mayor's Wife Is Accused in Death of Son, 2
description: The wife of Mayor William Rohrer of Haddon Township has been indicted on charges she killed their 2 1/2-year-old adopted son in May 1975.

title: THE MUSIC WORLD SALUTES THE ARTISTRY OF RUDOLF SERKIN
description: Ordinarily, one might assume that a great artist's 80th birthday would be most appropriately celebrated on the actual day -in the case of Rudolf Serkin, on March 28 of next year. Mr. Serkin, however, is a shy man, and he has stoutly declined invitations from the likes of Seiji Ozawa and Claudio Abbado to mark his 80th birthday with gala concerts in Boston and London.

title: COOKBOOKS
description: People who welcome cookbooks as gifts are so dedicated to cooking that they regard each new collection as a new world of possibilities to discover and conquer. Fortunately, there are plenty of challenges in this year's cookbooks, for tastes ranging from simple American fare to lavish European dishes, humble breads to rich cakes. CHRISTMAS COOKBOOK By John Clancy. 165 pp. Illustrated. New York: Hearst Books. $17.50.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY BOOKS
description: HUNGARIAN MEMORIES By Andre Kertesz. Introduction by Hilton Kramer. Illustrated. 194 pp. Boston: New York Graphic Society/Little, Brown & Co. $55.

title: THE UNCONQUERABLE WELSH
description: ''Nobody,'' writes the author, ''has ever denied the peculiar beauty of Wales.'' Below left: An elderly resident strolls through the village of Beaumaris. Below: Carreg Cennen, a 13th- century castle, overlooks the hamlet of Trapp.

title: BATTERED WIVES FIND SHELTER
description: ARAMBLING old house of no particular architectural period, it is a cozy place where a woman can feel safe and comfortable, but not too comfortable, for in six weeks at the maximum she must leave. This is the site of Long Island's only shelter for battered women and their children, situated somewhere in Nassau County, serving an increasing number of women, the majority of them homemakers who earn no income, who have no place else to turn.

title: Better Judging Is A.K.C. Goal
description: For the first time since it introduced the provisional judging system in 1970, the American Kennel Club is taking a major step to improve judging of dog shows.

title: DANCE: THE DUTCH OFFER NEW VAN MANEN WORKS
description: As often happens for no discernible reason with visiting companies, the Dutch National Ballet's second program was much better than its first as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Ballet International'' series.

title: ART
description: The first thing to be said about making collages is that up to a point almost anyone can do it. The second thing to be said is that almost no one can do it as well or has been doing it as long as William Dole, whose new exhibition opens at the Staempfli Gallery, 47 East 77th Street, on Tuesday and can be seen through Jan. 15.

title: THE SQUARE ROOT OF MERV GRIFFIN
description: In a Chicago hotel room they showed me a television set with no controls. It was the very latest thing. ''You operate it by remote control with this thing right here,'' the bellhop explained, and pointed to what looked like a pocket-size computer on the coffee table.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BANS SCRIPT OF A BROADWAY PLAY
description: South Africa's censors have decreed that it is a criminal offense to import or distribute copies of ''Master Harold ... and the Boys,'' a play by the South African dramatist Athol Fugard that is starting its eighth month on Broadway.

title: ORCHID FANCIERS GATHER AT BOTANIC GARDEN'S SALE
description: Before the sun broke through yesterday morning's clouds, a quiet group of collectors gathered outside the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. When the gates opened they passed through, and a few broke, somewhat indecorously, into a jog.

title: DESPITE EAST-WEST CHILL, TRADE MAY GROW
description: The Soviet natural gas pipeline dispute has faded with the lifting of United States sanctions and indications that Western Europe will eventually agree to tighten up on trade and credits for the Soviet Union. The lessons of the episode, including some paradoxical ones, are still being evaluated.

title: CHILD PORNOGRAPHY LAW MODIFIED AT URGING OF LIBRARIANS IN ILLINOIS
description: The Cook County Board of Commissioners, under pressure from librarians, has revised its child pornography ordinance to allow the distribution of educational and art materials. But county commissioners have refused to accept the librarians' demands for complete exemption from the law.

title: UPSET IN TITLE GAME
description: With Hermann-Joseph Engles and Max Rodriguez scoring the goals, Florida International University upset Southern Connecticut State, 2-1, today and won the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II soccer championship.

title: Q.'SPEAK TO YURI?' REAGAN: 'UM, DA.'
description: Remember the ''missile gap'' crisis of the early 60's and the fears it produced here at home about America being No. 2? Well, Yuri V. Andropov's emergence as general secretary of the Communist Party now confronts us with a crisis of a different sort, unique in Soviet-American relations.

title:
THE DANCE WORLD TURNS ON A COMPANY IN TOTOWA;
TOTOWA
description: TO ALMOST any young woman, Capezio Ballet Makers means pink-leather ballet slippers. To dancers, it also means satin toe shoes.

title: NEW GENERATION HAS ITS OWN PERSPECTIVE
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz comes to Madrid later this month to see Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, he will be taking the measure of the first Socialist to govern Spain since the civil war and the chief representative of the young generation that has abruptly come to power. Proud and nationalistic, they are eager to be part of the West but fearful of being rejected by it. They are determined to bring Spain out of international isolation but are also tugged by neutralist go-it-alone temptations.

title: BULL'S EYE FOR PRESIDENT LINCOLN
description: To the Editor:

title: PHYLLIS SCHEFER IS MARRIED TO CHARLES KAMANOFF
description: Phyllis Schefer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Schefer of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Charles Komanoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Komanoff of Long Beach, L.I. Rabbi Donna Berman of the Port Jewish Center in Port Washington, L.I., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: LATIN REALITY INTRUDES ON REAGAN'S DREAM OF UNITY
description: a simple chance for President Reagan to travel to Latin America to preach his familiar gospel of democracy, vigilance and free enterprise. But well before it was over, Mr. Reagan's 11,000-mile journey became a lesson in what President Belisario Betancur of Colombia called ''the reality of the continent as it really is.''

title: Pomerantz Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for Abraham L. Pomerantz, founder of the law firm of Pomerantz Levy Haudek & Block of New York City, will be held tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. Mr. Pomerantz died Nov. 20 at the age of 79.

title: REAGAN AND 1984
description: On the Monday after unemployment rose above 10 percent, the Dow Jones average broke 1,000. On the day the Commerce Department announced that unemployment had reached 10.8 percent, President Reagan's political advisers let it be known that they had begun to plan his re-election campaign. It's a strange year.

title: END OF LINE FOR TRAP FISHING?
description: TRAP fishing, long a tradition in the waters off Long Island, has grown increasingly rare. While modern fishing technology has caused many of the Island's fishermen to reject time-worn methods, one area fisherman has remained steadfast to the tradition.

title: What's New in Consumer Research; WHEN PIZAZZ PAYS OFF
description: There is growing consternation on Madison Avenue because some advertisers are beginning to think they are spending huge sums of money unnecessarily on commercials.

title: RESIDENTS OF TOLEDO DIVIDED OVER DOWNTOWN RENEWAL EFFORTS
description: The sand came from the Great Lakes and natural gas was so cheap that no one bothered to meter it on its way to the pot furnaces where the glass took form, and where Toledo made its early fortune as the glass capital of the country.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BEHIND THE SCENES AT THE GATT TRADE TALKS IN GENEVA
description: GENEVA W hile his countrymen were enjoying a long Thanksgiving weekend, Bill Brock, representing the United States at a world trade conference here, talked and listened, argued and cajoled. And by Monday morning of that over-extended weekend, he was saying that he had not slept in three nights. He wasn't the only one.

title: M. THAYER
description: Elizabeth Mifflin Thayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Thayer of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Edmund Geoffrey Verney, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Verney of Benninigton, N.H., and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. John Crocker Jr., performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: TRADE TALKS HIGHLIGHT AGENDA AT BASEBALL MEETINGS
description: If all of the players who were rumored as possible trade material at baseball's annual winter meetings were stretched end to end, the human chain might link Hawaii to the mainland.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: volume edition. A MARGIN OF HOPE, by Irving Howe. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The critic's description of his intellectual development. THE NUCLEAR DELUSION, by George F. Kennan.

title: The Pentagon
description: To the Business Editor: The words of David Blond, a Pentagon strategist and advocate of increased Pentagon funding, in ''At War Over the Pentagon'' (Nov.14), deserves especially careful scrutiny. In the context of the fostering by the Japanese Government of technological change, Mr. Blond is quoted as saying that ''... only the Department of Defense's budget is rich enough to experiment with new approaches to complex problems.''

title: A BURLESQUE SHOW STRIPPED OF STYLE
description: FARMINGDALE ABUNCH of patched-together burlesque shows have followed in the shadow of ''Sugar Babies,'' as if all that's needed to satisfy an audience are scantily clad showgirls, stale jokes about getting fresh with them and incessant medleys of old songs.

title: NEW YORK PUPILS GET 'HOUSE SENSE'
description: New York City has began to teach 25,000 pupils in kindergarten through ninth grade how to take a more active role in combating neighborhood deterioration.

title: AS TRAFFIC ANARCHY INCREASES, SO DOES CONCERN OF CITIZENS
description: Manhattan today has more motor vehicle traffic than at any time in its history, and city officials say that more and more of these motorists drive as though signal lights, stop signs and speed limits were simply traffic tips, not traffic law.

title: 1st-Class Flight; For $52.4 Million
description: Flight attendants may still have to endure the boorishness of some passengers, but at least they have won a battle against the indignity of job discrimination. Last week a Federal judge awarded $52.4 million to more than 3,000 women attendants of Northwest Airlines in settlement of a 1970 lawsuit.

title:
MUSIC;
CHAMBER GROUPS GAINING IN POPULARITY
description: IN RECENT years, the growing popularity of chamber-music concerts has led to the formation of highly qualified New Jersey-based ensembles - the New Jersey Chamber Music Society, the Walden Trio and the American and Garden State Chamber Orchestras, to name just a few.

title: As Advertised
description: To the Business Editor: In attempting to relax ''truth in advertising rules,'' James C. Miller 3d, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, wants to put some well-established economic findings into practice, despite opposition from both advertisers and consumerists, as noted in ''A Curious Push to Weaken F.T.C. Advertising Rules'' (Nov.14).

title: IN CHARACTER, KENNEDY EXITS FOR NOW
description: On Wednesday, as the capital lay huddled under a rain that blurred and diminished its shining vistas, Senator Edward M. Kennedy strode into a Capitol Hill hearing room to deliver a message. For the third time in 14 years, he said he would not run for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: WE NEED A FIRST-NAME STANDARD
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN calls Sarah McClendon by her first name, but she calls him ''Mr. President.'' Mrs. McClendon was berated recently by a few people; they felt that her persistent questioning of Mr. Reagan at his news conferences showed improper respect for his office.

title: AS CONVENTIONS RISE, SO DO HOTELS
description: THE largest hotel ever built on the Island has opened its doors, another will open early next year and several others are being planned. All, according to hotel and tourism officials, are responding to a demand for more business convention space.

title: BABIES BORN TO SINGLE WOMEN IN 1980 ESTABLISHED A RECORD
description: Out-of-wedlock births rose by 11.4 percent in 1980 to a new record, according to the Federal Government, which said the main reason was the ''rise in the rate for unmarried white women.'' Part of the increase was a result of a change in the calculation method.

title: A LESS-THAN-OMINOUS SOCIAL SECURITY PROSPECT
description: To the Editor:

title: LOOK TO MIDPRICE FOR THE BEST AUDIO VALUES
description: Our seasonal shopping list of commendable components took stock of the bargain basement last week and now ascends to the midprice range. It is here that the best values are to be found. The reason lies in the price structure of audio equipment. Up to a point, performance goes up right along with the price tag. In short, you get what you pay for. But beyond that point - which lies roughly at $1,500 for the whole system, allowing for discounts - the price goes up a lot faster than any corresponding rise in performance. Consequently, it is midprice sound gear that offers the highest degree of cost effectiveness. It may not touch the limits of technical possibility, but neither is it constrained by the designer having to keep a constant eye on cost.

title: WHEN DIMAGGIO AND CO. TOOK HAWAII BY STORM
description: IT was the week that the Fifth Army entered Rome and the Marines landed in Saipan. It was the week in June 1944 that a small army led by Staff Sgt. Joe DiMaggio alighted from a troop ship at Pearl Harbor.

title: NICARAGUAN, SUING U.S., TELLS OF EXILE ATTACK
description: A Nicaraguan health official who said she was attacked by a group of anti-Sandinists on her country's border with Honduras last year has been brought to the United States to publicize a suit filed by seven Nicaraguans against the Reagan Administration. The suit seeks to challenge American support for such paramilitary groups.

title: Pinero of Spain Leads World Cup Golf by Shot
description: Manuel Pinero of Spain had birdie putts on the final two holes, including a 30-footer on No. 18, and took the lead by a stroke in the third round of the World Cup golf tournament today.

title: SPARKLERS FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: A BOUNTIFUL selection this afternoon begins the Christmas music season. At 4 o'clock, there is ''The Festival of Lessons and Carols,'' a pageant of songs and Bible readings patterned after the centuries-old tradition at Kings College in Cambridge, England, that is now an annual event at Hartford's Immanuel Congregational Church. And among a number of holiday programs on campuses today, the Wesleyan Choir is presenting sacred and secular music in candlelight concerts at 4 and 8 P.M. in the university chapel, while the celebrated Yale Glee Club gives a yuletide recital at 8 in Battell Chapel.

title: COUNTY'S DELEGATES IN ALBANY RESIST PLEAS FOR M.T.A. AID
description: DESPITE discussion of an increase in the New York City subway fare, transportation officials say that the Metro North Railroad is facing a far more serious fiscal problem and, if nothing is done, commuters could soon be paying sharply higher fares to travel to work.

title: A Message From Unesco
description: On paper at least, there will still be room for free-wheeling reporters to audit governments in the ''new world information order'' that was endorsed last week by Unesco. But the United States and other Western democracies were unable to stop the 158-nation organization from asserting its concerns about news - ''messages and what they say'' - in a program to help developing countries lessen their dependence on outsiders' reports.

title: END TO C.B. LISCENSES PROPOSED
description: The Federal Communications Commission has proposed to stop issuing individual licenses to operators of citizens' band radios.

title: A RIGHTIST MEXICO?
description: Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado succeeds Jose Lopez Portillo as President at a time when Mexico's financial crisis threatens to produce a social convulsion that would lead not to some egalitarian utopia but to the demise of the Mexican Government's commitment to a more just society.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel good.'' - Dr. Barney B. Clark. (1:4.)

title: ST JOHN'S RALLIES FOR 61-60 TRIUMPH
description: Jeff Allen, a 6-foot-10-inch junior center, made two free throws with a second remaining tonight as undefeated St. John's rallied to a 61-60 Big East Conference victory over Providence.

title: Everyone Waits For Someone to Move in Trenton
description: Governor Kean's proposed 5 percent gas surtax keeps rolling out to the runway and failing to take off. It passed the New Jersey Assembly but fell one vote short in the Senate earlier this year.

title: Books
description: To the Editor: In the Q & A column (Travel, Nov. 14) the response to an inquiry from a couple in Lincoln, Mass., seeking suggestions for fiction or nonfiction relevant to a trip to the south of France neglected to mention the Travellers Bookstore, located at 75 Rockefeller Center in New York City. This new bookstore specializes in fiction and nonfiction for travelers to even the remotest parts of the world.

title: MISS LAUTERSTEIN BECOMES BRIDE OF J.H. MANDELL
description: Margaret Maud Lauterstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Weil Lauterstein of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Jonathan Hartley Mandell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Augustus Mandell of Ridgefield, Conn. Rabbi Seth Bernstein performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club.

title: DEATHS CAUSED BY WEEK OF MAJOR STORMS REACH 38
description: A storm that battered areas from California to the South and caused at least 38 deaths stalled over Louisiana and Mississippi yesterday, producing eight-inch rainfalls that came at the rate of two inches an hour in some places. Waters pushed over river banks and flooded streets in New Orleans.

title: No Headline
description: West Georgia Wins Title in Division III

title: GAMBLING WITH THE FUTURE OF PHYSICS
description: In 1988, if all goes as planned, part of Long Island will become hotter than the hottest exploding star -10 million billion degrees Fahrenheit, a temperature so high scientists can only compare it to the conditions that existed in the fraction of an instant after the great explosion that created the universe.

title: No Headline
description: Pate Leads on Long Chip Shot

title: DIVORCED FATHERS PROTEST
description: Hundreds of divorced fathers are protesting a new Federal law concerning child support. Since the beginning of the year it has permitted the Internal Revenue Service to withhold tax refunds if the recipients are delinquent in the payment of court-ordered child support.

title: CONFEREES DISCUSS CITY'S FISCAL WOES
description: In the incongruous setting of a baronial estate on a ridge in the Ramapo Mountains, New York City's mounting fiscal problems were the focus of a two-day conference involving bankers, members of civic groups and foundations, city and state officials and labor leaders.

title: PAKISTAN PAYS POLITICAL PRICE FOR STABILITY
description: Nearly five and a half years after Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq seized the leadership of Pakistan in a bloodless coup and established what he said would be an interim Government, his martial-law regime appears to be free of effective opposition and prepared to hold power for some time to come.

title: WATER DISPUTE CROSSES BORDER
description: GREENWICH and Port Chester, contiguous communities in Connecticut and New York, have something more than a boundary line in common. For several years, both towns have been fighting a battle with their common supplier, Connecticut-American Water Company, over water rates and adequate deliveries.

title: Ready for Danger
description: Tennessee's Commissioner of Public Health, Dr. Eugene W. Fowinkle, believes that the best time to react to disaster is before it happens. In November 1981, his department began distributing potassium iodide pills to the 7,000 families living within five miles of the Sequoyah nuclear power plant at Soddy-Daisy.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: USERS and potential buyers of portable kerosene heaters, especially those concerned with safety, are not likely to get unanimous advice from state officals.

title: SHOPPING MALL MEDICINE
description: Milt Freudenheim, an editor on The New York Times Week in Review, is writing a book about the nursing profession.

title: 2 Chilean Unionists Exiled
description: Two labor leaders were exiled today after a demonstration yesterday, according to the Interior Minister, General Enrique Montero. He said Manuel Bustos and Hector Cuevas had violated a law banning street demonstrations and were put on separate flights out of Chile to undisclosed destinations.

title: A FLOW OF FINE DISKS ENHANCES JANACEK'S STATURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: Chemical War In Afghanistan
description: While State Department officials charged for the second time last week that the Soviet Union was using chemical weapons in Afghanistan, the United Nations General Assembly demanded for the fourth time that the Russians get out of that country altogether. Moscow denied the former and dismissed the latter.

title: ANIMAL BOOKS
description: Animals have always played an important part in the celebration of Christmas - from the ox and the ass at the manger (or even the raven that was said to have alerted the shepherds before the arrival of the angel) to Donder and Blitzen and Rudolph; from Noah's arks under the tree to teddy bears and stuffed Snoopys. This year, for book givers who've had it with cats - house, alley and dead - there's a fine mixed bag of animal books. THE AUDUBON SOCIETY ENCYCLOPEDIA OF ANIMAL LIFE Edited by John Farrand Jr. Foreword by Les Line. Illustrated. 607 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $45.

title: THE E.E.C. CAN'T PLOW US UNDER
description: If the United States achieved anything substantial at the conference of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva, it probably falls under the category of reminding the European Economic Community that its ''right'' to swing its agricultural-subsidy fist ends at Uncle Sam's nose.

title: BARON GUY DE ROTHSCHILD STARTING OVER IN AMERICA
description: Urbane and well-preserved at 73, Baron Guy Edouard Alphonse Paul de Rothschild, dean of the French branch of the European banking family, has little in common with most of the other aliens, legal and illegal, who have managed to settle in New York this year. He does, however, share their dream of self-betterment - in his case, by augmenting his shrunken but still considerable fortune (''The fact is,'' he says, ''I cannot provide an accurate figure'') and by attempting, in his words, to ''put the Rothschilds back on the financial map.'' Baron Guy hopes to accomplish this through Rothschild Inc., the expanding New York investment bank that he owns jointly with his English cousins. (For an account of the English Rothschilds, see page 115.)

title: A TALE OF TWO DUCAL CITIES
description: OLIVIER BERNIER's most recent book, ''Lafayette: Hero of Two Worlds,'' will be published by E.P. Dutton next fall.

title: PARTING SHOTS AS BRODSKY LEAVES BOARD
description: TYPICALLY, last week's meeting of the Board of Legislators seemed to revolve around the recommendations, allegations, quips and insults of Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Greenburgh. But it was one of the last such performances, because Mr. Brodsky is going to Albany as a freshman Assemblyman.

title:
WHAT'S HAPPENING AT THE LABOR DEPARTMENT?;
ABANDONING ITS ORIGINAL MANDATE
description: NEARLY 70 years ago, Congress created the Department of Labor. In s eparating the newly created Cabinet-level entity from its former p lace as a minor part of the Commerce and Labor Department, Congress m ade this charge to the new department: ''To foster, promote and d evelop the welfare of the wage earners of the United States, to i mprove their working conditions and to advance their opportunities f or profitable employment.''

title: THE OPPOSITION IN ISRAEL NEEDS NO AMERICAN MACHINATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN CITY ISLAND
description: cut off by Long Island Sound from the world and, p erhaps more importantly, from the rest of the Bronx and its woes - i s a yachting center reeking with New England charm. Since World War I I, the island has been a haven not only for yachts and yachtsmen, b ut for middle-income families fleeing decaying and crime-ridden s ections of the borough. But even today, it has more boats than p eople.

title: HELEN MOYNAHAN IS MARRIED
description: Helen Newman Moynahan and Harvey Lewis Nettleton, both of Milford, Conn., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Howard Spain in Darien, Conn. Superior Court Judge Dennis F. Harrigan of New Haven performed the ceremony.Mrs. Nettleton, a freelance writer and editor, taught creative writing at the Milford Senior Citizen Center and at the Raymond Baldwin Center in Stratford, Conn. Mr. Nettleton recently retired as director of manufacturing at the Hamilton Manufacturing Company in West Haven, Conn. His first wife died.

title: Yugoslav Independence Supported by the U.S.
description: President Reagan, in a letter delivered today by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, reaffirmed the importance that the United States placed on this nonaligned Communist country's independence.

title: No Headline
description: 7 DIE IN NEW PHALANGIST-DRUSE BATTLES IN LEBANON

title: A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: GIVE TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: AGENCIES HURT BY WEAK ECONOMY AND REDUCTIONS IN GOVERNMENT SUPPORT

title: SUSAN ROSS IS ENGAGED
description: Susan Gillespie Ross and Paul Edward Cusack plan to be married in May in Princeton, N.J. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Ross's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Ross of Princeton, to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence X. Cusack of Manhasset, L.I. Miss Ross is a portfolio manager with the First National Bank of Boston, where Mr. Cusack is an independent furniture designer.

title: CALIFANO REJOINING FIRM WHERE HE GOT HIS START
description: In 1958, Joseph A. Califano Jr. began his legal career with the New York law office of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood. By his own admission, he quickly grew ''bored with splitting stock for Tom Dewey's law firm,'' and in 1961 he left for a job under Cyrus R. Vance in the Defense Department.

title: REFORM LEADER CAUTIONS JEWS ON ISRAELI TIES
description: Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, head of the organization of Reform Jewish synagogues, called on American Jews yesterday to exert greater efforts to ''affirm our own identity'' apart from Israel.

title: IRIS PETERSON AND GORDON RYAN SET WEDDING MAY 14
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Peterson of Hollywood, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Iris Dianne Peterson of Montauk Point, L.I., to Gordon George Ryan of East Hampton, L.I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack R. Ryan of Weston, Conn.

title: MISS JACOBS HAS NUPTIALS
description: Valerie Ann Jacobs, daugher of Mr. and Mrs. Jay W. Jacobs of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Anthony Mladen Horvat, son of Dr. and Mrs. Vladimir Horvat of Erial, N.J., and Craigleith, Ontario.The Rev. Richard J. Stearns and the Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich.

title: EVEN PENTAGON PALS FIND ITS BUDGET TOO FAT
description: When the House Appropriations Committee came close to knocking the Administration's MX missile program off its launching pad last week, it may have been a reflection of an important shift in public attitude.

title: NORTH EDISON WINS
description: Mark Mofsowitz, a senior tailback, rushed for 128 yards and scored all four touchdowns for North Edison in a 28-19 victory over Middletown North yesterday in the Central Jersey, Group 4 championship game before a crowd of 11,000 at Red Bank High in Little Silver.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PALM SPRINGS
description: BILL BELL is editor of The Valley News in Apple Valley, Calif.

title: PAMELA ANN DAVIS TO WED
description: The engagement of Pamela Ann Davis to Gary Stephen Schpero, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan K. Schpero of Fairfield, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John N. Davis of Atlanta. An April wedding is planned. Miss Davis is a vice president in the corporate finance department of E.F. Hutton & Company Inc. Her fiance is an associate with the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN POLITICS AT A GLANCE
description: Guatemala This most populous Central American republic has been shaken by political violence from left and right since the left-of-center Government of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman was toppled in a United States-backed coup in 1954.

title: GROUP THINK IN JAPAN INC.
description: Arthur S. Golden lived in Japan from 1980 to 1982 and was managing editor of the Japanese-owned English-language magazine PHP.The question of what makes the Japanese tick has come to concern many Americans, as they see some of this country's key industries reeling under competition from the island people we knew as such a tough opponent in war. How do the Japa-nese manage to do so well in the economic campaign on which they have refocused their energies? My way of getting at an answer was to study Japan and the Japanese language through college and graduate school, and then to spend time living in Japan and working in a Japanese company. The greatest surprise to me was not what I found in Japan but what I found when I returned to the United States.

title: Carpenter Return Lifts Giants
description: Rob Carpenter will be the chief focus of attention Sunday when the Giants meet the Houston Oilers at Giants Stadium.

title: THE INDEPENDENTS
description: They are the designers who work quietly in their showrooms, apartments or lofts. Their creations are rarely paraded down fancy runways. Yet, increasingly, women and stores are turning to them for clothes of understated elegance.

title: Gretzky Ties Scoring Mark
description: Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers set up Jari Kurri for a power-play goal early in the first period tonight against the Calgary Flames to tie the National Hockey League consecutive-games scoring record.

title: PHONING OF JURORS REMAINS A MYSTERY
description: The official explanation from the judge was that ''an outsider'' or ''a crank'' had telephoned five jurors in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president.

title: A BACK-TO-BASICS PLAN FOR SCHOOL CRIME
description: Less than 48 hours after Mayor Koch and Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola announced new measures to curb crime in the public schools, a 16-year-old student at Eastern District High School in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn was critically wounded when he resisted a robbery attempt by two schoolmates.

title: TUFTS PRESIDENT ASKS ARMS TALK WITH RUSSIAN
description: The president of Tufts University has written an educator in the Soviet Union urging that their universities join in a search for ways to halt the nuclear arms race.

title: NOTABLE BOOKS OF THE YEAR
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of December 1981. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The New York Times Book Review. Autobiography & Biography

title: THE BEST BOOKS OF 1982
description: Fourteen years ago, at about this time of year, the editors of the Book Review, who were used to thinking of themselves as the helpmeets of criticism, moved front for one week and picked what they considered the best books of the year. Picking the best became a habit, and in this Christmas issue we offer our 15th annual choice.

title: OUTDATED HUNTING LAWS
description: EMIL MAFFUCCI was killed on Sept. 6, Labor Day, by a bullet fired from a .22 caliber rifle by a hunter who apparently thought he was aiming at a groundhog.

title: BROKER WEDS ELLEN MOYLAN
description: Ellen Mary Moylan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice F. Moylan of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to John Milton McMillin 3d, son of Dorothy F. McMillin of Somers, N.Y., and Mr. McMillin Jr. of Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. John L. Ferrand, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony, assisted by the Canon John W. Davis, an Episcopal priest, at the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y.

title: VINTAGE TOY BOATS MAKE A FINE FLEET FOR THE COLLECTOR
description: This Christmas a major collector is sharing some of the toy boats acquired over the last eight years, with those who visit ''Toy Boats From the Forbes Magazine Collection'' at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences, Morristown, N.J. The exhibition opens today and remains on view through April 2.

title: Thai Police Report Capturing 185 Pounds of Heroin in Raid
description: The Thai police said today that they had seized 185 pounds of heroin after a gun battle with seven traffickers on a beach southeast of Bangkok.

title: Youths Deny Killing Father
description: A teen-age brother and sister pleaded not guilty Friday to charges that they waited in ambush and killed their father, who had reportedly mistreated them. Richard Jahnke, 16 years old, and his sister, Deborah, 17, entered their pleas in Laramie County District Court.

title: JUSTICE GIVES DETAILS ON INNER WORKINGS OF THE HIGH COURT
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court, in an unusual television interview today, said he resented being called a ''butcher'' and ''murderer'' for his role in the Court's 1973 decision legalizing abortion.

title: EXPLORING HUMANITY IN MASKS
description: RIDGEFIELD THERE is Titania, majestic and magical. And Menelaus, bearded and benevolent. Delilah, however, wears the cold, vacuous expression of the betrayer.
