They, and dozens of other figures from history and myth are among the many faces of Suzanne Benton, metal sculptor, mask maker and storyteller. Using a welding torch, Mrs. Benton endows cold steel, bronze and copper with life and spirit in the studio of her Ridgefield home. ''I make masks,'' the sculptor explained, ''to explore our humanity.''

title:
OPINION;
A 'STRANGER' FROM QUEENS
description: COFFEE and a seeded roll taste better in Queens, and by 6:20 I'm on the expressway heading east. By the time I'm at Exit 50, Dix Hills is a latent blur, fog-smeared and sun-licked. Eastbound the L.I.E. is clotted. Driving against traffic, I empathize with the neurasthenia to my left.

title: ALBANY'S ROLE IN STIMULATING NEW HOUSING CONSTRUCTION
description: IF HISTORY is any guide, the incoming Cuomo administration and State Legislature will have to face the i ssue of what government can do to stimulate housing production. Neither state nor city government can any longer borrow money at l ow enough interest rates to make possible new middle-income projectsu nder the Mitchell-Lama program. And though the Battery Park City A uthority has an ongoing housing-development program in the city and m ore construction is expected at Roosevelt Island, the number of new u nits they will produce is meager in relation to over-all need. As f or the Federal Government, it has withdrawn as a financier of new c onstruction for low-income people.

title: U.S. Aide, Under Inquiry, Leaves New Delhi
description: An American official under investigation of smuggling contraband into India left here today for Washington at the direction of Ambassador Harry G. Barnes Jr., the United States Embassy said.

title: Article 076790 -- No Title
description: Lawsuits totaling more than $200 million have been filed against Harrison County officials in connection with a jail fire in Biloxi that killed 29 inmates, the authoritiies say.

title: No Reason For Bafflement
description: An article on meteorites (''The Meteorites of Wethersfield Leave Scientists Baffled,'' Nov. 14) is the kind of stuff on which superstition is founded. It suggests that the circumstance of two meteorites falling through roofs of Wethersfield residences in a period of 11 years is impossible to explain as the result of natural causes, and cites opinions of two ''baffled'' scientists in support of that view.

title: A Shaky Bow To Free Trade
description: Trade ministers of 88 countries last week sweated out an agreement that seemed to offer scant relief after five days of pain. But with protectionist pressures rising and more than 30 million unemployed in the West, even a shaky rededication to free-trade ideals seemed worth having.

title: NAVY TRIUMPHS OVER ARMY, 24-7
description: Navy struck early to score after each of two big Army mistakes in the first four minutes today and then wore down the Cadets in the second half for a 24-7 victory in the 83d edition of the armed services classic.

title:
GARDENING;
SAFE HANDLING OF CHRISTMAS GREENERY
description: DRIED out Christmas greens are unsightly and may create a fire hazard. Discrimination in selection and proper care will go a long way toward preventing these problems.

title: REPORT ANALYZES DEATH RATE AT STATE'S MENTAL INSTITUTIONS
description: Mentally disabled people in state developmental centers had a death rate in the last decade that was roughly double that of New York's general population, according to a state report.

title: BACK TO WORK AFTER RETIRING
description: VAL SIMONS is 69 years old. For many years he worked for the railroad, but when he turned 65 he was, as he puts it, ''forced'' to retire. He initially enjoyed his freedom, but after three years decided it was time to go back to work. His problem was how to get a job at his age.

title: NEON LIGHT AS ART: A LYRICAL DISPLAY
description: ROSLYN ANYONE who has yet to be introduced to neon light as art would do well to absorb the visual content provided by the Stephen Antonakos exhibition that now fills the first-floor galleries at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art. There could scarcely be a better initial experience, not only because these new pieces represent the artist's most lyrical achievement to date, but also because they present a virtuosic demonstration of the range of possibilities within this medium.

title: Unequal Parks
description: Many of Chicago's black and Hispanic residents have long complained that there was nothing accidental about the shabbiness of their neighborhood parks. Last week, the Justice Department said that it agreed.

title: BALLET: 'THE NUTCRACKER' IS BACK
description: Ardent dance fans who measure the passage of time in terms of the ballet season rather than the calendar can now confidently proclaim that the winter holidays are upon us. The New York City Ballet opened its monthlong run of ''The Nutcracker'' Thursday night in the New York State Theater. And the arrival of ''The Nutcracker'' always means that it's holiday time.

title:
Publicker's Suitor: David Cohen;
THE LAWYER WHO BUYS SICK COMPANIES
description: PHILADELPHIA DAVID COHEN, standing behind a table that serves as his desk, extends his hand to a visitor without interrupting a telephone conversation. ''Well, call me when you get into the Fairmont in Dallas,'' he says into the telephone. ''Take it off,'' he motions to the visitor, who is still wearing an overcoat. Then he pours a can of Diet Pepsi into a plastic coffee cup, depresses the next hold button and picks up the next call, all without sitting down.

title: HOW TO SHAPE A CAREER FROM NATURAL INCLINATIONS
description: There are performers who see a goal and mold their minds and bodies to fit its dimensions. Others, like the American tenor John Aler, take a more graceful path - following inborn tastes and tendencies toward their natural habitat.

title: KEROSENE HEATERS STIR DEBATE
description: AS energy costs have risen, so has the popularity of supplementary heaters that warm one or two rooms, allowing central heating systems to be turned down. But despite the savings, many homeowners have expressed concerns about the heaters' safety and the fumes they give off.

title: SUSAN WEINSTEIN AND DR. KENNETH DOBULER TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Weinstein of Sands Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Martha Weinstein, to Dr. Kenneth Jay Dobuler of Branford, Conn., son of Mrs. Morton Young of Lake Mahopac, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: CHAGRA JURY ISSUE: WHOM TO BELIEVE
description: Charles V. Harrelson, the convicted hired killer charged with assassinating Federal Judge John H. Wood Jr., stepped down from the witness stand this week after five and a half days of testifying, leaving the jury with a single fundamental question: Whom to believe.

title: No Headline
description: TEXAS ROUTS ARKANSAS BY 33-7

title: Another View Of Horsemanship For shame!
description: The rider pictured on Page 1 of the Long Island Weekly section (Nov. 14, illustrating the article ''Reining: A Bit of Old West'') is committing a cardinal sin of dressage riding. He permitted the horse to run on the wrong lead, thus causing the forelegs to cross, and is flirting with serious injury to horse and himself.

title: DESIGN COMPETITION FOR EXCESS SCHOOL
description: WILTON OVER the last several years, disposing of excess school buildings has been a problem faced by most Connecticut towns and cities. Wilton, a community of 15,000 in central Fairfield County, has dealt with the problem three times in the last three years, most recently last summer, when Center School was turned over to the Board of Selectmen by the Board of Education.

title: STUDY FINDS COLLEGE PAYS OFF FIRST FOR WOMEN OF '72 CLASS
description: Does college pay? A follow-up Government survey of graduates from high school classes of 1972 found that the answer was ''yes'' for young women, but ''not yet'' for young men.

title: NEW PATH TO DOWNTOWN RENEWAL
description: IN a new twist to urban renewal, New York State has started one of t he country's most wide-ranging, yet inexpensive, programs to r evitalize downtown business districts by redeveloping the decaying r emnants of 19th century industry.

title: MISS WHITTLESEY, A WRITER,
description: MARRIES NICHOLAS C. OSBORN

title: ALISON MORRELL IS WED TO WILLIAM THOMPSON
description: Alison Morrell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James F. Morrell of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to William Barnes Thompson of Fort Washington, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Thompson 2d of Meadowbrook, Pa. The Rev. Anthony DallaVilla performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Cathedral in New York, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Philip E. Hughes of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Huntingdon, Pa.

title: PANEL TO VOTE AGAIN ON RULES TO LIMIT ASSERTIONS ON FOODS
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has taken strong exception to a recommendation that the commission drop a proposed regulation restricting assertions made for low-calorie, low-fat, lowcholesterol and ''natural'' foods.

title: TUG OF WAR DEVELOPS OVER ACCESS TO DATA ON TOXIN
description: A tug of war has developed over access to results of tests of soil contaminated by the deadly chemical dioxin in Missouri. Lieut. Gov. Kenneth Rothman said Thursday that Rita Lavelle, assistant administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, had refused his request for data obtained in October from extensive sampling in neighborhoods near Imperial, 20 miles south of St. Louis.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: FILMING A LIFE

title: TITLE TO NEW CANAAN
description: New Canaan, which had not won in 29 straight games going into the 1981 season, completed a rags-to-riches story yesterday with a 20-12 victory over Naugatuck in the L-2 Connecticut championship game at Hamden High field.

title: Social Security
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Social Security's Overblown Problems (Nov.14), Barbara R. Bergmann says that Social Security is a welfare program. But she still wants to keep it, even though at least half of our old people are wealthy enough to live comfortably without it, and the other half could go on welfare and get exactly the same money they're getting now - the only difference would be the name of the check.

title: FAMILY OF PATIENT CITIES HIS PROGRESS
description: Moments before he was wheeled into an operating room for pioneer artificial heart surgery, Dr. Barney B. Clark told his wife: ''Honey, In case I don't see you again, I want you to know you have been a darned good wife.''

title: WHERE THE TWAIN MEET-DELICIOUSLY
description: In a city where more than one-seventh of the population is Chinese, the food to be found in San Francisco's vast array of Chinese restaurants had better be good. It is. And because San Francisco is the gateway to the United States for most Chinese and thus often the place where regional cooking trends begin, a recurring demand for the new must be met. It is.

title: Federal Agents in Miami Seize Nearly 700 Pounds of Cocaine
description: Agents of United States Customs and a Federal task force made one of Miami's biggest narcotics seizures today, confiscating nearly 700 pounds of cocaine.

title: GRANT TO AID JUVENILE JUSTICE
description: A PROGRAM designed to reduce the incidence of drug-and alcoholrelated crime will be extended on an experimental basis next year to Westchester's Family Court system after having been used effectively in the county's Criminal Courts.

title: A LONG HISTORY IN GREEK COOKING
description: VILMA LIACOURAS CHANTILES of Scarsdale, whose interest in Greek food goes back to her childhood and family meals prepared by her immigrant parents, has recently completed her second cookbook. Her first, ''The Food of Greece, has been described as a classic by The Hellenic Times, an English-language tabloid published in Manhattan. The second book, to be published next fall by Everest House, is on the New York ethnic food market and gives the addresses of about 250 stores and recipes for 200 ethnic foods.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
HE LET HIS SUBJECTS BE THEMSELVES, NOT SYMBOLS
description: The subject matter of John Albok's photographs is by now only too familiar from the work of other photographers. It is the Great Depression as it was experienced by the poor of New York City. Yet his photographs have an old-fashioned charm - an effect of sweetness, almost - that is quite unlike anything to be found in the work of better-known photographers.

title: More Legal Insults for the Poor
description: What would you think of a law that gave you the right to sue the Government for depriving you of your rights - provided only that no public funds be used to redress the grievance if you win? No one even dreams of such a law for suits by those who can afford a lawyer, but President Reagan's appointed guardians of the national poverty law program want just such a rule for the poor.

title: ARMS MADE IN STATE NOT SET FOR CUTS
description: WASHINGTON DESPITE recent calls in Congress for cutting the military budget, many of the defense systems produced in Connecticut are not major targets for reductions. So far, the cuts that have been suggested involve weapons made elsewhere.

title: TWO ARE APPOINTED TO THE RENT BOARD
description: THE Rent Guidelines Board got a replacement last week for a member who has been serving unofficially since his term expired almost four years ago, and also saw the re-appointment of a member whose term expired at the end of last year.

title: FROM 'WHAT'S MY LINE' TO 'CHILD'S PLAY,' THE GAME'S THE THING FOR HIM
description: Mark Goodson was standing in his office fiddling with the Betamax. He had just inserted a tape of his latest game show, a series rather mysteriously entitled ''Child's Play,'' which is broadcast every morning at 10:30 on CBS.

title: ROCK: RUSH, OF CANADA
description: ''In the high school halls/ In the shopping malls/ Conform or be cast out,'' goes the song ''Subdivisions,'' from the latest album by the Canadian rock trio Rush. Sentiments like these, which mark the quintessence of solemn teen-age angst in contemporary rock, are one reason that Rush is so phenomenally popular with adolescents.

title: WHY BOXING NEEDS TO BE REFROMED, NOT ABOLISHED
description: BOXING is, and has been for many years, a sport badly in need of reform. It is by its nature a brutal endeavor, often corrupt, sometimes squalid, on rare occasions fatal. But that is not sufficient cause to ask that it be abolished, at least not until the case is made by those who participate in the sport rather than by those who write about it.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title:
CRAFTS;
RANGE OF GIFTS AT RYE CENTER
description: ALTHOUGH ambitious Christmas shoppers have probably been haunting the department stores for several weeks, the Rye Art Center's gallery is filled with interesting, well-priced articles designed for holiday gift giving.

title: MIDWIFE IS UPHELD IN DISCIPLINARY CASE
description: NEWARK AN ADMINISTRATIVE law judge has recommended the dismissal of all charges against a prominent New Jersey certified nurse-midwife in a disciplinary proceeding that still could lead to the loss of her license.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 10 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 6 4 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 3 5 8 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction, sequel to ''The Foundation Trilogy.'' 4 4 14 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 5 7 4 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Continuing the journey through the solar system begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 6 2 14 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 7 3 15 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 8 10 4 DEADEYE DICK, by Kurt Vonnegut.

title: 'BRAIN BANK' HELPS BUSINESS SOLVE ILLS
description: WHEN the Union Carbide Corporation found itself overwhelmed with a supply of synthetic paper as a result of technical experiments, it hired the Innotech Corporation to find a use for the unused paper. Working together, Innotech and Union Carbide developed the idea of using the durable paper for children's books, mechanic's manuals and map manufacturing.

title: Library Gets $168,500
description: The Performing Arts Research Center of the New York Public Library has been awarded $168,500 by the National Endowment for the Arts.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE FUN WENT OUT OF THE JOKSTER'S LIFE
description: MY FATHER was born in a little village outside of Kiev, Russia, in 1898, and was brought to the United States, the youngest of eight surviving children, when he was only 3 years old.

title: What's New in Consumer Research; OF BELONGERS, ACHIEVERS, SURVIVORS ET AL.
description: Advertising executives will spend close to $15 billion on television commercials this year, even though they don't always understand the consumers they are trying to reach.

title: Court Examines Evidence Rule
description: The Supreme Court last week created an opportunity to consider changing the so-called exclusionary rule, the doctrine that bars illegally seized evidence from criminal trials and makes President Reagan, among others, hopping mad.

title: SMALL MIDTOWN STORES CHALLENGE 'TOURIST TRAP' LAW
description: A group of New York City merchants has challenged a new law that requires the licensing of mid-Manhattan stores that sell audio, video and photographic equipment, electronic calculators and Oriental- or Persian-style rugs.

title: COAST YOUTH WHO BOASTED OF KILLING GIRL IS SENTENCED
description: On Friday, just three days before his 18th birthday, Anthony Jacques Broussard was sentenced here to 25 years to life in prison for the strangling of a 14-year-old girl in a case that became a stigma on the town of Milpitas, a few miles east of here.

title: PANEL TO VOTE AGAIN ON RULES TO LIMIT ASSERTIONS ON FOOD
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has taken strong exception to a recommendation that the commission drop a proposed regulation restricting assertions made for low-calorie, low-fat, lowcholesterol and ''natural'' foods. The regulation was tentatively adopted in 1980 but never formally issued, and on Tuesday the commission will again vote on its merits.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Gas Problem

title: Data Update
description: *4*MORTGAGE DELINQUENCY RATES *4*(Percentages of mortgages held by savings and loan associations) 1982 1981 1980 October 1.22 0.94 0.84 September 1.21 0.99 0.83 August 1.15 0.99 0.84 *4*Source: U.S. League of Savings Associations *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) NEW YORK Week of Nov. 29 Week of Nov. 22 Week of May 31 Conventional 13.99 14.04 16.76 Rollovers 14.26 14.34 16.71 Adjustable Rate 13.51 13.57 16.36 *4*Source: HSH Associates NEW JERSEY Conventional 13.67 13.78 16.53 Rollovers 13.77 13.87 16.47 Adjustable Rate 13.17 13.24 16.31 *4*Source: HSH Associates CONNECTICUT Conventional 14.02 14.02 17.29 Rollovers 13.06 13.08 17.00 Adjustable Rate 12.81 12.88 16.57 *4*Source: The Millard Group Inc. CO-OPS (N.Y.C) Conventional 15.33 15.33 18.03 Rollovers 15.16 15.17 17.09 Adjustable Rate 14.00 14.00 17.40 *4*Source: HSH Associates

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe Gains Final by Beating Borg

title: Reclaiming The Meadows
description: It may not live up to its nickname, but it's not as if the Garden State isn't trying. On a patch of Hackensack Meadowlands once covered by garbage dumps and befouled streams, New Jersey opened a $3.1 million environmental study center last week and will spend millions more making the environment worth studying.

title: ON AREA STAGES, 'TIS THE SEASON TO BE DICKENSIAN
description: COME December, no show proliferates as predictably as ''A Christmas Carol.'' In 1936, John Barrymore was heard on the radio as the quintessential curmudgeon, Ebenezer Scrooge. In 1979, Henry Winkler played the part on television. While the 140-year-old Charles Dickens novel is clearly meant for all media, it isn't a classic for all seasons. Three years ago, a black musical version, called ''Comin' Uptown,'' opened on Broadway in December, tried to run through January - and failed.

title: Proposing a Vote To Fill Vacancies
description: We were interested in reading Paul Feiner's article ''Charter Revision Urged on Replacing Elected Officials'' (Opinion Page, Nov. 14), which discussed the need for opening up the replacement process to the people.

title: When Our Judges Run for Office
description: I have been puzzled for many years at the selection process for judges in our area. Recently, we, the voters, were presented with a long list of candidates for judicial office, which resembled a ''scratch sheet'' at the races. In fact, most bettors at race tracks are better informed as to the horses running than the average voter is as to the potential candidates running for judicial office. Not only has the average voter little knowledge of the candidates but in two successive selections in this area, the electorate has chosen candidates who were deemed ''not qualified'' by the Westchester County Bar Association.

title: HOLIDAY HARBINGER
description: Drawing once again on the popularity of its mock-colonial Christmas concerts, the Chamber Orchestra of New England has sent out the word that ''sources close to Buckingham Palace (circa 1792) indicate that a breakthrough in the Paris negotiations could come at any time.''

title: A SYNDROME SUITED TO DISPARAGE THE OLD
description: To the Editor:

title: PAKISTANI'S U.S. TRIP SAID TO MARK BIG GAIN IN TIES
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the pending visit of the Pakistani President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, represented a significant advance in American links to the Asian subcontinent after nearly a decade of strained relations with Pakistan as well as India.

title: BUSINESS SHOULD BE SCHOOL'S PARTNER
description: WHAT are schools for? There are many answers given to that question, and they often indicate a paradox that exists in our educational system.

title: No Headline
description: RED WINGS' SLUMP ENDS AS DEVILS FALL

title: Colon Wins 2-Mile Race
description: Tony Colon, former Manhatan College star, won the two-mile run Friday night at the Manufacturers Hanover/ Metropolitan Athletics Congress Olympic Development meet at the 168th Street Armory. His time was 9 minutes 10.6 seconds. Frank Rogin of Earlham College won the mile in 4:38.2.

title: LAND SWAP SOUGHT TO SAVE A SWAMP
description: DIVIDING CREEK NEGOTIATIONS to save the remains of a privately held primeval swamp forest may lead to a land swap with the owners in what has been described as ''one of the most agonizing environmental issues in New Jersey.''

title: Two Postal Clerks Told To Pay Burglary Loss
description: Two postal clerks have been told to pay the Postal Service more than $7,000 to make up for what was lost in a burglary of the Bullhead City Post Office.

title: White House Disavows Session on Re-Election
description: President Reagan told the political consultant Lyn Nofziger there would be ''no official White House involvement'' in Mr. Nofziger's effort to organize a 1984 Reagan re-election campaign, a White House spokesman said today.

title: U.N. INQUIRY FINDS SUGGESTIVE EVIDENCE OF SOVIET TOXIC WAR
description: A United Nations inquiry has given heavily qualified support to accusations that the Soviet Union and its allies have been waging chemical warfare against insurgents in Afghanistan and Southeast Asia.

title: Executive Director Appointed By the News Election Service
description: News Election Service, the national vote-collecting organization of major American news agencies, has appointed Robert W. Flaherty of Rockville Centre, L.I., as its executive director.

title: COURSE HELPING ADULTS READ
description: SIX years ago, Corea Murphy longed to grip the attention of her drug rehabilitation adult reading students at Fairfield Hills Hospital in Newtown.

title: STUDENT OF THEOLOGY IS FAULTED ON CULTS
description: Dear Editor: When a student of theology (James Kullander, Opinion Page, Nov. 21) fails to see the danger of cults, fails to recognize their mind-altering techniques, fails to investigate the behavior modification they undeniably practice and fails to place cults in proper perspective, we are in trouble.

title: JOAN A. BELSERENE IS WED IN SUBURBS
description: Joan Anne Belserene, daughter of Nancy Belserene of Eastchester, N.Y., and the late Mr. Belserene, was married yesterday to Carl J. Forcheskie, son of Carl S. Forcheskie of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Geraldine Forcheskie. The Rev. Howard Major performed the ceremony at the Eastchester Presbyterian Church.

title: JAZZ GUITAR: PETER GROSETT, FROM KANSAS
description: Peter Grosett, a young jazz guitarist from Kansas, is making an itinerant debut in New York, moving from one night showcase to another, leading a quartet built around a pair of guitars.

title: TUNNEL PROPOSAL REVIVED
description: discarded proposal to supplant the Cape May-Lewes (Del.) Ferry with a bridge-tunnel as a tourist incentive.

title: KOCH PUSHING PLANS TO AID YOUTH CENTER AFTER DEFEAT ON JAIL
description: After giving up a proposal to place a juvenile detention center on top of the jail to be built on the edge of Chinatown, Mayor Koch said that plans would be pressed to improve the old Spofford Youth Center in the Bronx.

title: No Headline
description: Kentucky Defeats Villanova by 93-79

title: CALLOWAY ENSEMBLE
description: Christmas Day will mark the 75th birthday of Cab Calloway, one of America's most original and enduring musicians. He and his family will attend the opening from 6 to 8 P.M. today of an exhibition in his honor titled ''Of Minnie the Moocher and Me'' at the White Plains Public Library.

title: MISS, MRS. OR MS.?
description: William Safire feels that ''Ms.'' has little or no etymological antecedent, other than as a contraction of either Miss or Mrs. (both, confusingly, abbreviations of ''mistress''). But surely Ms. is as valid and neutral an abbreviation of mistress as ''Mr.'' is of ''mister.'' The parallel is exact. SOPHIA DOUGLASS PFEIFFER Chief Staff Attorney State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations Supreme Court Providence

title: NEW IS NOT ALWAYS BETTER
description: Not long ago at a party, an acquaintance came up and expressed amazement that I had enjoyed Ballet Rambert's recent engagement at Brooklyn College. ''But how could you have liked it?'' he demanded to know. ''It was all so 1951!'' Now, to be pedantic about the matter, 1951 was the year in which George Balanchine choreographed ''La Valse,'' Jerome Robbins choreographed ''The Cage,'' Frederick Ashton choreographed ''Daphnis and Chloe'' and Merce Cunningham choreographed ''16 Dances for Soloist and Company of Three,'' the first work in which he utilized chance methods of composition. However, what one says blithely at a party one may wish to rephrase more soberly on the morning after, and I suspect that my acquaintance was not referring to the Rambert's creativity. Rather, he was probably trying to say that he found the British company old hat.

title: Questions Are Raised On Bus Terminal Safety
description: On Sunday, Nov. 28, at about 10:30 P.M., I witnessed an incident in the midtown Port Authority Bus Terminal that raises questions as to whether bus services and facilities are going the way of the New York subways in violence and poor service. These questions demand answers from Port Authority, bus and state officials, and action to avert this sad possibility.

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY 80-79
description: Dan Roundfield had a poor shooting night from the field but made all six of his free throws, including two with 13 seconds remaining that provided the Atlanta Hawks with an 80-79 victory over the Knicks at the Garden last night.

title: WINDS OF CHANGE RUFFLE MUSEUM
description: SOUTHAMPTON IS the Parrish Art Museum undergoing radical changes in direction? Or is the museum merely experiencing the stress that comes with reorganization under a new director charged with transforming the venerable institution, founded in 1897 as the repository of a single patron's collection, into a major regional museum?

title: USE OF POLYGRAPH GROWING ON L.I.
description: TO counter what they see as an alarming rise in employee theft, a large number of businesses on Long Island have turned to using polygraph tests, commonly known as ''lie detectors.''

title: Stimulate
description: The economy is suffering the worst recession since 1937. Washington has practiced overkill in the war against inflation. Yet policymakers are paralyzed by memories of recent inflation peaks and the fear of future ones. They are unwilling to ease credit or increase consumer spending power. America is hurting, yet the only policy the Reagan Administration can find is more pain. That policy is wrong; worse, it is unnecessary.

title: MONEY ALONE CAN'T HELP THE BEAUMONT
description: Even in this economy, I am surprised to learn that the Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation, a philanthropic enterprise known to be generous with its money, has recently decided to snatch back a $4-million grant it had promised to Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater. The funds had been earmarked for the ''interior renovation'' of the building in order to give its stage and auditorium a more ''traditional'' look, which really meant transforming its semiexperimental shape into a standard proscenium-arch playhouse. But the donation was contingent upon Lincoln Center's hustling up an equal sum for the purpose. The Lincoln Center people hadn't managed to scrape together their share of the costs, and the deal was off.

title: MADRID DEVALUES THE PESETA BY 8%
description: Spain's new Socialist Government, holding its first official meeting, devalued the peseta by 8 percent today to shore up the ailing economy and stem the flight out of the country of up to $3 million a day.

title:
LEISURE;
A NEW LOOK AT THE OLD PARLOR PALMS
MARY RIDDER IS BETROTHED TO EDUCATOR
description: The engagement of Mary Jane Ridder to Michael Thomas McDermott has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Victor L. Ridder of Pelham Manor, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. McDermott of Stratford, Conn.

title: Sports of The Times; Carpenter and Campbell II
description: ONCE they were teammates, Rob Carpenter displaced by Earl Campbell at running back on the Houston Oilers' depth chart. But today they will be opponents at Giants Stadium in a new chapter Rob Carpenter struggling now to salvage a playoff berth for the Giants after a long contract impasse, Earl Campbell struggling now for yardage in the Oilers' new offensive system after having averaged a remarkable 1,614 rushing yards in his first four seasons.

title: REAGAN DENOUNCES THREATS TO PEACE IN LATIN AMERICA
description: President Reagan concluded his Latin American trip with a speech in Costa Rica Saturday in which he called for an end to ''foreign support for terrorists and subversive elements'' in Central America. He also met in Honduras with the leaders of that country and Guatemala, to whom he pledged support.

title: WHY BROWNSTONE FACES ARE PEELING
description: Sandstone, better known locally as brownstone, was a popular building material in New York from about 1840 until early in this century. Old newspaper accounts show that as early as the 1880's New Yorkers recognized that the brownstone facades of their town houses were not weathering well, according to Frank Matero, an assistant professor of architecture at Columbia University.

title: A Future at the Energy Office
description: From the start, Administration plans to click off the Department of Energy's lights for good generated little support on Capitol Hill. Last week, Donald P. Hodel, nominated to be the five-year-old agency's fourth secretary, conceded that the proposal itself had flickered out.

title: EXPLORING OHIO, LONDON THEATER, SAVANNAH; Mother's Day On Wheels
description: If you're a bicyclist and want to join a tour that is practically a cult event among cyclists, it may not be too early to start thinking about Mother's Day.

title: TAXING OPTIONS GET COOL RESPONSE
description: HARTFORD THE distant drums of a state income tax are being heard across Connecticut these days, but a countermessage is coming in from taxpayers and key legislators: Not this year, or next.

title: THE STOCK MARKET AND 'THE LITTLE GUY'
description: IT is the nature of the small investor to take the stock market's u ps and downs to heart. Emotions run high. Stocks tend to take on p ersonalities, and become intimate, daily companions -some faithful f riends, others treacherous turncoats. Yet such emotional i nvolvement can be a trap, according to John Train, a New York i nvestment adviser - especially when a stock goes sour.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor: Barbara Bergmann's belief that taxation of Social Security benefit payments to Federal and other retirees ''would be desirable from the point of view of fairness'' is something that should be pursued. I receive pension benefits, related to employment in the private sector, from both a private pension plan and the Social Security Administration.

title: CABARET: ARJA SAIJONMAA
description: In American cabaret acts, something entitled ''The Love Story of the Century'' would not be a bitter 30-minute monologue about marriage to an alcoholic. But that was just one of the surprises in the Finnish actress and singer Arja Saijonmaa's shows at the Symphony Space Monday and Wednesday.

title: Q&A
description: Question:We are going on a cruise of the Queen Elizabeth 2. We have been on this ship before but we are still confused about tipping and we would like to do it correctly. We believe that you should tip your stateroom and dining room stewards $3 to $4 a day a person. On our 12-day cruise we have two dining room stewards, a busboy and a wine steward; we also have two stateroom stewards as well as a night steward. We obviously do not tip each one $3 to $4 a day a person, but we do not know how to divide it. Can you help us determine how to tip correctly? - M.A.G., South Bend, Ind. Answer:''There are no set guidelines,'' said Alice Marshall, a Cunard Line representative. ''We feel that on a ship like the QE2 - with 24 different cabin categories ranging in price from $1,000 to $5,000 for a five-day trans-Atlantic crossing and with passengers who have widely varying service demands - it would be very difficult to set guidelines. For example, while some people are rarely in their cabins, others might want to use 24-hour room service and have their shoes shined every night. Tipping is really an individual matter.''

title: WOMEN'S STUDIES ARE SHOWING GAINS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK IN 1969, there were fewer than 20 college courses in women's studies in the United States. Today, according to the National Association of Women's Studies, some 20,000 courses about women are being offered, with more than 300 schools granting degrees in such studies,

title: REPUBLICAN GRASP ON CHICAGO: 9 JOBS
description: Timothy P. Sheehan sums it up in four words. ''I have nine jobs,'' the gray-haired former Congressman says glumly. ''Nine jobs in 77 precincts.'' His voice trails off and he gestures, signaling futility.

title: CHILDREN COMMUTE TO DANCE IN BALLET
description: REBECCA KUPERSMITH is an angel - and that's not just her mother's opinion. Because this holiday season, Rebecca, an 8 year old who lives in Bronxville, will be dancing in the role of an angel, along with several other county children who will take their places as soldiers, a mouse and a bunny in the New York City Ballet's yearly production of ''The Nutcracker.''

title: ASIAN GAMES GIVE MRS. GANDHI A POLITICAL VICTORY
description: The end of the ninth Asian Games tonight marked what is widely perceived here as a political victory for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who brushed aside a threat from militant Sikhs to disrupt the 15-day-long event.

title: MEXICO: BACK TO REALITY
description: There is good news from Mexico. Its former President, Jose Lopez Portillo, went out of office here with a whine and a fortune, blaming the superpowers for most of his country's economic problems.

title: Peru's Capital Blacked Out
description: Explosions at two utility substations blacked out this capital city Friday night. The police said leftist ''bandits'' were responsible. No injuries were reported.

title: DIARY OF POLAND'S DISCONTENT
description: Copyright c 1982 Kazimierz Brandys. Translation Copyright c 1983 Random House, Inc.

title: Taking on Caesar
description: After agonizing over what to render to Caesar when Caesar is deploying nuclear arms, Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle decided last

title: PHILHARMONIC: LOPEZ-COBOS
description: Jesus Lopez-Cobos's second New York Philharmonic program of the season Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall lacked anything overtly glamorous - no big-name soloist, no blockbuster, no premiere, no certified exotica. Yet in its own modest way the program and performances added up to a most pleasant evening.

title: CONSIDER CAVIAR'S TASTY AND VERSATILE IMPOSTER
description: WITH the holiday season under way, ideas for hors d'oeuvres that require neither much time to prepare nor expense to purchase are particularly welcomed. Dare we suggest caviar? Before you turn the page, note that it is not the caviar you imagine, which may be simple enough to set before eager guests but is guaranteed to wipe out the entire Christmas budget in a few mouthfuls. A tasty and versatile imposter, eggplant caviar, often called poor man's caviar, is the delicacy in question here.

title: Remembering Harry Chapin
description: Harry Chapin would have been 40 years old on Dec. 7, 1982. I met him twice, both times while he was in concert.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: From Finland And Elmsford

title: RAIL FARE RISE: THE FEARS AND THE FIGURES
description: DESPITE all the talk lately about an increase in the New York City subway fare, transportation officials are now saying that the Long Island Rail Road is facing a far more serious problem, and if nothing is done, commuters could soon be paying 50 percent more to get to work -although few expect commutation costs to rise that much.

title: Senator Has Total Unrecall
description: A string of ''I have no recollection's'' from a United States Senator, the health of the principal defendant and crank phone calls pulled the bribery-conspiracy trial of teamsters president Roy L. Williams back from the era of high-tech prosecution to more conventional courtroom ground last week.

title:
STAMPS;
SPORTS AND HUMANITIES DOMINATE '83 ISSUES
description: Sports, the arts and the humanities will be dominant on the issues being put out by the United States during the second half of 1983 - and after seven years of commemoratives the Bicentennial of the American Revolution will formally come to an end.

title: A JOYCEAN EVENING
description: Colleen Dewhurst will appear in her one-woman show, ''Molly Bloom,'' based on the character in James Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' at the Whole Theater in Montclair on Dec. 13. Afterward, Miss Dewhurst and Joseph Strich, the film director and authority on Joyce, will chat with the audience about the play, their careers and the theater in general.

title: KEAN ROLE QUESTIONED IN DISPUTE ON BUDGET
description: TRENTON ''THE Governor shall communicate to the Legislature, by message at the opening of each regular session and at such other times as he may deem necessary, the condition of the state, and shall in like manner recommend such measures as he may deem desirable.''

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE county's efforts to find a solution to the airport noise problem continued last week, but the issue remains up in the air. In one major shift in direction, the Federal Government offered to help the county financially with a series of noise tests at the Westchester County Airport. The tests were called for by a court agreement among parties to the lawsuit that airport users brought against the county in an effort to enjoin its ban on night flights at the Airport.

title: YALE ACTIONS ARE CRITICIZED
description: NEW HAVEN YALE President A. Bartlett Giamatti says the university doesn't take stands on political issues. But to conservative critics both on campus and in the national press, Yale has taken political stands recently regarding draft-registration resisters and Solidarity, the outlawed Polish labor group.

title: Topics; Weather Eyes; Forecasters
description: This is what the meteorologists said in September. They said it was going to be a cold winter, and mustered all kinds of evidence to prove it.

title: W.A. KNIGHT JR. WEDS MISS EVANS
description: Wendelin Jean Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Evans of New York, Fishers Island, N.Y., and Essex, Conn., was married yesterday to Warren Arthur Knight Jr., son of Mrs. William S. Wallace of Olean, N.Y., and the late Mr. Knight of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony in the chantry of St. Thomas Episopal Church in New York.

title: CHINESE EXPERTS TELL OF GAINS IN MEDICINE FOR REHABILITATION
description: China is embarked on an ambitious effort to wed modern rehabilitation medicine with traditional practices. Typical of the marriage is the use of laser beams instead of needles for acupuncture.

title: Sports of The Times; Learning the Family Trade Together
description: THE second race at Latonia Race Course in Kentucky was a family affair last Wednesday night. There was Leah Barton in the outside lane with her fiance, James Bruin, trying to hang on in the middle, and coming up the middle was the matriarch of the clan, Patti Barton, one of the best jockeys in the region.

title: Olegna Fuschi Recital Set
description: Olegna Fuschi, whose Carnegie Hall piano recital Nov. 29 was postponed after she was injured slightly in an automobile accident, has rescheduled her recital for Dec. 22 at 8 P.M.

title: POSTINGS
description: For 30 years, a discrete portal numbered 851 Madison Avenue led to a whole block of second-floor frontage from 70th to 71st Street that was the home of the Tobe-Coburn School of Fashion. Since July, that space has been vacant, following the removal of the school to 686 Broadway, at East Fourth Street.

title: CONTINENTAL FARE, WITH CHANGES
description: WHEN Frederick's first opened in Melville a little over three years ago, it offered Continental food that was often better than average and served in a comfortable, attractive, contemporary setting. While success may not have spoiled Frederick's, it does not seem to have improved it, either.

title: RENOVATED RAIL LINE A BOON TO FARMS
description: It didn't seem like a major accomplishment for Don Weelborg and the boys down at the Farmers Co-op grain elevator today when they finished loading 40,800 bushels of corn into 12 huge railroad hopper cars.

title: Unplugging a Lake
description: Once Lake Piegneur in Louisiana was shallow enough to wade across in most spots, and the Jefferson Island salt dome in the lake yielded more than a million tons of salt a year for the Diamond Crystal Salt Company. That was before the bottom fell out of the lake on Nov. 20, 1980.

title: PORT CHESTER AND GREENWICH TRY TO RESOLVE WATER PROBLEMS
description: PORT CHESTER and Greenwich, Conn., contiguous communities, have something more than a boundary line in common. For several years, both towns have been engaged in a losing struggle with their common supplier, the Connecticut-American Water Company, over water rates and adequate deliveries. The drought of 1981 brought severe and allegedly avoidable water shortages to both towns, producing deep resentment over the water company's continuing applications for rate increases.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on page 33 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the architect of the Berlin building housing the ''Zeitgeist'' exhibition. He was Martin Gropius.

title: STATEWIDE SYSTEM OF TRAILS PROPOSED
description: NEW BRUNSWICK WITHIN a few years, those so inclined will be able to hike or bicycle more than 70 miles along a continuous trail that starts at Military Park in Newark, winds through Essex County and ends near the western boundary of Morris County.

title: BARRI WALKER IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Walker of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barri Carolyn Walker, to David Leigh Becker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Becker of Merrick, L.I. Miss Walker is a senior at Emory University. Her fiance was graduated from Emory and is a law student there. A July wedding is planned.

title: FRIENDS OF THE OTHER SIDE'S PEACE GROUPS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW BREED OF STAND-UP COMICS
description: I have my own apartment now," says the comedian Elayne Boosler, her face a bright orange disk in a comedy club spotlight, ''and when my parents come to visit, I make them stay in separate bedrooms. I tell them, 'I don't care what you do on the outside, but in my house ...''

title: GOING BY THE BOOK
description: Not that long ago, commendable and inventive cookbooks were somewhat of a rarity. But times, and tastes, have changed. Here are recipes from five recent, and worthy, new books.

title: 'HUMBLE YET GRAND,' WRIGHT HOUSE LEAVES ITS MARK ON L.I.
description: GREAT NECK THIS is the story of an extraordinary house, a visionary architect and a Long Island couple, Ben and Ann Rehbuhn, who in the late 1930's invited Frank Lloyd Wright to build them a house in Great Neck, his first commissioned structure east of Buffalo.

title: MANY LIGHTS OUT ON NORTHERN STATE
description: DRIVERS on the Northern State Parkway, where long stretches of road are sporadically unlighted, are complaining that night driving is unsafe. The outages creating the hazards are largely a consequence of projects to improve safety.

title: LETTERS
description: Images of Israel I was moved by Terence Smith's article on the Israeli photographer Micha Bar-Am (''Images of Israel, Oct. 31). The discussion of Mr. Bar-Am's inner conflict and confusion echoes some very basic truths about Israeli life.

title: 'HUB' PLAN PUSHED
description: THE idea of developing a transportation hub in the vicinity of the Ronkonkoma railroad station, which is sandwiched between Long Island MacArthur Airport and the Long Island Expressway at the geographical center of the Island, has been around for almost 20 years. Although no money has been earmarked for the hub development, town and county officials now say they are ready to move forward.

title: DAY CARE FOR THE AGED BEGINS IN YONKERS
description: FOR the 42,000 elderly of Yonkers, the prospect of waiting for a nursing-home bed could be daunting. But an interim solution has recently become available for those in need of long-term rehabilitation - geriatric day care.

title: FUTURE EVENTS
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. All in the Family Dec. 6 - Members of the Seeger clan including John, Mike, Kate, Tony and Nicky will perform blue grass and country music at a party at the Top of the Gate, 160 Bleecker Street. Event scheduled to start at 8 P.M., will benefit the scholarship fund of the Elizabeth Seeger School, named for the educator and aunt of John, Mike and Pete Seeger. Thirty to 50 per cent of the pupils at the private secondary school at 93 Franklin Street receive some scholarship aid. Tickets, $40 at the door.

title: Norwich City Wins, 1-0, Stops Liverpool Streak
description: John Deehan's 14th goal of the season gave Norwich City a 1-0 victory over first-place Liverpool today in an English League First Division soccer match.

title: SKI OPERATORS GET A JUMP ON WINTER
description: VERNON VALLEY BUOYED because last winter was the most prosperous in their resort's 13-year history, executives of the Vernon Valley-Great Gorge skiing complex again are relying on their snow-making equipment to make the 1982-83 season another banner one.

title: 'FREEZE' LEADER HAD DEFENSE CAREER
description: WATERFORD ON the face of it, southeastern Connecticut's defense-oriented region is no place to advocate a nuclear arms freeze. The Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics in Groton employs 20,000 people building Trident and 688-Class, fast-attack submarines. Thousands of Navy and civilian employees work at the Submarine Base in Groton and the Naval Underwater Systems Center in New London and dozens of small consulting firms are under contract to Electric Boat. Defense spending accounts for hundreds of millions of dollars in the region's annual payroll.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART RECIPIENTS WILL HAVE CHOICE ON LIFE
description: Recipients of artificial hearts will get keys to turn off their life-support pumps in case they decide against living tethered to machinery, according to Dr. Willem Kolff, a pioneer in artificial human organs.

title: Mailbox; A Cyclist Notes Patterson's Feat
description: To the Sports Editor: As the winner of one of the races in the Union Square Criterium, I was very pleased to to see my name mentioned in an article in Sports-Monday, on Nov. 15. However, the main race of the day involving pros and top amateurs, which John Patterson of North Carolina won after lapping the field, did not receive a mention. I am sure that this was an oversight. VINCENT C. McDONALD

title:
GARDENING;
SAFE HANDLING OF CHRISTMAS GREENERY
description: DRIED out Christmas greens are unsightly and may create a fire hazard. Discrimination in selection and proper care will go a long way toward preventing these problems.

title: HOUSING ON TAP
description: Most of the local breweries whose products once drew the same kind of loyalty as baseball teams have been demolished to make way for urban expansion. But in Jersey City, the half-dozen red brick buildings that housed the Lembeck and Betz Eagle Brewing Company still stand, although beer was last brewed in them during the Great Depression.

title: Driver Held in Missile Spill
description: Gary Wayne Wade has been arrested on suspicion of being drunk when his truck overturned Friday with a cargo of 18 Navy guided missiles near here. A preliminary test at a hospital showed that the alcohol level in Mr. Wade's blood was ''either at the legal limit or over the legal limit,'' said Highway Patrolman Doyne Cates, who arrested the 23-year-old driver at the hospital.

title: JOHNSON
description: Deborah Lynn Branscomb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Branscomb of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Alan Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Victor Johnson of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Malcolm Mooers, pastor of the Congregational Church of Huntington, performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Stamford, Conn.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: ART DEALER CONVICTED OF TAMPERING IN ROTHKO SUIT
description: Frank Lloyd, the owner of the Marlborough Gallery and one of the world's best known art dealers, was convicted yesterday on charges of tampering with evidence in connection with a lawsuit against him, his gallery and the executors of the estate of Mark Rothko, the painter.

title: BOBBIE A. BROMBERG WED TO THOMAS FRANK PEPITONE
description: Bobbie Ann Bromberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bertram E. Bromberg of Glen Head, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Frank Pepitone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Pepitone of Sands Point, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Interfaith Chapel of C. W. Post College in Greenvale, L.I., where the Rev. Philip Eichner, a Roman Catholic priest, and Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated.

title: THE PIANO QUARTET GETS A NEW BOOST
description: There are perhaps a baker's dozen of standard works composed for piano quartet. Piano quartet means piano, violin, viola and cello. Mozart wrote two works for that combination, Beethoven four (none of which is considered among his supreme efforts), Schumann one, Dvorak two, Brahms three, Faure two. That about exhausts the list (and, come to think of it, it is a bigger list than that of standard piano quintets, but that is another story).

title: MONDALE HAPPY TO BE PARTY'S '84 FRONTRUNNER
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, in his first extensive comment on Senator Edward M. Kennedy's withdrawal from the 1984 Presidential race, says he wants to be considered the frontrunner for the Democratic nomination.

title: JAMIE BLOCH WEDS DR. JOHN P. GERGEN, BIOCHEMIST
description: Jamie Estelle Bloch, daughter of Charles E. Bloch of New York, and Mrs. Edward M. Cramer of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. John Peter Gergen, son of Dr. John Andrew Gergen of Frankfort, Ky., and Janet Gorman Gergen of Stony Creek, Conn. Rabbi Mark Goldman performed the ceremony at the Faculty Club of Princeton University.

title: Estimate Board Survives Suit
description: Ever since the New York City Council ran into constitutional difficulties last year, some politicians have been waiting for the other shoe to fall on the Board of Estimate, arguably the city's most powerful body. Last week it fell - and missed.

title: THE SUBLETIES OF SIMPLE SUIT COMBINATIONS
description: One might think that the possibility of a group of world-class players arguing about the play of a simple suit combination would be about as likely as finding Artur Rubinstein and Vladimir Horowitz arguing about how to interpret ''Chopsticks.'' But in fact suit combinations present endless subtleties.

title: HOW HE STARTED A MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: A FEW years ago, a member of Robert Ross's New York-based administrative staff came to him with a problem. ''He said he had a son who was qualified to attend a United States medical school, but unfortunately, because of the quota, he was unable to get in -each school has a limited number of students they can accept.''

title: NOW THE RELIGION IS ANTI-MODERNISM
description: It is common to speak of this as a time of pluralism, as a moment in architecture when the eclectic impulse is paramount - as a time, even, when we yearn to expand our esthetic to take in all of history. After all, if there are any buildings that seem to sum up the concerns of the moment they would have to be the Portland (Ore.) Building by Michael Graves, which is a brightly colored pile of reinterpreted classical decoration, and Philip Johnson and John Burgee's A.T.& T. Building in New York, which twists and turns Renaissance and Chippendale forms into a sumptuous skyscraper.

title: Letters; Assessment Law
description: To the Editor:

title: The Politics of Politics Costs Packwood a Post
description: Richard G. Lugar, once known as President Nixon's favorite mayor, might not be President Reagan's favorite Senator. But at the moment he may be a close second.

title: Cordero Tops $9 Million
description: Angel Cordero became the first jockey to top $9 million in singleseason purse winnings when he won the third race at Aqueduct yesterday with Dearest Rosalie. Cordero finished the card with a total of $9,021,216 in winnings and said he hoped ''to reach $10 million'' before the end of the year.

title: CAIN AND KRAL-AFTER 33 YEARS, STILL GROWING
description: Pop singers of the 30's, 40's and 50's have, as a rule, not aged particularly well. They had their day when they were young and then, if they stayed around, settled into a predictable performing style based partly on nostalgia, partly on the fading capabilities of their voices. In view of the radical change in pop singing styles brought on by rock and roll, no one would expect - or would want - the earlier generation of pop singers to change their musical colors completely. But it is surprising how few of that generation of singers have grown once they passed a youthful peak.

title: FROM THE HALLS OF MONTEZUMA, TO THE SHORE OF MEMORY
description: THAT Sunday, Dec. 7, 1941, a few friends and I had taken the IRT subway from Brooklyn into Manhattan, a rare pilgrimage in those days because we Brooklynites, a very insular and provincial people, had always believed that Brooklyn offered all the delights of living needed for the complete happy existence.

title: TRYING TO SERVE ALL THE WORKERS
description: ANALYSIS of the declining fortunes of America's labor unions has b ecome an increasingly popular pastime. Nothing succeeds like successa nd vice-versa. During recent periods of economic decline, these woesh ave compounded and are, according to labor's spokesmen, brought a bout in major part by the Reagan Administration's actions and a ntilabor attitude.

title: Rescue Deepens Friends' Ties
description: Tony Lush, the American sailor in the single-handed round-the-world race who was rescued by another competitor after abandoning ship last week in the stormy Southern Indian Ocean, is reported to be in good condition.

title: Shuttle Builder; Pays Some Back
description: Cost overruns on Federal contracts are a yawn in the aerospace industry, but the possibility of fraud does raise eyebrows in Washington. Last week Rockwell International Corporation - without admitting guilt - agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle a civil suit charging the company with overbilling on the space shuttle project.

title: POP MUSIC
description: Third World's recorded collaborations with Stevie Wonder have helped this Jamaican band win a black American audience that few other reggae performers enjoy. But even before Third World encountered Mr. Wonder at a Jamaican musical strains.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THE event, someone joked, should have been called Peking Meets Preppie. Sixteen City branch of the Consulate of the People's Republic of China had piled into two vans and driven up the highway to the so-called horse country of northern Westchester. Now they were touring Rippowam Cisqua, a private school set on two campuses in the rolling hills of Bedford and Mount Kisco that prepares children 3 to 14 years old for the rigors of further education.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The No. 13 that Dan Marino has worn for four years as the quarterback at the University of Pittsburgh will be retired Thursday at a dinner honoring the football team. Marino, who is the Pitt career leader in passing and total offense, joins Tony Dorsett (33) and Hugh Green (99) as the only Panther players to have their numbers retired. ... The New Jersey Devils have sent John Wensink, a left wing who has played in the National Hockey League for seven seasons, to their farm team in Wichita, Kan., for two weeks of conditioning. Wensink played in 15 of the Devils's 20 games and had one assist. ... Jiri Crha, a goaltender who was suspended a week ago when he refused to report to St. Catherines of the American Hockey League, has become a free agent after he cleared league waivers and accepted a cash settlement on the balance of his contract from the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: 40 YEARS AFTER, ARTISTS STILL STRUGGLE WITH THE HOLOCAUST
description: ''At Auschwitz,'' wrote Elie Wiesel, ''not only man died but also the idea of man.'' Some four decades have now passed since the Nazis murdered six million European Jews, and that most tragic and incomprehensible of events remains the formative experience of modern times, for, as Mr. Wiesel observes, the Holocaust not only confronts us with a vision of radical evil but also forces us to reassess our entire Enlightenment legacy of humanism - all our comfortable theories about man and reason and God.

title: THE GAME'S AFOOT: SHERLOCK HOLMES RETURNS TO THE SCREEN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Billington frequently reports on the cultural scene in England. DEVONSHIRE, ENGLAND

title: Acid Rain Study Cut
description: Having said that not enough was known about acid rain damage to do anything about it, the Reagan Administration last week decided to starve a major study aimed at devising a strategy to control it.

title: DREAM OF OARSMEN FINALLY COMES TURE
description: DERBY IT took 20 years of dreaming and a lot of hard work, but James Segaloff and his rowing mates have earned their gold medals. After three years of 5 A.M. wake-up calls and practices every day of the week, the New Haven Rowing Club's master-event oarsmen displayed a championship form in Amsterdam in October that finally established them as one of the premier rowing teams in the world.

title: A 'FLOWER DRUM' RESOUNDS IN ANDOVER
description: ANDOVER FIE on ''Fiddler.'' Enough of ''The Sound of Music.'' Minette Skloot believes in putting on musicals that, she says, ''haven't been done to death.''

title: HEARNS TRIUMPHS BY OUTBOXING A BOXER
description: Emanuel Steward smiled at the recollection of Thomas Hearns fighting as an amateur. Hearns was a boxer then, a tall. skinny teen-ager who kept his opponents at a distance with a long left jab and fancy footwork. Steward knew the punching power would come later, when Hearns added a few pounds to his frame.

title: Argov Report
description: For weeks after he was shot by terrorists in London last June 3, Shlomo Argov, Israel's Ambassador to Britain, lay in a coma. According to the surgeon who operated on him, a bullet fired at point-blank range had gone through the brain, entering the head above the right ear and leaving above the left ear.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a Posting item last Sunday, the present location of a section of the house Frank Lloyd Wright built in Wayzata, Minn., for Mr. and Mrs. Francis Little was given incorrectly.

title: ST. JOHN THE BAPTIST WINS METRO BOWL
description: The ''triple crown'' is what the players from St. John the Baptist of West Islip, L.I., were calling this year's Metro Bowl game. The Catholic High Schools Football League champions ran away with the title for the the third straight year as they defeated John Adams, the Public Schools Athletic League champion, 27-16, yesterday at Midwood Field in Brooklyn.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
JOB TRAINING: CAN BUSINESS DO IT BETTER?
description: SOME members of the business community called it a boondoggle program. The media focused news coverage on the program only when there was a scandal. And now, that program is over, that job-training program called CETA.

title: JAZZ COMES TO THE WHITE HOUSE FOR PBS
description: Jazz, that most American of musical forms, made its first appearance this afternoon at the television series ''In Performance at the White House.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Off Off Broadway entry today in The Guide, section 2A, lists an incorrect telephone number for ''David and Paula.'' The 92d St. Y's box-office number is 427-4410.

title: LETTERS
description: The Genetic Assault On Cancer If monoclonal antibodies attach themselves to cancerous cells and can be tagged with radiation, the radiation can be of sufficient strength to kill the cancer cells to which the antibodies cling, and bring about remission (''The Genetic Assault on Cancer,'' by Sharon McAuliffe and Kathleen McAuliffe, Oct. 24).

title: PEKING IS TROUBLED BY RISE IN DEFECTIONS TO WEST
description: China's policy of sending students, scholars and others to the United States for extended visits has created tensions between the two Governments because of the large number of defections, according to American officials.

title:
ART;
'CAMERA VISION': STARTING AT THE START
description: WITH all the literature - erudite, high-toned and questioning - on photography in recent years, it is stimulating to come across an exhibition intent on returning a consideration of photography to square one. ''Camera Vision'' at the Pace University Gallery on the Briarcliff campus (through Dec. 15) gently makes the case again for photography's being a democratic vision.

title: BARGAINS IN SKI TOUR PACKAGES
description: T his is the time of year when skiers who have told themselves for months that they couldn't afford a trip to the Rockies or the Alps begin to weaken. The first reports of snow in Colorado, Utah and Idaho are in, the full-color spread on St. Anton in the latest issue of a skiing magazine has just been carefully studied, and now the skier's resolve, along with his or her checkbook, is about to embark on a downhill slalom course.

title: BEETLE FUMIGATION GAS Is Released in Brooklyn
description: A toxic gas was slowly released yesterday from an empty Brooklyn warehouse that Federal officials said contained the last-known infestation of khapra beetles in the United States.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: A survey of last week's debut recitals divides neatly into categories -two sopranos and two pianists. Neither singer was new to performing -both being more in the middle of their careers than at the beginning. One seems to have profited greatly from her experience; the other less so.

title:
COINS;
FOREIGN AND ANCIENT COINS TAKE CENTER STAGE
description: Much of the big news in the world of coins this year has centered on U.S. issues and developments - for example, the release of the George Washington commemorative half dollar, the staging of the U.S. Gold Coin Sale, and the preparations for the 1984 Olympic coinage. This week the spotlight shifts at least temporarily to world coins as dealers and collectors gather in New York for the 11th annual New York International Numismatic Convention.

title: REFLECTIONS ON THE INDIAN POINT HEARINGS
description: Peter A. Bradford, chairman of the Maine Public Utilities Commission, was a member of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission from 1977 to 1982. The following article was excerpted from a speech he made to the Environmental Defense Fund Associates in New York City earlier this fall.

title: To Curb Violence In Pro Football
description: To the Sports Editor: It is time that something more definitive is done to curb the unnecessary violence in professional football. It is only good fortune that no serious injuries were sustained by Leon Bright of the Giants or John Jefferson of the Packers last weekend after vicious hits.

title: Reagan Grants Plan Is Called Peril to Lead Poison Surveys
description: A House subcommittee has been told that the Federal program for finding children who suffer lead poisoning is threatened by the Regan Administration's decision to finance it through grants that allow states to decide how to spend the money.

title: SHAMIR'S ZAIRE TRIP CALLED ISRAEL'S RETURN TO AFRICA
description: The visit to Zaire this week by the Israeli Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, marked ''our return to Africa,'' as one Israeli official eager for the nation to renew its diplomatic ties in Africa put it.

title: Costs of Unbuilt Plant Push Up Utility's Rates
description: Orange and Rockland Utilities will raise its electric and gas rates Monday, largely to pay for preparations for the Sterling nuclear power plant that was never built.

title: Books for Santa's Sack
description: 'Tis the season to be told that good books make good gifts (as you've noticed, no doubt, if you've recently seen any bookstore ads or displays). For those who want help in selecting just the right titles to give individuals of all ages, here's some information on two guides to good reading and on this year's diverse assortment of boxed paperback sets. The Topical Treatment.

title: THE 71ST APPEAL
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was established in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of The Times. That year 117 contributors donated a total of $3,630.88 to be distributed among three private social-service agencies.

title: ART BOOKS
description: THE PALACE MUSEUM: PEKING Treasures of the Forbidden City. By Wan-go Weng and Yang Boda. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $65.

title: VIRTUES APLENTY LIE AMID 'SMITHEREENS'
description: Accompanied by some good reviews and less publicity than would attend the opening of a new supermarket in Mineola, Susan Seidelman's ''Smithereens'' has slipped into town and taken up residence in Greenwich Village's 200-seat Waverly Theater 1 where, I hope, it will stay a long time.

title: JUNE 11
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Martin Victor of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Helen Louise Lash Victor, to Harmon Lawrence Remmel, son of Harmon Liveright Remmel of New York and Souhampton, L.I., and the late Jaquelin Towson Remmel.

title: REPUBLICAN WORRIES RISE ALONG WITH JOBLESS RATE
description: At a press breakfast last week, Martin S. Feldstein, the President's chief economic adviser, was pressed repeatedly to say when he expected a recovery from the recession to begin. He wouldn't do so. He said, ''All of the attributes for economic recovery are in place.'' And he said, ''Conditions are right.'' Finally, he allowed that a recovery was more likely to start in the first half of 1983 than in the second half. That was as far as he would go.

title: A PARISIAN NORMAN ROCKWELL
description: Vivien Raynor

title: ALASKA WILDS CALL GOVERNOR AS HE RETIRES
description: When Barbara Carey of Florida's Dade County suggested recently that Alaska pay the cost of a new Orange Bowl in Miami, she got a reply from Gov. Jay S. Hammond of Alaska.

title: LYING: THE SUBTLE TABOO
description: or what Emily Dickinson poetically describes as ''Telling the truth/But telling it slant'' - is a fairly uncomfortable subject. And, although common sense and our own slanted statements tell us that lying must go on every day, the actual word is rarely used. We talk about and hear about ''getting out of an invitation,'' ''not telling the whole story'' or ''making an excuse.''

title: PATRICIA V. GREENWICH MARRIES RICHARD WOLFF
description: Patricia Varvaro Greenwichm daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Varvaro of White Plains, was married yesterday to Richard Hugh Wolff, son of Mr. and Robert A. Wolff of South Nyack, N.Y. The Rev. Gerard Orlando, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Good Counsel Academy in White Plains, from which the bride was graduated.

title: CONCORD AT CHRISTMAS
description: LISA HAMMEL is a writer who divides her time between New York and Massachusetts.

title: LOTTERIES PAYING FOR 5% OF STATE AID TO SCHOOLS
description: After years of relative stagnation, revenues from New York State's lottery games grew substantially last year, reaching 5 percent of the state's contribution to elementary and secondary education.

title: MESSAGE IS CLEAR ON NEW TOTES
description: When it comes to totes, chic has had it. The objective is no longer a bag with prestigious initials, so obviously expensive that the owner looked, or hoped to look, as if carrying parcels was a mere whim.

title: WHERE TO GO SKIING IN A 2-HOUR RADIUS
description: WHITE PLAINS WHEN the county's early skiing enthusiasts set out for a weekend's expedition, their destination was the high mountain country of Vermont or New Hampshire. Until the mid-1960's, traveling that distance was considered essential.

title: 2 ELECTION WINNERS MOVE TO SUE LOSERS
description: TWO victorious Long Island legislators, in an unusual move, are planning to take their election opponents to court in libel and slander suits as a result of election charges and allegations that the unsuccessful opponents used.

title: LEAFS SET BACK ISLANDERS, 4-1
description: The struggling Islanders went from bad to worse tonight as they lost their second game in two nights, this time to the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4-1. Friday night they lost to the Jets in Winnipeg, 4-2.

title: ATTRACTIVE OLD MILL WITH A VIEW
description: YALESVILLE DINING out in an old red-brick factory might not sound like the most enticing culinary experience. But the Britannia Spoon Company, a restaurant with the same ownership as the New Haven, in the city of the same name, has turned an old mill on the Quinnipiac River into an inviting dining locale.

title: ECONOMIC LOSSES HIGH IN SALVADOR
description: The three-year-old guerrilla war here has caused tens of millions of dollars of damage to public installations, eliminated thousands of jobs and removed large areas of farmland from productive use, according to a study prepared by the Salvadoran Government.

title: PARTIAL ANSWERS TO SEVERAL VEXING QUESTIONS ON MASSACRE
description: JERUSALEM THE state commission investigating the Beirut massacre has completed the first phase of its work, producing a preliminary picture of what happened at the highest levels of Israel's Government and army before and during the killings of Palestinians in September.

title: Raiders' Dispute Rages
description: Al Davis, the managing general partner of the Los Angeles Raiders, has testified at a hearing in Salinas, Calif., that the Raiders could not move back to Oakland even if they wanted to. Speaking at a hearing in which the City of Oakland asked a judge to reinstate a 1980 temporary injunction barring a move by the Raiders, Davis said that the presence of the Invaders of the United States Football League in Oakland Coliseum made such a move impossible.

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC GROUP
description: There were several problems with the Los Angeles Philharmonic New Music Group's initial New York presentation Wednesday night. The concert was held in a packed New York University classroom with overly resonant acoustics.

title: L. BEERS
description: Isabel Lockwood Beers, daughter of Mrs. Nathan Thomas Beers of Southbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Beers, was married yesterday to Thompson F. Haskins, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Chandler Haskins of Concord and Wianno, Mass. The Rev. Linda Peyton of the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., performed the ceremony at a private residence at 146 East 37th Street in New York.

title: WALKER WINS HEISMAN
description: To the surprise of practically no one, Herschel Walker of the University of Georgia last night was named the winner of the Heisman Trophy, the award that goes to the college football player who is voted the best in the country. He received the 48th Heisman at a nationally televised show in the Downtown Athletic Club.

title: JAZZ: BILLY BANG, VIOLIN, LEADS TRIO
description: The violinist Billy Bang stuck to standards for his second set at Greene Street Thursday. Leafing through a song book and conferring with the bassist Art Davis and the pianist Michelle Rosewoman, Mr. Bang chose ''April in Paris'' and a few tunes associated with John Coltrane, including ''My Favorite Things'' and ''Mr. Sims.''

title: Boston College Named Top Team in Division
description: Boston College, which is headed for its first bowl game in 40 years, was named today as the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Division I-A football team of the year.

title: IMPROVEMENT SLOW IN BOARDING HOMES
description: ALTHOUGH almost two and a half years have elapsed since New Jersey enacted one of the most comprehensive rooming- and boarding-house regulatory laws in the country, conditions for many of the 40,000 or so people living in such homes, some state officials say, are not much better than they were before the law was passed.

title: Filipino Church's Dissent Grows
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has made a lot of enemies during the 17 years he has ruled the Philippines, but none so powerful as the one he risks making now: the Roman Catholic Church. Declaring that ''the law is the law,'' Mr. Marcos warned of a crackdown against priests who engage in subversive acts such as support for guerrilla groups.

title: ROMANCE NOVELS IN SCHOOL
description: AS formula-ridden adult romances enthrall a wide audience of mature women, so formula-ridden ''first-romance'' novels are attracting a growing readership among girls between the ages of 11 and 15 on the Island.

title: TRYING AN OPPONENT'S STYLE HAS ITS PERILS
description: There is a temptation, after having lost a sensational game to an opponent with a totally different style, to try to emulate him. But this is not a good idea.

title: Tailoresses
description: To the Editor: John Russell is a fine art critic, and his article on the Comedie Francaise entitled ''Backstage at a Paris Tradition'' (Travel, Oct. 31) had a good deal of interesting material. However, his unfortunate use of the phrase ''tailors and tailoresses'' is a deplorable lapse that even the language liberationists would probably abhor. BETTY MARKS New York ohn Russell writes: ''Tailor and tailoress'' is an invaluable formulation, and one that should have the universal currency that has always been granted to ''shepherd and shepherdess.''

title: Visas
description: To the Editor: In the article, ''When a Visa Is Required'' (Travel, Oct. 31), Irvin Molotsky lists several countries where, surprisingly, Americans must have visas to enter (Japan, Australia and Venezuela, for example). However, he neglects to mention that there are countries where visas are not required for Americans, but whose citizens must have visas to enter the United States.

title: From Sack to Sock
description: The Jets' Mark Gastineau will start taking boxing lessons from Larry Holmes's former manager, Rich Giachetti, when the football season ends.

title: A GUIDE TO ITEMS FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: THIS year, at holiday shows in craft galleries and shops around the state, strains of lighthearted humor - like a porcelain hippopotamus sunbathing with a pina colada - frequently blend with sophisticated collectibles and innovative useful objects.

title: U.S. MAY LIST CARIBOU AS ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: The Interior Department has agreed to place the Selkirk caribou herd, now consisting of fewer than 20 animals ranging the border between Idaho, Washington and British Columbia, on its list of endangered species, according to officials of the National Audubon Society.

title: The Rules of a Co-op
description: Question: My sister owned an apartment in the Penn South co-op. She passed away recently and left her entire estate to me, in addition to designating me as the executor of her will. Is it possible for me to retain the apartment since I am her sole heir or must I sell it back to the tenant-shareholder corporation? ... D.I.M., Baldwin, L.I. Answer: You must sell your shares back to the corporation, Mutual Redevelopment Houses Inc. The corporation, which owns the 2,820 units in the complex running from 23d to 29th Street and Eighth to Ninth Avenue, has a contract with the city specifying that the apartments cannot be inherited. There is a 10-year waiting list for apartments, according to Laurence V. Newman, general manager. To arrange to sell your shares and have the apartment inspected for damages, call the management office at 675-3200.
