You are entitled to the price your sister paid for her shares and, because of recent state legislation, a portion of the amortization on the building's mortgage. If your sister was among the original tenants in 1962, you would be entitled to $1,165 a room for amortization, plus the $1,130 a room she paid for the apartment.

title: WHO IS CHASING WHOM AT BRITISH FOX HUNTS?
description: In Britain, thousands of people go hunting every week. Some chase foxes, and some chase fox hunters. Animal protectionists have become increasingly militant in Britain, the home of the first humane society and possibly the only nation in which a man has been honored for saving a goldfish.

title: Call for Volunteers
description: To the Editor:

title: IN COSTA RICA, A SOUR VIEW OF THE GUARDS
description: The extensive security precautions for President Reagan's visit here startled many Costa Ricans who had been eager for a chance to cheer and wave at the President.

title: ATLANTA TO HONOR A THEATER PROMOTER
description: It has been 14 years since two young artists came to Atlanta from San Francisco to open this city's fourth theater. Now more than 50 theaters, ranging from the prominent and wellestablished to the ''off off Peachtree'' groups that indulge in experimental plays, make up Atlanta's theater community.

title: In Italy, It's Never Too Late - Or Too Often
description: When Italy's governing coalition fell apart last month, President Sandro Pertini called on an old hand to pick up the pieces. Last week, after an arm twist here and a compromise there, the 74-yearold Prime Minister-designate Amintore Fanfani announced that for the fifth time he had put together a new coalition.

title: Airport Neighbors Win $301,500 Court Round
description: Neighbors who say they have come to hate telling time by the takeoffs and landings have won a second round against airport noise.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: EAST HAMPTON town officials have announced plans to buy a 50-acre tract of land for $385,000 and then subdivide it into 100 half-acre lots that would be sold to local families.

title: EAGLES AND SALMON THIN OUT AT PARK
description: The annual salmon run in McDonald Creek, which attracts hundreds of bald eagles, which in turn attract thousands of spectators, was the smallest this year since 1965.

title: A VARIETY OF ROUTES TO CHRISTMAS
description: STANLEY CARR is assistant to the editor of the Travel section. Special rewards go to Christmas travelers, whether they are overseas or in their own country. They don't always come from Santa Claus, wrapped in red, green and gold, but experiencing the holiday season as a tourist brings sights and sounds that will linger through many Christmases to come. The Boys' Choir in Vienna, pantomimes and plum pudding in London, posadas and pinatas in Mexico City, and caroling with guitars under the sunny skies of Puerto Rico are among the overseas experiences. Closer to home the tourist can enjoy a holiday getaway with an ethnic sparkle, be it Moravian, Korean or just plain Yankee. Vienna Music of the Masters Many cities offer a variety of music at Christmas but in Vienna it is the music of the masters, superbly played and sung by the smallest village choir or the stars of the State Opera or the Volksoper. With the exception of Christmas Eve, when the city becomes strangely silent, the State Opera is offering a repertoire that includes ''The Nutcracker,'' ''The Magic Flute'' and ''Der Rosenkavalier.'' (Tickets from $25 to $70.) The Volksoper has a Dec. 20 opening night of ''The Merry Wives of Windsor,'' with seats from $13 to $26. On Dec. 21 children will enjoy an afternoon performance of ''Hansel and Gretel.''

title: MUSICIANS GET SET FOR HECTIC HOLIDAY
description: TROMBONES, trumpets, tubas and French horns at the ready, college music students are seeking to earn quick cash this holiday season by offering their talents to churches.

title: BLACKS SET UP UNIT TO FIGHT PROBLEMS
description: A network of 2,000 blacks in New York City has been formed to put pressure on politicians, agencies and institutions. The network grew out of a convention held in New York last August to devise ways of addressing problems facing blacks, according to convention organizers who formed the network.

title: SANITATION DEPT. REPORTS DECREASE IN TRUCK DELAYS FROM 'SLOWDOWN'
description: The city's Sanitation Department said yesterday that the number of garbage trucks delayed in what it has termed a job slowdown had decreased yesterday and that the backup of trash had been reduced.

title: BONJOUR TO GOOD BUYS
description: BARBARA BELL is a writer who lives in Paris.

title: FOR AIRLINES, THE TRIALS OF ERRORS ...
description: AT this time a year ago, the nation's airline industry was proudly approaching the end of a second consecutive year in which not a single major carrier would have been involved in a fatal accident. The accomplishment was awesome on its own - doubly so when contrasted with records showing five fatal crashes of foreign-operated airliners in 1981 and eight in 1980.

title: MUSIC: HABRERA HATIVIT
description: With an Indian violinist, an Iranian santur player, an Israeli bassist, an American guitarist and a Moroccan lead singer and percussionist, an Israeli group called Habrera Hativit (''The Gathering'') draws on all kinds of Eastern and Western music.

title: SEXUALITY BOOK STIRS DISPUTE
description: WOMEN are undergoing a ''lot of unnecessary surgery,'' according to an assistant professor of nursing and human sexuality, because they mistake ejaculation during sexual intercourse for bed-wetting.

title: BRINGING UP TV FOR CHILDREN
description: KATE MOODY of Larchmont, the author of ''Growing Up on Television'' and considered by many to be an expert on the subject of children's programming, is now director of corporate development for the Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Company. But the erstwhile critic of the effects of television on children sees no contradiction in her current position, in which she tries to persuade corporations to underwrite a cable channel that is exclusively for children.

title: 11 Alabama Cities Agree To Settle Job Bias Suit
description: Eleven Birmingham suburbs have been ordered to provide more government jobs to blacks and women and to pay $200,000 in back wages to 226 victims of discrimination.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: There are two concerts this week which might tend to be lost in the shuffle of usual musical events, but shouldn't.

title: A SOUTHERN FOLK ART
description: ROBERT SHERRILL is a reporter for the Durham Morning Herald in Durham, N.C.

title: No Headline
description: CELTICS' LATE SURGE OVERTAKES PISTONS

title: Recent Sales
description: Amityville $68,000 296 Richmond Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; *2*eat-in kitchen, Florida room, taxes $1,800. Massapequa $106,000 6 Alaska Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 21-year-old high ranch; *2*2 kitchens, Florida room; taxes $3,300. Sayville $205,000 202 Palmer Circle *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, den with fireplace, zoned heat, *2*air-conditioning, pool, waterfront; taxes $5,500. Syosset $110,000 6 Teibrook Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-oldranch; *2*eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $2,849. Wantagh $60,000 3199 William Street *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; *2*fireplace, basement; taxes $1,800. Woodbury $122,000 7 Irving Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old high ranch; *2*family room, sun porch, 2-car garage; taxes $2,408. OTHER AREAS Clifton, N.J. $120,000 12 Fitzgerald Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2*finished basement, air conditioning, 2-car garage; taxes $1,742. Cornwall, Conn. $210,000 Pine Street *2*3-bedroom, 3-bath, 12-year-old contemporary ranch; *2*2 fireplaces, on hillside, 4.1 acres; taxes $1,408. Ardsley, N.Y. $102,500 22 Highland Drive *2*3-bedroom , 2-bath, 30-year-old frame ranch; *2*playroom, garage, 0.18 acre; taxes $2,603.

title: MUSICAL 'CAROL' ARRIVES
description: STAMFORD VIRTUALLY every regional theater has a ''Christmas Carol'' to call its own, but few have the big-time talent of the Hartman Theater's production -an all-out musical - which begins performances on Friday.

title:
DINING OUT;
SMALL ON SEATING, BIG ON FARE
description: GIVEN the profusion of mediocre Chinese restaurants that abound, it's a pleasure to come across one that is more than merely acceptable. Choi Inn, which opened six months ago, is a tiny restaurant barely capable of seating 38 people. It is situated on one of the major streets in Carlstadt, and therefore is within easy reach of the Meadowlands Sports Arena.

title: BURIED TREASURE, SOARING DREAMS
description: A RECENT article in the Long Island Weekly section described a controversial plan to build condominiums at Garvies Point on a 17-acre piece of land in the City of Glen Cove that has been considered a park and is adjacent to a nature preserve. One sentence caught my eye particularly; it said that ''the price tag for Garvies Point may exceed the value of Captain Kidd's treasure, supposedly buried there.''

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ON ADMINISTRATION'S PLAN TO RAISE FEDERAL GAS TAX
description: A chorus of support has emerged for legislation to raise new revenue to build and repair roads, bridges and public transportation and to create jobs at the same time.

title: LETTERS
description: Miss, Mrs. Or Ms.? Ms. is a more useful title than William Safire thinks (''Terrific Honorific,'' On Language, Oct. 31).

title: Man Gets 98-Year Sentence For Stealing Gold and Gems
description: A man convicted of robbing a jeweler and a store of $118,000 in gold, gems and jewelry has been sentenced to 98 years in prison.

title: ON FAITH, FUNDS AND THE JONSES
description: MY FRIEND Jones - the one we try to keep up with - has just sent $200 to a committee sponsoring the constitutional amendment that would require a balanced budget.

title: Stepping Over a Medical Frontier
description: Drugs could not relieve the pain and corrective surgery was out of the question. The patient was 61, too old for a human heart transplant. So when his diseased heart started failing, doctors at Utah Medical Center last week took the one remaining course - and made history. In a 7 1/2-hour operation, they gave Barney B. Clark an artificial heart, the first to be permanently implanted in a human.

title: CAROLINA DEFEATS L.S.U.
description: North Carolina was limited to only 9 points in the first half but rallied from a 12-point deficit on Buzz Peterson's hot shooting and defeated Louisiana State, 47-43, today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Jet Carrying TV Crews Crash-Lands in Brasilia
description: A chartered jet carrying American television technicians and others who covered President Reagan's trip here made an emergency belly landing at Brasilia's airport today after clipping a light tower and losing half its landing gear.

title: LESLIE ALLEN IS MARRIED
description: Leslie Topping Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Allen of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday in the Community Congregational Church to Dr. David Elliston Guyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R.F. Guyer also of Short Hills. The Rev. Kenyon J. Wildrick performed the ceremony. The bridegroom, a cardiologist, is an instructor in medicine at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: COMMUTER KEEPS HIS EAR TUNED TO THE RAILS
description: AT times, Mark Eisenstat of Hartsdale may be the only Conrail commuter who knows what's happening when things go wrong on the railroad. Mr. Eisenstat carries a small radio on his hip that lets him listen in on the conversations of railroad crews as they discuss what is taking place on the line.

title: Italy Will Not Exchange Suspect in Papal Attack
description: The Italian Government told the Bulgarian Ambassador today that it would be ''absolutely unacceptable'' to exchange a Bulgarian jailed on charges of complicity in last year's shooting of Pope John Paul II.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor: I suggest Barbara Bergmann start writing a political column and not report in the business section.

title: FOUNDATION HEAD BACKS LONG SHOTS
description: Since becoming president of the Research Corporation, one of the country's oldest foundations, Dr. John P. Schaefer has been cultivating a gambler's instinct at picking long shots.

title: Loughlin Wins 3 Events At Indoor Relay Meet
description: Bishop Loughlin, which had lost seven of its top runners through graduation, sprang a surprise at the 33d Annual Catholic High School Athletic Association indoor relay meet yesterday by winning three of the six open events.

title: DECOMMISSIONING THE M.T.A.?
description: As sure as the IRT is crowded and the New Haven is late, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will run in the red. This fact of New York transit life inevitably leads to talk of higher subway, bus and commuter rail fares. Last week was no different.

title: ELLEN RADISH AND SETH ZARNY TO BE WED IN SPRING
description: The engagement of Ellen Radish to Seth Zarny, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Zarny of Farmingdale, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Radish of Douglaston, Queens. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Copter Mishap, Then Twins
description: Twin girls were born at Long Beach Memorial Hospital early today to Ruth P. Arthurs, who had been pulled unhurt from a crash-landed helicopter on a university campus. A doctor aboard suffered minor injuries when the pilot, whose engine had failed, landed at the California State University. The helicopter takes patients to the hospital in emergencies.

title: HAWAII HURRICANE SPURS SAFETY PLAN
description: The loss of telephones and electric power gave safety coordinators anxious moments when Hurricane Iwa, Hawaii's worst storm in 25 years, struck this state. The coordinators said better communications were needed and construction near Hawaii's beaches should come under stricter controls.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: FROM BAUHAUS TO OUR HOUSE. By Tom Wolfe. (Pocket Books, $2.95.) Dazzling and provocative, Tom Wolfe's essay on modern architecture argues that a cult-like group of ideologues foisted the ''glass box'' on a world that finds the style distasteful. In his review, Paul Goldberger pointed out the similarities between ''From Bauhaus to Our House'' and Mr. Wolfe's 1975 work, ''The Painted Word,'' which maintained that the theories of postwar American painting had become more important than the paintings themselves. ''I share Mr. Wolfe's irritation at the extent to which many contemporary architects seem to make words their priority,'' Mr. Goldberger said. ''But there is still a basically nonideological thrust to the best of post-modernist work around today.''

title: GUY SAINTY AND CYNTHIA VOLK ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hohne Volk of New York City and Quaker Hill, Pawling, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Holland Ash Volk, to Guy Stair Sainty, son of Mrs. Christopher Lawrence Sainty of London and the late Mr. Sainty.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY CHORALES

title: THE MIND IS A JUNK CLOSET
description: HIDDEN somewhere in the convolutions of the brain is a closet. Normally, the closet door is closed, for good reason. Just like the closet in your back hall, this one is filled with junk.

title: WEATHER EYES; Play It Again
description: The consolation common to all writers who receive rejection slips is the thought that the people who send them ought to have their heads examined. It is a consolation that a Californian named Chuck Ross is happy to support.

title: Hearing Postponed
description: Dick Howser, the manager of the Kansas City Royals, and his batting coach, Rocky Colavito, were granted a second continuance of their rehearing on charges of hindering and interfering with police officers in Kansas City, Mo.

title: SPORTS SUNDAY
description: Basketball Nets vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel 7:30 P.M., Radio - WVNJ 620 AM, 7:30 P.M.) Los Angeles Lakers vs Philadelphia 76ers, at Inglewood, Calif.

title: Texas
description: To the Editor: In his excellent, sympathetic essay ''A Critic Casts a Kindly Eye on Texas'' (Travel, Oct. 31), Jacques Barzun, after admitting to a general grasp of Texas history, perceptively comments that ''What is harder to determine is who this folk is or are.''

title: THE RETURN OF THE REIT'S
description: IN 1979, the Chase Manhattan Bank had a disaster on its hands. Its Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust Company, the biggest of the ill-fated real estate investment trusts, was forced into bankruptcy after many of its $1 billion in construction and development loans had gone sour. It was one of the darkest moments for the nation's third-largest bank. Along with many other banks, Chase lost millions of dollars before the whole affair was over and, since its name was attached to the REIT, the failure inevitably sullied the bank's reputation as well.

title: They're Off and Skiing
description: The 1982-83 World Cup skiing season begins today at Pontresina, Switzerland, with a field of more than 80 competitors taking part in a men's downhill event, including Steve Podborski of Canada and Harti Weirather of Austria, the downhill world champion. But Phil Mahre of Yakima, Wash., will not begin the defense of his World Cup championship until Thursday and Friday at Val d'Isere, France, where a downhill, supergiant slalom and a combined event will be held. Mahre was the first American to win the overall World Cup title in 1981 and repeated the feat this year.

title: A Correction
description: A table in The Week in Review of Nov. 28 effectively understated the numbers of long-range nuclear weapons. Counting bombs and multiple-warhead capacities of missiles, estimates from official briefings are that the United States has more than 9,000 deliverable warheads and the Soviet Union approximately 8,500.

title: Clerc Leaves Hospital
description: Jose-Luis Clerc was reported on his way to Miami yesterday after having spent Friday night in Northwestern Memorial Hospital outside Chicago. Clerc collapsed on the tennis court Friday afternoon while warming up for a doubles match in the $300,000 World Championship Tennis Chicago Open at the International Amphitheater.

title: JANE HETTLEMAN AND FRANK PORTER TO MARY IN APRIL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Hettleman of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Hettleman, to Frank Porter of Bridgeton, N.J. son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Porter of Bridgeton, N.J.

title: ILYSE MICHELLE ROSENTHAL MARRIES STEVEN G. KORSHAK
description: Ilyse Michelle Rosenthal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour A. Rosenthal of Forest Hills, Queens, and Steven G. Korshak, son of Lenore Korshak of Los Angeles, and the late James Korshak, were married yesterday by Rabbi Ben Zion Bokser, assisted by Cantor Erno Grosz, at the Westbury Hotel in New York.

title: Southern Cal Women Defeat Louisiana Tech
description: Paula McGee scored 22 points and grabbed 11 rebounds tonight to lead top-ranked Southern California to a 64-58 victory over Louisiana Tech, the No.2-ranked team and the defending women's collegiate basketball champion.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
IN FREEPORT, A REVIVAL OF GRACEFUL LIVING
description: SUBURBAN counterparts of those who renewed brownstownes in city n eighborhoods like Brooklyn Heights and Park Slope are hard at work i n the village of Freeport, restoring gracious homes that were built i n the early part of this century.

title: LETTERS BROUGHT HER TO BROADWAY
description: She was young, stagestruck and poor. She lived in a tiny, furnished ground-floor apartment whose landlord turned off the heat during the day because none of the other tenants were home. She, however - swaddled in moth-eaten sweaters and old pants - spent her days as well as her nights there, chain-smoking and shivering and eking out a subsistence income as a script-reader.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Public Lending Right THE first of January will be a landmark for British authors, and admiring and envious American writers are circling the day on their calendars too. That is when P.L.R. - Public Lending Right - goes into effect. Under it British authors will begin to receive some payment for their books that have been borrowed from public libraries. Brigid Brophy, a British novelist who was among those who led the fight, said in an interview, ''It calls for three cheers. With the system in operation there's the hope of a flow of money to writers.''

title: Federal Study Links Alcohol To 55% of Fatal Car Crashes
description: A new Federal study of records in 15 states estimates that alcohol is involved in as many as 55 percent of all fatal highway crashes, contributing to 27,500 deaths and 700,000 other injuries each year.

title: Manila Hotel
description: To the Editor: Pamela G. Hollie's article on the Manila Hotel (''Colonial Comfort in the Philippines,'' Travel, Nov. 7) recalled my first experience of that famous establishment when I was a teen-ager. My father's salary as an engineer with the Philippine government had not permitted my mother to indulge the desire she had had since her arrival in the islands as a bride in 1912 to stay at the Manila Hotel. An insider who knew that a gold mine was running out of ore sold him stock. President Franklin D. Roosevelt revalued gold, more ore was discovered and suddenly we no longer needed to stay at a cheap boarding house when we went to Manila.$ My first stay at the Manila Hotel was in November 1935 and was undertaken because my mother wanted me to witness the arrival of Pan American Airways' flying boat ''China Clipper'' on the first commercial flight across the Pacific. We had a table in the big openair dining room next to that of Captain Ed Musick and his crew.

title: LETTERS
description: Laissez-Faire Landscape This is a comment on Russell W. Peterson's article ''Laissez-Faire Landscape'' (Oct. 31). I refer specifically to the paragraphs where he discusses the problems associated with acid rain. There he impugns the objectivity of the nine scientists who make up the committee appointed by the President's Science Adviser to conduct an impartial review of current activities in the area.

title: HELLO TO 'QUALITY' ON THIRD AVENUE
description: Can Fifth Avenue ambiance be replicated on Third Avenue? That is what Trafalgar House Real Estate, part of the multinational company that owns the Cunard Steam-Ship Company, has set out to do. Trafalgar is tearing down the Pinehurst Garage at Third Avenue and 70th Street, once the home of Rolls-Royces owned by Fifth and Park Avenue residents, to erect luxury condominiums that will attempt to ''bring that quality feeling to Third Avenue,'' according to Gary Stluka, manager of the project for the New York architectural firm Kohn, Pedersen & Fox.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: MERCHANTS along Newark's Mulberry Street, many of whom have occupied their stores for more than a generation, have won a major skirmish with city officials, but the war to remove them from the area is far from over.

title: MARRYING OLD AND NEW IN CONVERSIONS
description: ALTHOUGH the 18th Century Company of Durham is primarily engaged in preserving 17th- and 18th-century houses and barns by dismantling them and restoring them in new locations, the owner, William Norton, also uses period building materials in contemporary barn conversions and produces inventive solutions to problems of renovation.

title: PEVENTING ACHING BACKS
description: STRETCHING LOWER BACK EXTENSOR MUSCLES: Lie on the back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor or mat. Raise one knee to the chest as far as possible without straining or using the hands. Then return the foot to the floor with knee bent. Slide the heel out along the mat until the leg is straight. Gently roll the leg from side to side. Return to starting position and repeat with other leg. Repeat the exercise three to six times with each leg. STRETCHING HIP FLEXOR MUSCLES: Breathe out as you bring both knees toward chest. Hold one knee tightly to chest with arms. Slide other leg down until it is flat, trying to touch back of knee to the floor. Hold while counting out loud to six. Slowly return to the starting position. Relax. Alternate legs. Repeat five to six times with each leg.

title:
DINING OUT;
AURA OF ADVENTURE ON THE HUDSON
description: NEVER mind that the restaurant is one of more than two dozen bearing the same name or that it is a cousin to the Burger King empire. The Chart House not only provides good food but also effects a marked change of consciousness - cross the bridge over the railroad tracks just south of Dobb's Ferry Station to enter the tropical traces of another life style, one inherited from the first Chart House established in La Jolla, Calif. Restless angular architecture, views to the George Washington and Tappan Zee bridges, map-faced tables, photomurals of racing yachts and surfers, the river flowing at the back door - The Chart House promises adventure, discovery; it creates an aura of excitement, of going places.

title: POLICE SEEK LEADS IN ROBBERY SPREE
description: A task force of 30 detectives questioned witnesses, examined evidence and tracked leads yesterday in a widening hunt for three gunmen who staged 11 predawn robberies Friday, breaking into homes and accosting victims on streets in Queens and Brooklyn.

title: OVERCOMING A STUTTER
description: SMITHTOWN ''IAM still a stutterer, but I have learned a skill that enables me to control my speech,'' Bill Preble told an audience of about 30 at the New York Avenue School here without stuttering or hesitation.

title: CANDIDATES AIMING AT NEW HAMPHSIRE
description: With the midterm elections and Senator Edward M. Kennedy's withdrawal behind them, Democrats with Presidential ambitions are preparing in earnest for their march on New Hampshire and the nation's first primary.

title: Downhill Terrors
description: To the Editor: It is obvious from Peter Benchley's enjoyable article ''The Little Joys (And Terrors) of Family Skiing'' (Travel, Nov. 7) that he has never heard that the three most dangerous words in downhill skiing are: ''Follow me, Dad.'' ELINOR S. PROCKOP Princeton, N.J.

title: Louisiana Sues for $9 Million In Chemical Spill by Railroad
description: The State of Louisiana sued the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad and other parties Thursday for $9.8 million in damages as a result of a derailment of a train carrying chemicals that exploded and burned for two weeks.

title: BATTLE BETEEN CHAVEZ AND DISSIDENTS WIDENS
description: The rift between the leadership and dissidents in the United Farm Workers has been widened with the union's filing of a $22 million slander and libel suit against nine Salinas farm workers.

title: ALTERNATIVE TO REAGANOMICS
description: I have been in business for 34 years and I believe we are facing the most dangerous worldwide economic situation of my professional experience. We are facing it with a political philosophy that appears to be uncaring and backward and without a governmental process worthy of the name. We are facing it with less international cooperation than at any time since World War II.

title: HEART PATIENT UNDERGOES SURGERY TO CORRECT AIR LEAK COMPLICATION
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, who on Thursday became the first recipient of a permanent artificial heart, was taken back to the operating room this evening so doctors could correct the first complication to his recovery. In a one-hour operation, the doctors sealed several leaking air-filled blisters in Dr. Clark's lungs that they said were unrelated to his artificial heart mechanism.

title: Mobile Yields On Elections
description: Challenges to at-large local elections, which can effectively shut out minorities, have been the cutting edge of voting rights advances for a decade. Until last week, when Mobile officials said they would not appeal in the fourth round of a seven-year law suit for city council elections by district, few cities have been as resistant as the Alabama seaport.

title: MANAGUA PROTESTS INCURSIONS
description: The Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry, asserting that Honduran troops and anti-Government exiles living in Honduras had attacked two Nicaraguan border towns, sent a protest note to Honduras today that called the situation ''highly dangerous.''

title: SOME WAYS TO HOLD OFF THE SHERIFF
description: FALLING behind on mortgage payments and facing foreclosure can be a b itter and traumatic experience, but sometimes the situation may not b e as bleak as it first appears. With some talking, counseling, and n egotiations, it may be possible to postpone your monthly payments orr educe them until your situation improves.

title: CAROL ANN LIPETZ AND WARREN D. WOESSNER ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gordon M. Lipetz of Southampton, L.I., and Pompano Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ann Lipetz, to Warren Dexter Woessner, son of Mrs. Flora D. Woessner of Woodstown, N.J., and the late Dr. Warren D. Woessner.

title: Angler Still Awaits Prize for Big Bass
description: MORE than two months have passed since Albert McReynolds of Atlantic City hauled a 78 1/2-pound striped bass from thesurf, a potential world record for the species.

title:
ART;
SHOWING HOW AND WHAT TO DRAW
description: SOUTHAMPTON TWO complementary exhibitions on view at the Parrish Art Museum offer some illuminating examples of drawing as depiction and expression, as observation and self-revealing interpretation. A broad spectrum of artistic sensibility is made manifest, and not a few traditional notions about the act of drawing and the meaning - or meanings - of the word are called into question.

title: JURY GIVEN LESSON IN HOLLYWOOD LIFE
description: Eight women and four men boarded vans this week and were handed a document titled: ''Jury Viewing Itinerary, Night 1, Yolanda Washington and Judy Miller.''

title: House Tries to Get a Handle On Nuclear Waste
description: On the 40th anniversary of the first nuclear chain reaction, the House of Representatives approved legislation last week for getting rid of decades' worth of radioactive waste. The bill laid out a timetable by which Government would choose a permanent burial site.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: The 97th Congress rolled into Washington last week for its last sitting, a three-week special session convened mostly to deal with money bills the lawmakers left hanging when they adjourned to campaign. It passed the week mostly doing other things, including setting the tone for the agenda of the 98th. Senate majority leader Howard H. Baker drew the line. ''We're never going to save our way out of the recession,'' Mr. Baker warned the White House, even as the White House budget office forecast that the Federal deficit would hit $200 billion in the mid-1980's unless more budget cuts were made or more taxes raised - recovery or no.

title: CHINA MOVES TO RESURRECT A CREDIBLE LEGAL SYSTEM
description: In a courtroom in northeastern Shanghai, the defendant stood accused of embezzling three tons of steel plate from his factory by diverting it to a commune's agricultural machinery plant under a false bill of lading.

title: STOPPARD GETS EMOTIONAL
description: Benedict Nightingale writes frequently about theater in London. LONDON Tom Stoppard's plays are clever, detached, sophisticated, scintillating; and that, it has sometimes been said, is what is wrong as well as right with them. They aren't committed enough politically, and they lack emotional power. The first of these two accusations Mr. Stoppard has answered with such relatively recent works as ''Every Good Boy Deserves Favor'' and ''Professional Foul,'' two pieces about the abuse of human rights in Eastern Europe; but the second has continued to haunt him. Wasn't he the dramatist who sent the protagonists of ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead'' to their violent ends with a shrug, a smile and a wry quip on their lips? Yes - and he has not created a single character in the 16 years since that dazzling debut who could honestly be said to suffer pain.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TRIES TO SELL ITS ARMS
description: In the five years that South Africa has been the target of a mandatory United Nations arms embargo, its shopping in the international arms market has by necessity been clandestine. Now, in hopes of drumming up enough business to help sustain its own growing armaments industry, it is eagerly calling attention to its readiness to deal from the other side of the counter as a seller.

title: ECUMENICAL GROUP AIDING THE LATINS
description: Liberation theology, a form of contemporary Christianity with its roots in Latin American Catholicism, has become the basis for the ecumenical ministry called the New York Circus, housed on Manhattan's Upper West Side and dealing mainly with problems of Latin American immigrants in the city.

title: SUSAN YOUNG IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Young of Rye, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan April Young, to Mark Eliot Sosnowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Sosnowitz of Greenwich, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Writer of Article On Svetlana Castigated
description: As a longtime friend of Svetlana Alliluyeva, I take exception to the article by Julie Aberger (Speaking Personally, Nov. 28). Not only was it devoid of any current information about the subject, but the few facts presented were erroneous, including even the most basic fact - the name. Svetlana, in total repudiation of her father's policies, had long ago taken her mother's name, Alliluyeva, and has never been known in this country as Svetlana Stalin.

title: JET DEFENSE CONTINUES TO EXCEL
description: Like old times, Joe Gardi bellows ''Swarm!'' and the Jets' defense -pro football's second-stingiest in yielding yardage - stings the ball-carrier.

title: 12 Drowned in South Africa
description: A bus carrying 60 passengers rolled down an embankment and came to rest upside down in a culvert, drowning 12 passengers and injuring 20 others, the South African Press Association reported today. The accident occurred Friday 150 miles west of here.

title: 29 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Health Department last week cited 29 food establishments for violations of the health code. Five others were reopened after correcting previous violations, and seven were closed for failing to comply.

title: JUNE
description: Dr. and Mrs. James W. Smith of Greenwich and Madison, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lucinda Ann Smith, to Richard James Hay, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Douglas Hay of Toronto.

title: ...AND ON THE HIGHWAYS, BETTING ON BETTER DRIVERS
description: ''T HERE is too much focus on building cars safe for people unskilled in driving,'' said Representative Robert S. Walker. The Republican from Pennsylvania offered this rather novel opinion last week in support of the Reagan Administration's new automobile safety program. The occasion was a series of hearings on small car safety, or unsafeness. But participants, such as Mr. Walker, included a few sidetrips into Federal policies on highway safety and automobile design.

title: HIGH COURT TO HEAR AD CASE
description: WASHINGTON DO UNSOLICITED mailed advertisements for condoms violate a person's right to privacy? Or are such advertisements protected by the constitutional right to free speech?

title: A TALK WITH GABRIEL GARCIA MARQUEZ
description: The playful, imperturbable Gabriel Garcia Marquez was troubled and tense. His brown eyes and the large wart over his mustache seemed to have shrunk. He had buried his hands deep in the pockets of his navy blue overalls and paced his hotel room in this small Central Mexican town, where he had come to escape a barrage of well-wishers and journalists.

title: THE GALLERIA: MEASURING ITS SUCCESS
description: WHITE PLAINS WHEN the $100 million Galleria shopping mall opened here two years ago, its developer, Cadillac Fairview, promised it would be ''a unique shopping experience'' and Mayor Alfred DelVecchio forecast that it would ''give the city a heartbeat.''

title: THERE'S POETRY IN THE NEWEST OFFICE PORTALS
description: IN the years following World War II, the entranceways to many New York office buildings were treated like throwaway spaces to be u sed only as passages from sidewalks to elevators. Even when entries w ere dressed up with art works, the paintings, tapestries and s culptures often were undistinguished, had little relationship to t heir surroundings and clearly seemed to be afterthoughts.

title: LONDON ESPIONAGE TRIAL SPURS DEBATE IN CANADA
description: The London espionage trial of a Quebec economics professor has led to calls in Canada's Parliament for a fuller explanation of the case and has raised broader questions about the effectiveness of Canada's security laws.

title: SHOPS 6 MILES APART BUILD CUSTOM BIKES
description: CUSTOM building of bicycle frames is the business of two young craftsmen in the Connecticut River Valley. Richard Sachs of Chester and J.P. (Peter) Weigle of East Haddam, who each charge upward of $700 for a frame, have waiting lists of customers - serious racers, long-distance tour enthusiasts and people who just enjoy bicycling.

title: Foes of Army Win in Uruguay
description: Uruguay used to be so stable and prosperous that it was called the Switzerland of South America. It even copied the Swiss-style collective executive.

title: REV. J.R. WHITTEMORE WEDS MARY RICE
description: Mary Bolling Rice and the Rev. James Robinson Whittemore were married yesterday in the Chapel of St. James at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York performed the ceremony.

title: MIDDLE CLASS GETS HELP WITH HOUSING
description: People earning up to $58,000 a year in one of the nation's wealthiest counties will soon qualify for subsidized mortgages on new homes costing as much as $160,000.

title: THE MODERATING OF INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON THE outstanding achievement of President Reagan's economic policy this year is the dramatic slowing of inflation. For the first time since the late 1960's, inflation is clearly on the run:

title: MARY G. RUDGE
description: Mary G. Rudge, an active fund-raiser for philanthropic groups and an honorary trustee of the New York Association for the Blind, died of a heart attack Thursday at her home in Manhattan. Mrs. Rudge, who also lived in Southampton, L.I., was 86 years old.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE Shoreham nuclear power plant squats, all but complete, on the sunlit shore, framed by hills and trees and Sound. Its lines are simple, a cylinder and a cube, with a frieze of tanks and outbuildings at its base. From the road a mile away, across the bright tawny marsh grass, it looks insignificant.

title: FRIENDS OF THE OTHER SIDE'S PEACE GROUPS
description: To the Editor:

title:
CAMERA;
POINTERS ON TAKING BETTER PICTURES OF CHILDREN
CONCERT: ANGELENOS PLAY SCHUBERT AND BRUCKNER
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic under Carlo Maria Giulini continued its visit to New York on Friday night playing Schubert's Symphony No. 4 and the massive Bruckner Ninth at Carnegie Hall.

title: Mailbox; Thank You, John McEnroe
description: To the Sports Editor: I am so proud that John McEnroe plays for the United States in Davis Cup play.

title: GROWING MILITARY CONTRACTS KEEP SIKORSKY AT TOP PRODUCTION
description: STRATFORD WHILE many Fairfield County corporations are laying off employees, adopting shorter work weeks and other cost-cutting measures, business at Sikorsky Aircraft is better than ever, say company executives.

title: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1982
description: International Central America was urged by President Reagan to end ''foreign support for terrorists and subversive elements,'' in a speech from Costa Rica broadcast on television throughout the region. Ending a five-day visit to Latin America, Mr. Reagan then flew to Honduras for talks with President Roberto Suazo Cordova, Honduras's first civilian president in a decade, and with Guatemala's President, Gen. Efrain Rios Montt. In Costa Rica, he had talks with President Luis Alberto Monge. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Soviet Aide to Visit Japan
description: The Government has invited the Soviet Union's Fisheries Minister, Vladimir M. Kamentsev, to visit Japan to exchange views on fishing issues. A Foreign Ministry official said today that Mr. Kamentsev would be the first Cabinet-level Soviet official to visit here since Japan adopted sanctions against Moscow in response to its military intervention in Afghanistan in 1979.

title: VERMONT AND ITS HUNTERS BATTLING OVER DEER
description: When the Vermont Legislature handed over control of the state's wild deer to the Fish and Game Department in 1977, a decades-long debate was thought to be over.

title: BOOKS THAT GAVE ME PLEASURE
description: For the Christmas issue the Book Review asked a number of prominent people what they had enjoyed reading this year. John Barth got a kick out of his own most recent novel; Red Grooms got an idea for a sculpture from his reading. Three of our contributors found special pleasure in the novels of Barbara Pym; two in the works of Charles Darwin. Proust, Charlotte Bronte, Jane Austen and the Bible were mentioned; and one of our respondents, Anne Tyler, turned up among the choices of three others. Mario M. Cuomo Governor-elect of New York

title:
ANTIQUES;
TOYS THAT TAUGHT LESSONS
description: WEST HARTFORD THE collection of more than 200 toys now on exhibit at the Noah Webster Foundation and Historical Society on South Main Street was brought out for the occasion from the society's own storeroom and borrowed from members and friends.

title: Udall Considering Race For Presidency in 1984
description: Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, said Friday that he was seriously considering a bid for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination and would make up his mind in the next few weeks.

title: LETTERS
description: Political Profiles If newspapers throughout the country would give us side-by-side comprehensive views of the personalities and philosophies of political candidates, as your Lehrman-Cuomo articles did, perhaps we voters would lose some of our apathy and would choose our leaders more intelligently (''Cuomo: The Old Liberalism,'' by E..

title: MATSUSHITA: THE CAUTIOUS GIANT
description: OSAKA, Japan THE formula was set some six decades ago. A maverick entrepreneur, who had been orphaned as a child and quit two jobs before starting his own business, began with a grubstake of less than $100 and an electric light socket of his own design. When the business failed, he pawned his wife's kimono to stay afloat and designed an electric plug.

title: JOHN P. GIDEZ TO MARRY FRANCES ZIPOLI IN MARCH
description: Thomas A. Zipoli of Watertown, Conn., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Frances Antoinette Zipoli, to John Paul Gidez, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis I. Gidez of Demarest, N.J. A late March wedding is planned.

title:
A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: GIVE TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND;
WILL FOR INDEPENDENCE DESPITE HER HANDICAPS
description: ''IWAS in shock for almost a week - I couldn't sleep,'' said Nancy J, describing what happened after her apartment was vandalized last month.

title: STUDY SAYS POLLUTION IN ARCTIC COULD ORIGINATE FROM SOVIET
description: The air over the North American Arctic is being contaminated by pollution that might originate from heavily industrial areas of the central Soviet Union, a six-year study sponsored by the Office of Naval Research contends.

title: MANITOBA EAGER TO SELL ELECTRICITY
description: This prairie province, which produces a surplus of the cheapest electricity on the continent, is eager to expand its capacity still further. Manitoba's hope is to export electricity to utilities in the Middle West, where questions about thermal and nuclear plants are inhibiting the growth of power capacity.

title: INSIDE ANDROPOV'S MIND (2)
description: A couple of months ago, when last I shared my innermost thoughts with you in this space, I explained how I -Yuri Andropov - was going to gain control in the Kremlin after Brezhnev's death. Events have proceeded according to the plan I laid out then: Chernenko and the Brezhnev clique have been rebuffed, and Viktor Grishin has been told by Marshal Ustinov that he would have to wait his turn.

title: Mexico's Chill New World
description: Mexico's new President, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, has six years to make his mark, but the first 100 days are critical. He needs right away to convince foreign banks that Mexico is working its way back from near ruin, and to persuade his people that sacrifices are being exacted fairly with real hope of future benefit.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Of Songs and C.D.'s A woman found an oversized brown envelope recently on 42d Street and was startled to find in it ''a number of six-digit bank C.D.'s.'' The certificates of deposit bore the name of Irving Caesar, the 87-year-old lyricist of ''Tea for Two,'' ''Swanee,'' ''Just a Gigolo'' and other classics. Mr. Caesar was calm when the woman telephoned his midtown apartment.

title: Workers Strike New Haven Hotel
description: About 110 hotel workers walked off their jobs at the Park Plaza Hotel, the city's largest, at midnight Saturday after management refused to cancel a cost-cutting plan.

title: ALLEN PACES RAIDERS
description: Marcus Allen bounced back from an unproductive performance in Cincinnati last week to rush for 156 yards on 24 carries today as the Los Angeles Raiders held off the Seattle Seahawks, 28-23.

title: Books Of The Times
description: CHRISTINA'S WORLD. Paintings and Prestudies by Andrew Wyeth, with text by Betsy James Wyeth. 281 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $75 until Dec. 31; $90 thereafter.

title: MRS. BHUTTO ACCUSES U.S. OF DOUBLE STANDARD
description: The widow of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the former Pakistani Prime Minister who was executed in 1979, has accused the United States of using a double standard in its relations with the martial law Governments of Poland and Pakistan.

title: JUSTICE HAMPERED BY CHASE FOR COURT PAPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Wasting Precious Time on Waste
description: Two years of progress in planning for New York City's solid waste disposal has stopped dead because Comptroller Harrison Goldin noticed that the Board of Estimate was discussing a recovery plant in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard. People live near the yard, and they understandably do not want a garbage plant nearby.

title: Veteran in Stabbing Case Paroled on Stress Plea
description: A Vietnam veteran convicted of trying to kill a motorist has been granted parole on the basis of war-related stress.

title: PAUL BERGMANN
description: Paul Bergmann, president of the Marco Bergmann Company of New York, a wig-making concern, died of renal failure Friday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Mr. Bergmann, who lived in Manhattan, was 72 years old.

title: FAILURE TO REACH ACCORD IN LEBANON WORRIES U.S. AIDES
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that they were becoming increasingly concerned over the United States failure to initiate negotiations for the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon.

title: McCaffrey Gets T. Rowe Price
description: McCaffrey & McCall's 18-month-old direct marketing subsidiary has just won its biggest piece of business.

title:
ZIA'S STATE TERRORISM;
President Reagan and Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's selfappointed President, on Tuesday are expected to discuss the pace and composition of $3.2 billion in armaments and economic assistance to his regime and Pakistan's role in supporting Afghan rebels. Issues unlikely to be raised are General Zia's failure to honor his pledge - made more than five years ago - to restore constitutional government, and his total abolition of the rule of law.
description: On Sept. 27, General Zia decreed, by Martial Law Regulation 53, the death sentence for ''any offense liable to cause insecurity, fear, or despondency amongst the public.'' Crimes punishable under this measure, which supersedes civil law, include the following: ''Any act with intent to impair the efficiency or impede the working, or cause damage'' to public property or the smooth functioning of government; abetting ''in any manner whatsoever ... the commission of such an offense''; and failure to inform the police or army of the ''whereabouts or any other information about such a person.'' Thus, one is liable not merely for what one says or does but also for what one does not do.

title: NEW CHIEF AT AUTOMATIC DATA
description: Many companies do not get as much time as they would like to plan for changes at the top. But Automatic Data Processing Inc., whose chairman and chief executive officer, Frank R. Lautenberg, was just elected United States Senator from New Jersey, had more than a year.

title: LIFE OF DESTITUTE PROMPTS NEEDIEST CASES DONATION
description: The misfortune of New York City's poor and homeless motivates many charitable impulses, and Jeffrey Schultz of Manhattan has donated $1,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ''as my feeble acknowledgment of what life in this city is for far too many people.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INN THING

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp. will issue 965,022 shares of its common stock in exchange for $58.7 million principal of its 7 7/8 percent debentures, for a tax-free gain of $17.6 million.

title: THEATER: 'LES AND BESS' BREAKFAST
description: CALL it a guilty pleasure, but I'm a sucker for the type of lighter-than-air comedy that is exemplified by Lee Kalcheim's ''Breakfast With Les and Bess,'' which opened at the Hudson Guild last night. This is a play whose concerns border on the trivial, but whose writing is almost always professional. The jokes are not wisecracks, but derive from the characters; the feelings are sincere. ''Les and Bess'' is a delightful throwback to the romantic comedies of Broadway yore, back before the sloppy habits of situation-comedy writing eroded craft in our theater's boulevard entertainments.

title: 14 ARAB STUDENT OFFICERS DETAINED AT KENNEDY AFTER GUNS ARE SEIZED
description: Fourteen student officers of the United Arab Emirates Army on their way home from California were detained for five hours at Kennedy International Airport last night after their baggage was found to contain 60 guns and 10,000 rounds of ammunition.

title: RANGERS TOP LEAFS IN 6-5 SEESAW GAME
description: In a brief flashback to the heyday of their partnership on ice, Ulf Nilsson and Anders Hedberg combined to produce the winning goal for the Rangers last night.

title: GOVERNMENTAL BAD HABITS CALLED OBSTACLES TO PUBLIC-WORKS PLANS
description: New government efforts to repair long-neglected public works are being hampered by the same administrative problems that caused much of the disrepair, according to authorities on the subject.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POET FREED AFTER 7 YEARS
description: Breyten Breytenbach, who is widely held to be the most important living poet in the Afrikaans language, has been released from prison after serving seven years of a nine-year sentence for terrorism.

title: New Leader For Grace's Retail Group
description: Edward H. Tuton has been named group executive for W.R. Grace & Company's retail group, to succeed Robert H. Anderson, who is retiring Jan. 1.

title: GRETZKY CRACKS RECORD
description: Wayne Gretzky scored a goal and assisted on four others tonight to set a consecutive-game scoring record and lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 7-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: CITY PLANNING NEW AD DRIVE TO SAVE WATER
description: There may be some question about how New Yorkers respond when the city says in its public service messages: Don't smoke in bed. Don't spray graffiti on the walls. And, while you're at it, don't litter. But the campaign that asked them to save water - which took to the air in the middle of the 1980-81 drought emergency - worked so well that city officials are planning to try it again.

title: 2 I.R.A. AIDES TO VISIT LONDON
description: Two leaders of Sinn Fein, the political front of the Irish Republican Army, will visit London on Dec. 14, city officials said today. The announcement drew angry protests from Conservative legislators appalled by I.R.A. bomb attacks.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Political Job Market

title: ADVERTISING
description: Keynote Marketing has opened its doors at 303 Fifth Avenue as a specialty communications company in the wonderful world of books. Wonderful, but not booming.

title: GROUPS RACE TO PREVENT TEXAS EXECUTION
description: It was a painful decision for Jack Strickland. Five years ago, as the Terrant County District Attorney, he argued for the death penalty against Charlie Brooks, who was accused of slaying a man in Fort Worth. Barring a last-minute stay, Mr. Brooks would become the first person to die by lethal chemical injection early Tuesday morning.

title: DANCE: 'TRYING TIMES'
description: QUITE soon into the first act of David Gordon's gleefully perverse ''Trying Times,'' one observer felt sure that Mr. Gordon was demonstrating that art imitates life. Everything was mundane for much of the two-act work that the David Gordon-Pick Up Company offered Friday night at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: Ski Unit Tightens Amateur Rules
description: The International Ski Federation decided today to do away with the lucrative ''B'' license, which allowed ski racers to obtain sponsorship money while remaining technically amateur under international regulations.

title: 2 Men Are Killed In Fall From Cliff
description: Two local men died early today when they fell 100 feet from a cliff, the police said.

title: Louisiana Parish Investigates Begging by Krishna Clauses
description: Stepping out of their traditional white robes, members of the Hare Krishna religious sect are dressing like Santa Claus and soliciting contributions from Christmas shoppers, the Jefferson Parish Council reported.

title: LAWMAKERS BACK IN ALBANY TODAY FOR FISCAL TALKS
description: Members of the New York State Legislature return to Albany today to consider proposals to hold down bus, subway and commuter rail fares and to reduce the state's budget deficit.

title: 100 JOBS IN SAUDI ARABIA SPAWN YEARLONG SEARCH
description: In the promotional literature of Boyden Associates, the big executive search firm, it is noted, ''On any given day, Boyden's worldwide offices are working on over 400 searches. Currently the typical Boyden search falls within the $40,000-$80,000 salary range and takes an average of 90 days to complete.''

title: ARBOUR CALM AS ISLANDERS FRET
description: Many times this season Al Arbour, the coach of the beleaguered Islanders, has been exasperated by the performance of his players, even when they won.

title: McENROE DEFEATED BY LENDL
description: Ivan Lendl defeated John McEnroe, 3-6, 7-6, 6-3, 6-3, today and become the first winner of the European Champions tournament.

title: Bruins 6, Flyers 4
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Barry Pederson continued his scoring spree with his second three-goal game in two days, helping Boston to stretch its unbeaten streak to seven games.

title: Leader in Attica Riot Is Slain
description: A leader of the 1971 prison uprising in Attica, N.Y., who later waged a one-man war against narcotics traffic in his neighborhood, died in an ambush by angry drug pushers, the police said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have no scorched earth policy. We have a policy of scorched Communists.''

title: DANCE: 'VIRGIN'S CAROLE'
description: THE world of the Renaissance mystery or miracle play came alive Saturday night, when the Ananda Dancers presented ''A Virgin's Carole'' at Christ and St. Stephen's Church.

title: EVERYTHING CHANGES ON THE CAVALIERS BUT THE FACE OF FAILURE
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio EUGENE and Frank, a pair of program vendors, were leaning against a wall in the mezzanine of the Coliseum here. It was in the first quarter of last Wednesday night's quiet game against the Knicks. From their vantage point, the vendors could gaze upon the canyon of empty yellow and brown seats, nearly 18,000 of them.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART RESEARCH NOW SEEKS A PORTABLE AND 'FORGETTABLE' DEVICE
description: The artificial heart now beating in the chest of Dr. Barney B. Clark is a dramatic step in a long effort that has a much larger goal: development of a heart that is reliable, permanent and ''forgettable,'' the term the heart's chief designer, Dr. Robert K. Jarvik, uses to define his objective.

title: TOUGH LESSONS AT NOTRE DAME
description: Asked last month to name the person responsible for the difficult early schedule for his Notre Dame basketball team, Coach Digger Phelps said: ''I'm that bad guy. But it's just a time for learning.''

title: JOHNSON HELPS NETS WIN FOURTH IN ROW
description: When Mickey Johnson was traded from the Milwaukee Bucks to the Nets last month, he was joining the fifth team in his nine-year pro career. The move caused him some despair, but he says he has stopped feeling sorry for himself.

title: TV: KIRK DOUGLAS ROLE
description: ''REMEMBRANCE OF LOVE,'' NBC's television movie at 9 this evening, is an unsettling experience for reasons having nothing to do with the intentions of the producers. Harold Jack Bloom's script uses - and that is the precise word - the 1981 World Gathering of Holocaust Survivors in Israel as the basis for a romantic melodrama. The result is questionable entertainment drenched in facile sentimentality.

title: ISRAELI INQUIRY ON MASSACRE CLEARS HADDAD FORCES
description: The state commission investigating the Beirut massacre announced today that it had no evidence of any involvement by the Lebanese Christian militia commanded by Maj. Saad Haddad.

title: Washington Watch; A New Tactic For Low Rates
description: WASHINGTON THE continuing effort by Congress to nudge the Federal Reserve in the direction of lower interest rates - but nothing inflationary, please - has taken an interesting turn in the last few days.

title: Indians Cut Back Plan For Black Hills Camp
description: Indians who are suing to save their Yellow Thunder Camp in the Black Hills said they are willing to reduce its size, but a lawyer for the Government said the change makes no difference.

title: HARD, FAST START FOR ECONOMICS AIDE
description: He did a press breakfast and two speeches on Monday, a half-hour television interview Tuesday, another press breakfast Wednesday, a speech Thursday night to the directors of the 12 Federal Reserve banks and an address Saturday to the British-North American Committee, a business group.

title: Third Bulgarian Linked To Attack on the Pope
description: The Italian Foreign Ministry wants the diplomatic immunity of a Bulgarian Embassy employee lifted so that he can be arrested for complicity in the 1981 attack on Pope John Paul II, sources said today.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1982
description: International The U.S. failure to start negotiations for the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon is worrying senior Reagan Administration officials. They said that because of the impasse it was now virtually impossible that the troops would leave by the end of the year, the date set by the State Department. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel cleared a close Lebanese ally of any involvement in the massacre of hundreds of Palestinians in the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps near Beirut last September. The state commission investigating the massacre said it had no evidence that forces of Maj. Saad Haddad, leader of a Lebanese Christian militia, had participated in the killings. (A11:1-6.)

title: It's Children Who Are Being Cheated
description: The national school lunch program is an anomaly among social programs in that, until recently, all it has asked from its participants is honesty. Parents applying for free or reduced-price lunches were asked only to declare their incomes.

title: A Maverick Fighter In Pursuit of Pabst
description: He is a private man who rarely gives interviews. His estate in northern California's wealthy Marin County separates him from neighbors. And those who know Paul Kalmanovitz, the multimillionaire beer executive, say he is a maverick businessman who is strong-willed and who will fight to the end in a takeover battle. Mr. Kalmanovitz how has a chance to show these qualities.

title: BUSH PLEDGES TO WIN ENACTMENT OF CARIBBEAN PLAN
description: Vice President Bush said tonight that the Reagan Administration ''will do everything in our power'' to persuade Congress to approve the remaining parts of its Caribbean Basin Initiative before the end of the current term.

title: UCONN OUSTED BY DUKE
description: Charles Guevara and David McDaniel scored goals today to lead Duke to a 2-1 victory over Connecticut, the defending champion, in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament.

title: RECOVERY RESUMES FOR HEART PATIENT
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the recipient of the world's first permanent artificial heart, was reported to be sleepy and comfortable today but more reserved about what had been a surprisingly smooth recovery until new surgery was required Saturday night.

title: MEXICAN LEADER WANTS 'RESPECTFUL' U.S. TIES
description: The new President of Mexico, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, said in an interview over the weekend that he wanted ''cordial and respectful'' relations with the United States and a more stable trade balance between the two countries.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1982; The Economy
description: Economic growth is likely to resume early in 1983, according to surveys of professional forecasters. But there are questions about the durability of the recovery. Many say that hinges on a continued decline in interest rates. (Page D1.)

title: ISRAELI ACADEMICS FOR MENACHEM BEGIN
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPECT SURRENDERS IN SPREE OF ROBBERIES AND BEATINGS
description: A Brooklyn man surrendered to the police yesterday and was charged in three of 11 robberies committed early Friday by gunmen who kicked in the doors of homes and apartments in Queens and Brooklyn and accosted other victims in the streets.

title: OPERA: FIRST VERSION OF BEETHOVEN'S 'FIDELIO'
description: ALICE TULLY HALL turned itself into an opera house for a few - well, more than a few - hours Saturday afternoon. The Princeton University Opera Theater was in town, bringing with it what was purported to be the first staged presentation in New York of Beethoven's original ''Fidelio.''

title: Carnes Re-Elected By Track Group
description: The Athletics Congress closed its fourth annual convention today by re-electing Jimmy Carnes as president and awarding the 1984 United States Olympic marathon trials for women to Olympia, Wash.

title: No Headline
description: FLOYD WINS IN PLAYOFF

title: RECOVERY'S DURABILITY IN DISPUTE
description: Economic growth is very likely to resume early in 1983, fueled by increased investment in housing and a general rise in consumer outlays.

title: Fibak Victor
description: Wojtek Fibak of Poland, scoring with passes and neat backhand drop shots, won the World Championship Tennis Chicago Open today by defeating Bill Scanlon of Dallas, 6-3, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.

title: ROBINSON SLUMP HURTS KNICKS
description: Eddie Donovan once said: ''The good trades are those that help both teams. If they don't, they are bad trades.'' Considering that logic, and considering that their team has a 5-13 record, Dave DeBusschere, the Knicks' director of basketball operations; Donovan, the director of player personnel, and Coach Hubie Brown made a bad trade last July when they sent Maurice Lucas to the Phoenix Suns for Len (Truck) Robinson.

title: MITCHELL'S RUNNING SPURS CARDS' VICTORY
description: The St. Louis Cardinals won a game yesterday without Ottis Anderson, their leading running back who was sidelined by recurring chest pains. His replacement, Stump Mitchell, came through with 145 yards rushing, including a 32-yard touchdown run, in the 23-20 victory over the Eagles at Philadelphia.

title: PAKISTAN'S ROLE IN KABUL
description: When President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan meets President Reagan tomorrow, the least advertised but most momentous topic on their agenda will be how to reconcile the significant differences now developing between Islamabad and Washington over future policy toward Afghanistan.

title: Australia's Ruling Party Claims Election Success
description: Australia's ruling Liberal Party claimed victory today in a special election caused by the retirement of the party's former deputy leader and Industry Minister, Sir Phillip Lynch.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A WINNING SMILE
description: President Reagan and his weary staff were on the way from Brasilia to Bogota on Friday morning when they received word from the United States Embassy that Colombia's new President, Belisario Betancur, planned to assail the United States in his public remarks.

title: Edward Teller in Israel To Advise on a Reactor
description: Edward Teller is in Israel to advise the Government on building a nuclear reactor for peaceful purposes, a spokesman for the Ministry of Science said today.

title: CHILE RIGHTS ABUSES PERSIST, MONITORS IN COUNTRY REPORT
description: Although there is budding political expression in Chile, now in its 10th year of military rule, widespread abuses of human rights continue, according to human rights groups and Roman Catholic Church officials.

title: CHARLES PROFFITT, FORMER HEAD OF COLUMBIA PRESS, DIES AT 86
description: Charles G. Proffitt, who as president of Columbia University Press helped make it one of the nation's most prominent academic presses, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 86 years old.

title: U.S. May Aid 3 Fuel Plants
description: The Government's Synthetic Fuels Corporation, which is responsible for distributing billions of dollars to encourage development of alternatives to oil and gas, has selected proposed plants in California, New Mexico and North Carolina for possible assistance totaling as much as $557 million.

title: TV'S 'BLOOD AND HONOR' DRAWS HUGE RESPONSE
description: When "Blood and Honor" was aired on West German television last August, it attracted more than 50 percent of the available viewers - and prompted an extraordinary outpouring of 10,000 letters, several of them as long as 50 pages.

title: 60-SECOND DEBATE
description: Nancy Landon Kassebaum Republican Senator from Kansas

title: Braun's Big Night
description: Thirty-five years ago today, a skinny rookie from Colgate scored 47 points for the Knicks to set a National Basketball Association scoring record. In only his seventh game as a professional, Carl Braun connected on 18 of 36 shots from the field and all 11 of his free throws to break the mark of 41 set the previous season by Joe Fulks of the Philadelphia Warriors.

title: Liquidator Named at El Al
description: The district court in Jerusalem today appointed an interim liquidator for El Al Israel Airlines.

title: Skirling at the Waldorf
description: Bagpipes and kilts enlivened the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel during weekend events of the 226-year-old St. Andrew Society, including a dinner for 700 in the grand ballroom. But Scottish-Americans heard more than nostalgia from Glasgow's Lord Provost, or Mayor, who bears the somewhat unlikely name of Michael Kelly.

title: COSELL SAYS, 'I'VE HAD IT'
description: HOWARD COSELL'S disaffection with boxing did not begin as he broadcast the Larry Holmes-Tex Cobb mismatch 10 days ago. That event was merely the catalyst for him to call for the end of professional boxing, one of the most public criticisms the business has ever taken.

title: Crossbow Injures Ulster Man
description: A 20-year-old man was hospitalized today with a crossbow bolt in his head after he had apparently been demonstrating how to fire the weapon, the police reported. The condition of the man, who was not identified, was ''very serious,'' a spokesman said. Crossbows have been used in Ulster's feuding between Protestants and Roman Catholics since violence flared in the province in August 1969.

title: Hatch Has Tendon Surgery
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, underwent surgery Saturday for a torn Achilles tendon.

title: 'All Lies,' Soviet Attache Says of Spying Charges
description: The Soviet naval attache expelled from Britain for spying flew home to Moscow today, insisting that the allegations against him were ''all lies.''

title: Jury Grants $4.18 Million In Georgia Strike Case
description: A jury has awarded a man $4.18 million in damages in a lawsuit in which he asserted that the Georgia Kraft Company maliciously prosecuted him in an effort to break a labor strike.

title: KANGAROOS WIN
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: AILEY 'SATYRIADE' AND 3 DUETS IN 'WAVES'
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is certainly starting out on the right foot this season. Its latest success is ''Satyriade,'' a premiere by Mr. Ailey himself, followed closely by the company premiere of Kathryn Posin's modern-dance piece ''Waves.''

title: News Analysis
description: Three months after President Reagan announced his peace proposal for the Middle East, United States diplomacy in the region appears to be floundering, according to senior Lebanese officials and Western diplomats.

title: Tests Awaited in Burn Case
description: An immigrant dishwasher who died Nov. 28 near the grave of John F. Kennedy in Arlington Cemetery may have drunk too much and fallen into the memorial flame, the Park Police said today. Sgt. Clem Warner said laboratory test results were being awaited to determine the cause of death of Noof Ramon Mejia, 44 years old, who came from El Salvador in 1974. His partly burned body was found a few feet from the flame.

title: Matchup of the Year
description: A matchup that some college basketball buffs think was made in heaven will take place Saturday night at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md. In what may be the most anticipated regular-season meeting since Lew Alcindor and U.C.L.A. opposed Elvin Hayes's Houston team at the Astrodome in 1968, Virginia and Georgetown will bring undefeated records into a game that will give the winner the No.1 ranking. Last week both major wire services listed the Cavaliers No.1 and the Hoyas No. 2.

title: Guess Who's Guest?
description: In the 14 years that Tony Basileo has operated Mimmo's Restaurant in Westbury, L.I., he has come to be friendly with many trainers and drivers from Roosevelt Raceway, the harness racing track he says is ''just across the street.''

title: Commodities; Copper Market Is Glutted
description: THE copper pipeline is full, so full that prices of futures contracts reflect neither hope of a housing recovery nor of a rebound in the auto industry. Copper goes into the plumbing for new houses, and it is heavily used also in the auto industry. But commodity analysts have been talking little about a recovery next year.

title: News Analysis
description: There are many reasons why efforts to get the Lebanese and the Israelis to sit down and discuss the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon have been bogged down, not the least of which is Israel's desire eventually to forge a peace treaty with its northern neighbor.

title: 25 Colombia Guerrillas Freed Under Amnesty
description: Twenty-five members of the Colombian leftist guerrilla group known as M-19, including its founder, Carlos Toledo Plata, have been freed from jail under a new amnesty law, prison authorities said.

title: Market Place; Propane Stake Of Belzbergs
description: WHEN Samuel Belzberg, the Canadian businessman, joined his brothers, William and Hyman, three years ago to buy a 5 percent slice of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, Wall Street seemed perplexed.

title: LEGISLATORS STUDY JERSEY DEFICIT
description: Both houses of the Legislature will return here Monday for voting sessions as legislative leaders begin party conferences to search for ways to close a $150 million budget deficit.

title: U.S. Studies Trials of Juveniles
description: Most juveniles tried in adult courts are charged not with acts of violence, but with property crimes or minor offenses such as public drunkenness, a new Federally financed study says.

title: CHILDREN PREPARE FOR 'THEIR' NEW BABIES
description: ''It may be a boy or it may be a girl, or maybe I'm going to have two of them,'' Alethea Torrellas, 3 1/2 years old, said as she peered intently through the window of the nursery for newborns at Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center recently.

title: FOLK SONG: BURL IVES AS EVER
description: BURL IVES'S kindly folk music is so deeply ingrained in the national psyche that it is very easy to take him for granted. And at his sold-out concert at the Herbert H. Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts yesterday afternoon, it was clear that a large portion of the audience had been brought up listening to his children's records.

title: The Talk of Howard Beach
description: They are not used to armed robbery in the middle of the night in Howard Beach. It is a neighborhood where children ride double on expensive bicycles and play football in the street, where on a particularly warm December weekend people raked leaves, washed their cars or cleaned out their garages.

title: BRIEFING
description: Opening at State

title: Advertising; Conflicts And Marion Harper
description: LAST week, when Scali, McCabe, Sloves got the $20 million Continental Air Lines account despite the fact that the agency's parent company, Ogilvy & Mather, handles the competing Trans World Airlines, attention was focused once again on the age-old agency problem of client conflict.

title: 2,500 U.S. Soldiers Reported Holding Maneuvers in Oman
description: About 2,500 United States soldiers are on maneuvers in Oman, testing defenses in the event of a Soviet or other foreign attack on the Persian Gulf region, Arab diplomatic sources said today.

title: No Headline
description: GUATEMALAN VOWS TO AID DEMOCRACY

title: D'Amato Opposes Health-Benefit Tax
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato today criticized a plan being pressed by some members of the Reagan Administration under which the Government would tax part of the health insurance benefits paid by employers.

title: DeLOREAN LAWYERS SEEK THE DETAILS OF U.S. CASE
description: The Government's case against John Z. DeLorean, charged with promoting a cocaine-selling scheme, is shaping up as a two-man show centered on the credibility of the maverick automaker and of the paid informer who contributed much to the Government's investigation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Parachute-Cloth Art For an Airport Anniversary

title: The Catch By Woolfolk
description: 14 victory over the Houston Oilers yesterday at Giants Stadium with only three and a half minutes remaining. He made the catch by reaching up with those long fingers on his right hand, which almost resembles a baseball glove, and snatching a pass from Scott Brunner for a 40-yard touchdown. And every few minutes now, he was asked to describe that one-hand catch.

title: ADDITIONAL RATE DROPS FORECAST
description: A weak economy remains the primary reason why predictions of further declines in interest rates are widespread. Though the steep fall in short- and long-term rates in the last five months has improved the prospects for an end to the recession, the consensus among credit market participants seems to be that the improvement in the economy has so far been narrowly based in housing and construction activity. Lower mortgage rates have helped revive the housing market but have been of little benefit to the rest of the economy, where factory orders decline and unemployment rises.

title: ROCK: BRITISH CULTURE CLUB
description: LIKE many other English groups nowadays, the pop quartet Culture Club blends soul, rock, funk, reggae and salsa into a music that programmatically reconciles white, black and Latin styles. But in the hands of the Culture Club, which performed at the Ritz on Friday and Saturday, the idea of thoroughly blending these musical cultures isn't just trend following, as it has become with other groups, but a passionate obsession.

title: DR. GARY KRIGSMAN MARRIES HELEN EICHLER, A LAWYER
description: Helen Pam Eichler, daughter of Harry Eichler of Richmond Hill, Queens, and the late Ethel Eichler, was married yesterday to Dr. Gary Krigsman, son of Sylvia Krigsman of Brooklyn, and the late Harry Krigsman. Rabbis Salamon Faber and Joel Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: GRAND MOZAMBIQUE HOTEL: HISTORY'S LODGING PLACE
description: The water, it is true, does not run hot and at breakfast guests desirous of preserves or butter bring their own to the table, clutching them possessively in polyethythene bags.

title: ZIMBABWE STILL PRESSING HUNT FOR 6 TOURISTS
description: A search for six tourists, including two Americans, kidnapped by gunmen loyal to a Zimbabwean opposition leader has entered its 20th week with no clues to their whereabouts.

title: FLOW OF NEW OFFERINGS SLOWS A BIT
description: The flow of new corporate and tax-exempt bonds continues to be heavy but should be less than the November pace. According to Salomon Brothers, $3.8 billion of corporate notes and bonds were sold in November, but only $1 billion of new issues have been scheduled in the next four weeks.

title: DEBRA FREEDMAN IS MARRIED TO ANDREW W. SIDMAN
description: Debra Michele Freedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Freedman of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew William Sidman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Sidman of Bethpage, L.I. Rabbi Louis Stein performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel.

title: 10 UTILITIES FORCED TO CHECK X-RAYS
description: One utility has spent $2 million and nine others have spent thousands of dollars more tracking down doctored X-rays of welds in nuclear power plants, the companies have said.

title: Chief of Bobbie Brooks Quits After 10 Months
description: Lawrence Halpern has resigned as president and chief executive of Bobbie Brooks Inc., a leading but troubled women's apparel maker based in Cleveland.

title: INSURERS' FAIRNESS OR DISCRIMINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Minnesota Tax Package Going Before Legislature
description: Gov. Albert H. Quie and legislative leaders agreed Saturday on another round of tax increases to shore up the state's finances, and called a special session for Tuesday to present it.

title: HOWDY, GENGHIS
description: Under the name of ''anti-Communism,'' the President of the United States has just had a friendly meeting with a tyrant who makes a policy of mass murder. That is what has happened, in Ronald Reagan's Administration, to Americans' belief that their country stands for basic human decency in the world.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: 2d Man Is Charged In Woman's Death
