description: A second man was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a young woman who was thrown seven stories to her death Saturday night. The police said the woman had been killed in an argument over drugs.

title: QUICK OUTCOME IS NOT EXPECTED ON FATE OF MX
description: The House of Representatives is scheduled to vote Tuesday on whether to finance the MX intercontinental missile and the so-called dense-pack basing system that President Reagan has proposed for protecting the missiles.

title: SALES IN CITY'S STORES UP
description: Sales in November at seven major New York City department stores showed their best one-month gain of the year, rising an average 5.1 percent above sales of November 1981, a recent spot-check showed.

title: OPERA: HOUSTON TROUPE OFFERS BUSONI 'HARLEQUIN'
description: The novelties Friday night at the Houston Grand Opera were Busoni's ''Harlequin'' and the conceptual aptness of its pairing with Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci.'' But what turned out to be extraordinary was the performance of ''Pagliacci'' - a classic case of how a director, conductor and cast can revitalize even the most familiar and seemingly tawdry of operatic standards.

title: ISRAELI PLANS 3 DAYS OF TALKS WITH TOP HONDURAN OFFICIALS
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon left this weekend on a trip that is to include a three-day visit to Honduras, where he said he planned to meet with defense officials.

title: SUSAN GOLDSTEIN WED TO MARTIN K. GOLDSTEIN
description: Susan Beth Goldstein, daughter of Mrs. Gertrude W. Goldstein of New York and the late Dr. Eli Goldstein, was married yesterday to Martin Kenneth Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goldstein of Monsey, N.J. Rabbi David Kahane of the Sutton Place Synagogue performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel.

title: Condominiums at 8 3/4% Bring Crush on Coast
description: More than 1,500 people waited in line for hours for a chance to buy one of 286 beachside condominiums with financing as low as 8 3/4 percent annually.

title: COWBOYS DEFEAT REDSKINS
description: The Dallas Cowboys defeated the Washington Redskins today, 24-10, to give their coach, Tom Landry, his 200th regular-season victory and the Redskins their first loss of the season.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Jets vs. Detroit Lions, at Pontiac, Mich. The Jets, with a three-game winning streak, will try to gain a share of the American Conference lead.

title: The Trouble With 'Good Faith'
description: The Supreme Court is tinkering with the Constitution by calling for arguments over the so-called exclusionary rule, which bars illegally seized evidence from criminal trials. Since 1914 the rule has enforced the Fourth Amendment's prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures. If judges condone the illegal practices, a unanimous Court said then, the Fourth Amendment ''might as well be stricken from the Constitution.''

title: Fourth article of a series appearing periodically on current world economic problems.
description: The recession in the industrialized nations has translated into increased economic hardship and new political tensions across much of Asia, Africa and Latin America.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Hoist and Derrick Co., St. Paul, has named Jerald B. Ostergren executive vice president for administration, and has realigned and consolidated several divisions into a new Construction, Marine and Mining Equipment Group. Walter R. Olson has been named senior vice president and group executive.

title: 22 SURVIVORS OF PEARL HARBOR HONOR VICTIMS OF THE ATTACK
description: They survived the Depression and several recessions. They survived rocky marriages and rebellious children. But all that was easy compared with those few hours, 41 years ago Tuesday, when they survived what is perhaps their most vivid memory: the Japanese sneak attack on Pearl Harbor.

title: A Long, Long Shot
description: For a wager of $100 at odds of 50-1, Mike Dunaway a month ago stood on the roof of the 26-floor Dunes Tower in Las Vegas, Nev., and attempted to drive a golf ball onto the 18th green of the the Dunes Country Club course, 375 yards away from the base of the building. He was given six shots.

title: Della Femina President
description: Alan Pando, who joined Della Femina, Travisano & Partners a year ago as a group senior vice president after 13 years at Doyle Dane Bernbach, has been promoted to president of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners/West in Los Angeles. This is a title that has been unused since James D. Travis was named president of the whole company in August 1980.

title: BRADSHAW ON TARGET IN STEELER TRIUMPH
description: Terry Bradshaw demonstrated again yesterday his remarkable recuperative powers. After having been forced to the sidelines with a sprained shoulder for the final three quarters during Pittsburgh's 16-0 loss to the Seattle Seahawks a week ago, the Steelers' quarterback performed against the Kansas City Chiefs as if he were a picture of health.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A 'T.G.I.December' Party

title: MRS. LLOYD WINS AUSSIE TITLE FIRST TIME
description: It was the ''missing link'' in my career, said Chris Evert Lloyd today as she put out a challenge for the world's No.1 ranking after having defeated Martina Navratilova, 6-3, 2-6, 6-3, for the Australian Open tennis title.

title: ROHATYN AND GOTBAUM CRITICIZE ISRAELI ACTIONS
description: Two prominent New Yorkers criticized the policies of the Israeli Government last night at ceremonies at which they were honored by the American Jewish Congress.

title: ST. PATRICK MASS HAILS NEW POLISH SAINT
description: St. Maksymilian Kolbe, the Polish Franciscan who was elevated to sainthood on Oct. 10 by Pope John Paul II, was honored yesterday by thousands of worshipers at a mass of thanksgiving in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: YANKEES REPORTED SEEKING LANSFORD
description: The Yankees, seeking to improve their offensive punch anyway they can, have joined the quest for Carney Lansford, the third baseman the Boston Red Sox have decided to trade.

title: HUSSEIN AND ARAB LEAGUE GROUP ARRIVE IN CHINA FOR MIDEAST TALKS
description: King Hussein of Jordan and an Arab League delegation arrived in China today, hopeful of winning Chinese support for a Middle East peace compromise.

title: IAN SMITH HOME RAIDED BY POLICE
description: Former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that the Zimbabwean police had raided his farm and seized private papers.

title: HOSTAGE'S FAMILY PRAISES NEW PLAY
description: Jesse and Mary Lopez went to a play called ''Made in America'' last night. With their son Jim and other family members, they had spent hours with the playwrights, Christine Muldoon and Joel Lipman, describing their experiences and emotions from the time their son, Sergeant James M. Lopez of the Marines, was taken hostage in Iran, through the homecoming following his release in January 1981 after 444 days in captivity.

title: Zia Frees 5 Pakistanis On Eve of His U.S. Trip
description: Five prominent political opponents were freed from detention today, hours before President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq left for a state visit to the United States.

title: A CLASSIC CONFRONTATION LOOMS OVER FATE OF A NEW MISSILE
description: When Congress returned for its special session last Monday, the LTV Corporation put down $100,000 to purchase full-page advertisements in five newspapers and brought the Multiple Launch Rocket System to breakfast tables all across town.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With the bases loaded and one out, a hard ground ball is hit to the third baseman. He fields it, steps on the base and simultaneously tags the runner, who has remained on third. What is the ruling, for baseball and for softball?

title: Salvador Prelate Hails Rights Move by Regime
description: El Salvador's top churchman today praised the Government's creation of a human rights commission but said the body could only be judged by its action.

title: WRISTON CONFIDENT
description: The chance that the international banking system will collapse and plunge the world into a severe depression is ''close to zero,'' Walter B. Wriston, the chairman of Citibank, said today. Mr. Wriston, also chairman of President Reagan's economic policy advisory board, discussed the growing concern that the banking system would fall apart if less developed nations defaulted on their multibillion-dollar debts on the CBS TV News program ''Face the Nation.''

title: WOOLFOLK LEADS GIANTS TO VICTORY
description: For three and a half quarters against the Houston Oilers today, the Giants played so lethargically that their fans were booing and chanting, ''Strike, strike.'' Then, without warning, the Giants scored two touchdowns in three minutes, kept the Oilers in a hole with three consecutive sacks and scored an unartistic but welcomed 17-14 victory.

title: THE 42 FIRST LADIES: THEIR PLACE IN HISTORY
description: The nation's 42 First Ladies came under scrutiny over the weekend at a conference that touched on everything from Martha Washington's stodgy tea parties to Eleanor Roosevelt's social activism to Nancy Reagan's ''new-china policy.''

title: Beetle Reported Eradicated in U.S.
description: The Agriculture Department said yesterday that the voracious khapra beetle had been eradicated from the United States - at least for the moment - with the fumigation over the weekend of an empty Brooklyn warehouse.

title: McNEIL PREFERS TO RUN ALONE
description: HE cooks. He sews. He irons. Freeman McNeil's mother always taught him that he would have to take care of himself when he went out into the world.

title: LEGAL INTERPRETATION OF THE 'MESSIAH'
description: Eighty voices cried out as one over the weekend at the City Bar Association about making the crooked straight and the rough places plain. They were not, however, referring to more vigorous criminal prosecutions or land-use planning. They were singing Handel's ''Messiah.''

title: A WEEKEND WINTER TOOK A VACATION
description: The ice skaters wore T-shirts. Sidewalk Santas sweated. A baseball game drew a crowd in Central Park. And on Fifth Avenue, a bagpiper in kilts played Christmas carols.

title: GROWING OIL MARKET TENSIONS
description: The stability of the international oil market is being threatened by mounting dissension among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 6, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: JAPANESE OFFER TRADE CONCESSION
description: Japan tentatively promised to take steps soon to open its market further to foreign goods. The Japanese response came in two days of talks with American officials that ended late Saturday.

title: MICROSCOPIC TECHNIQUES HAVE A GIGANTIC EFFECT ON CATTLE BREEDING INDUSTRY
description: Rio Vista Farms, a modest 760 acres, is a bright patch of emerald in the low gray-green South Texas hills. It is a small ranch, beautifully pruned, not much more than an Oriental garden on the Lone Star scale of things, where a county or two is considered about right for a good-sized spread.

title: STAGE: ANTIWAR MUSICAL
description: THERE is nothing subtle about ''The Boogie-Woogie Rumble of a Dream Deferred,'' Vinnette Carroll's antiwar musical at the Urban Arts Theater. But the show has so much heart, vitality and tunefulness that it could almost be forgiven for its many inadequacies. Complete with choreographed battle scenes and a United Service Organizations canteen sequence of soldiers wildly jitterbugging with their girls, the show at times threatens literally to burst the seams of the tiny theater.

title: WIFE ABUSE IN JEWISH FAMILIES
description: SHE is 28 years old, she has three daughters and two sons, all undert he age of 7. She left her husband after five years of marriage and b eatings whose number she cannot count. The time finally came, she s aid the other day, when ''he no longer hit me.''

title: WHEN PLANT OWNERSHIP BECOMES THE ALTERNATIVE TO JOBLESSNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 IN ARTS GET HONORS IN CAPITAL
description: It was celebrity time in the capital this weekend as well-known figures from opera, the theater, film, music and the dance joined with official, cultural and social Washington in honoring five artists for their achievements. The occasion was the fifth annual Kennedy Center Honors, which this year, were given to George Abbott, Lillian Gish, Benny Goodman, Gene Kelly and Eugene Ormandy.

title: DWINDLING WATER SUPPLY MAY BRING CURBS BY CITY
description: Only months after New York City emerged from a drought emergency, it is again facing a dwindling water supply, and officials say that without more rain across the Upper Delaware Basin more serious conservation measures could soon become necessary.

title: Bridge: Lightner Double Is Routine But It Won't Always Work
description: About half a century ago the late Theodore Lightner proposed a new convention to his partner, Ely Culbertson. A double of a slam, he suggested, should call for an unusual lead. The first time it came up some disaster ensued, and Culbertson angrily refused to have anything more to do with it.

title: CINDY MAKSTEIN IS WED TO JONATHAN CHASE ON LONG ISLAND
description: At the Jewish Community Center of West Hempstead, L.I., yesterday Cindy Makstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Makstein of Franklin Square, L.I., was married to Jonathan Chase, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Chase of Hartsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Sidney Schwarz officiated.

title: Knowing the Enemy
description: The Knicks may be faring poorly this season, but it must be conceded they know their opposition well enough. Their yearbook lists Tom Nissalke as the coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: PURCHASING MANAGERS REPORT FURTHER DECLINE
description: Industrial companies across the country received fewer new orders, laid off more employees and experienced a further drop in production during November, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: NINA M. STENGEL IS MARRIED TO DR. ANDREW C. SCHWARTZ
description: Nina Margaret Stengel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Stengel of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday at Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn., to Dr. Andrew Charles Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Schwartz of New City, N.Y., and Cape Coral, Fla. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Jack Stern.

title: PEOPLE WHO OUGHT NOT TO BE IN PRISON
description: To the Editor:

title: PARTICLE SEARCH HALTED AMID HOPEFUL SIGNS
description: EFFORTS at CERN, the European Laboratory for Particle Physics near Geneva, to produce the long-sought particles embodying the so-called weak force that controls many subatomic reactions, were suspended Monday night with no announcement that the particles had been found.

title: SPIRIT OF THANKSGIVING SPURS GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the celebration of the Thanksgiving holiday awakens a sense of gratitude and provides an opportunity to help those less fortunate. Among those who donated early to the fund's 71st annual appeal was Benjamin Grund of Manhattan, who, ''in the spirit of Thanksgiving,'' made a donation of $350.

title: RUTGERS DOWNS OREGON, 53-42
description: Jim Haney, Oregon's basketball coach, had a plan against a highly favored Rutgers team, and it almost worked.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ballet Theater Post Goes to Schermerhorn
description: Kenneth Schermerhorn has been named general music director of the American Ballet Theater. Mr. Schermerhorn was musical director of the company from 1960 to 1968 and conductor on several world tours.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1982; The Economy
description: A bill that would raise the gasoline tax to finance a highway repair program ran into opposition in the House despite the support of both parties' leaders. (Page A1.) The Congressional Budget Office urged Congress to consider a different approach to highway improvement. (B15.) Many in Congress acknowledge that the House bill would do little to help the jobless. (B15.)

title: THE NEMESIS OF AMERICA'S HIGHWAY SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvester Sale
description: The International Harvester Company will sell a business making truck axles to the Dana Corporation in a few days for $55 million to $60 million, Harvester sources said.

title: CITY OF BROTHERLY LOVE'S LADY OF PEACE
description: A slowly thickening crowd of people gathered on a street corner here today, their eyes slowly rising as they beheld a shining embodiment of a sculptor's vision of peace.

title: CBS SHOW TIRELESS IN COVERING ACTION
description: Ted Shaker stood in the control room of Studio 43 at the CBS Broadcast Center, less than 30 seconds before the 3:30 P.M. edition of ''The NFL Today'' show was about to go on the air Sunday.

title: VOTERS' MEMORIAL
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNMENT PRICES ADVANCE
description: Government security prices rose briskly yesterday as the fixedincome market continued to react to the unexpected bulge in the November unemployment rate. Elsewhere, a decline in the Federal funds rate provided further encouragement for market participants.

title: TECHNICIAN EXECUTES MURDERER IN TEXAS BY LETHAL INJECTION
description: The state of Texas injected Charles Brooks Jr. with a deadly combination of sedatives and drugs just after midnight today, making him the first condemned prisoner in the United States to die by lethal injection.

title: Honduras Welcomes Sharon; He Meets With Military Aides
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel arrived here today for an overnight visit and was greeted by the armed forces chief, Gustavo Alvarez, an armed forces statement said.

title: DRAMA LEAGUE GIVES AWARDS
description: The 1983 Drama League Special Playwrighting Assistance Awards will be presented this afternoon at the Drama League of New York's annual luncheon at the New Luchow's. A total of $3,000 will be awarded to the playwrights Granville Wyche Burgess and Ellen Fitzhugh, and to the production groups Playwrights Horizons and Second Stage.

title: Sale of Unimation To Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had agreed in principle to buy a 78 percent interest in Unimation Inc., a leading maker of robots, for $84 million, or $21 a share.

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings figures reflects a 6 percent stock divd distributed in Nov

title: SOVIET WARNS U.S. IT WILL MATCH MX
description: The Soviet Defense Minister said today that if the United States began to deploy the MX missile, the Soviet Union would respond by deploying a new intercontinental ballistic missile ''not inferior'' to the Amerian weapon.

title: Comings and Goings
description: For his efforts in leading the surging Nets to four consecutive victories last week, Buck Williams, a second-year forward, was named the National Basketball Association's player of the week. He averaged 16.2 rebounds a game and scored 63 points in the four games. ... The injury that the Islanders' Bob Bourne suffered Saturday against Toronto was diagnosed as a depressed fracture of the small bone below the temple. Dr. Vincent DiGregorio, the team's plastic surgeon, will operate today to reduce the fracture.

title: KENNEDYS IN COURT FOR DIVORCE
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy and his estranged wife, Joan Bennett Kennedy, appeared in Barnstable Probate Court today to file for divorce on the ground that their 24-year marriage had suffered an ''irretrievable breakdown.''

title: WOMAN WITH LINKS TO SALVADOR'S REBELS DIES IN A BLAZE HERE
description: A 36-year old secretary for the United Presbyterian Church who was also active in a news service associated with leftist rebels in El Salvador died Saturday as a fire spread through her Manhattan apartment.

title: Forstmann to Buy Beverage Concern
description: Forstmann Little & Company announced a definitive agreement to buy all the outstanding stock of Beverage Management Inc. for $24 a share, or a total of about $98 million.

title: RECORD U.S. BORROWING RAISING FEARS ON CREDIT
description: The total amount of money raised through loans and stock issues in the United States increased during the third quarter, according to newly published Federal Reserve estimates of the flow of funds in the nation's economy.

title: STOCKS UP SHARPLY IN BUSY DAY
description: Stock prices soared yesterday, spurred by a sharp rise in the shares of International Business Machines. The best gainers were the blue-chip corporations, technology and airline issues.

title: Advertising; Media Seer Fine-Tunes A Forecast
description: FOR the first time in a decade of confident predictions on advertising spending, Robert J. Coen, media seer and senior vice president of McCann-Erickson, has revised an annual forcast downward for the second time in one year.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1982
description: International The President cited Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor 41 years ago today as evidence of the nation's need for effective deterrence as he led a vigorous last-ditch campaign to save the threatened MX missile program. Mr. Reagan invited 76 Representatives to the White House and lobbied them in behalf of the program in advance of a key vote on the MX in the House today or tomorrow. (Page A1, Column 3-4.) Moscow, decrying the MX missile, warned that if Washington began deploying the intercontinental ballistic weapon, the Soviet Union would respond by deploying an equally effective missile. (B17:1.)

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $166,000 for the qr and 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: Spanish Peseta Rises
description: The Spanish peseta rose slightly against the dollar today in its first trading following a weekend devaluation by the new Socialist Government. The peseta rose to 8.26 cents in Madrid from an opening 8.22 cents, and foreign exchange market officials said the Bank of Spain bought about $60 million to shore up the currency. The Government had announced an 8 percent devaluation of the peseta Saturday, saying the action was taken to help the sale of Spanish products abroad.

title: Maple's Ban Is Set for August
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday upheld a seven-day suspension of Angel Cordero and set a precedent by ordering that another jockey, Eddie Maple, serve his suspension during a key part of the racing season next year.

title: MEMORABLE NIGHT FOR WALKER
description: For all the thrilling moments Wesley Walker has had with the Jets since he joined them in 1977, he had never caught three touchdown passes in one game.

title: CONCERT: 'AMAHL'
description: THE three kings bearing gifts to Bethlehem walked up the aisles of Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday afternoon, on their way to a shepherd's hut. Their arrival caused a sensation not only with Amahl and his mother, but also with the audience of children who had come to see a new production of ''Amahl and the Night Visitors,'' Gian Carlo Menotti's classic operatic tale, presented by the Little Orchestra Society's ''Happy Concerts for Young People.''

title: REPRESENTATIVES BACK N.F.L. PACT, 19-9
description: National Football League player representatives, one from each of the 28 teams, voted by 19 to 9 today to recommend that the 1,500 players approve the collective bargaining agreement that ended their 57-day strike last month.

title: ITALIANS REFUSE TO FREE BULGARIAN
description: A special tribunal today rejected an appeal for the release of a Bulgarian airline employee who was arrested last month on charges of complicity in the attempt to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981.

title: DRIVER KILLED AND 5 HURT AS CAR HITS BUS IN PARK
description: A stolen car being pursued by the police crashed head on into a city bus on a rain-slick Central Park transverse yesterday morning, killing the driver of the car and injuring the bus driver and four passengers.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why is straw important in brickmaking? Just how is it used?

title: PRESIDENT, INVOKING PEARL HARBOR, PRESSES CAMPAIGN TO SAVE THE MX
description: President Reagan, citing the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor as evidence of the need for an effective deterrent, led a vigorous last-minute campaign today trying to save the jeopardized MX missile program.

title: IN SHARK WOMB, FETUS 'CANNIBALIZES' RIVALS
description: IT was the biggest surprise of Stewart Springer's life. Mr. Springer, a veteran shark researcher, was in his laboratory dissecting a sand tiger shark that he had caught near Chandeleur Island, off Louisiana. To his consternation, when he reached into one of the animal's oviducts, or birth canals, he was bitten. Each oviduct contained a living, nine-inch shark pup.

title: Hagler to Fight Briton
description: Bob Arum has paid more than $2 million for the rights to promote the fight between Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the world middleweight boxing champion, and Tony Sibson of Britain, who has been the leading contender for a year.

title: CHILDREN'S WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Editorial Comments

title: Seven-Up's Complaint About Pepsi Is Rejected
description: The National Advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus has turned down a request by Seven-Up that the organization ''use its influence'' to stop Pepsi-Cola's advertising for its Pepsi Free brand.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Making a Point In South Brooklyn

title: Sea-Law Talks Hear Plea by Canadian
description: Canada said today that it hoped difficulties preventing some countries from signing a United Nations Law of the Sea Convention could be worked out by a preparatory commission that is to begin work in March.

title: ABC-TV News to Ayer
description: The ABC-TV Network, all of whose nontelevision advertising promotion has been handled by McCaffrey & McCall, has split off the news operation and assigned it to N.W. Ayer. Thus, that venerable agency will create the print and radio advertising needed to promote such programs as ''World News Tonight,'' ''Closeup,'' ''20/20'' and the Barbara Walters specials.

title: Oilers' Inaction Puzzles Giants
description: When the Giants rallied to beat the Houston Oilers, 17-14, at Giants Stadium Sunday, they were helped by the Oilers' not calling their last two timeouts. Giant coaches and players wondered whether Coach Ed Biles of the Oilers had forgotten about the timeouts or had simply given up.

title: News Analysis
description: The Madrid Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe appears, after two years, to have entered a new phase in which the chances for any agreement are bleak.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid in July 1982

title: Kriek Triumphs
description: Top-seeded Johan Kriek twisted his ankle today but still managed to beat Mike DePalmer, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2, 7-6, in the second round of the $427,000 Australian Open tennis championships.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Kentucky Sheriff Sentenced
description: Sheriff Paul Browning Jr. of Harlan County was sentenced today to 10 years in prison for conspiring to murder two political rivals. He was convicted by a jury last month of conspiring to murder Johnny Y. Blanton, a Cumberland mining equipment dealer, and Magistrate Elijah Buell. The two men said they did not know why they were to be murdered.

title: BOSTON CORRUPTION INQUIRY RAISES QUESTIONS ON THE MAYOR'S FUTURE
description: A widening Federal investigation into accusations of corruption in city government has raised public questions about the career of Mayor Kevin H. White, who has responded with angry attacks on the United States Attorney here.

title: BRIEFING
description: Choice for Mammals Panel

title: Memorial for Marty Feldman Features Laughter and Jazz
description: The comedian Marty Feldman was eulogized today amid laughter and jazz music during brief memorial services, then laid to rest near the graves of Stan Laurel and Buster Keaton.

title: Sterling Drug Promotes Executive to Top Post
description: Sterling Drug Inc. has named John M. Pietruski Jr. president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Glenn W. Johnston, who on Jan. 7 is taking early retirement at age 62.

title: MUSIC: RICHARD GOODE, PIANIST
description: RICHARD GOODE is a commanding pianist, and he was at his magisterial best Saturday night at the 92d Street Y. Mr. Goode built Beethoven's Opus 81 Sonata, ''Les Adieux,'' as a series of contrasts, ranging from the sense of resignation in the poignant opening to the giddy ecstasy of the finale. The pianist ended the sonata with an impeccable flurry of dramatic fingerwork, prompting a sustained ovation.

title: OPERATOR AT 3 MILE ISLAND ASSERTS SAFETY TRAINING WAS INADEQUATE
description: A control room operator on duty when the 1979 accident occurred at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant testified yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan that he had been caught by surprise - the plant's builders, he said, had told him that the combination of events that caused the incident could never happen.

title: Mortgage Rates Down
description: The average interest rates charged Americans for new mortgages plunged almost a point in November, to 14.71 percent, its lowest level in two years, the Government said today.

title: MINNESOTA FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split made onJuly 30, 1982

title: AUDITORS THEY ARE, WORDSMITHS, NO
description: Hyman S. Baras climbed into a brand new M-1 Army tank one day, eager to check out the $1.7-million piece of war equipment. But after the 62-ton machine had traveled a short distance, Mr. Baras heard a ''tremendous explosion.'' The tank had thrown its track. Then its radio broke down and its repair kit was missing, requiring that an S O S be sent back to headquarters in the classic way, on foot.

title: Sanyo in England
description: Sanyo Marubeni U.K. Ltd. expects to make videotape recorders at its Lowestoft, England, plant, a company official said. The plant, which opened in October, would continue to emphasize the production of color television sets next year, but might assemble videotape recorders by 1984 or 1985.

title: IN EXILES' WAR AGAINST SANDINISTS, FLORIDA IS H.Q.
description: On a recent evening in Miami, half a dozen men, several in conservative business suits, assembled in a cluttered ground-floor office of the Interamerican Engineers and Constructors Corporation.

title: LEGISLATURE SPLIT ON POSSIBLE RISE IN TRANSIT FARES
description: Members of the New York State Legislature met in private conferences today and differed widely over whether an increase in bus, subway and commuter rail fares could be avoided this year in the New York metropolitan area.

title: STAGE: 'MARVELOUS GRAY,' DRAMA ABOUT INFANTCIDE
description: INFANTICIDE is the disturbing subject of a new play, ''Marvelous Gray,'' which opened last night at the Lion Theater. The drama was written by Diane Kagan, who also stars as the bewildered mother of a doomed baby. Marvelous Gray is the name of the child, and that fact offers a hint of the evening's drift into linguistic pretension. The play swirls with dialogue that aims for -and falls short of - verse, as in ''a womb and a tomb - one is alive, one is dead.''

title: Dormitory Authority Picks New Executive
description: The seven-member New York State Dormitory Authority has unanimously selected Christopher H. Richmond as its executive director, George D. Gould, the agency's chairman, said yesterday.

title: Market Place; Big Demand In New Issues
description: ARISING tide lifts all ships, it is said. Similarly, a rising stock m arket has a pervasive effect on issuers and investors, even though i t lifts some higher than others and does not prevent a few from s inking.

title: A SQUEEZE IN VIDEO GAMES
description: Lucio Aguado sells video game cartridges at his Manhattan camera shop, but it's strictly a sideline. The cartridges, designed for home consoles, get squeezed into one or two shelves near the front of the store.

title: Cost of Closing Savings Units
description: More failing savings and loan associations are likely to be liquidated as shutdown costs decline, the head of the savings and loan insurance fund said today.

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The shr earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split in June 1982

title: Family Rescued in Pacific
description: A California family of three was recuperating in a Fiji hospital today after being adrift in a dinghy in the Pacific for 29 days and stranded on a sand bar four more days. The Coast Guard in Honolulu said it was unsure when Robert and Margaret Aros and their son, Christian, all of Los Angeles, were rescued. The three had reportedly abandoned their 36-foot sloop, Vamonos, after the vessel developed engine trouble.

title: Rebels Said to Kidnap Over 140 in Salvador
description: Leftist rebels kidnapped two soccer teams and about 120 spectators from a rural stadium, forcing them to march through the night to a mountain guerrilla camp, witnesses said today.

title: BOMB IN ULSTER KILLS AT LEAST 8
description: A bomb at a village tavern frequented by British soldiers brought the roof crashing down on the crowded dance floor on Monday night, killing at least eight people and injuring 51 others, the police reported.

title: CITY WARNS J-51 HOUSING PROGRAM WILL DIE UNLESS ALBANY ACTS
description: Top officials of the Koch administration warned today that New York City's most important program to spur housing rehabilitation would die at the end of the month unless an extension was passed by the State Assembly.

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MACHINERY MAKERS IN SWITZERLAND HAVE ROUGH YEAR
description: In winter the chill always settles quickly over Switzerland, rolling down from the snow-covered foothills of the Alps.

title: KUHN CAUTIONS TEAM OWNERS
description: Bowie Kuhn opened baseball's 81st business convention today by warning the club owners who had recently voted to depose him: ''Baseball should passionately resist efforts to diminish the stature and functions of the commissioner.''

title: GEORESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Electronic Components Co., Morris Township, N.J., a unit of Allied Corp., has named Phillip W. Arneson executive vice president.

title: Auto Workers Reject New Chrysler Proposal
description: The United Auto Workers today rejected a new Chrysler Corporation proposal for a two-year contract featuring a wage increase for workers in Canada and the United States.

title: U.N. Issues Report on Inquiry On Chemical Warfare in Asia
description: The United Nations made public a report by a group of experts today that concludes that there is ''circumstantial evidence'' but no definite proof to support United States allegations that the Soviet Union and its allies have used chemical weapons in Afghanistan and Southeast Asia.

title: GERMAN CATHOLICS FOR A NUCLEAR DETERRENT
description: To the Editor:

title: GUATEMALAN IS SAID TO PLEDGE ELIMINATION OF 'DEATH SQUADS'
description: President Efrain Rios Montt told President Reagan on Saturday that he would rid Guatemala of Government death squads, a senior State Department official said today.

title: Hiker in Oregon Escapes From Hole After 4 Days
description: A hiker who fell into a snow-covered hole was trapped 14 feet below ground for four days before he managed to hoist himself up by a rope.

title: SARGENT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $804,000 for the qr and $1,331,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $1,023,000 for the qr and $2,036,000 for the 6 mos

title: NEW DEPUTY FOR DEFENSE
description: President Reagan has chosen a man who has been a World War II fighter pilot, aerospace executive and recent critic of the military budget to be the new Deputy Secretary of Defense.

title: Budget Options Urged For Localities in Jersey
description: Local governments should have the option of adhering to the current 5 percent annual limit on budget increases or to a limit based on inflation, a state study commission recommended today.

title: COURT WILL RULE ON PREGNANCY BENEFITS FOR SPOUSE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the extent to which employers must provide medical coverage for the pregnancies of male employees' wives.

title: VILLAGE SUPERMARKET reports earnings for 12 weeks to Oct 23
Boesky Increases Holding in Pabst
description: The Ivan F. Boesky Corporation's Seemala unit said it had lifted its interest in the Pabst Brewing Company to 9.9 percent from 7.7 percent.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Water-Skating in the Park

title: HICKORY FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPYING ADMITTED IN LONDON TRIAL
description: A Canadian economics professor admitted at his espionage trial today that he secretly photographed NATO documents and passed them to the Soviet Union.

title: MYSTERIOUS BRAIN DISEASE ATTRACTING WIDER INTEREST
description: The growing awareness of a type of progressive intellectual impairment among older people known as Alzheimer's disease is spurring scientists and others to pursue and underwrite new avenues of research to solve the mysteries of this little-understood illness.

title: Court Refuses to Hear Grumman Appeal
description: The trustees of the Grumman Corporation's pension plan failed today to persuade the Supreme Court to hear their appeal in a case growing out of the LTV Corporation's thwarted takeover bid for Grumman last year.

title: Coach Has a Sideline
description: Keith Moody is planning a dual football career in 1983, having signed to coach Brockton State, a Division III team in western New York, and to play for the New Jersey Generals in the new United States Football League. The schedules mesh neatly for him: As a return specialist and backup defensive back, Moody will play from March through July - if he makes the team - and then take up his coaching role in the autumn. ... The Boston Breakers of the U.S.F.L. signed Roman Gabriel, the former pro quarterback, as offensive coordinator and quarterback coach.

title: DATA POWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including extraordinary tax credits of $16,000 for the qr and $53,000 for the 6 mos

title: Moroccan Receives Habib
description: King Hassan II tonight received Philip C. Habib, the United States Middle East envoy, the Moroccan press agency reported.

title: MUSIC: DAVID ROSENBLOOM PLAYS A SYNTHESIZER CONCERT
description: DAVID ROSENBLOOM'S Friday night concert at the Public Access Synthesizer Studio, although somewhat uneven, gave evidence of a young composer with rare gifts. Mr. Rosenbloom creates a sonic texture that is simultaneously very old and very new, combining chantlike monophony, elegant minimalism, world music and rock elements into a beguiling blend that owes as much to the Far East as to Lower Manhattan.

title: Steel Output Up 2.1%
description: Steel production increased by 2.1 percent in the week ending last Saturday, to 934,000 short tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The previous week's production was 915,000 short tons. For the year to date, adjusted production stood at 68.6 million tons.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Becton Dickinson & Co. filed a shelf registration statement with the S.E.C. for up to $150 million of debt securities, with terms to be set at the time of sale.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $378,000 for the qr and $1,034,000 forthe 9 mos

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
News Analysis
description: In the fiscal year ending in September, the Reagan Administration has sought authority to spend $21 billion on two aircraft carriers, the MX missile system, B-1B bombers, Trident submarines and cruise missiles. Yet, if Congress eliminated these requests, actual outlay savings would be only $3.5 billion, according to the Congressional Budget Office. This points up the fundamental trap facing Congress as it grapples with the military budget to reduce this year's estimated Federal deficit of $175 billion.

title: LA BELLE EUROPE REIGNS AGAIN A MET MUSEUM
description: Some said she simply could not do it again, that Diana Vreeland, as gifted a fashion aerialist as ever lived, would never pull off her 11th annual foray into the high-wire world of costume exhibition and society event. But last night she and the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute unveiled their latest joint effort, entitled ''La Belle Epoque (1890-1914),'' and proved that the magic is still there, the balancing act still intact.

title: CHINA URGES RECOGNITION OF ISRAEL
description: China's Communist Party leader said today that Peking would support the Arab cause until final victory, but he urged the Arab nations to recognize Israel's right to exist.

title: TEMPLETON GROWTH FUND LTD (CANADA) reports earnings for As of Nov 30
description: Assets figures represent net assets

title: Electronic Mail
description: The Electronic Mail Corporation of America said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Telecom Systems Group Inc., a privately held operator of an international communications network. Electronic Mail would issue 716,667 common shares and pay $950,000 to acquire Telecom, it said. Leonard Elfenbein, Telecom's president and principle stockholder, will become president and chief executive officer of Electronic Mail on completion of the merger.

title: West German Steel Off
description: Crude-steel output from West German mills in the first 11 months of 1982 fell 12.3 percent from the period a year earlier to 33.8 million tons, the federal statistics office's regional bureau said today in a provisional report.

title: CHECKING PLAN WITH NO CEILING ON INTEREST SET
description: In a further change in the way Americans do their banking, Federal regulators today authorized commercial banks and savings institutions to offer a checking account that pays unlimited interest rates for anyone who can maintain a minimum balance of $2,500.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt GOODBYE, MICKEY MOUSE. By Len Deighton. 337 pages. Knopf. $14.95.

title: Joint Settlement of Suits In Hyatt Disaster Gains
description: A judge today tentatively approved a combined settlement of all civil damage suits filed in state court in the Hyatt Regency Hotel skywalk disaster, which left 114 people dead.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After a charge of $796,000 for the qr and 9 mos for the effect of a change inthe estimate of the useful life of Fotomat kiosks from 20 to 15 years...C-Including gains of $380,000 for the qr and $1.9 million for the 9 mos on the sale of capital assets

title: Dickerson's Loss
description: It wasn't until noon yesterday that Eric Dickerson realized that he had lost his football pants. And jersey, helmet and shoulder pads, too.

title: FEDERAL PAYMENT OF WESTWAY FUNDS BACKED BY COURT
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that New York State could obtain about $90 million in Federal funds to pay New York City for land needed to build the Westway project.

title: Weekend League
description: A new professional basketball league has been formed although the format is not new at all. The Pro-East Basketball Association will begin its first season on Jan.14 and run though March 13.

title: OF THE PRINCIPLES OF SEVENTH-DAY ADVENTISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Adam Nagorski, 97, Advised Western Embassies in Poland
description: Adam Nagorski, a Polish lawyer who had for many years been legal adviser in Warsaw to the embassies of the United States, Britain, Switzerland and Sweden, died last Thursday in Warsaw.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
VW-China Agreement
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. of West Germany signed a preliminary agreement to help renovate a Shanghai automobile factory that would be used for building some of VW's Santana cars, according to a report in Saturday's issue of Wen Hui Bao, a newspaper in Shanghai. After renovation, the plant could build 500 Santanas next year in trial production.

title: Illinois Town Is Upheld In Appeal of Gun Law
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the nation's toughest gun ordinance, ruling that the Chicago suburb of Morton Grove acted within its authority in banning sale and possession of pistols.

title: Street Scenes; Pie in the Sky
description: New Yorkers love to watch early stages of building construction. They stare through apertures in the fence, trying to decipher the whistle signals that precede and follow each blast in Manhattan bedrock.

title: Tokyo Tempts a Giant
description: Reggie Smith, the San Francisco Giants first baseman, said that although he had not yet signed with the Tokyo Giants, he has agreed to accept their offer. Smith declined to discuss reports that the Tokyo price was about $1 million for a season, but he did say it was ''more than I could make in four or five years in the big leagues.'' Last year, with San Francisco, he earned $300,000.

title: Mel Gray to Retire
description: Discouraged by his demotion to the reserve squad, Mel Gray, a 34-year-old wide receiver for the St. Louis Cardinals, announced his retirement, effective at the end of the season. Gray, with 12 years in the N.F.L., had caught at least one pass in 121 consecutive games. That streak was broken Sunday in a game against Philadelphia.

title: RICHMOND BEGINS PRISON SENTENCE
description: Former Representative Frederick W. Richmond surrendered at a Federal prison camp today to begin serving a term of one year and one day for his conviction on income tax evasion, marijuana possession and making an illegal payment to a Federal employee.

title: NEW RULES SEEK TO SEPARATE ABORTION AND FAMILY CLINICS
description: The Department of Health and Human Services has prepared new rules for hospitals and clinics that would require abortion activities to be completely separated from all family planning services financed by the Federal Government.

title: A BIG 1983 EXPECTED FOR THE DIGITAL MOUSE
description: HAVING run through apples, oranges, limes, peaches and most of the other familiar fruits in search of people-comforting nomenclature, personal computing marketeers are now setting their sights on animals. Witness, for instance, Leading Edge's Elephant floppy disks. However, the biggest computer news personality of all is soon to be the pachyderm's mythological archenemy, the mouse. In fact, after visiting the Comdex computer conference and exposition in Las Vegas last week, I came away with very much the feeling that 1983 will see the ascendancy of the digital mouse.

title: ONCE-UNHAPPY NET GIVES A TOP EFFORT
description: Mickey Johnson joined the Nets on Nov.10, but he did not become part of the team until Sunday. Until then, he was in his private world - feeling sorry for himself for being traded to his fifth team in a nine-year career, and from a contender to a team of young prospects that was pointing to the future.

title: LANSFORD TRADED TO A'S
description: Carney Lansford, one of the third basemen the Yankees have pursued at baseball's winter meetings, went elsewhere today when the Boston Red Sox traded him to Oakland in a five-player deal that brought them Tony Armas, one of the A's trio of fine outfielders.

title: Charlotte Curtis; The World of Enid Haupt
description: ENID ANNENBERG HAUPT appeared at a lunch party not long ago in an elderly and beloved black Chanel suit with leopard's head earrings and a domed-topaz ring, and, as usual, she was thinking about flowers. She had brought her hostess a cluster of giant, white cattleya orchids, which she urged her to put ''in any old Perrier bottle. They make perfect vases.'' And before long, flowers being essential in Mrs. Haupt's rather special life, she was describing the difficulties in raising them.

title: ECONOMIC STUDY PUTS JAPAN NO. 1
description: For the third consecutive year, Japan has been judged the world's most competitive economy by some 700 corporate executives, economists and labor leaders in 22 industrial countries.

title: HOUSE AIDES BACK TAXES ON BENEFITS
description: Two House Democratic leaders favor making Social Security benefits partly subject to Federal income tax as one of several ways to shore up the Social Security system, aides of the Ways and Means Committee reported today.

title: Judge in Cairo Trial To Hear Torture Charges
description: The chief judge in the trial of 300 men charged with plotting an Islamic fundamentalist revolution in Egypt agreed today to consider the defendants' charges that they had been tortured by their jailers.

title: A MAN ON THE RUN COVERS A COUNTRY
description: Tarak Kauff started running south during the last basketball season. He ran across the Delta States before the Stanley Cup playoffs and the Indy 500. While Conquistador Cielo was winning the Belmont, Tarak Kauff was conquering the Pacific Northwest.

title: ERNIE D'S ESCAPE FROM LIMBO
description: It's the varsity against the much younger and shorter junior varsity, but the Jayvees have an equalizer: they have Ernie D, who, feeling younger by the minute, has the ball.

title: DEVILS LOSE TO JETS ON FOUR LATE GOALS
description: The Devils carried their dependence on Glenn (Chico) Resch one period too far tonight as the seemingly inexhaustible goalie gave up three of four third-period goals to the Winnipeg Jets as the Devils lost, 5-3, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the present White House leadership runs the gantlet of common sense and the people's will for peace and challenges us by starting MX missile deployment, the Soviet Union will deploy in response a new ICBM of the same class and its characteristics will not be inferior to those of the MX missile in any way.'' - Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov of the Soviet Union. (B17:1.)

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. won its third construction permit for cellular mobile telephone systems, adding Pittsburgh to earlier approvals for Chicago and Boston. The permit was granted by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Transamerica Airlines Names New Chairman
description: Henry P. Huff, president and chief executive of Transamerica Airlines, has been named chairman. Mr. Huff will retain his duties as chief executive. Howard K. Howard, executive vice president, succeeds Mr. Huff as president.

title: Seat Plan Chosen
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Kingdome seating for the 1984 National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship Final Four will be the same as for Seattle SuperSonics games, accommodating 38,965 fans.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Executive Changes listing in Business Day yesterday incorrectly identified the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. He is John Brademas, who also remains president of New York University.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SUCCESS TIED TO POTATO CHIPS
description: Herman W. Lay, the entrepreneur who developed the first national brand of potato chips and later, as head of the Frito-Lay Company, helped found Pepsico, the giant conglomerate, died of cancer yesterday at Baylor Hospital in Dallas. He was 73 years old.

title: Price Advice For OPEC
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should use graduated oil price cuts as a way of disciplining its members that break production and pricing agreements, a new independent research group with OPEC connections has suggested. Its report was published today by the Middle East Economic Survey, a newsletter.

title: JETS DOWN LIONS FOR 4TH IN ROW
description: The New York Jets, who had failed so often before national television audiences on past Monday nights, scored a smooth and powerful 28-13 victory over the Detroit Lions tonight.

title: National Patent
description: The National Patent Development Corporation and the NPS Corporation said they had agreed to market jointly a new radioactive waste immobilization technology. Details were not disclosed. The companies said the technology, called porous glass matrix, offered an ''effective and economical method'' to clean low-level nuclear waste generated by reactors.

title: Amax President Will Retire Early
description: John Towers, president and chief operating officer of Amax Inc., a major metal producer, will be retiring early from the company at the age of 61. The company said the retirement was part of its efforts to restructure and reduce its management as a result of continuing poor conditions in the metal industry.

title: THE MX'S ECONOMIC IMPACT
description: The Congressional battle this week over the MX missile is likely to have an economic impact far beyond the 20 square miles of southeastern Wyoming ranch country that the Reagan Administration has chosen for its 100 missile silos.

title: HOUSE CRITICS OF JOBS BILL EXPRESS DOUBTS ON ITS CHANCES OF SUCCESS
description: While the highway improvement bill debated by the House today has been promoted as a ''jobs'' bill by Congressional leaders, many lawmakers on both sides of the aisle acknowledge that it will do little to alleviate the nation's 10.8 percent unemployment rate.

title: THE NEMESIS OF AMERICA'S HIGHWAY SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: PENNEY AND THRIFT UNIT PLAN FINANCIAL SERVICES
description: The J.C. Penney Company yesterday announced its first step into broad-based financial services. Penney, the nation's third-largest retailer behind Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K Mart Corporation, and First Nationwide Savings, a major savings and loan assocation, said they had agreed to offer next spring an array of financial services in five Penney stores in northern California and through direct marketing to Penney's credit card customers.

title: A Slight Case Of Arithmetic
description: When Bert Sugar, the editor of Ring Magazine, boarded a flight from New Orleans to New York last Saturday evening, he was shown a copy of the official scorecard of the Thomas Hearns-Wilfred Benitez fight for the World Boxing Council super welterweight championship. Gladys Thomas, a boxing fan who lives in the Bronx, had a copy of the scorecard.

title: Required Reading Sense and Scents
description: 1982 Toy Quality and Safety Report, published by the Consumer Affairs Committee of Americans for Democratic Action. Dec. 1, 1982: Christmas, 1982 will be remembered as THE YEAR OF THE BIG SMELL. And if you think the toy industry is sniffing big profits you are right.

title: GASOLINE TAX BILL IS PASSED BY HOUSE ON A 236-169 VOTE
description: The House of Representatives this morning approved a 5-cent-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax to help finance a program to repair highways and create jobs. The vote was 236 to 169.

title: A Coat for a Jet
description: Mark Gastineau strutted though the Jets' hotel in Pontiac, Mich., yesterday wearing his new $11,000 full-length coat of ranch mink. Even Mrs. Helen Dillon, one of the club's owners, wanted to try it on.

title: BALLET: DUTCH CAST CHANGES
description: AS we were saying, the second of the two programs being presented by the Dutch National Ballet is the better one of the two in the Brooklyn Academy's current ''Ballet International'' series. On Saturday night, some New York debuts in the ballets on the program made for even better cast changes.

title: Bridge: An Unselfish Bidder Lets Her Partner Take Charge
description: The task of leading the World Bridge Federation, which was founded in Oslo in 1958, is not an easy one. Its presidents have all been wealthy men with time to spare for their duties, and the job has become more and more onerous.

title: ZIMBABWE POLICE TAKE SMITH TO CAPITAL AND SEARCH HOME
description: Former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, who angered the Government by criticizing it while abroad recently, was taken with his wife from their farm today and escorted by policemen to their home in a suburb of this capital city. The home was searched room by room for four hours.

title: Talking Business with Silas of Phillips Petroleum; Oil Reserves Off California
description: People in the oil industry are speculating these days about the significance of a new oil discovery in the Santa Maria Basin, part of the continental shelf off Santa Barbara, Calif. The companies holding the most leases for drilling in the area are Texaco Inc., the Standard Oil Company of California and the Phillips Petroleum Company.

title: WARNING FOR AFRICA
description: Despite a peevish signal of breakdown by Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France some weeks ago, the Western group working on Namibia still holds together.

title: U.S.-Japan Trade Talks
description: The United States today asked Japan to liberalize its restrictions on agricultural imports to help reduce the American trade deficit with Japan, officials said. Under Secretary of State W. Allen Wallis, here for a two-day meeting on trade issues that ends Tuesday, also told Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe that protectionist sentiment among American farmers is rising, according to sources at the United States Embassy.

title: Man Dead at Kennedy Grave Termed Heart Disease Victim
description: The man whose charred body was found on the grave of President Kennedy in Arlington National Cemetery last week died of heart disease, the authorities said today.

title: U.S. TELLS WORKERS TO PAY BACK LOANS
description: More than 46,000 Federal employees have defaulted on almost $68 million in student loans, Education Secretary T.H. Bell announced today. He said his office was taking steps to get the money back.

title: ARCHITECTURE: CHANIN A MASTER OF THE SKYLINE
description: MOST of the architects and builders who shaped the Manhattan skyline of the 1920's and 30's - the skyline that is probably the object of more romantic yearnings today than when it was new - seem now like figures from a distant past. They are venerated, but in the manner of characters of another era altogether. Indeed, in the New York of the 1980's one might as easily imagine an encounter with Stanford White as with the likes of Raymond Hood, who designed Rockefeller Center and The Daily News and McGraw-Hill buildings, or Fred F. French, builder of Tudor City, or William Van Alen, architect of the Chrysler Building.

title: Talks on Selling Sotheby's Held
description: Sotheby's, the auction house, indicated it was up for sale. The 239-year-old fine art auctioner said it had entered into preliminary talks with unidentified potential buyers.

title: Accounts
description: * Fownes Brothers & Co. to Kornhauser & Calene Inc. for its glove products.

title: STREET SCENES; U-Drive
description: An out-of-town couple tried to hail a cab during a recent rainstorm in mid-Manhattan. As they were almost ready to admit defeat a woman drove up to the curb, lowered the window and asked, with evident frustration, if they knew of a nearby parking garage.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Bulls, at Chicago. The Knicks, mired in last place in the Atlantic Division with a 5-13 record, face a team that has lost seven straight games and is at 6-13.

title: Army Dismisses Coach
description: Army dismissed Coach Ed Cavanaugh yesterday, as expected, 48 hours after its 24-7 loss to Navy that ended the Cadets' third straight losing football season under him.

title: HOPES FOR 'CEMENTING' OF TIES
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan arrived here today for talks with President Reagan that will focus on United States military aid, the Soviet presence in Afghanistan and United States concern over Pakistan's nuclear abilities.

title: THE GREAT TEXAS ARMADILLO HUNT: TRACKING DOWN A SHY GUEST OF HONOR
description: Chris Christian, who runs Pat's outdoor dance hall here and is the man responsible for it all, conceded that it was downright embarrassing.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: Per shr figures are fully diluted; Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce is listedon the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: Tokyo Market at New High
description: Helped by a spurt of late buying, prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange advanced today to a record high of 8,020.53. The gain of 28.96 points for the day pushed the Nikkei Dow Jones average of 225 stocks just ahead of the previous record of 8,019.14, set on Aug. 17, 1981.

title: Stony Brook Moves Up
description: The State University of New York at Stony Brook will elevate its football program for the 1983 season from the club level to Division III status and the school's president, Dr.John H. Marburger, says: ''Stony Brook's club teams over the past few years have demonstrated that scholar athletes can meet the academic demands of a university like Stony Brook whle achieving outstandng records in sports.'' Stony Brook was 7-2 last season. ... Joe Lee Dunn, 36, the defensive coordinator at the University of New Mexico, was named head football coach, replacing Joe Morrison, who has taken the coaching position at South CArolina.

title: QUEBEC REBUFFED ON POWER OF VETO
description: The Canadian Supreme Court rejected Quebec's claim to a veto over constitutional issues today, setting the stage for a heightened dispute between the separatist political leaders of the French-speaking province and the federal authorities.

title: Saarstahl Rescue Is Called Unlikely
description: The West German Economics Minister, Otto Lambsdorff, said it was unlikely that the Government and the metalworkers' union could agree in time on a cost-saving plan to save Saarstahl from collapse, a ministry statement said.

title: STILL, A PERSON OWNS HIMSELF
description: ON-HUDSON, N.Y. -Every competent adult is considered to be the master of his own body. He may treat it wisely or foolishly. He may even refuse life-saving treatment, and it's nobody else's business. Certainly not the state's. That is the law of the land.

title: A PRISONER IS KILLED IN PLUNGE WHILE TRYING TO FLEE U.S. JAIL
description: An inmate of the Federal Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan apparently fell to his death last night during an attempt to escape by lowering himself on a rope fashioned from bed sheets, city and Federal authorities said.

title: Doyle Dane Director
description: Paul Bernbach, younger son of the late William Bernbach and a specialist in real estate investment, was named to the board of Doyle Dane Bernbach International.

title: Argentines Go on Strike, Defying Military Junta
description: Argentina's first nationwide general strike in six and a half years of military rule closed factories, public transportation and shops today as nine million workers defied the Government to protest inflation and reported human rights abuses.

title: U.S. ASKS INTERNATIONAL MONETARY CONFERENCE
description: The Reagan Administration disclosed today that it wants to convene an international conference similar to Bretton Woods in 1944 to improve the world's monetary system and to deal with the mounting debt of developing countries and rising worldwide unemployment.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Fire That Wasn't

title: China-British Air
description: China is discussing the possible purchase of used Trident aircraft from the state-owned British Airways, a company spokesman said.

title: MILWAUKEE WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Court Rejects N.F.L. Appeal
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear the National Football League's appeal of an antitrust ruling that permits N.F.L. team owners to own or manage teams in other professional sports leagues.

title: Was the Drug Plan Only a Ploy?
description: Just before the November elections, President Reagan announced a new plan to fight organized crime and drug trafficking. It called for adding 900 agents to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Drug Enforcement Administration and creating task forces to conduct major investigations in 12 cities.

title: FRANCE PLANS CUT IN ARMED FORCES
description: France will make significant cuts in the size of its conventional armed forces, according to a statement by the army Chief of Staff.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: A leading consumer research organization and an institution with 15 years' experience in evaluating educational materials have joined forces to give schools, colleges and parents' groups advice on which computer products to buy and which to shun. The new alliance hopes to avert the kinds of errors that killed earlier educational technologies and that already threaten to turn the current educational computer boom into a costly bust.

title: Horace B. Jenkins, 42; His Films Won Awards
description: Horace B. Jenkins, an award-winning film maker, died Friday in St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan, where he had been admitted two days earlier, following a heart attack. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JERSEY WOMAN, 25, SEIZED IN CAR AND FATALLY STABBED AT ROUTE 80
description: A 25-year-old waitress was apparently abducted from her car near her home here early Sunday and later stabbed to death at a secluded rest stop on Interstate 80, about 25 miles away, the state police said today.

title: Genes for a Glow
description: Biologists in California have taught ordinary intestinal bacteria to glow in the dark by giving them genes from other luminescent bacteria.

title: REP. REUSS: LOOKING BACK ON 28 YEARS IN THE HOUSE
description: When Representative Henry S. Reuss was selected recently by the Democratic leadership to respond to one of President Reagan's Saturday afternoon radio talks, a leadership aide offered him a script. Mr. Reuss scanned it and replied, ''I think I'll go with what I've got.''

title: 3 Italians Accused Of Red Brigades Work
description: The police said today that they had arrested three people suspected of being Red Brigades guerrillas and of trying to rebuild the terrorist organization in Turin after a recent police crackdown.

title: No Headline
description: All-America Team

title: Robert Zeller, 63, Dies; Orchestra Conductor
description: Robert Zeller, a conductor of ballet, symphony and operatic orchestras in the United States and Europe, died of cancer in Dallas Sunday. He was 63 years old and maintained residences in New York city and Zihuatanejo, Guerrero, Mexico.

title: HOW NOT TO CURE LEBANON'S ILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: RIGHTLY UNENFORCEABLE JOURNALISTIC ETHICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain to Cut Steel Plants
description: The British Government and the steel castings industry have agreed on a plan to close down some of Britain's steel foundries, a banker involved in the negotiations said today.

title: COLUMNIST TESTIFIES PEARSON FEARED BLACKMAIL
description: Drew Pearson, the columnist, believed he would be blackmailed by one of his bitterest enemies, Senator John L. McClellan, when he learned that the Senator had obtained some intimate letters from Mr. Pearson to a civil rights worker, a jury was told today.

title: ALTERNATIVE PROPOSAL FOR ROADS PROGRAM IS GIVEN TO CONGRESS
description: As the House began debate today on President Reagan's request for a 5-cent-a-gallon rise in the tax on gasoline and diesel fuel, the Congressional Budget Office proposed a different approach to financing and administering highway construction and maintenance.

title: Sale of Technicolor
description: MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc. said it had purchased 3.48 million shares of Technicolor Inc. under its $23-a-share tender offer, which expired last Friday. The purchases bring MacAndrews's stake to 81 percent of Technicolor.

title: CONCERT: TWO BY BRAHMS
description: BRAHMS'S 150th birthday is not till May, but the tide in New York's concert halls is already beginning to build. Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall it was the American Symphony Orchestra in an all-Brahms program - the D minor Piano Concerto and the Symphony No. 4. Moshe Atzmon, one of the orchestra's new principal conductors, presided over both pieces, and the soloist was Steven De Groote.

title: OVER DRINKS, TEEN-AGERS ON L.I. ASSESS NEW LAW
description: Nobody at the Washington Square Pub and Restaurant here seemed to notice that at 12:01 Saturday morning New York State's minimum drinking age was raised to 19 from 18. Steven Streichler, 17 years old, picked up his glass, emptied it and said, ''This is what I think of the new drinking law.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UPTOWN CENTER

title: NEW GENERATION OF TEST PILOTS SOARS ALOFT ON A WING AND A PRAYER
description: wire jack rabbits in full fright. Dark clouds stretched from horizon to far horizon, a low ceiling. Fitz Fulton, a test pilot, went inside to telephone Operations. ''No flight today,'' he said, hanging up. ''Weather's not bad enough.''

title: Leaky Loophole for Toxic Waste
description: Joe the auto mechanic, Harry the dry cleaner and Phyllis, who runs a jewelry repair shop, may not seem to pose a problem for the environment. Yet they and tens of thousands of other ''small generators'' make a troublesome contribution to the national buildup of toxic waste that threatens public health.

title: New York Wants You!
description: My friend Trafalgar called last week in a snit about my columns on the worrisome state of the city's finances and the resultant crumbling of our public works. Trafalgar, you may recall, is the oracle who some months ago proposed building subways in El Salvador to create construction jobs for the hungry peasants and simultaneously provide transportation to carry Salvadorans to the polls on election days so they could vote for democracy.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 7, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, a Company Brief in Business Day on Saturday incorrectly located eight daily and three weekly newspapers acquired by The New York Times Company. All but one are in the South- east.

title: PRICE CURB ON NATURAL GAS URGED
description: As a result of sharply rising natural gas prices, Congress is coming under intense pressure to legislate emergency relief for consumers that could take effect in the current heating season.

title: The West Bank Struggle, in Lebanon
description: President Reagan's admirable proposals for Arab-Israeli negotiations about the West Bank have been decisively rejected by three parties: Syria, Israel and the P.L.O. The President's desire to help Lebanon regain its independence is blocked by three foreign armies: those of Syria, Israel and the P.L.O. The coincidence is anything but accidental.

title: WHITE HOUSE ANSWERS ISRAELI CRITICISM ON AID
description: The Reagan Administration, responding to Israeli criticism, said today that it was ''puzzled that Israel can call into question our good faith'' simply because the White House opposed Congressional attempts to increase aid to Israel.

title: U.N.'S AFGHAN PLAN INTERESTS MOSCOW
description: The Soviet Union, bogged down for three years in Afghanistan, has given encouraging signals to a United Nations plan to end the conflict.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Briefing item on the Washington Talk page Saturday incorrectly reported the occupation of James Abourezk, former Senator from South Dakota. He is a Washington lawyer.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CUOMO ASKED TO HIRE COORDINATOR FOR SHELTERING STATE'S HOMELESS
description: A coalition of religious groups called on Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo yesterday to create the post of state coordinator for the homeless to formulate and carry out a comprehensive plan to shelter the state's homeless people.

title: WHY ARE EARLIEST MEMORIES SO FRAGMENTARY AND ELUSIVE?
description: ON the verge of recalling the earliest childhood memories, one can have the sense of nearing recollections of great power; these emotion-laden scenes often beckon inward, tantalizing, sometimes disturbing.

title: A BOARDING SCHOOL CHANGES ITS IMAGE BUT KEEPS ITS GOAL
description: In their corduroys and flannel shirts, their running shoes and print skirts, the 523 students of the Taft School here could slip unnoticed into any suburban high school. Their rooms, adorned by India prints and pictures of rock stars and post cards from art museums, could pass for any middle-class teen-ager's bedroom.

title: SHULTZ, IN EUROPE, TO SEEK A JOINT POLICY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived here early today at the start of a two-week tour of Western Europe to try to put into effect a new agreement on a joint economic policy toward the Soviet Union.

title: SIMKINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After an extraordinary loss of $1,152,100

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WITH JAPAN REARMED
description: This Pearl Harbor anniversary is different. The ''day that will live in infamy'' is now 41 years behind us and largely forgotten. A Japan chastened by war and defeat is chastened no more. New forces are pushing Japan to translate its economic might into political and even military power.

title: Chess: How to Lure an Opponent Into Very Finely Spun Web
description: It is not easy to say what the art of provoking the opponent into complications consists of, but part of it is jabbing to prevent him from fastening on a clear strategy and another part is looking vulnerable without really being so.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: creation of Maxim's at the museum. ''I see no reason why I should eat Mr. Cardin's ve-ge-tah-bellz,'' he said as he sat in hiss uite at the Pierre.

title: Swiss Bank Rule Sought
description: The Swiss Federal Banking Commission is seeking to extend its supervisory powers under a new banking law to cover financial institutions that do not take customer deposits, commission officials said today.

title: Manville Insurers Are Subject of Suit
description: Two companies with asbestos-related claims against the Manville Corporation, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, said they had asked the Bankruptcy Court in New York to permit the claims to be brought against Manville's insurance carriers.

title: LANGUAGE GAP DEBATED ANEW
description: THE debate over how far public schools must go to meet the special educational needs of the students who come from homes where a language other than standard English is spoken is once again before the Federal courts.

title: Allied to Purchase Majority of Bendix
description: The Allied Corporation said yesterday that it would proceed with its purchase of a majority stake in the Bendix Corporation and a 39 percent interest in the Martin Marietta Corporation, following a Justice Department decision clearing the way for the $2 billion takeover.

title: No Headline
description: PLAN FOR HEALTH BENEFITS TAX HAS NOT YET REACHED REAGAN

title: HEART PATIENT RESTS WELL WITH THE HELP OF HANDEL
description: SALT Lake City, Dec. 6 - Dr. Barney B. Clark, the recipient of the world's first permanent artificial heart, rested comfortably today while listening to a tape recording of Handel's ''Messiah'' sung by the Mormon Tabernacle Choir.

title: KOCH ACKNOWLEDGES BUDGET'S IMPACT ON MINORITIES
description: Mayor Koch met with black and Hispanic legislators yesterday and agreed with their contention that the reductions in city services he has planned would disproportionately affect the neighborhoods they represent.

title: YOUNG AUDIENCES BENEFIT HONORS RUDOLF SERKIN
description: Isaac Stern, Eugene Istomin and other lights of the musical world paid tribute last night to a colleague who normally shuns attention: the pianist Rudolf Serkin.

title: SENATOR'S TESTIMONY ON TEAMSTER SESSION CONTRADICTED AT TRIAL
description: Two witnesses in the bribery and conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, today contradicted portions of sworn testimony given last week by Senator Howard W. Cannon.

title: Warsaw Pact to Meet
description: A meeting of Warsaw Pact leaders, including Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet party chief, is expected Jan. 4 and 5 in Prague, diplomatic sources in the Czechoslovak capital said today.

title: David Blue, Singer-Actor, 41, Was Part of 60's Folk Revival
description: David Blue, a singer with roots in the 1960's Greenwich Village folk-music revival, died of a heart attack Thursday while jogging around Washington Square Park. He was 41 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Rep. Garcia Elected For House Panel

title: NEW YORK CONSIDERS REPLACING LEGAL AID SOCIETY
description: The Legal Aid Society's lawyers have been on strike for nearly seven weeks, and the walkout has prompted Mayor Koch and some court officials and lawyers to question whether the society should be replaced as the primary defender of indigents charged with crimes in New York City.

title: Soviet Trade Lagging in '82
description: Soviet foreign trade will expand by less than 5 percent in 1982, one of the lowest growth rates since World War II, Foreign Trade Minister Nikolai S. Patolichev disclosed today.

title: CROWN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FGI INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ITZHAK PERLMAN
description: THE virtuosity of the violinist Itzhak Perlman was everywhere in evidence in his recital Sunday night in Avery Fisher Hall, but it was a particular sort of virtuosity. Mr. Perlman can do just about anything he wants on the violin. But he is not the sort of virtuoso who reaches into a listener's guts, or who has the audience balancing with him on the sliver of contact between bow and string. Nor is he the master technician whose patter chills a listener with glistening perfection. Mr. Perlman is not a visitor from other realms casting spells; he does not separate himself from the audience as a being with special powers - frightening and transcendental.

title: U.S. TRIES TO OBTAIN AID FOR YUGOSLAVIA
description: The Reagan Administration is trying to put together an aid package worth roughly $1 billion to help Yugoslavia through a financial crisis arising from debts of about $20 billion. According to American officials, the Yugoslavs are facing a cash-flow problem rather than the specter of insolvency.

title: PAUL NEWMAN STARS IN 'THE VERDICT'
description: A solidly old-fashioned courtroom drama such as ''The Verdict'' could have gotten by with a serious, measured performance from its leading man, or it could have worked well with a dazzling movie-star turn. The fact that Paul Newman delivers both makes a clever, suspenseful, entertaining movie even better.

title: LOW IN SPIRITS, NORWEGIANS COPE WITH A DRY SPELL
description: Tradition here has it that the best way to handle the mountains of fatty mutton and pork at the pre-Christmas dinner feast known as ''julebord'' is to drown them in a sea of alcohol.

title: TV: 'THE ROSEMARY CLOONEY STORY'
