description: AN irritating example of the kind of television biography that seems to be revealing a lot but is really carefully vague can be found on CBS at 9 o'clock tonight. ''Rosie: The Rosemary Clooney Story'' begins with the popular singer's nervous breakdown in 1968. Sitting in a mental institution, she struggles to remember her past, beginning with the first singing job she and her sister Betty got with a radio station in Cincinnati. The girls were still teen-agers. The year was 1945.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NICARAGUA EASES RULES ON FOREIGN INVESTMENT
description: In an effort to improve Nicaragua's business image, Joaquin Cuadra, Nicaragua's Minister of Finance, outlined new foreign investment rules yesterday. He described them as more favorable to foreign companies than the investment policies of the regime of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: BEATING AROUND THE BUSH
description: News item: Right-wing Republicans are intensifying opposition to Presidential aide James Baker on grounds that he is soft on Vice President Bush. Conservative political strategist Lyn Nofziger recently cautioned colleagues that they must make sure the coming Reagan-Bush campaign doesn't become a Bush-Reagan campaign.

title: A Vegetarian View
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: ''The Great Thanksgiving Turkey Debate'' (Nov. 17) should have offered some help to those of us who are offended by having a celebration centered around a dead bird. Instead, the no side of your article simply assured those who prefer the taste of another kind of bird that that kind of change in the menu would be perfectly acceptable.

title: MORE FRENCH PLANS FOR MILITARY CUTS REPORTED
description: The Chiefs of Staff of the French Air Force and Navy, in papers published today, said that the Government planned to reduce their services' manpower and equipment and suggested that such steps would require basic rethinking of French military strategy.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 23
description: Sales figures include leased departments

title: Arizona Faces N.C.A.A. Charges
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has accused the University of Arizona of improper conduct in athletic policies and practices from 1971 to the spring of 1980.

title: GUINNESS: A DISTINCTIVE TASTE OF IRELAND
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lisa deMauro is a New York writer who reports frequently on food. BY LISA deMAURO DUBLIN TWO visitors were making their way uncertainly along a grimy, deserted street on the north side of the River Liffey one evening when they came upon two police officers. ''We're looking for a wine bar,'' one of the visitors said. ''It's supposed to be around here somewhere.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fords in Town

title: CBS/Sony Inc.
description: The Sony Corporation and CBS Inc. said their CBS/Sony Inc. unit, which produces digital audiodisks in Japan, plans to make compact audiodisks in the United States.

title: 5 GET 15 TO 30 YEARS ON L.I. FOR TERRORIZING 100 IN MAY
description: Five Brooklyn men who pleaded guilty last month to rape and robbery in terrorizing more than 100 Long Island residents at two diners and a private home last May, were sentenced today in Nassau County Court to 15 to 30 years in prison.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISLANDERS SURGE TO VICTORY
description: The Islanders tonight recovered their knack for scoring as they trounced the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-3, in a free-wheeling game in Nassau Coliseum.

title: Welfare-Game Suit Dismissed by Judge
description: A judge ruled yesterday that a New York City official had been justified in urging stores not to sell a game that ridiculed welfare recipients.

title: LOMAK PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHARING BRAZIL'S ECONOMIC WOE
description: The results that emerged last month from Brazil's first free elections for executive offices in 17 years hold out great promise for future democracy. Whether or not this promise is fulfilled will depend on fundamental choices that the Government faces in the next few months - choices, above all, about who will bear the costs of reviving Brazil's stalled economy.

title: HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect new accounting methods for foreigncurrency translations

title: Ex-Soviet Writer Found Fatally Shot
description: A former Soviet screenwriter and film director who wrote two books since emigrating to the United States in 1972 was found shot to death Monday in his Manhattan apartment.

title: Jones May Miss Season
description: Bert Jones will miss Sunday's game because a neck injury and may be out the rest of the regular season, the Los Angeles Rams said today.

title: Hayden Takes Coast Office
description: Tom Hayden, the Chicago 7 defendant who led street protests in the 1960's against the Vietnam War, has taken office as a State Assemblyman. The 42-year-old Democrat, representing a Santa Monica district, took the oath Monday for his first elected office from Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. in opening day ceremonies for California's 1983-84 Legislature.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Saturday on the Reagan Administration's cancer policy incorrectly identified Frederica P. Perera. She is a senior staff scientist for the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: Advertising; Consumer Research Methods
description: CONSUMERS really dig the name of Purina Butchers Blend on a dog food product. Corning Ware has strong brand loyalty. Many listeners would be willing to pay for commercial-free radio. All three of these conclusions resulted from focus group interviews, sessions at which trained questioners delved into the minds of 10 to 12 just plain folks grouped around a table. All three were also reported in the advertising trade press.

title: Promotions at Morrow
description: Sherry W. Arden, who joined William Morrow & Company as publicity director in 1968 and was named associate publisher in 1978, has been appointed publisher. James Landis, the company's editorial director, was elected a senior vice president. Both appointments were announced by Lawrence Hughes, president of Morrow, a subsidiary of the Hearst Corporation.

title: Rumanian Debt Accord
description: Rumania signed an agreement with major creditor banks to restructure its 1981 and 1982 debt payments, Barclays Bank International said today. The plan spreads repayment of 80 percent of 1981 arrears and 1982 principal over six and a half years, with three years' grace. The remaining 20 percent is to be paid by March 1983.

title: Bomb Kills 2 in Lebanon
description: Two people were killed and 10 others wounded here today when a bomb exploded outside the local headquarters of the Progressive Socialist Party, a largely Druse group. Druse militiamen have been fighting almost daily gun battles with Christian armed groups in recent weeks in the mountains near Beirut. The Druse leader, Walid Jumblat, escaped a car bomb attack last Wednesday.

title: Angola Reported Ready To Meet South Africa
description: Angolan and South African Government representatives are expected to meet today on neutral ground for direct talks after seven years of undeclared war, official Cape Verdean sources said.

title: News Analysis
description: The elimination within the next month of ceilings on the amount of interest banks may pay on certain consumer checking and savings accounts is expected to have profound effects on the economy.

title: DANELO UNDAUNTED DESPITE PROBLEMS
description: Joe Danelo, the Giants' field-goal kicker who has not been doing well, watched the Jets beat the Detroit Lions on television Monday night. When the Jets' Pat Leahy missed two reasonably easy field-goal attempts, Danelo felt compassion.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE single most versatile and easy-to-cook dish from a raw state, in my opinion, is shrimp. In their most basic form, direct from a net, heads and shell left on, they can be tossed into a pot for a moment and they are ready to peel and eat with a little melted butter. In Louisiana a little Worcestershire and Tabasco are traditionally added to the butter.

title: Exit President Lopez Portillo
description: There is a dramatic moment in Mexican politics when the brilliant sash of the nation's colors is taken from the shoulder of the presiding President and placed across the shoulder of his successor.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: AMERICAN record retailers have been waiting for several years now for a new album from the British supergroup Led Zeppelin. It doesn't really matter that the group has been officially defunct since the death of its drummer, John Bonham, in 1980.

title: MUSIC: ESCOBAR'S MADRIGALS
description: ONE of the real pleasures of attending a concert at the Center for Inter-American Relations is its setting in an old Park Avenue Mansion. On Friday night, the center's lavish drawing room was the site for a concert of music by the contemporary Colombian composer Luis Antonio Escobar.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MX DEBATE IN HOUSE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the general debate in the House of Representatives today on the military appropriation bill and the funds for the MX missile, as recorded by The New York Times: Don H. Clausen Republican of California

title: Public Service Workers Go on Strike in Israel
description: About 400,000 public service employees started a 48-hour strike today over wage provisions in a new contract.

title: Dow Gains 1.29; Volume Rises
description: The stock market managed to finish with a small advance yesterday after much of its rise from earlier in the day evaporated as investors cashed recent profits. Trading was busier.

title: Enlightening Flight
description: Bobby Francis has spent a lot of time around the National Hockey League because his father is Emile Francis, the coach and general manager of the St. Louis Blues. But now the young center is finally getting a chance to play - with the Detroit Red Wings.

title: LANGUAGE BARRIER IS THWARTING YOUNG VIETNAMESE IMMIGRANTS IN ELMHURST
description: She stays up half the night copying over the notes she took in class, hoping the repetition alone will help her absorb the English. She keeps long lists of vocabulary words and has not missed a day of school since she began. She gets all her assignments done early - including the report on ''Death of a Salesman,'' but after reading the play at least four times, she is still not sure who the salesman is. And Khan Duong, who is 20 years old, is failing at Newtown High School. There are few at Newtown, in Elmhurst, Queens, who know about Miss Duong - how she is already in charge of a household of five, that in addition to school she works stuffing Chinese-style steam buns in a factory and practices the piano two hours a day instead of eating lunch.

title: ISRAEL MAY SELL ARMS TO HONDURAS, SHARON SAYS AFTER MEETING CHIEFS
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel said today that he was talking with officials here about possible Israeli arms sales to Honduras.

title: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $215,000...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,016,000 for the latest period and $347,000 for the yr-earlier period; the results for 1981 have been reclassified to reflect discontinued operations and include Service Machine Group (SMG) since its acquisition effective Apr 30, 1981

title: P & F INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-After a loss of $162,079 from discontinued operations and a gain of $4,608,508 on the settlement of long-term debt

title: MUSIC: PIANIST IN VARIED BILL
description: RITA BOUBOULIDI played piano music by Brahms, Beethoven and Chopin in a benefit concert for the Leukemia Society of America in Carnegie Hall Monday night. For followers of piano music it was all familiar territory - the two Brahms Rhapsodies (Op. 79), two Beethoven sonatas, the Opus 109 in E and the ''Moonlight,'' and finally Chopin's 24 Preludes.

title: FORMER NEW YORKERS CONTINUE TO HELP NEDDIEST CASES FUND
description: The effect of the recession and Federal economy measures on the poor is a source of concern to many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, even among those who view the city's needy from out of state.

title: DISPUTE BREAKS OUT ON LINCOLN WEST
description: A new dispute over the Lincoln West housing project - involving the developer's promise to pay for remodeling the cramped IRT subway station at 72d Street and Broadway - has arisen between City Council President Carol Bellamy and the Koch administration.

title: Q&A
description: Q. A word about recipes in which you specify ''Salt to taste, if desired.'' Isn't it a bit of a cop-out to use this expression instead of giving a substitute for the omitted salt? An herb, for example, that you have actually tried out in the recipe?

title: MILLER TECHNOLOGY & COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
COMTECH TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $100,000 or 2 cents a shr

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MEETING IN CAPITAL TODAY WILL FOCUS ON TRIBAL WATER CLAIMS
description: Over the last decade Indian tribes across the West have increasingly clashed with state governments and private interests over what they say are their historic rights to the region's scarce supplies of water.

title: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Military Analysis
description: Western intelligence sources say the Soviet Union's military position in Afghanistan appears to be deteriorating despite official announcements of victories over the Moslem insurgents.

title: IOWA OFFERS HART LESSONS FOR 1984
description: Senator Gary Hart was offered several lessons about running for President when he arrived here Sunday for his sixth visit this year.

title: Raging Panthers
description: Foge Fazio, the football coach at Pittsburgh, said his players were ''raging mad'' about reports of dissension on the Cotton Bowl-bound Panthers. But two players, Tim Lewis and Ron Sams, again criticized their teammates at a school-sponsored news conference.

title: HICKORY FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Power System Inc. has elected Alan J. Noia a vice president.

title: ECONOMIC ILLS SHAKE CHILEAN REGIME
description: The regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, although firmly entrenched after nine years in power, is being shaken for the first time by what both its supporters and opponents agree is a national crisis of confidence.

title: KNICKS LOSE THIRD STRAIGHT
description: The Knicks, who have collapsed offensively in the second half of many games this season, came up with one of their worst performances of the season tonight. They failed to score a point in the final 4 minutes 23 seconds and were beaten by the Chicago Bulls, 91-85.

title: Syracuse Chosen
description: State officials have awarded the Empire State Summer Games next year to Syracuse, which has been host to the Olympic-style event since its inception in 1978.

title: Economic Scene; Dealing With Joblessness
description: WITH 12 million Americans out of work -10.8 percent of the labor force - national economic policy is focusing increasingly on the causes and cures of unemployment.

title: NEW LEADER FOR SCIENCE FOUNDATION
description: When the White House announced a few weeks ago that President Reagan had appointed Edward A. Knapp, a physicist, to be director of the National Science Foundation, the threesentence notice attracted little attention.

title: For the Record
description: Steve Boda said he got such inquiries frequently. A former football player or a university sports information director will call to ask why the National Collegiate Athletic Association is overlooking a record.

title: KING SITS IN MANAGER'S SEAT, AT LUNCH
description: Clyde King, the Yankees' manager-in-waiting -he is waiting to find out if he is still the manager - walked into the annual managers' luncheon at the Sheraton-Waikiki Hotel today and sat in the manager's seat at the Yankees' table. He was even introduced as the Yankee manager, and he received the loudest applause of all the introductions.

title: Trial Under Way for Floridian Charged as Nazi Collaborator
description: A 75-year-old man accused of collaborating with the Nazis in World War II and lying to gain entry to this country has gone on trial.

title: MANILA NEWSPAPER CLOSED BY MARCOS
description: In the first crackdown on the Philippine press since the lifting of martial law in January 1981, the military arrested the editor-publisher of the English-language newspaper We Forum today.

title: No Headline
description: MISSOURI TOWN LOSES ITS GAMBLE WITH RIVER

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1982; The Economy
description: Americans reduced their outstanding consumer debt in October for the first time in 10 months, lowering the total debt by $324 million, the Federal Reserve reported. It cited a $350 million drop in cash loans outstanding from banks and certain finance companies. Credit for auto loans also declined. The figures were seen as evidence of continuing consumer caution. (Page D1.)

title: Pros Urged In Olympic Soccer
description: The world governing body of soccer has proposed that professional soccer players be allowed to participate in the 1984 Olympic Games at Los Angeles.

title: ALCOHOLISM: TREATING THE FAMILY AS A WHOLE
description: Alcoholism-rehabilitation centers across the nation are adopting a new style of therapy - treatment of the family as a whole. Its practitioners believe such treatment raises the long-term recovery rates of alcoholics and helps their family members as well. The increasing emphasis on the involvement of families in a variety of ways during the recovery process, according to some alcoholism experts, is transforming the nature of treatment in America. Some researchers believe First of two articles on a widening form of alcoholism treatment. that the use of family therapy is helping to heal the historic rift between mental-health professionals and alcohol-rehabilitation counselors, many of whom have been traditionally skeptical of recovery strategies not based on the precepts of Alcoholics Anonymous.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
ZIA SEES PAKISTAN AS THE 'FRONT LINE'
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq likes to show visitors a map of this part of the world to which he has affixed a transparent, bright red acetate overlay. The overlay portrays Afghanistan, Pakistan's northwestern neighbor, and the adjoining part of the Soviet Union as a single red arrowhead pointing at, and almost reaching, the Arabian Sea and the mouth of the Persian Gulf. Only Pakistan stands in the way.

title: GINGERBREAD MOLD
description: THE baking bug is stirring in many cooks these days, even in those who avoid it the rest of the year. The holiday season is synonymous with colorful cakes, garish cookies and festive pies. One of the most whimsical traditions is the gingerbread house.

title: Defense Opens in Raid On Kentucky Home
description: A former Kentucky prosecutor testified today that a ''plan of action'' to infiltrate schools, destroy churches and discredit local officials was seized from two civil rights workers who contend their constitutional rights were violated in the 1967 raid on their home.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CASE IN WESTCHESTER AGAINST U.N. ENVOY IS INTERNATIONAL ISSUE
description: A police case involving a North Korean diplomat who has been secluded in his country's mission in Manhattan for almost three months rather than face charges of sexual abuse has grown into a diplomatic issue with international repercussions.

title: News Analysis
description: The decisive vote in the House of Representatives today to reject funds to procure the MX missile reflects a broad belief on Capitol Hill that President Reagan's military buildup has gone too far, too fast.

title: NCH reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including income of $355,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr and $1,005,000 or 10cents a shr for the 6 mos from an accounting change; yr-ago results have not been restated

title: BASEBALL
description: MILWAUKEE (AL) - A free agent, B ob McClure, pitcher, agreed to re-sign w ith the team. MINNESOTA (AL) - Named Charlie M anuel to manage its Class A affiliate at W isconsin Rapids in Midwest League.

title: A's DUGOUT: FROM ACERBIC TO CEREBRAL
description: ''Baseball people hear you're writing a book,'' says Steve Boros, who is writing two, ''and it makes them nervous.'' Also, curious. They are curious because Boros is the man who recently replaced Billy Martin as manager of the Oakland A's, and there is no greater contrast in the corridors of baseball's business meetings here.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1982
description: International The MX missile was threatened as the House voted 245 to 176 to delete funds to produce the weapons in 1983. Fifty Republicans joined 195 Democrats in denying the funds for the $26 billion program to build 100 of the intercontinental weapons. Although the House vote was not the final Congressional action, it was a severe setback for President Reagan. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The Administration accused Moscow of trying to influence the Congressional debate over the MX missile with warnings that the Soviet Union would match any new missile produced by Washington. (D23:6.)

title: BEN KINGSLEY IN PANORAMIC 'GANDHI'
description: TRUE greatness cannot be hidden behind mere ordinariness. Some subjects are so pervasively great that no film, given a certain level of intelligence on the part of the people who make it, can fail to catch something of the essence.

title: UNWITTING QUENCHER OF STUDENTS' THIRST
description: To the Editor:

title: RADIANT TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
TV: WNET WILL SHOW 'THIRD REICH'
description: ''THE RISE AND FALL OF THE THIRD REICH,'' which airs at 9:05 tonight on WNET, Channel 13, was made in 1968 and was last shown here about five years ago. As a rule, public stations find it considerably cheaper to buy an old program than to produce a new one and, given their straitened circumstances, we shall probably be seeing more such acquisitions in the months ahead. May they all be up to the quality of this one.

title: BOMB PIONEER SOUGHT NUCLEAR BAN
description: Dr. George B. Kistiakowsky, who worked on the developing the first atomic bomb and later became a leading advocate of banning nuclear weapons, died today at home at the age of 82, Harvard University announced.

title: New Tylenol Packages Shipped to Stores in Northeast
description: The first tamper-resistant packages of Tylenol capsules have been shipped to 120 supermarkets in the Northeast, according to a spokesman for the Supermarkets General chain.

title: One Man's Prediction
description: Mark Murphy of the Washington Redskins, one of the player representatives who opposed the tentative agreement that ended the N.F.L. strike, predicted that the league's 1,500 players would ratify the contract in the voting scheduled today by a 2-to-1 margin. The 28 player representatives voted Monday, 19-9, to recommend the ratification of the five-year, $1.6 billion agreement. ''I would expect the membership to vote about the same way,'' said Murphy, a member of the union's executive committee and a Redskins defensive back.

title: U.S. AND CANADA TALKS SET TODAY
description: The Chrysler Corporation late Tuesday rejected a proposal by the United Automobile Workers Union for a larger wage increase than the company had offered, increasing doubt that a new labor agreement can be reached before Jan. 1.

title: 3% STATE AID CUT ORDERED BY KEAN
description: Governor Kean signed an executive order today that will cut all state aid programs and department budgets by 3 percent starting Jan. 1 to help close a projected $150 million deficit in the current state budget.

title: THIRD DEFENDANT RESTS CASE IN SLAYING OF JUDGE IN TEXAS
description: The third defendant on trial here for the murder of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. rested her case today after declaring that she was not guilty of conspiracy.

title: The Worst-Kept Secret War
description: When asked the other day if he could confirm a report in The Times that the C.I.A. is mobilizing a secret war against Nicaragua, President Reagan replied: ''No, and I don't think The New York Times can.'' But the growing evidence of American involvement can't be shrugged off so blandly. There's nothing secret any more about the training of exile armies in Florida and the recurrent border raids into Nicaragua by insurgents claiming C.I.A. help; all this has been widely reported for months.

title: TEXACO AND PHILLIPS TO PAY LESS FOR OIL
description: Two major oil refiners, Texaco Inc. and the Phillips Petroleum Company, said yesterday that they were lowering the price they will pay for domestic crude oil by $1 a barrel. The moves were attributed to the oversupply of crude and lower-than-expected seasonal demand for heating oil.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sports People column on Saturday misidentified the fiancee of Duk Koo Kim, the South Korean boxer who was fatally injured in about last month. She is Lee Young Mi.

title: A LEANER LOOK FOT THE AIRLINES
description: A sustained slowdown in air traffic growth in recent years, together with high fuel costs, has made a tougher approach to operating costs all but compulsory for the world's international airlines. Most have shed their old managements and brought in more cost-conscious executives who have made deep personnel cuts, sold off aircraft and challenged the old strategy of growth for growth's sake.

title: Accord in Ohio Bus Strike
description: A tentative agreement in a three-week strike by city bus drivers and mechanics here was announced Monday night. The buses could be back in service Thursday if members of the Transport Workers Union approve the contract. Details of the agreement were not released.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sammy Serrano of Puerto Rico will defend his World Boxing Association junior-lightweight title against unbeaten Roger Mayweather of Las Vegas, Nev., in San Juan Jan.19, the promoter Don King said. ... Jayme LaRocca, the jockey from Fremont, Neb., who suffered spinal injuries in a fall at a West Virginia track, was transferred to a hospital in Philadelphia. ... Mats Wilander and Vitas Gerulaitis have clinched berths in the $400,000 Volvo Masters set for Jan. 18-23 at Madison Square Garden. ... Vin Scully, the sports broadcaster, has signed a multiyear contract with NBC worth $1 million annually, The Los Angeles Times reported. ... Ken Johnson, the sophomore center who started all 28 games as a freshman at Southern California and led the Trojans in rebounding, is quitting the team. Johnson will transfer to another school at the end of this semester. ... Bob McClure, a Milwaukee pitcher who had been a free agent, has re-signed with the Brewers.

title: Ann Novotny, 46, the Founder Of Editorial Research Service
description: Ann Novotny, the founder of Research Reports, a New York editorial research service, died of a stroke Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 46 years old and also lived in New Lebanon Center, N.Y.

title: Handoff on Exit 8
description: Exchanging game films is part of every National Football League team's weekly routine. Usually, films are sent by air and are picked up at the airport by a team photographer or administrative aide.

title: 5 WORKERS HURLED TO DEATHS AS A TEXAS TOWER COLLAPSES
description: An 1,800-foot television tower toppled as workers were lifting an antenna onto its pinnacle today, hurling five men to their deaths. Three workers atop a building nearby were injured.

title: Ian Smith Is Suspected Of Treason, Official Says
description: The Zimbabwean Minister of Legal Affairs said today that his Government had been conducting searches of former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's residences because it believed him ''guilty of subversive and treasonable behavior.''

title: LONG SPACE MISSION ENDING
description: Two Soviet astronauts were preparing to return to earth after establishing a new space endurance record, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: DRAFT REGISTRATION: SNAGS EMERGE IN PROSECUTIONS
description: Eleven months after President Reagan announced that he would continue to require 18-year-old men to register for a possible military draft, his Administration's efforts to prosecute violators are at least temporarily stuck in a legal and public relations quagmire.

title: Suspect Convicted of Causing $2 Million Watershed Damage
description: A 20-year-old Pequannock man was convicted of criminal mischief today for his part in an act of vandalism that caused more than $2 million in damage to the Newark water system.

title: PINKERTON'S IS BEING ACQUIRED
description: As part of a continuing acquisition campaign, American Brands Inc. will acquire Pinkerton's Inc., one of the biggest names in security services.

title: Consolidated Foods Loses a Top Officer
description: John J. Cardwell, the 51-year-old president and chief operating officer of the Chicago-based Consolidated Foods Corporation, abruptly resigned yesterday, citing ''differences over policy and management style'' with the chairman and chief executive officer, John H. Bryan Jr.

title: STATE LAWS URGED ON CHILD CAR SEATS
description: A Federal safety board, asserting 90 percent of infant deaths in car accidents could be prevented, urged all states today to enact laws requiring that young children traveling in motor vehicles be confined to safety seats.

title: SETBACK DEALING WITH RADIOACTIVE WASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: Clark Family Thanks Nation for Its Support
description: The family of Dr. Barney Clark thanked ''the people of this wonderful country'' today for their support for the artificial heart recipient.

title: THE GENUINELY STALINIST WAYS OF MAO ZEDONG
description: To the Editor:

title: Icahn Raises Dan River Bid
description: Carl C. Icahn, the investor, has raised his group's hostile tender offer for Dan River Inc.'s common stock to $18 a share from $16.50. The previous offer by Mr. Icahn and three companies he controls was for up to 2 million shares and was to have expired Monday night.

title: EXECUTION BY INJECTION STIRS FEAR AND SHARPENS DEBATE
description: The execution early this morning of a convicted murderer by injection of a lethal dose of anesthetics, the first such execution in the United States, today sharpened the debate over the moral validity of the death penalty and over whether it can be administered in a ''humane'' manner.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Down on the Farm In Bushwick

title: URANIUM DEAL FOR INDIA ASSAILED
description: Two members of Congress said today that the Administration's decision to permit France to provide nuclear fuel for an American-supplied reactor in India ''casts doubts'' on the United States commitment to stopping the spread of nuclear arms.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANIMATED

title: 'POLITBURO' POWER-EAST AND WEST
description: To the Editor:

title: T. Cortlandt Williams, Ex-Head Of Stone & Webster Engineers
description: T. Cortlandt Williams, a former president and chairman of the Stone & Webster Engineering Corporation, an international construction and consulting concern, died Saturday in Bel Air, Fla. A former resident of Greenwich, Conn., he lived in Largo, Fla., and was 85 years old.

title: Nicaraguan Exiles Seek Wider Base of Support
description: A coalition of Nicaraguan exile leaders who are running a paramilitary campaign against the Sandinist Government in Managua made a public appearance today.

title: Japan Weighs Easing Trade
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone directed his Cabinet today to draft new measures to increase imports and ease trade relations with the United States and Europe, Government officials said.

title: SOVIET MX WARNING PROTESTED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration today accused the Soviet Union of trying to influence the Congressional debate over the MX missile with warnings from Moscow that the Soviet military authorities would match any new missile produced by the United States.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3:00 P.M.

title: Kidding Around About Crime
description: Just before the election, the Senate tried to show voters how tough Congress could be about crime. Never mind constitutional niceties like the presumption of innocence; in the name of public safety it passed a preventive detention bill that would make it national policy to jail people who can't prove they won't commit a violent crime.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Monsanto Staff
description: The Monsanto Company said 1,240 of its salaried workers in the United States had chosen voluntary early retirement since last July 1 in response to its drive to trim employment. It said that it would continue to reassign workers within the company but that it planned no further large-scale reductions. The employees who chose early retirement represented 60 percent of those eligible, the company said.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including special credits of $992,000 for the qr and $3,396,000 for the 9 mosfrom the sale of rental properties...C-I ncluding a special credit of $264,000...D-Net loss including a special credit of $415,000

title: A FESTIVAL OF LIGHTS AND LATKES
description: HANUKKAH, the Jewish Feast of Lights, which begins at sundown on Friday, commemorates the miracle that is said to have occurred in 165 B.C. when the Maccabees recaptured the Temple in Jerusalem and rededicated it. They found only enough consecrated oil to keep a holy lamp burning for a single night, but incredibly the oil lasted for eight nights - hence the celebration during which candles are lit in the candelabrum called a menorah on eight consecutive evenings.

title: FREDERICK SILAS BUCK
description: Frederick Silas Buck, an official at Yonkers Raceway since it opened in 1950, died at his home today after a series of illnesses over the last year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER. By Judith Krantz. 531 pages. Crown. $15.95.

title: Edward O'Rorke, 75, Ex-Head Of City Chamber of Commerce
description: Edward A. O'Rorke, a former president of the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry, died Monday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y.. He was 75 years old.

title: SYMPOSIUM ASKS WHY THERE IS EVIL UNDER GOD
description: Why, if God is good and omnipotent, is there evil in the world? Why do people suffer? Those questions, perhaps the most perplexing in theology and intensified by the Holocaust, were addressed by three leading Jewish thinkers and authors at the 92d Street Y on Monday night during its annual Theology Roundtable.

title: Daniel Swern, 66, Researcher Who Developed New Plastics
description: Daniel Swern, who helped pave the way for the ubiquitous use of plastics and became a chemistry professor and senior researcher at Temple University, died Sunday of a heart attack in Philadelphia. He was 66 years old.

title: Canada Oil Profits Drop
description: The after-tax profits of the Canadian petroleum industry fell by 54 percent during the first half of the year, to $810 million, from $1.8 billion in the comparable period a year ago, the Government reported today.

title: Stevenson Asks Court For Recount in Illinois
description: Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate defeated in the Illinois gubernatorial race last month, petitioned the State Supreme Court today for a statewide recount of ballots.

title: ROLL-CALL OF HOUSE VOTE ON FUNDS TO PROCURE THE MX MISSILE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 245 to 176 by which the House today rejected funds for the MX missile. A ''yes'' vote is a vote in favor of withholding the money. Voting ''yes'' were 195 Democrats and 50 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 38 Democrats and 138 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, no; Flippo, no; Nichols, no; Shelby, no. Republicans - Dickinson, no; Edwards, no; Smith, no.

title: CCI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including gains of $871,000 or 14 cents a shr for the qr and $1,784,000 or 28cents a shr for the 6 mos from the repurchase of CCI subordinated debentures

title: WEALTH OF CLASSIC GIFTS FOR CHILDREN
description: THE V.I.P.'s on almost anyone's Christmas list are the children. They, in turn, have been busy thinking up what they would like and making lists as long as their arms. Adults have to face the fact that electronic games will figure prominently on the most-wanted lists. But hordes of traditional gifts are to be found: dolls and sleds, trains and cuddly toys -things that youngsters have always loved and still play with, electronic age or not. 1. Sled With a Seat If Christmas should be white this year, a child should have a sled. A handsome one from Canada, of maple and with steel runners, has a seat to make it safe for the youngest members of the family. The Penny Whistle shops at 1283 Madison Avenue (91st Street) and 448 Columbus Avenue (81st Street) have it for $45. 2. Big Little Red Truck What small boy doesn't want to drive a truck? A bright red wooden one from France is big enough (26 inches long) for a preschooler to sit in. The large white wheels are just decor; smaller real wheels underneath make the truck mobile. It's at Barney's at $125.

title: DANCE: MEL WONG COMPANY
description: MEL WONG certainly kept his dancers busy at Sunday night's concert by the Mel Wong Dance Company in the Theater of the Riverside Church. Each piece offered was crammed with steps and, on occasion, with symbolism. Yet steps and symbols rarely added up to much.

title: TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: In regard to the Miller-Capon Great Thanksgiving Turkey Debate of Nov. 17: It was not by chance That Capon took the negative stance Turkey couldn't be the favorite game He'll always be a booster Of a plump castrated rooster. EZEKIEL KOSBERG Bronx

title: F.H.A. Loan Requests Rise
description: Applications for home loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration soared to 82,545 last month, the largest November figure ever, the Government's top housing official announced today.

title: House Democrats Vote New Power to Speaker
description: House Democrats adopted a package of rules changes today to strengthen the Speaker's control and make it harder to force floor votes on social issues.

title: Heinz's Net Up 7.2% in Quarter
description: The H.J. Heinz Company said today that its profit rose to $54.4 million, or $1.14 a share, in the fiscal second quarter, ended Oct. 27, up 7.2 percent from $50.8 million, or $1.08 a share, in the corresponding period of 1981.

title: Careers; Entering Business School
description: EACH spring Victoria A. Falco, director of admissions at Carnegie-Mellon University's Graduate School of Industrial Administration, reads about 1,000 applications for entry to the school's two-year program. She accepts 250 or so, expecting half of them to show up. This fall, 122 did.

title: BOND PRICES FALL AS FED ACTS
description: Bond prices retreated yesterday after the Federal Reserve, in a surprise move, temporarily drained reserves from the banking system by selling securities to dealers.

title: 3 Indicted in Firebombings At Home of a Black Family
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted three men on charges of participating in a series of firebombings at the home of a black family in a Chicago suburb.

title: For Better Teacher Balance
description: The relaxation of Federal requirements for desegregating teaching staffs in New York City's public schools was a victory for the powerful teachers' union and another example of the Reagan Administration's eagerness to retreat from affirmative action. Chancellor Frank Macchiarola applauds the decision because it leaves him with greater flexibility.

title: Nancy Hanks Honored For Civic Leadership
description: Nancy Hanks, former head of the National Endowment for the Arts, was presented yesterday with the first Founders Award for Civic Leadership. The award was established by Partners for Livable Places to recognize outstanding leadership in the field of community livability.

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
JOBLESSNESS IS MISERY-EVEN IN BRITAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: DeLorean Seeks Lower Bail
description: Attorneys for John Z. DeLorean told a Federal district judge today they would seek reduction of the $10 million bail the automobile maker has posted.

title: SOCIALISTS CRITICIZE U.S. OVER NICARAUGA
description: A delegation of Latin American and European Social Democrats has ended a four-day visit to Central America, apparently convinced that American support for anti-Sandinist rebels is helping radicalize Nicaragua's Government.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Aerosol Food Scents

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ONE of the first hints I had of my pregnancy in 1969 was the development of a distinct aversion to two previously beloved foods: red meat and coffee. Just the thought of them made me slightly queasy, and consuming either one of them was out of the question for most of those nine months. And while I vividly recall my husband and I toasting the news of our long-awaited pregnancy with a glass or two of champagne, my tolerance of and desire for alcohol were greatly diminished until after I gave birth.

title: WINE TALK
description: ANYTHING related to wine makes a superb Christmas gift, but glasses are especially appropriate, even for wine lovers who already have an ample supply, because there never seem to be enough for tasting parties and large dinners. The glass is the basic item of equipment for any oenophile, which seems obvious but is often ignored. A glass can have a crucial impact on the overall wine experience, yet its size, shape and design may be considered secondary to cost and the ability to survive in an automatic dishwasher.

title: U.S. Reported to Oppose Fast Cleanup of Dioxin
description: Officials at the Environmental Protection Agency have decided against ordering an emergency cleanup of suburban St. Louis residential areas contaminated with dioxins, sources at the agency said tonight.

title: People
description: * Stan Gerber and Colin Probert have been promoted to executive vice president at Calet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector.

title: American Medical
description: American Medical International Inc. and Petrolane Inc. said American Medical would buy certain Petrolane assets for $87 million. Included are 24 psychiatric and substance-abuse hospitals in 10 states, mostly in the West and Southwest. The companies said the transaction would be completed in early 1983.

title: BOWMAR INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ZAKES MOKAE'S BROTHER EXECUTED
description: The brother of the South African actor Zakes Mokae was hanged for murder today despite 11th-hour attempts to win a reprieve.

title: THE USO AT KENNEDY
description: The USO center at Kennedy International Airport offers information and referral services, travel guidance, light refreshments and a nursery for the thousands of members of the armed services and their families who use the airport each year on their way around the country and overseas.

title: Richard Todd Takes Command
description: R ichard Todd is in command now as the Jets' quarterback. It's his offense. His team, really. By the nature of the National Football League, if the quarterback is not in command, nobody is. The defensive players can't do it by themselves. The quarterback has to put those points up on the scoreboard, as Richard Todd did Monday night, when he completed 23 of 32 passes for 384 yards and three touchdowns in a 28-13 victory over the Detroit Lions that gave the Jets the glow of a true Super Bowl contender.

title: Invaders Sign Chester
description: Raymond Chester, the former tight end for the Oakland Raiders and Baltimore Colts, has been signed by the Oakland Invaders of the United States Football League. The 34-year-old Chester was waived by the Raiders before the National Football League season began.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SIMCOE ERIE INVESTORS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: Trimming Wings at F.A.A.

title: PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Washington Bullets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. The Nets will be trying for their fifth straight victory.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp. of Evanston, Ill., said it had signed a letter of intent to sell three intravenous products businesses to Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: NEW MIDTOWN LAW OFFICES FEATURING SPECIAL SERVICES
description: The most expensive office space in Manhattan will cost you $100 a square foot or more. It is not, however, ordinary office space: It is a hybrid, a kind of hotel full of offices for business executives, lawyers and other professionals.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Toy Store! Wow!

title: PRINCETON DEFEATS FORDHAM BY 69-54
description: Fordham was forced to play tonight against a textbook that Princeton players know by heart: Basketball by Pete Carril.

title: Restraint on Coaches Due
description: A proposal expected to be approved at the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention next month would make it mandatory that every coach's contract include the stipulation that he could be suspended without pay or dismissed for ''deliberate and serious violations of N.C.A.A. regulations.''

title: MUSIC: CANTILENA PLAYERS
description: Though the Cantilena Chamber Players have made a specialty of playing contemporary works and little-known Romantic works written for the piano quartet, at the 92d Street Y on Sunday afternoon they sounded like Classical musicians. The playing was always conversational and balanced; phrases answered counterphrases; the thickest textures were scrupulously transparent.

title: HEAD OF TEAMSTERS DENIES BRIBERY
description: Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, repeatedly denied on the witness stand today any attempt to bribe Senator Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada.

title: Dr. Ruth B. Freeman, Public Health Professor
description: Ruth B. Freeman, a professor of public health administration and a former national director of nursing services for the Red Cross, died last Thursday in Cockeysville, Md., of Alzheimer's disease. Dr. Freeman was 76 years old.

title: SENATE PANEL ADOPTS A REPORT TERMING U.S. LAX IN ABSCAM
description: A special Senate committee adopted a report today criticizing the Federal Government for what it said were lax controls over its Abscam undercover operation, committee sources said. The investigation led to the conviction of seven members of Congress on bribery and conspiracy charges.

title: STAGE: '84 CHARING CROSS ROAD' OPENS
description: AFTER seeing ''84 Charing Cross Road,'' the tiny divertissement that opened at the Nederlander Theater last night, you don't feel as if you've been to the theater, but to afternoon tea. For nearly two hours, two fine actors, Ellen Burstyn and Joseph Maher, stand at either side of the stage and recite good-natured, sporadically amusing, utterly innocuous letters that were once written between a struggling New York writer named Helene Hanff and a London antiquarian book dealer named Frank Doel. Although Miss Burstyn does take the radical step of crossing from her side of the stage to Mr. Maher's at play's end, this is mostly an evening of sedentary gentility.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The dark sedan went down the street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, then backed up and went down the street again. The car had red and white Indiana plates. So did all the other cars parked on the street. The people who live in the neighborhood sat on the stoops. A young man in a sweatshirt, with an easy, ambling walk, came down the street after the car had backed up for the second time.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER PREMIERE
description: WHAT promised to be an interesting program by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center never quite came off. Sunday's concert, in Alice Tully Hall, included some offbeat material, but did not add up to a successful totality.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: As she was riding the E train recently on the way to her office in midtown Manhattan, Dolores M. Byrne heard a curious conversation. It is faithfully offered here in its entirety:

title: SONG: DI LASSO REMEMBERED
description: MOST of us seemed to have overlooked an important musical anniversary -that of Orlando di Lasso born 450 years ago this year. Capella Nova, the 23-voice a cappella vocal ensemble led by Richard Taruskin, has not.

title: Canada's Budget Deficit
description: Canada's September budget deficit rose to $1.96 billion from $230 million a year earlier, the Finance Department said today. Revenues for the month totaled $4.08 billion, compared with $5.23 billion a year ago, while spending rose to $6.04 billion from $5.46 billion.

title: RECIPIENT OF HEART SUFFERS SEIZURES BUT PHYSICIANS RULE OUT A STROKE
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the recipient of the world's first permanent artificial heart, suffered several seizures today while he was talking with his doctors.

title: LOX AND STURGEON: THE WEST SIDE FOOD STORY
description: IT is 8:40 on a cold Sunday morning and upper Broadway is about as quiet as it ever gets. In a narrow, inconspicuous shop at 89th Street, with assorted nuts and dried fruits in the window, six white-frocked men are rhythmically slicing the rosy flesh of smoked salmons. A patient and appreciative audience, ranging from florid joggers in pastel athletic suits to frail old men in threadbare overcoats, takes in the performance at Murray's Sturgeon Shop, occasionally uttering a ''yesss,'' or ''bew-tee-full.''

title: BUDGET PROPOSAL WOULD CUT BACK HEALTH PROGRAMS
description: A new budget proposal by the Department of Health and Human Services would reduce Medicare and Medicaid benefits, tighten the fee schedule for physicians and make other changes to lower the expected cost of the two health programs by $5.2 billion in the next fiscal year.

title: VOTE DUE ON U.S. AUTO CONTENT BILL
description: The way was cleared today for a House vote as early as Thursday on the most bitterly contested trade bill to hit Congress in years - the so-called domestic content bill requiring cars sold here to be built mostly with American parts and manpower.

title: Miss de Agostini Wins Downhill
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 7 (AP) - Doris de Agostini of Switzerland won the season's first World Cup women's downhill ski race in driving snow and rain today.

title: AIDED IN RADAR DEVELOPMENT
description: Dr. Irving Wolff, a former vice president for research of the RCA Laboratories and one of the developers of radar, died Sunday at Princeton Hospital in New Jersey. He was 88 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * ARGO Systems Inc. said it had completed an offering of 880,649 common shares at $21.50 a share, through an underwriting group led by Alex. Brown & Sons.

title: Allied Unit Sale
description: The Allied Corporation, a major supplier of chemicals to the electronics industry, has agreed to sell its Hi-Pure Chemicals Inc. unit to settle antitrust allegations, the Federal Communications Commission said. The agency had charged that Allied's 1981 acquisition of Hi-Pure's parent company, the Fisher Scientific Company of Pittsburgh, was anticompetitive because Allied and Hi-Pure were competitors. Allied, which did not admit it violated the law, must sell the company to an approved buyer within 15 months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ray of Hope

title: DEATH TOLL AT 16 IN ULSTER BOMBING
description: The toll in a bomb attack here Monday night rose today to 11 British soldiers and 5 civilians killed, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher pledged in London that her Government would not ''rest until these merciless killers are brought to justice.''

title: Death, Purified
description: Death row inmates call lethal injection ''the ultimate high.'' Instead of suffering electric shock and burns or gagging on poison gas, the victim simply drifts off in a trance. That is how the state of Texas executed Charles Brooks, a murderer, and so marked another advance in the technology of death.

title: Deere Drops 78 Percent; Bombardier Posts Profit
description: Deere & Company said yesterday that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter plunged 78 percent because of the badly depressed farm equipment business. The company, the world's largest maker of farm equipment as well as an important producer of construction machinery, held out little hope for an improvement in the current fiscal year.

title: CONSUMER DEBT DOWN IN OCTOBER
description: Americans paid back more money than they borrowed in October for the first time in 10 months, lowering the total of outstanding consumer debt by $324 million, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Who's Counting?
description: Nassau Coliseum, the home rink for the Islanders, is one of the few arenas in the National Hockey League without a shot counter, or ''shot clock,'' that records shots on goals. Some fans think that management is depriving them of useful information for the sake of saving money.

title: Poet Traveling to U.S.  To Be Married to Wife
description: Armando Valladares, the poet who was freed from a Cuban jail after 22 years and has been living here in exile, said today that he would fly to the United States to be married to his wife, Marta, in a religious ceremony in Miami.

title: A TIME TO STUDY THE WHOLE OF MARTIN LUTHER
description: To the Editor:

title: SAUDIS REPORTEDLY PLANNING TO LEND $2 BILLION TO FRANCE
description: Saudi Arabia has agreed to lend the French Government $2 billion to help swell its depleted foreign exchange reserves and support the ailing franc, two French newspapers reported today.

title: Article 084150 -- No Title
description: A John Lennon Award has been created at the University of California at Los Angeles to provide $1,000 a year to a graduate student whose research proposal best exemplifies the spirit of the slain musician.

title: THE QUESTION OF SILENCE RAISES VOICES
description: This was not something cooked up by a band of religious zealots or a national organization of Christian fundamentalists. Thomas Cherney, a member of the local school board, just thought ''it would be nice to, you know, say a little prayer of thanks at the beginning of the school day.''

title: Lincoln Stock Plan
description: The Lincoln Income Life Insurance Company said it had agreed to buy back 289,048 shares of its common stock from the ICH Corporation in exchange for 98.8 percent of the stock of its Integrity National Life Insurance Company and $2.09 million in cash.

title: NICK NOLTE AND EDDIE MURPHY IN '48 HOURS'
description: WALTER HILL, the director of such beautiful but stilted tough guy movies as ''The Warriors'' and ''The Long Riders,'' has attempted something very different in ''48 Hours,'' a male-buddy action film that's positively witty and warm-hearted compared with his other work. It teams a messy, mean-talking white cop with a hip young black convict who's been freed on a two-day pass, during which time the two trade bitter insults but develop a friendship beneath all the bluster.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Saturday about job interviews incorrectly identified the district attorney's office described by one law student, Joseph Tock. It was the Brooklyn office.

title: Energy Panel Backs Hodel
description: A Senate committee recommended today that Donald P. Hodel, Under Secretary of the Interior for the past two years, be confirmed as Secretary of Energy.

title: Top St. Joe Minerals Post Is Changing
description: John C. Duncan, chairman and chief executive officer of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, will retire at the end of the year, and John A. Wright, president, has been elected to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS URGE WORKS BILL AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR ROAD-JOB PLAN
description: Senate Democrats today proposed a three-year, $17.9 billion public works job program that would be more expensive and wide-ranging than the highway-repair bill adopted by the House early today.

title: Kroger Elects President And Adds New Position
description: The Kroger Company, Cincinnati, announced the election yesterday of William G. Kagler as president and John A. Cornett as vice chairman, a new position. Kroger is the nation's second-largest supermarket chain after Safeway Stores Inc.

title: VIDEO CONTRACEPTION
description: Provocative sexual innuendo dominates prime-time television and prestigious magazines. Films made to attract teen-age audiences are blatantly erotic. So, too, the lyrics of popular songs, as well as the passionate plot lines of soap operas.

title: Required Reading Thurmond at 80
description: On the occasion of the 80th birthday of Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, Senators Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the majority leader, and Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin offered their congratulations. Dec 6, 1982:

title: Denmark Is Freezing Funds for U.S. Missiles
description: The Danish Parliament froze Denmark's contributions today to the deployment of new United States missiles in Western Europe.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The Royal Bank of Canada is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stockexchanges

title: OPERA: MET'S 'PARADE' TRIPLE BILL BACK
description: TWO seasons ago, when the Metropolitan Opera first staged its triple bill of French music under the portmanteau title of ''Parade,'' the effect was intoxicating. It was all so wonderful, so various, so new. The jumbling prodigality of theatrical ideas was bewildering at times, but the production was suffused with such color, wit and charm that it ranked with the most entertaining evenings offered by the company in years. The very idea that an evening consisting of Satie's ''Parade,'' Poulenc's ''Les Mamelles de Tiresias'' and Ravel's ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges'' could be put together in such a way as to make these disparate works somehow seem to cohere had aroused doubts beforehand, but the fizz and vitality of the enterprise overrode all else.

title: City Investing Plans Sale
description: The City Investing Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Southern California Savings and Loan Association subsidiary, based in Beverly Hills, to the Securities Groups of New York for $27 million. City Investing added that the sale should be completed before the end of the year, if regulators approve. Securities Groups is a dealer and market-maker in Government securities.

title: EXPERTS DEBATE ETHICS OF DOCTOR'S EXECUTION ROLE
description: Experts in medical ethics expressed sharply differing opinions today about whether the limited participation of a doctor in the execution of Charles Brooks Jr. in Texas verged on unethical and inappropriate conduct.

title: Crown Zellerbach
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said it had agreed to sell its lumber and plywood manufacturing facility in Joyce, La., to the Manville Corporation's Manville Forest Products unit.

title: SPY IN LONDON GIVEN 10 YEARS
description: A Canadian professor was sentenced to 10 years in prison today for having spied for the Russians two decades ago. The sentence was passed after he abandoned his story about being a double agent and changed his plea to guilty.

title: STATEMENT OF WHITE HOUSE ON MISSILE SETBACK
description: Following is the statement the White House issued tonight on behalf of President Reagan after the House vote defeating procurement funds for the MX missile:

title: CONCERT: LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC
description: THE fourth and final concert of the Los Angeles Philharmonic's 1982 New York visit Monday night in Avery Fisher Hall offered the only inkling of Carlo Maria Giulini's lifelong affinity for Italian opera, and the only piece of contemporary music (which was also the only piece of American music). But the highlight of the night came with Beethoven's Fifth Symphony.

title: Balco Merger Plan
description: The Balco Energy Corporation announced a preliminary agreement to merge with the newly formed Forge Energy Corporation in a stock exchange.

title: Pipeline Order Won by Bonn
description: West Germany has won an order to supply more than 100,000 metric tons of steel pipe for the Soviet gas pipeline, Salzgitter, the state-owned steel and engineering group, announced today.

title: SETBACK FOR REAGAN POLICY
description: The House of Representatives voted tonight to delete funds to produce the MX missile in 1983, thus threatening to end the long-troubled program.

title: ODDS SAY WEAVER IS OFF-KEY
description: Mike Weaver was leaving the converted conference room at Caesars Palace where the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion had somewhat lethargically worked out for his first fight in 14 months. In the corridor, he spotted a baby grand. There was no lethargy now.

title: A Time to Play, A Time to Rest
description: After playing tennis for most of the year and having helped the United States to retain the Davis Cup with a victory against France 11 days ago, Gene Mayer decided to take his annual six weeks off to rest and recuperate at his home in Woodmere, L.I. Only this time, Mayer did so against the wishes of his financial adviser and knowing that a berth in the Volvo Masters tournament might be in jeopardy.

title: Market Place; Rejuvenated I.B.M. Stock
description: ONE of the most closely analyzed companies in the country, and the most widely held stock among institutional investors, International Business Machines has shown new vigor recently. In yesterday's trading the stock rose to a record price of 95 1/8, up from a low last spring of 55 5/8 and 81 1/4 as recently as Nov. 23.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $885,000 for the qr and $1,438,000 for the yr, losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $2,037,000 for the qr and $5,056,000 for the yr and an extraordinary gain of $2 million for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,541,000 for the qr and $995,000 for the yr, losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $3,693,000 for the qr and $6,587,000 for the yr and an extraordinary gain of $430,000 for the qr and yr

title: MORE BEING FREED IN POLAND, BUT SOME MAY NOT BE
description: The Polish authorities have begun releasing scores of interned supporters of the outlawed Solidarity trade union. But there were indications today that some leading activists could be kept in custody even if martial law ends.

title: 2 Members of Red Brigades Are Captured by Italian Police
description: Dozens of policemen armed with submachine guns and wearing bulletproof vests stopped a crowded bus here today and captured two long-sought leaders of the Red Brigades urban guerrilla group, the police reported.

title: Jets' Defense Primed for Sims Fumble
description: M ore than 79,000 people were roaring, and players were shouting ''fumble, fumble'' and Ken Schroy of the Jets looked down and the football was at his feet, only inches from the goal line.

title: THE PERSONAL TOUCH ON HOLIDAY FRUITCAKES
description: THE nicest Christmas presents of all, it seems to me, are those that bear a personal touch. One in particular that is recalled fondly is a marvelous 10-year-old fruitcake, given to me years ago by a friend's mother who was aware of my interest in cooking. Black with currants and raisins and mellow and satiny in texture, it was perfumed with the aged Cognac with which she had carefully doused it over the years.

title: Harvester Talks
description: The International Harvester Company resumed preliminary talks several days ago with the Cummins Engine Company about the sale of its Spanish diesel engine manufacturing line, sources from both companies said. Cummins had broken off the talks several months ago with Harvester, which reportedly refused to lower the $45 million purchase price.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ZIA TELLS REAGAN HE WON'T BUILD ATOMIC WEAPON
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan told President Reagan today that his Government was not interested in acquiring or making nuclear weapons but was seeking nuclear technology ''for peaceful purposes,'' Administration officials said.

title: House Panel Chief Sells Transit Bill
description: An hour before the highway and mass-transit bill was to be debated on the floor of the House, its author, the chairman of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, was anxiously describing its merits to two colleagues.

title: ARCTIC ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $237,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1 million onthe sale of snowmobile assets...C-Including a tax credit of $47,000 and an extraordinary gain of $253,000 on expenses absorbed by the snowmobile group

title: Bridge: Jacoby's Zest for the Game Still High as He Reaches 80
description: Some 60 years ago a student at Columbia University became the youngest person ever to qualify as an actuary. Soon he became the enfant terrible of the bridge world and a master of many games.

title: Spain Plans to Reopen Gibraltar Crossing
description: Spain's new Socialist Government approved plans today to reopen the border with Gibraltar to pedestrian traffic, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said.

title: More Confident Consumer Seen
description: Consumers grew more confident in November that business conditions and job opportunities will improve in coming months, according to a new survey released yesterday.

title: SHULTZ AND BONN REPORTEDLY AGREE ON POLAND
description: The United States and West Germany were reported in agreement today on the need for the allies to take their time before lifting sanctions against Poland if the authorities there lift martial law this month.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Furnished House for Rent

title: Inland Takeover
description: The Inland Natural Gas Company, saying it doubted the legality of the Trans Mountain Pipeline Company's proposal to sell shares to Carter Energy Ltd., announced it would take steps to restrain the sale, if necessary.

title: WHO WILL SAVE ZBIZHEK ROMASZEWSKI?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Continue to Be Impressive
description: ''What was the score?'' one of the Jets asked at 1:15 this morning as their bus sped to the airport in Pontiac, Mich., for the return flight to New York.

title: CAREY ORDERS SPECIAL LEGISLATIVE SESSION
description: Governor Carey today ordered an ''extraordinary session'' of the New York State Legislature to convene Monday to deal with financial problems of the state, New York City and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A majority chose to go sleepwalking into the future.'' - President Reagan on MX missile vote in House. (D23:1.)

title: THE MX MESSAGE
description: The MX fight is not over. President Reagan, the Air Force and the aerospace manufacturers will now intensify their lobbying in the Senate. Congress may yet be persuaded to accept a compromise that keeps the program going in some form.

title: Chock Full Dissidents Defeated
description: The management of Chock Full o'Nuts announced yesterday that it had won a bitter shareholder vote against a dissident group for control of the company.

title: ALICO INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
FOR THOSE RULED BY THE MOODS OF THE RIVER, THE FLOODS BECOME A WAY OF LIFE
description: Edith Kellogg got a big surprise today. Neighbors and relatives helped celebrate her 88th birthday, but first they had a surprise of their own. They had to evacuate her to another town, along with a ton or two of furniture and personal belongings.

title: MAN SLAIN IN CAPITAL MONUMENT THREAT
description: A daylong standoff between the police and a man who threatened to blow up the Washington Monument with a truck he said contained explosives ended Wednesday night with a flurry of gunshots.

title: Draft Resister Ordered To Do Public Service
description: Enten Eller, the college student who said he refused to register for the draft because of his religious beliefs, was ordered by Federal District Judge James Turk today to perform two years of unpaid public service.

title: SPANG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $37,332 for the qr and 9 mos...C-After loss from discontinued operations of $299,157

title: HOUSE VOTES TO BAR U.S. HELP TO REBELS FIGHTING NICARAGUA
description: The House voted overwhelmingly tonight to bar the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency from giving weapons or training to anti-Sandinist guerrillas ''for the purpose of overthrowing the Government of Nicaragua.''

title: F.C.C. CLEARS CHANNEL 9'S SHIFT TO JERSEY
description: The Federal Communications Commission today authorized RKO General Inc. to move its New York City station - WOR-TV on Channel 9 - to New Jersey, giving the state its first commercial very-high-frequency television station.

title: HOUSE VOTES FUNDS PERMITTING STUDY ON MX TO CONTINUE
description: The House of Representatives voted today to keep the MX missile alive in the development stage, and then adopted a military appropriation bill for the current fiscal year of $230 billion. The legislation, which now goes to the Senate, was adopted by a vote of 346 to 68.

title: Herald Gets New Publisher
description: Rupert Murdoch today named Robert E. Page, a vice president in his publishing company, as president and publisher of The Boston Herald American.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After an unrealized loss of $192,000 on marketable securities...C-After a loss of $12,000 from discontinued operations and unrealized income of $71,000 on marketable securities...D-After a loss of $618,000 from discontinued operations and a pretax loss of $199,000 on maretable securities...E-After a loss of $1,255,000 from discontinued operations, a pretax gain of $88,000 on marketable securities and a pretax gain of $6,940,000 on the partial sale of common stock of a subsidiary

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Ex-Head of Bally Loses License Plea
description: William T. O'Donnell, former chairman of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, today lost his final attempt to win a New Jersey casino license through the state courts.

title: 2 KILLED IN LEBANESE-ISRAELI ARMY CLASH
description: Two Lebanese soldiers were killed near Beirut today in a five-minute clash with an Israeli convoy, and an Israeli was wounded. Both nations agreed that the fighing was an isolated incident that did not reflect any deterioration of relations between the two armies.

title: Dissent by Chinaglia
description: Giorgio Chinaglia does not share the view that the United States could successfully stage the 1986 World Cup soccer tournament. The Cosmos star, in Milan, Italy, listed yesterday a few objections to the country's playing host to the event.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
TROUBLED COVENT GARDEN AT 250 YEARS
description: It was, as the program proudly proclaimed, ''the precise 250th anniversary'' of the opening of the first theater on the site of the present Royal Opera House in Covent Garden.

title: No Headline
description: Hawks Trounce Rangers

title: NATHAN PINE, 90, BOOKSELLER AND LITERARY WORLD LEGEND
description: Nathan S. Pine, a bookseller for 77 years, until his retirement earlier this year, died of a heart attack Tuesday night. Mr. Pine, his wife, Tilly, and eight friends had gone directly from dinner to a performance of ''Hamlet,'' at the Public Theater. Mr. Pine was stricken in the theater lobby. He was pronounced dead at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: TWO DECORATORS STRESS CHARM IN NEW HOMEY HOTELS
description: ''IASSUME doing a hotel is the most difficult thing you can do. Nothing could be worse.'' Thus, with characteristic acerbity, Sister Parish, founder of Parish-Hadley Associates, sums up her yearlong experience decorating the new Ritz-Carlton Hotel on Central Park South.

title: POOR TOKEN SUBSTITUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO SAYS HE IS WILLING TO TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR INCREASED TAXES
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said today that he was willing to take responsibility for new taxes passed this month to close a state budget deficit and aid mass transit.

title: Rise in the Dial-It Rate Approved by the P.S.C.
description: The New York Public Service Commission yesterday voted a substantial increase in the amount New Yorkers pay to dial ''976'' numbers for time, temperature, race results and other recorded announcements, but deferred the increase until the spring.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a gain of $232,000 or 7 cents a shr for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of property

title: Fund Case Resignation
description: Carl P. Herbert Jr., a former State Commissioner of Securities, has resigned as head of a Minneapolis investment office following charges that he diverted $300,000 to his personal use. Stein, Roe & Farnham, based in Chicago, told clients in a letter today that Mr. Herbert, 49 years old, had admitted diverting the funds and had resigned. The case was turned over to the United States Attorney's office here and to the Chicago office of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: SOUTH AFRICA AND ANGOLA HOLD UNEXPECTED TALKS
description: South Africa announced today that its Foreign and Defense Ministers had met in the Cape Verde Islands with a delegation from Angola on the issue of South-West Africa.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: No Go in SoHo

title: Miss Hess Wins World Cup Race
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 8 (AP) - Erika Hess of Switzerland made a flawless second run today to win the first giant slalom race of the women's World Cup season.

title: AMAX: COPING WITH AUSTERITY
description: Pierre Gousseland, the French-born chairman of Amax Inc., talked enthusiastically about minerals for an hour and then slumped back into his chair. It had not been an easy year. ''I have watched 25 percent of my staff leave,'' the 61-year-old executive said. ''Many of these people are my friends.''

title: FACTORS IN BUYING A RESTAURANT STOVE
description: BECAUSE buying a restaurant range for a home kitchen involves a large investment of space and money, it is important to consider several factors before buying. ''One of the first things is to determine whether your kitchen is suited for such equipment,'' said Charles Mount, an interior designer who has installed many professional ranges in homes. ''Because so much heat is generated from these ranges, large hoods for proper ventilation are necessary,'' he said. ''It is often difficult to tell whether these hoods can be easily installed in a space, so it may be wise to consult a kitchen designer or professional engineer before making a purchase.''

title: SOUTH AFRICA REPORTS KILLING 30 IN ATTACK ON FOES IN LESOTHO
description: South African forces attacked the capital of the tiny landlocked country of Lesotho early today, killing at least 30 members of the underground African National Congress, according to an announcement by the Defense Ministry in Pretoria.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Testing the City's Water 800 Times a Month

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bingham in Congress: The Complete Record

title: Vasquez, Venezia Suspended
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday ordered a one-year suspension of Jacinto Vasquez and a three-month suspension of Michael Venezia for violations stemming from reported fixed races at New York thoroughbred tracks in the mid-1970's.

title: REAGAN WITHDRAWS 9 NOMINEES TO LEGAL UNIT
description: President Reagan today withdrew his nine nominations to the board of the independent Legal Services Corporation and the White House said at least some of them were not ''philosophically in tune with his policies.''

title: Pennsylvania Governor Signs Bridge Repair Bill
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania signed into law today a program that would create 20,000 jobs a year for the repair of 979 bridges in the state.

title: NEW JUMBO JET ENGINES ARE PLANNED BY PRATT
description: Pratt & Whitney, the nation's largest producer of jet engines, announced today that it is developing a new family of powerful engines for jumbo jets that will have 54 percent fewer parts and burn 7 percent less fuel than its most efficient engines now in production.

title: Georgia Judge Barred From Custody Dispute
description: A judge who took custody of a boy away from his mother after she bore an illegitimate, racially mixed daughter was disqualified today from presiding over the latest round in the custody fight.

title: Harry Jerome, 42, Sprint Star
description: Harry Jerome, the former track star who for eight years held the world record in the 100-meter sprint, died in a hospital Tuesday after suffering a brain seizure earlier in the day. He was 42 years old.

title: Bond Prices Off Almost a Point
description: Sales of new corporate bonds met with a chilly reception yesterday as prices of outstanding issues moved lower for the second consecutive session. Declines of nearly a point were registered by both Government and corporate bonds.

title: ATARI RELIEVES EXECUTIVE OF DUTIES
description: Perry D. Odak, the president of the home video game division of Atari Inc., has been relieved of all his duties, the company announced yesterday.

title: Last Acres Bought For Lincoln West
description: The builders of Lincoln West, the 4,300-apartment project planned on Manhattan's shoreline, took title to the entire site yesterday.
