Orlando Salvestrini, president of Lincoln West Associates, announced that the company had paid $21.6 million to the landowner, the Owasco River Railway Inc, a subsidiary of the Penn Central Transportation Company, for the southern portion of the site.

title: Firestone Settlement
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that it had agreed to settle a class action suit filed in 1979, arising from claims primarily involving its steelbelted radial 500 tire line. It said it would establish a settlement fund of about $3 million to satisfy claims by purchasers of the tires from Dec. 1, 1975, to July 24, 1978.

title: 3 OF 5 JOINT CHIEFS ASKED DELAY ON MX
description: The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., disclosed today that three of the five military chiefs had recommended against proceeding now with the muchdisputed plan for closely spaced basing of the MX missile.

title: T.W.A. Strike Called Off
description: A strike that would have grounded Trans World Airlines planes was called off late today minutes before the deadline after the airline made a new offer, a union official said. No details were released on the offer, which union members must vote to approve.

title: Strike Penalties For Guards Upset
description: The State Court of Appeals today ordered the state to refund some penalties collected from 300 employees who participated in the 1979 state prison guards' strike. The court also barred the state from resuming the collection of penalties from employees that the state contended were underassessed.

title: BELL PETROLEUM SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEWARK TO ASSUME GIBSON TRIAL COSTS
description: The City Council today unanimously approved payment of more than $477,000 in legal fees for Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and the former Council President, Earl Harris. They were recently acquitted on charges of conspiracy and misconduct in office.

title: Advertising; Doyle Dane Is Forming U.S. Unit
description: THE so-called smart money was predicting that Roy Grace would replace Paul J. Paulson as president of Doyle Dane Bernbach-New York, unless it was Barry Loughrane.

title: Change at Schenley Benefits Rosenfeld
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has become the major beneficiary of Schenley Industry's decision to close out its account at Shaller Rubin Associates after a 15-year stay.

title: Canadian Ballet Names Bruhn Artistic Director
description: The National Ballet of Canada has announced that Erik Bruhn, the Danish premier danseur and ballet director, will succeed Alexander Grant as artistic director of the Toronto-based company. Mr. Bruhn's three-year contract goes into effect next July 1.

title: THE PUSH QUESTION
description: Should the President's public opinion pollster - the man who briefs Mr. Reagan ever few weeks on what Americans think about various issues - hire himself out to a pro-Arab organization that would dearly like to influence what the President learns about attitudes toward the Middle East?

title: FORMER CHIEF OF STAFF, 1958-61
description: Gen. Haim Laskov, a former chief of staff of the Israeli Army, died here today of cancer. He was 63 years old. Colleagues described him as perhaps the most ''professional'' soldier ever to head the army. They credited him with tightening discipline in the ragtag forces that fought the war of independance in 1948.

title: Wieboldt Stores Inc.  Elects New Chairman
description: Jerome M. Schottenstein, best known for his acquisitions and liquidations of retail stores, was elected chairman of troubled Wieboldt Stores Inc. yesterday and said he was ''committed to revitalizing'' the Chicago-based chain of 14 department stores.

title: Soviet Accuses West Of Sowing Distrust
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov praised Soviet-Finnish relations today as a model for the world and accused the West, particularly the United States, of trying ''to sow distrust between peoples.''

title: Mavericks 110, SuperSonics 94
description: DALLAS (AP) - Brad Davis scored 10 of his 16 points in the third quarter as Dallas led throughout and built its biggest margin - 22 points -in the third period by sinking 13 of 17 field-goal attempts. Davis had only 4 points at halftime.

title: Legal-Aid Lawyers Reject Arbitration
description: An offer by the Legal Aid Society to submit its labor dispute with 550 striking staff lawyers to binding arbitration was rejected last night.

title: Lloyd's of London
description: Lloyd's of London said it had suspended W.M.D. Underwriting Agencies Ltd. and an underwriter, Colin Davies, as part of its continuing inquiry into reinsurance transactions at P.C.W. Underwriting Agencies Ltd. and at W.D.M., a 40 percent owned associate agency. P.C.W. is owned by Minet Holdings P.L.C., an insurance broker that is held 20 percent each by the St. Paul Companies of St. Paul and the Corroon & Black Corporation of New York. Lloyd's would not give specific reasons for the latest suspension.

title: COMPROMISE ARISES ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: A Democratic member of President Reagan's panel on Social Security has drafted a compromise proposal to shore up the old-age benefits program and it is said to be moving the 15-member panel closer to consensus.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was a significant vote, an important vote. But it doesn't mean the MX is dead.

title: ACTIVITY OF GENES REPORTED ALTERED IN TREATING MAN
description: For the first time, scientists have successfully altered the activity of genes in the human body in a research attempt to treat a serious illness.

title: TIME TO FOCUS ON NONNUCLEAR DETERRENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: JUSTICES BACK MINOR POLITICAL PARTIES ON DISCLOSURE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a minor political party that faces a ''reasonable probability'' of harassment cannot be forced to disclose the identity of either its campaign contributors or the recipients of its campaign funds.

title: Sri Lanka Reports A Dispute With U.S.
description: The United States has asked Sri Lanka to recall a ranking diplomat from Washington in retaliation for the ouster of his American counterpart in Colombo, the Government announced today.

title: CONFRONTING GLOBAL FINANCIAL UNCERTANTY
description: At a meeting originally scheduled to deal with an increase in lending power for the International Monetary Fund, the finance ministers of the five major industrial nations will open discussions Thursday on the much broader issue of changes in the world's monetary system.

title: Military Analysis
description: Israel's Army and Air Force have emerged from the campaign in Lebanon triumphant but troubled. Victories over the Syrian Army and Air Force and the virtual elimination of the Palestine Liberation

title: NETS SET BACK BULLETS
description: The Nets rolled to their fifth straight victory tonight, defeating the Bullets by 98-95. In the course of the triumph there was one moment that epitomized the kind of relaxed mood that the Nets are in these days.

title: Penobscots Win Round On Sunday Gambling
description: A judge has temporarily barred the state from breaking up high-stakes Sunday beano games on the Penobscot Indian's Island reservation.

title: GROUP OF BIDS FOR SUBURBAN PROPANE
description: The multimillionaire Bass family of Fort Worth has joined with top executives of the Suburban Propane Gas Corporation to seek to buy the company, the Morristown, N.J., propane supplier said yesterday.

title: New Hepatitis Vaccine Effective for 2 Groups
description: A newly developed hepatitis vaccine is effective for up to five years against a type of hepatitis that annually afflicts 200,000 Americans, mainly hospital employees, homosexual men and drug addicts, a doctor reported today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt ROBERT LOWELL. A Biography. By Ian Hamilton. 527 pages. Illustrated. Ran- dom House. $19.95.

title: DOCTORS ALTER HEART PATIENT'S TREATMENT TO AVERT MORE SEIZURES
description: Doctors altered the drug treatment and diet of Dr. Barney B. Clark today to prevent him from suffering further seizures as he neared the end of his first full week with an artificial heart.

title: ABC Home Network Account Goes to Grey
description: From among an initial list of 15 agencies, Grey Advertising has emerged the winner of the ABC Home View Network account, which will be billing in the multimillion-dollar range after its debut next year.

title: Pope's Assailant Speaks Of Bulgarian Role
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman who wounded Pope John Paul II last year, was quoted today as having told Italian investigators that he ''received instructions'' to kill the Pope while in Bulgaria and was helped in Rome by Bulgarian secret service agents.

title: BISHOPS AND THE BOMB
description: The proposed pastoral letter on war and peace is the latest effort by the American bishops of the Roman Catholic Church to provide spiritual guidance on one of the most disturbing realities of our time.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Motors Corp., Detroit, has named Jean-Marc Lepeu vice president of finance; John P. Tierney vice president of finance staff and controller, and Kenneth A. Lawton treasurer.

title: Bulls Grant Dailey Leave to Seek Help
description: Quintin Dailey, the Chicago Bulls' rookie guard, is suffering from ''extreme emotional stress'' and has requested a temporary leave of absence to seek psychiatric help, a team spokesman said today.

title: AN EXCEPTIONAL EVENING WITH TWO GALA PARTIES
description: IT'S pretty darned hard to know what's what, who's who and why anyone is where in the New York social scene these days. Establishment events are riddled with jet-set strays, the frolics of the international set are punctuated with blue blood and old green, the 400 has a cast of thousands, and the beautiful people aren't always.

title: Management Shift At LTV Is Revised
description: Sometimes the best-laid corporate plans don't quite work out. Earlier this year, W. Paul Thayer, the chairman and chief executive officer of the LTV Corporation, announced that he would relinquish the title of chief executive on Dec.1, rather than wait until his retirement in 1984. The aim was to provide for a smooth top management transition for the big Dallas conglomerate.

title: No Headline
description: E.P.A. AGREES TO CLEANUP OF MISSOURI DIOXIN SITES WITH U.S. FUNDS

title: KUHN FOES ON PANEL
description: The quest for a new commissioner of baseball took an unexpected turn today when two of Bowie Kuhn's chief critics were added to the club owners' search committee.

title: WILL LEE, 74, WAS MR. HOOPER ON TELEVISION 'SESAME STREET'
description: Will Lee, a character actor who played Mr. Hooper, the storekeeper on ''Sesame Street,'' since the children's program went on the air 13 years ago, died of a heart attack Tuesday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income...C-Including a gain of $35,394 on the sale of equipment

title: CONFRONTING GLOBAL FINANCIAL UNCERTAINTY
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's proposal this week for a reexamination of the world financial system struck a responsive chord among international financial experts: Even before his suggestion, there had been a growing consensus among economists and private financiers that such changes may be necessary both to spur recovery and to prevent future difficulties.

title: ANCIENT INDIAN ART FOUND IN TENNESSEE CAVE
description: Anthropologists announced today a rare find of prehistoric Indian drawings that may have been made on the walls of a cave in eastern Tennessee three centuries before Columbus arrived in the New World.

title: DR. HELEN S. BRELL
description: Dr. Helen S. Brell, retired deputy chairman of the education department at Brooklyn College, died Tuesday in Manhattan.

title: CHARITY ADVISERS TERM ECONOMY'S ROLE CRUCIAL
description: President Reagan's advisory panel on charity today presented him with an assortment of heartening claims, proposals for doubling the nation's corporate and personal giving and a warning about ''the negative effects of a weak economic climate on stifling private sector initiative.''

title: Chairman of Cyanamid Is Giving Up One Post
description: James J. Affleck, chairman and chief executive of the American Cyanamid Company, said yesterday that he would recommend the election of George J. Sella Jr., president, to replace him as chief executive effective Jan.1.

title: Del Monte Corp.
description: The Del Monte Corporation said it is seeking buyers for two interstate trucking companies and four truck dealerships owned by its Distribution Systems subsidiary. The trucking companies are Willis Shaw Frozen Express Inc. of Elm Springs, Ark., and Ida-Cal Freight Lines Inc. of Nampa, Idaho. All four dealerships are in Idaho. Del Monte is a unit of R.J. Reynolds Inc.

title: THE ARTFUL BATHROOM
description: WHEN he was at Bloomingdale's, he was known for creating his own model rooms. So when he was faced with a series of American Standard bathroom settings, Fred Palatinus was able to decorate them imaginatively in honor of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's ''Beautiful Bathrooms/Fabulous Phones,'' an exhibition at the American Standard Showroom, 50 West 40th Street.

title: Motorola Radios For G.M. Backed
description: Motorola Inc. said Delco Electronics had recommended that Motorola's AM stereo broadcasting system be used on radios in General Motors Corporation vehicles.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH it takes considerable skill and a well-equipped shop to build professional-looking furniture with drawers, anyone familiar with basic woodworking can build simple, strong storage drawers with ordinary hand tools and, perhaps, a portable electric drill.

title: BY CAROL VOGEL
description: FOR the past decade commercial kitchen appliances, restaurant stoves and refrigerators in particular, have been considered something of a status symbol. Professional stoves, gleaming or matte black, are placed almost like sculpture in the kitchen's center; glass-front cafeteria refrigerators display the week's shopping; overhead pot racks allow shiny pots, pans and utensils to dangle proudly before friends and family; open-wire shelving and industrial lights show off cookware and china.

title: BUDGET AIDE WARNS OF NEW DEFICIT PERIL
description: The chief economist of the Office of Management and Budget said today that the nation is facing deep-seated budget deficits that would remain even in the face of a strong recovery and, in fact, could abort one.

title: BLINKA BANNED FOR GAME BY N.F.L.
description: Stan Blinka, the Jets' starting middle linebacker, was suspended for one game without pay today by Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League for what Rozelle described as a ''foul that ranks with the worst infractions I have witnessed in an N.F.L. game.''

title: News Analysis
description: The extraordinary charmed life of the French military establishment appears to be coming to an end in a debate on finance, manpower and strategy that could affect France's allies.

title: CUOMO CHOOSES MOYNIHAN AIDE FOR A MAJOR POST
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo completed the inner circle of his government yesterday, appointing Timothy J. Russert to the new post of Counselor to the Governor, with responsibility for relations with news organizations, people in the nation's capital, and other states.

title: Players Union Elects Moffett
description: The executive board of the Major League Baseball Players Association unanimously elected Ken Moffett today to succeed Marvin Miller as the association's executive director.

title: FOR ELLIS ISLAND, A REBORN ROLE AS A MONUMENT
description: The ships used to pull up to a glass and steel canopy at the edge of the pier. And it was there, in front of the imposing brick and limestone Grand Hall on Ellis Island, that 17 million people disembarked to begin new lives in this country.

title: 9 YEARS AT COUNTY HELM, DELBELLO PRAISES COURSE
description: Alfred B. DelBello looked back on his nine years as Westchester County Executive today and seemed pleased. ''If my successor is smart, if he's really smart,'' the 48-year-old politician said, grinning, ''he won't make any changes at all.''

title: LAXALT IS URGING REAGAN TO PLAY PITCHMAN ROLE
description: President Reagan spent part of his early career appearing on television and urging viewers to buy electrical appliances. If Senator Paul Laxalt has his way, the President will go back on the home screen next year with a similar appeal. Next time, however, Mr. Reagan will be pushing homes and cars as well as washers and dryers.

title: PSA WILL LEASE 30 BRANIFF PLANES
description: Pacific Southwest Airlines announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Braniff International whereby it would form a new division that would lease 30 planes from Braniff and operate a new route system out of Dallas.

title: COSTA RICA PLANS DEBT TALKS AS AUSTERITY PROGRAM GAINS
description: Costa Rica, which only six months ago had the most serious debt problem in Latin America, has been gradually putting its finances in order and now appears ready to renegotiate its huge foreign debt.

title: No Time to Read
description: Dave Rimington had another plane to catch. Ever since Nebraska ended its regular season in Hawaii last Saturday night, the all-America center and two-time winner of the Outland Trophy as the nation's best lineman has been traveling the awards dinner circuit, picking at the chicken and rice while accepting complements for his outstanding play this season.

title: Japan Reviews Import Quotas
description: Japan will expand import quotas on beef and oranges and cut tariffs on tobacco in a new package of measures designed to ease trade friction with the United States, the economic newspaper Nihon Keizai reported today.

title: KENNEDY'S DECISION WRONGLY INTERPRETED
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvester Unit
description: Receivers for International Harvester Australia Ltd. and lenders will continue talks to head off liquidation despite a Supreme Court hearing Thursday in Victoria to liquidate the company, the receiver, David Crawford, said. Lenders have been negotiating for the last week in an effort to reach an accord to stop the legal action by seven lenders to liquidate the company, a unit of the International Harvester Company.

title: Skalbania's Downfall
description: The sports and real-estate empire of Nelson Skalbania, the 42-yearold Canadian who bought franchises in hockey, football, soccer and baseball, has collapsed. Skalbania, who is reportedly $30 million in debt, made the admission at a dinner Tuesday night in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Trial Testimony Ends In Slaying of Judge
description: Prosecutors and defense attorneys rested their cases today in the trial of three defendants charged in the first assassination of a Federal judge in this century.

title: ISALY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $321,000 from discontinued operations...C-After a loss of $568,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a loss of $1,628,000 from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated for the effect of Clabir's June 9, 1982 conversion of 150,000 shrs of preferred stock into 2.31 million shrs of common stock

title: RECITAL: SERKIN, AND BEETHOVEN
description: RUDOLF SERKIN'S enormous appeal as an artist must be at least partly rooted in his audience's belief in him as a genuinely good and great man. The Serkin followers who came to Carnegie Hall last night for his annual recital there attended in what seemed to be a congregational mood, eager to pay tribute to the pianist in his 80th birthday season. Mr. Serkin will not reach that milestone until March, but opportunities to hear him discourse on the last three Beethoven sonatas do not come along often, so all available seats were filled and extra pews were set up onstage.

title: ZIA SEES NO QUICK SOLUTION TO SOVIET ROLE IN AFGHANISTAN
description: Pakistan's President said today that the Soviet occupation of neighboring Afghanistan posed a ''grave threat'' to his nation's security. And despite talks with Soviet officials, including the new leader, Yuri V. Andropov, he has ''no proof, no indications, no promises'' that the Soviet Union will soon withdraw its 100,000 troops.

title: Gleason Works
description: Gleason Works, an industrial-machinery maker based in Rochester, said it will cut the wages of 1,800 hourly and salaried workers in its machine division by 10 percent beginning Jan. 1. The company added that it would not pay holiday bonuses and that until business improved it would not provide cost-of-living increases. Gleason said the recession had cut demand for its parts and machinery.

title: TOP CHRYSLER AND UNION OFFICIALS FLY TO TORONTO IN BID TO AID TALKS
description: Top officers of the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers unexpectedly flew here today in an effort to break the bargaining impasse in Canada that has jeopardized efforts to reach a new labor agreement on both sides of the border.

title: Nuclear Plant in California Wins U.S. Approval on Welds
description: Charges of unsafe welding practices at the San Onofre nuclear power plant were unfounded, a Nuclear Regulatory Commission official said Monday in announcing the results of a month-long investigation.

title: BEGIN DEFENDS ACTIONS TO PANEL ON MASSACRE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin has written a letter to the state commission investigating the Beirut massacre, in which he sets forth his arguments defending his Government's behavior, his press secretary, Uri Porat, said today.

title: THE STAGE: VAN VEEN'S ONE-MAN SHOW
description: THE title does not lie. ''Herman van Veen: All of Him'' is the name of the one-man show that opened on Broadway last night, and all of Herman van Veen is what you get. You get his singing, his mime, his dancing, his jokes, his politics, his fiddle playing. And it doesn't take too long to discover that this is way too much of a poor thing.

title: IN REVOLUTIONARY GUINEA, SOME OF THE FIRE IS GONE
description: The revolution here has slowed and blurred over the years, its slogans intact but its achievements and alignments less distinct than in the early days when President Ahmed Sekou Toure's Guinea was a rallying point for black politicians in Africa and elsewhere.

title: U.S. TO HELP TRIBES NEGOTIATE THEIR CLAIMS TO WATER RIGHTS
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt told a delegation of Western state officials, businessmen and Indian leaders today that the Federal Government would play an active role in helping to negotiate the growing number of disputes over Indian water claims.

title: BALLET: THE DUTCH NATIONAL COMPANY
description: ON Tuesday night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Dutch National Ballet repeated its opening night program with several cast changes and the performance indicated some of this troupe's strengths and weaknesses.

title: U.S. RAISES ISSUE OF ETHIOPIAN TOXIC ARMS IN U.N.
description: The United States called today for an investigation of reports that chemical warfare was waged this year in Ethiopia, whose Soviet-aided armed forces have been fighting Eritrean rebels.

title: A CENTURY'S WORTH OF TOYS IN FRANCE
description: PARIS CHILDREN may seem the same the world over, but in France childhood has historically been viewed as a time to apprentice for adulthood. Childhood is, as well, a time for fantasy and dreaming, playing with dolls and toy trains, but even today French children remain a rather serious lot, trained from an early age to look forward to joining the privileged adult world.

title: BRIBE TRIAL JUDGE ASSAILS REQUEST ON CURBING JURY'S ACCESS TO TAPES
description: The judge in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president, scolded defense lawyers today for what he repeatedly called ''desperate'' efforts to deny the jury, in its deliberations, access to the 50 wiretapped conversations that are the core of the Government's case.

title: Rare 1918 Stamp, Stolen In 1955, Is Recovered
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced the recovery of a rare 1918 ''Inverted Jenny'' air-mail stamp valued at $150,000 that was stolen at a 1955 stamp collectors convention in Norfolk, Va.

title: DESIRE TO SHARE GOOD FORTUNE INSPIRES GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: An awareness of one's own good fortune amid widespread hardship often inspires gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and one of the contributors to the fund's 71st annual appeal who has responded to the misfortune around him is Gary M. Mills of Manhattan.

title: CONCERT: FROM BEL CANTO TO POPULAR SONGS OF 1915
description: ROSSINI attributed the ''irretrievable decay of the art of singing'' to the decline of the castrati. But the tenor Stefan Zucker has recently been attempting to revive their tradition.

title: U.S.O., Show of Shows
description: There's no business like show business, and no greater audience than our men and women in uniform.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Harris to Sell Unit For $250 Million
description: The Harris Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its printing equipment division, the nation's largest manufacturer of printing presses, to a new corporation headed by the division's current management for $250 million.

title: GENOVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
REDMEN TRIUMPH BY 87-65
description: St. John's (6-0) earned the 300th victory for Coach Lou Carnesecca by defeating Fairleigh Dickinson, 87-65, last night at Alumni Hall. David Russell scored 14 of his 20 points as St. John's built a 43-25 lead at intermission. Russell finished with 20 points. Kevin Williams, who came off the bench, led the Redmen with a career-high 21 points, including 13 in the second half. He made 10 of 13 fieldgoal attempts. Chris Mullin had 16, making 8 of 11 shots, and Billy Goodwin 13.

title: Rose Kennedy Found Better
description: Rose Kennedy is ''improving gradually'' from bruises suffered in a Thanksgiving weekend fall at her Cape Cod home, it was reported today by Dr. Robert D. Watt, the family physician. The 92-year-old Mrs. Kennedy has been recuperating at her 17-room home overlooking Nantucket Sound since the fall on Nov. 26. Mrs. Kennedy's injuries were not serious, according to Dr. Watt.

title: Tennis Players Threaten Boycott
description: Several players have threatened to boycott the $450,000 Australian Open tennis tournament because of scheduling under which they will have to play two rounds of singles on Thursday.

title: Fedders Lawsuit
description: The State of Kentucky has settled its 1981 lawsuit against the Fedders Corporation with an agreement that Fedders will inspect, repair, replace or extend warranties for defective heating and air-conditioning units in many homes, state officials said. Attorney General Stephen Beshear said that as many as 250 residents had complained of problems with heat pumps or airconditioners and that total repairs and refunds could cost more than $100,000. Under terms of the settlement, Fedders, based in Edison, N.J., denied any wrongdoing.

title: CALENDAR: SALES OF CRAFTS AND CERAMICS
description: Crafts in the Armory '82, New York State Armory, 125 West 14th Street, 212-897-0084.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Normand Leveille of the Boston Bruins, who suffered a brain hemorrhage Oct. 23 in Vancouver, British Columbia, is sitting up regularly in a chair at the Montreal Neurological Institute. ''It is very unusual for someone to go from prone to sitting like this in just two weeks,'' said a spokesman for the institute. The 19-year-old forward remains paralyzed on his right side, and he has not regained speech. ... Wayne Smith, the cornerback who was beaten for three touchdowns by Wesley Walker of the Jets Monday night, was given his unconditional release by the Detroit Lions.

title: PLAYERS RAFIFY N.F.L. CONTRACT
description: National Football League players, who struck for 57 days earlier this season, ratified by a 3-1 margin today a five-year, $1.6 billion collective bargaining agreement.

title: No Headline
description: Sampson's 36 Lead Virginia

title: WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $102,000 for the qr and $275,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $67,000 for the qr and $381,000 for the yr

title: POOR TOKEN SUBSTITUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: Muslim Ceremony for Killer
description: Charles Brooks Jr., the convicted murderer who found peace in the Islamic faith before his execution, will be eulogized in a brief Muslim service Friday and buried in a suburban cemetery. Mr. Brooks, 40 years old, was executed Tuesday by lethal injection for the 1976 slaying of a Fort Worth automobile mechanic.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Quick, What Avenue Is Between 5th and 7th?

title: A Depressed Coach
description: A 1-4 record, including losses to New Orleans, the Los Angeles Rams and Pittsburgh since the end of the players' strike, has brought Marv Levy of the Kansas City Chiefs the most troubled time of his coaching career. Levy said: ''The miserable feeling is worse about three or four hours after the game, after everyone else is gone and you're left alone with the realization that you didn't win, that you played poorly.

title: Pension Trust Mergers Set
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said today that it had agreed to acquire National Associates Inc., and had agreed in principle to acquire Planning Counselors Inc. and National Associates Inc. of Northern California. Terms of the three cash transactions were not disclosed.

title: COURT IS TOLD REACTOR MEMO COULD HAVE AVERTED MISHAP
description: The operator on duty at the time of the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant on March 28, 1979, testified yesterday that the mishap could have been averted if he had had access to a memorandum that the manufacturer of the plant had not distributed.

title: RED WINGS DEFEAT ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders, winners of the Stanley Cup the last three seasons, were shut out tonight, 2-0, in Joe Louis Arena by the Detroit Red Wings, the second worst team in the National Hockey League.

title: A MILLSTONE NAMED STATE INCOME TAX
description: To the Editor:

title: IMMIGRATION BILL IS CLEARED FOR HOUSE DEBATE
description: A comprehensive immigration bill, broadly similar to one passed by the Senate, was cleared today for debate on the floor of the House of Representatives as Congress moved toward a scheduled adjournment at the end of next week.

title: Swift Enlarging Iowa Facilities
description: The Swift Independent Packing Company, the freshmeats packing concern spun off from Esmark Inc. two years ago, will begin a $10.5 million expansion of its beef and pork operations in Iowa, John A. Copeland, chairman and chief executive officer, said.

title: NICARAGUAN EXILE LIMITS ROLE OF U.S.
description: The top commander of exile forces seeking to overthrow the leftist Government in Nicaragua said today that the aims and operations of his troops were not subject to control by the United States.

title: Loan Losses In Canada
description: Canada's eight biggest banks incurred loan losses of more than $2 billion in the year ended Oct. 31, Russell Harrison, chairman of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, said here today.

title: THE PUBLIC LIBRARY GET $2 MILLION FROM U.S.
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities announced today that it had awarded a $2 million matching grant to the New York Public Library, the largest matching grant ever given by the endowment to a single institution. The award is part of $5.3 million in grants to 13 independent research libraries across the country.

title: Article 086280 -- No Title
description: A $2.5 million programming grant from the General Electric Corporation will underwrite a third sea-son of ''Inside Story,'' the PBS series that examines media performance.

title: BOARD OF EDUCATION HALTS EFFORT TO OFFER 9TH-GRADE TRANSFER OPTION
description: The Board of Education agreed yesterday to halt an effort to offer students entering the ninth grade the choice of either enrolling in their local high schools or remaining in junior high schools. The decision means that students in junior high schools having a ninth grade will be required to remain in those schools next fall.

title: SCORES LOW, CITY ENDS CIVIL SERVICE TEST
description: New York City yesterday threw out a Civil Service test for park laborers after finding that about 800 of the 1,000 employees who took the test scored too low to keep their jobs.

title: REDPATH INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income includes a tax credit of $1.9 million

title: Accounts
description: * Falcon Jet Corporation, the United States subsidiary of Dassault-Breguet Aviation of France, to McCaffrey and McCall Inc. for general and direct-mail advertising.

title: WAGES AND PRODUCTIVITY QUESTION STALL CITY-SANITATION UNION TALKS
description: Negotiations between New York City and the sanitationmen's union appear deadlocked on wages and a productivity question as a slowdown in collections continued into a second week.

title: Itel Plan Cleared
description: The Itel Corporation said that a bankruptcy court had approved a disclosure statement for its amended reorganization plan and that it expected to seek acceptances from creditors and security holders by Dec. 31. The plan includes issuance of 15 million new common shares with an estimated market value of $1.50 to $2.50 a share, up to $210 million of 14 percent secured notes, up to $110 million of 10 percent notes and one million new preferred shares. Itel also said it expected to make a cash distribution of about $324 million to unsecured creditors after the plan is confirmed.

title: BONN JOINS BAILOUT FOR STEELMAKER
description: The Government today approved $7.6 million in aid to Arbed Saarstahl, the unprofitable German steelmaking unit of the Luxembourg-based Arbed Steel Company, after the company's biggest union agreed to contribute more than $24 million to a rescue plan.

title: ANIXTER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1982
description: International The MX missile was kept alive in the House, but only in the development stage. By a voice vote, the representatives decided to retain $2.5 billion for research and development on the experimental missile. The House then adopted, by a vote of 346 to 68, a military appropriation bill of $230 billion in this fiscal year. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The plan for closely spaced basing of the MX missile is opposed by three of the five military chiefs of staff, according to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr. In Senate testimony, General Vessey said that the nation's military leaders regarded the Reagan Administration's basing proposal as ''very difficult to understand and difficult to explain'' and that three wanted to delay action on it until ''technical uncertainties'' were resolved. (A1:5.)

title: 'CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON,' PRIZE PLAY
description: ''THAT CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON,'' directed by Jason Miller and adapted by him from his own Pulitzer Prize-winning play, begins beautifully with a ''nonpolitical'' political rally in a park in Scranton, Pa.

title: U.S.F.L. Opening Camps on Jan. 31
description: The United States Football League said yesterday that it would open training camps in Florida, Arizona and California on Jan. 31 in preparation for its 108-game inaugural season that begins March 6.

title: YANKEES AND KEMP REACH AGREEMENT
description: Steve Kemp, a key element in George Steinbrenner's 1983 plans, is about to take his place in the fourth spot in the Yankees' lineup, between Dave Winfield and Don Baylor.

title: Employees Buy Hallmark Stock
description: Hallmark Cards Inc., the closely held greeting card manufacturer, said nearly 47.5 million of its shares had been purchased by employees for $94 million under its profit-sharing and stock ownership plan.

title: Carl Schaeffer, Lawyer, 74; Treasurer of Actors Studio
description: Carl Schaeffer, a lawyer who specialized in bankruptcy cases and who was treasurer of the Actors Studio, died at New York Hospital Monday after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 510 Park Avenue.

title: DOW LOSES 9.85 IN LATE SELLOFF
description: Late selling pressure sent the stock market down moderately yesterday. The biggest losers were some of the technology and video game issues that had shown recent strength.

title: The Fight Game
description: The World Boxing Council said that Donald Curry, its No.2-ranked welterweight, has lost his chance to contend for the title left vacant by the retirement of Sugar Ray Leonard. A spokesman for the council in Mexico City said that the time period had expired for Curry to have set up a fight with Milton McCrory of Detroit, the No.1 contender.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the front page of The Living Section yesterday gave an incorrect price for the child's wool sweater. It is $52 in size 6 at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: LDB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including income of $115,000 from discontinued operations

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GRANDMA

title: GEORGE STEVENS JR., MAN FOR ALL FILMS
description: In a town known for political power and international diplomacy, George Stevens Jr., a West Coast filmmaker who moved here some 20 years ago, has cut his own broad swath.

title: Bahamas Ratifies Rio Treaty
description: The Bahamas today ratified the I@nterAmerican Treaty of Reciprocal Assistance, the hemispheric security agreement commonly known as the Rio Treaty. The accord, approved in 1947 in Rio de Janeiro, is part of the framework of the Organization of American States.

title: SERVED ON U.S. COURT OF APPEALS
description: Judge Leonard P. Moore, who served for 25 years on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, died of pneumonia Tuesday night at his home in Mystic, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: More Moscow Appointments Announced Under Andropov
description: The Soviet Union announced the retirement today of Stepan D. Khitrov, 71 years old, as Minister for Rural Construction.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: MINNESOTA (AL) - Named Phil Roof m anager of the Orlando affiliate in the S outhern League. NEW YORK (NL) - Promoted Bob M andt, ticket manager since 1964, to new p osition of director of operations; Bill Ian- n iciello, assistant ticket manager, to t icket manager, replacing Mandt; Tim H amilton to promotions director, and Jim P lummer to promotions administrator. BASKETBALL CHICAGO (NBA) - Granted Quintin D ailey, guard, a leave of absence. PORTLAND (NBA) - Claimed Hank M cDowell, center and forward who was p ut on waivers by the Golden State Warri- o rs; placed Audie Norris, rookie center, on i njured reserve list.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Prime Minister Olof Palme's Government, in its first major foreign policy move since taking office two months ago, announced a drive today to create a nuclear-free zone in Europe.

title: Market Place; Bullish Case For Gold Price
description: THE price of gold, a key barometer of the world's economic and financial system just a few years ago, has shown some signs of revival in recent weeks as the metal's price has moved generally higher - it was set at $445 at the afternoon fixing in London yesterday, up from $406 on Nov. 23 and a recent low of $296 an ounce on June 21. It fell to $437 in later New York trading.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $2 million for the qr and $4 million for the yr...C-Including a gain of $50 million on the sale of plastics subsidiary anda tax credit of $6 million

title: Woolco Head Resigns Post
description: Bruce Allbright, chairman of the soon-to-be-closed Woolco division of the F.W. Woolworth Company, has resigned as an officer and director of the nation's fourth-largest retailer to return to a position with the Dayton-Hudson Corporation, Woolworth announced yesterday.

title: Technology; Binding Books With Adhesive
description: THE craft of bookbinding came into existence some time before A.D. 400, when the papyrus roll began to be supplanted by the handmade codex - what is now known as the book -with pages made from animal skins and bound by threads along one side.

title: The Editorial Notebook; New Jersey's Tideland Troubles
description: A few years ago, a discussion of riparian land claims would have driven most New Jerseyans to their dictionaries - if not to sleep. Today it is a hot issue for realtors and homeowners.

title: N.F.L. and Drugs (Cont.)
description: O ver the lifetime of some National Football League players, the most important aspect of the labor treaty up for ratification yesterday by the members of the Players Association will not involve money. Sooner or later the players will spend the money. Instead, what might be much more important to some players is the ''testing'' clause to determine what they have spent some of the money on. Cocaine, for example. Cocaine, as in ''it now controls and corrupts'' pro football.

title: ANOTHER APPROACH TO FAMILY THERAPY
description: AN approach to family treatment different from that at St. Mary's Rehabilitation Center in Minneapolis is practiced at the Hazelden Foundation in Center City, Minn. Hazelden, a 194-bed rehabilitation center that has its own ''family week'' program, also offers outpatient treatment in Minneapolis, St. Paul and Alexandria, Minn.

title: NICHOLS, S E, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Putting MX in Its Place
description: What kind of new strategic land missile does America need, one that is more lethal or more survivable? That's the underlying question about the MX missile, but it has been buried in all the current debate. Now the House has finally voted to take the only sensible course: halt spending to build the MX until further research proves it can be securely based.

title: GLEMP AND PRIESTS SAID TO CLASH
description: Priests in Archbishop Jozef Glemp's Warsaw archdiocese have accused the Roman Catholic Primate of not taking a stronger public line toward the Government, church sources said today.

title: U.S. Stand on Envoy Backed by U.N. Aide
description: The legal counsel to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, in a report he will issue Thursday, concurs with the United States that a North Korean diplomat accused of sexual abuse does not enjoy diplomatic immunity.

title: G.& W. Profit Off 15.1%
description: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified holding company, said yesterday that profits for the first quarter of its 1983 fiscal year fell more than 15.1 percent from a year earlier. For the quarter just ended, G.& W. said, earnings fell to $60.8 million, or 80 cents a share, on sales of $1.24 billion. In 1981, the company reported earnings of $71.6 million, or 93 cents a share, on sales of $1.32 billion.

title: Manville Ruling
description: The Keene Corporation and Standard Insulation Inc. cannot bring claims in current proceedings against the Manville Corporation's insurance carriers but must file a separate third-party complaint, according to a Federal Bankruptcy Court ruling in New York. The two companies had contended that failure of the insurance companies to indemnify Manville contributed to its bankruptcy filing. Stand ard and Keene, a unit of the Bairnco Corporation, both had purchased Manville's asbestos and had been sued by purchasers of their insulation supplies.

title: 4 Police Officers Are Robbed in Bar
description: Four off-duty police officers were robbed early yesterday by three gunmen at a bar in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: RIZZO ALMOST, BUT NOT QUITE, MAKES RACE OFFICIAL
description: Former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo stepped back into the limelight tonight to roars of applause from his longsuffering faithful.

title: ONE FAMILY'S EXPERIENCES WITH ALCOHOLISM THERAPY
description: MINNEAPOLIS ''THE way I feel about it now, if I drink, it's something I'm doing to myself,'' said Steven Kramer. ''But I don't think I could have been helped as much if I'd been treated alone, without my family.'' ''Being involved in Steven's treatment profoundly changed some of the patterns and problems in our family for the better,'' said Mr. Kramer's mother, Margaret Shryer. ''It's a permanent change: we're more honest in the way we deal with each other.''

title: Burroughs Line
description: The Burroughs Corporation introduced a new line of large computers at the top of its product line.

title: DEBUT OF THE HOMEY HOTEL
description: THERE is a new breed of hotel designed to provide pleasant homes away from home. Intimate in scale, these cozy establishments are familiar to travelers in London and Paris. Often furnished with country antiques and flowery fabrics, the rooms are more charming than they are lavish.

title: MUSIC: PHILADELPHIANS
description: KRZYSZTOF PENDERECKI, the Polish composer, appeared as a podium guest of the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall Tuesday night to conduct a performance of his ''Te Deum.'' The work was inspired by the election of Karol Wojtyla as the first Polish Pope.

title: If the World's Broke, Fix It
description: Finance ministers and central bankers, abhorring any commotion that might upset public confidence, value secrecy almost as much as money. So why, with the world in danger of going broke, did Treasury Secretary Regan go public with his ''personal'' agenda for a supposedly confidential five-nation monetary meeting in Frankfurt tonight? A belated sense of urgency, we suspect. Whatever the motive, it revealed a welcome concern. At last, the Reagan Administration wants action to shore up the world's finances.

title: Robber and Victim Die in a Gun Duel
description: The owner of a Camden travel agency and a holdup man shot each other fatally today in an exchange of gunfire during the aborted robbery.

title: STAGE: 'THE PHILANDERER'
description: ''The Philanderer,'' revived at the Yale Repertory Theater, is George Bernard Shaw's theatrical commentary on the outbreak of Ibsenism in the late 19th century. According to the author, the play deals with ''the comedy of the bewilderment of conventional people when brought suddenly into contact with the Ibsenite movement.'' The title character, Leonard Charteris, makes a career out of his ''amatory enthusiasms.'' The background for most of his exploits is a mythical Ibsen Club in London, and a bust of the Norwegian playwright stares balefully down on the proceedings. Imagine Shaw, next to him, smiling at his own dialogue.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1982; Companies
description: The overseas communications market was opened up to competiton by the F.C.C. The move clears the way for companies to compete with A.T.& T. abroad just as companies like MCI now do in the U.S. longdistance market. The agency also voted to allow A.T.& T. to start offering data and message services such as telex. (Page D1.)

title: File Closed by Stanford On Gene-Splicing Patent
description: Stanford University this week revoked its permission for the public to have access to the United States Patent and Trademark Office's decisions on its application for an important genetic engineering patent, university and patent officials said yesterday.

title: Without a League
description: In 1978, Carol Blazejowski of Montclair State was named the first winner of the Wade Trophy, awarded to the woman voted the best collegiate basketball player in the country. The 1980 Summer Olympics and a lucrative professional career in the Women's Basketball League awaited her.

title: Postal Service Reports Surplus
description: The United States Postal Service ended the fiscal year 1982 with a surplus of $700 million, Postmaster General William F. Bolger said Tuesday.

title: HERS
description: ONCE upon a time, at that darkest season of the year that strikes so dismally on the soul that humankind since its beginning has been impelled to light lights, tell stories, come together in reverence as well as revelry, and in general do everything it can to dispel gloom and encourage optimistic attitudes, I found myself in a Woolworth's with my 6-year-old son a few days after Christmas.

title: Coleco Industries Is Sued by Atari
description: Warner Communications Inc. said its Atari Inc. unit had sued Coleco Industries Inc., charging patent infringement and unfair competition and seeking damages of more than $350 million.

title: BRIEFING
description: Udall: A Matter of Health

title: Caterpillar Trucks
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it may soon stop producing lift trucks at its Towmotor Corporation unit in Mentor, Ohio. It cited overcapacity and reduced demand, which it said would be met through increased production at its plants in Leicester, England, and Dallas, Ore. It also said Towmotor, which employed about 1,300 people at the end of the third quarter, is negotiating to make lift trucks outside the United States.

title: THE STORE PROMOTIONS ARE TRIVIALIZING E.T.
description: WHEN a movie ascends to the highest firmament of American pop cultural mythology, there's bound to be some manifestation at that most pragmatic of shrines, your local store. In the case of ''E.T.,'' a film that one might suppose had made its mark even without all the extras, the paraphernalia has now arrived. There are E.T. dolls and posters, of course, and there are also E.T. clothes, bedsheets, keychains, pins, calendars, notepads, erasers and so on. There are Tshirts that read, ''I Love E.T.,'' and others that say, ''E.T. I Love You'' for variety.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Brooklyn College vs. United States International of San Diego, at Roosevelt Gymnasium, Bedford Avenue and Avenue H, Brooklyn, 8 P.M. The Kingsmen, having entered Division I this season, have a 2-1 record, with victories over Maryland-Eastern Shore and Concordia and a loss to Marshall.

title: REPORT OF A THIRD ABDUCTION INTENSIFIES THE FEARS IN MORRIS
description: Fear throughout Morris County, heightened after the fatal stabbing of two women in the last two weeks, increased today as the police investigated reports that another woman may have been abducted at knifepoint.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: WITH the proliferation of cassettes of various kinds - music tapes and game cartridges - has come the need for organizers and carriers for cassettes.

title: Gas Tax Bill Gains In Senate
description: The Senate Finance Committee overwhelmingly approved tonight an increase of 5 cents a gallon in the Federal gasoline tax to finance a repair program for highways and mass transit systems.

title: Japan G.N.P.  Rises by 0.6%
description: Japan's gross national product rose by six-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter ended Sept. 30 from the preceding quarter, the Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: Continental Air Offering Discounts
description: Continental Air Lines said it would offer discounts of 30 to 50 percent on coach fares on all its domestic routes through Jan. 14. The move was the first major cut in fares by one of the 11 trunk airlines during the holiday season.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * The Federal National Mortgage Association said the average weighted yield on conventional mortgages accepted at its latest auction of four-month commitments to buy home loans fell to 13.729 percent from 13.748 percent four weeks earlier.

title: MUSICIANS VOTE OUT OLD LEADERS
description: After 17 years, the presidency of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, the largest musicians' union in the country, has changed hands in an upset election that swept the union's leadership from office.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO BE ISOLATED IN ITS OPPOSITION TO SEA-LAW TREATY
description: A United States official said today that the Reagan Administration had become isolated in its opposition to a treaty to govern the use of the seas.

title: U.S.F.L.  Generals' Schedule
description: March 6 - at Los Angeles, 1 P.M. March 13 - at Philadelphia, 1:30 P.M. March 20 - Tampa Bay, 1:30 P.M. March 27 - Boston, 1:30 P.M. April 3 - at Arizona, 6 P.M. April 10 - Michigan, 1:30 P.M. April 17 - Washington, 1:30 P.M. April 25 - at Chicago, 8 P.M. May 1 - at Denver, 1 P.M. May 9 - Birmingham, 9 P.M. May 16 - at Michigan, 8 P.M. May 22 - Chicago, 1:30 P.M. May 29 - at Washington, 1:30 P.M. June 4 - at Oakland, 5 P.M. June 12 - Philadelphia, 1:30 P.M. June 17 - Los Angeles, 9 P.M. June 25 - Arizona, 9 P.M. July 3 - at Boston, 1:30 P.M.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The headline on an article Tuesday about a meeting between the leader of the Chinese Communist Party and a delegation from the Arab League was incorrect. The party leader, Hu Yao- bang, said the Arabs should recognize ''the Israeli people's right to peaceful coexistence.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. My 12-year-old beach house has cedar shingles. We have been advised to apply a clear wood preservative to them. Is this a good idea?

title: Kentucky Coal Concerns Sued For $52 Million in Deaths of 7
description: Survivors of seven victims of an 1981 coal mine explosion have filed a $52 million damage suit in which they accused the mine operators of failure to provide a safe work place.

title: 43 FOR KING
description: Bernard King was sent to the locker room before the end of the game tonight. But before he was ejected for unsportsmanlike conduct, the forward was unstoppable, scoring 43 points in a 120-109 victory by the Knicks against the Detroit Pistons at the Silverdome.

title: Transamerica Bid
description: The Transamerica Corporation said it had been tendered about 8.4 million shares of Fred S. James & Company by the expiration date of its $33.50-a-share offer for all of James's stock outstanding. The new shares plus those previously held by Transamerica give the diversified San Francisco company about 98 percent of the insurance broker's shares, Transamerica said.

title: IMMIGRATION: DON'T IMPEDE NEEDED SPECIALISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Notre Dame Asks For Stricter Code
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, C.S.C., president of Notre Dame, said that unless other university presidents make a concerted effort to end the irregularities in college athletics and adopt a code of strict academic standards, Notre Dame will no longer play those universities. ''And if we refuse to play those who won't abide by these standards, the mess will be cleaned up tomorrow morning,'' Father Hesburgh said.

title: North Carolina St.  Under an Inquiry
description: North Carolina State University announced today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association has conducted a preliminary investigation and found ''substance and reliability'' to reports of recruiting violations involving one of its football players.

title: THE BIG (GR)APPLE
description: An incredible thing happened to me recently while I was driving from Miami to New York. A gas station attendant in North Carolina actually smiled and said ''think you'' when I paid him.

title: ALBANY'S RED-TAPED PURCHASING ROUTINES
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ REASSURES ALLIES ON EUROPEAN MISSILE PLAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met here today with allied foreign ministers and sought to insure that the defeat of the MX basing plan in the House did not weaken allied resolve to proceed with plans to deploy new medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe next year.

title: Duke Chooses Sloan
description: Duke University has chosen Steve Sloan as its new football coach.

title: Bridge: The Best Teaching Device Adds Some New Material
description: Of the multitude of bridge-teaching devices that have been marketed in the history of the game, the most durable and effective is certainly Autobridge.

title: OVERSEAS TELEPHONE CURB EASED
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted yesterday to open up the market for overseas communications to competition. The decision effectively clears the way for companies to compete with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in offering telephone service between the United States and other nations, just as companies such as MCI Communications now compete in the longdistance market within the United States.

title: Reagan Picks Aides For Public Broadcasting
description: President Reagan has nominated Richard Brookhiser, editor of National Review magazine, to be a member of the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 23
description: The yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for compensated absences

title: DISABLED GETTING A PLACE LIKE HOME
description: The Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine has announced that renovation work on its Horizon House is nearly completed and that it will reopen the facility in February.

title: HOFFA IS RULED LEGALLY DEAD
description: James R. Hoffa, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who mysteriously disappeared in 1975, was declared legally dead today.

title: CONCERT: BOSTON CHAMBER
description: THE winning enthusiasm of the Boston Conservatory Chamber Players more than makes up for their occasional want of subtlety. At their Abraham Goodman House recital Sunday afternoon, the violinist Stephanie Chase, the cellist Ronald Thomas, the violist Katherine Murdock and the guest pianist Christopher O'Riley presented an enjoyable program of music by Mozart, Ravel and Dvorak.

title: MUTUAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a nonrecurring charge of $125,000

title: Runner's Quest for Maturity
description: C hris Curtin, a junior at Mepham (L.I.) High School, expects to step to a starting line in Orlando, Fla., Saturday and wait for the beginning of the national high school cross-country championship race for girls. Her wait has lasted more than two years, extended by an illness and a calf injury that kept her out of the past two races after she qualified in both years.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell three intravenous products businesses, in Mexico, New Zealand and The Philipines, to Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Merrill Lynch Suit
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the nation's largest securities firm, said yesterday that it had filed suit against Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., charging the brokerage firm with infringement of Merrill lynch's patent on its Cash Management Account and misappropriation of trade secrets.

title: Fifth article of a series appearing periodically on current world economic problems.
description: The worldwide recession has stopped neither the economic growth of Japan and its industrializing East Asian neighbors - Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore - nor the flood of exports that these countries are sending into Western markets.

title: LEARNING TO READ LANGUAGE OF LEAVES
description: HOUSE plants have a leaf language. When things are growing right, their foliage is rich in color. When they are in a slump, leaves may be spotted, brown-edged, limp or yellow. Wise is the gardener who recognizes these signals and can provide quick remedies.

title: NEW YORK CITY ORDERED TO DOUBLE CUTBACK ON DELAWARE WATER
description: With reservoir levels continuing to drop despite recent rains, the Delaware River Basin Commission has doubled its cutback in New York City's daily water allotment from three upstate reservoirs.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Indicted In Drowning in Jersey
description: Two Hopatcong teen-agers were indicted today in the drowning on Aug. 31 of another youth during a drinking party at Lake Hopatcong.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THERE was a good deal of Christmas shopping going on at Sotheby's t he other night. On the other hand, some people just dropped in for t he goat cheese, spiced olives and salami. ''A Christmas Celebration a t Sotheby's'' - cocktails, an auction and dinner to benefit the I rvington House Institute for Medical Research - was that sort of c hummy evening.

title: CATHERINE B. COFFIN
description: Catherine Butterfield Coffin, the mother of Dr. William Sloane Coffin Jr., senior minister of the Riverside Church, died Wednesday at her home in New Haven.

title: SPECIAL PROSECUTOR FOR WATERGATE
description: Leon Jaworski, the Texas lawyer who earned national fame as special prosecutor in the Watergate case, died today at his ranch near Wimberley, Tex. He was 77 years old.

title: ALEKSANDR BELYAKOV, SOVIET FLIER
description: Aleksandr V. Belyakov, a Soviet aviation pioneer who took part in the first flight from Moscow to the United States across the North Pole, died in late November, according to Soviet newspapers received in New York.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST SEE GREATER REASON FOR INCREASING GIFTS
description: ''I doubled my gift this year because I am sure the need is much greater,'' said Walter E. Dennis of Tenafly, N.J. ''I am grateful I can do this.''

title: FUTILE WHITE HOUSE APPROACH TO THE 'GENDER GAP'
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRE DEPT. DEFERS ELIMINATION OF 4 UNITS
description: The Fire Department said yesterday that it had deferred a plan to eliminate three battalions and a division in the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn, after devising other ways to trim its budget.

title: Jessica Lange wins support for an Oscar.
description: ''FRANCES,'' which just finished one week's run in New York (it will be back at the Beekman starting on Dec. 19, but it had to be shown now in order to qualify for 1982 Academy Award consideration) was not admired by everyone who saw it. But there seems to be a strong feeling that its star, Jessica Lange, can't fail to win an Oscar nomination.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: EXQUISITE VIOLINS THAT ARE BETTER OFF IN THE HANDS OF MILLIONNAIRES
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Citibank to Refund Cash Lost in Ploy
description: Citibank has agreed to return approximately $135,000 to 485 customers in the metropolitan area who were the victims of a confidence game at the bank's electronic cash machines in 1980 and 1981, Attorney General Robert Abrams announced yesterday.

title: THE PROPER LIMIT TO CURBING CRIMINAL EVIDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Dokes Aims for a Stylish Title
description: Michael Dokes, ranked as the No. 1 heavyweight challenger by the World Boxing Association and the World Boxing Council, is the 3-1 favorite to defeat Mike Weaver tomorrow night for the W.B.A. version of the title.

title: BIG DEFICITS FORCE CALIFORNIA TO CONSIDER INCREASING TAXES
description: Pressure is building in California for an emergency tax increase of more than $1 billion even though leaders of both major political parties have refused to take the lead in fighting for it.

title: ZIA SAYS SOVIET MAY BE FLEXIBLE ON AFGHAN WAR
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan said in New York yesterday that there was a ''hint of flexibility'' in the Soviet attitude toward its military intervention in Afghanistan and that the Soviet leadership might recognize a need for an early resolution of the Afghan crisis.

title: U.P. Rail Merger Upheld by Court
description: A Federal appeals court rejected pleas by three competing railroads to delay the Union Pacific Corporation's acquisition of the Missouri Pacific Corporation and the Western Pacific Railroad. The decision effectively clears the way for the merger of the Union Pacific and Missouri Pacific and the acquisition of the Western Pacific, approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission on Oct. 20

title: Harvester Extends Layoffs for 3,000
description: The International Harvester Company said it is extending layoffs by two weeks for about 3,000 workers at two farm equipment plants. A spokesman, William Greenhill, said 2,400 workers at the Rock Island, Ill., tractor plant and 600 at the East Moline, Ill., farm equipment plant would return to work Jan. 17 instead of Jan. 3.

title: WON A GRAMMY FOR 'EL PASO'
description: The country singer Marty Robbins, whose song ''El Paso'' won the first Grammy Award for best country and western song in 1960, died at St. Thomas Hospital in Nashville late Wednesday night six days after a heart attack. He was 57 years old and was a member of the Country Music Hall of Fame.

title: Landlords Charged In Arson Scheme
description: Three former landlords were charged yesterday with setting fires to burn down their apartment buildings in Manhattan and the Bronx to obtain insurance payments.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs San Antonio Spurs, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. The Nets, looking for their sixth straight victory, have an imposing task in going against the fourtime league scoring champion George Gervin and his San Antonio teammates. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 7:30 P.M.) Knicks vs.

title: 'Van Veen' to Close
description: ''Herman van Veen: All of Him,'' a one-man show, will close after Saturday evening's performance at the Ambassador Theater. Directed by Michel Lafaille, the musical will have run for five performances and one preview.

title: MARION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dissident Holder Sells Tosco Stake
description: Kenneth M. Good, the shareholder who led an unsuccessful fight to oust Tosco Corporation management last spring, has sold his group's holdings back to Tosco for $49.5 million in cash and securities, the company said.

title: REAGAN RIGHTS POLICIES
description: Tod ay, on human rights day - so named because the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on Dec. 10, 1948 - it is time to assess how the Administration has performed on human rights during its first two years. The record is inconsistent, at best. What is clear is that while Ronald Reagan came into office determined to ignore human rights in the formulation of foreign policy, he has been unable to bury the issue. In fact, for all his efforts, human rights con %derations have in the last few years become one of the most important standards by which the world judges any foreign policy. Yet, despite considerable shifts in Washington's rhetoric and practice, I believe that the Administration continues to do a disservice to the cause of human rights.

title: Fans Impatient
description: The New Jersey Nets have won five consecutive games and raised their home record to 6-2, ahead of last season's pace when they finished 25-16 at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena. But the team is not drawing as well.

title: BACHE AND THE HUNTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices Move Slightly Higher; Fed Supplies New Reserves
description: Prices of Government bonds rose slightly yesterday after the Federal Reserve purchased securities for its own account in a move that supplied permanent reserves to the banking system.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fine Tuning for Tokens

title: U.N., IN 3 VOTES, ASKS BAN ON NUCLEAR ARMS TESTS
description: The General Assembly, which has repeatedly urged a ban on all nuclear tests, adopted three resolutions today calling for a comprehensive test ban treaty.

title: Mime Troupe's Run Is Extended 2 Weeks
description: The San Francisco Mime Troupe's production of ''Americans, or Last Tango in Huahuatenango'' at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, has been extended for two weeks, through Dec. 19.

title: DAN E. HUTCHINS
description: Dan E. Hutchins, director of advertising marketing for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died of a heart attack yesterday while at a luncheon at the Dorset Hotel on West 54th Street in Manhattan. Mr. Hutchins, who lived in New Canaan, Conn., was 58 years old.

title: VIDEO GAME INDUSTRY IS JARRED ANEW
description: The video game industry was further jolted yesterday as Warner Communications Inc.'s stock plunged 16 3/4 points on the New York Stock Exchange, to 35 1/8, and Mattel Inc., the second-largest video game company behind Warner's Atari division, said it expects a loss in its current fiscal quarter.

title: C.A.B. MAY END TICKET REGULATIONS
description: Most of the members of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that they favored taking a major step in deregulating the sale of airline tickets, thus ending a 40-year-old system under which tickets can only be sold by the airlines and accredited travel agents.

title: Musical version of Kaufman-Hart 'Lifetime' on way.
description: A MUSICAL comedy, ''Going Hollywood,'' based on the 1930 hit comedy ''Once in a Lifetime'' by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart, will be completed next month, and there are plans to open it on Broadway on May 10 in a house to be announced. Michael Frazier, the producer, had to pass an acid test: to get the go-ahead from Kitty Carlisle Hart, Mr. Hart's widow, and Anne Kaufman Schneider, Mr. Kaufman's daughter, who control the work of the authors.

title: Pabst Rejects Takeover Bid
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said it had rejected a $32-a-share offer from a California brewer, Paul Kalmanovitz, for 4.2 million of its shares and said it would honor an earlier deal to be acquired by the G. Heileman Brewing Company.

title: After MX, Why Not CTB?
description: If only he would recognize it, President Reagan's defeat on production funds for the first five MX missiles gives him an opportunity to stop pursuing a strategic arms race and seek, instead, serious limits on the nuclear arsenals of both superpowers.

title: STYRON'S 'SOPHIE'S CHOICE'
description: THE heroine of William Styron's ''Sophie's Choice'' is a creature of such extravagant and contradictory attributes that it isn't always easy, while reading the novel, to imagine her in the flesh. She is tragic, voluptuous, suddenly exuberant and then just as suddenly sodden, the survivor of one calamity and the woman at the heart of another. Mr. Styron's Sophie would seem too oversized and literary a figure to be embodied by any actress, even by an actress of extraordinary resourcefulness and versatility.

title: Packers Thrive on 'Unpredictable' Plays
description: In the seven years that Lynn Dickey has been a quarterback for the Green Bay Packers, they have finished with a winning record only once. That was in 1978, when they were 8-7-1 and Dickey missed the entire season because of a broken leg.

title: Village Italian, East Side Czech.
description: THE 15-month-old Zinno is one of the most pleasant and satisfying additions to New York's restaurant scene. It is a large, bus@tling and convivial cafe-restaurant that has replaced Reno Sweeney's on 13th Street in Greenwich Village. The casually dressed crowd at the big front bar and in the white-brick-walled dining room is young and spirited, and a sense of good will emanates from the staff and management. Add very good Italian food and, usually, a sophisticated jazz piano-and-bass combo, and you have the makings of a thoroughly delightful dinner. Only at the most crowded times - say on a Saturday night - does the noise level get uncomfortably high.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Detroit dispatch by United Press International yesterday incorrectly described a judge's action involving James R. Hoffa, the teamsters union president who disappeared in 1975. The judge declared him ''presumed dead.'' A corrected article is on page D17.

title: Medieval Drama On
description: A new production of ''Daniel and the Lions'' a medieval liturgical drama in French, will be presented five times this weekend by the Ensemble for Early Muisc, directed by Frederick Renze, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, beginning tonight at 8. Performances will also be given tomorrow and Sunday at 4 and 8 P.M. The cathedral is at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. Tickets, $10, $12 and $15, are available at the box office.

title: MANVILLE'S ROBUST BANKRUPTCY
description: The Manville Corporation is looking awfully good for a company in bankruptcy - at least so far. Unlike most other corporations that file for protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law, Manville is still trading on the New York Stock Exchange, and its shares are slowly rising. They have climbed from 4 1/4 on Aug. 27, the day after Manville's bankruptcy filing, to 9 1/2, where they closed yesterday.

title: RESCUING PAST SPLENDOR
description: The Old Executive Office Building, which stands next to the White House on Pennsylvania Avenue, is a granite mass of columns, carvings, porches and turrets that looks like a cross between a haunted mansion and a giant wedding cake and probably causes more double-takes than any other structure in Washington.

title: DANCE: LIMON 'CARLOTA' REVIVED AFTER 4 YEARS
description: THE last dance work Jose Limon choreographed before his death in 1972 was ''Carlota,'' and it is this unusual piece that the Jose Limon Dance Company revived after four years Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Garbage Strike in Paris
description: More than 6,000 tons of garbage cluttered the sidewalks of central Paris today because of a pay strike by garbage collectors. Plastic garbage bags, some of them spilling their contents, were piled along the Champs-Elysees and in other shopping areas. Mayor Jacques Chirac ordered 200 trucks from other city departments to help to clear up the garbage, but they were making slow progress.

title: HOFFA RULED 'PRESUMED' DEAD
description: James R. Hoffa, the teamsters' union leader who vanished seven years ago and was widely believed to have been the victim of an execution, has been declared presumed dead.

title: AN ECHO OF THE PAST IN NEW REAGAN PLAN TO AID FARM INCOME
description: The Reagan Administration's new payment-inkind proposal is simply another means to the same end sought in the 1933 Agricultural Adjustment Act: It is an additional way to pay farmers to plant less and bring supply into line with demand in the hope of raising farm income.

title: Decorative art of 2 centuries.
description: THIS weekend there will be auctions of late-19th- and early-20thcentury furniture, lighting, stained glass and decorative accessories, the most noteworthy of which start at 2 P.M. today and tomorrow at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street. These sessions offer a virtual who's who of the decorative arts in the Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Arts and Crafts styles.

title: American Express Unit Getting Vice Chairmen
description: The American Express Company announced the appointment yesterday of two vice chairmen of its subsidiary, the American Express Travel Related Services Company, which had revenues last year of $2.18 billion.

title: OFFICIALS PARTICIPATING IN TALKS ON MONETARY PROBLEMS
description: Following are profiles of the officials of the five major industrial nations meeting in Frankfurt: Donald T. Regan, United States Secretary of the Treasury, was a political unknown when named to his post in 1980 by President Reagan. He had been chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company. Mr. Regan has insisted that cutting Federal spending and taxes will lead to robust growth.

title: MORE MONEY ASKED IN FIGHT OF DRUGS
description: Attorney General William French Smith urged a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today to add $130 million to the Justice Department's budget for the fiscal year 1983 to finance a program to combat narcotics trafficking by organized crime.

title: Iraq Reports Destroying 3 Iranian 'Naval Targets'
description: The Baghdad radio said that Iraqi forces destroyed three Iranian ''naval targets'' today in an air and sea battle near the northern tip of the Persian Gulf.

title: Schlumberger Appoints Two Top Executives
description: Schlumberger Ltd., a leading company in worldwide oilfield services, has named Michel Vaillaud president and chief operating officer and Roland Genin chairman of the executive committee.

title: OPERA: 'MACBETH' CAST
description: THE inexorable cast shifts and erosions of directorial intention that afflict any new operatic production have begun, for better or for worse, to affect the Peter Hall and Metropolitan Opera's staging of Verdi's ''Macbeth.'' Reportedly, some of the more extreme sexual carryings-on of Lady Macbeth had been toned down by the second performance.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Secret Journey Of Skandy and Caroline

title: NEW CONVERT TO JUDAISM MARKS FIRST HANAUKKAH
description: When Sally Moren decided to convert to Judaism, she found in her new religion an appropriate metaphor for her life.

title: ON SOUTHERN AFRICA
description: The English say that treacle traps flies more easily than a swatter. The Administration's treacly foreign policy for Southern Africa - called ''constructive engagement'' - is designed first to encourage South Africa to yield control of Namibia and second to persuade South Africa to help the West insure the region's security. In fact, the policy has brought no answer to the Namibian question and has unintentionally allowed South Africa to intensify security measures at home.

title: Rule Eased By Citibank
description: After weeks of advertising that people would need $5,000 to open a high-yielding money market account, to be offered starting next Tuesday, New York's Citibank has decided to lower the requirement to $2,500 - the lowest allowed by Federal regulations. The new accounts result from the deregulation of Government ceilings on interest rates that banks may pay.

title: Text of Begin letter, page A12.
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin says he has decided not to exercise his right to reappear or cross-examine witnesses before the state commission investigating the killings of Palestinian civilians in Beirut.

title: ALTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Jerry Farnsworth, Artist, 86; Painted Truman and Mother
description: The portrait artist Jerry Farnsworth, who painted President Truman and his mother in 1944, died in a nursing home here Wednesday following a long illness.

title: COMPUTERS AND SMOKESTACKS MUST COEXIST
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLINS, MORGAN TRADED
description: Before the Yankees officially unveiled their newest multimillion dollar free agent, Steve Kemp, they cornered another free agent, Bob Shirley, from the market today. Afterward, they shipped one of last year's free agents, Dave Collins, to the Toronto Blue Jays with Mike Morgan in a five-player trade.

title: TEXAS TRAILER LOTS ARE BARE AS MANY JOB HUNTERS HEAD HOME
description: Like the thousands of others who fled the industrial sector of the North as the economy soured and the jobs moved south, David Brown came to Houston because it was the city of opportunity: the golden buckle on the Sun Belt, as the Chamber of Commerce liked to say.

title: Soviet Premier in Finland
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov of the Soviet Union arrived here today for a three-day visit and for talks expected to focus on economic relations and a trade imbalance in Moscow's favor.
