title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DETENTE COMES EASILY AT SCHOOL IN BRONX
description: It was all very simple really - no complicated negotiations or throngs of Secret Service agents. It could, in fact, emerge as a new diplomatic style.

title: Witter to Contest Merrill Lynch Suit
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said it intends ''to vigorously contest'' claims made by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. in a lawsuit filed Wednesday in a Federal court in Delaware. In the suit, Merrill charged Dean Witter with infringement of Merrill Lynch's patent on its Cash Management Account and misappropriation of trade secrets.

title: Burroughs Computer
description: The Burroughs Corporation has introduced its B7900 line of large computers. It said the new system increases memory, speeds data transferral and requires less electricity and floor space than previous systems. Prices for the new line, to be available in 1983's third quarter, start at $2.5 million.

title: JAZZ CLARINETS MAKING COMEBACK AT THE PUBLIC
description: ''IT'S an awful lot of work playing the clarinet,'' Benny Goodman remarked the other day. And as if to prove his point, the otherwise immaculate living room of his East Side apartment was strewn with the tools of his trade. Two clarinets were out of their cases and ready to play, and dozens of little purple boxes, each containing several cane reeds, were scattered everywhere. ''You have to practice,'' he added. ''Of course, these days a clarinet player is likely to be subjected to amplifiers. I think that's one of the reasons you don't hear many jazz clarinetists anymore.''

title: Video Imports Fought
description: Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken and its 10 partners in the V2000 video system will file an antidumping complaint with the Common Market against imports of video cassette recorders from Japan, Philips said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mastering the Bow Tie

title: Fairbanks, Envoy in Mideast, Is Nominated for Higher Title
description: President Reagan nominated Richard Fairbanks today for the official title of ambassador while he serves as a negotiator in the Middle East.

title: Another Strike Casualty
description: A week after Harvey Martin of the Dallas Cowboys filed for bankruptcy, citing losses he had incurred because of the player strike, Rick Upchurch of the Denver Broncos has now filed a similar petition.

title: LEADERS IN HOUSE WRITE A JOBS BILL
description: House Democratic leaders have drafted a $5.4 billion public works program intended to create 300,000 jobs and augment a bipartisan highway bill approved by the House on Tuesday.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Suriname Reports Foiling An Attempted Coup

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: You Are Cordially Invited to Rikers Island

title: ONE SURE WAY TO GET IN ON A $5 MILLION JACKPOT
description: To the Editor:

title: JEERS AND FEARS FOR EAGLES
description: In at least one workingman's mind, professional football has come to this: Fear has displaced much of the fun.

title: ROBERT A. BAKER
description: Robert A. Baker, former executive vice president of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, died Wednesday in Stuart, Fla., where he had a winter residence.

title: Lineman of the Year
description: Dave Rimington, a two-time All America center at Nebraska and a two-time Outland Trophy winner (voted to the top interior lineman), added the 13th Lombardi Award to his achievments last night. The winner is considered the top collegiate lineman.

title: ART: ABBOTT H. THAYER, A PAINTER OF WOMEN
description: THE genteel work of Abbott Handerson Thayer (1849-1921) belongs less perhaps to the history of American art than to that of American taste. A member of the so-called ''American Renaissance'' generation of artists and architects - Stanford White, Richard Morris Hunt, John La Farge, Edwin Austin Abbey, Kenyon Cox, Elihu Vedder and others - whose creations paid sedulous homage to the European past, Thayer is best known for his fatuously idealized paintings of women, many actually equipped with angel-type wings.

title: Advertising; Chemical Bank on Public TV
description: EVEN though it cut its advertising budget at midyear, Chemical Bank leaped at the opportunity to become an advertiser on WNET-TV, Channel 13. It will be the first to run commercials on a continuing series on the public television station, one of 10 such stations participating nationally in a Congressionally directed test of ways to offset financial losses from reduced Government support.

title: ENTWISTLE CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Column A or Column B?

title: Funds' Assets Off in Week
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds dropped $1.77 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $230.5 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. A spokesman attributed the decline ''to changes in short-term interest rates, which gave alternative investments a slight edge.''

title: CONCERT: YALE PRESENTS WORKS OF LEO ORNSTEIN
description: HISTORY is a hobby of the artists of this century -making it, breaking it, anticipating it, deceiving it. No artist, it seems, can get by on just present achievements and present appreciation. The true judge, on all accounts, is some mythical force known as History itself, toward which all supplications are addressed.

title: SALES DRIVES FAIL TO AID STORES
description: For the last two weeks, in sales lasting six hours, a full day, two days, an entire weekend, the New York City area's major retailers have been hurling bargain after bargain at Christmas shoppers.

title: Safer on the Field
description: Chuck Ramsey, the Jets' punter, has had his share of minor miseries, yet none has ever prevented him from playing. When the players strike ended, he was suffering from conjunctivitis, an eye inflammation, and could not drive from his home in Knoxville, Tenn., to the Jets' camp in Hempstead, L.I. When he did arrive by plane, he slept through the first workout.

title: House Votes Bill Aimed At Ending Pupil Busing
description: The House voted today to forbid the Justice Department to spend money for litigation that would force the busing of pupils to schools outside their neighborhoods.

title: MEMBERS OF MINORITY GROUPS GAIN UNDER AN F.C.C. ACTION
description: The Federal Communications Commission, in the recent award of an FM radio license, has indicated that it plans to give preferences to members of minorities bidding for new stations, even when the community around the station has no sizable minority population.

title: Nugget String Is Ended at 136
description: Washington got 23 points from Jeff Ruland and held Denver under 100 points for the first time in 23 months in beating the Nuggets, 98-90, tonight.

title: Frederick H. Carpenter, 64; Pioneer in Insulin Research
description: Dr. Frederick H. Carpenter, a leader in insulin research and a professor of biochemistry at the University of California, died here Sunday. He was 64 years old.

title: SLAYINGS ROB A JERSEY COUNTY OF CHRISTMAS CHEER
description: Christmas carols wafted down at lunchtime today from the bells of the old granite and brownstone churches surrounding the green in the center of town, and a ''Santa'' sat inside a little clapboard house waiting for visitors.

title: U.S.-EUROPEAN FARM TALKS
description: Five Cabinet officers will meet Friday in Brussels with ministers of the European Economic Community for what the Agriculture Department says will be the final attempt to persuade Common Market countries to stop subsidizing farm exports.

title: NIMSLO MAKES OFFER FOR BERKEY PHOTO
description: Berkey Photo Inc., one of the nation's biggest photo processors, said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited merger offer from the United States subsidiary of Nimslo International Ltd., a British maker of three-dimensional cameras.

title: NATO SAID TO AGREE ON SOVIET POLICY
description: The United States and its European allies reportedly agreed today to combine a policy of firmness toward the Soviet Union with a heightened willingness to reach accords with the new Soviet leaders if they show a similar interest.

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Decision Reserved On Yankees Suit
description: Acting State Supreme Court Justice Richard S. Lane reserved decision yesterday in Manhattan on whether to let the New York Yankees play their first three scheduled home games in Denver next April. The city has sued in an attempt to force the baseball team to play in Yankee Stadium.

title: JAZZ: MITCHELL-RUFF DUO
description: THE French horn, with its stately sonorities, is not an instrument that is readily adaptable to jazz. But for more than a quarter of a century Willie Ruff has been playing the horn in a very exposed position as half of a jazz duo with the pianist Dwike Mitchell.

title: FINAL ARGUMENTS OPEN AT TRIAL IN JUDGE'S SLAYING
description: Charles Harrelson killed a Federal judge here ''in cold blood,'' and four people who testified he was in Dallas at the time were wrong, a prosector argued today.

title: Moore Shipping
description: Moore McCormack Resources Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Moore McCormack Lines shipping subsidiary to McLean Securities Inc. for $30 million in cash and $30 million par value of McLean preferred stock. McLean is the parent company of United States Lines Inc. The closing is still subject to several conditions, including Maritime Administration approval, the company said.

title: Soviet Astronauts Scheduled To Return From Record Flight
description: The Soviet astronauts Anatoly Berezovoy and Valentin Lebedev will end their record flight Friday, returning to earth after nearly seven months aboard the Salyut-7 orbital station, Tass reported.

title: 12-ROUND LIMIT FOR W.B.C.
description: The World Boxing Council, in a move to help prevent serious injuries in the ring, announced today that it would reduce the length of future championship fights from 15 to 12 rounds and would allow referees to order standing 8-counts for fighters in trouble.

title: NATO's Swirling Currents
description: there is a swirl of cross-currents among the allies these days, so mixed you can take your choice and place your bet. It is as reasonable to argue that they are beginning at last to pull together as it is to say things have never been worse.

title: Miss Holtzman Ordered to Testify
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn yesterday ordered District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman to appear in court to testify about possible prosecutorial misconduct by her office in an arsonfor-profit case.

title: RUNNING INTERFERENCE FOR REAGAN WITH THE PRESS
description: In a Kafkaesque White House, David R. Gergen would be Minister of Propaganda, charged with making the surreal seem normal. As things are, he is the Director of Communications, charged with making President Reagan seem the model of executive wisdom.

title: Intestinal Ailment Struck Landaluce
description: Landaluce, the outstanding 2-year-old filly who died Nov. 28, was a victim of ''an intestinal infection followed by a bacterial invasion'' that led to blood clots on the lungs and other organs, a veterinary pathologist said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jacek Duda, a 6-foot-10-inch center for the Polish national basketball team, has defected and is seeking asylum in the United States. Duda left the team while it was on a recent tour of America, and now he hopes to remain with his parents, who left Warsaw in September and settled in Rhode Island. ... Joseph Ulrich, a sweeper for Duke, has received the Hermann Award, presented annually by the Intercollegiate Soccer Association to the college player it considers the nation's best. ... Kelly Tripucka of the Detroit Pistons had a cast removed from his left leg, and doctors predicted that he could return to the lineup in four weeks.

title: Coach Answers Back
description: Monte Kiffin says that if there was a recruiting violation during his tenure as football coach at North Carolina State, it was a ''minor'' one and involved only one player.

title: It Only Looks Like a Jobs Bill
description: For a brief moment it appeared that the lame-duck session of Congress might produce a quick, clean bill to repair roadways and revive mass transit by increasing taxes on gasoline and heavy trucks. President Reagan and the Congressional leadership had all signed on. It looked like a sure thing - and a good one, too.

title: Demby and Dunn Involved in New Firms
description: Emanuel H. Demby, the consumer researcher who took the industry beyond demographics to psychographics and christened the ''creative'' and ''passive'' consumers, has started a firm called Demby & Associates.

title: SOVIET ROLE IN FREEZE MOVEMENT FOUND MINOR
description: A report issued today by the House Select Committee on Intelligence presents evidence that the Soviet Union attempted to influence the American nuclear freeze movement, but it does not appear to support President Reagan's assertion that foreign agents are ''manipulating'' the movement.

title: Thrown for a Loss
description: The players of the San Francisco 49ers, Super Bowl champions, voted by a wide margin on Wednesday to approve the new collective bargaining agreement with the National Football League. There was nothing unusual about that, inasmuch as the league-wide vote was about 3 to 1 in favor of the pact.

title: Notre Dame 92 Fairfield 70
description: Tim Kempton, a freshman, scored 26 points, making 10 of 14 field-goal attempts, to lead Notre Dame (3-3). Another freshman, Ken Barlow, had 15 points. Fairfield (4-1) was led by Tony George, a freshman guard, who scored 14 of his 18 points in the second half.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
REED STENHOUSE INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
BRAIN DAMAGE TO HEART PATIENT HELD UNLILKELY
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark appears to have escaped without brain damage from the seizures he suffered Tuesday, his doctors said today.

title: A Multimillionaire Kidnapped in Canada
description: A multimillionaire financier, Hyman Belzberg, was kidnapped today by at least two masked men who forced him at gunpoint into a rainbow-colored van, the police said. They said no ransom demand had been received.

title: PORT AUTHORITY TO AID PAN AM WITH TERMINAL
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday agreed to help Pan American World Airways refinance its main terminal at Kennedy International Airport in an attempt to raise more than $50 million for the troubled air carrier.

title: SENATE PANEL IS GIVING UP EFFORTS TO AMEND HAZARDOUS WASTE LAW
description: Senator Robert T. Stafford said today that the Environment and Public Works Committee, which he heads, would not propose legislation this year to tighten provisions of the law that controls the handling and disposal of toxic wastes.

title: Caribbean Plan Gains
description: After being considered moribund, President Reagan's plan to provide trade incentives for 23 countries of the Caribbean Basin cleared a major Congressional hurdle today, opening the possibility of passage into legislation by the end of next week.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FRIDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan proposed a new farm plan under which surplus Government grain, cotton and rice would be given to farmers to sell or use for animal feed if they left up to half of their land idle in 1983. The idea, he said, would be to re-establish a balance between supply and demand. (Page A1.) In Brussels today, the U.S. will again ask the Common Market to stop subsidizing farm exports. (D3.)

title: Dailey's Distress
description: Quintin Dailey, the troubled rookie for the Chicago Bulls who went on a leave of absence Wednesday so that he could seek psychiatric help, has been so depressed recently that at one point he considered suicide, according to his attorney, Bob Woolf. Dailey has been under great pressure in Chicago, a result of the highly publicized case in which he pleaded guilty earlier this year to a reduced charge of assaulting a female student nurse at the University of San Francisco when he was a student there.

title: Knicks Lose A Player but Save a Game
description: T he Knicks had been in similar situations several times before this season - taking a lead late in the game but worrying if they could hold it.

title: A VICTORIAN CHRISTMAS ON WEST SIDE
description: With street criers and music-hall songs, Morris dancers and a Dickensian ghost story, a Victorian English Christmas will unfold this weekend on the stage of the Symphony Space on Broadway at 95th Street.

title: DEVILS BEATEN BY CAPITALS, 6-4
description: Shawn MacKenzie's inexperience was evident at least twice in his first National Hockey League start in goal tonight, and both mistakes cost the New Jersey Devils goals in a 6-4 loss to the Washington Capitals.

title: New Accounting Standards Board Advances
description: An organization to set accounting standards for state and local governments came a step nearer to reality this week with an announcement by the Financial Accounting Foundation that it planned to set up a Government Accounting Standards Board.

title: Marguerite De La Poer Weds John Schlesinger
description: Marguerite Mary Abercrombie De La Poer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Persse Powers of Charleston, S.C., was married yesterday in New York to John Harold Schlesinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Harold Schlesinger of New Haven. The Rev. Anne Brewster Jones and the Rev. John Woolsey performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: James Baker's Son Arrested
description: The 23-year-old son of James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, has surrendered to the county authorities on a felony warrant charging him with delivering marijuana. John C. Baker was freed on $10,000 bond Tuesday on the charge of delivering less than an ounce of marijuana.

title: Baldwin Sued By Stockholder
description: A stockholder of the Baldwin-United Corporation has accused the company and its president, Morley P. Thompson, of trying to inflate the price of Baldwin-United securities by making false or misleading statements.

title: Real Estate; Planned Units Arise In Jersey
description: THE financier Thomas Fortune Ryan fenced off a thousand acres of woodland in the hills of this western New Jersey town many years ago and used it as his private deer-hunting preserve. He had other property as well, some of it farmland, and he called it all Panther Ledge Farms.

title: Reagan Declares He's Willing To Hear Other MX Base Plans
description: President Reagan said today that he was willing to ''be fair, to hear other proposals'' on MX missile basing methods besides the ''dense pack'' plan, but White House officials quickly said the President was not abandoning it. The statement, in a phone call to an NBC News correspondent, was the first signal that he might compromise.

title: Illinois Governor to Seek Denial of Vote Recount
description: Gov. James Thompson plans to ask the State Supreme Court to reject the recount of votes in the Nov. 2 gubernatorial election requested by Adlai E. Stevenson 3d.

title: Mobil Gasoline Discount
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said yesterday that it was recommending that its dealers in New York offer a 4 cent-a-gallon discount to customers who pay cash and that it would reduce its wholesale price to all dealers and distributors starting today.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $2,410,000 on the sale of property and an anticipated loss of $2,382,000 on the future sale of water handling equipment operation; shr earnings reflect a 5 percent stock divd issued in June 1982

title: 'TOY' A COMEDY WITH PRYOR AND GLEASON
description: ''THE TOY,'' a new comedy that co-stars Richard Pryor and Jackie Gleason for the first time and, possibly, the last, is a remake of an especially witless, similarly titled, 1979 French comedy written and directed by Francis Veber.

title: Archer-Daniels
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire 1.75 million shares, or 77.8 percent, of Valmac Industries from Lane Processing Inc. in an exchange of stock. The company will exchange one share of its own stock for each Valmac share, it said. Archer Daniels stock closed at $20 a share, up 3/8, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange; shares of Valmac, a poultry processor and commodity merchandiser, last traded at $16.

title: SOVIET AND THE U.S. CLASH ON SEA LAW
description: The Soviet Union and the United States clashed today over United States claims to navigation and other rights under a sea-law treaty that Washington will not sign.

title: Limited Impact Is Seen In Move to Curb C.I.A.
description: A vote by the House of Representatives to restrict American covert operations in Central America was hailed today by some of its supporters as a symbolic vote of no confidence in the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: News Analysis
description: Once again Northern Ireland and the violence that scars daily life there has seriously embarrassed a British government and heightened the sense of national futility.

title: TEXT OF ISRAELI PRIME MINISTER'S LETTER TO THE COMMISSION
description: Following is the text of a letter from Prime Minister Menachem Begin to the state commission investigating the Beirut massacre, as made public today by the commission and translated by The New York Times from the Hebrew:

title: Currency Options
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange will begin trading today of foreign currency options, starting with options on the British pound, exchange officials said yesterday. Early next year, the exchange will begin trading options on the Canadian dollar, the Swiss franc, the West German mark and the Japanese yen. The market will operate on principles similar to those used in stock options trading.

title: Gilbert Hollander, Chairman Of City Health Planning Unit
description: Gilbert Hollander, chairman of the New York City Health Systems Agency, a federally financed health planning organization, and executive director of the Podiatry Society of the State of New York, died of heart disease Wednesday.

title: GRETZKY STRING HALTED AT 30
description: Wayne Gretzky of the Oilers was held without a point for the first time this season as Edmonton tied the Los Angeles Kings, 3-3, tonight.

title: Economic Scene; Social Security Revenue Plans
description: THE National Commission on Social Security Reform, headed by Alan Greenspan, is almost ready to issue its report on what can be done to shore up the Old Age and Survivors Insurance trust fund. The oldage fund has already started borrowing from the Hospital Insurance and Disability Insurance trust funds to meet its benefit obligations, but this solution cannot last long, as the other funds' surpluses shrink.

title: H.L. GUTTENPLAN, PROFESSOR IS DEAD
description: Dr. Henry L. Guttenplan, a professor of law enforcement and corrections at Pennsylvania State University whose doctoral thesis in 1966 led to the reorganization of the scientific units of the New York City Police Department, died Wednesday at Centre Community Hospital in State College, Pa. He was 64 years old and lived in State College.

title: NORTH KOREAN MISSION WARNED
description: The United States served notice today that it may restrict operations of North Korea's observer mission to the United Nations unless one of its diplomats is surrendered for trial on a charge of sexual abuse.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ex-Aide of Zhou Enlai To Be Envoy to the U.S.
description: United States officials confirmed today that Zhang Wenjin, a Deputy Foreign Minister, would become the new Chinese Ambassador here.

title: No Headline
description: In Percent Previous Year Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 11.50 11.50 15.75 DISCOUNT RATE 9.00 9.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 8.75 8.70 12.30 3-MO. TREAS.

title: 'HOLLYWOOD'
description: THE names say it all, and they include ''Batmen of Africa,'' ''Blonde Savage,'' ''The Brain That Wouldn't Die,'' ''The Cool and the Crazy,'' ''The Giant Claw,'' ''High School Hell Cats,'' ''Slime People,'' ''Musical Movieland'' ''Zombies of the Stratosphere'' and ''Mars Needs Women.'' These are but a handful of the titles touched on in ''It Came From Hollywood,'' which has neither a title nor a transcendent schlockiness to match any of the above, but which is nevertheless amusing in its second-hand, second-rate way.

title: Continental Illinois Challenges Suits
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest bank holding company, said it is seeking to dismiss shareholder suits against its top officers and directors.

title: Peggy Fleming Is Still a Star
description: In 1968, she capped an excellent amateur career when she won the Olympic gold medal in figure skating. Since then, Peggy Fleming has watched a succession of young women - most notably Dorothy Hamill - emulate her success, yet she remains as well known as any of them.

title: MARCHERS ON THE SIDEWALK OF PROTEST
description: On Wednesdays, a group supporting the equal rights amendment usually demonstrates at the western end of the sidewalk outside the White House, while a nuclear freeze group occupies the eastern end. At other times, a woman carrying a vast sack on her head and wearing a sandwich board covered with pictures of herself marches up and down the sidewalk. No one is sure what she wants.

title: Cowles Liquidation
description: Cowles Communications Inc., a Daytona Beach, Fla., investment concern, said it had set Jan. 14 as the date for the first liquidating distribution under its previously announced plan of voluntary liquidation. Cowles said that on that date, shareholders of record on Dec. 23 would receive about 0.655 of a class A share of The New York Times Company, one share of Cowles Broadcasting Inc. stock and $2.25 cash for each Cowles Communications share held. Cowles said the pro rata distribution would represent its entire holding of 2.6 million shares of class A common of The New York Times Company, all of the 3.97 million common shares of Cowles Broadcasting then owned by Cowles Communications and about $8.9 million in cash.

title: JAZZ: JOHN LEWIS SOLOS
description: JOHN LEWIS, who is best known as founder and musical director of the Modern Jazz Quartet, is making one of his very rare appearances as a solo pianist this week at the Knickerbocker Saloon, University Place and Ninth Street, through tomorrow (Saturday, Dec. 11). With Ron Carter accompanying him on bass, Mr. Lewis is playing a broader range of material than he customarily did with the MJQ, and the individuality of his playing style is made more evident.

title: INFANT WHO RECEIVED TRANSFUSION DIES OF IMMUNE DEFICIENCY ILLNESS
description: The Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta reported yesterday that an infant who had received blood transfusions developed a serious immune-deficiency disease that has principally afflicted homosexuals.

title: KOHL DEVISES PLAN TO INSURE MARCH ELECTIONS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl officially informed President Karl Carstens today of his plan to lose a confidence motion next week to open the way for the dissolution of Parliament and general elections on March 6.

title: New Chief Chosen At Goodyear Tire
description: Charles J. Pilliod Jr. said yesterday that he would relinquish his position Jan. 1 as chief executive officer of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in preparation for his mandatory retirement at age 65 next October.

title: DROP SEEN IN CAPITAL SPENDING
description: The nation's business leaders, worn down by 16 months of recession, sharply reduced capital spending this year and plan further reductions next year, a Government survey indicated today.

title: U.S. Bought 2 Currencies
description: In order to calm what they viewed as disorderly markets, the United States intervened in foreign exchange markets four times during August-October, officials at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday, buying a total of $102 million equivalent in West German marks and yen. The New York Fed acts for the central bank and the Treasury in foreign exchange operations.

title: EXQUISITE VIOLINS THAT ARE BETTER OFF IN THE HANDS OF MILLIONAIRES
description: To the Editor: I believe it is time for most of the instruments of the great 17th- and 18th-century makers to be retired to collections. In the first place, very few of the remaining instruments of that era are of concert-tone quality, and most of those that are have been extensively restored and modified to meet the requirements of today's virtuoso players.

title: A CHILEAN'S DARK WORLD: EXILED IN HIS OWN LAND
description: When Juan Carlos Martinez Hofmann was banished this year to this isolated village in southern Chile, his punishment was underlined by the name of the community itself: Selva Oscura means dark jungle.

title: HIGHWAY SIGNS YIELDING TO 'PEOPLE'
description: Signs along state roadway construction sites carry the familiar message ''Men Working.'' But Bill Ehms, a project manager for work along the Saw Mill River Parkway here, thought it would be nice to make a slight change.

title: Indiana Standard In Emirates Deal
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said it had signed an agreement with the United Arab Emirates to sell more than 1.5 trillion cubic feet of natural gas over a 20-year period.

title: 17 SHOW HORSES KILLED IN A BLAZE IN DUTCHESS BARN
description: A predawn fire leveled a barn here Wednesday, killing 17 show horses valued at $200,000 and destroying blankets, bridles and saddles worth more than $50,000.

title: CHAMBER: TELEMANN AND TAFELMUSIK
description: TAFELMUSIK is the name of a collection of chamber music by Georg Phillipp Telemann. It is also the name of a New York chamber ensemble, which consists of the flutist Lauren Weiss, the oboist Pamela Epple, the cellist Christine Gummere and the harpsichord player Linda Skernick.

title: 360-DOLLS-360 ON DISPLAY IN BROOKLYN
description: As the staff at the Brooklyn Children's Museum was putting the finishing touches on its new exhibition, ''Discover Dolls: Reflections of Ourselves,'' several children sneaked in for their own preview. Ann Clausen let them think they were getting away with something while she watched their reactions.

title: Cuomo Names Head Of Housing Division
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo today appointed Yvonne Scruggs-Leftwich, a former Federal housing official, as Commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Urban Renewal.

title: CHRYSLER REACHES A PACT WITH UNION IN CANADA AND U.S.
description: The Chrysler Corporation today reached tentative agreements with members of the United Automobile Workers union in both the United States and Canada.

title: 8 Die in Alaskan Air Crash
description: A SEA Airlines single-engine plane slammed into a mountain on Prince of Wales Island today, about 30 miles west of Ketchikan, killing all eight people aboard, authorities said. The victims were three Washington state residents and five Alaskans.

title: STAGE: FRENCH OFFERING, 'COME DOG, COME NIGHT'
description: FOR the world premiere of Bernard-Marie Koltes's ''Come Dog, Come Night,'' the large expanse of La Mama Annex was transformed into a rolling stretch of West African countryside. The set by Roberto Moscoso uses tons of earth to simulate a barren landscape. One's anticipation is heightened by the striking scenic design and by the playwright's credentials.

title: Bridge:; Assets of Good Generalship Work Well at Tables, Too
description: One of the strengths of the Duke of Wellington as a general was his ability to induce the enemy to commit himself early in the battle. The same strategy can serve well at the bridge table, and did so on the diagramed deal, played in the recent World Championships in Biarritz, France.

title: Toyota Venture
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nippon Steel Corporation said they had jointly developed a new sheet steel for car bodies to prevent rust and corrosion. The steel, called Excelite, is based on an electrolytically bonded double layer of iron and zinc alloy, the companies said. Nippon Steel said it was currently installing new equipment to prepare for full production by mid-1983.

title: Cornetist's New Works
description: The cornetist Butch Morris will present premieres of his own compositions tomorrow with the Systems Orchestra, made up of the violinists Billy Bang and Jason Hwang, the trumpeter Ahmed Abdullah, the singers Jean Lee and Ben Halley, Mr. Morris on cornet and nine others.

title: Maduff Buys Eastern Capital
description: Maduff Group Inc., which owns several financial service organizations, has acquired the Eastern Capital Corporation, a discount commodity brokerage house in Boston.

title: PHILLIES TRADE TRILLO FOR HAYES
description: After three days of mostly frustrating talks, trading activity picked up today at the winter meetings. The Cleveland Indians sent Von Hayes, an outfielder with a promising future, to the Philadelphia Phillies for five players, including Manny Trillo, an established second baseman who is 31 years old.

title: LESOTHO SAYS THE VICTIMS OF RAID WERE REFUGEES
description: Government and exile forces in this capital city denied today that the victims of a raid by South African forces were part of a cell of ''trained terrorists.''

title: A European Steel Fine
description: The European Economic Community's executive commission will fine Klockner-Werke, a West German steelmaker, up to $19.5 million for exceeding its production quota in the third quarter of 1981, a commission spokesman said today.

title: 'AIRPLANE II: SEQUEL' FOCUSES ON LUNAR SHUTTLE
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, Jim Abrahams, David Zucker and Jerry Zucker, the three men who wrote and directed the original ''Airplane,'' sent out reminders to the press that they had nothing to do with ''Airplane II: The Sequel,'' which opens today at Loew's State and Orpheum Theaters.

title: CONGRESS SEEMS STALLED ON BANKRUPTCY COURTS
description: Congress appeared stalemated today in its efforts to meet a Supreme Court deadline of Dec. 24 to reorganize the nation's bankruptcy courts.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $59,000

title: E-H INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After a provision of $320,000 for a doubtful note and interest receivable

title: PENTAGON TO GIVE POLYGRAPH TESTS TO PERSONNEL TO FIGHT DISCLOSURES
description: The Defense Department is planning an investigative program under which 100 polygraph operators will give liedetector tests to military and civilian personnel to be selected at random, senior Pentagon officials testified today.

title: 'JUDAS MACCABEUS' IS HERALD OF HANUKKAH
description: If George Frederic Handel's ''Messiah'' dominates the music scene this month, another of Handel's oratorios has the upper hand this weekend. It is ''Judas Maccabeus,'' which chronicles the trials and tribulations of the hero of Hanukkah, Judah the Maccabee.

title: League Conflicts Faced
description: Baseball's club owners took the first step today toward resolving longstanding conflicts between the American and National Leagues when they refined some of their voting procedures. But they postponed action on two other issues: the sharing of revenue from cable television and the use of the designated hitter in the All-Star Game and in all World Series.

title: UNIMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
News Summary; FRIDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1982
description: International Urgent international monetary talks opened outside Frankfurt as the five richest nations sought to avert a possible global banking crisis. Top finance officials and central bank chiefs of the United States, West Germany, Britain, France and Japan are expected to agree to press for a major, rapid increase in the amount of money that the International Monetary Fund can lend to developing countries that are unable to pay their huge foreign debts. (Page A1, Column1.) A new NATO policy toward Moscow was reportedly agreed upon by the United States and its 15 European allies at a meeting in Brussels. Spokesman said the allies had agreed to combine a policy of firmness toward the Kremlin with a heightened willingness to reach accords with the new Soviet leaders if they show a similar interest. (A3:1-3.)

title: Zia Defends Flogging As an Islamic Practice
description: President Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan yesterday defended his country's practice of flogging criminals, saying that the practice is allowed both by Islamic law and ''the civil law which was inherited from the British.''

title: U.S. AGREES TO TURN MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE REFUGE OVER TO TEXAS
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt today announced an agreement with the State of Texas turning over management of a Federal wildlife refuge on Matagorda Island in the Gulf of Mexico to the state, a move opposed by conservationists.

title: Volkswagen Curbs
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G., West Germany's biggest car maker, said it plans to put more than 38,000 workers on shorter working hours next year.

title: CABLEVISION REJECTS PROPOSAL BY CITY TO SWAP SOME AREAS
description: Negotiators for New York City tried yesterday to resolve a year-old dispute involving the city's cable television negotiations by reshuffling the areas assigned to two of the companies in line for cable franchise awards.

title: WHOLESALE OIL PRICE DIP MAY NOT CUT HEAT BILLS
description: The spell of unseasonably warm weather that ended this week and a glut in oil supplies have sent down the wholesale price of home heating oil in the New York metropolitan area. But the reduction, city officials and oil analysts say, will probably not result in comparable savings to the consumer.

title: WHAT GENDER GAP?
description: Differences between the sexes may seem out of fashion, but one new distinction is enjoying a vogue: Women are voting more often for Democrats than men, pollsters say. Surveys probing the touted ''gender gap'' have suggested that rough Republicans ought to beware, for women are especially sensitive on the subjects of war and social justice.

title: POP JAZZ
description: year-old trumpet player who has been a protege of Dizzy Gillespie for more than a dozen years, went to the White House with Mr. Gillespie last Saturday for the ''In Performance at the White House'' series on public television. The program, featuring established American artists and younger colleagues, will be seen on Channel 13 on Dec. 22 at 9 P.M.

title: ART: NICKSON'S BEACHES
description: NOT until quite lately was the beach represented in art as the primal scene - the place where sea, land and sky meet as equals and we reinvent Arcadia. In Dutch 17th-century painting, by contrast, the beach had a somewhat dingy look, as befitted a place where people scraped a humble living and were often on the lookout for trouble at sea. In the 18th century nobody, anywhere, thought of the beach as a place of collective enjoyment. But with the arrival of the French Impressionists, and of their American counterparts, the beach became in art what we now expect it to be in life - a subdepartment of paradise.

title: George Washington Hill Jr., 74, Ex-Officer at American Tobacco
description: George Washington Hill Jr., a former vice president and director of the American Tobacco Company, died of a heart attack Wednesday in New York City. Mr. Hill, a resident of Stamford, Conn., was 74 years old.

title: PARTNERSHIP LAW VETOED ON COAST
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein today vetoed a San Francisco city ordinance that would have extended to live-in lovers, including homosexuals, the health insurance benefits that now go to husbands and wives of city employees.

title: Help, Not Cheers, for Pakistan
description: Pakistan's President Zia presents two problems to his American hosts. The first is the simpler: he needs help and sympathy in shielding a vulnerable country from being clawed by Soviet invaders of Afghanistan. But his martial law regime indulges in some clawing of its own. It would be unfortunate if American misgivings about his highhandedness at home were obliterated by President Reagan's eagerness to give Pakistan the support it needs on a threatened frontier.

title: A JAUNT IN THE COUNTRY TO PICK YOUR HOLIDAY TREE
description: Once again it's time for nostalgic New Yorkers to contemplate a trip over the rivers and through the woods to a Christmas-tree farm to choose and cut their own trees. Tree farmers in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey have some cheerful news for the tree cutters: the trees look good, a little better than last year, and generally, the price has not gone up.

title: DOW DOWN BY 19.13, TO 1,027.96
description: The stock market plunged yesterday as the wave of selling that depressed the video game stocks on Wednesday expanded to most of the list.

title: CONDEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A RICH MATCHUP ON COURT
description: It will be the 7-foot-4-inch Ralph Sampson against the 7-foot Patrick Ewing on Saturday night in the Capital Centre in Landover, Md. It will also be known as the Georgetown-Virginia basketball game, probably the richest nontournament college basketball game played to date.

title: ANACIN MIGHT FACE PROBLEMS LIKE TYLENOL'S
description: News reports that a woman in San Jose, Calif., may have been poisoned by swallowing Anacin III capsules laced with cyanide raises a possibility that the American Home Products Company, which makes Anacin, might suffer problems similar to those of the Johnson & Johnson Company, the manufacturer of Extra Strength Tylenol.

title: Chile Court Suspends Exiling of 8 by Regime
description: In a major victory for human rights activists, the Supreme Court suspended expulsion orders against eight prominent critics of the military Government today and put them on three years' probation.

title: Steel Price Suggestions
description: The executive commission of the European Economic Community will recommend steel prices, starting Jan. 1, in an effort to halt price-cutting, commission sources said today.

title: Franco Bolla's English Debut
description: Advertising fans watching ''Falcon Crest'' on CBS-TV tonight will get to hear the first English spoken on television by Franco Bolla, who for the past three years has - through a translator - been spokesman for his family vineyards.

title: WARM SPELL COSTLY TO SKIING RESORTS
description: I n the wake of the unusual warm spell, massive snowmaking operations are under way as ski areas prepare for the weekend. The Big Melt, which caused most major ski areas in the Northeast either to close or severely curtail their operations last weekend, ended with the arrival of cooler temperatures this week.

title: 15 Waterways Rise Past Century's Flood Peaks
description: By The Associated Press The Mississippi River started dropping yesterday in St. Louis, and officials hoped the worst was over in floods that had sent 15 of the nation's waterways to levels expected only once in 100 years.

title: PROSECUTION REPLAYS 8 CRITICAL TAPES IN FINAL ARGUMENTS AT TEAMSTER TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors made their closing arguments today in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters' union, replaying for the jury eight of the 50 taperecorded conversations that are the core of the Government's case.

title: ESMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including net gains of $8,159,000 for the qr and $6.5 million for the yr on restructuring...C-Including a net gain of $58,512,000 for the qr and yr; shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid Dec 1, 1982

title: Drug Use in the Navy Is Found to Be Down
description: Drug abuse among Navy personnel has dropped sharply since 1980, according to a research concern that performed urinalysis tests last summer on men and women in San Diego and Norfolk, Va., the two major ports of the service.

title: South Africa Temporarily Lifts Ban on 'Master Harold' Play
description: The ban on ''Master Harold ... and the Boys,'' the play about South African race problems, has been temporarily lifted five days after it was imposed.

title: Friday; ASIANS ON SMALL SCREEN
description: Diverse video works, including performance pieces, can be seen in the first Asian American International Video Festival tonight and tomorrow at 8 at the Collective for Living Cinema, 52 White Street in TriBeCa. Tonight's fare consists of five documentaries. One of them concerns Asian-American women in nontraditional jobs, including a welder and a cockswain. Another explores tensions between Asian refugees and Americans in a California fishing comunity. In a third, Japanese-Americans tell of internement experiences during World War II. Admission is $3. Information: 925-8685. WREATHS IN THE PARK

title: THOMAS J. HARWOOD
description: Thomas J. Harwood, who was Supervisor of the Town of Islip for more than eight years, died Tuesday in Southold, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: BID FOR 6-MONTH PERIOD ON CAPITAL GAINS FOILED
description: Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, thwarted on the Senate floor today an attempt to consider legislation that would shorten the holding period for long-term capital gains to six months.

title: Gen. Joseph Hutchison Dies; Accepted Japanese Surrender
description: Lieut Gen. Joseph C. Hutchison of the Army, retired, who accepted the Japanese surrender in the Philippines in World War II, died here Tuesday at the age of 88 after a long illness.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
300 Policemen Block Buenos Aires Protest
description: A planned demonstration marking United Nations Human Rights Day was blocked today by about 300 policemen in full riot gear.

title: SUIT SEEKS TO HALT WORK ON UPSTATE ATOMIC PLANT
description: The executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board asked a judge here today to order a halt to construction of the Nine Mile 2 nuclear power plant on Lake Ontario.

title: A HAMLET TO WHOM PLAY, NOT GENDER, IS THE THING
description: THE moment of truth came, as it must to most tomboys, to Diane Venora when she was 13. ''I've got to be a girl,'' she told herself mournfully at the Noah Webster School in Hartford, ''I realized that all my girlfriends had boyfriends.'' Now she is 30, blissfully married and the mother of a daughter. And she is playing Hamlet.

title: JEFFERSON AND LOYOLA
description: T homas Jefferson could have made the Louisiana Purchase with the money being generated from tomorrow night's basketball game between his University of Virginia and Georgetown University. And St. Ignatius Loyola could have opened Jesuit schools in 100 outposts if he could have tapped the fervor at Georgetown.

title: Islanders' Slump Intrigues Rival Clubs
description: Throughout November, when the Islanders won only four of 16 games, most general managers and coaches in the National Hockey League made light of the slump, feeling that it was just a temporary struggle which the Islanders would shake off any day. But now that the Islanders have won only once in four games in December, the slump has become a bit more intriguing to their rivals.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PLUTO'S REPUBLIC. By Peter Medawar. 351 pages. Oxford. $25.

title: 3 WAYS OF SEEING NEW YORK THEN AND NOW
description: JUST as archeologists may undertake distant digs from clues in old documents or from oft-retold legends, so students of New York history may try to piece together the city as it was from writings that caught it at moments in its evolution. Two recently published books, recalling earlier eras in the city's life, are just such archeological starting points. Armed with them, the weekend explorer can visit sites that still bear marks of the past or, because this is a city where a familiar site may disappear with the sweep of a shovel, can reconstruct in the mind's eye how a place once looked. The choice of sites for such digging is up to the individual explorer; what follows are just a few suggestions.

title: FASHION GIFTS WITH FLAIR: A POTPOURRI OF IDEAS
description: There are some who will tell you that it's the thought, not the gift, that counts. They are people who don't know what they're talking about. The gift counts, believe it, but fortunately the criterion isn't usually the amount spent. If the recipient is the kind of person to whom the price tag is of major importance, there is a simple solution. Cross him, her or them off the list fast, and in ink. What should matter, and what really does count with most family members and friends, is the gift that is obviously bought with a lot of thought, whether it be a certificate for two burgers or a cruise around the world in a deck suite.

title: Forgotten Americans
description: A sign in a Veterans Administration Hospital reads, ''The Price of Freedom Is Visible Here,'' and the U.S.O. has not forgotten the men and women who have fought for the nation. The friendly smile of a volunteer and the red, white and blue U.S.O. banner make the Vietnam veterans in the 12 V.A. hospitals in the metropolitan area as well as the servicemen from World War I and World War II feel that their sacrifices are appreciated.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $6,000 for the qr and $15,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $19,000 for the qr and $66,000 for the 9 mos and a pretax gain of $355,000 for the 9 mos from the sale of a hospital

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Nov 6
description: B-Including tax credits of $2,156,000 for the 12 weeks and $2,335,000 for the 40 weeks...C-Including a credit of $523,000 for the reduction of state franchise tax

title: Abortion Control Law Barred in Pennsylvania
description: Pennsylvania's abortion control law, which went into effect Wednesday after passing a court test, was temporarily held up today by an appeals court panel.

title: POLICE TOOK MONUMENT THREAT SERIOUSLY
description: Police officials said today that they believed Norman D. Mayer, the man who was killed Wednesday after threatening to destroy the Washington Monument, was disposed to and capable of setting off a dangerous explosion. They said that snipers had fired at his vehicle to prevent him from leaving the monument grounds.

title: 4 AGENCIES SETTLE IRAN PAPERS CASE
description: Four Federal agencies have agreed to pay $16,000 to a free-lance writer and two technicians to settle a civil lawsuit over the Government's seizure of documents from their luggage when they returned from Iran a year ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The bottom line is that the hearings provide no evidence that the Soviets direct, manage or manipulate the nuclear freeze movement.'' - Representative Edward P. Boland, chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence. (A15:2.)

title: REAGAN PROPOSES OFFERING FARMERS GRAIN AS PAYMENT
description: President Reagan proposed a program today under which farmers would be given surplus grain, cotton and rice from Government stocks in return for taking up to half of their land out of production in 1983.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Airlines Inc.'s offering of 1.5 million shares of common stock was priced at $12.50 a share through First Boston Corp.

title: 5 NATIONS ADDRESS MONETARY PERILS
description: Top officials from the finance ministries and central banks of the five richest industrial nations opened urgent, secret talks here today aimed at averting an international banking crisis.

title: Former Manila Publisher Put Under House Arrest
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos placed a former newspaper publisher under house arrest today for what he said were links to a plot to overthrow the Government.

title: Regaining Seaver Is Still Goal of Mets
description: While the Yankees continued to make headlines, the Mets continued to make offers today in the hope of swinging at least one trade at baseball's winter meetings. And they conceded that their No.1 goal still was to regain 38-year-old Tom Seaver from the Cincinnati Reds.

title: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Guerrillas in Ulster Threaten New 'Action' Against Troops
description: The Irish National Liberation Army, which says it was responsible for the bombing Monday in which 11 British soldiers and five civilians were killed, warned today of possible ''further action without warning'' against British forces in Northern Ireland.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: To the Rescue With a Coat Hanger

title: BRIEFING
description: New Order of Convention?

title: Nucorp Inc.  Posts a Loss
description: Nucorp Energy Inc., an oil and gas production and development company based in San Diego that is reorganizing under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, announced yesterday a $7.9 million loss from July 28 to Oct.1. Revenue for the period totaled $28.7 million.

title: Kornhauser & Calene Acquires Hall Decker
description: Kornhauser & Calene, two years old and billing about $100 million, has acquired Hall Decker McKibbin, a health-care agency with offices in New York and Marina Del Rey, Calif.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
POLAND SAYS 317 ARE STILL IN INTERNMENT
description: More than 10,000 people were interned at one time or another during the year since martial law was imposed to crush the Solidarity union, and 317 are still interned, the Polish authorities said today.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Helen Gelbman, 86 years old, was found dead at 12:30 P.M. yesterday in her apartment at 630 Mace Avenue in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, with her throat slit and her hands bound. Robbery was believed to be the motive. ... Three teen-agers were arrested Wednesday night and charged with beating and robbing 13 elderly residents of the Rutgers housing project in Manhattan's Chinatown.

title: Market Place; M.T.A. Bonds: Firm Backing
description: THE Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the operator of New York City's bus and subway systems along with some regional commuter train lines, continues to enjoy access to the bond markets, even though state legislators have not come up with a subsidy and tax package needed by the authority to close a budget gap estimated at as much as $300 million in the current fiscal year.

title: No Headline
description: BULGARIA ARRESTS TURK IN POPE CASE

title: HABIB TO RETURN TO BEIRUT IN BID TO SPUR TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration's chief Middle East negotiator, Philip C. Habib, said today that he would return to Lebanon in the next few days in a renewed effort to ''accelerate'' talks for the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces.

title: Cable-TV Viewing Covered in M.R.I. Study
description: Mediamark Research Inc.'s seventh survey of 10,000 consumers included, for the first time, questions on cable-TV viewing. And, according to Timothy Joyce, chairman, its results show that despite the suggestion by some cable-network operators that theirs was the medium for reaching the light viewers of regular television, it turns out that heavy regular viewers are also heavy cable viewers.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split to be paid Dec 17

title: How to Remember Martin Luther King
description: How should the nation honor Martin Luther King? Some would declare a national holiday in memory of the civil rights leader. But that seems inappropriate, especially now that a better proposal lies before the Senate.

title: The Maritime Cartel in Full Sail
description: The competition-minded Reagan Administration might have been expected to give short shrift to the idea of exempting ocean cargo lines from the antitrust laws. Yet, being eager to eliminate subsidies to the maritime industry and lulled by the argument that exemption would promote American business, the White House has signed on to a ''reform'' that would let cargo lines form cartels with virtually no Government oversight. Only the Senate can now stop this costly runaway.

title: CRIME CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A BIT OF PREHOLIDAY, SUPERNATURAL SPOOKINESS
description: THIS may be the season to be jolly, but at least this weekend, the networks seem determined to scare us silly. Two new television movies are dabbling in supernatural spookiness: ''Don't Go to Sleep'' on ABC tonight at 9, and ''Cry for the Strangers'' on CBS tomorrow at 9.

title: CYANIDE IS FOUND IN CALIFORNIA CASE
description: A 30-year-old woman hospitalized in stable condition in San Jose may have been a victim of cyanide poisoning traced to a bottle of Anacin III capsules.

title: SOVIET CREW RETURNS TO EARTH AFTER SETTING RECORD IN SPACE
description: The Soviet astronauts Anatoly Berezovoy and Valentin Lebedev returned safely to earth tonight after a record 211 days in orbit, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: News Analysis
description: In a swift and confusing sequence, South Africa appeared this week to wave an olive branch at one of its black neighbor states, then brandished its sword at another.

title: U.S. OPPOSES IT; Provisions of sea law, page 6.
description: A major step to govern sea lanes and ocean resources was taken here today when 117 nations signed a treaty codifying law for the seas.

title: DEFENDER OF THE NEWS MEDIA'S RIGHT TO CARRY MISINFORMATION
description: To the Editor:

title: One More van Veen
description: ''Herman van Veen: All of Him,'' a one-man show scheduled to close today at the Ambassador Theater, has been extended until tomorrow. The musical will have run for one preview and six performances.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday incorrectly stated the outcome of a blood transfusion received by an infant from an adult who was later diagnosed as having acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The infant developed a severe immune deficiency but is still alive.

title: HOW CONGRESS CHOOSES THE ROAD TO MORE JOBS
description: The political fight in Congress over what is variously called ''highways,'' highways-jobs'' or ''jobs'' legislation merely begins with a disagreement over nomenclature.

title: Running Priority
description: Nonrunners never would understand this but a number of people were ready to risk life, limb and their marriages to participate in this year's New York Marathon. That's what Fred Lebow, president of the New York Roadrunners Club, discovered after receiving replies from 1,300 people who decided not to run.

title: LAW OF THE SEA PROVISIONS
description: Following are the main provisions of the Law of the Sea Treaty, which was signed yesterday in Montego Bay, Jamaica:

title: Hugo Burghauser, 86, Dies; Founded Salzburg Ensemble
description: Hugo Burghauser, a former bassoonist with the Vienna Philharmonic and founding director of the Salzburg Festival Players ensemble, died Thursday after a long illness.

title: DOCTOR CONFIRMS EXCESS OF CYANIDE
description: The doctor treating a San Jose woman believed to be a victim of poisoning by cyanide-laced capsules of Anacin-3 informed the police today that tests had confirmed she had 10 times the acceptable level of cyanide in her body when she was admitted for treatment.

title: How the I.M.F. Operates
description: The International Monetary Fund was created in 1944 to help nations prevent the sort of economic disarray that marked the global depression of the 1930's.

title: NEW YORK CITY CHOCK-FULL OF TRAFFIC VIOLATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkish Leader to Tour Asia
description: President Kenan Evren is to fly to China on Sunday to begin a five-nation tour of Asia. In his first foreign trip since being elected President in a national referendum on a new Constitution last month, General Evren will spend four days in China, three in Indonesia, three in South Korea, two in Bangladesh and one in Pakistan before returning home Dec. 26.

title: Your Money; Money Fund Bank Accounts
description: CONFUSION has been widespread among consumers about the new money market accounts that commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations will be permitted to offer beginning next week. Yet even before these accounts are actually available, a second and distinctively different kind of money market account has been authorized by the Washington bank regulators and may become available early next year.

title: REAGAN HAILS POLAND'S EASING OF MARTIAL LAW
description: President Reagan welcomed today what he described as recent ''partial steps'' easing the military crackdown in Poland and promised to relax United States sanctions against Poland if ''meaningful liberalizing measures'' were introduced in the future.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL UNIT ACCUSED OF SEEKING TO SILENCE A CRITIC
description: Federal investigators have concluded that the Environmental Protection Agency improperly sought to silence one of its employees, a leading critic of the agency, by subjecting him to unjustified investigations.

title: VAL R. LORWIN, EX-PROFESSOR AND EXPERT ON FRENCH LABOR
description: Val R. Lorwin, an economist and historian whose specialties included the French labor movement and the development of smaller European democracies, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Eugene, Ore.

title: House Gets Content Bill
description: An emotionally charged bill to preserve jobs in the crippled United States auto industry reached the House floor today amid warnings that enactment would risk retaliation by America's trading partners and possible world depression.

title: GUATEMALAN CHIEF SAYS WAR IS OVER
description: President Efrain Rios Montt says that ''the war against the subversives is already over'' and that his Government is shifting its emphasis to reconstructing Guatemala's impoverished countryside.

title:
Patents;
Using Pronunciations To Identify Callers
description: New procedures used to identify speakers on the telephone, patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., employ the storage of reference words as pronounced by known individuals.

title: RANGERS, CAPITALS TIE ON LATE GOALS
description: The theme of the Washington Capitals after they rallied tonight and tied the Rangers, 4-4, was: ''We were lucky.'' The theme of the Rangers was: ''We were foolish.''

title:
Patents;
New Type Of Digital Recording
description: WASHINGTON ANEW method of recording and playing back speech, sound or music from a microcomputer was patented this week for the RCA Corporation. The method is described as operating at very low cost and requiring no hardware other than a microphone, amplifier and speaker.

title: NJ Transit Delays Service Cutbacks
description: NJ Transit, responding to a public outcry, has postponed service cutbacks that were scheduled for Jan. 1, the executive director of the agency, New Jersey's commuter transportation unit, said Thursday.

title: Fighter Builds A Foundation
description: Mark Breland is 19 years old and the world amateur boxing champion at the 147-pound class. But Breland, who is from Brooklyn, said it would take a considerable amount of money to convince him to become a professional right now.

title: Sports of the Times; WHERE BRYANT SEEKS ADVICE
description: S everal times over the years, Paul W. (Bear) Bryant, an academician at the University of Alabama, has penned letters to Ann Landers. They are not the conventional ones she gets that seek advice for the lovelorn.

title: 0.6% RISE IN PRODUCER PRICES LED BY NOVEMBER SURGES IN FUEL COSTS
description: Producer prices, which signal eventual changes in consumer prices, rose six-tenths of 1 percent in November, more than they have increased most months this year, the Labor Department reported today.

title: November's Retail Sales Jumped 2.3%; Biggest Gain Since Spring Led by Autos
description: Retail sales jumped 2.3 percent in November, as surging auto sales led the way in the biggest one-month gain since last spring, the Government reported today.

title: G.A.O. CITES GAS RISE
description: Natural gas prices are climbing sharply even though the supply is far more than existing demand, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: Canadian Kidnapping Ends With Arrest of 3
description: Hyman Belzberg, a millionaire businessman kidnapped outside his furniture store on Thursday, was released today without ransom being paid after negotiations by the police, and three suspects in the case were arrested.

title: TO EXIT THE TROUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: PESO CURBS ARE EASED BY MEXICO
description: Mexico will relax its monetary exchange controls beginning Dec. 20, allowing the peso to float freely but keeping a special controlled rate for certain essential foreign payments, Miguel Mancera, Mexico's central bank director, said tonight.

title: EUROPEANS AGREE TO FURTHER TALKS ON FARM SUBSIDIES
description: The United States and the European Common Market agreed today on steps to defuse a crisis over agricultural exports that has threatened to undermine the Atlantic alliance.

title: IONA WINS, 99-76, IN TOURNEY
description: Iona blocked 15 shots and used a overpowering fast-break attack tonight to rout Loyola of Baltimore, 99-76, in the opening round of the Manufacturers Hanover Classic at Mulcahy Campus Center.

title: Sun Co. Outlay
description: The Sun Company's capital spending will drop to about $1.4 billion in 1982 from $1.5 billion in 1981 and will probably fall several hundred million dollars further in 1983, the company president, Robert McClements, told analysts. The company had previously announced plans for capital spending to average $1.7 billion a year for the 1982-84 period.

title: Panel Will Defer Legal Aid Report
description: Three lawyers studying how New York City provides legal help for poor people accused of crimes have decided to withhold their report until the strike by lawyers against the Legal Aid Society is settled, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: MORE NOUVEAU WINES
description: BEAUJOLAIS nouveau, the young wine from France made available withinw eeks of the harvest each year, has won so much popularity among c onsumers that imitations have begun to appear all over the world. F rom France alone we now have Muscadet nouveau, Cotes du Rhone n ouveau, sauvignon blanc nouveau, gamay nouveau, even Bordeaux n ouveau, all in the 1982 vintage.

title: Bulgaria to Hold Inquiry Into Pope's Shooting
description: The Bulgarian Government, terming the implication of two Bulgarians in a plot to kill Pope John Paul II ''nonsensical and absurd,'' has announced it will conduct its own investigation into the assassination attempt.

title: GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST HERALD BIRTHS AND HONOR THE DEAD
description: The celebration of the arrival of new family members and the memory of departed loved ones equally inspire contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL AIDE INDICTED
description: An assistant state attorney general was indicted yesterday on a charge of promoting prostitution by operating a midtown theater in which women performed sexual acts with customers.

title: PRIVATE FUNDS GROW FOR '84 OLYMPICS ON COAST
description: In a building on the edge of the University of California campus here, more than 200 people are preparing for an event that might have bewildered the Olympians of ancient Greece: an Olympiad produced by private enterprise.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Dec. 1 on the World Hunger Media awards omitted one of the winners. ''Famine: Its Causes, Effects and Management,'' by J.R.K. Robson, shared the book award.

title: GEM DEALER GETS 28 YEARS FOR FRAUD IN CASE LINKED TO 3 CBS SLAYINGS
description: A former diamond dealer was sentenced to 28 years in prison yesterday on fraud and tax charges in a case that the authorities have linked to the killings of at least one witness and three CBS technicians.

title: MONEY SUPPLY ADVANCES MODERATELY
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday a moderate increase in money supply during November that analysts said reflected a growing public tendency to keep money in short-term savings during a period of economic uncertainty.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 51. 1. Leon Jaworski, pictured above, the special prosecutor in the Watergate case who died this week, said the reason he had not pushed for an indictment of President Nixon on charges of obstruction of justice was his belief that (there was not enough evidence to justify the indictment/it was unlikely that Mr. Nixon could receive a fair trial/the office of the President should not be subjected to such a proceeding/the nation would be torn apart by such a proceeding).

title: Nureyev Opens Jan. 18 With the Boston Ballet
description: Rudolf Nureyev will appear in New York with the Boston Ballet in 21 performances of his full-length ''Don Quixote,'' which opens at the Uris Theater Jan. 18.

title: 2 Watershed Vandals Get Year's Probation
description: Two 20-year-old Pequannock men were sentenced today to probation and community service for their parts in vandalism that caused $2 million in damage to Newark's water system in July 1981.

title: LEBANON'S DUTY TO TRY ITS WAR CRIMINALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Contempt Bid on E.P.A. Chief
description: The House Public Works Committee voted today, 28 to 11, to cite Anne M. Gorsuch, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, for contempt of Congress for withholding subpoenaed documents on President Reagan's orders.

title: Jury Clears Playtex In Woman's Death
description: A Federal jury found International Playtex Inc. not guilty today in the death of a woman whose husband filed a $5 million lawsuit charging that she died from toxic shock syndrome caused by the concern's super-absorbent tampons.

title: New Safety Rules Adopted by Nevada
description: The Nevada Athletic Commission adopted three rule changes today that its chairman said will ''revolutionize the sport of boxing.''

title: TALK OF SALE OF SOTHEBY'S SPURS TRADING IN ITS STOCK
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet's stock edged upward throughout the week, following published reports that it was up for sale and the auction house's statement Monday in London that it had entered into preliminary talks with unidentified potential buyers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: All in a Day's Work

title: Raiders Suffer Legal Setback
description: A Monterey County Superior Court judge ruled today that the Los Angeles Raiders must move back to Oakland.

title: Surprise Upon Surprise
description: To watch the members of the Notre Dame High School girls'basketball team after they had beaten Lookout Valley, 50-36, Thursday night in Chattanooga, Tenn., one might have thought that they had a blase familiarity with victory. When the buzzer sounded, they strolled over to the opposing players and casually shook hands, then headed off the court.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American United Energy Corp. said it had acquired International Nuclear Safety Systems Inc. in an exchange of stock valued at about $8 million.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. It was unlikely that President Nixon could receive a fair trial. 2. That the Government of Pakistan is not interested in acquiring or making nuclear weapons. 3. The payment is for legal fees for Mayor Kenneth A. Givson and the former Council President, Earl Harris, who were recently acquitted on charges of conspiracy and misconduct in office. The lawyers, who charged up to $225 an hour, will receive more than more than $477,000.

title: Seagram Net Down by 13.5%
description: The Seagram Company said today that net income in its fiscal first quarter ended Oct. 31 fell 13.5 percent on a 10.6 percent decline in sales.

title: Defendant Changes Plea In Indiana Mayor's Death
description: Harold W. Lang, after hearing the case against him, stopped his trial today by pleading guilty but mentally ill to charges he murdered Mayor A.J. Rumely of LaPorte and the Mayor's wife.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 11, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Maina Gielgud to Head Australian Ballet
description: The Australian Ballet has announced that Maina Gielgud has been named artistic director of the company, starting next Feb. 1.

title: NEW YORK CITY CHOCK-FULL OF TRAFFIC VIOLATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribute to Steve Gordon Set
description: A memorial tribute to the screenwriter Steve Gordon will be held Tuesday at 11 A.M. in the Beekman Theater, Second Avenue and 66th Street. Mr. Gordon, who was 44 years old, wrote and directed the hit movie ''Arthur.'' He died last Saturday.

title: Steel Pier Burns; Arson Suspected
description: A spectacular eight-hour fire, blamed on arsonists, today wrecked the famed Steel Pier, for decades the Boardwalk's main amusement attraction until its closing in 1979.

title:
PATENTS;
Limiting Contamination From Reactor Coolant
description: Anatoly M. Bukrinsky and eight co-inventors, all residents of Sverdlovsk, in the Soviet Union, received patent 4,362,693 for a system to lessen the consequences of the loss of coolant in a nuclear power station.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Georgetown vs. Virginia, at Landover, Md. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) Illinois at Kentucky. (Television - Channel 4, 1:30 P.M.) Houston at Syracuse. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 3:30 P.M.) Boxing Rafael (Bazooka) Limon, champion, vs. Bobby Chacon, World Boxing Council's superfeatherweight title bout, 15 rounds, at Sacramento, Calif. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.) Football Giants vs. Philadelphia Eagles, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 12:30 P.M. (Television -Channel 2, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 12:30 P.M.) 49ers vs. San Diego Chargers, at San Francisco. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 4 P.M.) Wisconsin vs. Kansas State, Independence Bowl, at Shreveport, La. (Television - Channel 11 and ESPN, 8 P.M.) Delaware at Louisiana Tech, Division I-AA playoff semifinal. (Television - Channel 7, 1 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Devils, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 8 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WVNJ, 620; WGBB, 1240; WALK-FM, 97.5; 8 P.M.) Other Events Harness Racing: Yonkers Raceway, Central and Yonkers Avenues, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 11:30 P.M., tape.) Freehold (N.J.) Raceway, noon. Monticello (N.Y.) Raceway, 8 P.M. Soccer: Aston Villa of England vs. Penarol of Uruguay, Toyota Cup, at Tokyo. (Television - Channel 41, 9:45 P.M.) Track and Field: City College-Chemical Bank Relays, collegiate and high school competition, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and 138th Street, 10:30 A.M. Thoroughbred Racing: Aqueduct Race Track, Ozone Park, Queens, 12:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 6 P.M., tape, and SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M., tape.)

title: NATO URGES SOVIET TO REBUILD TRUST
description: The United States and its European allies, stressing their willingness to develop trade and human relations, told the new Soviet leadership today that a chance was at hand to rebuild a climate of international trust.

title: MATTEL STOCK BUFFETED BY VIDEO GAME SCARE
description: The video game stock scare claimed two more victims yesterday. Mattel Inc. lost nearly a third of its market value in heavy trading. And Imagic Inc., a game cartridge company that had been planning to make its first public common stock offering in the middle of this month, said it was postponing its offering until early next year because of ''unsettled market conditions.''

title: DR. JULIAN ROGATZ
description: Dr. Julian Rogatz, a pediatrician in New York City for more than 50 years, died Thursday of heart disease.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TREASURE CHEST

title: RECITAL: SANTIAGO RODRIGUEZ AT THE PIANO
description: It seemed at times as if there were two different pianists playing during Santiago Rodriguez's piano recital in Alice Tully Hall Tuesday night. The first played like a competition winner, having won the silver medal in the sixth Van Cliburn Competition.

title: Piece of Jetliner Hits Queens House
description: The roof of a Queens house was hit by a 45-pound piece from the right wing of a Delta Air Lines passenger plane approaching La Guardia Airport Thursday about 9:30 P.M., the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday. No one was injured and the plane, a Lockheed L-1011 with 246 people aboard, landed safely.

title: SIDNEY R. NUSSENFELD
description: Sidney R. Nussenfeld, a retired partner in the law firm of Paul Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison and later a medical researcher, died Monday at the home of a son in Merritt Island, Fla. He lived in West Palm Beach, Fla., and was 73 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Cabby on the Run

title: PHILADELPHIA STUDENTS' CAREER HELPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: METS AND REDS IN AGREEMENT ON SEAVER TRADE
description: Tom Seaver's return to New York baseball was almost assured today when the Mets reached an agreement with the Cincinnati Reds on a trade that requires only the pitcher's approval.

title: MONTH-TURNERS FOR 1983
description: Time was when a calendar was a utilitarian freebee from one's bank or a cute portrait of puppies or flowers courtesy of the butcher or the dry cleaner. Most entertaining of all were the pinups of scantily-clad young women that always found their way to filling stations and locker rooms.

title: TV: ABC LOOKS AT THE FED
description: One of the nation's least glamorous, most mysterious institutions, the Federal Reserve Bank, is the subject of a businesslike ''ABC News Closeup'' report tomorrow night. ''The Money Masters'' explains in a low-keyed way what the ''Fed'' is, who runs it, and how it has been using its powers in recent years.

title: Professor Picked as Envoy
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Lewis A. Tambs, a professor of Latin American affairs at Arizona State University, to be United States ambassador to Colombia.

title: Trans World, Odyssey Talks
description: The Trans World Corporation, parent of Trans World Airlines, said that an investor group known as Odyssey Partners no longer intended to press for the breakup of Trans World. It said, however, that Odyssey, which owns or has rights to 5.2 percent of Trans World, intended to approach the company to discuss its views about such a breakup.

title: Nixon and Kissinger Visit Zia at Waldorf
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan was visited yesterday at the Waldorf Towers by former President Richard M. Nixon and former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Norman-Zukerman Bill In Carnegie Hall
description: Jessye Norman, soprano, will be joined by Pinchas Zukerman, playing the viola, in two of Brahms's traditional Christmas songs for voice, piano and viola, in Carnegie Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. They will be accompanied by Phillip Moll.
