title: The Deficit Dance in Albany
description: With three major budgetary gaps unclosed as the year ends, a special session of the New York State Legislature is urgently needed. Governor Carey, Governor-elect Cuomo, Senate Majority Leader Anderson and Assembly Speaker Fink agree on that, but unfortunately on nothing else. If the deficits were large enough to require creative rescue that stirs the blood, they might pull together. But the gaps are only political-sized, big enough to require unglamorous compromise on sacrifices that each wants the others to bear.

title: STRIKE DIMS CHRYSLER'S HOPES
description: The five-week strike by the Chrysler Corporation's Canadian workers halted production of some of the company's most profitable models and all but eliminated Chrysler's slim prospect of reporting an operating profit for 1982.

title: DEFENSE CITES 'REASONABLE DOUBT' AT END OF TRIAL IN JUDGE'S KILLING
description: Defense lawyers repeatedly invoked the legal phrase ''reasonable doubt'' today in asking the jury to find that the Government had failed to prove its case against three defendants accused of plotting, carrying out and trying to cover up the assassination of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr.

title: More Jobless Seek Aid in Connecticut
description: The number of people applying for unemployment benefits in Connecticut jumped 10.7 percent, to a weekly average of 56,961, during the two-week period that ended Dec. 4, the State Labor Department said today.

title: New Editor for Boston Paper
description: Joe Robinowitz, who was assistant managing editor of The New York Post for four years, has been named editor of The Boston Herald American, which was purchased last week by Rupert Murdoch, owner of The Post. Mr. Robinowitz, 31 years old, succeeds Don Forst, who will become vice president and associate publisher.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Strike Benefit
description: Although the National Football League player strike led to an increase in the number of no-show fans at games when the walkout ended, it may help raise attendance figures for several United States Football League teams. The New Jersey Generals, for example, report selling approximately 11,700 season tickets, slightly ahead of management's expectations.

title: CONCERT: ALICIA DE LARROCHA
description: Whose idea could it have been that Alicia de Larrocha should play Brahms's Piano Concerto No. 2 in the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra concert presented at Avery Fisher Hall Wednesday night in the ''Great Performers at Lincoln Center'' series.

title: CAREY PROPOSES SERIES OF TAX BILLS
description: Governor Carey today submitted a package of tax bills and other items to the Legislature to close what he said was the state's $579 million budget deficit.

title: Anne Boleyn's Psalter Is Sold for $249,480
description: A London book dealer paid the equivalent of $249,480 Tuesday for a little 16th-century book of psalms that belonged to Anne Boleyn, the second of King Henry VIII's six wives. Anne, the mother of Queen Elizabeth I, was beheaded in 1536, accused of incest and other crimes.

title: A New Outlook For Artis Gilmore
description: I t is that time of the season when Artis Gilmore used to talk about leaving basketball. In fact, he said so many times during recent seasons in Chicago where he was the most visible - he is 7 feet 2 inches - target for the critics of a mediocre team. Some of the criticisms, the personal ones, were like tiny needles piercing his sensitive skin. When he was among friends, like the Nets forward Mickey Johnson, Gilmore would often wonder if enough was enough.

title: Man Guilty of Assault On Justice White
description: A jury found Newton C. Estes guilty of assault today for striking Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court several times just before the Justice addressed a bar association meeting here last July.

title: Bridge: Science Helps to Clear Up Some Problems in Bidding
description: Just as in the wide world scientists have brought under control diseases that have plagued mankind for millenniums, so at the microcosm of the bridge table scientific theorists have greatly reduced the incidence of some classical bidding diseases.

title: Mavericks 122, Pistons 121
description: DETROIT (UPI) - Jay Vincent scored a season-high 30 points and Dallas withstood a 21-10 Detroit streak in the final three minutes to stretch the Pistons' losing streak to three games. Rolando Blackman added 20 and Mark Aguirre scored 18 as Dallas outscored Detroit by 14-2 in 3 minutes 29 seconds midway through the third quarter and then spurted by 12-4 at the start of the final period.

title: CAMERA PRICES IN SHAMBLES
description: The numbers are striking. A Nikon FE camera, priced at $300 a year ago, now sells for as low as $210. A Canon AE-1, which fetched $240 last year and $270 in 1979, is advertised at $180. At camera stores all over New York City - historically, the nation's most competitive market for photographic equipment - prices are in shambles.

title: Kenya Devalues Shilling
description: Kenya's central bank said today that its currency, the shilling, had been devalued 15 percent. Business officials and bankers had been expecting the devaluation, to ease pressure on the country's foreign exchange and balance of payments position, banking sources said.

title: Rail Merger Fight
description: Santa Fe Industries, the diversified holding company with major interests in railroads, oil and gas, construction and forest products, said it would appeal to the Supreme Court to block a lower court ruling that cleared the way for the combination of the Union Pacific, Missouri Pacific and Western Pacific railroads into one 22,800-mile system. The Santa Fe, one of three competing railroads protesting the merger, said it was anticompetitive, an infringement on its trackage rights and would cost it $73.1 million in lost revenues. Industry analysts expect the Supreme Court to rule on the request for a stay within 10 days.

title: Daimler-Benz
description: Daimler-Benz, maker of the luxury-class Mercedes, will sell its new compact car for about $11,000 in Europe and $24,000 in America, its main sales target, the company said. It had announced plans in the fall to produce the car as part of a strategy to widen its base of customers. The new model, known in Europe as the 190 and 190E, will be distributed in Europe next year and a different version, designed to comply with United States road requirements, will be introduced in the United States in October.

title: OPERA: MASSENET 'MANON' AT JULLIARD
description: For the ultimate in operatic pleasure, nothing matches the experience of hearing renowned singers at their peak in roles they have brought to a high sheen after years of polishing vocal and dramatic nuances. You don't easily forget the night you heard Callas's Tosca, Bjoerling's Riccardo, Nilsson's Isolde, Sutherland's Lucia. Those are the thrills that only maturity can offer, and you add them to your memory bank along with the time your uncle let you drive his vintage Packard.

title: CONNECTICUT COMMISSION REJECTS A TAX ON INCOMES
description: A bipartisan commission completing a nine-month study today rejected a state income tax for Connecticut and recommended that the state expand its existing tax structure to solve its fiscal problems.

title: Pretoria's Regrets Are Hollow
description: South Africa says it regrets that its armed forces killed women and children during a punitive foray into the capital of Lesotho. The seven victims, it explains, just happened to get caught in a ''crossfire'' with alleged terrorists.

title: Big Men, Big Money, Big Matchup
description: When Georgetown and Virginia meet tomorrow night at the Capital Centre all 19,035 people in the arena and millions viewing the telecast will be watching every move by Ralph Sampson, the 7-4 Virginia senior, and Patrick Ewing, the 7-0 Georgetown sophomore. To most fans that is what this basketball game is all about - an updated version of Wilt Chamberlain vs. Bill Russell.

title: RECITAL: SHIRLEY VERRETT
description: As Shirley Verrett's voice has matured, her tone has become fuller, richer and more resonant. Miss Verrett's Tuesday evening recital at the 92d Street Y was devoted entirely to the music of Brahms - songs that demand a lively intelligence, a mercurial temperament and a supple instrument of size and strength.

title: Global Resources Loss
description: Global Natural Resources P.L.C., an energy company based in Jersey, the Channel Islands, said yesterday that it lost $14.1 million in the nine-month period ended Sept. 30, compared with a net income of $6.1 million, or 29 cents a share, in the same period of 1981.

title: 75 Cents Is Enough
description: Statistics are often used to cloud men's minds, but occasionally they illuminate. Such is the case with the subway fare. In 1969, when this city's population was around 7.9 million, the fare was still 20 cents and daily ridership on the subway system was 4.5 million fares.

title: TV CURB IS BACKED BY U.N. ASSEMBLY
description: The General Assembly, endorsing a curb on the free flow of information, declared, in effect, today that all nations had the right to veto any incoming television broadcasts by satellite from abroad.

title: FISH HANDLERS REACH A TENTATIVE ACCORD WITH FULTON MARKET
description: A tentative agreement between striking fish handlers and Fulton Fish Market employers was announced yesterday by a Federal mediator. The union said it would ask its members to return to work Monday.

title: MORE SUB THAN WAY
description: Transit in New York City passed two depressing milestones this year: the number of subway riders has fallen below one billion, the lowest point since 1917, and fare revenues failed for the first time to cover at least half the cost of providing subway and bus service.

title: A Friend at Times Square
description: The bright lights of Broadway that beckon to visitors to New York - the most popular leave and liberty port -can also be bewildering to a young recruit.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A vote against MX production today is a vote against arms control tomorrow.'' - President Reagan. (1:6.)

title: PRESIDENT SAYS FREEZE PROPONENTS MAY UNWITTINGLY AID THE RUSSIANS
description: President Reagan said today that wellintentioned proponents of a nuclear weapons freeze might unwittingly be ''carrying water'' for the Soviet Union or aiding it.

title: School Board Lifts Ban On Menorah Displays
description: The Commack Board of Education has overruled the District Superintendent and will allow the display of menorahs, the symbol of the Jewish holiday Hanukkah, in district schools.

title: APPELLATE RULING IN SUIT OVER RAID
description: A Federal appeals court refused today to dismiss a former Kentucky prosecutor from a 13-year-old lawsuit filed by a couple whose home was raided in 1967 before they were charged with sedition.

title:
PATENTS;
Labeling Chromosomes In the Sperm of Bulls
description: A method of separating cattle sperm so that the sex of the offspring may be determined has been devised for Genetic Engineering Inc. of Denver, a leading company in cattle embryology.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The TV Weekend column yesterday gave an incorrect date for ''Perry Como's Christmas in Paris.'' It will appear on ABC Dec. 18 at 10 P.M.

title: DOKES STOPES WEAVER IN 1:03, BUT PROTEST IS LODGED
description: Michael Dokes won the World Boxing Association heavyweight title from Mike Weaver in 63 seconds tonight and, almost as quickly, Weaver, his manager and an angry crowd at the Caesars Palace Sports Pavilion claimed the fight was fixed.

title: AMOS IN RADIO'S 'AMOS 'N ANDY'
description: Freeman F. Gosden, who created the role of Amos in ''Amos 'n Andy,'' the comedy in Negro dialect that was one of the most popular and longest-running programs on radio, died yesterday morning at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles of heart failure. Mr. Gosden, who had lived in Beverly Hills, was 83 years old.

title: KNICKS LOSE BY 108-100
description: Before the Knicks made their first choice in the college draft last June, the sixth selection over all, fans at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum chanted: ''Kellogg, Kellogg.'' They were trying to influence the Knicks to select Clark Kellogg of Ohio State, a 6-foot-7-inch power forward. But the Knicks instead chose Trent Tucker, the Minnesota guard, and the Indiana Pacers, with the eighth selection, chose Kellogg.

title: A Union Call for Grant
description: Bud Grant, the head coach of the Minnesota Vikings, says he has been approached by some assistant coaches around the N.F.L. who are impressed by the gains the players made as a result of their strike and who now want to form a union of their own.

title: Blinka Won't Appeal
description: Stan Blinka, the Jet linebacker whom Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League suspended earlier this week for tomorrow's game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, has decided not to appeal his punishment.

title: 3 Stores Destroyed In Westwood Fire
description: A four-alarm blaze early today destroyed three stores in the main business district here. The fire occurred next to a group of shops that burned down in May, authorities said.

title: Confirm the New Judges
description: In the teeth of resistance by Warren Anderson, the New York State Senate Republican leader, Governor Carey has submitted 11 nominations for new judgeships on the Court of Claims. The nominations will expire unless acted on by the end of the month. The Governor has also nominated four people for vacancies on the court and proposed reappointing four other judges. He has promised to nominate eight more candidates of Senator Anderson's choosing for other vacancies, provided only that a bipartisan screening committee finds them well qualified.

title: 13 ARRESTED IN FEDERAL RAIDS AGAINST KEY NARCOTICS RING
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they had broken up a narcotics ring operated by organized crime that had smuggled into the United States 15 percent of the heroin sold in New York City each year.

title: Back Off A Little, Kiddies
description: Speaking as one who looks forward to many years of happiness on Social Security, I want to urge the increasingly surly youth of America to stop whining about their obligation to finance me through old age and start thinking about what they must do to make their own future happy.

title: Rights Protesters March In Buenos Aires
description: A 24-hour human-rights demonstration swelled today into a march through the city center by 6,000 people who chanted that the rally was ''the beginning of the end of the dictatorship.''

title: C. NORMAN STABLER
description: C. Norman Stabler, who as business and financial editor of the old New York Herald Tribune had covered the 1929 Wall Street crash and the subsequent Depression, died Thursday at his home in Keene, N.H. He was 81 years old.

title: TEXT OF U.N DOCUMENT ON SATELLITE DIRECT TV BROADCASTING
description: Following is the text of the annex to a General Assembly resolution adopted today containing the principles governing the use by nations of artificial earth satellites for international direct television broadcasting: Special to the New York Times

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Park Ave. Lights Are Dark

title: SOCIAL SECURITY REFORM PANEL EXTENDS FINAL TALKS
description: With Democrats and Republicans unable to agree on how to shore up the finances of the Social Security System, the National Commission on Social Security Reform today postponed its final round of negotiations pending consultations with the White house.

title: SANDINISTS BLAME U.S. 'AGGRESSION' FOR DEATH OF CHILDREN IN COPTER
description: The Nicaraguan Government said today that 75 children who died in a helicopter crash while being evacuated from combat zones in northern Nicaragua were ''victims of the aggression'' of the United States against the Sandinists.

title:
PATENTS;
Electricity and Sound In Heart Monitored
description: Both the electrical energy and the sound energy of the heart are detected by an instrument patented this week for the Hughes Aircraft Company, Culver City, Calif. The invention, which includes a stethoscope, is held in the hand near the heart, generating displays of the electrical and sound activity.

title: TEAMSTERS' BRIBERY CASE SET TO REACH JURY TODAY
description: An attorney for Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president, pleaded with a jury in Federal District Court here today to disregard what he called the Government's ''Alice in Wonderland'' charges against his ailing, 67-year-old client and to ''let him pass his twilight hours in honor.''

title: Conviction of Lawyer Upheld In Bribing of a Federal Judge
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit today upheld the conviction of a Washington lawyer, William A. Borders Jr., on charges of obstructing justice and soliciting a bribe for a Federal judge.

title: Chinese Congress Ends Its Final Session
description: The fifth National People's Congress ended the final session of its five-year term today after ratifying blueprints for carefully planned growth rather than the ''great leaps'' favored by Mao Zedong.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART RECIPIENT SHOWING SIGNS OF RECOVERY FROM SEIZURES
description: When Una Loy Clark walked into her husband's room in intensive care this morning, she said, ''Good morning, honey.'' Dr. Barney B. Clark opened his eyes, looked toward her, reached out and squeezed her hand.

title: Labor Contractors in Florida Lose Permits in Abuse Case
description: Florida has suspended, revoked or refused to renew the permits of 117 labor contractors in a crackdown on abuse of farm workers, officials of the State Department of Labor and Employment Security say.

title: Queens Man Held In 80 Cab Holdups
description: A 33-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday morning in connection with at least 80 holdups of gypsy cabs in the borough since the beginning of the year, the Queens police robbery unit reported.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Marie La Guardia lives in a comfortable white Colonial house surrounded by rhododendron bushes in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She is 87 years old now, and she @doesn't go out much; the perimeters of her world are, in general, the @perimeters of her living room.

title: A Spartan Sophomore
description: Adrian Branch, the sophomore forward who leads the Maryland basketball team in scoring with a 23.3-point average, has decided not to undergo arthroscopic surgery on his injured left knee. In fact, he may play in tonight's home game against Duquesne. ... A possible viral infection and pain from knee injuries will force Jeff Acres, a forward for Oral Roberts University, to sit out the remainder of the basketball season.

title: WHITTAKER BUYS 8.3% OF SMITH INC.
description: The Whittaker Corporation, stymied for now in its goal to buy a major health care company, said today that it had acquired 8.3 percent of Smith International Inc., a large oilfield services company, in a series of recent stock purchases valued at $49 million.

title: Audubon Society Backs Watt Decision in Texas
description: Russell W. Peterson, president of the National Audubon Society, said today that his organization supported Interior Secretary James G. Watt's agreement to turn over management of the Federal wildlife sanctuary on Matagorda Island to the State of Texas.

title: Minerals Found by Spaceship
description: An area potentially rich in gold, silver and other ore deposits has been discovered in a remote Mexican desert by a sensor carried on an American space shuttle flight.

title: BANK LENDS THE M.T.A.  $35 MILLION FOR A PAYROLL
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority borrowed $35 million from the Chemical Bank yesterday in order to meet the final payroll of the year on its commuter rail lines. It was the second time in two years that the authority had required a loan to meet short-term cash needs.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BOSTON (AL) - Traded Chuck Rainey, p itcher, to the Chicago Cubs for Doug B ird, pitcher. HOUSTON (NL) - Signed a free agent, O mar Moreno, center fielder, to a five- y ear contract.

title: Political Fix for the Professions
description: The dentists' and physicians' trade associations are unhappy. A Federal administrative law judge recently ruled that the Indiana Federation of Dentists illegally threatened to boycott an insurance company that was pressing cost-containment measures on them. Another judge ruled that the Michigan State Medical Society had illegally undermined Blue Shield's effort to control Medicaid bills.

title: CUSTODY BATTLE WAGED OVER MOTHER'S LEFTIST POLITICAL ACTIVITIES
description: A bitter custody battle here has pitted a 39-year-old mother active in a leftist political group against her former husband, who works for a weapons manufacturer.

title: MORENO SIGNS WITH THE ASTROS
description: While negotiations for the two most attractive free agents, Floyd Bannister and Steve Garvey, continued to lag, the Houston Astros removed Omar Moreno from the market today by signing the outfielder to a five-year contract worth $3.5 million.

title: Books of the Times; 2 Civilized Mysteries
description: SHEIKS AND ADDERS. By Michael Innes. 180 pages. Dodd, Mead. $10.95. DEATH OF AN ENGLISHMAN. By Mag- dalen Nabb. 172 pages. Charles Scrib- ner's. $10.95.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1982; International
description: The U.S. and the Common Market agreed on talks to defuse a crisis over farm exports. After a meeting in Brussels, both sides indicated that while differences remained, they could be settled in follow-up meetings to be held early next year. (Page 1.) The U.S. and its allies agreed to increase the I.M.F.'s basic lending power by 50 percent. Little was said, however, about a U.S. proposal that changes in the world monetary system be discussed. (42.)

title: BIGGER LOAN FUND GETS KEY SUPPORT
description: The world's major industrial powers have agreed to increase the basic lending resources of the International Monetary Fund from $62 billion to about $93 billion, a top European official announced today.

title: New York Tech Put on Probation
description: Scotty Whitelaw, the commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, announced yesterday that the conference has placed the New York Institute of Technology men's basketball program on probation without sanctions for one year.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada
description: The United States today exploded a nuclear warhead buried in the Nevada desert, its 19th announced nuclear test this year. The explosive force was 20 to 150 kilotons, a spokesman for the Department of Energy said. A kiloton is equal to the explosive force of one ton of TNT.

title: Dutch Say Suriname Executed at Least 13
description: Lieut. Col. Daysi Bouterse's military regime said tonight that some Surinamese detained on suspicion of plotting a coup were killed trying to escape, but he would not say how many.

title: CONSERVATIVE SENATORS BEGIN FILIBUSTER ON RISE IN GAS TAX
description: A small group of Senate conservatives began a filibuster today against legislation to increase the gasoline tax, and Republican leaders warned that they might have to keep the Senate in session Christmas week to dispose of the measure.

title: U.S. PLANS WAR HEADQUARTERS IN BRITAIN
description: The Reagan Administration plans to build a $13 million support headquarters in Britain, into which 1,000 staff officers of the United States European Command would move if war began in Europe, senior Administration officials said today.

title: REAGAN IS WILLING TO REVIEW HIS PLAN FOR BASING THE MX
description: President Reagan, pressing for Senate approval of production of the MX missile, said today that he was ''perfectly willing to sit down'' with Congress and see whether there were alternatives to his proposal for basing the missiles.

title: BRIEFING
description: In Defense of Johnson

title: DANCE: ALVIN AILEY WITH SOMETHING OLD, SOMETHING NEW
description: When we call a dance sincere, we are certainly indicating that it's a serious effort. But that compliment can also imply that, despite our respect for the work, we nevertheless find something not quite right about it. Truly successful dances live out their lives so vividly on the stage that we never think to comment on their sincerity.

title: TOYS IMPROVE BUT HAZARDS REMAIN
description: In the late 1960's and early 70's consumer advocates often pointed to the unexpected dangers that could come in holiday wrapping: ovens for little girls that could reach flesh-searing temperatures, plastic dolls for toddlers with pinlike protrusions, science kits with exposed electrical terminals that could give a child a fatal shock.

title: Lesotho Denounces Raid
description: South Africa used ''a lie'' to justify a raid against black exiles that took 37 lives in Lesotho, the Government said today. The Lesotho radio service rejected South Africa's charge that those slain had been staging guerrilla raids into South Africa. It said all the victims were refugees and quoted an unnamed Government spokesman as saying, ''The only real reason why South Africa invaded Lesotho was Lesotho's rejection of apartheid,'' South Africa's policy of racial segregation.

title: Bird Leads Celtics to Rout of 76ers, 123-97
description: Larry Bird scored 24 of his game-high 33 points to lead a first-half runaway tonight and lead the Boston Celtics to a 123-97 rout of the Philadelphia 76ers and a share of first place in the Atlantic Division of the National Basketball Association. Both teams have 17-4 records.

title: Million-Dollar Desk
description: A French 18th-century black lacquer desk by Martin Carlin sold for $1,033,560 Wednesday at Christie's in London, the second-highest price ever paid for a piece of furniture at auction. The record is held by a Louis XV corner cupboard, sold at Sotheby's in 1979 for $1.8 million.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1982
description: International Steps to resolve a crisis over European subsidies for farm exports were agreed upon by the United States and the Common Market. The disagreement has threatened to undermine the Atlantic alliance. ''First of all, there will not be an agricultural trade war,'' said Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block, who has been most outspoken in criticizing the subsidies. (Page 1, Column 1.) A sea treaty was signed by 117 nations, but the United States and other major industrial nations did not sign at the ceremonies in Jamaica. The treaty, which codifies law for the seas, is a major step in the governance of sea lanes and ocean resources. President Reagan has firmly rejected the treaty, chiefly because of its seabed mining provisions, but the others that did not sign have not ruled out signing later. (1:2.)

title: U.S. OFFERS FIRST ALTERNATIVE TO BUSING PLAN FOR SCHOOLS
description: The Justice Department, in papers filed with a Federal District Court in Louisiana, presented a detailed plan today to replace court-ordered busing as a means of desegregating the East Baton Rouge school system.

title:
WITH SHCHARANSKY;
Anatoly Shcharansky is more than a mere person. Arrested five years ago by the Soviet regime, he was sentenced to a 13-year prison term on charges that he worked for the Central Intelligence Agency - an allegation denied by President Jimmy Carter. Before his arrest, he was an active member of the Helsinki Watch Committee and he agitated for the right of Jews to emigrate to Israel. Thus, he is being oppressed not only as a man but also as a representative of the human spirit - and particularly of the Jewish quest to be identified with the people and land of Israel.
description: Those of us who have never met him have come to know him through his wife, Avital. On the morning after their wedding eight years ago, Mrs. Shcharansky, who had received permission to emigrate, left the Soviet Union with the assurance that her husband would join her within six months. She was further informed that if she did not leave then, she would find it virtually impossible to leave later. As time passed, it became clear that the Kremlin had no intention of granting Mr. Shcharansky a visa. During their separation, Mrs. Shcharansky has labored tirelessly to bring his plight before the eyes of the world. If you have not seen her pain, you cannot understand the meaning of anguish. Recently, Mr. Shcharansky embarked on a hunger strike to protest the cutting off of the very few letters and visits that he had been permitted yearly.

title: CLICHES BEYOND QUICHE
description: With so much emphasis on creativity in cooking these days, it is a surprise to realize that culinary cliches not only are still with us, but also seem to be steadily on the increase. Although we do have more and better choices than we did 15 or 20 years ago, there are a discouraging number of look-alike, taste-alike offerings in hightoned takeout food shops and trendy restaurants from New York to Los Angeles and all stops in between.

title: DOW OFF 9.20, TO 1,018.76, REVERSING EARLIER RISE
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell yesterday for the third consecutive session, bringing the decline for the week to 12.60 points, as concern over the economy plus unexpected weakness in the video game stocks continued to depress prices.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sculptural Hazards

title: FOR CUOMO, A TIME TO FIDGET
description: Mario M. Cuomo, who does not have to run for governor anymore but soon must become the Governor, was standing in a hallway near the wood-paneled State Senate chamber the other day.

title: Giants Wary of Eagles' Woes
description: Selling an opponent short is a quick route to defeat in any sport, especially in football, which relies so much on emotion. That's why the Giants tried to take the uninspired Houston Oilers seriously last Sunday, and that's why the Giants are anticipating such a physical battle against the lethargic Philadelphia Eagles at 12:30 P.M. today in Giants Stadium.

title: CUOMO FAVORS GAS-TAX AID FOR BUFFALO
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would consider directing a large share of revenue from a proposed Federal gasoline tax increase to Buffalo and the Southern Tier because of high unemployment in both areas.

title: Norwegian Oil
description: The Norwegian Government said it had awarded five petroleum production licenses off north Norway. Some of the companies sharing in the operations are: Phillips Petroleum Norsk A/S; Statoil, the Norwegian state oil company and Esso Exploration and Production Norway A/S.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN NEWS CONFERENCE ON THE MX
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference at the White House yesterday on the MX missile, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: FROM DELAWARE TO PENNSYLVANIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: REBUILDING PLAN OFFERED BY STATE FOR HUTCHINSON
description: The State Transportation Commissioner today recommended a $55 million reconstruction of more than seven miles of the Hutchinson River Parkway in Westchester County, keeping it to its present four lanes in heavily-populated communities and widening it to six elsewhere.

title: ROCKEFELLER'S AIDES RECALL A DYNASTY
description: There was a rare gathering today of officials from the administrations of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, which governed New York State for 16 years.

title: Ford Price Rise
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had increased the prices for its new Thunderbird and Cougar cars from 1982 levels. The new price of the Thunderbird will increase to $9,197 from $8,492 in 1982. The Cougar will rise to $9,521 from $9,094.

title: HEART PIONEER IS CRITICAL OF ARTIFICIAL DEVICE
description: Dr. Denton A. Cooley, the heart transplant pioneer, today criticized the idea of using an artificial heart as a permanent replacement at the present time, comparing the attempt to putting ''John Glenn in a rocket in 1950 and aiming him at the moon.''

title: IRAN ELECTED AN 83-MEMBER PANEL TO SELECT A SUCCESSOR TO KHOMEINI
description: Iran's 82-year-old revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, led Iranians today in voting for a special 83-member assembly to choose his successor after he dies.

title: MSGR. DENIS Q. BLAKE
description: Msgr. Denis Quinn Blake, a former pastor of St. Martin of Tours Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx, died on Monday at Good Shepard Manor in @Albuquerque, N.M., where he had lived in retirement since 1970.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Seeking Help From on High

title: POSSIBLE IMPROPER USE OF FED'S COMPUTER IS INVESTIGATED
description: Federal investigators are trying to determine whether a former employee of the Federal Reserve Board secretly tried to gain access to the board's computer, which holds confidential information of interest to the financial community.

title: SPURS STOP NETS' STREAK AT 5
description: The San Antonio Spurs, leaders of the Midwest Division, ended the Nets' winning streak at five games tonight with a 114-102 trouncing before 11,686 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Nuggets 117, Cavaliers 107
description: Alex English scored 19 of his 27 points and Dan Issel scored 14 of his 20 in the first half as Denver built a 64-54 lead. The advantage became 95-79 at the end of three quarters as Denver shot 64 percent. For the game, Denver shot 59 percent.

title: Donations for Poor Sought
description: The nation's 7,500 Federal office buildings will be open to accept donations of canned food, clothing and staples for the poor during business hours Dec. 13-17, the General Services Administration said today. The agency said the donations would support the Salvation Army's annual holiday program.

title: Harvester Wins Debt Concessions
description: The International Harvester Company, the financially troubled maker of trucks and farm equipment, said that it had received $70.2 million in financial concessions from its suppliers, including $60.8 million in written commitments and $9.4 million in oral commitments. Harvester, which originally sought $50 million in contributions from its suppliers as part of its revised debt restructuring plan, increased the goal to at least $85 million because of the good response.

title: STARS DISCUSS TRAVAILS OF STEPPING INTO A PART
description: David Dukes, now in ''Amadeus,'' said he favored selective theft. Farley Granger, recently in ''Deathtrap,'' told of ''stealing'' something that didn't exist. Millicent Martin of ''42d Street'' recounted her dismay when the show's star, Jerry Orbach, bellowed. And Nancy Marchand remembered panicking after agreeing to star in ''Sister Ignatius Explains It All for You.''

title: Judges Shift Dinner From All-Male Club
description: The site of the annual dinner here for State Supreme Court justices has been changed from an all-male club to a restaurant in downtown Albany.

title: ISLANDERS IN ROMP
description: The Islanders defeated the Devils, 7-1, at the Nassau Coliseum tonight as Clark Gillies and Denis Potvin had two goals each.

title: Shultz Sales Trip
description: A considerable body of opinion in Western Europe is opposed to deployment on the continent of any nuclear missiles and, in particular, the 572 cruise and Pershings that the North Atlantic allies propose to install next year. Last week, after the House defeated MX production and basing plans, the Reagan Administration was more concerned than ever about allied solidarity.

title: THE CLOUT OF THE 'NEW' BOB DOLE
description: When I first got to know Bob Dole,'' says George McGovern, ''he was tough and mean.'' That was back in the early 1970's, when Senator Robert J. Dole was a most acerbic Republican Party chairman and Senator McGovern was a most liberal Democratic candidate for President. Today, the two men count each other as friends. ''He has changed,'' says McGovern - not only on the personal and psychological levels, he adds, but in his ''approach to Government policy.''

title: Soviet and Finland Appealing For Arms Curbs and Detente
description: Finland and the Soviet Union appealed strongly today for detente and a curb to the nuclear arms race.

title: Resort Sued Over Avalanche
description: Anna Conrad, a 22-year-old graduate student at the University of California at Davis, has sued the Alpine Meadows ski resort in the Sierra Nevada after losing part of a leg there.

title: St. Joseph's 110 Fairfield 83
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Bob Lojewski and Lonnie McFarlan scored 25 points each in the home debut for the Hawks (2-1). The Hawks grabbed an early 10-2 lead but Fairfield stayed close for the next 10 minutes. With the score at 23-17, Lojewski scored 17 of St. Joseph's next 24 points in a stretch of 5 minutes 51 seconds and the Hawks built a 47-28 lead.

title: 'TEXAS' TRIUMPH
description: Two decades ago, when the process of selecting American teams for world team championships was on a pair basis, a paradox developed in the Spingold and Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championships. Since both teams reaching the final qualified for the crucial trials, the semifinal stage of the event became, in a sense, more significant than the final.

title: Virginia County Board Bans Students' Crossbow Making
description: The Fairfax County Board of Supervisors has stopped production of crossbows by junior high school students in an industrial arts class.

title: Miss Young, R.C. Wilson Are Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Claiborne Young of Hillsborough, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Young, to Ransom Carlos Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hoffman Wilson of Southport, Conn., and John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for April.

title: NOBEL PEACE LAUREATE DENOUNCES BIG POWERS
description: Alva Myrdal, a co-winner of this year's Nobel Peace Prize, criticized the United States and the Soviet Union in her Nobel lecture today, saying they had created a ''cult of violence'' that threatened global war and bred urban crime.

title: UTILITY SHUT-OFFS REPORTED ON RISE
description: Sharply rising prices for gas and electricity, cuts in welfare benefits and rising long-term unemployment are making more people than ever fall behind on their utility bills, leading to record numbers of utility shutoffs.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MIRIAM KRIEG, a pioneer social worker whose efforts spanned more than four decades of service, will be honored with a special certificate of recognition by the Family Service Association of Nassau County tomorrow - on her 100th birthday.

title: MUSICAL RETURNS
description: ''Gloria!'' will return to the scene of its premiere performance at the Scarsdale Congregational Church, at 1 Heathcote Road, at 8:30 P.M. Saturday.

title: TOWNS WOOED TO SELL METHANE
description: SINCE July, a methane recovery facility at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island has been providing the Brooklyn Union Gas Company with enough pipeline-quality gas to meet the equivalent energy needs of 10,000 homes. Although none of Long Island's landfills is anywhere near the size of Fresh Kills - at 2,219 acres, it is the largest landfill in the world -officials in virtually every town on the Island have been approached by vendors anxious to acquire methane mining rights in exchange for royalties.

title:
ART;
SUBTLE METAPHOR IN JERSEY CITY
description: JERSEY CITY FRANC PALAIA'S color photographs of Chinese billboards, an exhibition on view at the Jersey City Museum through Jan. 15, may seem like an esoteric essay. They are not.

title: Columbia 59, Holy Cross 57
description: Darren Burnett hit a 16-foot jumper with two seconds left as Columbia rallied to win its second game of the season.

title: REFEREE DEFENDS HIS DECISION
description: Hours before he stopped the fight after only 63 seconds, hours before he would be accused of either ''panicking'' or being part of a ''fix,'' Joey Curtis said he could sense that he was stepping into the middle of another boxing controversy.

title: Director Denies Presence At Fatal Movie Crash
description: Steven Spielberg, the movie producer and director, has told Federal investigators that he was not on the ''Twilight Zone'' set the night of July 23, when a helicopter crashed, killing the actor Vic Morrow and two children.

title: KEEPING MORE FOR YOURSELF
description: The 97TH Congress has been good to investors. It cut tax rates, gave deductions for retirement-income deposits to all taxpayers and accelerated depreciation on business equipment. But it also wrote into law a string of compliance and enforcement provisions that even honest taxpayers may find nettlesome.

title: Change of Heart On the Sales Tax
description: A broken campaign promise isn't illegal but a busted budget is, at least in New Jersey. Faced with a spending plan that could end up with a $150 million deficit, Governor Kean said last week he would support an increase in the state sales tax, a levy he said he wanted to lower when he ran for office last year.

title: HOW TO CATCH THE CARIBBEAN BEAT
description: The islands of the Caribbean and the Bahamas, those dots and dashes of land running from the coast of Florida to the coast of Venezuela, are bracing for their annual migration of travelers seeking warmth, ocean breezes and crystalline waters.

title: FAMILY TRIPS
description: To the Editor: No wonder William Geist's children are so intolerant and inconsiderate; they evidently have a superb role model. No wonder his children whine so; they seem to have learned it at their daddy's knee. No wonder his children have only the narrowest appreciation for the possibilities of travel: William Geist has never bothered to open his mind to the myriad ways that children can make travel more educational, exciting -and fun. H. NANCY SPECTOR Juneau, Alaska

title: SMALL BUSINESS HELD AS AID IN JOB CRISIS
description: REPRESENTATIVE Henry J. Nowak, Democrat of Buffalo, who is considered an expert in the House of Representatives on small businesses, told more than 100 owners of such companies in the Greenburgh and Elmsford area last week that ''a healthy smallbusiness sector could be the greatest single solution to the nation's unemployment crisis.''

title: Family Trips
description: To the Editor: I am writing in response to William Geist's article ''Family Trips: What Parents Know'' (Travel, Oct. 10), which referred so negatively to the Chalfonte Hotel in Cape May, N.J. Our accommodations in the annex with our 3- and 6-year-olds were indeed absolutely bare bones, though clean, but we were paying the amazingly low price of $108 a night for all four people, with large breakfasts and dinners included.

title: Not Overblown
description: To The Business Editor: In ''Social Security's Overblown Problems'' (Nov.14), Barbara R. Bergmann has not done anyone a service by attempting to minimize the problems facing the Social Security system.

title: TRAINING WOULD-BE COACHES AT NORWALK
description: NORWALK SOMETHING is drastically wrong, said Frank Morgan, when a 70-yearold woman who is an English teacher could be certified to coach football in Connecticut while a Johnny Unitas could not.

title: Gas Tax Picks Up Speed, Weight
description: The $5.5 billion gas tax and highway repair bill trucking through Congress hit a little pothole in the Senate last week. A group of conservative Republicans mounted a filibuster on the merits - Reaganomics-style.

title: TALES OF TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO
description: SHIRLEY LORD, whose first novel, ''Golden Hill'', is published by Crown, is director for special projects, beauty and fitness at Vogue magazine.

title: Still No Pistols In Morton Grove
description: Supporters of gun control won one for a change last week. A Federal appeals court upheld the ban on the sale or possession of handguns that took effect in the Chicago suburb of Morton Grove early this year.

title: Miss Friese, T.P. Mulvey Are Married
description: Elizabeth Nevins Friese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Beryl Nevins Friese of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Patrick Mulvey, son of Mrs. Thomas Patrick Mulvey of Hyde Park, Mass., and the late Mr. Mulvey. The Rev. Mark Carr performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Precious Blood in Hyde Park.

title: Susan David, Editor, to Wed Robert Lewin, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lester David of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan H. David, to Robert Lewin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Lewin of New York.

title: JOE JACKSON FUSES POP AND SALSA
description: ''Believe it or not, I'm still getting reviews where people call me the angry young man of British New Wave,'' Joe Jackson remarked recently. ''People latch on to one image so they don't have to think, and that kind of laziness has come to characterize the whole music scene these days.''

title: TAKE A NUMBER
description: Who needs another number in these days of access codes, credit cards, and digital everything? Unfortunately, the people of Essex, Conn., do, officials there believe, to make it easier for emergency and service vehicles to locate residences in the growing community.

title: COMING DOWN TO EARTH
description: STEVEN RATTNER is a former correspondent in the London bureau of The Times.

title: WHAT CAN LOTS OF MONEY BUY?
description: In declaring ''The rich are different,'' F. Scott Fitzgerald was wrong in one respect. According to the latter-day augury known as market research, the audio buying habits of the well-to-do are like everybody else's. They are hardheaded and go for cost-effectiveness. Therefore they stick to midpriced equipment.

title: COALITION IS FORMED TO STUDY WAYS TO IMPROVE EDUCATION
description: Eleven Governors and 17 business, academic and labor leaders have formed an organization to seek ways to improve the country's elementary and secondary schools to bolster the economy.

title: Zia Hangs Tough On Afghanistan
description: Even if Pakistan is something less than the ''bastion of stability'' touted last week by President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, it has been steadfast in refusing to legitimize the puppet Government in Afghanistan. ''Pakistan will not talk to this man who came to be head of the Afghan regime by riding on Soviet tanks,'' Mr. Zia vowed.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
OUT OF SORROW, A JOYFUL RENEWAL
description: GOING through our Dad's effects after his death in October, my sister and I found a family menorah that had been used years earlier at the old house in Hartford, and while browsing in a closet, my sister found a second menorah.

title: Judge's Sentence of a Texan Includes a Course in English
description: A United States citizen who attended Texas schools but had to use an interpreter in court has been ordered by a judge to take an English course.

title: HOW AND WHERE TO FIND A FINANCIAL ADVISER
description: WHOM CAN YOU TRUST with your money? Catherine Carmany, for one, w ould like to know. At 29, the New York suburban housewife now c ontrols a nest egg that her parents put into trust for her years a go. The Wall Street bank that manages her money has it invested e ntirely in stocks, however, and Mrs. Carmany would like more d iversity. She would also like to be ''a little involved,'' she said.

title: PHILADELPHIA BARS WASTE DEPOT PLAN
description: Mayor William J. Green ordered a city agency Friday to stop reserving some land owned by the city for a Newark corporation that planned to build a toxic-waste shipping terminal on the site.

title: TEEN-AGER, LIVING AS NOMAD, GIVEN AN IDENTITY AND A HOME
description: Joe, a teen-ager who can neither hear nor speak, did not legally exist until a judge gave him a last name and issued a birth certificate, a document that gave the youth a mother and a chance to get a job.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
WHAT THE BOOKCASE REVEALED
description: A FRIEND once told me that he was fond of inspecting people's bookcases because he was able to analyze the characters of the owners by the type of books they chose for their libraries.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN VIENNA
description: PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a Times correspondent, lives in Europe.

title: OPERA'S ATTIC YIELDS SOME WORTHY CURIOS
description: If opera's newer recordings demonstrate the narrowing availability of quality vocal talent, they are at least offering variety. Six releases over the past year poke into long undisturbed corners of recent operatic history. Several of these undertakings seem to have been worth the effort, others less so.

title: RACIAL BLENDS ENLIVEN POP
description: Black and white popular music have had a long and often uneasy relationship in this country. Black artists have frequently perfected new styles and sparked trends only to watch white musicians dilute the original and cash in. On the other hand, there have been periods when a large popular audience appreciated both black and white innovations. During the mid-1960's, for example, Detroit's Motown label made superb black pop records that were also big sellers while white rock groups like the Beatles and Byrds took popular music in different directions that were just as fresh, and just as commercially viable.

title: ADDICTS TURNING TO DRUG COMBINATION CHEAPER THAN HEROIN
description: Drug-enforcement officials and medical authorities say an inexpensive and hazardous substitute for heroin has gained popularity among addicts in the New York area in the last 18 months.

title: Penthouse Case Judge Is Overruled on Appeal
description: The trial judge in a $522 million libel suit against Penthouse magazine was wrong when he decided to hear and reject a motion to disqualify himself, the State Court of Appeal has ruled.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Rome dispatch by United Press International printed Nov. 28 incorrectly described the Roman Catholic organization Opus Dei.

title: ONE-WOMAN SHOW AT WHOLE THEATER
description: MONTCLAIR DELORES GRAY is one of the shining, surviving exemplars of an allbut-vanished breed: The musical theater STAR. If the world were a coherent place, musicals would be created for her.

title: Carey Fights Final Round On the Budget
description: The game may be over for Governor Carey, but he seems determined to remind the opposition that it's still his ball.

title: DAY CARE CENTER IS A BOON FOR SINGLE PARENTS
description: EAST BRUNSWICK IT IS 7:30 on a Friday morning. The Smurf comes whooping through the front door of Christ Memorial Lutheran Church, closely followed by 3-year-old Donald Kuneyl Jr.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WITHIN the next few days, the Federal Emergency Management Agency is expected to release an evaluation of revised emergency plans for the Indian Point nuclear power plants. The agency's report will focus on whether major flaws in the existing emergency plans have been corrected.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Closely Watched Dance Kurt Jooss, the German dancer and choreographer who died in an automobile accident in Germany in 1979, was keenly interested in creating a ''new German dance'' - one that would incorporate the classical tradition with the modern spirit. His most famous work is the antiwar ballet ''The Green Table.'' It was Mr. Jooss' artistic response to the horrors of World War I and served as a warning of the dangers to come. The 50-year-old work will be presented on television in its entirety for the first time on Monday at 8 P.M. on Channel 13. There will also be taped segments of three other Jooss works and excerpts from interviews with him.

title: U.S. DENIES ENTRANCE TO RUMANIAN GIRL
description: The Federal Government has refused entry to a Rumanian girl whose family is seeking political asylum in the United States, prompting expressions of concern from Rumanian human rights activists in this country and from the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: Hunger Striker Arrives In Paris From Moscow
description: The daughter of a Soviet general who participated in a 33-day hunger strike last summer in an attempt to win permission to emigrate arrived in Paris today, her husband reported. They have not seen each other since 1976.

title: Bristol Given Its Rightful Place
description: I read with interest the article about Bristol (''The Talk of Bristol: Looking for Work - and Hope,'' Nov. 28).

title: Manhattan Merrymaking
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. City Winter Wonderland Dec. 12 - For the second year, Marvin Schwam, president of American Christmas Decorating, will convert his own Chelsea loft in Greenwich Village into a holiday wonderland for about 300 partygoers attending a benefit dance and cocktail party for Happi, (Help Autistic People Please Inc.) In addition to continuous food and an open bar, there will be dancing from 5 to 10 P.M. to Peter Duchin's orchestra. Benefit funds will help toward the establishment of a home for autistic adults. Tickets $50, from 989-3282 or 247-4514. Debut for Christmas Dec. 14 - Chamber Ballet U.S.A., New York's newest ballet company, directed by Finis Jhung, will make its official debut with more than an opening performance. A gala benefit will mark the event, after a show of five ballet premieres in the Space at City Center, with a tempting cold buffet by the Shelter, a restaurant, holiday drinks and live music in the center's Arpino Room. Tickets $100, from 580-0517.

title: Crying 'Wolf' On Rail Fare Rise
description: Richard Ravitch sounds like the boy who cried ''wolf'' in his repeated warnings of a rise in commuter fares on the Long Island Rail Road. Meanwhile, ridership continues at peak levels, and fares steadily rise for commuters and other passengers, as well.

title: TURKS CAREFUL IN ITALIAN INQUIRY ON POPE'S SHOOTING
description: Turkey has been cooperating with Italy's investigation of allegations that there was Bulgarian involvement in the attempt to assassinate Pope John Paul II. But the Government appears reluctant to take any steps that might jeopardize relations with its Eastern bloc neighbor.

title: DISSENT IN ISRAEL
description: THE LONGEST WAR Israel in Lebanon. By Jacobo Timerman. Translated from the Spanish by Miguel Acoca. 167 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: Aide to Begin Confirms Settlements' Expansion
description: The Deputy Prime Minister, David Levi, said today that ''a massive program of building'' was being undertaken at established Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan.

title: Brigham Young 70 Fordham 62
description: Devin Durrant scored 15 points in the second half to lead Brigham Young to its first victory of the year in the Cougar Classic.

title: St. John's 88, Niagara 53
description: The senior forward David Russell had 20 points and nine rebounds to lead the unbeaten Redmen. St. John's (7-0) was also sparked by Chris Mullin, with 17 points, Bill Wennington, with 13, and Billy Goodwin, who had 10. Russell scored 10 points and grabbed six rebounds as St. John's broke open a close game with an 8-point run to lead at the half, 41-27.

title: DOES A SLIVER FIT?
description: Marvin H. Meltzer agrees that the 16-story condominium he designed for a 40-foot-wide site at 224 East 52d Street can fairly be called a ''sliver.'' That is a disparaging term used by critics of overdevelopment in the city to describe buildings that are disproportionately taller than they are wide and that loom over their low-rise neighbors.

title: FAMILY OF THREE GENERATIONS FIGHTS ILLNESS AND JOBLESSNESS
description: The birth of a grandchild is normally a joyous occasion filled with hope, good will and warmth of family and friends. But for Norma L, afflicted with arthritic pain, a heart condition, and mounting debts, the birth not long ago of Jonathan - the second child of her only son - was an occasion that also brought with it sadness and tears.

title: NEW HOPE FOR TREATING LEPROSY
description: Carol Levine is the editor of Hastings Center Report, which deals with ethical issues in the life sciences.Every three months, James Rodriguez travels by subway, ferry and bus from his home in Queens to Bayley Seton Hospital on Staten Island. A burly, sun-tanned man, he looks vigorous and healthy. The only signs of the disease he has had for 30 of his 49 years are the lesions on his hands, which look like unhealed burns or abrasions.

title: LEGAL MARIJUANA: BAD IDEA GETTING WORSE
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
THE CASE OF THE MISSING CAREER
description: THE first time it happened, we were watching a television film about an attractive female evangelist, portrayed adeptly by Faye Dunaway. The actor playing opposite her looked familiar. ''Well, I'll be darned,'' I almost shouted, ''if that isn't Bill Jordan!''

title: Vaughan Is Appointed Chief Doubleday Editor
description: Samuel S. Vaughan has been named editor in chief of Doubleday Publishing Company, and Thomas H. Guinzburg, former president of the Viking Press, has joined Doubleday as senior consulting editor.

title: 4 Yale Students Win Top Villa-Lobos Prizes
description: Four students from the Yale University School of Music were the recipients of the top four prizes in the Second International Villa-Lobos Cello Competition, held in Rio de Janeiro last month.

title: City's Test Gives Wrong Answer
description: New York City last week flunked a Civil Service exam rather than those who took it. About 80 percent of the Parks Department employees tested scored too low to keep their jobs, so officials decided that the 60-question exam, designed to judge how effective a worker would be, must go.

title: Federal Answer To Dioxin Risk
description: Seven years after being advised to clean up a St. Louis suburb contaminated with dioxin, the Environmental Protection Agency last week offered residents a plan for getting it out of their yards, playgrounds and streams. Most homeowners, however, felt less than overwhelmed by the agency's generosity.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Inexpensive Gifts From the Museum

title: THE STATE PENSION SYSTEM NEEDS SCRUTINY
description: EARLY in his administration, Governor Kean realized that paying for the state's pension system was one of his most serious fiscal problems. Seeking a long-term solution rather than a ''quick fix,'' he appointed a Pension Study Commission to wrestle with the problem. Its report is due by next December.

title: TWO NEW TRIUMPHS CAP A FINE YEAR FOR ACTRESSES
description: Look on the bright side: Though the world continues to misbehave and the economy is in a mess and Richard Pryor's ''The Toy'' is one of the worst movies ever made, it's been a vintage year for exceptional performances by film actresses. I'm thinking of Diane Keaton in ''Shoot the Moon,'' Anna Jemison in ''Smash Palace,'' Debra Winger in ''An Officer and a Gentleman,'' Julie Andrews in ''Victor/Victoria,'' Barbara Sukowa in ''Lola,'' Beatrice Romand in ''Le Beau Marriage,'' Anouk Aimee in ''Leap into the Void'' and Claudia Cardinale in ''Fitzcarraldo.''

title: TRYING TO SORT OUT INVESTING IN FIXED ASSETS
description: No FIELD OF INVESTING has a monopoly on obfuscatory language, but certainly the market in fixed assets is as saturated with technical terminology as any. With the proliferation of new types of accounts, it has become harder but more important than ever to be able to differentiate between BAN's and RAN's, or tell Ginnie Mae apart from Fannie Mae. Here, then, is a guide to fixed-income investments, starting with short-term instruments and running through mortgagebacked securities and corporate and tax-exempt bonds to the market in long-term Government bonds. Where possible, current yields have been given to facilitate comparisons between different types of securities. SHORT-TERM FIXED ASSETS

title: MUSIC RINGS IN THE HOLIDAYS
description: WITH the customary emphasis on Handel's ''Messiah'' and ''The Nutcracker'' ballet and a liberal sprinkling of community caroling, the holiday music season goes into high gear this week.

title: CABBY AND WRITER JOIN STADIUM FIGHT
description: New York City officials, seeking to force the Yankees to play their first three games next season in Yankee Stadium rather than in Denver, have enlisted the aid of a cabdriver and a best-selling baseball author to attest to the team's importance to the city's morale.

title: OLDEST PAKISTANI COMMUNITY IN U.S. DRAWS ZIA TO SACRAMENTO
description: Selim Khan, hefting a cloth-wrapped copy of the Koran in English and Arabic, addressed the question of why President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan would include a three-hour visit to a freeway-bordered corner of Sacramento on his American visit.

title: KNICKS BEAT BULLETS WITH DEFENSE, 85-79
description: Since the Knicks and the Washington Bullets are two of the poorer offensive teams and two of the better defensive teams in the league, it was no surprise that the score was low in last night's game at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks won, 85-79.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WILL THIS BE THE WINTER THAT WAS, WEATHERWISE?
description: IT'S RIGHT around the corner and heading our way - fast! Winter '82, that is. It's the one worth writing home about. The biggest and baddest of the century. A real old-fashioned Currier & Ives, go-tosleep-with-hot-coals-in-your-pajamas winter like grandma used to know.

title: HOW LONG SHOULD THE ARM OF THE LAW BE
description: Early next year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation will begin testing a communications system in which inquiries about criminal suspects from all over the United States will be funneled through an F.B.I. computer in Washington to the computers of 17 states.

title: Bar Dexter Wins
description: Bar Dexter was a winner by a nose over Sing Sing in the $85,200 Gallant Fox Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Challenging Condos
description: In the Hamptons The recent article ''Condos vs. Water'' spoke with accurancy of the ''new militancy'' among an increasing number of property owners in the Hamptons.

title: BLACK EXECUTIVES AND CORPORATE STRESS
description: Fred Dudley vividly remembers the start of his corporate career. He was one of two blacks in the engineering division of a Fortune 500 consumer-products company in Ohio. An articulate, intelligent man, one of two people in his department with any knowledge of computers, he nevertheless experienced a great deal of tension at work. ''I was apprehensive when I joined the company and realized that I was one of two blacks in my department,'' he recalls. ''I grew up in a Southern town with the notion of white superiority. Deep down inside, I wondered if I could compete, if I was smart enough.''

title: LET'S GO TO THE FAIR
description: As Geoff Weedon and Richard Ward note in the preface to their FAIRGROUND ART (Abbeville Press, $85), ''when items become collectible they rise to the level of art.'' The prancing, pawing, snorting wooden horses and other animals used on merry-go-rounds are very desirable collectibles.

title: FRIENDSHIPS FORM IN 4-PART HARMONY
description: ON a recent evening, members of the Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America gathered for their weekly rehearsal at the Purchase campus of the State University of New York. When the last member had arrived, all talk ceased and attention was focused on Dave Schuman, the society's musical director.

title: OVER 250 KINDS OF EXPLOSIVES FOUND IN BEIRUT
description: American-led bomb squads searching for weapons and munitions in Beirut have found 250 different kinds of explosives from 17 countries so far, a United States expert said this week.

title: THE SHINING: THE MYSTERIOUS POWER OF THE NORTHERN LIGHTS
description: I was lolling in a pool of steaming Yukon mineral water one night this last August when the darkened interior of the bathhouse was suddenly suffused with a cold light. At first I thought it must be the headlights of a passing car shining through the windows, but my Alaskan friends, who were already pulling themselves out of the pool and heading for the door, knew better.

title: KOCH, MISS BELLAMY AND GOLDIN TRY MAKING UP
description: After engaging in feuds that they agree were excessively harsh and perhaps disruptive to municipal government, Mayor Koch, City Council President Carol Bellamy and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin say they are trying to mend their relationships.

title: Laurette Joy Siegle Is Bride Of Mark S. Kessler, Lawyer
description: Laurette Joy Siegle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Siegle of Wantagh, L.I., was married there yesterday to Mark Stuart Kessler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kessler of Altamonte Springs, Fla.

title: SMALL RISK FOR BIG GAINS
description: The United Nations resolved last week, by a vote of 111 to 1 with 35 abstentions, that all nuclear tests should be outlawed. The opposing vote was that of the United States, with Deputy Representative Kenneth L. Adelman repeating the ritual position of the Reagan Administration:

title:
ART;
WHAT THE ARTIST AND THE PRINTER WROUGHT TOGETHER
description: EAST ISLIP ''THE second half of the 20th century,'' Robert Rauschenberg once said, ''is no time to start drawing on rocks.'' But draw on rocks he did, and with remarkable results. His change of heart and the similar conversion of a host of other contemporary artists was effected by the late Tatyana Grosman, founder and guiding spirit of Universal Limited Art Editions, the Island's internationally acclaimed graphics workshop, celebrating its 25th anniversary this year.

title: THE 'RICHEST MAN' IN AUSTRALIA
description: LANGLEY GEORGE HANCOCK must have seen the documentary ''Dig a Million, Make a Million'' at least 100 times since it was made in the late 1960's. It stars a much younger, stockier Lang Hancock as himself, a tough talking Australian prospector; the late Tom Price, the right-hand man of the late industralist Henry Kaiser, as the prospector's American sidekick, and A.W. Clausen, then a Bank of America vice president, as the banker who helps the prospector and Kaiser Steel strike a deal to explore and mine the prospector's iron ore El Dorado in the Hamersley Range. The film ends happily with the prospector flying off into the Australian sunset.

title: THE GROWING INTEREST IN BACKING PROMISING NEW BUSINESS IDEAS
description: VENTURE CAPITAL. For the cautious investor, the words and the i ndustry are anathema. By and large, in order to get in to venture c apital you have to be rich, involved and patient. Luck also helps. S o why, in an age of increasing volatility, have private and i nstitutional investors, including pension funds, been stepping up t heir commitment to the industry?

title: Crete
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed the glass-roofed market described in ''Crete Under One Roof'' (Travel, Nov. 14).

title: ENTERPRISE ZONES FOCUS OF MEETING
description: NORWALK OFFICIALS from several states came to this coastal city last week to see how one community has joined in what some economists hope will be the catalyst for the economic rebirth of America's inner cities.

title: GIANTS DEFEAT EAGLES, 23-7
description: A week ago, Leon Bright could not play because of a badly sprained neck. Floyd Eddings did not play because third-string free-agent wide receivers do not always get into pro football games.

title: YONKER'S WAR OVER OTIS GATHERS FORCE
description: YONKERS AS bitter and frustrated as betrayed lovers, politicans in City Hall last week vowed reprisals against the United Technologies Corporation for deciding to close the historic Otis Elevator plant here and eliminate 375 jobs.

title: A NEW SENSE OF STYLE
description: After decades of looking dowdy and drab, newspapers are trying on a new wardrobe that promises to be slick, stylish and vividly colorful. Some of the fashions are easy to see - the use of color, for example, or the segregation of coverage into specific, identifiable sections for sports or life style or business news. Other changes, which readers may not even notice, include simplified typefaces, greater use of charts, graphs and drawings and a livelier makeup.

title: CONCERTS APLENTY, AND WITH VARIETY
description: HOLIDAY concerts are the rule at this time of year, but even for those who cannot bear the thought of hearing another hallelujah or looking at yet one more Sugar Plum fairy, good musical cheer abounds.

title:
GARDENING;
HERBS FOR A FRAGRANT HOLIDAY SEASON
description: SMELLS play an important role in our lives. We object when a neighbor creates a smelly nuisance next door or when a community proposes that an incinerator or landfill be located next to our homes. Yet we are fascinated when a member of the opposite sex wears an exotic new perfume or cologne.

title: CLIMATE SHIFT OFF PERU TIED TO ERUPTION IN MEXICO
description: Sulfur compounds thrown into the sky by the eruption of a Mexican volcano last spring are possibly responsible for the reappearance of the sometimes devastating aberration of climate known as El Nino.

title: UNGUIDED MISSLE
description: When a President of the United States is denied a nuclear weapons system that he says is vital to both national security and effective arms control, he loses a sizable measure of his authority, abroad and at home. That is why it had never happened until the House of Representatives blocked the MX last week. That is also why Ronald Reagan's considered reaction in the weeks to come will leave a profound mark on his Presidency.

title: American Academy Elects 5 to Its Board
description: Five new members have been elected to the board of trustees of the 77-year-old American Academy in Rome, a residential community of American artists and scholars.

title: THE CHURCH SEEKS A WAY OUT FOR ARGENTINA
description: Argentina, wracked by the ghosts of the disappeared and struggling to find a way to end military rule, has turned for salvation to its most revered institution - the Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE DRUMMER TO BEAT
description: Buddy Rich, who is not just a jazz drummer but THE jazz drummer, will bring his band to West Orange next Sunday night for a concert at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. The peformance also features Steve Marcus on tenor saxophone and Andy Fusco on alto saxophone.

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE FOREIGN SERVICE
description: Somewhere in the annals of American diplomacy, it is recorded that one of our early Presidents once remarked to his Secretary of State that since he had heard nothing from his Minister to Spain for over a year, he assumed that our relations with the country must be on an even keel and that the Minister was, therefore, doing a good job. Those were the halcyon days of diplomacy, when an ambassador relied on the clipper ship for delivery of his instructions - and when, before the advent of the jet and electronic ages, Presidents and their Secretaries of State relied on the judgment and abilities of their envoys in defending the national interest abroad.

title: 'PIRATE' VESSEL SETS OFF A HUNT FOR BOOTY
description: Treasure hunters say they have located the pirate ship Whidah, wrecked in a storm in 1717, purportedly carrying a fortune in gold, silver, ivory and jewels. Salvage operations are due to begin next spring.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in the Sunday Business section incorrectly stated the growth of Japan's gross national product. It grew by 2.7 percent in 1981.

title: FOLK: PRISCILLA HERDMAN
description: Priscilla Herdman, one of the clearest and most compelling voices of contemporary folk music, has carved herself a niche by discovering and bringing to North America some of the best folk music from Australia and New Zealand. Miss Herdman has set to music and recorded verses by the Australian folk poet Henry Lawson on a record album called ''The Water Lily.''

title: URGES SENATE VOTE ON NOMINATION
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz intervened publicly today in an effort to persuade Senate leaders in Washington to override the opposition of some conservative Republicans and approve the nomination of Richard Burt as Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs.

title: HARD TIMES FEEDING UNREST IN CHILE
description: When the bank foreclosed on Emilio Naulin and called an auction to sell his wheat farm in November, a group of angry farmers from this key agricultural region in southern Chile showed up to discourage bids. Regional banks called off any more foreclosures.

title: Conviction in Child's Death
description: Kenneth Sealy, 23, who said his religious beliefs prevented him from bringing his 11-day-old baby girl to a doctor, was convicted Friday of manslaughter in her death. He was freed on $5,000 bond, pending sentencing Jan. 6. The baby, Carie, died March 11 of pneumonia, jaundice and dehydration.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: GREENPOINT
description: ON a Sunday morning in Greenpoint, the streets are empty but the c hurches are full. The dozen or so local churches, which sponsor d ances, bingo games and annual Easter and Christmas parades, are an i mportant element in the life of this quiet, predominantly w orkingclass community of 67,000 on the northern end of Brooklyn.

title: 76ers 128, Pistons 111
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Julius Erving scored a season-high 44 points as Philadelphia posted its 19th straight over Detroit at the Spectrum, where the Pistons last won on Nov. 2, 1974.

title: KODALY WAS MORE THAN A COMPOSER
description: Zoltan Kodaly, the Hungarian composer who died at the age of 84 in 1967, would have been 100 years old this Thursday. A number of New York musical organizations have marked this anniversary by programming Kodaly works. Among them is the New York Philharmonic, which will present his ''Peacock'' Variations and the Suite from his opera ''Hary Janos'' on its subscription concerts this week, starting Thursday in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Two Seized in Robbery Of an IRT Token Clerk
description: Two men robbed a subway token-booth clerk in upper Manhattan of nearly $2,000 when they caught her outside of a booth emptying turnstiles yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Frost Etchings Are Offered
description: NOT long ago, an appreciation of what constitutes a truly valuable rod, gun, knife, decoy, sporting book or painting of yesteryear was restricted to a knowledgeable few, but that has changed.

title: FORGET THE ECONOMY, STOCKS AND BONDS ARE BUYS
description: QUESTION: What investment environment are we likely to encounter next year? What are the big dangers?

title:
DINING OUT;
THE LURE OF NEWARK'S IRONBOUND
description: THE Ironbound section of Newark is a mecca for admirers of the ample, moderately priced fare and easygoing atmosphere of its Spanish cum Portuguese restaurants. Tucked in a corner there, amidst the neat row houses, is Tony DaCaneca, a neighborhood restaurant and tavern that has been dispensing satisfying mariscada, shrimp al ajilo and the like for almost 12 years.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: A GIFT of wisdom is always welcome - and nourishing and lasting, too - and it's abundantly available in a variety of books by New Jersey authors or about the state.

title: For Security Or Secrecy?
description: Defense Department officials last week disclosed a plan to administer lie-detector tests to thousands of randomly selected military and civilian personnel. But the truth about why they want to do it was elusive.

title: Benazir Bhutto Detention Extended by 90 Days
description: Pakistan's military authorities have extended for 90 more days the detention order on Benazir Bhutto, the daughter of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, family sources said today.

title:
ART;
NEW BAUHAUS PHOTOGRAPHY
description: TO those unfamiliar with the full history of the Bauhaus, the New Bauhaus might seem like a contradiction. The original Bauhaus, founded in Germany by Walter Gropius in 1919, was conceived as the ultimate in newness, in fresh thinking about designs for living. However, in 1937, Lazlo Moholy-Nagy, who was a teacher at the Bauhaus, relocated in Chicago where he established the New Bauhaus: American School of Design. Soon thereafter it became simply the Institute of Design.

title: TO VIENNA AND BACK VIA THE THEATER
description: FOR romanticists, Vienna may be the city of one's dreams. For Ruth Brinkmann, it's been the fulfillment of them. Twenty-three years ago, she went on a European holiday with her parents that ended with a three-day stopover in Vienna. The parents returned to their home in Kings Point. Miss Brinkmann, then an aspiring actress, didn't.

title: Imposing Lawyer
description: With a shrug and a sigh, Leon Jaworski told the Supreme Court what his able legal staff needed volumes to say. Asked from the bench in July 1974, about Richard Nixon's objections to any lawsuit against a President, Mr. Jaworski scarcely contained his anger before matterof-factly dismantling the White House's stone wall.

title: SCRAPBOOK TELLS OF VILLAGE HISTORY
description: STONY CREEK A NEW book that has captured the attention of Stony Creekers is not on the list of best-sellers and never will be. But as the book is about their favorite subject - themselves and their community - hundreds of copies were sold before it was even published.

title: DEAR WASHINGTON: I THINK...
description: WASHINGTON ''IT is with complete amazement that I am writing to disagree with the President's proposal to tax unemployment benefits. Those people must be in Disney World to believe that the people on unemployment lines are doing this because they want to.''

title: 6 MORE YEARS OF REAGAN?
description: The campaign for a second Reagan term in the White House has already started, so don't say you weren't warned. Lyn Nofziger, who helped give us Mr. Reagan the first time, has taken it upon himself, without the President's permission, to organize sort of an informal committee of conservative truebelievers to get ready for a second try.

title: Cost of Addiction
description: Two months after he completed a 30-day treatment at a California rehabilitation center for chemical dependence, Tim Raines of the Montreal Expos yesterday revealed the extent of his addiction to cocaine in a story in The Montreal Gazette. The left fielder was quoted as having said that he used more than $40,000 worth of the drug in the first nine months of 1982, taking it in the Expos' clubhouse between innings and before games in the Olympic Stadium parking lot.

title: CITY HOUSING OFFICALS CRITICIZE RATINGS
description: THREE public-housing authorities in New Jersey are on the verge of meeting the standard of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development for fiscal well-being, but Federal officials and local public-housing administrators disagree about whether the standard is fair.

title: DANCE: JOSE LIMON TROUPE PERFORMS 'UNSUNG'
description: Much of the new, second program presented by the Jose Limon Dance Company Tuesday in the Joyce Theater had been performed in bits and pieces last week at the company's gala. Happily, the dances looked a good deal better when seen in their entirety. And the performance of Limon's ''The Unsung'' suggested that there are some promising male performers in the current crop of Limon dancers.

title: 18th Gorilla Is Born at Zoo
description: The Cincinnati Zoo has increased its world record for gorillas born in captivity. A gorilla born Monday night was the 18th born at the zoo and the 16th to survive, a spokesman for the zoo said.
