title: PASTRY CUPS: A DELICATE MOLD
description: One of the most delicate, elegant and yet easily made of French pastries is something known in the pastry chef's kitchen as tulipes. They are fragile, brittle, wafer-thin ''cups'' into which a multitude of good things go. The fillings may consist of one or more scoops of sherbet or ice cream, either a single flavor or several; a fine layer of irresistible pastry cream topped with fresh fruits or berries and perhaps a dusting of confectioners' sugar, and so on.

title: 20 Food Places Listed by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department cited 20 food establishments last week for violation of the city's health code. The department also said six establishments had reopened after correcting earlier violations. VIOLATIONS Margie D's Pub, 167 Bleecker St. Spring Street Bar, 401 W. Broadway Pine Tree Restaurant, 4139 Boston Rd., Bronx El Toro Bravo, 1214 Jerome Ave., Bronx The Allegro, 2212 White Plains Rd., Bronx Norma's Bar, 215 E. 167th St., Bronx Hong Kong Kitchen, 1845 Eastern Pkwy., Brooklyn Christian Brothers & Sisters, 743 Franklin Ave., Brooklyn Best Pizzeria, 811 Grand Ave., Brooklyn Conca Doro Cafe, 274 Knickerbocker Ave., Brooklyn Glory Food Shop, 727 Nostrand Ave., Brooklyn Bagels, 52 7th Ave., Brooklyn Caravan Bar, 94-10 Astoria Blvd., Queens Snack Bar, IND Union Turnpike Subway Station, concourse level, Queens Galaxy Restaurant, 29-38 Northern Blvd, Queens Dunkin Donuts, 42-02 Northern Blvd., Queens Desambiar Stationery, 144-03 Northern Blvd., Queens New Mughal Restaurant, 65-12 Roosevelt Ave., Queens Golden Unicorn Ice Cream Store, 103-04 Roosevelt Ave., Queens Four O'Clock Lounge, 751 Forest Ave., Staten Island REOPENED Laguna Pizza, 132 E. 14th St. Dong Deli, 12 W. 32d St. Tara & Keith Lounge, 133 Kingston Ave., Brooklyn Lung Zheng Chinese Kitchen, 977 Fulton St., Brooklyn Fantasy II, 30-02 30th Ave., Queens Pepino's Restaurant, 2879 Amboy Rd., Staten Island

title: THE BANKS FIGHT BACK
description: The Banks Fight Back

title: THE EFFECT ON TAX BENEFITS
description: FOR about 12 years, Dr. Fred Wissner, a clinical psychologist, has u sed a converted first-floor one-bedroom apartment at 15 West 72d S treet as an office. Two years ago, when the building was converted i nto a cooperative, he was told that he could buy it, but for $ 14,000 more than what a similar residential unit in the building c ost. Then he was told he could not buy at all.

title: A RETAILER THAT'S LEADING THE WAY
description: AN ancient Buddhist robe drapes one wall in the better sportswear department; an 18th-century French bedspread highlights the latest shoes. Where the bargain basement used to be, there is ''The Club,'' a men's wear department featuring Ralph Lauren and Giorgio Armani. And in the children's department, the star attraction - Santa Claus is only a seasonal visitor - is an animated baby elephant, ears mechanically flapping, trunk hopefully lowered for peanuts.

title: 100 TUBAS TO SOUND IN TRIBUTE TO SEASON
description: NEW HAVEN SOUNDS of oom-pahs will bellow through New Haven on Saturday, when 100 tuba players are expected to gather for the city's third annual Tubalation on the New Haven green.

title: Winslow Tuttle Weds Elizabeth H. Freedland
description: Elizabeth Hazzard Freedland, daughter of Mrs. William Wigg Hazzard Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., and the late Mr. Hazzard, was married yesterday to Winslow Guertin Tuttle, son of Mrs. Edward E. Bartlett of Palm Beach, Fla., and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Tuttle. Retired Justice Archibald Tunick of the Connecticut Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: SURVEY SAYS RECESSION FORCES CUTS AND LAYOFFS IN 25 STATES
description: A survey of 25 states indicates that the recession has forced them to cut services, lay off employees and undertake other cost-saving measures in the last six months, the National Governors Association reports.

title: WILLIAM STYRON ON HIS LIFE AND WORK
description: AS he struggles to write his first novel, Stingo, the young hero of ''Sophie's Choice,'' dreams of becoming ''a writer - a writer with the same ardor and the soaring wings of the Melville or the Flaubert or the Tolstoy or the Fitzgerald who had the power to rip my heart out and keep a part of it and who each night, separately and together, were summoning me to their incomparable vocation.'' Stingo, of course, is an autobiographical version of his creator - a portrait of the author as a young man, innocent of history and hungry for artistry and fame - and, at 57, William Styron himself has now spent some three decades working at that vocation.

title: Suicide's Other Victims
description: ''Suicide's Other Victims'' (Nov. 14), Lisa Bergson wrote well about the kaleidoscope of emotions that rages through your heart when someone you love dies in this way. She also dealt with the excellent help now available from groups such as Compassionate Friends.

title: Margaret S. Solinger Is Married to an Actor
description: Margaret Smith Solinger, a lawyer with the U.S. Customs Service in New York, and Daniel-Jay Pinto, an actor, were married yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Seamus Quinn.

title: Cambodian Shell Kills Thai
description: A Thai woman was killed and her husband was seriously injured Friday when a stray mortar shell hit a Thai border village during fighting in Cambodia, a Thai military officer said today.

title: To the Contrary, About Adult Education
description: We were dismayed to read John Chervokas's unwarranted indictment of adult education in Westchester (''A Reconsidered Look at Adult Education,'' Opinion Page, Nov. 7). Lest readers be left with the wrong impression, we know the county's many adult-education programs and none deserves the superficial remarks that appeared.

title: A PLAN THAT APPEARS TO WORK
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE garden-apartment complex about a mile from the downtown area here looks like countless other such developments: five ordinary buildings in an ordinary setting (150 apartments altogether).

title:
DINING OUT;
TWO VERY DIFFERENT PLACES IN ONE
description: THIS sprawling roadside restaurant has been a convenient and popular traveler's landmark since its inception more than 40 years ago when Bill Reiber opened its doors. During the 1930's and 40's, it was one of the popular watering holes for the political shakers plying their way between Albany and New York. After Bill Reiber's death, the restaurant continued as Tale of the Fox until it closed suddenly and eerily on New Year's Eve about four years ago, leaving coffee in cups, cloths on tables, ashtrays full. John Antun and Vincent Cagnetta swept up the confetti and streamers, trashed the horns, renovated, decorated and opened Razzberry just one year ago. Its proximity to the Saw Mill River Parkway and Routes 87 and 287 make it worth knowing about.

title: WHEN A PRELATE TAUNTS A PRESIDENT, WHAT'S NEXT?
description: The era of critical collaboration between the Roman Catholic Church and the Philippine Government is threatened with extinction. ''It seems to be more critical than collaboration,'' admits Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, who created the concept and is trying to save it through military-church ''dialogues.''

title:
GARDENING;
HERBS FOR A FRAGRANT HOLIDAY SEASON
description: SMELLS play an important role in our lives. We object when a neighbor creates a smelly nuisance next door or when a community proposes that an incinerator or landfill be located next to our homes. Yet we are fascinated when a member of the opposite sex wears an exotic new perfume or cologne.

title: Constance N. Ringgold Wed to Lawyer
description: Constance Niki Ringgold, daughter of Mrs. James Richard Ringgold of New York and Athens and the late Mr. Ringgold, was married in Zermatt, Switzerland, yesterday to Peter Anthony Williamson, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Schenck Williamson of Sayville, L.I. The Rev. Norbert Lutz performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Anglican Church.

title: Audrey Kelley Roos, a Writer Of Mystery Novels and Plays
description: Audrey Kelley Roos, a mystery writer and playwright, died yesterday of cancer on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. She was 70 years old and lived in Edgartown, on Martha's Vineyard.

title: THE TALK AT ELAINE'S
description: A friend took me to Elaine's, a restaurant-bar on the Upper East Side that rivals the PEN Club in the number of famous authors it attracts. It seemed to me that everybody was there, from Czeslaw Milosz to Judith Krantz. The table next to ours was crowded with National Book Award, American Book Award and National Book Critics Circle Award winners. I tried to hear what they were saying, but they were all talking at once. Nor could I read their lips, because it's hard to read the lips of people talking with their mouths full.

title: A Prolife Victory, 11,000 to Zero
description: The article on the effects of the abortion issue on the Westchester political races (''Races Said to Turn on Abortion,'' Nov. 21), presented only the proabortion version of the results. Not only did it not include the prolife side of the story, it did not even present factual vote totals, the only true measure of an effect on any political outcome. In that regard, Right-to-Life had a banner year in Westchester and the proabortion side was, in a word, ''creamed.''

title: BLACK CHURCHES FORGING COALITION TO BATTLE ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL ILLS
description: Striving to relieve worsening social problems, the country's large black churches have taken steps to forge a united front. Leaders of these churches believe this is the first effort by blacks for a national church drive to combat economic, social and political ills. They seek to build a movement based on the largest institution among blacks, a network of 65,000 churches and 20 million Christians.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Nuclear Freeze Frame

title: FOR STANFORD ARTS, A NEW HOME RISES
description: ''WE hope this will be a turning point in the city's cultural life,'' said Randy Brion, head of development of the new Stamford Center for the Arts, ''and serve notice to everyone about the vitality of our community.''

title: Angeline Griffing Wolf and E.G. Ortel to Be Married
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Stewart G. Wolf of Bangor, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Angeline Griffing Wolf, to Erik Gueiros Ortel, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C.G. Ortel of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: SUFFOLK AND LILCO SPAR OVER EVACUATION
description: IN the last 10 days, some of the best-read volumes on the Island have been the thick looseleaf notebooks that have become the ammunition in one of the last and most important clashes over the Long Island Lighting Company's 809-megawatt Shoreham nuclear power station.

title: SENDING THE SURPLUSES BACK HOME
description: For the past fifty years, ever since President Roosevelt began paying farmers to stop producing, the Government has been looking for a cheap way to get rid of the costly grain and cotton surpluses it acquires with discouraging frequency in years of good weather and poor markets. Last week, the Reagan Administration proposed a new wrinkle on the old New Deal pattern - give the surplus wheat, corn, cotton and rice back to the farmers who created it in the first place, if they agree not to plant up to half of their land.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC ABC has emerged as the leader of a phalanx of new English pop-rock bands whose principal subject is romance. Martin Fry, the quartet's lead vocalist, is a clean-cut matinee idol type whose cleverly worded declarations of amorous intent are framed, on record at least, by a full orchestra and billowing pop-soul arrangements.

title: Feldstein Gives The News, Such As It Is, in Person
description: Those waiting for recovery from recession got little cheer from Martin S. Feldstein, confirmed last week as chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers in exchange for a trip to Capitol Hill and testimony on the economy's sorry state. (Partly to register their differences with the Administration and partly out of interbranch irritation, Senate Democrats had balked at voting confirmation until Mr. Feldstein came on over, which he'd been refusing to do because, he said, he was too busy and anyway, hadn't been confirmed.)

title: No Headline
description: VILLANOVA IS UPSET BY PENN, 84-80, IN BIG FIVE

title: SUICIDES BY YOUNG WORRY TOWNSFOLK
description: BETHEL A SHAFT of misty morning sunlight slices through the canopy of centuries-old maple trees along Greenwood Avenue, the main street of this quiet, residential community a few miles south of Danbury. From the doorway of Eileen's Diner, not far from the railroad station, comes the pungent aroma of breakfast eggs on the grill. Nearby, teenage boys chase a football across a grassy field.

title: OLD SAYBROOK AIDS NEIGHBOR
description: the dog pound.

title: Coast Train
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest the article about ''The Coast Starlight'' train ride from Los Angeles to San Francisco (Travel, Nov. 14).

title: THE NEW WILD WEST
description: TRUE LOVE By Herbert Gold. 214 pp. New York: Arbor House. $14.25. By PETER ANDREWS

title: THE SPIRIT OF STREET DANCE PERVADES 'STACK-UP'
description: Walking past Lincoln Center recently one night after a performance, music and dance lovers were treated to another dance performance, on the sidewalk. A group of young men had placed their giant cassetterecorder on one of the tree-pots outside Alice Tully Hall. A thin mat was spread on the ground. It was clear this was as carefully planned a display as the programs that the passers-by had just witnessed inside the theaters.

title: OPTIONS LURE EVEN THE TIMID
description: SPECULATORS TRADE put and call options in hopes of turning a quick profit, but options are also versatile tools that offer conservative investors a way to increase income while holding onto their stocks.

title: TAKING A WIFE IN SOUTHERN FRANCE
description: LOVE, DEATH AND MONEY IN THE PAYS D'OC By Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie. Translated by Alan Sheridan. 597 pp. New York: George Braziller. $30.

title: MANAGUA'S ARCHBISHOP IS NOT A 'CONSERVATIVE'
description: To the Editor:

title: BONN IS FEARFUL OF BULGARIA TIE WITH TERRORISTS
description: West German officials say that in the aftermath of allegations of Bulgarian involvement in the shooting of Pope John Paul II, they have become increasingly concerned about possible Bulgarian involvement in subversive activities, including drug smuggling and terrorism.

title: NEW TROUBLE SEEN FOR HEART PATIENT
description: While Dr. Barney B. Clark's natural organs and his artificial heart were working almost perfectly, his doctors expressed concern today that psychological reactions seemed to be significantly delaying his recovery.

title: WHAT'S NEXT FOR RUPPERT RENEWAL
description: ALTHOUGH the Board of Estimate has given final city permission for Y orkville Gardens, a 131-unit apartment project for the elderly on t he site of the old Ruppert Brewery on the Upper East Side, a suit b y a community group could force a renewal of the whole tortuous l and-review process.

title: REAGAN SAYS BASING SYSTEM FOR MX IS NOT AN ISSUE
description: President Reagan today disavowed any intent to make an issue of his MX missile-basing plan as he warned that Senate rejection of production funds for the missile would weaken the chance for peace.

title: FOR THE CHILDREN DURING THE HOLIDAYS
description: AS the holiday season approaches, parents are wondering, ''What are we going to do with the children during Christmas vacation?'' On Dec. 26, when hundreds of county children join in a chorus of ''What am I going to do? I'm bored!'' families may want to choose from some of the following activities:

title: LIVING IN A LANDMARK: THE PRESERVATION STRUGGLE GOES ON
description: OYSTER BAY DRIPPING with fish-scale shingles, dentils and elaborate plaques, the Adam-Derby House stands poised on a small patch of land. Its original five-acre setting is crowded with condominiums. As the scene indicates, the house, built in 1878, has so far survived modern encroachments. But the fight to preserve it continues even as its new owners begin living in the landmark.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: A New Look At School Busing
description: For its first recommendation of a specific replacement for school busing, the Justice Department last week chose East Baton Rouge, La., a desegregation case dating back to 1955 and one of the oldest in the country.

title: TOWN AND PASTOR ARE ANGERED FOES
description: ''Visit Louisville'' is the message on a big orange and blue sign erected at the south edge of town by proud citizens to trumpet the high school basketball team's 1977 state championship.

title: MORE N.F.L. SUSPENSIONS NEEDED
description: WHEN the Jets run onto the field at Shea Stadium for their game with the Tampa Bay Bucs today, Stan Blinka won't be among them. The middle linebacker will be doing time, National Football League time - a one-game suspension by Commissioner Pete Rozelle for having leveled John Jefferson, the Green Bay Packers' wide receiver, with a measured, malevolent forearm two weeks ago.

title: Cup Downhill Skiing Is Canceled by Blizzard
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 11 -(AP) - The men's World Cup downhill ski race was canceled today after being postponed for three straight days because of a blizzard.

title: AN INVITING SETTING IN CHESTER
description: CHESTER WHEN you dine out, which comes first -the setting or the food? Setting may not be everything, but it certainly is the outstanding feature at the Chart House in Chester, which is one of three in the state with the same name and ownership. They are part of a 52-restaurant chain. (Others in Connecticut are in New Haven and Simsbury.)

title:
GARDENING;
HERBS FOR A FRAGRANT SEASON
description: SMELLS play an important role in our lives. We object when a neighbor creates a smelly nuisance next door or when a community proposes that an incinerator or landfill be located next to our homes. Yet we are fascinated when a member of the opposite sex wears an exotic new perfume or cologne.

title: Suzanne Heggie To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Heggie of Lexington, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Katherine Heggie, to Robert William Werner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic P. Werner of West Hartford, Conn.

title: A SWAP WORKS ON CONDOMINIUMS
description: Albert J. Falloni, former president of the North Shore Council of Homeowners, well remembers how angry much of the Bay Terrace community in Queens was a decade ago about the proposed construction of two 21-story condominium towers there. By right, the developers were entitled to towers of 14 and 17 stories, according to Wilma Jitney of Community Board 7, but they wanted more.

title: Ann Derry Engaged To C.A. Thompson
description: Mr. and Mrs. William D. Derry of San Marino, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Marie Derry, to Cameron Acheson Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Thompson of New York.

title: New Act at Apollo
description: A new role was envisioned last May for Harlem's Apollo Theater, where such stars as Count Basie, Ella Fitzgerald and Duke Ellington got their start. Percy E. Sutton, chairman of the Inner City Broadcasting Company, the theater's operator, said more than $5 million would be spent to convert the Apollo into a cable TV studio.

title: Why No Outcry Over Stingley?
description: To the Sports Editor: Stanley Cohen was right on the mark in his article (''Why Boxing Needs to Be Reformed, Not Abolished'', The New York Times, Dec. 5).

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A convenience store chain reached an outof-court settlement Friday with attorneys for a 4-year-old boy who was severely burned by gasoline purchased in an illegal plastic container. The settlement could amount to $15 million.

title: AUTO UNION'S LEADERS OVERWHELMINGLY ENDORSE CHRYSLER PACT
description: Union leaders voted nearly unanimously today to accept a new one-year contract with the Chrysler Corporation that provides an immediate pay increase. The next step is a ratification vote Friday by members of the United Automobile Workers.

title: Recent Sales
description: Clifton $82,000 1 Tyler Court *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old Cape Cod; *2*finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,200. Edison $63,900 129 Highland Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; *2*two-car detached garage; taxes $993. Fair Haven $109,000 332 River Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath ''older'' colonial; *2*new gourmet kitchen, skylight, fireplace, front proch; taxes $5,400. Neptune $86,000 324 Lakewood Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; *2*new wet bar in basement; patio; taxes not available. North Haledon $155,000 6 Saw Mill Road *2*6-bedrooms, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old ranch; *2*septic system, 2-car garage, 1.5 acre; taxes $3,911. Ocean Township $80,000 37 Oak Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old ranch; *2*wall-to-wall carpeting, fireplace; taxes $1,901. OTHER AREAS St. James, L.I. $96,800 41 Hobson Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, twobedroom cottage; taxes $1,986. Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. $105,000 64 Bellair Drive *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old stucco/ brick ranch, *2*flagstone patio, wrap-around proch; taxes $2,445. Litchfield, Conn. $150,000 Old South Road *2*5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 1736 gambrel colonial; *2*4 fireplaces, original chestnut floors, mantels *2*and inlaid paneling; 1.4 acres; taxes $2,433.

title: TALES TO INSPIRE THE YOUNG GARDENER
A BOUNTIFUL YEAR FOR TREES
description: SHELTON MORE often than not, the setting at the sprawling Jones Tree Farm in early December has resembled that of a Currier and Ives painting - rolling, snow-covered hills dotted with thousands of evergreen trees.

title: A FRIEND'S ADVICE ON TAKING A TRIP
description: HERBERT J. TEISON of Dobb's Ferry, publisher of two travel newsletters, once thought he might start a club called ''The 7:15 Dropouts.'' This would consist of people who, as he did, stopped commuting to New York City and instead established home-based businesses. He believes those numbers are increasing in the county.

title: WEST COAST ORIGIN TIED TO FRAGMENTS
description: Virtually all of North America west of a line following the California-Nevada border and through Idaho into Canada is alien terrain, formed of former islands, submarine platforms and continental fragments swept up as this continent pushed westward over the floor of the Pacific Ocean, according to findings being reported here by a number of geologists.

title: NOT OVERBLOWN
description: Top The Business Editor: Barbara Bergmann asserts that if we view the problem in terms of resource flows, rather than financial solvency of an isolated Federal account, all of Social Security's problems disappear. ''We can afford to be more generous'' and can fund the system out of our general revenues, she wrote, and added, ''The bread our retired citizens eat this week was baked this week by younger citizens.''

title: WIDENING OF RIGHTS OF NURSES WEIGHED
description: REGISTERED nurses in New Jersey, who last summer gained legal sanction to make pronouncements of death, soon may be filling out and signing death certificates as well.

title: THE CROWD PLEASING YOUNG MARKETS IN STOCK INDEX FUTURES
description: THE DIFFERENCES between buying stocks and gambling, which were never altogether clear to some investors, have been blurred still further by the introduction of futures contracts on stock indexes. And based on the reception these new futures have received, there is no shortage of people who want to bet on the market.

title: CHARGERS TRIUMPH OVER 49ERS, 41-37
description: Quarterbacks Dan Fouts of the San Diego Chargers and Joe Montana of the San Francisco 49ers passed for more than 800 yards today in a wild and entertaining game that the Chargers won, 41-37.

title: 7 KILLED IN A 5TH DAY OF FIGHTING IN LEBANESE CITY
description: Fighting between rival Moslem militia groups left at least seven people dead in this northern port city today, authorities said.

title: CULTURE THRIVES ON CAMDEN CAMPUS
description: CAMDEN THE local newspaper advertisements said simply: ''The Mozart Orchestra. Performance of works by Mozart and Haydn. Rutgers-Camden Theater, Fourth and Linden Streets, Camden. Tue. noon. Free.''

title: IS IT TIME TO UNITE THE UNIONS?
description: Changes in production and newsroom technologies, along with some well-publicized failures of big-city dailies, have created a pressure on newspaper unions to reconsider what their role will be in coming decades.

title: Ellen E. O'Connell And Lawyer Plan February Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. John Daniel O'Connell of West Hartford and Madison, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Ellen Egan O'Connell, to George Scott McGuirk, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. McGuirk of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 11 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 5 5 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Continuing the journey through the solar system begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 3 7 16 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 4 3 9 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction, sequel to ''The Foundation Trilogy.'' 5 4 15 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 6 6 15 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 7 2 5 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 8 10 19 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE FAILURES OF A CHAIR-BOUND SCIENCE
description: THE economy is in sad shape these days, and so is the reputation of t he science of economics. The bad advice of some economists has been i nstrumental in getting us into trouble and keeping us mired there. T he failure of economists to come up with convincing solutions to thee conomy's travails has become obvious to the politicians, the b usiness community, the general public and those academic economists w ho retain their common sense.

title: Mary Vann Odom To Be Wed May 14
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Samuel S. Odom of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Vann Odom, to Michael Westcott Brown, son of Mrs. J. Stuart Brown 3d of St. Simons Island, Ga., and Frederick H. Jones of Sewickley, Pa.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: WORTH THE PAPER IT'S WRITTEN ON
description: 1. Massimo Vignelli's horizontal format letterhead. 2. Mary Ann Rumney's stationery and second sheet for Hambrecht Terrell International. 3. A bilingual letterhead for the American Academy in Rome by George Sadek, director of the Design Center at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art. 4. An invoice designed for the photographer Susan Wood by Chermayeff & Geismar Associates. 5. Social paper by Pentagram features an illustration of the client's home by the Canadian artist Donna Brown. 6. Deckle-edged letterhead by Massimo Vignelli for the Chicago architect Bruce J. Graham. 7. A house correspondence card by Dempsey & Carroll. 8. Crested note paper by Dempsey & Carroll. 9. Massimo Vignelli's elongated social sheet monogrammed on heavy cover stock. 10. Tiffany's dark-brown social paper for the New York executive William Fine. 11 and 12. Two papers by Milton Glaser for the artist Jean Michel Folon: one on lightweight stock for his boat, The Blue Shadow (11), and the other tailored to the artist's slanted handwriting (12). 13. Monogrammed note paper by Dempsey & Carroll. 14. A blue country-house envelope designed by Cecil Beaton for William Fine and printed by Walton Street Stationers, London.

title: CHILD-CARE TIPS FOR UNWED
description: GLEN COVE THE day-care room at the Lincoln House, with toddler-size table and chairs and several down-at-the-heels stuffed animals, seems comforting - in contrast to the plight of the women, some with their children, who are meeting here at night.

title: HIGH RISK AND ITS REWARDS
description: Over the years, you pored over the charts and tables, weighed price/earnings ratios, listened to endless advice and chose your stocks. They are solid, if perhaps unspectacular, and you are happy. Suddenly, however, the carefully acquired portfolio is in the midst of the merger game, plunging you into another world: arbitrage.

title: TEAMSTER TRIAL GOES TO THE JURY
description: Jury deliberations began today in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and four teamster-related co-defendants.

title: WHERE HAS ALL THE BUSINESS GONE?
description: THE DEINDUSTRIALIZATION OF AMERICA Plant Closings, Community Abandonment, and the Dismantling of Basic Industry. By Barry Bluestone and Bennett Harrison. 323 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: The U.S.O. at Kennedy
description: The U.S.O. center at Kennedy International Airport offers information and referral services, travel guidance, light refreshments and a complete nursery for the thousands of service men and women and their families who use the airport each year going to stations around the country and overseas.

title: L.I. Schoolgirl Wins Title
description: Chris Curtin of Bellmore, L.I., and Eric Reynolds of Somis, Calif., were winners today in the Kinney national cross-country championships for high school students.

title: SUSPENSION IS FAIR, BLINKA OF JETS SAYS
description: Stan Blinka, who will sit out today's Jets' game against Tampa Bay as only the second player in National Football League history suspended for a foul, said yesterday that Commissioner Pete Rozelle's decision was ''fair.''

title: Paternity Battle
description: Women working for the National Broadcasting Company were eligible for six months of maternity leave with job and seniority guarantees. But when Robert A. Batsche, an NBC engineer in New York, asked for a paternity leave, he said the company told him he could go, but it couldn't guarantee his job or seniority rights.

title: CIRCLING PUERTO RICO BY CAR
description: MORTON N. COHEN, the editor of ''The Letters of Lewis Carroll'' (two volumes), lives part of the year in Puerto Rico.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
FOR MOM, IT'S NOW OR NEVER
description: MY dog is not allowed outside the house without a leash, and when we sit on our patio, that leash is tethered on our lawn. At first, the dog pulled at the tether, straining to overcome the limits of its boundaries. Now, she knows its range, and plays happily within the space it allows her. In fact, she feels insecure outside without her leash, and waits at the open door until we attach it to her collar.

title: A U.S. COURT RULING MAY HELP HAITIANS
description: Lawyers for some of the Haitian ''boat people'' fighting to remain in the United States say that a recent decision by a Federal judge in Brooklyn could aid the efforts of hundreds of the refugees scattered across the country.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WHAT do you do when there's nothing to do, you have had an at least trying week in the city, it's your day off on the Island and you don't want to do anything, and everywhere you go at home you keep meeting yourself coming through doors and around corners? And, most important, you are dedicatedly lazy?

title:
CAMERA;
HOLIDAY PHOTOGRAPHS
description: During the December holidays there are always lots of photographic possibilities because of the many parties, family visits and holiday festivities in general. There are also multiple opportunities for picture-taking around the Christmas tree and at gift-giving time.

title: WINFIELD IS PLEASED BY DEALS TO BOLSTER YANKEE OFFENSE
description: Dave Winfield, watching the George Steinbrenner free-agent show from the nearby island of Maui, recalled with no fondness his days in San Diego.

title: Mary R. Rogers Is Married
description: Mary Regina Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Rogers of Sarasota, Fla., and Rock Island, Ill., was married yesterday in New York to Christopher Sean Flanagan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Flanagan of New York. The Rev. Paul Walsh performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church.

title: RETIREMENT: AN I.R.A. IS ONLY THE BEGINNING
description: WHILE INFLATION and interest rates have recently abated, their breakneck rise over the last several years has made many people cynical about investing for retirement. When projections show that even the average couple will need a nest egg of $1 million or so over the next several decades just to eke out a modest existence, the magnitude of the numbers becomes so staggering that it can sap the will to save.

title: Article 092418 -- No Title
description: New York University, the nation's biggest private university, has received the largest amount ever contributed to the university during a single year in its 150-year history, Dr. John Brademas, N.Y.U.'s president, has announced.

title: IN NEW YORK CITY, BERENICE ABBOTT FOUND HER BEST SUBJECT
description: For Berenice Abbott, at age 84 one of our greatest living photographers, 1982 has been a crowning year. It began with an exhibition at the International Center of Photography, which subsequently traveled to the National Museum of American Art in Washington, D.C., and it is ending with a retrospective show at the Witkin Gallery (41 East 57th Street, through Jan. 15), accompanied by a freshly minted monograph written by Hank O'Neal (''Berenice Abbott: American Photographer,'' McGraw-Hill, $59.95).

title: MAINTAINING HIGH STANDARDS
description: WHEN La Veranda opened in Glen Cove a little more than two years ago, it quickly acquired a well-deserved reputation as one of the better restaurants in the area. It is now a pleasure to report that the high standards of service and consistently fine preparation observed in the early months of La Veranda's operation have been maintained. If the overall impression is somewhat shy of three stars, the potential for such a rating certainly exists.

title: SOME COMMUNITIES SEEK RELIEF FROM COMMERCIAL CONGESTION
description: ''IT wasn't a home - it was a film studio,'' said the middle-aged Larchmont woman, who paused while walking her dog in the Manor section of the village to talk about a large, elegant house on her block, the scene of the making of allegedly countless commercials. ''During peak periods, the production companies were there three times a week, illegally parked in the street, blocking fire and police access. There was the rainmaker. There was noise from the generators. The crews would take walks in the neighborhood and throw gum wrappers on the ground. First we complained to the owner, but it did no good. Now we have a new law.''

title: ANNETTE SCHARF IS ENGAGED
description: Mrs. Toby Scharf of Flushing, Queens has announced the engagement of her daughter, Annette Melinda Scharf, to Kenneth Charles Stier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Stier of Lawrence, L.I. The future bride also is a daughter of the late David Scharf. A May wedding is planned.

title: SCHOLAR FACING OUSTER BY U.S. GETS HOPE
description: The President of Colombia, Belisario Betancur, has asked President Reagan to halt deportation proceedings against a Latin American scholar at the University of Maryland, the White House said today.

title: THOSE WHO EDUCATE THE CRITIC BY MAIL
description: Music critics and burglars work best at night. I like that epigram, even though I believe it was originally said about actors, not critics. Beyond that one-liner, however, the great epigrammatists have not left us many sharp and snappy insights into criticism, the world's second oldest profession. The few aphorisms that cry out to be remembered tend to be somewhat vulgar and do not bear repeating in the presence of sensitive newspaper readers. Certain pungent witticisms on the subject do circulate in the musical world, but no decent person wants to hear about them. Certainly no decent critic would pass them along. The more printable japes run along the general lines of this one, contained in a sniffish note recently received at this desk: ''A music critic is like a surgeon who thinks that when he has removed a woman's appendix he has made love to her.'' Ugh! You call that funny?

title: A HEART DOCTOR WINS A ROUND IN THE SPIRITED FIGHT OVER CHOCK FULL O'NUTS
description: ''Y OU'RE out of order,'' Leon Pordy shouted, a surprising outburst for a 63-year old cardiologist, whose monogrammed shirts and thin, silver mustache give him the appearance of a dapper Englishman.

title: NEW HEART'S PROMISE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAVE NEW WORLD FOR INVESTORS
description: Investment has always been an adventure. It is the way that people share the risks of great undertakings, and small ones, even as they share their dreams of fortunes. Ceaseless effort goes into cloaking investment in reassuring terms. But it is and always will be a form of gambling, for it is a placing of one's chips on something that cannot be seen or touched, a game played against an infinitely imaginative opponent: the future. It is, in bookies' lingo, how we as a nation ''lay off the bets.''

title: PIANO: JEFFEREY LOHN HISTORY
description: Jeffrey Lohn's ''Music for Two Pianos,'' a romp through the history of classical piano from Mozart to Reich, was performed Tuesday and Wednesday at Roulette. The one-movement piece makes for a diverting half-hour.

title: FAMILY TRIPS
description: To the Editor: I fear your reporter William Geist has transformed his anger at his children into an undeserved swipe at Mel Jennings' Dana Place Inn in Jackson, N.H. ontrary to Mr. Geist's experience, our two sons, age 10 and 12, were accorded prompt and professional service while dining with their grandfather in August. While they, too, no doubt prefer cheeseburgers, they have learned to endure shrimp scampi when dining at an adult occasion.

title: A MOTHER KEEPS WATCH OVER HER SECOND FAMILY
description: RUTH B was in her 20's when she came to New York City from Memphis, Tenn., to work as a housekeeper. She had separated from her husband. Her seven children, all born by the time she was 22, stayed in Memphis with their father for three years, until she had enough money to send for them.

title: STATES CALL FOR FEDERAL PLAN TO COMBAT THE GYPSY MOTH
description: Experts on the gypsy moth have urged the Federal Government to adopt a long-range strategy to fight the treekiller.

title: ENERGY: USE DROPS, PRICES RISE
description: Americans have cut their home energy use by 17 percent but are paying 27 percent higher bills, according to the Energy Department.

title: Jobless Benefit Claims Down By 56,000, Labor Dept. Says
description: First-time claims for unemployment compensation benefits declined by 56,000 in the week ended Nov. 27, mainly because of the shortened Thanksgiving holiday filing period, Department of Labor figures showed Thursday.

title: OLD BRIDGE TACKLES 'SILENCE'
description: OLD BRIDGE ''Please remain standing for a moment of silence.''

title: Albuquerque Police to Give Film Tickets to Good Drivers
description: Several hundred motorists will be stopped by the police and given tickets for obeying traffic safety laws, a spokesman for the Albuquerque Police Department said. The tickets will be free passes to the movies.

title: FOUR HAVENS FOR ALPINE WINTERING
description: KAY ELDREDGE is a writer with a special interest in travel.

title: A WORK OF HER OWN
description: THE DIARY OF BEATRICE WEBB Volume One. 1873-1892. ''Glitter Around and Darkness Within.'' Edited by Norman and Jeanne MacKenzie. Illustrated. 386 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $25.

title: RENEWAL PLAN SPLITS NEW HAVEN
description: NEW HAVEN THE first act of Mayor Biagio DiLieto's script for reviving New Haven unfolded this month. Work has begun on refurbishing the historic Shubert Theater - the centerpiece of a projected $21.5 million downtown entertainment district called Shubert Square.

title: Homes for Winter Are Found For Palestinians in Lebanon
description: About 95,000 Palestinians left homeless after Israel's invasion of Lebanon on June 6 have found housing for the winter, the chief of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency said.

title: EXECUTION BY INJECTION: A DILEMMA FOR PRISON DOCTORS
description: Although it was never determined which of the two men fired the shot that killed a Fort Worth car mechanic six years ago, Charles Brooks Jr. was executed last week for the crime, while his codefendant may be paroled in a few years.

title: PINE BARRENS INDUSTRY PLAN PRESSED ANEW
description: BROOKHAVEN DEVELOPERS have joined with officials in the Town of Brookhaven to try to pave the way for the location of high-technology industries in portions of the environmentally sensitive Brookhaven pine barrens.

title: August Wedding For Miss Harrison
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Harrison 2d of Rye Brook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ruth Harrison, to John Edward Powers 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Powers of North Barrington, Ill. The wedding is planned for Aug. 13.

title: Miss Levy to Wed K.S.Grossman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Berger of Massapequa, L.I., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Ellen Beth Levy, to Kenneth Scott Grossman, son of Louis Grossman, Acting State Supreme Court Justice, and Mrs. Grossman of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
HERBS FOR A FRAGRANT HOLIDAY SEASON
description: SMELLS play an important role in our lives. We object when a neighbor creates a smelly nuisance next door or when a community proposes that an incinerator or landfill be located next to our homes. Yet we are fascinated when a member of the opposite sex wears an exotic new perfume or cologne.

title: LONG AUSTRALIAN DROUGHT NOW IMPERILS CITIES
description: (Reuters) - A drought that has parched Australia's rich eastern farmlands for the last few years is now forcing the nation's cities to take drastic measures to save water.

title: TRIBAL CLASHES FLARING IN PAPUA NEW GUINEA
description: The police hoped that the leaders of the Okane and Kumukane clans would join at a recent outdoor meeting in signing a Government-drafted agreement to end their tribal conflict, which has left 13 people dead in three months.

title: INSURANCE WITH A YIELD
description: FEW PEOPLE in recent years thought life insurance was much of an i nvestment. But that attitude might be changing with the advent of u niversal life insurance, which offers both insurance protection and w hat some people say is an attractive yield on the savings build up o n a policy.

title: Florida Issues a Guide To Hospitals' Charges
description: Hoping to promote competition among hospitals, the State of Florida has released a shoppers' guide to gall bladder surgery.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
Y OFFERS SOMETHING FATHERS AND CHILDREN SOMETIMES DON'T HAVE: TIME
description: THE relationship between father and child has been the subject of countless novels, not to mention sessions of psychoanalysis. It has been explored through behavioral science and art, in ponderous studies and in sentimental songs, such as the soliloquy from ''Carousel,'' in which a father-to-be contemplates ''My Little Girl'' and ''My Boy Bill.'' Fathers may not always have as close proximity to his child as mothers, but the feelings are there.

title: Collins Not Bitter
description: When the Yankees traded Dave Collins to Toronto, there was no bitterness on his part about leaving New York. ''I'm a free man,'' Collins said from his home in Springboro, Ohio.

title: COPTERS MOVING MORE ACCIDENT VICTIMS IN CITY
description: A city program that went into full operation in recent months is using police helicopters to rush accident victims who have suffered severe burns or other critical injuries to specially designated New York hospitals.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
INITIATE ENERGY SAVING AT LOCAL LEVEL
description: DEPENDENT New England awaits the winter of 1983. President Reagan has decontrolled the price of oil, thereby pushing its cost higher. The consumer has responded by using less oil and the producers, until recently, have responded by spending more money to find new sources of oil.

title: Fat Cat Flat Tax
description: To the Business Editor: The article by William Nordhaus, ''A Proposed Flat Tax for Fat Cats'' (Nov.28), implies that this reform would not be fair. Mr. Nordhaus has attempted to show that in a flat tax system the rich would show a tax decrease, and the poor a tax increase. It is more likely true that the rich have hidden most of their money in tax shelters and already pay far less tax than they would under a flat tax system.

title: WHAT RONALD REAGAN HAS DONE FOR INVESTORS
description: TWO YEARS AGO, Ronald Reagan was elected President and the stock market marched off to hit new peaks a few weeks later. Then last month, the Democrats failed, despite a 10-percent-plus unemployment rate, to break decisively Mr. Reagan's hold on Congress. The very next day, more market records were shattered.

title: WALESA ASKS WARSAW TO FREE DETAINEES AND RESTORE UNIONS
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the outlawed Solidarity trade union, has asked Poland's martial law ruler to restore the legal status of free labor unions and grant amnesty to all internees.

title: SANDY HOOK PLANS PROVOKE QUESTIONS
description: SANDY HOOK THE National Park Service has been studying ways to restore a former military complex at the northern tip of this beach peninsula and transform it into a revenue-producing meeting center for 200 people.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: FLORIDA CLUB DROPS BARRIERS IN FACE OF DISCRIMINATION SUIT
description: The Bal Harbour Club has dropped a 36-year-old policy barring Jews and blacks from this exclusive seaside community, a practice that brought on a $10 million discrimination suit.

title: Stalking the Common Cold
description: As Garrett Epps mentions, cold viruses like the temperature of the nose - 91.4 degrees (''Stalking the Common Cold,'' Nov. 14).

title: OIL-REVENUE MEASURE IS EXPECTED TO DIE
description: WASHINGTON WAIT until next year. That's the message Congress has sent to New Jersey and other coastal states hoping for a piece of the billions of dollars in Federal income generated annually by offshore oil and gas activities.

title: CENSUS REPORT SHOWS INCREASE IN STATE POVERTY
description: HARTFORD DESPITE Connecticut's reputation as a wealthy state, more of its residents slipped below the poverty level in the last decade, the State Office of Policy and Management reported last week.

title: For a Bearable Social Security Tax
description: Three cheers for Tip O'Neill and Dan Rostenkowski. The Speaker and the Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee are risking the voters' wrath by supporting a tax on Social Security benefits. Such a policy change, they courageously argue, is needed to restore confidence in the solvency of the system. They're right.

title: A ROUNDTABLE: DO JOBS PROGRAMS WORK?
description: As the number of Americans officially listed as unemployed passed 12 million in November, proposals to create jobs for some of them, such as the highway repair program that passed the House of Representatives last week, multiplied. The Week in Review asked three experts -William H. Kolberg, Assistant Secretary of Labor for Manpower in the Nixon and Ford Administrations and now head of the National Alliance for Business; Marion Pines, director of Baltimore's Office of Manpower Resources; and Robert Taggart 3d, administrator of the Office of Youth Employment in the Carter Labor Department and now president of the Washington-based Remediation and Training Institute - to talk about the record and the promise of jobs programs and jobs training.

title: Heat Wave for Boston's Mayor
description: For many of his 14 years in office, Boston Mayor Kevin H. White has headed the sort of smooth-running political machine that the late Richard J. Daley of Chicago took pride in. In recent weeks, however, Federal investigators have been looking under the hood for violations that could bring it to a halt.

title: Biggest-Ever Defense Budget Obscured by Flak
description: As the White House tells it, Dec. 7, 1982, was almost another day of infamy. The House of Representatives that day voted 245 to 176 to delete $988 million in seed money for the MX missile from the 1983 military spending bill.

title: WHAT KEEPS PATIENTS ALIVE CAN SOMETIMES DESTROY THEM
description: Within days of emergency surgery for air blisters in his lungs, Dr. Barney B. Clark, recipient of the first artificial heart implant, suffered a major setback. Seizures wracked his body for three hours last week. He was reported to be resting comfortably again, his recovery proceeding ''in the right direction,'' according to attending physicians at the University of Utah medical school.

title: THE BIG APPLE CIRCUS PRESENTS A HOLIDAY GALA
description: ''Slow down!'' cried an usher to a running child. ''This isn't a playground! It's a circus!'' And indeed it was - to be exact, the Big Apple Circus, currently playing at the Damrosch Park bandshell behind the New York State Theater. For the past two seasons, the Big Apple Circus has presented a holiday gala at Lincoln Center, under the direction of Paul Binder. In direct contrast to a three-ring extravaganza, the Big Apple restores the intimacy of circuses past. At Lincoln Center, the most remotely placed member of the audience is only 35 feet from ringside.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR AGENCY DRAFTS RULES TO STRENGTHEN WALLS OF REACTORS
description: 14WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) - The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is drafting rules to prevent nuclear reactor walls that have been weakened by radiation from cracking under the sudden cooling that might occur in an accident.

title: ACCORD IN STATE ON MX
description: FOR varying reasons, all of Connecticut's congressmen opposed financing for the MX missile in a vote last week. Their criticism of the missile ranged from doubts about the effectiveness of the ''dense pack'' basing system selected by President Reagan, to concern that deployment of the land-based missile could escalate the arms race and upset the SALT II agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: Police in Moscow Arrest 60 At Silent Vigil on Rights Day
description: About 60 people in a group marking United Nations Human Rights Day with a silent vigil in downtown Moscow were arrested on Friday, witnesses said.

title: Mahaffey-Carner Team Leads Field by 3 Shots
description: John Mahaffey and JoAnne Carner eagled the first hole today and went on to card a nine-under-par 63 that gave them the third-round lead with a 54-hole total of 198 in the $500,000 Mixed Team Classic.

title: Age-Problem On Old-Age Fund
description: The National Commission on Social Security Reform, appointed to report on its delicate subject after November's Congressional elections, last week again pedaled back from grappling with the fundamental question until President Reagan and House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. do.

title: CHRISTMAS VILLAGE IN ITS 35TH YEAR
description: TORRINGTON WHEN Carl Bozenski took his young son to visit Santa Claus at a Torrington department store 36 years ago, he found a hastily costumed Santa sitting on an office chair in the store's basement.

title: Sudden Riches
description: When Nicholas Eisenhardt Jr., a worker in a sign shop in Reading, Pa., won $4.6 million in the Pennsylvania lottery two months ago, he said he hadn't heard from his wife and six children in 10 years - but he imagined he would. Officials in Colorado and Kansas were reported trying to determine if he should repay the states for welfare given to his family.

title: FAMILY TRIPS
description: To the Editor: My wife and I were very amused by the William Geist article. Since we have taken our children, age 12 and 9, on trips for many years and can empathize with his views on traveling with children. ut if he thinks traveling in America has its problems, he should try a trip to Europe with youngsters, especially to England where children are generally regarded as being just beneath dogs.

title: A New Vision For New Jersey
description: To paraphrase an old joke, New Jersey has long been a test pattern between New York and Philadelphia. That may finally change.

title:
ANTIQUES;
CHESTS WERE MORE THAN UTILITARIAN
description: WHATEVER else their households may have boasted or lacked, to some early New Englanders a strong chest may have been the most important piece of furniture they owned. It could be used not only as a container for clothing and other valuables but also could serve in turn as a table, a sideboard or a bench.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DOCTOR DE SOTO Written and illustrated by William Steig. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. (Ages 4 to 7) By GEORGE A. Woods

title: David Gordon's Dance Ironies
description: ''David Gordon began dancing with James Waring. Continued dancing with Merce Cunningham. Began studying with Martha Graham and Louis Horst and stopped immediately and stopped dancing with James Waring. Began studying composition with Merce Cunningham and with Judith and Robert Dunn. Began dancing alone and with Valda Setterfield and married her. Began dancing with Yvonne Rainer. Hopes to stop all this dancing soon.''

title: THE JOYOUS SOUNDS OF CHRISTMAS
description: MUSIC lovers in the county will have a wealth of programs to choose from during the holidays, in many cases at their own houses of worship. At this time of year, music directors and clergymen countywide welcome nonparishioners to their special holiday offerings.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am a horse-racing aficionado planning a trip to Florida in late February and early March. Can you tell me what tracks are open and the dates they are assigned for the season? - E.S., Lodi, N.J. Answer:A representative of the Parimutuel Wagering Division of Florida's Department of Business Regulation said three tracks less than an hour's drive from the Miami International Airport and a fourth, about 350 miles northwest of Miami (near Tampa on the Gulf coast), offer horse racing in the winter tourist season.

title: THE SAFE WAY: RELYING ON RATES
description: Beginning Tuesday, the ball game will be changed for short-term investments. At that time, banks and savings institutions will be allowed to offer market rates of interest on deposits that are insured by the Federal Government. The only condition imposed by the Government on these so-called money market accounts is that they must have minimum balances of $2,500.

title: Life and Work
description: To the Editor:

title: SINGAPORE SLING IS SPOKEN HERE
description: It would be satisfying if you could slide down sweatily into one of the bamboo chairs at the Long Bar of Singapore's old Raffles Hotel, where the first Singapore sling is supposed to have been mixed in 1915, and know for a certainty that the cold, pink, frothy mixture in front of you was the only authentic Singapore sling in the world.

title: FAMED PICTURE OF WASHINGTON CROSSING THE DELAWARE CHALLENGED
description: The painting was found hanging unnoticed in a library in New Jersey. The scene was instantly familiar: Washington crossing the Delaware. But something was different.

title: FAMILY TRIPS
description: To the Editor: When I read William Geist's article, I thought I would pick up some helpful tips on traveling with children. Instead, I was assaulted with the most sickening attitude toward children I ever encountered.

title: 'POWERHOUSE' AIMS ITS MEASURES AT INNER CITY YOUNGSTERS
description: ''What we had to do,'' Ira Klugerman was saying, ''was develop an inner-city neighborhood, racially and ethnically mixed.'' Thus, the narrow turn-of-the-century row house with the ornate molded entry, somewhat the worse for age, could be in any older residential neighborhood in any American city. The graffiti on its inside walls are an urban constant, as is the presence of streetdrinkers, numbers runners and young toughs. Basketball is the street game. Those in and around the house are recognizably inner city: the black mother-figure, the tough cop, the kids, black, Hispanic, Jewish, Irish.

title: DAY CARE'S FUTURE IS ASSESSED
description: ALTHOUGH the County Board of Legislators has once again averted an immediate day-care crisis in the county, the future of the day-care system remains hazy.

title: Traffic TV Cameras Stolen
description: Four television cameras have been stolen from the Santa Monica Freeway, along which they had been installed for a closed-circuit traffic monitoring system. The cameras, worth nearly $47,000, were stolen over the four-day Thanksgiving weekend, the California Department of Transportation said, but the theft was not disclosed until Friday.

title: Sri Lanka Landslides Kill 22
description: Soldiers searched for more bodies today after landslides caused by monsoon rains crushed several houses, killing 22 people in Sri Lanka's mountainous tea growing region Friday. At least 12 more people are feared buried. Floods set off by the rains in central, northern and eastern Sri Lanka left 30,000 people homeless, officials said.

title: 13 FOR THE 13TH AT WITCHCRAFT
description: SOUTH ORANGE THE Whichcraft Studio and Gallery here is celebrating not its 10th or 25th anniversary, but its 13th with a holiday show featuring, of course, 13 artists. Many have exhibited at the gallery regularly since it opened.

title: Mexican Proposes Restructuring of Debt
description: Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog of Mexico said today that the Government hoped to restructure $25 billion in short-term foreign debts.

title: MIGRATION CHANGE BY PUERTO RICANS
description: The Puerto Rican population's 30-year movement out of port-of-entry neighborhoods, through New York City and into the suburbs is traced in a new City Planning Commission report.

title: Court Rejects Several Claims By Priest Charged as Robber
description: A judge has dismissed civil claims against the State of Delaware by a Roman Catholic priest who was charged as the ''Gentleman Bandit'' responsible for a series of armed robberies and later cleared.

title: THE ELECTRONIC OFFICE
description: A goal of increased productivity in the office does not necessarily mean that employers want to replace people with machines; it may simply entail enhancing workers' skills and eliminating the drudgery of error-prone tasks like proofreading.

title: A Connection To Wordsworth
description: Having seen your cutting from your issue of Sept. 26 (Connecticut Journal), I thought you would wish me to point out an error of fact concerning Dove Cottage in Grasmere, where William Wordsworth spent much of his life.

title: Dominican Hotels
description: To the Editor: In the article, ''Rediscovering the Dominican Republic'' by Richard J. Meislin (Travel, Nov. 21), local telephone numbers were listed for the Hotel Santo Domingo and the Casa de Campo resort.

title: PRINCETON HOUSING UNRESOLVED
description: PRINCETON MEMBERS of New Jersey's Congressional delegation are seeking to have the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development reverse a decision under which it approved, and then denied, a $3.7 million grant for a housing project for the elderly and handicapped in Princeton Borough.

title: BOARD SEEKS TO AVOID TAX RISE
description: AMONTHLONG effort by the Board of Legislators to trim the already lean county budget proposed for 1983 could end next week, according to Chairman Andrew J. O'Rourke, ''with $6 million to $7 million in cuts,'' or no county tax increase for Westchester residents.

title: 20,000 FLEE LOUISIANA AREA AFTER CHEMICAL PLANT BLAST
description: More than 20,000 people were evacuated from their homes early this morning after a chemical storage tank exploded at a Union Carbide Corporation plant near here shortly after midnight.

title: Depreciation Eligibility
description: Question: I recently purchased an occupied apartment in a noneviction co-op conversion. In addition to the purchase price, I am responsible for a portion of the underlying mortgage of the building. Can this amount be added to the purchase price of the apartment to establish the taxable basis for depreciation calculations? ... W.D., North Babylon, L.I. Answer: Part of your share of the mortgage may be included in your cost for depreciation purposes, according to regulations adopted by the Internal Revenue Service in 1964. Unless the land is leased, some of the value of the mortgage is on the land, not just the building, and land cannot be depreciated. Leon M. Nad, a partner in Price Waterhouse, a leading accounting firm, says there are several sources you might consult to determine the value of the land. Talk with the sponsor of the conversion, the company that insures the property or the financial institution that holds the mortgage. A Key Question Question: Must I provide my landlord with a key to the second lock that I have installed on my apartment door? When I requested a copy of an executed lease, my landlord said he would not give me the copy of the lease until I gave him that key. ... C.B.R., Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times; The Sandwich Eater
description: IT all began with a turkey sandwich. Just your basic Thanksgiving leftover sandwich, thick with cranberries and stuffing and meat, wrapped in a cellophane bag and crammed in R.J. Murray's jacket pocket.

title: Poison Victim's Husband Sets Lie Detector Test
description: The husband of a woman who almost died from cyanide placed in an Anacin-3 capsule will voluntarily take a lie detector test next week, the police said today.

title: A NEW MISSION CONFRONTS THE SALVATION ARMY
description: DESPITE the spring-like weather last weekend, the unmistakable strains of ''Hark, the Herald Angels Sing'' could be heard in White Plains. Shoppers stopped on Main Street and some smiled as they beheld three street musicians, one playing the euphonium, another the trombone and a third the cornet. As the music grew louder, the message grew clearer. As has been its custom for more than a century, the Salvation Army was on hand, providing a sense of stability during a time of need.

title: Under 40
description: To the Editor:

title: Linfield Captures Title With a 33-15 Triumph
description: Rander Mueller threw three touchdown passes today as unbeaten Linfield of Oregon defeated William Jewell of Missouri, 33-15, to win the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics Division II football championship.

title: TALK WITH CHAPLAIN LEADS TO MURDER CHARGES
description: A conversation between an Episcopal priest and a teen-ager in prison for a parole violation has led the authorities to charge the young man with two murders.

title: 50 NEW CONGRESSMEN 'CRAM' AT HARVARD
description: The seats that 50 of the country's new members of Congress have been occupying this week are shiny black captain's chairs with the Harvard crest across the back, and the speeches they are hearing are pedagogy rather than demagogy.

title: SCHOOL PRAYER SUIT DIVIDES OKLAHOMA DISTRICT
description: In the Federal district court battle over prayer in the Little Axe school, deeply held beliefs about religion prevail on both sides.

title: ITALY IS STRUGGLING TO RESERVE POMPEII'S PAST
description: In a gloomy, shabby room here, with cracks in the walls and dust collecting everywhere, the features of Alexander the Great can be seen on one of the ancient world's most renowned mosaics.

title: The Electronic Office
description: We read with interest and frustration Sandra Salmans's article, ''The Debate Over the Electronic Office'' (Nov. 14). Unless managers understand and apply principles of effective communication, electronic mail will become nothing more than a costly replacement for a scribbled note or a hasty phone call.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
MORE KNOWLEDGE NEEDED ON IMPACT OF 'ACID RAIN'
description: 'ACID RAIN' has existed for at least 20 years, and perhaps since the start of the industrialization. Over the last several decades, rain in the northeastern United States has become more acidic, presumably as a result of manmade inputs of chemicals emitted by power utilities and other industries that burn oil and coal. Once these chemicals combine with moisture in the air, sulfur and nitric acids are produced, and acid rain results.

title: BACK IN VOGUE WITH MUTUAL FUNDS
description: RICHARD TISCH, president of the Richbar Sales Corporation, a 46-year-old New York dress importer, has a bout $850,000 in investments, and almost all of it is in mutual f unds. ''I used to trade stocks, but frankly I couldn't keep up with i t,'' he said. ''There were tons of trading slips and it was s upercostly.''

title: RIFT STIRS DOUBT ON PRUDENTI POST
description: THE once-close relations between Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan and Anthony Prudenti, the Suffolk Republican leader, have become so strained that Suffolk Republicans are questioning how long Mr. Prudenti can survive as county chairman.

title: Patricia Trombley Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Trombley of Glens Falls, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Trombley, to Vincent J. Barone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Barone of Old Brookville, L.I. A May wedding is planned. Miss Trombley and her fiance graduated from Marist College. Mr. Barone's father is a senior vice president of the RCA Corporation in New York.

title: WHY AUTO STOCKS LEAD THE PACK
description: AFTER several false starts in 1980 and 1981, the auto stocks this y ear have been acting like the pace car at the Indy 500. Ahead of them arket even before the big rally began in August, the autos have c ontinued to outperform the broad market averages in recent months.

title: PARK CAN BE MORE THAN A PLACE TO PLAY
description: FOR Joseph Pappalia and his wife, Ellen, the growing pains of 6-year-old Christa have been particularly poignant. Their daughter was born with Down's syndrome.

title: Pigskin Road
description: To the Editor: In writing the article, ''Notes From the Pigskin Road'' (Travel, Oct. 3), D. Keith Mano has chosen the low road of Columbia University's sports, whereas for the last five years my father and I have taken the high road by following the five-time Ivy League champion Columbia soccer team - to Oneonta, and Hartwick College's mountaintop stadium with its 50-foot drop, to Syracuse under the stars and to Rhode Island. Yet, soccer is a city game, so the really fine trips are on the ''D'' train to Flatbush and Long Island University's sidelineless nonstadium, the Bronx's Fordham and its quadrangle-turned-soccer field, to Garden City, where Adelphi overlooks elegant estates, and, of course, to Baker Field, which lies across the street from my grandfather's luncheonette, which fed the fans at half-time during the 40's and 50's, and from where I (a Yale man) was weaned on Lions' sports. ALAN MARLIS, New York

title: CHARITY APPEALS SHARPLY ON RISE
description: Charitable organizations in the New York metropolitan area are stepping up efforts to raise money this Christmas season from individual contributors, businesses and foundations, according to government and charity officials.

title: ATLANTA SEES ROLE AS GLOBAL TRADER
description: When he campaigned for Mayor last year, Andrew Young, the outspoken former United States delegate to the United Nations, promised to make Atlanta a ''gateway'' to business with developing nations.

title: SCROOGE AND COMPANY
description: CHAPPAQUA WHEN eight actors take their bows at the merry end of ''A Christmas Carol,'' Greeley Street Theater-style, the effect is astonishing. For the last two hours, we have seen more than twice that many characters - count them - and would swear there were even more, so cunningly has the cast assimilated their characters. The staging by the director, Nancy Hall Bell, evokes the panorama and the populus of Dickensian London, if not as seamlessly as one would hope.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
A PRO AT 12, HE SINGS A FAVORITE: 'AMAHL'
description: MANHASSET WHEN it comes to type-casting, Bill Blaber would seem to have little in common with Amahl, the young hero of Gian Carlo Menotti's opera ''Amahl and the Night Visitors.'' A strapping 12-year-old with sun-bleached blond hair and clear green eyes, Bill is far removed from the slight, crippled shepherd boy who journeys with the three Magi to pay homage to the Christ-child in Bethlehem.

title: Rutgers 57, Lafayette 50
description: Roy Hinson scored 16 of his game-high 22 points in the second half to lead the unbeaten Scarlet Knights to their fifth victory.

title: 20 VIE FOR TITLE OF 'VALLEY GIRL'
description: STAMFORD HERE'S the problem: You tell your teen-age daughter to clean her room, fully expecting the usual whining and groaning. It's Saturday, and she would rather be shopping or out with friends.

title: June A. Haselton To Become Bride Of T.G. Stephens
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Haselton of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, June Ann Haselton, to Timothy Gage Stephens, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joe Bill Stephens of Bangs, Tex.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HAPPY HANUKKAH
description: On the second day of Hanukkah, as they prepare to light the third festive candle at sundown today, Jews throughout Long Island will join in community parties. For example, the Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association of Suffolk, 74 Hauppauge Road in Commack, will hold its family party from 1 to 4 P.M., and in addition to the customary games, sing-along and potato latke noshing, will feature a performance by Ohad Naharin, an Israeli dancer. It will cost nonmembers $5 a family to attend.

title: Valerie Ann Nifosi Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Nifosi of Smoke Rise, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Valerie Ann Nifosi, to Matthew J. Gilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger P. Gilson of Syracuse.

title: Topics; Memorable Men; Chemist of Conscience
description: George Kistiakowsky, a chemist, was present at the creation of the nuclear age. In fact, he designed the trigger for the first nuclear explosion at Alamogordo, N.M., on July 16, 1945.

title: ZUNIGA REPLACES MOORE
description: ''Four Generations,'' the sculpture by Francisco Zuniga, used to adorn the courtyard of St. Bartholomew's Church at Park Avenue and 51st Street, and Henry Moore's ''Interconnecting Figures'' used to grace a small plaza at 900 Park Avenue, an apartment house at 79th Street. Now the Zuniga (left) sits where the Moore once was and the

title: HIGH MOUNTAINS AND FAR PLACES
description: THE appeal of books about extraordinary adventures or travels into strange places and times lies in the suspicion that some realities cannot be known or at least not revealed. There might be a discovery of himself too deep for the adventurer to disclose. We suspect he may have stepped over the margin of escape and become part of a lost civilization or a world we had never imagined. Strangeness alone is not enough; the best accounts of travel and adventure leave you with an odd sense of loss and longing. In part that comes from the common experience - that going does not necessarily mean we get anywhere. We are fascinated by the few who have taken a leap and landed in an enchanted place. QUEST FOR ADVENTURE By Chris Bonington. Illustrated. 448 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/Crown Publishers. $30.

title: CASHING IN ON SENTIMENT
description: DURING the summer and fall, movie audiences across the country were once again treated to Steven Spielberg's vision of alien life. ''E.T., The Extra-Terrestrial,'' is the story of an alien who is stranded on Earth, where he is befriended and protected by a young boy.

title: Mailbox; Boxing Reforms Begin in Corner
description: To the Sports Editor: I started my boxing career when I was 17 years old at Billy Grupp's Gym - 116th Street and Eighth Avenue. After nine months of schooling from Billy Grupp, I had a few bootleg fights. At 18 I fought 10 amateur fights, winning them all.

title: SELLING A CONVENT REFLECTS THE TIMES
description: THE vacancy and proposed sale of the Mount St. Ursula Convent in Oyster Bay represents both the current economic climate and the decline in the number of young women entering religious orders over the last 20 years - a trend that, church representatives say, is beginning to reverse itself.

title: 2 Slain in Harlem Apartment, Apparently Victims of Robbery
description: Two men were found shot to death yesterday in their Harlem apartment, apparently the victims of a robbery, the police said. One of the victims, 40-year-old Ralph Alphonso, was found lying face down in a bedroom with a pillow over his head.

title: Oversight on Aged
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. DECISION IN PREACHER'S INQUIRY STIRS DEBATE
description: After a three-year investigation of allegations that the PTL Club and its host, Jim Bakker, had defrauded television viewers, the Federal Communications Commission has voted in a closed meeting to pass the charges to the Justice Department. Mr. Bakker will be allowed to close the matter before the commission by disposing of his television station.

title: BLAZING A TRAIL FOR SOME POLITICAL SAVVY
description: FOR nine weeks, ending Election Day, I left reality behind to assume the role of a political candidate. It was my maiden voyage and my goal was to garner enough votes to entitle me to wear black judicial robes in January.

title: Drawing Room, Circa 1200
description: ALTHOUGH oil and tempera are ordinarily considered the media of the old masters, there is a great deal to be said for mud. Recently discovered drawings etched into the clay-like walls of a Tennessee cave have given archeologists new insight into pre-Colombian culture - and they have lasted 800 years without cracking, peeling or flaking.

title:
THE WORLD IN SUMMARY;
Dominoes Fail To Line Up in Central America
description: ''They're all individual countries,'' President Reagan remarked with some surprise on his return last weekend from Latin America. They certainly are.

title: 22 MARRY BEHIND SAN QUENTIN'S BARS
description: It was a pristine fall day in the San Francisco Bay area, a beautiful day for a mass wedding, even one conducted behind the walls of San Quentin State Prison.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
I'M SHOPPING AS FAST AS I CAN
description: THE responsibility during this festive season has been almost more than a holiday maker can bear. With newspaper financial pages pointing an accosting finger almost every week since Halloween, I've acquired a furtive air when I try to sneak past my friendly neighborhood retailer without doing my part for the economy.

title: COPING WITH SANTA CLAUS
description: Julie had turned 8 in October and as Christmas approached, Santa Claus was more and more on her mind. During the week before Christmas, every night she announced to her father, ''I know who really brings the presents. You do!'' Then, waiting a moment, she added, ''Right?''

title: Guest Killed by Party Host
description: Otis Mullen, the host of a party in July who tried to shoot a beer can off a friend's head, killing him, has been convicted of manslaughter.

title: STATING THE CASE FOR A LAW SCHOOL
description: ''STARTING a new law school, as we are, really makes us the envy of many of our colleagues in legal education,'' said Charles R. Halpern. ''There's much dissatisfaction with legal education as it now operates and a good deal of frustration because it is so difficult to alter present practices in existing law schools. As with any well-established institution with a tenured faculty, it is very hard for a law school to change directions in any substantial way. So we have a special opportunity.''

title: MAYOR GIVES STUDENTS AN HOUR OF NEWS
description: It is not often that Mayor Koch concludes a news conference by thanking his interrogators. Nor is it often that they return the courtesy by applauding him.

title: Brazil and Ambassador's Son Face Lawsuit Over Shooting
description: A nightclub bouncer has filed a $10 million lawsuit against Brazil and the son of that country's Ambassador to the United States in connection with a shooting incident at the bar last month.

title: A Fatal Case of Ulster Disease
description: Explosives experts last week may have crippled London's latest attempts to calm Northern Ireland. They blew up an Ulster disco-bar, killing 11 British soldiers and five civilians and wounding 66 people.

title: THE PUZZLING TANGLE OF GLOBAL FINANCE
description: DONALD T. REGAN, Secretary of the Treasury, gave the financial world a shock last week when he called for an urgent top-level conference to restructure the international financial system.

title: RENOVATING THE CITY'S SHELTER PROGRAM
description: THE heartbreaking plight of New York's homeless grew that much worse last week as temperatures dropped. With city shelters swollen by about 4,400 such people, and uncounted thousands still on the streets, there were new calls for action. An interdenominational group, the Partnership for the Homeless, urged Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo to replace the state commissioners of mental hygiene and social services, whose ''bankrupt'' policies it blamed for the problem, and appoint a state coordinator for the homeless. The organization said temporary shelters would soon be opened in churches and synagogues. City officials, whose request to modify a 1981 agreement for facilities for the homeless so as to reduce costs was rejected by State Supreme Court Judge Richard W. Wallach last month, were studying what to do next. Robert M. Hayes, who has argued major court cases on the homeless and is counsel to another concerned group, the Coalition for the Homeless, and James A. Krauskopf, head of the Human Resources Administration, which runs the municipal shelters, recently discussed the city's efforts. Excerpts from their conversations with Robin Herman, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, follow.

title: Freight Train Derails in Iowa
description: An engine and 12 cars of a Milwaukee Road freight train, including a tank car loaded with 10,000 gallons of chlorine gas, derailed today, leading to the precautionary evacuation of about 600 residents from their homes in this Mississippi River town. The overturned tank car posed no immediate threat, the authorities said, because it had a double shell and only the ''outer skin'' was punctured. No injuries were reported.

title: TRENTON
