description: ''THIS package,'' Assembly Speaker Alan J. Karcher said, ''probably gives New Jersey the toughest program in the United States'' on drunken drivers.
To the Editor:

title: GOLD LOSES ITS BAD NAME
description: GOLD, THE OLDEST monetary substance, has undergone an extraordinary transformation in the eyes of investors since the metal was decontrolled by Washington on Jan. 1, 1975. Once, it was viewed as the province of eccentric ''gold bugs,'' who believed that their ''doomsday metal'' was the ultimate store of value for a world beset by chronic inflation, social and political upheavals. Now, bullion has found its way into the richly paneled and carpeted halls of the nation's leading investment banking houses, and dealing in the metal is accepted as part of sound money management.

title: MANAGING YOUR PORTFOLIO ON A HOME COMPUTER
description: When C.A. Butler, a chemical engineer in Linville, N.C., got fed up with the service he was getting from his investment adviser, he started doing his own stock analysis on his personal computer. Once a week, he enters certain stock prices and other data from Barron's into his computer, which then cranks out charts and analyses that would be impossibly time-consuming to do by hand.

title: ANGEL CORDERO: JOCKEY THE FANS LOVE TO HATE
description: LIKE most kids who answer the call of the race track and start s pending their time there, Angel Tomas Cordero Jr. began as a bettor.T his was 25 years ago, at the old El Comandante track in San Juan, P .R., when Cordero was 15 and planning to please his mother by b ecoming a dentist instead of following his father's side of the f amily into racing. He didn't last long as a horseplayer.

title: A RESOUNDING 'DESERT SONG'
description: DARIEN IF dinner theaters must serve popular musicals in a potpourri of styles, so they must. Should the Darien Dinner Theater, however, opt for a more exclusive identity, it could become a full-time operetta house. With ''The Desert Song,'' it is operating on all cylinders.

title: MUSIC: 'MESSIAH,' BY CHARLES CHOSET
description: Charles Choset's ''Messiah,'' which opened at the Theater for the New City on Thursday, uses the same passages from the Bible as Handel, but in a modern translation. Performed by 11 singers and a keyboardist, the score is an eclectic potpourri of modern pop and serious idioms, from gospel to Philip Glass.

title: Pretoria Talks - And Shoots
description: South Africa last week took the offensive on two fronts - one decidedly more peaceful than the other. In a surprise move, its Foreign and Defense Ministers met in the Cape Verde Islands with a delegation from Angola, a country South Africa has been warring with, off and on, for the past seven years.

title: Diana D. Peterson Married in California
description: Diana Dunbar Peterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Royal E. Peterson of Greenwich, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Donald Dean Ackland, son of Mrs. Rodney P. Parks of Ojai, Calif., and the late Dale Ackland of Bakersfield, Calif. The Rev. Lanny Arrowsmith performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Ojai.

title: ROGER SALENDER, CLARINETIST, AMONG RECITALISTS
description: The five debut recitalists of the week included two pairs of players of the most familiar instruments, violin and piano. But the best of the bunch was a clarinetist, Roger Salander, who performed Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall under the auspices of the Austrian Institute.

title: POWER RULING DRAWS CHALLENGE
description: WHEN the Federal Government recently ordered the State Power Authority to sell more cheap hydroelectric power to 51 municipal systems and less to three large, upstate investor-owned utilities, the decision was hailed as a victory by Rockville Centre, Freeport and Greenport, the only Long Island villages that have their own generating plants, supplying electricity to consumers at slightly more than half the price charged by the Long Island Lighting Company. A victory celebration, however, may be premature.

title: TURNCOAT REVEALED CAMPSITE TO BRITISH
description: TUCKERTON GEN. CASIMIR PULASKI'S practice of talking captured Hessian officers into joining the Continental Army - a practice frowned upon by General Washington - led to the massacre of 50 of his men by British troops who already had wiped out a ''nest'' of American coastal privateers.

title: HOW TO PICK THE STANDOUTS, STANDBYS AND CYCLES
description: Although everyone is agonizing over prospects for a slow economic recovery, what may be less than ideal for business and the population as a whole may be just what the stock market needs. A slow recovery is unlikely to reinflate the economy, and gradual growth may keep interest rates at a level low enough to provide a sustained recovery.

title: Linda Corwin Is Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harold E. Corwin of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Beth Corwin, to Thomas Coryell Palmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Palmer of Riverside, Conn.

title: Toll in Helicopter Crash In Nicaragua Rises to 84
description: The death toll in a helicopter crash in northern Nicaragua Thursday has risen to 84 with discovery of the bodies of nine women in the wreckage, Government spokesmen said today.

title: HOTEL WALKOUT
description: NEW HAVEN SEVERAL hundred members of the Food and Commercial Workers scheduled a luncheon for Monday inside New Haven's Park Plaza Hotel. Instead of having lunch there, however, the union canceled the engagement and many of its members ended up on a picket line outside the hotel.

title: BANKRUPTCIES: FINDING TOYS 'R' US
description: WHEN THE INTERSTATE Stores Corporation emerged from bankruptcy proceedings in 1978 as T oys 'R' Us, the toy supermarket chain, Wall Street paid little a ttention. It should have. Shares of Toys 'R' Us common stock, which t raded at 1/8 in 1975 and 6 3/8 only two years ago, were fetching $ 50 last month, a return of some 40,000 percent in seven years.

title: DATED ORNAMENTS ON COLLECTORS' LIST
description: COLLECTORS have many different ways of displaying their treasures. At this time of year, the Christmas tree is a favorite showcase for those who can't resist the dated silver, crystal and porcelain ornaments that are issued annually, many of them in limited editions.

title: HOLIDAY SALES OVERCOME SLOW START
description: WITH less than two weeks left to the holiday shopping season, retailers on the Island say that after a slow start things began picking up in the middle of last week and that sales, despite the continuing recession, were better than had been anticiated.

title: Air Force Back Hurt
description: Derek Foster, a starting halfback on the Air Force Academy football team, was listed in critical condition in the intensive care unit of Penrose Hospital in Colorado Springs, after he sustained head injuries Friday morning in an accident on the school's grounds. A car that Foster was driving skidded on an icy patch and struck a tree.

title: CRISTINA MONET- PALACI AND MICHAEL ZILKHA ENGAGED
description: Mrs. Robert E. Simon Jr. of New York and Glen Head, L.I. and Dr. Jacques Palaci of Paris have announced engagement of their daughter, Cristina Monet-Palaci, to Michael Zilkha, son of hte Lady Lever of London and Manchester, England, and Selim K. Zilkha of New York.

title: No Headline
description: Delaware Gains Final by 17-0

title: LAURIE ALDERMAN TO BE JULY BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Alderman of New Providence, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Barbara Alderman, to David Wales Cutler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Cutler of Wichita, Kan.

title: CONCERT: FIVE PIECES BY EIGHT COMPOSERS
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic's Meet the Moderns series, under the direction of Lukas Foss, offered five pieces by eight composers at Cooper Union Friday night. Bad arithmetic you say. Well, not really. ''Party Pieces,'' the centerpiece of this long and often rich evening, required four men to bring it into being.

title: LIFE FOR ELDERLY FOUND IMPROVED BY HEALTH CARE OFFERED AT HOME
description: Older Americans receiving medical treatment at home live longer and more enjoyable lives than those in institutions, according to a report to Congress, but the study cautioned that the home care would cost the Government more.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption today in The Guide, section 2A, gives an incorrect opening date for the Clint Eastwood film ''Honkytonk Man.'' It opens Wednesday.

title: 'TRUTH IN TESTING' ACT FORCES TRIPS OUT OF STATE
description: At 8 o'clock this morning, Drew Claxton of Ossining, N.Y., walked through the light snow on the Yale University campus to take an admissions test for graduate school that three years ago she could have taken a few miles from her home.

title: M.B. Strauss to Marry Debra Kaufman in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Kaufman of Monsey, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Hope Kaufman, to Michael Benjamin Strauss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Strauss of Wantagh, L.I.

title: LEGAL HEROIN: GOOD IDEA 60 YEARS OVERDUE
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Fiction as Meditation JOHN GARDNER, the prolific novelist and medieval scholar who died three months ago at 49 in a motorcycle accident, has a book coming out in January. No one at Southern Illinois University Press expected that it would ever publish a work bearing his name as editor and cotranslator, let alone soon after his death.

title: Varia Obolensky To Marry in June
description: Mrs. Ivan P. Obolensky of New York and Southampton, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Barbara Obolensky, to Vincent McGann, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Lee McGann of Water Mill, L.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: CHANGING VIEWS OF LIABILITY
description: LAST JULY 7, the State Supreme Court handed down its decision in Beshada v. Johns-Manville et al. Although the case was immediately recognized as significant for asbestos litigation, New Jersey companies - and national ones doing business in the state - have reason to fear that it will have dangerous ramifications in virtually every area of industry.

title: SCHOOLS WARNED OF FISCAL 'TRAUMA'
description: TRENTON ''IT'S GOING to be traumatic, I'm afraid,'' said Vincent B. Calabrese, Assistant Commissioner of the state's Department of Education, referring to a letter that local school districts received from the department last week.

title: 'MESSIAH' DISKS DIFFER JOYFULLY
description: At this time of year, amateur and professional performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' abound throughout the land. Each holiday season brings us new recordings of this cherished work, and this year there have been two noteworthy renditions added to an already crowded market, both of them based on very different guiding philosophies.

title: Newhall 2d
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday, Elizabeth Bowdoin Warriner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lendall Pitts Warriner of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Pocono Lake Preserve, Pa., was married to William Price Newhall 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kurtz Newhall of Naples, Fla. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: MOST Connecticut residents would grumble about new taxes, but now the state has found one tax even machines cannot accept - vending machines to be specific. The problem is a plan to remove the existing state sales tax exemption for meals priced under $1.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ADOZEN or so teen-age boys have been literally ''raising the roof'' in Wharton State Forest, deep in the Pine Barrens. Under the supervision of the Division of Juvenile Services of the state's Department of Corrections, and together with staff members, the youths have been converting an abandoned hunting lodge into a 30-bed housing unit.

title: THE BEAR DOESN'T DANCE TO OUR TUNE
description: The logic of the Reagan Administration's policy toward the Soviet Union is based on one key underlying assumption: that Western policy generrally and American policy specifically can seriously affect Soviet international conduct by exerting influence on internal Soviet developments. This assumption is simply fallacious and spawns maximalist and unrealistic objectives.

title: 'American Women Artists'
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSECUTORS IN THREE COUNTIES GAIN COURT-MANDATED RAISES
description: The state can tell a county how much to pay its full-time district attorney, New York's highest court has ruled. In a case involving three upstate prosecutors, the Court of Appeals said that setting the salaries was ''a proper concern of the state.'' The ruling will mean substantial raises - about $14,500 in one case - for Joseph Kelley, District Attorney in Clinton County; John R. King Jr., District Attorney in Dutchess County, and James R. Harvey, District Attorney in Ontario County.

title: THE ADMINISTRATION'S CASES FOR CAREER JOBLESSNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: COTTAGES AND SKYSCRAPERS
description: A few years ago book buyers showed relatively little interest in architecture. There have always been architecture books, of course, but far too many of them were bland, overpriced tomes destined for the one piece of furniture that has given its name to a publishing genre, the coffee table. A few years ago things began to change with the appearance of an increasing number of books about decorating and furnishing one's own nest. Now it is hard not to think that we are entering a period of somewhat less narrow concerns, for architecture publishing in the past season has been wide in its scope, ranging from scholarship about modernist architects of distinction to investigations of the English picturesque. Here are some of the more stimulating volumes that should outlast the glitter of their Christmas wrappings. RICHARD NEUTRA ANDTHE SEARCH FOR MODERN ARCHITECTURE A Biography and History. By Thomas S. Hines. Illustrated. 356 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $49.95.

title: Headliners; Defense Dollars
description: New Jersey taxpayers had to foot the bill for prosecuting Newark Mayor Kenneth Gibson on conspiracy and official misconduct charges earlier this year. Now Newark taxpayers will ante up more than $302,000 for his defense. Under a law passed more than a year before Mr. Gibson and his codefendant, former City Council President Earl Harris, were indicted, the city is required to pay the legal fees of officials in cases arising from the performance of their duty - if they are acquitted. Mayor Gibson and Mr. Harris -the latter's lawyers are to get $175,000 - were found not guilty of creating a no-show job for a retired city worker.

title: SPLITTING THE DOCTOR'S BILL
description: GENEROUS medical insurance coverage, totally paid for by the c ompany, has traditionally been considered one of the mainstays of c orporate employee benefit programs. But skyrocketing health care c osts are causing a fundamental re-evaluation of this key benefit, a nd many companies are beginning to charge workers for some of the c osts they once bore themselves or to scale back the amount of c overage available.

title: CAVIAR: BEYOND ITS PLACE ON A BUTTERED PIECE OF TOAST
description: ''IF you must give yourself the illusion that you are impressing everyone by serving caviar, then you must do so in the grand style by providing your guests with half a dozen tins of the stuff into which they can dip freely, even if they are a little bit sick afterwards.''

title: Dorothy Potter Teipel Wed
description: Dorothy Potter Teipel and John Marshall Finch, both of Washington, were married there yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square.

title: EXPANDING SITES FOR WHITE-COLLAR WORK
description: AN advertising firm gave an assignment a year ago to Tishman Speyer P roperties, the development company: Find an old building of about 3 00,000 square feet where modern office space can be produced and r ented for less than $30 a square foot.

title: MOSCOW INDICATED EASING OF STANCE ON CUTS IN MISSILES
description: The Soviet Union has indicated that it will propose reducing its intermediate-range missile force by more than half if the United States agrees to forgo its planned missile deployments in Europe, according to Reagan Administration officials. But the officials said the plan would leave the United States at a disadvantage and was therefore unacceptable.

title: FROM MICHIGAN AND TENNESEE
description: SELECTED & NEW POEMS 1961-1981. By Jim Harrison. Illustrated by Russell Chatham. 212 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. Cloth, $14.95. Delta paper, $6.95. COUNTRY MUSIC Selected Early Poems. By Charles Wright. 159 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $15. Paper, $8.95.

title: THIS BOYISH PRINCELING IS AN UNPERSUASIVE HAMLET
description: s things turned out, what interested me most during the first half hour of Joseph Papp's new ''Hamlet'' at the Public wasn't the fact that I was - for the first time in my theatergoing life - watching an actress play the Prince of Denmark. What interested me most was that I seemed to be watching a 14-year-old play the Prince of Denmark.

title: JERSEY REVIEWING ITS COMMUTER TAX
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court is reviewing a tax on New Yorkers commuting to work in New Jersey, who contributed $82.9 million to the state's coffers last year.

title: TEXT OF LETTER WALESA SENT TO JARUZELSKI ON POLAND'S FUTURE
description: Following is the text of a letter written by Lech Walesa, the labor leader, to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the martial law administrator, on Dec. 4. A copy of the letter was given to ABC News in Gdansk, Mr. Walesa's hometown, and it was translated by ABC and distributed to Western correspondents today.

title: Starting the Season With 'Messiah'
description: The recent mention in the Long Island Guide that the Long Island Singers Society and the Long Island Choral Society were presenting the first productions of Handel's ''Messiah'' this year was not correct.

title: RESTORE INTEGRITY TO COLLEGE SPORTS
description: EVERY day the postman drops on my desk another batch of letters from supporters and detractors of Clemson University and college athletics. As one would imagine, the letters - often accompanied by clippings of news accounts and editorials -reflect a wide range of opinions and emotions.

title: AGENCIES STRUGGLE TO MEET A GREATER NEED AT A TIME OF SHRINKING; RESOURCES
description: By MSGR. JAMES J. MURRAY Executive Director Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York

title: From Lab to Bedside With Gene Chemistry
description: High on medicine's wish list is the ability to treat disease by tinkering with genetic material. That wish has been fulfilled in part by scientists at the National Institutes of Health and the University of Illinois medical college, who successfully altered the activity of genes in patients with a chronic blood disease. Their achievement was described last week in The New England Journal of Medicine, which editorially hailed the report as proof that the revolutionary understanding of the chemistry of genetics has moved from the laboratory ''to the bedside.''

title: OPEC'S HUMBLING COULD BE A PROBLEM
description: NEXT Sunday OPEC oil ministers will gather in Vienna to try to d etermine a new price for oil. In the past, such meetings were p receeded by anxious speculation in all oil importing countries abouta nother price hike. Now the only speculation is over whether the p rice will fall and, if so, whether the fall will be controlled and s mall, or uncontrolled and large.

title: TAKING A PAGE FROM SATELLITES AND COMPUTERS
description: Newspapers, which spend much of their time chronicling what's new in the world, are now getting around to renewing themselves. They are radically changing the way they look, and experimenting with different technologies for getting information to readers, grappling with the new media that promise financial health and offer opportunities to reach more people. And all these changes are likely to accelerate in coming years, experts say.

title: SON SAYS HE THINKS SCIENTOLOGY FOUNDER DIED
description: The son of L. Ron Hubbard, the founder of the Church of Scientology, has asked to be named trustee of the religion's holdings.

title: Conservatives Opening Drive Against Nuclear Arms Freeze
description: With a slogan of ''Remember Pearl Harbor,'' the American Conservative Union has opened what it said would be a $1 million campaign to oppose the growing nuclear freeze movement.

title:
ART;
FANTASY AND REALISM ENVELOP ORIENTALISM SHOW
description: DO let the pink and dark-blue walls of the Neuberger Museum fool you. You're being set up for splendor, for being transported out of the everyday world. The museum at the Purchase campus of the State University of New York has been painted to hint of a sultan's palace for ''Orientalism: The Near East in French Painting 1800 Through 1880,'' which will be on view through Dec. 23.

title: Chacon Wins W.B.C. Title
description: Bobby Chacon sent Rafael Limon to the canvas with a pair of hard rights in the final seconds today to clinch a 15-round unanimous decision and capture the World Boxing Council super-featherweight title nine months after his wife committed suicide because he wouldn't quit boxing.

title: Janis Surtees Wed To L.B. Jones Jr.
description: The marriage of Janis Surtees, a senior vice president of the securities division of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, to Louis B. Jones Jr., a vice president and management supervisor at Benton & Bowles Inc., took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Beatrice Blair.

title: Fires Set at 3 Hospitals In San Francisco
description: Fires were set in three neighboring hospitals within two hours Friday, causing at least $1.5 million in damage but no injuries, officials said today.

title: RESHAPING THE CLASSICS AT THE HOUSE OF CHANEL
description: When a woman buys an authentic Chanel suit in 1983, she will find that its familiar 'safe' shape has been sharpened up. The jacket has been shortened and its snug shoulders widened and padded. The skirt has been narrowed and the hem hiked up to an above-the-knee level. All of this has given the famous classic a younger, jauntier look. But, of course, not everyone agrees with such tampering with tradition.

title: STATE MUSEUM: AN ARTIST OBSESSED
description: TRENTON JOHN FOLINSBEE, whose paintings are on view at the State Museum, was a painter's painter. He had an unconquerable compulsion to paint, from early youth until his death at age 80 in 1972. And paint he did, no matter what the adversities.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: RUNNING INTO TROUBLE ABROAD
description: M illions of Americans travel abroad every year and a minority of them - a minority that comes to thousands of people - run into trouble of some sort or another and go to the nearest United States embassy or consulate for help.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Celtics vs. Denver Nuggets, at Boston. Last Thursday night, in beating Denver, 98-90, the Washington Bullets finally ended at 136 games the Nuggets' league-record string of scoring at least 100 points a game. (Television - ESPN, Cable 7:30 P.M.).

title: TEAM AMERICA: NOT THE WAY FOR SOCCER
description: AS an American-born athlete in a sport historically dominated by athletes from virtually every country except America, I've been deeply involved in the long and difficult crusade for soccer in our country. My first and foremost soccer priority will always lie with what benefits the American player.

title:
STAMPS;
VARIETY OF BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS GIVING
description: For Christmas gifts this year, the book to give is ''AIR MAIL: An Illustrated History 1793-1981,'' by Donald B. Holmes. It is an exciting and richly detailed account of one of the great developments of communication accompanied by vintage photographs and stamps and covers in color.

title: ALABAMAN IS HUB OF A NATIONAL NETWORK OF WHISTLE BLOWERS
description: Almost every night, Bill Bush waits for phone calls from Government employees who are ''blowing the whistle'' on abuses of authority. To those who phone or write him from all over the country, he offers legal information or simply moral support.

title: A SHARP RISE IN U.S.. RETAIL SALES
description: Sales by U.S. retailers jumped 2.3 percent in November, the largest increase since May. The rise, to a seasonally adjusted $91.9 billion, followed several months of lackluster sales. Car sales, up 10.6 percent over October, played a significant part in the improvement. Other retail sales, excluding autos, rose just 0.5 percent.

title: HEATING IN THE WRONG PLACE IS COSTLY-AND AVOIDABLE
description: IN the continuing battle to keep heating costs down, many homeowners may not realize that they can often cut down the amount of heat that is wasted by simply making certain the heat is used only where it will do the most good. Heating unused rooms, for example, can be quite wasteful, as can neglecting to apply weatherstripping around doors that connect a heated area to an unheated area (attics, garages and most basements, for example).

title: BROOKS ANGERED BY RANGERS' LATE LAPSE FOR 4-4 TIE
description: After the Capitals and the Rangers had played to a 4-4 tie Friday night at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., the Washington players could afford to be generous in their praise of the Rangers.

title: CANADIAN ASSET
description: The biggest recent boost to Canadian chess was the arrival of the international master Igor Ivanov from the Soviet Union three years ago. He is the national champion, was the Canadian entrant into the Toluca Interzonal Tournament and played first board for their Olympiad team in Lucerne, Switzerland.

title: Death Sentence Is Appealed
description: Ted Bundy, a convicted killer, should not die in the electric chair because the murders of two sorority sisters in 1978 were not ''heinous, atrocious and cruel,'' according to his lawyer, Robert A. Harper. Mr. Harper challenged the sentence in an appeal to the Florida Supreme Court. Mr. Bundy, 36 years old, was convicted of beating the two women to death as they slept in their rooms at Florida State University's Chi Omega house.

title: WHEN COLLAGE ENTERED THE REALM OF HIGH ART
description: Collage, the technique by which snippets of pasted materials are used to make or enhance a picture, has had a busy career since Picasso and Braque first introduced it into ''high'' art around 1912. The two originally used collage in a formal way, incorporating bits of patterned paper or cloth, fragments of wood or newsprint, into their hermetic Cubist compositions as a way of bringing in ''reality'' without having to represent it in terms of spatial relationships and figurative detail. Other artists - particularly the Dadaists - quickly seized on the new idea, however, and not only as a means of breaking out of the two-dimensional boundaries of painting. Extending the repertory to include less neutral material - photograph shards, parts of old engravings, scraps of advertising, etc. - and inventively juxtaposing it, they made use of collage for symbolic, satirical and political comment.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
RECTANGULAR DESIGN SELECTED FOR ANS MEDAL
description: The American Numismatic Society has selected Marcel Jovine, a well-known sculptor and medalist, as designer of its 125th anniversary medal. His entry was chosen by a panel of judges from among the works of seven leading sculptors in a special, invited competition.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Win One For the Dipper

title: Sign Language
description: To the Editor: Hurray for the sign-language travel book cited in the Advisory column (Travel, Nov. 21).

title: Manhattan 61, Siena 57
description: Perry Bromwell was called upon to be the playmaker for Manhattan's undefeated team. The 6-foot-1-inch freshman guard from Boston not only handled the assignment well, but also scored 13 points as the Jaspers posted their fifth victory.

title: Nina J. Sauro Fiancee Of William Maginnis 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Sauro of Kendall Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Jeanne Sauro, to William Stuart Maginnis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maginnis Jr. of Fullerton, Calif.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MUSEUM RECALLS YULETIDES OF OLD
description: NEWARK HOLIDAY gifts this year might be video disks or games, a hi-fi set or perhaps even a computer. In the Music Room of the Newark Museum's Ballantine House are the holiday gifts of 100 years ago. In an exhibit entitled ''Precious and Personal: Victorian Holiday Presents,'' some three-dozen decorative objects from the brewer's mansion of the 1880's have been assembled to show what a well-to-do Victorian might have given as a Christmas gift.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: FILM To coincide with the opening of Alan J. Pakula's latest and most ambitious film, ''Sophie's Choice,'' a retrospective series at the Museum of Modern Art will provide a look at the earlier works of this director. Mr. Pakula's best prior films, like ''To Kill A Mockingbird'' (which he produced) and ''All The President's Men'' (which he directed), have combined outstanding star performances with a serious approach to important moral issues, qualities that are evident in his latest film as well. The series runs from Friday, through Dec. 21. Also on the agenda are ''Klute,'' which Mr. Pakula will introduce on Dec. 17, ''The Sterile Cuckoo,' ''Comes a Horseman,'' ''Love and Pain and the Whole Damn Thing,'' and ''Fear Strikes Out,'' the 1957 film produced by Mr. Pakula and directed by Robert Mulligan. Janet Maslin

title: MX: HOW DELEGATION VOTED
description: WASHINGTON ELIOT BRUMMEL is engaged in something unusual in these days of big conglomerates, huge aerospace industries and sophisticated lobbying organizations.

title: Cindy Schrom Married to Robert George
description: Cindy Schrom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schrom of Suffern, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Peter George, a lecturer in jurisprudence at New College, Oxford University. The ecumenical ceremony was performed in the Andover Chapel at Harvard University by the Rev. Thomas Powers, Roman Catholic chaplain at Harvard, and Rabbi Benjamin Z. Rudavsky.

title: OPERA: 'PARIS AND HELEN'
description: Gluck's nearly forgotten opera, ''Paris and Helen,'' found its way to Queens College this week. Hugo Weisgall conducted Thursday night's performance, with the singing, playing and staging coming from students, faculty members and a scattering of outsiders.

title: Cameron Crone To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Seth Crone of Charleston, S.C., Buffalo, and Glenwood, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cameron Crone, to Brent Ross Bilger, son of Mrs. Richard Muth Bilger of Timonium, Md., and the late Mr. Bilger.

title: U.S. ROLE IN FLOOD DISASTER AID HELD ADEQUATE
description: A General Accounting Office study concludes that Federal agencies performed their duties well in responding to the June floods in Connecticut.

title: Tough Times, Tough Talk
description: In prospect, the subject hardly seemed inflammatory, but sparks began to fly when publishers and agents gathered to discuss ''Mass Market Publishing Today: The Evolution from Reprinter to Full Line Publisher'' at the annual meeting of the Mass Market Paperback Division of the Association of American Publishers.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: NEVER DONE A History of American Housework. By Susan Strasser. Illustrated. 365 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $11.95.

title: Roadside Landmark
description: Say goodbye to the Holiday Inns' ''Great Sign.'' That looming green structure topped by a curving, flashing yellow arrow and a starburst, is headed for oblivion.

title: STALKING THE COMMON COLD
description: Unless one has a health problem that will be aggravated by a cold, there are certain benefits that a runny nose and a scratchy throat provide.

title: KEVIN KLINE'S GREAT JUMP TO FILMDOM
description: In the musical ''On the Twentieth Century'' he won his first Tony award as Bruce Granit, a small-time Hollywood roue whose manner was as well-oiled as his hair. In Michael Weller's play ''Loose Ends,'' he created a moving portrait of a young man struggling to adapt the countercultural values of the 1960's to the complicated realities of adulthood, marriage and career in the late 1970's.

title: WALL STREET BECKONS AGAIN
description: To most Americans, the stock market's record rally in late summer and early fall in the face of dour economic news stretched the bounds of reason, seeming like a chapter out of ''Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds,'' a book published in 1841 that chronicled such investment frenzies as the South Sea Bubble and Tulipomania. Not only was the nation's economy reeling from one of the worst recessions ever, but the recovery that finally was in the offing looked to be more insipid than robust.

title: Marcy Kramer Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Kramer of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marcy Kramer, to David S. Tannenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Tannenbaum, also of Brooklyn. The future bride, a graduate of Brooklyn College, received an M.B.A. degree from Fordham University and is employed by Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New York. Her fiance, also a graduate of Brooklyn College, is attending Brooklyn Law School.

title: IN SCULPTURE, TOO, HE IS AN ARTIST OF SURPRISES
description: With a Vermeer or a Picasso or a Leger, you can feel like the whole world is in one of their paintings. Take a Leger. There may be 12 colors, each one used three or four times. Maybe there are a hundred black and white shapes, with all the juxtapositions between them. There are hundreds of situations. He was able to handle all of them. I would like to make a whole room that says as much as one of their paintings.''

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq flew here today for a two-day visit that is to include a trip to the Johnson Space Center. Pakistani opposition groups said they planned to protest General Zia's visit.

title: QUEENS MAN SEIZED, ACCUSED OF RUNNING SEX RING IN 103 CITIES
description: A 57-year-old man who the police say operated a 103-city prostitution ring by telephone from his home in Flushing, Queens, has been arrested in New York on an Indiana warrant.

title: How Salaries Escalate
description: Pete Peterson, the general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, says that Omar Moreno, a free agent who signed with the Houston Astros on Friday for $3.5 million over five years, left the Pirates for ''only - and I stress the word only - $25,000 a year.'' Moreno had spent his entire eight-year major-league career with the Pirates.

title: SPANISH TREASURE
description: Let me state my case right away: I think that Spain is the most underrated eating country in Europe. My time there had been limited until this year, and what I had tasted hadn't impressed me much; I had confidently dismissed Spanish cooking as an oily mediocrity, a compound of gazpacho and paella and excessively heavy red wine. But a recent extended stay there provided a chance to sample the fare of that richly endowed land a lot more thoroughly, and it is clear to me that I didn't know what I was talking about.

title: Holding Course; On Law of Sea
description: Nearly a decade ago the nations of the world set out to agree on who could sail where on the oceans and who could mine what under them. Ultimately - and with growing predictability - the debate boiled down to the question of dividing up ''the common heritage of mankind,'' the wealth of minerals on the ocean floor.

title: WHEN BEAUJOLAIS IS KING IN PARIS
description: PATRICIA WELLS is restaurant critic for The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: SELECTED LETTERS OF JAMES THURBER. Edited by Helen Thurber and Edward Weeks. (Penguin, $6.95.) Funny and endearing, James Thurber's selected - and illustrated - letters have been grouped here according to their recipients, the men and women who mattered in Thurber's life. Edited by his wife of 36 years and his editor at The Atlantic, the collection includes an assessment of Thurber's epistolary abilities alleging that ''His circle of correspondents was perhaps no larger but it was easily more bewildered than that of any other American of his generation,'' and concluding ''I am not sure that we should not judge him too harshly.'' It is, of course, signed James Thurber.

title: Tennessee Sues World's Fair For 3,500 Tourists' Refunds
description: Tennessee has filed suit against the World's Fair and two former lodging agencies in an attempt to get refunds for more than 3,500 tourists who canceled reservations and never got their money back.

title: COOPERATIVE ARTISTS
description: Five years ago, six young Connecticut artists set out in search of a cooperative studio and found one in a vacant Bridgeport industrial loft. Two years later they moved to larger quarters in a better neighborhood. Now they are holding solo exhibitions of their work in their own gallery at 170 Elm Street, parallel to Golden Hill Street in downtown Bridgeport.

title: Those Who Won't Pay For Child Support
description: At a time when almost half of all marriages end in divorce, we are encumbered by a court system that either will not or cannot - perhaps because of the magnitude of the dilemma - deal productively with the problem of unmet child support payments.

title: Ex-Giant Killed in Crash
description: Rich Houston, a former Giants wide receiver, was killed early this morning in a head-on collision that left one other person dead, the police and team officials said.

title: Heroines
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy's Highest Court Voids Conviction of Female Sailor
description: The Navy's highest military review court has overturned the conviction of a female sailor who ran away from her ship after being threatened with a ''demeaning and sexually harassing'' initiation rite.

title: 1,000 March in California In Antiracism Protest
description: More than 1,000 people marched through this rural town today in a protest against racism touched off by the slaying of a teen-ager who had told the police about the distribution of Nazi leaflets.

title: WHAT LIES AHEAD FOR CULTURAL PROGRAMMING
description: his week, sometime around 4 in the morning on Friday, CBS Cable will go out of business. This season, public television's ''Great Performances'' series is celebrating its 10th anniversary. And thereby hangs a tale of television programming.

title: HOW A HOLLYWOOD RUMOR WAS BORN, FLOURISHED AND DIED
description: On Aug. 18, four days after his 46th birthday, Norman Garey, a successful Hollywood entertainment lawyer, canceled his lunch date, went into his den, and shot himself in the head.

title: BOARDING HOMES: HELP SCARCE
description: THE creation of the state's Bureau of Rooming and Boarding House Standards almost two and a half years ago, and the closing since then of 64 homes for violations, have made little difference for the average rooming- or boarding-house resident, according to Arnold Rabin, executive director of the Essex County Mental Health Association.

title: HARLEM HOTEL TO HOUSE COMMUNITY OF THE HOMELESS
description: A community group in Harlem has purchased a hotel that it plans to convert into the area's first permanent, long-term residence for the homeless. The organization, Emmaus, bought the hotel entirely with private funds after a legal battle with the existing tenant.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: HOW the state's Department of Environmental Protection can continue to negotiate to save Bear Swamp in Cumberland County and simultaneously encourage a proposal to mine the swamp's most sensitive sector is a question not easily answered.

title: Elizabeth S. Kean Affianced
description: Hamilton Fish Kean and Ellen Shaw Kean, both of New York, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Stuyvesant Kean, to Philip Le Breton Douglas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Douglas, also of New York.

title: SEASON'S 'REVELS' RETURNS
description: John Langstaff's annual ''Christmas Revels'' returned to Symphony Space this weekend, with a cast of dozens, a panoply of Victorian entertainments and a cheerful way with anachronisms. It offered a chance to sing along with Christmas carols, dance along with morris men, listen to music-hall songs and see St. George in rubber boots.

title: A DEFT, MERRY 'I LOVE MY WIFE'
description: EAST FARMINGDALE BECAUSE yet another touring company of the musical is being formed, the Arena Players Repertory Theater lost the rights to produce ''They're Playing Our Song.'' No great loss, that.

title: GEORGE STARKE, 77, EX-JUSTICE, IS DEAD
description: George Starke, a retired justice of New York State Supreme Court, died of cancer Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: John H. Beard Is Dead at 59; Director of Fountain House
description: John H. Beard, executive director of Fountain House Inc., which emphasizes community-based rehabilitation of the mentally ill, died Thursday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 59 years old and a resident of Montclair, N.J.

title: CHIEF JUSTICE IS LOBBYING ON BANKRUPTCY PROPOSAL
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger is urging Congress to reject a Reagan Administration proposal to give bankruptcy judges lifelong jobs and higher salaries.

title: COURSE HELPS INMATES GET JOBS
description: CHESHIRE FINDING jobs for men who have been in prison is not an easy task. For one recent ex-inmate at the Connecticut Correctional Center in Cheshire, it was not only easy to find a job, but also easy to make his boss realize just how valuable an employee he is.

title: 3 HUMAN RIGHTS GROUPS ASSAIL REAGAN POLICY
description: Three human rights monitoring groups accused the Reagan Administration last week of ''cheapening the currency of human rights'' since it took office.

title: PHILHARMONIC: BACH MASS
description: There has been much recent discussion about the correct way to approach Bach's Mass in B Minor. One approach that can certainly be ruled out is the one presented by the New York Choral Artists and the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Erich Leinsdorf Friday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: A CHALLENGE ON ESCROW ACCOUNTS
description: AWESTCHESTER COUNTY lawyer has filed a class-action suit charging t he State Banking Board and the Banking Superintendent with n egligence in failing to set a fair interest rate for the millions ofd ollars held in homeowners' escrow accounts.

title: JIM HENSON'S CREATURES POPULATE A FANTASY WORLD
description: Barney Cohen writes about the world of entertainment.

title: PRIEST STRUGGLES AGAINST TIMES SQ. DECAY
description: The Rev. Robert Rappleyea, pastor of Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church on West 42d Street, tells with rueful humor of the priest visiting from Toronto who saw a man lying on the sidewalk near the church. Alarmed, the visitor pointed him out to Father Rappleyea, who replied with resigned calm, ''No, that's just his usual place.''

title: FOR MOST POLES, THE FUTURE LOOKS AS GRAY AS THE PAST
description: Collectors take notice. The Polish Government is issuing a new stamp tomorrow commemorating, of all things, the imposition of martial law one year ago. Designed by a Colonel Tulodziecki, the stamp shows two sides of a medallion. One face is the Polish eagle and the formal name of the junta, the Military Council of National Salvation. The obverse has the words, ''We shall save our fatherland, Poland.''

title: Dr. Fritz Freyhan Dies; Psychiatric Researcher
description: Dr. Fritz A. Freyhan, a former director of research at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center and one of the first researchers to study the use of drugs in psychiatric treatment, died last Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in his office in Washington. He was 70 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: IN THE HOLE: DEFEAT PUTS REAGAN IN A DEFENSIVE MODE
description: WASHINGTON FROM the start, support for the ''dense pack'' system for basing the MX missile required faith in an unverifiable theory that sorely tested common sense - that lumping 100 missiles into an area less than 20 square miles would cause incoming Soviet warheads to blow each other up, leaving most of the MX's intact to retaliate.

title: PREPARED TO LOSE IT ALL? TRY TAX SHELTERS
description: WITH WEALTH comes the 50 percent tax bracket and a search to lessen t he taxman's bite. Everything from rail cars to cattle to oil and g as drilling ventures are available to high-income investors as tax s helters. But it is often difficult for the unwary investor to selectt he best - and safest - way to reduce taxes.

title: Recruiting Big
description: While some parts of the country were reporting growing layoffs of workers, the Houston Police Department said last month that it couldn't hire officers fast enough.

title: Noah and Smid Gain Final in Toulouse Event
description: Yannick Noah of France and Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia rallied to win their semifinal matches tonight and gain the final of a $75,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: OHIO SENATE DEMOCRAT IN POWER PLAY
description: After 16 years in the Ohio Legislature, Senator M. Morris Jackson says he should not be taken for granted by his fellow Democrats. He has pledged to line up with the Republicans in a move that, he says, he hopes will bring him the Senate leadership.

title: Drusilla A. Crawford Weds Richard Donald Herbert Jr.
description: Drusilla Ann Crawford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell George Crawford of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Richard Donald Herbert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert of Fallston, Md. Msgr.

title: A CHANGING OF THE GUARD
description: Sam J. Sebastiani and his wife, Vicki, are seated at a table in the Proven,cal Room at the Sonoma Mission Inn, one of the more elegant restaurants in the California wine country near Boyes Hot Springs. On a table nearby stand two bottles of very unusual wine, and Sam is watching carefully as a young waiter tries to decant the first.

title: MAPLEWOOD SCHOOL HAS EYE ON THE SKY
description: MAPLEWOOD WHEN Alan Levin, a physics teacher and amateur astronomer, came to Columbia High School six years ago, he was thrilled to find intact an observatory that had been constructed with the original building in 1927.

title: Associated Press
description: A new center for the study of social issues in medicine has been established by the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

title: A HAVEN FOR LOVERS OF EARLY NEW YORK
description: ''All the waters of the New Netherlands are rich with fishes,'' Barbara Cohen read seven years ago in Adriaen Van der Donck's ''Description of the New Netherlands,'' and ''The peaches, which are sought after in the Netherlands, grow wonderfully well here. If a stone is put into the earth, it will spring in the same season, and grow so rapidly as to bear fruit in the fourth year.''

title: U.S. HOPES TO END LEBANON IMPASSE WITH A NEW PLAN
description: The United States hopes to break the impasse over the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon by proposing a specific American plan to Israel and Lebanon that will not require direct talks between the two sides, American officials said today.

title: U.S. SEEKS ACTION TO PROTECT WORLD BANKING SYSTEM
description: There has been no lack of ideas for strengthening the international financial system but until last week the reformers were not getting a hearing in the one place that counted most - the Reagan Administration. Now Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan has joined the chorus advocating big changes.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
PLAINSPEAK'S THE NEW CONTRACT LANGUAGE
description: AFEW years ago, a tenant reading an apartment lease might have been s topped by a clause that said ''the Tenant shall not expose any sign,a dvertisement, illumination or projection in or out of the windows ore xteriors or from the said building or upon or in any place, except s uch as shall be approved and permitted in writing by the Landlord ort he Landlord's authorized agent.''

title: THE HIGH RETURN UNDER YOUR OWN ROOF
description: IN 1965, A MUSICIAN and his wife bought a brownstone that had houseda rundown rooming house on Manhattan's Upper West Side. The couple p aid $22,000 for the four-story structure and spent almost $80,000 f or repairs and renovation to make it their home. For the first eighty ears, the couple rented out the basement apartment for extra income.T hey then used it as a studio and now plan to rent again to help pay t he tuition costs of their children.

title: Faith Restored
description: To the Editor: Returning from a recent trip to Italy, I was outrageously overcharged by the cab driver who drove me from my hotel to the airport terminal in Milan.

title: Funds Freed For Westway
description: Despite early optimism, the Westway highway and redevelopment project has remained stuck for the last decade in heavy legal and financial traffic. Last week, however, there was a new sign of movement.

title: Not Desperate
description: To the Business Editor: It was with great concern that we read ''Auctioning Away Housing's Woes'' (Nov.7), by Winston Williams. Our firm is Kennedy-Wilson Inc., an auction-marketing company that has sold over $250 million worth of commercial, residential and resort property since 1977.

title: METZENBAUM FILIBUSTERS AS SENATORS BURN
description: ''I rise not to address myself to the merit or lack of merit of this legislation but, rather, to address myself to the fact that the matter is before the Senate at all,'' Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, said recently of a bill that would have retroactively altered corporate liability in antitrust cases. ''We don't have time to do anything that is important, but we have plenty of time to take up every special interest bill that any highpriced lobbyist pushes before the Congress of the United States.''

title: BREEDER REACTOR FAULTED ON COST
description: The General Accounting Office has concluded that the Reagan Administration's cost estimates for the Clinch River breeder reactor ''should be viewed with caution.'' It says the project at Oak Ridge, Tenn., could cost $8.5 billion, more than twice the Administration's estimate.

title: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1982
description: International Soviet missile negotiators have indicated they will propose a sharp cutback in in their missile forces if the United States agrees to forgo its planned missile deployment in Europe, Reagan Administration officials said. They said the Soviet Union was expected to propose reducing its intermediate-range missile force by more than half, from more than 600 to about 250, with about 150 aimed at Western reduced force would still be ''unacceptable,'' Administration officials said, principally because the Russians would still have medium-range missiles and the United States would have none. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: U.S. CRISIS EXERCISE REPORTS MAJOR GAINS IN ABILITY TO MOBILIZE
description: Pentagon and civilian officials recently tested the nation's ability to mobilize in a global crisis and found it substantially improved over nearly disastrous conditions in the past, senior military officials say.

title: IN THE HOLE: DEFEAT ON MX PUTS REAGAN IN A DEFENSIVE MODE
description: WASHINGTON IT is one of those ironies of Washington politics that Ronald Reagan, who came into office chastizing Jimmy Carter as an indecisive and ineffective manager of national defense, now finds himself charged with muddled policies and flipflops on a central element of his strategic buildup, the MX missile.

title: The Pentagon
description: To the Business Editor: The words of David Blond, a Pentagon strategist and advocate of increased Pentagon funding, in ''At War Over the Pentagon'' (Nov.14), deserve especially careful scrutiny. In the context of the fostering by the Japanese Government of technological change, Mr. Blond is quoted as saying that ''... only the Department of Defense's budget is rich enough to experiment with new approaches to complex problems.''

title: IT MIGHT HELP NOW, BUT IN TIME ...
description: AS the December OPEC meeting draws near, speculation mounts about t he future of world oil prices. Demand for OPEC oil remains severely d epressed and could drop even further by next spring. In the face of l agging demand, OPEC countries may need to cut production by about 5 p ercent early next year. If some concerted action is not taken, p rices could spiral downward, perhaps to as low as $20 a barrel.

title: A TOUGH SELL FOR MADISON AVENUE
description: LAST summer, Hal Shoup, president of the Carr Liggett advertising a gency, received a call from an industrial advertiser whose p atrongage he had been zealously seeking. ''Hal, I've got some good n ews and some bad news,'' the businessman said. ''Congratulations on w inning our account - but we're cutting the budget 50 percent.''

title: ON THE ROAD WITH A 'MIRACLE'
description: WASHINGTON To William Gibson, Washington stirs the bleakest memories. It was one night 11 years ago that Mr. Gibson, author of such plays as ''Two for the Seesaw,'' and ''The Miracle Worker,'' returned in despair to his room at the Hay-Adams Hotel after deciding that his new play about John and Abigail Adams was a ''disaster'' and should fold without opening on Broadway.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. MIGHT CUT AID TO SURINAME OVER KILLINGS

title: BRIGHT RETAINS OLD FLAIR ON PUNT RETURNS
description: After having missed one game as the Giants' punt-returner because of a severely sprained neck, Leon Bright appeared to be playing as recklessly as ever today in running back nine punts for a personal best of 143 yards in the Giants' 23-7 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Most are barely postcard size, and some are even smaller. Yet the nearly 100 landscapes in watercolor by William Trost Richards at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Jan. 16) give as lively and detailed a report on mountains, meadows, seas and architectural monuments as Richards' larger paintings, and in the same meticulous colors.

title: Joseph F. Vermaelen, 77, Dies; Led Triborough Bridge Agency
description: Joseph F. Vermaelen, retired executive director and chief engineer of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Randall Manor, S.I. He was 77 years old.

title: JURY GETS CASE AGAINST 3 IN MURDER OF U.S. JUDGE
description: The Government's case against three people charged in the murder of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. went to the jury today.

title: FIRST SNOWFALL PUSHES ASIDE BALMIER DAYS
description: The first snowfall of the season drifted down in gentle swirls over the metropolitan area yesterday. It made the city more wet than white and left only modest accumulations to the north and west, but it put an icy glaze on roads as temperatures fell sharply last night.

title: CON ED ASKS TO PAY GAS REBATE SOONER
description: With its customers facing natural-gas bills a third higher than those of last winter, the Consolidated Edison Company asked permission last week to accelerate payments of $20 million in refunds due its customers next year.

title: U.S. IS INTENSIFYING ITS LEGAL BATTLE TO CURB POLLUTION AT NIAGRA FALLS
description: The Federal Government is pressing the cleanup of chemical pollution in Niagara Falls, N.Y., with new legal moves, warning that one contaminated site might threaten the city's water supply.

title: ADULT RESIDENCES A HELP TO HOMELESS AND CITY
description: New York City has anywhere from a few hundred to several thousand homeless men and women who roam the streets, sleep in doorways, huddle in bus and railroad stations and occasionally seek refuge at city shelters.

title: POLAND'S MARTIAL LAW
description: The anniversary of the imposition of martial law in Poland - one year ago tomorrow -offers an opportunity to ask how martial law differs from the ordinary state of affairs in a totalitarian country like Poland.

title: American Jews and Israel
description: Mark Helprin's article, ''American Jews and Israel: Seizing a New Opportunity'' (Nov. 7), is flawed by a false premise - that American Jews are offered ''no choice except blind loyalty (to the Begin Government), hostile dissent or silent abstention.'' This is so, he writes, because the middle ground ''has neither sufficient voice nor sufficient public representation.'' In fact, ''the great middle'' is neither uncharted nor silent. It is represented by the 36 national Jewish secular and religious institutions that make up the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. And it is expressed in the consensus held by the conference - a view that, I believe, also speaks for the many American Jews who are not affiliated with any Jewish organization.

title: A PLAYWRIGHT ASKS THORNY QUESTIONS
description: Don Shewey writes frequently about theater.

title: HOW A NOVELIST CAME TO THE STAGE
description: Sylviane Gold is a freelance writer with a special interest in theater.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY Walk into Metro Pictures at 169 Mercer Street this week and you'll see what looks to be a group show of the gallery's most a la mode artists - Robert Longo, Cindy Sherman, Laurie Simmons, et al. Yet this is, believe it or not, a one-artist show.

title: PLAN SEEKS TO AID SCIENCE TEACHING
description: A PROFESSOR of science education at Pace University will lead a new project to addressing what has been described as a severe shortage of certified science teachers.

title: FOR SOME, 'A LONG WAY TO GO'
description: MARY BOGEN of Wanaque went to Trenton last Wednesday to hear Governor Kean proclaim this week as Drunken and Drugged Driver Awareness Week and publically propose a legislative package to deal with the problem.

title: Comissiona Will Direct Houston's Symphony
description: Sergiu Comissiona has been appointed music director of the Houston Symphony Orchestra. The Bucharest-born Mr. Comissiona has served as music adviser in Houston for the last three seasons, fulfilling most of the functions of music director.

title: LYnn G. Goldman Is Fiancee of D. Stephen Mathias
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Goldman of Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Gale Goldman, to D. Stephen Mathias, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Kale Mathias of Westminster, Md.

title: Letters; Moratorium Call
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY TRIP
description: To the Editor: It is obvious that Mr. Geist gave little thought to planning his trip with children in mind. His children must have been bored silly and thereby spoiled the vacations of other persons who might otherwise have enjoyed the quiet, quaint charm of the inns in New England and Cape May, N.J. Mr. Geist belongs in the attic. CHARLES R. TOBIAS Laureldale, Pa.

title: KIN OF CONDEMNED APPEAL TO ANKARA
description: The families of 1,880 prisoners who are facing the death penalty for politically motivated crimes have appealed to Turkey's highest authorities to commute the sentences to life imprisonment.

title: A WORLD OF WOMEN
description: REMARKABLE RELATIONS The Story of the Pearsall Smith Women. By Barbara Strachey. Illustrated. 351 pp. New York: Universe Books. $15.95.

title: ACCORD ON OBTAINING SEAVER FULFILLS A KEY MET OBJECTIVE
description: The biggest waves on Waikiki Beach this week may have been made by the Yankees. But the Mets achieved one of their two goals at baseball's business meetings when they cleared the way for the return of Tom Seaver.

title: U.S. REBUFFS CITY ON OFFSHORE SLUDGE DUMPING
description: The Federal Government has refused to grant New York City's request to continue dumping treated liquid wastes in the Atlantic Ocean 12 miles from shore. Instead, it proposed a site 106 miles from shore.

title: AIDING THE FAMILIES OF THE MENTALLY ILL
description: ''MY family has been understanding, but my friends can't deal with the fact that my daughter is mentally ill,'' said Linda C., whose 16-year-old daughter recently attempted suicide. ''I don't know if they can't face the situation or they can't face me. It's as if I don't exist anymore to them,''

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: FREQUENT FLIERS TO WASHINGTON GIVE A PARTY
description: When Richard Rogoff greeted Mary Rouse for lunch the other day, he allowed as how he didn't recognize her without her uniform and she allowed as how she didn't recognize him with his eyes open.

title: MARKETS ARE BETTER THAN THE ECONOMY
description: The long-awaited recovery has still not arrived. In fact, it is not even expected now until the first quarter of next year, or perhaps even later. And when it does arrive, it is expected to be moderate at best, with unemployment remaining high. For people with money to invest, however, even a feeble recovery should hold promise. ''The year-end economic outlook for investors is probably better than it has been for a decade,'' according to Francis H. Schott, senior vice president and chief economist at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. ''The investment markets will be better than the economy itself.

title: STATE PLAN MAY RAISE GRAPE AND APPLE PRICES
description: State officials have recommended that corn and hay growers get a tax break next year but that orchards and vineyards be taxed at a higher level than regular farmland. As a result, the price of wine grapes and apples could rise.

title: Missouri to Get Federal Aid
description: President Reagan today declared a major disaster in Missouri as a result of damage from flooding and tornadoes. The declaration means Federal money to help in the cleanup and recovery efforts. The Federal aid includes family grants, unemployment assistance and money for temporary housing for disaster victims.

title: FIRMS TO SELL MOBILE PHONES
description: A FORMER Connecticut contractor and two friends have found second careers for themselves in a new high technology business. The former contractor, Martin Fierberg, and two other Connecticut businessmen run Mobile Cellular Telephone Inc., a Hartford company that plans to offer cellular radio services, a system in which wireless telephones can be used in automobiles, and eventually in homes, businesses or on the street.

title: IONA WINS ON BURTT SHOT, 65-63
description: Steve Burtt, a junior guard, sank a jump shot from the top of the key with four seconds remaining to give Iona a 65-63 victory over American University in the final of the Manufacturers Hanover Classic at Mulcahy Campus Center tonight.

title: A LITTLE LATE, GREAT BRITAIN'S SECURITY WOES ARE NO SECRET
description: When Geoffrey Prine was convicted this fall as a Russian mole, raising new concerns for British security procedures, his former colleagues at the Government's top-secret communications headquarters in Cheltenham dug out the tale of the tourist couple who lost their way and mistook the main gate there for the entrance to the nearby racetrack. They showed their track passes, so the story goes, and the guard waved them inside.

title: SITE OF MASSACRE OF 1778 IS AFFIRMED
description: TUCKERTON AFTER almost a year of digging - both literal and figurative - an archeologist clearing the way for a housing development has affirmed what many people around here say they knew all along: the exact site of the farm on which Gen. Casimir Pulaski and his soldiers bivouacked before their disastrous Revolutionary War battle.

title: AN ORCHESTRA THAT NEEDS NO CONDUCTOR
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: OWNERS STRIPPING FACADES OF ORNAMENT
description: LOCAL LAW 10, enacted by New York City to prevent injuries from falling masonry, is resulting in the w idespread removal of cornices, balconies, moldings and other o rnamental elements from buildings throughout the city.

title: VIRGINIA HOLDS OFF GEORGETOWN, 68-63
description: Ralph Sampson of Virginia had 23 points tonight and got the better of Patrick Ewing and Georgetown as the Cavaliers remained undefeated with a 68-63 victory. It was Georgetown's first defeat after six victories.

title: STUDENT TO WED MOLLY SCHUELER
description: Mrs. Mary Coxe Schueler of Brookline, Mass., and Charles Richard Schueler of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Parsons Schueler, to Omar Franklin Elder 3d of Westport, Conn. A March wedding is planned.

title: Mailbox; Society's Right
description: To the Sports Editor: Stanley Cohen asks: ''Who has the right to tell a man that he must surrender his trade?'' When his trade allows him to beat another man to death, the answer is simple: A society with a conscience - and the backing of law - has the duty and the right to give a human being the same protection afforded chickens.

title: PUNK ROCK: RAINCOATS, FROM BRITAIN
description: The Raincoats, a British punk-art-rock-feminist band that was one of the more curious but also most admired products of the late 1970's new-wave rock scene, gave its first New York concert in more than two years late Wednesday night at Danceteria - the beginning of a short East Coast Tour that ends up tonight at the kitchen, the avant-garde performance space.

title: TOMMORROW IS A BIG DAY FOR THE BUDGET
description: TRENTON TOMORROW'S session of the State Legislature is the one that everybody has been waiting for. Governor Kean finally set the stage last week for some solution to the state's short-term budget problem and a start on resolving the built-in problems of the budget process. Tomorrow will show whether the Legislature was listening.

title: South Africa Detains Leader Of White Supremacist Group
description: The leader of a rightwing white supremacist movement has been detained for questioning under South Africa's internal security laws, a police spokesman said today.

title: CREATING A COUPLE
description: HER VICTORY By Alan Sillitoe. 590 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $16.95.

title: WHEN VATICAN ART GOES ON THE ROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Sailor Aims for Olympics
description: The biggest challenge in sailing is not found on the big boats, at least not for Gary Knapp. A top-seeded small-boat sailor aiming for a berth on the United States Olympic team, Knapp also is in charge of the Grand Prix ocean racer Infinity.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: volume edition. A MARGIN OF HOPE, by Irving Howe. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The critic's description of his intellectual development. THE NUCLEAR DELUSION, by George F. Kennan.

title: Military Analysis
description: In the eyes of Israeli military leaders, Syria remains the best equipped and most dangerous potential foe despite its setbacks in last summer's fighting in Lebanon.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''None of us is doing each other a favor and none of us has to ask for agreement on our knees because agreement is a necessity if you care about the good of the country.'' - The Polish labor leader Lech Walesa, in a letter to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the martial law chief. (1:4.)

title: Lindsay Green and Robert B. Blackford Are to Wed
description: The engagement of Regina Lindsay Green to Robert Blackford Carroll has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James G. Green of Brooklandville, Md., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll 3d of Ruxton, Md.

title: FLEA MARKETS SET CRITICS HOPPING
description: ''WE'RE a phenomenon - the wave of the future,'' said Sigmund Margulies, president of Tri-County Flea Markets, who estimates that his Smithtown outlet draws as many as 60,000 customers ''on a good day.''

title: SUDDENLY, BONDS ARE BELLES OF THE BALL
description: THE BOND MARKET, once the domain of institutions and the very rich, has gone plebian in recent years and has been drawing far more money from household investors than the stock market. In the last eight years, individuals invested $196 billion in all kinds of Treasury securities and $55 billion in the tax-exempt market, while their sales of common stocks exceeded purchases by $109 billion. This year, public demand for tax-exempt bonds issued by state and local governments has been especially heavy. These bonds are exempt from Federal income tax, and in some cases, state income tax.

title: WHITNEY BURNETT PLANS A WEDDING
description: Whitney Ann Beekman Burnett, casting director for "Edge of Night," the daytime tlevision series on ABC, and Philip Voss Jr., executive vice president and management director of Compton Advertising Inc., plan to be married in the spring.

title: Insult to the Poor, and the Constitution
description: Not content with abusing the poor by trying to gut their legal services program, President Reagan is extending the insult to the United States Senate. His sudden withdrawal of all his nominations for the Legal Services Corporation's board of directors brings chaos to the organization and cynically frustrates the Senate's ability to protect it with its advise-and-consent power. The maneuver is a gross abuse of the President's authority to make so-called recess appointments.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Nov. 29 about the city of Buffalo incorrectly quoted Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League. Mr. Rozelle, who did not mention Buffalo, said he was considering changing the sites of two playoff games this season because of forecasts of severe winter weather.

title: 'Super' Ski Race to Mueller
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 12 (AP) - Peter Mueller led Switzerland to a sweep of the top five places today in the first super-giant slalom race of the World Cup season. The winning time was 1 minute 35.16 seconds.

title: New N.F.L. Pact Signed Quietly
description: The labor dispute between the National Football League and the players' union officially ended this weekend when a new collective-bargaining agreement was signed.

title: An Effigy of Marcos Is Burned At a Rally in the Philippines
description: Some 5,000 human rights activists burned an effigy of President Ferdinand E. Marcos today at a rally in Cebu, the Philippines' second-largest city.

title: 'EYES ON THE ENVIRONMENT' CAN STOP ITS POISONERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Policeman Admits Inventing A Report He Was Kidnapped
description: Police Officer Charles Futrell, who said he had been kidnapped and shot by four men who were performing a cult ritual, has resigned after admitting that he shot himself and made up the story.

title: ALBANY SESSION TO BEGIN WITH FARE ISSUE CLOUDY
description: A special session of the New York State Legislature ordered by Governor Carey will convene in Albany today amid uncertainty over what measures can be taken to hold down bus, subway and commuter rail fares.

title: Socialist Faults Partners In Italy-Bulgaria Furor
description: Italy's Socialist Party leader, Bettino Craxi, accused his Christian Democratic coalition partners today of playing down allegations that Bulgarian agents plotted to kill Pope John Paul II.

title: FLIGHT OF TALENT CALLED PERIL TO ULSTER'S FUTURE
description: Violence and a deteriorating economy are helping to force so many skilled people to leave Northern Ireland that the province's ability to rebuild may become impaired, according to demographic studies being conducted here.

title: Shamir to Open Talks With 2 Latin Nations
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir left today on a 12-day trip to Argentina and Uruguay. He is the second Israeli Cabinet minister to visit Latin America this month.

title: No Headline
description: DARRYL SUTTER GETS 4

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY THE POLISH LEADER
description: Following, as translated and distributed by the Polish press agency P.A.P., are excerpts from a speech by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's martial law leader, in which he announced that martial law would be partly lifted by the end of the year:

title: New Owner to Revive Saturday Review
description: Saturday Review just won't stay dead. The durable national journal, which ceased publication last summer after 58 years, five owners and millions of dollars in losses, is scheduled to reappear on the newsstands under new ownership by the end of January.

title: Kenyan Says August Uprising Was Planned Early in the Year
description: President Daniel arap Moi told Kenyans today that an air force uprising last August had been planned as early as last year.

title: Index; International
description: Oil blowout sowing fear in Al- berta backwoods A2 To Israeli Arabs, war in Lebanon is still a ''bad dream'' A3 Around the World A5 Quebec physician campaigning for nationwide abortion clinics A6 A two-way view of Andropov A7 Excerpts from Jaruzelski's speech A9 Salvadoran rebels kill 11 soldiers in overrunning army post A12 Bonn inquiry on bribes is spread- ing for politicians A13 Irish Labor Party agrees to form coalition A14 Washington Talk Briefing D16 The Calendar D16 Not-so-vital statistics on Moyni- han D16 Changing the rules for running the House D16 General Neighbors and companies rebuild a burned Christmas Village A1 Around the Nation A16 Colleges paying more to profes- sors in technical fields A16 New park near New Orleans fighting a tide of sewage A16 Lutherans' Missouri Synod heal- ing from 70's turmoil A20 M.T.A. might face penalty, even if it forgoes Canadian loan B4 Hanukkah is marked in a cele- bration of Jewish life B8 Soviet emigre reunited with family after long struggle B14 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the snow, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. SportsMonday Baseball: Seaver returning in late innings of career C1

title: NEW HISTORICAL PARK NEAR NEW ORLEANS TRYING TO FIGHT OFF A TIDE OF SEWAGE
description: In the bayou country south of here, appearance deceives. What looks like lonely primeval marsh is often humming with the activity of fishermen, oil drillers, surveyors, levee inspectors, game poachers, drug smugglers and, in pursuit, lawenforcement agents.

title: SOVIET EMIGRE GREETS FAMILY AT THE END OF LONG STRUGGLE
description: A tearful reunion today at National Airport ended a six-year struggle by Edward Lozansky, the Soviet emigre and human rights activist, to have his wife and 11-year-old daughter released from the Soviet Union.

title: The Editorial Notebook; In Caves, Man Is the Enemy of Art
description: A discovery of ancient cave art is a notable event - and a calamity since preservation is a shaky science. Exposure itself creates a deadly peril for works that have survived the damp darkness for hundreds, even thousands, of years.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1982; International
description: Brazil's biggest bank was rescued from default by the intervention of several New York banks after it was unable to meet more than $175 million in foreign-exchange commitments last week, banking sources said. (Page A1.)

title: ISRAELIS GETTING EINSTEIN'S PAPERS
description: The Hebrew University here has received the personal papers of Albert Einstein, a collection it said contains far more social and political commentary than scientific works.

title: HERE'S A TALE OF TWO TALES OF ANDROPOV
description: With a new leader in the Kremlin and statesmen preparing for what will probably be an intense cycle of East-West negotiations on arms control and other matters next year, rumors and ''planted information'' have begun to swirl around European capitals.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: REMARKABLE RELATIONS: The Story of the Pearsall Smith Women. By Bar- bara Strachey. Illustrated. 351 pages. Universe Books. $15.95.

title: Bridge: This Opening Lead Meant Survival or Complete Rout
description: The rubber bridge player who thinks about the opening lead is sometimes jocularly urged to ''lead the one nearest your thumb.'' Unless you have a highly intuitive thumb it is wise to use your head instead, even if it means taking a little time.

title: Shift to Riches
description: What Darrell Waltrip calls ''a typical rags-to-riches story'' has now definitely reached the ''riches'' era. The 35-year-old stock car driver from Owensboro, Ky., recently won the Grand National Winston Cup for the second consecutive year, accumulating record purses of $878,118 en route to the top spot in Nascar competition. He also won the Olsonite driver-of-the-year title for the third time. Last week in New York, he picked up checks totaling $187,000 for his driving achievements in 1982.

title: FOR CHRISTMAS GIFTS, 700 RAG DOLLS FOR THE NEEDY
description: Any Santa Claus worth a ho-ho-ho knows that, at a certain age, one doll is worth a sackful of sables and diamonds. True, dolls aren't as hockable, but would anyone be so crass as to hock Jacques the wilderness adventurer, Etthen-Oolah the Eskimo, Nicole the roller skater or Flapper Beth?

title: RECITAL: NICOLAI GEDDA, FREDRICA VON STADE
description: Anniversary concerts that opera companies offer as tributes to veteran singers tend to be predictable affairs. As many of the honored artist's ambulatory colleagues as can be rounded up are sent onstage to perform their favorite arias, smorgasbord-fashion, and everyone gets tipsy on 100-proof nostalgia. This is known as a ''gala,'' and it can be wonderful fun, in a kaleidoscopic way.

title: COLLEGE PAYING MORE TO TEACHERS IN DEMAND
description: Tom Warschauer, a finance professor at California State University at San Diego, got a little sweetener in his paycheck this fall, a small raise meant to persuade him to ignore job offers that might come his way from other schools or industry.

title: Commodities; Wary Days In Florida's Citrus Belt
description: FOR quite a few speculators, orange juice growers and orange juice processors, the weather in Florida for the next month or so is even more significant than it is for hopeful vacationers. In a week the frost season will begin to hang over the orange groves like a scythe.

title: Playing Red Light
description: It's pleasant to think that honesty is what stays the hand from the slug at the subway turnstile. That concern for the neighbors' feet has the occasional dog owner cleaning up after his dog. That respect for the wisdom of those who set speed limits keeps the accelerator off the floor. Pleasant, but naive.

title: Television Images
description: According to the recently announced results of a study taken last summer by Benton & Bowles regarding television viewers' attitudes toward sports and athletes, Jack Nicklaus, Chris Evert Lloyd and Sugar Ray Leonard are the familiar sports figures who most consistently appeal to Americans in terms of likability and believability when endorsing a product.

title: DOLE ASKS REAGAN TO OFFER GUIDANCE ON SOCIAL SECURITY
