description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, a ranking member of the Republican majority, complained today that President Reagan had failed to consult with his main allies in the Senate or with those he appointed to the commission on reforming Social Security.

title: Discount Rate Cut Is Seen by Wall St.
description: An eagerly awaited cut in the discount rate - the main instrument of credit policy now used by the Federal Reserve - is not expected before this Friday at the earliest, according to market participants.

title: Artificial Heart Recipient Remains Semiconscious
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, who received a mechanical heart 11 days ago, remained semiconscious today, his condition critical and ''basically unchanged.''

title: LONGSTANDING TRADITIONS CITED IN GIFTS MADE TO THE NEEDIEST
description: A tradition of giving is often cited as a reason for contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, with many donors continuing a practice that they or their families have carried on for 50 years or more, or even from the start of the appeal 70 years ago.

title: BEN KINGSLEY'S JOURNEY FROM HAMLET TO GANDHI
description: TWO years ago, Ben Kingsley, an actor with the Royal Shakespeare Company, was playing Mr. Squeers in the original London production of ''Nicholas Nickleby.''

title: MAJOR SNOW BLANKETS NEW YORK AREA
description: With winter still officially nine days off, the first major snowstorm of the season dusted city streets and suburban woodlands yesterday, slowing weekend traffic and leaving accumulations of two to three inches in New York City and about six inches on eastern Long Island.

title: NOT-SO-VITAL STATISTICS
description: For Senate-watchers and collectors of Moynihania, here are some little-known assertions by Daniel P. Moynihan about the senior Senator from New York:

title: CUOMO PlANS TO CONTINUE CONSTRUCTION INQUIRY
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo plans to continue a state investigation into charges of corruption in the construction industry. But Mr. Cuomo says he wants a progress report from the State Commission of Investigation before spending more money for the inquiry, which began six months ago.

title: 2 Israeli Soldiers Wounded
description: Two Israeli soldiers were wounded today when two grenades were thrown at their jeep near Nabatiye in southern Lebanon, a military spokesman said.

title: Jeanne M. Davern Memorial
description: Architects and architectural critics will speak at a memorial service for Jeanne M. Davern, former managing editor of Architectural Record and honorary member of the American Institute of Architects, who died Nov. 19. The service will be held at 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Church of Our Savior, Park Avenue and 38th Street. Participants will include Edmund Bacon, Jonathan Barnett, Paul Rudolph, Martin Filler and Frederick Gutheim.

title: People
description: * Bruce Fabricant is rejoining Grey & Davis Inc., a subsidiary of Grey Advertising, as executive vice president.

title: Jury Still Out in Texas Case
description: The jury in the trial of Charles V. Harrelson and two other people charged in the assassination of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. recessed today. It will resume deliberations Monday.

title: POP: DICK HYMAN OFFERS NEW GERSHWIN SURVEY
description: DICK HYMAN'S almost annual holiday survey of the music of George Gershwin at Michael's Pub (two years ago he switched to Irving Berlin, and last year he drew on a variety of composers, but for three years before that the focus was on Gershwin) is back on the Gershwin track this month. As in years past, he is mixing fairly familiar Gershwin with unknown Gershwin, glowingly melodic Gershwin with comic Gershwin.

title: MUSIC: LEAGUE OF COMPOSERS OFFERS ELECTRONIC CONCERT
description: ELECTRONIC music is not so ubiquitous as it once was, so Thursday evening's League of Composers-I.S.C.M. program in Carnegie Recital Hall came as a welcome opportunity to catch up on recent developments.

title: Child Case Moves Red Cross To Study Blood Donor Policy
description: The American Red Cross will review its policy for selecting blood donors following reports that a 20-month-old baby in San Francisco may have gotten an often-fatal immune deficiency from a donor, the group's director says.

title: IRISH LABOR PARTY AGREES TO FORM COALITION WITH THE PREMIER-ELECT
description: The Labor Party voted today to form a coalition government with Prime Minister-elect Garret FitzGerald's Fine Gael Party.

title: Women in England Rally Against Missiles
description: Thousands of women linked arms today to form an unbroken nine-mile chain around a British air base to protest plans to site 96 cruise nuclear missiles there.

title: Wallace Pleads for Help In Aiding the Jobless
description: Governor-elect George C. Wallace predicts ''violent and radical results,'' perhaps even deaths, if the unemployed are not helped this winter.

title: Air Force Player Critically Injured
description: Derek Foster, a running back for the Air Force Academy, remained in critical condition here today following an auto accident on Friday, and hospital authorities said he was not improving.

title: 8 SOCCER OVERTIMES BRING INDIANA TITLE
description: It took eight overtimes and 159 minutes, but for Indiana University and its soccer coach, Jerry Yeagley, the frustration finally ended late Saturday night.

title: HOW TO BUILD YOUR OWN FLY ROD
description: ANGLERS anchored in the Northeast can use the winter months to fashion their own rods and lures. With my father looking over my shoulder, I assembled my first rod, a surf stick, about 45 years ago. Actually, ''assemble'' is a somewhat grandiose term, because all that was involved was gluing a tip and wrapping a couple of guides on a 9-foot length of Calcutta bamboo. To the bamboo, using heavy marline, I lashed a big Vom Hofereel. The reel had no drag - drag was provided by a leather thumb stall - and it was better suited for trolling than casting. But I found it infinitely preferable to the surf-fishing equipment I had used up to that time: 120 yards of heavy cod line wound on a shingle.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anaconda-Ericsson Inc. signed contracts totaling $37 million with eight affiliates of the United Telephone System of Kansas City to supply them with cellular, or mobile, telephone systems.

title: Queens Youth Seized in Theft Of 136 Christmas Trees on L.I.
description: A Queens youth has been arrested in connection with the theft of 136 Christmas trees worth about $4,750 from a garden center here, the police said today.

title: WIDE COCAINE USE BY MIDDLE CLASS SAID TO THWART PROSECUTION
description: Public acceptance of the use of cocaine has become so widespread in the New York metropolitan area that some prosecutors and police officials say support for vigorous prosecution has been sharply eroded.

title: ALTERING THE WAY THE HOUSE OPERATES
description: The rules of the House of Representatives always represent a balancing act: the rights of the minority versus the rights of the majority; free discussion versus efficiency; individual independence versus party discipline.

title: GINA ELLEN LEVEY MARRIED TO KENNETH MANDELBAUM
description: Gina Ellen Levey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel M. Levey of South Orange, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to Kenneth A. Mandelbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Mandelbaum of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Barry Greene and Rabbi Samuel Cohen performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: ARTS-PANEL SKIRMISH
description: President Reagan's recently announced Committee on the Arts and Humanities, a body of distinguished citizens established to encourage private contributions to the arts, may be denied Federal funds if a House subcommittee has its way. The issue is scheduled to reach the Senate floor early this week and should eventually be resolved by a Senate-House conference. But in the meantime, it has, in a small way, served to embarrass the President and his arts policy.

title: To the Editor: Since I am mentioned in George Crile's article on your Dec. 3 Op-Ed page, ''Toppling Managua's Regime,'' I may perhaps be permitted to comment that Mr. Crile's phrase ''the Kennedys unleashed the Central Intelligence Agency against Fidel Castro'' is a contribution to historical legend.
description: As the 1975-76 Church Committee reports showed, it was the Eisenhower Administration that ''unleashed'' the Central Intelligence Agency for the purposes of assassinating Castro and organizing an exile invasion of Cuba. ARTHUR SCHLESINGER JR. New York, Dec. 3, 1982

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Oilers vs. Dallas Cowboys, at Houston. The Cowboys have won two of the last three games between the teams, which have two of the finest running backs -Tony Dorsett of Dallas (4-1) and Earl Campbell of Houston (1-4).

title: No Headline
description: SALVADOR REBELS ARE SAID TO KILL 11

title: JEFFERSON 68, LOYOLA 63
description: AS the huge crowd began to empty all at once, a couple dressed mostly in orange began to arrange the orange scarves and orange caps for a trek into the chilly night. ''Well, darlin','' the man said to his wife in an accent decidedly Blue Ridge, ''that was just about as good as we hoped it would be back in JOO-lie.''

title: U.S. ADDS 2 COUPON ISSUES
description: The Treasury will dominate new financing activity in the fixedincome market this week with the sale of two coupon issues, in addition to its regular Monday auction of three-month and six-month bills.

title: Rewarding The Loyal
description: IN the upper deck at Shea Stadium, the snow had crusted on the steep stairs between rows of empty orange seats, creating an incongruous image - ski trails in orange groves. And never since the Jets moved into the stadium in 1964 had there been as many empty seats, or as many weatherwise customers. Of all the people who had intended to use the 60,370 tickets sold for yesterday's game with the Tampa Bay Bucs, those who decided not to dogsled through the snow to Shea outnumbered those who did - 32,223 no-shows to 28,147 shows.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Citizens, the martial law Council of National Salvation is of the opinion that conditions have arisen for suspending martial law.'' - Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's martial law chief, in a speech yesterday. (A9:3.)

title: Economic Analysis
description: Last of six articles that have appeared periodically on current world economic problems

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Stardust Shower

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'A Snow Picture'

title: FEAST OF HANUKKAH IS MARKED IN A CELEBRATION OF JEWISH LIFE
description: As the Jewish Sabbath ended Saturday, a crowd of young people gathered at the Hillel Foundation at Brooklyn College to mark Hanukkah, the Feast of Lights, by enjoying themselves.

title: TENNIS: A GAME FOR THE DISABLED, TOO
description: Kathy McCaffrey did not look like a tennis player in her pale blue sweater, blue corduroys, black eye liner and wheelchair. ''I was really nervous about getting on the court,'' Miss McCaffrey, 19 years old, said as she sat alongside court one at the Point Set Indoor Racquet Club in Oceanside, L.I.

title: No Headline
description: Celtics, Led by Bird, Overtake Nuggets

title: STEELERS FALL, PASS FOR MINUS 2
description: In the last three weeks of the National Football League season, it has been bust or boom for the Pittsburgh Steelers. Yesterday, in swirling snow at Orchard Park, N.Y., it again was bust as the Buffalo Bills shut down the Steelers' aerial attack and emerged with a 13-0 victory.

title: PROPER YARDSTICKS FOR OSHA'S SERVICE TO AMERICAN WORKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WORTHINGTON MINER, PRODUCER IN THE EARLY DAYS OF TV, DIES
description: Worthington C. Miner, a leading producer in television's early days and the creator of programs such as ''Studio One,'' ''The Play of the Week'' and ''The Ed Sullivan Show,'' died Saturday in New York Hospital, where he had been admitted the day before. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mahaffey-Carner One-Shot Winner
description: John Mahaffey and JoAnne Carner combined for a two-under-par 70 today to win the $500,000 Mixed Team Classic by one shot.

title: BUDGET OFFICE IS SAID TO BE ASKING 17% CUTBACKS FOR E.P.A.
description: The Office of Management and Budget has proposed a 17 percent reduction in the budget of the Environmental Protection Agency, according to Government officials and environmentalists.

title: 'DENSE PACK' WORKS
description: Last week, the House voted to continue research and development on the MX missile but voted against its production. This week, as the Senate votes on these issues, we may ask ourselves: Why should we believe that the ''dense pack'' - the tightly-formed array of 100 missiles that the Administration proposes to build in Wyoming - is survivable? Do we even need a survivable intercontinental ballistic missile?

title: The Mayoral Cookie Jar
description: Let President Reagan keep his jelly beans. Mayor Koch seems to be doing just fine with cookies. There was the Mayor taking peanut butter cookies by helicopter to the inmates at Rikers Island on Thanksgiving Day (and reporting that a pickpocket took two).

title: CUOMO'S MAN TO TAKE OVER AS PARTY CHIEF
description: William C. Hennessy is scheduled to change careers today, going from civil servant and a state commissioner to chairman of the Democratic Party in New York State.

title: The Lions' Share
description: No collage of New York's landmarks would be complete without the brace of lions that guard the Central Research Library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue. Nor, for that matter, would a collage of national landmarks.

title: E.T. STARRING IN SALES OF TOYS
description: That stumpy guy from another planet, E.T., the Extra Terrestrial, has done pretty well for himself. Retailers say he's a toy store superstar this Christmas season, and that the hundreds of licensed products in his image - from knickknacks to night lights - will end up under a lot of Christmas trees.

title: Foote, Cone Wins Cinzano Assignment
description: Foote, Cone & Belding/New York is following the FCB/Milan office and offices serving 12 other European countries, as it picks up the assignment to do advertising for Cinzano Wines.

title: ALAN C. BOTSFORD
description: Alan C. Botsford, senior vice president of PRC Harris Inc. of New York City, an international consulting and development concern, died at St. Vincent's Hospital Thursday after suffering a collapsed lung. He was a resident of Locust Valley, L.I., and was 62 years old.

title: STATES COULD GET U.S. FUNDS BY USING NEW ROAD MIXTURE
description: The House has voted to alleviate the national solid waste problem, reduce foreign dependence on oil and increase the life expectancy of the nation's roads, all by persuading states to add old, shredded tires to conventional black asphalt when mixing pavement.

title: HAPPY DAYS FOR SLY WILLIAMS
description: Sly Williams is the type of player who is always in the middle of the action. With his flatfooted stride, he has great court sense and instincts that were developed long before he came to the Knicks as the third of three first-round draft choices in 1979. Wherever the ball is, it is there you are apt to find Williams.

title: A STUNNING DEBUT BY GIANTS' EDDINGS
description: Floyd Eddings knows how to play pro football, even if he is not sure how to celebrate. On Saturday, in Eddings's first National Football League game, Scott Brunner threw five passes at him. The rookie free agent from California caught all of them for 148 yards and helped the Giants rout the Philadelphia Eagles at Giants Stadium, 23-7.

title: Average U.S. Pay Put At $15,691 Last Year
description: The average American worker earned $15,691 in 1981, an increase of 9.2 percent over the previous year, the Labor Department reported Saturday.

title: MET PLANS BIG SHOW BY MOORE
description: Henry Moore, long regarded as one of the most distinguished of living sculptors, will be the subject of a major retrospective exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum next spring.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TOUCH OF GOTHAM

title: KEY OFFICIALS IN BONN TIED TO BRIBE CASE
description: For almost a year three investigators in the modest-looking Prosecutor's Office here have been looking into the possibility that the giant Flick holding company bribed West German Cabinet officials and other politicians in the 1970's to obtain tax waivers of $175 million.

title: TV: 'TWO WEEKS IN WINTER,' A DOCUDRAMA ABOUT POLAND
description: THE first anniversary of the suppression of Solidarity, the Polish workers movement, is commemorated tonight by television stations in this country and in Western Europe, with the showing of the BBC production ''Two Weeks in Winter.'' The program, which will be shown at 9 o'clock on WNET, Channel 13, makes strong use of smuggled film and audio tapes of the confrontations between workers and the Polish regime. Mostly, however, these 90 minutes consist of dramatizations of events that took place on the workers' side of the barricades. The end product falls into the category of docudrama. Like the oneeyed man in the kingdom of the blind, where censorship prevails, the docudrama comes into its own.

title: Question Box S. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: A ball returned in a tennis match hits the net cord, rolls over on the side of the opposing player and is trapped in the bulge of the net without touching the ground. What is the ruling?

title: THE MX INVITES ATTACK
description: The Administration's claim that the MX missile is necessary to bolster the United States' deterrent against Soviet nuclear aggression is a prostitution of the basic concept of deterrence - the notion that no nation would launch a nuclear attack because the consequences of a possible retaliation, not against their strategic nuclear missiles but against their other military and industrial targets, would be totally unacceptable. In fact, the MX would act as a magnet - would attract a Soviet attack not deter one.

title: LUTHERANS' MISSOURI SYNOD HEALING FROM BITTER POLITICAL DISPUTE OF 70's
description: As the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod moves into a new $10 million headquarters here this month, its leaders say they see few scars remaining from the struggle that split the 2.6 million-member church a decade ago.

title: Washington Watch; Money Supply: A Global View
description: WASHINGTON ONE result of the American initiative to improve the workings of the world's monetary system may be a greater attention paid to international demand for dollars in trying to control domestic money supply.

title: Choice Draftee
description: When the North American Soccer League has its annual draft of college and high school players tomorrow in New York, one of the early selections is expected to be Gerry Reardon of Adelphi. Reardon, a 5-foot-8-inch, 135-pound sweeper, has several elements working against him in the draft, but is expected to overcome them simply on the basis of his superb skills.

title: LIVINGSTON PARSONS
description: Livingston Parsons, retired vice president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, died yesterday at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. Mr. Parsons, who was a resident of Greenwich, was 88 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: ''In no other known instance in American jurisprudence,'' lawyers for Kathy Boudin contend, ''has an accused been compelled to stand trial in such a small, aroused community where the accumulated data is as massive on the issue of actual bias as that now before this court.''

title: BRAZIL'S BIGGEST BANK SAID TO GET BAILOUT CREDIT IN U.S.
description: Brazil's biggest bank, the Government-owned Banco do Brasil, was unable to meet more than $175 million in foreign exchange commitments last week and was rescued from default only by the intervention of several major New York banks, banking sources said last night.

title: AT SEAPORT TONIGHT, SCROOGE REFORMS AGAIN
description: Tonight at 7:30 in the gallery of the South Street Seaport Museum, facing the Lower Manhattan waterfront that so fascinated Charles Dickens, several of the country's leading performers will stage a reading of ''A Christmas Carol'' for the museum's benefit.

title: U.S. Navy Pilot Is Killed
description: A United States Navy pilot was killed and his co-pilot seriously injured when their Seasprite antisubmarine helicopter crashed in the Sea of Japan early Saturday morning. A Navy spokesman at the Subic Bay naval base said today that Lieut. Comdr. Kenneth Kraper, 36 years old, of Vienna, Va., was killed during routine night flying operations.

title: 49ERS SLIDE FROM A CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON TO ONE OF MISFORTUNE
description: By ones and twos, the San Francisco 49ers trickled into the locker room at their training complex today. Most of them looked weary. Many of them were still sore and bruised from the exciting but disappointing 41-37 loss the day before to the San Diego Chargers.

title: CENSUS REPORTS THAT GROWTH OF HISPANIC POPULATION IS LARGELY IN BIG CITIES
description: Hispanic people, one of the nation's fastest-growing minorities, have established communities in every region and most large cities, and yet their expansion has been so selective that almost half of them live in just 10 metropolitan areas.

title: CITY BALLET: 'NUTCRACKER' PROVIDES MANY DEBUTS
description: THE New York City Ballet's production of George Balanchine's ''The Nutcracker'' has barely reached the midpoint of its monthlong run at the State Theater and already it has come up with an unusually large number of debuts in different roles.

title: AIDE TO HEAD UNIT HARRIS IS SELLING
description: The Harris Corporation has been manufacturing printing equipment since 1895. Now it is selling that business to concentrate on electronic information equipment.

title: JURY IN TEAMSTER CASE CONTINUES DELIBERATING
description: The jury in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, sent out a question today about the ''background'' of Joseph Lombardo, one of Mr. Williams' four co-defendants.

title: ROXANNE KELBER AND MICHAEL L. TABAK ARE MARRIED
description: Roxanne Kelber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kelber of Minneapolis, was married there yesterday in the Beth El Synagogue to Michael L. Tabak, son of Frieda C. Tabak of East Rockaway, L.I., and the late Abraham S. Tabak. Rabbi Kassel Abelson performed the ceremony.

title: 1,500 STUDENTS, NOW IN SHELTERS, MISSING SCHOOL
description: About 1,500 New York City children, displaced with their families to temporary housing in hotels or shelters, have not been going to school, according to the Board of Education.

title: PUSH BY BANKS TO SELL ACCOUNT
description: In a rush of jostling, posturing and redesigning, banks and savings institutions are concocting their plans for tomorrow's debut of the new money market fund accounts.

title: Cooney Challenge Sent to Holmes
description: Gerry Cooney, who six months ago was stopped in the 13th round by the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, Larry Holmes, yesterday sent a telegram to Holmes challenging him to a four-round bout tomorrow.

title: Rogers Leads Rangers Past Devils
description: Mike Rogers scored his fourth short-handed goal of the season last night to lead the Rangers to a 4-0 victory over the New Jersey Devils at Madison Square Garden.

title: Suit Is Dismissed In Canceled Game
description: A Federal judge has thrown out a suit by the University of Washington against Florida State University for canceling a scheduled 1982 football game between the two schools.

title: NAMIBIA: NO DEAD END
description: The Reagan Administration's attempt to settle the brooding African problem of Namibia is being written off by many as a failure. But a check with people involved in the negotiations convinces me that the policy's death is exaggerated.

title: Market Place; Mobile Homes Highly Rated
description: THE recent decline in interest rates and the expected forthcoming economic recovery are supposed to be good news for manufacturers of mobile homes as well as the rest of the housing industry.

title: JETS DEFEAT BUCCANEERS, 32-17
description: Suddenly, the Jets call the snow and wind ''New York Jets weather'' - as if this wasn't the same sort of dank, bruising cold that they used to lose in.

title: SEAVER RETURNING IN LATE INNINGS
description: year-old daughter, Annie, were browsing along the shops on Brompton Road and happened into a shoe store. A particular pair of brown shoes caught his pitcher's eye in the way he might notice a batter's weakness. He felt a little ripple of pleasurable expectation.

title: POLAND WILL LIFT BASIC RESTRICTIONS BY THE YEAR'S END
description: Poland's military leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, announced tonight that the basic provisions of martial law would be suspended by the end of the year.

title: 2 FAMILIES LEAVE DIOXIN-SOIL AREA
description: Two families near this St. Louis suburb moved away today from property poisoned by the deadly chemical dioxin, unhappy with what the Government has offered to do to aid the neighborhood.

title: Addendum
description: * The Dial magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 20 percent, to 1.2 million from 1.01 million, and its national advertising rates 10 percent, effective with the March issue.

title: RETAILERS HOPING FOR LATE SURGE
description: Christmas retail sales, a rough gauge of consumer confidence that is drawing unusually intense interest this year, are barely keeping pace with last year, a spot-check at the season's halfway point shows.

title: South Carolina Coach 'Stable'
description: Bill Foster, the South Carolina basketball coach, remained in ''stable'' condition today after suffering what doctors called a ''moderate heart attack.''

title: Peking Says 15,000 Students Will Be Sent Abroad for Study
description: China plans to send 15,000 students abroad, most of them to study natural science and technology, as part of its 1981-85 five-year plan, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Cadillac-Fairview Sale
description: Cadillac-Fairview, the Toronto-based development concern, has announced that it has agreed in principle to sell General Homes Consolidated Companies, a wholly owned subsidiary, for more than $31 million to the American Savings and Loan Association of Florida and a group of investors headed by Jeffrey Payson, the present chairman of General. General is a real estate development company based in Houston.

title: REAGAN'S IDEA OF FEDERALISM IS CALLED DEAD
description: A Governor who negotiated over President Reagan's ''new federalism'' plan for the last year says the idea as Mr. Reagan imagined it is now dead.

title: NANCY COHEN, A LAWYER, MARRIES PAUL NOVOGRAD
description: The marriage of Nancy S. Cohen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Cohen of Roslyn, L.I., to Paul J. Novagrad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin J. Novagrad of New York, took place yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony.

title: CABLE TV SOLUTION: A SEPARATION OF FUNCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Kriek Retains Title

title: Aqueduct Shut
description: The snowstorm in the metropolitan area caused Aqueduct to cancel its nine-race program yesterday. Today's card was expected to be run as scheduled.

title: F.B.I. AGENT'S COMMENT ON GAMBLING RAISES STIR IN LAS VEGAS
description: In the unusual moral climate of this gambling resort city, the top agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation appears to have cooled some tempers by declaring that he did not say what he was reported to have said about prostitutes and gamblers' being all the same.

title: LIONS PULL SURPRISE IN ROUT OF PACKERS
description: For the Detroit Lions, the National Football League players' strike had seemed to have an unsettling effect. The Lions had won both of their games before the 57-day layoff, but when the team returned from the strike it not only lost three games, but also looked unimpressive.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Literature and Politics

title: Raid on White Rightists Nets South African Arms
description: The South African Press Association reported today that a sudden police swoop on a right-wing white extremist organization led to the seizure of quantities of arms, ammunition and explosives in addition to the arrest of the organization's leader and eight other men.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1982
description: International Suspension of Poland's martial law by the end of the year, was announced by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the country's military leader. He said that the basic provisions of martial law, in effect since Dec. 13, 1981, would be lifted, but warned that it was impossible to normalize political life in the country in one step, and that the Government would retain some of its extraordinary powers. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Sandinist leaders of Nicaragua should make a ''dramatic change'' in direction, Nicaragua's Ambassador to Washington said. In an interview that authorities in Managua banned from appearing in an opposition newspaper and that led to speculation that he might resign, the Ambassador, Francisco Fiallos Navarro, said Nicaragua could ease its isolation by improving relations with neigboring governments and by increasing political freedom at home. (A1:6.)

title: MCCRORY GAINS ON KNOCKOUT
description: Steve McCrory, the amateur flyweight champion from Detroit, stopped Craig Katsuda of Honolulu in the third round today in the United States Amateur Boxing Championships.

title: THE RECESSION SPEAKS
description: This is your Recession speaking. The Democrats blame me on Reaganomics and Mr. Reagan blames me on Jimmy Carter. Everybody agrees I am bad news and something must be done about me right away. Nobody appreciates my contribution to the general welfare.

title: HOLIDAYS FOR A CHILD OF DIVORCE
description: YEAR-OLD Peter wants a video game for Christmas. His father w ould like to buy him one, but his mother says absolutely not. Such d omestic disagreements emerge every year at this time, and, somehow, c ouples manage to resolve them. What complicates the holiday for thisf amily and others like it is that Peter's parents are divorced.

title: Advertising; Cola Wars Spill Onto Dr Pepper
description: AS far as the cola wars are concerned, Richard Q. Armstrong feels like one of your typical injured innocent bystanders. He feels it as the new president of Dr Pepper, just as much as he did when he was president of Canada Dry, now a Pepper subsidiary.

title: THE LAND OF THE MISSING CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIANS ACCEPT PACT AT CHRYSLER
description: Canadian workers for the Chrysler Corporation voted overwhelmingly today to approve a new contract, ending a 38-day strike that won raises for employees of the struggling automobile maker in both Canada and the United States.

title: Portugal's Ruling Parties Suffer Some Local Losses
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao said early today that his conservative coalition government would stay in office despite some losses in balloting Sunday in local Portuguese elections.

title: MICHIGAN 65, DETROIT 63
description: (AP) Robert Henderson made two free throws with 12 seconds remaining today to give Michigan (6-0) the victory. The free throws by Henderson, a 6-foot-9 forward from Lansing, completed a second-half rally by the Wolverines.

title: NEW BATTLEGROUND FOR MOFFETT
description: HONOLULU KEN MOFFETT took one large jump and a bunch of smaller steps last week. He ran a mile last Wednesday for the first time since he had heel surgery a month earlier. The day before, he leaped from the bureaucracy of Washington to the biggest battleground of baseball.

title: New Face at Marschalk
description: Going in as executive vice president and director of strategic planning at Marschalk is Stuart J. Agres, who since 1979 has been doing similar work for the Adolph Coors brewery. He succeeds Paula Drillman, who shifted over to McCann-Erickson, the big-sister company in the Interpublic Group of Companies. Mr. Agres, who has a Ph.D. in psychology, started in consumer research at the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago.

title: ARAB OF ISRAEL: WAR AND 'BAD DREAMS'
description: ''It's like just a bad dream,'' said Mohammed Nimer, who lives in this Arab town in northern Israel, describing how the Israeli invasion of Lebanon affected him as one of Israel's more than 600,000 Arab citizens.

title: Sports World Specials; A Run on Money
description: As a teller in the First National Bank of Toms River, N.J., for the last three summers, Mike Benson had become used to handling money. But Benson said that his experience was of no assistance to him Nov. 28 when he tried to handle 10,000 dollar bills.

title: U.S.O., Show of Shows
description: There's no business like show business, and no greater audience than service men and women.

title: Murder Suspect Beaten By Crowd in Brooklyn
description: An angry crowd captured and beat a man accused of fatally stabbing a Brooklyn grocery store owner early yesterday, the police said. The suspect, Edwin Figueroa, lost an eye as a result of the beating, authorities said.

title: CANADIAN DOCTOR CAMPAIGNS FOR NATIONAL ABORTION CLINICS
description: A 59-year-old physician who has successfully challenged Canadian antiabortion laws in Roman Catholic Quebec is promoting the establishment of abortion clinics for the rest of Canada.

title: DANCE: TWO NEW WORKS CREATED BY STUART PIMSLER
description: Just because a choreographer has ideas does not guarantee that his dances will automatically express those ideas. Presumably, Stuart Pimsler had lots of ideas in mind when he choreographed the two pieces that the Stuart Pimsler Dance and Theater presented Thursday night at Parkfast Dance Stadium.

title: SENATORS TO EXAMINE OFFICIAL USE OF COMPUTER DATA ON INDIVIDUALS
description: More than 200 Federal and state projects are using computers to examine the names, addresses and other information about millions of Americans, looking for waste of public funds and a variety of criminal activities.

title: News Analysis
description: In the month since the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev and the succession of Yuri V. Andropov as head of the Soviet Communist Party, the bureaucratic immobility that characterized the last period of Mr. Brezhnev's rule has shown signs of giving way to a new vigor in the Kremlin.

title: 'DRAMATIC CHANGE' IN NICARAGUA URGED BY ITS ENVOY TO U.S.
description: Nicaragua's Ambassador to Washington has called for a ''dramatic change'' in the direction of the Sandinist Government, saying that it could ease its isolation by improving relations with neighboring governments and by increasing political freedom at home.

title: Gordon Captures Run in Honolulu
description: Dave Gordon of Olympia, Wash., set a course record today in winning the 10th Honolulu Marathon against a field of about 10,000.

title: Needham Adds Clorox Brands
description: Needham, Harper & Steers, which got its foot in the Clorox door with a little new-product assignment in October, has just landed well over $10 million in billings from going brands.

title: BRIEFING
description: On Defining Victory

title: MUSIC: THE DESSOFF CHOIRS
description: THE DESSOFF CHOIRS devoted the whole of its Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall to Monteverdi's long and variegated ''Vespers of the Blessed Virgin.'' Daring in their preference for tonality over traditional church modes and passionate in their Mediterranean sense of devotion, these Vespers were dedicated to Pope Paul V in 1610.

title: Roving Boy Wins Futurity; Copelan 5th
description: Roving Boy took the lead from Desert Wine at the head of the stretch and went on to win the $811,400 Hollywood Futurity by a neck today. Copelan, the 3-2 favorite, finished fifth in the richest event ever for 2-year-old thoroughbreds.

title: No Headline
description: PATRIOTS WIN, 3-0, IN SNOW

title: TV: 'THE GREEN TABLE,' JOOSS'S ANTIWAR BALLET
description: ''The Green Table,'' created by Kurt Jooss in Germany in 1932, was brought into the repertory of the Joffrey Ballet in 1967. The work remains one of the company's outstanding achievements, and it can be seen, tonight on public television's ''Dance in America'' series.

title: NEW PRESIDENT OF CETUS IS PRODUCTS SPECIALIST
description: The Cetus Corporation, readying itself for the introduction of its biotechnology products, has named a new president and chief operating officer.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Adage Inc.'s secondary offering of 550,000 shares of common stock was sold at $37.50 a share, through L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: U.S. WIDENS CURRENCY-TRADING ROLE
description: The Reagan Administration, in a significant departure from previous policy that many people see as a shift away from the creed of monetarism, is gradually increasing the American presence in foreign-exchange markets.

title: OPERA: 2 NEW WOMEN IN 'TANNHAUSER'
description: WAGNER'S cherished ideal of music drama came close to complete realization Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: NEW MAYOR OF HARTFORD SEEKS UNITY
description: After years of noisy quarrels and political plotting, an unusual tranquillity has settled over Hartford's old City Hall on Main Street. The city fathers actually seem to be getting along.

title: LIKE THE WEATHER, BUCS WERE COLD
description: When Doug Williams, the quarterback for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, woke up yesterday morning and looked out a window of the Marriott Hotel near La Guardia Airport, he saw snow, not quite but almost for the first time.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 13, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Gromyko Plans Bonn Visit
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will pay an official visit to West Germany Jan. 16-18, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: THEATER: 'STEAMING,' BRITISH COMEDY
description: NELL DUNN'S ''Steaming'' has the most literally splashy ending imaginable: virtually its entire female cast jumps nude into an onstage swimming pool. But the real splash being made at the Brooks Atkinson, where this British comedy opened with an American company last night, has nothing to do with water - it has to do with an actress's talent. In the end, ''Steaming'' won't be remembered for its nude bathing or for its intermittent comic pleasures, but for the fact that it gives Judith Ivey her stake to stardom.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Stores Corp. has appointed Robert L. Mettler president and division chief executive officer of Joske's, San Antonio.

title: Scali, McCabe, Sloves Signs Volvo Dealers
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which since 1967 has been the agency for Volvo of America, marketers of the high-priced Swedish motor cars, has just won its first of the country's six Volvo dealer advertising association accounts.

title: Store Decides Woman Can't Work as Santa
description: A department store Santa Claus who lost her job because she is a woman says children do not mind a woman as Santa because ''when you get into a Santa suit, all they see is your nose and eyes.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Friday about the cost of home heating this winter incorrectly attributed the monthly increase from $184.67 to $239.85 facing a typical Consolidated Edison customer. The figure referred to gas heating.

title: A PRO TOUR RETURNS FIGURES TO SKATING
description: When David Santee stopped figure-skating as an amateur a year ago, he reviewed with disappointment the career options that were open to him.

title: Rumania Says It Anticipates Trade Surplus of $1.8 Billion
description: Rumania expects a trade surplus this year of at least $1.8 billion after a $300 million surplus in 1981, the official Agerpres press agency quoted Foreign Trade Minister Vasile Pungan as saying today.

title: M.T.A. CAR DEAL SAID TO REMAIN SUBJECT TO PENALTY
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority could face up to $137 million in duties on a fleet of new Canadian subway cars, even if it cancels a Canadian loan to help buy the cars, according to the Commerce Department.

title: OIL BLOWOUT IS SOWING FEAR IN ALBERTA BACKWOODS
description: The scene was a cozy mobile home with homilies to Mom, Dad and assorted virtues hanging on the wall. A half-dozen residents of this backwoods village of 65 were sitting around the kitchen table, drinking coffee and talking about unpleasant things.

title: HOYAS MATURE FAST IN LOSS TO VIRGINIA
description: The $1.25 million production of the Ralph Sampson-Pat Ewing show had an excellent one-night stand in the Capital Centre.

title: CONSULTANT WILL LEAD DIVISION OF DAN RIVER
description: William M. Fine, who operates a corporate consulting concern in New York, is joining Dan River Inc. on Jan. 3 as president of its home fashions division.

title: MUIR SUIT IS REOPENING THE DIRKS-S.E.C. BATTLE
description: The decade-long saga of the battle of Raymond L. Dirks with the Securities and Exchange Commission begins a new chapter today. Mr. Dirks, widely known for his role in exposing a fraud at the Equity Funding Corporation in 1973, is scheduled to go to trial on civil charges of securities fraud stemming from an underwriting by John Muir & Company of $6 million of Cayman Islands Reinsurance Corporation securities.

title: Flood Relief Centers Opening In Missouri
description: By United Press International Federal relief centers were being established yesterday to help hundreds of victims left homeless by flooding in Missouri.

title: Accidental Gunshot Kills Boy
description: A 9-year-old boy was killed Saturday when a pistol that his mother carried in her purse for protection discharged accidently, the police said. The boy, Antoni Dante Franklin, was pronounced dead at a hospital after a .38-caliber bullet entered his back and pierced his throat. Officers said Antoni and his mother, Wanda Franklin, 28, a registered nurse, had gone shopping and were carrying sacks of groceries to their apartment when the mother dropped her purse and the gun went off.

title: CASTRO BLAMES U.S. FOR LATIN TURMOIL
description: Fidel Castro, addressing 100,000 people at a rally here, charged that the United States, not Cuba or the Soviet Union, was disrupting Central America. He also denied that Cuba was sending Soviet arms to Latin American revolutionaries.

title: MUBARAK ASSAILS SYRIA ON P.L.O.
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, in an interview published today, accused Syria of blocking a solution to the Palestinian problem.

title: REGAN ACTS TO CLARIFY MONEY PLAN
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, responding to widespread skepticism to his call last week for an overhaul of the world's monetary system, said over the weekend that critics of his proposal were responding to misinformation.

title: No Headline
description: SHARON SAYS U.S. IDEAS ARE REASONABLE

title: FROM ASHES, NEIGHBORS FORGE A CHRISTMAS SITE
description: The Mayor called it a ''miracle.'' Santa Claus himself proclaimed it ''the best Christmas ever.'' Grown men cried.

title: JAZZ: TALKING SCAT BY JANA HAIMSOHN
description: JANA HAIMSOHN can do remarkable things with her voice. Friday at the Public Theater, she declaimed poetry and sang with smooth, swooping phrases and pinpoint articulation. She would babble a single sound - a ''b'' or a ''z'' - up from a deep contralto to a high babyish squeal, pronouncing syllables with speed and precision that would astonish a linguist.

title: NO PENSION TALKS SET BY REAGAN AND O'NEILL
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., and a White House spokesman said today that there were no plans for a meeting between President Reagan and the Speaker to discuss the financially troubled Social Security System.

title: ON NICARAGUAN BORDER RAIDERS FAN FIRES OF WAR
description: The church bells clanged furiously and the villagers came running through the trenches cut across the town square. Within five minutes, some 60 peasant women, teenagers and men of nondescript age who formed the ''first alarm'' section of the local militia were standing in formation like trained soldiers, clasping World War II Czech rifles.

title: SPANISH CHIEF TIES NATO TO GIBRALTAR
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez indicated today that his Socialist Government would look more favorably on continued membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization if progress was made in Spain's longstanding territorial dispute with Britain over Gibraltar.

title: CROWLEY MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A NEW COMPUTER IS OFFERED BY ATARI
description: Atari Inc. announced a long-awaited new home computer yesterday, but the move seemed unlikely to divert attention from the setback in video games, its main line of business. Last week projections of weaker game sales sent the stock of Atari's parent company, Warner Communications Inc., on a sharp slide.

title: Designer Sleeves For Hoyas' Ewing
description: When Georgetown and Virginia met in their long-awaited basketball game last Saturday night, Patrick Ewing and Ralph Sampson were the two most visible athletes in America. And when the cameras for the nationwide telecast of the game showed a close-up shot of Ewing, the 7-foot sophomore became the largest movable billboard in the country: Each sleeve of the T-shirt Ewing wore beneath his Georgetown jersey carried a patch in the shape of a basketball shoe with the logo of the Nike Shoe Company.

title: Walker Scores Off Field
description: Herschel Walker, who earned the Heisman Trophy with his dazzling performances on the football field, is now credited with heroics off the field as well. The Georgia tailback ripped the door off an overturned car Sunday in Athens, Ga., and rescued a 67-year-old woman who had been trapped inside.

title: MONKEY BREAD
description: One staple of the Reagan family's Christmas dinner has always been ''monkey bread,'' a round, heavy, pull-apart loaf with a slightly sweet taste.

title: BRIEFS
description: * * AMCA International Corp. said it had purchased the business and certain assets of Chemetron Process Equipment Inc. of Louisville, Ky., a unit of Allegheny International Inc., for an undisclosed amount.

title: MCI Will Offer Service to Canada
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it will offer discount phone service to Canada on a trial basis starting next April, at prices from 10 percent to 30 percent below rates charged now.

title: JUDGE FRIESS, CENSURED FOR LODGING SUSPECT IN '80, SAID TO BE RESIGNING
description: Judge Alan I. Friess of Criminal Court, who was censured last year by a panel on judicial conduct for having allowed a woman accused in a murder case to spend a night in his home, has resigned, city and court officials said yesterday.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: While many heart specialists have agreed that coronary artery bypass surgery improves the quality of life for a considerable number of those suffering from angina pectoris, there has been dispute over whether such surgery actually lengthens lives. But a newly published major study indicates that men under 65 suffering from mild to moderate angina who undergo bypass surgery have a ''highly significant'' advantage in survival over those who receive nonsurgical medical treatment.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart published yesterday listing metropolitan areas with the highest percentage of black residents incorrectly identified the sixth-ranked area. It is Petersburg, Va.

title: MITTERRAND NOW FAVORS A MISSILE COMPROMISE
description: President Francois Mitterrand, who will meet here Tuesday with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, has modified his support for the American negotiating position in the talks with the Soviet Union on medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: Monmouth Victor
description: Mason McBride, a freshman forward, tipped in a shot by his teammate, Wilson Ross, with two seconds remaining tonight to give Monmouth College a 65-63 victory over C.W. Post in a Big Apple Conference opener for both teams.

title: Books Of The Times
description: AM I GETTING PAID FOR THIS? By Betty Rollin. 311 pages. Little, Brown. $14.95.

title: EMERGING NEW DETAILS INDICATE SOYUZ TROUBLE
description: Details now emerging about a Soviet space flight that ended Friday after a record 211 days indicate that the two astronauts had a harrowing re-entry, with their craft rolling across a Central Asian steppe swept by a blizzard.

title: 4 Yale Students Win Top Villa-Lobos Prizes
description: Four students from the Yale University School of Music received the top four prizes in the Second International Villa-Lobos Cello Competition, held in Rio de Janeiro last month.

title: Ginnie Mae Suit by U.S.
description: The Justice Department sued a Puerto Rican mortgage company today charging that it had defrauded the Government National Mortgage Association of more than $2 million.

title: WHITE'S PASSING PACES COWBOYS VICTORY
description: Danny White threw three touchdown passes, two to Butch Johnson, and Michael Downs returned a fumble 86 yards for a touchdown as the Dallas Cowboys trounced the Houston Oilers, 37-7, tonight.

title: PILL CASE SUSPECT FOUND IN NEW YORK
description: A fugitive charged in a plot to extort $1 million in the Chicago area Tylenol deaths was seized by Federal agents in New York City yesterday afternoon.

title: CANADA OIL: SIGNS OF AN UPTURN
description: Two years after the imposition of a tough national energy policy sent half the nation's oil rigs across the border into the United States, Canada's federal and provincial governments are providing new incentives for the troubled industry and signs of recovery are beginning to emerge.

title: LEBANESE AIDE WARNS OF NEW FIGHTING
description: Lebanon's Foreign Minister said today that unless Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces withdrew from Lebanon within the next four weeks, his nation would face a ''dangerous'' security situation that could lead to war.

title: LIFE ON A MOON OF JUPITER
description: It is barely possible that extraterrestrial life might be lurking in small ''oases'' beneath the ice of Europa, one of Jupiter's moons, two space agency scientists believe.

title: U.S. Awaits Lisbon Chief; Votes Are Being Counted
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao leaves Tuesday for a two-day official visit to the United States, leaving behind a shaken Government coalition still assessing Sunday's nationwide local elections.

title: REAGAN IS ASSURED BY DANE OF BACKING ON MISSILE POLICY
description: The Prime Minister of Denmark assured President Reagan today that his country continued to support deployment of American medium-range missiles in Western Europe even though its Parliament cut off funds for the missiles last week.

title: Pepsico's Inquiry
description: Pepsico Inc. said it had concluded its investigation of falsified reports by its company-owned foreign bottling operations.

title: WAR HAS COME A LONG WAY SINCE PEARL HARBOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Required Reading Radio Marti Critique
description: Senator Paul Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, in debate on funding for Radio Marti, the radio station proposed by the Reagan Administration to transmit broadcasts from the United States to Cuba. Dec. 6, 1982:

title: FRANKFURTER PAID TRIBUTE AS CITY COLLEGE REMINISCES
description: Felix Frankfurter - Supreme Court Justice, lawyer, scholar, mentor and a graduate of City College's class of 1902 - was honored yesterday by his alma mater at a luncheon marking the centenary of his birth.

title: PATIENCE F. STEVENSON
description: Patience F. Stevenson, a former vice president of the women's board of the Boys Club of New York, died of Alzheimer's disease on Saturday at Carolton Hospital in Fairfield, Conn.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: They'll Ride Forever ...

title: F.D.I.C., FED CLASH ON DREYFUS
description: The Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation clashed today over whether the Dreyfus Corporation, a major mutual fund company, should be allowed to purchase a bank.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET DISCUSS NAMIBIA
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have been conducting high-level talks on South-West Africa and on Cuban troops in Angola, officials in Washington said today.

title: Puppies Are Made Bad The sight of a child playing tug-of-war with a puppy warms the cockles of many parents' hearts. But such a game can often be a losing one for both dog and child, a Purdue University scientist says.
description: Dr. John Stump, professor of veterinary anatomy at Purdue's Center for Applied Ethology and Human/Animal Interactions, has observed that playing tug-of-war leads a puppy to adopt destructive habits. After many sessions of rope-tugging, he says, a dog looks at the world differently than it did before.

title: THE RETREAT IN PLANT SPENDING
description: When officials at the Dravo Corporation decided three years ago to move into a new office building in downtown Pittsburgh, they had no idea that a prolonged economic downturn was on the way. The engineering and construction company budgeted some $21 million in 1982 to cover the cost of moving and buying new equipment for what was to be called Dravo Tower, a 54-story edifice.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS LOAN RATE
description: The Federal Reserve Board, in a move intended to stimulate the long-awaited economic recovery, today cut its key lending rate to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent, effective Tuesday.

title: KELLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
QUICKPRINT OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WOOLFOLK KICK DUTY DEFENDED
description: The Giants' Butch Woolfolk is the only starting running back in the National Football League who is also used by his coaches to return kickoffs. The practice could be considered questionable because there is sentiment among other coaches around the league that returns are a dangerous pastime to which a valuable young back should not be exposed.

title: Mingo-Jones Gets Multivisions Account
description: When Mingo-Jones Advertising, New York, started five years ago, the founders, Frank L. Mingo and Caroline R. Jones, both blacks, were determined that it would be a general agency rather than ethnic specialists.

title: British Production Off
description: The output of all British industries fell four-tenths of 1 percent in October from the month before, the Central Statistical Office reported today.

title: Katharine Hepburn Injured in Car Crash
description: The actress Katharine Hepburn injured her right ankle today when a car she was driving went out of control on a snowy road and hit a utility pole, the police said.

title: JERSEY'S LEGISLATURE VOTES TO RAISE LEGAL DRINKING AGE FROM 19 TO 21
description: The New Jersey Assembly gave final legislative approval tonight to a bill raising the legal drinking age from 19 to 21, effective Jan. 1. Governor Kean has said he would sign the bill, which passed on a vote of 48 to 26, seven more than needed.

title:
TV SPORTS;
ANNE SIMON SHOWS GRACE UNDER FIRE
description: U ntil recently, a teen-age girl interested in a career as a sports broadcaster on network television might have concluded that she needed to win an Olympic medal or a Miss America pageant to qualify. Phyllis George, a former Miss America, and an assortment of former athletes were the only female sports commentators on any of the three major networks until this September. Then ABC Sports hired Anne Simon.

title: A CONTEST FOR NO. 1 IN WOMEN'S TENNIS
description: Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd offered contrasting opinions today on whether this week's Toyota tennis championships would decide the year's best woman player.

title: CONGRESS'S CHANCE TO BACK MASS TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE SOX GET BANNISTER
description: Floyd Bannister, the most sought-after free agent in this year's re-entry draft, agreed in principle to a five-year contract with the Chicago White Sox today.

title: PENNINGTON HAILE
description: Pennington Haile, a lecturer on international relations and former assistant director of the League of Nations Association, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 79 years old and lived in Norwich, Vt.

title: Dan River Plants
description: Dan River Inc., a textile company based in Danville, Va., said it planned to close two manufacturing facilities because of poor markets, imports and the general economic recession. The affected plants are Dan River's warp knit operations in Burlington, N.C., which has 300 employees, and its Crystal Springs printing and finishing plant in Chickamauga, Ga., with another 300 workers. Dan River also said it had rejected Carl C. Icahn's latest offer to buy two million shares, or about 50 percent, of Dan River common stock at $18 a share.

title: Sri Lanka Starts Flood Relief
description: Sri Lanka began a major relief operation today after monsoon floods killed at least 24 people and left thousands homeless. Government officials said at least 23 people were buried by landslides, one person was drowned and nine were missing.

title: INVENTORIES DOWN 0.1% IN OCTOBER
description: Business inventories edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in October despite an unusually sharp 2.2 percent drop in business sales, the Government reported today. The month-to-month sales decline was the biggest since the 1975 recession.

title: Chess: A Bold Sacrifice by Karpov Triumphs in Excellent Style
description: Just before the Olympiad, Anatoly Karpov won the sixth elite allgrandmaster Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, with a 7 1/2-3 1/2 score. This was the fourth time out of his four appearances that the 31-year-old Russian world champion had taken first prize. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Karpov 5 1 5 7 1/2 Timman 3 0 8 7 Andersson 2 0 9 6 1/2 Sosonko 4 2 5 6 1/2 Petrosian 3 2 6 6 Smyslov 2 1 8 6 Nunn 2 3 6 5 Portisch 2 3 6 5 Browne 2 3 6 5 Huebner 1 3 7 4 1/2 Torre 1 3 7 4 1/2 Larsen 1 7 3 2 1/2

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Lanier, the Milwaukee Bucks' center, will undergo more surgery on his right knee, and its expected to be out for at least four weeks. Coach Don Nelson said he hoped the surgery would lead to Lanier having ''a sounder knee on which to finish the season.''. ... Tom Hansen, an assistant executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, has been offered the post of executive director of the Pacific-10 Conference, to succeed Wiles Hallock. ... Jack Morris, a right-handed pitcher with Detroit, will become the highest-paid player in Tiger history under a four-year contract worth $3.2 million, according to The Detroit News. ... The Centrum in Worcester, Mass., will be the site of Marvelous Marvin Hagler's Feb. 11 defense of his world middleweight title against Tony Sibson of Britain.

title: IN CONGRESS, A RISING TIDE TOWARD PROTECTIONISM
description: To the dismay of the Reagan Administration, a rising mood of protectionism that emerged strongly during the election campaign has begun to impinge on a variety of legislation in the final rush of Congress.

title: Lloyd's to Name Outside Chief
description: The newly formed governing council of Lloyd's of London has unanimously decided to appoint the first independent chief executive for the troubled insurance exchange.

title: Advertising Chanel's New Wave TV Spots
description: IN this age when advertising copy testing seems to be the order of the day among big advertisers, it is interesting to note that Chanel, whose latest far-out, new wave TV commercial for Chanel No.5 began running on the networks on Nov. 26, never subjected it to copy testing.

title: Last-Minute Funds Buy Site of Dr. King Slaying
description: A citizens' group, hoping to build a monument to the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., put together $144,000 today to buy the small, run-down motel where the civil rights leader was killed.

title: BRANDEIS OFFERS PAY-NOW FEES AT FIXED PRICES
description: Next year Brandeis University will offer parents an opportunity to insulate themselves from as much as $4,000 in tuition increases by paying in advance for all four years of their children's college education.

title: 10 FILIPINO JOURNALISTS ARRAIGNED
description: Ten Filipino journalists pleaded not guilty today to charges of subversion and conspiracy to overthrow the Government. The defendants were brought from isolation cells at Fort Boniface outside Manila for their arraignment before a civilian judge. The hearing before Judge Jose Castro was delayed for two hours because the courtroom could not accommodate the 30 defense lawyers, the large press contingent and the crowd of sympathizers.

title: New Head of Warnaco Optimistic About Future
description: Robert J. Matura, who will become president and chief operating officer of Warnaco Inc. Jan. 1, thinks the apparel company has picked the right path in the faltering industry.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Business and the Law; A Plan to Limit Pretrial Work
description: MOST laymen think litigation means trials. Most lawyers, however, know better: What litigation really means is months or years of pretrial discovery. And to many lawyers and judges - not to mention clients - pretrial discovery all too often means harassment, delay and enormous costs.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
American Leisure Casino-Hotel Pact
description: The American Leisure Corportion said it had agreed in principle with Huber Hunt & Nichols, general contractors based in Indianapolis, to build a casino-hotel in Atlantic City for a guaranteed maximum price of $150 million.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: CHRISTMAS finally came, in every store window, on every counter, in e veryone's mind in the city. And if some of the merchandise, especially the accessories, looks s uspiciously familiar, it is because it has been saved from last y ear. That sort of retail sleight of hand, however, will not escape t he discerning fashion eye. Nothing looks more passe these days than a ll of those wooden cuffs hand-painted with New Wave squiggles, s tudded suede scarves or earrings made of big, black plastic t riangles that have been dusted off for another go-round. Still, t here were new things to be found, and at least one new store.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Big Scam in a Little Bank

title: CONCERT: 'MESSIAH' BY THE MASTERWORK
description: FOR 20-odd years, the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra, under the direction of David Randolph, have been presenting a series of annual New York performances of Handel's ''Messiah.'' At Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoon, Mr. Randolph and his forces presented their first thoughts of the season on a great subject.

title: MOTTO OF RAIDERS IS 'THROW DEEP'
description: On the final weekend of the 1963 American Football League season, the Oakland Raiders defeated the Houston Oilers, 52-49, on a field goal in the final seconds of play. The Raiders' young quarterback, Tom Flores, threw for 407 yards and six touchdowns, one touchdown more than George Blanda threw for the Oilers.

title: U.S. Officer Appointed For Credit du Nord Unit
description: Credit du Nord, a large French bank, is seeking to expand in the United States and has named James. R. Drumwright to do the job. Mr. Drumwright, 53, will be the bank's chief executive for the United States, a newly created position. Credit du Nord, with assets of $9 billion, began operations here three years ago when it sent Luc de Clapiers, 37, to be its representative in New York.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Frigid Ground-Breaking

title: Rams Eyeing Reeves
description: Dan Reeves, the Denver Broncos coach, is reportedly a candidate under consideration to replace Ray Malavasi as coach of the Los Angeles Rams, according to The Denver Post.

title: MUSIC: BERLIOZ'S SACRED ORATORIO
description: HECTOR BERLIOZ'S sacred trilogy ''L'Enfance du Christ'' combines soloists and a full-sized chorus with a delicate scoring for chamber orchestra.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $52,000 and an extraordinary credit of $346,000...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $59,000 and an extraordinary credit of $1,081,000

title: RAMPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PATIENT IS LITTLE CHANGED
description: Dr. Barney B Clark, the first human to receive a permanent artificial heart, was alert for longer periods this weekend and watched football games on television in his room at the University of Utah Medical Center.

title: Pabst Bids Altered
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company said its HBC Acquisition unit had amended terms of its offer for the Pabst Brewing Company to raise the number of shares sought to 5.6 million at $29 a share, from 3.75 million shares at $29 a share, which remains the minimum number of shares sought. Separately, Paul Kalmanovitz, who is also seeking Pabst shares, said holders whose shares were not bought would receive Pabst notes with a face amount of $26 a share, with 15 percent annual interest. He is offering $32 a share for up to 4.2 million shares.

title: TICKET BOOTH TO OPEN IN BRYANT PARK
description: Half-price tickets for music and dance (but not theater) events will be sold on the day of performance in a booth that will be set up on the 42d Street side of Bryant Park next spring.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $1.7 million for the qr and $2,950,000 for the 9 mos, a pretax gain of $2,036,000 on the sale of marketable securities; excludes pretax operating expenses of $2,076,000 charged to reserve for store closing costs and pretax proceeds of $2.5 million from the sale of real estate assetscredited to the reserve in the fourth qr...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $21,370,000 for the qr and $43,544,000 for the 9 mos

title: Rail Line Restored
description: Commuter rail service between Waterbury and Bridgeport, knocked out by flooding last June, will be restored Wednesday, the State Transportation Department said today. Buses have provided substitute service while repairs were made on the Turkey Brook Bridge in Milford.

title: WIFE OF DIAMOND DEALER IS SENTENCED IN TAX CASE
description: The wife of a former diamond dealer was sentenced to three years in prison and fined $35,000 yesterday in Manhattan on tax-evasion charges stemming from a $5 million fraud case in which her husband was involved.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AS THEY WERE

title: A BEHAVIORAL THERAPY FOR CANCER DRUG NAUSEA
description: MANY of the drugs used in cancer chemotherapy cause debilitating nausea and vomiting, and one-fourth of patients treated with the potent drugs develop these symptoms in anticipation of their next treatment.

title: St. Peter's Wins
description: Riley Scott scored 13 points to help St. Peter's (5-0) to an 82-45 victory over Allentown tonight. St. Peter's outscored Allentown by 14-2 in the opening seven minutes, and Allentown never came within 10 points after that.

title: MUSIC: PREVIN LEADING THE PIITTSBURGH
description: THE Pittsburgh Symphony, under the direction of Andre Previn, continues to be in the front ranks of our second-rank orchestras. No disrespect is intended by this statement; Mr.Previn is an able and sensitive conductor, the Symphony boasts many fine players and shows a healthy willingness to experiment.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY ASKS A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: Against opposition from the United States and its European allies, the General Assembly called on the major powers today to freeze the output and emplacement of nuclear weapons.

title: POLISH EXILES CHARGE THOUSANDS ARE HELD UNDER MARTIAL LAW
description: Calling for new sanctions against the Polish Government, a group of Polish exiles and American supporters of the Solidarity union yesterday made public the names of 933 people who it said were serving jail terms of six months to 10 years for violating martial law in Poland.

title: ERNESTINE FRIEDLAENDER
description: Ernestine Friedlaender, former president of the Women's City Club of New York, died of cancer Saturday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: I.M.F. URGED TO EXPAND LOAN CAPACITY FASTER
description: Leaders of an international group of bankers and bank regulators, meeting here today, urged the International Monetary Fund to prepare to borrow money from commercial banks or issue bonds.

title: TWO POLISH DEFECTORS ONE YEAR LATER
description: Romuald Spasowski, the former Polish Ambassador to the United States and once one of the capital's most elegant entertainers, has disappeared from the Washington scene. But Zdzislaw Rurarz, Warsaw's former Ambassador to Japan and once the very model of the Polish Foreign Service officer, is conducting what he describes as a ''war'' against the current Polish regime.

title: SHULTZ DISCUSSES POLAND WITH POPE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz discussed developments in Poland with Pope John Paul II today and said later that the steps announced so far by the Polish authorities to ease martial law did not seem to meet the allies' criteria for lifting economic and political sanctions.

title: Brazil's Debt Burden
description: No precise statistics are available concerning Brazil's foreign debt, but bankers estimate the current total at $89 billion. Debts

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Colonial Bank Investment
description: The First National Boston Corporation has agreed in principle to invest $25 million in the Connecticutbased Colonial Bank, whose London branch has encountered problems with loans to Greek shipowners, Colonial Bank's senior lending officer, Bob Mariano, said today.

title: SHULTZ AS FRIEND OF ACADEMIC FREEDOM-ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Vaughan Is Appointed Chief Doubleday Editor
description: Samuel S. Vaughan has been named editor in chief of Doubleday Publishing Company, and Thomas H. Guinzburg, former president of the Viking Press, has joined Doubleday as senior consulting editor.

title: TV: REPORT ON 'WHITE COLLAR MOB'
description: AT 8 tonight, WOR-TV, Channel 9, commemorates the 25th anniversary of the famous gathering of alleged Mafia caporegimes in Apalachin, N.Y. ''White Collar Mob,'' a one-hour documentary presided over by F. Lee Bailey, the lawyer, begins with the unsupported estimate that criminal enterprises are second only to America's oil industry in gross profits and are No. 1 in net profits. It concludes with the dire warning that the economic and political power of white-collar criminals ''may soon make them impossible to fight.''

title: Payless Cashways
description: Payless Cashways Inc., operator of a chain of building-materials retail outlets, said it had a definitive agreement to buy all of the capital stock of Lumberjack Stores Inc., Sacramento, Calif., and certain of the assets of a related real estate partnership for a total of $26.3 million.

title: CONCERT: CONDUCTORLESS ORPHEUS ORCHESTRA
description: WITHIN us all, tamed by civilization but capable of the occasional anarchic growl, lurks an instinctive dislike of conductors. Of critics, too, for that matter, but let's hurry on. Conductors incur the wrath not just of musicians but of the musician within us all: someone who plays nothing yet who stands mightily on high, hogging the plaudits that should rightly go to the people who actually make the music.

title: A Look Back
description: The clothes style has changed, as have the clubs and golf balls, but not the scene: several men practicing their putting indoors. Except the scene, as depicted on the United States Golf Association's Christmas cards this year, was probably set in a British men's ''eating club'' circa 1820.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bowne & Co. has named Franz Von Ziegesar president and chief executive officer, succeeding Victor Simonte Jr., who is retiring at year-end.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-After a charge of $400,000 from nonrecurring expenses associated with the closing of two Florida locations and other matters

title: Tom Seaver: Met Manager
description: W ith the Mets and Tom Seaver negotiating his return this week, the discussions should involve more than the length of his contract as a pitcher. His eventual future in the Mets' front office or in the dugout as the manager should also be explored. Until he was traded to the Cincinnati Reds in 1977 at the pique of M. Donald Grant's career as the Mets' chairman, Tom Seaver was known as the ''franchise.'' Now that he is about to return, the new owners should make sure that the franchise remains in the franchise.

title: Ike Turner Out on Bail
description: Ike Turner, a musician who was arrested last week on drug charges, has been freed on $5,000 bail. Mr. Turner, 46 years old, who was charged with possession of cocaine last Thursday, was freed on bail the next day, a sheriff's deputy, Ralph Martin, said Sunday.

title: RECOUNT
description: The continuing battle for the governorship of Illinois seems more heated than it was before the election. Former Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, a Democrat, formally filed last week for a recount of the election, which he lost to Gov. James R. Thompson by 5,074 votes. Today, the court set a hearing next Tuesday for the two sides to argue the suit.

title: Soviet Grain Imports
description: The Soviet Union's total grain imports this year are expected to be 35 million metric tons, sharply down from last year's record 46 million metric tons, the Agriculture Department said today in a revised forecast that was two million tons below the one made a month ago. The 1982 grain harvest is estimated at 180 million metric tons, far short of Moscow's goal of 236 million tons, but up from last year's harvest of 160 million tons.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Minstrelsy at Macy's

title: COSMOS TRADE WEGERLE
description: Steve Wegerle, the speedy South African wing, was traded by the Cosmos to Fort Lauderdale yesterday for the Strikers' first choice in the North American Soccer League draft today and the Strikers' top draft choice next year.

title: EX-WARNER AIDES PUT ON PROBATION
description: Steven J. Ross, the chairman of Warner Communications, was described by a Federal prosecutor yesterday as ''the real culprit'' in a fraud case involving the company's purchase of stock in the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: Arizona Is Sued By Tucson Paper
description: The Tucson Citizen filed suit today against the University of Arizona in an effort to obtain the release of information about the National Collegiate Athletic Association's investigation of the school's athletic department.

title: Kuwait Backs $34 Oil Price
description: Kuwait backed OPEC's oil reference price of $34 a barrel in talks today between the Venezuelan energy minister, Humberto Calderon Berti, and Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, sources familiar with the talks said today.

title: CON ED'S USE OF COAL WOULD HARM ASTHMA SUFFERERS, A WITNESS SAYS
description: An air pollution specialist testified yesterday that allowing the Consolidated Edison Company to burn coal instead of oil at three generators in New York City would mean more illness and death among an estimated 700,000 asthmatics in the metropolitan area. The utility has asserted that burning coal would add only slightly to air pollution without violating Federal regulations.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. In the first of five straight games against the top teams in the Eastern Conference, the Knicks seek their third victory over the Pistons this season. (Television -MSG Cable, 7 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio -WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) College Games: Manhattan at St. Francis, 5:30 P.M.; New York Tech at Old Westbury, 7:30 P.M.; City College at Hunter, 8 P.M.; Medgar Evers at Baruch, 8 P.M.; Ohio State at Syracuse (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.); Tennessee at Louisiana Tech, women's game (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Buffalo Sabres, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 8:05 P.M. This is the Islanders' first game of the season with the Sabres, one of the few teams to hold an overall advantage over them, with 24 victories 12 defeats 8 ties. (Television -Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; WALK-FM, 95.7; 8 P.M.) Minnesota North Stars vs. Hartford Whalers, at Bloomington, Minn. (Television - USA Cable, 8:30 P.M.) Tennis Toyota Championships, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7 P.M. Seventeen of the top players on the women's tour compete for $300,000 in a series-ending tournament of singles and doubles. In tonight's opening match, at 7 o'clock, Bonnie Gadusek plays Wendy Turnbull, followed by Barbara Potter against Virginia Ruzici, and in doubles, Paula Smith and Candy Reynolds against Leslie Allen and Mima Jausovec.

title: NEW YORK STATE PANEL DUE TO ASK A FREEZE ON HOSPITAL CONSTRUCTION
description: An advisory committee appointed by Governor Carey will recommend today a statewide freeze on about $5 billion in planned hospital construction, state officials said yesterday.

title: Chrysler's Canadian Workers Return to Plants After Strike
description: Chrysler's six Canadian plants started production again today after a 38-day strike that brought wage gains for both Canadian workers and Chrysler workers in the United States.

title: Guns That Strike Home
description: As the fear of crime increases, so do sales of guns to homeowners - a phenomenon that foes of gun control rarely question. But two recent news items again challenge the assumption that a gun in the home makes a family more secure.

title: Dome Canada Ltd.
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s Dome Canada Ltd. said it had received $65 million from the Arctic Petroleum Corporation of Japan, which represents a group of private and public sector Japanese interests. It said that the payment completes a $400 million exploration loan to Dome Petroleum and Dome Canada, and that the proceeds would be used for its exploration program in the Beaufort Sea.

title: NICARAUGA GETS LOAN TO MEET INTEREST DEBT
description: A group of foreign banks has agreed to grant Nicaragua $25 million to $30 million in short-term trade credits as part of an arrangement to meet a $40 million interest payment due Friday on Nicaragua's oustanding debt, Nicaraguan officials said today.

title: IN BUFFALO, THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE FOCUS IS ON A BETTER FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, George Vecsey's column yesterday in SportsMonday misquoted Coach John Thompson of the Georgetown University basketball team. When asked whether Virginia's players should be ranked first in the news-agency polls, Coach Thompson used a double negative, saying that they ''do not not deserve it.''

title: Nicaragua Says Envoy To U.S. Has Not Quit
