description: A spokesman for the Nicaraguan Embassy here said today that Nicaragua's Ambassador to Washington, Francisco Fiallos Navarro, had not resigned from his post here and was ''working with the revolution.''

title: PLAYS
description: I t isn't too often that a burglar wins a standing ovation as a football hero of the New England Patriots. Mark Henderson, a 24-yearold felon from Walpole, Mass., could still hear the roar of the crowd yesterday as he resumed his menial duties under a work-release program from the Norfolk Pre-Release Center. He was still being acclaimed from Salem to Ashley Falls by grateful Massachusetts football fans for his sweeping role in the Patriots' 3-0 victory over the Miami Dolphins on Sunday.

title: THREE MILE ISLAND OPERATOR CRITICIZES PLANT INSTRUCTIONS
description: A control panel operator on duty at Three Mile Island when the nuclear plant had its accident testified yesterday that the training he received from the plant's manufacturer misled him in dealing with the mishap.

title: Kuwait Puts Damper On Holiday Festivities
description: Kuwait today banned parties to celebrate Christmas or the New Year in hotels, clubs or public places and Interior Ministry sources said offenders would be punished.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Chairmen With Heart

title: Coach's Condition Is Improving
description: Bill Foster, the South Carolina basketball coach, remained in guarded condition today, but doctors said his heart had ''stabilized nicely'' since Sunday.

title: The Other Ayala
description: There was a time when Mike Ayala was the best known of four fighting brothers from San Antonio. He was the North American Boxing Federation junior featherweight champion who fought for the World Boxing Council featherweight championship in 1979 against Danny Lopez.

title: Nabisco Brands
description: The Justice Department said it is challenging the lease by Nabisco Brands Inc. of two corn ''wet'' milling plants to the Archer-Daniels Midland Company. Assistant Attorney General William F. Baxter, head of the antitrust division, said a suit will allege that the deal violates Section 1 of the Sherman Act, which prohibits contracts that restrain trade, and Section 7 of the Clayton Act, which prohibits acquisitions that substantially reduce competition.

title: BOMARKO INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $2,356,000 from discontinued operations...C-Ne t income after a loss of $677,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $46,000

title: Ali Exhibition Set
description: The Korean Boxing Commission says Muhammad Ali will fight an exhibition bout in Seoul or Pusan later this month to raise funds for a foundation in memory of Duk-Koo Kim, the South Korean who died of injuries received in his lightweight title match against Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini. Ali is expected to box an eight-round exhibition on Dec. 25 or 26. His opponent has not yet been determined.

title: Soccer Aide Said To Be Executed
description: A firing squad in Suriname has executed a high official of the Federation Internationale de Football Association, soccer's world governing body, the federation reported today.

title: Houston Lighting Write-Off Possible
description: Houston Industries said it might have to charge up to $166 million, or $2.10 a share, against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect a recent decision by the Texas Public Utility Commission on rates for its Houston Lighting and Power subsidiary.

title: GUNMEN ROB BRONX COMPANY OF $5.3 MILLION
description: Two men in ski masks, one carrying a shotgun, surprised the lone guard at a Bronx armored car company Sunday night and carried off an estimated $5.3 million packed in moneybags, the police said yesterday.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Deal
description: The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation said today that it had formed a partnership with Sumitomo Metal Industries of Japan for the manufacture and marketing of industrial titanium products. The partnership, the ALS Metals Company, will manufacture and market pure titanium, sheet, strip, plate and welded tubing for industrial application in the United States and Canada.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Asarco Inc. filed with the S.E.C. for an offering of two million common shares through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: POLISH PARLIAMENT GETS 3 BILLS EASING POWER OF MILITARY
description: The Polish authorities announced measures today that they said would ''suspend'' martial law. The action left the state with sweeping powers and shifted other curbs to the regular penal code.

title: A.T.&T. to End Hotel Payment
description: Thirty-eight years after it began the practice, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is about to stop paying long-distance commissions to hotels that amount to about $70 million a year. The result, at least in the short run, is likely to be higher phone charges for travelers.

title: 21 Colombian Rebels Yield
description: Twenty-one leftist guerrillas, 15 men and six women, surrendered over the weekend to the Roman Catholic Bishop of Florencia, Jose Luis Serna, and applied for amnesty, the Bishop said today.

title: Walton to Play More
description: Bill Walton is apparently ready to devote himself fully to basketball. According to Coach Paul Silas, Walton has said he will drop out of Stanford law school and begin playing full time for the San Diego Clippers in early January, if the doctors give him their approval next week.

title: AUGUSTYNIAK PLAYING UNAFRAID
description: A year after an injury that might have killed him, the recovery of Mike Augustyniak can be measured by his return to the starting fullback spot in the Jet offense. It can also be measured by what he did not do on Sunday. When the Jets took the field for the game against Tampa Bay, a white rib guard remained on a hook in the rear of Augustyniak's locker. ''I forgot to put it on,'' he said. ''I would have had to take off all my clothes to put it on. I thought I'd chance it.''

title: MUSIC: 2 ELECTRONIC WORKS
description: FRANKIE MANN'S ''Music Without Fans'' brought July to the Kitchen on Saturday, in the form of two tape pieces. ''Bandaid for Groundwave Aggression'' was ''a portrait of New York in July''; ''Perpetrator'' portrayed the South in July.

title: SEAVER HAS TALKS WITH METS' CASHEN
description: Tom Seaver met yesterday with Frank Cashen, the general manager of the Mets, in negotiations that are expected to bring the three-time Cy Young Award winner back to Shea Stadium.

title: Plea for Cuban Players
description: Jose Cardenal, the retired veteran of many major-league clubs, including the Mets, says he realizes that international politics may thwart his objective, but he still hopes young players from his native Cuba can be allowed to get to the majors. ''I've never seen so many good players,'' he said after a visit to his homeland. ''I think that with a year of minor-league experience, seven out of 10 could make it in the big leagues.''

title: CASUALTIES MOUNT IN LEBANESE STRIFE
description: Fighting among Lebanese has overshadowed efforts by the Government of President Amin Gemeyal to remove foreign forces from this country.

title: Tambellini Out 10 Days
description: The New Jersey Devils say that Steve Tambellini, who was injured in the 4-0 loss to the Rangers Sunday night, will be sidelined for about 10 days. X-rays revealed that the 24-year-old center had suffered a slight separation in his left shoulder in the second period of the Devils' fifth consecutive loss and third shutout of the season. ... Emile Francis, coach and president of the St. Louis Blues, said yesterday that Barclay Plager, his assistant coach, would take over the coaching for a week in an effort to help the struggling team, which has a 10-19-3 record.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: The 1982 results include the operations of the Benjamin Franklin Savings Association of Houston, acquired Oct 2, 1981 and of the Foster Martgage Corp of Fort Worth, acquired June 30, 1982

title: Israeli Minister in Argentina At Start of a Four-Day Visit
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel arrived today for a four-day official visit to Argentina that will include a meeting with President Reynaldo Bignone, the Foreign Ministry said.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
WAR HAS COME A LONG WAY SINCE PEARL HARBOR
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SAYS AUSTRIA LETS SOVIET HAVE SENSITIVE GOODS
description: The United States has threatened to impose trade sanctions against Austria if it does not stop the transfer of militarily sensitive products and technology to the Soviet bloc, a Pentagon official said today.

title: Yes, Congress Needs a Raise
description: A measure now before Congress would raise the salaries of senators and representatives to $77,662.50, an increase of $17,000. Some lawmakers resist an increase during a recession, fearing voters' resentment.

title: No Headline
description: A sign in a Veterans Administration Hospital reads, ''The Price of Freedom Is Visible Here,'' and the U.S.O. has not forgotten the men and women who have fought for the nation. The friendly smile of a volunteer and the red, white and blue U.S.O. banner make the Vietnam veterans in the 12 V.A. hospitals in the metropolitan area as well as the servicemen from World War I and World War II feel that their sacrifices are appreciated.

title: BRAZIL REQUESTS A FURTHER LOAN OF $1.5 BILLION
description: Nicaragua has arranged to get a badly needed loan of $25 million to $30 million from foreign banks. Page D1.

title: DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES EXPRESS CONCERN FOR SUFFERING
description: ''We are going through particularly difficult economic times,'' Richard Rosenberg of Manhattan wrote in a letter accompanying a donation of $50 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Air Florida Reduces Fare
description: Air Florida cut the one-way fare on its Florida-Northeast routes to $79 one way for travel during the off-peak period of Jan. 10 through Feb. 6.

title: SENATORS PURSUING A DELICATE MX COMPROMISE
description: Senate leaders are drafting a compromise that would give President Reagan the money he wants for building the MX missile but would also place severe restrictions on his ability to spend it.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How do an airplane's wings produce lift when the plane is flying upside down?

title: Uncle Morty, The Booky; Everybody, insists Mortimer J. Adler, should go back to reading.; by Charlotte Curtis
description: THE trouble with Americans (there always being a single folly that at any given moment seems to surpass all others) is that they are not very well educated. Even the best of them do not stack up with Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton, and if Mortimer J. Adler had his way, it would be back to the books for everybody, teen-age dropouts to aging scholars.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The yr-ago shr earnings adjusted for 3 percent stock divd paid Apr 1982

title: Court Bars Local Taxes On Goods Xerox Stored
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not impose taxes on goods that are temporarily stored in so-called customs-bonded warehouses awaiting shipment overseas.

title: CONCERT: COLLINS AT CARNEGIE
description: NEAR the close of Judy Collins's sold-out Carnegie Hall concert on Friday, the singer picked up a guitar for the first time in years and began to strum ''Who Knows Where the Time Goes?'' Sandy Denny's 1960's ballad is a quintessential Judy Collins song because it crosses boundaries, blending folk music, art song and pop into something artistically sound but uncategorizable. And its far-sighted lyric resonates especially well with Miss Collins's contemplative musical personality.

title: BIG-CITY PROBLEMS STRAIN HILTON HEAD
description: When Charles E. Fraser began building a ''paradise'' resort for the leisure class on this barrier island 25 years ago, the venture struck the fancy of real estate developers, gave public officials hope for reducing poverty and stirred fear among wildlife preservationists.

title: BRIEFING
description: Concern for Weinberger

title: INTELLIGENT COMMUNICATIONS NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Robbers was here.'' - Thieves who stole $5.3 million in the Bronx. (A1:3.)

title: Weekly Steel Output Up 10%
description: Steel production rose to 1.027 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a 10 percent increase from the previous week's 934,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Chief of Nuclear Agency Reports Tube Defects
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is concerned about defects in steam tubes in nuclear plants that allow leaks of radioactivity, the commission's chairman, Nunzio J. Palladino, said today.

title: SOVIET DIPLOMAT'S WIFE ARRESTED
description: The wife of a Soviet diplomat was arrested last Saturday and charged with shoplifting at a Paramus, N.J., department store, according to the town's Police Chief. After her release, the Chief rejected demands by Soviet diplomats that he publicly apologize for the incident.

title: Peking Hails Cause of Rebels In Cambodia and Afghanistan
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang renewed China's support tonight for the people of Cambodia and Afghanistan ''in their struggle against foreign aggression'' but did not criticize Vietnam or the Soviet Union by name.

title: ADVICE FROM DESIGNERS ON GIVING VIDEO GAMES
description: THERE are going to be a lot of pigs, mutants, cosmic swarms, alligators and frogs under the Christmas tree this year - all hiding within the game cartridges and floppy disks of video games. Why the ne plus ultra in electronic entertainment should presently be so amphibian as to render Frogger one of the top hits on the video game circuit probably only web-handed players know. But there it is, producing argy-bargy among a host of other amphibian contenders such as Frog Bog, Frogs and Flies and Frog Pond. Which frog, then, is the right frog to give someone this holiday season?

title: Drug Alert in Tennis
description: Marshall Happer, the chief administrator of the International Professional Tennis Council, said the group would take every step possible ''to keep the sport clean'' meaning it would introduce stiff penalties for a player found guilty of using illegal drugs at tournaments. The council has written an anti-drug rule into the conditions of the 1983 Grand Prix circuit, which makes drug-taking at a tournament an offense that can lead to instant default and a penalty of $5,000. ... Virginia Wade, the English tennis star who won the Wimbledon title in 1977, has become the first woman to be elected to the management committee of the All-England Club, which runs the Wimbledon tournament.

title: CLEMENT V DIDN'T DO IT
description: To the Editor:

title: American Bell Chief Named by A.T.&T.
description: Charles Marshall, an executive vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of American Bell, the new A.T.& T. subsidiary that will offer customer equipment and data processing services starting Jan. 1.

title: U.S. PLANS TO TEST INTEGRATED DRIVE ON AIR, WATER AND LAND POLLUTION
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, today announced a new program to integrate the agency's efforts to cope with pollution of the air, water and land.

title: British Police Remove Protesters From Base
description: The police removed scores of women who tried to block the gates of a United States Air Force base today to protest the planned deployment of American cruise missiles in Britain.

title: YEMEN QUAKE SAID TO KILL 335
description: An earthquake struck Yemen today, killing several hundred people, the Sana radio reported. The radio, monitored here, put the known death toll so far at 335 and said another 300 people were taken to hospitals.

title: EARLY MUSIC: 'DANIEL'
description: THE Dark Ages were over by the time the medieval pageant ''Daniel and the Lions'' was written. However, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine - unfinished, cavernous and, above all, dark - seemed an appropriate space for the Ensemble for Early Music's Saturday presentation of this work.

title: PHOENIX THEATER CLOSES, CITING FINANCIAL TROUBLE
description: Less than two months after observing its 30th anniversary with a gala benefit at the Citicorp building's Atrium, the Phoenix Theater announced yesterday that it had ceased operations because of financial troubles.

title: Guatemalan Cabinet Gets Deadline to Resign
description: President Efrain Rios Montt has asked all his Cabinet members and other top Government officials to submit their resignations by Wednesday, a presidential spokesman said today.

title: M.T.A. Delays Sale Of Monthly Tickets
description: The sale of monthly commutation tickets for January on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's commuter lines, scheduled to begin next Monday, will be delayed until later next week because of uncertainty over what the fare will be after Jan. 1.

title: Khomeini Bloc Is Ahead In Iranian Voting
description: Early results of elections for an assembly to choose Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's successor showed today that radical clergymen were leading the balloting in Teheran.

title: WESTWAY'S PRICE LIST
description: It's always a good idea to find out what you're paying for, especially if the price tag is in the billions and you're on a limited budget. I am grateful to the State Transportation Department for putting together for me an accounting of how much has been spent so far on the court-stalled Westway project and who has received the money.

title: JERSEY'S SENATE REJECTS AN INCREASE IN THE SALES TAX, KEEPING IT AT 5%
description: A bill that would have increased New Jersey's sales tax by 1 percentage point, making it 6 instead of 5 percent, failed in the State Senate tonight despite hours of negotiations by party leaders. The proposed tax increase was intended to offset a predicted $150 million budget deficit.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling acquisition in Oct 1982;shr earnings and shrs outstdng have been adjusted for a 100 percent stock divd paid in July

title: Williams Testifies Before Senate Unit
description: Former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, appeared before the Senate Ethics Committee today and said he had used excess campaign funds to pay for legal expenses in the Senate arising out of his Abscam conviction.

title: GRAND CENTRAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: B-After a charge of $341,694 from an accounting adjustment

title: Off Broadway Comedy To Feature Milton Berle
description: Milton Berle will make his Off Broadway debut in a new comedy, ''Goodnight, Grandpa,'' by Walter Landau. The play concerns a Jewish family, and Mr. Berle will play a man about to celebrate his 100th birthday. Mr. Berle's last appearance on the New York stage was in Herb Gardner's ''The Goodbye People'' in 1968.

title: DEADLY, DULL AND DIRTY; Resisting Football
description: The professional football season, barely resumed, will soon be over and then perhaps everyone can learn something from this year's molting.

title: Bridge: Articles of the 60's Retain Freshness in New Booklet
description: In more than half a century the most famous of the specialist periodicals, The Bridge World, has published a great many articles that are worth rereading because they are instructive or entertaining or both. A distillation of even a relatively short period is therefore an attractive thought, and the editors have recently published ''Best of the Early 60's.'' It is available for $4 from the magazine, at 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025, and although the price is high for a 48-page booklet, so is the quality.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: For almost two weeks, world attention has focused on the University of Utah Medical Center, where a team headed by Dr. William C. DeVries implanted a permanent artificial heart in Dr. Barney B. Clark.

title: GLOSSER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Veto on School Silence Defeated in Assembly
description: The Assembly voted today to override Governor Kean's veto of a bill that would require all public schools in New Jersey to start each class day with one minute of silence.

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net losses after an extraordinary loss of $11,721,000 for the qr and yr

title: TAX COLLECTIONS BY CITY GREATER THAN PROJECTED
description: New York City's tax revenues were ''relatively strong'' for November, reversing the trend of the previous four months, according to a report released yesterday by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: REAGAN'S MIDEAST
description: Throughout the Arab world, many people are concerned that the Middle East peace initiative President Reagan announced on Sept. 1 is languishing. There are two worrries: that he might back off the course and that he might not pursue it with sufficient vigor and determination. But in fact there is no realistic alternative to a deliberate, steady process.

title: FLU SHOTS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: The flu season is upon us. For millions of older Americans, this may mean more than just a few days at home with the sniffles. The flu season could produce increased medical costs, hospitalization - and even death from complicating illnesses.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE presidents of major universities are taking the lead in involving their institutions in the support of public schools. In addition, they are urging their colleagues on other campuses to join in similar efforts. This signals the reversal of a 20-year breach between higher education and the schools.

title: IMMUNO NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Israelis Withhold Data on War
description: Israel is withholding information from the United States about military lessons gained from its invasion of Lebanon until Washington agrees to certain conditions demanded by Israel, according to officials in Jerusalem.

title: Threat Against Supermarkets Brings On an Arrest in Miami
description: A Florida man accused of trying to extort $175,000 from a chain of supermarkets by placing or threatening to place bombs in its stores was sent to jail in $2 million bail by a Federal magistrate here today.

title: TAXING HEALTH BENEFITS CAN'T CUT HEALTH COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Inferno Is Closed For Back Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Service halted the operation of the Phoenix Inferno of the Major Indoor Soccer League today because of the franchise's failure to pay more than $110,000 in back payroll taxes.

title: 100 in Congress Found To Lack Home in State
description: At least 100 members of Congress do not have permanent homes in the areas they represent, but quite a few still take advantage of a tax break for maintaining two dwellings, the magazine U.S. News & World Report said Sunday.

title: MIAMI BANK INDICTED ON CHARGES OF LAUNDERING ILLICIT DRUG MONEY
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted 16 individuals and companies, including a bank based in Miami, in connection with currency transaction reports involving about $96 million in what the Government says was illegal drug money.

title: Chock Full Net Drops by 44%
description: Chock Full o'Nuts, the New York-based coffee and restaurant company, reported yesterday that net income for the first quarter of its fiscal year fell 44 percent, to $1.9 million, or 38 cents a share, from $3.4 million, or 69 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenue rose to $31.9 million from $29.8 million.

title: Topics; Deadly, Dull and Dirty; Fighting Boxing
description: By the force of personality, Howard Cosell, the television sportscaster, has given boxing credibility. But after the death of Duk Koo Kim, a Korean boxer, Mr. Cosell has come out for abolishing the professional sport.

title: Presley Autopsy to Be Sealed
description: A document which might indicate whether Elvis Presley died of a drug overdose must remained sealed because no official autopsy was performed on the singer, the Tennessee Supreme Court ruled today. The court dismissed a petition by the ABC News program ''20-20'' to force the medical examiner in Shelby County, Tennessee, to make public the the report of an autopsy authorized by the singer's father, because ''the District Attorney General did not order'' an official autopsy.

title: Gas Bills' Benefits Held Small
description: Various proposals before Congress to hold down sharply rising prices of natural gas would at best cut consumers' monthly bills by no more than 4 percent, Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today.

title: Jury Continues Deliberations In Trial of Teamsters' Leader
description: The jury in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, continued its deliberations today by listening to 13 more recorded telephone wiretaps that are the core of the Government's case.

title: A Manville Lawsuit Allowed to Proceed
description: A United States bankruptcy Judge in New York yesterday lifted the automatic freeze on litigation against the Manville Corporation to allow the resolution of a lawsuit against the company by a group of California condominium owners whose walls, made by Manville, are deteriorating.

title: DUNES CASINO TO BE SOLD TO PERLMANS
description: Dunes Hotels and Casinos Inc., citing severe problems in collecting debts from Mexican customers, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its principal property, the Dunes Hotel and Country Club, one of Las Vegas's largest casinos, to Clifford and Stuart Perlman for $185 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Broadway column in Weekend on Friday gave an incorrect name for a co-author of ''Going Hollywood.'' He is Joseph Leonardo.

title: Dow Climbs by 5.52, to 1,024.28
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.52 points, to 1,024.28 yesterday, after having fallen 38 points in the three previous sessions. Although issues that declined in price slightly outnumbered advancing stocks, investor sentiment was aided by a slight recovery in video game stocks.

title: Bank of Montreal
description: The Bank of Montreal and the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation said in Vancouver, British Columbia, that they would take over Kaiser Resources Ltd. and that Edgar Kaiser, the owner of Kaiser Resources, would withdraw from the company. The Bank of Montreal said that it and British Columbia Coal, a susbsidiary of British Columbia Resources, had agreed to share the proceeds from the eventual sale of the assets of Kaiser Resources and that British Columbia Coal had withdrawn from its bankruptcy proceedings against Kaiser.

title: DEADLY, DULL AND DIRTY; Trashing Trash
description: We were watching a man behind the wheel of a brown car eating a banana while trapped in a traffic jam. The jam lasted so long he was able to finish the banana, but with no place to put the peel.

title: JERSEY, CITING PCB LEVELS, URGES LIMIT ON EATING FIVE KINDS OF FISH
description: New Jersey appealed to people today to restrict their eating of five species of fish caught off the northern half of the state's Atlantic coast or in four river basins because of their possible chemical contamination.

title: MATERIAL RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Australia Promises To Curb Immigration
description: Australia will tighten immigration rules after demands for curbs by unions and employers because of rising unemployment, the Government said today.

title: The Job-Killer Bill
description: ''Why not a Datsun made in Detroit?'' So ask the newspaper ads taken by the United Automobile Workers to press for the ''domestic content'' bill expected to come up in the House tomorrow. The theory of the bill is that by requiring cars sold in this country to be at least partly made in this country, Congress would save jobs in this country. Many Congressmen, sympathetic to the plight of unemployed auto workers and angry at Japan for its protectionist policies, are tempted to go along. It would be a self-defeating mistake.

title: SEIZE THE MOMENT
description: Treasury Secretary Donald Regan has come up with some thoughts about the world's economic relations that could make a dramatic difference.

title: Market Place; Cole National's Toy Prospects
description: WHEN investors think of toys, the company that comes to mind most often is Toys 'R' Us, the nation's biggest toy retailer. If all goes well this holiday season, Wall Street analysts say, sales of the company, which topped $783 million last year, could reach $1 billion this year.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CITY STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-After an extraordinary loss of $500,000...C-Including an extraordinary creditof $3,938,000 or 96 cents a shr...D-Net loss; the company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange

title: THE DANCE: MISS SKURA
description: STEPHANIE SKURA and Daniel Lepkoff shared Saturday night's bill at A Clear Space and whereas Mr. Lepkoff offered lots of movement that never amounted to much, Miss Skura claimed to be unable to put movement together, yet made her bumbling deliciously comic.

title: MICHAELS HAS FAITH IN SLUMPING LEAHY
description: Once, two seasons ago, Coach Walt Michaels gave Pat Leahy an ultimatum - kick well, or be cut. The pressure worked. The next game, the Jets faced the Miami Dolphins, and Leahy kicked what turned out to be the winning field goal. Now, Leahy is again experiencing trouble; in the last three games he has missed eight kicks - four of seven field-goal attempts and four extra points. But today Michaels did not issue a kick-or-be-cut edict. In fact, he said Leahy's job was secure.

title: New-Product Market Continues to Boom
description: The booming of the new-product market continued in November, the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News reports, and that makes six months in a row that introductions exceeded by a considerable margin the totals in matching months last year.

title: COURT OVERTURNS LAW PERMITTING CHURCHES TO VETO LIQUOR LICENSES
description: The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a Massachusetts law that gives churches and schools veto power over the issuing of liquor licenses within 500 feet of their property.

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 6
description: B-Including a net gain of $17,650,000 or $1.53 a shr on the sale of stock in Aurrer a S.A.

title: FROM JAPAN, NEW FACES, NEW SHAPES
description: Rei Kawakubo is pert and pretty and wears black clothes that flow gracefully around her body. Though she is composed and reserved, she is considered the most innovative of the new breed of designers working in Tokyo. Her work, bold and experimental, is different from anything being done in the West. It contributes to the fashion force that is emanating from Japan and that, some believe, may change the way women think about clothes.

title: Witnesses Given $1,000 In Hyatt Quitclaim Move
description: The first 49 of 2,000 witnesses to the 1981 Hyatt Regency Hotel skywalk collapse picked up $1,000 checks today, releasing the hotel owners from liability to them in the disaster, which claimed 114 lives.

title: PLURALITY-VOTE ORDER IN TEXAS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a lower court order, issued under the Voting Rights Act of 1965, that required a Texas city to hold elections for two City Council seats under a plurality rule, rather than a majority-vote rule.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TV: 'E.T. AND FRIENDS' FROM SPACE ON CBS
description: THE marketing of ''E.T.'' continues tonight, on CBS at 8, with a special called ''E.T. and Friends.'' As a Steven Spielberg movie, ''E.T., The Extra-Terrestrial'' has been phenomenally successful and is still perking at the box office. Now, just in time for the holidays, the stores are chock full of E.T. dolls, mugs, T-shirts and countless other exploitative artifacts, even as various factions fight about who has the legal rights to the E.T. image. E.T., in short, has entered the pantheon reserved for such marketable celebrities as Mickey Mouse and Miss Piggy.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1982; The Economy
description: The Federal Reserve Board cut the discount rate, its charge on loans it makes to banks and thrift institutions, to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent. The move was viewed as a bid by the Fed to spur the long-awaited economic recovery and was also seen as reflecting concern about strains on the international financial structure. (Page A1.)

title: No Fed Help, Bank Says
description: The Banco do Brasil said yesterday that it had not borrowed from the Federal Reserve Bank to meet its liquidity requirements. ''We are meeting our daily funding needs from our normal commercial bank sources,'' it added.

title: Trade Talks With Japan
description: Japan and the United States will hold talks in Washington Thursday and Friday to seek ways to widen the Japanese market for American farm products, Foreign Ministry officials said today.

title: Guardsman Slain in Spain
description: A member of the civil guard was killed and another was seriously wounded by submachine-gun fire from a passing car in the Basque town of Tolosa, the police reported.

title: PULLOUT BY GULF ADDS TO STRAITS OF GAS STATIONS
description: To the 245 residents of this hamlet in the foothills of the Adirondacks, Tom and Ann's Gulf gasoline station has always been a bit more than just that.

title: SOME CIVIL RIGHTS LEADERS DIFFER OVER BOYCOTT OF ANHEUSER-BUSCH
description: A proposal that was quietly fashioned by the Anheuser-Busch Companies to end a boycott of its products, called by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, has gained the qualified support of national civil rights leaders in recent weeks, according to some of the leaders. But the plan collapsed when Mr. Jackson, president of People United to Save Humanity, refused to accept it.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1982
description: International Poland's leaders announced actions that they said would ''suspend'' martial law. But the legislation submitted to Parliament would leave the military regime with sweeping powers, shift key regulations to the regular penal code and underscore the Government's power to put other martial law restrictions back into force at any time. (Page A1, Column 2.) Criticism of Poland's moves to ease martial law was expressed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz after he met in Rome with Pope John Paul II. Mr. Shultz said the steps did not seem to meet the Western allies' criteria for lifting economic and political sanctions against Warsaw. (A11:1.)

title: AILEY TEACHING DANCE TO BLIND TEEN-AGERS
description: ''Reach up, come forward and out to the side,'' Alvin Ailey called out in the huge, bright studio at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center. ''To the right. To the left. Now everybody hug. Who do you want to hug? Well, hug them.''

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AS MERCURY PLUNGES TO 17 IN CITY, THOUSANDS COMPLAIN OF NO HEAT
description: With the thermometer at a low of 17 degrees at 8 A.M. yesterday, some New Yorkers awoke to heatless apartments, and many did what Dorothy Perry of Manhattan did - they dialed 960-4800, the city's Central Complaint Bureau.

title: FILIBUSTER ENDED AS SENATORS VOTE TO WEIGH GAS BILL
description: The Senate today broke a conservative filibuster intended to prevent consideration of a bill to increase the gasoline tax, and Senate Republican leaders expressed hope of wrapping up the post-election session this week.

title: FILM: ANDRZEJ WAJDA'S 'ORCHESTRA CONDUCTOR'
description: ''The Orchestra Conductor'' was shown as part of the 1980 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Sept. 29, 1980. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: JOURNALS COMBAT SCIENTISTS' DECEIT IN SUBMITTING STUDY REPORTS
description: Editors of leading scientific journals are cracking down on what they consider deceptive or improper practices by researchers who submit the same paper simultaneously to two or more journals,

title: SPAIN'S FALLEN OUPOST UNEARTHED ON GEORGIA ISLAND
description: lost traces of two cultures that came together here 400 years ago with not-so-happy results. Every bone and artifact reinforces the belief that they have found the site of Santa Catalina de Guale, the northernmost Spanish mission on the Atlantic coast of North America.

title: NEW GOAL: WIPING OUT SCIENTIFIC 'ILLITERCY'
description: IN 1953 James D. Watson, a biologist, and Francis Crick, a biophysicist, published a paper entitled ''Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids'' that laid out for the first time the chemical basis of heredity.

title: Fumes in Van Kill 3 Hunters Upstate
description: Three hunters, apparently asphyxiated, were found dead on Sunday in a van parked on a road south of Middleburg in Schoharie County, according to the state police.

title: Inquiry at Florida
description: The University of Florida today confirmed its football program is being investigated by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. In a letter dated Dec. 1 to Florida President Robert Marston, released by the university, the N.C.A.A.'s assistant executive director, William Hunt, said the N.C.A.A. would send an investigator to Gainesville to look into possible recruiting violations.

title: RATES DROP ON DISCOUNT CUT
description: Interest rates fell sharply late yesterday afternoon after the Federal Reserve announced a half-point reduction, to 8 1/2 percent, in the discount rate it charges on loans to financial institutions.

title: STATE SENATE CALLS A RECESS AFTER CONFIRMING 5 JUDGES
description: The New York State Senate, meeting in special session, today confirmed the reappointment of five judges sitting on the State Court of Claims, and then recessed amid complaints that Governor Carey had not provided the authorization needed to act on any other bills.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 14, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 3:30 P.M. on mandate for Cyprus peacekeeping force. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Dec. 1-10 Auto Sales Up 14 1/2%; Discounts Tied To Big 3 Gains
description: The nation's Big Three automobile manufacturers reported today that new car sales from Dec. 1 to 10 were up 14 1/2 percent over the same period last year, marking the seventh consecutive 10-day reporting period of improved sales.

title: EX-FUGITIVE'S WIFE IS HELD IN CHICAGO
description: Leann Lewis surrendered to the authorities in Chicago yesterday afternoon, a day after her husband, James W. Lewis, who had been sought for questioning in the Tylenol deaths there, was seized by Federal agents in New York.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 15, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HIS MUSIC ON CORNET IS A TITHE
description: It is a frantic shopping day before Christmas, and the throngs at the Willowbrook Mall are surging along the passageways. A middle-aged couple have taken refuge from the flow near a small island of green. In front of them members of a Salvation Army brass quartet, dressed in their dark blue tunics, have just started to play.

title: DOW DROPS 14.90 AFTER EARLY JUMP
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 14.90 points yesterday in a hectic session that included a huge swing of almost 35 points. Trading volume accelerated to 98.4 million shares from Monday's 63.1 million.

title: Nowhere Near Sited
description: The President said he had ''a siting problem'' with the MX missile. I didn't understand. ''A siting problem,'' he said. Pentagon talk. Congress would probably buy all the MX missiles he wanted if he could just think of a safe way to ''site'' them.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: '' It is not pertinent that there are so many people unemployed today.

title: TALES OF JAZZ SAXOPHONISTS
description: JACKIE McLEAN and the late Art Pepper, the subjects of two jazz films that are having a limited run this week at Film Forum, both took up the alto saxophone and began experimenting with heroin around the same time - the mid-1940's. It was a time of upheaval in jazz, when Charlie Parker, the most innovative alto saxophonist the music had known, was at the height of his powers and his influence.

title: PAYROLL-TAX PLAN IS BACKED TO CLOSE DEFICIT OF M.T.A.
description: Governor Carey and Democratic legislative leaders today proposed a new regional payroll tax to close a budget deficit of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and help forestall proposed increases in bus, subway and commuter-rail fares.

title:
AIDING CAMBODIA;
The memory of Vietnam has prevented America from responding to the rape of Cambodia. But national security and human rights concerns suggest that it should provide military and economic aid to the non-Communist Cambodian forces fighting Vietnamese colonialism.
description: For three and a half years from April 1975, Cambodia lived under the totalitarian rule of Pol Pot's Kampuchean Communist Party - a regime that exterminated two million people and turned the rest into slave labor. In December 1978, Vietnam, which from April 1970 until April 1977 had provided crucial military and propaganda support for Pol Pot, again invaded Cambodia. Under the pretext of ''saving the Khmer people from genocide,'' the Vietnamese overthrew their disobedient former comrades and installed a puppet regime. Intransigent in its colonial aspirations, Soviet-backed Vietnam ignored the United Nations's repeated calls to withdraw. Instead, its troops tried mass starvation (which killed 700,000 civilians in 1979) and biochemical warfare in order to crush resistance. These policies have failed.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
REAGAN DENIES BEING 'SCARED' OF SOCIAL SECURITY FUND ISSUE
description: President Reagan denied today that he was ''scared'' of the Social Security issue. He urged his deadlocked study commission to agree on a plan to solve the system's fiscal problems.

title: U.S. AND FRANCE AGREE ON STUDIES TO UNIFY STRATEGY ON SOVIET TRADE
description: The United States and France announced tonight that they had reached agreement on specific projects for coordinating allied strategy on economic relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Steinbrenner's Tasks
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he intended to settle the Yankees' managerial muddle within two weeks. For now, the question remains: Will Clyde King return, or will Billy Martin or perhaps someone else be brought in? ''I don't know for sure what we will do about the managerial situation,'' said Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner.

title: Mexico Shifts to Austerity to Win Loans
description: With a flurry of new laws, decrees and initiatives, Mexico's two-week-old Government has moved rapidly to impose a broad economic austerity program and to tackle the country's huge foreign debt problem.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1982; Markets
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 14.90 points, to 1,009.38, in a session that saw the Dow swing almost 35 points. Volume rose to 98.4 million shares. Analysts said the investors were interpreting the weakness in the economy. (D1.) Long-term interest rates rose and bond prices fell. Investors and traders cited fears that the Fed's latest moves could have the effect of reviving inflation. (Page D7.)

title: Without Transit, Nothing
description: Governor Carey and Democratic legislative leaders have agreed on ways to close New York State's budget gap. But the deal has two defects. The Senate's Republican majority is not a party to it, and the higher priority of the transit deficit has been forgotten.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MISS POTTER SERVES HER WAY TO VICTORY
description: Two serve-and-volleyers, Wendy Turnbull and Barbara Potter, won opening-round matches in the Toyota women's tennis championships tonight.

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
PANEL SAID TO SUGGEST 4 FOR APPEALS COURT SEAT
description: The State Commission on Judicial Nomination has recommended four men to Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo for the State Court of Appeals appointment he will make early next year, Democratic leaders close to Mr. Cuomo said yesterday.

title: RESPONSE MIXED FOR NEW ACCOUNTS
description: For banks across the country, yesterday marked the much-heralded introduction of their own money market accounts, making them competitive with the mutual funds that have lured away deposits in recent years.

title: PRESIDENT AGREES TO FREEZE MONEY FOR BUILDING MX
description: President Reagan, making new concessions to salvage production funds for the MX missile, agreed today to let Congress freeze expenditure of the funds until it ratified a system for basing the missile.

title: SYNTREX INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 29
description: B-After extraordinary credit...C-Net loss

title: BRIEFING
description: A Scene for Good News

title: CHANGED LINES, CHANGED LIVES FOR 23d PRECINCT
description: Anxiety permeates the station house of the 23d Precinct as 1982 comes to an end, but it is not the result of a commander's ire or a citizen's complaint or an officer's mistake. Nor is it the product of a particular crime, like the recent spree of store robberies along First Avenue or the fatal shooting of a woman in her car on East 87th Street. The anxiety is caused by the radical redrawing of the precinct's boundaries that is scheduled for Jan. 1, and would divide the ''two worlds'' that have long been the hallmark of the square-mile precinct that extends from Fifth Avenue to the East River between 86th and 110th Streets.

title: Video Unit Dumping
description: Grundig A.G. and N.V. Philips, which jointly produce videotape recorders, have lodged an antidumping complaint with the European Economic Community against Japanese manufacturers, officials said here today. Distributors of the unit, the Video 2000, have joined the companies in the complaint, officials said.

title: President Is Resigning At Buckbee-Mears Co.
description: Everett Carter, president and chief operating officer of the Buckbee-Mears Company, said he planned to resign effective Dec. 31. Mr. Carter, 55, joined the St. Paul company in 1969. Buckbee-Mears produces lenses for eye glasses and precision components for the electronics and TV industries.

title: Bank Pleads Not Guilty In Money Laundering
description: A bank pleaded not guilty today to charges of sanctioning a money-laundering operation involving more than $96 million in illicit drug profits.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE is absolutely no accounting for the perception one has of someone else, particularly on first meeting. Sometimes this perception is based strictly on the physical aspect of the other person. It is easier to attach the label of ''patrician'' to a tall, wellgroomed man than it is to a roly-poly bundle in an unpressed suit. And although there isn't any law that says a nuclear scientist, male or female, can't be extraordinarily good-looking, it comes as somewhat of a surprise, even shock, when this is so.

title: 3 ARE FOUND GUILTY IN ASSASSINATION OF FEDERAL JUDGE
description: After 18 hours of deliberation, a Federal jury, several members in tears, found three defendants guilty today on six counts of planning, carrying out and trying to cover up the assassination of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr.

title: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
OPERETTA: FIRST 'EILEEN' IN NEW YORK SINCE 1917
description: VICTOR HERBERT felt that ''Eileen,'' his Irish operetta produced in 1917 when he was 58 years old and past the peak of his career, was his finest score. But despite enthusiastic reviews and such lasting songs as ''Thine Alone'' (which has been outsold among Herbert songs only by ''Ah, Sweet Mystery of Life''), ''The Irish Have a Great Day Tonight'' and the title song, ''Eileen'' had a disappointing run of eight weeks. Since 1917, it has not been seen or heard in New York until the New Amsterdam Theater Company presented a concert version for a single performance on Monday night at Town Hall.

title: Fluor's Net Drops
description: The Fluor Corporation, the engineering and construction company based in Irvine, Calif., reported that declines in earnings from operations and weakness in the price of lead produced by its St. Joe Minerals Corporation metals operations caused fourth-quarter net income to drop 49.5 percent, to $32.3 million, or 41 cents a share, from $64 million, or 82 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues slipped 7.4 percent, to $1.76 billion, from $1.90 billion. St. Joe was acquired by Fluor in 1981 for $2.2 billion.

title: BRITAIN WILL INCREASE MILITARY OUTLAYS
description: The British Government announced an extra allocation for defense of more than $1 billion yesterday to increase ''the flexibility, mobility and readiness'' of its forces as a result of the experience gained in the war with Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

title: W. COLFAX SMALL
description: W. Colfax Small, a war correspondent for United Press and a freelance contributor to national magazines and news syndicates, died of a heart attack on Dec. 1 on a Manhattan Street.

title: Public Health Needs a Public Service
description: According to Webster, infrastructure means ''the basic installations and facilities on which the continuance and growth of a community, state etc. depend.'' Usually the word refers to roads, bridges and the like, but it is just as applicable to the enormous network that is the Public Health Service.

title: New Toyota Warranty
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. announced today that it had doubled its warranty coverage on power train components of its 1983 models. In a statement released in Detroit, Toyota said the new warranty offers coverage on the engine, transmission and other main powertrain parts for two years or 24,000 miles, whichever comes first.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE 'REAL CREAM' COMES TO HOSPITAL GALA
description: ANY party at which Brooke Astor, Happy Rockefeller, Mildred Hilson, Douglas Dillon, Henry Kissinger, William S. Paley, Kitty Carlisle Hart, Dru Heinz and Douglas Fairbanks Jr. are seated at the same table has to rate high in the New York social firmament.

title: LEGAL SERVICES BOARD MEMBERS CRITICIZED ON FEES
description: President Reagan's appointees to the board of the Legal Services Corporation were criticized at a Congressional hearing today for paying themselves five-figure consulting fees at a time when the corporation's services to its poor clients have been slashed.

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Phoenix Ingraham Dead at 65; Chief Clerk of City's Civil Court
description: Phoenix Ingraham, chief clerk of the Civil Court of the City of New York, died of a heart attack last Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65 years old.

title: REGIONAL ROLL-CALL ON CONGRESS PAY
description: Following is how representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut voted today in the House's approval, 303 to 109, of a 15 percent pay increase for members of Congress, effective Dec. 17. A ''yes'' represents a vote for the raise and a ''no'' represents a vote against it; ''xxx'' denotes those not voting.

title: Seafirst Reserve
description: The Seafirst Corporation, which owns the Seattle-First National Bank, said it had increased its reserve for possible loan losses by $45 million. Doing so will reduce its fourth-quarter earnings by $1.50 a share, the company said. Last July Seafirst announced a $125 million increase in its second-quarter provision for possible loan losses as a result of the failure of the Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City.

title: 'Whodunnit' Is Postponed
description: The Broadway opening of ''Whodunnit,'' by Anthony Shaffer, has been postponed until Dec. 30 at the Biltmore Theater. The play was supposed to have opened on Sunday, but the producers and the director, Michael Kahn, decided that it needed more work. During the final days of the tryout in Boston, George Hearn replaced Jack Weston in a leading role.

title: Felix Hirsch, 80, Ex-Professor And Librarian at Bard College
description: Felix E. Hirsch, former professor of history and librarian at Bard College at Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Trenton State College, died of Parkinson's disease Sunday at the Pennswood Village nursing home in Newtown, Pa. He was 80 years old.

title: EASTWOOD'S 'HONKYTONK MAN'
description: ONLY charm and sentimentality could have brought the requisite magic to Clint Eastwood's ''Honkytonk Man''; unfortunately, this well-intentioned but weak film hasn't nearly enough of either. Set in the Depression, opening in the Dust Bowl and heading east to Nashville, the story tracks a man and a boy, played by Mr. Eastwood and his son Kyle, through various rites of passage.

title: CITY'S DENIAL OF A TAX BREAK TO TRUMP IS RULED IMPROPER
description: The state's highest court ruled unanimously yesterday that New York City had improperly denied a multimillion-dollar tax abatement to Donald J. Trump, the developer who is erecting a 59-story building on the site of the old Bonwit Teller store in midtown Manhattan.

title: CITYSCAPE PAINTER
description: John Button, a San Francisco-born painter and teacher known for his city-scapes and his passion for light, died of a heart attack Sunday in New York City. He was 52 years old.

title: GIANTS' PERKINS SAID SET TO REPLACE BEAR BRYANT
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant of Alabama, the winningest coach in college football, will resign today and will be replaced by Ray Perkins, coach of New York Giants, informed sources told The Associated Press last night.

title: DR. FOSTER MURRAY
description: Dr. Foster Murray, a former president of the New York Lung Association and governor of the American College of Chest Physicians, died Sunday at Princeton (N.J.) Hospital.

title: PLYWOOD CONCERNS AGREE TO SETTLE SUIT
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation announced yesterday that it and two co-defendants had reached an agreement in principle to settle for $165 million a class action antitrust suit dating back to 1978 involving charges of fixing softwood plywood prices.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Satellite Co. said it had agreed in principle to form a joint communications carrier venture with the Mitel Corp.; American is to provide satellite transmission facilities with Mitel's telecommunications switching technology.

title: MEAT THERMOMETER
description: FOR those who are planning game dishes such as the traditional goose for Christmas or New Year's, precision in cooking time is vital. Game, more so than steaks, chops and commercially raised fowl, can be ruined by the slightest overcooking.

title: EDWARD L. COFFEY
description: Edward L. Coffey, a former partner in the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett and a specialist in labor relations, died of cancer Saturday in Naples Community Hospital in Florida. He was 77 years old and had lived in Naples and Marshalls Creek, Pa., in recent years.

title: N.B.A. Upholds Spurs' Protest
description: Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, today upheld a protest by San Antonio and ordered the last three seconds of the Spurs' Nov. 30 game against Los Angeles to be replayed. It was only the second time in O'Brien's seven years as commissioner that he has upheld a protest.

title: Orwell in Warsaw
description: Repression in Poland has a new nomenclature, not a new face. Martial law is to be ''suspended,'' not lifted. Internees are to be released, subject to fresh arrest. The warnings of telephone eavesdropping will be disconnected, but the wiretaps may continue. Military courts will still decide political and security cases. Protesting workers still risk dismissal and even conscription as ''social parasites.''

title: RYKOFF, S E, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Index; International
description: Colombian peacemaker finds the rebels unyielding A2 Spain ending its blockade of the British colony of Gibraltar A3 British to increase military out- lays in war's aftermath A3 Reagan reaffirms choices for two foreign policy posts A3 Jordan agrees to ''special'' link with a future Palestinian entity A4 U.S. and A.F.L.-C.I.O. assail Suriname for recent killings A5 U.N. drafting a resolution on Pretoria's raid on Lesotho A6 South African papers criticize raid into Lesotho A7 Transformer fire causes wide- spread blackout in Quebec A8 Around the World A9 FitzGerald, Ireland's leader again, asks sacrifices A10 U.S. cool to Soviet offer on inter- mediate-range missiles A20 Government/Politics Retired Boston official indicted in pension fraud A14 ''Mellow'' Rizzo girds for Phila- delphia drive A15 Pentagon reporters balk at sign- ing a secrecy agreement A17 Legal Services board members criticized on consulting fees A25 Clinch River reactor funds set aside A28 Koch warns agency heads on need of more spending cuts B2 Panel said to recommend four to Cuomo for Appeals Court seat B3 Cuomo plans large audience for inauguration, but at low cost B3 Judge says he will resign and at- tacks criminal justice system D19 Washington Talk Briefing A30 What Washingtonians command on the lecture circuit A30 The filibuster, a treasured Senate institution A30 The Living Section Food Holiday feasts, Swedish style C1

title: Harvester Sale By Teledyne
description: Teledyne Inc. sold 1.5 million common shares of its 5.5 million shares of the International Harvester Company in the open market from Dec.1 through Dec. 10, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Prices ranged from $2.95 to $3.95 a share.

title: Two Champions Playing It Safe
description: On the same day last week, almost at opposite ends of the United States, two of boxing's leading world champions did what they have been urging local ring commissions to do: They underwent complete physical examinations, including CAT scans of the brain.

title: THE DANCE: HANNAH KAHN
description: Anoted choreographer once commented that if people didn't like his ballets, they could shut their eyes and enjoy the music. That could have been done, certainly, on Saturday at the Emanu-El Midtown Y Dance Center, where the Hannah Kahn Dance Company presented a program of modern dance set to music by Dvorak, Schumann and Elliott Carter. But those who did would have missed seeing the music.

title: Archer Daniels
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company in Decatur, Ill., said that it was terminating an expansion project at its Clinton, Iowa, corn plant. The company estimated that there would be a charge of $8 million against future earnings. The project is being terminated because of a Justice Department complaint asking that the lease executed by Nabisco Brands Inc. and Archer Daniels be rescinded and the plant returned to Nabisco.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TVI ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHAT WASHINGTONIANS GET ON THE LECTURE CIRCUT
description: Henry A. Kissinger is hot. Richard V. Allen is not. Zbigniew Brzezinski is in greater demand now than when he was in the Carter Administration. But not Jody Powell and Hamilton Jordan. As for Alexander M. Haig Jr., he's very hot. But no one is sure for how long. ''Next year, the only one who may be listening to him is Harry Gray,'' said Milton Fenster, a public relations man, referring to the corporate executive who recently hired Mr. Haig as a consultant.

title: Cunningham Honored
description: Merce Cunningham has been named a Commander of the Order of Arts and Letters by the French Ministry of Culture. Mr. Cunningham, whose modern dance company has just completed a two-and-a-half month tour of France, received the award in a ceremony preceding the company's final performance in France. The Cunningham company will be seen in New York in a two-week season at City Center from March 15 to 27.

title: Indian Army Seeking to Keep Order in a City After Violence
description: Indian Army units today moved into the curfew-bound city of Baroda, north of Bombay, to help maintain order after a second day of violence.

title: Spurs 102, Rockets 93
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - George Gervin scored 29 points to lead San Antonio.

title: Giants Trade Morgan to Phils
description: The Philadelphia Phillies have obtained the veteran infielder Joe Morgan and Al Holland, a top relief pitcher, from the San Francisco Giants for the pitcher Mike Krukow and two minor leaguers.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Late Monday night, while the wind was blowing cold down 34th Street from the Hudson River, there were four women sleeping on the stone floor in the anteroom of the women's restroom on the lower level of Penn Station.

title: Seaver Considers Written Contract
description: Frank Cashen, the New York Mets' general manager, met yesterday with Tom Seaver and gave the pitcher a written contract offer to consider.

title: LONG-TERM RATES ADVANCE
description: Long-term interest rates rose yesterday and bond prices fell, reflecting the concern of investors and traders that the Federal Reserve's latest moves to reduce short-term interest rates might have the unpleasant side effect of increasing inflation in the future.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has named Meredith M. Fernstrom senior vice president, office of public responsibility.

title: POLAND CUTS BACK ITS CULTURAL TIES WITH U.S. AGENCIES
description: Poland announced today that it was cutting back on cultural and scientific relations with the United States Government and was restricting visas for Americans.

title: A BONUS FOR CONGRESS
description: Even at Christmastime, with about 12 million Americans unemployed and a Federal budget deficit of over $100 billion, it's hard to imagine that senators and representatives, now making $60,622.50 a year, should vote themselves a $17,000 raise.

title: WILSON A. SHELTON
description: Wilson A. Shelton, a former president of Compton Advertising of Manhattan and a former Police Commissioner of Cove Neck, L.I., died of a heart attack Monday while on vacation in Naples, Fla. He was 64 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: SURINAME ASSAILED FOR DEC. 9 KILLINGS
description: The killings last week of virtually the entire leadership of the opposition to the leftist Government of Suriname has brought an angry reaction from the Reagan Administration and from the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Another White Rightist Seized in South Africa
description: The South African security police have detained another leading member of a white rightist organization after arms caches were found throughout the country last week, a police statement said today.

title: Article 100977 -- No Title
description: Venezuela's oil minister, Humberto Calderon Berti, said in Teheran today that the oil price of members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should be pegged at $34 a barrel for the next two years, the Teheran radio reported.

title: FOULS COSTLY AS KNICKS LOSE
description: Teams coached by Hubie Brown have always been known to be aggressive and to commit many fouls. Last night, the Knicks picked up three crucial fouls within a 25-second span, and they paved the way for a 104-99 victory by the Detroit Pistons at Madison Square Garden.

title: THEATER: 'MONDAY AFTER THE MIRACLE'
description: IN ''Monday After the Miracle,'' which opened at the Eugene O'Neill Theater last night, the playwright William Gibson and the director Arthur Penn return to the scene of an early triumph: they pick up the story of Helen Keller and her teacher Annie Sullivan 17 years after the thrilling climax of ''The Miracle Worker.''

title: HOUSE UNIT FINDS NO TRUTH IN SEX ALLEGATIONS
description: A House ethics panel that has been investigating allegations of homosexuality and sexual misconduct by members of Congress and its pages issued an interim report today concluding that ''virtually every one'' of the charges was unfounded.

title: Economic Scene; Social Security At Crossroads
description: THE chances that the National Commission on Social Security Reform will offer a unified answer to how to keep the Old Age and Survivors Insurance trust fund solvent appear close to zero unless President Reagan and House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. can come to terms and instruct their respective political associates on what kind of a deal would be acceptable.

title: INDIANA SOCCER STAR IS TOP DRAFT CHOICE
description: Gregg Thompson, a defender from Indiana University, was taken by the Tampa Bay Rowdies yesterday as the first player in the North American Soccer League amateur draft.

title: HOLDS BIGGEST SHARE
description: GFI/Koll International, a wholly owned subsidiary of General Felt Industries, Inc. of Saddle Brook, N.J., yesterday became the largest stockholder in Sotheby Parke Bernet, acquiring 14.2 percent or 1,623,500 shares for $12.8 million.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Israeli Minister, in Argentina, Raises Issue of Missing Jews
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel told Argentina's President and Foreign Minister today that Israel is concerned about nearly 1,000 Jews who disappeared during the military regime's war on leftist terrorism from 1975 to 1979.

title: MCGRIFF AND MARTIN ANCHOR GIANT LANE
description: When the Giants lost their first three games this season, their defense lacked last year's steadiness and the ability to make the big play.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lighting the Tree

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Kings, at Kansas City, Mo. For first time since he was traded to the Nets last season, Otis Birdsong will be in Kansas City to face his old team. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 8:35 P.M.) College Games: St. John's at Fordham, 8 P.M., preceded by women's game at 6 P.M. (Radio -WNYE-FM, 91.5; at 7:45 P.M., and WGBB, 1240; and WFUV-FM, 90.7; 7:55 P.M.); Wagner at L.I.U., 7:30 P.M.; York at John Jay, 5 P.M.; C.W. Post at Dowling, 8 P.M.; Pratt at New York Tech, 8 P.M.; Lehman at Staten Island, 8 P.M.; Adelphi at Queens, 9 P.M.; Brookyn at Queens, women's game, 7 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Los Angeles Kings, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. The Rangers have a record of 8-3-1 in their last 12 games. Mike Rogers has led the way with 22 points in that stretch. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Tennis Toyota Championships, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7 P.M. Tonight's singles matches pit Pam Shriver against Bettina Bunge and Tracy Austin against Mima Jausovec. The doubles list Barbara Potter and Sharon Walsh vs. JoAnne Russell and Virginia Ruzici.

title: BRONX ROBBERS GOT $9.8 MILLION
description: Officials of the Bronx armored-car company that was robbed Sunday night by two masked men have revised the amount of the loss to $9.8 million, the police said yesterday. The loss had previously been placed at $5.3 million.

title: ELEMENTARY PUPILS PLAY OUT THEIR OWN STORY OF MODERN JUSTICE
description: Gold E. Locks was found guilty today of criminal trespass charges stemming from her unlawful entry Nov. 1 into the home of Mr. and Mrs. Bear.

title: BALLET: CHAMBER IN DEBUT
description: FOR many years, Finis Jhung has had the reputation of being one of the best ballet teachers in New York and professional dancers have been among those who have particularly sought out his guidance.

title: QUEBEC IS HIT BY LARGE BLACKOUT
description: A transformer fire knocked out power to the six million people of Quebec Province for several hours today, cutting off light and heat in freezing temperatures, stopping the Montreal subway and forcing thousands of businesses to shut down.

title: Teamster Evidence Reviewed
description: The jury in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and four other people deliberated for a fourth day today, reviewing conversations wiretapped by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Williams and his co-defendants are accused of conspiring to bribe Senator Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada, by offering him help in buying union-owned land in return for his aid in scuttling a trucking deregulation bill. Senator Cannon was not charged and the bill passed in 1980 with his support.

title: Simmons Buys Stock
description: On Monday, the Simmons Market Research Bureau, a leading supplier of syndicated magazine audience data, bought back its stock from four of its original investors, a move that raised the value of the shares of the remaining two, Frank Stanton, chairman, and the JWT Group, whose Target Group Index Simmons acquired for stock in 1978. The JWT equity now comes to about 80 percent, according to Mr. Stanton.

title: GAMBLE OUR DEBT AWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Opel Output Reduction
description: Adam Opel A.G., the West German unit of the General Motors Corporation, said today that it would reduce working hours at its main plant here for five days in the second half of January.

title: CRITICS OF A BREEDER REACTOR DEFEAT FUNDS IN HOUSE VOTE
description: The House of Representatives voted today for the first time to hold up funds for the Clinch River breeder reactor in Oak Ridge, Tenn., a project that has been hailed as a prototype for an unending source of nuclear power.

title: Our Mr. Brooks
description: Ray Perkins of the Giants won't have a coaching monopoly on local television much longer. Starting Jan. 9, area viewers will be able to tune in Herb Brooks, the head coach of the Rangers, who will be the host of a half-hour hockey show on Sunday evenings.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Unaccustomed Setting For the Mona Lisa

title: JORDANIANS AGREE TO 'SPECIAL' LINK WITH A FUTURE PALESTINIAN ENTITY
description: The Jordanian Government and the Palestine Liberation Organization announced today after two days of talks that they had agreed there would be a ''special and distinctive relationship'' between Jordan and a future Palestinian entity.

title: SPAIN ENDS 13-YEAR GIBRALTAR BLOCKADE
description: Spain lifted its blockade of the British colony of Gibraltar, opening the heavy black iron gate at midnight to a stream of tearful relatives, some of whom were reunited for the first time in 13 years.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. COOL TO ARMS OFFER EXPECTED FROM SOVIET
description: President Reagan confirmed today that he expected a proposal by the Soviet Union to dismantle its intermediaterange missile force ''in numbers,'' and added that such an offer still ''isn't adequate.''

title: Unhappy Ohio Democrat Reported Back in Fold
description: A fragile coalition of minority Republicans and a disaffected Democrat, which had hoped to control the Ohio Senate, fell apart today when State Senator M. Morris Jackson of Cleveland reportedly changed his mind. He ''will continue to serve as a vital part of the Senate Democratic Caucus in the 115th General Assembly,'' said State Senator Harry Meshel. Senator Jackson, who said he had been overlooked by his party, had agreed to serve as Senate President and vote with the Republicans, giving the party a one-vote advantage.

title: CAVCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PROPER IMMIGRANT REFORM
description: The Simpson-Mazzoli bill, now before the House, is a major effort to reform immigration policy. It would do so by both affirming the importance of lawful immigration and making possible firm steps to prevent illegal immigration in the future - an approach that is often called keeping the front door open while closing the back door.

title: NINE PUBLISHERS SUE N.Y.U., CHARGING COPYRIGHT VIOLATION
description: Nine major publishers filed suit yesterday against New York University, 10 of its faculty members and an off-campus copy center, charging them with copyright infringement. The suit, financed by the Association of American Publishers, is the association's first legal action aimed directly at universities and faculty members accused of violating the 1976 Copyright Act.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: SUSAN SEIDELMAN's film ''Smithereens,'' which was an American entry at the Cannes Film Festival and which is now playing at the Waverly Theater I in Greenwich Village, is an affectionate, detailed account of life on the fringes of New York's New Wave subculture. The film's stars (including the first-generation punk rocker Richard Hell), its craftsmanship, and the wonders its director has worked with an $80,000 budget have been getting good reviews. But the film's sound track music, which is by Glenn Mercer and Bill Million, is equally praiseworthy. Its passages of onrushing electric-guitar chording swell out of the sounds of the East Village's streets and seem to follow doggedly in the footsteps of the film's protagonist, Susan Berman, as she hikes briskly from nowhere to nowhere.

title: WINE Q&A
description: Q. I have a bottle of what purports to be Napoleon brandy. It has a label with the following: ''Cognac des Tuileries, Cognac Grande ... Reserve 1818.'' There does not seem to be any evaporation, but the cork, the part you can see, is shrinking. The cork is covered with a lead seal with an N embossed in it. The bottle has a false bottom and an N also embossed in the glass. Where might I find out about this bottle?

title: I.M.F. PLANS PRESSURE ON BANKS TO HELP BRAZIL
description: In an effort to keep Brazil from financial collapse, a plan is being prepared to coerce Brazil's 1,400 creditor banks into restoring any reductions in outstanding credit to the South American country and to make new loans to Brazil, banking officials said yesterday.

title: 'GANDHI' IS CITED FOR AWARD
description: Richard Attenborough's ''Gandhi'' has been chosen the best film of 1982 by the National Board of Review. Ben Kingsley, who plays the lead role in ''Gandhi,'' was named best actor and Meryl Streep captured the best actress award for her performance in ''Sophie's Choice.''

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Troopers to Get 9-Millimeter Pistols
description: Governor Kean announced today that the 2,500 members of the New Jersey state police would soon be issued 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistols, the weapons used by some police forces in other countries.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have trouble making mayonnaise. It sometimes thickens properly, but once in a while it curdles. Can you offer any sure-fire method for making it by hand?

title: Stenmark Wins; Phil Mahre Third
description: Ingemar Stenmark and Phil Mahre met in World Cup competition today for the first time this season, and Stenmark was the decisive victor.

title: U.S. ECONOMY'S ONE CONSPICUOUS PLENTY
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $150,000...C-Net income including a tax credit of $125,000 and a gain of $1,905,000 from the sale of an excess facility

title: Race to Stardom
description: Towering Inferno was minding his sheep in New South Wales when Tommy Woodcock noticed that he was a horse of the same color as Phar Lap. Towering Inferno no longer herds sheep; now he is a movie star, insured for $6 million, who this week is scheduled to finish his role as Phar Lap in a film about the thoroughbred race horse who died 50 years ago.

title: Ditka Criticized
description: Mike McCormack, the usually reserved head coach of the Seattle Seahawks, bitterly criticized Coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears for uncomplimentary remarks Ditka made after Seattle defeated Chicago last Sunday. After the game, Ditka said the Bears had lost to an inferior team and characterized the fourth-quarter quick-kick by the Seattle fullback Dan Doornink as ''a high school play.''

title: 8,000 in Bogota Flee Gasoline-Tank Blaze
description: Two tanks storing four million gallons of gasoline burned out of control in Bogota today and the police evacuated about 8,000 people from houses and a military base near the installation, used by Esso and Texaco.

title: NEW QUALITY IN MIKE ROGERS
description: For as long as he has played hockey, throughout his years in the juniors and then five seasons in the World Hockey Association, Mike Rogers has been a gifted scorer. Any questions about his offensive talents were answered by his first three seasons in the National Hockey League, in each of which he scored more than 100 points.

title: Damson Oil
description: The Damson Oil Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to buy $160 million in assets of the Petroleum Corporation of Texas, a privately held company based in Breckinridge, Tex.

title: KOCH WARNS OF NEW CUTS IN SPENDING BY AGENCIES
description: Mayor Koch, in a new warning about the city's fiscal condition, has ordered municipal agency heads to ready themselves for possible additional spending reductions.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington yesterday, together with some of the questions to and answers by Senators John Tower and Howard H. Baker Jr., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Assigned Dave F ord, pitcher, and Dan Graham, catcher, t o Rochester of International League. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Traded Joe M organ, second baseman, and Al Holland, r elief pitcher, to Philadelphia for Mike K rukow and Mark Davis, pitchers, and C harles Pennigar, outfielder.

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN REAFFIRMS 2 NOMINEES

title: Private Export Funding Appoints Top Officer
description: Robert B. Rivel, former president and chief executive of the Union Dime Savings Bank, has been named to similar posts at the Private Export Funding Corporation.

title: CUOMO PLANS BIG BUT LOW-COST INAUGURAL
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said today that more people would be invited to witness his swearing-in on Jan. 1 than had attended any recent gubernatorial inauguration, and at less cost.

title: Fairview Aide Cited in Fraud
description: A vice president of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation, the big Toronto-based development concern, was charged today with defrauding the company of $531,740 (Canadian) during 1981 and 1982.

title: Chief to Step Down At Applied Digital
description: William J. Catacosinos, a co-founder and chief executive of Applied Digital Data Systems Inc. of Hauppauge, L.I., plans to step down after 13 years at the helm.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
