description: Tough Choice: A Party Or a Legislative Session

title: CONNECTICUT TO ALTER ITS TURNPIKE TOKENS, SOLVING SUBWAY ISSUE
description: Connecticut agreed today to modify its turnpike tokens so they could no longer be used for the New York City subway.

title: LEFT SIDE OF PATIENT'S ARTIFICIAL HEART IS REPLACED
description: Surgeons replaced the entire left side of Dr. Barney B. Clark's artificial heart today after it began to fail. At the time of the crisis, he was experiencing a severe drop in blood pressure. After the operation, doctors described Dr. Clark as a ''very, very sick'' man whose condition was complicated because he had developed pnuemonia in his left lung.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The shr earnings results were restated for 50 percent stock divd declared in Sep

title: CARDS TURN BAD FOR LAS VEGAS
description: For Las Vegas, the easy assurance of an ever more prosperous future built on gaming revenues has given way, at least for now, to an intense competition among casino executives for a share of a shrinking business.

title: STUDY OF FINANCIAL REGULATORS
description: Vice President Bush yesterday announced the formation of a group to study consolidating the numerous Federal agencies that regulate banks, savings institutions, securities firms and other financial institutions.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1982
description: International New concessions on the MX missile were made by President Reagan. He agreed to allow Congress to freeze spending for development until it approved a system for basing the intercontinental weapon. Officials said Mr. Reagan had made the major concession after being told that approval of the missile was in jeopardy in the Senate. (Page A1, Column 6.) More than 1,000 people were killed in the earthquake that devastated areas of Yemen Monday. The Government said that more than 1,100 people had been hospitalized. The temblor leveled at least 11 villages and badly damaged 142 in the rugged, mountainous country. (A1:1.)

title: 50 Englishwomen Keep Protest Alive at U.S. Base
description: About 50 women maintained a picket line outside a United States military base today despite temperatures in the low 30's and vowed to continue protesting until at least spring against the deployment of American nuclear weapons there.

title: Marsteller International Gets New President
description: Reginald C. Bird, 46, has become president of Marsteller International, replacing Christian F. Norgaard, 41, who ''left to pursue personal business,'' according to the agency.

title: WALL ST.'S BOUNTIFUL BONUSES
description: Wall Street brokerage firms, with profits fattened by five months of some of the heaviest stock trading in history, are paying out large and, in some cases, record Christmas bonuses to their employees.

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Lloyd's Lets 2 Firms Stay
description: Lloyd's of London said today that its committee had decided to let PCW Underwriting Agencies and T.E. Sampson continue to underwrite certain kinds of insurance business. Details were not disclosed.

title: EDWIN P. YOUNG Jr.
description: Edwin P. Young Jr., a retired assistant publisher of The Providence Journal and Evening Bulletin, died of cancer Monday at the Medical College of Virginia Hospital in Richmond, Va. He was 74 years old. He had also been city editor of The Baltimore Sun and The Evening Sun.

title: 'OLD BOYS' STILL PREVAIL AS SCHOOL PRINCIPALS
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN UPDIKE RUMINATES ON MATTERS GUSTATORY
description: ''W HEN I was growing up in the Dutch-German area of Pennsylvania, we always had a vegetable garden and grew kohlrabi,'' John Updike said. ''Just standing there in the garden gnawing away at the woody outercovering was a satisfying sort of rabbit thing to do,'' explained the creator of Harry Angstrom, hero of Mr. Updike's novels ''Rabbit, Run,'' ''Rabbit Redux'' and ''Rabbit Is Rich.''

title: Advertising; Ketchum Man Joins Small Shop
description: WALTER KAPRIELIAN, president of Ketchum Advertising/New York and one of five regional presidents in Ketchum Communications, is putting that life behind him in favor of a partnership in small but creative Fearon/O'Leary Associates.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK

title: SYSTEM
description: Judge Jerome M. Becker, who has been serving on the Criminal Court bench has announced he will resign and yesterday criticized the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, the Legal Aid Society and the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals.

title: G.O.P. CHOOSES CANDIDATE TO FILL DELBELLO'S SEAT
description: Westchester County's Republican leaders tonight designated Andrew P. O'Rourke of Yonkers, the 49-year-old chairman of the Board of Legislators, to replace Alfred B. DelBello as County Executive.

title: AGREEMENT WITH I.B.M. STILLS ACADEMIC ANXIETY
description: An agreement among the International Business Machines Corporation, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard Medical School has averted the questions of academic freedom that have plagued other recent contracts between corporations and universities.

title: MILK PRICE FIXERS WIN
description: To the Editor:

title: UNRELENTING REBELS BEFOG THE 'PEACE' IN COLOMBIA
description: The suburban setting did not look like a place one would go looking for a leftist rebel. Two young girls in white communion dresses skipped down the street past well-tended lawns and two-story homes, and a delivery boy was busy at the corner tying a boxed pizza to the back of his scooter.

title: U.N. WORKING OUT A RESOLUTION ON LESOTHO RAID
description: The Security Council began drafting a resolution today to condemn South Africa for its raid last week on Lesotho.

title: DEVELOPER ACCUSED OF BRIBERY IN NEW ABSCAM TRIAL
description: Testimony began yesterday in the latest trial stemming from the Abscam investigation, and a Federal prosecutor charged that a realestate consultant and developer from New Jersey had been part of ''a group of individuals who conspired to bribe Congressmen.''

title: A Neighbor's Complaint
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: While I, as a resident of 82d Street between Amsterdam and Columbus, enjoyed finding in the trash two of DDL's handsome blue floor tiles with chipped corners, I take less pleasure in smelling day-old shrimp shells or viewing cartons which contained New Jersey cooking oil (''From Epics to the Epicurean,'' Nov. 17).

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Million-Dollar Story Starts With a Dollar Bill

title: RACAL ELECTRONICS: A BRITISH SUCCESS
description: It doesn't take a business-oriented visitor here long to encounter the Racal cult. The growth of Racal Electronics P.L.C., founded in 1951, into a highly profitable company with sales of more than $1 billion would have earned it attention anywhere.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Careers; Discontent Of Middle Managers
description: IS top management living in an ivory tower as more and more middle managers are dismissed to save money? Two separate surveys, taken together, indicate the answer is yes.

title: Israel N. Thurman, 98, Is Dead; Lawyer and Jewish Lay Leader
description: Israel N. Thurman, who had a corporate law practice in Manhattan for 50 years and was active in Jewish religious affairs, died Saturday at Union Hospital in the Bronx at the age of 98. A former resident of the Riverdale section of the Bronx, he lived at the Andrew Freedman Home for retired professional people at 1125 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: 1. Wreath for the Door
description: Nothing is quite like a fresh Christmas wreath hanging on one's door. The Hampton Greenery is making one this year of English boxwood, embellished with pine cones, wheat and bleached grasses and tied with a raffia bow. The wreaths, about 21 inches across, are priced at $40, plus $4 shipping (New York residents add sales tax). The Greenery ships its wreaths by United Parcel Service and says shipments to places in the Northeast usually get there the day after the order is received. Send orders and checks to Hampton Greenery, P.O. Box 447, Westhampton Beach, N.Y. 11978; the phone number is 516-325-0426.

title: FAMILY IS FOCUS OF LEISURE TIME, STUDY FINDS
description: THE American family may be undergoing drastic changes, but its members still prefer to spend their free time with one another and, by and large, to pursue their leisure activities at home. Furthermore, in families where both parents work outside the home, more time is spent with children in planned activities than in those families in which only one spouse is employed. And the television set, though a predominant force in the home, does not eradicate other interests nor interfere with family relationships.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After a gain of $228,000 from the writeoff of an S.B.A. loan

title: PANDICK PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The shr earnings results adjusted for stock split in Jan 1982

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST CASES SEEK TO AID CHILDREN
description: The vision of a poor, lonely or neglected child overlooked in the festivity of the holiday season inspires many gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE world's most zealous wine collectors are the Bordeaux buffs, who can recite the great vintages more readily than their children's birthdays. These are oenophiles who are convinced that the greatest red wines are consistently made in the Bordeaux district of France, and today they are talking about collecting the 1982 vintage, which may be the best in a generation. The talk is of unusual harvest conditions and very good, even great, wines of tremendous depth and power.

title: 3 Disciplined By C.B.O.E.
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange today announced disciplinary actions against three of its members. Irvin R. Kessler, a market maker, was fined $10,000 and suspended for two weeks on charges of having repeatedly violated the exchange's position limit rule, which limits to 2,000 the number of options contracts an investor may hold in any option class on either the buy or sell side of the market.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Picking Up Some Change

title: POLICE EFFECTIVENESS: THE THREE VIEWS OF THREE EXPERTS
description: For seven months, the Precinct 23 series has looked at crime and crime-fighting in the city, covering issues from the use of foot patrols to the quality of investigations. To examine more broadly these and related matters, The Times conducted a discussion among Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire; Michael Smith, director of the Vera Institute of Justice; Mark H. Moore, professor of criminal-justice policy and management at Harvard University, and M. A. Farber, a Times reporter. Here are excerpts from the the discussion.

title: THE FILIBUSTER: A SENATE INSTITUTION
description: The filibuster, a legislative tactic that is as old as the first Congress, is once again being used on Capitol Hill as the 97th Congress draws to a close.

title: PRIVATE SCREENINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-There are no comparable yr-ago results because the company's initial stock offering was in June 1982

title: HOTEL INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FOOD NOTES
description: Sampling Fruitcake

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE. Lessons From America's Best-Run Companies. By Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. 360 pages. Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Warriors Seek Dailey
description: According to the Chicago Bulls, the Golden State Warriors have expressed interest in acquiring Quintin Dailey, the Chicago rookie who is on a leave of absence for psychiatric care. But Rod Thorn, the Bulls' general manager, says, ''The ownership of our team is sticking with Quintin Dailey.''

title: PANEL IN JERSEY VOTES TO CANCEL 20% FARE RISE
description: The board of directors of NJ Transit today voted 4 to 0 with three abstentions to rescind a 20 percent fare increase that was scheduled to go into effect Wednesday.

title: RETIRED OFFICIAL INDICTED IN BOSTON
description: A former Boston city budget director was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of fraudulently obtaining a disability pension after he said he had slipped on ice inside City Hall.

title: SOUTH AFRICA RAID DEPLORED BY PRESS
description: Although South African newspapers are usually hesitant to find fault with army operations, the raid into the capital of Lesotho last week has been criticized by both pro-Government and opposition publications.

title: HOLIDAY FEASTING, SWEDISH STYLE
description: CHRISTMAS holidays! The words instantly conjure up a vision of the overfull date book: on Sunday at 4, eggnog and cookies at the Harringtons; on Tuesday at 5, rum punch and fruit cake with the Smiths; on Wednesday, cocktails and cheese with the Martins; on Thursday. ... But why continue? The case for what is amiss virtually makes itself.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The results for the latest first qr reflect a charge equal to 2 cents a shr from losses of Telmos Inc in which Analogic acquired about a 40 percent interest inAug

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: HOLIDAY presents and parties are here and with them come pounds, extra pounds that depress you every time you dress, sit down or look in the mirror. Many Americans approach the holidays with a sense of dread that by Jan. 1 their hard-won losses will have become illgotten gains. That concern is coupled with the equally depressing notion that preventing this setback means depriving themselves of beloved holiday foods and drinks for the next two weeks.

title: TASTING THE 'LITTLE' WINES OF FRANCE
description: PARIS THE French are the first to admit to their own provincialism, especially when the subject is wine. Alsatians familiar with their regional riesling and @gewurztraminer rarely drink anything else. If asked to discuss the merits of Cotes de Ventoux wines over those of the little wines of Provence, many French people are at a loss.

title: Market Place; Protecting Paper Profits
description: IF there is anything more frustrating for investors in stocks than losing money on poor investment choices, it is picking the right ones and then watching large paper profits vanish in a general market retreat.

title: Dump the Grain Slowly
description: Agriculture Secretary Block proposes a payment-in-kind farm plan as a radical new solution to the problem of massive grain surpluses. In truth, it is only a clever variation on the old policy of paying growers to hold down production. It gets us no closer to the goal of getting Government out of the business of supporting farm prices.

title: LEAVE ALL AGED POOR THE MEANS FOR DECENT BURIAL
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A SURPRISING number of people are not aware that if you master just one basic cooking technique, then you have a whole host of foods that you can prepare with equal facility.

title: REPORTERS BALK AT SECRECY PLEDGE
description: The Defense Department today took the unusual step of asking reporters to sign a secrecy agreement before attending a briefing about Soviet military capabilities.

title: A NEARLY PAINLESS WAY TO SAVE TRANSIT FARES
description: To the Editor:

title: 'MELLOW' RIZZO GIRDS FOR RACE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Frank L. Rizzo, who spent eight years earning a reputation as a tough Mayor, wants people to believe that he has changed with the times and has, in fact, become ''mellow.''

title: 7th in Row for Syracuse
description: Syracuse stayed unbeaten tonight by defeating Ohio State, 91-85. It was the Orange's seventh victory. Erich Santifer, Leo Rautins, Tony Bruin and Gene Waldron each scored 19 points for the winners.

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CBS to Sell Unit
description: CBS Inc. said it was negotiating to sell its specialty stores division, which retails home electronic entertainment products through 83 Pacific Stereo outlets, because it did not fit into the company's strategic plan in a restructured entertainment-information marketplace.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a gain of $1,446,000 on the sale of property...C-Inc luding a gain of $1,526,000 on the sale of property

title: HOUSE VOTES RISE IN PAY TO $69,800
description: The House voted today to raise Congressional salaries $9,138 a year, to $69,800, a 15 percent increase. At the same time it also voted a 15 percent increase for Federal judges and top officials in the executive branch.

title: HOMELESS CRISSCROSS U.S. UNTIL THEIR CARS AND THEIR DREAMS BREAK DOWN
description: Across the country, in church shelters, abandoned buildings, in broken-down cars with license plates from far away, the tide of homeless Americans is rising.

title: Landing Flaps Are Cited In Boston Airport Crash
description: The accident involving a World Airways DC-10 jumbo jet in Boston last January would have been minimized and theoretically might have been averted if landing flaps had been set at a higher angle and if a computer-controlled throttle had not inexplicably pushed up the speed, Government investigators said today.

title: K Mart Fights Jordache Suit
description: The K Mart Corporation, responding to a $100 million lawsuit filed against it by Jordache Enterprises, the blue jeans maker, said it would file a counterclaim, accusing Jordache of interference with business relationships and violation of antitrust laws.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Atlanta Gas Light Co.'s rating on its publicly outstanding first mortgage bonds and preferred stock was lowered to Triple-B from Single-A-Minus by Standard & Poor's Corp; its commercial paper rating was lowered to A-2 from A-1.

title: Actions and Reactions
description: T wenty-five percent. That's a big chunk of anything, whether a bite of somebody else's sandwich or a sales commission. It is also the portion of a dollar that New York bettors never see after wagering on the trifecta.

title: WORLD-CLASS VIOLINISTS ADORN FESTIVAL IN ISRAEL
description: A remarkable festival for the violin and orchestra opened Monday as Zubin Mehta and the Israel Philharmonic began a week of concerts in which 15 violin concertos and other pieces are being performed by seven world-class violinists.

title: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. STEEL SETS PRICE CUTS OF ABOUT 20% ON TUBULAR LINE
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it was cutting prices on most of its tubular products by an average of 20 percent. Analysts said the company was trying to retain its share of a depressed market in which huge inventories have led to widespread price discounting.

title: Swiss Hold Kidnap Suspect
description: The police said today that Swiss authorities were holding a man suspected of being an accomplice in last week's kidnapping of a Canadian millionaire. The Canadian, Hyman Belzberg, was abducted by gunmen outside his Calgary furniture store last Thursday and was later freed unharmed. The police say Mr. Belzberg was released after a $2 million ransom was paid into a Swiss bank account.

title: Sandinists Are Reported Getting Soviet Tanks
description: Recent shipments from the Soviet bloc may have doubled the number of tanks in the Nicaraguan Army, already rated the strongest in Central America, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Conrail Cars Derail In Westchester
description: Two cars of a New York-bound rushhour commuter train derailed this morning near Valhalla, in Westchester County. The derailment did not cause any injuries, but prompted delays on the Harlem line of more than an hour.

title: Bridge:; If You Do Make a Mistake, Be Sure It's Just in Scoring
description: It is not easy to think of competitive head-to-head events in which both sides lose. It can happen in rowing or yachting if nobody completes the course. More spectacularly, it used to happen in jousting when both knights were knocked out of the saddle.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Daughter of President Of Honduras Is Seized
description: The daughter of the Honduran President, Roberto Suazo Cordova, was kidnapped here today by an unidentified guerrilla group that is demanding publication of a ''political manifesto'' in return for her life, the Government announced.

title: AN UNWISE BLANK CHECK ON HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake Hits Parts of Mexico
description: An earthquake shook sections of Mexico today but there were no immediate reports of damage. The Tacubaya meteorological station said the epicenter was 236 miles southwest of Mexico City in the Pacific Ocean. It measured 5.7 on the Richter scale; a tremor of that magnitude can cause considerable damage.

title: Duke of Energy
description: The Duke of Energy Corporation, a diversified holding company with three data-processing subsidiaries, said that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Terminals Unlimited for 3.53 million shares of Duke in a transaction valued at $21 million. Terminals Unlimited is a computer sales and service company based in Falls Church, Va. Duke of Energy will relocate its corporate headquarters on Jan.1 from Cushing, Okla., to Dallas.

title: No Headline
description: Johan Kriek was fined $5,250 and suspended for 21 days after his defeat today in the first round of the New South Wales Open tennis championships.

title: Chocolate and Tooth Decay
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: It would be unfortunate if the public were to act on the proposition that eating chocolate does not promote tooth decay. A recent Personal Health column (Nov. 10) states that ''studies at three research centers, including the National Institute for Dental Research, have found an antidecay factor that largely counteracts the decay-enhancing character of sugar.''

title: GEOPHYSICAL FIELD SURVEYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NETWORKS EXPLAIN SHIFT IN COVERAGE OF PRESIDENT
description: When President Reagan made an unscheduled appearance at the White House yesterday morning to announce his compromise with Congressional leaders on the MX missile system, it was not without precedent. In the last few years Mr. Reagan has on at least a half-dozen occasions wrapped up crucial discussions with such appearances in the press briefing room.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: JULIA CHILD's recollection in this space of a 1940's alphabet game has thrown wide the gates of memory. ''The game was called 'A for Effort,' '' Mrs. Child wrote, ''and my cousin Noble Cathcart and some of his publishing friends were working on it.'' She recalled a few of the phrases, including ''B for pork,'' ''C for yourself,'' ''E for vescent,'' ''I for Novello,'' ''O for the wings of a dove,'' ''Q for coffee'' and, of course, ''T for two.''

title: Islanders, Mired in Slump, Beaten Again
description: The Islanders, mired in a six-week slump, were defeated, 5-3, tonight by the Buffalo Sabres, the fourthplace team in the Adams Division.

title: A Friend at Times Square
description: The bright lights of Broadway that beckon to visitors to New York - the most popular leave and liberty port -can also be bewildering to a young recruit.

title: COMPLEX OF EIGHT OFFICE BUILDINGS IS PLANNED IN JERSEY
description: ''For the first time in years the market is going my way,'' said William Achenbaum, a developer who is in the midst of construction on a project for 1.3 million square feet of office space in central New Jersey.

title: RECITAL: JESSYE NORMAN SINGING BRAHMS AND RAVEL
description: THE best words to describe Jessye Norman's voice in her Carnegie Hall recital on Sunday night came from the texts of the Brahms lieder that made up most of the program. These are words of sensuous delicacy - ''drifting blissfully,'' ''fragrant kisses,'' ''dewy tears.''

title: SOME HITS AND MISSES IN COOKBOOKS FOR THE HOLIDAY SEASON
description: ONE of the exceptions to the descending rate of inflation is the cost of cookbooks. Most of this year's hardcover cookbooks are more than $15, many more than $20. The use of photographs in several raises the cost considerably but does nothing to enhance the value.

title: DR. WILLIAM B. KIMMEL
description: Dr. William B. Kimmel, professor emeritus of music at Hunter College, died of a stroke Saturday at Bellevue Hospital.

title: TV: 'MEMORIES NEVER DIE,' WITH LINDSAY WAGNER
description: WOMEN who start out in television as glamour girls - and that includes everyone from Farah Fawcett-Majors in ''Charlie's Angels'' to Lynda Carter in ''Wonder Woman'' - generally find that creating a more substantial professional image can be frustrating.

title: HOUSE ALLOCATES $5 BILLION TO JOBS
description: The House of Representatives, defying the threat of a Presidential veto, tonight narrowly approved a stopgap spending bill that included a $5.4 billion public works job program.

title: 7 of 11 Claims in Ads Found Unsubstantiated
description: Among the 11 cases of challenged advertising claims settled in November by the National Advertising Division, four claims were substantiated and seven were not. And the Maytag Company was represented on both lists.

title: FITZGERALD, IRISH LEADER AGAIN, ASKS SACRIFICE
description: The Irish Parliament elected Garret FitzGerald Prime Minister today and the former economics professor called on the nation for sacrifices to meet the challenge of its fiscal crisis.

title: THE CASE OF LEBANON
description: The Foreign Minister of Lebanon, Dr. Elie Salem, has been in Washington sounding a simple theme in tones of urgency approaching desperation. There is a better chance today than for many years to rebuild a real Lebanese state, but the chance will be lost if foreign armies do not leave the country soon.

title: PAN AM ENGINEERS GRANT CONCESSIONS
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Flight Engineers International Association that includes continuing a 10 percent wage cut and cost-saving changes in work rules.

title: News Analysis
description: The conviction of Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president, on charges of bribery conspiracy and fraud brings a substantial new problem to a union already burdened with substantial difficulties.

title: Steel Trader In Chapter 11
description: The Intercontinental Metals Corporation, a steel trading company based near here, has been forced into an involuntary Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by four creditors who say they are owed more than $18 million.

title: Curb Is Sought on Japan Steel
description: The domestic steel industry announced today that it was asking the Government to curb imports of steel from Japan.

title: MEESE SAYS JORDANIANS CAN BUY ARMS WITHOUT JOINING TALKS
description: The United States will support the sale of arms to Jordan without any condition that King Hussein join talks with Israel, Egypt and the United States on Palestinian self-rule, according to Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor.

title: Cooney Goes 4 Rounds
description: Gerry Cooney, who had not fought since losing his bid for Larry Holmes's World Boxing Council heavyweight championship on June 11, performed in a four-round exhibition Tuesday night at a nightclub in Pasadena, Tex.

title: DELOREAN SEEKS LOWER BAIL, SAYING BANK DEAL IS IN PERIL
description: John Z. DeLorean, the automobile maker awaiting trial on cocaine charges, today asked a Federal district judge to reduce his bond to $500,000 from $10 million to avert what he said was a threat by a bank to cut off his credit.

title: People
description: * Paul D. Feldman named director, corporate affairs and communications for the American Express Company.

title: Recovery For Paper Is Forecast
description: Revived demand for paper and paperboard products should help the industry post a modest recovery in 1983 and further gains in 1984 and 1985, the American Paper Institute said yesterday.

title: Work Rules Have to Count
description: New York's sanitation men are not quite uniformed workers, but they do not consider themselves non-uniformed either. Their union rejects the increase given to other ''civilian'' unions and insists on the same percentage raises awarded to police and corrections officers and firefighters earlier this year. Over this difference of 1 percent in the second year of the proposed contract - a matter of $2.5 million - the two sides approach a deplorable impasse.

title: One's Not Enough
description: ''It just doesn't make sense,'' said Emanuel Steward, rejecting the somewhat unusual concept that there be only one world champion in the welterweight division.

title: Georgetown Upset by 62-61
description: American University built a 43-24 lead in the second half, thwarted a comeback bid and made clutch free throws during the last 3 minutes 10 seconds for a 62-61 upset victory over Georgetown tonight. The loss was the second in a row for the Hoyas (6-2), who fell by 68-63 last Saturday night to top-ranked Virginia.

title: National Steel
description: The National Steel Corporation said its board cut the quarterly dividend to 6 1/4 cents a share, from 25 cents, payable Jan. 31 to shareholders of record Jan. 3. It said the cut reflected continuing low levels of demand and an expected fourthquarter loss.

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RICHNESS OF SHOWS

title: Indians Keep Manning
description: When he became a free agent at the end of last season, Rick Manning said he was hoping to join a contending team for the first time in his major league career, which began with the Cleveland Indians in 1975. But the 28-year-old center fielder yesterday signed a five-year contract with the Indians, who have finished sixth in the seven-team American League Eastern Division for the last five years.

title: TO COUNTERACT THE 'FLOURISHING BARBARISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Panel Backs Nomination of Douglas to F.T.C.
description: The Senate Commerce Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of George W. Douglas, an economist, to the Federal Trade Commission.

title: SERVICE THAT CONCERNS 'UNPLANNED PARENTHOOD'
description: To the editor: The timely Op-Ed Dec. 8 article by Alfred Moran, vice president of Planned Parenthood of New York City, correctly assesses the hypocrisy of the television industry in refusing contraceptive advertising while countenancing sexual provocation and innuendo at every turn. TV must share in the responsibility for changing sexual attitudes and for some of the untoward consequences, among them the rise in pregnancies of unwed teen-agers.

title: PENSION PANEL HEAD VOICES DOUBT ON NEXT MEETING
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the bipartisan Presidential commission that has been trying to agree on recommendations to bolster the finances of Social Security, said today that because of a deadlock along party lines the panel might not hold any more meetings.

title: Ex-N. Carolina Jaycees' Chief Found Guilty in a Fraud Case
description: A former president of the North Carolina Jaycees was found guilty today of helping create false club chapters with money that was supposed to go to charity. The specific charge on which he was convicted was being an accessory to misapplication of $10,000.

title: BRAZIL, PLAGUED BY DEBTS, IS TO GET A $4.5 BILLION CREDIT FROM I.M.F.
description: The Brazilian Government and an International Monetary Fund negotiating team agreed today on a $4.5 billion credit that Brazil had urgently sought to keep up with payments on its huge foreign debt.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Breast Cancer Linked To High-Meat Diet
description: Women who eat a typical American diet high in meat and low in fiber may increase their risk of breast cancer by raising the level of estrogen in the body, a study released today shows.

title: BRIEFING
description: Bombshell From Kemp

title: ELECTRIC APPLIANCES AFTER THE WARRANTY
description: IN this age of the electric appliance, it is always a shock to find that the bagel warmer doesn't get hot, the vacuum cleaner has lost its suction or the blow dryer simply won't work.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: SEVERAL new products can make house painting easier. Good brushes are expensive and keeping them in good condition from one job to the next is important.

title: JOHANNA JOHNSTON
description: Johanna Johnston, author of several biographies and children's books, died of a stroke in New York Tuesday. She was 68 years old.

title: Norstar to Buy Nassau Trust
description: Norstar Bancorp, a statewide bank holding company based in Albany, said it had agreed to acquire the Nassau Trust Company, which has 11 bank branches in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and had assets of $170 million as of Sept. 30.

title: TRUCKING LOBBY'S TAX FIGHT
description: The trucking industry, already shaken by profound changes in the regulatory climate and the depressed economy, is convinced that pending tax increases on heavy trucks will drive many marginal operators out of business and help speed up the diversion of shipped goods from trucks to railroads.

title: SPECIAL SOCIETIES FOR ALL PLANT BUFFS
description: NO gardener can know everything about every plant -but one way to try is to join with others who are similarly inclined. The dreary winter days are as good a time as any to study the many nonprofit groups dedicated to the dissemination of plant information and to consider joining one or more.

title: USA Plans New Editions
description: The Gannett Company said it would publish eight new editions of its national newspaper, USA Today, starting with a Houston-Louisiana edition on Jan. 10.

title: Market Place; South African Gold Shares
description: FEW stock groups have performed as well this year as South African gold mining shares. While the cash price of gold bullion has risen about 9 percent, to $438 an ounce, since last Dec. 31, The Financial Times (London) index of South African gold shares has soared 70 percent, to 523. The shares are traded on most stock exchanges in the United States and Europe.

title: Advertising; Audience Research: Who Pays?
description: ADMITTEDLY, advertisers are not satisfied with the quality of audience research available on cable television, but asking them to pay for it? Well, isn't that carrying it a bit too far?

title: On Motherhood
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I was saddened to read Norma Rosen's column in today's Times (Hers, Nov. 25) about the encounter between two mothers, one the mother of an aggressive adolescent who intentionally injured the 11-year-old son of the other mother. Mrs. Rosen describes a painful conflict between principle and putting the child first.

title: CORONA SENTENCED TO 25 YEARS TO LIFE
description: Juan V. Corona was sentenced today to 25 years to life in prison for each of the murders of 25 itinerant farm workers. All 25 sentences are to be served concurrently.

title: Clausen Criticizes U.S.
description: The president of the World Bank, A.W. Clausen, today criticized the United States for failing to take a vigorous lead in solving global economic problems.

title: Trenton to Drop Education Aides
description: Education Commissioner Saul Cooperman today announced a reorganization of the State Department of Education that includes the elimination of 101 managerial positions.

title: News Analysis
description: The Defense Department's request Tuesday that reporters sign a secrecy agreement before attending a briefing about Soviet military capacity added a new twist to a familiar Washington phenomenon: the declassification of intelligence information by the Government for political purposes.

title: Medical Report
description: Bob Lanier, the Milwaukee Bucks' 34-year-old center, will be out of action from four to five weeks after undergoing arthroscopic surgery on his left knee in Milwaukee. ... Robert Parish of the Celtics has an injured left ankle because of a bone chip, but Coach Bill Fitch said that the 7-foot center will attempt to play tonight against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden. ... Bill Foster, the South Carolina basketball coach, who suffered a heart attack during the Gamecocks' upset of Purdue last Saturday, underwent quadruple coronary bypass surgery yesterday morning at Providence Hospital in Columbia, S.C. The surgery took about four hours, and his wife later reported his condition as ''good.''

title: CUOMO SEEKING MORE CANDIDATES TO FILL VACANCY ON APPEALS COURT
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said tonight that he would like more names to chose from in filling a vacancy on the New York State Court of Appeals.

title: Southland Dividend
description: The Southland Corporation said its board of directors had approved a 3-for-2 stock split and an increase in the annual cash dividend.

title: NEW MUSIC FREES ITSELF OF ATONALITY
description: IN the late 1950's, Pierre Boulez said that serialism was the ''only historically possible musical language of our time.'' Such a pronouncement seems totalitarian today, when there are as many musical languages available to us as there are composers to use them, and there have been hundreds of vital musical styles since his comment that have had nothing to do with atonality.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Appraisal Associates, Milwaukee, has elected Ronald Goergen vice president of administration and Lee P. Hackett vice president of operations.

title: BENDIX LOSS IS FORECAST
description: The Bendix Corporation will have a loss for the fourth quarter because of higher interest costs and lower investment income from its $1.2 billion purchase of stock in the Martin Marietta Corporation, the Allied Corporation said yesterday.

title: DONOVAN'S DEPUTY LEAVING IN MARCH
description: Malcolm R. Lovell Jr., the Deputy Secretary of Labor, said today that he would leave his post in March. Mr. Lovell, the only top-level official at the Labor Department with any previous department experience or links with organized labor, insisted that his departure was not caused by any conflict with Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan.

title: SENATE UNIT DROPS REAGAN'S DEADLINE FOR VOTING ON MX
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee voted a tough new restriction today on President Reagan's ability to buy MX missiles.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said it had agreed to acquire up to 70 percent of the outstanding shares of Ralli Brothers S.A., a private Swiss banking corporation. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Security Pacific said the acquisition, which must be approved by United States and Swiss authorities, would give it a majority interest in the company, which specializes in portfolio management and investment advice.

title: DAYTON MALLEABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $80,000...C-Net loss including credits of $420,000

title: Convicted Killer Tells of Fear Youths Will Emulate Slaying
description: The convicted killer Charles V. Harrelson said today that he feared the killing of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. might be romanticized and copied by teenagers.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: B-AFter an extraordinary credit of $219,000

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $182,000 for the qr and $270,000 for the 6 mos; shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June and another to be paid Dec 17

title: Connecticut Draws Funds for Jobless
description: Because of Connecticut's rising unemployment rate, the state is drawing a $70 million advance from the Federal unemployment trust fund to help pay benefits during the first three months of 1983, P. Joseph Peraro, the State Labor Commissioner, announced today. He said Connecticut might seek total advances of $104 million for all of 1983.

title: Union City Mayor On Trial Over Bids
description: Mayor Robert Botti of Union City created a series of phantom competitors to sell more than $50,000 worth of supplies to a Hudson County school, the Government charged today at the opening of Mayor Botti's bid-rigging trial.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
PARTNER IN LAW FIRM KILLED BY CLERK IN 5TH AVE. OFFICE
description: A 38-year-old clerk at a midtown law firm shot and killed the firm's managing partner yesterday and returned to her desk, detectives said.

title: HOLIDAY TIPPING: HOME GUIDELINES ABOUT AMOUNTS
description: GREEN and blue and red Christmas lights twinkle around the handwritten ''Happy Holidays'' sign at the Newport Garage at 370 East 76th Street. The sign lists names of customers who have already made their contributions to the holiday kitty.

title: RECITAL: CHARLES HOLLAND, TENOR AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: CHARLES HOLLAND probably began his singing career like many other tenors. At the age of 11, in 1920, he heard a recording of Enrico Caruso and told his mother that he also wanted to sing. But there was no place for a black opera tenor - neither in Norfolk, Va., where Mr. Holland began singing as a child in church and school, nor later in his career when he moved to New York to continue his studies.

title: DETROIT SYMPHONY ISSUE: ARTISTS RULE
description: The management of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and its 98 musicians appear deadlocked over an issue of artistic control, seven days into a strike that threatens the orchestra's lucrative holiday concert programs.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Coach Harry D unlop was named manger of Las Vegas i n Pacific Coast League. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Rick M anning, free agent center fielder. NEW YORK (AL) - Signed Bob Shir- l ey, free agent left-handed pitcher, and D ave Righetti and Shane Rawley, left- h anded pitchers. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed Hub Kittle, p itching coach; Chuck Hiller, third base c oach; Hal Lanier, first base coach; Dave R icketts, bull pen coach, and Red Schoen- d ienst, hitting instructor, to 1983 con- t racts. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Acquired Ray S earage, left-handed relief pitcher, from C leveland for a player to be named later.

title: Scientist Says a Solar Flare May Affect Communications
description: A scientist today forecast disruption of some communications systems and a possible display of northern lights because of a major solar flare.

title: HERS
description: WE were going to move to another state with our two small children after what was for me a lifetime in New York City. Yet I hadn't the sense to be scared. I knew no more about what I was leaving than our landlord, who would have been shocked to learn that his old apartment house represented an Eden of harmony to his tenants. Families lived there whose lives gripped other lives so that we were all - roots, rocks, trees, hills - cleft into one another like landscape.

title: Accounts
description: * American Florists Marketing Council, the marketing arm of the Society of American Florists, to Earle Palmer Brown & Associates, Bethesda, Md.

title: Yankees Sign Shirley
description: The Yankees signed their third free agent in two weeks yesterday when they added Bob Shirley to their pitching staff with a four-year contract worth $1.5 million.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 21
BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $240,000 from discontinued operations...C-Net loss after a loss of $3,633,000 from discontinued operations

title: Seaver and Mets Agree
description: The Mets completed three days of contract talks with Tom Seaver yesterday, and will announce today at a luncheon in Shea Stadium that he has agreed to be traded back to the team from the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Immigration and Purity
description: What do good conservatives think about immigration? The same thing, chances are, that good liberals do. Probably no issue lends itself less to partisan ideology - or attracts more centrist agreement. Yet paradoxically, that very quality explains the peril hovering over the immigration bill to come up in the House today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Paint and Public Service

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results reflect a change in accounting

title: TEAMSTERS' PRESIDENT AND 4 OTHERS CONVICTED OF PLOT TO BRIBE SENATOR
description: Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president, was found guilty with four other men today of conspiring to bribe a United States Senator and defrauding the union's Central States Pension Fund.

title: FILLING A GAP IN THE STUDY OF ACID RAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Prolonging Death Is No Triumph
description: When Barney Clark consented to receive a mechanical heart at the University of Utah Medical Center, he was told what might go wrong, and a lot has. For two weeks the public has shared his sufferings as the initial operation was followed by one to mend his damaged lungs, by a prolonged seizure and now by a third operation, to repair a broken valve. Dr. Clark's courage is admirable and we truly wish him well.

title: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO INC (AT& reports earnings for Qtr to Nov
U.N.'S COUNCIL CONDEMNS SOUTH AFRICAN RAID
description: The United States and the other 14 members of the Security Council today denounced South Africa's raid last week on Lesotho.

title: IN A DROWSING ULSTER TOWN, A NIGHTMARE INTRUDES
description: On a day when the weather breaks and the sun chases low-flying clouds over the north Irish coast, a visitor can stand on the seawall here, dodging the salt spray tossed by pounding waves, and see the green headlands of Donegal dipping into the ocean 12 miles to the west.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: Yr-ago results include an extra week and are adjusted for accrued vacation accounting change

title: A BILL WITH PARAGRAPHS FULL OF PLUMS
description: The Big Sandy River in Eastern Kentucky overflowed in 1977-78, causing $200 million in damage to the district served by Representative Carl D. Perkins, a Democrat who is chairman of the Education and Labor Committee. Mr. Perkins used his political muscle to persuade Congress and the Army Corps of Engineers to initiate a flood-control project, the Yatesville Lake Construction Project, which would receive $8 million under an omnibus spending bill that the House approved on Tuesday.

title: CHARLES RIVER BREEDING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for QTr to Oct 31
Honeywell Settles Suit
description: Honeywell Inc. said a lawsuit involving infrared-detector trade secrets that it had filed in a Massachusetts state court against the Magnavox Government and Industrial Electronics Company, among others, had been settled out of court.

title: NUTRI-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The 1981 shr earnings was adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective Aug 6, 1982

title: No Headline
description: YEMEN QUAKE TOLL IS NOW 1,340

title: Bank Concern In Venezuela
description: Venezuela is finding it difficult to borrow cash to repay short-term foreign debts, banking and financial sources said today. The problems follow the collapse last month of the nation's largest commercial bank, Banco de los Trabajadores, the sources added.

title: GRANGER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
U.S.-Soviet Talks Open On Nuclear Arms Spread
description: American and Soviet officials opened a two-day meeting here to discuss efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear arms, the State Department said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * The Republic of Austria said the S.E.C. had declared effective a shelf registration statement for $400 million of the nation's debt securities.

title: RAT GENE IMPLANT IN MICE REPORTED
description: For the first time, scientists say they have transplanted genes from one animal species to another and effected profound changes in growth. Mice were given rat genes and grew to twice their normal size.

title: Agency to Weigh Loan to Dunes
description: An offer by Clifford and Stuart Perlman to give the Dunes Hotel a $10 million infusion to ward off threats by the Internal Revenue Service to seize the resort's assets will be considered in an emergency meeting of the Nevada Gaming Control Board on Thursday.

title: Morton to Retire
description: Craig Morton, the Denver Bronco quarterback who is 39 and the oldest player in the National Football League, said that he would retire at the end of this season, his 18th. ''It's a decision that needed to be made; it's one that everybody expected,'' said Morton, who was replaced as the team's No. 1 quarterback by Steve DeBerg after the team's third game of the strike-abbreviated season.

title: India Sends More Men To Quell Riots in West
description: Military reinforcements rushed to the western city of Baroda today to help soldiers quell Hindu-Moslem fighting that left 11 people dead and 30 others injured, officials said.

title: Swiss, at Madrid Talks, Ask March 25 Cutoff
description: Switzerland today called on delegates to the European security conference to conclude their meeting in the spring.

title: REAGAN, WITH PORTUGUESE CHIEF, ASKS BETTER LINKS
description: President Reagan conferred today with the Portuguese Prime Minister and said later that the United States would seek to ''broaden and strengthen'' its security ties with the Lisbon Government.

title: Cavaliers Acquire Free
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers acquired World B. Free from the Golden State Warriors for Ron Brewer yesterday. Free, a guard, has averaged 22.8 points in 19 games for Golden State this season. Brewer, also a guard, has averaged 11.4 points in 21 games for Cleveland this season.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Topics Promises
description: Cross Your Heart

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN finishing wood or furniture, the first step may be to strip the old finish to expose the natural grain or restore the original color. However, after sanding and scraping or using a chemical paint and varnish remover, the do-it-yourselfer is often disappointed to find that the wood is still too dark.

title: PERKINS SHIFT SURPRISES TEAM
description: In his 10 seasons with the Giants, Brian Kelley has played for four different head coaches. Bill Parcells will be the fifth.

title: BABY-PROOFING FOR A SAFE HOME
description: SMART babies are curious babies, and the larger the space they are allowed to roam, whether indoors or out, the more exciting are their lives. Dr. Burton White, author of ''The First Three Years of Life'' and the director of the Center for Parent Education in Newton, Mass., said: ''If you prevent a child from moving around and use playpens and jump seats, you inhibit the child. To see people is a thrill. To find a piece of cellophane on the floor makes him delirious. By putting fancy antiques on tables and telling children not to touch them, people justify themselves by saying that the children will learn about no. But the child associates 'no' with the object and curiosity, so you teach him that what he's going after is bad.''

title: ST. JOHN'S STREAK AT 8
description: St. John's, with David Russell leading the attack, last night defeated host Fordham, 74-66, for the 13th consecutive time in nine seasons. Russell scored 21 points to move into eighth place among St. John's career scorers, a point ahead of Al Seiden.

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reza Fallah Dies at 73; Ex - Iranian Oil Official
description: Reza Fallah, an Iranian oil official under the Shah, died Dec. 5 at his home in Windsor, England, according to reports from London. He was 73 years old.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1982
description: International Brazil is to receive $4.5 billion in credits over the next three years under an agreement reached by its Government and a negotiating team for the International Monetary Fund setting the conditions for the credits. The credits, which could rise to $6.7 billion, are designed to help Brasilia resolve its liquidity crisis. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) Spain assured Washington that it would remain a loyal ally even though its new Socialist Government has ''frozen'' the country's further integration into NATO. The pledge was made to Secretary of State George P. Shultz by Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. (A11:1.)

title: INQUIRY BEGINS INTO FEES PAID LEGAL SERVICES BOARD
description: The White House began an inquiry today into reports that President Reagan's appointees to the Legal Services Corporation have been paying themselves five-figure consulting fees while services to the poor were being cut.

title: NEW ERA FOR THE TELEPHONE: OWNERSHIP REPLACING RENTAL
description: First of two articles on the changing telephone business. The way in which Americans have obtained their home telephones for decades is about to undergo a major change as the telephone industry enters a new era.

title: Zionist Group Opposes Israel Settlement Policy
description: The World Zionist Congress, a powerful opinion-maker in Jewish affairs, voted today to condemn the Israeli Government's policy of establishing settlements in occupied Arab territories.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1982; International
description: Brazil and an I.M.F. team agreed on a $4.5 billion credit that the country has urgently sought to keep up payments on its huge foreign debt. In return, Brazil has agreed to continue its austerity program. (Page A1.) It is also expected to ask foreign banks for about $5 billion in new loans and about $4 billion of refinancing. (D6.) As the list of countries seeking short-term emergency cash from the Bank for International Settlements grows, the central bank institution is becoming uneasy about its role and abilities. (D6.)

title: 'THE WORLD IS ROOTING FOR YOU,' HEART PATIENT HEARD BEFORE SURGERY
description: Minutes before Dr. Barney B. Clark was taken into emergency surgery to replace the left side of his artificial heart, doctors allowed him a few moments alone with his wife, Una Loy.

title: RANGERS WIN A CROWD PLEASER
description: Three of the most popular Rangers scored significant goals last night, causing three boisterous ovations from the Madison Square Garden crowd. When the scoring and the shouting finally subsided, the Rangers had a 7-1 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Capitol Air Sues Eastern
description: Capitol Air Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a suit against Eastern Air Lines Inc., charging that Eastern had engaged in predatory pricing policies and other violations of antitrust law.

title: HOLIDAY SURGE IN AIR TRAFFIC
description: Like most of the nation's consumers, Sherril Booth says she was more price-conscious than usual in her gift shopping this year. ''Everyone is a little more concerned about money these days,'' she said the other day.

title: TOXIC CHEMICALS IMPERIL FLOODED TOWN IN MISSOURI
description: As though one problem was not enough, residents of Times Beach, Mo., a Meramec River town inundated by flood waters last week, now have another problem: the deadly chemical dioxin along their roadsides and high concentrations of other hazardous chemicals in their community park.

title: HOUSE PASSES U.S. AUTO CONTENT BILL
description: The House, after long debate, passed tonight by a narrow margin a protectionist trade bill requiring foreign auto manufacturers selling cars here to use substantial percentages of American parts and labor in their vehicles, as well as use American advertising services. The measure was passed by a vote of 215 to 188.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After a loss of $450,000 on the sale of securities...C-Includi ng a pretax gain of $967,000 from equity in the income of nonconsolidated affiliates, a pretax foreign currency translation loss of $889,000 and a pretax gain of $11,366,000 on the sale of equity securities and businesses...D-Including a pretax gain of $1,768,000 from equity in the income of nonconsolidated affiliates and a pretax foreign currency translation loss of $370,000

title: U.S. Says Cultural Cuts Will Hurt Only Poland
description: The State Department said today that Poland was hurting only itself by its announced cuts in scientific and cultural ties with agencies of the United States Government.

title: Bridge:; A New Routine Is Followed In Regional Championships
description: For enthusiasts in the New York metropolitan area, 1982 ends with an old tournament with a new look: The Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, at the New York Hilton Hotel, have a substantially revised schedule.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard MIDNIGHT IN THE CENTURY. By Victor Serge. Translated from the French by Richard Greeman. 242 pages. Writers and Readers/Norton. $12.95.

title: Leo Burnett Picks Up Procter & Gamble's Pert
description: The Procter & Gamble Company has moved its Pert Shampoo brand from Compton Advertising to the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago. Both are longtime agencies.

title: BONN OPPOSITION TRIES ARMS TALKS PLOY
description: The opposition Social Democratic Party, in an effort to portray Chancellor Helmut Kohl as an uncritical supporter of President Reagan, has begun to distance itself from the American position in the talks in Geneva on limiting medium-range nuclear weapons.

title: ROY J. BENECCHI
description: Roy J. Benecchi, board chairman of Aeronca Inc. of Middletown, Ohio, died Tuesday of a heart condition at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati.

title: FED OPPOSES DREYFUS BANK PROPOSAL
description: The Federal Reserve Board has challenged another attempt by the Dreyfus Corporation, a major mutual fund company, to get into the banking industry.

title: Filly Sets Mark
description: Beautiful Glass, a 3-year-old filly ridden by Chris McCarron, set an American record for five furlongs on the turf today with a time of 0:55 4/5 in the $30,320 first division of the Jan Jessie Stakes at Hollywood Park. Maggie's Intent won the second division. Several horses shared the previous mark of 56 seconds.

title: ELECTRO AUDIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $30,000 and a gain of $1,576,000 on the conversion of debentures...C-Net loss after a loss of $388,000 from discontinued operations

title: Los Angeles Kills Press Tax
description: The Los Angeles City Council voted Tuesday to allow newspapers, book publishers and television and radio stations to remain exempt from city business taxes. The vote was 8 to 7 to receive and file a report from the council's Finance Committee, which had recommended imposing business taxes on the printed and electronic press. The vote effectively killed the proposal.

title: SPAIN'S CHIEF GIVES PLEDGE ON U.S. TIES
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that the new Socialist Government would remain a loyal ally even though it had ''frozen'' Spain's further integration into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Chrysler Profit Outlook
description: The Chrysler Corporation still has a good chance to be profitable for the year, despite a five-week Canadian strike that cost about $100 million, Robert Miller, executive vice president for finance, said today.

title: Promotion at C.& W.
description: Frank P. McDonald, a 20-year man at Cunningham & Walsh, has been promoted to executive vice president. The 46-year-old executive, who has been dirctor of media and marketing services for 11 years, has been a senior vice president for 10 years and on the board for two.

title: Flight Dynamics Inc.  And Officer Part Ways
description: Flight Dynamics Inc. of Hillsboro, Ore., is a small company trying to get off the ground with a sophisticated product that helps a pilot land a jetliner in adverse conditions. The company, however, has run into some management turbulence.

title: Dispute on Judges Shifts Site of Bout
description: A bout for the World Boxing Association's junior-heavyweight title was moved from Gary to Chicago, only hours before the fight was to take place tonight, because of a dispute between the promoter, Don King, and the Indiana Boxing Commission.

title: CBS INCREASES TV RATINGS LEAD
description: On the strength of its ''bread and butter'' weekly series as well as the increased popularity of its movies made for television, CBS has taken a commanding lead over the other networks in the prime-time ratings for the 1982-83 television season.

title: Houghton Mifflin
description: The Houghton Mifflin Company said yesterday that it had named Richard W. Young president, succeeding Harold T. Miller, who remains chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Young has been a director of the Boston publishing house since April 1981. He was formerly executive vice president and director of worldwide marketing at the Polaroid Corporation.

title: Bulgaria Plans News Parley
description: Bulgaria said today that it would hold a news conference Friday on Italian efforts to implicate Bulgarians in the attempt on Pope John Paul's life in May 1981.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION FALLS 0.4%
description: Industrial production declined four-tenths of 1 percent in November, as output by the nation's factories reached its lowest level in five years, the Government reported today.

title: DOW DROPS 16.74 MORE, TO 992.64
description: The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 16.74 points yesterday as bank trust departments and other large institutional investors continued to lighten their stock portfolios in profit taking.

title: George Young's Decision
description: More than any other National Football League team, the Giants seem to prefer to count by two's. In the not-always-peaceful coexistence between Wellington Mara and Tim Mara, they have two owners who often disagree. Temporarily they also have two head coaches. Ray Perkins will soon be leaving, and Bill Parcells will soon succeed him. But what's important is that in George Young the Giants have only one general manager. And that general manager quickly, quietly and decisively turned what could have been lingering chaos into instant order.

title: NETS FALL ON STEAL BY KINGS
description: Within the span of 19 seconds, the homecoming of Otis Birdsong went from triumph to defeat. Birdsong, the guard the Nets acquired from the Kings, hit a onehanded floater in the lane with only 19 seconds left to give New Jersey a 118-116 edge. But soon, after Larry Drew of Kansas City had hit two free throws to tie the game with 11 seconds remaining, Birdsong was victimized by a slip and the hands of Mike Woodson, a former Net.

title: Animal Kingdom Opens Pages for Advertising
description: The New York Zoological Society has decided to open the pages of its Animal Kingdom, a six-copies-a-year magazine, to advertisers with the April/May issue.

title: 54 on Lower East Side Arrested in Drug Sweep
description: In an eight-hour sweep through the Lower East Side yesterday, plainclothes police officers arrested 54 people and charged them with selling or possessing drugs, the police said.

title: Smith Chief Wary Of Whittaker
description: The Whittaker Corporation's recent purchase of 8.3 percent of Smith International Inc.'s stock does not sit well with Smith's chairman, Jerry W. Neely.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have telegrams here on my desk today criticizing me for abandoning ship while we are going down.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 19th Century Revisited

title: HOUSE WOULD BAR FUNDS FOR 2 WATER PROJECTS
description: The House has voted to deny money for two huge Western water projects that environmentalists have fought for a decade.

title: A MASTER AT THE ART OF SUCCESS
description: When Alabama defeated Auburn, 28-17, on Nov. 28, 1981, Paul (Bear) Bryant gained his 315th victory as a major college head coach, breaking the former record of 314 established by Amos Alonzo Stagg from 1892 through 1949. It took Stagg 57 years to win so many games, but Bryant set the record in 37 seasons as a head coach.

title: EVANS-ARISTOCRAT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for the 1982 qr and 6 mos have been reduced by nonoperating pretax costs of $492,000 attributable to the Easco Corp tender offer and Masco Corp merger

title: DELTA QUEEN STEAMBOAT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After a loss of $896,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Boston Celtics, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 8:10 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 8 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape.

title: THE IRANIAN PEOPLE'S 'ONLY SOURCE OF HOPE'
description: To the Editor:

title: LOTTERY: NOT A PENNY EXTRA FOR EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Skalbania Bankrupt
description: Nelson Skalbania, the real-estate and sports entreprenuer, filed a proposal in Vancouver, British Columbia, under the Bankruptcy Act that called for his 125 unsecured creditors to allow him five years to repay $30.3 million in debts. High interest rates, a depressed real-estate market and millions lost on sports ventures such as the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League and the Calgary Boomers of the North American Soccer League, brought about the bankruptcy. ... Irv Berger, owner of the Phoenix Inferno of the Major Indoor Soccer League, filed for financial reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: FED IS TOLD TO KEEP ITS RATES LOW
description: In an unusual step, the House of Representatives has directed the Federal Reserve Board to establish a level of interest rates low enough to stimulate economic recovery.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HOME INSURANCE LOSES SIMILAR SUIT
description: Two age-discrimination cases involving millions of dollars for almost 300 former employees of the Home Insurance Company and the Consolidated Edison Company have been decided.

title: Santas Say Children Seek Aid for Parents
description: Children going to see Santa Claus this year are frequently asking for jobs and money for out-of-work parents instead of presents for themselves, the nation's largest retailer said today.

title: CONGRESS IS URGED TO HELP HOMELESS
description: Congress was urged today to help the growing number of homeless Americans, displaced by unemployment and neglect, whose problems of cold, hunger and joblessness were described as a ''national disgrace.''

title: Marcos Foes in House Arrest
description: Ten journalists charged with conspiring to overthrow President Ferdinand E. Marcos were transferred today to a form of house arrest after eight days in prison. Their tabloid, We Forum, had published articles severely critical of Mr. Marcos and the armed forces.

title: BOARD BLAMES LACK OF DATA FOR DC-10 CRASH IN BOSTON
description: The National Transportation Safety Board ruled today that the failure of the Federal Aviation Administration to provide pilots with adequate data on icy runway conditions was the chief cause of the World Airways DC-10 accident in Boston last Jan. 23.

title: CRAB HOUSE INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 29
CONTRIBUTORS GIVE TO NEEDIEST IN LIEU OF SHOPPING FOR GIFTS
description: With the Christmas shopping season at its peak, many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have chosen to give to the poor and deprived ''in lieu of'' buying or exchanging gifts.

title: Salvador Army Inquires Into Death of American
description: The army began a formal investigation today into the case of a young American slain by a Salvadoran soldier, the United States Embassy said.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: WREATH EXHIBITION
description: The Wreath: Interpretations, Arsenal Gallery, 64th Street off Fifth Avenue at Central Park Zoo, third floor, 212- 360-8141.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Brother of Sadat Is Charged
description: The Egyptian Government today formally charged Esmat Sadat, half-brother of the late President Anwar el-Sadat, with corruption, fraud and influence-peddling, and demanded that he and two sons be imprisoned for one year.

title: Jos. Schlitz Site
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company is selling its former Milwaukee headquarters to two brothers, Harold and B.J. Sampson of Milwaukee, who plan to develop the space for industrial and commercial use, the company said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Architectural Lode

title: Founder of Synanon And 12 Others Indicted
description: Charles Dederich Sr., founder of the antidrug Synanon Foundation, and 10 associates have been arrested on charges of violating state securities laws, the authorities said.

title: Bank Adds Payout
description: The First Boston Corporation said yesterday that its board had declared a $3-a-share supplemental dividend, as well as its usual 25-cent quarterly dividend, payable Jan. 17 to holders of both common and class A common as of Dec. 27.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 60 Years at Beth Israel

title: Francis Kelly, Analyst For Agriculture Dept.
description: Francis A. Kelly, a retired commodity analyst with the United States Agriculture Department and an assistant agricultural secretary under Gov. W. Averell Harriman of New York, died of cancer Sunday at Providence Hospital in Washington. He was 64 years old and lived in Washington.

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
KEAN REJECTS INCOME-TAX RISE
description: Governor Kean said today that if members of the New Jersey Legislature passed a bill increasing the state income tax on earnings above $50,000 he would veto it ''and have it back on their desks in 10 minutes.''

title: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $415,000 and income of $3,597,000 from the sale of domestic timberland...C-Ne t loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,106,000 and losses of $1.5 million from a Canadian jointventure disposed of in the 1982 second qr

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: AS holiday crowds swirl around Rockefeller Center's 50th annual Christmas tree, few watching the glittering, festive scene are aware that above them, unseen from the plaza level, are rooftop terraces with formal gardens of great calm and symmetry.

title: TRACY AUSTIN VICTOR
description: Pam Shriver did not want to play a third set tonight. Not with jet lag from Australia and the prospect of meeting Chris Evert Lloyd in the next round of the Toyota women's tennis championships.

title: News Analysis
description: Far from easing martial law, the legislation that Poland's rulers have put before Parliament to ''suspend'' military rule, not only keeps sweeping state powers but also gives the authorities even harsher weapons against dissent.

title: A NEW BRANCH
description: a little cozier and a bit of a neighborhood store,'' said Mr. Conran. The new Conran's is at 2-8 Astor Place, between Broadway and Lafayette Street.

title: Mary Martin Working; First Show Since Injury
description: The actress Mary Martin began work today on an episode of ABC's ''The Love Boat,'' her first dramatic appearance since she was seriously injured in a traffic accident. Miss Martin and the film star Janet Gaynor were injured Sept. 5 when a van collided with their taxi in San Francisco.

title: Butler Filing
description: The Butler Communications Corporation, which bought radio stations WHLD-AM and WZIR-FM on suburban Grand Island in May 1980, has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. William M. Savino, lawyer for the company, said its debts total about $1.7 million. The company cited ''unexpectedly high start-up costs'' for creating a deficit before the stations switched last June to ''an album-oriented rock format.''

title: Shock-Therapy Ban Challenged in Berkeley
description: Three psychiatric societies have filed a lawsuit charging that Berkeley's ban on electroshock therapy is unconstitutional.

title: THE MX AND REAGAN'S RECEPTIVITY TO COMPROMISE
description: For most of his first two years in office, President Reagan established an image as a single-minded, selfconfident, determined leader with strong, even rigid, views who rarely gave much ground to his opposition on big issues.

title: No Idle Chatter
description: Howard Cosell, who says he has retired as a boxing commentator, will be replaced as a general sports announcer Sunday on his ABC network program, Sports Beat. But only for a minute.

title: REPORTERS SAY THEY'LL USE DATA FROM BRIEFING
description: Reporters who attended a Defense Department briefing Tuesday at which they were asked to sign a secrecy oath said yesterday that they would use information from that session in future reports.

title: Moosehead Returning To TV for Rose Parade
description: One of the advertisers whose commercials will be seen on both the CBS-TV and NBC-TV networks' coverage of the Tournament of Roses Parade on New Year's Day will be Moosehead Canadian Lager Beer.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Massachusetts Man Is Guilty Of Not Registering for Draft
description: Edward J. Hasbrouck, 22 years old, of Wellesley, was convicted today of failing to register with the Selective Service. Three supporters were arrested in a protest after the verdict was announced.

title: STAGE: 'UPPER DEPTHS,' A FAMILY TALE
description: IN his malevolent new comedy, ''The Upper Depths,'' David Steven Rappoport pinions the American family - and the wrestling image is intentional. One of the family's two teen-age daughters, the swaggering Rikke Borge, is a coed wrestling champion. Whenever her mother (Marilyn Chris) dares to criticize - or to ignore - her, she throws the older woman to the floor. After a while, when the mother sees her Amazonian daughter approaching, she runs for cover. In this self-destructive household, there is no hiding place.

title: COURT MOVES THE BRINK'S TRIAL TO ADJACENT ORANGE COUNTY
description: A state appeals court, finding that the six defendants in the Brink's murder and robbery trial were unlikely to receive a fair trial in Rockland County, transferred the case yesterday to adjacent Orange County.

title: FOR THE COLLECTOR, TREE ORNAMENTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judith Reiter Weissman is a freelance writer and lecturer on American folk art. By JUDITH REITER WEISSMAN

title: F.T.C.'S OVERSIGHT OF DOCTORS BACKED IN SENATE PANEL'S VOTE
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today, 15 to 14, to permit the Federal Trade Commission to continue policing the trade practices of physicians and other state-regulated professionals.

title: HOLDERS GET MORE TIME ON PARTIAL TAKEOVERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today gave shareholders more time to send in their stock in response to a partial takeover bid. The new rule is expected to make companies less eager to mount ''two-tier'' offers, whereby they typically offer cash for part of a company and a lower price, in stock, for the rest.

title: PROMISES; Settle for Excellence
description: Governor-elect Cuomo has made much of his commitment to finding both excellence and the first woman for the New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest. For the moment the second goal may not be attainable: the State Commission on Judicial Nomination has given Mr. Cuomo the names of four men, all judges, from whom he must choose one to replace retiring Judge Domenick Gabrielli.

title: Study Urges Aid Speedup
description: The Brandt Commission warned today that the world's wealthier countries must move boldly and quickly to augment credits available to the poorer and developing nations if a worldwide economic collapse is to be avoided.

title: U.S. Steel Cutback
description: The United States Steel Corporation suspended plans to modernize its Edgar Thomson plant as a high-volume producer of slab steel because of a depressed market, high labor costs and low productivity. The announcement by the country's largest steelmaker was another economic blow to the battered Monongahela River valley near Pittsburgh, which has already seen more than 15,000 steelworkers lose their jobs.

title: U.S. Gives Credit Guarantees To Iraq for Food Purchases
description: The United States has granted $210 million in export credit guarantees to finance food sales to Iraq, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: I.M.F. Funds to Turkey
description: The Finance Ministry said today that the International Monetary Fund was satisfied with the performance of Turkey's economy in 1982 and would release next year two remaining parts of a $1.6 billion, three-year standby credit. A statement issued after a meeting between an I.M.F. delegation and Finance Minister Adnan Baser Kafaoglu said $100 million would be released in January and the remaining $190 million in June.

title: CORRECTION
description: An announcement of a Sotheby Parke Bernet poetry contest in some editions of Weekend on Oct. 15 omitted the entrance fee. It is 2 ($3.24). The deadline has been extended to Dec. 31.

title: People's Big Gatefold
description: People magazine will be celebrating Christmas and the New Year with the biggest front-cover gatefold ad it has ever carried. The 11-page front-cover feature running in the annual double issue dated Dec. 20 is from Campbell Soup via Backer & Spielvogel. It will be sort of a retrospective of advertising for America's favorite canned soup going back to the Campbell Kids in 1916.

title: SEOUL LETS DISSIDENT LEAVE PRISON
description: South Korea has transferred Kim Dae Jung, a leading dissident, from prison to a university hospital and may allow him to go to the United States, according to Government officials in Seoul.

title: AROUND HARLEM, A LONG WINTER SHORT ON WORK
description: Frank Thomas does not have much in life and maybe never will, but there is one thing about him and that is grit. Mr. Thomas last had a regular job two years ago. He was a driver in an antipoverty program. But the program was ended, and today Mr. Thomas, 35 years old, married and a father of two, makes a living, such as it is, hawking clothes on the streets around 119th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard.

title: Katharine Hepburn In 'Good' Condition
description: Katharine Hepburn, who is recovering from a broken ankle suffered in an automobile accident, was reported in ''good'' condition today at Hartford Hospital.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty said that M/A-Com Inc. had agreed to buy out Aetna's interest in their partnership, Local Digital Distribution Co. of Rockville, Md., for 400,000 M/A-Com shares.

title: Ford Incentives On Tractors
description: The Ford Motor Company said it is agreeing to pay finance charges for up to a year on new-model farm and industrial tractor purchases.

title: HIGHWAY ROBBERY
