description: The multibillion-dollar highway-repair and job-creation bill emerging from the lame-duck session of Congress is essentially a fraud.

title: U.S. OFFICER HURT IN BLAST IN GERMANY
description: A United States Army officer was wounded today when a powerful bomb destroyed his car at an Army housing area near the south German city of Darmstadt, an Army spokesman said.

title: TWO JETS RECALL BRYANT
description: When Marty Lyons reminisced about Paul (Bear) Bryant, his college coach at Alabama who announced his retirement yesterday, he did not immediately think about football games. The Jet defensive tackle remembered a living room and an office, especially the office.

title: Technology; Mixed Signals For AM Stereo
description: STEREOPHONIC broadcasts over AM radio, an eagerly awaited technical advancement, may have overcome its most important barrier: Last week Delco Electronics, the nation's largest maker of car radios, selected a system developed by the Motorola Corporation.

title: ABANDONING AFGHAN RESISTANCE SOLVES NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRISTMAS: A SERMON BY LUTHER
description: In the realm of one-man performances, there is none quite like the virtuosity displayed by Prof. Roland Bainton at the Yale Divinity School's annual Christmas celebration. For the 88-year-old retired Yale professor of church history, it is a testimony of faith, a test of endurance and a show of scholarship.

title: Winfield Awaits Latest Payment
description: After months of private and public wrangling, the David M. Winfield Foundation and George Steinbrenner reached an out-of-court settlement last Sept. 9 on the foundation's lawsuit against the Yankees' prinicipal owner. The suit stemmed from Steinbrenner's failure to contribute $300,000 per year to the foundation under his agreement with Winfield.

title: Judge Stays Texas Execution
description: Federal District Judge Robert Parker today granted a stay of execution for James D. Autry, a convicted murderer who had been scheduled to die by injection in the death house Friday. Judge Parker said in a statement that he granted the stay ''to allow sufficient time'' for consideration of an appeal by Mr. Autry, 28 years old, who was convicted of killing a Port Arthur convenience store clerk in a robbery in 1980.

title: DEMOCRAT IS CRITICAL OF BUSINESS GROUP FOR BACKING G.O.P.
description: Robert S. Strauss, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, told the United States Chamber of Commerce today that it was hurting the cause of business in America by backing only Republican Congressional candidates.

title: 60 Rescued From Ship Sinking in the Pacific
description: The 61 crew members of a sinking Indian freighter abandoned ship in the storm-tossed Pacific just as a merchant ship steamed into sight to rescue them today, according to the Coast Guard, which said there was one fatality.

title: A NEW YORK CULTURAL LEADER
description: Alan J. Freedman, chairman of the board and president of Ketcham & McDougall Inc. and a leading figure in New York City cultural affairs, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home on Central Park West. He was 59 years old.

title: STATE COURT DISMISSES LIBEL SUIT OVER NOVEL
description: The Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court on Tuesday dismissed a libel suit against a novelist accused of basing one of his characters in part on a former girlfriend. The court ruled, in effect, that the differences between the fictional and real life characters outweighed the similarities.

title: A FRIENDLY COACH
description: To Giant fans, he is Bill Parcells, a big, amiable man who wears a red sweater or jacket on the sidelines and wigwags signals to the defense. To the players on that defense, he is Tuna, a coach who gives and takes locker-room and practice-field barbs with both grace and effectiveness.

title: DESIGN BOOKSHELF
description: 60 YEARS OF INTERIOR DECORATING: A CAREER OF ELEGANT ROOMS By JANE GENIESSE

title: Q&A
description: Q. My house has an enclosed porch with a crawl space underneath. I intend to cover the exposed ground in this crawl space with heavy plastic sheets, as mentioned in one of your columns. An opening which measures about three feet by four feet connects this crawl space with the adjoining cellar. With this opening, do I still have to provide for ventilation in the crawl space by cutting openings in the outside walls of the foundation?

title: Carrie Fisher in 'Agnes'
description: Carrie Fisher, who played Princess Leia in the films ''Star Wars'' and ''The Empire Strikes Back,'' has been signed to replace Amanda Plummer in ''Agnes of God.''

title: Zapata's President Adding Chief's Post
description: Ronald C. Lassiter, president and chief operating officer of the Zapata Corporation, will add the duties of chief executive officer on Jan. 1.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The shr earnings for both 1981 periods were adjusted for 4 percent stock divd paid in May 1982

title: PERKINS TO SUCCEED BRYANT AS ALABAMA COACH
description: On a day of rapid developments here and in Tuscaloosa, Ala., Paul (Bear) Bryant retired as football coach at the University of Alabama, Ray Perkins announced that he would leave as coach of the Giants to succeed him, and the Giants named Bill Parcells, their defensive coordinator, to replace Perkins.

title: SHORT-TERM U.S. RATES DROP
description: Interest rates fell slightly for short-term Treasury securities but rose a bit for long-term bonds in quiet trading yesterday as market participants focused on new offerings of Treasury notes and bonds totaling $19.5 billion this week and next.

title: Heileman Lifts Bid for Pabst
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company raised the price of its bid for the Pabst Brewing Company to $32 a share, matching a competing tender offer by Paul Kalmanovitz.

title: Brazil to Seek $9 Billion in Financing
description: Brazilian officials are expected to ask their foreign bank creditors next Monday for about $5 billion in new loans and for the refinancing of about $4 billion in principal payments that will fall due in 1983, banking officials said today.

title: DRAPER MEETS WITH GEMAYEL IN NEW EFFORT TO GET PULLOUT
description: Lebanese leaders met today with a special American envoy who was reportedly carrying new ideas to break the deadlock holding up negotiations on the evacuation of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon.

title: TO COUNTERACT THE 'FLOURISHING BARBARISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: DEFENSE HELPS THE ECONOMY
description: An already difficult defense debate has become increasingly clouded by assertions that military spending creates far fewer jobs than corresponding civilian outlays. A new rush of ''findings'' seems to be upon us. In light of today's unemployment rate and the new hard look at defense, even from once staunch supporters, such claims merit close examination.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $705,000 for the qr and yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,460,000 for the qr and $3,539,000 for the yr

title: DELBELLO'S DESIGNATED SUCCESSOR SUPPORTS STATUS QUO
description: For Andrew P. O'Rourke, the chairman of Westchester County's Board of Legislators and the man designated Tuesday by Republican leaders to succeed Alfred B. DelBello as County Executive, the move should be an easy one. His eighth-floor office is directly under Mr. DelBello's.

title: HINTS OF UNEASINESS AT SETTLEMENTS BANK
description: With country after country running short of cash, the line is lengthening at a specialized institution that functions as an emergency credit window: The Bank for International Settlements has arranged short-term credit this year for Hungary, Mexico and - sources said today - Brazil, in its role as protector of the world's lending network. Yugoslavia and Argentina are also seeking aid.

title: Shamir Denies Making Argentine Arms Deal
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir denied today that he had negotiated a new arms agreement with Argentina during his current visit there.

title: STAGE: 'FAMILY BUSINESS,' WITH ANGELA LANSBURY
description: IT would be unjust to say that ''A Little Family Business,'' the comedy that brought Angela Lansbury back to Broadway last night, is the worst production in a poor theater season. After all, those with long memories can still recall the summer's ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers.'' So let's be fair and just say that ''A Little Family Business'' is the season's worst nonmusical play. It's definitely the thing to see once you've exhausted all the all-night movies on 42d Street.

title: A Pianist's Neighbors
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: On ''Practicing at Home, Pianissimo'' (Dec. 2): My husband, Walter Hautzig, is a pianist, and so far our experience with neighbors in the building where we have now lived for some 26 years has been a source of mutual pleasure and amusement.

title: CROSS IN THE CROSS HAIRS
description: In August 1980 Yuri Andropov, then head of the K.G.B., was probably given an unpleasant assignment that would determine whether he had the daring and ruthlessness to be master of the Kremlin.

title: FORMER SPOUSES WIN JERSEY CASE ON COLLEGE COST
description: People who work to support their spouses in college with the expectation of sharing the benefits of that education should be reimbursed for their help if the couple are later divorced, the State Supreme Court ruled today.

title: MINUET WITH CATHOLIC BISHOPS OVER NUCLEAR WAR
description: When the nation's Roman Catholic bishops met here last month to discuss their pastoral letter on nuclear war, President Reagan and other senior officials made several unpublicized overtures to persuade them that Administration policy on nuclear deterrence could withstand the test of morality. The bishops politely but firmly spurned those as well as more publicized advances.

title: PAYROLL TAX MEASURE STALLS IN ALBANY
description: A tax measure to help avert an increase in bus, subway and commuter rail fares was stalled tonight after Republicans in the State Senate were unable to agree among themselves on what to do about it.

title: Now the Hottest Ticket
description: Liberty Bowl officials said last month that the Dec. 29 game was a 52,000-seat sellout. But the news that Coach Paul (Bear) Bryant of Alabama would make his farewell in the game, against Illinois, has brought a surge of calls seeking tickets.

title: A.T.&T. Down 3.7%; First Fall Since '75
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, citing the recession's adverse impact on demand for phone services, yesterday announced its first quarterly decline in net income since 1975.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
A FEW TEARS FALL ON ALABAMA
description: There were tears and lots of stories on this gloomy day when it rained heavily in Alabama and Bear Bryant stepped down.

title: GUATEMALANS MEET ON KIDNAPPING OF HONDURAN LEADER'S DAUGHTER
description: Government security forces searched houses and cars today for the kidnapped daughter of the President of Honduras, held under threat of death by leftist guerrillas demanding publication of a political statement.

title: SHARON DECLINES TO TESTIFY AGAIN
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon today informed the state commission investigating the killings of Palestinian civilians in Beirut that he did not intend to exercise his right to reappear, to call witnesses or to introduce new evidence.

title: SEX STEREOTYPING IN DESIGN
description: ''That every normal man should be repelled by any suggestion of effeminacy is only natural. But even so, there is no reason why the house of a man living alone should be furnished like the display rooms of a cement company.'' - ''The Personality of a House,'' Emily Post, 1948.

title: Dean Witter Has Insured Accounts
description: Dean Witter Reynolds, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company, offered its own insured accounts, intensifying competition between banking institutions and brokerage houses in the $230 billion money market mutual fund business.

title: I.B.M. Price Cuts
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it was cutting prices on its 3380 direct access storage device and 3880 controller by 15 percent. But shortterm lease and rental prices for the two products will be increased by 15 percent effective April 1. It also announced volume discounts ranging from 6 to 12 percent.

title: OFFICIALS EXTEND WARNING TO CITY ON USE OF WATER
description: The Delaware River Basin Commission today extended its drought warning for New York City through January. The action came after the regulatory agency's chief engineer, Robert L. Goodell, reported that storage in three upstate New York City reservoirs had fallen to levels that brought on a severe drought two years ago.

title: BACTERIOLOGIST LED RESEARCH ON AIR IONS
description: Prof. Albert Paul Krueger, a University of California bacteriologist best known for his research on air ions, died Dec. 8 at a hospital in Oakland, Calif. He was 80 years old.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $120,000; results for the latest first qr do not include the results of the food service equipment group whose operations lost $909,000 in the qr; thos results will be netted against the profits on the sale of the business to B.I.H. Inc which occurred Nov 12 and will be recorded in the second qr

title: AGE OF MAN'S OLDEST ANCESTOR IN DOUBT
description: A new analysis of fossil remains and geological strata has cast doubt on the age and perhaps the evolutionary significance of ''Lucy,'' the bones of an apelike species that is widely regarded as the oldest known human ancestor.

title: COMPUTER TO PICK 1984 OLYMPIC TICKET HOLDERS
description: Tickets for the most popular events at the 1984 Summer Olympic Games here will be allocated through a computerized national lottery, officials said today.

title: Dr. Philipp Lohman, 76, Dies; Former Economics Professor
description: Dr. Philipp H. Lohman, retired chairman of the department of commerce and economics at the University of Vermont and a former professor of economics at Brooklyn and Marymount Colleges, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Houston. He was 76 years old.

title: TOP EXECUTIVE NAMED BY NOVO INDUSTRIES
description: Novo Laboratories Inc. has named Stanley R. Haladayna president and chief executive officer. The company is the United States subsidiary of Novo Industri, the big Danish pharmaceutical company.

title: WHERE THE MYTHS MEET THE FACTS
description: Question: Isn't it true that nearly everyone who lives in the Washington area works for the Federal Government? Answer: No. In fact, only one fourth of those in the work force do, although 10 percent work for state and local governments. Most people work in private business, although that is often Government-related.

title: South African Agent Expelled by the British
description: Britain has ejected a South African Embassy employee on suspicion of espionage.

title: REAGAN WRITES TO BEGIN URGING FASTER PULLOUT
description: President Reagan has sent a letter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin in an attempt to prompt faster action by Israel in withdrawing its troops from Lebanon, according to Administration officials.

title: New Dean at Divinity School
description: The Rev. James E. Annand has been named dean of Berkeley Divinity School, an Episcopal seminary here affiliated with the Yale Divinity School. He will succeed the Rev. Charles H. Clark.

title: CABARET MUSIC: THOMPSON TWINS
description: BRITISH music-hall jollity is alive and decked out with the latest trappings in the form of the Thompson Twins. As a sextet plus a dancer, the group strutted and posed through a set at the Ritz late Wednesday night.

title: UNICEF URGES FOUR STEPS TO SAVE CHILDREN'S LIVES
description: The lives of 20,000 children could be saved each day by adoption of four simple, low-cost health measures that have already proved successful in limited trials in several developing countries, the United Nations Children's Fund said in a report yesterday.

title: Kean Signs Bill to Aid Rebuilding of a Track
description: A bill designed to encourage private investment in rebuilding the burned-out Garden State Park horseracing track was signed by Governor Kean today.

title: GIANTS' AIDES IN LIMBO
description: When Ray Perkins leaves the Giants at the end of the season to become the University of Alabama football coach, most of his nine assistant coaches will face uncertain futures.

title: SEAVER REJOINS METS WITH A YEAR GUARANTEED
description: Five and a half years later, Tom Seaver returned to the Mets, and was welcomed home yesterday with his old locker, his old No. 41 and a new four-year contract that is guaranteed for only one year.

title: No Headline
description: 4 F.B.I. AGENTS AND 2 OTHERS KILLED IN OHIO PLANE CRASH

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Casio Pocket TV
description: The Casio Computer Company said it would begin selling pocket-sized television sets next June for about $200. The company said the television, which will weigh 12.35 ounces and have 12 channels, could run for up to seven hours on batteries. It plans to produce 20,000 a month.

title: THOR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes income from discontinued operations of $29,000...C-Includes income of $83,000 from discontinued operations...D-Net income; the 1981 figures includedlosses from discontinued operations of $3,000 for the qr and $55,000 for the 9 mos

title: SCHMIDT HOPING FOR REVENGE IN HAMBURG VOTE ON SUNDAY
description: Helmut Schmidt said here today that Sunday's election for the Hamburg state legislature would be the first popular verdict on the coalition that ousted him from power 10 weeks ago.

title: PUBLISHING: CRITICS LIST 20 TOP BOOKS
description: THE National Book Critics Circle, an organization of some 200 critics and book-review editors, has nominated 20 books as the best of 1982. The nominees, five in each of four categories, include such widely discussed titles as Jonathan Schell's book about nuclear warfare and Robert A. Caro's massive study of Lyndon B. Johnson, but there are several sleepers in the list. The nominees:

title: RELATIVE OF SADAT INDICTED IN EGYPT
description: The Egyptian prosecutor's office indicted the half brother of Anwar el-Sadat today on charges that included influence peddling, the unlawful seizure of Government and private property, black marketeering and the import and sale of ''rotten'' food.

title: Capitals and Stars Tie, Keep Streaks
description: Tim Young scored with 27 seconds left to give the Minnesota North Stars a 4-4 tie with the Washington Capitals tonight.

title: Altman's Head Resigns
description: John W. Christian Jr. has resigned as president of B. Altman & Company and Lewis C. Kaufman, a longtime Altman executive, has been named to succeed him.

title: Posner Decision On Burnup & Sims
description: Victor Posner, the financier, has agreed not to try to take control of or change the board of Burnup & Sims Inc. at least until Jan. 10, the day hearings begin on the company's antitrust suit against him.

title: THATCHER CABINET LOSES VOTE ON BILL
description: Right-wing Conservatives joined forces with opposition members today to hand Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher her first major parliamentary defeat by voting down a bill intended to relax immigration.

title: U.S. STRESSES ALLIED SUPPORT ON MEDIUM-RANGE MISSILES
description: The White House issued a statement today stressing that the Administration and Western European allies still stood firmly behind President Reagan's proposal to eliminate all medium-range nuclear missiles from the Eurasian land mass.

title: JAPANESE ANGERED BY CAR BILL
description: Japanese Government and auto industry leaders here reacted with anger today to the passage by the United States House of Representatives of a domestic content bill aimed at restricting Japanese auto exports to America.

title: Cutting New Ice
description: Once the Olympics are over, a successful figure skater can look forward to signing a lucrative contract with an ice show. Robin Cousins of Britain, who won the gold medal in the 1980 Games in Lake Placid, N.Y., toured for a year with Holiday On Ice.

title: Bridge: Grand National Continues At the Waldorf on Sunday
description: The district final of the Grand National Pairs will be played Sunday at 1:15 P.M. in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The top three pairs in the final standings will qualify for a free trip to Hawaii, where the national finals will be played in March. In an early stage of the Grand National, a lesson learned many years ago proved helpful to one of the contestants on the diagramed deal. South was Kalman Rosenbluth of Hewlett, L.I., and North was Gilda Katz of Hewlett Harbor. The bidding began routinely, but North had a difficult bid on the second round.

title: Magnavox Gatefold
description: Magnavox ,with the help of Campbell-Ewald, its agency, has decided that the February issue of Playboy, traditionally the most free of advertising, would be a good one in which to run a centerfold of its own.

title: Girl With New Liver Released From Hospital
description: Jamie Fiske, the baby who doctors said would die before Thanksgiving without a liver transplant, smiled and waved goodbye today as she headed home to Bridgeport, Mass.

title: STAFF OF UTAH HOSPITAL IS INSPIRED BY THE TOUGHNESS OF HEART PATIENT
description: Doctors at the University of Utah Medical Center described two conditions today: the health of Dr. Barney B. Clark after two weeks with an artificial heart and their own emotional involvement in his case.

title: Hat, Cap and Millinery Union Joins With Clothing Workers
description: The United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, a small group with a rich history going back to the early 1800's, has affiliated with the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union.

title: SAFETY PANEL OFFERS RULES TO CUT CRASHES ON ICY AIRPORT RUNWAYS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board adopted a comprehensive set of recommendations yesterday for Government action to reduce the chances of crashes by airplanes landing or taking off on iceladen or other slippery runways.

title: Heart-Lungs Recipient Dies of Lung Infection
description: A 41-year-old man who was the recipient of a transplanted heart and lungs died Wednesday night from lung complications.

title: ONE-STOP SHOP-AND-SNACKING
description: Holiday shopping can be a wilting experience. Frayed nerves, aching feet and hunger can test anyone's Christmas spirit. However, a number of shops help ease the shopper's lot by providing not only gift items but also a place to eat.

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net includes a provision of $443,925,000 for restructuring costs, loss of $324,009 from discontinued operations and extraordinary income of $21,823,000...C-After a loss of $57,224,000 from discontinued operations

title: BUDGET QUESTIONS AND FRAYED NERVES
description: As surely as snowflakes and mistletoe accompany the Christmas season, so do ''horror stories'' about the Federal budget. For this is the time that Presidents review their options for spending cuts for the next fiscal year.

title: Christie's sets sales record.
description: CHRISTIE'S announced yesterday that total sales worldwide for the first half of its auction season, which began in August and ended this week, was $137,679,150, the highest for such a period in its history, up from $130,352,960 a year ago. For the first time also, Christie's in the United States, which had sales of $63,846,000, surpassed Christie's in Britain, where the total was $55,907,250. The Beat at Sotheby's Is Rock-and-Roll

title: HOUSE CHARGES HEAD OF E.P.A. WITH CONTEMPT
description: The House of Representatives voted tonight to cite Anne M. Gorsuch, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, for contempt of Congress. A Cabinet-level official has never before faced such a charge.

title: U.S. Grain Credit to Iraq
description: Iraq will be able to buy American grain under a new $210 million package of loan guarantees, the Agriculture Department announced today. Melvin E. Sims, the department's general sales manager, said the guarantees include $120 million for the purchase of wheat, $80 million for rice and $10 million for feed grains. All purchases and shipments must be completed by Sept. 30, 1983, he said.

title: CONCERT: FOR LOVE OF MUSIC
description: ANY chamber-music program that limits itself to Beethoven, Brahms and Dvorak nowadays must offer absolutely first-class performances of the works involved if it is to justify itself. That, unfortunately, did not happen in For the Love of Music's concert at Goodman House on Tuesday night.

title: A 5-11 GUARD SPRINGS A SURPRISE
description: G ordon Austin of American University decided Wednesday night that the highly ranked Georgetown team would not expect a guard who stood 5 feet 11 inches to challenge the 7-foot center Pat Ewing. Ewing's defensive prowess surpasses even that of Ralph Sampson, and the Virginia center is considered by many as the best player in the country.

title: Yankees, Stay Home
description: ''For baseball fans,'' says Roger Angell, ''opening days are psychic and profound.'' Thus does The New Yorker's sports correspondent support New York City's legal effort to stop the Yankees from playing their first three ''home'' games in Denver next year. Legions of fans cheer him on.

title: Italian pub-cafe; Pakistan revisited.
description: THE stylish, modern version of the Italian trattoria is the pubcafe-restaurant, a phenomenon that began five years ago, when Parma opened on Third Avenue, near 79th Street. Characterized by wood paneling, posters, a casual, noisy and attractive crowd, and a short, well-balanced menu, the style rapidly became popular. Almost as rapidly, it inspired imitations.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL NEW YORK (NL) - Acquired Tom S eaver, pitcher, from the Cincinnati Reds f or Charlie Puleo, pitcher, and Lloyd Mac- C lendon, catcher at Lynchburg of the C arolina League, and Jason Felice, out- f ielder at Little Falls of the New York- P enn League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Announced that F rank Taveras, shortstop, will not be join- i ng the team for spring training as a non- r oster player. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed Gaylord P erry, pitcher.

title: Pitt Linebacker Is Killed in Fall
description: Todd Becker, a University of Pittsburgh football player, was killed early this morning in a fall from a third-story dormitory building, police and school officials said.

title: SYMPHONY: QUEENS GROUP
description: IN David Katz, the Queens Symphony Chamber Orchestra has an earnest and sensitive conductor. Wednesday night at the Abraham Goodman House, the orchestra accompanied some fine soloists in several concertos and concerto-like pieces. But such attributes cannot disguise the group's deficiencies, and one was left with the impression that, chamber orchestra or not, this is an ensemble with a good deal of growing to do.

title: E.P.A. AIDE ACCUSED OF OUSTER ATTEMPT
description: The assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency asked the agency's inspector general to investigate a whistle blower who worked for her because she wanted to dismiss him, according to an affidavit made available today.

title: Youth Movement
description: The Soviet Union's national hockey team that will play a series of six games against National Hockey League teams, beginning Dec. 28 in Edmonton, will have a new look.

title: A.T.& T. TO ASSIGN NEW UNITS' STOCK TO SHAREHOLDERS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told its 3 million shareholders today how it will distribute stock in the local telephone companies that it will divest by Jan.1, 1984.

title: N.A.S. Billing Outlook
description: In a statement intended for use by the trade press in their yearend reviews, Ted J. Stepien, president of the National Advertising Service, which says it is the No.1 recruitment advertising agency, predicted that his industry would show billing increases of 10 percent in 1983. That, however, would hardly make up for the 25 percent loss he estimates for this year, a crash that would bring total billings down to $750 million from $1 billion. Mr. Stepien also owns the Cleveland Cavaliers basketball team, which isn't doing too well, either.

title: THEATER: 'THE RISE AND RISE OF DANIEL ROCKET'
description: ''THE RISE AND RISE OF DANIEL ROCKET'' (at Playwrights Horizon) is only the second play by Peter Parnell to be produced in New York - the first was ''Sorrows of Stephen'' - but already one has a sense of the playwright's vision. He regards the trauma of growing up with a sweet disposition and a childlike innocence. In each work, the hero is a propulsive romantic figure - driven to outrageous acts by his love for a young woman and by his need to prove himself.

title: Lie Tests Proposed In Bronx Robbery
description: City detectives and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation studying the robbery of the Sentry Armored Car Courier Company in the Bronx have asked company employees to take lie-detector tests voluntarily, investigators said yesterday.

title: Credit Union Loss Report
description: A Congressional panel today released the names of 139 credit unions that had a total of $111.5 million in deposits above the $100,000 insurance limit in the failed Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The worst fears about Abscam, the chilling vision of an executive branch conspiracy against the legislature, with overtones of manipulation and cover-up, have proved to be evanescent.

title: Chile Said to Arrest Over 200 In Anti-Government Protests
description: The police have arrested over 200 people for staging an anti-Government protest in three Chilean cities, Roman Catholic church sources said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Decisions, Decisions

title: People
description: * A. Potter Crolius named advertising director of Golf magazine.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: RUTH MORLEY does not run from challenge. She has designed costumes for operas at the City Center, where there wasn't enough money, and there wasn't enough time. She has dealt with the prima donnas who work in costume houses - ''They're very special,'' she says, ''regular seamstresses can't make the embroideries, regular tailors can't cut a 17th-century man's coat'' - and even the spontaneity of film doesn't faze her. ''I enjoy it,'' she says, ''when they call and say: 'We're not doing that scene. We're doing the hospital scene,' and overnight, I have to dress a hundred doctors and patients and visitors.''

title: COLIN CHAPMAN ,54, A DESIGNER OF RACING CARS, DIES IN ENGLAND
description: Colin Chapman, a designer and builder of automobiles whose ideas changed the face of Grand Prix racing, died yesterday at his home in Norfolk in eastern England, apparently of a heart attack, according to the police. He was 54 years old.

title: VOLUME ALSO DROPS
description: The stock market continued to slide yesterday as lower bond prices added another element of caution to the equity sector. Yields of fixed-income securities, which compete with stocks for investor dollars, moved moderately higher.

title: Conoco Refinery
description: Pacific Resources Inc. said it had completed arrangements to acquire Conoco Inc.'s refinery in Paramount, Calif. Pacific Resources said the previously announced acquisition, through a joint venture with the Oasis Petroleum Corporation, involves a cash payment of $12.5 million and other contractual terms. It said the refinery, with a daily capacity of 46,500 barrels, is expected to generate annual revenues of $400 million.

title: RECOLLECTIONS ON 'PINK PANTHER TRAIL'
description: TO be perfectly honest, Blake Edwards's ''The Trail of the Pink Panther'' is not an entirely ''new'' movie. It was put together - expertly, I think -from out-takes and previously unused sequences from four earlier ''Pink Panther'' comedies, all of which starred the late, great Peter Sellers as the magnificently muddled Inspector Clouseau.

title: Guatemala Will Decide Soon On a Demand by Kidnappers
description: The Guatemalan Government said today that it would decide soon whether to accede to the demand by kidnappers of the daughter of the President of Honduras for publication of a political statement.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Net income includes gains on sale of real estate of $11,486 for fiscal 1982 and$190,000 fora fiscal 1981; fiscal 1981 net includes a $205,000 credit

title: FUTURE AND PRESENT MEET AT CONFERENCE ON TRANSIT FOR CITY
description: The subject at an all-day conference yesterday was the long-range future of public transit in New York, but the present kept intruding. One official left suddenly because of a bomb scare on the IND in Brooklyn, and another hurried out saying he was on his way to Albany or Washington - he wasn't sure which - to lobby for transit aid.

title: Friday; KUROSAWA TO PAKULA
description: Two film events begin today. The uncut, 208-minute version of Akira Kurosawa's ''Seven Samurai,'' with Toshiro Mifune and Takashi Shimura, opens at Cinema Studio 1, Broadway, near 66th Street, in its first New York run. The Japanese classic, about a warrior band that protects a farm village from marauders, was released in the United States in 1955 in a 158-minute version. Admission: $5. Information: 874-8989. And, the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, opens a series of films produced or directed by Alan J. Pakula, starting with his first, ''Fear Strikes Out'' (1957), at 2:30 P.M. and ''Klute'' (1971), introduced by Mr. Pakula, at 6. Free with museum admission: $3 ($1 for children and the elderly; pay what you wish on Tuesdays). ART IN CHILDREN'S BOOKS

title: THE LOOKS AND SOUNDS OF CHRISTMAS
description: ALEXANDRA JOHNSON REX, 7 years old and tartan smart, tapped her patent leather toe impatiently against the glass of the Lever House window, her ponytail jiggling a fandango in the afternoon thaw.

title: Henry Schaffer Is Dead at 92; Founded Supermarket Chain
description: Henry Schaffer, founder of the Empire Supermarkets chain in upstate New York, died of leukemia Wednesday at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 92 years old and lived in Schenectady.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net income includes an extraordinary credit of $2.7 million

title: CARS TO GET RADIO SIGNAL IN TUNNEL
description: The Federal Communications Commission granted permssion today to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to build and operate low-power radio broadcast service in the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels.

title: TO MILLIONS IN NEED, THE U.S.D.A. GIVEAWAY IS NO 'EMPTY OFFER'
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: ELLSWORTH KELLY
description: IT would be difficult to look closely at ''Ellsworth Kelly: Sculpture'' at the Whitney Museum and not conclude that among living American artists Kelly has the role of Mr. Paradox and plays it to perfection.

title: ST. PETER'S (6-0) TOPS BROOKLYN
description: Shelton Gibbs scored 30 points to lead undefeated St. Peter's College to its sixth victory, 61-51, over Brooklyn College here tonight.

title: WALESA DETAINED TO BAR HIS SPEECH
description: Polish authorities today detained Lech Walesa, leader of the outlawed Solidarity union, preventing him from giving a speech at the shipyard workers' monument here.

title: SHARON TO SUBMIT NEW INQUIRY DATA
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon plans to introduce further written evidence and have his attorney make an oral and written summation to the state commission investigating the killings of Palestinians in Beirut by Christian militiamen, a spokesman for the panel said today.

title: ART: MET DISPLAYS GAINS IN SOUTH ASIA COLLECTION
description: UNTIL quite recently, the Metropolitan Museum's collection of Indian and Southeast Asian art was probably the weakest of its holdings, and there seemed little prospect of strengthening it. Objects were hard to come by, given the restrictions that such countries as India placed on taking out material. What's more, though collectors of Chinese and Japanese art have been on the increase, especially since World War II, the more exotic nature of Indian and Southeast Asian art and its often baffling iconography (for one thing, those many-armed deities!) have tended to put off private collectors.

title: CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ROCK: PAT BENATAR AT GARDEN
description: ALONG with the Wilson sisters of Heart, Pat Benatar helped pioneer a teen-oriented hard rock that put women in leading roles traditionally held by men. And on Monday, Miss Benatar, who is enjoying her fourth consecutive best-selling album, appeared at Madison Square Garden before an audience that was composed heavily of miniature versions of the singer raising their arms in tribute.

title: Chiseling on the Poor
description: Adding yet more insult to injury, the Reagan appointees assigned to wreck legal services for the poor have been feeding on the program.

title: Economic Scene; Social Security Impact a Puzzle
description: THE hardest thing for any economist to say is, ''I don't know.'' It is therefore greatly to the credit of Henry Aaron, a senior fellow of the Brookings Institution and professor of economics at the University of Maryland, that he has boldly said he does not know what effects the Social Security system has on national savings, the supply of labor, capital formation or the productivity and growth of the national economy.

title: Virginia Recount Confirmed
description: A panel of three judges of Washington County Circuit Court today declared Frederick Boucher, a Democrat, the winner over Representative William C. Wampler, a Republican, in a recount of southwest Virginia's Ninth Congressional District election.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
JETS PREPARE FOR SHULA'S OFFENSIVE TRICKS
description: The Jets' defense will be looking for the unexpected from Coach Don Shula of the Dolphins when the teams play Saturday afternoon in Miami. Although Shula is a fundamentalist in offensive strategy, he will take risks on occasion and most certainly will try for the unexpected on first-down plays.

title: No Headline
description: President Will Field Questions on Radio

title: MEMORIES OF LOVED ONES SPUR GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: The 71st annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has now received gifts totaling over $775,000, half of the record $1,535,501.34 donated in the 1981-82 drive.

title: Fiat-Allis Recall
description: As many as 500 idled workers at the Fiat-Allis Construction Machinery Inc. plant are to be recalled by Jan. 10, when the factory resumes production after a 10-week shutdown.

title: BURST SEWER FLOODS AREA OF CAIRO AND IMPERILS HEALTH OF RESIDENTS
description: Laborers worked frantically today to repair a major sewer main that burst 11 days ago, flooding a huge area of Cairo with untreated waste that is rapidly becoming a health hazard.

title: LEGAL SERVICES UNIT APPROVES CHIEF'S CONTRACT OVER PROTEST
description: A contract that includes paid membership in a private club for the head of the government's Legal Services Corporation was ratified today.

title: 2 U.S. Reporters Summoned In Moscow for Interrogation
description: Two American reporters were summoned separately to a Soviet prosecutor's office today and questioned about an appeal 10 months ago by 13 Jews to President Yitzhak Navon of Israel.

title: DUNBAR GARDEN COMPLEX IN HARLEM TO BECOME CO-OP
description: In the late 1970's it appeared that the Dunbar Apartments, six brick walk-ups around a spacious, grassy courtyard at 149th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard, would go the way of far too many Harlem residential buildings and fall into significant disrepair.

title: MYTHICAL HANDICAP OF U.S. CAR MAKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW RECRUITS TO JOIN CITY POLICE FORCE IN JANUARY
description: The class of police recruits that was delayed in November because of the New York City budget squeeze will join the force in January to keep it from falling below an agreed level, police officials said yesterday.

title: TV: HAGMAN TAKES TO HELICOPTERS
description: IF you like helicopters, you will love ''Deadly Encounter,'' the new television movie that can be seen at tomorrow night at 9 on Channel 2. In lieu of Santa in his sleigh, CBS is giving the country Larry Hagman in his chopper, complete with Susan Anspach providing ''Perils of Pauline''-style tidbits.

title: No Accord Reached On Tax-Break Plan
description: Negotiatiors failed tonight to reach an agreement to extend a controversial tax break program designed to spur housing renewal in New York City.

title: BANKERS RAISING LOANS FOR MEXICO
description: Bankers reported progress yesterday in their attempts to raise $5 billion in commercial bank loans for the Mexican Government. The International Monetary Fund has said that the loans must be raised before the fund will give final approval to a $3.84 billion credit for Mexico.

title: Southeast Banking Sets an Exchange
description: The Miami-based Southeast Banking Corporation said it and Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. had signed a definitive pact for the exchange by Florida National of certain banking offices, nonbank assets and cash for its stock held by Southeast.

title: Prentice-Hall Names Chief
description: Donald A. Schaefer, president of Prentice-Hall Inc. of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has been named to the additional post of chief executive effective Jan.1.

title: Topics; Pay Now or Weep Later; A Senate Trick
description: Headlines said the Appropriations Committee had rejected a pay increase for senators. But in fact it offered the members even greater income by other means.

title: ZIONIST GROUP AT AN IMPASSE ON ISRAEL'S WEST BANK POLICY
description: The World Zionist Congress, the representative body of the world Zionist movement, failed to reach a consensus today on Prime Minister Menachem Begin's policies in the occupied West Bank.

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $895,000

title: Italian City Hit by a Mudslide Puts Damage at $700 Million
description: Repairmen struggled to restore shattered utilities in this Adriatic city today as a vast wall of mud and debris from surrounding hills moved relentlessly through the suburbs toward the sea.

title: BBC in Polish in Jammed
description: Poland today began jamming all British radio transmissions in Polish, the British Broadcasting Corporation said.

title: Oil Private Placement
description: J. Henry Schroder Wagg & Company, an investment bank, said today that it had completed a $52 million private placement of shares in American Petroleum Production N.V., which will be listed on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange.

title: HOUSE BEGINS ITS DEBATE ON IMMIGRATION BILL AS ADJOURNMENT NEARS
description: The House of Representatives began an impassioned debate on a comprehensive immigration bill today, with opponents complaining that Congress had too little time left to finish work on the legislation.

title: Senators Seek Investigation Of Defense Briefing for Press
description: Two Democratic Senators called today for a White House investigation into whether top Defense Department officials violated Federal laws this week by giving Pentagon reporters intelligence secrets about Soviet military capabilities.

title: 'UNFRIENDLY DRIVING' EXPLODES INTO VIOLENCE ON TEXAS FREEWAYS
description: Their candlelight marriage ceremony was a bright memory just a few hours old when 19-year-old Darren Mayeaux and his bride, Michelle, 18, pulled up at a stop sign in Houston on their way to a honeymoon in Galveston. It seemed the right time for a kiss.

title: Required Reading 'Yea!!!'
description: The Senate custom of opening each Monday session with a poem is more than a year old. This week, the chosen poem, entitled, ''Yea!!!'', was written by Paul Cowan Garver, a 17-year-old from Denver, a month after he underwent cancer surgery.

title: Boeing to Cut Its Work Force
description: The Boeing Company said it would cut its work force in the Seattle area by about 9,000 next year. The major manufacturer of airplanes and missiles cited the soft airline markets and fewer plane orders for the reductions.

title: ATLANTA'S INTEREST RATE WARS
description: The six largest banks and saving institutions here began a retreat today from offering customers promotional interest rates of 21 percent to 25 percent on money market savings accounts.

title: NEW BALCONY FOR SHOPPING
description: If a basement can be chic, why not a balcony? Macy's, which transformed its lowly basement into the trend-setting Cellar, is trying to work the same brand of magic on the balcony overlooking the main floor of its Broadway building.

title: India Eases Baroda Curfew
description: A curfew in the riot-torn Indian city of Baroda was relaxed in some districts today but sporadic violence continued during the night despite heavy army and police patrolling, the state-run All-India Radio reported today. The radio said the death toll since the curfew was imposed after violence broke out Monday had risen to 12.

title: UNDER ANDROPOV, MORE FOOD IN MOSCOW'S STORES
description: The new leadership in the Kremlin has meant new grist for the Kremlinologist's mill, a new style for diplomats to ponder, and a mysterious increase of food for the Muscovite-in-thestreet.

title: Pemex Files Suit
description: Mexico's national oil monopoly has filed suit in Federal court, charging that two Houston engineering companies conspired to fix prices on marine construction and service projects for 20 years. The suit filed by Petroleos Mexicanos, commonly known as Pemex, said its damages amounted to ''many millions of dollars'' because of what was termed the violation of antitrust laws by Brown & Root Inc., a subsidiary of the Halliburton Company, and McDermott Inc. Pemex said it had spent more than $50 million for marine projects between 1960 and 1980. Both Brown & Root and McDermott officials declined comment.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING AT 22-MONTH HIGH
description: The recovery in the housing industry surged ahead in November as construction starts rose to an annual rate of 1.43 million units, the highest in nearly two years, the Government reported today.

title: Samuel Brecher, 80; Painter and Teacher
description: Samuel Brecher, the Austrian-born American painter and teacher, died last month in New York City of a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

title: MUSIC: A CLARION CONCERT
description: THE Clarion Concert presented at Central Presbyterian Church on Wednesday night was billed as ''A Venetian Christmas,'' but anyone lured to attend by the title alone must have been sorely disappointed, for there was no Christmas music of any kind in it.

title: Pagaents, Poems, Plays and Rockettes; Today; American Museum of Natural History-Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West at 81st Street. ''Star of Wonder,'' star show about the sky at the time of Christ's birth, including a look at the winter sky and traditional stories and music. At 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. Tickets, $3.25 ($2.25 for students and the elderly; $1.50 for those younger than 12). Through Jan. 4.  Information on show times: 873-1300, extension 206.; Cathedral of St. John the Divine
description: (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. Annual pageant of the Christmas story in mime with scriptural narration, medieval and early English music for chorus and an ancient fauxbourdon arrangement of the Magnificat, with the students of St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's School. At 2 and 4 P.M. Information: 666-9645. Church of St. Luke in the Fields (Episcopal), 487 Hudson Street. Reading of Clement Clark Moore's ''A Visit From St. Nicholas'' and caroling walk through the streets of Greenwich Village. Reading by the actor Earle Hyman; carolers led by West Village Chorale. At 7:30 P.M. Information: 924-0562.

title: Sovereignty at Sea
description: For all the chaff about diplomats sunning themselves, Jamaica's Montego Bay was a fitting place to launch the Law of the Sea. No sea was more lawless than the Caribbean when privateers made Jamaica their sanctuary. Where better to announce a constitution for all the seas? For once, the creaking machinery of the United Nations worked. The sea law's authors earned their dip.

title: Tests for Cummings
description: Terry Cummings, the San Diego Clippers' star rookie forward, was to be held out of last night's game against Portland after undergoing some medical tests.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Alexander Appointment
description: Alexander & Alexander Services said today that it had named its senior vice president-finance, William Farley, as a director of its British underwriting subsidiary, Sphere Drake Insurance P.L.C.

title: WHITE HOUSE SETBACK ON MX HAS DIVERSE ROOTS
description: On Nov. 22, President Reagan pinned his hopes for producing the new MX missile on the idea of deploying 100 of the missiles in a cluster near Cheyenne, Wyo. Administration officials confidently hoped that, at last, they had something that could persuade Congress to go ahead with the missile production.

title: Securities Bond Refused
description: The Federal district judge in the teamster trial refused today to accept securities valued at $10.75 million as a $5 million bond payment for Allen M. Dorfman, one of the five men convicted Wednesday of conspiring to bribe a United States Senator. Judge Prentice H. Marshall had said he would require cash or negotiable securities for the payment because he feared that Mr. Dorfman, a millionaire insurance man linked to organized crime, would flee.

title: PAY NOW OR WEEP LATER; A Judge's Worth
description: As they await the outcome of their leaders' budget negotiations, New York's legislators might study a proposal to raise and reconcile the pay of the state's judges. The Temporary Commission on Judicial Compensation offers a sober warning that further erosion of salaries will further erode justice.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: City's Gift Horse

title: LET DRUG DEALERS' LOSSES AID THEIR VICTIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dunk and a Jab
description: The last two Knick-Bullet games in Landover, Md., packed the fans into the Capitol Centre, obviously helped by the attractive pairings of Aaron Pryor and Alexis Arguello on Nov. 12 and Thomas Hearns and Wilfred Benitez on Dec. 3; both fights were shown on closed-circuit television as part of the price of admission to the basketball games. So now the Bullets have been commissioned by Bob Arum, the boxing promoter, to help sell closed-circuit television fights to other National Basketball Association cities in need of help at the gate.

title: David Murray Quartet
description: The David Murray Quartet will perform tonight and tomorrow night at Soundscape, 500 West 52d Street (581-7032). Along with the tenor saxophonist, the group will include John Hicks on piano, Ed Blackwell on drums and Art Davis on bass. The first set will begin at about 9 P.M., and admission is $7.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Deficit Posted For Payments
description: The United States posted a $4.2 billion deficit in its balance of payments on the current account for the third quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported yesterday; the nation appears headed for its first yearly deficit since 1979.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS: THE STRATEGIST VS. THE BISHOPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Grundig Talks Ended
description: Talks between Grundig A.G. and other European electronics concerns to find a possible alternative to the planned merger between Grundig and Thomson-Brandt S.A. have ended unsuccessfully, a Grundig spokesman said today.

title: DILLON, READ PLANS TO MOVE UPTOWN
description: Dillon, Read & Company, the Wall Street investment banking house, said yesterday that after 152 years in downtown Manhattan it would move uptown to be nearer its clients.

title: Capitol Hill Aide Jailed For Refusing to Testify
description: A Congressman's legislative aide was jailed Wednesday after he refused a judge's order to testify before a Federal grand jury that is investigating charges of drug trafficking on Capitol Hill.

title: RATLIFF DRILLING & EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
'TOOTSIE,' COMEDY
description: AFTER 20 years as a mostly unemployed New York actor, Michael Dorsey (Dustin Hoffman) is desperate. He makes ends meet by teaching acting classes and then, in his spare time, auditioning for parts he never gets. Michael's worst problem is that he's ''difficult.'' He insists on providing more subtext for a role than any director wants. He's the sort of actor who, when playing a tomato in a television commercial, angrily refuses to sit down because, as he insists, ''tomatoes don't move.''

title: DREAM SEASON FOR AN AILEY DANCER
description: ''Tonight's one of those nights when I'm dancing in everything,'' Maxine Sherman said happily the other day as she settled down to lunch before a long afternoon of rehearsals at City Center. She is performing with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and having one of those seasons dancers dream about. ''I can never decide whether to rest or start the morning with a ballet class.''

title: VOLCKER DELIVERS KENTUCKIANS A TOUGH ECONOMIC MESSAGE
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, strode into the Mayfield High School Gymnasium tonight, softened the crowd of about 1,500 with several jokes and then delivered his regular, tough message: that the economy can get better but that he cannot relax his fight against inflation.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE Modern Jazz Quartet, which broke up in 1974 after a 22-year career and has since made two stabs at resuming performances, is now actually back in business. It has tours lined up for Japan in February, for England and Switzerland in April and May, and a concert with The Orchestra, an ensemble led by Jack Eliott, in Los Angeles in April. And to make its return emphatic, the group will play a concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening to celebrate its 30th anniversary and will resume a tradition of Christmas concerts at Lincoln Center.

title: U.S. AIDE AVOIDS DISCLOSURE
description: Thomas C. Reed, one of President Reagan's most influential national security advisers, is working under a parttime consultancy arrangement that allows him to avoid public disclosure of his personal financial dealings.

title: O.E.C.D. ASSESSES DEBT RISKS
description: The threat posed to the world financial system by extensive third world borrowing is essentially confined to a few large developing countries, and international banks can continue to grant loans to other developing nations without adding unduly to their risks, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reports.

title: 'BEST FRIENDS,' MARITAL COMEDY
description: EVEN when ''Best Friends'' isn't working uproariously as a comedy, there's an element of original, offbeat humor that keeps it promising. The screenplay, by Valerie Curtin and Barry (''Diner'') Levinson, starts with the notion of a happy couple's deciding to upset their stable, cosy domesticity by getting married. Since the lovers are played by Burt Reynolds and Goldie Hawn, the film would seem to have the makings of a giddy farce, but its tone is much more muted.

title: Borg Wins Easily
description: Bjorn Borg posted an easy 6-4, 6-2 victory over Tim Mayotte today in the second round of the inaugural $300,000 Nastase-Hamptons tennis tournament.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE REGION
description: A woman who was receiving welfare payments when she won nearly $1 million at a slot machine has repaid the Camden County Board of Social Services all of the public assistance she received, officials said today.

title: Sense of Community
description: Set off and sometimes segregated by a uniform, often isolated by cultural and language differences abroad, American service men and women still want to be a part of the civilian community.

title: Virginia 72, Houston 63
description: TOKYO (AP) - Jim Miller, who started in place of the ailing Ralph Sampson at center, scored 14 points.

title: The Impasse In Poland
description: The arrest of Lech Walesa and Poland's limited, carefully hedged plan to suspend martial law confirms that the regime is still stuck in the impasse visible on Solidarity's second anniversary last August.

title: HOSPITALS MERGE, JOINING 2 FAITHS IN DEPRIVED AREA
description: The Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn and St. John's Episcopal Hospital officially merged yesterday in an ecumenical effort to continue to provide health care to impoverished neighborhoods in the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Crown Heights sections.

title: Senate Confirms V.A. Chief
description: The Senate today confirmed President Reagan's choice of Harry N. Walters as Administrator of the Veterans Administration and W. Paul Thayer as Deputy Secretary of Defense. Mr. Walters, who has been Assistant Secretary of the Army in charge of manpower, succeeds Robert Nimmo, who resigned amid criticism by Vietnam veterans. Mr. Thayer has been chairman of the board of the LTV Corporation.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Agent's Arrest Ruled Legal by Judge
description: A judge ruled today that the Government had legally arrested Edwin P. Wilson, the former agent of the Centrial Intelligence Agency who was convicted of smuggling guns to Libya. Mr. Wilson had asserted that he had been tricked into returning to the United States.

title: FRANK ENGLE
description: Frank Engle, a reporter who worked for the Fairchild News Service and later started the P.O.E. News Service, which covered metropolitan airports and shipping lines, died Sunday in Lithonia, Ga.

title: Seeking Comfort For the Road
description: Gordon Chiesa, the Manhattan College basketball coach, knows what it's like being away for the holidays, and playing in a tournament. New York teams invariably wind up playing the host team in the first round and then playing the consolation game the next night. Chiesa remembers last year, when he took the Jaspers to West Virginia for the Mountaineer Classic:

title: Advertising; New Y.&R.  Venture to Start Big
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM of New York and Dentsu of Tokyo, the world's two largest advertising agencies who are already joint-venture partners in Japan and Malaysia, will begin their United States relationship with the New Year.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
24 Held in Jersey In a Drug Probe
description: Twenty-four people were arrested last night on narcotics distribution and conspiracy charges after a fourmonth undercover investigation into a major heroin and cocaine ring in northern Bergen County, according to Richard T. Carley, acting County Prosecutor.

title: Connecticut City To Join With Town
description: This 89-year-old city will cease to exist as a separately governed community on July 1 after voters in Willimantic and the town of Windham today approved consolidation, resolving an issue that has divided residents for 30 years.

title: CALENDAR OF MUSIC FOR THE CHRISTMAS HOLIDAY SEASON
description: Following is a list of some of the musical presentations planned for the Christmas season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. Today Calvary Church (Episcopal) Park Avenue South and 21st Street. Carols and works by Marcel Dupre and L.- C. Daquin; Calvin Hampton, organist. Midnight. Free. Information: 475-0830. Cathedral of St. John the Divine (Episcopal), 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. ''Winter Solstice Whole Earth Christmas Celebration''; Paul Winter Consort with Susan Osborne (also tomorrow). At 8 P.M. Tickets, $10, $15 and $20. Information: 662-2133.

title: Top 2 Posts Filled At Morgan Stanley
description: S. Parker Gilbert has emerged from the anonymity of a management committee at Morgan Stanley & Company as possibly the next top man at the prestigious investment banking firm.

title: SALE OF AIRLINE TICKETS DEREGULATED BY C.A.B.
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today voted, 4 to 1, to deregulate the travel-agent industry, making it possible for anyone to seek an airline's consent to sell its tickets.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State, who could achieve his first national championship if his Nittany Lions defeat Georgia in the Sugar Bowl on New Year's Night, was named college football coach of the year by United Press International. ...Jack Nicklaus has been selected as captain of the United States Ryder Cup team that will play a Britain-Europe team Oct. 14-16 at the P.G.A. National Golf Course in Florida. ... Ricky Patton, leading rusher with 543 yards for the San Francisco 49ers last year but dropped from this season, was signed by the team again yesterday.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 13
MONEY FUND ASSETS OFF BY RECORD $4.73 BILLION
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds fell a record $4.73 billion in the week ended Wednesday, reflecting a switch in deposits from the funds to the new money market accounts that banks began opening on Tuesday, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: Market Place; New Investing Products
description: MONEY multiplier notes, extendable corporate bonds, floating rate debt and preferred securities, and zero bonds are just some of the innovative products that have been introduced by leading investment banking houses recently.

title: Freeport Charge
description: Freeport-McMoran Inc., formed last year by the merger of the Freeport Minerals Company and the McMoran Oil and Gas Company, said McMoran Oil and Gas, now a unit, planned to take a $72 million writeoff on three previously reported offshore oil and gas properties. The write-off will result in a nonrecurring charge to Freeport-McMoran's 1982 earnings of about $39 million, but will not affect cash flow or operations.

title: No Headline
description: Loss Predicted By Volkswagen

title: New Orleans Blacks Win Ruling on Police Force
description: A Federal appeals court ordered approval today of a system that would, among other things, give black New Orleans police officers 50 percent of all promotions until the force was half black at every level.

title: 22 Amerasians Leave Vietnam for the U.S.
description: Twenty-two more of the thousands of Vietnamese children of American fathers flew out of Ho Chi Minh City today en route to the United States.

title: LUXURY IS ALIVE AND WELL
description: ''My idea,'' says Count Enrico Carimati di Carimate, ''is that there are always people who have money and who make money. They make money when interest is down; they make money when interest is up. They are the superrich and they will always buy quality of the top level.''

title: UNITED MCGILL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
'Messiah' and Other Choral Programs; Today; Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and
description: 57th Street. Bach's Magnificat and Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 2; St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra with soloists, conducted by David Randolph, conductor. At 8 P.M. Tickets, $5 to $15. Information: 247-7459. Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319

title: OFFICIALS DEFEND AGENCY MATCHES OF COMPUTER DATA ON INDIVIDUALS
description: Officials from Congress's General Accounting Office and from New York and Massachusetts today defended the increased use of computers to detect fraud and waste as essential to the integrity of the nation's welfare programs.

title: Varied Folk Music Due At Museum in TriBeCa
description: The Alternative Museum, 17 White Street in TriBeCa, will present folk music from the Balkans and Central Asia this weekend.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Arts World Send-Off

title: MEETINGS OF SOCIAL SECURITY PANEL IS POSTPONED
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the National Commission on Social Security Reform, today ''temporarily postponed'' a meeting of the panel set for Friday. He said he wanted to discuss with the 15 members the White House's views on how to close the financing gap in Social Security.

title: GRANDPARENTS GO TO CONGRESS WITH PLEA ON VISITATION RIGHTS
description: The last time Edith Engel saw her two grandchildren was four years ago outside a courtroom. They were waiting to go before a judge, who later rejected Mrs. Engel's plea for regular visits with the children of her runaway daughter.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Concert by Jazz Duo
description: A free concert by the guitarist Gene Bertoncini and the bassist Michael Moore will be given Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street (925-2200). The duo will perform quiet, intricate versions of jazz standards, Brazilian tunes and a few classical pieces.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Child's Discovery A nthony Urbano from Nassau County was at Gimbels in Herald Square yesterday - invited, at the age of 6, to speak to Santa Claus. Anthony, who has cerebral palsy, was there to demonstrate a small electronic device with a keyboard that is designed for people with seriously impaired speech.

title: News Analysis
description: Experts in electronic surveillance agree that in its scope, duration and effectiveness the wiretapping used in the trial in Chicago of Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president, and four others broke new ground.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: HOLIDAYS are for children, some people believe, and children c ertainly seem to enjoy them more than anybody else. Take, for e xample, the annual children's Christmas party at the Museum of the C ity of New York.

title: Lombard-Wall
description: Lombard-Wall Inc., a government-securities firm, and a subsidiary, Lombard-Wall Money Markets Inc., have reached a tentative settlement with the Bankers Trust Company on countersuits they had filed as a result of Lombard-Wall's collapse last summer. According to a filing in Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York, the settlement, which must be approved by the court, would allow the release by Bankers Trust of $225 million in securities to Lombard-Wall in return for payment of $588,469 by Lombard-Wall to Bankers Trust.

title: HENSON'S 'CRYSTAL'
description: IN the way that great comic actors are supposed to long to play Hamlet, Jim Henson, who created the Muppets, and Frank Oz, his longtime associate, have apparently dreamed of creating mechanical marvels more significant and timeless than the irrepressible Miss Piggy and her pals. The result is ''The Dark Crystal,'' which aims, I think, to be a sort of Muppet ''Paradise Lost'' but winds up as watered down J.R.R. Tolkien.

title: 'SIX WEEKS'
description: ''SIX WEEKS'' aims directly for the heartstrings, but it may put you in a mood that's more quizzical than sentimental. Consider the story, which begins when Patrick Dalton, a California politician played by Dudley Moore, encounters a young adolescent girl named Nicole (Katherine Healy), who is smart, toothy and utterly selfassured - kind of a miniature Susan Anspach.

title: NIGHTCLUBS: DON SHIRLEY
description: FOR his occasional appearances in nightclubs, Don Shirley, a pianist whose orientation is toward the concert hall and a classical style, has created a musical world that draws on a rich variety of sources - folk music, spirituals, jazz, Broadway musicals and pop songs, as well as classical music. With the help of Ken Fricker on bass and Juri Taht, a versatile cellist who discreetly adds soft, ringing colors to the performances with small gongs, bells, cymbals and an African thumb piano, Mr. Shirley builds each tune or medley into a miniature production that may evoke a mood, celebrate an individual (Duke Ellington), or trace a musical lineage.

title: Four Die in Boston Fire
description: A fire in a boarding house late Wednesday killed four people, injured another and forced several people to flee, the police said. The authorities were checking to determine whether the building had smoke detectors.

title: MOMENT OF SILENCE IN SCHOOLS IS VOTED IN JERSEY
description: The State Senate tonight voted to override Governor Kean's veto of a bill requiring a daily one-minute period of silence in New Jersey public schools.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Perry Will Return
description: The pitcher who leads all active major league players with 307 victories may add to that total in 1983. Yesterday the Seattle Mariners announced that Gaylord Perry, the 44-year-old right-hander, had signed a one-year contract. Perry, who will be performing in his 21st major league season, won 10 game and lost 12 with the Mariners last season. He struck out 110 batters to raise his career strikeout total to 3,452, third on the career list, behind Walter Johnson and Nolan Ryan.

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
France Bolsters Saudi Oil Stand
description: On the eve of an important OPEC meeting, France has given Saudi Arabia support in its campaign to preserve the group's official base price of $34 a barrel.

title: ATLANTIC METROPOLITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DANCE: WILLIAM CARTER, MARIA ALBA AT RIVERSIDE
description: THERE were times when the stage sizzled so hard that it seemed the Theater of the Riverside Church might go up in flames on Wednesday, when Maria Alba and William Carter appeared in a program by the William Carter Dance Ensemble. The Spanish dance atmosphere, so often a matter of manufactured passion, was unforgettably potent here.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BOMBS ROCK I.B.M. BUILDING AND AIRLINE OFFICE
description: A powerful bomb exploded outside an I.B.M. office building in Harrison, N.Y., last night and caused extensive damage to the glasssheathed building, the police said.

title: EARN 100% AT MOUNTEBANKS
description: We all know now why the old Prudential National Trust Company changed its name to Crazy Louie Bank N.A., because by now everybody's heard the commercials:

title: Then There Were 8
description: Coach Jim Sochor of California-Davis, one of eight finalists from an original field of 150, will meet tomorrow with Carl Ullrich, the athletic director at Army, about the vacant job of football coach at the United States Military Academy.

title: PRAVDA EDITORIAL AFFIRMS MOSCOW'S AFGHANISTAN POLICY
description: Apparently reacting to speculation abroad that the Soviet Union is looking for a way out of Afghanistan, Pravda today affirmed earlier Soviet conditions for the withdrawal of troops.

title: Redland Purchase
description: Redland Ltd., a London-based manufacturer of building materials, said it had agreed to buy 80 percent of the Boston Industries Corporation, a holding company for McDonough Brothers Inc., for $70.4 million. Redland said the purchase, in which the price is subject to increase depending on future earnings, is expected to be completed on Jan. 5. McDonough's primary business is extracting, processing and distributing limestone from quarries near San Antonio.

title: ROCK: OFFSPRING OF THE FEELIES
description: THE FEELIES, New York's leading rock minimalists of the late 1970's, have divided and multipled into Yung Wu, the Trypes and the Willies. The three bands, which have overlapping personnel, performed Wednesday at Folk City as part of the club's weekly bargain new-rock series, ''Music for Dozens.''

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Vice Chairman Named At Chase Manhattan
description: John A. Hooper has been named vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, the bank said yesterday. Mr. Hooper, 60, has been senior executive vice president and is the bank's chief credit officer. He has responsibility for credit policy, country risk policy, real estate finance and lending services.

title: HARVESTER POSTS LOSS OF $1 BILLION
description: The International Harvester Company today reported a $1 billion deficit for its fourth fiscal quarter, one of the largest quarterly losses ever reported by an American corporation.

title: CITY'S TRANSIT FURURE MEETS THE PRESENT
description: In conjunction with the conference yesterday on the future of mass transit, a special edition of New York Affairs, a publication of New York University's Urban Research Center, was issued. Here are excerpts from the special edition.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: A church inquiry into the financial dealings of the late John Cardinal Cody turned up no evidence of wrongdoing but disclosed that some records were incomplete, the Cardinal's successor said today.

title: Xerox Cuts Prices
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had reduced the prices on seven copier models an average of 16.5 percent. The Rochester-based company said the new prices are: the 2350 copier, reduced 8 percent, to $3,295; the 3300-II, 20 percent, to $3,595; the 3300-I, 9 percent, to $4,495; the 3400, 22 percent, to $6,995; the 3450, 20 percent, to $7,995; the 5600, 19 percent, to $29,000, and the 5600 with finisher, 18 percent, to $30,600.

title: IS REAGAN 'SERIOUS'?
description: A month ago, in announcing his ill-fated decision to base the MX missile in the dense-pack scheme, President Reagan said that in the Geneva talks on strategic arms the Soviet Union's ''opening position is a serious one'' and ''there's no question we're heading in the right direction.''

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
2 OFFICIALS ASSAILED BY PANEL ON LOSS BY DORMITORY UNIT
description: State investigators said yesterday that two members of the New York State Dormitory Authority, one of them its former chairman, should either quit or be dismissed because they ''deliberately withheld'' damaging information about investments with a securities concern that went bankrupt.

title: CUOMO HAS A PLAN TO SHUT L.I. PRISON
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would make good a campaign promise and close a newly opened prison on the grounds of the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center on Long Island.

title: Dan River Shares Sold to McDonough
description: In a move to fight off a takeover by Carl Icahn, the New York financier, Dan River Inc. said yesterday that it had sold 475,000 shares to the McDonough Company. McDonough is a subsidiary of Hanson Trust of Britain, a company with textile interests.

title: FILIBUSTER BLOCKS ACTION BY SENATE ON RISE IN GAS TAX
description: Senate Republican leaders bowed last night to a filibuster by conservatives in their party and withdrew consideration of a 5-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax increase from the floor. The move was considered a severe setback for the measure.

title: MISS MANDLIKOVA IN SEMIFINAL
description: Hana Mandlikova rallied from match point in the 10th game of the final set and went on to win a 7-3 tiebreaker from Barbara Potter tonight for a 4-6, 6-3, 7-6 victory. The comeback gained her a berth in the semifinals of the $300,000 Toyota women's tennis championships.

title: Lewis May Leave Post
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis has been discussing the possibility of succeeding Gustave M. Hauser as chairman and chief executive officer of Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., executives in the cable television industry said yesterday.

title: HE GETS WRAPPED UP IN OTHER PEOPLE'S LIVES
description: PETER MacNICOL had run away. Appalled at his first experience with movie making, afraid that he might be temperamentally unsuited to his profession, he had left New York ''in the most profound kind of confusion'' to roam around Europe and the United States.

title: BRIEFING
description: Too Late for Humor

title: SEOUL TO LET OPPOSITION LEADER TRAVEL TO THE U.S.
description: Kim Dae Jung, a South Korean opposition politician who was imprisoned in 1980, was moved to a hospital in Seoul today, and his wife said she and their two sons expected to accompany him to the United States next week for treatment of his arthritis. She said, however, that they would return.

title: Dr. Computer
description: Jimmy Connors, Bjorn Borg, Guillermo Vilas and the rest of the 24-man field at the Ilie Nastase-Hamptons tennis tournament under way at North Miami Beach, Fla., were tied to be fit. With their feet hooked up by seven electrodes to a computer, they were asked to walk 25 steps as part of a new test to diagnose injuries or possible injuries in their lower extremities.

title: MIG's Are Reinforced On Isle North of Japan
description: The Soviet Air Force has deployed new warplanes on a disputed island off the northern Japanese coast in what might be a response to American plans for strengthening the United States Air Force in northern Japan, military sources said today.

title: KNICKS TRIUMPH IN OVERTIME
description: The strength of the Boston Celtics is their front line, but last night their 7-foot center Robert Parish was sidelined. So the Knicks' front line of Bernard King, Marvin Webster and Sly Williams outplayed the Celtics' big men for a 113-105 victory in overtime at Madison Square Garden.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES REGION PAYROLL TAX
description: The State Assembly passed a regional payroll tax last night to avert an immediate increase in bus, subway and commuter rail fares. But at the same time Republicans in the State Senate proposed a different tax - a sales tax - to save the fares.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Dec 4
The U.N. Today; Dec. 17, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ON THE ROAD TO EUROPE WITH THE SECRETARY OF STATE
description: George P. Shultz walked to the back of his Air Force plane as it flew from Paris to Madrid the other day to apologize to 13 reporters for his performance at a news conference the afternoon before. The Secretary of State acknowledged that he had forgotten to mention some of the specific agreements he had reached with President Francois Mitterrand of France and had been too imprecise in trying to explain what he had accomplished. It took a subsequent midnight news conference to clear it up.

title: U.S.I.A. finds art collection in its 'attic.'
description: ONE of the more intriguing ''granny's attic'' treasure-hunt stories is being written by the United States Information Agency in Washington. A recent inventory of the eight U.S.I.A. buildings in Washington has turned up an art collection valued at $250,000, featuring works by such artists as Josef Albers, Milton Avery, Stuart Davis and Robert Rauschenberg.

title: CONCERT: A BRASS QUINTET AT CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL
