description: OF all instrumental combinations, the brass quintet must be the one saddled with the least impressive repertory. The sound of two trumpets, two trombones and a horn has not inspired very much interesting music, let alone very much great music.

title: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
STAGE: 'ALMOST AN EAGLE,' ON SCOUTING
description: THERE is a daring laziness to the writing in Michael Kimberley's ''Almost an Eagle,'' the turkey that roosted at the Longacre last night. At the end of Act I, the audience is treated to the numbing and seemingly endless spectacle of watching four teen-age Boy Scouts do quasi-military maneuvers in circles to the rhythmic sound of boot-camp chants. Act II ends exactly the same way - albeit with the minor variation that martial music accompanies the chanting.

title: PROTESTER DIES AS ARGENTINE POLICE BREAK UP RALLY
description: Policemen firing tear gas dispersed an officially sanctioned rally tonight by tens of thousands of Argentines who had gathered to press demands for a return to civilian rule by next October.

title: Lanford Wilson's 'Angels Fall' now on way to big time.
description: LANFORD WILSON'S play ''Angels Fall,'' which recently ended a successful limited run at Circle Repertory Company and which was headed for another Off Broadway theater, has had a sudden change of course. The play is being rerouted to Broadway, where it will reopen next month. The exact opening date and the theater, which will be one of the Shubert houses, cannot be announced yet. This is one of those so-called ''death watch'' situations that no one likes to talk about because the theater that is to be the new home for ''Angels Fall'' currently houses another production whose demise is expected momentarily.

title: IMMIGRANT NON-BILL
description: To do one thing and to convince much of a nation that one is accomplishing the opposite is no mean feat. Yet that exactly is what the Administration has done with the Simpson-Mazzoli immigration bill, which Congress may enact in its current lame-duck session.

title: ISRAELIS SAID TO STEP UP ROLE AS ARMS SUPPLIERS TO LATINS
description: Israel is enlarging its military training missions and role as a principal supplier of arms to Central America, according to State Department and intelligence officials. They said that among the arms being offered were sizable stocks captured from Palestinian forces in Lebanon.

title: Fanfani Wins Key Vote; Bulgarian Furor Noted
description: Italy's new Cabinet won a key vote of confidence today, and Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani vowed to fully investigate charges of spying and terrorism by Bulgarians within the country.

title: Regulation Account Rule
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board yesterday issued Statement 71 on accounting for the effects of regulation, which gives guidance on preparing financial statements to utilities and other companies whose rates are regulated.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A BOY'S OWN STORY. By Edmund White. 217 pages. Dutton. $13.95.

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LETTERS CONTAIN THREATS TO TAMPER WITH DRISTAN
description: Capsules of Dristan that had been tampered with were sent with threatening letters yesterday to news organizations in the New York area. The letters said the capsules would be spread throughout the area.

title: Price Cuts Lift Interest Rates; Big Treasury Supply Cited
description: Interest rates rose yesterday as dealers cut prices in an effort to attract more investors to a heavy supply of new Treasury issues at the same time that corporations and local governments were also borrowing large amounts.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1982
description: International Polish officials seized Lech Walesa, preventing the leader of the outlawed Solidarity union from giving a speech in the shipyard at Gdansk. There was no official word on his whereabouts throughout the day, but he was returned to his home by evening, his wife said. (Page A1, Column 1.) Soviet firmness on Afghanistan was restated in an editorial in Pravda. The editorial reaffirmed the Soviet Union's conditions for withdrawal of its troops and said that the United States and Pakistan were responsible for the continuing strife. (A3:3-6.)

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. 76ers, at Philadelphia, 7:30 P.M. Sly Williams made his first start of the season last night against the Boston Celtics, in place of Len (Truck) Robinson. Last Dec. 16, when Williams substituted, he scored 18 points in 27 minutes in the Knicks' last victory over Philadelphia, 117-115. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.).

title: NEW RICHES FOR ROSIE CASALS
description: As the winner of the first women's professional tennis tournament, Rosie Casals is assured of a permanent place in the record books.

title: OF AND FOR THE PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: GAS PIPELINE POLICY CHANGED
description: In an effort to minimize future increases in the price of natural gas, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission today laid out a new policy requiring pipelines to absorb certain costs that heretofore have been largely passed on to consumers.

title: STYLE OF SEAHAWKS MAY BOTHER PATRIOTS
description: It was all well and good, and perhaps amusing, that the New England Patriots defeated the Miami Dolphins last Sunday on a field covered almost entirely with snow in Foxboro, Mass. The only points were provided by John Smith, who kicked a fourth-quarter field goal from a patch of turf wiped clear of snow by a tractor, driven by a prisoner on work release.

title: A BRITISH IMPROVISER WHO LIKES THE WORD 'FREE'
description: IT'S easy to explain what kind of music Derek Bailey doesn't play. The British guitarist improvises music that is not jazz, rock, clasical, flamenco, raga, aleatory or any other consistent style. Mr. Bailey calls it simply ''free improvisation'' and leaves it at that.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: 'CONSTRUCTIVE ENGAGEMENT' IN ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: B-Includes an extraordinary credit of $97,000 for the qr and $1,578,000 for the9 mos

title: SOPRANO RECITAL: EDDYE P. BERRY
description: EDDYE PIERCE BERRY'S evening at the Abraham Goodman House Monday demonstrated a strong, true and uncommonly attractive soprano sound. It is essentially a one-color voice - without much flexibility of shade and tone to go with its full and very reliable quality.

title: Accounts
description: * Hearst Magazines division to Creamer Inc. for Science Digest magazine.

title: Koch Says Security At U.N. Will Stop
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the city would end police security for the United Nations diplomatic community because it could not afford the cost.

title: A BRIGHT DAY OUT AT SHEA
description: T om Seaver was just enough of a romantic to see behind the midday gloom and pronounce Dec. 16, 1982, as a ''sunshine type of day.'' He was just enough of a realist not to predict the blue skies of yesteryear.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SENATE PANEL'S SUMMARY OF FINDINGS ON ABSCAM OPERATIONS
description: Following are excerpts from the summary of findings of a report issued today by a special Senate committee that examined the conduct of the Government in the Abscam investigation and other undercover operations. Benefits and Risks of Undercover Operations

title: Detroit Preparing Plan To Shelter Thousands
description: Detroit, with an unemployment rate above 20 percent, is preparing a citywide campaign to feed, clothe and shelter thousands of its homeless, hungry and jobless citizens, an aide to Mayor Coleman Young said today.

title: First City Federal
description: First City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Bradenton, Fla., said its directors had unanimously approved a proposal from Metropolitan Savings Bank of New York to acquire all of First City Federal's shares outstanding for $40 each.

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1982; Companies
description: A.T.& T. will distribute to shareholders one new share in each of seven regional phone companies for every ten shares of Bell stock now held, the company said in a court filing. The document provided the first details of how A.T.& T. plans to carry out the divestiture of its 22 local telephone companies. (Page A1.)

title: STATE INQUIRY UPHOLDS ABSCAM WHILE FINDING FLAWS IN METHODS
description: The special Senate committee that has been examining the Federal Abscam investigation and other undercover operations concluded today that the political corruption inquiry, while flawed, did not involve serious Government misconduct.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD DELAYS VOTE ON CABLE COMPROMISE
description: New York City officials proposed a new compromise yesterday to resolve a dispute that has delayed the city's cable television negotiations for more than a year. But at a heated City Hall meeting that went on late into the night, the Board of Estimate put off a vote on the new plan for a week.

title: THE CAMPAIGN TO SELL PHONES
description: There are more than 100 million bathrooms in the United States and hardly any of them has a telephone -now. If the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has its way, however, more and more bathrooms will have telephones. A.T.& T. recently participated in an exhibit of bathroom furniture to promote equipping bathrooms with phones, which Bell sees as an untapped market. A.T.& T.'s move is but one tack taken in an increasingly heated market battle to sell telephones to consumers. Changes occurring in the telephone business will spur millions of Americans to buy their phones rather than lease them from the local phone company, and the companies that sell phones are preparing to greet the new consumers with a variety of prices, special features and marketing campaigns.

title: JERSEY DEMOCRATS TO SEEK A COMPROMISE ON TAXES
description: TRENTON Dec. 16 - After trying in vain all day to round up the votes for an increase in either the state sales tax or income tax to close an expected deficit of $150 million in the current budget, leaders of the Democratic majority in both the Senate and the Assembly decided to quit for the night and return on Monday to seek a compromise.

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PLANT USE AT RECORD 67.8% LOW
description: American factories operated at 67.8 percent of capacity last month, a record low, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: TOP KOCH AIDE SAID TO CONSIDER LEAVING CITY HALL
description: Nathan Leventhal, New York City's Deputy Mayor for Operations for the last three years, has been offered a position outside government and may soon leave City Hall, according to several city officials.

title: Bowie Coming Back
description: Sam Bowie, the 7-foot-1-inch center for the University of Kentucky, announced that he would return to the school next season and hopes to play basketball for the Wildcats. Bowie missed all of last season and is unlikely to play this season because of a hairline fracture of his left leg that he suffered nearly two years ago. He said the leg was so weak that it will take at least six or seven weeks of conditioning before he could consider playing.

title: EX-MAYOR A FOE OF INTEGRATION
description: Orville L. Hubbard, the flamboyant former Mayor of Dearborn, Mich., whose 15 terms in office were characterized by municipal efficiency and his outspoken segregationist policies, died yesterday in Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit. He was 80 years old.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
No Headline
description: Gottfried Defeats Borg, 6-1, 6-3

title: Christmas Present
description: A band of Italian folk musicians and masked revelers, dressed in multicolored silks and velvets, came trouping down the great marble staircase of the New York Public Library on 42d Street Thursday evening, ringing bells and singing Christmas music. In another part of the hall, a chorus of men in black tie and women in long, winecolored dresses sang Renaissance songs.

title: 6 PAINTINGS GIVEN TO YALE BY WHITNEY ESTATE
description: Six oil paintings - by Degas, Gauguin, Pissarro, Picasso and Eakins - have been given to the Yale University Art Gallery from the private collection of John Hay Whitney, the late publisher and diplomat, the university announced yesterday.

title: PAINTER'S GEAR THAT CASTS A LIGHT; Suzanne Slein
description: The fact that no one was really interested in his artwork inspired Kyle Spencer to pursue a different course. Instead of continuing to create sculpture, he decided to try his hand at more practical objects.

title: U.S. Jet Crashes in Korea
description: A United States Air Force F-16 fighter crashed Wednesday on a training flight near Sosan, 60 miles southwest of Seoul, but the pilot ejected safely, United States military authorities announced today.

title: REAGAN REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR AIDE
description: The White House today affirmed its confidence in Thomas C. Reed, one of President Reagan's chief national security advisers, whose personal financial dealings have come under public criticism.

title: Refractories Co.  Restructuring
description: The General Refractories Company said it expects a one-time charge to 1982 earnings of $37 million because of a restructuring of its domestic refractories and building products businesses.

title: Annemarie de Waal Malefijt, Professor of Anthropology
description: Annemarie de Waal Malefijt, professor emeritus of anthropology at Hunter College and a founder of graduate studies in anthropology, died of cancer Wednesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx.

title: Oilers 10, Devils 4
description: Jari Kurri scored three goals and set up two others to lead Edmonton's rout of New Jersey. The Oilers jumped to a 3-0 lead and outshot the Devils by 36-13 during the first two periods in building up a 6-2 lead.

title: A Transit Tax Is Overdue
description: As the deadline for a big transit fare increase approaches, the New York Legislature that alone can fend it off has fallen apart. The Democratic Assembly voted to close the deficit with a tax on payrolls. The Republican Senate disbanded, determined to vote Monday for a higher regional sales tax. Unless one house changes its mind, or both compromise or find other taxes, M.T.A. riders will have to pay catastrophic fare increases of 33 percent or more.

title: Bombardier Inc.
description: Bombardier Inc., the Montreal company that recently won a $622 million contract to build 825 subway cars for the New York City Transit Authority, said it would lay off up to 600 workers at its La Pocatiere, Quebec plant for varying periods over the next six months, as it retools the plant for production of subway cars. Bombardier said the retooling was expected to result in few, if any, layoffs at its plant in Barre, Vt., however. The company said the Quebec plant would be simultaneously retooled for production of coaches for Via Rail, Canada's passenger train service.

title: Common Market Aides Meet On Banning Sealskin Imports
description: Environmental ministers of the European Economic Community met today to decide whether to heed strong public pressure and ban imports of sealskins from Canada.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The War of the Branches
description: There's much more than partisan politics behind the contempt of Congress citation against Administrator Anne Gorsuch for refusing to release Environmental Protection Agency documents to a Congressional committee.

title: Woman Loses Appeal On Helping Spy to Rob
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the conviction of a 42-year-old woman on charges that she helped an escaped spy rob banks in the Pacific Northwest, United States Attorney Guy Hurlbutt said today.

title: Angolans Report an Air Raid By South Africans on a Town
description: The official Angolan press agency said today that South African aircraft bombed an Angolan settlement 80 miles north of the border with Namibia on Tuesday.

title: LAKERS, WITHOUT ABDUL-JABBAR, TOP NETS
description: Playing without the ailing Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers displayed a versatile attack tonight in defeating the Nets, 117-106, before 15,786 fans at The Forum.

title: Teamster Trial Figure Gives Up to Authorities
description: One of five defendants convicted in the teamster bribery conspiracy trial surrendered today and was taken to jail while a second posted a $5 million bond.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART PATIENT'S CONDITION IS IMPROVING
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, critically ill and struggling to survive with an artificial heart, has shown ''small but significant'' improvement as his lungs were cleared of pneumonia and fluid, his doctors said here today.

title: Circus Acts of Kindness
description: He was talking with friends about the Big Apple Circus, and suddenly, John K. Butler had a brainstorm: Why not buy out the tent in Damrosch Park for a performance for children who would otherwise miss out? For $14,500, he bought all 1,600 seats for the 11 A.M. show next Wednesday.

title: Algerian Leader Pays Working Visit to Paris
description: President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria today made the first formal visit to Paris by an Algerian head of state.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CLEVELAND (AL) - Named Ronald M. M ottl, outgoing United States Representa- t ive, special assistant to Gabe Paul, the c lub's president. TORONTO (AL) - Assigned Jerry Gar- v in, left-handed pitcher, to Syracuse farm o f the International League.

title: MODIFY, BUT DON'T ABOLISH, J-51 TAX BREAKS
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Nuggets, at Denver. Since these teams joined the N.B.A. together in the 1976-77 season, the Nets have yet to win a game in nine trips to Denver. (Television - Channel 9, 10 P.M., delayed tape. Radio -WVNJ, 620 AM; 9:30 P.M.) College: Iowa vs. U.C.L.A. (Television - Channel 4, 3:45 P.M.) Syracuse vs. Niagara (Radio - WNYE FM, 91.5; 4 P.M.) St. John's vs. Princeton (Radio -WNYE FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.) City College at L.I.U., 7:30 P.M.; North Carolina-Charlotte at Iona (Radio -WFAS-FM, 103.9, 2 P.M.); Indiana vs. Kansas State (Television - WTBS Cable, 8:05 P.M.).; Fairfield vs Hofstra and William Paterson vs. Stony Brook, at Hofstra (Television - Cablevision 3 P.M. and 5 P.M.); Lehman at C.W. Post, 8 P.M. Manhattan at Wagner, 8 P.M. College of Staten Island at Yeshiva, 8:30 P.M. Other games: Brooklyn College at Baltimore; Adelphi at East Stroudsburg; Fairleigh Dickinson at DePaul.

title: Weary Senate Turns To Prayers for Relief
description: The Senate had been at work for 26 consecutive hours, and its members were exhausted. Time was running out on efforts to adopt an emergency spending bill to keep money flowing to the Government, and no end was in sight.

title: A LOST YIDDISH FILM OF '39 RETURNING
description: A Yiddish film, ''The Light Ahead,'' made in 1939, will open tomorrow at the Guild's Embassy 72d Street Theater, and it may be the first Yiddish movie to play a general-run Manhattan commercial house ever. Or it may not be - but either way it is a rare event.

title: News Analysis
description: With its agreement on terms for an International Monetary Fund loan, Brazil appears to have temporarily applied the brakes to its rush toward the status of a great industrial power.

title: Push for Game 12
description: The proposal to have a ''12th'' regular-season college football game next August between this season's national champion and next year's preseason favorite to be No. 1 - as voted by the wire services - has received the powerful support of Paul (Bear) Bryant. ''I can't see anything against it,'' said Bryant, ''so we'll probably vote for it.''

title: OUTGOING CHIEF OF MINERS' UNION ACCUSED OF SEEKING PENSION DEAL
description: Aides to Rich Trumka, president-elect of the United Mine Workers of America, charged today that Sam M. Church Jr. had refused to concede his ouster as union president because Mr. Trumka had rejected a secret proposal to guarantee his predecessor's pension rights and help him pay off campaign debts.

title: SHARING AMBROSIANO'S LOSSES
description: As much as $1 billion in bad debts may have been lost in Italy's long-running Banco Ambrosiano scandal, a scandal in which the Vatican still appears deeply involved, although it denies any wrongdoing. And the question of the hour for Italy and for the Vatican, according to Italian investigators, is how much of the loss the Roman Catholic Church should cover.

title: 18 MORE DIE IN LEBANON CLASHES
description: Eighteen more people died in street fighting in Tripoli today, and the Phalangist radio reported that a Christian politician had escaped a Moslem assassination attempt in Aleih.

title: No Further Tampering With Dristan Reported
description: The police and city and Federal officials said there had been no reports yesterday of anyone finding adulterated bottles of Dristan capsules, a nonprescription cold medication.

title: TIMES SUBPOENAED IN BOSTON
description: The New York Times and three Boston newspapers were subpoenaed today by the Federal District Court here in a case involving a former city employee who was convicted of extortion last spring and is now facing charges of perjury.

title: TO MEET MRS. LLOYD
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and Tracy Austin, who played twice within three days here last year but have not met since, will be paired in Saturday's semifinals of the $300,000 Toyota women's tennis championships.

title: Doctor Is Fatally Shot At Hospital in Houston
description: A gunman shot a cancer specialist this morning and then fled from the M.D. Anderson Hospital and Tumor Institute while doctors tried unsuccessfully to revive the physician.

title: BOMB WARNINGS SPUR EVACUATION AT I.B.M.
description: Bomb threats today at offices of the International Business Machines Corporation here and in Manhattan forced the removal of hundreds of employees, the authorities said.

title: Madrid Parley Adjourns Amid Crisis Warnings
description: The two-year-old Madrid conference on European security adjourned today amid warnings that it was headed for crisis unless an East-West deadlock was broken during the recess.

title: U.S. Halts Suriname Aid Because of Killings
description: The State Department said today that it was suspending aid to Suriname after violent reprisals by the Government against prominent citizens this month because of a reported coup plot.

title: Shares Tendered In Offer for Pabst
description: The company indirectly owned by Paul Kalmanovitz, 21-115 Inc., which is seeking 4.15 million shares of the Pabst Brewing Company common stock, said it had been advised by the depository for its offer that 1,017,889 shares had been tendered before the purchase offer deadline of Dec. 15.

title: Albanian Chief Writes Of Assassination Plot
description: Albania's Communist Party leader, Enver Hoxha, has charged in newly published memoirs that his former Prime Minister was aided by the ex-official's wife and two interior ministers in plotting to kill him.

title: LAWYER DISMISSED BY DIRKS
description: Raymond L. Dirks, a securities analyst, suddenly dismissed his lawyer yesterday after the lawyer advised him not to testify at his trial on civil fraud charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: PLANS FOR SAFETY AT INDIAN POINT FAULTED BY U.S.
description: The Federal agency charged with evaluating preparedness for an accident at the Indian Point Nuclear Power Station reported yesterday that the emergency plans were ''not feasible'' because of two ''significant deficiencies.''

title: Fire Kills 2 Girls On Jersey Shore
description: Fire swept through a frame home today, killing two sisters, 5 and 8 years old, and injuring their parents and two other sisters, the authorities said.

title: DEBATE IS HEATED OVER IMMIGRATION
description: The House of Representatives continued debate today on a comprehensive immigration bill, and supporters of the measure said its fate depended on the length of the current postelection session of Congress.

title: Disciple of Manson Is Denied Parole on Her Life Sentence
description: Susan Atkins, a former disciple of Charles Manson, was denied parole Thursday and a prison board said her case would not be considered again until 1985.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 18, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 3 P.M.

title: WITHIN THE FIRST AMENDMENT'S PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: The 'Old Man' at St. Peter's
description: Four years ago, when Phil Jamison came home, it seemed that something strange had happened to the streets of Jersey City. When Jamison played basketball at Snyder High School, his horizons extended only as far as the pickup games on the other side of the city. Jamison knew exactly where the best games were. He also knew the corners where some of his friends would stand around and have a few beers and a few laughs. Those places were not far apart.

title: Books of the Times; TREK IN VODKA COUNTRY
description: MOSCOW CIRCLES. By Benedict Erofeev. Translated by J.R. Dorrell from the Russian. 188 pages. Writers & Readers. $12.95.

title: Very Good Exercise
description: In the mirrored studio on West 58th Street, the barefoot women in the dance and exercise class ranged in age from 30 to 91. The problem this week was to identify the 91-year-old.

title: U.S. AIDE CALLS EVIDENCE STRONG
description: The Reagan Administration's senior specialist on Soviet affairs said today that ''the evidence looks pretty heavy'' that the Bulgarian intelligence service was involved in the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II last year.

title: The Assassin's Trail of Blood
description: As Thoreau observed, circumstantial evidence, like finding a trout in the milk, can be very persuasive. No trout has surfaced yet to support Italy's charge that Bulgarian officials had a hand in the attempted assassination of the Pope. Still, it is sadly conceivable that the gunman, a Turkish fanatic, had encouragement, maybe even help, from Bulgaria. And that raises the not unreasonable question of whether Bulgarians would dare assist in such an enterprise without an approving nod from Moscow's K.G.B., then headed by Yuri Andropov.

title: EX-NEW YORKERS RECALL CITY IN NEEDIEST CASES DONATIONS
description: ''Although I have lived in Los Angeles since 1950,'' Bertha G. Bernstein said, ''my heart and roots are in New York.'' With that affirmation of loyalty to her former home, Mrs. Bernstein contributed $200 to the 71st annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 26 on Coast Indicted In Alien Smuggling Ring
description: Twenty-six people have been indicted on charges growing out of what the Federal authorities described as a major ring smuggling Mexicans into the United States.

title: PHILADELPHIA'S RETAIL STRUGGLE
description: As the sonorous organ in the John Wanamaker department store's court on Market Street sounded a plea for peace on earth this week, a rough-and-tumble war over prices was being waged in this intensely competitive retail market.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A news-analysis article yesterday on the trial of teamsters union officials incorrectly stated the affiliation of Prof. Herman Schwartz. He is at the American University Law School in Washington.

title: SHULTZ SAYS ALLIES AGREE ON DEALING WITH SOVIET
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today, at the end of a 12-day tour of Europe, that the United States and its allies were in basic agreement on dealing with the new Soviet leaders from a position of military strength while holding a desire ''to solve problems and work constructively for better relations.''

title: No Headline
description: Tulane Upsets Rutgers By 55-54

title: NEW CRIMINAL CLASS IS FLOURISHING IN SUN BELT
description: The Sun Belt has begun to rival the North in the level and sophistication of criminal activity, say law-enforcement officials across the South. The growth is marked not only by the influx of drugs, particularly marijuana and cocaine, the officials say, but also by organized car theft, prostitution and pornography rings and complex fraud and money-laundering operations.

title: Braniff Fights C.A.B. Decision
description: Howard Putnam, Braniff International chairman, promised to challenge a decision by the Civil Aeronautics Board giving Braniff's lucrative route between Dallas-Fort Worth and London to American Airlines.

title: Juilliard Theater Plans Auditions in February
description: The Theater Center of the Juilliard School will hold auditions in New York City, New Orleans, Chicago and San Francisco next February, it has been announced by Peter Mennin, the school's president.

title: RIDERSHIP WOULD DROP 6% WITH $1 FARE, M.T.A. SAYS
description: Ridership on New York's subways and buses would drop by more than 6 percent, or about 63 million passengers a year, if the fare rose to $1, the president of the Transit Authority said yesterday. A fare of up to $1 has been forecast if there is no new Federal or state aid by early next week.

title: Searchers Fail to Find Medical Helicopter
description: Snow flurries and fog today hampered rescuers searching the rugged terrain of the Appalachian Mountains for a helicopter and three people aboard, including a critically ill heart patient.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 21. 1. Georgia. 2. False. There was a ''suspension'' of martial law, a partial measure towards normalization. 3. Third. 4. Mr. Haig commands at least $15,000 for each appearance on the lecture circuit. Mr. Allen gets much less. 5. Just five days after Christmas Village, a chaletlike structure where children met Santa Claus, was destroyed by arson, it was completely rebuilt through volunteered labor and materials.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COMEBACK

title:
Patents;
Electronic Searches To Begin
description: WASHINGTON A report to Congress on automating the work in the Patent and Trademark Office, submitted this week by Commissioner Gerald J. Mossinghoff, says the first stage will be completed by 1984. By then, the hand-done paperwork will be replaced, for one group of patents and all trademarks, by computer and electronic operations.

title: BONN OPENS DOOR FOR ELECTIONS IN MARCH
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative coalition intentionally lost a confidence vote in Parliament today, opening the way for general elections in three months.

title: ISRAELIS AND GERMANS DOUBT BULGARIAN LINK IN ATTACK ON POPE
description: Israeli and West German intelligence and security sources with a special interest in international terrorism are skeptical of charges of a Bulgarian connection in last year's attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II by a Turk.

title: JETS CAN CLINCH PLAYOFF SPOT
description: The Jets can become the first National Football League team to make the playoffs if they defeat the Miami Dolphins on Saturday. The game, though, pits the New Yorkers against the one club that has defeated them in a 5-1 season.

title:
PATENTS;
Disposable Fusion Units To Produce Electricity
description: A disposable nuclear fusion apparatus patented this week is described as promising high electric power production at limited cost.

title: CARIBBEAN AID PROGRAM WINS IN HOUSE, 260-142
description: The House of Representatives today approved President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative, a major program to increase trade opportunities and incentives to 23 nations in the region.

title: News Analysis
description: How is it that three conservative Republican Senators can frustrate the will of President Reagan, the leaders of both parties and the overwhelming majority of the entire Congress?

title: Your Money; Bond Swaps As Tax Aids
description: EVERY year around this time, tax swapping reaches a crescendo. For December is the month when thousands of holders of securities - generally bonds rather than stocks - use this device to create paper losses that will shelter part of their income from taxes.

title: Atlanta Parents Want Murder Cases Reopened
description: A group of parents who had charged that officials mishandled some of the Atlanta child murder cases has filed a Federal lawsuit demanding the investigations be reopened.

title: Educators Who Put Children Last
description: If you assume that public schools are run for the benefit of the children, you might want to think again. In at least one critical recent decision, the job interests of teachers and administrators were clearly and shamefully given preference.

title: YAMANI WARNS OPEC ON PRICE PACT
description: Saudi Arabia warned the other members of OPEC today that it would unilaterally lower oil prices if agreements on production and pricing were not reached at a crucial weekend meeting here.

title: Rules at 3 Mile Island Faulted
description: A nuclear power expert testified yesterday that the damage to the Three Mile Island nuclear plant would have been only minimal if the operators had followed new safety instructions recommended by a top engineer for the manufacturer of the reactor.

title: SENATORS APPROVE MOVE ON MX FUNDS BACKED BY REAGAN
description: The Senate, working around the clock in an attempt to adjourn before Christmas, today adopted a compromise endorsed by President Reagan that would allocate the money to build MX missiles but prevent him from actually spending it until Congress approved.

title: Decline in New Jobless Claims
description: The number of Americans filing firsttime claims for unemployment compensation dropped to 590,000 in the week ended Dec. 4, the lowest total for that statistic in more than four months, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

title: TV: 'WHO KILLED THE LINDBERGH BABY?'
description: ''Who Killed the Lindbergh Baby?'' is the wrong title for the hourlong documentary being shown at 8 o'clock tonight on WNET-TV, Channel 13. Ludovic Kennedy, the British journalist who wrote and narrated this BBC production, addresses himself to the question of who did not kidnap and kill the infant son of Charles and Anne Morrow Lindbergh in 1932. His answer: Bruno Richard Hauptmann, the man who was executed for the crime.

title: NIGHT OF FEAR ENDS HAPPILY
description: A big yellow school bus that disappeared with 10 members of a girls' basketball team and the coach was found today stuck in the mud on a lonely logging road, ending a nightlong search by the police and frantic parents. The girls were caked with mud but unharmed.

title: THE NEW MEN WHO RUN THE INTERIOR MINISTRY AND THE K.G.B.
description: Vitaly V. Fedorchuk

title: Bridge:; Eight Teams Battle for Title In Winter Regional Event
description: The knockout championship of the New York Winter Regional Tournament continues today at the New York Hilton with eight teams surviving from an original entry of 26.

title: Swaziland's Police Seize South African Exiles
description: The police arrested nearly 100 members of a banned South African black nationalist organization today but said the move was not related to a South African commando raid on Lesotho last week, a Government spokesman said. today.

title: NEW FEDERAL RULE ON FOOD ADVERTISING IS REJECTED
description: As a result of a tie vote today, the Federal Trade Commission will not issue regulations restricting advertising claims about low-calorie, low-cholesterol, low-fat and ''natural'' foods.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Brian Sipe, the Cleveland Browns' quarterback who was the N.F.L's most valuable player in 1980, will be replaced in tomorrow's game against the Pittsburgh Steelers by Paul McDonald, according to Coach Sam Rutigliano. ''Brian hasn't played up to his level the last four games,'' the coach said. ... Coach Roy Kidd of Eastern Kentucky, whose team will play Delaware for the Division I-AA football title today, is reportedly a candidate for the head coaching job at Army.

title: Graham Dancers Name Lee Traub Board Chief
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has announced the appointment of Lee Traub as president of its board of trustees. Mrs. Traub, a former student of Miss Graham's, is also on the boards of the National Corporate Fund for Dance, the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center and the International League for Human Rights.

title: DOW JUMPS BY 21.25, to 1,011.50
description: The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 21.25 points yesterday, to 1,011.50, ending a seven-day slump. Analysts said the rally resulted largely from the strong performance of International Business Machines, the market's current bellwether.

title: POLITICAL DEADLOCK IS BLOCKING ACCORD ON HELP FOR M.T.A.
description: Despite two weeks of trying, the Governor and legislative leaders have been unable to reach an agreement on how to close the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's budget deficit and hold off a rise in the transit fares. Early today, the leaders met in Governor Carey's office and decided to take the weekend off to consider the impasse and weigh public opinion. Here are some questions and answers about the situation, based on interviews with participants in the process: Q. What is the problem? The M.T.A. projects deficits in the 1983 calendar year of $187 million in the $2.2 billion budget of the Transit Authority and $117 million in the $900 million budgets of the Long Island Rail Road and the northern commuter rail lines.

title: ANALYSTS SAY OPEC OIL PRICE WILL DECLINE FURTHER
description: As OPEC ministers gather in Vienna to discuss ways to reverse the fall in oil prices, industry experts foresee the possibility of a substantial decline in those prices during the coming year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 9 misstated terms of an agreement settling a class action suit against the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company. Firestone said it would establish a fund to settle claims by purchasers of its stock from Dec. 1, 1975, to July 24, 1978.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: This is a story for everyone who thinks New York is the Ebenezer Scrooge of cities. It has yuletide carols being sung by a choir, tiny tots with their eyes all aglow and tidings of comfort and joy.

title: Willie Snow Ethridge, Author Of Travel and History Books
description: Willie Snow Ethridge, winner of this year's North Carolina Award for Literature, died Tuesday in Key West, Fla. She was 82 years old.

title: Stadium Problems
description: Don Coryell, the coach of the San Diego Chargers, complains that San Diego Jack Murphy Stadium, where his team plays, smells like a barnyard.

title: Quake Kills 6 Afghan Miners
description: Afghanistan's state radio said today that at least six people were killed in a mine by an earthquake that jolted the northern part of the country. The Kabul radio said the quake was felt in Kabul, the capital, and areas as far north as Baghlan, about 120 miles away.

title: A CHANGE IN PHONE CHARGES
description: "OPERATOR, may I charge this call to my home number?'' Out of change and standing at pay phones, people by the thousands in the metropolitan area this month were surprised when operators said ''No.''

title: 'Almost an Eagle' to Close
description: ''Almost an Eagle,'' the comedy by Michael Kimberley about a Boy Scout troop in Iowa, will close after tomorrow's matinee at the Longacre Theater. Directed by Jacques Levy, the play will have run for three previews and five performances.

title: OLD IS OLD IS OLD, FACE IT SQUARELY. AVOID DELUSIONS
description: I am old. Those hateful words are all but forbidden in these United States. The simple declaration marks the worst kind of defeatist. Such a stamp is applied by a nation addicted to the mindless worship of youth. Membership in the youth cult is understandable if the communicant is young. What baffles me is the oldster who states triumphantly: ''You're only as old as you feel.'' Nonsense! You are, of course, as old as you are. And one of the tricks of old age is to face it squarely. Few of us have mastered that trick. Instead, we indulge in dreams and delusions.

title: Hockey Fight Studied
description: A fight between rival players in the Vancouver-Montreal game Wednesday night that continued off the ice is under investigation by the National Hockey League. The league's executive vice president, Brian O'Neill, said he had asked for official reports and videotapes on fisticuffs between Chris Nilan of the Canadiens and Curt Fraser of the Canucks. The fight started during the second period and resumed in the hallway leading to the dressing rooms after both players were ejected.

title: Ohio State Routs Brigham Young
description: Tim Spencer ran for 167 yards and two touchdowns, including a 61-yard scoring burst, tonight to lead Ohio State to a 47-17 victory over Brigham Young in the Holiday Bowl.

title: BOSSY SCORES 3 AS THE ISLANDERS DEFEAT RANGERS
description: The Islanders came out hitting and checking last night with the vigor they have not shown recently, and overwhelmed the Rangers, 5-2, in a briskly paced, hard-fought game at Madison Square Garden. Their next objective is to beat the Philadelphia Flyers tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: 'FAME,' LAGGING IN U.S. RATINGS, PROVES A HIT WITH VIEWERS IN BRITAIN ; BY SALLY BEDELL
description: When ''Dallas'' captured the fancy of audiences in Britain two years ago the explanation was obvious: the machinations of J.R. Ewing and his family had become a phenomenon here and it was only a matter of time before they captured an audience overseas as well.

title: ARGUMENTS END IN UTAH FALLOUT CASE
description: Attorneys for the Federal Government and for a group of Southwestern citizens offered their final arguments here today in a landmark lawsuit charging that atomic weapons tests in the Nevada desert nearly three decades ago caused a high incidence of cancer death and illness among nearby residents.

title: METHODIST WORKERS VOTE FOR AFFILIATION WITH A MAJOR UNION
description: Nearly 200 secretaries and other clerical staff people at the United Methodist Church Board of Global Ministries voted last week to join District 65 of the United Automobile Workers, marking the first time that church workers had chosen to unite with a major American labor union.

title: Black Named in Alabama
description: James C. White, co-founder of a black accounting company, will become the first black Revenue Commissioner in Alabama history. Gov. George C. Wallace, the former segregationist who was elected in November to a fourth term, named the 34-year-old certified public accountant as his choice for the post Thursday.

title: Rogers Struggles
description: As a rookie for the New Orleans Saints last season, George Rogers made quite an impact on the National Football League. He rushed for 1,674 yards, more than any other rookie in the league's history, and scored 13 touchdowns.

title: Jersey Ring Changes
description: Robert Lee, the deputy commissioner of the New Jersey State Athletic Commission, said that, under new rules, boxers would need a document listing their fights in order for his office to monitor their recovery between bouts.

title: A PLACE FOR COLOR IN THE TRADITION OF U.S. HOUSES
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Banc One Corp. said it had agreed in principle to acquire First National City Bank of Alliance, Ohio. Under the agreement, each common share of First National City Bank will be exchanged for 0.8667 shares of Banc One common.

title: STRICLTY BEAU MONDE
description: The state's highest court scolded the city government this week for having denied a tax abatement to the glass and steel creation of Donald Trump, master builder - the structure that he calls, interchangeably, the Trump Tower or ''the world's most talked about address.''

title: CHIEF'S DEATH ADDS TO LOTUS WOES
description: The sudden death Thursday morning of Colin Chapman, the automobile designer who ran Group Lotus Car Companies Ltd., has raised new questions in the effort to reverse the company's sagging fortunes.

title: ANOTHER TEST-BAN AVENUE
description: Progress toward a ban on nuclear-weapons testing has halted, despite growing public support for control of such weapons. An alternate, new path to a complete test ban is thus worth considering.

title: FUNDS ALLOWED TO ARTS PANEL
description: A minor embarrassment to President Reagan's arts policy was removed today when a Senate-House conference committee voted to allow Federal funds to be spent for a special panel he appointed, called the Committee on Arts and Humanities.

title:
PATENTS;
A Board Game to Train Employees at Bank
description: A new method of training bank employees takes the form of a game.

title: Asia Society Elects Roy M. Huffington
description: Roy M. Huffington, a trustee of the Asia Society for the last three years, has been elected chairman of the board of the society and will assume the post next month.

title: Garvey Sets Deadline
description: The Steve Garvey sweepstakes got down to ''final offers'' yesterday, with three teams still bidding for the longtime first baseman for the Los Angeles Dodgers, who will be 34 years old next week and is a free agent. The three teams are the Chicago Cubs, the San Diego Padres and the San Francisco Giants.

title: WALESA VOWS A PEACEFUL BATTLE FOR BANNED UNION
description: Lech Walesa, who was detained by the authorities Thursday to prevent him from giving a speech, told foreign journalists today that he planned to continue to fight for his outlawed independent union, Solidarity, ''but only by peaceful means.''

title: DANCE: AILEY, 'TREADING'
description: The house went wild as the curtain went down on Elisa Monte's ''Treading'' Thursday at City Center, where the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is in residence. The dance, performed here in the original duet version, is an erotic tour de force, requiring not so much a developed dance technique as sheer physical strength and presence. Mari Kajiwara and Keith McDaniel happen to be two of the company's best dancers. And they certainly had presence.

title: ARGENTINES SPLIT OVER RALLY VIOLENCE
description: An anti-Government demonstration that ended in violence Thursday left Government and opposition leaders united in sorrow today but divided over who was responsible.

title: Weaver Sorry For Remarks
description: Mike Weaver, who lost his World Boxing Association heavyweight title last week to Michael Dokes, has apologized to the Nevada Athletic Commission for remarks he made.

title: 3 WANTED BY ITALY IN SHOOTING OF POPE MEET WITH PRESS IN BULGARIA
description: Bulgarian authorities presented three people at a news conference today who are wanted in Italy in connection with the shooting of Pope John Paul II. All three denied any involvement in the attack.

title: Deadline Passes in Abduction Of Honduran Chief's Daughter
description: The Guatemalan Government said tonight that it would not negotiate with ''terrorists,'' but did not say whether it would permit publication a manifesto demanded by the kidnappers of the daughter of the president of Honduras.

title: Pillsbury's Net Drops by 31.8%
description: The Pillsbury Company reported yesterday that a write-down of some assets, a substantial drop in the operating profits of its Agri-Products operations and a higher effective tax helped cause earnings in its second fiscal quarter to plunge 31.8 percent, despite a 7.5 percent increase in sales.

title: DIVORCED FATHERS PROTESTING TOO MUCH
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTBALL TO THE BEAT OF A DIFFERENT DRUM
description: W ith professional football back in reasonably normal stride, we decided to visit Walden Pond to discuss recent developments with its famous resident and sage, Henry David Thoreau.

title: ADMINISTRATION BATTLES CITATION OF E.P.A. CHIEF
description: The Justice Department said today that it would refuse to follow a directive from the House of Representatives to prosecute the head of the Environmental Protection Agency unless it was ordered to do so by a court.

title: SOUTHERN COMFORTS
description: T hirty-eight business and government leaders from 19 counties in Tennessee, Georgia and Alabama have been in the city this week, the latest wave of those who seek to lure businesses in the metropolitan area to their parts of the world.

title: DISSENT ON A.T.& T. PLAN
description: Affidavits filed by executives of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company show a disagreement within the company over how to handle the divestiture of one of A.T.&T.'s local phone companies.

title: LEGISLATORS TRADE CHARGES OVER TRANSIT DEADLOCK
description: In hallway news conferences outside Governor Carey's office at 1 this morning, Democratic legislative leaders and the Senate Republican leader traded charges over who was to blame for the deadlock over how to raise taxes and prevent an increase in bus, subway and commuter rail fares in the New York metropolitan area.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $3.5 BILLION
description: With business credit demands and the economy weak, the Federal Reserve released data yesterday that showed it was continuing to supply the banking system with the funds necessary to sustain both rapid money supply growth and lower interest rates.

title: REAGAN TO NAME PANEL TO DRAFT NEW MX PLAN
description: President Reagan, attempting to revive support for his MX missile plan, announced tonight that he would appoint a bipartisan commission to study the how to base the new missile before making fresh recommendations to Congress.

title: AFTER 30 YEARS, ERA ENDING IN HOUSE WITH DEPARTURE OF A G.O.P. LOYALIST
description: The bells rang and John J. Rhodes walked from his office to the House floor. But this time it was different. After 30 years in Congress, he was casting his final votes.

title: Mime's the Word
description: For Eddie Tamir, who left veterinary school in Melbourne, Australia, after three years when he discovered ''I didn't like animals,'' the choice was simple: Yeshiva University here or the Marcel Marceau School of Mime, in Paris. Yeshiva won, partly says Tamir, ''because Marcel Marceau can't hit a jump shot.''

title: 2 DIFFERENCES CONTINUING TO DELAY HOUSING TAX-ABATEMENT PROGRAM
description: The Koch administration and the critics of its housing taxincentive program said yesterday there were still two major differences between them in their efforts to reach a compromise that would allow the State Assembly to extend the program.

title: Mormon Statue Battered
description: For the second time in 18 months, the towering white statue of Christ in the Mormon Church's Temple Square has been battered with a hammer, church officials say. A man identified as Larry B. Sargeant, 51 years old, of Heber City, attacked the 12-foot statue Thursday, the authorities said, breaking its hands and arms before being pulled off by bystanders. He was charged with felonious destruction of property and aggravated assault.

title: Doctors' Group Said to Raise $2.5 Million for Legal Brothels
description: A group of California doctors has put together $2.5 million to buy three brothels in Winnemucca, Nev., according to their investment broker. The brothels were put up for sale by a French madam faced with deportation.

title: A COLD HARD NET
description: The only Santa Claus I've seen so far this season was wearing a blue suit and a badge, and he was being interviewed on television in Penn Station where he works as a railroad cop. It was in the morning's wee hours, the time when Santa traditionally performs his ancient charities, and the station had a silent, abandoned look.

title: O'Neill Outspent Connecticut Rival
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, a Democrat, narrowly outspent his Republican rival, Lewis B. Rome, in his successful effort to win a full term, according to reports filed today.

title: Duracell Adds Europe Business
description: Dart & Kraft Inc., the food, consumer and commercial products conglomerate, announced that its battery-making subsidiary, Duracell Inc., had acquired the mainland European battery business of British Ever Ready Ltd. of London for $60 million.

title: Wickes Closing Its Aldens Unit
description: The Wickes Companies, the retailer based in Santa Monica, Calif., that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act since April, announced that all attempts to find a buyer for its 93-year-old catalogue subsidiary -Aldens Inc. - had failed, and that it would close the nation's fifth-largest catalogue operation. PU COMPNEWS FOLOS

title: Carey Signs Measures To Help City's Budget
description: Governor Carey signed into law today two measures to help New York City close its budget deficit this year.

title: A LOTTO PLAYER'S ONE CHANCE IN 609 MILLION
description: To the Editor:

title: SAUDI GIVES HARVARD MUSEUM $600,000 TO FIND MIDEAST PHOTOS
description: Harvard University's Semitic Museum has received a $600,000 grant from the King of Saudi Arabia to search out and preserve early photographs of the Middle East, the museum announced today.

title: DISCOUNTS FOR AGED: PETS TO PIZZA
description: ''Now this,'' Frank Filson, a retired schoolteacher who recently moved to New York, said to the waitress, Eileen Doherty, as she presented him with his $6.44 dinner check, ''is one advantage of growing old.''

title: A CRITIC'S FAVORITES
description: As intriguing as it may be to find new and unusual foods to give at Christmas, I am beginning to miss some of the simple, basic classics that make up in quality for what they lack in originality. Aside from such obvious and costly classics as beluga caviar, truffles and foie gras, there are a dozen or so wonderful things to eat that I shall buy as last-minute gifts, and which any procrastinating friends can buy for me.

title: Old Report Led To Token Problem
description: Connecticut officials used an outdated report when they designed the state's 17 1/2-cent turnpike token, resulting in its being virtually the same size as New York City's 75-cent subway token, a state transportation official said today.

title: KOCH DISCERNS AN OUTBREAK OF COMMUNITY 'SELFISHNESS'
description: Mayor Koch yesterday criticized ''a disturbing new dimension'' in neighborhood opposition to a series of city projects - a jail in Chinatown, a shelter in Harlem for homeless men, an incinerator in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He described it as ''an outbreak of selfishness'' that he thought might be nationwide.

title: Soviet Expels Briton In a Retaliatory Move
description: The Soviet Union ordered Britain's naval attache to leave the country within a week in retaliation for the expulsion of the Soviet naval attache in Britain, the British Embassy announced today.

title: A FRENCH RESISTANCE LEADER
description: Clara Malraux, author, art critic and a leading figure in the anti-Nazi resistance in France, who was the first wife of Andre Malraux, author and Minister of Culture under President Charles de Gaulle, died in Paris Wednesday. She was 85 years old.

title: Delta Air Plans An Expansion
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said it planned to spend $100 million to add 22 new departure gates to its present 15-gate facility at the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport.

title: KOCH SAID TO PLAN LAYOFFS TO ABSORB CITY REVENUE LOSS
description: Mayor Koch has developed plans to lay off at least 3,300 municipal workers and leave about 5,300 other positions unfilled over the next 18 months, city officials said yesterday. The plan is designed to meet the likelihood that state aid will be $300 million less than the Mayor requested.

title: CHRYSLER'S U.S. WORKERS APPROVE NEW CONTRACT
description: A new contract between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers covering some 48,000 blue-collar and white-collar employees was ratified by the union's rank and file today, winning 79.5 percent of the vote.

title:
PATENTS;
Human Hormones
description: A method of producing human hormones from microorganisms by the process known as recombinant DNA has been developed for the University of California at Berkeley.

title: 7 Republican Congressmen Assail Legal Aid Corporation
description: Seven Republican Congressmen told President Reagan today that the conduct of his appointees to the Legal Services Corporation board ''is an embarrassment to us and is becoming a political liability to you.''

title: SENATE REJECTS AMENDMENT TO BAR F.T.C. JURISDICTION OVER DOCTORS
description: The Senate rejected a last-ditch legislative attempt early this morning to exempt physicians and state-licensed professionals from the Federal Trade Commission's consumer protection regulations.

title: MALONE LEADS 76ERS PAST KNICKS, 109-95
description: The Philadelphia 76ers played like the team with the best record in the National Basketball Association over the first half tonight. But they faltered in the third period, before they again overwhelmed the Knicks in the final quarter of a 109-95 victory at the Spectrum.

title: BRIEFING
description: Backfire From MX

title: LEWIS CARROLL IS HONORED ON 150TH BIRTHDAY
description: A shy mathematics teacher who enchanted children and adults alike with a vivid fantasy world about a girl named Alice tonight joined the pantheon of literary giants in Westminster Abbey.

title: IN HARMONY ON RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: SEARS PLANS TO SELL 4 SHOPPING CENTERS
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, a diversified concern with major interests in retailing and financial services, announced today that it had agreed to sell four company-owned shopping center developments to Corporate Property Investors Inc., a private New York concern. Sears did not disclose the purchase price nor the terms of the agreement.

title: MOVE AGAINST CORRUPTION IS SEEN
description: The official who has headed the K.G.B. security and intelligence organization for the last seven months, Vitaly V. Fedorchuk, was appointed Minister of Internal Affairs today and was succeeded at the K.G.B. by one of his top deputies, Viktor M. Chebrikov.

title: Giorgio Chinaglia, Please Call Home
description: Giorgio Chinaglia has been offered a six-year contract as president of Lazio, the Italian team he left in May 1976 to join the Cosmos, and the leading scorer in North American Soccer League history said yesterday that he was ''thinking about the offer very seriously.''

title: MEDICAL INSURANCE SAVINGS
description: Over the last 10 years, various Democratic and Republican proposals to halt the spiraling costs of medical care--each involving possible curtailment of services to many people--have proved unacceptable to powerful groups. There is one strategy, however, that none of these proposals has bothered to adopt--one that would impose scarcely any hardship on anyone and yet would save the public at least $16 billion annually. The strategy is simply this: Eliminate duplication of private medical insurance benefits.

title: OPERA: FIRST 'TROVATORE' OF SEASON AT THE MET
description: The Metropolitan Opera's first ''Il Trovatore'' of the season, presented Thursday night, was a routine runthrough that generated interest whenever Fiorenza Cossotto seized the stage as Azucena, but rarely otherwise.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Father in Heaven, the senators are very weary in body and mind.

title: Price of Clean Politics
description: In Mayor Koch's comments the other night, was there a hint of nostalgia for the bad old days when, some say, politicians used to make deals with people like ''power brokers''?

title: TURNER WINS SENATE CABLE SKIRMISH
description: In a lobbying move that angered broadcast and motion picture officials, Ted Turner, the cable television pioneer from Atlanta, succeeded in persuading a Senator from Georgia to put an amendment of special interest to the cable television industry on the emergency spending bill that has preoccupied Congress much of this week.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1982
description: International A change in Soviet intelligence chiefs appeared to be linked to moves by Yuri V. Andropov, the new Communist Party leader, to step up a Kremlin campaign against corruption and crime, two major reponsibilities of the Internal Affairs Ministry. Vitaly V. Fedorchuk, who had been head of the K.G.B. security and intelligence organization for the last seven months, was appointed Internal Affairs Minister. He was succeeded at the K.G.B. by one of his top deputies, Viktor M. Chebrikov. (Page 1, Columns 3-4.) A further drop in oil prices is a possibility in 1983, industry experts say, as the OPEC ministers gather in Vienna to discuss how to reverse the recent decline. Predictions of a continuing fall below OPEC's basic $34 a barrel price have raised fears that a decline could so reduce revenues for such exporting countries as Mexico and Nigeria by so much that they could not repay their foreign debts, placing the strained international banking system under further stress. (1:1-2.)

title: Jersey Lotto Pays Record Single Prize
description: An electrical engineer who said he had ''no real system'' claimed the top prize of $4.2 million today in this week's Pick-6 Lotto.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1982; Markets
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 21.25 points, to 1,011.50, ending a slump. The advance, which came after a 66-point drop over the previous seven trading days, was attributed to strength in I.B.M., favorable technical factors and covering of short positions. (35.)

title: JOHN D. CRAWFORD SR.
description: John D. Crawford Sr., vice president of Johnson & Higgins, an insurance-brokerage concern in New York, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in West Orange, N.J. He was 64 years old.

title: Son Said to Kill Parents
description: The son of a World Bank official was charged Thursday with killing his parents. Alain T. DeCock, 21 years old, allegedly used a .22-caliber rifle on Monday to kill his father, Romain Paul DeCock, 52, an agricultural loan expert with the World Bank, and his mother, Simone, 50.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Keijo (Keke) Rosberg of Finland was named world auto racing champion for 1982 at the International Auto Sports Federation's annual awards ceremony Friday in Paris. Rosberg was named despite winning only one Grand Prix event in 1982. ... Darrell Waltrip, who won the Nascar Grand National championship for the second straight year, was named 1982 Driver of the Year by Auto Racing Digest. ... Ronald M. Mottl, an outgoing member of the United States House of Representatives, has been appointed a special assistant to Gabe Paul, the president of the Cleveland Indians.

title: At What Price?
description: To the Business Editor: In ''F.D.A. Regulation - at What Price?'' (Nov.21), Paul MacAvoy said that the risk to consumers from old-type packaging was one poisoned package for each 100 million produced. Unfortunately, such precise calculations of risk and ''insurance value'' (one cent per package) are possible only after tragedy strikes, and they can apply only to the past.

title: NEW ROLE FOR A BALLET VETERAN
description: The wine glasses may be empty at the party that opens George Balanchine's production of ''The Nutcracker.'' The fast-growing Christmas tree may be a matter of pulleys. But when Francisco Moncion steps out onto the stage of the New York State Theater this week in his new role of Drosselmeier, the ancient visitor whose gift of a nutcracker initiates adventures, he will be proof that the magic is not all of the stage. A very real family inhabits the stage at each performance. Mr. Moncion, its oldest performing member, has spent 36 of his 60 years with the City Ballet. The adult dancers who share the stage with him represent two more generations. And the children, some of them as young as 9, are students at the City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet where Mr. Moncion learned to dance as a child and still takes class.

title: RENTAL PLAN STIRS THREE VILLAGES
description: SETAUKET THE Suffolk Interreligious Council on Housing, which owns 43 acres of former farmland near the State University at Stony Brook, is asking the Town of Brookhaven for a change in zone to allow the construction of 60 town house and garden apartment units on a 12-acre segment of the property.

title: CLARKE'S GOAL TIES ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders, for all their gallant effort to win a second consecutive game for the first time since October, came up with only a 4-4 tie in a hard-fought game tonight with the Philadelphia Flyers in Nassau Coliseum.

title: Mary S. Trimble Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Trimble of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Sussannah Trimble, to Robert Emmet O'Brien Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Emmet O'Brien of Deal, N.J. The wedding is planned for May 25. Miss Trimble is an account executive with the NCR Corporation in New York. Mr. O'Brien is a trader for MacMillan Bloedel Inc., a lumber concern in New York.

title: RAISE THE AGE, LOWER THE RISK?
description: ''The eyes and ears of the nation are literally on the State of New Jersey,'' Assemblyman Martin A. Herman intoned last week. At least teen-age ones, anyway. As President Reagan declared National Drunk and Drugged Driving Awareness Week, the Legislature voted to raise New Jersey's drinking age from 19 to 21, effective Jan.1. Governor Kean has said he will sign the measure, which is precisely the sort of legislation that a Presidential commission believes will curb youthful drunken drivers and the accidents they cause.

title: CHURCHES ARE OFFERING SACRED MUSIC IN NEW WAYS
description: Leslie Kandell is a freelance writer and a member of the choir at Riverside Church.

title: CITY UNION HEADS ASSAIL PLANS TO CUT WORK FORCE
description: The leaders of New York City's major municipal employee unions yesterday sharply criticized Mayor Koch's contingency plans to cut the city's work force and suggested that higher taxes and more pressure to increase state aid were needed to close the city's projected budget deficit.

title: Employees of Ohio Hospital Vote to End 4 1/2-Month Strike
description: Striking maintenance and service workers at Trumbull Memorial Hospital voted to end their four-and-a half-month walkout Friday, though some of the strikers will not go back to work for nearly three years.

title: COOKE TELLS CATHOLICS IN MILITARY OF ARMS STAND
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, in his annual letter to Roman Catholics in the armed forces, has sought to give assurance that the recent debate among the bishops over nuclear arms does not diminish the church's support of the efforts of the military.

title: Margiotta's Role Draws Protest
description: The arrogance of Joe Margiotta is boundless. Now he expects the Supreme Court of the United States, with all its multitude of farreaching issues, and with an overcrowded calendar as reported by Chief Justice Burger in his recent N.Y.U. speech, to decide to hear his case on insurance fee kickbacks.

title: Miss Koch Wins Title
description: Simone Koch of East Germany won the girls' event of the world junior figure skating championships today. She had only 3.2 penalty points.

title: THE LIMITS OF URBAN GROWTH
description: Paul Goldberger did not explain why no one defines and controls the limits of growth. I have two answers: No one wants to, and there is no tradition to do so.

title: U.S.S.R. TURNS 60, BUT SOME 'FRIENDS' WILL SKIP THE PARTY
description: There was a time when the curse of ''revisionism'' or ''opportunism'' levied at Tito or Mao sent shudders through the world of Communism. Emanating from the Kremlin, the bastion of Marxism-Leninism, the capital of the first socialist state, they amounted to a threat of excommunication from the ranks of history's vanguard. Nowadays, revisionism, opportunism and the other swearwords of intra-Communist haggling fly freely from Moscow, Peking, the capitals of Eurocommunism and 100-odd other Communist parties, with little evident impact.

title: PRINCETON GRADUATES TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Ingram 2d of Pasadena, Calif., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Shelley Ingram, to William Hunter de Butts 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. deButts Jr. of Marshall, Va. The couple, who are graduates of Princeton University,plan a May wedding in New York.

title: 4 Family Members Are Killed In a Blaze at an Albany Home
description: A man trying to rescue his son and daughter was killed with them and their great-grandmother today in an early morning fire in the woman's home, officials said.

title: QUINTIN DAILEY'S TROUBLED PAST, AND PRESENT
description: CHICAGO THE night of Oct. 30, the night the Bulls played their home opener against Washington, was particularly cold in Chicago. And the 60 or so women who gathered outside Chicago Stadium with picket signs wore, as one of them would recall, ''a lot of layers.''

title: IMPARTIALLY CERTIFY FOREIGN AID APPLICANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL INTEREST MOVED ROADS BILL
description: The doctors told Representative Bud Shuster to take it easy after two operations for a broken neck. But for the past week the Pennsylvania Republican has been on the floor of the House, working as Republican manager of the bill that would raise gasoline taxes to pay for a $5.5 billion job-creation program for highway and bridge repairs.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS KILL ARAB YOUTH
description: An Arab youth in the Israeli-occupied West Bank town of Nablus was shot and killed today and another student seriously wounded by Israeli troops, the Israeli radio reported.

title: POLITICS AND PERKS REVIVE REAGAN FIGHT ON LEGAL AID
description: The people President Reagan appointed to tame the Legal Services Corporation bowed out last week in a blaze of recriminations. After seeing their nominations for full terms on the board of directors unceremoniously dumped by the President, they were tongue-lashed by a Congressional panel, harangued by a hostile crowd at their last public meeting and temporarily blocked at the door by a stooped old black woman as they tried to go into closed session.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Linda E. Gay, John Powers Marry on L.I.
description: Linda Elizabeth Gay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Gay of Huntington Bay, L.I., was married in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., yesterday to John Joseph Powers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Powers Jr. of Centerport, L.I. The Rev. Carleton T. Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: BEFORE WE TAX SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Bloomingdale $81,850 17 Jeffry Drive *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old ranch; *2*finished basement, fireplace in family room, *2*deck; taxes $1,890. Kinnelon $172,000 45 Chilhowie Drive *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old contemporary; *2*fireplace in living room, central *2*air-conditioning, finished basement; taxes Ringwood $127,000 173 Buena Vista Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath. 12-year-old colonial; *2*wooded lot, fireplace in family room, 2-car garage; taxes $2,673. Pompton Lakes $130,000 179 Hilltop Court *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old ranch; *2*fireplace in family room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,470. Wanaque $93,500 67 Molinari Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old split level; *2*full basement, fireplace; taxes $2,100. Wayne $136,000 17 Alpine Terrace *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; *2*2 fireplaces, central air-conditionioning, *2*2-car garage; taxes $2,768. OTHER AREAS New Hyde Park, LI. $118,000 102 Joseph Street *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old Cape Cod; *2*formal dining room, full basement; taxes $2,000. Madison, Conn. $127,000 48 Stonewall Lane *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; *2*heated sunspace, 3/4 acre; taxes $1,682. Hartsdale, N.Y. $132,500 135 Mercer Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 41-year-old brick colonial; *2*enclosed porch, 70- by 100-foot lot; taxes $3,830.

title:
DINING OUT;
ANOTHER SPOT FOR 'CHINESE VILLAGE'
description: FAST becoming a linear Chinese village, Central Avenue now has 10 restaurants offering Chinese cuisine. That all of them are crowded on a Saturday night testifies to the popularity of Chinese food. It is cheap and almost never boring in its seemingly infinite taste combinations. Open since September, Golden Dynasty falls just within the Scarsdale border. An ambitious menu lists about 150 dishes from five regions and includes an intriguing-sounding few appearing for the ''first time in Scarsdale.'' Four visits found the kitchen uneven. Averaging dishes that ran from superior to dreadful resulted in the rating of one dim star.

title: DRINKING AGE: WHOSE VIEWS ARE REALISTIC?
description: year-old Dutch Colonial building that houses Rutgers University's administrative offices, sits on the crest of a slope overlooking the heart of the state university's main campus here.

title: HOME COOKING AT A COUNTRY INN
description: SALISBURY UNDER MOUNTAIN INN, at the northwest corner of Connecticut, just a few miles from the Massachusetts line, fulfills many of the romantic visions that most diners and weekenders seek in a country inn. Antiques abound, but the lounge and dining rooms don't look ''decorated.'' The natural look is part of the inn's considerable charm.

title: ANTINUCLEAR GROUP HOLDS SESSION ON STRATEGY
description: Participants in a two-day session, ''Funding the Prevention of Nuclear War,'' have found that antinuclear groups were able to raise only $20 million last year for their movement.

title: ENSEMBLE ACTING BUOYS 'THAT CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON'
description: The room was not a starched Victorian parlor in Scranton, Pa., but a sunny suite 24 floors up in the Waldorf-Astoria; the coach and his boys were not stoking up on whisky and fried chicken but on breakfast pastries and coffee. Otherwise it seemed nothing less than ''That Championship Season,'' moved East, and continued.

title: KOCH STATEMENT: 'TODAY THERE IS NOWHERE TO RUN'
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by Mayor Koch at City Hall yesterday on a new four-year financial plan for New York City.

title: Corabel R. Alexander Wed to Martin K. Shofner
description: Miss Corabel Roberts Alexander, daughter of Bebe Ham Alexander of Jackson, Miss., and the late Julian Power Alexander Jr., was married yesterday to Martin King Shofner, a New York architect. He is is a son of Brig. Gen. Austin Conner Shofner, U.S.M.C., retired, and Mrs. Shofner of Shelbyville, Tenn.

title: BY STEPHEN FARBER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. LOS ANGELES Many directors shy away from working with movie stars because they fear that their own authority will be challenged by insecure actors with oversized egos. But Sydney Pollack has worked with major stars on every one of his 13 films. He has directed Robert Redford five times (in such films as ''Jeremiah Johnson'' and ''Three Days of the Condor''), Jane Fonda twice (in ''They Shoot Horses, Don't They?'' and ''The Electric Horseman''), and has also guided Barbra Streisand in ''The Way We Were,'' Al Pacino in ''Bobby Deerfield,'' Paul Newman and Sally Field in last year's ''Absence of Malice.'' Although most of these stars have reputations for being strong-willed, Mr. Pollack has managed to control them and has often drawn from them the best performances of their careers.

title: WHERE DO YOU WANT THIS MISSILE?
description: FIRST in the early 1970's came the idea of an MX missile as a counterbalance to large Soviet land-based missiles. Then came the notion that Soviet missiles had become so accurate and powerful they could destroy American land-based missiles in their silos. Finally came the search for a way to base the MX so it could survive a Soviet attack and come out fighting.

title: BINGHAM TRYING TO LIMIT IN FLUENCE OF CAMPAIGN DONORS
description: Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, who came here 18 years ago after defeating Charles A. Buckley, the Bronx Democratic leader and Congressman, is retiring from political life convinced that Mr. Buckley's excesses were benign compared with what is going on in Congress now.

title: THE POET WHO FOUND HER OWN WAY
description: ZAMI: A NEW SPELLING OF MY NAME By Audre Lorde. 256 pp. Watertown, Mass.: Persephone Press. Paper. $7.95. CHOSEN POEMS OLD AND NEW By Audre Lorde. 115 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. Cloth, $12.95. Paper. $5.95.

title: The Role and Nature Of 'I Can Cope'
description: Linda Spear's article ''After the Hospital, Additional Care'' (Nov. 28) accurately and sensitively portrayed our hospital's continuing commitment to providing realistic options for patients who require additional care post hospitalization.

title: OF COMMON RIGHTS AND COMMON SENSE
description: FOR some time now, various members of the family have been rummaging through old books and cartons of papers that have occupied a corner of the basement in the home ofmy husband's parents, both dead for a number of years. Last week, my sister-in-law sent us some writings of my husband's maternal grandmother, Alice Berry Price.

title: JAEANN TITUS AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Titus of Old Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jaeann Whitemore Titus, to Burton Carnot Coit 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Coit Jr., of Washington, Pa. The wedding is planned for Aug. 20. Miss Titus is a sales assistant with All-Canada Radio & Television in Chicago. Mr. Coit is an account manager with the Chase Commercial Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Bank in Chicago.

title: EAST END SEEKS WEATHER REPORTS
description: REPRESENTATIVES of the Island's fishermen, farmers and tourist industry have begun a drive to improve the Federal Government weather reports in the eastern half of the Island and its offshore areas.

title: CONCERT: CLAUDIO ARRAU, Y CHAMBER
description: Claudio Arrau is appearing here often during his 80th-birthday season, but this weekend he is engaging in perhaps his most ambitious program -three concerts in which he offers both the Third and the Fifth (''Emperor'') Piano Concertos of Beethoven. The program, which also includes Beethoven's ''Coriolanus'' Overture, was presented by the Y Chamber Symphony for the first time Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall, was repeated at the 92d Street Y last night and receives its final repetition this afternoon at 3 at the Y.

title: ICEBOATING
description: Dick Andrews - painter, schoolteacher, Jack of many hobbies -is a big-boned, loose-jointed man with a strong chin and a nose that is slightly askew. There is that about him that puts one in mind of Croton Point, a craggy headland that juts into the Hudson River near Andrews's home in Ossining, N.Y.

title: GAME ABUSE HOTLINE RESULTS IN ARREST
description: A WILDLIFE hotline was established this month by the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection. In its first week of operation, the confidential, toll-free, 24-hour number provided information resulting in several arrests for game violations.
