title: A FRESH LOOK AT HOLIDAY WREATH TRADITIONS
description: Paula Deitz is a freelance writer. rnate or simple, no symbol of Christmas is more welcoming than the evergreen wreath affixed to the front door. Nineteenth century English novels are filled with holiday homecomings where entwined branches of green boughs figure prominently.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE PLAYBOY INTERVIEWS WITH JOHN LENNON & YOKO ONO. By David Sheff. Edited by G. Barry Golson. (Berkley, $3.50.) As he talks about his work in lengthy conversations taped shortly before his death two years ago, John Lennon provides what our reviewer, Joe Klein, called ''a fascinating, detailed glimpse into the workings of a musical genius.'' Mr. Klein, who learned more from this book than he wanted to know about Lennon's private life, valued the Playboy interviews for what they reveal about the relationship between John Lennon and Paul McCartney and about the exhilarating Beatles phenomenon.

title: IN METRIC FIGHT, CANADA M.P.'S TURN TO GALLON
description: The Government threatened this week to begin prosecuting merchants who have not adopted the metric standard, and 26 opposition Members of Parliament promptly challenged the move by taking over a filling station for the purpose of selling gasoline by the gallon.

title: GEOGRAPHIC'S TROUBLED WORLD
description: ASK people about the National Geographic Society, and the usual t opics come up. The yellow-bordered magazine with the fancy p hotographs. Maps. Coffee-table books. Television specials on g orillas or gems or some such thing.

title: O'ROURKE PREPARES FOR HIS NEW ROLE
description: ANDREW P. O'ROURKE was talking to a visitor in his eighth-floor office last Wednesday when a friend phoned to ask how he felt after being being named by the county's Republican leadership to replace Alfred B. DelBello as County Executive, at least until next November's election.

title: Why the Billions for Brazil
description: Why are we passing out billions of dollars to rescue Brazilians and Mexicans when millions of our people are walking the streets?

title: Transit Aid Is Stuck at The Turnstile
description: Like many a Seventh Avenue express, a transit aid package expected from Albany last week never arrived.

title: WHEN A DRAIN CLOGS UP AND THERE'S NOT A PLUMBER IN SIGHT
description: THERE is probably no plumbing problem that is more annoying - and harder to live with - than a clogged toilet, especially if it occurs on a holiday or at the beginning of a weekend when you cannot get a plumber to come over immediately and make the necessary repairs.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Joan Miro is one of the many 20th-century artists who have been fascinated by the figure of Pere Ubu, the monster in human shape who was invented by a French writer called Alfred Jarry toward the end of the 19th century. In the play called ''Ubu Roi,'' Ubu opens the proceedings with a word that even today cannot be printed here and goes on to flout every imaginable tenet of civilized behavior.
To the Editor:

title: BETRAYED BY SHAKESPEARE
description: THE SUNNE IN SPLENDOUR By Sharon Kay Penman. 936 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart Winston. $19.95.FLAMBARD'S CONFESSION By Marilyn Durham. 775 pp. New York and San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: O'NEILL IN SWEDEN
description: Although Eugene O'Neill never set foot in Sweden, he acquired a special affinity for that country. For one thing he is the only American dramatist to receive the Nobel Prize, awarded in 1936 and accepted by a letter acknowledging his artistic debt to August Strindberg, the Swedish playwright. Perhaps more importantly he was as impressed by the reception his plays received there as he was disgruntled by the way America seemed to turn its back on him in the 1940's.

title: NEW RULES PROPOSED ON THERAPY
description: MOUNTAINSIDE IN THE corner of a large, mat-lined room at Children's Specialized Hospital last week, a physical therapist urged a 2 1/2-year-old boy to pull himself to a standing position. She had designed special exercises to help him regain the muscle tone, trunk control, coordination and balance he had lost as a result of a head injury.

title: Fire Damages Church On West End Avenue
description: The roof and steeple of the West End Collegiate Church, a national landmark on West End Avenue at 77th Street, were extensively damaged during a three-alarm fire last night.

title: A CHINESE OFFICIAL PLANS AFRICA VISIT
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang is embarking on an extended tour of 10 African nations as part of China's campaign to enhance its image as a champion of the third world.

title: AS CABLE LAGS, NEW YORKERS TRY DISH ATTENNAS
description: With cable television in New York City still years away from expanding beyond Manhattan, frustrated residents of some privately owned housing complexes in the other boroughs are resorting to satellite master antennas to receive pay-television programs.

title: C.T. HAYDOCK TO WED CANDACE A. SPIELBERGER
description: Dr. and Mrs. George L. Spielberger of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Candace Ann Spielberger, to Charles Thorndike Haydock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis B. Haydock of Chestnut Hill and Ipswich, Mass.

title: MY FATHER, EDGAR LEE MASTERS
description: LAST STANDS Notes From Memory. By Hilary Masters. 210 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $14.95.

title: WRIGHT'S GENIUS IN DESIGN
description: Frank Lloyd Wright's furnishings, which went on view this month in a splendid pre-World War I living room and an adjoining gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, offer more than a few surprises for most of his admirers. The installation in the American Wing certainly proves that the most influential architect the United States has yet produced was also a genius at conceiving furnishings - especially in designs completed through the 1930's. Until now, most of the chairs, tables, desks, lighting fixtures, architectural elements and tablewares that he designed for houses, office buildings and a hotel have been known to the general public primarily through photographs. Now we are able to see originals, assembled so that it is possible to appreciate the many dynamic shapes, distinctive colors and strong textural surfaces that were the architect's trademarks.

title: Panamanian Says U.S.  Imperils Canal Accord
description: The President of Panama says serious problems threaten the 1978 Panama Canal treaties with the United States and could provide a focus for anti-American sentiment in his economically troubled country.

title: Dailey to Rejoin Bulls Monday
description: The Chicago Bulls announced late Saturday night that Quintin Dailey, their rookie guard, would rejoin the team Monday.

title: 'Generous' Vote Tally; Shows Holiday Spirit; Spirit
description: Saturday sessions of the Senate and the House of Representatives are none too popular with lawmakers who have other things to do with their time one week before Christmas.

title: 10 WINNERS AT THE ROBESON GALLERY
description: NEWARK ''CRAFTS: EMERGING ARTISTS,'' an exhibition of about 60 pieces in fiber, clay and metal by 10 artists, indicates that work with a strong personal identity can be produced at many levels of maturity,

title: HOMER FERGUSON, FORMER SENATOR FROM MICHIGAN AND AMBASSADOR
description: Homer Ferguson, an influential Republican voice on Capitol Hill when he served Michigan in the United States Senate from 1943 through 1954, died Friday at his home in Grosse Pointe, a suburb of Detroit. He was 94 years old.

title: DISCOUNTS OFFERED TO PUBLIC AGENCIES
description: EDISON NEED equipment to help run your public agency or non-profit organization, but can't afford to buy it? You probably can get what you require -and at sharply reduced cost, too -from the Federal Government's inexhaustible surplus-property warehouse here.

title: The Verdict On Abscam
description: When the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed that it had gone shopping for politicians in the Abscam affair two years ago, some critics charged that the agency had unfairly bought some who weren't really for sale.

title: Theater; FROM TRIVIAL DETAILS, A THEATRICAL OCCASION
description: The special skill that has bestowed so much warmth and animation on what is, after all, simply an exchange of letters in Helene Hanff's ''84 Charing Cross Road'' is nicely summarized by a contemptuous snap of Ellen Burstyn's fingers. Miss Burstyn snaps her fingers in New York. The snap is promptly heard by Joseph Maher, a second-hand bookseller in London. Mr. Maher doesn't know what he's heard or precisely where it's come from, but he knows the reproof is there and he knows it was meant for him. He looks over his shoulder and around and about, wondering if it will strike again. And we believe the whole business. We believe it and we laugh, which means that author, adapter, director and actors have all got us snugly locked in. But back to the buildup.

title: Brink's Trial Goes Next Door
description: Lawyers for Kathy Boudin argued unsuccessfully in June that their client, one of six defendants on trial in the 1981 Brink's robbery and murder of two policemen and a guard, could not get a fair trial in Rockland County. Last week, after reconsideration, a state appeals court agreed the lawyers were probably correct.

title: REGULATORY OFFICIAL'S UNUSUAL IDEAS VOICED IN FREE-WHEELING CLOSED SESSION
description: Frederic Andre, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, offered some unusual ideas at a free-wheeling closed commission meeting about the best way to proceed with trucking deregulation.

title: A GRANDE DAME RETURNS AS WHITE QUEEN
description: It is exceedingly rare for an actor or an actress to return to a role 50 years after first playing it, rarer still when the role calls for the character to fly across the stage. Such is the case with the ageless Eva Le Gallienne, who returns to Broadway this week, one month before her 84th birthday. She opens Thursday at the Virginia (formerly the ANTA) in ''Alice,'' a new version of her Civic Repertory Theater production of ''Alice in Wonderland.'' Miss Le Gallienne is recreating her role as the White Queen (Kate Burton is playing Alice), and is also re-staging the play, with John Strasberg as co-director. Sitting in a dressing room during a recent rehearsal, she said that the revival would be close to the original, except that, with a budget of $2 million, it will ''cost 2,000 times more.''

title: Downed Aircraft Found With 3 Aboard Dead
description: A medical transport helicopter that crashed while ferrying a critically ill heart patient was found today by searchers and all three people aboard were dead, the state police said.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Catering to All With Discounts

title: Q&A
description: Question:Next summer I plan to fly to Venice and want to go from there to Nice by surface transportation. Where can I get information about bus and train travel between the two cities? - U.D., Washington, D.C. Answer:A native of Venice who now makes her home in New York explains that in Italy the faster, express trains are called rapido and the slower, local ones, diretto. (Buses, which frequently go to places not on rail routes and which usually cost more than comparable train travel, are less popular with Italians.)

title: HEAD OF AN INDONESIAN REBELLION FACES HARD TIMES
description: In September, a former Indonesian Army officer emerged from the jungles of the Indonesian half of the island of New Guinea, where he began efforts 12 years ago to organize a guerrilla war of independence.

title: CASINO 'CANDOR' CASE PRESSED
description: TRENTON THE casino candor case moved a step closer to resolution last week. In April, Hugh M. Hefner, chairman of Playboy Enterprises, was denied a license to operate a hotel-casino in Atlantic City because two of the five members of the state's Casino Control Commission thought he had not been candid as a witness at the licensing hearing.

title: 'CAROL' LACKS MOMENTUM
description: STAMFORD THE Hartman Theater's ''A Christmas Carol'' is an imposing production. It has the look, the lighting, the effects and the feel, if not the flow, of a big-time musical, with 18 actors playing 67 roles.

title: A MASSIVE MURAL FOR A MICROCOSM
description: In the category of liabilities transformed into assets, consider the construction fence erected around the old Korvette's store in Herald Square. In about 18 months, the nine-story structure will be remodeled into what the New York Land Company, its redeveloper, has dubbed the city's first ''vertical shopping center,'' a microcosm of the city with shops on each floor distinctive to particular city neighborhoods.

title: FANTASTIC FUN
description: De Soto (the late car, not the man) discovers the Mississippi; a World War II German fighter plane buzzes the insideof the House of Lords; a commemorative stamp to honor heated shave cream is issued in the Blessings of American Life series; in a game of polo the steeds are World War I army tanks; at a zeppelin shoot Austro-Hungarians blast away with shotguns at those ships of the sky as if they were grouse.

title: BUYER'S CHOICE IN MULLICA HILL
description: MULLICA HILL TRUCK drivers barrel along Main Street (Route 45) with scarcely a look to the left or right, but antiquers stop. Lining both sides of the mile-long street in this Gloucester County country town are some two dozen antiques and crafts shops in old homes, barns and stores. They house about 70 antiques dealers, their premises ranging from the Grange Hall on the north to the lovely old Friends Meetinghouse and the Raccoon Valley General Store on the south.

title: Sentencing in Slaying of Girl
description: A man who shot and killed an 8-yearold girl when she burst into his apartment by mistake in a hide-andseek game has been sentenced to 160 hours of volunteer work. Steven Hiatt, 27 years old, had pleaded no contest to manslaughter in the shooting death of Wendy Watts. The volunteer work, ordered Monday by District Judge Michael Villano, was made a condition of four years of probation granted earlier to Mr. Hiatt.

title: Dissident Awaits Word On Departure in Seoul
description: South Korean officials have not told the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung when he might travel to the United States for medical treatment, an aide to the former presidential candidate said today.

title: Tanzania: A Dream Deferred
description: Leonard Levitt's revealing essay on foreign aid and the Tanzanian experience should be required reading for all Government officials (''Tanzania: A Dream Deferred,'' Nov. 14). As chairman of the Senate Foreign Operations Appropriations Subcommittee, and now as a United States delegate to the United Nations, I have often seen the best intended foreign-aid programs yield disappointing, if not tragic, results. The importance of creating wealth in a developing country, as opposed to redistributing the wealth that already exists, cannot be overemphasized. ROBERT W. KASTEN JR., United States Senate, Washington

title: ST. JOHN'S (9-0) BEATS PRINCETON
description: ''One thing you can't deny. This St. John's is a doggone good team and maybe the best St. John's team we've ever played.'' That was the reaction of the Princeton coach, Pete Carril, after his team gave the Redmen a good battle in the first half last night before undefeated St. John's broke away to beat the Tigers, 58-46, to the delight of a crowd of 6,048 in Alumni Hall at Jamaica, Queens.

title: St. Bart's Rebuttal
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK CATCHES UP WITH THE ART OF BERTRAND TAVERNIER
description: Stephen Harvey is the coordinator of special film projects at the Museum of Modern Art's Department of Film.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: North Stars 3, Canucks 3
description: Brian Bellows scored at 10:11 of the final period to give Minnesota the tie. Bellows, Minnesota's first choice over all in last year's amateur draft, stole the puck from the center Thomas Gradin and converted his rebound past the goaltender Richard Brodeur.

title: Elizabeth Friedgut and Russell Selman, Both Lawyers, Plan September Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Jack Friedgut have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Hamilton Friedgut, to Russell Bertram Selman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon D. Selman of Oceanside, L.I.

title: HUSSEIN DOESN'T NEED ARAFAT
description: In the discussion ensuing from President Reagan's Middle East peace proposal, much has been made of the supposed need for Yasir Arafat to grant his approval before King Hussein of Jordan may speak on behalf of the Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The underlying assumption is that otherwise the Palestinians will not accept the arrangements that might result from the Reagan proposal.

title: Sally Ann Biondo Wed To Travis Hammer Jr.
description: Sally Ann Biondo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Thomas Biondo of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Travis William Hammer Jr. of Marina del Rey, Calif., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hammer of Dallas. The Rev. Walter Taylor performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Miss Lynn and Cousins Take Pro Skating Titles
description: Janet Lynn of the United States and Robin Cousins of Britain, each scoring not less than 9.9 of a possible 10 points from nine judges, captured the women's and men's titles in the first International Professional Ice Skating Championships at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Sandra C. Phelan Marries a Lawyer
description: Sandra Christine Phelan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Phelan of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Dennis Julian Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Roberts of Teaneck, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the bridegroom's home in Montclair, Calif., by Superior Court Justice Stanley Golde of Alameda County.

title: Unmelted Americans
description: Researchers have known for years that the American melting pot is more of a cherished symbol than a demographic reality, but census data released last week make it seem even more of an illusion. The Government's ''State and Metropolitan Area Data Book'' for 1982 outlines a diverse society where people tend nonetheless to live with their own kind.

title: NINE-COUNTY GROUP ASKS BUDGET RELIEF
description: THE county has joined with eight other southern New York counties to lobby for financial relief from state-mandated programs. The effort is being coordinated by County Legislator Edward M. Gibbs and will focus on the increasing costs of Medicaid, education of the handicapped and operation of the court system.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Bird of a Different Feather

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
MEN IN THE RED SUITS
description: WHITE PLAINS THE boys and girls who perch on his knee don't know it, but Santa Claus is a 22-year-old college student. He has light brown hair, no trace of a paunch, and a preference for such topics of conversation as the commercialism of Christmas in a capitalist society.

title: SUFFOLK CLEARS ANOTHER HURDLE ON SEWER BONDS
description: AFTER all the maneuvering was over last week, the one thing that some Suffolk County lawmakers agreed on was that financing the Southwest Sewer District had become almost as controversial and complicated as the troubled project itself.

title: GIFTS FOR THE HOME ARE PRETTY...
description: GREENWICH THE show and sale at The Elements Gallery here through Jan. 8 takes as its theme ''A Country Christmas'' and offers a wide range of decorative and useful articles to give and enjoy in the home.

title: Free Glad to Come East
description: World B. Free, traded from the Golden State Warriors to the Cleveland Cavaliers on Wednesday, said today that he was glad to be back in the East because, he said, the fans out West do not appreciate good basketball.

title: MATTERS WORTH PONDERING INCLUDING STARDOM AND FLOPS
description: There follow 10 subjects for further thought in any consideration of the 1982 film year. They have nothing to do with the year's best films, which will be discussed next week, but have to do with some of the people, places, films and events that will henceforth be identified with the year that is now effectively over.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: GETTING UP Subway Graffiti in New York. By Craig Castleman. Illustrated. 191 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $15.

title: SNOWSHOE RABBIT IS A SPEEDY QUARRY
description: LONG after deer hunting and waterfowling is over, and through March 13 in some northern counties, a few dedicated New York State sportsmen are in the snow-deep woods in quest of the varying hare, or snowshoe rabbit.

title: DANCE: WIMMER TROUPE, MARITAL REMINISCENCES
description: Enough was never enough for Wimmer, Wimmer and Dancers, the company from Philadelphia that offered a program Thursday night in the Theater of the Riverside Church that was disturbing because of its brutal choreographic insistence.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS ARGENTINES WILL QUIT REGION
description: Argentina has promised Nicaragua that it will soon withdraw all its military advisers from Central America, including those now working with anti-Sandinist rebels based in Honduras, according to senior officials here.

title: GALLEON AHOY
description: Philadelphia has its Liberty Bell, San Francisco has its Golden Gate Bridge and St. Louis has its arch. But for years, Westbrook, Conn., languished without a promotional symbol.

title: David L. Minter Marries Jane Inglefield Lawyer
description: Jane Inglefield Lawyer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Tiffany Lawyer Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to David Luther Minter of Katonah, N.Y., son of Edwin Luther Minter of Gettysburg, Pa. The Rev. William Rhodes performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The Federal Reserve Board cut its discount rate to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent. The move was considered an effort by the Fed to help stimulate the long-awaited economic recovery, and as a reflection of concern about strains on the international financial structure.

title: JAPANESE SECURITY REQUIRES NO CHOICE BETWEEN EVILS
description: To the Editor:

title: Debra Lynn Silverman Weds Dr. Scott Kessler
description: Debra Lynn Silverman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney H. Silverman of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Scott Michael Kessler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Kessler of Hillsdale, N.J. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Middlebay Country Club in Oceanside, L.I.

title: Pamela Leary Becomes Bride of Banker
description: Pamela A. Leary, daughter of Joanna R. Leary of Bronxville, N.Y., and James F. Leary of Dallas, was married yesterday to Duncan Erling Goldie-Morrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith Goldie-Morrison of London and Bradden, England. The Rev. Samuel B. Matarazzo performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: JOSEPH T. KENNEALLY 3D TO MARRY LUCIE MEYER
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry H. Bard of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Bard's daughter, Lucie Wing Meyer, to Joseph Thomas Kenneally 3d, son of Mr. Kenneally Jr. and Patricia Steele Kenneally, both of Houston. A May wedding is planned.

title: WHEN ENOUGH IS ENOUGH
description: Recent works by several prominent designers indicate that a new nonchalance may be supplanting slick interiors. Some top professionals seem to be tending toward interiors that more closely resemble those done by amateurs. rchitects, decorators and interior designers are wont to say that, once they finish a residential interior, they assume their clients will make adjustments in order to personalize the place. Unfortunately, one has only to look at most designed interiors to see that this is, more often than not, virtually impossible. As a rule, every cubic inch has been so thoroughly accounted for, so precisely calculated as part of the whole that the inclusion or removal of the smallest object would set the whole scheme askew.

title: MOST COLLEGE FRESHMEN IN JERSEY FAIL MATH TEST
description: Most freshmen entering New Jersey public colleges fail basic algebra tests, and nearly half cannot solve simple math problems, according to a report to the State Board of Higher Education.

title: Tax Proposals Falter in Jersey
description: When push came to shove last week, Democratic leaders in the New Jersey Legislature lacked the muscle to pass either a sales tax increase or an increase in upper-bracket income taxes and decided to wait until tomorrow to seek a compromise.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: VISITING some of the many historic sites around the state at this time of year promises a glittering array of traditional treats, among them displays of Christmases past, tours of restored houses and villages, demonstrations of Colonial crafts and, for book devotees, an opportunity to stock up on historic publications often available only in the gift shops at these places.

title: MEDDLERS IN A DYING MAN'S DECISION
description: To the Editor:

title: WINTER IS NO TIME FOR HIBERNATION
description: tos at the Mountain Lakes Camp to the shoreline of Little Pine Lake. There he dipped the pail into the lapping waters, walked back to the fire and doused it.

title: HOW CITY REDUCES FORECLOSURE STOCK
description: AQUIET revolution in housing administration and urban policy o ccurred in New York City four years ago when the city's housing a gency took over the management of tax-foreclosed residential p roperty.

title: FROM INSPECTOR TO COMMISSIONER?
description: DEWITT TREDER, chief inspector of the Suffolk County Police, is a leading contender for appointment as Police Commissioner next April, when the term of Commissioner Donald J. Dilworth expires.

title: Sara J. Schechner To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Schechner of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Jane Schechner, to Joel Genuth, son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul M. Genuth of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: EXPECT THE UNEXPECTED
description: Years ago at the Manhattan Chess Club, if you were to assure one of the favorites in the yearly championship that his next-round opponent was no real threat, the question would be shot back, ''Does he know how to move the pieces?'' and - without waiting for a reply - ''Then I'm worried.''

title: Trying for the Top
description: ''The real culprit'' in a Warner Communications fraud case has yet to stand up, according to Federal prosecutor Nathaniel H. Ackerman.

title: SUBSIDIZING MASS TRANSIT
description: FARES on the various train and bus lines operated by NJ Transit have been going only in one direction of late - up -and they may rise again, or service may be shut down, unless the State Legislature comes to the rescue by appropriating to NJ Transit enough money to offset what it lost through a reduction in Federal assistance.

title: EVERGLADES INTERLUDE
description: MELVIN MENCHER is a professor of journalism at Columbia University.BY MELVIN MENCHER

title: THE LABOR DEPARTMENT REPLIES
description: To the Business Editor: William Winpisinger seems to hold the view that worker health and safety can only be measured in terms of inspections, citations and fines, and that employers must be bullied by big government into providing decent workplaces for their employees.

title: DOES FAMILIARITY BREED ACCEPTANCE?
description: Television's ability to excite flamboyant behavior is by now a given; observers have remarked on how relatively sane individuals and crowds respond with bizarre antics to the sparkle of a lens. But at the same time that such performances indulge the ego, they are likely to result in at least a temporary setback for any cause that the performers think they are championing.

title: 18 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 18 food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code. The department also named one restaurant that was allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and four that were closed after failing to do so.

title: Charles Buttimer, 73; Led Christian Brothers
description: Brother Charles Henry Buttimer, 73 years old, who became the first non-French leader of the Christian Brothers since the religious order was formed in 1680, died of a stroke Wednesday in South Kingstown after being stricken at his home here.

title: Shopping for Coaches
description: The Arizona Wranglers of the United States Football League are expected to sign Coach Jim Sweeney of Fresno State as their first head coach early this week. Brad Liebman, a co-owner of the Wranglers, said that either Sweeney or Mike White of the University of Illinois would be picked for the position, but White said Friday that he preferred to fulfill his commitment to Illinois. Sweeney coached Fresno State yesterday in the California Bowl against Bowling Green.

title: New York Times Magazine December 19, 1982
description: William Safire 18 On Language Vox of Pop Sixpack Russell Baker 28 Sunday Observer Bird of a Different Feather P.S. Wood 30 Iceboating On a winter's day, the exhilaration of flying on ice. Alan Cowell 38 Africa's Angry Young Men Madeleine G. Kalb 42 The U.N.'s Embattled Peacekeeper After years of overseeing peacekeeping operations, Brian Urquhart is striving to preserve his mission - and the U.N.'s. Eugene Linden 77 Endangered Chimps in the Lab While many scientists believe chimpanzees can communicate in human language, the fact that others disagree may mean the chimps' demise.

title: ABSENCE OF BLACKS ON JURY IS UPHELD
description: A sharply divided Court of Appeals has ruled that a black defendant could not contend that he had been denied a fair trial because the prosecution in the case had excluded all black and Hispanic people from the jury that convicted him.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Trade Hopes Dim

title: U.S. SUPPORTS SENIORITY SYSTEM IN BOSTON BIAS SUIT
description: Taking a position in a discrimination suit in Boston, the Reagan Administration says ''last-hired, firstfired'' seniority systems should not be scrapped to protect members of racial minorities from layoffs.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
COMPETITION USUALLY PRODUCES WINNING DESIGNS
description: ompetition is the essence of Olympic Games and this may be the ultimate irony in the current uproar regarding the designs of the 1984 Olympic coins: Critics say that the United States Treasury could have done far better if it had staged a special competition and invited outside artists to enter designs.

title:
GARDENING;
MATERIALS FOR HOLIDAY DECORATION
description: IN an age of chrome and plastic, it is refreshing to visit Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia, where the holiday decorations are made from the same natural materials that would have been used during the colonial period.

title: WHAT'S DOING ON HAWAII'S NEIGHBOR ISLANDS
description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, the author of ''Tin Roofs and Palm Trees: A Report on the New South Seas'' (University of Washington Press), lives in Hawaii.

title: MARCONI HAILED ON 80TH ANNIVERSARY OF RADIO MESSAGE
description: To the Government in Rome, which had spent the better part of three millenniums trying to cope with a peninsula of individualists, Guglielmo Marconi seemed especially presumptuous.

title: JERUSALEM'S SEPARATE WORLD
description: WILLIAM E. FARRELL is chief of the Cairo bureau of The Times.

title: No Headline
description: Headliners Purely Coincidental?

title: Raiders Defeat Rams by 37-31
description: Marcus Allen, who had run for many of his 46 touchdowns for the University of Southern California in the Los Angeles Coliseum, scored three more in that stadium today. These, however, were scored on behalf of the Los Angeles Raiders, and the last of them, an 11-yard run with 29 seconds left, beat the Los Angeles Rams, 37-31.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
SOLID STUDENT DOES BEST IN PRIVATE SCHOOL
description: PEOPLE sometimes ask out of a simple desire to understand and sometimes to dispute. Why should a family of modest financial circumstances sacrifice to send children to private school? Is it really worth it?

title: PLAYBOY APPEALS DENIAL OF JERSEY CASINO LICENSE
description: Hugh M. Hefner and his company, Playboy Enterprises, have charged in a court appeal that they were the victims of unequal treatment when New Jersey's Casino Control Commission denied them a casino license earlier this year.

title: WOMEN ALONE HAVE HOLIDAY NETWORK
description: NEW HAVEN THE four children of a divorced couple were spending Thanksgiving with their father last year. This left their mother, who does not have a car or a telephone, with the prospect of being alone for the holiday. She learned about a service in New Haven called Holiday Network, and through it, she enjoyed Thanksgiving with a group of women, who otherwise also would have been alone that day.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The debut recital in Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night was one of those rare events that offered a glimpse at a young artist who, with time, may well become one of our premiere cellists. The 17-year-old cellist Ofra Harnoy, a winner of the 1982 Concert Artists Guild Award, not only played like a mature artist, she seemed born to the instrument. The music was not just dutifully learned and dutifully performed; it was not an ''inspiration'' to the player or a focus for her attention. Rather, the music seemed to sing within her as it was played, and was effortlessly translated into instrumental gestures, free of artifice.

title: Jobless Rate Up in All States
description: Unemployment in each of the 50 states and the District of Columbia was higher in October than in the same month in 1981, the Labor Department has reported. It was the first time in the current recession that the year-to-year monthly employment comparisons showed no state escaping rising unemployment.

title: No Headline
description: Bullets Defeat 76ers

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
THE RHYTHM OF SUBURBAN FOLKWAYS
description: IHAVE noticed something here in the suburbs that makes me feel more joined to all life. I like to call this the Finite Life Phenomenon. It is a cycle, a rising and falling rhythm that crops up in diverse folkways of suburban life. We see it here as crowds and no crowds on the tennis court, and string quartets forming and falling apart. I suppose it is just the rise and fall of one fad or another, but I like to think about meanings.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S INTERVIEW ON RADIO AFTER WEEKLY ADDRESS
description: Following are excerpts from questions and answers from President Reagan's radio interview after his weekly address in Washington yesterday, as transcribed by The New York Times and the White House: Action on Jobs Bill

title: Big Glass Shootout
description: Car owners in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn were distraught. Night after night someone was shooting out the windows of parked cars -block after block, more than a thousand cars hit in a few months.

title: Auburn Victor By 33-26
description: Randy Campbell, normally the quarterback of a ground-oriented wishbone offense, set up three touchdowns and a field goal with the best passing performance of his career tonight, leading Auburn to a 33-26 victory over Boston College in the 37th Tangerine Bowl.

title: LEFT IN WILDS, MAN PENNED DYING RECORD
description: Tales of death and despair in the frozen north are not new in Alaskan folklore, but seldom have men recorded their own fatal adventure as graphically as Carl McCunn, a photographer of wildlife.

title: 'RUDOLPH' WRITER IS CAPTIVE OF HIT SONG
description: ALMOST everyone looks forward to the holiday season. Everyone but Johnny Marks. In 1949, Mr. Marks sat down at his piano and began tapping out the notes to a song, which, 33 years later, has sold 150 million records and has become as synonymous with Christmas as holly and mistletoe. The song, of course, is ''Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer,'' and Mr. Marks is getting a little tired of it.

title: Rumania
description: To the Editor: ''Moldavian Masterpieces'' (Travel, Nov. 21) brought back memories of our own trip to Northern Rumania last fall. Like R.W. Apple Jr., we found the medieval frescoes in the monasteries exquisite, but the region has much else of interest and merits a longer visit than Mr. Apple's.

title: HOUSE CAN HELP AGED RAISE CASH
description: ELDERLY homeowners have for several years been hearing reports of a n ew type of transaction in which they could use the equity in their h omes to get cash without having to actually sell their houses and m ove. The idea is favored by the Reagan Administration and it c ontinues to be a subject of considerable discussion.

title: REGULATING THE BED AND BREAKFASTS
description: IF you want to make a room or two in your home available for bed a nd breakfast, are you (a) taking in boarders, (b) running a rooming h ouse or (c) conducting a home occupation? If none of the above c learly covers what you are doing, are you then (d) violating the l aw?

title: 44 ON 50
description: The six children of Mary Louise and Ogden Rogers Reid, former president and editor of The New York Herald Tribune, used to romp through the woods and fields of their Ophir Hill estate in Purchase, N.Y. But those days are gone now, according to Mrs. Reid, so the family has sold 50 of it 65 acres for development by the Schulman Realty Group of White Plains.

title: Moves by Households Said to Be Declininge
description: The percentage of American households changing residences continued to decline in 1980, the Census Bureau said in a report compiled for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Barbara Eileen Cohen Marries Andrew M. Hutter
description: Barbara Eileen Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay J. Cohen of Bethesda, Md., was married last night to Andrew Mark Hutter, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert V.P. Hutter of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Hillel Klavan performed the ceremony at Ohev Shalom Talmud Torah Congregation in Washington.

title: American Academy Elects 5 to Its Board
description: Five new members have been elected to the board of trustees of the 77-year-old American Academy in Rome, a residential community of American artists and scholars.

title: IN REVENUE SHARING, CITIES PREFER THE OLD FEDERALISM
description: As White House meetings dragged on about the 1984 budget President Reagan will submit to Congress next month, rumors ran through the capital last week about proposals to slash programs benefiting cities, such as community development block grants and urban development action grants.

title: YOUNG OFFENDERS IN CAROLINA WORK TO REPAY THEIR VICTIMS
description: Juvenile offenders in Moore County plow fields and chop wood to pay back thousands of dollars to their victims, but few of the recipients ever learn the source of the money.

title: Mary Reining Is Married
description: Mary Reining, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Reining of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday in New Rochelle, N.Y., to Paul Edward Winters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Winters of Lakeville, Conn. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed in the chapel of the College of New Rochelle by the Rev. Sean Cooney, the school's chaplain. The bride is manager of placement for corporate operations with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in New York, where her husband is head of a furniture marketing concern.

title: BIGGER MOUSETRAPS AND THORNY ETHICAL ISSUES
description: Two white mice crouched on a blue cloth having their pictures taken. They appeared healthy and normal, with one difference: One was about twice the other's size.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: FOSTER HOMES FOR THE ELDERLY
description: THERE is a large and growing group of aging Americans who are as helpless as children and as lonely as orphans. They are not ill enough to be hospitalized or well enough to care for themselves.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SQUID & SPIDER A Look at the Animal Kingdom. Written and illustrated by Guy Billout. Unpaged. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall. $10.95. (Ages 8 and Up)

title: BACKGROUND NOISE ON OVERT COVERT C.I.A. PLOT
description: In the 1950's and 1960's, the Central Intelligence Agency had license to do pretty much what it pleased. Generally, the White House didn't want to know the details of the agency's covert paramilitary and political action operations, the better to preserve the President's ''deniability''; Congress didn't really care; and rigorous secrecy kept the public in the dark.

title: AUTO TESTS CONTINUE TO CONFUSE MOTORISTS
description: THE upcoming mandatory auto inspection program is confusing so many state residents that since mid-November at least 500 people a day have been calling a toll-free number to ask questions about it.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ORGANIZATIONAL PSYCHOLOGY;
THE LOPSIDED DUAL-CAREER
description: In the trade, they are called dual career ladders. Companies, mostly in industries that depend heavily on scientific research, set up two parallel career paths - one for managers, the other for scientists and technicians. In theory, salaries and status are equal at equivalent levels on the two ladders, even as high as the top rungs.

title: POLISH PARLIAMENT ADOPTS LEGISLATION ON MARTIAL LAW
description: The Polish Parliament approved legislation today that gave the Government the right to suspend - or reimpose - martial law. The action had the effect of tightening the grip of military rule.

title: WINDOW ON A RICH HERITAGE
description: SUSAN BILLINGTON is a Rhodes scholar at Oxford University.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Shaw, Student, Wed
description: Susan Barnes Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Shaw of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Dwight Delmar Hatcher, son of Mrs. Elna Hatcher of Toledo, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Henry Powers at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly.

title: IMPORTS GAIN IN AMERICAN WINE MARKET
description: American consumers, who began to abandon French wines in the mid-1970's because of sharply rising prices, are rushing back to them as part of an imported-wine resurgence in this country. Statistics for the first nine months of 1982 show that imports from France led a revival of the import market, while domestic wines were falling out of favor.

title: Cigarette Smoking Declines
description: Cigarette smoking per person is continuing a long decline and is at its lowest level since 1957, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The department reported that the preliminary average for 1982 was 3,778 cigarettes, fewer than 189 packages of 20 each. Last year Americans smoked an average of 3,853 cigarettes, or nearly 193 packages per person.

title: Lebanon Is Hard to Leave
description: Since nothing peaceful comes easy in the Middle East, even the relatively simple first stage in removing foreign forces from Lebanon is mired in multiple troubles. The complications were apparent last week as the United States launched a fresh effort to get Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces to withdraw. One American envoy, Morris Draper, handed Lebanese President Amin Gemayel a new plan to start the withdrawal process while another, Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's personal representative, met with Israeli leaders. Mr. Habib delivered a letter from Mr. Reagan to Prime Minister Menachem Begin that was reported to have urged faster action. The President made the same point in a radio interview yesterday.

title: WE THOUGHT WE'D MOVE TO THE CITY, BUT THEN......
description: FIVE years ago, my husband and I elected not to buy a cooperative apartment in Manhattan. Today, that suite of rooms has quadrupled its purchase price. Many factors entered into that judgment, which, as we think back, was financially a poor one.

title: NORMAN WAS NOT ORDINARY
description: MAILER A Biography. By Hilary Mills. Illustrated. 477 pp. New York: Empire Books/Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: Vote on Drinking Age
description: TRENTON (AP) - Following is how members of the State Assembly voted last week to raise the state's legal drinking age from 19 to 21. A ''yes'' vote indicates approval of changing the age from 19 to 21. REPUBLICANS - YES (26)

title: ABSCAM TAPE SHOWS ABORTED PAYOFF ATTEMPT
description: In the last scheduled trial stemming from the Abscam investigation, jurors in Federal District Court in Brooklyn have seen a videotape of a meeting in which undercover agents were prepared to pay a Congressman a $50,000 bribe.

title: Metaphysics
description: To the Editor:

title: WINGS RALLY AND TIE RANGERS
description: The Rangers took a two-goal lead early in the third period tonight but yielded a short-handed goal shortly afterward and settled for a 3-3 deadlock with the Detroit Red Wings.

title: A Family's Victory
description: Ever since human rights activist Edward Lozansky left the Soviet Union, he has had to live without the two women in his life - his wife and daughter remained behind. His six-year struggle to have Tatyanya Lozansky and the couple's 11-year-old daughter Tanya released came to an end last week.

title: NATURE PRESERVE AND MORMONS BATTLE OVER TEMPLE
description: The Grove Heritage Association and the Mormon Church are headed for court over whether the lights of a proposed temple should shine on a nature preserve.

title: ZVicki Martin Plans to Wed Mitchell Merber Next Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Martin of Yonkers have made known the engagement of their daughter, Vicki Martin, to Mitchell Merber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fill Merber of Woodmere, L.I. The wedding is planned for next autumn.

title: SEVEN PRESIDENTS AND BERNARD MERGENDEILER
description: FEIFFER Jules Feiffer's America From Eisenhower to Reagan. Edited by Steven Heller. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $25. Paper, $12.95.

title: Unharvested Cabbage And the Needy
description: ''Cabbage Left Unharvested,'' proclaimed a recent headline in the Long Island Weekly section. To a nonfarmer, such a situation came as something of a shock.

title: THE LIMITS OF URBAN GROWTH
description: The Limits of Urban Growth Thank you, Paul Goldberger, for adding to the mounting literature on the alarming growth of midtown Manhattan (''The Limits of Urban Growth,'' Nov. 14).

title: Bull Market On Words
description: William Safire's excellent description of the evolution of certain stock-market jargon demonstrates the general need to use words with precise definitions when dealing with business and financial matters (''Bull Market in Words,'' On Language, Nov. 14). Changes in definitions have wide-ranging public-policy implications, at times not fully foreseen by legislative bodies initiating such revisions.

title: Con Ed's View
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT INVITES DEAL IN CONGRESS ON BILLS FOR JOBS
description: President Reagan offered a clear invitation to compromise with his Congressional opponents today, even as he vowed to veto any stopgap spending bill that carried a billion-dollar job program that he has been fighting.

title: HOW POOR ARE THE ELDERLY?
description: WASHINGTON PROPOSALS to cut back Social Security and Medicare benefits have become an explosive political issue, testing the nation's commitment to elderly citizens. But how much would the elderly actually be hurt by such changes?

title: COLLEGE 'COPY MILLS' GRIND QUICKLY, SO PUBLISHERS SUE
description: The Association of American Publishers had warned that it planned to sue a major university for copyright infringement. Nevertheless, last week's lawsuit against New York University, 10 of its faculty members and an off-campus copy center surprised and angered educators.

title: Brooklyn Girl Sets National 100 Record
description: Angela Williams is attending her third high school in three years, but her running remains unaffected by the switches. At the 29th Annual Bishop Loughlin Games in the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday, the Brooklyn sprinter set another national schoolgirl record with a time of 10.9 seconds for the 100-yard dash.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
LOOKING FOR EXCELLENCE-AND FINDING IT
description: IUSED to ask my students if they possessed anything - anything at a ll - that was the best of whatever it was, something truly e xcellent.

title: CONGREGATION LOOKS AT PAST FOR CHRISTMAS
description: A Christmas drama blending the narrative of the birth of Jesus with the holiday rituals of a medieval English manor will mark the beginning of the holiday week at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church tonight.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FRATERNITIES AT ISSUE
description: IN the middle of a September school day, a store owner called to warn Peter Lynch, principal of Baldwin Senior High School. About 40 students from Freeport were walking down Grand Avenue toward a group of Baldwin students. Many of the youngsters were fraternity members, and, Dr. Lynch agreed, it looked like trouble.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
NO CURE FOR THE HOLIDAY OPTIMIST
description: AN incurable optimist, I believe everything I read whenever I am in sore need of a quick solution to a money problem. At this gift-giving time of year, my income and my outgo do not come out even. Therefore, magazine articles such as ''110 Gifts You Can Make for That Special Someone for Under $5'' or ''Gifts That Look Like a Million for a Minimum'' or ''Generous Portions of Yourself From Your Kitchen'' speak to me. I see myself deftly tossing together with little or no time, effort, talent or money, treasures that will bring gasps of incredulity from the recipients.

title: Two Cameras, Two Cities
description: To walk out of the movies and into the evening dark is to make a painless transition between shadow and substance. But walk into daylight, and reality, even when it is pleasant, is a momentary cruelty.

title: RISE IN TOLLS AND FARE PROPOSED TO PORT AUTHORITY
description: A panel appointed last spring by Governor Carey and Governor Kean has recommended in its final report that improvements to bridges, roads and rail lines in the Port Authority district be financed through higher bridge and tunnel tolls, a tripling of the PATH fare and the sale of the World Trade Center.

title: 97th Congress Climbs Toward The Bottom Line
description: ''Father in Heaven,'' intoned the Senate chaplain, the Rev. Richard C. Halverson, ''the senators are very weary in body and mind.''

title: Abductors Are Silent As Guatemala Balks
description: Kidnappers holding the daughter of the Honduran President under threat of death remained silent today after the Guatemalan Government refused to negotiate the terms of her release.

title: COUNSELOR DETAILS ADVANTAGES OF GIVING JOBS TO HANDICAPPED
description: Paul G. Hearne, the executive director of J.O.B., has a distinctly pragmatic sales pitch for persuading employers to hire the disabled. ''Disabled people are more productive, more motivated, less tardy,'' he said. ''Plus there are tax advantages for employers.''

title: INDIA
description: To The Editor: I would like to add a note to the information given to Edwin B. Brooks in the Letters column. It is true that the ''first-class trip from Cochin by ferry ...to Trivandrum,'' as outlined by Michael T. Kaufman in ''Two Passages to India'' (Travel, Sept. 26), does not exist.

title: Short-Term Psychotherapy
description: As an enthusiastic advocate of short-term dynamic psychotherapy, I was delighted by Dava Sobel's article ''A New and Controversial Short-Term Psychotherapy'' (Nov. 21). Anyone who has watched Habib Davanloo's videotapes of therapy and follow-up interviews cannot fail to be impressed that significant changes have taken place as a result of the interaction between therapist and patient.

title: MRS. LLYOD ROUTS MISS AUSTIN
description: With stunning ease, Chris Evert Lloyd routed Tracy Austin, 6-0, 6-0, today and set up a showdown with Martina Navratilova Sunday night for the Toyota women's tennis championship.

title: ...OR STYLISH AND WITTY
description: FARMINGTON FOR some time now it has been evident that what are usually termed crafts have taken on a broader and richer meaning. Those who take the word to mean ugly but honest are in for some surprises at the annual ''Arts In Season'' exhibition/sale at the Art Guild in Farmington.

title:
OPINION;
ATTENTION SHOULD BE PAID
description: I'VE just returned from visiting my mother, who is living in a nursing home. After a year and a half, I'm still not used to it. My first impulse each time I visit is to gather her up, run for the door and take her home with me.

title: NICARAGUA REMOVING ITS AMBASSADOR TO U.S.
description: Nicaragua said today that it was removing its Ambassador to the United States, Francisco Fiallos, who recently called for ''dramatic changes'' in the policies of the Sandinist Government.

title: Briefing in the Twilight Zone
description: Reporters may be a swearing lot, but few would dare take an oath not to share information with their editors. Certainly none of those who attended super secret Pentagon briefing on Soviet strength last week did so.

title: TAX STUDIED ON WORKERS COMMUTING TO CONNECTICUT
description: A commuter tax on residents of New York, Massachusetts and Rhode Island who work in Connecticut is being seriously considered by state officials as Gov. William A. O'Neill searches for additional revenue to solve the state's fiscal problems.

title: SIX BACH CONCERTOS OFFERED AT PURCHASE
description: ALBERT SCHWEITZER called them ''the purest products of Bach's polyphonic style.'' Herbert Weinstock says they ''exhibit Bach as a tireless experimentalist, constantly trying new effects, testing the color of various instrumental combinations and indulging his own concepts of form.''

title: No Headline
description: PEETERS AND BRUINS DEFEAT KINGS BY 4-0

title: On Refinancing
description: Question: I have a mortgage with Chase Manhattan Bank at 15 1/4 percent. Could I get a new mortgage at a lower rate - say, 13 percent? Could I do this without the aid of a lawyer? How much would my savings between the two interest rates be? ... J.A., Brooklyn. Answer: A Chase spokesman said that if your credit rating and financial position is as good as when you first applied for a mortgage, you could refinance at 13 1/2 for a conventional 30-year mortgage. There is no requirement that you have a lawyer. ''In general,'' she added, ''we would not encourage the customer to refinance as long as the savings is less than three percentage points.''

title: Linda Nass Wed To Dr. Brian Tell
description: Linda Rachel Nass, daughter of Edna Kadin Nass of New York and the late Samuel Nass, was married yesterday at the Harmonie Club to Dr. Brian Lloyd Tell, son of Frieda Tell of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Lake Worth, Fla., and the late Dr. Meyer Tell. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony.

title: CRIME
description: In the seven years or so since "Fletch" first appeared, Gregory Mcdonald has won a great deal of acclaim - two Edgars, lots of sales, enthusiastic reviews all over the place. Obviously Mr. Mcdonald touched osme kind of nerve with his mod, irreverent, truth-seeking Fletch, he of the courtly speech, icy intelligence and wry humor. So it is always good news when a new Fletch mystery has arrived, and here is FLETCH'S MOXIE (Warner, paper, $2.95).

title: DEMAND RISES FOR AID AT HOLIDAY
description: WHITE PLAINS THE 44-year-old Tarrytown man, a father of four who spends a lot of time waiting in an unemployment line, took a puff on his pipe and shook his head when asked whether he would be embarrassed to stand in line with his children to ask Santa Claus for a personal gift.

title: Indian Borrowing
description: A group of American Indians, saying they were ''cynical and wary of Federal efforts toward reservation development, especially since resources such as coal and oil were ripped off by shrewd corporate types,'' turned last April to Japanese industrialists for help.

title: AFRICA'S ANGRY YOUNG MEN
description: Stephen Peter, a young Ugandan, left the chaos of his homeland and came to Kenya to be educated. Not long ago, he qualified as a printer and proudly displayed his certificate to friends. Recently, bad news came: Since his student days were over, he would no longer be allowed to stay in Kenya, where there is some chance of work; he would have to return to Uganda, where there is none.

title: No Headline
description: MINNEAPOLIS CRIME WATCH PROGRAM CENTERS ON 8

title: PROPOSALS' TARGET IS CIGARETTE FIRES
description: In the face of protests from the tobacco industry, Congress and a growing number of state legislatures are considering requiring cigarettes that would not burn hot enough or long enough to ignite bedding and upholstery.

title: COMPOSERS STUDY REALMS BEYOND THE 12-TONE SCALE
description: The common 12-tone piano scale is more than just an alphabet of musical sounds. It has for some three centuries served as our culture's ''tuning,'' a presentation, in barest outline, of the tensions, consonances and possibilities of musical expression. Just as a five-note scale used in Java, a 22-note scale used in Indian music, and a 17-note scale in some Arabic music, serve distinct musical universes, so has our 12-toned ''equal-tempered scale.'' That tuning came to maturity just as the familiar language of ''tonality'' was developing, offering flexibility, variety and coherence for the dramatic musical narratives that began to be written during the Baroque period.

title: TYLENOL INQUIRIES CENTER ON COUPLE
description: In the 11 weeks since seven residents of the Chicago area died of cyanide poisoning, investigators have picked through a haystack of possibilities and negated one lead after another.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: BUDGET cutbacks are forcing the Bureau of Air Quality Management and Surveillance, part of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, to remove half the 100 air-quality monitors it had around the state.

title: PREGNANT WOMEN USE FOSTER HOMES
description: FAMILY SERVICES of Westchester, a nonprofit private agency based in White Plains, is trying to find temporary shelter for pregnant teenagers and women in their early 20's. According to the agency, a number of unmarried pregnant women are forced to leave their homes to avoid conflict with their parents or their male friends. So far, agency workers have placed a dozen such women in foster homes; now they are making a concerted effort to find more people willing to take in a boarder who is expecting a baby.

title: AMERICA WITH A LITTLE ENGLISH ON IT
description: THE AMERICAN CONDITION By Edmund Fawcett and Tony Thomas. 486 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: IRAN IS SAID TO GET NORTH KOREA ARMS
description: North Korea has become the leading supplier of arms to Iran in an arrangement that has helped Iran finance its continuing war with Iraq, according to a high-ranking American defense official.

title:
GARDENING;
MATERIALS FOR HOLIDAY DECORATION
description: IN an age of chrome and plastic, it is refreshing to visit Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia, where the holiday decorations are made from the same natural materials that would have been used during the colonial period.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The Mexican Senate has shelved a bill that would have imposed strict censorship on news outlets and silenced all nonofficial reports on governmental activities.

title: SIMSBURY QUESTIONS DESTRUCTION OF CONVENT
description: SIMSBURY TO some observers, the overnight demolition of the convent of St. Mary's Catholic Church here last week seemed slightly out of character in a state as dedicated to historical tradition as Connecticut.

title: 'A CHRISTMAS CAROL' SINGS WITH JOY
description: PORT JEFFERSON CHEERS for Theater Three's ''A Christmas Carol.'' This isn't one of those semi-dramatized, semi-narrated patchworks that so many theater owners drag out at this time of the year. In her program notes, Peg Murray, the director, all too modestly refers to it as a '' 'singing' or concert production.''

title: Lawn-Chair Pilot Faces $4,000 in Fines
description: Larry Walters, the lawn-chair pilot who catapulted to fame when balloons lifted his contraption 16,000 feet into the sky, faces $4,000 in fines for violations cited by the Federal Aviation Adminstration.

title: ENDANGERED CHIMPS IN THE LAB
description: Eugene Linden, the author of ''Apes, Men and Language,'' is currently at work on his third book on the subject. By Eugene Linden A technician wearing protective clothing unlocks the double metal doors separating the biohazard area -or ''hot unit'' - from the rest of the chimpanzee colony. He walks up to one of the aluminum cages suspended above the floor. Inside the cage, a big adult male chimp looks up inquiringly but, recognizing the intruder, does not try to threaten him in the characteristic way. The technician waves hello to the chimp and then makes a sign, drawing a finger down the center of his forehead. The chimp responds with a quick series of signs and comes to the bars. The technician tickles him and says, ''It's time for your shot.'' The chimp turns obligingly and receives a tranquilizing injection.

title: NEW TAX BREAKS FOR HYBRID COMPANIES
description: called Subchapter S corporations, permitting them s pecial tax benefits. But several recent changes in the tax laws havem ade this tax vehicle attractive as well for owners of cash-rich c ompanies.

title: 5 U.S. 'RANCHERS FOR PEACE' FASCINATE RUSSIANS
description: Five ranchers in plaid shirts, silver-buckled belts and down vests arrived here eight days ago from the American West to campaign for a freeze on nuclear weapons. They have made for a colorful contrast with the officials of the Soviet Committee for the Defense of Peace who have been their counterparts in discussions.

title: SHOW LOOKS AT TEN CULTURES
description: CROSS RIVER NARDIN Fine Arts, which recently relocated here from Manhattan, has begun an ambitious and varied program of exhibitions ranging from primitive to Far Eastern art and including categories as disparate as Hudson River School landscape painting and contemporary sculpture.

title: The House Cites Mrs. Gorsuch
description: When the cogwheels of government fail to mesh, sparks sometimes fly -especially when access to sensitive information is at stake. In a test of constitutional powers fed by widespread dissatisfaction with the Environmental Protection Agency, the House of Representatives last week voted with bipartisan resolve to hold Anne M. Gorsuch, the agency's administrator, in contempt of Congress. It was the first such charge against a Cabinet-level official.

title: Quake Shatters Yemeni Region
description: Mountain crags trembled and toppled last week in Yemen as the small Arab nation convulsed in an earthquake that may have left more than 3,000 dead and 400,000 homeless.

title: YULETIDE FAVORITE
description: It was Silvino Trompetto, the ''Tromps'' of legend, then maitre chef des cuisines of London's Savoy Hotel and tutor to entire generations of English chefs, who introduced me to Christmas pudding several years ago. One day in late November we were sitting in his cubbyhole of an office, which looked out over vast banks of ovens in the Savoy kitchens, drinking champagne -he always drank champagne - when the conversation turned to Christmas observances.

title: OF BRANCUSI, MONDRIAN AND PARIS IN THE 30's
description: Sidney Janis, the art dealer and collector, is writing his memoirs, from which this article has been excerpted. The exhibition ''Brancusi + Mondrian'' is at the Janis Gallery through Dec. 31.

title: STATES SEEKS TO CURB RISE IN CHILD ABUSE
description: WITH the abuse or neglect of children by parents on the rise as a result of the stress brought on by economic hardship, state officials and legislators are taking a new look at the delicate balance needed to protect children while keeping families intact.

title: HELP ON HOUSING
description: Like everyone else in New York, officials of Rockefeller University know how tough it is to compete for scarce rental housing in Manhattan. Unlike everyone else, however, they were able to take a giant step toward solving the problem for their staff.

title: AT AQABA, SUNTANS AND BORDER DISPUTE
description: Egyptian Border - Despite a sharp desert wind, Scandinavian tourists were sunning themselves on this disputed stretch of Gulf of Aqaba beach front, which has come to symbolize the strains in the Egyptian-Israeli peace efforts.

title: NATALIA MAKAROVA HURT IN AN ACCIDENT ON STAGE
description: Natalia Makarova, the Russian-born ballet star, was injured in an accident tonight during a performance at the Opera House of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: WENDY JO KISLIK BECOMES ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kislik of New York and Waccabuc, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Jo Kislik, to Dr. Peter David Blanck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Blanck of Roslyn, L.I. A June wedding is planned New York.

title: Susan Brundage Becomes the Bride Of E.C. Thorp Jr.
description: Susan Lounsbury Brundage, director of the Leo Castelli Gallery in New York and curator of the Paine Webber Art Collection, was married yesterday to Edward Cleland Thorp Jr., owner and director of the Edward Thorp Gallery in New York. The Rev. Charles Temple performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner).

title: THE LIMITS OF URBAN GROWTH
description: Paul Goldberger fails to visualize the future of the modern city. It is not, as he suggests, increasingly bulky buildings, built on streets which are ever more crowded and shaded.

title: C.P. Murray, a Physician, Is Wed to Karen Ann Slote
description: Karen Ann Slote, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Slote of Tenafly, N.J., and Goshen, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Clifford Paul Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Murray of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Avraham Soltes performed the ceremony at the Engineers Country Club in Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

title: PORTRAITS OF HOMES WIN POPULARITY
description: and-ink drawing of their 60-year-old frame house this Christmas, capturing its dramatic setting directly on the ocean front in Madison. The picture is to be hung in Mr. Risbridger's office.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ORGANIZATIONAL PSYCHOLOGY;
KILLING RUMORS BEFORE THEY KILL A COMPANY
description: Today's tough times have given new importance to the old corporate problem of rumors, which proliferate when uncertainty about the future of a troubled company trickles down to workers. Industrial psychologists have found that rumors, especially when they involve job security, can be dangerously disruptive to employees as well as to a company.

title: REPORT TO JOBS MONDAY, U.S. WORKERS ORDERED
description: Federal workers are on orders to report for work Monday even though Congress failed to meet a deadline for providing funds needed to keep the Government running.

title: DIVERSITY OF MUSICAL FARE IS OFFERED FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: THE wealth of good Christmas music that materializes in New Jersey every December is no less inviting in its diversity this year. Renaissance motets and Baroque cantatas and oratorios are being performed, along with 20th-century carols, including modern arrangements from many nations and cultures.

title: THEATER: A COMEDY, 'FRIENDS TOO NUMEROUS'
description: The turgid situation that envelops Ross Bernard in ''Friends Too Numerous to Mention,'' the new play by Neil Cohen and Joel Cohen (no relation) at the Jewish Repertory Theater, has him trying to escape a rap for financial misdeeds at his New Jersey theater. What could be tragedy, the ''death-of-a-theater-owner'' sort of thing, has been made into high comedy with sharp insights into human behavior abetted by good, snappy lines, a fast-moving production and a cast that throws itself joyously into the action.

title: A BUSY CATERER GIVES HERSELF A CHRISTMAS EVE PARTY
description: WHAT does a professional party-giver and caterer do on Christmas Eve, that most special of family-oriented days? If you have a hidden cache of surplus energy, boundless enthusiasm, and your name happens to be Martha Stewart, chances are you'll be having a party.

title: More on Flat Tax
description: To the Business Editor: As an attorney who works with Pennsylvania's flat personal income tax on a daily basis, I wish to comment on ''Flat Tax for Fat Cats'' (Nov.27), William Nordhaus' rather negative view of implementing such a tax on the Federal level.

title: OPEC SEEKS TO SETTLE A DISPUTE ON OUTPUT CEILINGS
description: Officials of the 13 OPEC countries, in an effort to avoid a possible price war or an open split in the organization, moved today to settle a dispute over oil production ceilings.

title: MUSEUMS ARE AGLITTER FOR CHRISTMAS
description: SO MANY art museum exhibitions are shot through with such sobriety of intent, grandeur of purpose and single-minded resolve that a respite is welcome.

title: Melbourne's Movable Feast
description: In Paris, the visitor can board the bateau mouche and dine while cruising the Seine, but now the Australians have come forth with dinner aboard a trolley car.

title: SHULTZ EMPHASIZES ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, returning to Washington today after 12 days in Europe, has asserted that his chief goal for 1983 is to find a way to bring about an expansion of the world economy.

title: RICHARD FROTHINGHAM 2D TO MARRY JUDITH HUNTER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hunter of Cape Elizabeth, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Gail Hunter, the Richard Thomas Frothingham 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Frothingham of Fishkill, N.Y. A June 18 wedding is planned.

title: DANCE: TWO PREMIERES BY ROBERT SMALL TROUPE
description: The quirkiness Robert Small showed in his choreography while he was still dancing with the Murray Louis Dance Company from 1971 to 1979 came to the fore when he formed his own troupe after leaving the Louis company.

title: CONCERT IS POSTPONED
description: A concert by Buddy Rich and his band, which was to have been held tonight at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in West Orange, has been canceled because Mr. Rich is ill. In addition to the jazz drummer, the concert was to have featured Steve Marcus on tenor saxophone and Andy Fusco on alto saxophone.

title: ANNE E. PUTNEY PLANNING NUPTIALS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Freeman T. Putney Jr. of Cedar Hill, N.Y., have announced engagement of their daughter, Anne Elizabeth Putney, to Peter Michael Swire, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Swire of Menands, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Aug. 28.

title: CARAMEL: AS SIMPLE AS WATER AND SUGAR
description: AS sugar is dissolved and heated, it passes from its original crystalline state to other stages. About the most appealing of these possible transformations is when the sugar deepens to a clear amber and acquires a distinctively mellow flavor and aroma. It has become caramel, an irresistable and versatile substance that can be candy, glaze, topping or sauce, and, with the addition of nuts, it is called praline in France. With caramel to sprinkle on top, even vanilla ice cream becomes a festive dessert.

title: BENJAMIN WEINER
description: RECENTLY a bank hosted a seminar in New York focusing on investment i n a South Asian country. Attendance was sparse, despite the c ountry's attractive prospects and the bank's reputation for fine l uncheons - complete with waiters resplendent in tails.

title: Brandeis Offers A Cost Solution
description: Necessity born of a shrinking Federal loan program has been the mother of inventive financial aid schemes at private colleges. Last week, Brandeis University unveiled its solution - a prepayment plan that holds costs down with a twist that makes them bearable in the first place.

title: IONA IN 83-62 ROUT OF N.C.-CHARLOTTE
description: Because they both missed practice Friday, neither Steve Burtt nor Gary Springer, Iona's two best players, started against the University of North Carolina-Charlotte today. But it did not stop them from dominating the play in the Gaels' 83-62 victory.

title: DUNGENESS CRAB CATCH DOWN ON PACIFIC COAST
description: Two weeks after the Dungeness crab season opened along the Pacific Coast, fisherman Rick Nice beached his crab pots for the winter.

title: EMERGENCY COOLING PLAN AT 3 MILE ISLAND IS FAULTED
description: An emergency cooling system of the undamaged reactor at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania cannot withstand an earthquake and must be modified, a report to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded.

title: PRISON FOOD: NOT FANCY, BUT -
description: TRENTON EVEN though the meals are similar to those consumed by many average American families, the food in some of New Jersey's prisons and jails is prepared differently.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: U.N. REFUGEE CHIEF GETS A NEW TERM
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has settled a backstage political struggle here over the key post of High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: India
description: To the Editor: Like Edwin B. Brooks who wrote a letter about India and the ferry ride through the backwaters of Kerala (Travel, Nov. 21), we were given a detailed route for our day-trip at the Government Tourist Office in Cochin. v. e started out on a 7 A.M. bus to Alleppey, a ride of about one and one-half hours, and were instructed to get off at the boat jetty.

title: LIFE IN A GINGERBREAD VILLAGE
description: EAST HADDAM WHILE reports from the building industry continue to be discouraging, there is one architect-builder here who never worries about selling the buildings she designs and makes.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: Robert Packard's article on ''The White Towns of Spain'' (Travel, Nov. 7) brought back a host of memories. ot surprisingly, Arroyo de la Miel (the first White Town I came in contact with) was not on Mr. Packard's list. Probably because it is tiny and there's nothing much to do there. But, the astounding thing to me about Arroyo was that it was so white it actually hurt the nose to see it - a crisp, sharp white that goes straight through the nostrils to the heart.

title: BOARDING HOMES CALLED CHANGEABLE
description: SINCE 1980, when the state created the Bureau of Rooming and Boarding House Standards, the bureau has closed 64 such houses, almost all since July 1981.

title: 'CHRISTMAS CAROL' DOESN'T SOAR
description: time musical, with 18 actors playing 67 roles. Like the classic whence it came, there are lulls along the way. Sheldon Harnick's book has enlivened them somewhat, but the musical's promise has been only partially redeemed by Michel Legrand's generally routine score and Charles Abbott's conventional staging. It remains for the story to carry the weight, from lugubriousness to levity at last, which is not what a collaborative musical is all about.

title: No Headline
description: Lendl and Scanlon Gain Final

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: NOT everyone is convinced that the current legal protection afforded New Jersey's pinelands is enough to assure the area's future well-being.

title: Day of Defiance In Argentina
description: Since the Falkland debacle, Argentina's bungling military rulers have felt accelerating pressure to turn power back to the civilians. Last week, the military took its strongest battering yet as tens of thousands of people demonstrated in Buenos Aires's Plaza de Mayo for a change to democratic government by October at the latest.

title: Miss Gerrity Wed To J.R. Hamilton
description: The marriage of Laura Pratt Gerrity of Bryn Mawr, Pa., to James R. Hamilton took place yesterday in the chapel of the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David B. Watermulder, assisted by the Rev. Beth Rhude Colgate.

title: Torpedo for Family Planning
description: Because Senators Hatch and Denton suspected Federal funds were being used to promote abortions in some family planning clinics, routine audits were remarkably stepped up last year. Although violence was done to some patients' privacy, the auditors reported no violations of the law. The General Accounting Office did say, however, that ''the Department of Health and Human Services needs to set forth clear guidance on the scope of abortion restrictions.''

title: SANTA AT THE BORDER
description: May I see your passport? ANSWER - I've been coming here every Christmas for many, many years and nobody ever asked me for a passport before. Q - Things are different now. You know, terrorists and all that. We have to be careful. What's your name and occupation? A - Santa Claus - cheerleader. Q - Is that your real name? I must warn you to tell the truth under oath. A - I have gone under the name of St. Nicholas, Old Nick and other names in other places. Q - Where have you come from? A - My last two stops were in Russia and Canada. Q - Mmm, very interesting. I should have known by the color of your uniform. Place of birth? A - I think Greece but I'm not sure. Q - Nationality? A - None. Q - According to U.S. regulations, I must put you down as an undocumented or illegal alien. Flying in here under the radar screen on reindeer is clearly a violation of civil and military regulations and also may bring you under charges of cruelty to animals. May I see your pilot's license?

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: EVEN the usually staid bureaucracy of state government cannot escape the sights and sounds of Christmas. That is evident at the State Capitol in Hartford and at the Governor's Executive Residence a few miles away.

title: SANTA-MORE REAL, LESS MAGICAL
description: SANTA CLAUS has come a long way from the jolly old elf who remained unseen and who in one night traveled the world in a miniature sleigh pulled by eight tiny reindeer.

title: TALES TALL AND SHORT
description: A CELEBRATION OF AMERICAN FAMILY FOLKLORE Tales and Traditions from the Smithsonian Collection. Edited by Steven J. Zeitlin, Amy J. Kotkin and Holly Cutting Baker. Illustrated. 291 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $20. Paper, $9.95.

title: DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS
description: HOWARD HAWKS, STORYTELLER By Gerald Mast. Illustrated. 406 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95. INGMAR BERGMAN A Critical Biography. By Peter Cowie. Illustrated. 397 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

title: MEXICO'S 'MOUNTAIN OF PITY'
description: RICHARD CONDON, the author of ''Prizzi's Honor,'' has another novel, ''A Trembling Upon Rome'' (Putnam), coming out in 1983.

title: Sports of the Times; Aggies' Spirit Adds a Kick
description: FIFTY feet in the air, perched on a tower of logs, Jackie Sherrill recently had a vision. It suddenly occurred to him that anybody tough enough to build the world's tallest bonfire could also light a fire on his football team.

title: Sarah Jennings, a Teacher, And Louis Zeppieri Marry
