description: Sarah Dormer Jennings, daughter of Eloise S. Jennings of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Dr. Frank Dormer Jennings, was married yesterday to Louis E. Zeppieri, son of Mr. and Mrs. Orlando Zeppieri of Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Lawrence D. Costello performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: CHICAGO PARKS' UPKEEP AT ISSUE IN BIAS CASE
description: At Indian Boundary Park, in a white workingclass neighborhood on the North Side, a large Tudor-style field house is the center for a variety of indoor recreational activities. A life-size Cinderella pumpkin coach and gaily painted swings on the neat grounds await the children who will be back in the spring.

title: MICHAEL JACKSON'S THRILLER': SUPERB JOB
description: Since he caught the public's fancy as a bouncing, spinning, piping, 11-year-old mini-superstar in 1970, Michael Jackson has been a fullfledged celebrity, living a celebrity's life. That's worth remembering, because it means that today, one must guard against the assumption that he is a mature, fully formed artist and human being. He is certainly a seasoned veteran: His whole life has been shaped by entertainment, and he is a practiced - sometimes too practiced - performer, recording star and film actor. But he remains a young man, and with luck he will continue to mature.

title: AGENCIES STRUGGLING WITH DIMINISHED RESOURCES
description: By BERTRAM M. BECK General Director Community Service Society of New York

title: MISSING PAPERS STIR BID DISPUTE
description: MINEOLA ALL the paperwork is missing, so Nassau taxpayers will never know how much of their money may have been lost through the county's longstanding system of renewing purchasing contracts without bothering to rebid them.

title: LOOKING AHEAD TO CHARLESTON IN BLOOM
description: ANN BARRY is on the staff of the Arts and Leisure section of The New York Times.

title: DRAWINGS FROM THE ASHMOLEAN PAY A VISIT; CLEVELAND
description: The Ashmolean Museum at Oxford University, which opened May 21, 1683, and will thus celebrate its 300th birthday next spring, is the oldest public museum in England, one of the oldest in the world, and certainly one of the greatest museums attached to a university. It got its odd name from its first benefactor, Elias Ashmole (1617-92), an archeologist and antiquarian, who in 1677 donated to Oxford a collection of curiosities. They formed the nucleus of what is today a marvelous miscellany of art from antiquity to modern times, including splendid European paintings; a great collection of 17th- and 18thcentury silver; bronzes, ivories, tapestries, miniatures, coins, Greek and Roman sculpture, and antiquities from all parts of the world. Among all this, one of the major holdings is a vast group of European drawings, from Michelangelo on down.

title: THE DOUBLE CROSS
description: Criminals are sometimes bridge players, and bridge players are sometimes criminals. As an example of the first half of this proposition consider Harry K. Thaw. Early in this century, obsessed by desire for a girl who preferred Stanford White, he shot down the famous architect in a restaurant.

title: A MYRIAD OF PROBLEMS FOR WARNER
description: THE declining demand for Atari video games is not the only problem p laguing Warner Communications. Just in the last month, the company has faced the departure of the c hairman of its money-losing cable television subsidiary, the sale o f its money-losing toy division and criminal proceedings against t hree former Warner executives, at which the Federal prosecutor said t here was an ongoing investigation of ''the real culprit'' -Warner's c hairman, Steven J. Ross.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: TAVERN owners got a chance last week to let the County Legislature know how they feel about proposals to close the bars two hours early. They don't like the idea. ''We're totally against any change in the closing hour, totally,'' Jim Mannion, president of the 250-member Restaurant and Tavern Owners Association, told Legislator Ronald C. Tocci of New Rochelle.

title: Auto Racing Loses Pioneer in Design
description: Colin Chapman, who died last week, apparently of a heart attack, at the age of 54, was the father of the modern Grand Prix racing car. A brilliant and creative engineer whose Lotuses won half a dozen world championships, Chapman pioneered most of the significant innovations in race-car design of the past two decades.

title: JUNIOR TENNIS TAKES WORLD SPOTLIGHT
description: PORT WASHINGTON JUNIOR tennis, the springboard for every big-name player in the game today, takes the world spotlight next Sunday when the sixth annual Rolex International tournament opens at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: THEATER: 'PORTRAIT OF JENNIE,' A MUSICAL ADAPTION
description: The musical ''Portrait of Jennie,'' a winner of the Richard Rodgers Production Award, tries to reach back beyond the David O. Selznick romanticized movie version to Robert Nathan's original novel. As you remember, the 1949 movie starred Joseph Cotten as an artist in love with an illusion, played by Jennifer Jones. Now playing at Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, the show focuses on the two central characters and jettisons subplots as well as, of course, Hollywood's torrential climactic hurricane.

title: PAUL AND I: AN EX-COACHING RIVAL RECALLS BRYANT
description: IT was funny that when I was named the head coach at Georgia Tech, the first person I tried to get as my top assistant was Paul (Bear) Bryant. He had just gotten out of the service and I felt he was the best coach available, but he had accepted the head job at Maryland. No one knew because it hadn't been announced yet.

title: No Headline
description: Jimmy Connors defeated Heinz Gunthardt of Switzerland, 6-4, 7-5, today in the semifinals of the $300,000 Nastase-Hamptons Invitational tennis tournament.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
CHILDREN'S BOOKS BY AREA AUTHORS: A SPECIAL GIFT
description: 'TIS the season to be jolly ... but watch out for the mysterious malady that strikes people shopping for children's books. Once again, December has brought on its yearly epidemic of bibliohysteria, an ailment that afflicts a large and vulnerable segment of the population: those loving and well-meaning parents, grandparents, aunts, uncles and neighbors who have put themselves at high risk by trying to buy a book for a child.

title: Edward Leigh Marries Rebecca Kapell
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls yesterday Rebecca Ellen Kapell and Edward Monroe Leigh, graduates of the University of Virginia School of Law, were married by the Rev. F. Forrester Church.

title: PATES COME OF AGE
description: Gateau de viande (Meat pate) 1 pound skinless, boneless chicken breast, cut into one-inch cubes 3/4 pound chicken livers 1 tablespoon butter, plus butter for greasing the pan 1 1/2 cups finely chopped onion 1 teaspoon finely minced garlic 1/4 teaspoon finely minced fresh or dried thyme 1 1/4 cups finely diced, sweet green or red peppers 1/2 pound spinach, trimmed and cleaned, about six cups loosely packed 1 cup, plus 2 tablespoons, fine fresh bread crumbs 1 1/2 pounds ground veal 1 egg, lightly beaten 1/8 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg Salt to taste, if desired Freshly ground pepper to taste.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: PORTUGUESE PRIME MINISTER SAYS HE WILL QUIT
description: Portugal's Prime Minister, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, announced his resignation today but said there would be no early general elections.

title: RURAL JUSTICE ON TRIAL IN LAWSUIT OVER RIGHTS
description: In a few days, a jury in the nation's capital will deliver a verdict in a case in which the jurors have been asked to sit in judgment of justice in a small Kentucky town.

title: COUNTRY FICTION
description: ''Shiloh and Other Stories,'' by Bobbie Ann Mason, reminds us that even in 1982 we still have a regional literature that describes people and places almost unimaginably different from ourselves and the big cities in which we live. For all the alleged influence of television and newspapers, there are men and women out in our countryside and small towns who remain strangers to us, whose existences are more foreign and incomprehensible than those of a European peasant.

title: REPUBLICAN LEADERS MOUNT EFFORT ON GAS TAX
description: Senate Republican leaders decided tonight to try to revive legislation to increase the gasoline tax, needed to support a program of highway repair and aid to mass transit.

title: Missed Interception Haunts Jet Defender
description: For nearly half an hour after the Jets' 20-19 last-second loss to the Miami Dolphins today, Bobby Jackson waved reporters away. He did not want to discuss his near-interception with 32 seconds remaining that would have assured a 19-17 victory. After his shower, he sat on a bench under the hook where his clothes hung and turned to a teammate.

title: LABOR UNIONS' HISTORY ON VIEW AT 2 ARCHIVES
description: The story of the struggles and the triumphs of the labor movement's early years has been preserved to a degree in the memories of a rapidly dwindling number of old unionists, in a few history books and in a clutter of files and boxed records in union offices.

title: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1982
description: International North Korean arms have helped Iran finance its continuing war with Iraq, providing about 40 percent of the $2 billion worth of arms Iran has acquired in the past year, according to a high-ranking American defense official. Francis J. West, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, said that North Korea has become the leading supplier of arms to Iran and that Iran has been paying for them partly in cash and partly in oil. (Page 1, Column 5.)

title: WHEN DISCOURAGEMENT FLEW OFF ON WINGS OF SONG
description: IT WAS dark, the wind was bitter and the dirty snow lined the sidewalks and silent streets of the early morning. I strained every muscle as I pumped my bike up the winding, unpaved driveway.

title:
THEATER;
POWERFUL 'RAISIN' IN MIDDLESEX
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE curious thing about ''Raisin'' is that it has succeeded in passing as a musical - and an award-winning one at that -in spite of its music.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHYIf Willy Maywald was not the last of the old school of fashion photographers, he was certainly very close to it. He flourished after World War II photographing the collections of most of the great Paris dress designers from Madame Gres to Givenchy, but he photographed them in the pre-war style of sumptuous, almost ponderous elegance rather than the post-war style of breezy informality.

title: FROM THE WHEELCHAIR, HE SEES REASON TO HOPE
description: By Robert E. Marks

title: PAMELA HILL AFFIANCED
description: Joan Mingie Hill and Arthur Hill of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Elizabeth Hill, to George Murdoch Edgar, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Edgar Jr. of Rye, N.Y. Miss Hill, an alumna of Allendale-Columnbia School in Rochester, is studying at Hartwick College, from which Mr. Edgar, graduated. He is alumnus also of the Westminster School in Simsbury, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Miss Haack to Wed R.S. Pierrepont 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Neilson Jr. of Malvern, Pa., and Northeast Harbor, Me., of the engagement of Mrs. Neilson's daughter, Priscilla E. Haack, to R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierrepont Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Layoffs in the City
description: Albany may have so far failed the M.T.A. but it did manage to provide a little help for New York City last week. Lawmakers approved, and Governor Carey signed, measures to speed collection of the city's corporate tax and change the way earnings of its pension funds are calculated, providing $70 million during this fiscal year and $92 in the following one.

title: BASIC RESEARCH'S BIG PAYOFF: A CASE IN POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: THE VERDEHR TRIO PRESENTS MUSIC OF THE 80'S
description: From the beginning of the Verdehr Trio's Alice Tully Hall recital Thursday night, it was apparent that this was to be no ordinary concert. For the ensemble - which consists of Walter Verdehr on violin; his wife, Elsa Ludewig-Verdehr, on clarinet; and Gary Kirkpatrick on piano - offered a program consisting entirely of works written in the 1980's, all New York premieres.

title: TEACHER CENTER AIDS PROFESSIONAL GROWTH
description: ''THE Teacher's Resource Guide on Aging Studies'' is one example of how contributions from communities, the county and businesses are coordinated by the Teacher Center of Ardsley, Greenburgh and Elmsford. The booklet, designed to be used by teachers in kindergarten through the 12th grade, was published this year by the center and the County Office for the Aging. The Gestetner Corporation of Yonkers donated the paper and printing.

title: THE ZERO DILEMMA
description: When President Reagan put forward his ''zero option'' for European theater missiles in November 1981, the proposal was widely hailed as masterly politics. But now the plan's useful life seems to be coming to an end, putting Mr. Reagan's flexibility, if any, to the test.

title: Submetering
description: To the Editor:

title: UNION CITY SCHOOLS SEEK 'STING' REFUND
description: ALTHOUGH payoffs to local officials increased the cost of two school construction projects here, the Federal Government may have to pay $2.2 million for cost overruns because a ''sting man'' working for the Federal Bureau of Investigation guaranteed the work of a corrupt contractor.

title: U.S. 'AGGRESSION' WINS SYMPATHY FOR SANDINISTS
description: Ever since the July 1979 Revolution, Nicaraguans have been getting Government warnings of an imminent ''aggression'' from abroad that never materialized. When a state of emergency was declared in March this year, many thought the governing Sandinists were using it as an excuse to clamp down on growing opposition at home.

title: Miss MacKinnon Engaged to Wed Newton F. Logan
description: The engagement of Sandra Elizabeth MacKinnon to Newton Franklyn Logan has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm David MacKinnon of Short Hills, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Logan of Shelburne, Mass.

title: THE U.N.'S EMBATTLED PEACEKEEPER
description: One cold night a few months before the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, Brian E. Urquhart, the United Nations' chief diplomatic troubleshooter, was in Damascus - and in a predicament. After meeting with top Syrian officials, the 63-year-old Briton was on his way to a Beirut rendezvous with Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, when a sudden snowstorm closed down the airport. The Swiss pilot of the old United Nations turboprop plane urged Urquhart to cancel the flight. But Urquhart, who survived a parachute drop in World War II when his chute failed to open, was not about to let a mere snowstorm interfere with crisis diplomacy. Firetrucks were wheeled up, the snow on the wings was sprayed off and the pilot proceeded on a roundabout route across Lebanon to avoid the Syrians' Soviet-made antiaircraft missiles, which had already shot down one United Nations plane by mistake.

title: On Housing Issues In Mount Vernon
description: I am writing to commend Betsy Brown for the concise and balanced article she wrote (''Mount Vernon Tenants to Sue City to Stay,'' Nov. 28) concerning a very complex subject -the problem of urban housing.

title: Building Blocks Of Recovery
description: Because he is not given to overstatemant, Malcolm Baldrige's comment on last week's housing report seemed as upbeat as the figure itself. The 26 percent increase in new building in November ''confirms,'' the Commerce Secretary said, ''that this key sector is in a solid recovery.''

title: DESPITE STRAINS, SYSTEM WORKS
description: THE international banking system, while straining to refinance the l arge loans extended to many developing countries, has demonstrated r esiliency in meeting continuing emergencies.

title: Texas Court Rebuffs Actress On Claim to Hughes's Estate
description: The Texas Supreme Court has rejected the assertion of an actress that she should get Howard R. Hughes's money because she married him in a 1946 ceremony she thought was a movie rehearsal.

title: MOSCOW DENIES A PLOT ON THE POPE AS 'ABSURD'
description: The Soviet Union issued a statement today strongly denying that there had been any complicity by Moscow in the attempt to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: THE LIMITS OF URBAN GROWTH
description: Paul Goldberger accurately described the widespread feeling that the East Side has been overbuilt. But then, he looked to ''planning'' by planners for a solution -the same planning that has contributed so heavily in recent years to the ponderous construction which violated the basic function of the zoning law.

title: NETS TOP NUGGETS, ENDING LOSS STREAK
description: For the last several weeks, Mike O'Koren has been struggling as he tried to learn to play guard. But tonight he showed just how good a forward he is, scoring a season-high 23 points to lead the Nets to a 123-114 triumph over the fast Denver Nuggets before 13,121 fans at McNichols Arena.

title: Rumanian Economy Lagging Behind Goals of 5-Year Plan
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu told a Communist Party conference this week that Rumania's economy was growing too slowly to meet the goals of the five-year plan established in 1980.

title: AT WHAT PRICE?
description: To The Business Editor: Paul W. MacAvoy concluded that new Food and Drug Administration regulations for over-the-counter drug packaging amounted to excessive regulation. He further expressed puzzlement over the reasons why the cost of the new packaging requirements (two to 10 cents per package, by his reckoning) should so far exceed the benefits (one cent per package, based on Professor MacAvoy's valuation of $1 million per life saved).

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 12 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 6 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 3 7 6 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 4 3 17 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 5 5 16 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) A continuation of the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 6 4 10 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction. 7 6 16 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 8 8 20 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King.

title: James Brophy Marries Bonnie Chronowski Dixon
description: Bianca Chronowski Dixon, daughter of Mrs. Hugh Francis McShane of Douglas Manor, Queens, and Thomas Chronowski of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to James John Brophy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Francis Brophy of Worcester, Mass. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title:
CAMERA;
HOW TO PHOTOGRAPH SMALL OBJECTS
description: Harvey L. Bilker is a freelance writer and photographer.

title: Merrill Lynch Gives Met Opera $300,000
description: Part of the Metropolitan Opera's 1983 spring tour will be underwritten by a $300,000 gift from Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., it has been announced by John A. Fitzgerald, vice president and director of corporate communications for the financialservices company, which made a similar contribution last year.

title: DR. J.E. KOLITZ TO WED DR. ELIZABETH J. SHPALL
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Shpall of Denver have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Elizabeth Joan Shpall, to Dr. Jonathan Eliahu Kolitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Zvi Kolitz of New York. The wedding is planned for March.

title:
ANTIQUES;
WASSAIL AND CAROLS FROM HOLIDAYS PAST
description: FOR many generations, staunch New England Congregationalists never celebrated Christmas - ancient traditions of wassailing, bringing in of a Yule log, even the decorated Victorian Christmas tree and the presentation of gifts were frowned upon as pagan-inspired.

title: AT VILLAGE, GOOD WILL IS BOUNDLESS
description: BRIDGEPORT THE emotion following the spectacular restoration of Christmas Village spread throughout last week, as truckloads of toys from all over the East Coast continued to pour into Beardsley Park. In addition to filling the village supply room with toys, members of the Police Athletic League, which has sponsored Christmas Village for 18 years, hauled the playthings into an adjacent trailer. Gifts will be given to the thousands of children who are expected to pass through Santa's Workshop until Thursday. The Christmas Village will be open from 1 P.M. to 8 P.M.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ORGANIZATIONAL PSYCHOLOGY;
ETIQUETTE OF THE BOARDROOM
description: If you want to serve on a company's board of directors, don't ask what the job pays. When one well-known public figure did just that, he was disqualified from further consideration, according to two researchers at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business who recently studied the do's and don't's, truths and myths, of the corporate board room.

title: KAUAI RECOVERING FROM PUNISHMENT SUSTAINED IN HURRICANE IN NOVEMBER
description: Hurricane Iwa punished the lovely island of Kauai for eight hours Nov. 23, but Kauai is covering the bruises with cosmetics.

title: MAKING MUSIC AND A NEW LIFE
description: IN the course of his 56 years, the Soviet-born violinist Lazar Gosman, who now lives in Port Jefferson, has performed in many places: at the Central Music School in Moscow; at the Moscow Conservatory; in Leningrad; in St. Louis and in New York City.

title: JUDGE HOLDS CHURCH VOLUNTEERS MUST BE PAID
description: Religious organizations whose members work in commerical businesses operated for the support of churches are subject to all Federal wage and hour laws, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: U.S. PANEL RECOMMENDS PAY INCREASES FOR 17 CONRAIL UNIONS
description: A Presidential emergency board has recommended a pattern of wage increases for employees of Conrail's Harlem, Hudson and New Haven Divisions that is in line with earlier settlements covering New York City transit workers and some groups on the Long Island Rail Road.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
'HANSEL AND GRETEL'
description: If this is a season for sharing and giving, several Long Island performing-arts groups are right in the spirit of things. They've combined forces to mount a special production of Engelbert Humperdinck's classic opera ''Hansel and Gretel,'' which today starts a four-performance run at Molloy College's Lucille S. Hays Theater in Rockville Centre.

title: Excerpts from statement, page 40.
description: Mayor Koch submitted a new financial plan yesterday, outlining the most drastic reductions in New York City's work force since the fiscal crisis of 1975.

title: Yemen Lists Needs For Quake Recovery
description: Yemen, one of the world's poorest countries, needs hundreds of millions of dollars to rebuild areas devastated by Monday's earthquake, which left 400,000 people homeless, officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: Some Considerations For Legislature The article (''Some Legislators Bid Charter Review'') by Gary Kriss in the Westchester Weekly section of Nov. 28, opens to serious question the role of the County Legislature. Although it would appear that there will soon be a Republican County Executive, there appears no doubt that whoever is chosen will be chosen by down-county Republican leadership. Because such leadership has produced a continuous supply of also-rans it may well serve the county's citizenry, our legislators, and the Republican Party itself, if the Legislature elects one of its own members to fill the position.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: IMPOSED BAN

title: LOOSELY SPEAKING, DEFENDANTS REGRET IT
description: A half century ago, when Federal gangbusters went after this city's Prohibition-era mob lord, Al Capone, they had to settle for snagging him on a relatively trivial charge, income tax evasion.

title:
INVESTING;
THE FUNDS THAT SHELTER DIVIDENDS
description: NOT so long ago, some people in the investment community h alfjokingly referred to utility stocks as the best hedge against c apital gains. While utilities typically offered relatively stable a nd high dividend income, price moves were virtually nonexistent. Notm any investors ever made a killing in a utility stock.

title: No Headline
description: U.C.L.A. (5-0) TOPS IOWA (6-1)

title: For Brazil, Debt Engenders Debt
description: Borrowing from Peter to pay Paul is about the only solution for debtor nations these days. Last week, Peter seemed permanently on call in Brazil, which had no way of meeting payments on an estimated long and short term debt of $89 billion except by contracting more debt.

title: Team America: A Clearer Role
description: To the Sports Editor: Ricky Davis of the Cosmos epitomizes the home-bred, new-generation American soccer player who will one day make the game as popular in the United States as it is in the rest of the world.

title: 9TH PRECINCT'S STATIONHOUSE BECOMES SANTA'S POST AGAIN
description: ''We have T-shirts, we have roller skates, we have Monopoly,'' announced Teisha Smith, 11 years old and the self-appointed marshal of the Ninth Precinct's annual Christmas party. ''We have Simon,'' she said, pointing to carton upon carton of Super Simon electronic games. ''We have dolls for the girls, we have sugar cones, we have racing sets.''

title: Reagan Settles For Less on Missile Plan
description: If the MX missile ever gets off the ground in a test, the countdown will be recalled as one of the more dramatic - and the longest - ever.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: It was with great interest that I read the article, ''Discovering the Hidden Paris'' (Travel, Nov. 14). However, having spent a recent weekend in Paris after a week of work in Germany, I would like to point out the merits of some of the old stand-bys of travel there. stayed in the pleasant, if rather charmless, St. James et Albany. It's right on the Rivoli in one of the most touristy neighborhoods in the world, but what richness the area offered. The Louvre offers no end of miracles and pleasure difficult to achieve on less-trafficked turf.

title: MARGARET ROSS PLANNING MAY WEDDING
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard Starr Ross of Baltimore have made known the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Casad Ross, to Robert Arnold Riesman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Riesman of Providence, R.I. The wedding has been planned for next May.

title: 'Armies of Occupation' Must Go, Reagan Says
description: President Reagan said today that the most pressing need in the Middle East ''is to get what now constitute armies of occupation'' out of Lebanon so that sovereignty can be restored to the Government.

title: Rematch on Agenda
description: At the request of Ed Brown, a World Boxing Association vice president for North America, the W.B.A. will hold an emergency executive committee meeting in Miami next Monday to discuss a possible heavyweight rematch of Mike Weaver and Michael Dokes and recent rules changes by the World Boxing Council. ''My concern is that the W.B.A. is not responding to certain matters fast enough,'' said Brown, who asked Gilberto Mendoza of Venezuela, the president, to call together the 15-man commission.

title: Cameraman and Wife Seized By Armed Men in El Salvador
description: A Salvadoran freelance television cameraman and his wife were kidnapped by armed men from their home in suburban San Salvador today, friends of the couple reported.

title: Beauty/FashionBy June Weir
description: A Lulu of A Haircut Clothes aren't the only surprises when designers reveal new collections. Hair styling, makeup, accessories - all are used to punctuate whatever fashion point a designer is trying to make. Often, in fact, the punctuation marks turn into trends themselves.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY AS HIGH ART
description: ALFRED STIEGLITZ: PHOTOGRAPHS & WRITINGS By Sarah Greenough and Juan Hamilton. Illustrated. 246 pp. New York and Washington, D.C.: Callaway Editions/National Gallery of Art. $67.50 until Dec. 31; $75 thereafter.

title: DETERRING PLAYERS' VIOLENCE ON THE FIELD
description: COMMISSIONER Pete Rozelle's suspension of the Jets linebacker Stan Blinka from last Sunday's game against Tampa Bay is a mixed blessing at best to those who want to control unnecessary violence in pro football. Although Blinka's suspension was necessary, unfortunately it will not serve as an adequate deterrent to further violent conduct in the National Football League because Rozelle is using an ambiguous standard to impose disciplinary measures in both an arbitrary and inconsistent manner.

title: LEBANON WAR IS OVER BUT NOT THE KILLING
description: Asked the other day to explain the recent outbreak of murders and kidnappings among Christian and Druse villagers in the Shuf mountains southeast of here, Pierre Gemayel, the founder of the Christian Phalangist party and father of President Amin Gemayel, had no trouble finding an answer. Clearly, he said, it was the fault of ''international Communism.''

title: 'BUON NATALE, ROMA'
description: "Merry Christmas," Merry Christmas.'' We sat in low easy chairs at Kennedy International Airport and toasted each other. It was Christmas Eve, and I could not quite credit that we would soon be on a flight to Rome. For 25 years I had put up a tree, roasted a turkey, mashed potatoes, baked pies (both pumpkin and mince) and steamed plum pudding (which no one liked).

title: Beaumont's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: A TALE OF TWO CITIES AND THE JOFFREY BALLET
description: ''Bi-Coastal'' is the way Robert Joffrey describes the Joffrey Ballet's future status once its appointment as the Los Angeles Music Center's first resident dance company takes effect in 1983. The company opens its usual four-week season on Wednesday at the City Center, but the impression among many is that the Joffrey has simply left New York and moved to Los Angeles.

title: Carol Murphy Bride of Dr. J.P. Lyden
description: The marriage of Carol Slater Murphy to Dr. John Pierpont Lyden took place in the chapel at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday. The Rev. Robert A. Nunn performed the ceremony.

title: ONE HOUSE STANDS IN ROAD PROJECT'S PATH
description: SCARSDALE LIKE other homes in the neighborhood, the one-story ranch at 362 Mamaroneck Road looks comfortably secure on its landscaped lot, but looks can be deceiving. Unlike the others, it probably will be torn down or moved. Its fate is being decided by people who build highways. And their decision is that the white shingle and fieldstone ranch on the edge of this village is in their way.

title:
STAMPS;
TRADITIONAL THEMES DOMINATE CHRISTMAS ISSUES
description: This year's Christmas stamps, which are dominated almost entirely by creches, carols and carvings and paintings depicting the Nativity story, is one of the most traditional in many a Yule. The creches and carols evoke the influence of St. Francis of Assisi, who is being commemorated this year by the United States and other countries on the 800th anniversary of his birth.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
MEMORIES OF CHRISTMAS AT GRANDMA'S
description: IT is the season for family gatherings. I can take a walk through my neighborhood on any holiday - Thanksgiving, Christmas or the Fourth of July - and witness the same ritual. The clans are gathering. Families are assembling to eat and drink together and reaffirm old bonds.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Vox of Pop Sixpack

title: HUDSON GROUP SEEKING RIVER STUDY PROPOSALS
description: The Hudson River Foundation, created two years ago to sponsor environmental research about the waterway and its uses, is inviting applications so that it can make its first grants in 1983. Initial grants totaling $1 million will be made for projects analyzing the distribution, natural history and interaction of the river system's animal and plant life.

title: MAESTRO FRONT AND CENTER
description: STOKOWSKI A Counterpoint of View. By Oliver Daniel. Illustrated. 1,090 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $24.95.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: POINTERS FOR THE FLORIDA-BOUND
description: P erhaps nothing better illustrates the current competitive confusion in the travel business than air fares from the Northeast to Florida and back and the multitudinous offerings to help you save money when you get there. More than ever before in planning a journey south, it is necessary to define your needs carefully and then to shop around exhaustively or consult The Best Travel Agent in the World.

title: Paying the Dead
description: The Federal Office of Personnel Management confirmed last February that the Government had been sending monthly pension checks to hundreds of dead people.

title: DEAN OF PRO LINEBACKERS
description: LOS ANGELES TED HENDRICKS hasn't been The Mad Stork for quite some time. He still admits to intermittent moments of lunacy. Like the time during practice when he dressed in full knightly regalia, including the lance, and raced around the field on a horse. Or the time he wore a Harlequin's mask on the sidelines during a Monday night game, and the cameras caught him.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Make no mistake about it: this is a tough program. It will not simply involve deferring planned improvements.

title: Nancy Ellen Fox Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Fox of Upper Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ellen Fox, to Dr. Anthony Edward Webber, son of Enid Webber of Johannesburg, South Africa, and the late Edward Webber. The wedding is planned for April. Miss Fox is a nurse practitioner with the Crittenton Clinic in Boston. Dr. Webber is senior resident in orthopedic surgery at the Massachusetts General Hospital there.

title: WITH A MOTEL PERMIT STALLED, DEVELOPER STARTS A PIG FARM
description: It used to be the last peaceful spot on a busy road, a 16-acre meadow framing a mountain view. Then Ramsey Associates, a New England developer, bought the meadow for $110,000 to build a 79-unit motel that would join a chain of tourist-related businesses on the two-lane road winding up to Mount Mansfield.

title: Eastern Kentucky Wins Title
description: Two turnovers on kicks, one of them resulting in a 75-yard return of a blocked field-goal return by Richard Bell, helped Eastern Kentucky win the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division 1-AA championship today with a 17-14 victory over Delaware.

title: A BAN ON KEROSENE HEATERS URGED BY SOME FIRE OFFICIALS
description: Fire officials from 17 communities, including some from Albany and Washington, contend that the sale and use of portable kerosene heaters should be banned.

title: THE TORMENT OF NORMAN D. MAYER
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SUPER REALTIY FOR THE JETS
description: MIAMI AS soon as Pat Leahy kicked a 49-yard field goal to lift the Jets into a 19-17 lead over the Miami Dolphins yesterday with about nine minutes remaining, his teammates pounded him in celebration. Some of them had been on the field with him, and the others had rushed out from the bench area to greet the place-kicker who had been in the worst slump of his nine National Football League seasons; he had missed five of his nine previous field-goal attempts (two were blocked) and five of his last 12 extra-point attempts (two were blocked).

title: SEASONAL READINGS
description: With his yearly public reading of ''The Night Before Christmas,'' Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio of White Plains may be following in the footsteps of the late Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, who gained fame for reading the comics over the radio during a New York City newspaper strike.

title: THE GAME TURNS SERIOUS AT ATARI
description: WORKING at Atari Inc. is like playing one of the company's video games. It requires quick reflexes, and one's turn at the controls maybe short-lived. Just in the last two weeks three Atari executives - none of whom had been at the company for more than eight months - have been zapped.

title: PROJECT TO TRAIN 30 STUDENTS FOR CLERICAL JOBS ON WALL ST.
description: About 30 students from New York City's public high schools will be trained next spring in the skills needed for clerical and technical jobs on Wall Street.

title: Yacht Breaks Apart
description: Desmond Hampton, a London real-estate broker, escaped uninjured yesterday when his Gipsy Moth V, a yacht once owned by the late Sir Francis Chichester, crashed onto rocks and broke apart off the coast of Australia. Hampton leased the 56-foot monohull from the Chichester family for the B.O.C. Challenge, a single-handed sailing race of 27,000 nautical miles around the world that began in Newport, R.I., Aug. 28.

title: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS
description: NOT all adverse economic relationships are easily explained and c orrected. Take, for example, the circumstances surrounding the m ining of copper, which have led to increased production and e mployment in Chile and developing nations, and less of both in the U nited States and Canada - with Chilean expansion financed by privateb anks here.

title: A GRANDMOTHER STRIVES TO RAISE FAMILY OF FIVE
description: FOR Mrs. J, who is in her 60's, her biggest challenge has come in the last five years as she has tried to raise her daughter's five sons, now aged 8 to 15. The children are deeply scarred - the oldest three saw their mother murdered in a fight five years ago. Their father died of cancer several months later.

title: DISCUSSION ENDED ON ALIENS MEASURE
description: A comprehensive bill to revise the nation's immigration laws seemed to be dead today, barring an unexpected extension of this post-election session of Congress.

title: PRETORIA AND BLACK EDUCATION: STATIC CHANGE?
description: For the last five years, starting with the student uprising in the vast black township of Soweto, the battleground of South Africa's racial politics has been the system of segregated schooling known as Bantu education. The new Central Secondary State School in this tidy but bleak township outside Pretoria is a tangible emblem of the white Government's response to the issue.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Another Look At Cordero
description: To the Sports Editor: Steven Crist's article on the jockey Angel Cordero Jr. (''The Jockey the Fans Love to Hate'', The New York Times, Dec. 12) could easily have been entitled ''The Jockey the Fans Love to Love.''

title: SHOWDOWN ON BUDGET IS SET BY KARCHER
description: TRENTON ASSEMBLY Speaker Alan J. Karcher, Democrat of Sayreville, predicts that he will succeed before Christmas in passing a bill increasing the state's income tax on gross earnings above $50,000 and thus help solve New Jersey's recurring budget problems. And he will do it, he says, despite open opposition from Governor Kean.

title: Fresca Flynn, Symphony Aide, to Wed John R. Madden, Candidate for M.B.A.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Joseph Flynn of Newport, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Francesca Rowe Flynn, to John Richard Madden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Blaine Madden of Ross, Calif., formerly of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Several years ago - eight, to be exact - Chiaroscuro Records issued an album called ''Dick Wellstood and His Famous Orchestra Featuring Kenny Davern'' (Chiaroscuro CR 129). This stellar organization, which rarely performs as a unit these days, will play for one night only on Tuesday at Hanratty's, Second Avenue near 92d Street, at 9 and 11 P.M.

title: RUSHING MEDICINE TO CRISIS AREAS
description: NEW CANAAN BECAUSE he put together a million-dollar airlift of medical supplies for war-torn Lebanon in August and rushed off a similar shipment of drugs to Poland earlier this month, Robert C. Macauley is being described these days as a ''Connecticut philanthropist,'' and the label bothers him a bit.

title: Article 108776 -- No Title
description: In regard to Linda Saslow's article, ''$20 Bank Error: To See or Not to See'' (Opinion Page, Nov. 28), I take issue with her statement that her ''honesty had meant nothing after all.'' Having been a bank teller for over three years, I can say sincerely that each shortage or overage is not only frustrating for the teller when he tries to trace it at the end of the day's proof, but also a humiliating experience.

title: THE PLIGHT OF THE GRAY DIVORCEE
description: Barbara S. Cain is senior clinical supervisor of interns at the Psychological Clinic of the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor. By Barbara S. Cain They had gathered from the back eddies of loneliness for a bimonthly support session to share their private torments, disentangle meshed emotions and unravel the story of divorce after 60, as experienced by a generation of women who had assumed that marriage was a lifetime commitment.

title: GURU'S DISCIPLES TAKING OVER IN OREGON TOWN
description: Red-robed followers of an Indian guru have gained control of this town in central Oregon after a political battle that caused deep division among people here.

title: ALTERNATIVES SOUGHT TO LOUD FIRE SIRENS
description: DEMAREST THE quality of life in this Bergen County bedroom community of 4,500 residents is being measured these days not in annual family income but, instead, in decibels.

title:
FROM CAPITAL TO CAPITAL;
BUSINESS' BUSINESS: GOVERNING
description: The attitude of American businessmen toward government has always been ambivalent. We may lobby and try to influence it, but we stay out of it ourselves. We leave it to others.

title: Phebe Willits Wed to Richard C. Bergenheim on L.I.
description: Phebe Willits, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Everett Willits of Glen Cove, L.I., and Richard Carlton Bergenheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Bergenheim of Cohasset, Mass., were married yesterday at the Matinecock Friends Meeting House in Locust Valley, L.I., by the Rev. Thomas Lamont, a Congregational minister.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC PLAYS HUNGARIAN MUSIC
description: In its simplest sense, Friday afternoon's concert of the New York Philharmonic offered a few hours of Hungarian music in Avery Fisher Hall. But on a more complex level, its three composers represented three very different responses to an old conflict -the struggle between originality and patriotism, between the individual creative impulse and the compelling pull of one's ethnic roots.

title: WHEN A CRITIC'S WORDS COME BACK TO HAUNT HIM
description: Every reviewer grows hardened after a while to seeing his opinions quoted selectively by people who want the public to believe he is a cheerleader for somebody or something that he actually has found wanting, if not worthless. The most jaded member of the breed must feel an occasional twinge of indignation at being so abused. The high-budget production that he found, say, to be ''a staggering disappointment'' becomes in some subsequent advertisement simply: ''Staggering!'' - Pinkerton, Daily Bugle. The reviewer's gorge must rise ever so slightly at that moment unless he is beyond caring.

title: IN AN ITALIAN-CONTINENTAL STYLE
description: AQUA MANOR is an outpost of northern Italian dining situated near the water in Manorhaven, an area of marinas and yacht clubs. It has been under new management for the last two months. The change has not altered the comfortably pleasant, dark wood panel look of the place, but the garish pink and white fluorescent lights that draw the eye to the undulating ceiling in the second dining room could have been eliminated without regret.

title: HEART PATIENT SITS IN CHAIR ON HIS BEST DAY IN MONTHS
description: For 38 minutes this morning, Dr. Barney B. Clark sat up in a chair in his intensive-care unit and looked out at the cloudless sky above the snow-capped Wasatch Mountains. It was the best day in two months for the retired dentist who is struggling to be the first human to live with a permanent artificial heart, his doctors said.

title: Miss Gilday Weds J.A. Roberts Jr.
description: Mary Jane Gilday, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Gilday of South Natick, Mass., was married yesterday to John Aloysius Roberts Jr., son of Mr. Roberts of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Mrs. Roberts. The Rev. Paul F.M. Zahl performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: TIPS ON MAKING YOUR DOORMAN HAPPY
description: ALTHOUGH Christmas tipping is a perennial problem for a partmentdwellers, there are fewer rules on whom to tip and how much t han there are sixpences in a plum pudding.

title: Thatcher Loses But Stays On
description: The vote last week didn't bring down the Government but it did point up economic and racial tensions now besetting Britain. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's cabinet suffered its first major defeat in the House of Commons on a bill to relax immigration rules in some instances and tighten them in others.

title: FOR DELBERT MANN, ALL THE PROBLEMS OF LIVE TV ARE WORTH IT
description: Susan Squire is an writer and editor based in Los Angeles.

title: HE MAKES THE ORDINARY EXTRAORDINARY
description: Ralph Richardson, who marks his 80th birthday today, is the least categorizable of actors and men. He has variously described his face as resembling a pineapple and a hot-cross bun, and he has spent much of his career playing notably unromantic parts. Yet he is also eccentric, with a puckish sense of humor, a knack for doing the unexpected both on and off the stage, and a talent for making the ordinary extraordinary, the unromantic magical. He is the most senior of Britain's theatrical knights, probably the most widely loved of its actors, and almost certainly the hardest person in any branch of the arts to interview conventionally.

title: OTHER WORLDS THAN EARTH
description: FOUNDATION'S EDGE By Isaac Asimov. 366 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95. EYE OF CAT By Roger Zelazny. 217 pp. New York: Timescape Books/ Simon & Schuster. $13.95. ESCAPE ATTEMPT By Arkady Strugatsky and Boris Strugatsky. Translated by Roger DeGaris. 321 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $14.95.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLE OF THE BRIDGE ROUSES HAMPTONS
description: A GROUP of luminaries from the worlds of arts and letters and politics are fighting the Suffolk County Department of Public Works in what is being referred to by local officials as the battle over the bridge in the Hamptons.

title: 'Ultimate' Gifts
description: For 13 years, in a spirit of year-end holiday fun, Sakowitz, the fashion specialty chain store based in Houston, had offered ''ultimate gifts'' for people who had everything. But last year the tradition suffered the ultimate rebuff: Not one ultimate gift was sold.

title: DEAL ON MX, RESISTANCE ON GAS TAX IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON TO President Reagan, the last few weeks on Capitol Hill must have seemed like a bad dream. On Sunday morning television, Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the chairman of the Finance Committee, was slamming the President for not taking a stronger lead on Social Security. On the Senate floor, a cadre of conservatives of his own party was holding up the proposal he has blessed to raise the gasoline tax by five cents a gallon, saying that taxes always cost jobs rather than create them. In private meetings, the Republican leadership rebelled against his plan for basing the MX missile, forcing acceptance of a compromise that saves the President face but ties his hands until Congress unties them.

title: GADGETS FOR HI-FI FANS MAKE LAST-MINUTE SHOPPING EASY
description: And now, as they say on the air, our series reaches its climactic conclusion wih today's episode. For weeks we whetted audiophile appetites with mouth-watering shopping lists of major components, and with Christmas gaining on us fast, we're now racing Santa to the chimney with a bagful of stocking-stuffers.

title: ANGLING IN COURT FOR FISHING RIGHTS
description: FISHING is an inherent part of the country life style in Southampton, where it is not unusual for a businessman to hang up a ''gone fishing'' sign on his door in the middle of the week and grab his rod and reel. These days, however, the local fishing enthusiasts are more intent upon going to court than they are on going fishing. But to them, it's all the same thing, because they are fighting the state to keep their town ponds and streams to themselves.

title: NEW TV CHANNEL DUE IN '84
description: ALOCAL commercial television station could be on the air by early 1984, according to Michael Pascucci of Locust Valley, who founded Life Broadcasting Inc. four years ago.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: Other recent books which, in the opinion of the Book Review staff, are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest. THE BEST AMERICAN SHORT STORIES OF 1982, edited by John Gardner with Shannon Ravenel. (Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) The latest in the annual series. BEYOND THE COLD WAR, by E.P. Thompson. (Pantheon Books. Cloth, $15; paper, $5.95.) A polemical report on the new peace movement in Europe. GRAMMAR AND GOOD TASTE, by Dennis E. Baron. (Yale University Press, $19.95.) A history of language reform in America. ISAK DINESEN, by Judith Thurman. (St. Martin's Press, $19.95.) A biography of the author of ''Seven Gothic Tales'' and ''Out of Africa.'' THE LONGEST WAR, by Jacobo Timerman. (Alfred A. Knopf, $11.95.) A dovish report on the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. PHILOSOPHY IN TWENTIETH CENTURY, by A.J. Ayer. (Random House, $22.50.) An accessible study by the philosophical heir of Bertrand Russell. RABBIS AND WIVES, by Chaim Grade. (Alfred A. Knopf, $15.95.)

title: Bridge Section Collapses
description: A two-lane bridge buckled and the middle section of the 70-foot span dropped into the Pawtuxet River early today while a man was driving across it. The driver, James K. Ralph, 20 years old, climbed off the bridge unhurt. He told the police the collapse forced his 1975 Lincoln to swerve and strike a support.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ENCOURAGED by last year's attendance of 1,200 people, the Nassau County Department of Drug and Alcohol Addiction is again sponsoring a nonstop, 22-hour New Year's party in the activities building at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow.

title: Atlanta Lawsuits Settled
description: The Atlanta Housing Authority has completed an $800,000 out-of-court settlement with 10 families in connection with a boiler explosion at a day care center in 1980 that killed a teacher and four 3-year-olds and injured six people. Victims' families had sued for nearly $40 million.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Basketball Celtics vs. Detroit Pistons, at Boston. (Television -ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) Los Angeles Lakers vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Inglewood, Calif. (Television - ESPN, 10:30 P.M.) High School tournament: Elmcor/Pro Keds Gold and Silver Classic at St. John's University, Utopia and Grand Central Parkways, Jamaica, Queens. Five games: Edison vs. St. John's Prep, 11 A.M.; Hillcrest vs. Long Island City, 12:45 P.M.; Springfield Gardens vs. Van Buren, 2:30 P.M.; Jackson vs. Cardozo, 4:15 P.M.; Boys and Girls vs. Francis Lewis, 6 P.M. Football Giants vs. Redskins, at R.F.K. Stadium, Washington. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 1 P.M.) Browns vs. Pittsburgh Steelers, at Cleveland. Browns (2-4) have replaced Brian Sipe at quarterback with Paul McDonald, former Southern California star. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Buccaneers vs. Buffalo Bills, at Tampa, Fla.. (Television Channel 4, 4 P.M.) 49ers vs. Atlanta Falcons, at Candlestick Park, San Francisco. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio -WCBS 880 9 P.M.) College: N.A.I.A. Championship: Mesa of Colorado vs. Central State of Oklahoma. (Television - USA Cable, 4:30 P.M. tape.)

title: Doctor Released Early From Rape Sentence
description: Dr. Arif Hussain, convicted with two other doctors of raping a nurse at a beach house, was released quietly from jail 21 days early because of good behavior.

title: DECADE AFTER LANDMARK RULING, ABORTION CASES BESIEGE COURT
description: There is a certain symmetry in the abortion debate returning to the Supreme Court after a long run in Congress and the state capitals of the country. Almost a decade ago - Jan. 22, 1973 - the Court decided Roe v. Wade, the landmark ruling that made abortion legal and, in the process, spawned a national political preoccupation.

title: Edith Ann Hahn Bride of Daniel Merritt Lundquist
description: Edith Ann Hahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Hahn Jr. of Media, Pa., was married yesterday to Daniel Merritt Lundquist, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Lundquist of Radnor, Pa. The bride's grandfather, the Rev. Lewis H. Worrall, performed the ceremony in St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Radnor.

title: JETS LOSE ON A KICK WITH :003 LEFT
description: In a game of missed kicks, the Dolphins won dramatically today when Uwe von Schamann kicked a 47-yard field goal with three seconds to play for a 20-19 victory over the Jets.

title: Patera Trial Starts
description: A member of the Washington State Patrol has testified in Mercer Island (Wash.) District Court that Jack Patera, head coach of the Seattle Seahawks at the time, was ''obviously impaired and unfit to drive a motor vehicle safely on the highway'' when he was stopped near his home in the early morning hours of Sunday, Sept. 12.

title: Hollace Roe and Ernesto Mejer to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Roe of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hollace Lindsay Roe, to Ernesto Jose Mejer, son of Mrs. Jose A. Mejer of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of Havana, and the late Mr. Mejer. The wedding is planned for Feb. 26.

title: STUDY FINDS BLACKS PROGRESS, BUT NOT YET TO MIDDLE CLASS
description: The condition of American blacks has improved in recent decades, but a new study concludes that they are not yet on the verge of joining the middle class.

title: COUNTRY MUSIC STRIKES A CHORD IN FAMILY
description: THERE is family togetherness - and then there is Family Togetherness. In the Sykes Family of Brookhaven, ''togetherness'' means country music, and the tradition is so strong that it has carried a computer engineer, a banker and their two children right into show business. Tuesday they will perform at the Patchogue-Medford Library.

title: BARBARA WATKINS TO MARRY IN APRIL
description: Mr.s John Custer Watkins of Lebanon, Va., has announced the engagment of her daughter, Barbara Sanders Watkins of Charlottesville, Va., to James herbert Kaufman of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Kaufman of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned in April.

title: Fingers's Problem
description: The torn muscle in the right arm of Rollie Fingers, which kept the Milwaukee Braves' ace relief pitcher sidelined during the American League playoffs and the World Series, is still sore. Fingers did not pitch after Sept. 2 although he threw 20 or 30 pitches every other day in a vain attempt to get ready for the World Series.

title: QUESTIONS MOUNT IN BOSTON INQUIRY
description: The political drama has mounted in Boston in recent days with an exchange of charges and disclosures that pose serious legal questions in the Federal investigation of Mayor Kevin H. White's administration.

title: MUST SANTA JOG?
description: A SKINNY Santa Claus? Now, you out there, you've gone too far. I've heard rumors that several Christmas card companies are presenting Santa this year as a slim, athletic figure, jogging or bicycling his way about town. I object. Why try to change all my favorite traditions?

WORKS of art on paper, such as drawings, prints, collages and watercolors, have been produced for so many centuries that it is hard to imagine a time when paper was not readily available. Whether hand-crafted according to techniques developed in the Middle Ages or made in bulk by modern mechanical means, high-quality papers are among the artist's most venerable and valuable materials.

title: AN ACTOR'S LIFE FOR THEM
description: CONFESSIONS OF AN ACTOR An Autobiography. By Laurence Olivier. Illustrated. 348 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.RALPH RICHARDSON An Actor's Life. By Garry O'Connor.Illustrated. 260 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95.

title: Willamette University Groups Assailed Over 'Ghetto' Party
description: A Willamette University fraternity and sorority that held a party with racist overtones avoided suspension by participating in a cultural awareness program, a university official said.

title: FILM: 'THE LIGHT AHEAD,' FROM 1939, RESTORED
description: ''The Light Ahead'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of Oct. 6, 1982. The film opens today at the 72d Street Theater, at Broadway.

title: CHARITABLE GROUP FIGHTS CITY DECAY
description: When the Oceanfront Development Corporation, a local community organization in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, sought help to upgrade the Neptune Avenue commercial district last year, it contacted the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the voluntary charitable agency.

title: THE FED'S UNCERTAIN NEW STRATEGY
description: LAST summer, confronted with an unprecedented combination of e conomic, financial and political pressures, the Federal Reserve System started to back away from its commitment to a tight monetary policy. Almost overnight, the Fed began pouring money into the banks, sending interest rates plummeting and the financial markets into euphoria.

title: P.J. RONDINONE TO WED KATHERINE JASON IN APRIL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leon Jason of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathrine Debra Jason, to Peter J. Rondinone, son of concordia Rondinone of Orlando, Fla., and the late Joseph P. Rondinone.

title: Marks & Marx
description: To the Editor: R. V. Denenberg's article ''Dialectical London'' (Travel, Nov. 4) reminded me of the time that my friend and I decided to go to Highgate and visit the famous cemetery where Karl Marx is buried.

title: PEER HELP A BOON FOR TROUBLED PARENTS
description: An article on the rising number of child-abuse cases and what the state is doing about them is on page 27.

title: COMMUNITY BOARDS LEARN HOW TO FLEX MORE MUSCLE
description: In the course of a few recent days at City Hall, 12,000 demonstrators marched from Chinatown to protest plans for a jail and a group of Harlem leaders met privately with Mayor Koch to complain about a shelter for the homeless. Had residents living near the site of a proposed incinerator in Brooklyn shown up, they too would probably have sounded the familiar refrain: ''Not in my neighborhood.''

title: DREAMING OF A 'RIGHT' CHRISTMAS
description: WELL, it happened again. While I was stuck on preparations for Thanksgiving, someone had snuck in Christmas. There's an elusive date at which one must start in order to have what the magazines call ''your most memorable Christmas ever,'' and it looks as if I've missed it.

title: VAN DYCK REMAINS THE QUINTESSENTIAL PORTRAIT PAINTER; LONDON
description: Throughout the English-speaking world the art of portraiture has been haunted for close on 350 years by the impossible perfection of Sir Anthony van Dyck, who was born in Antwerp in 1599 and died in London in 1641. Everyone knows this as a matter of accepted fact, but never has it been made more evident than in ''Van Dyck in England,'' an exhibition of the rarest beauty and distinction that can be seen at the National Portrait Gallery in London through March 20. (If you can't get to see it, by the way, you can see van Dyck six days a week at the Metropolitan, where his portrait of the Duke of Richmond bears witness to his almost lifelong Anglomania).

title:
DINING OUT;
IF GARLIC BREAD IS YOUR DISH...
description: AN UNEXPECTED find on one of the back streets of Paterson is L'Ombrello. From the outside, this could be any run-of-the-mill neighborhood bar, but inside the scene changes to a chic restaurant that would not be out of place in Manhattan.

title: HACKENSACK'S MAIN STREET IS PERKING UP
description: IT has been 10 years since Hackensack declared a 70-acre portion of i ts downtown area blighted, and about six years since a c omprehensive strategy was created to redevelop the area. But it has o nly been in the last two years, city officials and real-estate b rokers say, that Hackensack has seen the fruits of those labors.

title: Kim E. Daly Has Nuptials
description: Kim Elizabeth Daly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Daly of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Carroll Kelly, son of Mrs. Richard McShane Kelly of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Kelly. The Rev. Mortimer C. Newton performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Mailbox; Recalling Judnich In Hawaii Days
description: To the Sports Editor: I enjoyed reading Zander Hollander's article on Joe DiMaggio and the 7th Air Force (''When DiMaggio and Co. Took Hawaii by Storm,'' The New York Times, Dec. 5).

title: RESEARCHERS GRAPPLE WITH MYSTERIES OF DRUG DEVELOPMENT
description: ''IT could lead to nothing,'' said Dr. Francis Johnson, talking about any number of the scientific investigations under way in his department. ''It is the risk we musk take to uncover the noble secrets of science.''

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: The Search for Quality Lady Antonia Fraser, who has written biographies of England's King James, Charles II, Mary Queen of Scots and Oliver Cromwell, also writes mystery novels and television series. Her first mystery, written in 1977, ''Quiet as a Nun,'' was dramatized for British television and was warmly received there. Channel 13 will present the three-part mini-series, under the ''Mystery!'' umbrella, beginning Tuesday evening at 9.

title:
GARDENING;
MATERIALS FOR HOLIDAY DECORATION
description: IN an age of chrome and plastic, it is refreshing to visit Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia, where the holiday decorations are made from the same natural materials that would have been used during the colonial period.

title: KREMLIN'S GLOBAL GRIP LOOSENS, BUT IT'S STILL 'US' AGAINST 'THEM'
description: There is still a ''world Communist movement,'' but the one Yuri V. Andropov has inherited as head of the Bolshevik party is so different from what it used to be that it's hardly recognizable. The Russians have been unable to assemble a conference of all the Communist parties since their attempt to drum out the Chinese in the 1960's. The best they could manage was a European meeting in East Berlin in 1976, where Santiago Carrillo of Spain proclaimed in front of Leonid Brezhnev and the other chiefs that ''Moscow is not our Rome and the October Revolution is not our Christmas.'' The Russians had to swallow a drastic change of official rhetoric and the endorsement of ''many roads to socialism.''

title: THE BEGINNINGS OF LATIN BAROQUE
description: NEW ISLANDS And Other Stories. By Maria Luisa Bombal. Translated by Richard and Lucia Cunningham. 112 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

title: What Co-ops Can Do
description: Suppose you're a small creature trying to compete with behemoths. In publishing, as elsewhere, one way to even the odds is by joining forces with other small creatures, and that is what some of this country's thousands of smaller publishing houses are doing.

title: Henry Norton Grey Weds Sheila Shumway McCabe
description: Sheila Shumway McCabe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McCabe Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Henry Norton Grey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Everett Grey Jr. of Denver.

title: Correction
description: The correct address for information on the Jan. 29 Bermuda Marathon, listed in the Advisory column (Travel, Dec. 12), is Marathon Tours, Inc. 1430 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, Mass. 02138 (800-343-5088 or, within Massachusetts, 617-492-3088).

title: ONCE UPON A TIME
description: Juvenile Justice

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Japanese court dance is different from the classical dance forms associated with more popular entertainment such as Kabuki and that difference should be made clear in the Bugaku, or Japanese court dance concert at Japan House Monday and Tuesday at 8 P.M.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PARADOXES
description: A majority of voters in 1980 supported the proposition that the United States had to modernize its strategic and conventional forces if we were to avoid having to choose one day between conflict or capitulation. But something happened on the road to redemption.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT is holiday time and they are coming back. They have been gone for many weeks and they are awaited now as if they were old friends. It is the season for family, for a bit of sentimentality, and even the expectation is holiday sentiment enough.

title: State Elections Board Releases Vote Results
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Attorney General Robert Abrams claimed record re-election victories Friday as the State Board of Elections announced the official vote tallies of last month's voting.

title: Barney Clark Endures a Third Trauma
description: The artificial heart had reliably pumped some 1.5 million times in 13 days, emitting a reassuring clicking sound through the chest wall of Dr. Barney B. Clark. Then came a precipitous drop in pressure.

title:
GARDENING;
MATERIALS FOR HOLIDAY DECORATION
description: IN an age of chrome and plastic, it is refreshing to visit Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia, where the holiday decorations are made from the same natural materials that would have been used during the colonial period.

title: Sion A. Boney 3d Weds Miss Demarest L. Byles
description: Demarest Livingston Byles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Herrick Byles of Wilton, Conn., and Sion Alford Boney 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Boney Jr. of Greensboro, N.C., were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Methodist ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Olofson Jr. at the First Church of Round Hill.

title: BETTER LINKS SOUGHT ON MISSING PERSONS
description: LISA RUFFINO was fingerprinted when she was only 7 years old; her brother, John, was fingerprinted at 10. The Ruffino children had broken no laws. It was their father - Richard T. Ruffino - now a sergeant in the Bergen County Sheriff's Department, who had their fingertips covered with ink and rolled on paper.

title: NEW YORK VOCATIONAL TRAINING FAULTED IN STUDY AS INADEQUATE
description: Faced with high youth unemployment, New York City's high school students are still not being adequately trained for available jobs, according to a study by a private group that monitors the Board of Education.

title: TAXES ON PROPERTY ARE HEADING UP
description: TAXES on homeowners will almost surely go up next year throughout t he metropolitan region - in some places quite sharply - as local g overnments try to make up for recession-caused declines in other t ax revenues and in Federal and state aid.

title: CLEANING HOUSE AT WOOLWORTH'S
description: FOUR years ago, when John W. Lynn was chairman of the domestic Woolworth and Woolco units of t he F.W. Woolworth Company, he visited a Woolworth's variety store inM anhattan and was shocked by its shabby condition and unattractive m erchandise.

title: Bleach Cleanup Under Way
description: Federal environmental officers and the police blocked off access roads west of here Friday as they prepared to clean up 300 canisters of a strong bleach found dumped in a canal.

title: ERVING PLEASED BY 76ERS
description: Plenty of questions were on the minds of the prognosticators last October before the opening of the National Basketball Association season. They tried to guess what effect Moses Malone and his six-year contract worth more than $13 million would have on the 76ers.

title: Deborah Vaughan Wed To Arthur C. Romaine
description: Deborah Vaughan, daughter of Vinton William Vaughan of San Francisco and the late Dorothy H. @Vaughan, was married yesterday to Arthur Comstock Romaine, son of Mrs. Theodore Cole Romaine of New York and the late Mr. Romaine. The Rev. Beatrice Blair performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Redskins Respect Entire Giant Defense
description: Joe Theismann, the quarterback who directs the Redskins' creative offense, fully appreciates the skills of Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' outside linebacker, who continues to be a devastating force.

title: FILIBUSTER STALLS KEY MONEY BILL ON SENATE FLOOR
description: A conservative Republican filibuster that began late Saturday night threatened to delay Senate action on a stopgap spending bill needed to keep the Government running when it reopens for business on Monday.

title: GATHERING WOOD ON WEEKENDS
description: NORTH SALEM THE County's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation is again offering a ''come-and-get-it'' deal designed to keep home fires burning at minimum expense.

title: FARMLAND PROGRAM: WHAT CAN BE BUILT?
description: THE owner of an 83-acre horse farm in Jamesport was granted permission to build a barn on his property this month by an 8-to-2 vote of the Suffolk County Legislature's Farm Committee. The difficulty that the application had encountered had set off a controversy.

title: U.S. MILITARY AID FOR GUATEMALA CONTINUING DESPITE OFFICIAL CURBS
description: Loopholes in Congressional restrictions on aid to Guatemala have made it possible for the United States to continue to provide some military parts, instruction and informal advice to this country's armed forces, according to Western officials here.

title: Poland Tries Partial Law
description: Poland's military rulers admitted last week that they were far from ready to return to civilian government after all. They sent a caravan of helmeted, truncheon-bearing security police to Gdansk to prevent Lech Walesa, ''the former leader of former Solidarity,'' from making his first speech since his release from 11 months of internment. Mr. Walesa said he was ''kidnapped'' from his apartment, taken to a municipal tax office and then driven around in a car until his would-be audience had dispersed. He vowed to continue the fight for an independent union ''but only by peaceful means.''

title: Picking Up the DelBello Beat
description: ''If my successor is smart,'' Alfred B. DelBello, the outgoing Westchester County Executive, said earlier this month, ''he won't make any changes at all.'' Andrew P. O'Rourke has yet to be sworn in, but in Mr. DelBello's book, he may have already earned an ''A.''

title: IN SEARCH OF 'PEACE ON EARTH'
description: THROUGHOUT Long Island this week as Christmas is ushered in with varied religious observances, many of these will focus on the promise of ''peace on earth.'' For one denomination, however, the Society of Friends, Christmas means no formal liturgy but a spirit of peace and caring that it feels should live in each person all year long.

title: A NEW LOOK IN OLD CLOTHES
description: VINTAGE clothing shops, once the realm of hippies, artists and college students, today are attracting a more diverse clientele, as people search for distinctive, well-made clothes at affordable prices.

title: VOLUNTEERS HELP HOSPITAL BLOOM
description: When Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip came to New York in 1957 and 4,000 people attended the gala dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria, who designed the flower arrangements? Judith Garden, of course. For the 34 years she was in business, Miss Garden was considered the most creative of New York florists, and it seemed like everyone who didn't think of flowers as just a dozen red roses flocked to her shop on East 57th Street for clever arrangements of cut geraniums or anemones or white lilacs.

title: BY HEIDI WALESON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Heidi Waleson writes frequently about the performing arts.

title: THE WORLD A Little Less Western Disarray After Shultz Tour
description: All in all, it was not a bad two-week's work. Some rough spots in the United States's relations with its Western European allies seemed smoother after Secretary of State George P. Shultz returned home yesterday from a visit to seven European capitals. In London, his last stop, Mr. Shultz emphasized allied agreement on ''realistic'' ways of dealing with the new Soviet leadership. To the Europeans, Mr. Shultz's conciliatory manner brought relief from the tension that Washington's pressure tactics had created before he came on the scene in July.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: GARDEN CITY
description: GARDEN CITY began as the dream of a wealthy man and became a subjectf or dreams in the heads of house hunters, the kind of village that r eally does have tree-lined streets and lush green lawns and gardens t hat do justice to the name of the place. That Garden City turned outt hat way is something of a surprise, considering what it originally l ooked like.

title: POP: REUNION IN JERSEY
description: JANE POWELL and Vic Damone, who appeared in four M-G-M movies in the 1950's, performed together for the first time in 20 years at the Orrie De Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack, N.J., on Friday. The nearly four-hour marathon, in which each did a full-length solo set before joining together for an extended medley, was the latest extravagant caprice in Roger and Deborah Rudnick's ''40's in the 80's'' series.

title: JoAnne Burger Is Married
description: JoAnne Burger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Burger of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Caplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd L. Caplan of Port Chester, N.Y. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue. The bride, who will keep her name, and her husband are studying at the Yale University School of Medicine.

title: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: How long was John Dockery in the National Football League, and what were his statistics? When did he play for Harvard?

title: COUNTRY: NEW RANK AND FILE
description: Chip and Tony Kinman of the Dils and Alejandro Escovedo of the Nuns - who moved to Austin, Tex., to make ''square'' music.

title: Differing Scripts For Justice Bowl
description: Ignored by the selection committees of all the major football bowl games, New Mexico and Tulsa staged a different bowl during the last weekend.

title: COURTS LIMP ALONG AS LEGAL AID STRIKE GOES ON IN NEW YORK
description: After nine weeks of a strike by 550 Legal Aid Society lawyers, New York City's court officials and district attorneys say that the courts have managed to take up much of the slack with private lawyers but that postponements have begun to worsen the backlogs of criminal cases.

title: A WEEKEND OF MEANING
description: THIS is supposed to be the desperate time of year for football teams, a time of last-moment field goals and lost interceptions. It is not supposed to be a desperate time for a championship hockey team.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART PATIENT HAS BEST DAY SINCE 1st OPERATION
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark stood up, with assistance, and bore some of his weight on his own feet today for the first time since he received an artificial heart on Dec. 2.

title: Philips-CIT Radios
description: NV Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken said Friday that it had signed an agreement with CIT-Alcatel S.A. for worldwide cooperation to develop and supply a cellular radio system.

title: No Headline
description: LENDL DEFEATS SCANLON IN FINAL

title: THE DANCE: SALLY SILVERS AND POOH KAYE TRIUMPH
description: POOH KAYE and Sally Silvers found virtues in ungainliness in their concert Saturday night downtown at the White Dog Studio. Each of their dances involved obstacles that impeded the flow of movement. But the performers always managed to cope with those obstacles in a witty manner.

title: CUOMO CLASHES WITH COMMITTEE OVER JUDGESHIPS
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that a state law governing the nomination of judges to the State Court of Appeals was inconsistent with the State Constitution. He asked a nominating panel to disregard the law and recommend additional candidates for a court vacancy.

title: DR. GEORGE BAHDER
description: Dr. George Bahder, president of the Cable Technologies Laboratory of New Brunswick, N.J., died Friday of cancer at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 57 years old.

title: HOLIDAY SALES IN WHITE PLAINS
description: Christmas sales in the White Plains retail centers continued strong yesterday, a day after many merchants did their best business of the year. Following a slow start, holiday sales reversed direction a week ago when the weather cooled.

title: 'COUP DE TORCHON,' LIFE IN A FRENCH COLONY
description: IT is the peculiar talent of Bertrand Tavernier to make films of very apparent intelligence, purposefulness and wit, films that are nonetheless not always easily fathomed. Mr. Tavernier's ''Coup de Torchon,'' like the two other Tavernier films that have recently been seen here (''A Week's Vacation'' and ''The Judge and the Assassin''), is a handsome and unusual work that's also mildly baffling, probably quite a bit more baffling than it means to be.

title: Miss Dixon Wins 220 and 440 Races
description: Diane Dixon, the 1981 indoor national champion at 440 yards, won two events today at the Manufacturers Hanover/Metropolitan Athletics Congress grand prix meet in Jadwin Gym at Princeton University.

title: CAMBODIA DROPPED FROM INDIA PARLEY
description: India, the host country for the next summit meeting of the nations describing themselves as nonaligned, has announced that it is not inviting the Vietnamese-backed regime in Cambodia to the conference.

title: GROWING UNREST SETS OFF ALARM BELLS IN ARGENTINA
description: Three days after thousands of anti-Government demonstrators were dispersed with tear gas and gunfire, Argentina's Roman Catholic Church declared today a ''Day of National Reconciliation'' and, in sermons throughout the nation, priests read a statement pleading for social peace.

title: FERRY COLLISION OFF ENGLAND KILLS 6
description: Dozens of passengers were hurled into the sea tonight when two ferries collided off England's east coast in stormy weather. The harbor police said they pulled six bodies and 68 survivors from the raging waters.

title: ANGELINO PUPILS: 49% ARE HISPANIC
description: Children of Hispanic ancestry now constitute almost half the pupils in the Los Angeles Unified School District, according to a new census of the country's second-largest school system.

title: BOMBS DAMAGE ATOM PLANT SITE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Four bombs exploded today and Saturday at South Africa's only nuclear power station, which is under construction on the rocky Atlantic coast just north of Cape Town.

title: Spain's Communists Avow Independence
