description: Spain's Communist Party reaffirmed its independent line from Moscow at a national conference that ended today, the first under Gerardo Iglesias, its new leader.

title: A CURB ON DUPLICATE HOSPITAL SERVICES ASKED
description: Dr. David Axelrod, the State Commissioner of Health, says that New York's City's large teaching hospitals must be rebuilt if the city is to maintain its pre-eminence in medical care, research and education.

title: 8 Iranians Held in India
description: Eight Iranians traveling to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, were arrested at Madras airport today on charges of presenting forged travel documents, the police said.

title: Truth in Numbers
description: The Elias Sports Bureau handles official statistics for the National Basketball Association, the National Football League and baseball's National League. For its own purposes, it also keeps upto-date figures on the American League, the National Hockey League and the professional golf tours.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Chargers vs. Cincinnati Bengals, at San Diego. In a game important to the Chargers' playoff hopes, San Diego (4-2) brings the N.F.L.'s No.1 total offense against Cincinnati (5-1), the league's best defender against the rush.

title: DISPUTE DELAYS VOTE ON MARSHALL ISLES' FUTURE
description: A plan to give limited independence to the American-administered Marshall Islands became snagged last week because of a dispute over compensation to residents for the effects of nuclear weapons tests in the area.

title: SOME BROKEN FAMILIES RETAIN MANY BONDS
description: For a change, there are some good tidings about the American way of divorce. New research shows that caring feelings, friendly interactions and a significant degree of communication are not unusual among some former spouses in what social scientists call binuclear families.

title: Substance for Healing Is Isolated in Rabbits
description: Researchers say they have purified a substance in rabbits that helps damaged blood vessels grow back, and that they hope to isolate a similar chemical in people.

title: LAWRENCE W. HOYT, BOOK CHAIN'S CHIEF
description: Lawrence W. Hoyt, founder of the Walden Book Company of Stamford, Conn., now one of the country's largest bookstore chains, died Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 81 years old and lived in Easton, Conn.

title: Jeantot's Yacht Arrives in Sydney
description: Philippe Jeantot of France completed the second leg of the single-handed round-the-world yacht race, arriving here in his yacht, Credit Agricola, early this morning.

title: JESSICA LANGE, FILM STAR WHOSE FUTURE IS HERE
description: The Christmas tree is small and temporary, decorated with only a half-dozen white angels with golden wings. Jessica Lange will be going home to Minnesota for Christmas, and this red rented house in a California canyon is temporary, too.

title: Bridge: Greenberg Team Captures Winter Regional Knockout
description: A formidable quintet headed by Alan Greenberg of New York captured the Winter Regional Knockout Team title at the New York Hilton Saturday night. Teamed with him were Ira Rubin of Paramus, N.J., and Fred Hamilton of Hollywood, Fla., both 1976 world champions, and Jim Cayne and Alan Sontag of New York.

title: Metropolitan Savings
description: The Metropolitan Savings Bank, New York, and the First City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Bradenton, Fla., have agreed in principle to merge. Metropolitan's chairman, Luke A. Baione, said his institution, which has assets of $5.9 billion, would acquire all First City Federal's shares outstanding at $40 each, or a total of $33.5 million. First City Federal has $762 million in assets and has 20 offices on Florida's west coast.

title: Drivers Checked for Sobriety
description: About 1,500 motorists passed through Maryland State Police ''sobriety checkpoints'' this weekend, and two had been arrested when the checkpoints were dismantled today, troopers said.

title: DOLLAR'S FALL WILL LAST INTO 1983, ANALYSTS SAY
description: After a run-up that lasted nearly two years, the value of the dollar on foreign exchange markets has begun to slide. While the dollar is expected to remain strong, the decline is likely to continue well into 1983, according to economists, traders and foreign exchange experts.

title: NO TIME TO CURTSY, NO REASON TO BOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Rolls-Royce Engine Deal
description: Rolls-Royce Ltd. announced today it was developing its first new airplane engine in more than 10 years and negotiating a $300 million deal to sell it in the United States.

title: Coach Dismissed By Oral Roberts
description: Ken Hayes, the basketball coach at Oral Roberts University, today confirmed that he had been dismissed Saturday night shortly after the 63-56 loss to Tulsa in the final of the Oil Capital Classic.

title: CHRISTMAS TREES' BEAUTY IS IN THE EYE OF THE BUYER
description: In a makeshift Christmas tree lot along the West Side Highway, Peter Dolle and his three sons - after some debate over greenness and fullness - settled on a tree.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Novel Street Pitches

title: Citrus Agency Tables Review
description: J. Walter Thompson, U.S.A., and Geers Gross, who survived a field of 80 ad agencies to become finalists along with Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, the incumbent, for the $5.5 milliongrapefruit account of the Florida Citrus Commission, has learned that the commission voted to table the agency review.

title: Chile Ends All Dealings With Rights Agencies
description: Chile, in its first official reaction to a United Nations resolution condemning its policies, promised today to stop cooperating with the human rights agencies of all international organizations.

title: Jets to Evaluate Leahy Slump
description: The man in charge of finding replacements for the inefficient or the injured Jets, Jim Royer, said yesterday he has not been told to find a replacement for Pat Leahy, the slumping place-kicker.

title: LEONID LOGAN, A LEADING SOVIET VIOLINIST, 58
description: Leonid Kogan, the internationally acclaimed Soviet violinist, died Friday, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, announced yesterday. Tass did not report where Mr. Kogan had died nor give a cause of death. He was 58 years old.

title: Tampon Rule in Effect As Shock Cases Decline
description: A Government rule requiring tampon makers to warn women of a link between tampons and toxic shock syndrome takes effect Monday.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Democratic Star

title: PROPERTY TAXES DECLINE 9.3% WITH MASSACHUSETTS MEASURE
description: A tax-limiting measure approved by Massachusetts voters two years ago has brought a reduction of $311 million, or 9.3 percent, in property taxes in the last 17 months, according to the state revenue agency.

title: Market Place; Toronto's Gain In Technology
description: THE Toronto Stock Exchange, long dominated by the shares of oil, mining and forest product companies, is now seeing a boom in technology stocks.

title: FORMER CENCO LEADER ASSUMES AMERACE JOB
description: George S. Deutsch has resigned as president, chief executive and a director of the Amerace Corporation, and speculation has arisen about the future of the company.

title: ULITMATE EVIDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR POWER'S NEW PERIL
description: The cancellation of three more nuclear power plants in November alone merely confirms the obvious: the commercial nuclear industry is in deep trouble. Not one new reactor has been ordered since 1978, and 102 have been canceled since 1972 (including 18 this year). Opponents of nuclear power are justly inclined to celebrate this trend, but triumph must be tempered with concern - for nuclear power is likely to be even more dangerous in its decline than in its heyday.

title: WINDOW ON THE HEART PATIENT: CHASE NEBEKER PETERSON
description: For almost three weeks, Dr. Chase N. Peterson has been the voice of calm in periods of high excitement and repeated crises in the extraordinary story of Dr. Barney B. Clark's struggle to be the first human to live with a permanent artificial heart.

title: Abbi Greenfield Bride Of Paul D. Neuthaler
description: Abbi Greenfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Greenfield of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul D. Neuthaler, executive vice president of Warren, Gorham & Lamont Inc., legal and business publisher in New York. Rabbi Irving Spielman performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's sister, Mrs. Herbert Poster, in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Ruffian a Top Dog
description: Ch. Beaucrest Ruffian, a bouvier owned by Pat and Roy Schiller of Ijamsville, Md., was named best of 2,478 dogs Saturday at the 88th Kennel Club of Philadelphia show in Civic Center. Ruffian, handled by Roy Holloway, recorded his 48th victory.

title: GAS TAX BILL ALIVE AGAIN
description: The Senate tonight revived a bill to increase the gasoline tax and broke the filibuster that had forced the measure's withdrawal from floor consideration Thursday.

title: VIKINGS BEAT LIONS AS RESERVES EXCEL
description: Terry LeCount, Leo Lewis and Jarvis Redwine, who usually spend more time on the sidelines than on the playing field, made the big plays as the Minnesota Vikings defeated the Detroit Lions, 34-31, yesterday at Pontiac, Mich.

title: LEBANON SAYS IT'S READY TO NEGOTIATE
description: The Lebanese Government, reacting to a decision by the Israeli Cabinet earlier in the day, said today that it was prepared to enter into immediate negotiations with Israel on withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon.

title: LILLIAN B. ANDLAUER
description: Lillian B. Andlauer, executive secretary with the Clark Estates, a management-investment concern in New York City, died Thursday of cancer at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: AWAITING FATHERHOOD: THE STRAIN
description: THE schoolteacher confessed he had put on 20 pounds, gaining almost a s much weight as his pregnant wife. The advertising manager felt so l eft out he conceded he had become jealous and resentful. The book s alesman admitted he was scared stiff to realize he had just become t he sole breadwinner in the family. And the travel agent told of an u ncharacteristic spate of weird but vivid dreams that included an e pisode in which he tried to sell his baby-to-be.

title: NATALIA MAKAROVA IS INJURED
description: Natalia Makarova, who was hit by falling scenery in a performance at Kennedy Center Saturday night, suffered a broken shoulder blade and cut on the head that required six stitches, a George Washington University Hospital spokesman said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Remembering A Banned Tradition

title: Protester Killed at Monument Buried at Arlington Cemetery
description: The ashes of Norman Mayer, the protester killed by police gunfire after a 10-hour siege at the Washington Monument last week, were buried Friday at Arlington National Cemetery, to the distaste of the Army.

title: ATLANTA'S THRIVING ARTS WORLD HONORS THE MAN WHO PAID FOR IT
description: Some of the leading lights in Atlanta's world of culture and the arts recently turned the tables on the city's ubiquitous and heretofore ''anonymous'' benefactor: They made him a gift of public recognition as the man most responsible for the vibrant state of the arts in the capital of the South.

title: No Headline
description: BUCS BEAT BILLS DESPITE 3 INTERCEPTIONS

title: Eames H.Yates Weds Dallas Pell
description: Nuala Dallas Pell, daughter of Senator and Mrs. Claiborne Pell of Newport, R.I., and Washington, was married yesterday to Eames Hamilton Yates, son of Mary Olberg Yates of Washington and Naples, Fla., and the late Frederick Langdon Yates. Canon D. Lorne Coyle performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport.

title: FATE OF BANKRUPTCY SYSTEM IN DOUBT
description: The nation's bankruptcy system will apparently slip into legal paralysis before year's end unless the Supreme Court gives Congress another extension of its Dec. 24 deadline for restructuring the bankruptcy courts.

title: BILL TO CURTAIL STOLEN-ART TRADE IS NEAR PASSAGE
description: After having been blocked in Congress for more than a decade, a compromise bill aimed at curtailing the illegal international trade in stolen antiquities is nearing passage.

title: OUTDOORS: RACING CAMP IS NEWEST TREND IN SKIING
description: INSPIRED by the winning performance last season of the United States ski team and encouraged by the availability of amateur races, recreational skiers in increasing numbers are entering competitions. And, once they get a taste of running gates against the clock, they want to try again and do better.

title: Draft System Mailing Warnings to 450,000
description: The Selective Service System is sending warning letters to about 450,000 young men it believes have failed to register for Selective Service.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1982
description: International Israel removed a major obstacle that has prevented discussions with Lebanon on the withdrawal of Israeli forces by forgoing its stipulation that meetings be held in Jerusalem. Israeli officials said they hoped the talks could begin in the next few days. Israel said its concession had been made after Lebanon agreed to a negotiating framework that was reported to include talks on normalization of Israeli-Lebanese trade and tourism relations. (Page A1, Column 2.) Lebanon is ready to start talks with Israel immediately, the Government said after Israel announced that it would no longer insist that the talks be held in part in Jerusalem. Foreign Minister Elie Salem said that the United States must be a partner in the discussions. (A12:3-5.)

title: Quake Rocks South Pacific
description: A major earthquake rocked the South Pacific this morning just east of the International Date Line, the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center here said. The quake measured 7.2 on the Richter scale, which lists anything higher than 7 as a major quake. The quake was centered in the vicinity of the Kermadec Islands northeast of New Zealand.

title: CHILDREN'S SYMPATHY INSPIRES GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Happy children are often aware during the joyous holiday season that not all youngsters share their good fortune, and each year many become contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: BORED BY TRENDY? DARE TO BE DULL
description: Like a lot of dull people, Joseph L. Troise says he does not particularly like the Christmas season. ''The holidays are too exciting,'' says Mr. Troise, who revels in the mundane. ''I'm sort of looking forward to the first week of January.''

title: A YELLOW FLAG GOES UP ON INTEREST RATES
description: As 1982 draws to a close, the credit markets are beginning to express some doubts about the prospects for additional declines in interest rates.

title: Books Of The Times
description: CONFESSIONS OF AN ACTOR. By Lau- rence Olivier. Simon & Schuster. 348 pages. $16.95. RALPH RICHARDSON: AN ACTOR'S LIFE. By Garry O'Connor. Atheneum. 260 pagaes. $14.95.

title: Quadruplet Dies in Illinois
description: The eldest of 5-day-old quadruplets died late Saturday at Evanston Hospital after emergency surgery to correct a perforated bowel. The operation on Antonio DeCarlo showed that the damage was ''too extensive to sustain life,'' a hospital spokesman said. The baby was taken to his mother, Andrea DeCarlo, and died in her arms.

title: An Assistant Moves Up
description: Dec. 9 - Ray Perkins is told by the University of Alabama that Coach Bear Bryant would not return next season.

title: KING TO MOVE
description: Few heads of state have come to Washington on a visit so potentially fateful as the one King Hussein pays to President Reagan this week. For the King, in what he says, can breathe life into the Reagan peace initiative - or leave the Middle East in bitter instability for years to come.

title: 'THROWAWAY CHILDREN': BLAMING PROBATION IS NOT THE ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: REPAIRING LLOYD'S OF LONDON
description: There is plenty of superficial evidence that the venerable Lloyd's of London insurance exchange is flourishing. The trading floor, known simply as The Room, is crowded with brokers. The list of people wishing to invest in the Lloyd's syndicates, with which insurance brokers place their clients' risks, has grown to 1,900, almost 50 percent more than a year ago. A new Lloyd's building designed by Richard Rogers, architect of the Pompidou Center in Paris, is rising on Lime Street.

title: Schools Without Chaos
description: Whatever makes a good school, learning is impossible where behavior is disruptive. This inescapable fact has at last been addressed by New York City's Board of Education.

title: THEATER: 'BLACK ANGEL,' A VIEW OF THE HOLOCAUST
description: IN this week's drama about the Holocaust, ''Black Angel'' at the Circle Repertory Company, Michael Cristofer has made a strenuous attempt to avoid the oversimplifications that make so many works about this subject so offensive.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON AID TO ISRAEL
description: A House and Senate conference panel today compromised on funding of $2.185 billion in military and economic aid to Israel as part of an overall emergency government spending bill.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Icahn Move On Dan River
description: Dan River Inc. said late yesterday that Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, had conditionally increased his offer for its shares to $21 each, from $18, and now seeks all the shares outstanding. The offer came in a letter Friday from Mr. Icahn, the text of which was released by Dan River.

title: CITY POLICE, F.B.I. JOIN FORCES TO ROOT OUT CAR-THEFT RINGS
description: A special task force of F.B.I. agents and New York City detectives has been set up to combat crime rings that are believed responsible for about two-thirds of all car thefts in the city.

title: I.M.F. OFFICER TAKES NEW POST AT AGENCY
description: At the International Monetary Fund in Washington, the Western Hemisphere department routinely handles financial crises such as those faced by Brazil, Mexico and Argentina.

title: 2-DAY PRO SKATING WATCHED BY 26,000
description: There were several costume changes, countless flips, twirls and jumps and even an occasional fall. There were pre-competition nerves and post-competition sighs of relief. And for the first time in the history of figure skating in the United States, there was $100,000 in prize money at stake.

title: TWO EMOTIONAL GAMES BUOY ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders' recent slump has been much publicized, and many theories have been put forth in explanation. One is that they are not interested in finishing high in the regular-season standing, and that they are just conserving themselves for the home stretch that leads to the playoffs in the spring.

title: PREGNANT UNWED TEACHER DIVIDES EAST HAMPTON
description: There are moments when Patricia Hope wonders if she is playing out scenes from the novel ''The World According to Garp,'' but with a difference: T.S. Garp's mother was never assailed in a petition demanding that school officials dismiss her for being pregnant and unmarried.

title: FIGHTING FOR LIFE
description: At Kennedy Center last night, in the revival of the Rodgers and Hart musical, ''On Your Toes,'' the Russian ballerina Natalia Makarova was about to begin the ballet ''Slaughter on Tenth Avenue.''

title: PORTUGUESE COALITION STARTS ITS SEARCH FOR A NEW PREMIER
description: Portugal's right-wing coalition Government began seeking a new Prime Minister today after the resignation of the Social Democratic Party leader, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, after almost two years in the job.

title: ATLANTA'S FADED MEDIA DREAM
description: This city's bid to join New York, Chicago and Los Angeles as major media centers has met with a series of setbacks, leading some executives here to suggest that the business hub of the South may not achieve its goal anytime soon.

title: ORANGE COUNTY PONDERS A PLACE FOR BRINK'S TRIAL
description: The first order of business for Orange County officials now faced with the upcoming Brink's murder and robbery trial is finding a courtroom for it.

title: PRODUCTION NOW FOCUS OF OPEC
description: Ministers of the 13 OPEC countries adjourned today the first round of formal talks that have so far failed to yield an effective agreement on how much oil each member should produce. The meetings resume Monday.

title: GOLDIN ASSERTS MAYOR FAILED TO HEED HIS ADVICE ON BUDGET
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that Mayor Koch could have avoided imposing the city's stringent new financial plan if he had listened to the Comptroller's advice earlier in the year.

title: The Bankrupt Congress
description: Six months ago the Supreme Court gave notice that the nation needed a new law to reconstitute the Federal bankruptcy courts. Yet the dying Congress has been unable to fashion one. Blame for the default, which will inevitably increase the suffering of failing individuals and businesses, must be shared by a prideful Federal judiciary, a Reagan Administration hungry for new judgeships and a greedy credit industry.

title: News Analysis
description: For the last two months, Palestine Liberation Organization officials say, Yasir Arafat has been virtually ignoring P.L.O. hard-liners and pursuing a diplomatic strategy aimed at bringing his guerrilla organization into a position to take part in President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative.

title: 'THROWAWAY CHILDREN': BLAMING PROBATION IS NOT THE ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: GREGORIO GUILTY OF A CONSPIRACY IN NETWORK CASE
description: A Superior Court jury in Newark found State Senator John T. Gregorio guilty yesterday of conspiracy to commit official misconduct, but acquitted him of nine other charges arising from what the state said was a hidden interest in two Linden, N.J., bars in 1979 and 1980.

title: MOSELEY'S RECORD KICK WITH :004 LEFT BEATS GIANTS
description: It was just like in the movies. Nine seconds were left in the game, the hometown team was 2 points behind and only a field goal could save it. The hero had kicked 20 straight field goals, equaling a record. One more and he would break the record and win the game.

title: TURKEY'S CAPITAL GOES TO WAR AGAINST SMOG
description: The Government's radical new antipollution program for Ankara went into effect this month on a day when the air was brown and the sun a bloody splotch in the haze. There was no wind to relieve the city, which is shaped like a bowl in the Anatolian plateau.

title: POLAND MAKES THE DATE OFFICIAL: DEC. 31
description: The Council of State, Poland's collective presidency, formally announced tonight that, as promised, martial law will be ''suspended'' on Dec. 31.

title: Professors Want Clemson Changes
description: A group of Clemson University professors has called on the school's administration to dismiss the staff members responsible for the football recruiting violations that recently drew stiff sanctions.

title: Yemen Quake Toll Hits 1,540, And More Are Still Missing
description: The death toll from last Monday's earthquake in the Dhamar area in the southeast has risen to 1,540, and more people are believed buried under the rubble, officials said today.

title: MUSIC: CHRISTMAS VISIT BY VIENNA CHOIR BOYS
description: THE VIENNA CHOIR BOYS paid one of their periodic visits to New York this weekend, with Sunday afternoon's music at Avery Fisher Hall dividing most of its time between comic opera and Christmas.

title: 'OUTRAGE!': DRAMA BEHIND DRAMA
description: It was a case of art following life. Audiences at a new play at the Kennedy Center called ''Outrage!'' see a drama about a man who takes the law into his own hands, killing his daughter's murderer after the murderer has been freed on a ''technicality.''

title: TV: KNOTTY 'CYMBELINE' UNTIED AND UNCLUTTERED
description: SHAKESPEARE was hardly a stickler for credibility. His plays are crammed with such ticklish devices as mistaken identities, women masquerading in boys' clothing, wicked abductions and innumerable magic potions for simulating either death (''Romeo and Juliet'') or enchantment (''A Midsummer Night's Dream''). Generally, they work. Shakespeare, after all, is Shakespeare. But even the master seems to have overdone matters in ''Cymbeline,'' that very odd concoction, which can be seen tonight at 8 on WNET, Channel 13, as part of the BBC series ''The Shakespeare Plays.''

title: Washington Watch; I.M.F. Studies Alarm System
description: WASHINGTON THE International Monetary Fund may install an alarm to warn when a country's debt problems start getting unwieldy. The mechanism would lead to a prompt application to the fund for assistance, with a view to avoiding full-blown crises later.

title: TROOPS OF 5 SOVIET ALLIES REPORTED FIGHTING GUERILLAS IN AFGHANISTAN
description: Soldiers from five Communist countries are fighting with as many as 100,000 Soviet troops against Moslem insurgents in Afghanistan, sources in Pakistan said today.

title: SYRACUSE REGAINS REPUTATION IN EAST
description: In each of Jim Boeheim's first five seasons as the Syracuse coach, the Orangeman won at least 22 games. But last year was a disappointment as the team finished at 16-13, and it appeared that 1982-83 would also be a difficult season for the Big East Conference team. The strong teams in the East were supposed to be Georgetown, Villanova and St. John's.

title: MESA BID ON GENERAL AMERICAN
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company, in its second unfriendly bid to take over another oil and gas exploration company this year, announced yesterday a $520 million offer for more than half the shares of the General American Oil Company of Texas.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA DEFEATS MRS. LLOYD
description: All week, Martina Navratilova said that she wanted to prove ''beyond a reasonable doubt'' that she deserved to be No.1 for the year in women's tennis. Tonight, she did, beating Chris Evert Lloyd, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, in the final of the $300,000 Toyota championships.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bestiary on a Building

title: Brett Evonne Singer, Writer, Marries David R. Lachterman in Poughkeepsie
description: Brett Evonne Singer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Singer of Bel Air, Calif., was married yesterday to David Rapport Lachterman, son of Edith Abramson of Falls Church, Va., and the late David Lachterman. Rabbi Morris Bekritsky performed the ceremony at the Congregation Schomre Israel in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: CONGRESS DROPS JOBS PROGRAM AND MX FROM FUNDING MEASURE IN COMPROMISE TO AVOID A VETO
description: A House-Senate conference put together a rapid sequence of compromises tonight in concluding its work on a bill to keep Government agencies operating Monday.

title: U.S. BATTLING SMUGGLING OF CARS MADE IN MEXICO
description: Taking advantage of lower prices because of the absence of safety restrictions and the plunging Mexican peso, large numbers of Americans are buying automobiles made in Mexico and smuggling them into the United States, according to American customs officials.

title: Padres Cooling on Garvey
description: Ballard Smith, the president of the San Diego Padres, said today that he was frustrated by the lack of progress in the contract talks with Steve Garvey and that the club was ready to start making other plans. Talks between the parties broke off late Saturday night after reports that an agreement was imminent.

title: ISRAELIS GIVE WAY IN DISPUTE ON SITE OF LEBANESE TALKS
description: Israel today dropped its insistence on Jerusalem as a site for talks on security arrangements with Lebanon, thereby removing a major obstacle to direct negotiations aimed at the withdrawal of Israeli forces. Israeli officials said they hoped the talks could begin in the next few days.

title: CUOMO HAS PLANS ON TRANSIT FARE THAT HE HOPES CAN END DEADLOCK
description: With tonight set as the deadline for keeping the current New York City and suburban commuter transit fares, Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that he was prepared to step in with compromise proposals that he hoped would resolve the deadlock over transit financing in Albany.

title: GERMAN SOCIALISTS WIN IN HAMBURG
description: In the first test of opinion since the formation of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's 11-week-old coalition Government, the opposition Social Democratic Party won an unexpected victory today in elections to the state legislature in Hamburg.

title: Swiss Skier Wins For the First Time
description: Conradin Cathomen, a 23-yearold Swiss skier, scored his first World Cup victory today by outracing two Austrians in a men's downhill event.

title: Iraq Says Its Soldiers Killed 48 Iranians in Last 24 Hours
description: Iraq said tonight that its forces had killed 48 Iranian soldiers and wounded many more in the last 24 hours.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 20, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WEEKEND PASSES UNEASILY FOR MOST FEDERAL WORKERS
description: Hundreds of thousands of Federal workers faced possible furloughs Monday because of the continued deadlock over spending legislation to keep the Government running.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1982; Companies
description: Mesa Petroleum offered $40 a share, or $520 million, for 13 million shares of General American Oil of Texas. General American said the offer was not expected. (Page D1.)

title: Dailey Returning to Bulls
description: Quintin Dailey, the rookie guard, will return to the Chicago Bulls Monday after a 12-day leave of absence for psychiatric treatment.

title: Pilot Lost as Plane Falls Into Reservoir in Jersey
description: A single-engine plane crashed into the Wanaque Reservoir Saturday evening, and so far no survivors have been found, the police said yesterday.

title: 5 Israeli Students Are Killed As West Bank Bus Overturns
description: A bus carrying high school students on a tour overturned on a winding mountain road in the Israeli-occupied West Bank today, killing five passengers and injuring the other 24, the Israeli radio reported.

title: Advertising; Doyle Dane Cigarette Ban Ended
description: DOYLE Dane Bernbach has accepted the assignment of Parliament cigarettes from the Philip Morris Company, ending an agency ban against such advertising that had been in effect for at least a decade.

title: Undiplomatic Ambassadors
description: It is rare, and usually unwise, for ambassadors to lecture governments in public, either their own or their hosts'. Diplomacy is an art of discretion that should save its bluntest language for the most private communications. But this rule was twice broken recently in regard to Central America, with at least the possibility of salutary effect.

title: Israel Puts Restrictions On a West Bank Town
description: The Israeli Army placed restrictions on a town and refugee camp in the occupied West Bank today after border policemen fired into the air to disperse stone-throwing demonstrators, the army radio said.

title: Florida 84 Florida State 63
description: Vernon Delancey scored a game-high 29 points and Ronnie Williams added 19 as Florida had little trouble with the Seminoles, who were playing without their star, Mitchel Wiggins, who is suffering from mononucleosis.

title: New Charges Are Made Against Ex-Bonn Aide
description: The weekly Der Spiegel published new allegations today against former Economics Minister Hans Friderichs in connection with tax exemptions for a major private holding concern.

title: Bach Marathon on WKCR
description: FM, the radio station of Columbia University, is presenting 171 hours of the music of Bach around the clock through Dec. 26. This annual festival is commercial-free and includes rare recordings, live performances and discussions. Every night at 8 there will be a special program, the last one, on Christmas Eve, a tribute to the late Glenn Gould.

title: RHODES SCHOLARSHIP WINNERS INCLUDE THE FIRST FROM CITY U.
description: Raymond P. Paretzky, a student at Queens College, remembers hearing of the Rhodes Scholarships for the first time about two months ago, when Robert Picker, chairman of the school's department of Romance languages, suggested that the student try to emulate the professor.

title: LINE IS BETTER WITH AGE
description: SAN DIEGO THEY have this pact: That they will all play until they are 40 years old and then retire. Or, maybe, they won't retire at 40. If Russ Washington, Doug Wilkerson and Ed White can maintain their current level of play, why should they retire?

title: MUSIC: A WAVERLY PAGEANT
description: THE Waverly Consort's ''Christmas Story'' at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin on Thursday night mixed the 12th, 13th, 14th and 15th centuries into a pastiche of Christmases past. Still, there was a devoted unity of mood to this multistyle Nativity play - a oneness born of reticent good taste and ardent musicianship.

title: STEELERS FALL AGAIN, TO BROWNS
description: A quarterback making his first start in the National Football League, Paul McDonald, and a running back signed as a free agent three weeks ago, Johnny Davis, played key roles in the Browns' 10-9 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday in Cleveland.

title: EARLY APPLICANTS DOWN AT COLLEGES
description: As private colleges wind up their most active recruiting season in years, students are showing an unusual degree of caution before committing themselves to college careers at expensive, four-year institutions.

title: Another Loss for Kelley
description: MOST of the game seemed to belong to Brian Kelley, the Giants' 31-year-old linebacker, who had two interceptions and who had tackled John Riggins of the Washington Redskins for a 1-yard loss on fourthand-inches with only five and a half minutes remaining. But when the Giants lost, 15-14, on Mark Moseley's 42-yard field goal with only four seconds remaining, the game no longer belonged to Brian Kelley, who now was suffering from the 95th regular-season loss against only 45 victories in his 10 seasons.

title: Lakers 110 Mavericks 108
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, sidelined for two games with a sinus infection, returned and produced his best game of the season, scoring 33 points and grabbing 17 rebounds to lead a Los Angeles comeback.

title: Wanted: A Center
description: Two years after his Washington Bullets won the National Basketball Association championship, Coach Dick Motta resigned in 1980 following a disappointing season in which the Bullets won only 39 games and lost 43.

title: 150 Silos in Michigan Tainted With PCB's
description: At least 150 silos storing feed in Michigan are contaminated with PCB's, suspected carconigens, according to a state Department of Agriculture study.

title: Gypsy Moth Yacht Breaks Up On Rocky Coast of Australia
description: Gypsy Moth V, the yacht that carried Sir Francis Chichester on his second round-the-world voyage in 1971, was being broken up by rough seas today after foundering on a rocky coast during a race, its skipper reported.

title: EDITOR DEFENDS ROCKLAND NEWSPAPER'S ROLE IN BRINK'S CASE PUBLICITY
description: An editor who supervised articles on the Brink's murder and robbery case in the Rockland Journal-News, which were cited as a reason for moving the trial elsewhere, says that the amount of coverage was largely determined by the extent of public concern about the crime.

title: Something Different
description: The Delaware Water Gap Kennel Club, whose all-breed dog show begins today at Lehigh University's Stabler Arena in Bethlehem, Pa., wanted to come up with something different in trophies for winners in the draw of 1,404 dogs at the nation's 916th and final show of 1982.

title: MONEY BILL DECKED WITH MANY 'PLUMS'
description: Members of Congress, busily representing the interests of their constituents, have been packing special provisions into the stopgap spending bill, making it a vehicle for all sorts of policy decisions, big and small.

title: CRITIC HAD ACERBIC VIEW OF POLITICS
description: Dwight Macdonald, the author, essayist, editor and gadfly critic of books, films and politics, died yesterday at Metropolitan Hospital of heart failure. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Kimberly A. Shanahan Wed to Renaud Callet
description: Kimberly Anne Shanahan, daughter of Mrs. Reynolds C. Springborn of New York and William S. Shanahan Jr. of New York and Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Renaud Callet, son of Mrs. Andre Allary of Neuilly-sur-Seine, France, and the late Pierre Callet. The Rev. F. Reid Isaac performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: AVANT-GARDE: COMPANY
description: AS a rule, there were no rules in the music that the group called Company played at Roulette. The improvising ''workshop'' organized by the guitarist Derek Bailey included seven musicians Thursday, when it opened a three-night stand.

title: Amerasian Children Stop Off in Hong Kong
description: Twenty-two children fathered by Americans during the Indochina war arrived in Hong Kong today. The children are the third such group to be flown from Vietnam for homes in the United States this year.

title: Letter: On Prizefighting Don't Ban Boxing
description: To the Editor: With regard to your Nov. 17 editorial on boxing, ''Brain Beating Is No Sport,'' I thank you for your kind words about the New York State Athletic Commission and the fact that we have led the way by insisting that brain trauma kits be available at every match and by making mandatory the use of thumbless gloves to prevent eye injuries. The commission, established by state statute more than 60 years ago, has always been the leader in safety measures to protect the boxers it licenses and regulates.

title: Miami Bootleg Market Found in Haitian Aid
description: Food sent to Haiti through the United States foreign aid program is routinely smuggled back to the United States and sold at a profit to the Haitian exile community in Miami, The Miami Herald reported today.

title: In THE WINGS, IF REAGAN DOESN'T RUN
description: What would happen in the Republican Party if President Reagan decided not to seek a second term? For several weeks, White House aides have been fighting to stifle the speculation raised by this question. But Mr. Reagan's refusal to send an unequivocal signal about his plans has created a stir of submerged political activity among some prominent Republicans who might run if Mr. Reagan stepped aside.

title: A Question of Faith
description: A petition has been filed by the American Jewish Congress with the United States Supreme Court, asking for a review of a decision by a United States Court of Appeals that in effect bans the wearing of yarmulkes (skullcaps) by high school basketball players. The Court is expected to decide next month or in February whether to review the case.

title: Houston Names Comissiona
description: Sergiu Comissiona has been appointed music director of the Houston Symphony Orchestra. The Bucharest-born Mr. Comissiona, who has served as music adviser in Houston for the last three seasons, becomes music director-designate next season, formally assuming his new title with the 1984-85 season. He will resign as music director of the Baltimore Symphony at the close of next season.

title: J.S. GAZIANO, TYCO EXECUTIVE
description: Joseph S. Gaziano, board chairman and chief executive officer of Tyco Laboratories of Exeter, N.H., died Friday of cancer at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Epping, N.H.

title: Peso Curbs Are Eased By Mexico
description: Mexico's central bank today announced a sharp devaluation of the peso, effective Monday, for transactions in the controlled market.

title: A DISPUTE ARISES ON SILENT PERIOD VOTED IN TRENTON
description: A legal and political dispute has arisen over whether the Attorney General of New Jersey must defend any court challenges to a new law requiring a daily one-minute period of silence in New Jersey public schools.

title: Military Analysis
description: Military planners in Washington, at Atlantic alliance headquarters in Brussels and, it is reported, in Moscow are concerned over what they view as the possibility of a crisis in Iran once Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's rule ends.

title: U.S. Judge Clears Way On Another Wilson Trial
description: A Federal district judge on Saturday cleared the way for the trial of a former agent for the Central Intelligence Agency, Edwin P. Wilson, and two other people accused of conspiring to smuggle more than 20 tons of explosives to Libya in 1977.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have 111 ideas, but you don't address them until you have to'' - Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo on transit fares. (A1:4.)

title: NETS' O'KOREN BACK IN HIS FAVORITE ROLE
description: On Satuday night, Mike O'Koren had visions of the past, of the days during the 1981-82 season when he was the Nets' first player off the bench -their sixth man. His role was a very important one, especially when Albert King, the team's starting small forward, was struggling.

title: Commodities; Options On Farm Products
description: AMONG the bills awaiting the President's signature this morning is a measure with a rider that could dramatically alter the way agricultural commodities are traded on commodities exchanges.

title: FUEL TANKS EXPLODE OUTSIDE OF CARACAS KILLING AT LEAST 32
description: Two oil and gas storage tanks exploded today at a power plant near here, killing at least 32 people and burning hundreds of others in a fire that raced across a half-mile of ground, the Caracas Electricity Compaany reported.

title: New Offerings For the Week
description: Lack of investor demand and large financings by the Treasury are inhibiting sales of new corporate and tax-exempt issues in the last two weeks of the year. Although it is possible that investment bankers may decide to bring a few modest issues to market this week, they have not scheduled any major sales.

title: BUSINESS PLAN HOLIDAY SCHEDULES
description: This year the calendar has conspired to take away two traditional holidays for most workers, Christmas Day and New Year's Day, which both fall on Saturdays. But what the calendar has taken away, most employers seem inclined to give back, in one way or another.

title: No Headline
description: Devils Defeat Jets, 3-2, on Marini's Goal

title: BOSTON BANKS AND MUSEUM REACH ACCORD
description: A $3 million antique collection, including vintage cars and more than 100 fire hats belonging to the late Arthur Fiedler, the conductor of the Boston Pops, has been saved from foreclosure by an agreement between the local Museum of Transportation and its banks on paying off loans.

title: WIFE OF DISSIDENT ACCUSES SEOUL
description: The wife of Kim Dae Jung, the most prominent South Korean opposition politician, says that authorities here are ''forcing'' her husband into political exile against his will.

title: N.A.B. Campaign Focuses on Productivity
description: The Japanese will be the role models in a new public service advertising campaign aimed at increasing productivity of American workers. The campaign, being sponsored by the National Association of Broadcasters and scheduled to begin running on Christmas Day, was prepared by Trout & Ries.

title: NICARAGUA'S NO CUBA
description: Conventional wisdom has it that Nicaragua is a carbon copy of Cuba. It is not. To be sure, there are similarities, especially in the revolutionary trappings and governmental organization. Some of the nine ruling Sandinist leaders are almost amusing in their efforts to ape Fidel Castro, and certainly there are all too many Cuban advisers around.

title: No Headline
description: Sampson Returns And Paces Virginia

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE CAMPAIGN MADE IN U.S.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Pistons Top Celtics
description: Isiah Thomas scored 32 points and Bill Laimbeer contributed 21 tonight as the Detroit Pistons rallied in the fourth period for a 131-114 victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: THE MIDEAST PEACE WASHINGTON WON'T BROOK
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: But No Partridges In Pear Trees Were Seen

title: CORRECTION
description: The commodities column in Business Day on Dec. 6 incorrectly reported a record level of copper inventories in London Metals Exchange licensed warehouses. The record was 645,300 tons, in 1978.

title: STUDY SAYS MORE U.S. AID MAY HURT PUBLIC WORKS
description: If the Federal Government spent more on crumbling public facilities, an Administration study says, state and local governments would probably spend less. One result, it said, would be that the country's highways, bridges, rails and water systems would wind up in worse condition than they are now.

title: Salnikov Swims To 2 More Marks
description: Vladimir Salnikov of the Soviet Union cut six seconds off his 1,500-meter freestyle world record at the European short-course championships today, clocking 14 minutes 37.60 seconds.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Baby's First Christmas

title: FALCONS SET BACK 49ERS, 17-7
description: William Andrews accounted for 176 yards rushing and receiving, and the Atlanta defense stymied Joe Montana as the Falcons beat the San Francisco 49ers, 17-7, tonight.

title: China Plans on 4% Economic Growth in 1983
description: China announced today a target of 4 percent economic growth for next year. It is planning for higher agricultural output and a sharp rise in the production of some consumer goods.

title: News Analysis
description: The on-again, off-again deliberations of the President's panel on Social Security have generated not only some light about the program's financial problems but also a good deal of heat, verbiage and confusion.

title: 5 Die in Chicago House Fire
description: Five children died Saturday in a house fire that began while their 14-year-old baby sitter was cooking french fries, the authorities said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Greetings Corp. said its board had recommended a 2-for-1 stock split subject to shareholder authorization of a 100 percent increase in shares at a special meeting on Jan. 31.

title: PARCELLS SIDELINES NEW ROLE
description: WASHINGTON WHEN the Giants lost to the Redskins here yesterday, Bill Parcells was the defensive coordinator for the Giants, and Ray Perkins was the head coach.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AMERICAN IN PARIS

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in SportsMonday yesterday about the International Professional Ice Skating Championships incorrectly suggested the rarity of the $100,000 in prize money offered there. Such sums, or more, have been offered at other figure skating events in the United States, most recently the World Professional Figure Skating Championship held last Friday in Landover, Md.

title: A Tough Proposal
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's recruiting committee, headed by Commissioner Bob James of the Atlantic Coast Conference, will recommend to the N.C.A.A. convention in San Diego next month that only people employed by a college be allowed to have face-to-face meetings with athletic recruits. The recommendation, the latest of a number of ideas that are being advanced so that the convention can consider ways of stemming recruiting abuses, is considered extremely tough, however, and its chances of adoption are not good.

title: STUDY SUGGESTS VIGOROUS EXERCISE REDUCES RISK OF SUDDEN DEATH
description: IT is part of conventional health wisdom that habitual exercise helps guard against death from heart disease, but this knowledge does not answer an important related question: Is really strenuous exercise a good defense against sudden death from heart attack? According to newly published research, it may indeed provide that kind of protection.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1982
description: International OPEC ministers failed to agree on the key issue of production ceilings for members of the oil group at a two-day meeting in Vienna. Some industry observers at the conference said a decline of oil prices early next year now seems likely. (Page A1, Column 4.) The ousted Nicaraguan Ambassador to the United States said his country was threatened by a ''leftist dictatorship'' that censored the press and curbed political freedoms. (A1:3-4.)

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $207,000 for the qr and $667,000 for the 6 mos and again of $296,000 for the 6 mos on the extinguishment of debt...C-Including tax credits of $89,000 for the qr and $128,000 for the 6 mos

title: Diesel Car Sales Off
description: Sales of diesel-powered cars will fall to an estimated 360,000 in the United States this year, down 31 percent from 1981's record of 520,365, an industry trade journal reported today. Ward's Automotive Reports said the sales will probably climb to between 375,000 and 400,000 next year if there is a moderate recovery in total car sales.

title: IN A NATION OF EQUALS, DIFFERENCES ABOUND
description: To the Editor:

title: AS A CHILD RUNNER WON BIGGEST EVENT
description: W hen Jeanette Bolden thinks about her childhood, her memories do not include much about running. Her running memories are being manufactured now. She was a member of the United States Olympic team that boycotted the 1980 Moscow Games. Within two years she expects to compete in the Los Angeles Games, not far from where she grew up, and have the opportunity to win a medal and be remembered as someone special. When she was growing up, all she wanted was to be like everyone else.

title: NICARAGUA'S EX-ENVOY CALLS 'LEFTIST DICTATORSHIP' A THREAT
description: Francisco Fiallos Navarro, who was removed over the weekend as Nicaraguan Ambassador to the United States, said today that his nation was threatened by a ''leftist dictatorship'' that censored the press and limited political freedoms.

title: BRITAIN VOWS AN INQUIRY ON FERRY
description: The Government promised an investigation today into complaints of missing life jackets and jammed lifeboats aboard a ferry that sank after a collision in the icy North Sea, killing five people.

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
China's Premier in Egypt At Start of African Tour
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China arrived here today at the start of a 10-nation, monthlong visit to Africa and immediately met with President Hosni Mubarak.

title: DEFT MOVE FROM ICE TO BOOTH
description: E d Westfall, who is 42 years old, and Phil Esposito, who will be 41 in February, both played hockey virtually full time from childhood until their professional careers ended. Neither had any broadcasting education, and the opportunity to enter that field came only because they are former players. But they were intelligent enough not to rely solely on their hockey expertise to carry them in their new profession.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Reversing a decision he made during training camp, Coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears has chosen to waive the place-kicker John Roveto and replace him with Bob Thomas, whom Roveto had beaten for the job. ... Emile Francis, coach and general manager of the St. Louis Blues, says he will wait a while longer before resuming his duties behind the bench. Francis, seeking to reverse the Blues' poor play, turned the job over to Barclay Plager last week and said then that he would return tonight.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues.

title: Judge Drops Indictments In Pornography Case
description: A Federal district judge dismissed all 14 indictments today in a Federal Bureau of Investigation pornography inquiry here, saying the cases had been partly tainted by evidence that a key investigator confused his real identity with his undercover identity.

title: CONCERT: CHUNG TRIO
description: CHAMBER music is supposed to be metaphorically familial - musicians so welded together in temperament and technique that they play as one. But the Chung Trio's concert last night at Carnegie Hall was literally familial, in that all three Chungs are siblings. Their complementary musical sympathies were remarkable, and all the more remarkable in that each has built an international solo career, and that they play instruments - violin, cello and piano - that form a common but often difficult combination.

title: SANTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Germans Protest Acquittal Of Two in War Criminal Case
description: Spectators in a West German courtroom protested today when judges acquitted two former Nazis charged with complicity in the murder of 9,000 Soviet Jews during World War II.

title: 78-Pound Bass Is a Record
description: The International Game Fish Association said yesterday that it was mailing a letter to Albert McReynolds of Atlantic City telling him it had certified a striped bass he caught as an all-tackle world record.

title: Guatemala Would Meet Kidnappers' Demand
description: The Guatemalan Government said today it would allow relatives of the kidnapped daughter of the Honduran President, Roberto Suazo Cordova, to publish a rebel propaganda statement if the woman was released first.

title: Hearing Is Held On L.I.R.R. Pacts
description: The Long Island Rail Road and several unions outlined their positions on contract negotiations at a hearing yesterday before a Presidential Emergency Board.

title: MODELS AT HOME: THE LOOK IS THIER OWN
description: Their lissome bodies glide down the runways, their beautifully boned faces punctuate the pages of glossy magazines. As if the physical attributes are not enough, there are the clothes -absolute perfection billowing on a mountaintop, slinking through a nightclub, draped sinuously on a beach, striding along Fifth Avenue. Oh, to look so divinely right!

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The 1981 results in both periods include a gain of $248,000 from the sale of a plant

title: Swiss Bar Rumanian Prelate Ordered Ousted From the U.S.
description: The Swiss Justice Ministry said today that entry had been refused to Patriarch Valerian Trifa, head of the Rumanian Orthodox Church abroad, who has been stripped of United States citizenship and ordered deported.

title: Treasury Rates Show Decline
description: The Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday produced moderately lower average rates. On the three-month bills, the average rate was 7.857 percent, down from 7.995 a week ago, while that on the companion issue slipped to 8.104 percent, from 8.205 percent.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt BEYOND GREED. By Stephen Fay. 304 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $15.95.

title: Tulane Names English
description: Wally English, the man in charge of the Miami Dolphins' passing game, has been named head football coach at Tulane, replacing Vince Gibson, who resigned last month. English originally said he would be commuting between Miami and New Orleans so that he could fulfill his commitment to the Dolphins and also handle the recruiting chores that will be a big part of his new job.

title: DALLAS WONDERS IF IT'S TOO BIG FOR ITS COUNCIL
description: As political maneuvering begins here for a mayoral election in April, the dominant issue so far has not been the candidates, but whether the city's political structure has changed as much as Dallas has.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Food for Thought

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 6
description: B-Including capital gains of $160,000 for the latest 9 mos and $830,000 for theyr-ago 9 mos

title: Mira Zakai Appears In First Recital Here
description: Mira Zakai, a contralto from Israel with wide experience on the international orchestra circuit, made her first appearance as a recitalist in New York on Sunday night. Her program at Alice Tully Hall was short on vocal display for its own sake but long on musical difficulty and deep seriousness - with songs by Brahms, including the ''Vier ernste Gesange,'' and Schumann's Liederkreis (Op. 39).

title: PATIENT IS RELIEVED BY ARTIFICIAL JOINTS
description: In the last 18 months, Russie Berndt has been given an artificial hip, an artificial wrist, an artificial elbow and two artificial finger joints.

title: PATIENCE PAYS FOR MCDONALD OF BROWNS
description: Just as he had at the University of Southern California, Paul McDonald watched, waited and learned for two years before he was given the chance to start a game at quarterback for the Cleveland Browns. Coach Sam Rutigliano made the decision last Friday morning and later told the team that McDonald, not Brian Sipe, would start against the Pittsburgh Steelers at Cleveland on Sunday.

title:
EDUCATION;
AN UNORTHODOX COLLEGE SURVIVES ITS IMAGE
description: OLYMPIA, Wash. EVERGREEN State College's methods and atmosphere have been described as ''survivors of the 1960's,'' born of the the turmoil and educational reformism of the day.

title: Slater, Hanft Gets Bic Pen Account
description: Slater, Hanft, Martin, two years old and billing around $25 million, has been named agency for the Bic Pen Corporation, which puts its ad budget at some $10 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Celebrating the Solstice

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Big '82 Loss Seen By Allis-Chalmers
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, which reported a loss of $28.8 million in 1981, said it expects to report a 1982 loss of between $190 million and $200 million.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ISRAELI OUTLINES TERMS FOR A LEBANON SECURITY ZONE
description: The 25-mile-deep security zone that Israel wants in southern Lebanon would be off-limits to all artillery, rocket launchers, antiaircraft missiles and fortifications of the Lebanese Army, a senior Israeli official said today.

title: 3 Die on Slippery Roads In Snowfall in the East
description: By The Associated Press Autumn got in its last licks and dropped snow across parts of the East and New England, leaving three people dead on slippery roads and as much as eight inches of snow piled up yesterday in West Virginia's mountains.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 21, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Fund-Raising Bid By Dome Holders
description: A committee of shareholders seeking changes in the debt restructuring plan of Dome Petroleum Ltd. has begun an campaign to attract funds to aid its lobbying efforts.

title: TEXAS ENERGIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A TIME FOR LIGHTS IN SUBURBIA
description: White Plains Post Road is aglow this holiday season with the festive brake lights of motorists happening upon the megawatt wonder that is the Prisco family's outdoor Christmas display.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Galaxy Carpet Mills Inc. announced a 5-for-4 stock split of its common stock, to be effected through a 25 percent stock dividend to shareholders of record Dec. 29, and said it intends to make a public offering in early 1983 of 275,000 shares of common stock.

title: WHAT THEY WANT FOR CHRISTMAS
description: Some prominent Washingtonians were asked what they wanted for Christmas. Cosmic wishes, such as peace and happiness for all mankind, although commendable, were not encouraged. A selection follows:

title: AFGHAN IS ADAMANT ABOUT FIGHTING ON
description: Babrak Karmal, the Afghan leader, said today that there would be no compromise with the guerrillas and that Soviet troops would remain until the rebels gave up or were defeated.

title: Rangers Defeat Penguins
description: Rangers 6 Penguins 3 By ALEX YANNIS

title: ITALY PURSUES BULGARIAN INVESTIGATION
description: Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo said today that the Government wanted to make clear to Bulgaria ''Italy's determination to pursue with all means the objective of guaranteeing its internal security'' and of ''combating efficiently subversive foreign plots.''

title: No Headline
description: E.P.A. LIST OF 418 TOXIC WASTE SITES

title: PRESIDENT DECIDES TO SIGN FUNDS BILL DESPITE LOSS OF MX
description: The White House announced shortly after midnight that President Reagan would sign an emergency spending bill to provide money for a large segment of the Federal Government that technically ran out of funds at midnight Friday.

title: German Defector Convicted
description: A former East German border guard who killed a fellow soldier while defecting to West Germany on May 5 was convicted of manslaughter today. Klaus Decker, the 19-yearold guard, was sentenced to five years in a juvenile correction institution.

title: Steel Output Up 2.9%
description: Steel production rose to 1,057,000 tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 2.9 percent from the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 35.8 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 34.7 percent in the previous week.

title: NEW YORK AND JERSEY LEGISLATURES ACT IN STRUGGLES ON BUDGET
description: A bill that would have increased New Jersey's income tax for people earning more than $50,000 a year was approved by the Legislature tonight, but Governor Kean vetoed it minutes later.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TRIES A NEW BLACK CURB
description: New efforts to reduce the number of black workers allowed in municipal neighborhoods at night are reported under way in the major cities of South Africa.

title: STOP POL POT
description: To the Editor:

title: 'After the Miracle' Closes
description: ''Monday After the Miracle,'' a sequel to ''The Miracle Worker'' by William Gibson, closed after Saturday evening's performance at the Eugene O'Neill Theater. Directed by Arthur Penn and co-starring Jane Alexander and Karen Allen, the play ran for seven performances and nine previews.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: Yr-ago 9 mos results have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: A Talk With the King
description: One of the more interesting conversations of our era will occur today when King Hussein of Jordan calls on President Reagan. The King will say he is ready to make peace with Israel on Mr. Reagan's terms if only the United States will show it can force Israel to agree. The President will say, or should say, that while he intends to overcome Israel's rejection of his plan, there is only one way to move its people: with a convincing demonstration that the Arabs want to end their 35-year war against the Jewish state.

title: SOME 'PLUMS' FALL FROM MONEY BILL
description: The nine-month appropriations bill approved today by Congress, a 300-page document, is accompanied by a 300-page conference report. Few members of Congress know the details of either.

title: Musica Sacra Performs Handel's 'Messiah'
description: Musica Sacra, under the direction of Richard Westenburg, offered a sinuous rendition of Handel's ''Messiah'' at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday afternoon. Although the conductor has obviously researched the ''Messiah'' carefully, his interpretation is reassuringly quirky.

title: Belzbergs Make Bid For Gas Company
description: The First City Financial Corporation, a Canadian financial services company headed by the Belzberg family, said yesterday that it had offered $48.50 a share, or an indicated $256.1 million, to acquire the Suburban Propane Gas Corporation of Morristown, N.J.

title: Market Place; New Pressure On Utilities
description: WEAK industrial demand. Unseasonably warm weather. Consumers who cannot afford to pay their utility bills. Rising gas prices. All these factors are taking their toll on utilities. And some analysts say the outlook for most utility stocks - both gas and electric - looks rather dim.

title: U.S. SAFETY BOARD CITES CONCERNS ON AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLER TRAINING
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that a special inquiry into the training of air traffic controllers had ''revealed some specific safety problems which the board believes require immediate corrective action'' by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL PORTFOLIO
description: It was an easy decision, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency said, that led to her being cited for contempt of Congress.

title: MONTGOMERY BREAKS OUT OF A JAM
description: PLAYS James Tuite

title: 'GOOD COP, BAD COP'
description: A fter her decisive victory over Chris Evert Lloyd Sunday night, Martina Navratilova knew she could not accept all those cheers for herself. Instead, she turned to the stands and gave credit to ''my good friend, the famous basketball player, Nancy Lieberman.''

title: NEW YORK AND JERSEY LEGISLATURES ACT IN STRUGGLE ON BUDGET
description: The State Senate passed a regional sales tax increase Monday night that Republican legislative leaders said was a way to save the current bus, subway and commuter-rail fares. That tax had previously been rejected by the Democrats, however, and early today both sides met in an effort to find a compromise.

title: NEW YORK CRITICS VOTE 'GANDHI' BEST
description: ''Gandhi,'' the epic biography of the man who led India's struggle for independence, was voted best film of 1982 yesterday by the New York Film Critics Circle. The group voted Ben Kingsley, who plays the title role in ''Gandhi,'' the year's best actor and cited Meryl Streep as best actress for her performance in ''Sophie's Choice.''

title: Only Four Who Qualify?
description: The Commission on Judicial Nomination searched into every nook and niche and crevice in this state and couldn't find a single woman or black or Hispanic who qualified, in the commission's esteemed opinion, to serve on the state's highest tribunal, the Court of Appeals.

title: HANS ULRICH RUDEL, WORLD WAR II ACE DECORATED BY NAZIS
description: Hans Ulrich Rudel, Nazi Germany's most decorated air ace, died here today, a hospital spokesman said. He was 66. Friends said Mr. Rudel had died of a brain hemorrhage.

title: People Express
description: People Express Airlines announced fare increases for flights between Northern cities, effective March 1. New fares will be $35 for peak flights, from $29, and $23 for off-peak flights, from $19, for flights between Newark and Baltimore, Boston, Buffalo, Burlington, Vt., Hartford, Norfolk, Pittsburgh, Syracuse and Washington. The fares between Newark and Columbus, Ohio, will change from $39 at all times to $35 for off-peak flights and $55 for peak flights.

title: Advertising; Nabisco's Musical Logotype
description: AT first you may scoff. Imagine a competition between three ad agencies for the best combination of three musical notes. Having swallowed that, imagine a press party at which the Duke Ellington Orchestra introduces them. ''Much ado about almost nothing,'' perhaps you will say. But then W. Lee Abbott, vice president, marketing services of Nabisco Brands, will bring the entire matter into focus. Those three notes are in fact a new musical logotype for Nabisco Brands, the recently created corporation that resulted from the merger of Nabisco and Standard Brands, the world's fourth-largest food company.

title: ARTHUR RUBINSTEIN DIES IN GENEVA AT 95
description: With all his flair, Rubinstein nevertheless was a pure musician. An appreciation by Harold C. Schonberg, page D22.

title: TOOTSIE TAUGHT DUSTIN HOFFMAN ABOUT THE SEXES
description: While he was preparing to film the movie ''Tootsie,'' Dustin Hoffman spent months learning to transform himself into a credible semblance of a woman for the female character he would play, and doing a succession of screen tests to assess how convincing he looked.

title: PANEL RECALLS SHARON FOR CROSS-EXAMINATION
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon has been summoned before the state commission investigating the killing of Palestinian civilians in Beirut to answer questions from the Director of Military Intelligence, the commission announced today.

title: MOUNTAINS WORLDWIDE IMPERILED AS MAN AND NATURE COLLIDE
description: MOHONK LAKE, N.Y.

title: GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $469,537 from the disposition of real estate and mortgages...C-Including a gain of $62,010 from the disposition of real estate and mortgages

title: DELOREAN ACCUSED OF TIES WITH I.R.A.
description: John Z. DeLorean, who is charged with promoting a $24 million cocaine deal, boasted on videotape that the radical Irish Republican Army would back him in the deal by contributing money and terrorist force, according to Government papers filed today.

title: People Infect Hospitals
description: Hospital-acquired infections are common, debilitating problems that complicate the care of hospitalized patients. To combat these infections, which are sometimes life-threatening, most hospitals routinely take samples of various surfaces and equipment to test for bacterial contamination.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary tax credit...C-Net income

title: OPEC FAILS TO SET QUOTAS ON OUTPUT FOR EACH MEMBER
description: Oil ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended a frustrating two-day conference today unable to agree on the crucial issue of production quotas for individual members.

title: MESA SAYS HOLDER IN GENERAL PUT A $50 VALUE ON ITS SHARES
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company, which has offered to acquire 51 percent of the General American Oil Company of Texas for $40 a share, disclosed yesterday that a foundation set up by General American's founder had expressed an interest in selling its 26 percent stake in the company for $50 a share.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I play the violin. When I tune it I find that the pitch of the strings has ''slipped'' in different ways - one string may still be in perfect pitch, the others flat in different degrees. Why not all the same?

title: Talking Business with Zvi Porath of Elscint; CAT Scanner's New Rival
description: In advanced medical diagnostics, a new generation of technology is competing with the CAT scanner, which has revolutionized medical imaging. Nuclear magnetic resonance, or N.M.R., systems, producing pictures of the body based on the responses of atomic nuclei in a magnetic field, are considered by some experts to be safer and more effective than the CAT scanner. A half-dozen companies worldwide produce one or two of the systems. But only Elscint Ltd., an Israelbased company whose stock is traded on this country's over-thecounter exchange, derives almost all of its revenues from three imaging systems.

title: NEW YORK STATE TO BORROW IN PUBLIC CREDIT MARKET
description: New York State will borrow between $350 million and $500 million in the public credit market next month to pay its bills through the end of March, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said today.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
TEXT OF COMMUNIQUE
description: Following is the text of the communique issued in English today by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at the end of its ministerial-level meeting here:

title: Marvelous Draw
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler's sudden popularity in Massachusetts could make him unpopular with patrons of Fieldborough Travel and Leisure in England.

title: Congress Passes Bill On Radioactive Waste
description: The House gave final Congressional approval tonight to legislation establishing the first national policy for disposal of nuclear waste.

title: FLAWS IN PROCEDURES BLAMED FOR SKYSCRAPER CRANE DEATH
description: Engineering defects and operational errors were blamed yesterday by a review panel for the crane accident on the top of a 44-story midtown Manhattan office building last summer that killed one person and injured 16 others.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP SLIM 0.4%
description: Americans' personal income rose just four-tenths of 1 percent in November from the month before, probably barely keeping up with inflation, the Government reported today. But personal consumer spending rose 1.2 percent in what Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige called ''a good start for the holiday selling season.''

title: ROY WEBB, 94, FILM COMPOSER WHO WAS A FOUNDER OF ASCAP
description: Roy Webb, who helped found the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and wrote several musical scores for movies, died of a heart attack at St. John's Hospital Dec. 10, his family said Sunday. He was 94.

title: Rise Forecast In Car Output
description: Domestic auto production in the first quarter of 1983 is expected to reach 1.4 million cars, up about 35 percent from the million built in the comparable period in 1982, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Central Maine Power Co. said it would ask the Maine Public Utilities Commission for a 14 percent rate increase totaling about $57 million.

title: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a gain of $1,175,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of interestin a partnership...C-Net loss

title: KOCH PREFERS RENEGOTIATING UNION PACTS TO LAYOFFS
description: New York City could avoid laying off thousands of workers if the municipal unions would renegotiate the contracts they recently agreed to, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: CBS to Purchase MGM/UA Titles
description: CBS Inc. and the MGM/UA Entertainment Company announced a definitive agreement for CBS to purchase copyrights for 50,000 music titles owned by MGM/UA.

title: Taste for Salt
description: Although sodium is an essential nutrient, the amount of salt - or sodium chloride - people like in their food appears to be a learned preference. In the United States today, the average level of salt consumption is considered too high for the health of those people who are susceptible to the blood-pressure-raising effects of sodium.

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND RECEIVES GIFTS FROM FIRST-TIME GIVERS
description: Many of this year's contributors to the 71st annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are making donations for the first time.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
TWO GET PRISON IN COMPUTER CASE
description: The two brothers-in-law from Brooklyn who built an obscure company into a huge computer-leasing enterprise and one of the largest business frauds on record were sentenced yesterday to prison terms of 10 and 12 years, respectively, for fraud and conspiracy.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Next Move in Missile Chess
description: At last, after a long year of stalemate, there may be hope for negotiations to limit nuclear missiles in Europe. The Russians, after refusing to budge from unrealistic proposals, now hint that they would cut their medium-range missile force in half if the United States would give up plans to station similar missiles in Europe. It's a welcome, if belated, sign. Whether serious talks can now follow depends on the Reagan Administration. Can it respond with political adroitness, or will it let itself be immobilized by military rigidity?

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
South Africa Inquiry on Death Of Detained White Nears End
description: An inquest into the death of the trade union leader Dr. Neil Aggett, South Africa's first white to die under security police detention, entered its final stages today as Magistrate Petrus Kotze began giving his judgment before a packed Johannesburg court.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
LAID-OFF CITY WORKERS AIDED
description: Governor Carey signed a bill today to permit uniformed-service employees of New York City to receive credit for seniority and retirement for periods on or after July 1, 1975, during which they had been laid off.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART'S LAPSE TIED TO SPEED
description: One possible cause of the failure of Dr. Barney B. Clark's artificial heart last week may have been an ''overzealous'' attempt to make his heart beat too fast, his doctors said today.

title: The Talk of Whitehorse
description: Some of the boys in a saloon here the other night were talking about a local woman who had won $1,800 in a lottery. The consensus was that her decision to put the money in the bank showed a sorry lack of ambition.

title: U.S. WOULD EASE CURBS ON PENSION INVESTMENTS
description: The Labor Department proposed new rules today to allow pension fund managers greater flexibility in investing the $560 billion in workers' retirement funds that they control.

title: Bridge: 6 Established Players Win Hawaii Trip for Pairs Play
description: The most attractive prizes ever offered to rank-and-file tournament players in New York were the target in the district final of the Grand National Pairs Sunday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The first three pairs won a free trip to Hawaii in March to compete in the national final.

title: THE ALIEN ALREADY HERE: INSIGHTS INTO E.T.'S POWER
description: FOR many children, at least, the search for extraterrestrial life may seem superfluous. The Extra-Terrestrial has been among us for some time.

title: A.&P. HAS A PROFIT IN QUARTER
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company yesterday reported a net income of $8.2 million, or 22 cents a share, in its third fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 4. The quarterly profit was the third in a row for the struggling supermarket chain, following years of losses.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York has elected as vice presidents John G. Dockendorff, Frederick J. Meyer, Patricia Reiter and Douglas S. Thomson.

title: Decision File; Bankruptcy Plan Found Wanting
description: Abel Montano is paid $948 a month as a clerk at the World Bank in the District of Columbia. His expenses for himself, his wife and one child are $749 per month, and he owes $31,507 to creditors. So he filed recently for bankruptcy.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: BY last week, even those who had said they would under no c ircumstances buy anything for anyone this year had changed their m inds. On Friday, passers-by applauded the horn quartet perched on t he balcony of Clarence House on 57th Street. Guardian Angels sang c arols in the subways. A few heretics even prayed for snow. The b oldfaced names, however, fled southward. But that didn't stop f ashion for one second.

title: Charles Underhill, 73, Ex-CBS-TV Executive
description: Charles Matthew Underhill, the first program director for CBS-TV, died Friday at his home in Wellfleet, Mass., after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Two Named by Carey Are Expected to Stay
description: Governor Carey's Health and Labor Commissioners, Dr. David Axelrod and Lillian Roberts, are likely to be retained by Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo, officials said today.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
description: B-Including tax credits of $2,830,000 for the qr and $7.8 milli the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: FELDSTEIN DISAGREES ON GROWTH
description: The President's chief economist, Martin S. Feldstein, believes that the economy will grow more slowly next year than other top forecasters in the Administration have predicted, Government officials said today.

title: A NEW SOLAR COLLECTOR HEATS AIR WITH SMOKE
