description: ASOLAR energy converter in which black ''smoke'' absorbs sunlight and heats the surrounding air enough to drive a turbine has been tested by the Department of Energy's Advanced Components Test Facility at the Georgia Institute of Technology.

title: An Appreciation
description: From the very beginning, the career of Arthur Rubinstein followed a consecutive line, and the chances are that in essentials his piano playing changed very little during the years. Rubinstein used to tell reporters that he did not really start to practice until the 1930's; that he was a sloppy pianist before then, relying on personality and temperament. But his earliest recordings do not bear out that statement; and, in any case a few wrong notes, or even handfuls of wrong notes, have nothing to do with a pianist's spirit and imagination.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1982; International
description: OPEC oil ministers failed to agree on output quotas for individual members, ending a two-day conference with only an overall production ceiling. That level was raised to 18.5 million barrels a day, from the largely ignored 17.5 million, and the group reaffirmed its commitment to the $34-a-barrel base price. But without a system to enforce production, analysts were dubious about OPEC's ability to function as an effective bargaining force. (Page A1.) The inability of OPEC to reach an accord on production quotas will mean lower spot oil prices in the coming weeks, analysts said. (D6.)

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS TRY TO BAR OIL INTERESTS IN MONTANA AREA
description: The Montana Wilderness Association has asked the Forest Service to keep oil and gas developers out of a hiking area on the basis of a California ruling that the service's survey of roadless areas was inadequate.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: By FRED M. HECHINGER

title: Photo Examined In Etan Patz Case
description: A photograph of a boy possibly resembling Etan Patz, who disappeared in the SoHo section of Manhattan three years ago, was found earlier this month in Wareham, Mass., the police reported yesterday. The authorities said the photo had been found in the home of a man they arrested on charges of sexually assaulting a minor.

title: NANCY REAGAN HAS SURGERY TO REMOVE A GROWTH FROM LIP
description: Nancy Reagan had a small growth removed from her upper lip today in a minor surgical procedure performed in the White House physician's office, a spokeman said.

title: FLAME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After tax credits of $152,000 for the qr and $733,000 for the yr...C-Net loss

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Banks' Loans Scrutinized
description: The nine largest United States banks have nearly nine times their combined capital in outstanding loans to foreign countries, a House Banking Committee study said today.

title: PASSENGER SAVES BLIND MAN'S LIFE ON IND TRACKS
description: A 29-year-old unemployed father of eight children leaped onto the tracks of a Greenwich Village subway station yesterday morning and saved the life of a 75-year-old blind man who had stumbled and fallen between the cars of a train that was about to pull out.

title: Boy, 13, to Be Tried For Killing Mother
description: A 13-year-old boy who said he shot his mother to death because she insisted that he go to school was judged mentally competent today to stand trial for her slaying.

title: M.T.A. LIMITS SALE OF TOKENS
description: With the future of subway and bus fares still in doubt, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced that it had begun limiting token sales to two to a customer beginning at midnight last night.

title: Stock Distribution By Chrysler Corp.
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that more than 84,500 American and Canadian hourly and salaried workers each received about 74 shares of company stock for the 1982 year of their employee stock ownership plan.

title: Police Officers File Civil-Rights Suit
description: A group of police officers sued New York City yesterday charging that members of minority groups and women were receiving preference for promotion to sergeant in violation of Federal civil-rights laws.

title: Speight Jenkins Named Seattle Opera Director
description: Speight Jenkins, a Texas-born, New York-based music writer, has been named general director of the Seattle Opera, effective Sept. 1. Mr. Jenkins, who will be responsible for planning from the 1984-85 season onwards, has a three-year contract. He succeeds Glynn Ross, who founded the company in 1962.

title: I.R.S. REPORTS IT IS GETTING RESULTS IN NEW ROLE AGAINST DRUG DEALERS
description: The Internal Revenue Service says it is already seeing results from tough new laws giving the tax-collecting agency a major role in the battle against narcotics traffickers.

title: Kellogg Promotes Several Executives
description: The Kellogg Company of Battle Creek, Mich., announced a series of top executive promotions yesterday, including that of Robert L. Nichols to be a vice chairman of the big cereal company.

title: PESO IS DEVALUED STEEP 53%
description: The peso was permitted to float today at 148.50 to the dollar, but banks limited the number of dollars they were willing to sell to each customer.

title: WIDE NEW SEARCH FOR LIFE IN SPACE IS SET TO BEGIN
description: a quest that nearly died under the weight of Congressional criticism - is being revived in a new and vastly improved form. It will be the most sensitive and thorough exploration for life on other worlds ever mounted by man.

title: Icahn Raises Price In Dan River Bid
description: The Icahn Group confirmed it had offered to increase its offer for Dan River shares to $21 each from $18, subject to obtaining the necessary financing and to Dan River's providing access to certain information. The group also said it would now seek all the shares outstanding.

title: SCITEX reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 HANDBOOKS FILL NEED FOR PRINTED INFORMATION
description: FOR all the words that have been processed on personal computers across the land this year, the need for that now ancient sibling, printed information, has not decreased. A whole new industry has sprung up, in fact, purveyors of books that attempt to explain or guide the consumer through the mysterious world of computing.

title: No Headline
description: South Africa Pressing Inquiry Into Bombings

title: 418 TOXIC DUMPS LISTED IN CLEANUP
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today issued a list of the 418 most dangerous hazardous waste sites around the country that are to be cleaned up under the toxic waste law.

title: Sony Profit Off 31.5% in Year
description: The Sony Corporation's profits fell 31.5 percent in the latest fiscal year because of intense competition and the world recession, Sumio Sano, the company's general manager, said today.

title: THESE DAYS, ONE GOES TO A 'CAMP' TO COPE WITH THE COMPUTER
description: Hundreds of thousands of Americans who grew up in the days when the slide rule was the most complex tool they used in school are trying to catch up with the computer revolution that is engulfing their lives, and Larry Bonfoey is one of them.

title: Topics; Dark Times; Bloody Suriname
description: The outside world was caught off guard by the bloodbath that exploded in the South American nation of Suriname earlier this month. According to the military Government, the score or more victims, including most opposition leaders, were shot ''while attempting to escape'' after having been taken into custody for plotting.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for QTr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. StatementNo 52 which increased net income by $227,523 for the qr and $369,067 for the yr

title: FREDERICK EMMONS TERMAN, STANFORD ENGINEER, DIES AT 82
description: Dr. Frederick Emmons Terman, vice president and provost emeritus of Stanford University, a champion of excellence in the training of scientists and engineers and a force behind northern California's electronics industry, died Sunday at his home on the university's Palo Alto campus at the age of 82. He died of heart failure after several years of declining health, the university said.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC. APPOINTS TOP OFFICER
description: Research-Cottrell Inc. said yesterday that Peter J. Gianacakes will become chairman and chief executive officer Jan. 1. Research-Cottrell, based in Somerville, N.J., is an engineering and marketing company.

title: Concessions at Wheeling Backed by Union Chiefs
description: Officials of the United Steelworkers union have overwhelmingly approved wage and benefit reductions at Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel.

title: COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
JETS STILL UNDECIDED ON FUTURE OF LEAHY
description: Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets said today that no decision had been made on whether to try out any kickers to replace Pat Leahy, whose errant point-after-touchdown attempt was so costly in the 20-19 loss to the Dolphins at Miami last Saturday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The love for my people, the reverence for my country and the most elemental sentiment of personal dignity could not allow me to go on representing a Government that has forbidden me to express my ideas and my feelings to the Nicaraguan people'' -Francisco Fiallos Navarro, former Nicaraguan Ambassador. (A1:3.)

title: WOLF, HOWARD B, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $9,778...C-Net income including tax credits of $43,376 for the qr and $88,348 for the 6 mos

title: Girl, 3, Rejoins Family After 10 Months in Van
description: A 3-year-old girl has been reunited with her family after being kidnapped and held 10 months as a prisoner in a van that roamed the city's streets while two men sexually abused her.

title: HEAVY SNOWFALL IN MOUNTAINS SETS MOOSE UPON ANCHORAGE
description: ''We are currently experiencing some difficulties with a large herd of moose in the different parking areas,'' says a memo that Providence Hospital recently distributed to its staff.

title: PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE: A TALE OF TWO FOOD LINES
description: Ronald Reagan's political durability was starkly demonstrated the other night at the outdoor soup kitchen across from the White House. There, the spotlighted splendor of the President's home was a backdrop for the hunkering silhouettes of a long line of the city's down and out, the ''structurally unemployed,'' to use the current bureaucratic moniker.

title: THE SIMPLE TRUTH ABOUT MOSCOW'S AGRICULTURAL POLICIES
description: To the Editor:

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Fire in Boston Subway
description: A small fire broke out this afternoon under a subway car carrying 15 people, causing no serious injuries but forcing evacuation of the train as it pulled into South Station. Service was halted temporarily on a short portion of the Red Line, which runs between Cambridge and Braintree.

title: 3 Children Killed In Rochester Fire
description: Two young boys and a small girl died in a fire today that swept through a building on East Main Street, authorities said.

title: Richard Stoltzman, Clarinetist, in Concert
description: Richard Stoltzman's clarinet tone is so refined, his phrasing so sinuous and his technique so secure, that they conspired to distract him from the music in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: Officer's Gun Kills Wife in Brooklyn
description: The 23-year-old wife of a Brooklyn police officer was killed by a bullet from her husband's service revolver Sunday night as the couple were visiting friends in the Canarsie section.

title: News Analysis
description: From the White House on down, political leaders in the nation's capital are worrying that they seem to have lost control of events in recent weeks.

title: U.N. CHIEF TO HOLD INQUIRY ON RIGHTS IN POLAND
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, over protests from the Polish Government, will begin an inquiry into human rights in Poland on Tuesday, United Nations officials said today.

title: SHERRY LANSING RESIGNS AS FOX PRODUCTION CHIEF
description: Sherry Lansing, the first woman to be president of a movie studio, resigned unexpectedly today, almost exactly three years after her appointment as president of 20th Century-Fox Productions.

title: BURLINGTON SETS OFFER TO EL PASO
description: In a major diversification move, Burlington Northern Inc. said yesterday that it planned to offer $24 a share for up to 25.1 million shares, or just over 50 percent of the El Paso Company, a diversified energy concern whose main business is producing natural gas. If fully subscribed, the offer would be valued at about $516 million.

title: Steelers May Bench Bradshaw
description: Coach Chuck Noll of the Pittsburgh Steelers, although refusing to blame Terry Bradshaw for the team's offensive frustrations, said today that there was ''a possibility'' he would bench the veteran quarterback for next Sunday's game against New England.

title: Yemeni Says 2,800 Died in Earthquake
description: More than 2,800 people died in the earthquake and severe aftershocks in Yemen last week, and it is estimated that 700,000 were driven from their homes, the nation's Prime Minister said today.

title: Harry Glantz, Played Symphonic Trumpet
description: Harry Glantz, first trumpeter with many symphony orchestras, died of a chronic heart ailment Saturday in Bay Harbor, Fla. He was 86 years old and lived in Bay Harbor.

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BRAZIL ASKS $9.6 BILLION FINANCING
description: The Brazilian Government asked the major international banks yesterday for $9.6 billion in medium- and long-term financing to help meet foreign payments. The request, which would increase the banks' exposure to Brazil by 7 percent, came at a meeting at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan.

title: British to Supply 80 Soldiers To Peace Force in Lebanon
description: Britain has decided to contribute about 80 soldiers to the international peacekeeping force in Lebanon, Foreign Secretary Francis Pym told Parliament today.

title: When It Rains ...
description: Professional football fans might have missed eight weeks of games because of the players' strike, but New York area fans, television variety, are getting a chance in the final weeks of the season to make up for part of what they missed.

title: DANCE: MIMI GARRARD MELDS THE LIGHT, BODIES AND PROPS
description: LIGHT, bodies and props are equal, interchangeable quantities in Mimi Garrard's dances. And the new pieces she presented on Saturday in her SoHo loft theater were a provocative blend of the three that at times suggested the understated wit of some Bauhaus movement experiments.

title: FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-AFter a loss of $332,781 from discontinued operations

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WHEN TO ENJOY ART IS TO DESTROY ART
description: To the Editor:

title: Symbol Technologies Names a New President
description: Michael McHale is joining Symbol Technologies Inc. of Hauppauge, L.I., as president and chief operating officer on Jan. 3. Jerome Swartz, 42, a founder of the company in 1979 and its chief executive, said he would concentrate more on product development and advanced planning while Mr. McHale, 43, looks after the day-to-day operations.

title: DARK TIMES; Winter Standstill
description: These days the sun rises late, around 7:19, and sets early, around 4:33. It shortlights the Northern Hemisphere, climbs to its lowest noontime high of the year.

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: B-After a loss of $640,000 from discontinued operations

title: Caribbean Aid Backed
description: The Senate Finance Committee today approved President Reagan's plan for trade help to 23 countries in the Caribbean Basin, but despite intense lobbying by the Administration, the bill's fate was in doubt on the Senate floor.

title: Ford Credit Cuts Rate on Car Loans
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company, the financing arm of the Ford Motor Company, said it had lowered interest rates on car loans by about one percentage point, to about 16.25 percent. Previously, Ford Credit's national average car loan interest rate was 17.25 percent.

title: Robert J. Fitzsimmons, A Partner in Law Firm
description: Robert J. Fitzsimmons, who practiced law in Manhattan for 55 years and was active in a number of philanthropies, died of Alzheimer's disease Sunday at the Neptune (N.J.) Conva-@Center. He was 81 years and lived in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: Dow Off 6.99; Volume Lighter
description: Stock prices ended moderately lower yesterday in slower trading as growing concern over the economy weakened the list. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 6.99 points, to close at 1,004.51. On Friday, the blue-chip barometer rose 21.25 points after having dropped 66 points in the previous seven sessions.

title: POPE URGES RENUNCIATION OF WAR
description: Pope John Paul II today deplored a world that refuses to forswear war. The Pope described 1982 as a year in which ''people have shown that they preferred to use their weapons rather than to try to understand one another.''

title: Experts Predict Prices For Oil Should Fall
description: The inability of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reach a formal accord on production quotas in Vienna will mean lower spot oil prices in the coming weeks, petroleum analysts said today.

title: 10 Thrift Units Acquired
description: Ten savings and loan associations were acquired by other financial institutions in six mergers arranged with the help of $24.2 million in cash from the Federal savings and loan insurance fund, it was announced today.

title: DEATH TOLL REACHES 98 IN BLAZE NEAR CARACAS
description: A fuel-tank fire raged out of control for the second day today in a blaze that has killed at least 98 people and left half of the capital blacked out.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
HORSE RACING: AN INDUSTRY CONFRONTING TRANSITION
description: For the last 30 years, more Americans have attended thoroughbred races each year than baseball, basketball or football games at the college and professional levels. Attendance at the country's 92 sanctioned thoroughbred tracks last year was 56.1 million, and those who went wagered $7.6 billion on the races they watched. But those attendance and betting figures are not significantly higher than they were 10 years ago, and the tracks' operating costs since have increased at inflationary rates. As a result, some tracks have shut their gates permanently, others are perilously near that decision, and the survivors are frantically looking for new ways to promote and present the sport.

title: Norton Unit Sale
description: The Norton Company of Worcester, Mass., said it had agreed to sell its Safety Products division for $50 million to a new corporation in which it will hold a 26 percent interest. Siebe Gorman Holdings P.L.C., a British manufacturer of personal protection clothing, will have a 64 percent interest, and Safety Products management 10 percent, it said.

title: Trimmed Budget Passed in Nassau
description: The Nassau County Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a $977 million county operating budget for 1983 today after cutting $8.7 million from one proposed by County Executive Francis T. Purcell. Mr. Purcell said he would not veto the cuts.

title: HUSSEIN IN TALKS WITH U.S. OFFICIAL
description: King Hussein opened talks with American officials today on the possibility of Jordan's joining the negotiations with Israel and Egypt on Palestinian self-rule.

title: PUBLISHER HEADS MCA GROUP
description: Victor Temkin will resign as president of the Berkley Publishing Group on Jan. 1, 1983, to head MCA's new consumer products group. Peter Israel, president of the Putnam Publishing Group, will also become president of Berkley.

title: Joe Lee Williams, 83, Is Dead; Mississippi Blues Guitarist
description: Joe Lee (Big Joe) Williams, a rambling blues guitarist who wrote ''Baby, Please Don't Go,'' died here Friday at the age of 83.

title: SAL CABLE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DON'T PUSH MISSILES ON EUROPE
description: The Soviet Union seems to recognize that medium-range missiles have long constituted a touchy political issue for Western Europe, but at present the Reagan Administration demonstrates no such understanding. Indeed, by misreading the cards, it is playing into Moscow's hand.

title: REAGAN COMBING MX MISSILE PROVISIONS FOR WAY TO PRODUCE SOME MISSILES
description: The Reagan Administration, trying to recover from Congress's rejection of MX missile production, said today that it was studying MX research money provisions to see whether ''maybe some of it can be used for missile production.''

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks have lost all three of their games with the Bucks, the Central Division leaders.

title: PASSING MARK OF 883 YARDS SET
description: The last time the San Diego Chargers met the Bengals, last January in Cincinnati, the American Football Conference championship was at stake, the wind-chill index made the temperature minus-59 degrees and the Bengals won, 27-7.

title: Kohl, Despite Setback, Is Hopeful on '83 Vote
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he still believed his Christian Democratic Party had a good chance of winning the general election in March, despite losing a Hamburg state election Sunday.

title: AN SOS TO HUSSEIN AND REAGAN: ACT NOW
description: Occupied West Bank - In the aftermath of Israel's unprovoked military invasion of Lebanon and its catastrophic results, the future status of the occupied territories in the West Bank and Gaza is being debated more intensively than ever before. This makes the United States-Jordanian summit talks at the White House today a historic occasion of paramount importance.

title: TV: 'QUIET AS A NUN,' ENGLISH THRILLER
description: PUBLIC television's ''Mystery!'' series is on something of a Roman Catholic theme this season. We've had G.K. Chesterton's Father Brown. Now, in ''Quiet as a Nun,'' beginning at 9 o'clock on WNET tonight, we are getting Lady Antonia Fraser's Jemima Shore, who calls herself an agnostic but who really maintains strong ties to her convent past.

title: Baseball Loses One P. Rose
description: Peter Rose is leaving baseball. Not Pete Rose. Peter Rose. Pete Rose plays first base for the Philadelphia Phillies and earns a lot of money doing it.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Like Father, Like Son

title: NATIONAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SWANTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After tax credits of $61,000 for the qr and $71,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income

title: GASOLINE TAX MOVES AHEAD IN SENATE
description: The Senate early this morning approved an increase in the gasoline tax to finance highway repairs and sent it to a House-Senate conference, but the ultimate fate of the measure remained in doubt. The Senate vote was 56 to 34.

title: Noisy Struggle Over Silence
description: True, New Jersey's new law requiring public schools to start the day with a minute of silence says nothing about religion. Each student is free to use that 60-second span ''for quiet and private contemplation or introspection.''

title: Neill Faces Surgery To Explore Injury
description: The Giants, disappointed by their many letdowns in Sunday's 15-14 loss to the Redskins in Washington, received more bad news today.

title: STOPGAP BILL WOULD AID NEW YORK AREA PROJECTS
description: The stopgap spending bill that gained final passage in the Senate on Sunday would provide funds for many programs in the New York metropolitan area - from money to protect United Nations diplomats to operating funds for centers for the elderly and day-care centers that had been threatened with closings.

title: Johns-Manville Sells Pipe Unit
description: The Manville Corporation, Denver, said its Johns-Manville subsidiary had signed definitive agreements for the sale of its domestic pipe operations to the J-M Manufacturing Company and the J-M A/C Pipe Corporation, which, it said, were formed by an investors group not affiliated with Manville.

title: West German Bomb Blast
description: A bomb damaged a West German police school at Wolfenbuttel, near Brunswick, early today in the second attack on a police building in Lower Saxony within 24 hours, state officials said.

title: Chess:; Sometimes Best Defense Is Very Powerful Offense
description: There are players whose greatest enjoyment seems to come from stubborn defense, but there are times when this indulgence has to be put aside.

title: BRIEFING
description: Vote on the Run

title: No Headline
description: U.C.L.A. (7-0) Wins by 82-68

title: European Car Sales Up
description: Automobile sales in the European Economic Community rose nearly 1 percent this year from 1981 in spite of the economic slump. But 1981 was an exceptionally poor year, with sales just climbing back to their level of five years ago, a spokesman for the community said today. ''The outlook for the European automobile market for 1983 is one of very modest growth with demand in some national markets showing no change or even a slight fall,'' the spokesman said.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
T.W.A. May Face a Strike
description: Negotiators for the Machinists union and Trans-World Airlines resumed contract talks today, less than two days before a union deadline for a strike. The aireline said a strike early Wednesday by 10,000 mechanics, baggage handlers and other service workers could ground its planes for the Christmas rush.

title: CONESCO INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EX-AGENT IS GIVEN 15 YEARS IN PRISON
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent who was convicted last month of smuggling four pistols and an M-16 automatic rifle to Libyan agents overseas, was sentenced today to 15 years in prison and fined $200,000.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
THE LURE OF GENERAL AMERICAN
description: When Algur H. Meadows ran the General American Oil Company of Texas, there was little likelihood that the oil and gas exploration concern would be swallowed up by another oil producer.

title: KARL LAGERFELD, OVER LUNCH
description: Karl Lagerfield is the internationally acclaimed fashion designer, the one with his dark hair pulled back in a ponytail, and he had already described himself as "an image maker" whose job is to project through design whatever his various employers had to say. And he'd have elaborated his disdain for intellectuals but for a knock on the door of his Hotel Pierre suite, announcing the arrival of a waiter with his lunch: a hamburger and several salads.

title: RECESSION'S IMPERFECTIONS AS A 'THERAPY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sri Lanka Controls Extended
description: The Government of President J.R. Jayewardene brushed aside opposition demands today and extended for a further month a nationwide state of emergency imposed in October. The state of emergency, which was due to expire today, was imposed Oct. 20 after a presidential election in which Mr. Jayewardene was re-elected for a second term. The stated aim was to prevent the spread of violence.

title: UMC ELECTRONICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ART'S-WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Covert Operations

title: Dantley's Wrist in Cast
description: The right wrist of Adrian Dantley, the Utah Jazz forward and the National Basketball Association's leading scorer, will be placed in a cast for a week before a determination is made on whether he will need surgery to repair a torn ligament. Dave Fredman, a Jazz spokesman, said Dantley was examined in Hartford yesterday by Dr. Kirk Watson, a specialist, who said that if Dantley was able to play after the cast is removed and he underwent some treatment, it would probably not worsen the injury.

title: THE CLAUDE & GEORGE SHOW
description: George Shultz's first tour of Europe as Secretary of State had a remarkable impact. If he weren't so determined to avoid trumpeting and to mute his public voice to pleasantries, it could be called a triumph.

title: Garvey Agent Sees Padres
description: Jerry Kapstein, the agent for Steve Garvey, conferred tonight with Ballard Smith, president of the San Diego Padres, in a meeting the agent termed ''critical'' to the negotiations to sign the free-agent first baseman.

title: RENT INCREASES ALLOWED FOR $5,000 RESIDENTIAL LOFTS
description: The New York City Loft Board yesterday gave the landlords of about 5,000 residential lofts permission to raise rents on Jan. 1. The increases range between 7 and 33 percent, depending on the date of the last rent rise. But because of a complex formula devised by the board, most increases will be limited to less than 10 percent.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Dark Time at City Hall

title: Braves Sign Falcone
description: Pete Falcone, who left the Mets as a free agent after last season, has signed a two-year, $650,000 contract with the Braves that will reunite him with Joe Torre, the Atlanta manager. The 29-year-old Falcone, a left-hander, pitched for the Mets the last four seasons, three with Torre as his manager. Although Falcone had a record of 8-10 and an earned run average of 3.84 last season, Torre said that he would be given a chance to start.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DOWN UNDER

title: Armco Coal Sale
description: Armco Inc. said it had signed a renewable five-year contract, worth about $200 million if all options are exercised, to sell coal to Electricidade de Portugal. The contract calls for delivery of 3.5 million tons of lowsulfur coal during the life of the agreement, it said.

title: PLANS
description: Atlantic City's municipal and business leaders - ranging from the Mayor to the Superintendent of Schools to the head of this shore resort's casino association - were to begin a two-day meeting today in Maryland to consider proposals to revitalize the city's slumridden neighborhoods.

title: Advertising; Planning For Cable's Acceptance
description: NEXT year could be the year that cable television comes of age and becomes a recognized advertising medium, Kay Koplovitz, president of the USA Network, firmly believes.

title: Colarossi Will Handle After the Fall's Juices
description: Continuing right along with the natural kick, here's an announcement from Colarossi/Griswold-Eshleman in New York.

title: Executive Named To New Conoco Job
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company announced yesterday that Wilfred P. Schmoe would become chief operating officer of its Conoco Inc. subsidiary, a newly created position, in May.

title: IN UNDERDOG'S ROLE, RIZZO SETS PLANS TO WIN 3D TERM AS PHILADELPHIA MAYOR
description: Former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, now cast in the unaccustomed role of an underdog, is planning a campaign that will seek both black and white support and picture himself as a ''stoned-out liberal on human rights'' while still ''hard-nosed on violent crime.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Book Scare In Times Square

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Le Anne Schreiber BREAKING BREAD. The Catholic Worker and the Origin of Catholic Radicalism in America. By Mel Piehl. Temple Uni- versity Press. 296 pp. $19.95.

title: DELOREAN LINK WITH I.R.A. NOT CONFRIMED OR DISPROVED
description: Investigators could neither corroborate nor disprove John Z. DeLorean's contention that the Irish Republican Army was one of his partners in a major cocaine deal, law enforcement officials said today.

title: WINE TALK
description: EXUBERANT bidding at the annual auction of the Hospices de Beaune in France has once again sent prices into orbit for a prized batch of white Burgundy, distorting the Burgundy pricing structure in general and confusing consumers and dealers who use the auction as a barometer of things to come.

title: AUTOBIOGRAPHY IS NEW STAGE IN OLIVIER'S CAREER
description: Laurence Olivier, who up to now has never been known to reveal himself in print, calls his newly published autobiography, ''Confessions of an Actor.'' During a recent visit to New York, he made a small confession about that surprising choice of title: ''The realistic side of my nature observed that the word 'confession' was box office, the word 'actor' was box office - and even the author might be considered 'box office.' The combination of the three, I thought, had a certain ring to it that might sell.'' In other words, in his debut as author, Lord Olivier had his eye on the marquee.

title: THE ART OF TRANSFORMING WINTER VEGETABLES
description: A CARTOON in The New Yorker many years ago depicted a disgruntled little girl confronted with a mysterious substance on her dinner plate. Though assured by her mother that it was broccoli, she remained unconvinced. ''I say it's spinach,'' she insisted, ''and I say the hell with it.'' The child could have substituted any number of vegetables: Parsnips, turnips, rutabaga and squash come quickly to mind.

title: Ticket for Walker
description: Several residents of Greensboro, Ga., offered to pay a $35 traffic fine for Herschel Walker, the University of Georgia's Heisman Trophy winner, after he had been cited for driving 17 miles per hour over the 55 m.p.h. speed limit in their town Sunday. They withdrew the offer, though, when they were told that it would jeopardize Walker's amateur status. Back on campus, Walker learned yesterday that he had become the 46th recipient of the annual Maxwell Award, given by the Maxwell Football Club of Philadelphia.

title: LOUISVILLE DEFEATS N.C. STATE
description: Charles Jones scored 17 points and Jeff Hall came off the bench to provide a second-half spark as Louisville defeated North Carolina State, 57-52, tonight in a nationally televised basketball game.

title: TWO-FOR-ONE AVENUE
description: To the Editor:

title: DELTA PLANS TO LEASE 33 NEW BOEING JETS
description: Delta Air Lines announced a deal yesterday whereby it will lease a fleet of 33 Boeing 737 airliners, said to be worth about $650 million, to be delivered to Delta over the next two years.

title: BUYING A WOK, PLAIN OR FANCY: WHAT TO LOOK FOR AND AVOID
description: THE wok has been the basic Chinese cooking utensil for centuries. And why not? The design of this vessel is simple but superb: its generous, rounded shape permits quick searing of large or small quantities of food by stir-frying; it accomplishes deep frying with less oil than possible in a straight-sided pot; it accommodates steamer baskets of various sizes, and it may even be used to braise or smoke whole fish, chickens or large pieces of meat.

title: WESTWAY'S WELL-SPENT $75 MILLION
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-EDITOR SHOOTS WIFE, THEN HIMSELF
description: A retired Wisconsin newspaper editor and publisher who had been suffering from cancer shot and critically wounded his wife yesterday and then killed himself in their home on a Rockefeller estate in the Adirondacks, the state police said.

title: Dr. Richard Marshak, Radiologist and Teacher
description: Dr. Richard H. Marshak, a clinical professor of radiology and attending radiologist at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died of a heart attack Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DOUGHERTY BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr earnings have been restated to give effect to the 10 percent stock divd on Nov 15, 1982

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
IN CONGRESS, A 'MAN BITES-DOG'STORY
description: With members of Congress loading down the boughs of the legislative tree with local interest ornaments in the special session, Representative Carroll Hubbard Jr., Democrat of Kentucky, stood out recently by killing a proposal to spend $700,000 in his district to acquire the home of Alben Barkley, a former Senate majority leader and Vice President under Harry S. Truman, as a national historic site.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY ANDROPOV ON MEDIUM-RANGE NUCLEAR MISSILES
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet party leader, as translated and distributed by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: El Paso Board Meets Tomorrow
description: The El Paso Company said its board would meet tomorrow to consider the offer of $24 a share for just over 50 percent of its stock by Burlington Northern Inc. El Paso, an energy and chemicals concern, said it would announce whether it would accept the bid at that time.

title: AREA COSTS UNCHANGED FOR MONTH
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area, seasonally adjusted, was unchanged in November following a sharp jump in the previous month.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Trial Balloon on 52d St.

title: Changes Sought In Lobbying Laws
description: The State Attorney General's office and the Election Law Enforcement Commission announced a series of recommendations today designed to tighten New Jersey's lobbying laws.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK PRAISES U.N. VOTES
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate and a frequent critic of the United Nations, said today that ''some real progress'' had been made in the organization toward achieving Washington's objectives.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dial-a-Headache

title: Dailey Excels In Return
description: Quintin Dailey returned from a two-week leave of absence tonight and scored some crucial baskets as the Chicago Bulls scored a 124-116 victory in double overtime against the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Patera Convicted On Driving Count
description: Jack Patera, former head coach of the Seattle Seahawks, was convicted by a six-member jury Monday of driving while intoxicated.

title: WHERE IS REAGAN GOING?
description: President Reagan is in trouble at the end of the Old Year, halfway through his first term in the White House, but it doesn't seem to bother him. He still thinks he can govern the country, and even defend a civilization, with a wave and a smile.

title: BL Car Gets High Mileage
description: BL P.L.C., Britain's Government-owned auto maker, said it had built a lightweight five-seat car that will get 63 miles a gallon in typical driving conditions.

title: Arafat to Visit Moscow
description: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, will visit the Soviet Union in mid-January at the invitation of Soviet leaders, Palestinian sources said today.

title: GARVEY SIGNS PADRE CONTRACT
description: The pursuit of baseball's last major free agent, the first baseman Steve Garvey, ended today when Garvey signed a five-year contract worth a reported $6.6 million with the San Diego Padres.

title: Rodino Assails Inaction On Bankruptcy Courts
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, today assailed the failure of Congress to meet the Supreme Court's Dec. 24 deadline for restructuring the nation's bankruptcy courts.

title: DOUBTS EXPRESSED ON AMERASIAN LAW
description: Representatives of several American voluntary agencies have expressed concern that a new Federal law, meant to let thousands of Asian-born children of American fathers emigrate to the United States, may raise unintended difficulties, especially in the case of Vietnam. The law is due to go into effect on New Year's Day.

title: BRIEFING
description: Making Experience Count

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: HOUSE PANEL CRITICIZES PLAN TO RAISE I.M.F. AID
description: House Republicans and Democrats today criticized Administration plans to increase the financial resources of the International Monetary Fund so that it can help a number of countries meet huge foreign debt payments.

title: USAIR'S HIGH-YIELD STRATEGY
description: Paint is peeling from the walls and the carpeting is a bit threadbare, suggesting the low-budget operation of some struggling, start-up airline.

title: ENERGY METHODS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $65,000 for the latest first qr and $60,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: Monogram Sale To Nortek Inc.
description: Nortek Inc. said it had agreed to buy a 30 percent stake in Monogram Industries for $35.4 million from three Monogram officers and directors and their families. Nortek makes building products and provides textile services. It is based in Cranston, R.I. It said it would propose a combination with Monogram, of Santa Monica, Calif., which makes electrical materials and is active in real estate.

title: DANCE: ETHNIC FOLK CENTER
description: AS spectators took their seats for the program that Erin Matthiessen and Holly Williams presented Sunday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, the dancers were warming up to Christmas carols. And that was most appropriate, for much of the evening was as jolly as a holiday party.

title: Plays
description: A Charger's Big Charge

title: Altman, Stoller, Weiss Expands Mead Account
description: Altman, Stoller, Weiss has obviously been giving good service to the Mead Corporation, because the client has sent new business its way.

title: Republic Steel Recalling Workers
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said it would recall 700 workers at Gadsden, Ala., and 450 at Warren, Ohio, starting Jan. 9.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,658,000

title: ON DASHER! ON DANCER!
description: CHELSEA, as every schoolboy used to know back in the days when they taught city history and not computer languages, is the place where Clement Clarke Moore spent many a night before Christmas. Recently, a Metropolitan Diary reader was heading past the Chelsea Hotel on 23d Street, a quick sleigh ride away from the onetime residence of Bishop Moore, who wrote ''A Visit From St. Nicholas'' in 1822.

title: SENATE SHOWDOWN TO BE THURSDAY
description: As Congress struggled to end its session and go home for Christmas, the Senate agreed just after midnight to hold a showdown vote Thursday on a bill raising the Federal gasoline tax to pay for highway repairs and mass transit.

title: DEVELOPER CONVICTED IN ABSCAM TRIAL
description: A New Jersey real-estate developer, the last defendant to be tried in the Government's undercover Abscam investigation into political corruption, was found guilty last night of bribery and conspiracy.

title: YANKEES TRADE MAZZILLI
description: Lee Mazzilli, who started the year with the Mets, will not end it with the Yankees. Mazzilli, once the favorite of Met fans, confirmed early this morning that the Yankees had traded him to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: WARSAW IS INVESTIGATING WALESA FOR POSSIBLE TAX LAW VIOLATIONS
description: Lech Walesa is being investigated for tax violations during his period as leader of the outlawed Solidarity labor union, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Honey and Sodium
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The attempt of Chinese restaurants to lower the sodium intake of their customers was described in ''Low Sodium Chinese'' (Nov. 24).

title: FOR COLUMBUS IN U.N., A STORMY PASSAGE
description: Even old-timers here were hardpressed to recall another instance when so much had been said by so many to accomplish so little.

title: Surge by Thomas Turns Back Nets
description: Isiah Thomas spent much of the game against the Nets tonight on the bench, and when he was playing, he was performing poorly. But with the game on the line, Thomas scored the Pistons' last 6 points as Detroit defeated New Jersey, 102-97, before 12,081 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: U.N. Council Adopts Arabic as 6th Tongue
description: The Security Council decided today by consensus to include Arabic as its sixth official and working language.

title: KNICKS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: Paul Westphal, beset by injuries, a shooting slump and for a time relegated to fourth-guard status, showed his old form last night and paced the Knicks to a 101-94 overtime victory over the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Albert E. Thiele Is Dead at 90; Guggenheim Brothers Partner
description: Albert E. Thiele, a partner in Guggenheim Brothers, the mining investment and exploration concern, died Monday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 90 years old and also resided in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Neill Undergoes Surgery
description: Bill Neill, the Giants' starting nose tackle, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair cartilage damage in his left knee and will miss Sunday's game at St. Louis.

title: Boston Newspaper Renamed
description: The publisher Rupert Murdoch sealed his purchase of The Boston Herald American Monday, and officials said they would revamp the newspaper, beginning by changing the tabloid's name to The Boston Herald. ''You've been calling us 'the Herald' for years and now we've made it official,'' a message to readers said.

title: Lost Uranium Is Termed Within Limits of Rules
description: A report by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that more than 44 pounds of uranium could not be accounted for at five nuclear complexes around the nation, but officials insisted that none had been stolen.

title: Your Jobs or Your Help
description: In his revised four-year budget message, Mayor Koch has now raised the stakes in New York budget diplomacy by an alarming figure: 8,600 city jobs that will have to be eliminated by attrition and layoffs before July 1. The reduction is necessary, he told the Financial Control Board, because in the month since his last plan he has had to reduce the estimate of likely state aid in the next 18 months by $302 million. The prediction is prudent. Tax collections fall below estimates. Without more state subsidy, a balanced budget for next year needs to cut 3,300 more jobs than attrition could provide.

title: Evans to Stop Homebuilding
description: The Evans Products Company, a construction and building supply company in Portland, Ore., said it would discontinue its homebuilding operations on Dec. 31, resulting in a pretax loss of about $20 million, in addition to $40 million in operating losses already projected for 1982.

title: John Mullen Marries Ann Harper Hellman
description: Ann Harper Hellman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis M. Hellman of Washington and Baltimore, was married yesterday in New York to John Donaldson Mullen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Mullen of Champagne, Ill. The Rev. Carl Nelson performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: BOND SURGE HELPS DOW GAIN 25.75
description: A late rally enabled the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday to soar by 25.75 points, to 1,030.26.

title: Nat S. Finney, Ex-Reporter, Won Pulitzer in Journalism
description: Nat S. Finney, a Pulitzer Prize winning reporter and former Washington, D.C., bureau chief for The Buffalo Evening News, died last Saturday in Washington after a brief illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Panel Asks Investigation Of Legal Board's Fees
description: The General Accounting Office is being asked by Congress to help determine if more than $150,000 in consulting fees paid to board members of the Legal Services Corporation this year ''were justified,'' a subcommittee spokesman said today.

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 13
News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1982
description: International A Soviet arms-reduction proposal was made public by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. Under the plan, Moscow would reduce its mediumrange missiles in Europe from more than 600 to about 162, the number of missiles now maintained by Britain and France, if the NATO allies abandon plans to deploy 572 new medium-range missiles in Europe late next year. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington rejected the proposal on medium-range missiles in Europe made public by Moscow on the ground that it would leave the Soviet arsenal superior to NATO'S arsenal. (A1:5.)

title: DEMOCRATS REACT FAVORABLY TO G.O.P. TRANSIT FARE PLAN
description: Republicans in the State Senate put forward a new tax proposal - a surcharge on taxes on corporate profits - Tuesday night to save bus, subway and commuter rail fares.

title: A TALE OF MONKEY OUTLAWS SPREADS THROUGH CHINA
description: Three outlaws are being hunted down on the heavily forested slopes of Mount Emei for preying on pilgrims and other tourists who come to climb the sacred Buddhist mountain.

title: Clemson to Crack Down
description: Clemson's president, Bill Atchley, said that the school's head football coach, Danny Ford, and an assistant would be dealt ''appropriate penalites'' and that another assistant would be discharged as a result of the recruiting violations that caused Clemson to be placed on probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Mr. Atchley declined to specify the ''appropriate penalties'' or identify the coach who is to be dismissed.

title: Stolen Baby Alligator Is Found Safe in Israel
description: Israel's first baby alligator, stolen from the country's alligator farm in northern Israel Saturday, was found safe at the railroad station in Acre after a telephoned tip, Israeli newspapers reported today.

title: Lisbon Chief Accepts Premier's Resignation
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes accepted the resignation tonight of Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao, ending the 14th Government since 1974, the Prime Minister said.

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AN AFRICAN POET AT NORTHWESTERN LOSES A STEP IN DEPORTATION FIGHT
description: In a letter to Immigration and Naturalization authorities here, the State Department has said it knows of no reason why Dennis Brutus, a black poet in exile for 10 years from southern Africa, should not be deported.

title: HUSSEIN TELLS U.S. HE'S NOT YET READY FOR MIDEAST TALKS
description: President Reagan today renewed his appeal to King Hussein to enter Israeli-Egyptian negotiations on Palestinian self-rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: PLANTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
LEBANON SAYS PULLOUT TALKS WITH ISRAEL MAY START THIS WEEK
description: The Lebanese Government, which wants to negotiate the pullout of all foreign troops from Lebanon as soon as possible, has been told Israel may be willing to start talks in the next three days.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
PARIS AND LONDON SPURN SOVIET PLAN
description: France and Britain quickly spurned a proposal today by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet party leader, to reduce the Soviet Union's medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe to the level of those missiles under the control of Paris and London.

title: New Chief at Ed Libov
description: Avram Butensky, who has been chief operating officer of Ed Libov Associates, the media buying service, has taken over the leadership of the company following the departure of Carmine Cicchino, chief executive, who, the firm said, has left ''for personal reasons and to pursue other endeavors.'' Mr. Butansky, 40, came to Libov from Dancer Fitzgerald Sample as a corporate senior vice president in 1980.

title: Economic Scene; The Recession As Restorative
description: IS this steep and long recession the cure for what ails business? Or is the cure worse than the disease? Subjective answers depend not only on one's social and political philosophy but also on how particular people or groups are affected. For the unemployed the slump is experienced as all cost, no benefit. For some businesses, confronting falling sales and mounting debts, a continuation of the recession can mean unmitigated disaster. But, for most businesses and the economy in general, the recession may be a restorative.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $567,394

title: CHAMBER: THE MUSIC PROJECT
description: ONE of the special pleasures of Sunday's Abraham Goodman House performance by the Music Project was the sensation that the musicians genuinely loved the works they were playing. This small chamber ensemble, now in its seventh season, plays with dedication and enthusiasm; there was at all times a sense of energetic unity.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
JUDGE IN NUCLEAR PLANT TRIAL RESTRICTS EXPERT'S TESTIMONY
description: A Federal district judge yesterday rejected as ''grossly unfair and improper'' an attempt to get a key expert witness to blame the manufacturer of the Three Mile Island reactor for the nuclear plant's 1979 accident.

title: Bond Prices Advance Sharply; Drop in Key Rates Is Cited
description: Bond prices soared and yields sank yesterday after an unexpected drop in key short-term money rates set off bursts of buying. The buying caught many money managers off guard, particularly those who had sold Treasury issues short on Monday to square accounts for the holidays. Their efforts to cover their short positions helped to fuel the advance.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Period Redecorating At City Hall

title: BRIEFS
description: * Brunswick Corp. said it would take a one-time charge of about $37 million against 1982 earnings for costs associated with plant consolidations and closures and related losses.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 4.4 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was down 3.1 percent, or 4.4 million shares, in the month ended Dec. 15, to 135.3 million shares.

title: PATIENT SUPPORTS PIONEER IN ARTIFICIAL ORGANS
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark had one firm message when he met the father of the permanent artificial heart: ''Don't quit.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. At some point I have read or heard of a nutmeg melon. Are you familiar with this term?

title: ARMY IS REVIVING USE OF REGIMENTS
description: The Army has revived an ancient and honored military unit, the regiment, as part of a program intended to stabilize the lives of soldiers in combat units.

title: Fooling the Doctors
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: There are too many cases of patients whose lives were despaired of but who ''fooled the doctors'' to condemn anyone to the verdict that ''all hope for survival is gone,'' as is stated in the Personal Health article of Nov. 24. There is no reason why all the advantages of hospice care cannot be incorporated in a regimen aimed at prolonging the life of a patient: pain relief, homelike surroundings, etc.

title: 3 Killed and 3 Injured In Texas Gas Explosion
description: A small natural gas storage tank exploded in a rush of flames today, killing three oil field workers and injuring three, officials said.

title: UNEASY PEACE COMES TO RURAL GUATEMALA BUT DISQUIET LINGERS
description: The Guatemalan Government has succeeded in bringing an uneasy peace to much of the countryside, where just a few months ago reports of battles with guerrillas and massacres by Government troops were commonplace.

title: Guatemala Authorizes Printing of Rebels' Tract
description: The Guatemalan Government cleared the way today for publication of a statement from the rebel kidnappers of the Honduran President's daughter, the guerrillas' only demand for releasing the woman.

title: REAGAN SIGNS SPENDING BILL DESPITE 'SERIOUS' OBJECTIONS
description: Despite ''serious reservations'' over some of its provisions, President Reagan signed a $379 billion emergency spending bill into law this afternoon.

title: On Her Toes
description: Gene Monahan and Marika Molnar are both athletic trainers. Both work with star performers. But whereas Monahan, the Yankees' trainer, works with outfielders and pitchers, such as Dave Winfield and Ron Guidry, Miss Molnar deals with Peter Martins and Patricia McBride.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The lives of James Reino, Blanche Mishkin, Bernard Jensen and Arthur Levin intersected briefly this week. Mr. Reino is a cabinetmaker who lives in Yonkers and hates to drive in Manhattan. Mrs. Mishkin is retired and lives with her husband in a high-rise building on East 34th Street. Mr. Jensen was born in Iowa but has spent most of his life in New York, working as a letter carrier. Mr. Levin is part owner of a small restaurant that exhibits photographers' work as well as serving cannelloni and pate.

title: Agreement Set At Lloyd's
description: Lloyd's of London said today that agreement had been reached with the committee of Lloyd's that allows WMD Underwriting Agencies Ltd. to resume underwriting immediately on behalf of its syndicates.

title: Braniff Is Allowed To Keep Terminal
description: A Federal judge has upheld a ruling that the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport board cannot evict grounded Braniff International from its terminal, cargo building, maintenance hanger and other facilities.

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Kean's veto on Monday of an income-tax measure passed by the Senate and the Assembly culiminated a yearlong battle between the Democratic-led Legislature and the Republican administration.

title: Bridge:; Rare Score, if Not a Record, Was Achieved in Regionals
description: It is virtually certain that a scoring record was broken Friday night at the New York Winter Regional Championships, but the historical data needed for confirmation are not available.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO SIGN ATOMIC WASTE BURIAL BILL
description: White House officials said today that President Reagan would sign a bill, approved in the waning hours of the postelection session of Congress, calling for radioactive wastes from nuclear power plants to be buried permanently.

title: G.N.P. SAID TO FALL AT A RATE OF 2.2%
description: The nation's economy is continuing to decline in the current quarter, at a 2.2 percent annual rate, Government officials estimated today, indicating that the long-awaited economic recovery will not get going until spring.

title: 2 ON DORMITORY AUTHORITY, UNDER ATTACK, WON'T QUIT
description: Two members of the State Dormitory Authority, whose resignation or dismissal was called for last week by state investigators, said yesterday they would not quit, and the board chairman said he would not dismiss them.

title: Boy, 7, Is Killed In Gun Accident
description: A 7-year-old Brooklyn boy who found a .38-caliber revolver in his apartment was killed when the weapon discharged a moment after he asked his mother if the gun was real, the police said yesterday.

title: DOCTORS TO JOIN SHUTTLE CREWS TO MONITOR MOTION SICKNESS
description: A doctor will be added to two space shuttle flights next year to monitor the crew and to find ways to alleviate what the National Aeronautics and Space Administration calls ''space adaption syndrome.''

title: Potato Pancakes
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Kentucky at Indiana (Television - MSG Cable, 11 P.M., tape). Seton Hall at Villanova, and Colorado at Southern California (Television - USA Cable, 9 P.M. and 11 P.M.).

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1982; The Economy
description: The nation's economy continued to decline in the current quarter, at a 2.2 percent annual rate, Government officials estimated. The drop in the G.N.P., the broadest measure of the nation's economic activity, indicated that recovery would not get going until spring. (Page A1.)

title: JAPAN SAYS SOVIET WILL FREE 29 CAPTURED FISHERMAN SOON
description: The Soviet Union will soon release 29 Japanese fishermen, some of whom have been held for two years, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Synthetic Fuel Unit Is Sold by Exxon
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it had sold a coal liquefaction pilot plant in Baytown, Tex., to Ventech Inc., a private company. The sale continues Exxon's drive to get out of the synthetic fuels business.

title: RETIREES ARE GIVING WHATEVER THEY CAN TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Among those who remember New York's poor through contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are many who have limited resources themselves.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: POP critics spend an unconscionable amount of time thinking about their year-end 10 Best Albums list. They replay favorites from six or eight months ago to see if they still seem to hold up; they puzzle over how to compare a consistently workmanlike album to an inconsistent one illuminated by flashes of brilliance, and they compare choices with friends, musicians and fellow critics. The records that make it to the final list are the ones that sound even better after repeated listenings, records that command intense involvement and offer substantial rewards no matter how many times they are played.

title: No Headline
description: 2 NOMINATIONS LEFT HANGING

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FUTURES COMMISSIONER PLANS TO RESIGN POST
description: James M. Stone, former chairman of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, announced yesterday that he will resign as a commissioner of the C.F.T.C. and return to Boston to establish an insurance company. He is often described as one of the most liberal commissioners of any regulatory agency in Washington.

title: Manufacturers Hanover
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation raised its quarterly dividend yesterday to 76 cents a share from 73 cents, payable Jan. 25 to shareholders of record Jan. 4. The annual dividend is $3.04 a share, up from $2.92.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE are countless dishes that could never be made authentically in an hour. A coulibiac of salmon, for instance, or a good many large roasts and almost all yeast breads. But in some cases, with a little skill and inventiveness, it is possible to turn out quite tasty imitations. I thought of this recently when I was asked by a friend to devise a quick recipe for one of his favorite bourgeois French dishes, a cassoulet. And would I please, he asked, make it to serve 10 guests?

title: U.S. AND ALLIES REJECT PROPOSAL ON MISSILE CUT
description: The Reagan Administration, joined by Britain and France, today rejected the proposal on medium-range missiles made public by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet party leader, on the ground that it would leave the Soviet Union superior to the United States in this field.

title: CHIEF OF WELLS FARGO RESIGNS
description: In a puzzling move, Richard P. Cooley quit suddenly yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of Wells Fargo & Company, which he has headed for the past 16 years. Although the early retirement does not become effective until Dec. 31 the 59-year-old Mr. Cooley left the bank yesterday morning, immediately after a meeting of the board.

title: FOR SUBWAY RESCUER, PRAISE AND, AT LAST, A JOB
description: When Reginald Andrews leaped onto subway tracks Monday to save a blind man who had fallen between the cars of a train, he said all he could think about was that ''somebody needs help.''

title: WAS A BANKER AND ECONOMIST
description: August Maffry, an economist and international banker, died yesterday at a hospital in Cleveland. He was 77 years old. Mr. Maffry, who was born and raised in Macon, Mo., received his bachelor's and master's degrees from the University of Missouri and was awarded a doctorate in economics from that university in 1930.

title: Stern Ingalls Venture Gets Nature's Organics
description: Ingalls Associates of Boston and Nelson Stern Advertising of Cleveland teamed up to win the $8 million account of Nature's Organics Plus, a Paramus, N.J., manufacturer of hair care products.

title: Careers; Job Hunt: Holidays a Good Time
description: WHEN experienced minds agree, their advice is generally worth following. Both an executive of an outplacement firm and the head of a personnel association say that this Christmas season is a good time for middle managers to seek jobs.

title: DETROIT MUSICIANS SETTLE
description: Striking musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra today ratified a new contract that contains a compromise on the key issue of artistic control. The new agreement, which contains a 30 percent pay increase over the next three years, was ratified 87 to 5.

title: 5 Die in Gas Leak at Lodge
description: Five young people who stayed behind after a Christmas party in a hunting lodge died in their sleep today from gas that leaked out of a faulty heater, the authorities said. A sixth person, Robin Rogers, 19 years old, was taken a hospital, where officials said she was listed in critical condition.

title: Lawyer Gets 10 Years In U.S. Judge's Slaying
description: Saying he was sorry and had no excuses for his role in the slaying of Federal Judge John H. Wood Jr., an El Paso lawyer was sentenced today to 10 years in prison for conspiracy in the case.

title: THREE SURVIVORS SAY ISRAELIS WERE IN REFUGEE CAMP
description: Despite official Israeli denials, three survivors of the massacre of civilians in two Palestinian refugee camps here in September insist that some Israeli soldiers were in one of the camps during the killings by Lebanese Christian militiamen.

title: SOUTH AFRICA REACTOR DELAYED
description: The Government acknowledged today that the completion of South Africa's first nuclear power plant would be delayed as a result of a series of bombings over the weekend.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Loses Atlantic City Suit
description: A Superior Court judge today dismissed the last of three lawsuits challenging the city's mayoral election, ending a five-month court battle to overturn the results because of allegations of widespread vote fraud.

title: Index; International
description: A tale of monkey bandits is heard in China A2 Mrs. Kirkpatrick praises the United Nations A3 For Columbus in U.N., a stormy passage A3 U.N. Council adds Arabic as sixth official language A3 Walesa is being investigated for tax violations A4 Around the World A5 Japan says Soviet will soon free 29 captured fishermen A6 Lebanese reports possibility of talks with Israel this week A8 Three survivors say Israeli troops were in refugee camp A9 Doubts expressed about new law on Amerasian children A11 South African police exonerated in white's suicide in custody A12 Excerpts from Andropov speech on nuclear arms A14 Government/Politics Panel urges no-strike guarantee by Legal Aid Society B2 Washington Talk A look at Robert McNamara's re- tirement itinerary B8 A Congressional ''man-bites- dog'' story B8 Required Reading B8 Briefing B8 General Around the Nation A16 Army restoring use of the regi- ment A18 Scarsdale's dog warden killed in crash with stolen ambulance B5 African poet at Northwestern loses round on deportation B9 Judge restricts testimony of ex- pert in nuclear plant trial B11 Ex-publisher shoots wife and kills himself on Rockefeller estate B12 Reagan will sign bill requiring burial of nuclear wastes B15 The Living Section Food Using winter vegetables C1

title: Icahn-Dan River
description: The Icahn Group, which had offered to buy two million shares of Dan River Inc. for $18 each, lowered the minimum number of shares to one million.

title: Required Reading Recalling Burke
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, in remarks before the 20th annual conservation conference of the National Wildlife Federation. Dec. 8, 1982:

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
CAMPAIGN-TECHNIQUE EXPERTS SEE DIFFICULTIES FOR CONSENSUS
description: New political techniques will divide and polarize American voters and make it increasingly difficult to form consensus in government, campaign consultants from both parties said today.

title: Bring Back the Shmoo
description: There is something about the advent of the supermouse that doesn't thrill the heart. Yes, it's wonderful that scientists at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies have succeeded in transferring the growth hormone of rats into mice. Yes, it's terrific that 10 of the 19 offspring fathered by one of the world's new-style rodents are already as big as Dad. But no, it's not really good news that there now exists a mouse that, being twice the size of his relatives, is presumably twice the nuisance.

title: Mine Kills 2 Israelis
description: Two Israeli officers were killed today and three were injured when their army vehicle hit a mine in eastern Lebanon, the Israeli Army spokesman said.

title: Continental Illinois Designates Credit Head
description: William L. Staples, a senior vice president at the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, has been designated to head a new credit risk evaluation division created by the bank in the wake of large losses resulting from the failure last summer of the Penn Square bank of Oklahoma City. .

title: HARGERS SHOW 2D DIMENSION
description: It is difficult to imagine how much more imposing the San Diego Chargers' offense would be if their running game developed to the level of their passing game. That is a lot to ask, of course: Among the individual achievements in their 50-34 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals Monday night, the quarterback Dan Fouts threw for 435 yards, the wide receiver Wes Chandler caught 10 passes for 260 yards and the running back Chuck Muncie threw a touchdown pass of 66 yards.

title: CAROLINA COAST'S EVOCATIVE FOOD
description: THE arrival of the holidays, for me, calls to mind not only oysters on the half shell, paper-thin ham and beaten biscuits but also roast beef and plum pudding ablaze in a pond of brandy. My parents, one from New Orleans and the other from Victoria, British Columbia, were divided in their loyalties, and at Christmas it was accepted that both tastes be accommodated. That may explain why one of my favorite places to eat is the Low Country of the South Carolina coast, where both heritages survive.

title: SOVIET ANNOUNCES OFFER FOR CUTTING MISSILES IN EUROPE
description: Yuri V. Andropov made public a proposal today under which the Soviet Union would reduce its medium-range missiles in Europe from more than 600 to about 162, the number of missiles maintained by Britain and France, if the United States and its allies abandon plans to deploy 572 new medium-range missiles in Europe late next year.

title: AS THE COST OF CONGRESS KEEPS GOING HIGHER
description: To the Editor:

title: Leahy Is Still Jets' Kicker
description: Pat Leahy, the Jets' slumping place-kicker, received another vote of confidence yesterday from his coach, Walt Michaels. After three days of indecision, Michaels said, ''I have made my decision and Pat Leahy is our kicker.''

title: ROCK: ABC MAKES NEW YORK DEBUT
description: music fan magazine. That may explain his penchant for incorporating other rock stars's mannerisms. At ABC's New York City debut Saturday at the Palladium, Mr. Frye combined David Bowie's husky, theatrical singing style with Bryan Ferry's exaggeratedly suave physical poses.

title: MEDICAID IS VITAL TO THE POOR: CUT WITH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: AS THE TIME TO ADJOURN DRAWS NEAR, A FLURRY OF BILLS AND SPECIAL BENEFITS
description: As Congress rushed toward adjournment today, it approved numerous bills providing tax breaks, tariff reductions and other special benefits to selected individuals and industries.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FRIENDLY FROST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-After a loss of $274,000 for the qr and income of $2,887,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $1,462,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $50,000...D-Net loss including income of $154,000 from discontinued operations

title: CONCERT: MUSIC FROM KOREA
description: ONE finds few concert titles so apt and telling as Saturday's ''Evening of Korean Serene Music,'' for that is exactly what was offered. This concentration of works for traditional ethnic instruments, the last in a series of six concerts, was held at the Korean Cultural Service.

title: 3-Day Fire in Venezuela Leaves 129 Dead
description: United States. Canadian and Venzuelan firefighters brought under control today a fire that has burned for three days at a power plant, killing at least 129 people, injuring 500 and leaving 1,000 homeless.

title: Real Estate; Business Rent Curb Is Sought
description: SMALL businesses throughout the city are threatened with large - and unaffordable - rent increases as their leases expire, according to city and state legislators and spokesmen for trade associations and merchant groups. As a result, these groups are calling for commercial rent controls.

title: TOXIC WASTE RANK WANTED BY JERSEY
description: The Federal Government's finding that New Jersey has the nation's largest number of hazardous waste sites eligible for Federal cleanup funds was a designation eagerly sought by the Kean administration.

title: 'KISS ME GOODBYE'
description: ROBERT MULLIGAN'S ''Kiss Me Goodbye'' is like a Nassau cruise ship with eight bars, seven discos, five swimming pools and no compass. It sails out of New York, turns left instead of right at the Ambrose Lightship and heads confidently toward sunny Iceland.

title: GETTING MOST OF GARLIC
description: IT seems that every visit to a food-equipment show or kitchenware shop turns up another device for crushing garlic. In one of the latest the clove is placed in a plastic cylinder and pressed by turning a screwlike device at one end of the tube, which pushes the garlic through a perforated grate. Promotors of the tool say the advantage is that if you do not want to use an entire clove you can reverse the screw, put a plastic lid over the grate end and store the whole thing in the refrigerator.

title: CUOMO SAYS HE WILL CANCEL PLAN TO BUILD ARTHUR KILL POWER PLANT
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said today that he intended to live up to a campaign promise to halt longstanding plans for a coal-burning power plant on the banks of the Arthur Kill in Staten Island.

title: Jane Heller, Steven Garard, Bank Officers, Are Married
description: Jane Robin Heller, daughter of Gerald B. Tonkens of Cincinnati and Rosalie R. Tonkens of Boston, was married yesterday to Steven L. Garard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin B. Garard of New Hyde Park, L.I. Rabbi Leonard Troupp performed the ceremony in the chapel of the House of Living Judaism in New York.

title: U.S. AIDING JERSEY CITY PROJECT
description: Jersey City will receive a $40 million Federal grant for the redevelopment of its Hudson River waterfront facing lower Manhattan, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today.

title: GRUMMAN TO SELL TROUBLED BUS UNIT
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its troubled Flxible bus-manufacturing subsidiary to the General Automotive Corporation of Ann Arbor, Mich., for $40 million.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: DINNER was almost ready and Cara, age 8, was reminded that it was time to set the table. She placed dishes, utensils, glasses and napkins in their proper places and then asked her mother if she should pour drinks. Without spilling a drop, she filled her parents' wineglasses and poured milk from a gallon jug for herself and her younger brother, David.

title: Harold Eiber, Helped Develop Treatment for Arteriosclerosis
description: Dr. Harold B. Eiber, an internist and cardiologist who was one of the main contributors in the preparation of radioactive heparin, an anticoagulant used in the treatment of arteriosclerosis, died of a heart attack yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 8 in Salvadoran Patrol Reported Slain by Rebels
description: Leftist guerrillas killed eight members of a 10-man police patrol and wounded a ninth in a two-hour clash after an ambush in Usulutan province, national guard sources said today.

title: BADEN DISMISSAL ORDERED FOR COMMENT IN ARTICLE ABOUT MURDER
description: Dr. Michael M. Baden was ordered dismissed today as chief deputy medical examiner of Suffolk County after a magazine quoted him as giving what the County Executive called ''advice on how to kill people.''

title: DEVOTEES OF TAP DANCE KICK THEIR HEELS
HARCOURT AND WARNER IN SETTLEMENT
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to drop a lawsuit against Warner Communications Inc. that grew out of Warner's purchase of an 8.6 percent stake in Harcourt almost two years ago. In return, Warner amended its Schedule 13 filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission to state that it had no present plans to purchase additional Harcourt stock.

title: 1. Return of the Glove
description: Gloves are back. Not the woolly kind meant to keep one's hands warm, but decorative gloves, which are worn, like jewelry, as accessories. Carrie Bishop, who calls her company Glove Affaire, has designed some gloves with big, printed taffeta cuffs that would do a lot for a tailored suit or dress. The gloves are black or white cotton; the cuffs come in dots, stripes and plaids on red, blue or white backgrounds. They're at Bloomingdale's, priced at $35.

title: A LOOK AT ROBERT MCNAMARA'S RETIREMENT AGENDA
description: Probably the hardest thing, says Robert S. McNamara, is adjusting to the noninstitutional world, the one without the legions of staff that most accomplished people have learned to use to lever their efforts.

title: ATLANTIC OIL CORP (DENVER, COLO) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ISLANDERS RALLY FOR 3-3 TIE
description: Despite a chaotic situation in which a number of players substituted briefly for their disabled coach, the Islanders managed a 3-3 tie with the Quebec Nordiques tonight in a penaltyriddled game. Five of the six goals were scored on power plays.

title: A.T.& T. IN ANTITRUST VICTORY
description: A Federal District Court judge today cleared the American Telephone and Telegraph Company of antitrust charges filed by the Southern Pacific Communications Company, which competes with A.T.& T. in the long-distance phone market.

title: Cabby Says Rider Could Be Patz Boy
description: A 69-year-old retired cabdriver told the police yesterday that he may have picked up Etan Patz on the morning in May 1979 that the 6-year-old boy disappeared after leaving his home in the SoHo section of Manhattan.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 29
CONCERT: HOLIDAY MUSIC OF AN EARLIER AMERICA
description: APPARENTLY inspired by its recently installed and lovingly received Appleton pipe organ of 1830, the Metropolitan Museum invited Neely Bruce and his venturesome American Music/ Theater Group of Middletown, Conn., to present a most unusual and appealing holiday program last night in the Equestrian Court.

title: TRAFALGAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $38,000 for the qr and $55,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $100,000 for the qr and 6 mos

title: Tibetans Are Said to Return
