description: About 1,000 Tibetans living abroad returned to visit relatives or to settle in Tibet in the first 11 months of the year, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TREES IN THE BRONX

title: THEATER: 'THREE SISTERS,' A REVIVAL OF CHEKHOV
description: LYNNE MEADOW'S revival of ''The Three Sisters,'' which opened at the Manhattan Theater Club last night, does have three sisters. Dianne Wiest's Masha, Lisa Banes's Olga and Mia Dillon's Irina are all first-rate or well on their way to being so. It's unfortunate that the production that surrounds them ultimately proves as stultifying as the vulgar provincial town that smothers their characters' sensibilities.

title: REAGAN'S ARGENTINES
description: In the last two weeks, the Argentines have convincingly demonstrated their disdain for their military rulers, who first took power in March 1976. A general strike paralyzed the country. It was followed by a 24-hour demonstration by human rights organizations in which many thousands took part. And 100,000 people assembled last week to demand an immediate return to democracy. Still, the Reagan Administration seems intent on exhibiting support for the most unpopular Argentine Government in many generations.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bicycling's Victims

title: PANEL SUGGESTS CHANGES IN LEGAL AID
description: New York City should consider setting up a public defender's office to replace the Legal Aid Society if the society fails to sign a no-strike agreement with the city, an advisory panel told Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: Market Place; Judging Risk In Municipals
description: NEW YORK CITY has drawn up plans to lay off at least 3,300 workers and to leave thousands of other positions unfilled. New Jersey is struggling to come up with some new sources of tax revenues. Indeed, in cities and states across the country, governments are scraping to find ways of cutting costs and raising revenues to bring their budgets into balance.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Army Parade
description: Mal Moore, a member of Paul (Bear) Bryant's coaching staff at Alabama since 1964, will be interviewed at West Point today as Army continues its search for a head football coach to replace Ed Cavanaugh.

title: MRS. REAGAN'S SKIN CANCER REMOVED
description: A small growth that was removed from above Nancy Reagan's upper lip was diagnosed as skin cancer but it was ''adequately excised and no further treatment is required,'' the White House announced today.

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $14,000 for the latest first qr and $91,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: 2 Soldiers Wounded in Ulster
description: Two soldiers were injured by a bomb while on foot patrol in the border village of Crossmaglen, one of the most dangerous areas in Ulster for British troops, the police said today. A police spokesman blamed the Irish Republican Army and said one of the soldiers was seriously hurt, the other only slightly injured.

title: THE WORLD OF MUSIC REMEMBERS AND MOURNS ARTHUR RUBINSTEIN
description: The death Monday of the pianist Arthur Rubinstein at the age of 95 has affected the music world deeply, just as his playing affected audiences throughout his career. Colleagues have reacted to the death of one of the most respected and popular musicians of the century with personal affection and appreciation for his achievements.

title: A Species in Peril In the N.F.L.
description: T hey are two against the tide now, perhaps the last two of an endangered species. Each stands there, staring down at where his holder will spot the ball after the snap. Then each swings his right leg straight ahead to kick the ball -straight ahead, rather than from the side as the soccer-style kickers do.

title: U.S. Seeking Information On 400 in Korean War
description: The United States asked North Korea today to help account for nearly 400 American soldiers missing in action in the Korean War.

title: DECEMBER'S DUTY O'ER
description: Yesterday I finally got my shopping done. What a relief. I didn't want to get my shopping done. I never want to get my shopping done, but in December getting your shopping done is a public obligation.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income; results for the latest periods reflect a writedown of $15 millionmainly on tubular goods inventories

title: NOVEMBER CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.1%
description: Consumer prices rose a mere one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the best monthly performance since a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Government reported today. The index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Hoop Cheese Comeback

title: The Sidewalks of New York; Beantown
description: New York sometimes appears to have as much street java as it has street jive. Certain sidewalks, at this season, are strewn with what look very much like espresso beans.

title: GAP AT THE TOP OF A LIST OF BUSINESS SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: T.W.A.-Union Pact Averts Threatened Strike
description: Trans World Airlines and the machinists' union reached agreement just after midnight this morning on a tentative contract, averting a Christmas-season walkout by 10,000 union employees.

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The Sidewalks of New York; Sorry, Right Number
description: A character in Italo Calvino's ''If On a Winter's Night a Traveler'' suffers from a case of telephone angst: ''When I am out in the streets ... even when I am in strange cities ... hearing a ring, my first thought every time for a fraction of a second is that the telephone is calling me ... I am torn between the necessity and the impossibility of answering.''

title: Official Slain in Peru
description: A gunman shot and killed the regional director of the National Cultural Institute today in the central Andean city of Ayacucho, the police reported. Walter Wong was the third official to be attacked in Ayacucho in less than a week.

title: TV: JAZZ AT WHITE HOUSE STARS ITZHAK PERLMAN
description: THE concert series ''In Performance at the White House'' turns to jazz tonight at 9 on WNET, Channel 13, at 9, and it is quickly apparent that neither public television nor official Washington is terribly comfortable with the music. The producers chose as host Itzhak Perlman, the violinist, who has recorded a couple of jazzoriented albums but who is hardly a representative spokesman for the form. And the audience in the White House's East Room was almost grimly polite when confronted with musical free forms and improvisations.

title: TALL, TRIM JAWORSKI
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE Q&A
description: Q. Regarding the article on a blind Champagne tasting on Dec. 1, the voted preference for the Dom Perignon 1975 may be explained by the fact that you did not really have a ''blind'' tasting. Your article states that the bottles were tightly wrapped with paper and taped to assure that the identity of each Champagne would be hidden. The shape of the Dom Perignon bottle is distinctive and would not be concealed merely by taping. Is it possible that some of the tasters identified this wine by its bottle?

title: FOURTH AMENDMENT NEEDS NO REWRITE
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL ON PENSION APPEAL PASSES
description: The House has passed a bill allowing thousands of Americans dropped from the Social Security disability rolls to keep their benefits while they appeal the decision.

title: TROUBLE WITH NAMES? NOT ME!
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jean Kerr, the playwright and author, has most recently written ''How I Got to Be Perfect'' (Doubleday). By JEAN KERR

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Walton Makes Progress
description: Bill Walton was cleared by his doctors today to begin playing twice a week for the San Diego Clippers and possibly play fulltime by the middle of January, team officials said.

title: The Gambler and the Dead Ducks
description: In September, the President's gamble looked like a sure thing. Mr. Reagan insisted that Congress return, like errant schoolchildren, after the election. If Republicans won new seats in November, the special session could produce impressive new triumphs. If they lost ground he could still win. Let the lame ducks vote down his program; he would blame Democratic partisanship even while coming off as the stern principal keeping the rowdy legislators after school to buckle down.

title: Yanks Gaining In Money Game
description: According to the latest salary data compiled by the Major League Baseball Players Association, the Yankees have slipped in the salary standings. From 1979 through 1981, the Yankees had the highest average salary in the majors, but in 1982, the California Angels nudged past them with a $423,403 average.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results reflect the $2.5 million acquisition of Jered Inc

title: DANCE: ISRAELI THEATER
description: ZVI GOTHEINER had an interesting founding principle for the Israeli Chamber Dance Theater, which made its debut on Friday at the Larry Richardson Dance Gallery. Why not create a small company of Israeli dancers studying with Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham and at other schools in New York, then take them back to Israel to tour in new modern dance choreography?

title: Dallas Fed Gets Chairman
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas today named Gerald D. Hines, owner of his own real estate company, chairman for 1983.

title: Article 821222 -- No Title
description: Thirty $100 bills were dropped into three Salvation Army kettles at a Bloomington shopping mall, a Salvation Army spokesman said today.

title: IN PAGEANTS, CHRISTMAS GLORY IS FILLED WITH THE UNEXPECTED
description: ''Don't chew the stars, please,'' said Ann Jewitt to a 6-year-old singer putting teeth marks on a glittery paper star at Calvary Baptist Church in Manhattan.

title: McCormick Settles Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged that McCormick & Company, the Maryland-based spice maker, and top executives conspired to falsify the company's books. The defendants immediately settled the charges by agreeing to a court order not to violate certain provisions of the securities laws.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Two
description: The National Hockey League dealt two-game suspensions to Chris Nilan of the Montreal Canadiens and Curt Fraser of the Vancouver Canucks for a fight the two had last Wednesday that started on the ice and continued in the hallway outside the dressing rooms.

title: Yanks Promote Oates
description: The Yankees yesterday named Johnny Oates as manager of their Class AAA team in Columbus in the International League.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Funds Draw $19 Billion
description: The new bank money market funds that became available Dec. 14 attracted about $19 billion in deposits in the week ended last Saturday, according to a report released by a market research firm that surveys consumer investment trends for financial institutions.

title: ROCK: PULSALLAMA, WOMEN AND RHYTHM
description: WEARING prom gowns and miniskirts, and carrying enough percussion instruments for a couple of samba bands, the seven women of Pulsallama came onstage Sunday at the Underground for a set that was silly, spirited and full of ingenious noise. The rock group mixes campy recitations, girl-group poses and cheerful vulgarity into mockrituals that hold nothing sacred.

title: MET MUSEUM GETS POLLOCK WORKS
description: Forty drawings by Jackson Pollock have been given to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by Lee Krasner, the painter and widow of the artist. The gift includes perhaps the Abstract Expressionist's best-known drawing, ''War.''

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Indiana Standard
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said directors approved a 1983 capital and exploration budget of $5 billion, up 9 percent from 1982. It said $3.3 billion is for projects in the United States.

title: Rockland Votes A Tax Increase
description: The Rockland County Legislature approved a $165 million budget today. The tax increase required to finance the new budget will vary between 10 percent and 17 percent in the county's five towns, but the average homeowner's tax bill will rise by about $60.

title: No Headline
description: 76ERS' CUNNINGHAM GETS 300th

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are prepared, among other things, to agree that the Soviet Union should retain in Europe only as many missiles as are kept there by Britain and France - and not a single one more.

title: WARDEN OF DOGS IN SCARSDALE DIES IN RTE. 22 CRASH
description: The dog warden of Scarsdale, N.Y., was killed Monday night in neighboring Eastchester when his car was struck head-on by a stolen ambulance, the police said.

title: SOUTH AFRICA CLEARS SECURITY POLICE IN SUICIDE OF A WHITE IN CUSTODY
description: A magistrate exonerated the security police today in the suicide in their custody of a white official of a largely black labor union who had been held without charge for intensive interrogation.

title: Mesa Petroleum's Offer for General
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said the deadline for the Justice Department or the Federal Trade Commission to seek additional data on Mesa's takeover bid for the General American Oil Company of Texas would be Jan. 5, a day later than expected.

title: FOR TAXES ON BENEFITS
description: Taxation of entitlement programs is a sound and progressive way both to raise revenues and to provide benefits to those most in need.

title: RACING CONSIDERS ITS OPTIONS
description: When Conquistador Cielo charged through the mud to post a 14-length victory in the Belmont Stakes June 5, about $7.6 million was legally wagered on the race. Less than a quarter of that total, $1.753 million, came from the pockets of the 45,000 fans who watched the race at Belmont Park. Bettors at the state's 156 offtrack betting parlors accounted for $2.9 million, and OTB bettors at 12 parlors and a betting theater in Connecticut bet another $314,736. Legal bookmakers in Nevada handled about $100,000 on the race.

title: Fritsch Retires
description: After 12 seasons in the National Football League, the place-kicker Toni Fritsch retired yesterday. Signed by the New Orleans Saints this season after the Houston Oilers had cut him, Fritsch missed on a 20-yard field-goal attempt in the Saints' 3-point loss to Tampa Bay Dec. 5.

title: J.L. McCAFFREY, EX-EXECUTIVE
description: John L. McCaffrey, who rose from salesman on horseback in Kentucky for the International Harvester Company to chairman and chief executive of Harvester, one of the world's largest manufacturers of agricultural machinery, died Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 90 years old.

title: Army Plans to Review Rules On Placing Ashes in Arlington
description: The Army is preparing to review its regulations for Arlington National Cemetery since the interment there of the ashes of a demonstrator who had threatened to blow up the Washington Monument.

title: Durables Orders Up By 1.9%
description: Orders to American factories for durable goods rose 1.9 percent in November, regaining some of the ground lost in October's 5 percent decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
West Germany Plans to Offer Foreigners $3,700 to Leave
description: West Germany is planning to offer some unemployed foreigners $3,700 if they agree to return home in the next two years, Government sources said today.

title: BEATRICE FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including a gain of $45,077,000 from the sale of the company's Dannon unit and a gain of $31,870,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change

title: Bausch Official Going To Western Electric
description: In a move that might indicate the enormous changes taking place in Ma Bell's marketplace, Western Electric, A.T.& T.'s equipment manufacturing arm, has gone outside the company to hire a vice president in the marketing area. Going outside for an officer is almost unheard of in A.T.& T. circles.

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
LESS COSTLY FURNITURE CAN GAIN IN VALUE, TOO
description: Sharp increases in the value of much American antique furniture during the last two decades are not limited to the top of the line.

title: Fresno State Gets 1-Year Probation
description: The Fresno State basketball program was placed on probation for one year and penalized with the loss of two scholarships for 1983 and 1984 today because of violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules involving recruiting.

title: GHOSTS
description: It has been 10 years now. At this season in 1972, American bombers made their last massive attack in Vietnam: the Christmas bombing. Over 12 days, 100 B-52's and 500 smaller planes struck Hanoi and Haiphong. It was the most intensive conventional bombing campaign in history.

title: Argentine Judge Quits In Protest on Military
description: A federal judge who emerged as a leading critic of Argentina's military rulers has resigned in protest at what he said was their refusal to obey court orders.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dog Show for Holidays

title: BOND RULE DEFERRED 6 MONTHS
description: The House and Senate late Tuesday approved a bill that grants a six-month reprieve on a provision in the 1982 Tax Act requiring that most municipal bonds be issued only in registered form, rather than anonymously to bearers. The new effective date is July 1, 1983.

title: SERMONS AT CHRISTMAS TAKE MANY FORMS TO REACH MANY
description: For the voice from the pulpit, this is the season of the Word. In their rectories and parish studies, the clerics of Christendom have been ''brooding and meditating,'' as one put it, to find just the right words or image for what is usually the most widely heard sermon of the year - the Christmas homily.

title: House Assailed on Union Law
description: Because the House of Representatives did not pass an antiracketeering bill, an insurance executive convicted in the teamster bribery conspiracy trial could collect $30 million in fees from a union health and welfare fund while appealing, Senator Orrin G. Hatch said today.

title: ARMED INTRUDER ATTACKS OFFICIAL AT BRONX SCHOOL
description: A 48-year-old assistant principal of Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Northwest Bronx was raped at gunpoint Tuesday during school hours, the police said yesterday. Security at the school has been reinforced by the Police Department and by the Department of Education's office of school safety.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INDIAN PT. REACTORS GET REPRIEVE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 3 to 2 this evening to permit the Indian Point nuclear reactors to operate and to wait until an accident drill in March to determine whether deficiencies in emergency planning had been corrected.

title: MOSCOW AIDE SEES EVIL INTENT IN TALK ABOUT ATTACK ON POPE
description: A senior Soviet official denied today that there was any validity to speculation linking Bulgaria and the Soviet Union to the attempt to assassinate Pope John Paul II in Rome last year.

title: New York Phone Appoints Chairman
description: Delbert C. Staley, president and chief executive of the New York Telephone Company, will move up Feb.1 to become chairman, a post that has been vacant for several years, the company said yesterday. Mr. Staley, 59 years old, retains the title of chief executive, but not that of president.

title: PREGNANT, UNWED TEACHER KEEPS JOB
description: The president of the East Hampton District Board of Education said Tuesday night that he doubted any action would be taken on petitions calling for the dismissal of an unmarried high school biology teacher who is seven and a half months pregnant.

title: A FLAVOR OF PARIS
description: HIS idea was to recreate the atmosphere of a real Parisian cremerie - a dairy store.

title: MAYOR OF UNION CITY GUILTY OF CONSPIRACY TO RIG BIDS
description: The Mayor of Union City was convicted today by a Federal jury of conspiracy, mail fraud and income tax evasion in connection with a bid-rigging scheme in Hudson County.

title: CONSUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Including a tax credit of $83,000...D-Including a tax credit of $58,000

title: TECHNOLOGY
description: ABOUT 12 years ago, a major shift took place in the complex technology used in integrated circuits: Computer chips using a new technology known as metal-oxide-semiconductor, or MOS, started gaining a greater share of the market at the expense of chips using an older technology known as bipolar.

title: OPERA: 'CAROL' SET TO MUSIC
description: When Charles Dickens read his stories aloud, he treated them as dramatic scripts, taking on different speaking voices, altering facial expressions for each character, pacing the telling for sentiment and effect. Gregory Sandow, in turning Dickens's ''A Christmas Carol'' into opera, followed in that tradition, creating an effective retelling of the familiar story.

title: No. 1 on the List Of Tennis Fines
description: Johan Kriek finished eighth in the season-long Volvo Grand Prix point standings on the men's professional tennis tour. But for dubious distinction in the numbers game, Kriek appears to be the overwhelming winner for the 1982 season.

title: Ex-Cardinal Back Killed at Home
description: Chuck Latourette, a 40-year-old physician and former defensive back for the St. Louis Cardinals, was shot and killed early today in his suburban home in West University.

title: Pabst Share Offer Is Lifted to $40
description: Paul Kalmanovitz raised the price of his tender offer for about half the stock of the Pabst Brewing Company to $40 a share from $32. A week ago, the G. Heileman Brewing Company raised its offer for control of Pabst to $32 a share from $29.

title: Grey Will Promote Auto Safety Belts
description: Grey Advertising, whose commercial against drunken driving for the Department of Transportation was showered with creativity awards in the early 70's, has now beat out several other agencies to do a multimillion-dollar automobile safety belt promotion.

title: MOSCOW ASSERTS MISSILE-CUT OFFER DOESN'T AFFECT LAUNCHERS IN ASIA
description: A senior Kremlin official said today that Moscow's latest proposal to reduce medium-range missiles meant that the weapons would be removed from the European part of the Soviet Union, not that all within reach of Europe would be removed.

title: Worker Indicted In Slaying of Boss
description: A clerical worker has been indicted for second-degree murder in the fatal shooting of her boss, the managing partner of a Fifth Avenue law firm, authorities said yesterday.

title: Richard J. Parmentier Marries Cornelia Kammerer
description: Cornelia Ann Kammerer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lewis Kammerer of New Paltz, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard J. Parmentier, son of Amory J. Parmentier Jr. of Westfield, N.J., and West Paris, Me., and the late Una Jane Rupp Parmentier. Town Justice Rexford H. Schneider of New Paltz performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: GAS TAX SUPPORTERS PREDICT VICTORY IN SENATE VOTE TODAY
description: As senators juggled flight schedules and holiday plans, supporters of a bill to raise the Federal gasoline tax by 5 cents a gallon lobbied frantically for votes today and predicted victory when the legislation reaches a showdown in the Senate Thursday morning.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt IN THE CITY OF FEAR. By Ward Just. 291 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: Morehead St. 79
description: Robert Cole scored 25 points, including seven 3-point field goals, and had a game-high 10 assists to lead Long Island University in the consolation game of the Rebel tournament. The Blackbirds (6-2) led through nearly all of the second half, but Morehead State scored 9 of the game's final 13 points to make it close.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FIRES in the home kill thousands of people each year and destroy millions of dollars in property. Fire experts say that much of the loss could be avoided if everyone constantly observed common-sense safety precautions.

title: BRIEFING
description: Complaints on Counting

title: GENERAL AMERICAN COUNTERBID
description: The General American Oil Company of Texas, fighting a $520 million takeover bid by the Mesa Petroleum Company, disclosed last night a counteroffer for its own stock in a move that could start a bidding war.

title: CHANGED VIEWS ON MARRIAGE
description: Though most young Americans believe that they will eventually marry, they no longer regard the married state as significantly better than being single, according to a recent study.

title: STAGE: MISS SARANDON IN 'EXTREMITIES'
description: William Mastrosimone's new play isn't called ''Extremities'' for nothing. It opens with a graphically depicted attempted rape and quickly moves on to a series of violent brawls featuring the malevolent slamming of hammers and shovels, the spilling of boiling water, and a grueling assortment of well-targeted kicks and bites. These blackout sketches of horror often end with piercing screams, which then blend into a mechanical screech that sounds like a grinding garbage disposal. And that's only Act I. After intermission, a new prop is introduced for our delectation - a hunting knife.

title: 800 Extra Flights Approved
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it had approved more than 800 charter and other extra flights by airlines over the Christmas and New Year's Day holidays.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LTD reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
COMPANIES' WORKERS GATHER CONTRIBUTIONS TO HELP THE NEEDIEST
description: ''Christmas cards are opened, read and discarded,'' wrote Miguel A. Martinez in a letter accompanying a $100 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''So instead of mailing cards this year, we are enclosing this small donation to bring some comfort to those in the greatest need.''

title: SENATE OFFERS WEAPON AGAINST JAPANESE TRADE
description: The Senate has unanimously adopted a resolution urging President Reagan to apply a new trade weapon against Japan - barring American companies from taking the 15 percent investment tax credit when buying certain Japanese machine tools.

title: 600 LIVING ON A PRIVATE HAWAIIAN ISLAND
description: That lumpy form rising out of the sea on the southeast horizon is Niihau, a privately held island as inaccessible to the public as any place in the United States.

title: Photo in Patz Case Released by Police
description: A photograph of a boy possibly resembling Etan Patz, who disappeared more than three years ago in lower Manhattan, was released yesterday by the Police Department. The photograph was found this month in a house in Wareham, Mass., that the authorities said had been used by a homosexual organization.

title: Holiday Inns Sale
description: Holiday Inns Inc. said a Crowley Maritime Corporation subsidiary had purchased the stock of its Delta Steamship Lines Inc. unit for $96 million. Holiday Inns said proceeds would be used for general corporate purposes, including financing of its hotel development efforts. The disposition is not expected to differ significantly from the loss from discontinued operations of 58 cents a share reported in the company's nine-month results, it said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Monday about a bird count in Brooklyn incorrectly gave the number of species identified. It was 112, including either a bald or a golden eagle.

title: TWO NUCLEAR TREATIES: JUST SITTING THERE
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MOUNTAIN CIRCUIT

title: Firestone Plant
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said that it had signed a definitive agreement with Bridgestone Tire Manufacturing Inc. (U.S.A.), under which Bridgestone would buy Firestone's radial truck tire manufacturing plant in Lavergne, Tenn., for $52 million. Bridgestone is a manufacturing subsidiary of the Bridgestone Tire Company Ltd. of Tokyo.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Headaches and Trees

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
FOR CAN AND BOTTLE
description: IT isn't as easy to get into the holiday spirits as it once was. In olden times we had bottles with corks or metal caps.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The fare is saved.'' - Richard Ravitch. (A1:6.)

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JEAN BLAISE ORTEIG
description: Jean Blaise Orteig, the former manager of Cafe Lafayette, at one time a Greenwich Village gathering place for the French community, died Saturday at New York Hospital after suffering a stroke a year and a half ago.

title: A TREE OF 1,000 ORNAMENTS
description: FEW years ago, as John and Sarina Mascheroni were celebrating Christmas at their house in East Hampton, L.I., they asked their housekeeper to take the ornaments off the tree and pack them up. ''She saw it as a challenge,'' Mr. Mascheroni recalled. ''But she stopped counting at 1,000,'' he said, because there were so many.

title: THEATER: ORSON BEAN'S BLACK-HEARTED SCROOGE
description: In his adaptation of ''A Christmas Carol,'' Orson Bean remembers the first principle of Scrooge: He is a mean, nasty scoundrel, so black-hearted that he seems irredeemable, a fact that makes his redemption all the more amusing.

title: CARING FOR FLOWERING PLANTS
description: FLOWERING plants are welcome holiday gifts and should last a long time if given proper care. Two general rules apply to almost all of them. First, keep soil moist. The earth should feel damp, never soggy. Depending on the home's growing space and type of container, watering may be necessary every day or every week. No rules can be set; proper timing will depend on each individual.

title: California Judge Bars 20-Week Abortion Limit
description: A judge ruled today that a California law banning abortions after the 20th week of pregnancy violated the 1973 Supreme Court ruling on abortion.

title: AFTER KIM'S FREEDOM
description: Although for now Kim Dae Jung, the opposition leader released from prison, is not being allowed to stay in South Korea, his release seems to be good news. What is the significance of the release and the permission granted him to come to the United States, ostensibly for medical treatment? Is it the military-dominated regime's first small but important step toward the democratic process it has promised to establish by 1988, the end of Gen. Chun Doo Hwan's Presidential term? Or is it an isolated concession to political expediency that offers no real hope to South Koreans who seek restoration of democratic government?

title: A MAN-MADE HEART WELL WORTH TRYING
description: To the Editor:

title: Lark Moves to DFS
description: Lark Luggage, a division of General Mills, has left March Advertising for DFS Direct, the direct marketing subsidiary of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, a major General Mills agency. Billings are said to be around $1 million.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY PANEL TO GO ON
description: President Reagan will extend the lifetime of the National Commission on Social Security Reform by 15 days, still hopeful it can agree on a set of recommendations, a White House spokesman said today. The commission was to have expired Dec. 31.

title: The Christmas Hostages
description: The Senate is angry, and small wonder. Here it is, almost Christmas. The House has already gone home. But the Senate's still stuck in Washington, and why? Because Senator Grinch - North Carolina's ultraconservative Jesse Helms - and his Shadows so despise the gas tax/highways/jobs bill that they're using every last procedural trick to defeat it. The outrage is understandable, but let's not get sanctimonious.

title: STOCKS UP IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: The stock market posted a moderate gain yesterday in active trading after Tuesday's sharp advance. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column most of the session, ended up 4.78 points, to 1,035.04. The day before, the Dow soared 25.75 points, spurred by the strong performance in the bond market where prices climbed and yields fell.

title: Swiss Draft On Bank Law
description: The Swiss Government today released the draft of a banking law, which, if enacted, would open chinks in Switzerland's traditionally impregnable bank secrecy laws.

title: AT 70, MRS. JOHNSON SOWS FOR THE FUTURE
description: Striding like a queen through a crowd of more than 200 well-wishers, friends and conservation-minded associates from Texas and New York, Lady Bird Johnson, wife of the late President Johnson, celebrated her 70th birthday today by announcing a gift of 60 acres of land and a birthday commitment of $125,000 for the latest of her many beautification projects: the first National Wildflower Research Center.

title: Fireworks on River Alarm Residents
description: A series of loud explosions alarmed residents in the area of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village last night, but the noise turned out to be a fireworks display from a barge in the East River, the police said.

title: HERS
description: NOW that both my children have left for college I marvel at how such an inappropriate metaphor as the empty nest has taken hold. ''Empty nest'' is all wrong. No one has ever seen a bird mope about a nest after the departure of its young. The parent birds are off like a shot. How can a few weeks out of a spring and summer be compared with 18 years of proximity to a child? During those years the child has grown toward adulthood; the parent has left his or her own youth behind and entered middle age.

title: HOMICIDE BY INJECTION
description: The worst sin of all, the critic Alexander Woollcott once said, is to do well that which shouldn't be done at all.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My living-room floor has been sanded and scraped twice during the 11 years that I have lived here, and I would like to redo the floor once more. However, I do not want to scrape the floor again, as I am afraid that the parquet might be wearing a little thin. Can I remove the existing layers of wax and polyurethane with a regular paint remover and then put a new stain on in a darker color before I reapply the polyurethane?

title: Bankruptcy Court Request
description: The Justice Department today asked the Supreme Court to extend the Dec. 24 deadline for Congress to restructure the nation's bankruptcy courts until March 25.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for QTr to Nov 30
Bankers Trust
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said it had agreed to sell the 33 branch offices of its Bankers Trust Company of Albany unit to the Buffalo Savings Bank. Terms were not disclosed. Bankers Trust said sale of the branches, with deposits of about $300 million, would substantially complete the divestiture of consumer-related operations.

title: U.S. PUTS SOVIET'S AFGHAN CASUALTIES AT 10,000
description: The State Department said today that the Soviet Union had suffered 10,000 to 15,000 casualties in Afghanistan since its forces entered that country three years ago and that it had not been able to gain military superiority over the Afghan insurgents.

title: CONGRESS RENEWS CURBS ON ACTIONS AGAINST NICARAGUA
description: Congress has renewed an order barring the Reagan Administration from supporting military operations aimed at overthrowing the Nicaraguan Government.

title: SCORECARD OF LEGISLATION IN POST-ELECTION SESSION
description: The post-election session of Congress now ending may be remembered as much for what it did not do as for what it did. The House has already adjourned, but still before the Senate is a bill that would raise the Federal gasoline tax to repair highways and bridges and finance mass transit, creating about 320,000 jobs. Once that has been decided, the Senate is also expected to adjourn.

title: BILL TO CURB THEFT OF ART APPROVED
description: After being bottled up in Congress for 10 years, a measure designed to halt the illicit trafficking in stolen antiquities was approved early today and sent off to President Reagan, who is expected to sign it.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Taxi!
description: Humiliation is an empty cab passing you by, only to pick up someone else. Chasing cab drivers who refuse to stop for blacks - because they assume all are headed for Harlem or don't tip - could consume the week. But after one incident last summer, I felt compelled to wave for the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Leftist Text Published In Guatemala Abduction
description: Newspapers and radio and television stations throughout Central America carried the text of a left-wing manifesto today, raising hopes that the kidnapped daughter of the Honduran President, Roberto Suazo Cordova, would soon be released.

title: Friday Closings
description: Stock markets and commodity markets will be closed tomorrow, Christmas Eve.

title: No Headline
description: Scoring Mark Set By Kings

title: BOEING SEEKS U.S. APPROVAL TO SELL $600 MILLION IN AIRCRAFT TO LIBYA
description: The Boeing Company has applied to the Federal Government for permission to sell $600 million worth of commercial jet airliners to Libya.

title: F.A.A. CHIEF ORDERS NEW AIR SAFETY EFFORTS
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration, replying to expressions of concern by another Government agency about the training of new air traffic controllers, ordered his top aides yesterday to step up their surveillance and inspections of the flight system.

title: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Washington Bullets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 8:10 P.M. The Bullets eliminated the Nets in two straight in last season's playoffs, but are 0-2 against New Jersey this season.

title: WELLS FARGO'S EX-CHIEF TAKING OVER AT SEAFIRST
description: Richard P. Cooley, who resigned Tuesday as chairman and chief executive officer of Wells Fargo & Company, yesterday was named chairman, president and chief executive officer of the troubled Seafirst Corporation of Seattle.

title: New Wells Fargo Chairman Sees Few Problems for Bank
description: Precarious foreign loans and uncertainty over new costs arising from the deregulation of consumer banking are among the biggest problems confronting Wells Fargo & Company, the new head of the nation's 11th-largest bank holding company said today.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Yr-ago results include a gain equal to 9 cents a shr on the sale of 60 percen;tinterest in Echlin's Mexican subsidiary and from the sale of interest rate futuress

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $18,000 for the qr and $57,000 for the 6 mos

title: Shavers on Probation
description: Earnie Shavers, the recently retired heavyweight boxer, was sentenced to two years' probation by a Federal judge in Cleveland after pleading guilty yesterday of having filed a false income-tax return for 1977. An indictment against Shavers had accused him of falsifying not only his 1977 return but the following year's as well by reporting that he had paid $7,500 into a retirement fund and by claiming $7,860 in business deductions that were unjustified. Shavers, who originally pleaded not guilty, reversed that plea to the 1977 count yesterday, and in return the Government dropped the other charge.

title: FORDHAM SURPRISES ST. PETER'S BY 67-52
description: Coach Tom Penders of Fordham said that he had not criticized his players when they were losing five of their first seven games this season against strong teams like St. John's and Syracuse.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Appearance by Scrooge

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Allied Maintenance Corp. has appointed Jack M. Feiring president and chief operating officer, succeeding Donald H. McCampbell, who has been named vice chairman.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
CRIMINAL JUSTICE CHANGES PRESSED
description: Representatives of law-enforcement agencies and business groups said yesterday that they had joined forces to seek legislative approval for a program to improve criminal justice in New York State.

title: VIDEO CASSETTES SOOTHE THE PSYCHE
description: THERE are deserts at dawn and Hawaiian palms, meandering rivers and floating swans. These placid scenes, and a variety of other nature vignettes, are available on 30- and 60-minute color video cassettes designed to induce relaxation and, as ''moving paintings,'' to complement home decor.

title: PIANIST: OLEGNA FUSCHI PLAYS BRAHMS THEME
description: IF one were asked to name the ten most important pianists now playing before the public, names would come easily to mind. Yet far below that first rank are multitudes of musicians whose skills and talents may be considerable but whose playing just carves out just narrow niches of loyal listeners, who go through their careers offering a recital now and then, teaching students and playing chamber music.

title: Politics, Sports
description: The Eastern European bloc nations have continually maintained that politics has no place in sports.

title: Dairy Price Support Plan Blocked in Carolina Suit
description: A judge has blocked the Federal Government from collecting a new price support assessment from dairy farmers until a hearing scheduled for Jan. 3.

title: Blast Kills 4 and Injures 6 At a Hydroelectric Plant
description: An explosive charge blew up in a rocket launcher used to control avalanches at a hydroelectric plant today, killing four workers and injuring six, the authorities said.

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Sightseeing Plan
description: When most people contemplate taking a boat ride around Manhattan, they usually think of the Circle Line cruise. But now there might be an alternative, a little more strenuous form of sightseeing, perhaps, but certainly more challenging.

title: Bridge: Suggestions May Emerge From Unexpected Sources
description: One of the more unusual episodes in international bridge history occurred in 1966, when Sue Sachs of Baltimore was a member of the partnership that placed second in the World Women's Pair Championship in Amsterdam. She skipped the award presentation and flew home, just in time to have a baby.

title: WALTER, JIM, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After a loss of $5 million from discontinued operations

title: BRIEFS
description: * Capitol Air said it was returning five DC-8's it had leased from Eastern Airlines but would continue to pursue its claim for $5.25 million in damages from Eastern for breach of the lease agreement. Eastern said its litigation was still pending against Capitol to recover $1.4 million in unpaid leasing charges.

title: LET GEORGE UNDO IT
description: Let us lift the veil concealing three U.S. blunders in the Middle East. 1. The Hussein Rejection. The reason George Shultz put forward for unilaterally awarding Israel's West Bank land to the Arabs - against all Camp David accords - was that such a dramatic announcement was needed to bring King Hussein of Jordan to the negotiating table.

title: Gladys T. Root Is Dead at 77; Prominent California Lawyer
description: Gladys Towles Root, a California lawyer who gained nationwide attention 19 years ago when she defended three men convicted of kidnapping the son of Frank Sinatra, died Tuesday after suffering a heart attack in a courtroom in Pomona.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Donors at Yeshiva

title: MARCUS CO reports earnings for QTr to Nov 11
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: Burlington's Leader Talks About El Paso
description: Richard M. Bressler, 51, chairman, president and chief executive of Burlington Northern Inc., had the manner of an executive yesterday who had prepared his ground carefully and was ready for a long struggle to get what he wants.

title: ONE COUPLE'S PURSUIT OF A PET PROJECT
description: To make a mark on this town, it helps to have a cause or a project, along with a friend or two in high places. The combination can often open doors as quickly as election or appointment to office.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for QTr to Nov 30
Hanson Studying Dan River Bid
description: The Hanson Trust Company P.L.C.'s McDonough Company subsidiary said it was considering several plans that could result in the acquisition of all shares of Dan River Inc.

title: 2 Jockeys Hurt
description: Two jockeys were injured in a three-horse accident in the sixth race today at Hawthorne. Ron Hirdes, 20 years old, suffered a possible fracture of the lower left leg. Lupe Macias, 26, had shoulder and back injuries.

title: STRING RECITAL: TREMONT QUARTET
description: THE Tremont String Quartet, which made its debut in Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night, is a competent, earnest but not thoroughly polished group. The players - Richard Balkin and Laura Mahan Balkin, violins; Linda Walton Kirkwood, viola, and James Kirkwood, cello - were energetic, but their rough edges came from intonation difficulties and pressured musical breathing.

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: INDIANA FOUL SHOTS TOP NO. 2 KENTUCKY
description: Randy Wittman scored 17 points and Ted Kitchel 16 as Indiana rallied from a 7-point deficit in the second half tonight to upset Kentucky, 62-59.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for QTr to Nov 27
MIZE UNDERGOES HEART OPERATION
description: Johnny Mize, the former power-hitting first baseman for the New York Yankees, the New York Giants and the St. Louis Cardinals, was reported in good condition today after a triple bypass heart operation.

title: HEART PATIENT TAKES FIRST FEW SHORT STEPS NEARER TO NORMALITY
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark took a few short, shuffling but encouraging steps today in his struggle as the first human to live with a permanent artificial heart.

title: WALLACE, SAM P, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
STATE APPROVES FINANCIAL PLAN REVISED BY CITY
description: The State Financial Control Board yesterday approved New York City's four-year financial plan, but warned that many obstacles remained on the city's path to full fiscal health.

title: Global Settles With Dissidents
description: Global Natural Resources P.L.C. and a group of dissident shareholders said they had reached an agreement under which all litigation between them would be dropped and a Global subsidiary would pay $1.8 million to the shareholders.

title: POLISH DEFECTOR BLAMES ANDROPOV IN THE ATTEMPT ON JOHN PAUL'S LIFE
description: A Polish defector said today that he believed Yuri V. Andropov, while head of the K.G.B., might have been behind the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II in 1981.

title: I.M.F. Supports Loan to Brazil
description: Brazil won official approval from the International Monetary Fund today for a $546.5 million loan at favorable interest rates. The loan is the first in what analysts expect to be a series of loans totaling $6 billion.

title: WEIGHING ANCHORS AND NEWBURGERS
description: The secret is out. All suspicions are confirmed. ''Newswatch,'' the new book by Av Westin, executive producer at ABC News, makes clear that the part played by the network anchors in determining the makeup of a given evening's news show is measurably less than that of the show's producers, directors, writers, editors, camera crew and technicians, not to mention the correspondents in the field. The anchor's contribution lies somewhere between the girl with the clipboard and the boy who goes for coffee.

title: ONE-PIECE KITCHENS FOR TIGHT SPACES
description: in kitchens have been popular in recent years as families have sought to arrange their homes around their lives rather than the contrary. That's fine if one has several hundred square feet to play with, but for many people, especially occupants of small apartments whose kitchen space may resemble a luxurious broom closet, the challenge is strictly geometric. How does one get all the essentials, including the kitchen sink, into a tight space?

title: Clinch River by a Thread
description: Voted down in the House, approved by a single vote's margin in the Senate, the Clinch River breeder reactor has survived the lame-duck session of Congress with dismal prospects. Its ebbing support marks the fading of the grand design of early nuclear energy strategists. They blame the public's lack of vision, but the fault lies nearer home.

title: Massey Posts Record Loss
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Toronto-based agricultural equipment manufacturer, yesterday announced a record loss for the year ended Oct. 31 of $413.2 million. In the previous year the company lost $194.8 million.

title: Devine Seeks Post
description: Gavin White, the athletic director at Temple, acknowledged yesterday that he had met and discussed the university's vacant football coaching job with Dan Devine, formerly the head coach at Missouri, Notre Dame and the Green Bay Packers. ''It was a very exploratory visit, a friendly meeting,'' White said of their gettogether Tuesday in Tempe, Ariz., where Devine is executive director of Arizona State's booster organization.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Visits Ulster Blast Survivors
description: Amid tight security, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher arrived unannounced in Northern Ireland today and visited survivors of a bombing that killed 17 people, including 11 British soldiers.

title: NORTH OF THE BORDER, DOES ROCK SPEAK CANADIAN?
description: For three consecutive nights last week, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation presented a nationalistic, even, arguably, chauvinistic television series celebrating Canada's contribution to pop and rock music over the last three decades.

title: U.S. to Seize Diet Eyeglasses
description: The Federal Government said it would seize eyeglasses that were sold by an optometrist as a dieting aid. Dr. John D. Miller of Jacksonville, Fla., invented the glasses and began selling them this year for $19.95. They have one brown lens and one blue that Dr. Miller says induce a low level of subconscious confusion that causes the wearer to eat less, the Government said.

title: Citibank Purchase
description: Creditanstalt-Bankverein said today that it had agreed to sell its 36.2 percent share in Citibank (Austria) A.G. to Citibank, for an undisclosed price. The sale, effective today, makes Citibank the sole owner.

title: NORTHWEST ACCEPTANCE (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Northwest Acceptance is the commercial finance subsidiary of Orbanco Financial Services Corp

title: OUTDOORS
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y. I f, along with most trout fishermen in the Northeast, you are chafing at inactivity and daydreaming of spring's sweet blossoming, there is a way to put an end to your idleness, to translate your affection for trout streams into action.

title: Lakers 124, Jazz 100
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 21 points and grabbed the 14,000th rebound of his National Basketball Association career as Los Angeles rolled to an easy victory.

title: ENVIRONMENT GROUPS SUE U.S. OVER NEW RULES FOR WETLANDS
description: A group of 16 environmental organizations sued the Reagan Administration today in an effort to revoke new rules issued by the Army Corps of Engineers to ease regulation of the use of the country's fragile and rapidly disappearing wetlands.

title: Advertising; Promoting The Use Of Coal
description: THE American Coal Foundation, created a year ago by both the management and labor of the industry to promote the use of coal, will institute its first $1 million advertising campaign, largely on television, next week.

title: Market Place; Tax Strategies At Year's End
description: THE securities markets have their own version of last-minute Christmas shopping - a process that, in this case, can involve selling as well as buying.

title: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for QTr to Nov 30
description: Results for the latest qr and yr reflect expenses of $628,000 related to legal expenses in defense of a tender offer and also capital gains of $544,958 from the sale of real estate; yr-ago net income includes a capital gain of approximately $1 million from the sale of real estate

title: SHOT FROM 75 FEET HELPS DEFEAT DEVILS
description: The Devils made several mistakes tonight, but the worst came in the second period when they yielded a short-handed goal and another goal from 75 feet away that resulted in a 3-1 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Budget People Get in the Spirit

title: RELUCTANTLY, UNSER BOWS OUT
description: PLAYERSMalcolm Moran

title: DENVER RETAILERS STRUGGLING
description: The oil and gas business moves this city, but what has irked Denver's retailers the most in the past few days are the unseasonal 50- and 60-degree temperatures that have slowed sales of outerwear and ski apparel.

title: 24 CATHOLICS IN HOUSE OPPOSE BISHOPS ON A-ARMS
description: Two dozen Roman Catholic members of the House of Representatives have written a leader of the church in the United States to oppose a draft pastoral letter that declares nuclear weapons and some of this country's strategic policies immoral.

title: Soviet Order For Germany
description: Mannesmann Anlagenbau A.G., a subsidiary of the Mannesmann steel group, has signed a contract worth $196.6 million to supply the Soviet Union with natural gas equipment, the company said today.

title: VILLANOVA 87 SETON HALL 68
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP)-Mike Mulquin, a reserve forward, scored 15 points as Villanova easily downed Seton Hall.

title: Reynolds Provides For Restructuring
description: SALEM, N.C., Dec. 22 (Reuters) - R.J. Reynolds Industries said it will set up a $46 million provision against pretax operating earnings in the fourth quarter for the cost of restructuring its Del Monte operations.

title: HELMS: FROM REAGAN ALLY TO FOE IN ONE FILIBUSTER
description: In early 1981, any reasonable scenario for the Reagan Presidency would have cast Senator Jesse A. Helms as one of Mr. Reagan's champions on Capitol Hill. Yet in this grim winter of 1982, the North Carolina Republican with the owlish mien and the fat campaign treasury has emerged as one of the Senators most disliked by the White House staff.

title: Avianca Change
description: Avianca, Colombian International Airways, and TBWA Advertising have parted company and the carrier has been talking to a number of other shops seeking a replacement. TBWA acquired the account when it bought the Flaherty & Company agency in February 1981.

title: Chicago Board of Trade Will Elect New Head
description: Thomas P. Cunningham, 44, a grain trader, now appears to be next in line for chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest futures marketplace. Mr. Cunningham's advancement to that position seemed more certain yesterday as Leslie Rosenthal, the two-term incumbent, announced that he would not seek re-election to a third term.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Arizona Bancwest Corporation's offering of 750,000 shares was priced at $16.125 a share, through Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for QTr to Oct 31
News Analysis
description: As the special session of Congress limps to an inconclusive end, there is some question of whether the next Congress can deal with the acute problems of the economy any better than they were dealt with this year. The question is critically important now because much of the power to deal with the economy has shifted from the White House to Capitol Hill.

title: Beatrice Posts Increase in Net
description: The Beatrice Foods Company reported yesterday that earnings in its third fiscal quarter rose 2.6 percent, to $82 million, or 78 cents a share, from $79.9 million, or 77 cents, in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1982
description: International Military action against Nicaragua by the United States is barred under an order renewed by Congress. The order, contained in a spending bill signed by President Reagan, prohibits the Reagan Administration from supporting military operations aimed at overthrowing the Sandinist Government. (Page A1, Column 3.) An elaboration of a Soviet arms plan was presented to journalists by a senior Kremlin official. He said the plan to reduce medium-range nuclear missiles meant the removal of weapons from the European part of the Soviet Union, not the removal of all weapons within reach of Europe. (A1:1-2.)

title: Long-Term Bond Prices Drop; Yield Falls at Treasury Sale
description: Long-term bond prices fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading as the United States Treasury sold $3 billion of new 20-year, one-month bonds at an average yield of 10 3/4 percent, down from 11.68 percent at a similar sale in September.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: B-Including tax credits of certain foreign subsidiaries of $411,000 for the qr and $1,035,000 for the yr...C-Net income

title: M.T.A. FARES SAVED WITH A SURCHARGE ON TAX ON PROFITS
description: The New York State Legislature tonight passed a tax surcharge on corporate profits to subsidize mass transit. It is intended to prevent fare increases on subways, buses and commuter rail lines for the next 12 months.

title: Hartford Repairs Cause Dispute
description: Contracts for renovations to State Capitol offices were awarded without competitive bidding in violation of the law, state auditors said today.

title: CARIBBEAN BILL TO BE REOFFERED
description: President Reagan, complaining about ''procedural maneuvering'' by Senate filibusterers, assured the Organization of American States today that he would resubmit and fight for his Caribbean Basin Initiative as his ''highest priority'' in the next Congress.

title: Allied Completes Acquisitions
description: The Allied Corporation said it had completed purchase of a stake in the Bendix Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SYSTEMS & COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings are fully diluted

title: Italian Wins Ski
description: Michael Mair gave Italy its first World Cup skiing victory in three seasons by winning a supergiant slalom today.

title: Two Denver Banks Planning a Merger
description: An agreement to merge the Intraw@est Bank of Denver with the First Interstate Bank of Denver was disclosed yesterday by their holding companies.

title: MUSIC: TRIO PLAYS OLD, NEW MUSIC
description: ONLY in recent years has the harpsichord been fully restored to the family of instruments, but its rebound has been little short of spectacular. It is perhaps representative of the instrument's shifting fortunes that all the music heard Monday night on the Lucarelli-Norell-Siebert Trio's Abraham Goodman House recital was written either before 1800 or after 1950.

title: Zia's Stay Is Extended At Walter Reed Hospital
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan, who was admitted to a hospital here Sunday for a routine medical checkup, remained hospitalized today, a Pakistani Embassy spokesman said.

title: Decision File; U.S. Declines To Be Sued
description: Theodore L. Lombard says he handled plutonium, uraniumm and other radioactive materials without any safty warning and without the benefit of protective garments while he served in the Army between 1944 and 1946 at Los Alamos, N.@M., where the atomic bomb was developed.

title: Lion Told to Quit
description: James Hunter, the 28-year-old cornerback for the Detroit Lions who suffered a neck injury last Sunday in the 34-31 loss to the Minnesota Vikings, has been told by team physicians that he must retire from football. Dr. Robert Teitge, the Lions' chief physician, said yesterday that if Hunter continued to play, he would risk permanent injury because of a recurring spinal condition. Hunter suffered a neck injury, which caused numbness in his arms and legs, on the nextto-last play of the first quarter. After the quarterback Tommy Kramer passed to Sam McCullum, a wide receiver, for a 21-yard gain, Hunter tackled McCullum on the sidelines at the 25-yard line, and McCullum fell on top of Hunter.

title: Pan Am Has Union Accords
description: Pan American World Airways said it had reached agreements in principle with all five of its major labor unions calling for concessions on work rules and a continuation of a 10 percent wage freeze that went into effect two years ago.

title: PIRATES TO START MAZZILLI IN CENTER FIELD
description: Lee Mazzilli, who was once the most glamorous member of the Mets and finished last season with the Yankees, moved again yesterday, this time to Pittsburgh where the Pirates introduced him as their new center fielder. Barring yet another move in the next week, Mazzilli's travelogue for the year is complete: He has been traded three times in 1982 for a total of six minor-league players and Bucky Dent.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1982; Companies
description: I.B.M. will buy a 12 percent stake in Intel, a leading maker of microelectronic circuits for computers, in an unusual move. The purchase, which joins two powerhouses of American technology, will give Intel, a key supplier of components to I.B.M., a much needed infusion of capital. (Page A1.)

title: DR. BADEN SAYS ARTICLE ON HOMICIDE MISQUOTED HIM
description: Dr. Michael M. Baden said yesterday that he had been inaccurately quoted in a magazine article that led to the order for his dismissal as chief deputy medical examiner of Suffolk County.

title: A TOUCH OF GOLD
description: B rooks Robinson playing third base was, like a rainbow, routinely marvelous. He didn't always look beautiful, however. He had a wobbly, heavy-footed way of locomotion. Once, the former track star Jesse Owens tried to show him how to run better. ''But he gave up,'' Robinson would recall. ''He said I ran like a duck.''

title: MUSIC: 3,000 JOIN THE TRADITIONAL 'MESSIAH SING-IN'
description: TIMES change, and with them musical fashions. In Victorian England, immense performances of Handel's ''Messiah''- with inflated orchestras and thousands of choristers - were great crowd pleasers. However, when Sir Thomas Beecham recorded something along those lines in the late 1950's, he was vilified by Baroque scholars for a lack of stylistic authenticity. Sir Thomas's cutting reply: ''A musicologist is somebody that can read music but can't hear it''.

title: TRUMKA IS SWORN IN AS PRESIDENT OF MINE WORKERS
description: Rich Trumka, a new and young labor leader of an old and troubled union, was sworn in here today as president of the United Mine Workers of America.

title: AT SOUTH AFRICA'S 'IN' RESORT, THE UNSEEN SHANTIES
description: ''That's Johannesburg by the Sea,'' a Cape Town intellectual snorted. ''I wouldn't go near the place at this time of year.''

title: MILLIONS LOSE ELECTRIC POWER AS STORM BLASTS WEST COAST
description: Hurricane-force winds from a two-day storm that blasted the West caused power failures for millions today, shattered hotel windows here and forced a two-hour shutdown of the Golden Gate Bridge at rush hour.

title: 77 Debutantes Attend Annual Christmas Ball
description: Seventy-seven young women were presented to society last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at the 47th annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball.

title: HOUSING DEPARTMENT INVESTIGATING BOSTON'S USE OF U.S. FUNDS
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is conducting a criminal investigation of the city's management of the federally financed Community Development Block Grant program, Federal officials familiar with the inquiry said today.

title: IN UNUSUAL STEP, I.B.M. BUYS STAKE IN BIG SUPPLIER OF PARTS
description: In an unusual effort to aid an electronics company that supplies it with vital parts, the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it will pay $250 million to purchase 12 percent of the Intel Corporation.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FOR INTEL, A VOTE OF CONFIDENCE
description: Throughout the electronics revolution of the 1970's, the Intel Corporation repeatedly proved itself more far-sighted and technologically astute than competing manufacturers of semiconductors and microprocessors.

title: ON BAILING OUT THE SHAKY OVERSEAS DEBTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR ON HOLIDAY TRAFFIC PUTS 400 ON FRONT LINES
description: For Leonard Wolfson, who has been driving a cab for 15 years, it was just another day of waiting for lights to turn green, of leaning on the horn and exchanging epithets with fellow motorists.

title: LINCOLN'S FAMOUS SOLO AT COOPER UNION
description: To the Editor:

title: School of Arts Is Made Landmark
description: The School of the Performing Arts in the theater district was granted landmark status Tuesday night by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: STUBBORN JOBLESSNESS IS FORECAST
description: Unemployment in the United States will remain above 10 percent at least until the summer of 1984, reflecting the weakness of the expected American recovery, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted in its latest semiannual forecast for the non-Communist industrial world.

title: NEW PEPPER IS BALM TO DELICATE PALATES
description: The mild-mannered jalapeno pepper has taken a polite bow and entered the marketplace. The purpose of the cross breeding that produced it was not entirely to cater to all those people out there with delicate palates, Yankees, most of them, but it turned out that way.

title: Connecticut Lawmaker Charged With Larceny
description: A Connecticut State Representative was arrested last night in Hamden on charges of first-degree larceny, insurance fraud and false reporting of an incident, the Hamden police said.

title: Storm Over Patriots
description: The New England Patriots have gone from ineptitude to playoff contention under their first-year head coach, Ron Meyer, but they remain a troubled team. Though requesting anonymity, several Patriot players told both The Associated Press and United Press International that they were upset with what Meyer calls his ''autocratic democracy,'' that discontent on the team was widespread and that it could begin to affect on-field performance.

title: STREAKING CAPITALS SHED LOSER'S IMAGE
description: The Washington hockey team that will skate at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., on Thursday night is a far cry from the one the Islanders used to dominate.

title: VIKINGS YEARNING FOR THE COLD
description: There no longer will be a weather advantage or disadvantage when the Jets and the Minnesota Vikings meet in downtown Minneapolis on Sunday.

title: Christians and Druse Clash South of Beirut
description: Fighting erupted today between Lebanese Christian and Druse militiamen in an Israeli-controlled area six miles south of Beirut as President Amin Gemayel held consultations here in preparation for negotiations with Israel on the withdrawal of its troops.

title: SYNCOR INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
INVESTING: ANTIQUE FURNITURE VS. STOCKS
description: MANY is the time that furniture dealers have told their customers - often with a generous helping of hyperbole - that a particular piece would be a good investment as well as a beautiful and functional item for the home. But when it comes to rare 18th-century American furniture, such a statement is by no means an exaggeration.

title: A MAN-MADE HEART WELL WORTH TRYING
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense Is Planned For Silent Minute
description: The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that he will push a bill to force the Attorney General to defend laws such as the controversial statute requiring a minute of silence in public schools.

title: I.M.F. Plan For Mexico
description: The International Monetary Fund is expected to approve a loan of nearly $3.9 billion for Mexico on Thursday, monetary sources said today.

title: Family to Retain Spendthrift Farm
description: The owners of Spendthrift Farm, one of the world's largest breeders of thoroughbred race horses, have decided against selling any part of it and will look for other ways to insure that it remains in the Combs family.

title: Lloyd's Begins Inquiry
description: Lloyd's of London said it had appointed Anthony Colman, a lawyer, and Stephen Hailey of accountants Arthur Andersen & Company as a committee of inquiry to take control of the investigation into the involvement of any Lloyd's person, firm or company with the Fidentia Marine Insurance Company. last week Lloyd's announced it was investigating relationships with Fidentia, which was formerly a subsidiary of Brookgate Investments, the holding company of Brooks & Dooley Underwriting Ltd., managing agents at Lloyd's.

title: Dr. King's Statue Approved
description: The Senate gave final Congressional approval Tuesday to a resolution authorizing a bust or statue of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in the Capitol.

title: HOLIDAY DECORATING BOTH INSIDE AND OUT
description: OME New Yorkers look for Christmas in obvious places. Rockefeller Center, say, with the tree and the skating rink, or the windows of Fifth Avenue department stores. Other New Yorkers, mindful that the city extends beyond the borders of Manhattan, find the spectacles of the season at other locations. For example, at 106-38 78th Street in Ozone Park, Queens, or 722 Hollywood Avenue in the Bronx or 2822 Brigham Street in Brooklyn.

title: F. Mark Garlinghouse Is Dead; Former A.T.&T. Vice President
description: F. Mark Garlinghouse, retired vice president and general counsel of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Tuesday at Methodist Hospital in Rochester, Minn. He was 68 years old and a resident of Short Hills, N.J.

title: A BENCHFUL OF COACHES
description: ''I t was total chaos,'' said Bob Bourne. ''Everybody was screaming.'' ''Everybody wanted to be the coach,'' Mike Bossy explained. ''It was hectic,'' said the coach, Al Arbour, but he did not know at the time that many of the Islanders were scrambling to take over his chores. He was in the trainer's room, too busy having his dislocated left shoulder treated to know what was happening in the Quebec Coliseum.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 14
Much of France Is Flooded
description: Flooding throughout the country today closed roads and forced the evacuation of houseboats along the Seine and people living in the western region famous for its Cognac.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: TRANSITION AND TRANSIT
description: Hugh L. Carey sat in the governor's office on the second floor of the state Capitol the other day, looking out the window at the Albany Mall, the most visible legacy here of Nelson A. Rockefeller's four terms as governor.

title: 3 HURT IN BOMBING AT ISRAELI CONSULATE IN SYDNEY
description: A bomb exploded in the Israeli consulate offices in Sydney today, injuring at least three people, the police said.

title: LOCAL PHONE RATES TO RISE IN '84 AS F.C.C. VOTES END TO SUBSIDIES
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved a plan today that will increase local phone rates by about $2 a month per household. The charge will mark the end of the nearly 50-year-old practice of using long-distance revenues to subsidize local service.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Atlanta Braves designated Tom Hausman for reassignment to make room on the roster for another former Mets' pitcher, Pete Falcone, who was signed earlier in the week as a free agent. The Braves have one week to trade, release or assign Hausman to a minor-league team. ... Johnny Rutherford, a three-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, has signed to race with the Pat Patrick team, replacing the retired Bobby Unser.

title: A REPORTER FOR OVER 75 YEARS
description: James L. Kilgallen, one of the nation's best-known newspaper reporters in a career that spanned three-quarters of a century, died Tuesday night at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan, which he had entered earlier this month. He was 94 years old.

title: Cowboy Poetry
description: Each year, as a public-relations gesture, the Dallas Cowboys informally present cups engraved with a sort of poetry to a handful of the year's most successful college football coaches.

title: Insider Case Is Dismissed
description: Judge Morris E. Lasker of the United States District Court in Manhattan yesterday dismissed insider trading charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Aaron Rubenstein, brother of Kenneth Rubenstein, a 35-year-old lawyer formerly employed by the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson.

title: BETTER WAY TO GET 'U.S. CONTENT' INTO CARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Semiconductor Loss
description: National Semiconductor, a major manufacturer of semiconductor components, said it had a loss of $3.5 million for its fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 12, compared with net earnings of $182,000, or 1 cent a share, in the 1981 quarter. Sales were $277.5 million, up 8.9 percent from $254.9 million a year ago. It cited ''adverse business conditions worldwide.''

title: GENERAL DEFENDED AT MASSACRE INQUIRY
description: The attorney for the Israeli officer responsible for West Beirut at the time Palestinian civilians were killed there by Phalangist militiamen said in a memorandum today that the general had not passed along the reports of civilian deaths as soon as he received them because he felt they were unclear and unsubstantiated.

title: ISRAELI REPORTS PROGRESS ON LEBANON PACT
description: The Israeli Ambassador said today that his Government had gone beyond the previously reported agenda for negotiations with Lebanon and had already achieved substantial agreement on terms for Israeli military withdrawal and normalization of relations between the two countries.

title: WALESA TALKS ABOUT INTERNMENT AND HIS HOPES FOR THE FUTURE
description: Lech Walesa says that he was kept ''completely isolated'' and pressured for two weeks before he wrote the conciliatory letter to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, that led to his release from 11 months of internment.

title: RANGER LOSE TO SABRES AND CLOCK
description: The official timekeeper apparently ''lost'' five or six minutes out of the second period of last night's game between the Rangers and the Buffalo Sabres at Madison Square Garden. The Rangers lost something more important - the game, by a 3-1 score.

title: Sorry, Billy
description: Now that the World Boxing Council has agreed to trim its title fights from 15 to 12 rounds, some of Billy Conn's friends around Pittsburgh have begun teasing him about what might have happened if his heavyweight fight with Joe Louis in the Polo Grounds on June 18, 1941, had been a 12-rounder.

title: HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES OFFICIAL RESIGNS
description: David B. Swoap, the second-highest official at the Department of Health and Human Services, said today that he was resigning to join the Cabinet of the newly elected Governor of California, George Deukmejian.

title: ONE DEFENDANT IN BRINK'S CASE SET TO AID U.S.
description: One of the defendants in the state's prosecution of the Brink's armored-car robbery and shootout in Rockland County last year has agreed to testify for the Government in a parallel Federal investigation of the crime, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary foreign tax credits of $26,100 for the qr and $41,100for the yr...C-Including an extraordinary foreign tax credit of $29,320 for the qr and yr

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly reported transactions of the Meadows Foundation and the RepublicBank Dallas in General American Oil Company stock. The bank transferred 3.2 million shares to the foundation from the estate of Algur H. Meadows, for whom it was co-executor.

title: Savings Unit Outflow
description: Withdrawals exceeded deposits at the nation's savings banks by $1.4 billion in November, a record ''net deposit outflow'' for that month, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks said yesterday. The loss followed an $1.8 billion outflow in October.

title: STAGE: SNOOPY IS BACK ON DOGHOUSE, SINGING
description: SITTING on top of his doghouse, David Garrison is typing his first novel. ''It ... It was a dark ... '' and, finally, in a full burst of inspiration, ''It was a dark and stormy night.'' Then he emits a Snoopian sigh of relief. Good writing is hard work. So is good acting, but with Mr. Garrison the effort never shows.

title: SOFT FOOD TAKEN BY HEART PATIENT
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark's nurses gave him an early Christmas present today - a vanilla milkshake. It was the 61-year-old retired dentist's first soft food by mouth since his operation on Dec. 2, when he was given an artificial heart, said John Dwan, a spokesman for the University of Utah Medical Center.

title: DEFENSE SPENDING TOO RAPID FOR THE U.S. GOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: Saban Back in Football
description: Lou Saban resigned as the president of the Yankees yesterday to return to football, signing on as head coach at Central Florida in Orlando, a Division II school with plans to go big time. The 63-yearold Saban, a former head coach at six colleges and with pro teams at Boston, Denver and Buffalo, had held his Yankee post since March 1981.

title: Economic Scene; Strains Global, Voices Bitter
description: THE news of this holiday season lacks the old ho-ho-ho. Unemployment afflicts the industrial world, and looks to get worse before it gets better. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development forecasts that the jobless rate will stay above 10 percent in the United States at least until the summer of 1984 and will climb to almost 12 percent in Western Europe by that time. ''The situation is extremely serious,'' said Dr. Sylvia Ostry, who is about to lose her own job as O.E.C.D.'s chief economist.

title: NEW GENERAL AMERICAN MOVE
description: The General American Oil Company of Texas, fending off a $40-ashare takeover bid from the Mesa Petroleum Company, began a worldwide search yesterday for a merger partner, only hours after offering to buy nearly a third of its own stock at $50 a share.

title: Still Bad, Still Getting Worse
description: The American economic condition is stark. Inflation continues to subside, but what might have been good news has become part of the bad news. The tight credit that pounded down inflation also pounded the economy, and the decline has not been stopped. Recovery is still not visible; neither are national policies that would make it happen.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Leventhal Keeps Post

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc. said it had sold 1.95 million shares of its stock to Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. for $46.6 million of Amax debt securities; the stock was offered by Lehman Brothers at $19.62 a share.

title: CHRISTMAS CLUB'S MERRY '82
