description: While it has been a confusing year in much of the savings industry, with a dizzying array of new accounts bombarding savers, one thrift tradition, Christmas Clubs, has survived healthier than ever.

title: THE REGION
description: Governor Kean warned lawmakers today they should be prepared to remain ''in continuous session'' next week until they approve a tax-increase plan he can accept as an alternative to severe state spending cuts.

title: Praise for Craig
description: Lou Vairo, the Brooklyn-born coach of the United States national hockey team, has been impressed with the play of his goalie - Jim Craig, one of the heroes of the 1980 Olympic champions.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
REMARKS BY REAGAN AND HUSSEIN AFTER TALKS
description: Following is the text, as issued by the White House, of remarks made by President Reagan and King Hussein of Jordan after their final round of talks today: By President Reagan

title: CHOIR: ST. THOMAS, WITH AULOS ENSEMBLE
description: THE Metropolitan Museum celebrated the season Monday evening in its Medieval Sculpture Court. Encircled by statuary from an earlier Christian age and standing before the Museum's Neapolitan Christmas tree, the St. Thomas Choir and the Aulos Ensem@ble offered music of both depth and outgoing lightheartedness.

title: 1ST CLAIMS BY JOBLESS DIP AGAIN
description: The number of Americans filing firsttime claims for unemployment benefits dropped to 533,000 in the week ended Dec. 11, reaching the lowest level since July, the Labor Department reported today.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: year-old senior at the Rhodes School, planned h is strategy before he set foot in the Grand Hyatt Hotel for the 26tha nnual Gold and Silver Ball. He bought a dozen red tulips, even t hough two friends who accompanied him rejected his offer of p articipation.

title: HOSPICE CARE'S PROMISE-FOR ALL BUT NEW YORK STATE RESIDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl, 4, Missing 3 Years, Is Reunited With Mother
description: A 4-year-old girl abandoned earlier this week by a man she thought was her father is actually a kidnapping victim from Albuquerque who had been missing more than three years, the police said today.

title: Swedes Oust 2 Russians; Technology Issue Hinted
description: Sweden today ordered two Soviet diplomats to leave the country for what the Foreign Ministry described as activities incompatible with their diplomatic status.

title: ISRAEL REVEALS SITES FOR TALKS WITH LEBANESE NEXT WEEK
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's office announced today that direct negotiations with Lebanon on security arrangements and the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon would begin early next week, alternating between a Beirut suburb and a northern Israeli border town.

title: GUNMEN FIRING WILDLY KILL 3 IN CHINATOWN BAR
description: Masked gunmen firing pistols burst into a crowded Chinatown bar and reputed gang hangout early yesterday and killed three people, including a 13-year-old boy. Eight others were wounded, two of them critically.

title: BASSETT FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
OLD AGE FUND PLANS TO SEEK $ 1.3 BILLION TO CONTINUE BENEFITS
description: The Social Security old-age trust fund will borrow more than $13 billion on Dec. 31, at least $6 billion more than was contemplated, to make sure it can pay monthly benefits through June 1983, Administration officials reported today.

title: No Headline
description: NORDIQUES THWART CANADIANS

title: Fryman, Expos Agree
description: Woodie Fryman, the 42-year-old relief pitcher, has reached an agreement to return to the Montreal Expos after a pay dispute that led to a brief fling with free agency. ...

title: DELAYED YEARS, CABLE TV TO EXPAND TO ALL OF CITY
description: After years of negotiation, a final division of the four boroughs outside Manhattan among six cable television companies was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Officials said service could be brought into some homes as early as June.

title: Wehrli to Retire
description: The defensive back Roger Wehrli, elected to the Pro Bowl seven times in his 14 years with the St. Louis Cardinals, has announced his retirement, effective at the end of the season. ''I felt this was the time to do it,'' said the 35-year-old Wehrli, ''since I've been able to contribute and would like to go out while having contributed to the team.''

title: A GERMAN CITIZEN ORDERED DEPORTED
description: A German citizen who lives in Chicago was ordered deported today as a former Nazi who assisted in the murder of millions of people at the neighboring death camps of Auschwitz and Birkenau from 1941 to 1945, the Justice Department announced.

title: FILIBUSTER CUT OFF, SENATE VOTES RISE IN GAS TAX, 54 TO 33
description: The Senate approved a 5-cent-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax today to finance highway repairs and mass transit, after breaking a filibuster by two conservative Republicans.

title: U.S. Says $11 Billion In Waste Was Averted
description: The inspectors general named by President Reagan to lead an attack on waste and fraud in Government helped save $11.5 billion in the last fiscal year, Federal officials reported today.

title: Bridge: Gail Moss's Daughter Joins Mother's Side, in a Switch
description: An unusual rivalry occurred in the final of the world women's pair championship in Biarritz, France, in October. One of the favorites, Gail Moss of New York, found she had to face some stiff competition from her 21-year-old daughter, Gillian Blanchard. Mrs. Blanchard, a student at Columbia Law School, was the youngest player in the final, and was ahead of her mother going into the last session of play.

title: Not Guilty Plea on Stix
description: Thomas R. Brimberry, a former vice president of Stix & Company, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal District Courts in St. Louis, Mo., and in East St. Louis, Ill., to charges related to the bankruptcy of the brokerage firm more than a year ago.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net income; results for the latest periods include equity in net loss of affiliate of $2,576,000 for the qr and $2,332,000 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results include equity in net income of affiliate of $190,000 for the qr and $895,000 for the 6 mos

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CONTRIBUTORS TO FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST PUT IMAGINATION TO WORK
description: Contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund seem to have an inexhaustible well of ideas when it comes to raising money for New Yorkers in need.

title: Boeing Seeks Sale Of Planes to Libya
description: The Boeing Company is asking the Federal Government for permission to sell as many as 12 jet airliners to Libya for the state airline, a company spokesman said.

title: Times of London Fails To Publish for 4th Day
description: The Times of London was not printed tonight for the fourth successive night because of a dispute involving 92 electricians.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Brunner's Job Is in Jeopardy
description: Coach Ray Perkins of the Giants has given his quarterback, Scott Brunner, a warning. If Brunner is not playing well against the Cardinals Sunday in St. Louis, Jeff Rutledge will replace him.

title: KIM DAE JUNG ARRIVES IN U.S. AFTER BEING FREED BY SOUTH KOREA
description: The South Korean opposition figure Kim Dae Jung arrived in Washington tonight and said that his most fervent wish was to return to his homeland and dedicate his life to the peaceful reunification of North and South Korea.

title: EL PASO: A MIXED OPPORTUNITY
description: El Paso directors rejected Burlington Northern's $24-a-share takeover offer. Page D3. By THOMAS J. LUECK

title: THE CITY
description: A year after he first called on the city's houses of worship to help shelter the homeless, Mayor Koch said yesterday that 10 churches in Manhattan and Brooklyn are now providing shelter for 110 men and women.

title: POP JAZZ
description: FOR more than 20 years, Beverly Peer, a stocky man of medium height with a round and jovial face, has spent his nights standing unostentatiously in the shadows behind and slightly to the left of Bobby Short, plucking at a bass while audiences at the Blue Angel, the Copley in Boston or, as now, at the Cafe Carlyle on Madison Avenue and 76th Street, listened to Mr. Short belt out songs by Cole Porter, Cy Coleman, Noel Coward and Stephen Sondheim.

title: WARNER REPORTS ATARI INSIDER CASE
description: Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner Communications Inc., said yesterday that two top officers of Warner's Atari Inc. unit had sold Warner stock just before Warner's announcement on Dec. 8 that its earnings this year would be only 10 percent to 15 percent above last year's figure. The earnings announcement caused the stock to plunge in price.

title: MOST POLES IN INTERNMENT BEING FREED
description: The Polish authorities said today that all political internees were being released, but that seven former Solidarity leaders among them had been formally arrested.

title: ART: THE SOARING MALCOLM MORLEY
description: IN art, as in football, there are times when someone gets the ball and cuts loose with it. That person in art at this moment is Malcolm Morley, whose new paintings and watercolors can be seen through Dec. 31 at the Xavier Fourcade Gallery, 36 East 75th Street.

title: UTILITIES PLAN TO PASS ALONG TRANSIT AID TAX SURCHARGE
description: A portion of a tax surcharge on corporations designed to subsidize mass transit fares will be passed along to utility customers and cost them up to $80 million a year, the New York State Public Service Commission said yesterday.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: 20-Point Difference

title: Legal Board's Fees Defended
description: A preliminary investigation of the large consulting fees charged by members of the board of the Legal Services Corporation has found no sign of wrongdoing, a White House official said today.

title: HEILEMAN WINS THE BATTLE FOR PABST
description: The year-and-a-half battle for the Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's fifth largest brewer, was finally settled yesterday with the G. Heileman Brewing Company, the fourth-largest brewer, winning control.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Slain In Gang-Style Shooting
description: A 24-year-old man who worked at his father's Brooklyn funeral parlor was shot to death gangland style yesterday morning as he left work for a coffee break, the police said.

title: In era of fund cuts, 2 nonprofit troupes team to do drama.
description: THE American Place Theater and Playwrights Horizons are joining forces to present a new American play - ''Buck'' by Ronald Ribman, who wrote ''Cold Storage,'' among other things. The marriage makes sense, they say, at a time of cuts in funding for the arts by the Government and corporations.

title: Mize Satisfactory
description: Johnny Mize, the 69-year-old former first baseman for the Yankees, the New York Giants and the St. Louis Cardinals, remained in satisfactory condition today following triplebypass heart surgery Tuesday at Emory University Hospital. Officials said he remained in the intensive care unit.

title: U.S. JUDGE QUASHES SUBPOENAS TO REVEAL TIMES NEWS SOURCES
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that a New York Times reporter did not have to testify about the sources for an article he wrote about a criminal defendant. But the court left open the possibility that a United States attorney might have to say whether he was one of the sources.

title: DEFENSE SPENDING TOO RAPID FOR THE U.S. GOOD
description: To the Editor: Professor Losman is right: analyses of military versus civilian spending which focus on the number of jobs created miss the main point. The social expenditure of labor and natural resources on producing any good or service - be it housing, subways, health care or MX missiles - is desirable precisely to the extent that the good or service produced is itself socially desirable. I vote for housing, subways and health care. ALAN SOKAL New York, Dec. 17, 1982

title: Perverted Technology vs. Wolves
description: Alaska is twice as big as Texas, with the population of Vermont. Appropriately, it's an inventive place. Last summer the state was paying each resident $1,000 from oil revenues just for living there -a windfall the newcomers pocketed happily but some of the oldtimers who really love the land resented, feeling that life in Alaska ought to be reward enough. A friend of ours whose car broke down five times on a vacation trip across the outback found that on every occasion he was helped by hospitable people who, because he was in trouble, charged him much less than would have been the case in the Northeast.

title: A 'DIMINISHED' SPIRIT OF COMPROMISE
description: The special post-election session of the Senate presented a spectacle of protracted and irritable confrontation that the nation has not seen in the World's Greatest Deliberative Body in many years.

title: U.S. Will Permit Entry Of Rumanian Girl, 16
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service reversed its earlier decision and granted permission yesterday for a 16-year-old Rumanian girl to join her family in the United States.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Fitchburg Gas
description: The Fitchburg Gas and Electric Light Company of Fitchburg, Mass., said it had agreed to make its January payment of $500,000 for its participation in the Seabrook nuclear units project in New Hampshire. There are 16 participants in the project, including the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the lead company. Fitchburg Gas said its directors had sanctioned the payment as a result of commitments from other Seabrook participants to conduct an in-depth study of the entire project over the next few months.

title: THE U.S.O. CARES
description: Since 1941, one organization has existed solely to provide for the physical and spiritual well-being of American service men and women.

title: Knicks Given a Deadline
description: The Knicks, having received permission to discuss contract terms with Johnny Davis, the Indiana Pacers' free-agent guard, are now faced with a deadline for signing him.

title: Egypt Freeing 127 Militants
description: The authorities have ordered the release of 127 Moslem militants who were detained as threats to domestic security, the Middle East News Agency said today. Thirty-two others were freed last Saturday.

title: Team Visits Jail
description: The bus ride was subdued. But then members of the St. John's University basketball team were hardly accustomed to riding in a Department of Corrections screened bus and practicing at Rikers Island.

title: Bennett Listing
description: The Bennett Petroleum Corporation, which recently filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code, said that as a result of its losses, it will be unable to meet the capital requirements set by the National Association of Securities Dealers for listing in the Nasdaq stock quotation system after Dec. 31.

title: LARGE AND SMALL COMPANIES AMONG THE WINNERS OF CABLE CONTRACTS
description: The six cable-television companies that were awarded rights to wire the boroughs outside of Manhattan under an agreement concluded yesterday are variously owned by large communications concerns and small local ventures.

title: BOND PRICES RISE HALF A POINT
description: Bond prices rose about half a point and short-term interest rates fell slightly in quiet trading yesterday. Dealers in Treasury securities - the most active sector of the credit markets in recent days - closed at 2.30 P.M. and will be closed today.

title: No Headline
description: U.C.L.A. IS UPSET IN TWO OVERTIMES

title: DR. ROBERT WELTSCH
description: Dr. Robert Weltsch, a leading Israeli journalist, died in Jerusalem Wednesday at the age of 91. Dr. Weltsch began his career in the German-language press in the Austro-Hungarian Empire and ended it as the London correspondent of the Israeli daily Haaretz.

title: From the tables of Central Asia.
description: ALTHOUGH the foods of Russia and the Ukraine have been represented in New York in a small way for many years, the exotic and lusty dishes of such Soviet republics as Georgia, Tadzhikistan and Uzbekistan are virtually unknown to this city. These hearty cuisines of Central Asia, most easily compared to Middle Eastern food, are distinguished by contrasting flavors of coriander, dill and hot chili peppers, onions, garlic and walnuts, pomegranate and lemon juices, sour plums and yogurt. In all these Central Asian regions, meats, fish and chicken are grilled on skewers, and there are the wonderfully crusty flat bread (lavash), thick stews and soups, boiled dumplings (vareniki, manty and pelmeni) and baked or fried turnovers (chebureki, sambusa and pirozhki) filled with meat or cheese.

title: Mexico Holds Oil Price
description: Mexico will keep its oil export prices unchanged in January, a spokesman for the state oil concern, Pemex, said today. He said prices would remain at $32.50 a barrel for light Isthmus crude and $25 a barrel for heavy Maya crude. Mexico, which is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, has held its prices steady.

title: STOKELY-VAN CAMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
VIOLENT YOUTH GANGS OF CHINATOWN REFLECT TENSIONS OF COMPLEX SOCIETY
description: The Golden Star bar on East Broadway, the site of a Chinatown shooting in which three people were killed early yesterday, squats below a typical Lower East Side red-brick tenement of the sort where various waves of immigrants to this country made their first homes.

title: Ousted Briton Leaves Soviet
description: Britain's naval attache, Capt. Bruce Richardson, whose expulsion was announced last week, left today. Captain Richardson, 42 years old, was expelled in what the British authorities have said was retaliation for the expulsion by Britain earlier this month of the Soviet naval attache, Capt. Anatoly Zotov.

title: People
description: * Richard Catania and Vernon Mackie have joined Sawdon & Bess Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates, as senior vice presidents and creative group heads.

title: LANECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
James E. Asker Is Wed To Stephanie E. Miller
description: Stephanie Elizabeth Miller and James Edwin Asker, both of Manhattan, were married yesterday in Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Joseph M. Zorawick, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: ITALIAN SOCIALISTS ACCUSED OF PLOTS
description: The Christian Democratic Party of Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani denounced its Socialist coalition partner today for accusing Bulgaria of complicity in the shooting of Pope John Paul II last year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Gifts for a Hero

title: TRADE UNIONISM STILL UNDER ATTACK BY ANKARA
description: To the Editor:

title: Stokely-Van Camp Gets Takeover Bid
description: Stokely-Van Camp Inc., a can and frozen-foods concern, said it had received a takeover offer from an investor group that is led by William B. Stokely 3d, its chairman, and includes senior management of the company.

title: Sorvino at last reaches age of his role.
description: AT 43, Paul Sorvino is finally the right age to play, in the movie version of ''That Championship Season,'' the part of a business tycoon that he created on stage 10 years ago. Mr. Sorvino, the only member of the original theater cast to appear in the film, had a terrible time when he and the other actors in the movie came together for a first reading of the script.

title: IN FRANCE, NOEL, NOEL REMAINS HO HUM, HO HUM
description: At nightfall now, they turn on the white lights in the plane trees on the Champs-Elysees. It is a decorator's icestorm: branches glowing cold, even and slick, a hard beauty, unassailable.

title: ART: MEGA TO MINI IN 2 SHOWS
description: AMONG the many outdoor sights to see around Manhattan this holiday season works of art loom large. Two recent - and temporary - additions to the scene, by the well-known English-born sculptor William Tucker, and Stewart Wilson, a young North Carolinian-turned-New Yorker, are in midtown, and well worth including on a Christmas constitutional.

title: THE CITY'S CHRISTMAS STOCKING
description: CHRISTMAS DAY is traditionally a time to spend with friends or family. But it is on such a holiday, when the streets are empty, their hubbub stilled, that the city extends a special kind of hospitality. ''Yes, come inside,'' it seems to say, like some unhurried hostess. But life doesn't come to a halt in New York, even on Christmas. And for those who wish to study this other face, the city offers a variety of prospects. One could, for instance, spend an entire day on Fifth Avenue and its side streets, guided by a tape tour that is now available.

title: JACK WEBB, LACONIC SGT. FRIDAY ON TV 'DRAGNET' SERIES, IS DEAD
description: Jack Webb, the stone-faced actor who achieved national reknown in the early days of television for his portrayal of Sgt. Joe Friday on the ''Dragnet'' series, died at his home in Los Angeles yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

title: Robert Charles Senkfor Wed to Constance Kent
description: Constance Kemler Kent, a teacher of English at the Horace Mann School in Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Robert Charles Senkfor, senior manager in New York for the Banco do Estado do Rio de Janeiro. The ceremony was performed at Trinity Episcopal Church in San Jose, Calif., by the Rev. David A. Cooling, a cousin of the bride.

title: Zia Out of Hospital; Reported to Have Flu
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan was released from Walter Reed Army Hospital today after a medical checkup, a Pakistani Embassy spokesman said.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY BALLET IN 'TAMING OF SHREW'
description: SOMETHING funny and wonderful happened to the Joffrey Ballet's production of ''The Taming of the Shrew'' on the way to the City Center this season.

title: NEW LAW ON TRUCKS WILL PERMIT BIG RIGS ON MORE U.S. ROADS
description: Sometime before next summer, motorists on crowded city streets that lead to major highways are likely to see a startling new sight: 75-foot double trailer trucks competing for space on the road.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ON THE BLACK HILL. By Bruce Chatwin. 249 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: RUTGERS DEFEATS STANFORD
description: Roy Hinson, the 6-foot-9-inch senior center, had one of the best games of his career tonight when he scored 21 points and blocked 11 shots to lead Rutgers to a 70-63 victory over Stanford.

title: Text of remarks, page A12.
description: President Reagan and King Hussein of Jordan held their second and final meeting of the week today, and afterward Mr. Reagan voiced optimism that negotiations aimed at achieving a Middle East peace settlement were ''within our reach.''

title: STAR GODS OF ANCIENT AMERICAS DROP IN
description: Any doubt that early New World peoples developed a sophisticated knowledge of the heavens should be dispelled by ''Star Gods of the Ancient Americas,'' an archeoastronomy exhibition that is at the American Museum of Natural History until March 27. No need to imagine visits from ancient astronauts to account for the enigmatic patterns on the Nazca plain in Peru. No reason to believe the Babylonians and early Egyptians, among others in the Old World, had a monopoly on the curiosity and patience required to see order in the movements of the sun and moon and stars.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Two girls were shot and killed in a Brooklyn apartment that was apparently used by a narcotics ring. The girls, Evette Guardiola, 17 years old, and Lillian Rodriquez, 16, were found last night at 370 Bushwick Avenue. ... A Brooklyn boy, Adanan Hasan, 15, was shot dead at 11 A.M. with a gun he and two friends had in a car near Prospect Park. ... Two trucks - one containing liquor, the other men's clothing - were hijacked.

title: Tiffany lamps get top prices.
description: CHRISTIE'S auction of Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Arts and Crafts designs on Dec. 10 and Dec. 11 at its Park Avenue and 59th Street galleries was one of the most successful of such wares in years. Of 321 lots, 270 sold, for $2,055,020. The stars of the sale were the stained-glass-shade, bronze-based lamps of Louis Comfort Tiffany. The most important of these were table lamps - one with a lotus-pattern shade sold for $308,000, another in a cobweb style brought $203,500 and a third with a shade awash with squash leaves was $198,000.

title: Closings Today
description: Stock markets and commodity markets are closed today, Christmas Eve. Most major New York banks will be open, but some in Connecticut and New Jersey will close.

title: STAGE: TENNIEL'S 'ALICE' AT THE VIRGINIA THEATER
description: IF there's any philanthropist around who's still frantically shopping for a present to give New York City this Christmas, his worries are now over. At Broadway's Virginia Theater, there is an exquisite collection of scenery and costumes that must be preserved for the delight of future generations of children - no matter what the cost.

title: Basketball Plan Doomed to Defeat
description: The attempt by the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council to reorganize Division I basketball by demoting 39 or more of the present 277 major college teams to Division II may be doomed to defeat during the N.C.A.A. convention in San Diego next month.

title: I'VE AN ACUTE CASE OF O.D.D., AMERICA'S PSYCHOTAXICAL MALADY
description: When Congress passed the sweeping tax bill of 1981, its members probably did not realize that the new law would have the effect of aggravating one of America's most pernicious psychological disabilities: obsessive-deductive disorder (or O.D.D., as it is commonly known).

title: ON THE INTREPID FLATTOP MUSEUM FOR HOLIDAYS
description: THE aircraft carrier Intrepid, no less a battlefield where Americans died fighting for their country than the fields of Flanders, Gettysburg and Normandy, lies tethered to Pier 86, West 46th Street on the Hudson River, where she has become a museum and a good place for a family visit this holiday season.

title: OMNI EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-The company went public in Nov, 1981 and, therefore, no comparable yr-ago results are available

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Christmas in Style

title: JAZZ: MODERN QUARTET
description: Aconcert by the Modern Jazz Quartet at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening not only renewed the group's custom, until it broke up in 1974, of giving a Christmas concert annually at Lincoln Center but it also celebrated the 30th anniversary of the quartet's founding and launched a series of short tours that will bring the quartet back to regular activity. It also introduced what may become known as the Modern Jazz Quintet.

title: Company Ends DeLorean Bid
description: Consolidated International said it would not exercise its option to purchase the plant and equipment of the DeLorean Motor Company in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

title: GRUMMAN GETS JOB REFURBISHING PLANES
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it had won a contract worth more than $120 million to update and refurbish light attack military aircraft that Malaysia had bought from the Air Force.

title: Sri Lanka Parliament Extended Six Years
description: President Junius Jayewardene signed a constitutional amendment into law today that extends the term of Sri Lanka's Parliament by six years starting next August.

title: BAIL FOR DELOREAN IS CUT BY ONE-HALF TO $5 MILLION
description: A Federal district judge has cut John Z. DeLorean's bail from $10 million to $5 million after defense attorneys said the automaker would lose his New York apartment and a $7.5 million credit line if bail was not lowered.

title: Suburban Propane
description: The Suburban Propane Gas Corporation of Morristown, N.J., said it had rejected a proposal from a major industrial company, which it did not identify, to acquire the company for about $51 a share, or a total of $268 million.

title: BTK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Oct 2
Judge Stays Execution Of Man Due to Die Today
description: A Federal judge reversed himself today and granted an indefinite stay of execution to a convicted murderer, Freddie Davis, who had been scheduled to die in the electric chair Friday.

title: INDIRECTLY
description: David and Helene Selznick owe something of a debt to Mitchell Berenson, although they don't know him. The Selznicks are a couple in their 20's who moved last July into a new condominium at Ledgewood Commons, off Route 100 in Millwood, a hamlet in the town of New Castle in Westchester. Mr. Selznick is an accountant in White Plains and his wife is a lawyer in Yonkers.

title: Dr. Joseph H. Fries, 80, Dies; A Retired New York Allergist
description: Dr. Joseph Harman Fries, a New York pediatric allergist, died Monday of a heart ailment at Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: No Santa, But A Hope
description: No, Messrs. Presidents and Prime Ministers, there isn't any Santa Claus. Or as Sylvia Ostry puts it, governments were saying early this year that there isn't any free lunch in fighting inflation, but they didn't realize how expensive lunch would be.

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1982; The Economy
description: An extension to restructure the bankruptcy courts was denied Congress by the Supreme Court. The decision cast substantial doubt on the ability of the Federal court system to handle corporate and personal bankruptcies in the foreseeable future. At issue is the jurisdictional status of the bankruptcy judges. (Page A1.)

title: Wife of Former Editor Dies of Gunshot Wound
description: Elsie Rockefeller McMillin, who was shot by her husband on Tuesday at her home on a Rockefeller estate in the Adirondacks, died yesterday at the Champlain Valley Medical Center-Physicians Center in Plattsburgh, N.Y. She was 58 years old.

title: HOLIDAY VIEWING TO START WITH 'YULE LOG' AFIRE
description: NOT surprisingly, Christmas weekend is overflowing with holiday programming. Just by flipping the dial this evening, viewers will be able to pick up a large assortment of caroling, beginning at 8 with the traditional ''Yule Log'' on WPIX, Channel 11. For two hours, the screen is filled with only the sight of a burning log, while the soundtrack offers Christmas songs. At midnight, CBS, Channel 2, will carry, live, a Christmas Eve mass in Spanish and English from SS. Peter and Paul Church in the South Bronx. Over on NBC, Channel 4, ''Christmas Rome - 1982'' will have Pope John Paul II celebrating mass at St. Peter's Basilica.

title: AINGE PROGRESSING PATIENTLY
description: Red Auerbach walked in on an unusual one-on-one game recently between Danny Ainge and Ainge's father at the Boston Garden. ''Donald Ainge is a young-looking man,'' said Auerbach, the president and general manager of the Boston Celtics, ''and they were going at each other pretty good. After Danny beat him, I asked his father how he could let his kid beat him. I told him I would never let a thing like that happen.''

title: Tax Impasse in Trenton
description: New Jersey's Legislature has bravely increased the state's income tax to cover a $150 million budget deficit, but Governor Kean is in full flight. He's prepared a veto message noting that income tax revenues are dedicated to education, which would gobble them up without relieving other budget problems.

title: Bolivian Officers Sacked For Destroying 'Prestige'
description: Gen. Luis Garcia Meza, a former President, and 14 other high-ranking military officers have been discharged from the armed forces, accused by a military tribunal of having ''destroyed the prestige of the armed forces.''

title: Addendum
description: * House Beautiful magazine will raise its cover price to $1.95, from $1.50, with the February issue.

title: British Trade Data
description: Record exports in November pushed Britain's visible trade surplus up to 470 million, or about $755 million, in November from 259 million, about $416 million, in October, the trade department said today.

title: ONCE AGAIN, BUSTLES ARE BIG IN NEW YORK
description: The first question is why. Why in the world would they do it? The second question is how. How in the world do they manage it? The third question is: Is it really worth it? All this ado about something as archaic as laced corsets, crinolines and black stockings at the beach. Still, it cannot be denied that bustles are back, and that, just as sleeves looked as though they would take off into space last year, this season it's derrieres, bedecked in poufs, drapes and gigantic bows.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 13
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $271,000 for the qr and $1,128,000 for the24 weeks mostly from the exchange of common stock for convertible debentures and a tax credit of $630,000 for the 24 weeks

title: NUNS ARE UPHELD IN SUIT ON BISHOP
description: Four Roman Catholic nuns have the right to sue their bishop for a public hearing on the church's decision to dismiss them as parochial school teachers, the New Hampshire Supreme Court ruled today.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Merlin Off Till Jan. 30
description: ''Merlin,'' the musical co-starring Doug Henning and Chita Rivera, has been postponed until Jan. 30. Directed by Ivan Reitman, the play will continue in previews at the Hellinger Theater. This is its second postponement.

title: MERGER TALKS SPUR MARKET
description: With takeover situations providing much of yesterday's excitement, stock prices generally advanced on modest trading volume in the final session before Christmas. Steel issues moved higher in response to substantial increases in mid-December sales of new automobiles.

title: THE CITY'S CHRISTMAS STOCKING
description: AS surely as the enthronement of Santa Claus in department-store toy sections, as surely as the enshrinement of the great tree above the skating rink at Rockefeller Center, Christmas - like other holidays - brings to the movie screens that category of film known as children's entertainment.

title: The Next Governor At Bank of England
description: Robin Leigh-Pemberton, chairman of the National Westminster Bank, was named yesterday to be the next governor of the Bank of England, Britain's central bank.

title: Harvester Extends A Deadline Again
description: The International Harvester Company, the farmequipment maker that is struggling to win concessions from public debt holders, said it had again extended the deadline for its offer to exchange old bonds for new debentures with detachable warrants.

title: Basement Blast Injures Owner of Explosives
description: Richard Lucas, 53 years old, lost a hand and a foot in an explosion in his basement Wednesday afternoon. When the police came they removed 120 pipe bombs, parts for 100 others, 15

title: Bombs in Australia Hit Jewish and Israeli Sites
description: Two separate bombings wrecked the Israeli Consulate in Sydney and damaged a surburban Jewish club today.

title: DR. WALTER BRIEHL, A PIONEER OF GROUP THERAPY METHODS
description: Dr. Walter Briehl, a Los Angeles psychiatrist who helped to develop group psychotherapy, died of congestive heart failure Monday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 85 years old.

title: SEOUL'S CONSTANT CRITIC
description: When he was a young soldier during the Korean War, Kim Dae Jung was captured by Communist forces and sentenced to be shot. Moments before he was to be brought before a firing squad, Mr. Kim escaped.

title: The Gift of Freedom
description: T omorrow will be just another workday for Pedro Ramos on the west side of Miami. He will report to his job and put in an eight-hour day, with no time to observe Christmas.

title: Referee's Rationale
description: Joey Curtis is the referee who stopped the World Boxing Association's heavyweight title fight between Mike Weaver and Michael Dokes at 63 seconds of the first round Dec. 10 -and who could not help hearing the ringside cries of ''fix, fix, fix'' that accompanied his decision. Two weeks later, Curtis now says that he spent several sleepless nights after that Las Vegas bout but that he is convinced he was right when he awarded the fight to Dokes, making him the new champion.

title: KING'24 SPARK NETS
description: Albert King, in the worst shooting slump of his short career, had been saying that if he just concentrated on the other parts of his game, the shooting touch would return. Tonight, he proved himself correct.

title: PSA-Braniff Pact
description: PSA Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement with the Braniff International Corporation on the previously announced plan for PSA to lease 30 Braniff aircraft and form a new domestic route system. It said the plan includes hiring more than 1,500 former employees of Braniff, which has declared bankruptcy, in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

title: CARE Chooses BBDO Direct
description: Just in time for Christmas, when thoughts of giving to others should be paramount, BBDO Direct has been named a consultant on advertising, direct marketing and fund raising to CARE Inc., the 36-year-old international aid organization.

title: Catherine Wolpert Is Wed
description: Catherine Lynn Wolpert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Wolpert of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul Dudley Novas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Novas of Chicago. State Supreme Court Justice Frank Vaccaro performed the ceremony at the Laurent restaurant in Manhattan. The bride is a student at the Northwestern Medical School in Chicago, where her husband is an engineer for Amoco Oil Company.

title: McDonnell Planes
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has been awarded a $2.8 billion contract to build 44 KC-10 cargo tanker aircraft as part of the Air Force's buildup of airlift capability, the Defense Department said. The five-year contract obligates $866 million in the first year for production of the initial eight planes, to be built by the company's plant in Long Beach, Calif.

title: ASSETS OF MONEY FUNDS OFF A RECORD $8.3 BILLION
description: Total assets of the nation's money market mutual funds dropped a record $8.3 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Despite the size of the decline, the funds were able to handle the withdrawals without any forced sales of assets.

title: AT 3-4, GIANTS SAINTS, LIONS AND BUCS FACE PLAYOFF
description: RISK By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

title: TOPPS & TROWSERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Advertising; New Color In Life's Campaign
description: HAVING spent five years pre-empting red and white as its private color combination, Life magazine will test the adaptability of the advertising community next month. It's going to strike with shocking pink. And that is just the beginning.

title: INVITATION TO BARGAIN
description: Yuri V. Andropov's arms reduction proposals are too vague and leave too many unanswered questions for quick acceptance; but they were forthcoming enough to make the public responses of the United States, Britain and France seem too abrupt and dismissive.

title: KOCH VISIT HELPS REOPEN REDONE BRIDAL CHAPEL
description: Mayor Koch kissed the bride yesterday. She couldn't have been more surprised. Minerva Inchusti and Juan Torres had gone to the Municipal Building chapel for a quiet wedding. What they got instead was the Mayor and his Budget Director, Alair A. Townsend, as guests, television crews to record the event and champagne and cookies on the house - Gracie Mansion.

title: UNITED CANSO OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; results for the latest yr reflect a writedown of oil and gas properties of $23.8 million and a net loss of $11.1 million from increased depletioninventory writedowns and losses from discontinued operations and on their disposal; the company is listed on the Boston, Philadelphia, Pacific, Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT REAGAN'S NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. OPENING STATEMENT

title: MOSCOW'S FUR HATS-A CLASS ACT
description: Turgenev once wondered why people in the streets of Paris turned around to stare at him as he strolled along, and it may well have been because of the fur hat he wore. In Moscow today, people are apt to turn and stare at anyone not wearing a fur hat in winter. Indeed, the fur hat has become for the ordinary Russian, male and female, an indispensable article of clothing. And more than that, it is a kind of status symbol.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A CHRISTMAS BOUNTY OF FUN FOR YOUNGSTERS
description: From Orson Bean as Scrooge, the man we love to hate, to young ballet dancers in a new version of ''The Prince and the Pauper'' and even those madcap Paper Bag Players, the Christmas season brings a bounty of entertainment for young audiences in and around the city.

title: No Headline
description: SUPERSONICS TAKE 5th IN ROW

title: A DEMOGRAPHER IN DEMAND, UNLIKELY AS IT SEEMS
description: Of all the miles of dreary corridors and offices in which civil servants work at the uncelebrated tasks of government, none are reputed to be more stifling than those at the Department of Agriculture, where ossification has become respectable with age.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We think this is a tremendous move forward for transportation, and a great breakthrough for mass transit.'' - Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis. (A1:6.)

title: ADVENT OF HOLIDAYS DEEPENS SCARS OF THOSE ON THE ROAD SEEKING WORK
description: On Dec. 1, Jim Holt set out from Jackson, Miss., to look for work in San Diego. He is on his way home for Christmas now, with nothing to show for a month on the road but some aches in his body and the hurt in his soul.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Wheat
description: The Agriculture Department said today that private exporters had reported sales of 775,000 tons of winter wheat for shipment to the Soviet Union during the year ending next May 31.

title: BRIEFING
description: Two-Way Stampede

title: News Analysis
description: The quick rejection by the United States, Britain and France of the latest Soviet proposal for arms control is regarded here as only the first, and perhaps the lightest, salvo in what may be a complicated year ahead in East-West relations.

title: Icahn Extends Bid
description: The Icahn Group said it had extended its $18-a-share tender offer for Dan River Inc. until midnight Dec. 27.

title: SURGING CAPITALS ROUT ISLANDERS
description: The young and energetic Washington Capitals, the Cinderella team of the season, lengthened their unbeaten streak to 14 games tonight with a 5-1 victory over the Islanders.

title: JAPAN EASES TARIFFS ON SOME IMPORTS
description: The Japanese Government said today that it planned to cut import tariffs on more than 70 items in another effort to ease the mounting friction with its Western trading partners. The list of items includes tobacco products, chocolate, biscuits and 40 other agricultural goods, and 28 manufactured items.

title: COURT ENDS STAY ON BANKRUPTCIES
description: The Supreme Court refused today to extend the Dec. 24 deadline that it gave Congress for restructuring the nation's bankruptcy courts.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Erte's Art Stolen From Brooklyn Deli

title: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Summary; FRIDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1982
description: International Seoul freed the leading challenger to the Government. The opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, left South Korea on a flight for the United States after serving two and a half years of a 20-year prison sentence for sedition. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) President Reagan and King Hussein held their second and final meeting of the week. After the 25-minute session, Mr. Reagan expressed optimism that negotiations aimed at achieving a Middle East peace settlement were ''within our reach,'' but the Jordanian leader indicated he had not yet acceded to American appeals that he enter Israeli-Egyptian negotiations on Palestian self-rule. (A1:4.)

title: WHEN A STAR IS BORN IN A STEAMROOM
description: Less than a year ago, Judith Ivey was ready to leave the theater for good. She was ready to give up acting, maybe become a veterinarian instead. It wasn't that she'd failed to get good roles - in fact she'd just won praise for her performances in ''Piaf'' and ''Pastorale''; it was more that she was tired of being poor, tired of waiting in unemployment lines between shows, and she was impatient for success. With her latest Broadway show, ''Steaming,'' however, all that has changed - acclaimed by the critics, Judith Ivey has become a star.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for QTr to Nov 30
BRIEFS
description: * Bethlehem Steel Corp. said it had agreed to sell its ship repair yard in Boston to Boston Shipyard Corp. for an undisclosed amount.

title: HONDURAN'S DAUGHTER FREED
description: The Honduran President's kidnapped daughter was freed tonight as her abductors had pledged, a relative said.

title: 2 L.I. Men Guilty In Business Plot
description: Two Suffolk County men were convicted Wednesday night of charges involving what prosecutors said was an attempt by organized crime to take control of a major Long Island mortgage company.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Ring for the Wedding

title: PAPER ORDERS REPORTERS TO IDENTIFY SOURCE ACCUSING EX-IRAN HOSTAGE
description: Two reporters for a suburban newspaper here have been directed by their publisher to break a pledge of confidentiality and to identify publicly their sources for a 1981 article linking a former hostage in Iran to drug dealing.

title: BURLINGTON'S BID CALLED INADEQUATE BY EL PASO'S BOARD
description: The El Paso Company said yesterday that its board of directors had found the $24-a-share offer by Burlington Northern Inc. for just over half of the energy company to be inadequate and not in the best interest of its shareholders.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amarco Resources Corp., Dallas, announced that R. Brooks Reed, chairman and chief executive officer, was assuming the additional responsibilities of president, following the resignation of Jack E. Meyer.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Thoroughbred Racing Aqueduct Race Track, Ozone Park, Queens, 11 A.M. This is the only horse racing, flat or harness, in the metropolitan area today. Belwood Deb is the favorite in the feature, a $41,000 handicap for fillies and mares at six furlongs. With the post time moved up an hour and a half, the feature will probably go off between 1:45 and 2 P.M. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7 P.M., tape.)

title: Argentina's Leader Promises '83 Vote and End of Army Rule
description: President Reynaldo Bignone said today that the military Government would step down late next year after national elections, restoring democracy after almost eight years of military rule.

title: Michigan State Sued Over Coach
description: Attorneys for the Philadelphia Stars of the United States Football League filed a lawsuit today against Michigan State, contending that the university interfered unlawfully with the Stars' coaching contract with George Perles.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES JUMP 38.3%
description: The Big Three domestic automobile manufacturers reported today that sales of new cars jumped 38.3 percent in the Dec. 11-20 period, continuing a trend of rising sales that began in mid-October. The increase prompted optimism among industry analysts even though, at the end of this month, Detroit will close out its worst year of sales in more than 20 years.

title: REXON BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $75,000 for the qr and yr

title: Stabler, Rogers May Be Sidelined
description: The quarterback Kenny Stabler and a running back, George Rogers, were listed as doubtful by the New Orleans Saints for Sunday's game against the Washington Redskins.

title: DIOXIN THREAT CITED
description: Federal health officials told residents of Times Beach, Mo., today not to return to their flooddamaged homes because preliminary test showed the area to be contaminated with high levels of dioxin.

title: CAROLING: WHEN EVERYONE IS A SINGER
description: CHRISTMAS carols bring out the singer in everyone. People who wouldn't dare warble along with Kiri Te Kanawa, or even with Mick Jagger, gladly lift their voices in song when the song is ''O Come All Ye Faithful'' or that misnomer ''Silent Night.'' From a musical perspective, the spirit of the season belongs to the spirited amateur, and roving bands of them regularly take to the streets of New York with tidings of comfort and joy amid teetering high notes.

title: INDIA-PAKISTAN COMMISSION IS APPROVED
description: India and Pakistan announced agreement here today on the formation of a joint commission to promote cooperation between their Governments in a variety of fields.

title: A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's
description: A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's Last of nine articles that have appeared periodically since Sept. 27. By DENA KLEIMAN

title: MOTORISTS MIGHT ESCAPE BRUNT OF THE HIGHER TAX
description: The nickel-a-gallon increase in the Federal gasoline tax is likely to go virtually unnoticed - and perhaps even largely unpaid - by American motorists, analysts said after final approval of the measure by Congress today.

title: Reward in School Rape Case
description: The Council of Supervisors and Administrators, a 4,000-member union representing principals and assistant principals in the New York school system, offered a reward of $1,000 yesterday for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the man who raped a 48-yearold assistant principal at Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx last Tuesday morning. Anyone with information is asked to call the 48th Precinct at 220-5311.

title: RONYK CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
New Budget Voted For Westchester
description: The Westchester Board of Legislators cut $1.2 million from County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's proposed 1983 spending plan tonight before approving a final budget of $547.6 million.

title: REAGAN ASKS EACH BUSINESS TO HIRE ONE JOBLESS WORKER
description: President Reagan, asked what seasonal comfort he might offer the nearly 12 million jobless workers, today urged the nation's businesses to ''take a look and see if they can hire just one person'' to cut into the highest unemployment rate since World War II.

title: CUBA AS AN EXAMPLE TO ITS NEIGHBORS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS EXCHANGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INTERCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
I.M.F. Loan To Mexico
description: The International Monetary Fund today gave final approval for a $3.9 billion loan to Mexico and said $2 billion of new trade credits had been arranged from 10 industrial nations.

title: THE DISTANT MUSIC OF THE HOUNDS
description: To perceive Christmas through its wrapping becomes more difficult with every year. There was a little device we noticed in one of the sporting-goods stores - a trumpet that hunters hold to their ears so that they can hear the distant music of the hounds. Something of the sort is needed now to hear the incredibly distant sound of Christmas in these times, through the dark, material woods that surround it. ''Silent Night,'' canned and distributed in thundering repetition in the department stores, has become one of the greatest of all noisemakers, almost like the rattles and whistles of Election Night. We rode down on an escalator the other morning through the silent-nighting of the loudspeakers, and the man just in front of us was singing, ''I'm gonna wash this store right outa my hair, I'm gonna wash this store ...''

title: BRICKHOUSE IN HALL
description: Jack Brickhouse, a veteran of 5,000 baseball broadcasts in the Chicago area, was named the recipient of the Ford C Frick Award, presented annually to a broadcaster by the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: THE CITY'S CHRISTMAS STOCKING
description: ALTHOUGH strolling through midtown on Christmas Day can be as spiritually satisfying as it is visually exciting, there comes a time when one is in need of rest, warmth and sustenance in the form of food and drink. Many restaurants that will be open tomorrow, of course, but most require serious planning and advance reservations. For strollers in search of impromptu stopovers, such as cafes and patisseries, the choice is fairly limited. The following places do offer possibilities, and if they do not consistently turn out wonderful food, each has a few reliable specialties. In most of these places, prices are fairly high, the two moderate exceptions being Cafe Geiger and the Museum Cafe.

title: 'HEADLINE PUZZLE' FOR CODE BREAKERS
description: On the theory that crossword puzzles and other traditional brain teasers would not present a sufficient challenge to the thousands of code breakers who work at the National Security Agency, the editors of the agency's monthly newsletter publish a monthly feature called Headline Puzzle.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BERGMAN TEAM FINDS JUST THE RIGHT WORDS
description: FEW writers who create songs for movies have enjoyed more success than Alan and Marilyn Bergman, the husband-and-wife team who won Oscars for ''The Windmills of Your Mind'' and ''The Way We Were.'' This season, the Bergmans are busy as ever, having written song lyrics for two big Christmas releases, ''Tootsie,'' (the title song and ''It Might Be You'') and ''Best Friends'' (How Do You Keep the Music Playing?''). And next year, Barbra Streisand's movie ''Yentl,'' for which they wrote nine songs with Michel Legrand, is due for release.

title: Friday; CARNEGIE CHRISTMAS EVE
description: A Christmas Eve tradition will continue tonight, when the New York String Orchestra conducted by Alexander Schneider plays at midnight at Carnegie Hall. The orchestra is made up of about 65 high-schooland college-age musicians chosen by audition from the United States and Europe. They spend their Christmas vacations in intensive rehearsals, workshops and master classes, and then play twice at Carnegie Hall and once at Washington's Kennedy Center. Tonight's program is Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 2and Vivaldi's Concerto No. 2 for Two Violins. The second concert is Wednesday at 8 P.M. Tickets are $4 to $7.50. The number to charge tickets is 247-7459. CAROUSEL SHOW IN PARK

title: Now Give the M.T.A. a Deadline
description: New York City's transit fare remains at 75 cents because legislators in two capitals finally read their deadlines accurately.

title: Nevada Institutes Wait for Boxers
description: Gov. Robert List signed an emergency regulation today requiring boxers who are knocked out to wait at least 45 days before they fight again.

title: PACIFIC REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including a gain of $1.2 million on the sale of properties and recoveries on former non-earning assets and an extraordinary expense of $130,000...C-Net loss including a gain of $179,000 on the sale of properties and recoveries on former non-earnings assets and an extraordinary expense of $600,000

title: Dorsett Has a Scare
description: Tony Dorsett, the Dallas Cowboys' running back, had a scare early yesterday.

title: RETAILERS' CHRISTMAS GAINS SLIM
description: With one day to go till Christmas, retailers around the country are reporting sales gains that, on average, lag behind those of last year's generally weak shopping season.

title: When a Top Executive At Bell Unit Speaks Out
description: At the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, executives are known for their ability to toe the company line - even if they sometimes disagree with policy. Last week, however, one executive showed that not all senior Bell managers are willing to conform.

title: KIM DAE JUNG ARRIVES IN U.S. AFTER BEING FREED BY SOUTH KOREA
description: Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's leading opposition figure, left Seoul today for the United States after serving two and a half years of a 20-year prison sentence for sedition.

title: THE 'APPEASEMENT' OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLIDAY TRAVEL UPSTATE SLOWED BY A SNOWSTORM
description: A snowstorm swirled into northern New York State from the West yesterday, dumping more than six inches of snow on Binghamton and three inches on Albany before changing to rain.

title: THE YEAR'S TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the year's most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. The standings are based on national sales and radio air-play reports. Albums 1Asia Asia 2Beauty and the Beat Go-Go's 34 Foreigner 4American Fool John Cougar 5Freeze-Frame J. Geils Band 6Escape Journey 7Get Lucky Loverboy 8Bella Donna Stevie Nicks 9Chariots of Fire Vangelis 10Ghost in the Machine The Police Singles 1Physical Olivia Newton-John 2Eye of the Tiger Survivor 3I Love Rock 'n' Roll Joan Jett & Blackhearts 4Ebony & Ivory McCartney & Wonder 5Centerfold J. Geils Band 6Don't You Want Me Human League 7Jack and Diane John Cougar 8Hurts So Good John Cougar 9Abracadabra Steve Miller Band 10Hard to Say I'm Sorry Chicago Copyright c 1982 by Billboard Publications Inc.

title: OPELIKA MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $162,000 for the qr and $777,000for the yr

title: Last in 'Messiah' Series
description: The fifth and final performance of this year's ''Messiah'' series by David Randolph's Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra will take place Sunday afternoon at 2:30 in Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets are $7 to $16. Information: (201) 538-1860.

title: Oregon Guru Rebuffed in Bid On Permanent U.S. Residency
description: Immigration officials have refused to grant permanent residence status to Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, a guru whose disciples took political control of the Oregon town of Antelope.

title: Salazar Detours
description: Alberto Salazar is lining up his 1983 running program, and it does not include the Wanamaker Millrose Games nor the Boston Marathon. But it does include an April 30 marathon in Australia against Rob de Castella, the Commonwealth Games champion, for a planned first prize of $30,000.

title: Vietnam Veterans Begin Vigil
description: A group of unemployed Vietnam veterans began a round-the-clock candlelight vigil at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial tonight to call attention to the 1,421 veterans still missing in action.

title: STARTING GUN IN AN AIRLINE TICKET COMMISSION WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowl Games Offer Consolation
description: The bowl games they are playing in today are not exactly what they had in mind when the season started, but Washington and North Carolina have a chance to gain some consolation for previous disappointments.

title: BUSHWICK PARISH RESTORING ORGAN TO PAST GLORY
description: According to letters the Rev. Edmund Brady found in the attic of the rectory, the pipe organ at St. Barbara's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn had begun to falter early in 1972. By the end of that year, many of the keys would not work. Others would not shut off.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1982; The Economy
description: Auto makers are closing out the year with the lowest output since 1958 - 5,055,551 cars. But analysts see the low dealer inventories that resulted setting the stage for stronger orders in 1983. (Page 29.)

title: ROCK: STEVE FORBERT CONCERT
description: IN the last three years, Steve Forbert, the folk-rock singer-songwriter from Meridian, Miss., has taken a critical beating after having been initially hailed as a pop music savior . While it's true that the fresh-faced Mr. Forbert's songwriting hasn't developed in depth and sophistication since his first album, ''Alive on Arrival,'' he nonetheless remains an engaging rock-and-roller who exudes the charm of a perpetually innocent young rake.

title: LAWS AS USEFUL AS PEOPLE THINK THEY ARE...
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Orders Benefits Restored to Mentally Ill
description: Thousands of mentally ill people in six Middle Western states will again receive Social Security disability assistance payments under an order striking down strict Federal guidelines that had halted the benefits.

title: Top-Rated Teams Take a Fall
description: Chaminade's victory over top-ranked Virginia was not the only upset Thursday night involving unbeaten college basketball teams rated in the top 20.

title: YOUNGSTERS TELL SANTA A JOB FOR DAD IS WHAT THEY NEED THIS CHRISTMAS
description: Since Thanksgiving, Chris Ravlin has been portraying Santa Claus in the Bristol Centre shopping mall here. At least once an hour, he said, a child has made the same request of him. He remembers the first one to do so.

title: Lautenberg Quits Port Agency Post
description: United States Senator-elect Frank R. Lautenberg today announced his resignation as a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Mr. Lautenberg, elected in November over Representative Millicent Fenwick, a Republican, disclosed he was resigning in a letter to Governor Kean.

title: BUSINESS LOSSES AND GAINS IN CONGRESS
description: Among the few beneficiaries of the post-election session of the 97th Congress was the hard-pressed trucking industry, which received some much needed help from the gasoline tax legislation. The session is more likely to be remembered for the bills affecting business that fell victim to filibusters and the rush to get home for Christmas.

title: ATTACK ON THE POPE: THE HARD QUESTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Faces Arson Charge In School Headquarters Fires
description: A high school teacher has been accused of trying to burn down his school district's administration building.

title: NOBODY'S STORY
description: He lived in a busy place, and he worked very hard to live. He had no hope of ever being rich enough to live a month without hard work, but he was quite content, God knows, to labour with a cheerful will. He was one of an immense family, all of whose sons and daughters gained their daily bread by daily work, prolonged from their rising up bedtimes until their lying down at night. Beyond this destiny he had no prospect, and be sought none.

title: Salvadoran Army Says It Killed 42 Rebels
description: The army killed 42 guerrillas and destroyed four rebel camps in eastern El Salvador in a three-day offensive, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today. Government troops reportedly suffered only two wounded.

title:
PATENTS;
Diagnostic Instrument For Knee Joint Granted
description: A veteran orthopedic surgeon who for the last five years has limited his practice to the knee joint was granted a patent this week for a diagnostic instrument to be used in that area. Dr. Joseph H. Dashefsky of Plainview, L.I., has found the instrument very helpful in evaluation of many knee problems.

title: 2 Sisters Win Lotto; Split $1.9 Million
description: Two sisters who played the same six numbers in the state's Pick-6 Lotto game this week split a jackpot of nearly $1.9 million, state lottery officials said today.

title: Navy Reports on Sub Disposal
description: Sinking nuclear submarines at sea or burying their radioactive comparments at the Hanford nuclear reservation in eastern Washington would not seriously affect the environment or human health, the Navy says.

title: Bridge: A Good Fit Doesn't Mean The Suit Has to Be Right
description: A popular theme in bridge literature for more than half a century has been the superiority of the 4-4 fit over the 5-3 fit. This has some validity, particularly on deals where a discard or two is needed, but there are plenty of exceptions.

title: CLASH NEAR BEIRUT KILLS 13 LEBANESE
description: Rightist Christian and leftist Druse militiamen traded daylong artillery and rocket barrages near United States Marine positions south of Beirut today, and the police said 13 more Lebanese were killed.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 36.

title:
PATENTS;
Heart Valve Reduces Chance of Clotting
description: A heart valve invented at the Pennsylvania State University's Medical Center in Hershey, Pa., is described as resembling a natural aortic valve and as eliminating many of the complications found in earlier prosthetic valves. It has undergone successful trials with animals.

title: CAR OUTPUT LOWEST IN 24 YEARS
description: When the assembly lines of the five domestic auto makers halted on Thursday for the customary year-end break, they had produced the fewest cars for any year since 1958.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses to Bar Nativity Scene in Florida
description: A Federal District judge ruled today that West Miami can keep its Nativity scene on display at City Hall because tax money was not used to put it up.

title: Don't Rush the Air Controllers
description: Inadequate training for air traffic controllers, says the National Transportation Safety Board, has created ''some specific safety problems.'' Newly certified controllers, the board argues, should not serve as instructors for trainees.

title: MORGAN FAIRCHILD TURNS TO THEATER
description: Could this be the paranoid Jennifer who did in her boyfriend's father in the soap opera ''Search for Tomorrow?'' Or the rich, spoiled Constance who put thugs on the trail of her husband's girlfriend in television's steamy ''Flamingo Road?''

title: 5 Die as Car Runs Red Light
description: Five people, including three children, were killed and four others were injured today when their auto ran a red light, hit another car and struck a tree. The driver of the victims' auto, Santos Colon, 28 years old, of Reading, was in the intensive care unit of Sacred Heart Hospital, where he was arraigned on five counts of homicide by motor vehicle and a charge of driving under the influence of alcohol, the police said.

title: Chase Drops Peat Marwick
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had dropped Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co., its auditor since 1969, and appointed Price Waterhouse in its place.

title: Ratings Game
description: The numbers are in for the first year of the N.C.A.A.'s four-year football television contract with ABC and CBS. ABC won - just barely - but college football lost some of its overall clout.

title: Police to Question Mrs. Latourette
description: The police said today they would question the widow of Dr. Chuck Latourette on Sunday in connection with the doctor's death from a gunshot wound.

title: KUWAIT IN BAILOUT EFFORT AFTER MARKET COLLAPES
description: Almost five months after the crash of Kuwait's unofficial stock market, the Government this week began paying off some of the thousands of investors who lost billions of dollars in a complex crisis that staggered the tiny oil-rich state overlooking the Persian Gulf.

title: 'WRENCHING' DUTY FOR BROWN BELL
description: Charles L. Brown made history this year - and changed forever the telecommunications industry. Mr. Brown, the 61-year-old chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, agreed in January to divest A.T.& T., the largest private corporation in the world, of the 22 Bell System operating companies that provide most of the nation's local phone service.

title: C.F. FINDLEY WEDS DOROTHY DARLINGTON
description: Staff Sgt. Dorothy Sillcox Darlington and Gunnery Sgt. Charles Francis Findley, both of the Marine Corps, were married yesterday at St. Eustace Episcopal Church in Lake Placid, N.Y. The Rev. William D. Hayes performed the ceremony.

title: Skiing 'Hotshots'
description: When Lloyd and Eleanor Lambert organized the 70-Plus Ski Club in January 1977, they said the purpose of the club was to obtain free skiing and discounts for active downhill skiers.

title: RULING UPHOLDING NUNS IN A LAWSUIT COULD AFFECT CONTRACTS BY CHURCHES ; News Analysis
description: A decision by the New Hampshire Supreme Court allowing four Roman Catholic nuns to go ahead with a suit against their bishop breaks with Catholic tradition and highlights the increasing court involvement in intrachurch disputes.

title: Pipe Bomb Found
description: An eight-inch pipe bomb was found beneath an automobile parked on Third Avenue near 49th Street shortly after dawn yesterday, the police said.

title: PLAYERSMalcolm Moran; Playing Hockey as Therapy
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. J effrey Bourne's new playmate arrived two weeks ago. ''We didn't know what his reaction would be,'' said Bob Bourne, his father and a forward for the Islanders. But not long after the arrival of Justin Thomas Bourne, the second son of Bob and Janice Bourne, it was clear that Jeffrey approved.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Elf Who Visited P.S. 2

title: SINE QUA NON FOR AN AFGHANISTAN SETTLEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSITION FOR AGEE
description: When he announced in August that the Bendix Corporation wanted to buy the Martin Marietta Corporation, William M. Agee, the chairman of Bendix, surely thought he would finish the year atop a bigger, broader-based company.

title: Nevada Gaming Board Shifts; Nevada Gaming Board To Get New Members
description: The state Gaming Control Board, which polices Nevada's billion-dollar casino industry, is going through its biggest changes in 16 years.

title: '100-TO-1' LOSS FOR VIRGINIA
description: ''Last week, we beat the University of Hawaii, and we looked at it as our biggest day ever. Now we knock off the No. 1 team in the nation. It's unbelievable, 100-to-1 odds and more. What more can I say?''

title: LAWS AS USEFUL AS PEOPLE THINK THEY ARE...
description: To the Editor:

title: A Blackout Stays
description: Seats for next week's Liberty Bowl in Memphis, between Alabama and Illinois, had been sold out even before Paul (Bear) Bryant announced that the game would mark his farewell as head coach of the Crimson Tide. But the bowl's executive committee refuses to drop its television blackout in the Memphis area despite a Federal lawsuit filed there by Jack Sammons, an Alabama alumnus who lives in Memphis and who contends that the blackout violates the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: FOR MONTANA, A SANTA CLAUS WITH $40,000
description: An anonymous benefactor who believes that God ''does not want any sad little faces on Christmas morning'' spent $40,000 this year to make sure poor children get toys.

title: Career on Ice
description: As an amateur, Lisa-Marie Allen was one of the most prominent American figure skaters. Tonight, Miss Allen will start her second season as a professional with the Ice Capades show, but she is equally enthusiastic about the possibilities of joining the Pro Skate tour that opened successfully last weekend at Madison Square Garden.

title: SCOUTING
description: Chaminade University's stunning 77-72 upset of Virginia on Thursday night in Honolulu was a major boost for the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics, which has always lived in the shadows of its counterpart, the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Nets, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. The Nets have beaten the Knicks in six straight games, the longest winning streak any club has against New York.

title: NETWORKS DIVIDED ON PBS CONVENTION ROLE
description: A proposal by Leonard Goldenson, chairman of ABC, that the Public Broadcasting Service assume sole responsibility for gavel-to-gavel coverage of the 1984 political conventions has provoked mixed reactions at the other two major commercial networks, CBS and NBC.

title: AGE HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH BEING OLD
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Analysis
description: Three years ago yesterday a Soviet airborne division landed at the airport at Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan. Five days later two Soviet mechanized infantry divisions, leading a force of about 60,000 troops, crossed the Soviet-Afghan border and seized the country's cities, airports and highways.

title: Court to Give Up Control Of Boston School System
description: Federal District Judge Arthur Garrity Jr., who spent eight years overseeing integration in the nation's oldest public school system, will hand control of the system to the state on Jan. 3.

title: Apartment Fire Kills 4
description: A fire that killed four people in a downtown apartment building today was suspicious in origin, the state police fire marshal's office said. What is left of the Palm Plaza Apartments probably will be demolished next week, Fire Chief William Balthaser said.

title: A Full Field
description: From more than 300 applications, The Association of Tennis Professionals has narrowed the field to 15 in its search for an executive director to succeed Earl (Butch) Buchholz.

title: Honduran's Daughter, Now Free, Sees Father
description: The daughter of the President of Honduras flew to Tegucigalpa today for a meeting with her father after her release from nine days of captivity in Guatemala.

title: Japan Assails Trade Bar
description: Japan's top trade official, Sadanori Yamanaka, said today that a United States Senate resolution to bar Japanese-made machine tools from investment-tax credits hampers trade talks.

title: FLU DETERRENCE
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATNETS;
Improved Projection For TV Screens Added
description: An improved projection television tube, useful in the display of football games and other events on large screens in homes or public places, was patented this week by Henry E. Kloss, president of the Kloss Video Corporation, Cambridge, Mass. About 60,000 of the tubes have been produced and sold in this country and abroad.

title: To Forgive Is Divine
description: The City Council is forever complaining that it gets no respect, that people snicker unfairly at its occasional pratfalls, that its dominant but unmerited public image is that of a large chamber of hot air. Well, this time it may have a point.

title: BRIEFING
description: Loyalty in a Defection

title: 14 Killed by a Rightist Group, Colombia Rights Unit Reports
description: Colombia's human rights committee said today that 14 people had been killed in the country by a paramilitary right-wing organization in the last two months.

title: DANCE: AMERICAN GROUP PERFORMS JAPANESE GAGAKU
description: LINCOLN KIRSTEIN has described Gagaku, the 14-centuries-old music and dance of the Imperial Court of Japan, as a completed art, performed within its own limits of perfection by musician-dancers who exhibit a fulfilled correctness of presence. On Monday, Suenobu Togi and performers from the U.C.L.A. Gagaku Study Group made that perfection palpable in a performance of Bugaku, or Gagaku dance, at Japan Society.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Man With the Figures Is Moving On

title: U.N. Agency Says the Israelis Detained 164 of Its Workers
description: The Israeli Army has detained 164 employees of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency since invading Lebanon on June 6, and 83 are still being held, the agency said in a statement today.

title: MORE TAINTED CAPSULES FOUND
description: A drug store chain pulled Anacin-3 pain relievers from its stores in five states today after California health officials announced they had found cyanide in 10 Maximum Strength capsules from a single bottle that was purchased Dec. 8 in San Pedro.

title: JUDGE CURBING TV IN COURT DRAWINGS
description: An Arizona judge has ordered journalists at a murder trial to clear drawings of jurors with him before showing them on television. Today Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court refused a request from journalists to stay the order.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Sometimes the parents come up behind me and whisper, 'Christmas is kind of tight this year.

title: Irresolute Resolution
description: WHEREAS Houdaille Industries, an American manufacturer of hightechnology machine tools, claims injury by predatory Japanese manufacturers; and

title: NEW PATHS FOR I.M.B. UNDER OPEL LEADERSHIP
description: The International Business Machines Corporation this week departed from its deeply ingrained corporate tradition by buying a 12 percent stake in the Intel Corporation.

title: MADISON BID HALTED BY WARNER
description: Warner Communications Inc., the diversified communications company whose earnings have been hurt by disappointing video-game sales of its Atari subsidiary, announced yesterday the cancellation of its agreement to acquire Madison Fund Inc., a closed-end investment company.

title: RETURNING GIFTS: SOME BASIC GUIDELINES
description: Whether marked by the arrival of your third alabaster shoehorn this Christmas, or the sweater more fitting for a pterodactyl's torso than your own, or the E.T. toy that took two steps, squeaked and died, the gift return season has begun. Here are some commonly asked questions and answers about returning gifts to stores.

title: THE REGION
description: A man was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train just east of the train station here this morning, causing long delays and train cancellations, the police said.

title: 62 GETTING REAGAN'S GIFT OF FORGIVENESS
description: E. Howard Hunt and Jeb Stuart Magruder will not be receiving the special Christmas gift each had hoped for from President Reagan this year.

title: Time to 'Move On'
description: Gene Upshaw and Art Shell, who made up the left side of the Raiders' offensive line and who for years were one of the National Football League's most powerful tandems, are the latest of a growing list of pro football veterans who have announced retirement in recent days. The retirement of Upshaw, the longtime Raider guard who serves as president of the N.F.L. Players Association, had been expected for some time and is effective at the end of the season.

title: U.S. ENVOY MEETS WITH GROMYKO ON ARMS CONTROL ISSUES AND MX
description: The United States Ambassador, Arthur A. Hartman, saw Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today at the American's request for a 90-minute discussion of arms control issues, the United States Embassy said.

title: QUEUING UP FOR CODFISH ROE
description: A man was getting prunes with Armagnac as a present - $23. For one of her gifts, a woman was getting Perugina chocolates contained in a china violin - $25. Cima alla Genovese was moving. Torta Trevigiana was moving. Pagnotta Pugliese was moving.

title: SOTHEBY'S IS IN DISAGREEMENT WITH ITS NEW SHAREHOLDERS
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet, the world's largest auction house, says that it cannot cooperate with the two American owners of GFI/Knoll International who last week became the company's biggest shareholders.

title: 5-Year India-Pakistan Accord On Stronger Ties Is Initialed
description: India and Pakistan, opening a new phase of warmer relations, initialed a five-year accord today setting up a joint commission to strengthen economic and cultural ties.

title: Judge J.P. Moore of Maryland; Ex-Counsel to Senate Panels
