description: Judge John P. Moore, a member of the Maryland Court of Special Appeals and formerly chief counsel to two Senate committees, died Thursday in Georgetown University Medical Center after suffering a stroke. He was 66 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 24.

title: BAKER AND O'NEILL PREDICT PRESIDENT WILL BACK JOB BILL
description: Washington, Dec. 24--The leaders of the House and Senate have agreed to reintroduce legislation to create public works jobs when Congress reconvenes Jan. 3, and they say they expect President Reagan to support such an effort.

title: Reagan Wish Heard; Toy Trains Rolling In
description: Nowadays, national television just might be more effective than a letter to Santa, particularly if you are the President of the United States.

title: Mother and 3 Children Killed As Fire Engulfs Tent in Texas
description: A 27-year-old woman and three of her four young children were killed Thursday in a fire that engulfed the tent where they were living, the authorities said.

title: The Talk of Rio de Janeiro
description: It was the night before Christmas, the temperature was 82 degrees and families were busy opening presents and planning early outings in the morning to secure a spot on the beach.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Thousand Warm Hands

title: LOUSI ARAGON, FRENCH POET AND PROMINENT COMMUNIST, DIES AT 85
description: Louis Aragon, the French poet and Communist Party luminary, died yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 85 years old.

title: DESIRE TO BRIGHTEN CHILDREN'S HOLIDAY INSPIRES GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: There was no festive wrapping paper or ribbons on the gift that 9-year-old Daniel Sterling Taylor received from his grandparents as his family gathered in Manhattan last night for its annual Christmas Eve tree celebration.

title: SECRET SERVICE MAY GET TO USE F.B.I. COMPUTER
description: Washington, Dec. 24--Attorney General William French Smith has approved a plan that would allow the Secret Service to use a large computer system of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to keep track of people it believes may pose a threat to officials who are guarded by the Secret Service.

title: Two 'Hazzard' Actors Will Return to Series
description: Tom Wopat and John Schneider will return to their roles on the CBS prime-time series ''The Dukes of Hazzard'' before the end of the television season.

title: Yale Dramatists' Fund Honors Audrey Wood
description: A scholarship fund has been established in the name of Audrey Wood, the theatrical agent, at the Yale School of Drama and Repertory Theater, by a group of her friends and clients.

title: VATICAN-ITALY STUDY SET ON AMBROSIANO LINKS
description: The Vatican and the Italian Government announced today that they had set up a joint commission to study the intricate relationship between the Vatican bank and the Banco Ambrosiano.

title: Your Money
description: IF you are thinking about leasing a car in 1983, a proposed regulation of the Internal Revenue Service could change the way the process is handled or possibly add to the monthly cost.

title:
Patents;
Processing Chinese Characters
description: WASHINGTON ASYSTEM for the recognition of a large vocabulary of Chinese characters and entering them into text processing and data processing equipment was patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation. It also recognizes Kanji words, the Japanese equivalent of the Chinese symbols.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Cincinnati Reds signed the relief pitcher Tom Hume, who has spent 11 years in the Cincinnati organization, to a guaranteed fouryear contract that extends through the 1986 season. The contract also provides the Reds an option for 1987. ... Evelyn Ashford, one of the world's premier sprinters, will head the field for the women's 60-yard dash in the Millrose Games Jan. 28 at Madison Square Garden. And Carl Lewis, the sprinter and long jumper whom Track and Field News named this year's outstanding track and field performer in the United States, has entered the USA-Mobil Indoor Championships at the Garden Feb. 25.

title: Jets Will Have an Eye on the Scoreboard
description: Scoreboard football - in which a team on the field glances frequently at the scoreboard to see what is happening in other games - will become an inevitable part of Sunday's Jets-Vikings game in Minnesota.

title: Suspect Is Arrested In 1979 Abduction of Girl
description: A man suspected of kidnapping a little girl nearly three years ago was arrested today, one day after the child was reunited with her mother.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: RECALLING GASTRONOMIC GHOSTS OF CHRISTMAS PAST
description: As much as I enjoy sharing Christmas morning with my family, I must confess to cherishing a few hours I spend alone before my husband and son are awake. Because we have always had guests for Christmas dinner and because I am an early riser, I am in the kitchen by 7 A.M. to get cooking under way before my family comes down to open gifts and have our traditional gala breakfast of fruit, sauteed sweetbreads with beacon, toasted stollen or panettone and coffee.

title: Thieves Rip Out Night-Deposit Box
description: Thieves ripped a brass night-deposit box out of a bank's brick wall early today and escaped with an estimated $250,000.

title: MUSIC: NEW LE JAZZ HOT ENSEMBLE AT IL FIORE
description: STAN LEVINE, the drummer whose Original Traditional Jazz Band plays on Sundays at Il Fiore, 407 East 70th Street, has organized a quartet called Le Jazz Hot Ensemble that takes a slightly different approach to traditional jazz on Wednesdays at Il Fiore.

title: SPIELBERG'S CREATIVITY
description: Steven Spielberg proved again that creativity - this time in the guise of a wizened, pot-bellied creature with stratospheric intelligence - can pay.

title: NURSES SEEK TO BRIGHTEN ROUTINE OF HEART IMPLANT PATIENT'S DAYS
description: For Dr. Barney B. Clark, doctors want the Christmas holidays to be more restful than festive. For his nurses, these will be days when they will be giving continued intensive care and encouragement to Dr. Clark in the quiet celebration of what he regards as his extended life.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: On this day dedicated to unselfish giving and goodwill among human beings, let us now praise Dorothy Smith. Miss Smith does nothing more or less upon this earth than take 32 little people every day and teach them to read, write, keep their feet under their desks, hold on to their own pencils, stay in straight lines on their way to the bathroom and remember that there's a little bit of magic in us all. Her only claim to fame is that she loves her work, and she does it well.

title: From Basketball Court to Judge's Bench
description: brand-new, having been sworn in only on Monday - returned from the courtroom Thursday at noon and entered the chambers in the Middlesex County Courthouse here. He is going through a twoweek orientation period. After that, the 37-year-old judge will sit on the bench in the Roxbury District Court, one of only 16 black judges in the state and Federal system of Massachusetts.

title: O'Koren to Get Another Start
description: The New Jersey Nets, seeking a cure for their backcourt ills last season, went to the free-agent market for Otis Birdsong, who had been a three-time all-star with the Kansas City Kings. Birdsong received a five-year contract at $1 million a year.

title: RESIDENTS FEAR MORE VIOLENCE FOR CHINATOWN
description: Chinatown residents and police investigators expressed concern yesterday that the killing of three young men in a basement bar Thursday signaled the start of a new cycle of gang violence.

title: CHRISTMAS COUNTING OF BIRDS IS EMERGING AS RESEARCHERS' TOOL
description: The Christmas Bird Count, the early-winter rite that inspires some 35,000 American birders to don cold-weather gear and spend a day scanning forests and fields for birds, listening for owls and recording their findings, has come of age.

title: Miami Widow Duped By Botanical Bandits
description: Two men posing as city employees stole a pair of palm trees worth about $2,000 from in front of the home of an elderly widow after they convinced her that the plants were diseased.

title: In Scholarly Pursuit, A Historic Punch
description: The latest Wall Street talk fills the downstairs dining room of Fraunces Tavern. Upstairs, the two museum floors evoke 18th-century social and political life with a new exhibition, ''Taverns: For the Entertainment of Friends and Strangers.''

title: FOUR TOP PLAYERS GET TENNIS BYES
description: Jimmy Connors, Guillermo Vilas, Ivan Lendl and John McEnroe have received first-round byes for the $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden Jan. 1-23

title: BRANIFF'S PUTNAM FACES THE DEATH OF AN AIRLINE
description: During a May 13 news conference, Howard D. Putnam, chairman of the Braniff International Corporation, began to cry. Earlier that day, Braniff, the nation's ninth-largest airline, became the first major American air carrier to seek protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws. In a year that produced a record number of business failures, Braniff's was almost certainly the most spectacular.

title: The Editorial Notebook Save Me a Seat
description: It's Christmas morning, which means it's time to think ahead. By tonight the wrapping paper will be swept away, the kids will be bored with their new toys and the only thing left of dinner will be a lingering glow from the chardonnay. Then what?

title: The Police Blotter
description: James Jackson, a 25-year-old marine who lived at 210 West 153d Street in Manhattan, shot and killed his girlfriend, Teona Boyce, 20, in an argument Thursday evening, the police said. He then shot himself, walked to the roof of her seven-story apartment building at 2794 Eighth Avenue and jumped off. His body was found in the courtyard. ... Michael Bristol, a retired police officer from Guyana, tackled a robber running from the Flatbush Federal Bank at 2146 Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday morning, took the robber's gun away and held him until city police arrived. ... In upper Manhattan, at 1:50 A.M., two men grabbed an off-duty patrolman, hit him on the head and fled with his wallet containing his police shield and $900.

title: Blenders And All That
description: It's my impression that men don't get as many neckties for Christmas as they used to. I certainly don't, and it's too bad. The reason is that Christmas neckties became a big joke a few years ago. How awful they were. How they never matched the color of your eyes. How they didn't go with your personality, and so on. It became such a common joke that children and women, the givers of Christmas neckties, stopped the practice for fear you might think they were laughing at you.

title:
PATENTS;
Method for Sending Secret Messages
description: A method of sending a number of secret messages to various destinations by a single transmission was patented this week for the Communications Satellite Corporation.

title: A Different Game
description: The nationally ranked men's basketball team at Syracuse University draws an average of 16,400 fans a game at the Carrier Dome. And last February the Orangemen attracted the largest on-campus crowd in N.C.A.A. basketball history - 27,318, for a game against St. John's.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: A WEAK, pained bleep sounded in Roz Post's Chelsea apartment one morning earlier this month. Miss P ost awakened groggily, thinking that one of her cats was in trouble. Her cats were fine, but her smoke detector was on its last legs. ''It makes this intermittent squeaking sound before it dies,'' e xplained Miss Post, who, not so coincidentally, works for the New Y ork City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the a gency that enforces the city's smoke detector law.

title: FOR HOMELESS, THE CHEER IS GONE FROM CHRISTMAS
description: ''We got thrown out of the Mary Crest Mission because the lady said I was an angry person inside, because of my upbringing,'' said Edward Langley, a 23-year-old father of two. His wife Marie is four months pregnant. He lost his job at a pallet-making plant in Sterling, Mich., and moved to Oklahoma City where he worked day labor.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRESSY

title: CORRECTION
description: The TV Notebook column on Thursday incorrectly reported the position of ''60 Minutes'' concerning a doctor's opportunity to respond to a charge. The doctor declined to appear on the program. The physician sued CBS for libel, and a legal settlement, described as an ''amicable disposition,'' was reached.

title: Jersey Pursues Drunken Drivers
description: New Jersey has established a toll-free telephone number to report drunken drivers, and by 1 P.M. today, 775 people had used it, according to the state police.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Quest for a Job Promises A Placement Dividend

title: Truck Fire Spurs Evacuation
description: A truck loaded with oak logs sheared off two propane hoses and caused a fire that forced the evacuation of 200 townspeople until early today, the police said. The driver and a companion were seriously burned when the truck burst into flames, but the propane tanks at the Petrolane Gas Company did not explode. The driver said his brakes failed.

title: Islanders' Attitude Is Torrey's Concern
description: After yet another loss, General Manager Bill Torrey of the Islanders said yesterday that the team's immediate concern was to correct the attitude of the players rather than to trade any of them or demote them to the minor leagues.

title: Tylenol Posts an Apparent Recovery
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that its Tylenol analgesic brand had regained much of the market that it lost this fall when seven Chicago-area residents died from taking cyanide-contaminated Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules.

title: News Analysis
description: As the world's Christians gather to celebrate the Nativity of Jesus, theological disputes continue to divide the churches, but for the most part they no longer center on the child whose birth, the Bible says, took place in a cattle shed and was marked by the appearance of a miraculous star.

title: SOME IN FLOODED SUBURB IGNORING ADVICE ON DIOXIN CONTAMINATION
description: Many of the 2,037 residents of Times Beach, a Missouri suburb of St. Louis inundated by a flood three weeks ago, seem to be ignoring a Federal agency's recommendation that they stay away from their homes because soil tests show dangerously high levels of the chemical contaminant dioxin.

title: BALLET: 2 DEBUTS BY DANCERS IN JOFFREY'S 'TAMING OF SHREW'
description: Whether or not John Cranko's ''The Taming of the Shrew'' was conceived as a family show, that is the way the Joffrey Ballet is successfully treating this comedy ballet, with one more performance tomorrow afternoon at the City Center.

title: Man Is Killed in Northern Italy During a Kidnapping Attempt
description: A man who tried to kidnap the daughter of a hotel owner was killed in an exchange of gunfire with the national police in this northern Italian town today, the police said.

title: Benefit for Henry Street
description: Tony Bennett, Count Basie and his Orchestra, and Carmen McRae will be the headliners at a Lincoln Center benefit on Monday evening, Jan. 24, to help reopen the Henry Street Settlement's Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center Before its temporary closing Oct. 1, more than 5,000 people attended performances or workshops at the Abrons Center every week. Tickets for the benefit, priced from $15 to $100, can be reserved by calling the box office at Avery Fisher Hall (874-2424), the Henry Street Settlement (766-9200 or 598-0400) or through CenterCharge (874-6770).

title: BANKS INCREASE SECURITIES PURCHASES
description: Large banks in New York are compensating for declining business loan demands by increasing their purchases of securities, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Children at the Window
description: A Christmas without children would be like a sleigh ride without snow. What gives this day its special grace is the glimpse it yields of a child's belief in the better angels of a grown-up world. Selfishness recedes, good will and gentleness for a blessed moment prevail. It is the enduring gift of the Magi, this vision of a peaceable kingdom ruled by the quintessential Child.

title: HARD CHOICES FOR A SOUTH AFRICA PARTY
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha's plan for extending limited political rights to two nonwhite minority groups without opening the door to any effective role for the black majority has presented the opposition in the white Parliament with some difficult choices.

title: JETER REPLACES BURT ON ROSTER
description: The Giants reactivated Gary Jeter, the defensive end, today and, in a surprise move, made room for him by placing Jim Burt on injured reserve. Phil Tabor, a defensive end, will start in Burt's place at nose tackle Sunday against the Cardinals in St. Louis.

title: 22 Are Reported Killed In Chinese Airliner Fire
description: Twenty-two people died Friday when a Chinese airliner burst into flames during an emergency landing in the southern city of Canton, the Canton Daily News reported today.

title: SANTA'S RIDE
description: Zebby Adams, a Harvard man and a widower, entered the old folks' home up near Riverside Drive shortly after Pearl Harbor, because he lost his only son in the First World War and got depressed at the prospect of another generation of lost sons.

title: STRUGGLE IN WELSH STEEL TOWN
description: First came the rumors. Then, on Monday, the British Government confirmed that it would preserve Ravenscraig, the British Steel Corporation's only integrated steel mill in Scotland.

title: EVEN SANTA IS STRANDED BY BLIZZARD IN ROCKIES
description: Boulder, Colo., Dec. 24--By midafternoon, the snow was already 18 inches deep and still coming down. Roads were impassable. The Denver airport was closed.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Essence of a Novelist By ANATOLE BROYARD THE LETTERS OF GUSTAVE FLAU- BERT, 1857-1880. Selected, edited and translated by Francis Steegmuller. Il- lustrated. 309 pages. The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $15.

title: 500 $1 Bills Handed To People on a Street
description: In an expression of holiday cheer, Peggy Kutz handed out 500 $1 bills to passers-by on the streets of Pittsburgh.

title: ALFA PLANS EXTENSIVE DIVESTITURE
description: The troubled Alfa Industrial Group, Mexico's largest conglomerate, has proposed divesting itself of all but a handful of its more than 50 subsidiaries as the only way of resuming payments on its $2.3 billion foreign debt.

title: Movement for Oilers
description: The Houston Oilers announced both a loss and a gain. The loss involves Jim Shofner, their offensive coordinator the last two seasons, who will resign at the end of the year to enter private business.

title: Turkey Releases 19 Accused Of Disgracing Nation Abroad
description: Nineteen defendants in a trial of Turkish Peace Association members were freed today, defense lawyers said.

title: ONE SIDE EFFECT OF BIRTH CONTROL IN CHINA: THE BRAT
description: China's drive to hold down its population by restricting couples to one child has created an uni@ntended side effect - the spoiled brat.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1982
description: International More feuding in Lebanon between rightist Christian and leftist Druse militiamen took place near the United States Marine positions south of Beirut on Friday. Thirteen Lebanese were killed in daylong artillery and rocket barrages, the police said. (Page 3, Column 6.) The release of 1,200 prisoners in South Korea was welcomed by the State Department. It said the move ''will make a further contribution to political harmony in Korea.'' (3:1-5.)

title: U.S. WELCOMES SEOUL'S MOVE TO RELEASE 1,200 PRISONERS
description: The State Department welcomed the release of 1,200 prisoners today by the South Korean Government, saying it ''will make a further contribution to political harmony in Korea.''

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

title: LINDA JANE RUSSO FIANCEE OF WILLIAM HOWARD STAPLES
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Russo of North Merrick, L.I., have made known engagement of their daughter, Linda Jan Russo, to William Howard Staples, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard I. Staples of Wilton, Conn. The wedding is planned for May 29.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: ART On a trip to the People's Republic of China last summer, Robert Rauschenberg, who has worked with paper for much of his career, stopped off in the town of Jing Xian, home of the world's oldest paper mill. Collaborating with townspeople and local technicians, he turned out 70 sets of elaborate paperworks, each set of 10 variations on one of seven calligraphic characters for seven Chinese words: ''light,'' ''howl,'' ''individual,'' ''truth,'' etc.

title: Vietnam Veterans Hold Vigil
description: About 12 unemployed Vietnam veterans began a round-the-clock vigil Friday night at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial to call attention to the 1,421 servicemen still listed as missing in action.

title: Keeping Warm Is Easier Than Ever
description: IT is much easier to keep warm outdoors in cold weather than it was a decade or more ago. The boom in winter sports from skiing to ice fishing to snow-camping has helped create, and in part been created by, the continuing improvement of garments, tents and sleeping bags that has transformed what was often an ordeal into pleasure.

title: STRIKING PAY DIRT
description: One would not normally consider looking for a gold mine in Minneapolis, but two bridge experts struck pay-dirt there at the end of November. They were Ivan Scope of San Francisco and Bill Nutting of Kensington, Calif. Although they have a considerable record as a partnership, including the Grand National Pairs title in Niagara Falls, N.Y., this will surely rank among their most memorable moments.

title: STATE LOSES 2 FROM OIL PANEL
description: NEW JERSEY'S only private-sector members of a regional advisory committee for offshore oil and gas leasing have been dismissed by Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt. One is a leading environmentalist, the other a pro-environment social scientist.

title: Paula Rozalsky Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Rozalsky of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paula Carol Rozalsky, to Robert Jay Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Levine of Mountainside, N.J. The wedding is planned for next October. Miss Rozalsky graduated from Northeastern University and her fiance is an alumnus of Fairleigh Dickinson University. Her father is president of Shor's Drugs in Elizabeth, N.J., and Mr. Levin's father is co-owner of the Brevine Construction Company in Mountainside.

title:
ART;
SURREALISM AT PLAY
description: PHILIPPE HALSMAN wore two hats. As a chronicler of his era, he photographed almost everyone of importance in fields ranging from show business and sports to science and politics. But he was also a creative photographer, collaborating in projects with the likes of Salvador Dali and Jean Cocteau.

title: BOOKS
description: THE number of new books by New Jersey authors, or about events relating to the state, continues to grow. In the following listing, the publisher is situated in New York City, unless otherwise stated:

title: HEART PATIENT'S FAMILY MARKS A SPECIAL HOLIDAY
description: A month ago, at Thanksgiving, the members of Dr. Barney Clark's family thought it would be his last holiday. Heart disease was taking his life. Today, as an artificial, polyurethane heart pumped blood through his body for the 24th day, Dr. Clark happily celebrated the Christmas that was not expected to be.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS ENCOUNTERED WITH NEW PLANTS
description: HOUSE plants acquired at this time of year may be subject to stresses not encountered in other seasons. The most obvious of all problems is that of exposure to cold. Most house plants are either tropical or subtropical in origin and are not adapted to exposure to cold temperatures. Such conditions may be encountered during delivery. Too frequently, a plant will not have been adequately wrapped as a means of protecting it from exposure.

title: JAZZ: CEDAR WALTON, PIANO
description: Cedar Walton's approach to the piano is a model of moderation. He has style but he does not make his style insistently apparent.

title: ELECTION '82 BREAKS RECORD FOR SPENDING
description: HARTFORD LONG after the counting of the votes, the financial accountings for the Nov. 2 election campaigns are piling up this month in filing cabinets at the Secretary of the State's office, and they contain some common themes - record spending and several cases of leftover debts.

title: A DANDY SEASON FOR SCALLOPS
description: EAST HAMPTON WHEN deft shuckers wield knives, scallop shells fly. The shuckers, whose task is to cut free the adductor muscle, the scallop's edible part, have had ample opportunity to sharpen their skills this season as baymen on the East End brought ashore one of the biggest and most profitable scallop harvests in years.

title: American and 22 Others Died in China Air Crash
description: One American was among 23 passengers killed when a Chinese airliner made an emergency landing and burst into flames Friday at the Canton airport in southeastern China.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS ENCOUNTERED WITH NEW PLANTS
description: HOUSE plants acquired at this time of year may be subject to stresses not encountered in other seasons. The most obvious of all problems is that of exposure to cold. Most house plants are either tropical or subtropical in origin and are not adapted to exposure to cold temperatures. Such conditions may be encountered during delivery. Too frequently, a plant will not have been adequately wrapped as a means of protecting it from exposure.

title: 30,000 Greek Refugees Are to Be Repatriated
description: The Greek Government said today that it would repatriate about 30,000 political refugees who have lived abroad, mostly in Eastern Europe, since the 1947-49 Greek civil war.

title: FLEETING FAME: WHEN QUIZ KIDS GROW UP
description: In the 1940's they were envied by thousands of American children above the age of 7 and thoroughly hated by just about all the rest because they were the examples, the models, the ideals with whom parents compared their own offspring.

title: SIZING UP THE COUNTIES
description: Q. During the recent battle over your budget for

title:
ANTIQUES;
CHANGE IN ROOMS' TERMS AND USE
description: IF today some 17th- and 18th-century men and women were able to visit the houses they built so many generations ago, they might have difficulty knowing which room was which. Those who live in the old houses today have changed the meaning of many of the descriptions the first owners used and added other terms they never imagined.

title: COMPANIES OFFER HELP ON HOUSING
description: THIS winter, many of the major corporations in Hartford and Stamford are becoming increasingly involved in subsidizing the constructional rehabilitation of moderate-cost housing. The momentum appears to be growing despite an adverse business climate.

title: RING-NECKED PHEASANT; Phasianus colchicus
description: Size: Male, 30 to 36 inches; female, about 20 inches. Color: Male, brilliant coloration; head and neck, dark green with purplish iridescence; white neck ring; red-bronze breast; body in varied browns with black and white markings.

title: BARBARA WELLS TO WED DR. RON KEVIN WOLNER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Wells of Highland Falls, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Wells, to Dr. Ron Kevin Wolner, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wolner of Forest hIlls, queens. An April wedding is planned.

title: MONOLOGUES: RUTH DRAPER'S ART RECALLED
description: In ''The World of Ruth Draper,'' a one-woman show at the South Street Theater, Ruth Brinkmann attempts to revive the performance art of the legendary American monologist. Miss Brinkmann has previously performed her anthology at Vienna's English Theater, which she co-founded with her director-husband, Franz Schafranek. However, she was preceded in New York last season by another American actress, Patrizia Norcia, with a similar theatrical venture.

title: A LOOK BACK AT 1982 STOCK PICKS
description: THE chancey art of picking favorite stocks for the new year has b ecome a tradition on Wall Street. This process finds research a nalysts and market strategists setting down their choices - and thenc rossing their fingers. And every year, it seems, International B usiness Machines turns up on the recommended lists.

title: ANTHONY SHAFFER PLAYS A GAME OF 'WHODUNNIT'
description: Newgate Callendar regularly reviews detective fiction for The Times Book Review section.

title: BLACK CHARITIES FACE OPPOSITION
description: In 1968 Walter Bremond, a community activist in Los Angeles, set in motion his dream of a nationwide charity to aid blacks, a vision that became the National Black United Fund.

title: Lisa Huber Plans To Marry June 11
description: Mrs. Robert C. Stanley Jr. of Middletown, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lisa Marshall Huber, to William Brooks Goodspeed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Goodspeed of Grand Rapids, Mich. The wedding is planned for June 11.

title: Stage Struck
description: Natalia Makarova has brought down a house or two in her dance career, but until last weekend she probably never had one fall on her. The former star of the Soviet Union's Kirov Ballet suffered a broken shoulder blade and a cut on the head when a piece of scenery tore loose and fell on her during a performance of ''On Your Toes'' at the Kennedy Center in Washington.

title: Marian McLaughlin Engaged to Thomas O'Connor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McLaughlin of Forest Hills, Queens, and Stony Brook, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marian McLaughlin, to Thomas Patrick O'Connor, son of Mrs. John O'Connor of New York and the late Mr. O'Connor. The wedding is planned for March 26.

title: 2 Viking Stars Will Not Start
description: The Vikings' two leading receivers, Ahmad Rashad and Sammy White, will not start against the Jets today in the Metrodome.

title: THE DISCOUNTERS STORM WALL STREET
description: BACK in the mid-1970's, the fledging Quick & Reilly Inc., one of the pioneers of the discount brokerage business, had few friends on Wall Street. Quick & Dirty, it was called by a Wall Street fearful of its rock bottom rates - nearly 50 percent below what the big firms charged to buy and sell stocks.

title: Saving a Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR POWER'S CARE AND FEEDING
description: AFTER a half-decade drought in new power plant orders - and many c ancellations of facilities already on the drawing boards - it is e asy to understand why the more ardent opponents of nuclear energy a re flush with a sense of victory. But while the nuclear power i ndustry may not be the picture of health, its supporters claim that r eports of its demise have been greatly exaggerated.

title: CONGRESS PASSES A GASOLINE TAX
description: Congress passed the nickle-a-gallon gasoline tax bill and sent it to President Reagan for his signature. A cloture vote Thursday ended the conservative-led filibuster, allowing a vote to be taken. The tally in the Senate was 54-33 for the measure that is expected to raise $5.5 billion a year to finance a highway and mass transit improvement program. Sponsors said the bill, passed earlier in the week by the House, would create 170,000 jobs.

title: U.S. SURVEY SHOWS A STEADY GROWTH IN SOVIET'S G.N.P.
description: In a long analysis of the Soviet economy, the Central Intelligence Agency says the Soviet gross national product has grown at an annual rate of 4.8 percent, in Western terms, over the last three decades. But it adds that in recent years the increase has dropped to less than 3 percent a year because of poor harvests.

title: Thousands Flee Homes In Wide French Floods
description: Floods have forced thousands of people throughout France to flee their homes and spend Christmas in improvised shelters.

title: COMPUTER SUBSIDY DIVIDES EDUCATORS
description: Educators are sharply divided over efforts to obtain Federal subsidies for putting personal computers in the nation's classrooms, at little or no cost to school districts.

title: POPE WISHES 'A NEW HOPE' FOR THE POLES
description: Pope John Paul II delivered special Christmas wishes to his fellow Poles today, saying he prayed they would find ''a new hope, a new light.''

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: GOOD NEWS AND BAD
description: EVEN as New Jersey buzzes with photography shows, its most prestigious gallery devoted to the medium and, for several years, the only one of its kind in the state is closing.

title: Japan to Lower Import Duty On Tobacco and Chocolates
description: The Japanese Government decided today to reinstate tobacco, chocolates and biscuits to a list of 75 itmes on which import duties are to be cut next April, Economic Planning Agency officials said.

title: ON TWO-CAREER MARRIAGES AND I.R.A.'S
description: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q.My wife is getting her Ph.D. and can only do her research at the institution she now attends. My career has forced me to take a job about four hours from our home, which is in the town where she attends school. Is there any way we can deduct costs of maintaining two households, as well as commuting expenses and telephone calls? A.Sorry, but the I.R.S. has turned thumbs down on subsidizing twocareer marriages in which the spouses work and live in different locations. Byrle Abbin, a tax partner with the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company, says that recent court cases have consistently held that married couples working in different cities do not necessarily have the same home for tax purposes.

title: RESIGNATION AT 20TH CENTURY-FOX
description: Sherry Lansing (right), the first woman to be president of a major studio, resigned unexpectedly as president of 20th Century-Fox Productions, a post she had held for almost three years.

title: COZY AND COMMENDABLE
description: BY the end of the year, the options for dining out in eastern Suffolk diminish as restaurants are shuttered until spring, but a bright oasis of cozy atmosphere and commendable food that closes only for the month of February is the Patio in Westhampton Beach.

title: The Immortality Of a Dean's List
description: To the Sports Editor: Having had a long association with the Jesuits (Xavier High School, Fordham College, Fordham Law School), I particularly enjoyed George Vecsey's Sports of The Times column (''Jefferson and Loyola'', The New York Times, Dec. 10).

title: JAZZ: SHARON FREEMAN
description: Sharon Freeman has been writing bits and pieces of ''A Christmas Celebration, a Jazz Suite for Five Voices and Ensemble'' for the last 12 years. In its current form, consisting of seven segments, it is being performed with Miss Freeman at the piano, on Sundays and Mondays during December at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South.

title: J.S. Lief to Wed Cathy L. Berson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Berson of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cathy Lynne Berson, to James Scott Lief, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Lief of New York and Weston, Conn.

title: NEW JERSEY AUTHORITIES SUED OVER OCEAN SLUDGE-DUMPING
description: The National Wildlife Federation has filed a Federal suit charging that six sewage authorities are illegally dumping sludge into a 13,000-square-mile stretch of ocean off the coasts of New York and New Jersey.

title: Knocks, Pings At OPEC Session
description: With world recession dampening demand, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has found unity in short supply. Last week in Vienna, OPEC ministers failed for the third time this year to set new production quotas.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: DANCE At half-stretch through the holiday season, this week may be the time for a little frivolity. The Joffrey Ballet, which returns to its regular repertory this week at City Center after a spate of ''Taming of the Shrew,'' will offer two ballets that fit that bill.

title: NEW TACK ON BOARDING HOMES
description: THE problem of what to do about the increasing number of elderly people who are unable to take care of themselves, as well as the continuing stream of those being released from mental institutions, is expected to grow worse in New Jersey in the next few years.

title: No Headline
description: There are no pat solutions for the working mother. She must, like the women profiled, make her own choices and sacrifice along the way, and be fortunate enough to have the support of family and employer.

title: No Headline
description: Why should an interruption in a woman's career necessarily be a handicap? After World War II, many men returned to jobs, following an absence of several years, when the Government required employers to take them back. They also returned as more mature workers, surely an asset in most occupations. Would this not be true of women who take time out for the responsibilities of motherhood? Obviously, the discrimination that imposes male timetables upon women's careers is not necessary. VIRGINIA BLUM New York City

title: A TRADITIONALIST WHO WORE RADICAL STRIPES
description: Dwight Macdonald, who died last week at the age of 76, was a radical and a democrat, an iconoclast and an elitist. To all these roles he brought the high wit and solid scholarship that distinguished him as journalist and critic.

title: Mr. Reagan Heads for Third
description: A distinguished scholar of the Presidency, Professor Richard Neustadt of Harvard, observes that history has judged most recent Presidents on their third year. In the first year, the new man and the newcomers around him learn the ropes. In the second, they know their jobs - and the limits of their jobs, but their capacity to perform hasn't coalesced. In the third year, the President finally sorts out his priorities for the big push that will determine how he looks when the tidal wave of electioneering sweeps over the fourth.

title: WORK CONTINUES TO RESTORE CAPITOL
description: HARTFORD THE scaffolding that encircled the State Capitol from 1979 until 1981 may be gone, but the work of the Capitol Preservation and Restoration Commission continues.

title: Sunday Observer By Russell Baker; LITERATE TELEVISION
description: Television has become like foreign movies. You have to read it to get the full flavor of what's going on. At times, there's so much reading material on the screen that you can't see the football players for the alphabet.

title: SARAH K. BARTLETT TO MARRY BRADFORD PAYNE NEXT MAY
description: Mrs. White Bartlett of Bloomfield, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Sarah Kimball Bartlett, to Bradford Willson Payne, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Burton Payne of Darien, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: A Shadow of Vredeling
description: American multinationals working in Europe can breath half a sigh of relief--Vredeling is going to be emasculated. Probably.

title: Bridge to Nowhere
description: Detractors said the Humber Bridge would be a ''bridge to nowhere.'' Dreamers saw it as the world's longest single-span suspension bridge and a magnet for new industry, linking the city of Hull, England, with virtually undeveloped country across the Humber River to the south.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Talks of the Town

title: Gadfly of Jever
description: Before the Holocaust, there were 200 Jews in Jever, Germany. After the Holocaust, one returned: Fritz Levy. He became a controversial figure in the western city of 12,000 people: a gadfly, homespun philosopher and eccentric counterculture hero who reminded townsfolk of a past that some would sooner have forgotten.

title: A MORE CENTRIST CONGRESS HEEDS ITS OWN DRUMMERS
description: WASHINGTON WHEN Congress finally closed its postelection show last week, the reviews from the players were almost universally bad. Senator Paul Tsongas, Democrat of Masschusetts, said it was not a ''lame duck'' session, but a ''lame brain'' session. Senator Dan Quayle, Republican of Indiana, called the last few weeks a ''demeaning process'' that made Congress ''sort of the laughing stock of America.''

title: Sports of The Times;  A Smiling Resch
description: THE best way to gauge the losing season of the New Jersey Devils is to note that even Chico Resch once found himself in a foul mood. It is not easy to depress Resch. Yet, as the Devils have won 7, tied 7 and lost 23, Resch admits: ''It was getting to me. I was feeling selfish.''

title: Willing Brink's Defendant
description: When Federal officials disclosed last March that they had obtained the cooperation of a defendant in the state's prosecution of the Brink's armored-car robbery and shootout, no names were mentioned. But signs pointed to Samuel Brown.

title: HOLIDAY MERCY AND GUILT; The Tip For The Super
description: The season of benevolence is also a season of conflicts. They generate a seasonal psychic affliction: Christmas guilt. Take the clubs and co-operative apartment houses that set up funds to give employees a collective Christmas bonus.

title: WINED AND DINED, HUSSEIN STILL NIBBLES AT REAGAN'S PLAN
description: WASHINGTON NEARLY four months after President Reagan appealed for ''a fresh start'' toward peace in the Middle East, it may be saying a lot to simply report that the American initiative is still alive. The effort to get Arabs and Israelis to talk to each other has been frustrating, as expected, but its ''shelf life'' - as one official put it - ''has not yet expired.''

title: COUNTRY COMFORT IN FRANCE
description: ''There were vegetables, on and on. Perhaps I have never walked past so many unattainable beauties. I was hungry, and I thought of what I could do, if I were home, with the crisp gleaming glowing brilliance of all the lettuces and endives and purple eggplants and tiny turnips and strange twists and pats and whorls of live freshness. It was beyond my grasp, except spiritually, for any nourishment past my eye, occasionally my nose. I was hotel bound.''

title: Robin G. Shamah Marries Physician
description: Robin Gail Shamah, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Shamah of New York and York, Pa., was married yesterday to Dr. Jay Gary Merker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Merker of Paterson, N.J. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, assisted by Rabbi Charles Tannenbaum, performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue in New York.

title: SUIT ON TOXIC WASTE SETTLED
description: WHILE the Government was announcing last Monday what it said were the 418 most dangerous hazardous waste sites around the country, the owners of one of the four sites listed in Connecticut reached an agreement that is rare in the sometimes emotional issue of chemical waste.

title: WINNING STUDENT ESSAYISTS
description: The following two articles won first prizes in a recent essay contest for high school students in Westchester and Rockland Counties. More than 2,000 students submitted essays on the topic, ''Growing Up in the 80's: New Challenges, Fresh Answers.'' The competition was sponsored by Citibank, and the winners were chosen by a panel of five judges from the fields of education and journalism. By MARIANNE HAGAN

title: IN HARD TIMES, POP MUSIC SURGES WITH FRESH ENERGY
description: ''It's like a jungle, sometimes I wonder how I keep from going under,'' Grand Master Flash and the Furious Five chanted on their plain-spoken rap hit ''The Message,'' the most powerful pop record of 1982. They were talking about the South Bronx, Harlem, and America's other inner-city neighborhoods, but they could just as easily have been talking about the pop music business.

title: THE CREATIVE SOURCE WAS OFF BROADWAY
description: It takes courage for a theatergoer to stroll back through the memory lane of 1982 - it's easy to trip on potholes. The first Broadway opening of the year was ''Waltz of the Stork,'' in which the protagonist wandered disconsolately about the stage uttering private thoughts that remained forever beyond the audience's comprehension. The last opening, as of this writing, was ''Almost an Eagle,'' in which a troop of Iowa Boy Scouts marched pointlessly in circles for two mind-numbing acts. In between ''Stork'' and ''Eagle'' came a whole aviary of fly-by-night theatrical birds, all too many of them suitable for roasting.

title: APARTMENTS CLOTHED WITH STYLE
description: Fashion designers always seem to exhibit as strong a sense of style in their homes as they do in their clothing. And Jean-Paul Gaultier and France Andrevie, two young avant-garde fashion designers, are no exception.

title: MAKING COLD WATER HOT WITH SUN POWER
description: WATER flows into New York City buildings at 42 to 54 degrees and comes out of kitchen and b athroom taps 50 to 100 degrees higher. In most buildings, the water t emperature is raised by burning expensive fuel oil or natural gas, b ut a few landlords have discovered that the sun can be drafted to dom uch of the work instead.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE 55-M.P.H. SPEED LIMIT
description: If you are driving at the 55-mile-an-hour legal speed limit on New York's Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and you seem to be overtaken by every other vehicle on the road, you probably are. According to the latest available statistics of the Federal Highway Administration - for April through June of 1982 - a total of 83 percent of the vehicles monitored on the Interstate System in New York State were clocked at speeds exceeding 55 m.p.h.

title: SERVING MR. DONUT AND THE COMMUNITY
description: OSAKA, Japan IT can be argued that anyone who opens a Mister Donut franchise in Japan really wants to. On the first day of management training, the future entrepreneurs are sent by bus to a Kyoto residential district, where they go from house to house, knocking on doors and politely asking permission to scrub the family toilet. According to members of the company, it is an exercise intended to instill a sense of community service.

title: FINALLY, BRITAIN IS ON THE RIGHT TRACK
description: THERE is, of course, no gratitude in politics. For at least a decade now British political discussion has been e ngulfed by the inflation issue. Governments have been made and b roken by attempts - mostly misconstrued remedies based on wrong d iagnoses -to ''do something'' about it.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: BECAUSE the new year marks the beginning of the county's tricentennial celebration, the Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation is opening the historic Washington's Headquarters Building in White Plains to the public this week.

title: No Headline
description: I presently hold a middle-management position at a relatively small (400-person) firm. If I were to take a maternity leave, a job would be held for me for a few months; however, I could not be guaranteed that I would be returning to my job.

title: OCEAN FLOOR MAPS GIVEN NEW DETAIL
description: Two revolutionary mapping systems are giving oceanographers new and superior images of the floors of all the world oceans. The new methods are based on satellite measurements of the ocean's surface so sensitive they reflect local distortions of average sea level caused by the gravitational effects of undersea features.

title: 'FIDDLER' HITS SOME SOUR NOTES
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES UNDER the banner of J. Gordon Bell Productions, Jack Bell, an actor and director who lives in Mount Tabor, converted one of the banquet rooms at Neil's New Yorker, a restaurant on U.S. 46, into a dinnertheater in 1974.

title: AMID GLOOM, GOOD COMEDY STAGED AN EXHILARATING COMEBACK
description: It's been a year of revivifying contradictions, of splendid films made on shoestring budgets and of splendid films that cost more than some counties spend on education in an entire year. A film that goes wildly over budget, as ''Tootsie'' reportedly did, can look like a model of efficient moviemaking. Yet the extremely generous production and publicity budgets for ''Annie'' could not turn a so-so hit into a smash. Without warning, Steven Spielberg's ''E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,'' designed to be a nice, unassuming family film, became the kind of runaway hit that happens only once or twice in a decade.

title: Nepal Climb Is Abandoned
description: A seven-man climbing expedition led by an Italian, Reinhold Messner, called off an attempt on Nepal's Cho Oyu peak, a team member said today, after narrowly escaping death from falling stones and avalanches.

title: CHILDHOOD YESTERDAY
description: ''The Victorian era was the first time in history that childhood was recognized as a separate and important state,'' according to Amy Cowell, whose presentation of ''A Victorian Childhood'' may be seen at 2 P.M. today in the Hudson River Museum, at 511 Warburton Avenue in Yonkers.

title: AGENCIES TEAM UP TO AID YEMEN AFTER QUAKE
description: Volunteer agencies and international development organizations are coordinating disaster relief efforts for the victims of the earthquake that struck Yemen on Dec. 13, leaving more than 2,800 dead and more than 700,000 homeless.

title: GUITAR: CARLOS BARBOSA-LIMA
description: Village West, usually a jazz room, is presenting a solo classical guitarist, Carlos Barbosa-Lima, through Dec. 31. Although he does not improvise, Mr. Barbosa-Lima plays George Gershwin and Antonio Carlos Jobim along with Bach and Albeniz.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: CYNICAL people may claim that the favorite pastime of bureaucrats is conspiring to increase the size of government. But one night this month the City of Willimantic began to disappear, and its top elected officials took to the streets to celebrate.

title: DIANE B. KREISMAN FIANCEE OF DR. WARREN M. ZWEIFLER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman L. Kreisman of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Beth Dreisman, to Dr. Warren Michael Zweifler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Zweifler of Lawrence, L.I. The wedding is planned for next fall.

title: 3 in the Philippine Opposition Arrested in Raid on a House
description: Three members of a Philippine opposition party were arrested today in a raid on a house in Cebu, military officials said.

title: May Wedding Planned By Janis Mara Michael
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Michael of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Janis Mara Michael, to Justin Koslan Schwartz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Schwartz of Vienna, Va. A May wedding is planned.

title: Jerusalem Police Investigate Arson Bid at a Greek Church
description: The police are investigating an attempt to set fire to a small Greek Orthodox Church in the Ein Karem quarter of Jerusalem, a police spokesman reported here tonight.

title: RENAMING GUIDO TO HEAD POLICE WEIGHED
description: WHITE PLAINS IT all began with a phone call early in 1981 from the County Executive, who asked, according to the man who got the call, ''if I could take a temporary position to help him out.'' Daniel P. Guido's answer to Alfred B. DelBello was yes.

title: CREATE A TUITION FUND
description: The United States faces a financial crisis in higher education: Tuition costs continue to rise beyond the ability of families to pay for a college education. A family with more than one child in college at the same time, or educating the second child before paying the debts incurred by the first, faces insupportable expenses. A national remedy is possible.

title: Sharon D. Rabinowitz Affianced to Robert Chard
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Stanley Rabinowitz of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Deborah Rabinowitz, to Robert Chard, son of Ina Chard of Givat Hayim, Israel, and Francis Chard of Tiberias, Israel.

title: Juggling Career and Motherhood
description: How timely and welcome was Anita Shreve's article ''Careers and the Lure of Motherhood'' (Nov. 21) as I face the letter from my assistant superintendent requesting my decision to return or not to return to work next September. As a teacher, I have had the luxury most of my Vassar '67 classmates now in business have not had: to stay home with my 6-year-old for a year after her birth and, then, to stay home with my second daughter, who will be 2 when and if I return to the classroom.

title: UNION TURNS TO MARKETPLACE
description: LINDEN WAGES and improved benefits are not the only items that members of the United Auto Workers are negotiating for these days. Long familiar with handling worker-management disputes, some members of Local 595 at the General Motors plant here are now using their mediating skills to settle disagreements in the marketplace.

title: Miss Rourke And a Broker Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Rourke of University Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Ann Rourke, to James McDonnell Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murphy of Far Hills, N.J., and Groton Long Point, Conn.

title: STATE OF ART IN KIDNEY DIALYSIS
description: THERE are about 400 patients in the county who require dialysis. They suffer from end-term kidney disease, which causes uremic poisoning and the certain death of its victims if they are not linked to an artificial kidney. ''End-term'' is the phrase used to indicate a kidney that has fully lost its ability to function.

title: Nephew Killed by His Uncle
description: A 72-year-old man who carried a pistol because he had been robbed five times killed his nephew Friday because he felt a hand on his shoulder, the police said. Cecil Clark, 45, spotted his uncle, George Williams, and crossed the street to wish him a merry Christmas, Mr. Clark's companion told the police. But Mr. Williams thought he was being robbed again, and turned, pulled out a .38-caliber Smith & Wesson and shot his nephew, the police said.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: The Big Night at Home For those who prefer to remain at home on New Year's Eve, there are a variety of offerings this Friday night. For starters, Channel 5, from 7 to 10 P.M., will repeat its holiday staple, Offenbach's ''Tales of Hoffmann,'' as produced at the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden. John Schlesinger directed; Placido Domingo and Ileana Cotrubus sing the leads.

title: MANY GIVE TO NEEDIEST CASES IN THE NAMES OF LOVED ONES
description: For many people, the holiday season seems a particularly appropriate time of the year to honor the memory of relatives and friends. The number of contributors who make donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in the name of loved ones grows each year.

title: No Headline
description: Please do not assume that the career-parenting role strain is a women's problem. It is everyone's problem. The father who gives away in marriage a daughter he has never known, or who goes to a psychotherapist because he sees no point to his life or who dies of a heart attack before retirement has a problem because he did not experience role conflict.

title: Mamaroneck Avenue: A Vanishing Point?
description: In her article on The Galleria (''The Galleria: Measuring Its Success,'' Dec. 5), Lena Williams quotes me as deploring the exorbitant rents now being asked by Mamaroneck Avenue landlords as a result of The Galleria's high rents. What she did not quote is my statement on the impact The Galleria has had on business on Mamaroneck Avenue and East Post Rodd

title: Miss Twomey Sets Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Neil F. Twomey of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deirdre Mary Twomey, to Guy P. Cipriano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Cipriano of Millburn, N.J. A September wedding in Wyckoff is planned.

title: Laura R. Becker Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jason Charles Becker of Winnetka, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Laura Reiman Becker, to Dominique Georges Boniface of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Boniface of Rouen, France.

title: Julie Lisa Eisenberg Plans To Marry Lee C. Peterson
description: Mr. and Mrs. George S. Eisenberg of Marblehead, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Lisa Eisenberg, to Lee C. Peterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester E. Peterson of Worcester, Mass.

title: On Language William Safire; WATCH WHAT YOU SAY
description: What time is it?

title: China's Premier in Algeria
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China had talks today with President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria, the official Algerian press agency reported. The Chinese leader arrived in Algeria on Friday from Egypt where he started a monthlong tour of 10 African countries.

title: ON CHRISTMAS, A DAY OF PEACE AND QUIET
description: A fog had crept over New York overnight, shrouding its turrets and towers and muffling its clamor. With the temperature reaching 63 degrees in Central Park, it felt more like Easter. But it was Christmas, and a serenity descended with the fog on the city and the suburbs.

title: A Man in Motion: Herschel Walker
description: To the Sports Editor: Surely the person reporting the recent heroic deed of Herschel Walker was somewhat inaccurate. We are told that Herschel jogged up, ripped open the car door to release the trapped victim and simply jogged off. Come now, didn't this caped marvel fly off? DAVID L. EVANS

title: FAREWELL TO A THEATER, GREETINGS TO NEW TALENTS
description: Iam sitting here drawing up a list of 10 of the season's theatrical achievements and, mixed in somehow with a scattering of notes, a recent but unopened press release has come to hand. It's from the Phoenix Theater and I've just now opened it. It begins with a simple, blunt statement: ''The Phoenix Theater announced today that it has ceased operations as of Wednesday, Dec. 8, 1982.'' Staring at it, I realize that it is really nothing for me to be bringing up today, nothing to add to the festive aura of the season. It's scarcely anything we'd want to call an achievement, is it?

title: BEER BOYCOTT SPLITS JERSEY CITY
description: JERSEY CITY THE municipally endorsed boycott of Anheuser-Busch beers has been official since Nov. 24, but it's not easy to see its effect in this beer-loving city.

title: WHAT WILL SELL?
description: Not wanting to leave his profits to chance, Ian Bruce Eichner is trying to find out whether microwave ovens will sell apartments, or whether potential buyers believe a bidet is necessary to their lives.

title: SNARING BARGAINS WITH COUPONS
description: Companies marketing dozens of wine brands are increasingly trying to tempt bargain-conscious consumers by offering rebates, notably in the form of price-cutting coupons.

title: MA Bell's New Facts of Life
description: It's going to cost less to call Granny in Green Bay, but more to reach Daddy downtown. That is the probable effect of a Federal Communications Commission plan approved last week that ended almost 50 years of using long-distance telephone profits to subsidize local service.

title: METS TO SEND ZACHRY TO DODGERS FOR ORTA
description: Pat Zachry, who came to the Mets in the Tom Seaver trade in 1977, will not be Seaver's teammate next season, either. Zachry will join the Los Angeles Dodgers in a trade to be announced in the next few days.

title: SEEKING ACCEPTANCE FOR MOBILE HOMES
description: CONNECTICUT'S state legislators this week will get a complex set of p lans and recommendations that would upgrade the status of mobile h omes.

title: BUSINESS EXPERTISE AIDS MUNICIPALITIES
description: NEW BRITAIN almost stopped helping its Hispanic residents find jobs and places to live last year, when the city-run Spanish Speaking Center faced bankruptcy. Then a group of private specialists stepped in and identified where city officials could manage the program better. The center survived.

title: Official Chicago Song Fails to Hit Right Note
description: Organizers of the Chicago Song Contest have extended the deadline for entries to June 1 because none of 1,500 songs submitted so far was ''truly outstanding,'' said Anne Rashford, coordinator of the contest.

title: No Headline
description: Anita Shreve says a number of things that need to be said about the tensions that make life difficult for women who try to manage careers, family and homes simultaneously.

title: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS/William D. Nordhaus; Destroying the Economy To Save It
description: LIKE children who have discovered that there is no Santa Claus, the country is becoming increasingly disillusioned about the Reagan Administration's promises that Christmas will come every day.

title: QUESTIONS FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: It's fairly clear that nobody anywhere in the world had any good answers to the problems of 1982, but going into the new year, what are the questions?

title: TRUDEAU AND LEVESQUE CONTINUE TO SQUARE OFF
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec continued their confrontation on Canada's federal future this week.

title: HOMEOWNERS WORKING TO IMPROVE RENTAL PROPERTY
description: "At any political meeting, nine-tenths of the questions from the homeowners are about multifamily housing,'' says Hy Sardy, chairman of the Midwood Development Corporation in Brooklyn.

title: New President Is Appointed For the Y.M.C A. of New York
description: William A. Markell has been appointed president of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York to succeed William A. Howes, who is retiring. The New York Y.M.C.A. is the largest in the world, with 21 branches in the five boroughs of the city and a current annual budget of $34 million.

title: ROBERT MINDLIN
description: Robert Mindlin, who wrote a column on New York politics and government that was syndicated in the Newhouse newspapers, died Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 57 years old and lived in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: A NEW LIFE FOR ANCIENT APHRODISIAS
description: MARVINE HOWE is chief of The Times bureau in Ankara.

title: THE NETHERLANDS
description: To the Editor: The article by Michael Kammen about ''Hunters' Tables'' was most interesting even to someone like myself who is quite familiar with the fine cuisine in Holland. One small correction might serve the reader: the Restaurant Excelsior is referred to as being ''in a well-established hotel of the same name'' when actually it is in the distinguished Hotel de L'Europe. SANDY LESBERG, New York, Michael Kammen replies: The letter writer is correct.

title: Gifts to Drivers
description: In the spirit of the holiday season, the Albuquerque (N.M.) Police Department began handing out tickets to good drivers earlier this month - free tickets to the movies.

title: Maribeth Gerard To Wed Physician
description: Dr. and Mrs. Franklyn P. Gerard of Glen Ridge and Sea Girt, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maribeth Gerard, to Dr. F. Dana Fortunato of Montclair, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Fortunato of Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: KARPOV OUTPOINTS TOP RIVAL IN TEAM OLYMPIAD
description: Anatoly Karpov outscored Gari Kasparov in the Olympiad in Lucerne, Switzerland - even if this was a team tournament and that, as comrades on the Soviet team, they could neither play each other nor officially compete with each other. Whenever the world champion and the player ranked second in the world by the International Chess Federation's computer take part in any tourney, they cannot escape comparison.

title: ADDING UP THE LEGISLATIVE SCORECARD
description: WASHINGTON The second session of the 97th Congress passed much of its time on budget priorities, at the expense of much substantive legislation. The Senate, held hostage by a stubborn conservative filibuster, didn't leave until Thursday, when it approved a gas tax/highway repair bill that had sailed through the House weeks ago. The filibuster also delayed until last weekend passage of a stopgap funding bill laden with patronage baubles in the spirit of the season and the tradition of urgent spending bills.

title: Watergate Tapes
description: Faced with a budget cut and the loss of 12 of 31 technicians, the National Archives said last Jan. 3 that its processing of the Watergate tapes would be delayed until 1987. But the next day the agency said ways would be found to prevent the delay.

title: DANCE: ROCK 'FEAST' AT P.S. 122
description: Last year, Rhys Chatham, a well-known composer on the downtown art-rock scene, collaborated with Karole Armitage, a member of Merce Cunningham's dance company and a vanguard dance choreographer herself, on a piece called ''Drastic Classicism,'' which was enthusiastically received by the dance critics. Wednesday night at the P.S. 122 performance space, Mr. Chatham joined forces with Lisa Fox, another choreographer and, in her case, a former Cunningham company member, for a collaborative effort entitled ''The Feast.'' Lightning did not strike twice.

title: NETS DEFEAT KNICKS IN OVERTIME, 112-110
description: The Knicks overtime heroics ended last night. After recent extrasession victories against the Boston Celtics and the Milwaukee Bucks, the Knicks missed five free throws in the final 88 seconds of the five-minute overtime and lost to the Nets, 112-110, at Madison Square Garden.

title: SOME PLAIN-SPEAKING BRITONS GET LAST WORD ON GIBBERISH
description: Several civil servants, an insurance company and an appliance dealer were singled out this month for what was called the worst gibberish written in Britain this year.

title: 76ers Lead Balloting
description: Moses Malone and Julius Erving lead a band of Philadelphia 76ers who are dominating the fan voting for the Eastern Conference team for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game Feb. 13 at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE DECEMBER 26, 1982
description: William Safire 6 On Language Watch What You Say Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Literate Television Edward Schumacher 12 Argentina After the Falklands Disillusioned by defeat and crippling inflation, angered by new evidence of military repression, the Argentines have become ever more cynical. Even the promise of elections has failed to alter the mood.

title: Old Buddies
description: To the Editor: Whenever I travel abroad, for whatever reason and for whatever length of time, I make it my business to visit an American military cemetery. In Europe there is always one nearby.

title: Article 117793 -- No Title
description: With the cold breath of winter upon us and furnaces burning fuel at a prodigious rate, here is a welcome offer from the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. For $50, paid in advance but well below what private contractors would charge, the department will test the combustion efficiency of an oil or gas furnace in any multifamily dwelling in the city.

title: 'EMPLOYEE' CONCERN SHUTTERED
description: THE ghosts of Christmas past, present or future have not, singly or together, prevented the Internal Revenue Service from seizing the assets of the Feuer Transportation Company in Yonkers last week, adding 50 middle-aged employees to the unemployment lines and halting an unusual experiment in employee ownership.

title: BUSINESS ADVICE
description: THE RE-UNITED STATES OF AMERICA An Action Agenda for Improving Business, Government, and Labor Relations. By David A. Heenan. 286 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Co. $13.95. THE COX REPORT ON THE AMERICAN CORPORATION By Allan Cox. 451 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $21.95.

title: Age of Limits For Hospitals
description: The best way to hold down New York health care costs is to put a lid on new hospital construction, the Health Care Capital Policy Advisory Committee has concluded. Dr. David Axelrod, the State Commissioner of Health, seconded the notion last week, proposing that the city's large teaching hospitals, like the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, reduce or merge their highly specialized and expensive services rather than begin new construction.

title: AND NOW IT'S THE DAY AFTER THE DAY BEFORE
description: IT'S a day to get going early - or to sit by the fire with a friend, slowly unfolding reminiscences. It's a good day to think about making some upbeat changes in your life. But it's good, too, to hold still and be happy in this interlude that is holiday-warm, companioned with love.

title: Chaim Grade
description: To the Editor:

title: Suicide for Legal Aid?
description: It's hard to read the report of Mayor Koch's panel on New York's criminal defense services without feeling that the Legal Aid Society, and the union that has been striking against it for two months, seem destined to go down the tube together.

title: A MAN OF EARTH AND GOD
description: LUTHER A Life. By John M. Todd. Illustrated. 396 pp. New York: Crossroad. $17.50.MARTIN LUTHER An Illustrated Biography. By Peter Manns. Photographs by Helmuth Nils Loose. Translated by Michael Shaw. Introduction by Jaroslav Pelikan. 223 pp. New York: Crossroad. $50.

title: Steelworkers to Vote At Wheeling-Pittsburgh
description: Ten thousand workers at the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation will decide next week whether to grant contract concessions to the ailing company or to take a chance that it can survive the new year without help.

title: 'Freeze' Diversity Is Its Strength
description: While Harold Nash (''Freeze Leader Had Defense Career,'' Dec. 5) fears that the movement toward a nuclear freeze ''might not develop the strength it needs because of its diversity,'' I suspect the appeal of the freeze movement is its diversity.

title: FLEISHER, 'CANDIDE' AND A 'COSI' RESONATE IN THE MEMORY
description: Looking back is not generally a healthy or useful exercise. Even if you do not acquire a severe crick in the neck from peering over your shoulder, there is the great danger of coming down with an even more serious ailment: yesteritis. The affliction seems to strike older members of the musical public, while generally sparing the young. Its symptoms are easy to recognize. The eyes begin to tear ever so slightly at the mention of any soprano above the age of 50. The fingers move convulsively, as if shuffling through yellowed concert programs. The heart beats calmly at the prospect of hearing the latest sensational young pianist or computerized composer, but begins to thump dangerously at the mere thought of names such as Rubinstein or Schubert. There is no known cure.

title: No Headline
description: Campaign Charges And Free Speech State Senator Carol Berman is to be commended for her efforts to hold Assemblyman Dean Skelos to account for his charges leveled at her during the recent campaign.

title: Dutch Navy Saves 51 From 2 Oil Rigs at Sea
description: Fifty-one men were rescued by Dutch Navy helicopters from two listing North Sea oil platforms during a storm today, the Royal Dutch Navy said.

title: The Netherlands
description: To the Editor: It was exciting for me to read Michael Kammen's article ''Hunters' Tables in the Netherlands'' (Travel, Nov. 21). While living a year in Nijmegen, we made several visits to the nearby Kroller-Muller Museum and Hoge Veluwe Park in Arnhem. Mr. Kammen certainly captured the spirit of the place in his description, but other details should be noted.

title: Liver Transplant Child Gets Thousands of Greeting Cards
description: Jamie Fiske, home from the hospital for a very special Christmas with her family, celebrated the holiday today amid thousands of greeting cards from around the country.

title: Kean Veto Leaves A Tax Vacuum
description: The New Jersey Legislature's uncharacteristic enthusiasm for an income tax increase was no match last week for the uncharacteristic opposition of a chief executive.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS ENCOUNTERED WITH NEW PLANTS
description: HOUSE plants acquired at this time of year may be subject to stresses not encountered in other seasons. The most obvious of all problems is that of exposure to cold. Most house plants are either tropical or subtropical in origin and are not adapted to exposure to cold temperatures. Such conditions may be encountered during delivery. Too frequently, a plant will not have been adequately wrapped as a means of protecting it from exposure.

title:
PAPERBACK TALK;
Another Angle on What We Read
description: Year-end is, of course, traditionally a time for taking stock, and in the last days of 1982 we asked publishers of several major paperback lines to look back and identify their five all-time top sellers.

title: THE PLAY'S NOT THE THING
description: In the curriculum of literary criticism American plays are not given much credit these days. No serious French literary critic would fail to take into account the plays of Albert Camus or Jean Genet, and in Germany you would be thought odd if you discussed language and style without reference to Max Frisch or Peter Handke. But you can read many volumes of American literary criticism without finding a note about Tennessee Williams or Arthur Miller, or even Thornton Wilder or Eugene O'Neill.

title: THEATER'S FIRST COUPLE
description: Mention the remark that many make about them - that they've been side by side for 40 years and are still in love - and Hume Cronyn grimaces and Jessica Tandy looks as though she's just swallowed a doorknob.

title: CANNED CABERNET AND PINOT NOIR IN PLASTIC?
description: After long years of being put up mostly in glass bottles, wine is increasingly being sold in cans and plastic containers. Geyser Peak, a California winery that prides itself on being an innovator in packaging, sells wine on the West Coast in 187-milliliter cans, which contain 6.3-ounce servings. Around the spring of 1983, the company plans to offer its wine in cans on the East Coast.

title: 'A GOOD SHEET,' SAID DWIGHT MACDONALD
description: THE HOUND & HORN LETTERS Edited by Mitzi Berger Hamovitch. Foreword by Lincoln Kirstein. Illustrated. 247 pp. Athens, Ga.: University of Georgia Press. $25.

title: 418 Places Not to Visit
description: The dark side of industrial society was illuminated by the Environmental Protection Agency last week, though the light burned more like a candle than a flare. Two years after Congress created a $1.6 billion ''superfund'' for cleaning up toxic waste dumps, the agency released a list of 418 cases from South Carolina to Samoa judged most dangerous out of at least 12,000 hazardous sites.

title: Index; International
description: An English Christmas tradition is carried on at Cambridge 3 Pope, in Christmas message, wishes ''a new hope'' for Poles 3 U.S. preparing to make overture to Albania 4 Trudeau and Levesque continue dispute over Constitution 6 Agencies team up to aid Yemen after earthquake 8 Ethiopia appears to be enjoying greater stability 9 A paradise in Papua New Guinea awaits next volcanic eruption 10 Athens moves to restore a histori- cal section 11 Awards are given for the worst gibberish written in Britain 12 Around the World 13 Fate of six tourists kidnapped in July in Zimbabwe is unknown 15 General Around the Nation 11 Philadelphia commuters face an- other transit shutdown 19 Dioxin leaves Missouri town with uncertain future 22 Black charity groups meeting success and opposition 24 Erosion of Cape Code dunes an environmental threat 26 Educators divided on Federal subsidy for donated computers 30 Yale faculty required to disclose corporate links 40 Education/Welfare The city university's law school will serve the disadvantaged 31 Arts/Entertainment ''The World of Ruth Draper'' at South Street Theatre 52 ''Bottom Line'' parodies Reago- nomics 52 ''Land of Look Behind,'' film 56 ''Messiah'' at Carnegie Hall 58 ''A Christmas Celebration, a Jazz Suite...'' 58 Classical guitarist Carlos Barbo- sa-Lima 58 Dance: Rock ''The Feast'' 60 Vocal Arts Ensemble perform 60 Experimental Intermedia Foundation,''Music of the Fu- ture'' 60 Dance: ''Void'' and other dances by Sanasardo 61 Rock: Two Progressive Bands 62 Cedar Walton performs at Greene Street 62 Style Fleeting Fame: When quiz kids grow up 63 Obituaries Dr. Jose Ferrer Jr., Columbia professor emeritus of surgery 36

title: ANOTHER SUCH VICTORY
description: The eyewitness evidence of assiduous Christmas shoppers is that the stores were not nearly as busy as usual this year; and the first official estimate of third quarter economic activity - down at an annual rate of 2.2 percent - seems to support that empirical judgment.

title: ROCK: TWO PROGRESSIVE BANDS
description: Monday's concert at the Squat Theater by two bands, Etron Fou Leloublan and Skeleton Crew, was progressive rock at its drollest and most intricate.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Some Sweet Music On Pianos and Organs

title: FIVE DEMOCRATS READY CHALLENGE TO O'ROURKE
description: WESTCHESTER's designated County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, will not be sworn in for another week, but there are already five Democrats lined up to take his job away. The list may grow even longer before one of them emerges as his opponent in next November's general election.

title: Leslie Brooksher to Wed R.E. Gottlieb
description: Mr. and Mrs. K. Dane Brooksher of Greenwich, Conn., formerly of St. Louis, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Carter Brooksher, to Richard Eric Gottlieb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Gottlieb of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: FOR BOB NEWHART, AFFECTION IS STILL THE ESSENCE OF SUCESSFUL COMEDY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Karen Stabiner is a West Coast writer who frequently reports on films and television. LOS ANGELES If comedians were articles of clothing, Bob Newhart would be a classic navy blue blazer: not faddish, not flamboyant, hardly at the fashion vanguard and yet an essential component of a man's wardrobe. Always in good taste, never dull.

title: DARE WE SAVOR SUCCESS
description: TEN years ago, Cecilia and I lost touch. We were co-workers, the only women in an accounting firm. She, a mature person with three children (two in college), was just returning to the work world. I, in my early 20's, was caught in the storm of social change and dealing with life on my own - having run from a family torn by alcoholism and abuse.

title: KEAN RENEWS EFFORT TO RESOLVE BUDGET IMPASSE
description: TRENTON AFTER vetoing the fruits of the special legislative session that he convened last month - an increase in the state income tax - Governor Kean will bring the lawmakers back tomorrow for another attempt at solving the state's short-term budget problem, a projected $150 million deficit.

title: Sea-Scallop Summer
description: William McGowan's article about sea scalloping brought back vivid memories of the summer of 1949 (''Braving the Seas for Scallops,'' Nov. 28). I spent that summer on a deep-sea scalloper out of Woods Hole, Mass.

title: MUSEUM GIVEN ORIGINAL BLUEPRINTS OF RIVER STEAMSHIPS
description: For 50 years, more than 5,000 drawings of steamboats, paddle wheels and engines remained in a basement vault at the Bethlehem Steel Shipyard in Hoboken, N.J. ''They had nothing to do with Bethlehem, so our archivists didn't care about them,'' said Alexander Boyt, the chief estimator at Bethlehem.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A WORTHWHILE SIDE TRIP
