description: MULLICA HILL DRIVING to Philadelphia or Washington in the near future? Time permitting, a visit to some of the antiques shops in this Gloucester County community might prove to be a worthy side trip.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: RAVEN The Untold Story of the Rev. Jim Jones and His People. By Tim Reiterman with John Jacobs. Illustrated. 622 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: BRITONS HARK TO KING'S CHAPEL VOICES
description: Some of them had been waiting in line all night, as they do every year, in the Great Court of King's College. It was cold, and the skies were leaden, but no one complained, because they knew that their fortitude meant they would be able to witness England's most famous Christmas celebration.

title: A Strong Front Four Revives Cardinals
description: When the Giants play the Cardinals Sunday at Busch Memorial Stadium, the key man may be a baldish, 46-year-old former defensive tackle named Floyd Peters.

title: What Happens?
description: To The Business Editor: Despite some minor differences, in ''What Happens If Oil Prices Plummet? (Dec.12), both John Lichtblau and Alvin Alm conclude that it would be harmful for world oil prices to fall.

title: 70,000 ON A BEAUTIFUL ISLE LIVE WITH GROWING VOLCANO THREAT
description: Ringed by green mountains, Rabaul lies nestled on New Britain Island on the rim of a deep blue bay that is surrounded by volcanic cones, old and new.

title: THE EXPERIMENT HAS NOT WORKEED
description: WITH more than a touch of irony, the Bank of International S ettlements once described Mrs. Thatcher's economic policy as an e xperiment it would watch with interest. After three and a half yearsi t is possible to draw up a balance sheet and judge promise against p erformance. The experiment has not worked.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AFTER a small number of Lattingtown residents expressed concern over a proposal made by the Creek Club to add 11 guest cottages to the four guest dwellings already on its 190-acre Gold Coast property, the private golf and beach club decided ''not to pursue the matter any further,'' according to Peter Weiler. Mr. Weiler is an associate in the law firm of Humes, Andrews, Botzow & Wagner, representing the village.

title: MUSIC: YEARLY CARNEGIE HALL 'MESSIAH'
description: Every year since Carnegie Hall was opened to the public, the Oratorio Society of New York has been presenting an annual Christmas rendition of Handel's ''Messiah.'' Tuesday evening's performance, then, was the continuation of a long-established New York tradition.

title: Kohl Appeals to Soviet To Agree to Missile Offer
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl appealed to the Soviet Union today to scrap its medium-range nuclear missiles and forestall Western plans to counter them.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS ENCOUNTERED WITH NEW PLANTS
description: HOUSE plants acquired at this time of year may be subject to stresses not encountered in other seasons. The most obvious of all problems is that of exposure to cold. Most house plants are either tropical or subtropical in origin and are not adapted to exposure to cold temperatures. Such conditions may be encountered during delivery. Too frequently, a plant will not have been adequately wrapped as a means of protecting it from exposure.

title: A Decision On the Merits
description: The spirit of Hester Prynne may have attended an East Hampton, L.I., school board meeting last week on behalf of a pregnant, unwed teacher. Though urged by petitions from offended parents to dismiss Patricia Hope, a 41-year-old biology instructor, the board decided to leave well enough alone.

title: FROM PARIS TO HARLEM, IT WAS A TIME OF SURPRISES; T his in many ways has been a greased pig of a year - a time at which the international art world was full of life, full of surprises, unexpectedly agile and quite impossible to pin down.
description: It was, for instance, the year in which the best exhibition by a 20th-century American artist was not in this country at all, but in Paris. All of those who saw ''Jackson Pollock'' at the Pompidou Center are of the same mind - that it could not have been bettered either in its timing, in its choice of work by a major American cultural figure, or in its use of galleries that have often been called recalcitrant.

title: PETRO-CANADA'S COMPETITIVE PUSH
description: Canada - Canada's state-owned oil company -set up shop in 1976 was predictable: They promptly dubbed the company's brick building ''Red Square'' and took to calling the company's leaders ''commissars.''

title: MAJOR CHALLENGES ON STATE ECONOMY ARE FACING CUOMO
description: Battered by rising unemployment, high taxes and a severe national recession, the economy of New York State as Mario M. Cuomo prepares to assume the governorship has stalled after years of modest growth and now stands at a critical stage, rife with difficulties and opportunities.

title: Snug Harbor
description: To the Editor:

title: Steven Blasnik to Wed Miss Lowengrub in July
description: The engagement of Linda Lowengrub to Steven Blasnik, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Blasnik of Englewood, N.J., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Judge Paul A. Lowengrub of the New Jersey State Superior Court and Mrs. Lowengrub of Westmont, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: ATHENS RESTORING A HISTORICAL AREA
description: Efforts to restore and preserve Plaka, the historical heart of Athens, have long been under way, but they are being given special impetus under the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.

title: Beth Harris Is Engaged To Mark L. Robertson
description: Mrs. Hoback Harris and Charles A. Harris, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Selena Harris, to Mark Laverne Robertson, son of the Rev. Arnold Laverne Robertson of Greensboro, N.C., and the late Mitzi Haymore Robertson. A Jan. 15 wedding is planned in Atlanta.

title: Ailing Polish Boy Must Wait for a Reunion
description: An 8-year-old boy, who doctors say is literally pining away for his father in Poland, may have to wait months for a reunion. Polish officials have denied Miroslaw Bielecki a passport and exit visa to visit his ailing son Mariusz until the man's wife straightens out a question of residency in this country.

title: Home for the Holiday
description: Some college football players were not home for the holiday yesterday because they were playing in bowl games, but Todd Hart was one player who was home, and he was happy for it.

title: LEISURE
description: PROPER CARE WILL ASSURE LONGEVITY FOR THE SHOWIEST AZALEA PLANTS By Michael Trimble --------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Trimble is a professional horticulturist and freelance writer.

title: No Headline
description: Hospital Beds: A Real Need The recent article on the hospital bed situation on Long Island (''Need for More Hospital Beds Debated'') falls far short of describing the real situation that patients face when they need to be hospitalized on Long Island. The facts are that virtually all the hospitals are filled to capacity (and beyond) almost all the time.

title: Miss Hawkes Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Hawkes of Waterville, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Anne Hawkes, to Paul David Grand Pre, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Grand Pre of Wilton, Conn.

title: Society of Joneses Objects to Use of Name
description: The Jones Protection Society has voted unanimously to censure you and Arthur Reinstein for the pusillanimous and corruptive slander of the good name Jones in an Opinion article on Dec. 5.

title: Taking Stock of General Motors
description: The one thing that came across in John Holusha's article ''General Motors: A Giant in Transition'' (Nov. 14) is that marketers don't know how to improve their market share.

title: Wilson Gets 15 Years for Gun-Running
description: Edwin P. Wilson had a ''remarkable record of serving'' his country while in the Central Intelligence Agency, a Federal judge commented last week. But his record of illegally serving the Libyan Government was no less remarkable and, as a result, he was sentenced to serve 15 years in prison.

title: WHEN PRICE MEANS MORE THAN BOUQUET
description: ''Finally, a Chardonnay for every day'' is the oddly prosaic advertising theme used to plug Bollini Italian Chardonnay wine in these recessionary times. The no-nonsense slogan and the premiumquality wine's modest retail price - just under $5 for a regular sized, 750-milliliter bottle -have been designed to fit the price-and value-consciousness that is spreading among this country's winebibbers.

title: Kimmelman's Way
description: A law requiring a moment of silent meditation in New Jersey public schools set off a legal controversy last week, but not the expected one. The issue wasn't whether the measure violated the separation of church and state but whether the Attorney General, Irwin I. Kimmelman, violated his responsibility in saying he would refuse to argue such a case.

title: LAB TRIES TO WEATHER STORM
description: UPTON THIS has not been a happy year for the Brookhaven National Laboratory. Construction funds for its high-speed atom smasher, a multimillion-dollar project that was the pride and joy of the Island when initially announced, have been cut off in Washington, and the project has been downgraded and sent back to the drawing board.

title: ECONOMIC PEACE ERUPTS AMONG THE ALLIES
description: Peace and good will are in season between Western Europe and the United States as the two halves of the Western alliance draw back from the brink of economic warfare.

title: DUTY OF EDUCATORS TO THEIR STUDENTS
description: THE intellectual unfreedom of today's college student is widespread because, like most Americans, they are experiencing a loss of security. There is growing confusion in their lives; they face too much complexity and ambiguity; modern life poses too many threats to their certitudes.

title: HOUSING FOR THE SPIRIT
description: AMERICAN CHURCHES By Roger G. Kennedy. Illustrated. 296 pp. New York: Stewart, Tabori & Chang. $50. EXPLORING CHURCHES By Paul and Tessa Clowney. Illustrated. 91 pp. Grand Rapids, Mich.: William B. Eerdmans Publishing Co. $12.95. SYNAGOGUES OF NEW YORK CITY By Oscar Israelowitz. Illustrated. 83 pp. New York: Dover Publications. $6. STAINED GLASS FROM MEDIEVAL TIMES TO THE PRESENT Treasures to Be Seen in New York. Text by James L. Sturm. Photographs by James Chotas. 152 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $16.95.

title: Nations Near Salmon Pact
description: John R. Sharpe, the Canadian consul general here, said the United States and Canada were on the verge of signing an agreement to manage salmon harvests on the Pacific Coast.

title: TENANT GROUP PUTS CLOUT TO WORK
description: IT was one of those issues that make enemies of tenants and landlords. The tenants of Lincoln Towers, the 4,000-apartment complex on Manhattan's West Side, were outraged to learn that the management wanted to install meters in each apartment and stop including the cost of electricity in their rents.

title: OIL GROUP SUES FOR EXPLORATION OF SEA PRESERVES
description: A major group of oil companies is asking the Federal courts to nullify the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary off Santa Barbara so that oil and gas leasing, development and extraction can be conducted in the preserve area.

title: 21 Food Outlets Cited For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 21 food establishments it said had violated the Health Code. The department also released the names of four restaurants that reopened after correcting earlier violations and five that were closed for failing to do so.

title: SNOWBOUND 9-YEAR-OLD SAVED
description: A 9-year-old girl, left in a snowbound car by her father while he went to search for help, ''did just what she was told'' and waited alone for 18 hours before three snowmobilers found her.

title: HOLIDAY MERCY AND GUILTY; The Gift of Seoul
description: Credit one big gain for America's quiet diplomacy. Without it, Kim Dae Jung, now in the United States for medical treatment, would be rotting in a South Korean prison or hanged for sedition.

title: Election Upset In Hamburg
description: West Germany's Social Democratic Party got a big boost in its comeback drive with an unexpected victory last week in the city-state of Hamburg. The election was the first test of public opinion since the Government changed hands in September with Helmut Kohl and the Christian Democrats replacing the Social Democrats under Helmut Schmidt.

title: AN AVIAN TRADITION SINCE 1900
description: EVERY December there is a mad rush of checking lists and of trying to make certain that everything is in order. Then comes the seemingly interminable period of waiting for the special day when Westchester residents can scan the treetops in keen anticipation. Their time for guessing has ended. Some watchers, unable to contain themselves any longer, began gathering their bounty during today's early morning dark; what they discover will keep them engrossed far into the night and for many weeks and months to come. Dec. 26 has arrived at long last, and for the county's bird watchers that can mean only one thing: the yearly Christmas Bird Count is at hand.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Indianapolis, 7:35 P.M. Indiana has won both previous meetings this season. (Radio - WNEW-AM 1130.) Spurs vs. Philadelphia 76ers at San Antonio, and Clippers vs. Portland Trail Blazers at San Diego. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M. and 10:30 P.M., respectively.)

title: Chair-Bound
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Bergmann's conclusions regarding the shortcomings of economic theory, ''The Failures of a Chair-Bound Science'' (Dec.12) were indeed provocative.

title: Spirits By Terry Robards
description: An authentic 1805 Cognac that bears Napoleon's name sold for 5,500 francs, or about $800, at an auction held in Paris on Dec. 1. The Mystique Of Brandies Millions of bottles of brandy purporting to be from Napoleon are sold, but virtually all of them are less than 20 years old.

title: Jets Need to Blunt Fierce Viking Rush
description: A taped, protected, and somewhat ailing Richard Todd will set up behind one of pro football's outstanding offensive lines Sunday and expect not to get banged up - at least, not as much as in the previous game.

title: Shelby Charger Excites Chrysler
description: BACK in 1964, when Lee Iacocca was president of Ford Motor Company, he had a better idea - a sporty car that would appeal to a generation of young drivers. He called it the Mustang, and that original pony car gave rise to a herd of similar vehicles. Then Mr. Iacocca had another brainstorm: He brought in a former racer named Carroll Shelby and allowed him to put his brand on the Mustangs.

title: MRS. GORSUCH AS A CRUSADING TIGER? CRITICS WONDER WHY
description: As Anne M. Gorsuch tells it, the bell that tolls this Friday at midnight will be for communities throughout the nation that have failed to meet the air quality standards set by the Clean Air Act.

title: By Herbert R. Lottman; Herbert R. Lottman, a longtime Paris resident, is the author of ''The Left Bank'' and ''Albert Camus.''
description: LEON BLUM By Jean Lacouture. Translated by George Holoch. Illustrated. 571 pp. New York: Holmes & Meier. Cloth, $39.50. Paper, $24.50.

title: A Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, an article last week about high school fraternities incorrectly gave the name of a man who was killed behind a shopping center in Oceanside. The victim was John Dodson.

title: Reluctant Exile
description: Faced with the tough choice between being locked up in his native land or locked out of it, Korean opposition leader Kim Dae Jung chose the latter last week. Mr.Kim, a former presidential candidate who was sentenced to death in 1980 on sedition charges that were never fully explained, arrived in the United States for ''medical treatment'' after his sentence, which had been reduced to 20 years, was suspended. Officials in Washington said the sudden reversal of Mr. Kim's fortunes was a result of ''quiet diplomacy.''

title: PASSING BECOMES DOMINANT IN COLLEGES
description: Major college football teams combined to pass for more yardage this season than they gained rushing, the first year that has happened since the pass was made legal in 1906. Only seven years ago, rushing yardage reached a record-high average of 204.5 a game.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: PILOT PROGRAM UPGRADES BUILDINGS WITHOUT EVICTIONS
description: FOURTEEN months ago, Vito Rafanelli, a custodial engineer for the N ew York City Board of Education, purchased a seven-unit, three-storyb uilding on Bogart Avenue in the Bronx for $54,000.

title: A RINGING FINALE TO THE YEAR
description: SANTA CLAUS may have gone home, but the Nutcracker dances on. For some reason, Tchaikovsky's ever-popular ballet seems to be especially so in the waning days of the year, and at least two major productions here are vying with the famous Balanchine edition at the New York City Ballet.

title: December 26, 1982
description: NONFICTION AMERICAN CHURCHES. By Roger G. Kennedy. 3 THE COX REPORT ON THE AMERICAN CORPORATION.By Allan Cox. 9 EXPLORING CHURCHES.

title: NOHO RESIDENTS' OPPOSITION KILLS PLAN FOR HOMELESS SHELTER
description: One of the 10 private agencies picked by New York City to help shelter homeless men and women has withdrawn its offer after residents of the Manhattan community where the facility was to open protested.

title: FROM TELEVISION, A LOVE OF HEROINES
description: FOR the last year or so, I have been hopelessly, shamefully in love with several glorious women. The object of my affections? Lovely, courageous heroines as portrayed on public television.

title: PROGRAM MUSIC, WITH A PROGRAM
description: MUSIC AND POLITICS Collected Writings 1953-81. By Hans Werner Henze. Translated by Peter Labanyi. Illustrated. 286 pp. Ithaca, N. Y.: Cornell University Press. $24.95.

title:
TV VIEW;
INCREASING COMPETITION WIDENED THE AUDIENCE'S CHOICES
description: Areview of the past year indicates that American television is getting better, even if only imperceptibly at times and even if imported British products still dominate a good portion of the overall picture. The fact is that selective viewers, picking their way carefully through fields of mediocre or downright insulting material (a chore not unknown to movie- or theatergoers), could have found a respectable quantity of first-rate, often outstanding productions.

title: Christina Hopkins To Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hopkins of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christina A. Hopkins, to Ian Michael Winchester, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan G. Winchester of Sussex, England, and Seattle. An April wedding is planned.

title: Susan M. Aurilio Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Aurilio of Flushing, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan M. Aurilio, to Peter S. Kanuika Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kanuika of Bayside, Queens. A June wedding is planned.

title: MARY MCDERMOTT TO WED E.M. NASSAU
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Hilbert Connell of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Connell's daughter, Mary Elizabeth McDermott, to Ernesto Manuel Nassau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt-Helmut Nassau of Cupertino, Calif.

title: NEW STABILITY, OLD PROBLEMS FOR ETHIOPIA
description: Eight years after toppling Emperor Haile Selassie, Ethiopia's Communist military Government appears to be enjoying greater stability.

title: HEADHUNTERS GO TO JAPAN
description: A TELEVISION documentary about a particular facet of life in the United States -corporate headhunting -was filmed recently in Fairfield County, based on the experiences of a Connecticut family. The film will be shown only in Japan, where headhunters - also called executive search companies - are virtually unknown.

title: Eubie Blake Birthday Party
description: In honor of Eubie Blake's 100th birthday, St. Peter's Church, at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street, will hold a 24-hour celebration beginning at midnight Feb. 6. The marathon tribute to the composer will feature entertainment by a host of musicians, vocalists and dancers, including Billy Taylor, Bobby Short, Dick Hyman, Honi Coles and the Copacetics, Bill Balcom and Joan Morris, Max Morath, Marianne McPartland, Maurice Hines and Cab Calloway. Mr. Blake, who was born in Baltimore on Feb. 7, 1882, may attend.

title: JAMAICA IS THE 'LAND OF LOOK BEHIND'
description: In his book ''Heart of Glass,'' Alan Greenberg describes how Werner Herzog made a film of that name with the entire cast under hypnosis. The Jamaican reggae musicians, poets and mystics who drift through Mr. Greenberg's first film, ''Land of Look Behind,'' could easily be mistaken for subjects in a hypnosis experiment that somehow went awry. But one suspects that they are simply in a haze of smoking the potent marijuana cigars that the island's Rastafarians call ''spliffs.''

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. And Bear in Mind Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest. ALFRED STIEGLITZ: PHOTOGRAPHS & WRITINGS, by Sarah Greenough and Juan Hamilton. (Callaway Editions/National Gallery of Art. $67.50 until Dec. 31; $75 thereafter.) A selection of the great American photographer's work. THE BEST AMERICAN SHORT STORIES OF 1982, edited by John Gardner with Shannon Ravenel. (Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) The latest in the annual series. FEIFFER, edited by Steven Heller. (Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $25; paper, $12.95.) Twenty-five years of Jules Feiffer's cartoons, with commentary by the artist. GRAMMAR AND GOOD TASTE, by Dennis E. Baron. (Yale University Press, $19.95.) A history of language reform in America. HOWARD HAWKS, STORYTELLER, by Gerald Mast. (Oxford University Press, $29.95.) An analysis of the film director's career. THE LONGEST WAR, by Jacobo Timerman. (Alfred A. Knopf, $11.95.)

title: FOR PATERSON, A STITCH IN TIME?
description: Two 19th century textile mills in Paterson, N.J., are being converted into housing for artists and artisans as part of an effort by the city to upgrade the 116-acre downtown area called the Great Falls Historic District.

title: John Williams Contract With Pops Is Extended
description: John Williams has signed a contract with the Boston Pops Orchestra that will keep him as conductor through 1987. The contract stipulates that Mr. Williams will conduct seven weeks of the Pops season in the spring, special concerts at the orchestra's Tanglewood base in the Berkshires and Christmas Pops concerts and Independence Day and other traditional concerts on the banks of the Charles River. No other terms were disclosed.

title: AN OFFBEAT FOCUS
description: Antiques collectors have been considerably more adventurous this year than in many years past, shifting gears to acquire wares in styles once viewed as unconventional or unfashionable. Spurred by gallery events and museum shows, where the focus has been increasingly on certain periods of the decorative arts that have not yet been fully explored by scholars and major dealers, pioneering collectors have done what they do best - enthusiastically embraced the offbeat, initiating the buying of wares long ignored by the establishment.

title: A DEBATE: WHAT TO DO ABOUT SOCIAL SECURITY
description: A first order of business for the 98th Congress will be shoring up Social Security. The old-age trust fund has exhausted its cash reserves. Since November, it has been borrowing from other Social Security funds to pay monthly benefits.

title: CHERRY HILL HOPING TO SHAPE PLANS TO REBUILD RACE TRACK
description: Government officials and business executives in this prosperous suburb of Philadelphia are expressing delight that Cherry Hill's prime piece of real estate, unused since 1977, may soon be a race track again.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN FROM what I see, looking to my left, to my right, across the street and up the block, we are the only family on the North Shore without a Mercedes or Cadillac.

title: Trail Blazers 95 SuperSonics 88
description: Jim Paxson, a guard, scored 22 points and the Portland front line was too strong for Seattle off the boards. Jack Sikma's hook shot gave Seattle its only lead, 2-0, but Portland outscored the Sonics by 12-6 during the next four minutes. Paxson had 12 of his points in the first quarter, and Darnell Valentine had three steals to pace the Blazers to a 34-21 firstperiod lead.

title: PATCHOUGE RIDING A TIDE OF OPTIMISM ON REVITALIZATION
description: PATCHOGUE ''WE made a large commitment to Patchogue because we believe in Patchogue,'' said Frederic Rose, president of Clare Rose Inc., in his modern $400,000 office building, which seems out of place in an area characterized mostly by run-down or boarded-up buildings.

title: CHARLESTON, W. Va.
description: AS 33-year-old Richard L. Trumka was inaugurated as the youngest president of one of the nation's oldest labor unions last week, West Virginia Governor John D. Rockefeller 4th praised his ''extraordinary energy and abilities.'' Mr. Trumka will surely need those qualities if his union, the United Mine Workers of America, is to overcome the intertwined problems of dwindlng membership and growing debt.

title: Man, 32, Shot to Death On Sidewalk in Chelsea
description: A 32-year-old Manhattan man who was walking with his date to a Christmas Eve party in Chelsea was fatally shot by one of two men who accosted the couple, the police said yesterday.

title: NO CURE-ALL FOR TRANSIT
description: YEARS too late, the nation's citizens have finally faced the fact that their transportation network is crumbling. Networks need maintenance, and the United States has constructed the most energyprofligate, least cost-efficient system of any in the world: the flydrive travel plan.

title: SLEDDING RACE IS A HIGHLIGHT FOR ALASKANS
description: For three weeks each winter, Alaska's populace seems divided into dog mushers and those who wish they were. The smaller of the two groups by far is the mushers, a few dozen of whom captivate the entire state as they race more than 1,000 miles over some of Alaska's most forbidding terrain and through some of its worst weather.

title: CHURCH'S GROWING SOUP LINE REFLECTS HARD TIMES
description: AT 1:10 P.M. the other day, Alice C. Parker walked up the steps to the back entrance of the First United Methodist Church of New Jersey at 135 South Broad Street, a few blocks from the State House.

title: Nazi Party to Relocate
description: The American Nazi party, concluding that Washington area citizens ''are not people looking to join revolutionary organizations,'' is changing its name to the New Order and relocating in the Middle West.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: This FICTION Last Weeks Week Week On List

title: Breakthrough on Stolen Artifacts
description: Congress passed a bill last week that surely made the Seventh Earl of Elgin roll over in his grave. After years of blockage by art dealers, collectors and some museums, a compromise measure to halt trafficking in stolen antiquities arrived on the President's desk, where final signature was expected.

title: N.C.A.A. MISREADES ITS PURPOSE
description: AT its annual meeting in San Diego next month, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, under pressure from the College Football Association, will try to restructure its Division I basketball competition so that most nonfootball colleges are left out. Colleges can stay in if they give a large number of athletic scholarships, draw an average of 3,500 spectators to their basketball home games, and fund eight other men's sports.

title: JULY KIDNAPPING BAFFLES ZIMBABWE
description: Every morning before breakfast, William H. Ellis receives a call from the State Department and on most days the message is the same: ''Good morning, this is P.J. We have nothing from Zimbabwe. If things change, we will call later on.''

title: Letters; Wrong Site
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Moscow's First Offer on Missiles The Final Word?
description: Yuri V. Andropov went public last week with a proposal to reduce Moscow's medium-range missile arsenal in Europe if the Western allies abandoned plans to deploy 572 Pershing and cruise missiles. Publicly and predictably, the West shrugged it off. Even so, however, whether the new Soviet leader was aiming his Kremlin speech solely at world opinion or was signaling a new negotiating effort was a question likely to come in for considerable discussion among allied leaders.

title: THE CENTRALITY OF ARMS CONTROL
description: First of two articles

title: 'DOWNTOWN' COMPOSERS ARE HEADED 'UPTOWN' FOR A FESTIVAL
CREATE A NEW SYSTEM FOR PROSECUTERS
description: CONNECTICUT'S prosecutorial system is said to be unique, in that it comes under the judiciary. Much of the criticism of this arrangement possibly misses the real issues.

title: ERA OF CHANGE FOR LIQUOR STORES
description: ONE year after price controls were removed on liquor and beer sold in Connecticut, the forecast that hundreds of liquor stores would close has not proved to be an accurate one.

title: Symbol of Kindness
description: In reply to attacks on Santa Claus 46 years ago, a judge in Pennsylvania proclaimed that ''Santa is the symbol of kindness; he is the token of smiling charity.'' Yesterday once again, all over the land, children discovered miracles of delight in Santa's stockings and under brightly dressed Christmas trees. In millions of homes, the spirit of Santa reigns.

title: Unstable Tangle
description: To The Business Editor: Robert A. Bennett, in ''The Puzzling Tangle of Global Finance'' (Dec.12), stated that we can avoid any crisis in the international banking system as long as the central banks are ready to print more money.

title: Dramathon to Extend 55 Continuous Hours
description: The Quaigh Theater's annual Dramathon will be held over New Year's weekend, starting at 5 P.M. next Friday - 55 hours of continuous drama, musicals, play readings, one-acters, children's shows and revues. On the bill are six revivals: ''The Jewish Wife'' by Brecht, ''The Marriage Proposal'' by Chekhov; ''Before Breakfast'' by O'Neill, ''This Property Is Condemned'' by Tennessee Williams, ''Crawling Arnold'' by Jules Feiffer, and ''Icki, Nicki'' by Lanford Wilson.

title: Union Leaders Face Poland's Legal Truncheon
description: Poland's military rulers last week sent 100 political detainees home for Christmas, but perhaps more significant were the people they kept locked up. Seven key leaders of the outlawed Solidarity union were placed under formal arrest.

title: RESTORING THE 'WILD' OF WILDERNESS
description: NEWFOUNDLAND THE cage door swung open and the bobcat took off like a bullet, bounding swiftly through the underbrush and over felled trees. In what looked like one smooth, effortless motion, it scaled a 50-foothigh rock formation and was gone.

title: CORNWALL: LURE OF A LAND OF LEGENDS
description: D.M.THOMAS is a British poet and novelist, author of ''The White Hotel.'' His novel, ''Ararat,'' and ''Selected Poems'' will be published by Viking Penguin early in 1983.By D.M.THOMAS

title: Carol Cogan, Producer, Engaged to Burt Savitsky
description: Mr. and Mrs. David J. Cogan of Bedford Hills, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Cogan, to Burt Savitsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Savitsky of Newton, Mass.

title: U.S. IS PREPARING ALBANIA OVERTURE
description: For the third time in nine years the United States is preparing to make an overture toward taking up relations with the Communist Government of Albania.

title: If you're thinking of living in:; RYE
description: RYE City is a small, tranquil community on Long Island Sound with a w ealth of trees, open spaces, marine vistas and residents who are a ware of the town's advantages and are quick to point them out.

title: A SYMPOSIUM: THE BISHOPS AND THE ARMS RACE
description: THE National Conference of Catholic Bishops, in a broad condemnation of nuclear war, has questioned the morality of United States strategic policy. In a proposed pastoral letter, the bishops call the deterrent posture of the United States ''clearly unsatisfactory...from a moral point of view.'' Deterrence may be acceptable, they declare, ''provided it is used as a step toward progressive disarmament.'' The bishops also specifically oppose ''the willingness to foster strategic planning which seeks a nuclear war fighting capability.''

title: THE LAW AND NOISE?
description: WHAT is noisy and what isn't? That, says Stephen Frano, an ordinance inspector for the Town of Southampton, is the question, and he took three days recently to explore it at a federally financed seminar at the Cook College campus of Rutgers University. The experience is proving a considerable asset, he said, as he and Fred Thiele, the Southampton Town Attorney, work to put the final touches on a draft for a tough new antinoise ordinance.

title: Mailbox; Another View Of Quintin Dailey
description: To the Sports Editor: The emotional problems of the Chicago Bulls' basketball star, Quintin Dailey (''Quintin Dailey's Troubled Past, And Present'', The New York Times, Dec. 19) is perhaps the best evidence that vengeance has become our only visible approach to crime and having fewer victims.

title: POINTERS ON SETTING UP A HOME DSRKROOM
description: Technological innovations continue to flow from designers and manufacturers of photographic equipment in all parts of the world as announcements of new products come from Japan, Sweden, Germany, England, and the U.S. At the giant Photokina exhibit that was held in Cologne during the first week in October, many of these products were shown to the public for the first time.

title: DIOXIN THREAT PUTS U.S. UNDER FIRE
description: A small forlorn Christmas tree, its decorations caked with mud, stood today in the living room of what had been Paul and Donna Mansker's trailer home on Driftwood Street until a flood wiped them out three weeks ago.

title: JACK PEARL, 88, COMEDY STAR OF RADIO AND STAGE
description: Jack Pearl, a popular radio and stage comedian, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 88 years old and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: NJ TRANSIT TO USE 500 EXTRA BUSES IN CASE OF RAIL STRIKE JAN.1
description: NJ Transit Corporation officials, facing a Jan. 1 deadline for settlements with 16 rail unions, has announced plans to use 500 extra buses to carry most of the state's 70,000 train commuters in the event of a strike.

title: ON STRUGGLING TO TEACH
description: OUR DISSATISFACTION with schools will remain a topic of considerable interest for New Jersey's recently elected politicians. The rhetoric of this last campaign was particularly alarming, since it gave voice to so many complaints about my profession.

title: Splitting the Bill
description: To the Business Editor: Deborah Rankin's article, ''Splitting the Doctor's Bill'' (Dec.12), rang a sour note with me. The only gain realized from cutting employee medical benefits will be an increase in corporate profits, not a reduction in medical costs.

title: Q&A
description: Question:My high school-age daughter is interested in spending the summer studying in Italy. How can she find good programs that might include academic work or living with an Italian family? - S.S., Montclair, N.J. Answer:For a copy of a recently published basic booklet of information on work, study and travel programs and services, send $1 (for postage) to the Council on International Education Exchange, 205 East 42 Street, New York, N.Y. 10017; 212-661-1450. (Students in the New York City metropolitan area may go to the New York Student Center at 356 West 34th Street, between 8th and 9th avenues, and get a copy at no charge.) The council, in addition to offering an ''International Student Identity Card,'' also puts out a 338-page paperback called ''Whole World Handbook'' (E. P. Dutton, $5.75) that lists many sources of information on student travel and study.

title: HOMEOWNERS FIGHT WELFARE 'DUMPING'
description: GORDON HEIGHTS When irate homeowners in this predominantly black community charged that the Suffolk County Department of Social Services was ''dumping'' problem welfare clients into boardinghouses here, it created a controversy that has had wide repercussions.

title: YALE FACULTY REQUIRED TO REVEAL BUSINESS LINKS
description: In an effort to detect potential conflicts of interest, Yale University has decided to have its faculty members make yearly reports disclosing their consulting arrangements with or substantial investments in corporations.

title: COSTLY U.S. 'NO' TO THE LAW OF THE SEA
description: To the Editor:

title: TROUBLES OF BOSTON'S MAYOR ARE TIED TO POLITICAL MACHINE
description: Mayor Kevin H. White's mounting troubles, with the conviction of city officials and a Federal investigation into municipal corruption here, grow from his creation of an elaborate political machine in the late 1970's after he nearly lost an election, many of his friends and adversaries believe.

title:
GOING OUT GUIDE;
IT'S ALL ILLUSION
description: While there's always something quite magical about the holiday season, a little reinforcement never hurts. And starting today in a three-performance run at the Long Island Playhouse in Great Neck, John Harrison will provide that extra ingredient with ''The Magic World of Illusion.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: OVER the years, the march of civilization has just about wiped out portions of the Appalachian Trail along New Jersey's northern border. Hikers setting out for the wilderness found themselves trekking through meadows, farmers' fields and along front yards and sidewalks.

title: Texas
description: To the Editor: That was a beautiful article by Jacques Barzun, ''A Critic Casts a Kindly Eye on Texas'' (Travel, Oct. 31), but in extolling the virtues of its size, emptiness and beauty, he restricted himself to the Eastern third, along the Gulf and up to the northern border. v. hen I first visited Texas in 1946 as a guest of Uncle Sam at the United States Naval Base, Corpus Christi, that is the only part I ever saw, and I didn't much care for it.

title: No Headline
description: TEXAS LOSES BOWL TO NORTH CAROLINA

title: 'SMITHEREENS'-THE STORY OF A CINDERLLA MOVIE
description: Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Yale, is the author of the forthcoming ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust.''

title: Order of Cincinatti Founded by Officers
description: The splendid articles on General Pulaski's role in the 1778 massacre (Dec. 12) are a boon to amateur historians like myself. But may I point out an error - that the Order of Cincinatti is not, as the article said, ''a patriotic Polish organization.''

title: SPAIN'S TEMPTATION FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: ROBERT PACKARD is a professor of the humanities at Stevens Institute of Technology.

title: THE SOUTH AFRICAN BLACK'S ADVANTAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: MOST OF THE ENERGY CAME FROM ABROAD
description: I t was a scattershot year for dance. Here a good ballet, there a fine individual performance, an occasional revelation from a choreographer or a new face among dancers. But generally, amnesia starts to set in as soon as one attempts to recall the year as a coherent whole. The spurt of creativity and burst of revivals of recent years were less evident in 1982. One had to be satisfied with business as usual in terms of performance quality and that was high enough. Numerically, there were plenty of decent new works, rarely great ones. It was seemingly a time when the American dance world was taking a breather.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN LOS ANGELES
description: JUDITH CUMMINGS is a correspondent in the Los Angeles bureau of The Times.

title: MEDICAL EXHIBIT AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN AN exhibit entitled ''Images of Women in Medicine,'' now on view in the rotunda of the Yale School of Medicine, includes a rare birthing scene printed in 1554; a treatise on the care of women and babies by Loyse Bourgeois Boursecourt, who was midwife to the French court in the mid-16th century, the writing of Hildegarde of Bingen, a 12thcentury nun who healed the sick and wrote medical texts, and a finely carved 17th-century figurine of a pregnant woman, whose abdomen opens to reveal the fetus of a male child.

title: Headliners; Helping Hands
description: There are few job openings for heroes as such these days, even if they are experienced. But with the help of a reference from President Reagan, Reginald Andrews of Manhattan landed one last week. Mr.Andrews, a 29-year-old unemployed father of eight, was on his way home from a fruitless job interview when he saw David Schnair, blind and 75 years old, stumble and fall between subway cars at a station.

title: LEGAL SERVICES BOARD: A CLUE TO PRIORITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy M. Hilton To Marry in May
description: Rear Adm. Robert P. Hilton, U.S.N., and Mrs. Hilton of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Muriel Hilton, to Philip Edward Jones, son of the Rev. and Mrs. E. Keith Jones of Kingston, Ontario.

title: STAGE: REVUE PARODIES REAGANOMICS
description: While President Reagan and the woes of Reagonomics offer a ripe target for political satire, C.R. Portz's musical revue, ''The Bottom Line,'' at the Labor Theater, is so crude it manages to score only glancing blows. Its five performers, dressed in Army fatigues, play members of a military band, who met on the unemployment line and who call themselves the Not Yet Ready for Fort Dix Players. Having applied to the National Endowment for the Arts for a $375 grant and been turned down, they have been given $2.5 million and a tank from the Pentagon.

title: BEYOND THE THRESHOLD OF THE SUBSTITUTE HEART
description: T o the Editor As a medical writer who was in Salt Lake City covering the story, I feel that your Dec. 16 editorial about Dr. Barney Clark's artificial heart missed its mark. It seemed an attempt to intellectualize on a complex issue without the benefit of all the available information.

title: CASINOS FIGHT BID TO BREAK MASTER PLAN
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE Hilton Inns Corporation will consider canceling its plan for a $250 million hotel-casino here if the Golden Nugget wins approval of a proposed zoning change in the city's Master Plan that would clear the way for a second Golden Nugget on a highway approach site.

title: NEW SPOTS FOR GOURMET TAKE-OUT
description: 'TIS the season to be jolly -and if you are in the take-out food business, to be busy as well. Never before have state residents had such a wide range of freshly prepared foods ready to be taken home as are available now. The ''gentrification'' of take-out food shops - featuring gourmet fare above and beyond delicatessen items - began a year or so ago, but in 1982 it accelerated considerably.

title: FOOD FOR THOUGHT ON BANK DEPOSITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Greek E's And T-Bars
description: In regard to the article ''Pen, Paper and Analysis'' (''About Westchester,'' Nov. 28), it would not be surprising if readers were skeptical of ''handwriting analysis'' that is based on such ridiculously simplistic concepts as Margaret Manna teaches. She is a Graphoanalst (a commercially copyrighted trade name), not a graphologist, and Graphoanalysts do not go beyond the elementary examination of single, fixed signs in a writing. (For example, to say that Greek e's are a sign of ''literary ability'' is sheer nonsense. No single indicator, taken out of context of the whole writing, has any meaning at all.)

title: Sticking Up for The Bulgarians
description: True or not, Italian police reports of a ''Bulgarian connection'' to the assassin who shot Pope John Paul II hit a nerve in Moscow last week. In the latest official reaction, Leonid M. Zamyatin, the Kremlin's top information specialist on international affairs, denounced speculation about a trail leading from the attack in St. Peter's Square last year to Sofia's secret police and thence to the K.G.B., the Russian security agency whose leader at the time happened to be Yuri V. Andropov.

title: ROBERTA KANIA ENGAGED TO WILLIAM J. SCHNOOR
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Kania of Cheshire, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Roberta Mathews Kania, to William John Schnoor Jr., son of Eleanor Schnoor of Tenafly, N.J., and the late Mr. Schnoor.

title: FROM HERE TO PERPLEXITY
description: EUGENE J.McCARTHY is a former United States Senator from Minnesota. BY EUGENE J.McCARTHY

title: Hawks 97, Bullets 91
description: Eddie Johnson and Dan Roundfield each scored 27 points to pace Atlanta as the Hawks ended a three-game losing streak and improved their record to 13-14. Washington, which got a season-high 37 points from Greg Ballard, lost its second game in a row and fell to 14-13.

title: HOW A RECORD FED A NEW LIFE
description: Only lately have I become aware that crises and transitions in my life were often alleviated in some way by a phonograph. In the fractures and dislocations of my youth, recorded music - transported, much like myself, from one time and place to another - somehow supplied the link that formed continuity where otherwise there would have been chaos and incoherence.

title: CITY TO OPEN A LAW SCHOOL WITH LOW TUITION
description: New York City's first publicly supported law school, intended to serve economically disadvantaged students, will admit students next fall with tuition fees considerably lower than those in private law schools in New York.

title: NEW YORK TOURISM NEARLY MATCHES 1981 LEVELS
description: A surge of tourists and business visitors in the last three months has enabled New York City to come close to matching last year's figures, according to city tourism officials.

title: A 2d Branch of a Bank Robbed in Connecticut
description: Thieves robbed a Colonial Bank branch early this morning, using a truck to rip a night-depository door out of a wall and escaping with an undetermined amount of cash.

title: A COLLEGE IN SEARCH OF A LEADER AND A PLACE IN THE COMMUNITY
description: When Medgar Evers College opened its doors in September 1971, Dr. Richard D. Trent, the school's first president, declared: ''I think a Yale man looking for a job in New York City will find he'd be better off with a degree from us.''

title: 14 ARTISTS IN SHOW AT THE CASTLE GALLERY
description: NEW ROCHELLE A GROUP show organized by an artist is usually worth investigating and Douglas Craft's ''Selected Women Painters,'' at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle is no exception (through Feb. 18).

title: MUSINGS THE DAY AFTER
description: IEXPECT Christmas to be perfect. I expect snow and a roaring fire a nd a Norman Rockwell tree. I don't expect slush on my floors; a firet oo damp to burn and a tree with all the ornaments crowding the upperb ranches while the lower branches lie barren - the ornaments well a way from baby's curious grasp.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Legislators Pass a Tax to Save the Fare
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's fiscal crisis, a thorn in the side of New York legislators for nearly a month, was removed last week, but it left a scar.

title: No Headline
description: When 60 percent of families with children are two-paycheck families, day care at the work place is no longer a luxury but a necessity.

title: 43 Deny Charges In Cairo Conspiracy Trial
description: Forty-three of the 300 people being tried on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat denounced the charges today as ''sheer lies.''

title: Leo H. Carey
description: IT WAS reported here last October that the state's Department of Environmental Protection had completed a five-year study on the presence of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB's) in edible fish.

title: VARIED RICHES BRING THE ANALOUGE ERA TO A CLOSE
description: This will be a valedictory wrap-up of the best records of the year - a valedictory for the analogue era. By this time next year, we should have a healthy crop of compact digital disks to consider, and we will have to weigh even more than we do now the competing claims of technology and art.

title: THE MODERN CITYSCAPE NOW FINDS ROOM FOR THE PICTURESQUE
description: Michael Graves's Portland Building in Portland, Ore., finished last October, may not be the best building of 1982 - indeed, it is not. But its completion certainly ranks as the most compelling architectural event of the year, for the transformation of this structure from a much talked-about set of drawings into a real and rather powerful work of built architecture represents something much larger than a single building. It reminds us that the movement that has come to be known as Postmodernism has become vastly more than a curiosity; now, at the end of 1982, it is unquestionably something that is having a genuine effect on the cityscape.

title:
DINING OUT;
A CRITIC'S CHOICE FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: THIS year, 175 eating establishments, plain and fancy, opened in the county. This marked increase over the 125 fledglings that open their doors last year has the desirable effect of sparking wide competition between the old establishments and the young Turks, a situation that benefits the diner as older restaurants rethink and improve their style and seductive newcomers offer fresh excitement.

title: WINNERS OF INDIVIDUAL AND TEAM CHAMPIONSHIPS DURING 1982
description: Archery U.S. Champions Men - Rich McKinney, Glendale, Ariz. Women - Luann Ryon, Parker Dam, Calif. Crossbow Men - Ervin Myers, Dallastown, Pa. Women - Carol Pelosi, Greenbelt, Md.

title: Study of Hypothermia Finds Link to Alcohol
description: A 10-year study of victims of hypothermia, or abnormally low body temperature, has found that most people who freeze to death are intoxicated or without proper shelter and many die during the Christmas holidays.

title: Saudi Sheik Charged In Florida Jewel Theft
description: A young sheik accused of stealing a $1.2 million emerald and diamond ring was released today on $25,000 bond. Sheik Allal al-Fassi, related by marriage to the Saudi royal family, was ordered to stay in the area pending a hearing next week.

title: TOXIC CHEMICALS IN DRINKING WATER DISRUPT LIFE IN 2 SUBURBS IN MINNEAPOLIS
description: Each day Harry Werlein comes home from work carrying several large containers of water that he has purchased or obtained from his job in St. Anthony, three miles away.

title: Turkey's Leader Hopes For Gains in Afghanistan
description: President Kenan Evren of Turkey said today that he hoped Afghanistan would be free of foreign domination soon.

title: 'I LOVE YOU STILL,' SAID HERMOINE
description: ANDROMACHE Tragedy in Five Acts, 1667. By Jean Racine. Translated by Richard Wilbur. Illustrated by Igor Tulipanov. 104 pp. New York and San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10.95.

title: Anne M. Johnson Engaged to Wed Joseph Marchetta
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Clay Johnson of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Marie Johnson, to Joseph Francis Marchetta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Marchetta of New Rochelle, N.Y. The wedding is set for July 2.

title: Cheryl L. Hepburn, James Greenhalgh Are to Be Married
description: Mrs. LeRoy J. Hepburn of Ewing Township, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Cheryl Lou Hepburn, to James Dieter @Greenhalgh, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. @Greenhalgh of Baraboo, Wis. A February wedding is planned.

title: E.R. SHIPP
description: Even a system characterized by inaction and delay has a breaking point, and by many accounts the nine-week strike by Legal Aid Society lawyers has pushed New York City's courts and jails perilously close to it. ''We just can't continue to limp along as we've been doing,'' said Joseph B. Williams, the administrative judge in charge of criminal proceedings in the city. ''We've been making do, but there is just so much we can take before grinding to a halt.''

title: THE CONVERSION OF JAPAN
description: THE SAMURAI By Shusaku Endo. Translated by Van C. Gessel. 272 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: ELECTION DAY, A.D. 2000
description: ''Yet the notion of the shadow cast over men's minds at the time (the end of the First Millennium, A.D.) by the supposed immanence of the Day of Wrath is not altogether wrong ... Waves of fear swept almost incessantly over this region or that. ... (But) in spite of everything, an irresistible vitality fermented in men. ...'' - MARC BLOC, Feudal Society

title: ON BEING PART OF A MIXED SOCIETY
description: ''CONTRARY to what's been believed in the area of psychotherapy,'' said Irving M. Levine, ''cultural factors are tremendously important, and cultural differences maintain themselves sometimes into the fourth and fifth generations. Highly assimilated WASP's and Jews are not going to be as alike in behavior patterns and belief systems as has been previously thought.''

title: MUNICH'S BRACE OF THREE-STARS
description: MARIAN BURROS reports on food for The New York Times.

title: Nancy K. Pollok To Wed in March
description: Lewis William Pollok Jr. of Houston has announced the engagement of his daughter, Nancy Knox Pollok, to Dr. Vincent Florence Guinee, son of Kathleen Kelly Guinee, of New York, and the late Dr. Florence Vincent Guinee. A March wedding is planned.

title: WHEN HEATING SYSTEMS CLANK, QUIET CAN SOON BE RESTORED
description: BANGING or hammering noises that occur in a steam or hot-water heating system can be very annoying, yet in many cases the cure for the problem is relatively simple and involves no extensive plumbing work or ripping out of walls and ceilings.As a rule, this problem is encountered more often in homes and apartments that have steam heat than in those that have hot-water heat. In a steam system the problem can be in the radiator or in the pipe leading to that radiator.

title: ARGENTINA AFTER THE FALKLANDS
description: He was a major in the Argentine army, and he was sitting bare chested and angry on the beach at the resort town of Mar del Plata. He and his military colleagues, he complained, were being accused abroad of being torturers and assassins, and accused at home of being bunglers.

title: IN HOLIDAY SWIRL, ISLANDS OF CALM
description: GREENWICH HAD he been wearing a red coat and cotton whiskers, Patrolman Robert P. Grosso of the Greenwich police would have been clad for the season. He certainly had the bulk one would want of Santa Claus.

title: ARMED CONFLICT THREATENS TO SPREAD IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: It was a page out of a contemporary doomsday book - bombs set by ''terrorists'' going off inside a nuclear power station. If it had happened six months later, the danger of a disastrous leak of radioactive gases on the outskirts of a major metropolitan area would have been more than slight.

title: 'CHARLEY'S AUNT'--90 AND FULL OF PEP
description: HERRICKS THERE'S plenty of life in the nonagenarian ''Charley's Aunt.'' Clinton J. Atkinson's production at the Nassau Repertory Theater through Jan. 2 has the energy and style to prove it.

title: THE PUPPETS GOT BIGGER AND BIGGER
description: DID you ever put on puppet shows in your parents' garage when you were a child? Larry Engler couldn't take no for an answer. To Mr. Engler, creator of the Poko Puppets, which will be playing at the Westbury Music Fair tomorrow through Thursday, everyone's a puppeteer at heart and anyone can have the world on a string.

title: WHERE THE AMATEUR SINGER IS KING
description: Matt Anders, a 17-year-old tenor from Baltimore, journeyed 388 miles to sing ''Messiah'' at Avery Fisher Hall last week. Fred Jacobson, a bass, jogged down Fifth Avenue for ''Messiah'' at the Church of the Heavenly Rest. And a soprano from Philadelphia, Shellie Camo, sloshed through icy snow to sing ''Judas Maccabaeus'' at the 92d Street Y. Altogether, thousands of New York's amateur singers are now recovering from the many sing-alongs during these past weeks of festivities. They are part of a tradition of community singing that has long flourished here.

title: MIRIAM DAVID IS ENGAGED TO KENNETH ROGER GRAY
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Arthur David of Woodmere and Cutchogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miriam David, to Kenneth Roger Gray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Gray of Spring Valley, N.Y., and Ocala, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
NOW PICTURE THIS: THE HONORS AND DISHONORS OF '82
description: AT the conclusion of another fantastic year in sports, it's time once again to salute the many distinguished achiev... What's that? It wasn't fantastic? Well, maybe not, but it was still a pretty good year in sports and so once again ... Huh? O.K., so it wasn't so hot. So it was depressing. Hey, they can't all be classics. Still, there were vivid, memorable moments and we now salute them. On to the highlights! Let's go to the video tape!

title: BIRDS? SO WHO'S COMING?
description: MONTAUK THE wind was not cooperating. Blowing in from the northeast at over 15 knots, it kept the birds down, snug in the protective underbrush, away from the probing eyes of ''birders'' who, binoculars at the ready, were anxious to spy them. Not to hurt them, of course; merely to record them.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW VARIETIES ADD SPICE FOR CENT COLLECTORS
description: The United States Mint has apparently given collectors at least seven different kinds of 1982 Lincoln cents. Specialists have discovered that the '82 cents come with both ''large'' and ''small'' dates, and since they also come in two kinds of metals and two different mintmark varieties, the result could be a bonanza for numismatic scavenger hunters.

title: THE MYSTERY AT THE BOTTOM OF THE SOUND
description: WHEN I was 12 years old, a mystery occurred at sea that took the lives of nine men. At the time I was too busy doing other things to notice the stories the papers carried about the progress local authorities and the Coast Guard officials were making to find an answer to this puzzle.

title: Change of Clothes
description: To the Business Editor: The best news I read this week in ''What's New in Newspaper Publishing'' (Dec.12) was that there may soon be an ink that would dry quickly on newsprint and not rub off on readers. Then maybe I'll be able to stop wearing all black clothes every Sunday. Please excuse the smudges on this stationery. AGNES H. WEIS

title: PRIMARY NURSES BRING BACK ONE-ON-ONE CARE By Natalie Davis Springarn
description: Natalie Davis Spingarn is the author of the recently published ''Hanging in There; Living Well on Borrowed Time.'' By Natalie Davis Spingarn osephine Cordischi proudly displays the chart she was given during her previous stay at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston: down the left side, a long list of medicines, along with the dosage and time she was to take them; down the right side, check marks showing that the directions had been followed.

title: GOOD TIMES COMING
description: MEGATRENDS Ten New Directions Transforming Our Lives. By John Naisbitt. 290 pp. New York: Warner Books. $15.50.

title: HITLER ONSTAGE
description: John Cullum will play the title role of Adolph Hitler in ''The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H.'' opening New Year's Eve at the Hartford Stage Company, 50 Church Street.

title: A YEAR OF THE JOYOUS FIRSTS AND LONELY LASTS
description: I N 1982, much of what happened in sports represented either the fascination of the first time, or the loneliness of the last time. The National Football League endured its first strike as well as a jury's antitrust decision that allowed one of its teams, the Raiders, now of Los Angeles and formerly of Oakland, to move for the first time without league approval.

title: NOT EXACTLY ART FOR ART'S SAKE
description: HUNDREDS of years ago, artists used living personalities as models for religious pictures and nobody raised an eyebrow. It's different today, at least in Ize, France, where a stained-glass church window has won considerable nonreligious attention.

title: 'HANDS-ON' LORE
description: Not everyone cares about the evolution of molding styles, or the techniques needed to restore an 18th century window sash, but those who are passionate about such things can get all the details at a workshop that will take place Jan. 7, 8 and 9 on the campus of the University of Bridgeport in Connecticut.

title: APARTHEID CREATES RIDDLES IN BLACK EDUCATION
description: In 1959, South Africa's all-white Parliament enacted a law called the Extension of University Education Act. It was the keystone of its efforts to create a self-enclosed system of ''Bantu education'' that would fit the vision of a racially compartmentalized society by educating blacks for futures in their own separate homelands.

title: Austrian Ski Slope
description: To the Editor: The article ''In Austria, the Definitive Downhill'' (Travel, Nov. 7) was accompanied by a picture identified as the Hahnenkamm course in Kitzbuhel, Austria, but it was not the Hahnenkamm course.

title: A WEEK'S EVENTS FOR CHILDREN
description: NOW that the presents are distributed, the feast consumed, the relatives gone and at least one toy broken, the children's weeklong vacation looms ahead. Fortunately, Connecticut has much to offer young people in the way of entertainment, much of it enjoyable for adults as well.

title: AN OLYMPIC ISSUE
description: Ten years after the Austrian skier Karl Schranz was banned from the 1972 Winter Olympics because of his professional activities, a major push is under way within the International Olympic Committee to revise eligibility guidelines.

title: Paula Alduino to Marry John Sutherland Next Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Alduino of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paula Marie Alduino, to John Arthur Sutherland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sutherland of Winchester, Mass.

title: EX-HEAD OF BANTAM TAKES ON NEW JOB
description: OSCAR DYSTEL of Rye, who retired in 1980 as chairman of the board of Bantam Books, has embarked on a new venture in publishing. With two partners, he recently formed a consulting company to advise book and magazine publishing companies.

title: RICH 'DESERT SONG' RESOUNDS IN DARIEN
description: time operetta house. With ''The Desert Song,'' it is operating on all cylinders.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THIS was Maria Ritacco's first Christmas at the Neuberger. She has worked there since September last year, but last Christmas she went home to Italy for the holidays. So this season was her first for celebrating with friends made on the job at the museum at the Purchase campus of the State University of New York.

title: JEts for Sale
description: The Boeing Company would like to sell $600 million worth of its big jets to Libya, a spokesman disclosed last week. The trouble is the 1979 Export Control Act severely restricts such sales to countries ''supporting international terrorism,'' and Congress has blocked them in the past.

title: Dinner for 2,000 Draws 300
description: Officials of the Mississippi Coast Coliseum cooked enough turkey and trimmings to feed 2,000 poor people on Christmas, but only about 300 showed up.

title: Trojan Horse
description: To the Business Editor: ''Matsushita: the Cautious Giant'' (Dec.5) was of special interest to me. In the article it was stated: ''The company began its entry to the American consumer market by selling high-quality transistor radios through R.H. Macy & Company in New York.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 42 of today's Times misidentifies the South Street Seaport Museum official study- ing ship blueprints. He is Norman Brouwer, the museum's curator and historian.

title:
DINING OUT;
A TOUCH OF THE ORIENT IN MADISON
description: IN A suave and simple modern setting just off Madison's Main Street, Darwin and Yen Chang operate an appealing new Chinese restaurant. What had started as a take-out place was expanded a couple of months ago into two pleasant dining rooms seating a total of 75 people.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A GIFT FOR THE GIVER, TOO
description: IN THE 12 years that I have been a volunteer fireman, I have responded to hundreds of alarms. On many, only our will and determination overcame the flames. We have seen the destruction of property and the far sadder, far more tragic destruction of lives.

title: Iowa Savings and Loan Explodes, Killing Two
description: An explosion at the First Federal Savings and Loan Association late Friday afternoon killed two people and injured six others.

title: MUSIC: VOCAL ARTS ENSEMBLE
description: Effective programming and performance of traditional Christmas music - the smaller things, not Handel's ''Messiah'' or Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio'' - calls for a special set of talents that can easily elude some of the best musicians. Particular sensitivity to literary texts, musical textures and styles and expressive nuance, and even to performance locale and ambience, is demanded in addition to the musicianship and skills required by compositions of all kinds.

title: LAWRENCE MCNAMEE JR. FIANCE OF MICHELLE SMITH
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. Smith Jr. of Highlands, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sgt. Michelle Elaine Smith, to Sgt. Lawrence E. McNamee Jr., both of the Marine Corps.

title: BUYING WITHOUT SURPRISES
description: THERE is a 60-unit cooperative on Park Avenue that last year assessed its shareholders an average of $14,000 each so it could pay off its mortgage. Less than 15 blocks a way is a 300-unit co-op where owners carry average shares of $67,500 in the mortgage.

title: JOSE M. FERRER JR., PHYSICIAN, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Jose M. Ferrer Jr., professor emeritus of surgery at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Friday of complications after abdominal surgery at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Dr. Ferrer, who had homes in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I., was 70 years old.

title: PHILADELPHIA FACES ANOTHER TRANSIT SHUTDOWN
description: Nearly 50,000 commuters in this city are preparing for their second transit shutdown in less than two years. The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority plans to eliminate all service on 13 commuter rail lines for an indefinite period even though employees who run the trains have agreed to continue working after their contracts expire nexct Friday.

title: Air Controllers' Training Duties A Safety Worry
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has been working furiously to train replacements for the more than 11,000 air traffic controllers dismissed when they went on strike last year. Perhaps too furiously, the National Safety Board fears.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: THEATER Sam Shikaze is a hardboiled but sentimental private eye, Sam Spade with a Japanese-American twist, the scourge of criminals operating along Vancouver's Powell Street. Sam, dashingly portrayed by Donald Li, is the hero of ''Yellow Fever,'' by Canada's R.A. Shiomi, a new play that works both as parody and adventure.

title: Fire at Apartments Kills One
description: Fire raged through the Peppertree Apartments on Christmas Eve, killing one person, injuring at least five and destroying 30 to 40 apartments. Delmer Tolson, 64 years old, died in the blaze on the city's northeast side, and Elsie Abdo, 49, was in critical condition. Officials said the cause and amount of damage had not been determined.

title: A TORPID 'HOLIDAY'
description: NEW HAVEN

title: MANY TAX BREAKS ARE AVAILABLE
description: TO encourage the use of solar power, the Federal Government will pay 40 percent of a homeowner's investment i n a solar hot-water system up to $10,000 in the form of a credit up t o $4,000 on the following year's tax return.

title: REVIVAL PLANS FOR APOLLO THEATER ARE DROPPED
description: Private investors who planned to convert the Apollo Theater in Harlem into a cable television studio say they have abandoned the project because of they could not get state financing.

title: RECESSION IS MANAGING TO CUT TEXAS DOWN TO SIZE
description: ''Texas has held one winning lottery ticket after the other,'' Joe B. Frantz, the eminent Texas historian, said recently. ''When every year your population is bigger than last year, you can believe in growth and it gives the illusion you are smart. Now they are learning the facts of life belatedly. That is sobering.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''On the day of the birth of our Lord, I ardently wish all my brothers and sisters of Poland, particularly those who suffer and those who are separated from their loved ones, a new hope, a new light.'' - Pope John Paul II. (3:4.)

title: Calling Dr. Baden On the Carpet
description: There are clear distinctions in medicine between speculation and fact, but only a thin line separates advice from indiscretion. Dr. Michael M. Baden has been accused of crossing it.

title: Jamal Dar, Pakistani Official, Is Stricken During a Speech
description: Jamal Dar, Pakistan's Minister for Kashmir and the Northern Areas, had a heart attack while making a speech today and died in an Islamabad hospital, doctors said.

title: American Publishers
description: To the Editor:

title: Anybody Want To Be Mayor?
description: Union City Mayor Robert C. Botti, who set out in the footsteps of former Mayor William V. Musto in August, has followed them all the way to the jailhouse door. Mr. Botti, who took office after Mr. Musto's sentencing on Federal racketeering charges, was himself convicted of conspiracy, mail fraud and income tax evasion last week in Federal court in Newark.

title: POLLY RUTHERFORD PLANS WEDDING IN MAY
description: Dr. and James Woodson Rutherford of New Canaan, Conn., and Annisquam, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Polly Wanton Rutherford, to Dr. Stephen Bruce Dowton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Dowton of Dubbo, New South Wales, Australia.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: MASS MARKET

title: HERE LIETH A BIT OF L.I. HISTORY
description: HUNTINGTON FOR more than 250 years, gravestones in the Old Burial Grounds in Huntington have been battered by the elements, the British, vandals and unskilled gravestone robbers.

title: Brady to Resign Early As Senator From Jersey
description: United States Senator Nicholas F. Brady of New Jersey will resign tomorrow to give Senator-elect Frank Lautenberg a head start of about two weeks in establishing himself and his staff in Washington, a spokesman for Governor Kean said yesterday.

title: DANCE: 'VOID,' OTHER DANCES BY SANASARDO
description: Anyone who titles a dance ''The Abiding Void'' must certainly be serious. Paul Sanasardo titled a dance just that and he has long been one of our most serious choreographers. How peculiarly serious his choreography can be was evident on Monday night at the New York University Theater when the Paul Sanasardo Dance Company presented four works that he choreographed during the last two decades.

title: PRISON EMPLOYEE KILLED IN VIRGINIA
description: A prison employee was stabbed to death and an inmate was injured when rival gangs of prisoners clashed at a Christmas breakfast at the Federal Correctional Institution here.

title: Suzanne Groves to Wed Joshua B. Littlefield in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Freeman Groves of Southborough, Mass., formerly of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Groves, to Joshua Bayley Littlefield, son of Mrs. W. Joseph Littlefield of Miami and the late Mr. Littlefield. A July wedding is planned.

title: Maureen A. Kelly Affianced
description: The engagement of Maureen Andrea Kelly to Donald Herbert Mac Neal, son of Herbert P. Mac Neal of Glen Rock, N.J., and the late Vera A. Mac Neal, has been announced by Miss Kelly's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Kelly of Cranford, N.J. A September wedding is planned. Miss Kelly, an alumna of Seton Hall University, is an assistant vice president of the First Jersey National Corporation in Jersey City. Her fiance, a graduate of Georgetown University, is an audit manager with Arthur Anderson & Company in New York.

title: NEW WAYS TO CURB CHILD ABUSE
description: Second of two articles.TRENTON WHEN to treat child abuse as a social problem and when as a criminal one is ''probably the most difficult part of the decisionmaking process,'' says George J. Albanese, Commissioner of the state's Department of Human Services. ''I think there has to be a checks-and-balances system.''

title: A Question on Conversion
description: Question: We want to convert our two-family house into a condominium. Where can we obtain material that will tell us how to go about it? .... M.H., Highland Park, N.J. Answer: First, you need a copy of the Planned Real Estate Development Full Disclosure Act regulations. Then you probably will want to be exempted from those regulations. For an exemption, apply to the Department of Community Affairs, Division of Housing. If you do not get an exemption you would have to file an application and a public offering statement. A public offering statement, usually prepared by a lawyer, includes a description of property, engineer's survey, energy audit and details of the purchase. To obtain an exemption, you have to submit legal proof of the size of the development. According to James Cannon, a principal field representative for the department, adequate proof would be a copy of the master deed or site plan approvals.

title: Barbara Ann Martin Engaged to Nicolas Flagello
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Martin of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Martin, to Nicolas Flagello of White Plains, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dionysis Flagello of Salerno, Italy. A Feb. 12 wedding is planned.

title: SOME END-OF-THE-YEAR AWARDS
description: THE end of the year is award-giving time in the entertainment industry, and the serious culinary scene in Connecticut is most certainly part of this industry. Therefore, it seems appropriate to award a few culinary carrots or escarole epaulets of our own. Herewith an edible Oscar in the likeness of Auguste Escoffier:

title: WHY KODAK WENT FOR THE DISK
description: IN one out of 13 American homes yesterday, someone pulled the ribbon from a package, tore off the wrapping paper and discovered Kodak's newest innovation in a decade - the disk camera. The shirt-pocketsized camera incorporates all the wizardry of electronics, optics and chemistry and all the business acumen of George Eastman, the company's late founder.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1982
description: International The Soviet gross national product has grown at an annual rate of 4.8 percent over the last three decades, according to an analysis prepared by the Central Intelligence Agency for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. However, the study found that in recent years the rise has dropped to less than 3 percent a year because of poor harvests. The committee's chairman, Representative Henry S. Reuss, said the study indicated that the Soviet Union was ''far from being on the verge of collapse.'' (Page 1, Col. 4.) After a summer of carnage, West Beirut is assuming a normalcy that is as chimerical as it is cherished. As Christmas was celebrated, Beirut International Airport, once a batteground, was back to normal, and Hamra Street, once deserted, was crowded with shoppers again. (1:2-3.)

title: Another Crisis In Portugal
description: Fourteen governments have run aground, pursuing the bright promises of Portugal's 1974 revolution. Last week, a 15th was sought after the resignation of Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao's conservative coalition.

title: HOPE SPRINGS ETERNAL EVERY CHRISTMAS TIME
description: IEXPECTED Christmas to be perfect. I expected snow and a roaring fire and a Norman Rockwell tree. I didn't expect slush on my floors; a fire too damp to burn and a tree with all the ornaments crowding the upper branches while the lower branches lie barren - the ornaments well away from baby's curious grasp.

title: Icy Aftermath
description: The players' strike may have left an indelible mark on the 1982 National Football League season, but the New England snowplow incident may turn out to be even more widely debated and disputed. Nearly two weeks after the incident, which produced a 3-0 victory for New England over Miami, two veteran N.F.L. coaches are involved in a long-distance dispute over the issue.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: CHARMED CIRCLE: Gertrude Stein & Company. By James R. Mellow. (Avon/Discus, $4.95.) James R. Mellow's meticulous and loving reconstruction of the illustrious circle that revolved around Gertrude Stein and functioned as a ministry of propaganda for Cubism in the early years of this century is ''the biography of a milieu,'' Herbert Leibowitz said in his review. Mr. Mellow re-creates the texture of Gertrude Stein's life and of the durable, productive relationship between her and Alice B. Toklas. Miss Toklas's letters written in the 20 years after Miss Stein's death in 1946 have been collected in STAYING ON ALONE: Letters of Alice B. Toklas, edited by Edward Burns (Liveright/ Norton, $8.95). A splendid volume, ''Staying on Alone'' reveals Miss Stein's companion of 40 years as a woman also remarkable on her own.

title: BEENS: FOR THE WINTER, FOR LUCK IN THE NEW YEAR
description: BEANS are a sustaining, comforting food, particularly during winter months. So it is hardly surprising that in many countries bean soups, stewed beans with pig's feet and ham, are a popular dish on New Year's Eve or New Year's Day.

title: A Cordial Do-It-Yourself Project
description: Recently, we were asked if we could duplicate at home an imported, sweet and aromatic cordial that has become quite popular in the United States. Its flavors, basically, are vanilla and anise.

title: Mardi Gras In Style
description: For those who like to travel in style, there's the prospect of rolling down South to New Orleans and Mardi Gras in February in the two oldest privately owned rail cars in the country - LV 353, built in 1916 for the president of the Lehigh Valley line, and Clover Colony, built in 1923 by the Pullman Company.

title: MUSIC: AFTER THE APCOLYPSE
description: What will music be like after the apocalypse? is the question Jim Theobald posed Monday night at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation. The answer, judging from ''Music of the Future,'' played in his program of ''Music for Live and Preserved People,'' is that it would be very similar to the music of the avant-garde of the 1960's.

title: Praised Flight Attendant Was Not One at All
description: No one paid much attention to William Cohn until pleased passengers started praising the courteous flight attendant in letters to Pan American World Airways.

title: California Health Inspectors Seek More Poisoned Anacin
description: Health inspectors said today that agents picking through cartons of Maximum Strength Anacin-3 had found no new instances of capsules laced with cyanide.

title:
STAMPS;
FIRST 1983 ISSUE IS A 20-CENT COMMEMORATIVE
