description: The first issue from the United States in 1983 is an attempt to embody the contributions of science and industry to the growth and development of America in a single commemorative.

title: JAZZ AT WILLIAMS CENTER
description: The William Carlos Williams Center for the Arts in Rutherford will present its first jazz program next Sunday. The two-hour concert, which starts at 4 P.M., will feature a quintet playing Gershwin, Kern and Ellington standards, as well as some of the peformers' original compositions.

title: Nuggets' Game Set Back by Snow
description: The Denver Nuggets announced today that their scheduled home game Sunday night against the Golden State Warriors has been rescheduled for Monday night because of travel complications arising from a snowstorm.

title: Laurie Silbergeld Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Silbergeld of Great Neck, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Silbergeld, to Jay Berkman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Berkman of Manhasset, L.I. A spring wedding is planned. The future bride is an employment interviewer at Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center. Her fiance is an options trader with Marcus Schloss & Company.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: JAZZ When Erroll Garner was growing up in the 1930's, he was fascinated by film scores - the lush breadth and sweep of ''Gone With the Wind,'' the entrancingly melodic rhythms to which Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers danced. He used the drama, the rhythms and the color that he acquired from this background as basic elements of the style that he developed and which made him a strikingly distinctive jazz pianist.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY HAS BECOME PART OF THE PRACTICE OF ART
description: Although fraught with disappointments, including the closing of three major New York photography galleries (add Robert Samuel Gallery to the list that already includes Photograph and Light), the year 1982 was not without bright spots for photography. What the medium needed to distract itself from its economic doldrums was a fresh infusion of talent and energy; it got one from the art world, and we all should feel better for it. Throughout its history, of course, photography has drawn from the styles and ideas of painting, so in one sense this art-world influence is nothing new. (Even while purportedly adhering to its own ''inherent'' qualities under the dictates of Modernism, the photography of this century has been influenced by Cubist, Constructivist, Surrealist and even Abstract Expressionist styles.) Artistic trends continue to affect photography, but today the influence clearly goes both ways, with the art world taking as much as it gives. Photography is now an integral part of the practice and discourse of today's art - which may explain why the segregated photography marketplace seems to be withering.

title: BEANS: FOR THE WINTER, FOR LUCK IN THE NEW YEAR
description: BEANS are a sustaining, comforting food, particularly during winter months. So it is hardly surprising that in many countries bean soups, stewed beans with pig's feet and ham, are a popular dish on New Year's Eve or New Year's Day.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: As technicians monitoring the body economic huddled over the vital signs last week, Dr. Reagan, ever hopeful, prescribed a simple remedy. If every American business would just hire one new worker, the unemployment rate, now at a 42-year high of 10.8 percent, would meliorate.

title: NEW P.D.Q. BACH FINDS TO BE PLAYED
description: THIS time, the perpetrator was caught preparing his dreaded act. In a West Side rehearsal room the other day, Prof. Peter Schickele stumbled, butting James Billings of the New York City Opera, who railed at him in song. Though discovered, Mr. Schickele showed no remorse or weakening in his annual purpose. Each year during the holiday season, inexorable as the tides that wash him in, Mr. Schickele slips into Manhattan and across the stage of Carnegie Hall, clutching compositions by P.D.Q. Bach, ''the last and least'' of Bach's 20-odd children.

title: LAWRENCE W. HAGER Sr.
description: Lawrence W. Hager Sr., a publisher and broadcasting executive, died Christmas Day after a brief illness. He was 92 years old.

title: UNLOAD POISONS AT THE 'FRONT END'
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Marketing Premium Products
description: WHO knows how many of you went through the weekend with fingers chocolate-sticky thanks to an ad that ran earlier this month on two pages in The New York Times, as well as in the posh pages of The New Yorker, Town and Country and Gourmet.

title: Chicago Mayor Orders Removal of Iron Gates
description: An ''iron curtain'' dividing a mostly white neighborhood from a black community on Chicago's South Side has been torn down at the order of Mayor Jane M. Byrne. Similar gates in the city are scheduled for removal Monday, an aide said.

title: No Significant Issues Slated
description: Investment bankers have not scheduled any significant new bond offerings in the corporate or tax-exempt markets this week.

title: Burlington's Bid
description: Burlington Northern Inc., whose takeover bid for the El Paso Company was delayed by a Texas State Court restraining order last Thursday, said yesterday that the order was dissolved by a Federal judge in El Paso on Friday.

title: HOW THE SUGAR BOWL GOT SO GOOD
description: NEW ORLEANS MICKEY HOLMES had made up his mind not to attend the Georgia-Georgia Tech game. There was no sense sitting in the Georgia press box in Athens, the executive director of the Sugar Bowl said, pretending to be calm and collected when everyone around him would know just how nervous he would become should Georgia encounter any difficulty.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GOING, GOING

title: N. Dakota Loses
description: A veteran Czechoslovak team defeated the University of North Dakota, 7-4, in the first match of the round-robin Spengler Cup hockey tournament today. North Dakota, last year's national collegiate champion, scored the first goal, then rallied from a 2-1 deficit to take a 3-2 lead before the Czechoslovaks regained control.

title: HOMOSEXUAL ADOPTING A SON
description: A judge has granted a 29-year-old homosexual permission to adopt his teen-age foster son. ''Oh, God, I'm happy,'' David Frater said in a telephone interview Tuesday following the hearing that gave him adoption rights to Kevin Frater, 17 years old. ''This is the greatest Christmas present ever.''

title: A CLUTTER IN SPACE MIGHT STOP ICBM'S
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A punter on his 5-yard line, in a National Football League game, accidentally kicks the ball backward and through his own end zone. Is it a safety or a touchdown?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have gone through the valley of death four times and now my posture toward politics has changed somewhat.

title: John Paul Itta Sends Its Impossible Invitation
description: The Christmas cards from the John Paul Itta agency reflect the fact that Mr. Itta, the president, is a creative man. It is a card that one looks forward to getting each year, knowing that it will be still another invitation to an impossible dream.

title: PILOT AND CO-PILOT DIE IN A CRASH IN IOWA FOG
description: Two people died in the Christmas Eve crash of a twin-engine American Central Airlines plane that tried to land at the municipal airport in dense fog.

title: No Contaminants Found In Capsules in California
description: No contaminants were found in any Maximum Strength Anacin-3 capsules tested today by health inspectors checking bottles from the same lot as two that contained cyanide, the officials said.

title: BOND OUTLOOK AND U.S. POLICY
description: The past 30 years have been perilous times for investors in the bond market, as shown by the composite price of outstanding issues, which are worth roughly 70 cents on the dollar. Even though bond prices have risen more than 25 points since midyear and yields on Treasury bonds have fallen from 14 percent to 10 1/2 percent, investors are still worried.

title: U.S. Bows, 6-4, In Junior Hockey
description: Czechoslovakia built a 6-1 lead after two periods and went on to defeat the United States today, 6-4, in the opening round of the world junior hockey championship in Leningrad, the official news agency Tass said today.

title: No Headline
description: 3 FOUND DEAD AS COLORADO DIGS OUT OF SNOWSTORM

title: MET OPERA: 'HANSEL' BACK FOR CHRISTMAS
description: IN the first decade after its composition in 1893, Engelbert Humperdinck's ''Hansel and Gretel'' was conducted by Richard Strauss and Gustav Mahler and staged by Cosima Wagner. Since then the opera's audience has grown as large as its earlier champions were distinguished.

title: Virginia Prison Security Is Tightened After Brawl
description: Security was tightened at the Federal Correctional Institution here today after a brawl between rival gangs of prisoners that left a jail employee dead and a prisoner injured.

title: NONCASH GIVING ON RISE TO NEEDY ORGANIZATIONS
description: Fire Chief Basil Haliberda drove up to the Shady Grove Volunteer Fire Department a few miles outside of Birmingham, Ala., at the wheel of a 20-year-old petroleum tank truck donated by Chevron U.S.A., the San Francisco-based oil company.

title: GIANTS BOW IN SEESAW FINISH
description: Aided by some of the strangest plays in their 23 seasons, the Jets bounded into the playoffs today for only the fourth time in their often frustrating history.

title: Nicaragua, Reporting Death Of 5 Rebels, Accuses C.I.A.
description: Nicaraguan security forces have killed five rightist guerrillas who had plastic explosives that the Government said were supplied by the Central Intelligence Agency, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: GREEK COMMUNISTS WELCOME REPATRIATION OFFER FOR EXILES
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's decision to permit the repatriation of 30,000 political refugees who have been living in Eastern Europe since the 1947-49 Greek civil war received a qualified welcome today from Greek Communist refugee groups.

title: Fit to Parent, Fit to Teach
description: In 1872 the principal of a New York City public school set rules for teachers' behavior. If they were men, they could take one evening out for courting -unless they were regular churchgoers, in which case they could take two. They were not to hang around bars and poolhalls, nor could they smoke or get a shave in a public place. If women, they were not to engage in ''unseemly conduct'' (not further defined) and were to resign immediately upon marrying.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Stalking the Lunar Eclipse

title: Bucks 106, Pistons 96
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Marques Johnson scored 30 points and Phil Ford 15, including 13 in the third quarter.

title: Nazi Party to Relocate
description: The American Nazi Party, concluding that Washington area citizens ''are not people looking to join revolutionary organizations,'' is changing its name to the New Order and relocating in the Middle West. Martin Kerr, an organizer of the National Socialist White People's Party, refused Saturday to give the exact place, for what he said were security reasons. Originally called the American Nazi Party, the organization was founded in 1959 by George Lincoln Rockwell.

title: Market Place; Seeking Plays In Productivity
description: or nonexistent - growth in productivity was viewed as an important factor in the American economic malaise of the 1970's. As the United States economy emerges from the current recession, attention is likely to turn once again to ways for business to increase productivity. Some analysts say this could provide good investment opportunities, even in a slow growth economy.

title: DONORS' JOBS INSPIRE GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST
description: Among the contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund this year are those who say their professions have given them a heightened sensitivity to the plight of the city's poor.

title: LAWS SOUGHT BY CITY TO END UNNEEDED AMBULANCE RUNS
description: The Koch administration will seek state legislation next month to give New York City ambulance crews and emergency room physicians authority to refuse emergency ambulance service to people they decide do not need it.

title: KEY FIGURE IN SPIES' EXPOSURE NOW WRITES HIS SIDE OF STORY
description: By his own account, Michael Whitney Straight always wanted to be a kind of political knight-errant. Certainly he had the means to do so: inherited money, a superb education and friends in high places here and abroad.

title: Israeli Papers Curbed On Photos at Funerals
description: The Israeli Press Council announced a ban today on publishing close-up photographs of mourners at funerals. The step was largely a reaction to Israeli television broadcasts that show funerals of military casualties and focus on the grief of the families.

title: Looking Ahead
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini will resume training next week for what he hopes will be a busy 1983 as he attempts to put the fatal bout with Duk Koo Kim behind him. He plans a nontitle fight in February, followed by several defenses of his World Boxing Association lightweight title.

title: ONE GROUP SOUGHT IN THEFTS FROM 3 NIGHT-DEPOSIT BOXES
description: The same gang of thieves may be responsible for three recent Connecticut robberies in which covers of night-@deposit boxes were ripped from the banks' concrete walls, the police said yesterday.

title: OUTDOORS: WATERFOWL HUNTERS USE VARIETY OF DECOYS
description: WHEN today's waterfowl hunter arranges his decoys in front of his blind, he is continuing an ancient tradition that had its beginnings with the most rudimentary approximations of ducks or geese.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Paean for Percolators

title: General American Collateral
description: The General American Oil Company of Texas, which has arranged a $600 million loan to stave off a takeover attempt by the Mesa Petroleum Company, said yesterday that the loan package was to be secured by ''substantially all of the assets of General American.''

title: WORRIES OF FOOD TAMPERING
description: As a result of the seven deaths from cyanide-contaminated Tylenol capsules in September, the nation's largest food manufacturers have become just as concerned about the possibility of tampering as their counterparts in the pharmaceutical industry. Many are so worried that they would not even discuss the problem.

title: Guerrillas in Zimbabwe Reported to Kill 3
description: Guerrillas killed three people in a string of raids on cars, buses and a train, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Swedish Youth Advances in Rolex
description: Kent Carlsson of Sweden, the European 14's champion, gained the third round of his division at the annual Rolex International junior tennis championships today.

title: CANADIENS 4 NORDIQUES 4
description: MONTREAL (UPI)- Real Cloutier scored on a 50-footer with 7:45 left to give Quebec the tie. The Nordiques had a one-player advantage when Cloutier shot from just inside the blue line past the goalie Richard Sevigny. The Canadiens led by 3-1 entering the final period but the Quebec defenseman Normand Rochefort picked up a loose puck in front of the net and lifted a 30-foot slapshot past Sevigny to narrow the Canadiens's lead to 3-2.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1982
description: International Peking told Moscow that the Chinese leadership acknowledges the necessity for compromise by both sides if they are to progress in efforts to reduce tensions. The message took the form of a greeting on the 60th anniversary of the founding of the Soviet Union. (Page A1, Column 4.) Most South Koreans feel betrayed by the United States, Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean dissident politician who arrived in Washington from Seoul last week, said. Mr. Kim said the United States had failed to demand a return to democratic government in South Korea, but he said he was ''very grateful'' that the Americans had welcomed him to this country. (A1:5.)

title: Bridge: Carrot Club System Works Even When It's Implausible
description: One of the minor mysteries of international bridge concerns the derivation of the Carrot Club, a device that has been successfully used in world championships by a group of top Swedish players. One theory connects it to the name of the system's principal inventor, Anders Morath, because Morath happens to sound like the Swedish word for carrot. Another connects it to his hair, which is of a carroty hue.

title: Oilers 4, Flames 4
description: Mark Messier's second goal of the night capped a three-goal scoring spree in a 10-minute span of the third period, enabling Edmonton to gain the tie.

title: BYSTANDER IS KILLED IN DISPUTE BETWEEN PATRONS AT NIGHTCLUB
description: A bystander was killed and another man shot in the arm yesterday by a young woman who began firing a pistol in a midtown Manhattan nightclub, authorities said.

title: JOBLESSNESS TAKES TOLL ON CANADA'S POPULATION
description: Canada, which has always needed a constant flow of settlers to harvest its plentiful resources, is sharply reducing its immigration quotas and radically revising demographic projections in the face of high and, in some cases, chronic unemployment.

title: LEGAL SERVICES' WASTEFUL INVOLVEMENT IN CLASS ACTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAQ REPORTS AIR ATTACKS ON IRAN
description: Iraq said its warplanes carried out 74 bombing missions today in a ''daring coordinated'' attack that destroyed military targets throughout Iran's southern oil province of Khuzistan.

title: News Analysis
description: In refusing to pass a comprehensive immigration bill, Congress made a statement about immigration policy as profound as any that could have been made through legislation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Bastion Falls

title: STROCK CARVES ROLE AS MIAMI RELIEVER
description: MIAMI THERE was a time in his 10-year career with the Miami Dolphins that Don Strock envisioned himself as the team's ''quarterback of the future.'' He was young and ambitious and, like any quarterback entering the National Football League, eager to prove his worth.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: MARYANNE DESMOND WEDS JOHN BARRY
description: Maryanne Trump Desmond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred C. Trump of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday to John Joseph Barry, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James J. Barry of New York. The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: FORGIVING: A KIND OF FREEDOM
description: IN a surprising number of places ranging from dinner parties to t ake-a-check queues, an equally surprising number of people around t own seem to be pondering the ''turn-the-other-cheek'' aspects of them ovie ''Gandhi.'' Maybe it has something to do with the f orgive-andforget feeling that overwhelms everyone as a new year a pproaches. Or perhaps it's a testament to the legacy of the man, andt he film that has brought Gandhi's story before American audiences o nce again.

title: Chief Says Regulations Hurt and Benefit Nalco
description: Worley H. Clark is taking over a company that has lost a big chunk of its business because of one set of Government regulations, but is also expecting increased sales because of another.

title: A FAMILY THAT MAY CHANGE U.S. VIOLIN PLAYING
description: THE Russian way of making music may not dominate American stringplaying style as it once did; but the emigre Markov family is, in its own way, helping to revive the Slavic tradition of big sound and broad Romantic expression.

title: Future Still Uncertain For a Cuban Stowaway
description: Clara Nunez, a 20-year-old Cuban stowaway whose efforts to seek refuge in the United States became a rallying point for Miami's Hispanics community, is struggling to adjust to American life one year after her arrival.

title: NUCLEAR DETERRENCE AS A NEIGHBOR
description: Somewhere on Griffiss Air Force Base near here, in a secret location known only as the ''Category A Area,'' sit five B-52 bombers. On Dec. 16, they became the first in the United States to be equipped with the newest nuclear weapon in the American arsenal, the cruise missile.

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN PRESSES SOVIET ON AFGHAN ACCORD

title: JAPAN DRAFTS 5.1% RISE IN ARMS BUDGET
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and his Cabinet approved a Finance Ministry draft budget during the weekend for the 1983 fiscal year that would increase military spending by 5.1 percent to $11.4 billion, a far smaller rise than the United States had hoped for.

title: Lakers 96, Rockets 94
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Jamaal Wilkes scored 22 points to lead Los Angeles to its fourth straight victory.

title: NEW TESTS AT DEVASTATED TOWN TO DETERMINE IF FLOOD SPREAD DIOXIN
description: Federal and state authorities said today that they planned to send teams of technicians into the devastated St. Louis suburb of Times Beach this week to determine if recent flooding has spread deadly dioxin pollution.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Post-Christmas Rush

title: BRIEFING
description: F.T.C. Chief Gains Ally

title: CIVIL DEFENSE CANNOT AVERT A NUCLEAR DEFEAT
description: T o the Editor: Somewhere in the middle of his Dec. 9 Op-Ed article about ''Bishops and the Bomb,'' Herman Kahn defends the Administration's plans for civil defense by stating that ''studies show (they) could save tens of millions of lives'' in a nuclear attack. He implies that therefore one cannot rationally be against such measures.

title: Forget of France In Tennis Final
description: Top-seeded Guy Forget of France breezed past Spain's Martin Jaite, 6-4, 6-3, and gained the boys' 18 final of the Orange Bowl international junior tennis tournament today at Flamingo Park.

title: Audubon Group Warns Of Solar Energy Danger
description: Solar power and other renewable energy sources present ''environmental risks'' that must be evaluated in any major drive for alternatives to fossil fuels, the Audubon Society says.

title: Bauer Gains Final
description: Chris Johnstone of Australia and Mike Bauer of the United States advanced today to the final of the $75,000 South Australian Open.

title: Payton Goes Past 10,000
description: Walter Payton gained 104 yards today and became the fourth player in National Football League history to surpass 10,000 in rushing for his career, as he paced the Chicago Bears to a 34-26 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

title: 'Dr. King Avenue' Opposed
description: A citizen group has filed a lawsuit in Superior Court in an attempt to prevent the City Council from changing the name of Santa Barbara Avenue to Dr. Martin Luther King Avenue.

title: Kings 120, Jazz 118
description: Free throws by Ray Williams and Kevin Loder in the final six seconds lifted Kansas City.

title: 5,000 Slain in Salvador In '82, Churchman Says
description: About 5,000 people were killed in 1982 in El Salvador's ''unending nightmare'' of political violence, a leading Roman Catholic churchman said today.

title: Stone & Adler In New York
description: Stone & Adler, based in Chicago and one of two direct-marketing subsidaries of Young & Rubicam, plans to open a full-service office in New York around Feb.1. The office space hasn't been picked.

title: 42 Years of the U.S.O.
description: Beginning in 1941, the U.S.O. began providing a missing element in the lives of American service men and women across the country and around the world. The warmth and comfort of a friendly face and a helping hand mean a great deal to lonely soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines serving their country far from family and friends.

title: 2 Jersey Men Are Lost at Sea In Capsizing Off Los Angeles
description: The Coast Guard called off the search today for two New Jersey men who apparently drowned when a 16-foot homemade sailboat capsized 12 miles from the entrance to Los Angeles Harbor on Christmas Day.

title: CAPITALS' STREAK IS ENDED
description: Mark Howe and Brian Propp each scored power-play and shorthanded goals tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Washington Capitals, 6-3, ending the Capitals' 14-game undefeated streak.

title: LEGACY OF WALKER CONTINUES IN BOWLS
description: As Herschel Walker prepared for Georgia's Sugar Bowl meeting with Penn State on New Year's night, a couple of things were clear about the extent of the legacy he could leave to college football.

title: Bengals 24 Seahawks 10
description: CINCINNATI (UPI) - Ken Anderson teamed with David Verser on a 56-yard scoring pass, and Pete Johnson ran for two touchdowns as Cincinnati clinched a playoff berth.

title: G.O.P. MODERATES CALLED VITAL TO COALITION BEHIND REAGAN
description: The Reagan Administration must include traditional moderate Republican ideas to succeed, according to a Brookings Institution magazine, and recent Democratic gains are likely to increase strains within the Reagan coalition.

title: The Euromissile Game
description: Euromissiles, like Eurodollars, are a claim on the United States. Though unable to reach America, these medium-range weapons affect the balance of European power, which America is pledged to preserve, with nuclear war if necessary. That is why the upgraded force of Soviet missiles aimed at Western Europe impelled NATO to propose that they be either negotiated away or matched by comparable American weapons starting late next year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander's Inc. has promoted Brian M. Kurtz to vice president, group controller; Thomas M. Coleman to vice president, financial administration, and David C. Rubin to vice president, division merchandise manager.

title: PRICED OUT OF KEY WEST, NATIVE RESIDENTS SAY
description: The longtime residents known as Key West Conchs say high property taxes and water bills are forcing them to leave the coral island settled by their ancestors.

title: M.T.A. IS PUSHING CONTRACT TALKS TO AVERT A CONRAIL STRIKE SATURDAY
description: With less than a week left before the Metropolitan Transportation Authority takes over Conrail's commuter lines, labor and management were pressing to reach a contract settlement. But they warned that a strike of the lines on Saturday was still possible.

title: PLANNED PARENTHOOD MUST DEAL WITH ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: PHYSICIANS AT HOME: PROBLEMS TO BE HEALED
description: Although society expects that physicians will be model parents because they are trained to care for others, the relationship between doctors and their children is often strained.

title: Christmas 'Very Active' For Heart Patient
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, rested quietly today after a ''very active'' Christmas, complete with carolers and a tree.

title: Packers Romp, Gain Playoffs
description: The Green Bay Packers, their name once a synonym for power and prestige in the National Football League, qualified for the playoffs for the first time in 10 years with a 38-7 victory over the Atlanta Falcons today.

title: DUMBARTON OAKS ACQUIRES RARE ICON
description: Dumbarton Oaks, the country's leading museum of Byzantine art, has purchased a rare 14th-century icon of St. Peter, paying for it by selling one painting by Matisse and another by Picasso.

title: AS SNOW CLOGS DENVER, DAFFODILS STIR ON L.I.
description: Atop New England's Mount Washington the snow melted. In New York's Gramercy Park, a mosquito was sighted and swatted. In Northport, L.I., daffodil shoots poked up from beneath the soil.

title: BUCCANEERS RALLY TO BEAT LIONS, 23-21
description: The winning points scored by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in their 23-21 victory over the Detroit Lions yesterday came on a 27-yard field goal by Bill Capece with 25 seconds left in the game at Tampa.

title: JERSEY LAWMAKERS TO MEET ON DEFICIT
description: New Jersey legislators, ordered by Governor Kean to convene in a special session, will arrive in Trenton today to try to resolve their differences over a tax plan to close a $150 million state deficit.

title: RANGERS DEFEATED BY PENGUINS, 4 TO 3
description: Both teams played erratically, and the referee called penalties erratically. So it shouldn't have been surprising that the game followed a chaotic pattern.

title: Astronaut Injured in Alps
description: James Lovell, the United States astronaut, fractured his upper arm and shoulder while skiing and is being flown back to the United States for medical treatment, the Austrian Press Agency reported today.

title: SINDONA, IN U.S. PRISON, STAYS ENMESHED IN GLOBAL INQUIRIES
description: Two years after he began serving a Federal prison term for bank fraud, Michele Sindona is enmeshed in international investigations involving multimillion-dollar financial swindles, a mysterious right-wing political organization, murder and the underworld.

title: PHYSICIANS IN FIELD CITE RARE OCCASIONS FOR PRENATAL SURGERY
description: Surgery on fetuses should be tried only if treatment cannot wait until after birth and there is a reasonable chance of success, a group of specialists has recommended.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1982; The Economy
description: ''Selective'' tax increases are being weighed by Treasury Secretary Regan as projected budget deficits soar, an Administration official said. A source close to Mr. Regan said the Secretary is now skeptical about the Administration's ability to make further cuts in nonmilitary spending. (Page A1.)

title: 235 in Egypt Plead Not Guilty to Sedition
description: A State Security Court heard 235 Moslem extremists plead not guilty to sedition charges today during a sixhour hearing.

title: Books Of The Times
description: ZANY AFTERNOONS. And Other Glimpses of the Golden Age of Play. By Bruce McCall. 125 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. Hard cover, $25; paperback, $14.95.

title: BYSTANDER SHOT DEAD IN NIGHTCLUB DISPUTE
description: A bystander was killed and another man shot in the arm yesterday by a young woman who began firing a pistol in a midtown Manhattan nightclub, authorities said.

title: PEKING, IN MESSAGE TO MOSCOW, URGES EACH SIDE TO BEND
description: The Chinese leadership has sent a message to the Kremlin indicating that Peking acknowledges the necessity for compromise by both sides if they are to make progress in their effort to reduce tensions.

title: Leaders Optimistic About Flxible Bus
description: Cruse W. Moss and Mark J. Obert think they can do something that the Grumman Corporation could not -make money building and selling the Flxible bus.

title: FOR THE BUSY WOMAN, A SALON THAT'S OPEN AT DAWN
description: It's an hour when a lot of people are rolling over, upsetting everything on the bedside table as they reach out to still the alarm. Soon, bleary eyes will open, toothbrushes will be smeared with paste and life will become bearable. It is 7:15 A.M.

title: Washington Watch; Reagan's Plan For Exports
description: WASHINGTON SOME gifts to exporters may be packaged in the State of the Union message next month. They would help President Reagan make the case that the solution to worsening trade problems is to export more, rather than to import less.

title: HELENE MOTHE IS MARRIED
description: Helene Mothe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Mothe of Perpignan, France, was married in Los Angeles yesterday to Robert Bookman, vice president, worldwide production, of ABC Motion Pictures Inc. Rabbi Edgar F. Magnin performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Bookman. The bride's father is president and general director of Riz Perliz, rice refiners and distributors in Perpignan. Dr. Bookman is an allergist.

title: Pakistani Leader Ends Tour
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq returned home today after a three-week state visit to the United States and Canada that he described as ''very successful.'' General Zia, who reportedly suffered a bout of flu during the trip, said he was fully recovered ''except for a sore throat.''

title: Colombia's Banking Scandals; Top Officials Are Involved
description: This country's financial life and its reputation for conservative money management have been shaken by a series of scandals that have forced the liquidation of one bank, the emergency nationalization of another and the jailing of a state governor and more than a dozen top officials of financial institutions.

title: Clippers 112 Trail Blazers 105
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Bill Walton, in his most impressive outing in more than three years, scored 25 points, pulled down eight rebounds and blocked seven shots to help San Diego snap an eight-game losing streak,

title: Higher Truck Output
description: Truck production in the United States will start the new year with an 11.3 percent increase from the 1982 level, according to an industry report.

title: Steelers Revive To Crush Patriots
description: Terry Bradshaw is all right. The Pittsburgh quarterback, following two ineffective games, passed for 282 yards and two touchdowns yesterday as the Steelers defeated the New England Patriots, 37-14, in Pittsburgh. It was an easy victory for the Steelers, who scored on their first four possessions and were ahead, 20-0, before New England had made a first down.

title: RESEARCHER FAKED DATA AT MT. SINAI MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: A research scientist who spent four years at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine trying to create drugs fabricated data that appeared in scientific journals, a Federal grant proposal and a patent application, according to school officials.

title: PACERS HOLD OFF KNICKS, 87-81
description: A rookie mistake cut short a fourth-quarter rally by the Knicks tonight and the New Yorkers lost to the Indiana Pacers, 87-81.

title: 2 Whales Beach on Cape And One Dies There
description: Two pygmy whales went ashore on a bathing beach on Nantucket Sound and one died, the officials reported today.

title: Commodities; Naysayer At C.F.T.C.  Is Leaving
description: FIGHTING the Federal bureaucracy, especially from within a regulatory agency, requires courage, for success will often be rewarded with a one-way ticket out of Washington.

title: THEATER NUCLEAR POLITICS
description: Can the Reagan Administration manage a political problem that touches the deepest sensitivities of our European allies and divides its own experts? That is the real question posed by Yuri Andropov's offer on intermediate-range nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: Addressee Unknown
description: The first Ranger Alumni Association Christmas card came back undelivered from a Toronto suburb. It was intended for Bob Cunningham, who played for the New York Rangers in the early 1960's.

title: MISSISSIPPI GOVERNOR IS BIG WINNER ON EDUCATION
description: The Mississippi Legislature has adopted a sweeping education package, on the third try, vowing to pay for it with the biggest tax increase in the state's history.

title: DISPUTED CAPITAL LINK IS OPEN, TO SPARSE USE
description: A 10-mile section of Interstate 66 opened last week in Virginia between the Capital Beltway and the Potomac River, accompanied by the controversy that has surrounded the project since it was authorized almost 20 years ago.

title: KIM SAYS MANY IN KOREA SPEAK OF U.S. BETRAYAL
description: Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean political dissident, said today that he believed most South Koreans felt betrayed by the United States. He asserted the United States had failed to demand a return to democratic government in his country.

title: OTHER GOALS FOR DURRANT
description: IF you ask Devin Durrant about the biggest thrills in his first 22 years of life, he will not begin by talking about his high-scoring basketball games for Brigham Young University. Instead, he will talk about the day in a Mormon church in Madrid, when he participated in the baptism of the first family he helped convert.

title: CHINA'S CATHOLICS SEE LIFE THROUGH TINTED PLASTIC
description: A few colored windows cast glowing rainbows across the bare stone floor of the Xujiahui Catholic Cathedral in southwestern Shanghai. The windows look like traditional stained glass, but their panes have been fashioned from plastic by Catholic priests who made plastic umbrella handles during the grim years of the Cultural Revolution.

title: U.S. MOVE DISTURBS JAPANESE
description: What seemed to be a narrowly focused resolution adopted Tuesday by the United States Senate urging President Reagan to deny investment tax credits for the purchase of certain Japanese machine tools is being viewed here as a broadside aimed at Japanese industrial policy, the centerpiece of its successful system of economic management.

title: Command Presence
description: The office staff did a double-take recently when Lou Gorman, the vice president in charge of baseball operations for the Mets, strolled through the team offices at Shea Stadium in the uniform of a Navy captain, complete with seven decorations on his chest. ''A few people even stood at attention and saluted,'' he said last week.

title: 76ERS MOVE TO 22-5 BY DOWNING SPURS
description: Andrew Toney scored 13 of his 23 points in the fourth quarter to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 124-122 National Basketball Association victory over the San Antonio Spurs tonight.

title: WEINBERGER FACES FIRST REAL ATTACKS
description: After two years of relatively minor skirmishing with White House officials and members of Congress, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has run into his first real whiff of grapeshot.

title: North Stars 3, Jets 2
description: Tom McCarthy and Neil Broten set each other up for a goal apiece as Minnesota broke a five-game streak without a victory.

title: TREASURY'S REGAN IS SAID TO CONCEDE NEED FOR TAX RISE
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has begun to argue within the Administration for selective tax increases next year to shrink the huge budget deficits being projected for 1984 and beyond, according to a senior Administration official.

title: New Exchange Curbs Sought
description: Mexican money traders said today that they were swamped with business from United States travelers, but leftist opposition parties called for the Government to reimpose exchange controls to prevent foreign companies from taking advantage of Mexico's economic crisis.

title: NAVY SECRETARY SAID TO KEEP TIES TO COMPANY AIDING ARMS MAKERS
description: Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr., who pledged on joining the Reagan Administration that he would sell his interests in a consulting company that does business with Pentagon contractors, did not sever all his connections with the company, according to public documents.

title: Chinook Pass Wins on Coast
description: Chinook Pass raced to his third record performance today, scoring a 3 1/2-length victory in the $67,050 Palos Verdes Handicap, the traditional opening-day feature of the Santa Anita thoroughbred meeting.

title: No Headline
description: BRUINS GET 4-0 LEAD, DEFEAT DEVILS BY 5-2

title: A New Attack on Hospital Costs
description: The economy is making painful progress against inflation, but the benefit stops at the hospital door. The price of a hospital room increased 13.8 percent this year, nine points more than the cost of living. Struggling with this problem, the Reagan Administration's latest plan would have Washington set in advance the rates at which hospitals are reimbursed by health insurance plans. The purpose is to force inefficient hospitals to live within a budget.

title: MULLIN IS STUDENT OF HIS GAME
description: While Coach Jim Boyle of St. Joseph's, one of the four teams in the E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival that begins tonight at Madison Square Garden, was discussing his starting lineup at a luncheon yesterday, Chris Mullin paid little attention. Instead, Mullin, the high-scoring St. John's guard, was studying the Brigham Young basketball brochure.

title: French Working to Evacuate Flooded Areas East of Paris
description: The Seine River flooded hundreds of acres of land east of Paris today and a network of raised wooden walkways was being built to evacuate residents, French radio broadcasts said.

title: Japan Plans Bond Sales
description: The Japanese Finance Ministry said it would issue the equivalent of about $55.84 billion in bonds in the fiscal year starting April 1, up 27.8 percent from the amount that is projected in the original budget for the current year.

title: HEART ATTACK KILLS A WOMAN DENIED TREATMENT AT HOSPITAL
description: A 67-year-old Brooklyn woman was taken in a private ambulance to Kings Highway Hospital Center on Dec. 16. The woman was turned away by an emergency room nurse, and died soon afterward of a heart attack at Brookdale Hospital and Medical Center.

title: No Headline
description: TALKS ON WITHDRAWAL DUE TOMORROW IN LEBANON

title: Ardan Moving Account
description: Ardan Catalog Showrooms, a Des Moines subsidiary of the Carlson Companies, is moving its account to W.B. Doner & Company in Detroit. The business was previously handled by Swanson, Rollheiser, Holland of Omaha. Ardan, with 78 outlets in 16 states and biggest in California, sells such catalogue merchandise as hardware, electronics, jewelry, housewares and sporting goods.

title: News Analysis
description: When it was established in 1978, the Commission on Judicial Nomination was supposed to remove politics from the process of choosing Court of Appeals judges and lead to true merit selection for New York State's highest court.

title: WHEN '3' MEANT 6
description: JUST when the departing coach's offense had put the Giants ahead, 21-17, with only 67 seconds remaining, the next coach's defense was quickly punctured for a touchdown with only 27 seconds remaining. After one of their most startling comebacks in recent years for Ray Perkins, the Giants yesterday endured one of their most disappointing defeats for Bill Parcells, a 24-21 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals that left them with only a remote chance of qualifying for the Super Bowl XVII playoffs.

title: THE MONEY FUNDS ARE GEARING UP
description: Money market mutual funds are beginning to find ways to compete against the federally insured money market accounts that banks and thrift units began offering this month.

title: MOSLEMS JOIN MORMONS IN UTAH BUILDING BOOM
description: An investment group run by a wealthy Saudi Arabian family announced plans last June to build a $410 million downtown complex here. When completed, it will include twin 40-story office towers, a major hotel and three 25-story condominum buildings.

title: Cheap Seats Wins $56,300 Beaugay
description: Theodore M. Sabarese's 3-year-old filly, Cheap Seats, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr., posted a four-length, front-running victory in the $56,300 Beaugay Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: TV: ASBESTOS TRAGEDY, WHOSE RESPONSIBILITY?
description: WHO is to bear responsibility for the deaths and illnesses that have struck thousands of people who had contact with asbestos over the last several decades? That is the question addressed on an ''ABC News Closeup'' documentary tonight at 8. The answer of the victims is that responsibility rests with the companies that manufactured the useful but sinister product.

title: No Headline
description: Basketball Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620-AM; 7:30 P.M.). College: Pittsburgh at Syracuse, in the Carrier Dome. This is the first Big East Conference game for the undefeated Orangemen. (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.). Houston at Pepperdine (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.) Pace at St. Francis of Brooklyn, 8 P.M. Tournaments: 31st annual E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, opening round, St. Joseph's vs. Wake Forest, 7 P.M.; St. John's vs. Brigham Young, 9 P.M. St. John's is the defending champion, beating Kansas and then Villanova last year, when the Redmen's Chris Mullin was named the tournament's most valuable player. David Russell, the Redman forward, was the M.V.P. in 1979, when St. John's beat Boston College in the final. (Television - MSG Cable, 7 P.M. live and 1 A.M. tape. Radio - WBGG-AM, 1240; 8:55 P.M., and WNYE-FM, 91.5; 10 P.M., tape following Syracuse-Pitt game.) Music City Invitational, at Nashville, opening round, Penn vs. Manhattan, 7 P.M., and Vanderbilt vs. Eastern Kentucky, 9 P.M. Rainbow Classic, at Honolulu, Missouri vs. Arizona State.(Television - ESPN, 11:30 P.M.) Women: Queens College Holiday Tournament, at Fitzgerald Gymnasium, Kissena Boulevard and Long Island Expressway (Exit 24), Flushing, Queens. Montclair State vs. Temple, 1 P.M.; St. John's vs. Virginia Tech, 3 P.M.; North Carolina vs. Northeastern, 7 P.M.; Queens vs.

title: Advertising Slogans
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach has completed for the third time its compilation of advertising slogans for the previous year. Slogans in Print 1981, available through the agency's library for $10, will help answer the question, ''Who said...?'' Who said ''From one beer lover to another'' (Stroh's), ''You're beautiful to me'' (Tab), ''We've brought the computer age home'' (Atari) or, if you're particularly thick, ''Come to think of it, I'll have a Heineken.''?

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; 8 Polish Union Leaders Vow to Fight

title: CARROLL'S CURIOUS KIN
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE FAULTS U.S. ON GULF DUMPING
description: A Federal judge here has ruled that the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers failed to uphold environmental regulations when they permitted the dumping of polluted material at a site off Florida's Gulf coast.

title: THINK-TANKS, POLITICK!
description: One rarely noticed oddity of Washington life is that while trade groups like the National Potato Council and the American Chiropractic Association are allowed by law to use tax-deductible money to lobby Congress, foundations and ''think-tanks'' often aren't. Even stranger is that many of these brainy organizations, whose very object is to improve public policy, don't want to press their case politically. They prefer instead simply to ''contribute to the debate.''

title: Sabres 2, Red Wings 2
description: BUFFALO (AP) - Mike Foligno, a former player for the Red Wings, scored near the 5-minute mark on a perfect setup by Phil Housley to earn Buffalo the tie.

title: MUSIC: 40 SONGS OF CUBA
description: THE music of Cuba has had a worldwide influence on forms of song and dance. Rene Buch who conceived and directed a musical ''collage'' called ''!Habana!'' at the Repertorio Espanol on East 27th Street, points out the influence on Spain, for example, which received 'habaneras' and 'contradanzas' from Cuba; in this century, in the 1920's, the ''rumba'' and such songs as ''El Manisero'' and ''Siboney'' made their way north to become part of United States culture.

title: Eubie Blake Birthday Party
description: In honor of Eubie Blake's 100th birthday, St. Peter's Church, at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street, will hold a 24-hour celebration beginning at midnight Feb. 6. The tribute to the composer will feature a host of musicians, vocalists and dancers, including Billy Taylor, Bobby Short, Dick Hyman, Honi Coles and the Copacetics, Bill Bolcom and Joan Morris, Max Morath, Marianne McPartland, Maurice Hines and Cab Calloway. Mr. Blake, born in Baltimore Feb. 7, 1882, may attend.

title: BANK OF AMERICA OFFICER LEAVES TO BUY COMPANY
description: Lawrence E. Nerheim, an executive vice president of the Bank of America, has quit to buy an investment bank.

title: AWAITING THE SURGE IN MEXICO VACATIONS
description: When Mexico untethered the peso from an official exchange rate of 70 to the dollar in early December, the currency promptly plunged on the free market to 148 to the dollar - cutting the cost of hotels, meals and travel for American travelers to Mexico by more than half.

title: Redskins Top Saints, 27-10
description: Joe Theismann hit Charlie Brown on touchdown pass plays of 57 yards and 58 yards to spark the Washington Redsins to a 27-10 victory over the New Orleans Saints today. The Redskins, who sewed up a playoff berth last week, clinched the home advantage in the playoffs with today's victory.

title: CURRRENT INTEREST RATES
description: TERM RATES Tax-Exempt Bonds* 9.84 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds* 12.38 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: Eagles Stay Alive, Upsetting Cowboys
description: Ron Jaworski broke a club record for touchdown passes today with a game-winning 10-yard completion to Harold Carmichael in the fourth quarter, as the Philadelphia Eagles kept their playoff hopes alive by upsetting the Dallas Cowboys, 24-20.

title: Farfetched Fight
description: It sounds intriguing: a Madison Square Garden boxing match between two of New York's most popular athletes, the roughest, toughest Ranger, Nick Fotiu, and the most emotional Jet, the quarterbackchasing Mark Gastineau.

title: DR. KATHLEEN K. GUINEE
description: Dr. Kathleen K. Guinee, professor emeritus of nursing education at Hunter College, died Saturday of cancer at her Manhattan home. She was 80 years old.

title: ARMS-CONTROL STEPS
description: Since arms control is indispensable to United States security, the nation must get behind a sustained program of negotiations, beginning with the most threatening weapons of all - the strategic arms that can strike all targets both in America and the Soviet Union.

title: 'YOU HAVE NO PROOF'
description: On Nov. 9, the day before Leonid Brezhnev died, Italian Interior Minister Virginio Rognoni received a visit from the C.I.A.'s vice-chief of station in Rome and a staffer from the U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee. The Americans wanted to know about the Bulgarian connection to the shooting of the Pope.

title: Chargers 44, Colts 26
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Dan Fouts threw five touchdown passes, three to the tight end Kellen Winslow and two to the wide receiver Wes Chandler.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Between Two Lands

title: ISLANDERS EDGE WHALERS, 3-2
description: The Islanders may not be out of their sevenweek slump yet, but tonight they played as though it was history. They revived the lost art of checking and moved the puck to beat the Hartford Whalers, 3-2, with a performance that was one of their best in recent weeks.

title: Raiders 27, Broncos 10
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Marcus Allen, the National Football League's leading scorer, caught two touchdown passes from Jim Plunkett as the Raiders improved their record to 7-1. Los Angeles scored 24 points in the second quarter to take a 27-0 halftime lead.

title: Ludvig Traveled Far to Reach Devils
description: While the Devils did some relocating to get from Kansas City to Colorado to New Jersey, Jan Ludvig needed an even more circuitous route to become a Devil. To get to the United States, the Czechoslovak refugee found his way through Yugoslavia, Austria and Canada from his native country before coming to New Jersey to play hockey.

title: THOMAS KEOGH
description: Thomas Keogh, a lawyer specializing in trusts and real estate for more than 55 years, died Saturday at the Courtland Gardens Nursing Home in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Keogh, who had lived in Larchmont, N.Y., was 83 years old.

title: DISAPPOINTING END FOR 'ALL-SAVERS'
description: The meteoric life of the ''all-savers'' certificate, a special one-year, tax-free deposit aimed at helping thrift institutions and the housing industry, is nearing its end in the midst of general disappointment with the results.

title: DAMAGE TO INDIA'S FORECASTS BRINGS TRIBAL RAGE
description: The destruction of forests by commercial interests has led to revolts by tribal people in India, according to a report by an environmental group here.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOME OF THE RAVE

title: TREASURY BONDS UP MODESTLY
description: The Treasury bond market advanced modestly yesterday in the belief that the Federal Reserve will reduce its discount rate soon from the current level of 8.5 percent. This view also caused a modest rally in prices of tax-exempt and corporate bonds.

title: OVERHEATED; Doing Well
description: When, under questioning, other public figures say ''um'' or ''ah,'' President Reagan says ''well.'' It may even be his favorite word.

title: HOUSTON AGENCY BACKS A DOWNTOWN SUBWAY
description: Directors of the Metropolitan Transit Authority voted unanimously today to build an 18.2-mile rapid rail system that will include a section of subway downtown rather than an elevated track.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including a pretax gain of $1,291,000 for the latest qr and 6 mos from the sale of an inn in Denton, Texas; shr earnings and shrs outstdng have been adjustedfor a 4-for-3 stock split deistributed in Feb 1982

title: No Headline
description: UNBEATEN SYRACUSE DEFEATS PITTSBURGH

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Rangers have sent Dave Silk, a right wing, to their Tulsa farm club for the second time this season. Silk began the season with the Rangers before he was returned to the Central Hockey League team. He rejoined the Rangers earlier this month when the team was hit by injuries. ... Jimmy Connors has earned the No.1 ranking of Tennis magazine, with Ivan Lendl second and John McEnroe, who had been ranked first last year, third.

title: Fetal Movement and Health
description: Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania have shown that observations as simple as a mother's perception of fetal movement can be an indicator of fetal health.

title: NAVY SECRETARY DENIES CONFLICT EXISTS IN BUSINESS TIES
description: Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. said today that his current relationship with the Abington Corporation, the consulting company he operated before he joined the Government, did not constitute a conflict of interest.

title: SCHOOLS' IMPROVEMENT GOES UNREWARDED
description: THE indicators of the public schools' academic achievement have risen dramatically in 1982, but the public still thinks the public schools are failing. The year about to end may well have been the schools' most successful in several decades, but at the same time, they face severe cutbacks in financial support from all sources - local, state and Federal.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MORE CONGESTION SEEN IN THE CITY FROM BIGGER RIGS
description: New York City traffic officials said yesterday that they were concerned about the effects of new Federal regulations permitting double trailer trucks more than 75 feet long on many of the city's crowded streets, but that they would comply with the law.

title: STETSON, JOHN B, CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Reflects equity in loss of $280,209 from Wilshire Corp...C-Including equity in income and prior yrs interest of $562,284 from Wilshire Corp

title: DMG Debt Load
description: DMG Inc. said it continued ''to be unsuccessful'' in efforts to renegotiate or extend its $41.6 million debt to Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, which is due this Friday. DMG, based in West Palm Beach, Fla., develops and sells real estate acquired through foreclosure. DMG said that if it could not pay the debt, it might be forced to sell certain assets under unfavorable conditions or seek legal alternatives to protect its interests.

title: People
description: * Alice Platt, Walter Weis and Mary Ellen Harris have been elected senior vice presidents at SSC& B Inc.

title: Review Asked On Oil Tax
description: The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today to review a ruling by a Wyoming judge that overturned the ''windfall'' oil profits tax, which has brought the Government $26 billion in revenues in two years.

title: Plot to Seize Haiti Reported
description: The Dominican Republic has foiled a plot to overthrow President Jean-Claude Duvalier of Haiti, police sources said today. They said the plot leader was arrested Thursday when he arrived from Miami with 12 submachine guns, 11 pistols and five rifles. The man, Hilertaut Dominique, admitted planning to smuggle the arms across the border to Haiti to be used to oust Mr. Duvalier, the sources added.

title: A WORLD CAUGHT UP IN COMBAT AND HOPE
description: A Soviet leader and a glamorous Princess died, a British Prince was born and wars racked the Middle East, the South Atlantic and Central America. Solidarity, the Polish union, faltered under martial law.

title: GIANT'S PROSPECTS FOR PLAYOFFS ARE SLIM
description: After their last-minute 24-21 loss to the Cardinals in St. Louis Sunday, the Giants have only a remote chance to make the National Football League playoffs. And even if they make them, their coach does not think they deserve to be there.

title: Madison Fund Studies Its Options
description: Madison Fund Inc., a cash-laden investment company, said its board would meet in the ''very near future'' to consider possibilities available to it now that Warner Communications Inc. has withdrawn its merger offer.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY: WHAT FISCAL REALISM DEMANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Arafat Holds 3-Hour Meeting With the Austrian Chancellor
description: Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria met for more than three hours today at Mr. Kreisky's vacation home here.

title: EXTRA CARE EACH DAY KEEPS REPAIRMAN AWAY
description: OVER the past few decades, the concept of disposable consumer goods has crept into prominence. From use-them-once razors to throwaway toasters and rustaway cars, the material fruits of modern technology are less and less designed to be durable and repairable. The notion of preventive maintenance underlying Western technology since its inception is being rather rapidly replaced with an it's-cheaper-tobuy-a-new-one-than-to-fix-it philosophy.

title: Gift for Zachry
description: ''I've just had a real nice Christmas, we got traded,'' Pat Zachry said from his home in Waco, Tex., yesterday, confirming a report of last weekend that he was on his way from the Mets to the Los Angeles Dodgers in a trade that will bring Jorge Orta to the Mets. ''That's a pretty good Christmas present.''

title: COUPLES TEMPTED BY LOWER RATES LEAD MODEST RISE IN HOME BUYING
description: For more than a year, Charles Flynn, a salesman, and his wife, Deirdre, a bookkeeper, saved money against the day when mortgage rates fell. Several weeks ago they stopped waiting and decided to buy a $120,000 town house in suburban Orange County.

title: Freighter's Role Studied In Deaths of Jersey Men
description: Coast Guard officials said today they were investigating why a Greek freighter summoned help for a capsized sailboat but failed to stop to rescue its three passengers.

title: DR. CLARK'S SLOW PROGRESS CONTINUES
description: On the 26th day that an artifical heart kept Dr. Barney B. Clark alive, his doctors reported today that there was continued slow progress toward his recovery.

title: CALIFORNIA WEIGHS END OF FREE COLLEGE EDUCATION
description: California's public system of higher education, long the envy of many other states, is edging toward acceptance of something even Ronald Reagan, as Governor, could not force upon it: tuition.

title: 3 Americans Among 23 Killed In Airliner Fire in South China
description: Three United States citizens died in a Christmas Eve fire that killed 23 people aboard a Chinese airliner in Canton, the United States Consulate in Canton confirmed today.

title: ONE BRIDGE TOO MANY FOR ROOSEVELT ISLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: TOUGH ROAD FORECAST FOR HIGHLY TRAINED BLACKS
description: The perception of many people is that well educated, highly trained blacks are easily finding their way into senior positions in and out of Government, says Reginald E. Gilliam Jr., a black who is vice chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission. But that perception, he says, is not generally supported by reality.

title: Kansas Hires Gottfried
description: Mike Gottfried, who posted 6-5 records as head football coach the last two years at the University of Cincinnati, has been appointed the new coach at the University of Kansas. The 38-year-old Gottfried replaces Don Fambrough, who was released after a 2-7-2 record this season.

title: LIFE EXPECTANCY OF NEWBORNS HAD REACHED 74 YEARS IN 1981
description: The average American baby born in 1981 can be expected to live past the age of 74, the National Center for Health Statistics said today, adding that it was the first time life expectancy at birth, 74.1 years, was so high. For babies born in 1980, life expectancy was 73.8 years.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including extraordinary income from tax credits and the redemption of bonds of $3,179,000 for the qr and $5,156,000 for the yr...C-Including extraordinary income from tax credits and the redemption of bonds of $1,759,000 for the qr and $4,734,000 for the yr

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE disenchanted said it was the worst year that fashion had e xperienced. It wasn't. But it was black. Black was the noncolor of t he year. Never have so many people worn so much of it, a situation s till known in some circles as a trend, the battered child of the f ashion lexicon.

title: S.E.C. Cites 5 In Stock Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a group of five promoters with operating a scheme to sell shares in virtually worthless ''shell'' corporations.

title: State Sues to Bar Kodak-Eastern Offer
description: Consumers who bought instant cameras to take advantage of the advertised Kodak-Eastern Airlines two-for-the-price-of-one offer could have flown more cheaply without it, according to the State Attorney General, who filed a suit in New York State Supreme Court in Albany yesterday.

title: DESIGN CENTERS: NEW IDEAS AND OLD THEMES
description: The relative positions of the world's fashion centers have undergone some re-evaluation in the last year. Paris, which admits to no competition, still draws the biggest crowds, but some of the retailers and press representatives who attend the semiannual fashion presentations believe it is leading fashion down the primrose path. Instead of developing new directions for fashion, its leading designers are overwhelmingly preoccupied with redeveloping and reconstructing themes from the past.

title: O'Neill Backs Rise In Tax for Jobless
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today he would support an increase in the tax employers pay into Connecticut's unemployment compensation fund if needed to keep the financially strapped fund solvent.

title: REAGANS ARRIVE IN THE WEST FOR HOLIDAYS AND VISIT TO SHIP
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, arrived here today for an overnight stay at the home of Mrs. Reagan's mother. They intend to go on to California to spend the New Year's holiday in Palm Springs.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Matters of Importance

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including net income of $39,087,000 or $3.50 a shr from the cumulative effecton prior yrs of changes in accounting and a tax credit of $1.5 million

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Cooper Laboratories Inc.'s Coopervision Inc. unit filed with the S.E.C. for an initial public offering of three million common shares, through L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: Judge-to-Be Recalls Sobering Experience
description: Gregory Frost says his drunken driving conviction last year gave him valuable experience to use when he is sworn in next month as a Licking County municipal court judge.

title: N.F.C. Playoffs a Tangle of Ifs
description: The National Football Conference's playoff picture is so uncertain that, with one weekend of games remaining, seven teams are still in contention for the two remaining berths. The situation in the American Conference is somewhat less muddled.

title: Gulf Sells Assets Of a Chemical Unit
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it had sold the assets of its subsidiary, Millmaster Onyx, to Millmaster Onyx Group Inc., a new company based in New York.

title: THEATER: FRED CURCHACK
description: THERE are one-man shows -and then there is Fred Curchack's ''Fred Breaks Bread with the Dead: Fragments of a Lost Repertoire.'' The actor begins his evening at Theater for the New City by performing a solo Noh play in mask and follows that with Samuel Beckett's ''Cascando'' and a self-contained section of ''Hamlet,'' presented in the style of Kathakali dance-theater. And that is just the first act.

title: CHRISTO WILL WRAP 11 ISLANDS IN PINK
description: He has wrapped trees and cliffs and floors and a section of the Roman Wall. He has constructed a nylon-and-steel ''Running Fence'' along more than 24 miles of California countryside. He plans to wrap the Pont Neuf in Paris and the Reichstag in Berlin, and he is looking for the proper site in the Middle East to pile oil barrels into a mountain 49 stories high and five city blocks long.

title: A RARE HAIG, AT DINNER
description: ALEXANDER M. HAIG Jr., in a dinner jacket and a tan acquired on a recent trip to Israel, was at Alice Mason's elaborate holiday dinner the other night, and he was in a deliciously good mood. Life has been interesting, he said, since he so precipitously left the State Department last summer. He likes the Hudson Institute think tank, his speech-making and whatever he does at United Technologies, and he is indeed at work on a book.

title: Olin Sets Takeover And Expects a Loss
description: The Olin Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a majority of the stock of the Philip A. Hunt Chemical Corporation for $90 million and added that it would report a loss for the fourth quarter because of a $24 million claims settlement.

title: For a Good Cause
description: Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe regularly receive lucrative guarantees to play in tennis exhibitions. But neither Connors nor McEnroe will receive anything for playing in the fifth annual Woodmont Tennis Festival today and tomorrow in Tamarac, Fla.

title: DOLPHINS WIN, 27-10
description: The Miami Dolphins turned three second-half turnovers by Buffalo into scores tonight as they defeated the Bills, 27-10, and prevented them from clinching a playoff spot.

title: Loan to Chinese Bank
description: The World Bank will lend $70 million to the Investment Bank of China for loans to revamp small and medium-sized Chinese factories, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Chinese Premier in Morocco
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China flew here today for a three-day visit. Mr. Zhao and his delegation, on a 10-n@ation tour of Africa, arrived in the Moroccan capital from Algiers. The Chinese stopped first in Cairo.

title: ALASKA IS TELLING JOB HUNTERS TO STAY HOME
description: Thousands of people looking for work in the lower 48 states have turned to Alaska for hope, but Lynn Escola of the state Department of Labor has a message for them: Don't come without having a job lined up or a pocketful of money to see you through if you can't find work.

title: CITY CRACKDOWN SEEKS TO UNCLOG MIDTOWN TRAFFIC
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday a new crackdown on illegally parked cars that clog midtown Manhattan streets. He said the city would seek to increase fines, reduce the number of spaces for diplomats' cars, use a forklift truck where a tow truck won't do, and - for the first time - issue points against drivers' licenses for illegal parking.

title: Man Is Sentenced In Extortion Case
description: A man who boasted to undercover agents of his ties to organized crime was sentenced today to five years in prison after being convicted Oct. 22 of transporting $300,000 obtained by extortion across state lines.

title: Ex-Official Loses Plea in Connecticut
description: A former State Transportation Commissioner, Arthur Powers, today lost a second attempt to avoid trial on corruption charges by being granted accelerated rehabilitation and having the charges erased after a probation period.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For Chinatown, A New Working Temple

title: GOAL OF AID FOR NEEDY IS TO SHARE
description: Some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are well-to-do, some are of modest means and others are often facing their own financial difficulties. What they have in common is a concern for the needy and those less fortunate than themselves.

title: Captured Pole Given 4 Years For His Underground Activity
description: Piotr Bednarz, a leader of the Solidarity underground movement, was sentence in Wroclaw today to four years in jail for carrying on union activity in defiance of martial law.

title: Trading Halt In New York
description: Trading at the New York Commodities Exchange center was halted for a half-hour late yesterday morning because of telephone problems and resumed shortly before noon, the exchanges said.

title: Tylenol Ads to Begin
description: Johnson & Johnson said today that next week it will begin the first nationwide television advertising for Extra-Strength Tylenol since seven people died in the Chicago area after taking cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules.

title: SYSTEMS & COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
TO STOP THE 'ANARCHY' IN U.S. IMMIGRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPE'S FIERCE AUTO RIVALRY
description: Inside, the vast windowless factory is eerily silent and clean. The dominant colors are pastel shades of purple, yellow and green.

title: Pan Am Extends Special $99 Fare
description: Pan American World Airways said that it was expanding its special $99 one-way fare to all its markets in the United States.

title: POTENTIAL AREAS FOR WILDERNESS SHARPLY REDUCED
description: The Department of the Interior announced today that hundreds of thousands of acres managed by its Bureau of Land Management would be dropped as possible Federal wilderness areas.

title: Rudnay to Retire
description: Jack Rudnay, Kansas City's veteran center, will end his 13-year career after the Chiefs' final game of the season against the Jets Sunday, The Kansas City Times reported in its Tuesday editions.

title: Style Sections of The Times Win Penney-Missouri Award
description: The Living and Home Sections and the Style page of The New York Times have won first place in the 23d annual J.C. Penney-Missouri Newspaper Awards competition for sections in daily newspapers with circulations of more than 250,000.

title: AFTER THE HOLIDAY, TIME TO RETURN TO THE STORES
description: The ghost of Christmas presents came to haunt the Consumer Affairs Department yesterday. While much of city government was becalmed in the four-day week between holidays, the nine people who take complaints at the consumer agency were busy. Sanitation workers were also working hard. An extra 2,500 of them were out on Sunday carting off Christmas remnants.

title: Satellite Company Ownership Shift
description: Fairchild Industries and Continental Telecom Inc. said they had agreed to acquire the interest they do not already hold in the Space Communications Company from the Western Union Corporation, for $29 million.

title: Two at I.B.M.  Get New Posts
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has given new assignments to two vice presidents. Terry Lautenbach has been named assistant group executive for business development of the Information Systems Group, and David McKinney has been named president of the I.B.M. World Trade Americas/ Far East Corporation.

title: TV: 'MAZES AND MONSTERS,' FANTASY
description: FANTASY role playing is the subject explored tonight at 9 o'clock in the CBS-TV movie entitled ''Mazes and Monsters,'' or more precisely, ''Rona Jaffe's 'Mazes and Monsters.' ''

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball St. Peter's vs. Arkansas, followed by West Virginia vs. North Carolina State, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J.; first game, 7 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape.)

title: Talent Blends on Soviet Six
description: The Soviet hockey all-stars, scheduled to arrive here today for the start of a six-game series against National Hockey League clubs, include most of the players on the national team. And many of their names are familiar from the 1980 Olympics at Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Charge at Houston Industries Possible
description: Houston Industries, an electric utility holding company, said it might have to take a ''substantial charge'' against 1982 earnings. The company said that the Public Utility Commission of Texas had granted it a $182.6 million rate increase on Dec. 6, but had disallowed the recovery of about $166 million of costs incurred for the Allen Creek nuclear generating project, which was canceled in August.

title: CHICAGO AND THE ARTS: MERGING CONSTITUENCIES
description: Whatever success President Reagan may have enjoyed in persuading Congress to reduce nonmilitary spending, he has consistently failed in his attempts to cut Federal funds for the arts and humanities. To a large extent, this is because of the efforts of a Congressman from Chicago, Sidney R. Yates.

title: LYONS OF JETS IS INJURED AGAIN
description: Even as they celebrated their playoff berth with a hot dog buffet today, the Jets learned that they would be forced to start a revamped right side of the defensive line - the erstwhile New York Sack Exchange that is now honored more in memory than for performance.

title: Pact May End El Al's Strike
description: The Histadrut Labor Federation signed a new labor agreement on behalf of El Al's employees today but legal obstacles prevented the immediate reversal of a liquidation order for the state-owned airline.

title: FEVER: NEW VIEW STRESSES ITS HEALING BENEFITS
description: THE ancient Greeks, who regarded disease as an imbalance of ''humors,'' believed fever cured the sick by cooking the bad humors and helping the body get rid of them. The notion of fever as beneficial persisted for more than 2,000 years, and countless patients were actually treated with ''fever therapy'' to aid their recovery from such ailments as syphilis, tuberculosis and even mania.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cozying Up The Twin Towers

title: Standouts of 1982
description: M ore than any single live or taped event of 1982, the National Football League's player strike exposed the importance of pro football to network television sports. But, while the networks lost ratings and advertising dollars, there were plenty of achievements, some unexpected, that enhanced the year for the TV sports viewer.

title: TV: 'NBC WHITE PAPER: REGAN AT MID-TERM'
description: IT is that time of year when television news departments feel a compulsion to subject the body politic to its annual checkup. An early entry, an ''NBC White Paper: Reagan at Mid-Term,'' can be seen tonight on NBC-TV at 10 o'clock.

title: Market Place; Metromedia's Restructuring
description: AT first glance, it looked as if Metromedia could not quite make up its mind. It was selling the 45,000 billboards owned by its Foster & Kleiser division for almost $500 million to a limited partnership. But the transaction included a somewhat unusual clause that provided for the possibility that Metromedia might buy back the billboards in five years - if both the buyers and sellers agreed.

title: CLEANER LAKE ERIE LURING FISHERMEN BY THOUSANDS
description: Sport fishermen, enjoying the resurrection of Lake Erie, wedge themselves shoulder to shoulder along its tributaries for the fall run of fighting, flavorful chinook and coho salmon.

title: ENCEPHALITIS WARNING ISSUED FOR FLORIDA TOWN
description: Vinnie Carfora heard the news on the radio while driving to work. People were being urged to wear heavy clothing and spray themselves with insect repellant.

title: Salvadoran Guerrillas Sabotage Power Lines
description: Salvadoran guerrillas sabotaged power lines in the eastern third of the country late Sunday and the area remained without electricity today.

title: Paris-Peking Nuclear Accord
description: France and China have concluded a preliminary agreement aimed at helping China develop peaceful nuclear technology, a spokesman for the French Atomic Energy Commission said today. The deal provides a framework for separate future agreements on reactor safety, sodium technology and geology.

title: DREYFUS BUYS BANK IN JERSEY
description: Over the strong objections of the Federal Reserve Board and threats by the Fed of protracted legal action, the Dreyfus Corporation made the purchase yesterday of the Lincoln State Bank of East Orange, a tiny New Jersey organization with assets of $29 million.

title: 3 Killed and 20 Hurt In Dutch Rail Crash
description: An international express train and a Dutch passenger train collided today, killing 3 people and injuring more than 20, a railroad spokesman said.

title: Overheated; Defending the Wreckers
description: We now have the White House's first line of defense to charges of chiseling by Reagan appointees to the Legal Services Corporation. ''There shouldn't be a Legal Services Corporation,'' declares Ed Meese, the White House counselor, apparently meaning that the way to stop excessive consultant's fees is to kill the program, intended to provide lawyers for the poor in civil cases.

title: THE ARTIFICIAL HEART'S BEAT: A FEAT OF MIMICRY
description: A few yards from Dr. Barney B. Clark's bed, a video display terminal shows the amount of blood his artificial heart pumps with each beat. A computer continually calculates data about the polyurethane heart's activity over the preceding 60 minutes, and new readouts of the changes are flashed on the monitor screen every few seconds.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in SportsMonday yesterday about Don Strock of the Miami Dolphins was accompanied by an incorrect picture.

title: RISKY FAKE WORKS FOR JETS, CARDS
description: A lthough 66 percent of all field-goal attempts in the National Football League have been successful this season both the Jets and the St. Louis Cardinals chose a fake field goal play in their games on Sunday. Despite the considerable risk, the plays went for touchdowns and 6 points rather than the field goal's 3. The Cardinals used it to score their first touchdown in a 24-21 victory over the Giants at St. Louis, and the Jets scored their fourth touchdown with it as they defeated the Minnesota Vikings, 42-14.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1982
description: International Yuri V. Andropov is the first leader of the Soviet Union since Lenin to have lived abroad. Mr. Andropov served in the Soviet Embassy in Budapest from 1953 to 1957, at the time of the Hungarian uprising. Some Hungarians recall him as a shrewd, calculating official. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) The Kremlin declared an amnesty for convicts to mark the 60th anniversary of the formal merger of republics into the Soviet Union, but the wording of the decree indicated that it excluded those convicted of political offenses and a wide variety of other crimes considered serious. (A9:1-3.)

title: Steel Output Drops Again
description: United States steel mills operated last week at their lowest rate in 50 years, and less steel was produced than when the weekly recordkeeping began in 1962, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
