title: A DAY OF RECOGNITION FOR BLACK AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: New Voice for Mets
description: Tim McCarver, the St. Louis Cardinals' catcher in three World Series in the 1960's, will be the new voice in the booth for the Mets for their games on commercial and cable television next season. He succeeds Lorn Brown, who had been badly received by television critics and sports columnists during his one season in New York this year. Al Harazin, a vice president for the Mets, said McCarver would join Ralph Kiner and another announcer to be named in the Channel 9 telecasts, and that he would work with Kiner and Bud Harrelson on the cable telecasts.

title: Dr. J.R. Muir Wed To Ann L. Froelich
description: Ann L. Froelich, daughter of Mrs. Louis B. Froelich of New York and the late Mr. Froelich, was married yesterday to Dr. John Robert Muir, son of Lady Muir of London and the late Sir Edward Muir. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's mother by Acting Judge Herbert Altman of the State Supreme Court.

title: Dr. Saul Blatman, 64; Professor of Pediatrics
description: Dr. Saul Blatman, a pediatrician and founder of the maternal and child health department at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H., died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Hanover. He was 64 years old.

title: Inheriting Behavior
description: Few issues have evoked so much heat among biologists as the nurture-versus-nature debate on the inheritance of behavioral traits. As noted by three geneticists at Cambridge University, sociobiologists argue that a tendency to choose one particular course of action can be passed to one's offspring.

title: ST. JOHN'S OUSTS BRIGHAM YOUNG
description: St. John's, experienced and undefeated, and Wake Forest, less experienced and undefeated, advanced to the final of the E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ships of Sixth Ave.

title: OFFICIALS ASSIGN EIGHT DETECTIVES TO THE PATZ CASE
description: In a renewed effort to find a solution in the disappearance of Etan Patz, the Police Department assigned eight detectives yesterday to work full time on the case.

title: Unhappy Patriots
description: Player discontent continues to trouble the New England Patriots. Last week, several players voiced objection to the style and approach of Ron Meyer, the Patriots' first-year coach, saying Meyer was too strict and was also unreceptive to player input into game strategy.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial markets were closed for national holidays yesterday in Australia, Belgium, Beirut, Canada, Ireland, Egypt, Greece, Hong Kong, Lebanon, Luxembourg, New Zealand and Britain.

title: Blanche Evan, 73, a Pioneer In Dance Therapy Techniques
description: Blanche Evan, a dancer and choreographer who was a pioneer in the development of dance therapy, died Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 73 years old.

title: A Police Mentality
description: The French Communist Party has launched a remarkable campaign that would simply be ludicrous if it didn't seem so revealing about the new Soviet leadership.

title: OMNI EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-The company went public in Nov 1981 and therefore there are no comparable yr-ago results

title: WILLIAMS RECALLS DIFFICULT PASSAGE
description: T he most noticeable measure of the transformation of Kevin Williams, and perhaps the least important one, is the line of statistics next to his name. He has become an important part of a St. John's team that has won its first 10 games this season. For that reason and others, there are smiles and animated conversations where there was once a withdrawn personality that tried, unsuccessfully, to hide his anger inside.

title: Microscopic MX
description: The nature we see may be red in tooth and claw, but under the microscope her weapons are more sophisticated. Take the missile system operated by the greenhouse fungus Haptoglossa mirabilis.

title: Trade Report Delayed
description: The Commerce Department said today that its report on the United States merchandise trade balance in November, scheduled for release tomorrow, would be delayed indefinitely because of a computer failure.

title: Top Esmark Executive To Look for Successor
description: Donald P. Kelly, chairman, president and chief executive of Esmark Inc., says that he is not necessarily looking for a successor in his own image when he gives up the title of chief executive next year, as he has announced that he will do.

title: Alaska Air-Boeing
description: The Boeing Company said it had received an order from Alaska International Air for six of its 737-200 airliners costing about $100 million. Boeing said two planes would be delivered this week. The others will be delivered in 1984 and 1985.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $236,000 for the qr and $996,000for the 9 mos a net loss of $1,121,000 for the qr and 9 mos on the disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $126,000 for the qr and 9mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $576,000 for the qr and $1,397,000 for the 9 mos

title: McCall's Holding Line On Its Ad Rates
description: In an unusual announcement, Ray Eyes, publisher of McCall's, has promised the advertising community that the magazine will have no ad rate increases in the coming year.

title: ISSUE AND DEBATE
description: Takeover fever has broken out again among energy companies, this time prompted by the fact that declining oil prices have created seeming bargains among oil stocks. In recent days, Burlington Northern Inc. has announced a bid for about half the stock of the El Paso Company, while the Mesa Petroleum Company has touched off a battle for the General American Oil Company of Texas.

title: BRIEFING
description: New Policy at Interior

title: THE SKIRTS OF LEBANON
description: To the Editor:

title: Machine Tool Orders Drop
description: Machine tool orders in the United States fell to $88.2 million in November, down 26 percent from October and 54.9 percent from November 1981, the National Machine Tool Builders Association, in McLean, Va., said today.

title: LAUTENBERG, IN COLORADO, IS SWORN IN AS A SENATOR
description: Frank R. Lautenberg was sworn in as a United States Senator from New Jersey this afternoon in the living room of his vacation home here.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Bank Merger In Connecticut
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has cleared the way for the Hartford National Corporation, a Connecticut banking organization, to acquire Mattatuck Bank and Trust Company of Waterbury, Conn.

title: Daughter of Rep. Ryan Married at Guru's Ranch
description: The daughter of Representative Leo Ryan, who was slain in 1978 while investigating the Peoples Temple religious cult, was married here today at the ranch of the guru she follows.

title: SOVIET IS ASSAILED ON AFGHAN POLICY
description: China called on other countries today to give more support, including ''moral and material assistance,'' to the guerrillas in Afghanistan and thereby put pressure on the Soviet Union to withdraw its ''aggressor troops.''

title: FED VOTED FOR FASTER MONEY RISE
description: The Federal Reserve System, clearly concerned about continuing weakness in the econony, voted last month to accept growth in its broadest meaasures of the money supply at rates above the targets originally established for 1982.

title: U.S. TO PRESS RUMANIANS ON EMIGRATION TAX
description: The Reagan Administration plans to send a high-ranking official to Bucharest next month to warn Rumania that it faces a setback in relations with the United States if it carries out an announced plan to impose an education tax on emigrants, American officials said today.

title: Picking Music For Browsing
description: If you notice the absence of polkas or even fast disco beats as background music in your local supermarket, it might be because the manager has learned that slow music stimulates purchases.

title: 82 YEARS OF HISTORY IN LACKAWANNA
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's announcement today that it would stop making iron and steel at its Lackawanna plant here brings to an close an 82-year industry that built and defined this Lake Erie town.

title: CHRISTIANS ARE TORN IN THE LAND OF DR. LIVINGSTON
description: This is the land where David Livingstone lies buried and where, too, the great evangelical effort of the Scottish missionary and his peers has stamped itself indelibly on a nation once steeped in Africa's animism.

title: SECURITY BEGUN FOR LEBANON TALKS
description: Israeli and Lebanese Army soldiers set up a security cordon today around a beach hotel in this troubled town south of Beirut where talks are to open Tuesday on Israeli demands for security arrangements and a normalizing of relations.

title: FIRST CITY PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,043,000 or 12 cents a shr for the qr and $2.3 million or 27 cents a shr for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,066,000 or 12 cents a shr for the qr and $4,007,000 or 46 centsa shr for the 9 mos

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL TO CUT 7,300 JOBS AT UPSTATE PLANT
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel company, announced yesterday that it was sharply cutting back operations at two of its plants. The move will eliminate nearly 10,000 jobs and reduce Bethlehem's steelmaking capacity by 15 percent in the next year.

title: Judicial Panel Refuses To Supply Longer List
description: The commission that nominates candidates for the state's highest court has turned down Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo's request to send him more names to consider in filling a forthcoming vacancy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Pamela Cheng, Anthony T. D'Angelo, Vincent B. Fieseler Jr., Phillips A. Gribbins, J. Robert Hitchings, Mark T. Hughes and Bruce Hathaway as vice presidents.

title: SOVIET GRANTS PARTIAL AMNESTY FOR ITS CELEBRATIONS
description: The Soviet Union declared an amnesty today to mark the 60th anniversary of its formal merger as a federation of republics, but the decree indicated that it excluded those convicted of political offenses and other crimes considered serious under Soviet law.

title: SIMPLE CATARACT OPERATION ON AN UNUSUAL PATIENT
description: EVERYTHING about the operation, a simple cataract removal, was normal. The patient, who happened to weigh four and a half tons, was led into a warehouse, injected with a few ounces of an anesthetic that could have killed a thousand humans, then gently pushed over onto her side and, except for her head, covered with sheets.

title: ARTHUR J. SILLS, ATTORNEY GENERAL IN JERSEY FROM 1962 TO 1970, DIES
description: Arthur J. Sills, New Jersey Attorney General from 1962 to 1970, died of a stroke Sunday at Perth Amboy (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Metuchen, N.J.

title: Advertising; New Guide For Buying Computers
description: GEORGE BURKE is 55 years old and is through with the advertising and public relations business after 20 years at it. ''I hated the pressure and I hated the clients,'' he says now, two years after closing George Burke Advertising, which had recently lost the $2 million Liberty Travel account. ''I'm eating better and sleeping better and I don't have that tic anymore.'' The tic developed over the years in such locations as Ted Bates & Company, Kelly Nason and VanSant, Dugdale & Company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In Paterson, the state and the nation libraries have become a rather low priority with elected officials.

title: Business and the Law; State Controls On Takeovers
description: ILLINOIS might be defeated in its efforts to control corporate takeovers, but there is apparently no stopping Ohio. In June, the United States Supreme Court struck down an Illinois state law regulating corporate takeovers. Under that law, tender offers for companies in which 10 percent or more of the shares was owned by Illinois residents were subject to a waiting period and had to be registered with state officials so they could judge their fairness.

title: BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Signed Tim McCarver, f ormer catcher with St. Louis Cardinals a nd Philadelphia Phillies, as commer- c ial and cable television broadcaster. BASKETBALL DALLAS (NBA) - Removed Corny T hompson, forward, from injured re- s erve list.

title: Roger Bowling, 38, a Writer Of Country-Western Songs
description: Roger Bowling, a country-western songwriter who was co-author of the songs ''Lucille'' and ''Coward of the County,'' made famous by Kenny Rogers, was found dead in his home on Saturday.

title: DEMANDS OF INTENSE PSYCHOTHERAPY TAKE THEIR TOLL ON PATIENT'S SPOUSE
description: DR. Howard F. Wallach, a Los Angeles psychoanalyst, well understands the rigors his therapy imposes on his patients. But he found nothing in his experience had prepared him for the emotional effects he suffered when his wife started to see a psychoanalyst herself.

title: ISRAELI OFFICER CHALLENGED ON TESTIMONY
description: Attorneys for senior Israeli officials began cross-examining middle-ranking army officers in public hearings today, in an effort to throw their credibility into question before the state commission investigating the deaths of Palestinian civilians in Beirut.

title: Soviet Atom Test Recorded
description: A Swedish seismological institute said today that it had registered an underground nuclear explosion in the Soviet Union. The institute, the Hagfors military observatory, said the explosion occurred at the Semipalatinsk nuclear test area in Siberia on Sunday. The tremor registered 6.7 on the Richter scale, officials said.

title: SNOW-GLOGGED DENVER AREA BRACING FOR NEW STORM AND COLDER WEATHER
description: Three days after a Christmas Eve blizzard dumped two feet of snow here, Denver still had the appearance today of a city besieged, with most major roads barely passable because of ice and snow and many downtown shops and offices closed.

title: Universal Pictures Replaces President
description: Ned Tanen, the president of the Universal Pictures division of MCA Inc. since 1978, is leaving to become an independent producer, the diversified entertainment company announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by Robert Rehme, head of Universal's marketing and distribution arm, who joined the company in 1981.

title: KEAN TO WORK FOR BOTH BILLS
description: Bills to increase the state's sales tax from 5 to 6 percent and to raise liquor taxes were introduced today after a special session of the Legislature was convened, and Governor Kean said he would help round up votes to pass the bills Thursday.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When a mosquito bites us, we itch almost immediately. Wouldn't it be more advantageous for the mosquito to evolve so we are not allergic to its bite? Then we would leave them alone.

title: Elizabeth L. Kirby Weds Lieutenant at West Point
description: Elizabeth Leona Kirby, daughter of Col. Gilbert W. Kirby Jr., U.S.A., and Mrs. Kirby of West Point, was married there yesterday to Lieut. William Bewick Fullerton, U.S.A., son of Col. Avery S. Fullerton, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Fullerton of Indian Harbor Beach, Fla., and David, Panama.

title: THE SEA DREW HIM EVER DEEPER
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass. WHILE astronauts are rocketing noisily into space and probing the solar system, another exploration, quieter but equally challenging, is taking place among the mountains, valleys, deserts and abysses at the bottom of the sea. In this blue, murky realm, a handful of pioneers in tiny machines have begun to limn man's perception of a strange new world. Their oceanic searches have discovered a huge mountain range girdling the globe, some of whose peaks are higher than Everest; have observed strangely-shaped creatures thriving in streams of hot chemicals spewed from the planet's interior, and have been puzzled by an undersea alchemy that produces new mineral compounds.

title: JOHN S. ALLEN, FLORIDA EDUCATOR
description: John S. Allen, the founding president of the University of South Florida and a former staff member of the New York State Board of Regents, died of pneumonia Sunday at his home in Tampa. He was 75 years old.

title: 2,000 Rebel Tribesmen Surrender, Thailand Says
description: More than 2,000 Communist rebel tribesmen surrendered today to Government forces in northern Thailand, the authorities said.

title: PORTUGUESE CHIEF PICKS SUCCESSOR
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao announced today that he would nominate Vitor Crespo, president of the Social Democratic parliamentary group, as his successor.

title: I.R.S. Mails 1982 Tax Forms
description: The 1982 tax forms are in the mail, the Internal Revenue Service said today. And despite earlier efforts to disconnect the telephone, a tax collector is waiting on a tollfree line to answer questions.

title: News Analysis
description: Negotiations between Israel and Lebanon start Tuesday in an atmosphere of uncertainty about the ability and willingness of President Amin Gemayel to reach an accord on Israel's major demands for security arrangements and normalization of relations.

title: SOCIAL SCIENCE STUDENT GIVING $500 TO STAY WITH POOR FAMILY
description: A woman studying for a master's degree in social science will donate $500 to live with a widow and seven children in low-income housing in a ''class exchange'' program, a sponsor of the plan says.

title: South Korean's Criticism Brings U.S. Response
description: The State Department, responding to criticism from the South Korean dissident political figure Kim Dae Jung, said today that it had made known its hope that South Korea could make progress toward a more open political system.

title: Beware the Cow in E.T.'s Barn
description: In the days when saber-toothed tigers prowled the night, humans acquired a healthy instinct: fear of the dark. Astronomers, boyishly defiant of this inherited wisdom, have renewed their search of the universe's dark spaces for signs of alien civilizations. What if they should find them?

title: WHEN THE CHAIN HIT THE PIPE
description: T omorrow night in the Liberty Bowl game, 69-year-old Paul (Bear) Bryant will be prowling the sideline for the last time as Alabama's coach, the sideline where he has produced a record 322 college victories in 38 seasons, the sideline where he once growled at Ray Perkins, his successor next season.

title: Sheik in Theft Case on Bail
description: A Federal magistrate today permitted a Saudi Arabian sheik to remain free on $25,000 bond pending a hearing on a charge he tried to sell a stolen $1.2 million ring. Magistrate Jean F. Dwyer tentatively set a Jan. 6 hearing for Sheik Allal al-Fassi, 21, whose in-laws are members of the Saudi royal family. He is a brother of Sheik Mohammad al-Fassi, who has gained publicity for gift-giving and a dispute with a Miami-area hotel over a $1.4 million bill.

title: NETS DEFEAT CAVALIERS
description: Injury and dissatisfaction have again placed the Nets' backcourt in a state of uncertainty. Mike O'Koren, who had replaced Otis Birdsong in the starting lineup the last three games, suffered a broken right wrist tonight late in the first half of the Nets' third straight victory, a 94-82 triumph over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $124,000 or 10 cents a shr, for the qrand $194,000 or 16 cents a shr for the 6 mos...C-Including an extraordinary taxcredit of $119,000 or 9 cents a shr for the qr and 6 mos

title: FURTHER PRICE CUTS DRAW SHOPPERS
description: After a Christmas week that fell short of expectations, retailers across the country slashed prices further in a bid to sustain a latedeveloping buying surge.

title: El Paso Is Sued By Burlington
description: Burlington Northern Inc. said it had filed suit in the Delaware Chancery Court to prevent the El Paso Company from paying a stock dividend and from changing its bylaws, steps that El Paso took last Thursday to discourage stockholders from accepting Burlington's tender offer.

title: TOO QUIET FOR COMFORT
description: Leo Fichtelberg is a librarian, but never in his most irascible moments did he want to see the library this quiet. Paterson's main library and all seven branches have been temporarily shut for lack of funds, and Mr. Fichtelberg, the system's director, was commenting on the eeriness of it all as he walked through the main reading room and up the marble steps to his office, where small stacks of dollar bills held together with paper clips and rubber bands sat on his desk.

title: TRADERS GROW NERVOUS ABOUT MESA'S INTENTIONS
description: The stock of the General American Oil Company of Texas slid $3 a share yesterday to $43 in hectic trading on the New York Stock Exchange amid nervousness that the Mesa Petroleum Company might abandon its $40-a-share offer for 51 percent of General American.

title: SOME INSIGHTS INTO ANDROPOV GLEANED FROM BUDAPEST ROLE
description: In a number of ways, the fortunes of Yuri V. Andropov have been linked to those of Hungary. Mr. Andropov, the new Soviet party leader, served in the Soviet Embassy in Budapest from 1953 to 1957, initially as a second-rank official, then as Ambassador.

title: MISQUOTING IS CITED
description: Suffolk County yesterday dropped its bid to dismiss Dr. Michael M. Baden as chief deputy medical examiner over remarks on homicide attributed to him in a magazine article.

title: FIGHTING ILLINI COACH IS FIGHTING THE PAST
description: This Wednesday night, in a game likely to be best remembered as Paul (Bear) Bryant's last as a head coach, the University of Illinois football team will play a postseason game for the first time since the 1964 Rose Bowl.

title: CONFUSION OVER STATUS OF BANKRUPTCY COURT
description: Although the Manhattan bankruptcy court ran smoothly yesterday - the first business day after Congress missed its deadline for restructuring the nation's bankruptcy system - there was an undercurrent of confusion about its legal status.

title: JUST BEFORE CHRISTMAS, CONGRESS GAVE TO ME...
description: Congress never goes home for the holidays without bestowing special treats on its favorites. Although the lame-duck session fudged or fumbled most of its major bills, it passed lots of trivial ones. Not every bill cited below passed both houses, but together these trinkets provide a glimpse of the merriment pork-barreiers and political-action committees had at the public's expense in the tumultuous days before Christmas.

title: M.T.A. Preparing For Conrail Strike
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority began preparing a contingency plan yesterday to put into effect this weekend if there should be a strike on Conrail's commuter lines north of New York City.

title: Navy Orders 2 Nuclear Ships
description: The Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company said it had received a $3.14 billion contract to build two nuclear-powered aircraft carriers for the Navy. The contract is one of the largest the Navy has made.

title: LOBBYISTS MOBILIZE FOR BATTLE OVER SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The battle over the future of Social Security, which has been gathering for several months, will force members of Congress next year to face one of the most intense lobbying drives in years.

title: RUSSIANS COLLECT ARGOT FROM THE LOWER DEPTHS
description: WHEN Kirill Uspensky, a Russian writer, began a five-year term in a Soviet labor camp in 1960, he was surprised to find that he often did not understand the ''evidently Russian'' language of his fellow prisoners.

title: Not Getting Involved
description: We have been reminded again that there are people who witness crimes and don't report them - even crimes against little children. It is impossible to sympathize with the criminals, and it is almost as hard to forgive these guilty witnesses their harmful silence.

title: SEYMOR D. SIMPSON, HEADED SHOPWELL CHAIN
description: Seymour D. Simpson, president and chief operating officer of Shopwell Inc., died of a heart attack Sunday while vacationing in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 58 years old, and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: OVERHEATED; Pepless Peppers
description: Imagine a lobster that emerged from its shell as easily as a pea from its pod. A watermelon that, being seedless, freed you of the need to spit.

title: FIVE CRUCIAL YEARS IN A MIDEAST PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess: A Terrific Tactical Concept Destroys Black's Defense
description: The reason a small but incredibly dedicated number of players are willing to endure the acute defensive complications of the poisonedpawn variation of the Najdorf Sicilian is that it also imposes great demands on White.

title: DOW JUMPS TO 1,070.55, A RECORD
description: Signs of an economic recovery helped to push the Dow Jones industrial average up 25.48 points yesterday, to a closing record of 1,070.55.

title: Window Claims Found Exaggerated
description: ''Cut heat loss through your window by up to 98.5 percent,'' said the advertisement for an interior storm window. The advertiser, Plaskolite of Columbus, Ohio, also stated that ''field tests'' in three cities proved that its windows had ''slashed'' heating bills by up to $252.20 a year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Of Signs and the Season

title: WEAVER REMATCH IS ORDERED
description: The World Boxing Association today ordered a heavyweight-championship rematch between Michael Dokes and Mike Weaver. Dokes captured Weaver's title on Dec. 10 when the fight was stopped early in the first round.

title: LASER-PLAYED DISKS DUE
description: THE CD's are coming! The CD's are coming! Not the banking CD's, but the audio compact disks. The hoopla for the new technology is evident in the technical magazines, which are busy reviewing the equipment for playing the disks. The record companies are busy preparing the disks, which are expected to be available commercially in this country sometime after their introduction in Europe in March.

title: The Superfund Turned Upside Down
description: To judge by Anne Gorsuch's actions, you'd never guess that hazardous waste dumps are a national problem. The Environmental Protection Agency's administrator recently published a list of the country's 418 worst abandoned dump sites, to be cleaned up under the Superfund law. But the list was produced a year and half late. It cited a minuscule fraction of the 14,000 or so hazardous dumps that may exist. And given the E.P.A.'s equivocal record of cleaning up the sites, the listing is no guarantee of future action.

title: When 509 Yards Are Not Enough
description: Vince Ferragamo, who is pitching footballs again in the National Football League after a Canadian season he hopes to forget, proved last Sunday you can't have everything. Ferragamo, playing quarterback for the Los Angeles Rams against the Chicago Bears at Anaheim, gained 509 yards passing. Although that figure is now second best in N.F.L. records, the passing did not rescue the Rams: they lost, 34-26.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE BELARUS SECRET. By John Loftus. Edited by Nathan Miller. 196 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Sale to United Technologies
description: The United Technologies Corporation said it had bought its headquarters building in downtown Hartford for about $50 million.

title: Bridge: Victory Came on Last Deal In Jersey Double Knockout
description: It rarely happens that the last deal of a long match turns defeat into victory, but it did last week in the final of the New Jersey Bridge League's Double Knockout Team Championship. Although they did not know it, Bob Sartorius, David and Linda Berkowitz, Judy Tucker and Mark and Roberta Epstein were trailing their opponents - Ron Rubin, Eileen Brenner, Michael Pickert, Lester Sokolower and Barbara Tepper - by just three international match points. Then came the tricky part-score deal shown in the diagram.

title: Control Data's Research Venture
description: The Justice Department said it would not challenge an effort by the Control Data Corporation to form a joint venture to coordinate research projects in the computer and microelectronics business.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1982; Companies
description: Bethlehem Steel said it will eliminate nearly 10,000 jobs by closing most of its steel operations in Lackawanna, N.Y., and consolidating operations at its Johnston, Pa., mill. The actions by the country's second-largest steel company will produce a fourth-quarter write-off of between $750 million and $850 million. As a result, analysts said Bethlehem could lose $1 billion in the quarter. (Page A1.) The closing of the 82-year-old Lackawanna plant ends an era in the Lake Erie town. (D3.)

title: Market Place; Analysts Back Tire Concerns
description: ON Monday, when the Dow Jones industrial average finished at a record high of 1,070.55, 64 common stocks on the New York Stock Exchange traded at their loftiest prices for the last 52 weeks or more.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: 'I Feel Strongly'

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock and foreign exchange markets were closed for national holidays yesterday in Australia, Ireland, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand and Britain. In Japan, except for foreign exchange trading, markets closed at noon. Tables reflecting these markets do not appear in today's paper.

title: Brother of Princess Grace Wounded in Robbery Attempt
description: John B. Kelly Jr., brother of the late Princess Grace of Monaco, resisted a would-be robber and was shot, the authorities said.

title: JACK SWIGERT, ASTRONAUT ELECTED TO CONGRESS, DIES
description: Jack Swigert, a former astronaut from Colorado who was elected to the House of Representatives in November while suffering from cancer, died Monday night at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 51 years old.

title: MACARTHUR ON THE WISDOM ON NUCLEAR CONTEST
description: To the Editor:

title: Nashua Violation
description: The Nashua Corporation said that, as a result of previously reported losses, it is in technical violation of covenants in bank loan agreements made earlier this year, and that it expects directors to suspend dividend payments.

title: Blaze Forces Marcos From Palace in His Robe
description: Fire broke out in ceremonial rooms at the palace of President Ferdinand E. Marcos today when a Christmas tree light bulb exploded.

title: Real Estate; Brooklyn Navy Yard Program
description: TWO months ago the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, overseers of the sprawling industrial park on the East River, inaugurated its own steam production system, enabling it to provide steam to its tenants at rates below those of Consolidated Edison.

title: Garden State to Reopen in '84
description: Garden State race track in Cherry Hill, whose clubhouse and grandstand burned down in 1977, will be rebuilt in two years and will reopen with a New Year's Eve party on Dec. 31, 1984, its new owner promised at a news conference here today.

title: Economic Scene; Call to Hire 'One Person'
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S proposal to solve the unemployment problem by urging every American business to hire ''just one person'' did not exactly get off to a flying start this week, as it collided with Bethlehem Steel's announcement that it was eliminating the jobs of nearly 10,000 workers in Lackawanna, N.Y., and Johnstown, Pa.

title: BANK OF AMERICA GAINS IN WAR FOR NEW ACCOUNTS
description: The new market rate account has touched off another round in the long battle for consumer deposits among most California banks and thrift institutions.

title: Keogh Plans Due
description: Friday is the last day for taxpayers to establish a 1982 Keogh plan, a type of tax-deferred retirement account for the selfemployed. Funds, however, do not have to be placed in the account until next April 15. The maximum annual contribution to a Keogh account is 15 percent of total self-employed income up to a maximum of $15,000.

title: DOW DROPS BY 11.68, TO 1,058.87
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday after Monday's sharp advance despite a cut in interest rates by a major bank. The main casualties were some of the blue chips and technology issues.

title: TSUYEE PEI, BANKER IN CHINA FOR YEARS
description: Tsuyee Pei, a former governor of the Chinese Nationalists' Central Bank of China, a member of China's delegation to the Bretton Woods Conference in 1944 and a seminal figure in the creation of a modern banking system in China, died in Lenox Hill Hospital Monday. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Customs Service Brochure Inquiry
description: The Joint Committee on Printing of Congress is investigating the arrangement made by the United States Customs Service with a private company for a brochure that will include a customs form as well as advertising.

title: REAGAN HAILS NAVY LED BY BATTLESHIP
description: President Reagan today recommissioned the World War II-vintage battleship New Jersey and asserted that his Administration had dramatically improved American military readiness after what he called a period of unilateral disarmament from 1970 to 1979.

title: The Rules for Reshaping Life
description: The genetically engineered strain of giant mouse announced recently shows the surprising ease with which researchers can effect changes in living organisms. Though it is just a matter of time before such interventions become technically feasible in humans, the issue has received remarkably little public discussion from the biologists who are fast developing the tools for reshaping the handiwork of evolution.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Consolidated Foods Corp. said it would redeem its outstanding $4.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock on Jan. 28, at a redemption price of $101 a share.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split payable Feb 25, 1983

title: A Light Touch
description: For runners who take their training and racing seriously, the Midnight New Year's Eve run in Central Park is always welcome relief. Friday night's five-mile race will be no exception.

title: Duke of Energy
description: Duke of Energy said its chairman, Rockie L. Smith, had signed an agreement to exchange about 6.3 million of his Duke shares - or 30 percent of the company's stock outstanding - for 42.9 million shares of the Federal Resources Corporation.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ''DON'T hate yourself for making mistakes,'' says Max the Bartender. ''Why? Because in the second place, it's useless. And in the first place, it's too late.'' This week, when everyone is nudging the loose ends of 1982 under the rug while keeping a suspicious eye on 1983, could there be an aphorism more apt? And could there be a better aphorist?

title: LAW OF THE SEA: THE CORRECT U.S. RESPONSE
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ALTHOUGH every season has its associated hazards (for example, the pesticides of spring), winter has more than its fair share of risks to life and limb. Everything from slippery sidewalks and stalled cars to electric blankets and space heaters can turn a winter wonderland into a nightmare. Knowing what the hazards are and heeding a few precautions could save your eyes, your fingers, your limbs or even your life without depriving you of winter's delights. Here are some tips to help you avoid all-too-common cold-weather mishaps.

title: PANTRY PRIDE SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for QTr to Nov 20
description: The company is listed on the Pacific, Boston and Philadelphia stock exchanges

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I first encountered a dish called spaghetti Caruso, on arriving in this country many years ago, I was told it was an American creation. I didn't wonder about it further until a friend recently asked me about it.

title: PEACE IN THE NEW YEAR?
description: The latest round of negotiations between Israel and Lebanon has started with a blare of propaganda on both sides, and an argument over the facts of past negotiations.

title: DELAYED FEDERAL STUDY SAYS WASTE PONDS ENDANGER DRINKING WATER
description: An Environmental Protection Agency report says that thousands of pits, ponds and lagoons around the country contain waste that poses serious threats of ground-water contamination.

title: Tylenol Suspect Denies Charges of Extortion
description: James W. Lewis, a key figure in the investigation of seven Tylenol-cyanide deaths, pleaded not guilty today to Federal extortion charges.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
SLEEP AS 'EXPRESSION' AT ISSUE
description: A three-judge panel of the Federal Court of Appeals here was asked today to rule that sleep could be a form of expression protected by the First Amendment.

title: TV: BEAUTY-PAGEANT TRIBULATIONS
description: BEAUTY contests, especially the Miss America Pageant, may be the stuff of blockbuster television ratings, but ''serious'' television never tires of pointing out how empty and humiliating the crowning process is. Witness tonight's television movie on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock: ''Miss All-American Beauty,'' starring Diane Lane as an 18-year-old Kansas City girl who is depicted as somewhat naive. For the purposes of this script, written by Nancy Audley and Emily Tracy, she is unbelievably naive.

title: RACISM IS THE ENEMY
description: To the Editor:

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax recoveries of $84,000 for the qr and $110,000 for the yr...C-Net loss

title: BRYANT'S LAST GAME DRAWS A TIDE OF TRIBUTES
description: A Crimson Tide of people swelled in the lobby of the Holiday Inn Rivermont Hotel as Alabama football fans gathered today for what alumni and opponent alike are calling a historic occasion. No one looked to be in a hurry to leave as a special bar was set up to tend to the thirsts of those telling nostalgic tales about the man they affectionately called ''The Bear.''

title: MEXICO SOFTENS IMPACT OF BANK NATIONALIZATION
description: Mexico's new Government moved to soften the impact of the nationalization of the country's private banks last September by announcing plans to sell off 34 percent of the nationalized banks.

title: FOR A CLEARER VIEW OF HOLIDAY LEFTOVERS
description: PROBABLY more home cooking is being done at this season, as friends and relatives drop in for the holidays, than at any other time of the year. This always leads to a rich quarry of leftovers, with refrigerators sagging under the weight of partly excavated turkeys, strip-mined casseroles and stray slabs of pies and cakes.

title: Collins Lost to Bullets
description: The Washington Bullets lost their second starting guard in the last two weeks when Don Collins was found yesterday to have a stress fracture behind the second toe of his left foot. He will be out for five to six weeks. Frank Johnson has a fractured elbow and is not expected back for a month.

title: How Competition Led Houdaille To Ask Trade Curb
description: Like many machine tool makers, Houdaille Industries is caught in the double bind of recession and foreign competition. While it cannot do much about stimulating the economy and demand for its products, the Fort Lauderdale-based industrial conglomerate is attacking a much more palpable target: the Japanese machine tool business.

title: CAESARS WORLD PUTS OFF DECISION TO BUY DUNES
description: Caesars World Inc. failed to reach a decision yesterday on whether to purchase the Dunes Hotel and Country Club in Las Vegas. If it decides to proceed and eventually succeeds in buying the Dunes, it would end an agreement announced earlier this month under which Clifford and Stuart Perlman. former majority stockholders of Caesars World, would purchase the Dunes for $185 million.

title: SLOWER 1983 RISE IN ECONOMY SEEN BY REAGAN AIDES
description: The President's top economic advisers, in preparing next year's budget, have significantly scaled back their forecast for economic growth in 1983, Administration officials said today.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. The Hawks lead the league in shot blocking; the Nets are second. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WVNJ, 620; 7:30 P.M.) Knicks vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Richfield, Ohio. The Knicks, who have beaten Cleveland 14 consecutive times, have a chance to extend the streak to 16 by winning tonight and then at the Garden Thursday night. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M.) College Games: Holiday Festival, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. Brigham Young faces St. Joseph's in the consolation game at 7 P.M., followed by St. John's against Wake Forest for the championship. (Television - MSG Cable, 7 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape); Columbia vs. Georgia, at Atlanta (Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; 8:55 P.M.); Christmas Classic, at Medgar Evers, winners of John Jay vs. Old Westbury and Lebanon Valley vs. Medgar Evers meet for the championship, following the consolation game at 6 P.M.; Christmas Tournament, at Hunter, winners of Oneonta State vs. William Paterson and Yeshiva vs. Hunter meet for the championship, following the consolation game at 5 P.M.; Dolphin Christmas Classic, at College of Staten Island, winners of Castleton State vs. Widener and Staten Island vs. Kean meet for the championship, following the consolation game at 7 P.M. Football Alabama vs. Illinois, Liberty Bowl, at Memphis. In his final game, Coach Paul (Bear) Bryant tries to add to his record of 322 victories.

title: Mortgage Commitments
description: As interest rates dropped, savings and loan associations committed more money for mortgages in November than in any month since the fall of 1980, the Government reported today.

title: Judge Bars Shutdown Of Philadelphia Trains
description: A Common Pleas Court judge granted an injunction today preventing the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority from temporarily halting commuter rail service on Jan. 1.

title: SECRETARY LEWIS QUITS CABINET JOB TO ENTER BUSINESS
description: Drew Lewis resigned today as Secretary of Transportation to return to private business as the head of one of the nation's largest cable television operations.

title: The Ruling On Key Play Hurts Bills
description: It was ruled a muff, not a fumble, and it was the play that shifted dramatically the game between the Miami Dolphins and the Buffalo Bills at the Orange Bowl Monday night.

title: Dokes Will Give Weaver Rematch
description: Michael Dokes will comply with a World Boxing Association order that he meet Mike Weaver in a rematch, Murray Goodman, a spokesman for the champion, said yesterday.

title: BUILDING PACTS RISE
description: The total value of construction contracts awarded, a key barometer of economic activity, rose 16 percent in November as the housing market responded to declining interest rates, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Tidewater Vessels
description: Tidewater Inc. said its Tidewater Marine Service Inc. unit had agreed to buy 11 new offshore oil field support vessels from Halter Marine Inc. for about $33 million. Sam S. Allgood, an executive vice president of Tidewater, a diversified New Orleans-based energy company, said that eight of the vessels were available for immediate delilvery and that the rest would be ready in the first quarter of 1983. Four are 192-foot-long towing-supply vessels with top speeds of 13 knots, and the remainder are 180-foot-long supply vessels.

title: ADDALS OF MEDICID
description: There seemed to be several fish hooks lodged in my throat. All teeth in the upper jaw throbbed with pain, and unaccustomed pressure behind the eyeballs threatened to pop them right out of the skull at any moment. I went to the doctor.

title: AFTERSHOCK OF LAYOFFS HITS LACKAWANNA
description: The death in Lackawanna was a long time coming. But to a person who has known the death of an elderly parent or of a friend who had lain unconscious a long time, the death in Lackawanna, while almost sure to come, was no less shocking, meant no less pain.

title: A Desperation Move
description: Saying he has nothing to lose, Coach Lou Holtz of the Arkansas football team, plans to use his all-America defensive end, Billy Ray Smith, as a field-goal kicker against Florida in the Bluebonnet Bowl at Houston Friday night.

title: PRAB ROBOTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE RIGHT TECHNIQUE IN OPENING CHAMPAGNE
description: The popping of Champagne corks is an evocative sound, symbolic of gaiety and celebration. What many Champagne drinkers don't realize, however, is that expelling a Champagne cork with such force that it rockets through the air like a missile can be dangerous. It is also counterproductive.

title: KOCH SEES EASIER TIMES FOR CITY AFTER ROUGH ONES
description: Mayor Koch surveyed the future from his armchair in City Hall yesterday and saw some rough days ahead, smoother ones beyond that, and a city that could take whatever happened.

title: STAHR IS WINNER
description: Mike Stahr, the best schoolboy miler in the country last year as a junior, ran his first mile of the season today and was an easy winner in 4 minutes 16.66 seconds at the Christmas City Relays at Lehigh University.

title: Mother's Orders
description: Saying she was upset over many poor line calls, the mother of the 15-year-old Bulgarian tennis player Manuela Maleeva ordered her daughter to walk off the court during the finals of the Orange Bowl World Junior Tennis Championships yesterday in Miami Beach.

title: Encore Creditors
description: Encore Industries said three creditors of its Concorde Manufacturing Company subsidiary had filed a Chapter 7 bankruptcy petition against the unit on Dec. 23.

title: BELL'S BLUES, OR ALL ALONE ON THE TELEPHONE
description: LOOK, I don't want to hear one more word about the sad fact that with the invention of the telephone we lost the art of writing letters. It is sad, it is a fact, but we've known it for quite a while now. It's more than a hundred years since Alexander Graham Bell made that first faint call on his wire: ''Please come here, Mr. Watson, I need you.'' Watson, I assume, was a repair man. Anyway, that's all past history except for a new, rather sinister development. It's not bad enough that we don't know how to write letters anymore. Any minute now we won't know how to talk on the telephone. It's true. With the invention of these new, lower-priced answering machines, all charm, all style, all grace is disappearing from phone conversations.

title: Burlington Keeps Its Proration Date
description: Burlington Northern Inc. said a Federal court in Delaware had denied a motion by the El Paso Company that sought to extend the proration date of Burlington's $24-a-share tender offer for 50.7 percent of El Paso's common stock. Burlington said the proration period would run out midnight Thursday, as scheduled.

title: CHRYSLER TO EXPAND PLANT NEAR ST. LOUIS
description: ST. LOUIS. Dec. 28 (AP) - The Chrysler Corporation said today that its plant in Fenton, Mo., would begin production of its new G-24 sports car and other 1984 models in July. The company said it would invest $96 million and create 1,400 to 1,700 jobs at the plant.

title: GULF ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Q&A
description: Q. When dining at a seafood restaurant in Houston, I had a delectable fish listed on the menu as ''mahimahi.'' Are you familiar with this fish?

title: 2 Japanese Hunted on Everest After One Reaches Summit
description: Yasuo Kato, a 33-year-old climber from Japan, and a companion were missing on Mount Everest today, a day after Mr. Kato reached the summit, the Tourism Ministry announced.

title: A NATION MOVED BY 'E.T.' AND ECONOMY
description: For the nation, 1982 was a year that brought triumphs in space and a little magic on earth, along with more than the usual economic troubles. The Columbia space shuttle soared to success, and E.T. provided a make-believe bridge to the unknown.

title: A CATCH-22 FOR PRETORIA'S BLACKS AND A POSSIBLE OUT
description: When the smoke lifted from the 21-gun salute that marked the start of a recent ''summit conference'' here between Prime Minister P.W. Botha and the leaders of four tiny black states that have taken the nominal independence South Africa offers its former tribal reserves, the Government was said to have committed itself to a new development strategy that stressed interdependence rather than separation.

title: POP-BLUES SONGS: ARTHUR PRYSOCK
description: ALTHOUGH he has been performing for three decades, Arthur Prysock, the pop-blues baritone who opened a two-week engagement at Marty's on Monday, is probably best known to the young generation as the mellow-voiced spokesman for Lowenbrau beer. And at his first performance on Monday, he smoothly reprised the commercial that has revitalized his career.

title: Executives See Upturn Coming
description: Business leaders' confidence in the American economy improved again in the fourth quarter of the year, the Conference Board, a business-supported research organization, said yesterday.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1982
description: International Lebanon and Israel opened talks designed to bring about a withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanese soil. Israel also hopes that the negotiations, being held outside Beirut amid tight security, will pave the way for an Israeli-Lebanese peace treaty. (Page A1, Column 1.) Ethnic tension among Israeli Jews has re-emerged over the fatal shooting of a man by a policeman in a housing dispute. The shooting occurred in a Tel Aviv slum dominated by Sephardic Jews from Middle Eastern countries. Officials have received threats, and swastikas and slogans against Ashkenazim, or Jews of European stock, have been spray-painted on cars and buildings in affluent sectors of Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. (A7:1.)

title: QUEEN ELIZABETH PLANS VISIT TO REAGAN RANCH
description: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, will visit President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, at the Reagans' ranch in the mountains outside Santa Barbara next March 1 during the royal couple's 10-day stay on the West Coast, the White House announced today.

title: CHAMPAGNES (WELL, ALMOST) THAT SPARKLE TOO
description: AS New Year's Eve approaches, thoughts automatically turn to Champagne. For some that evening is the only occasion during the year when they drink the world's most popular wine of celebration. But Champagne is expensive and this year, with the economy still in the doldrums, less costly alternatives will be chosen by many celebrants.

title: ARKANSAS EDGES ST. PETER'S
description: Arkansas, unbeaten, nationally ranked and averaging 82.7 points a game, ran into a swarming St. Peter's defense tonight and emerged with a 52-48 victory at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The Razorbacks' eighth victory of the season was not decided until they scored 5 points in the final 10 seconds.

title: Marc Robinson Weds Miss Hammond
description: Frances Ruth Hammond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E.S. Hammond of Wellington, New Zealand, and Lagos, Nigeria, was married yesterday to Marc Seiden Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Z. Robinson of New York. The Rev. John Malcolm performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Anglican Church in Manakau, New Zealand.

title: CLOSING IMPERILS 8,000 EMPLOYED IN RELATED WORK
description: A state economist said today that the shutdown of steelmaking operations at the Lackawanna plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation could result in the loss of 8,000 more jobs in related industries.

title: Outlook Said to Be Improving On Floods in Northern France
description: Hundreds of soldiers and firemen with boats and rescue equipment were on alert today for floods along the lower reaches of the Seine River in northern France, but officials said the outlook was improving.

title: Advertising; Unsung Media Heroes
description: AMONG the unsung heroes of advertising are the ''reps,'' those toilers in the media marketplace who represent out-of-town broadcasting stations, newspapers or magazines in New York, the main trough of national advertising dollars.

title: STATE AGENCY PROPOSED TO OVERSEE CRIMINAL JUSTICE
description: A key Assembly committee chairman proposed yesterday the creation of a criminal-justice agency in New York State to oversee the operation of 10 state programs and review their budgets.

title: LEGAL AID'S LAWYERS REACH TENTATIVE PACT AFTER 9-WEEK STRIKE
description: A tentative agreement to end the nine-week strike by Legal Aid lawyers in New York City was reached last night between representatives of the lawyers and the Legal Aid Society, spokesmen for both sides announced.

title: Mesa's Credits Total $1 Billion
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said that it had bank commitments for credits of $1 billion to be used in part for a pending takeover bid for the General American Oil Company of Texas.

title: NOW, A NEWSLETTER FOR 'INTELLIGENCERS'
description: Thomas F. Troy scoffed at the idea that he had achieved his life's ambition. But it seemed that he had as he sat in the basement of his home, surrounded by books and papers, talking about the reason he started one of Washington's newest and most unusual newsletters, ''Foreign Intelligence Literary Scene.''

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. INTRIGUED BUT UNCERTAIN ON A BULGARIAN TIE TO POPE
description: United States intelligence officials remain intrigued but unconvinced by allegations in Italy that Bulgaria instigated the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II, Administration officials said today.

title: NEW PROPOSALS SEEK TO IMPROVE EMERGENCY CARE
description: Criminal penalties against emergency room doctors and nurses who turn away critically ill patients were proposed yesterday by Mayor Koch and Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Girding for a Strike

title: A NEW LIBEL LAW STIRS PROTEST BY MEXICO PRESS
description: Within days of taking office this month, Mexico's new President, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, moved to carry out an ambitious campaign pledge to end corruption and curb abuses of power by the Government.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Michiko Kakutani SOME PEOPLE. By Harold Nicolson. 175 pages. Atheneum. $6.95.

title: Another Draft
description: While the National Football League prepares for the final week of its strike-interrupted regular season, the United States Football League is finishing plans for its first collegiate draft of players next Tuesday at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Illinois Sales Pitch
description: To Illinois football recruiters, the Liberty Bowl game against Alabama tonight is more than just the Fighting Illini's first postseason appearance in almost two decades. ''We've built everything, our whole recruiting program this year, around the Liberty Bowl,'' said Gary Horton, the university's director of national recruiting.

title: FOR RECORDING GUESTS AND TIME'S FLIGHT; 1. A Festive Guest Book
description: For party givers who might like to start the new year with a fresh guest book, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has published a very handsome one whose cover is a reproduction of the flower print on an early 18th-century Chinese fabric in the museum's collection. Inside, the pages are scattered with copies of French flower etchings of the same period. The book is $14.95 in the museum's gift shop.

title: ELATION AT ECONOMICS MEETING
description: The economy is dismal. But rather than wringing their hands over what they may have done wrong, many of the economists attending the three-day meeting of the American Economics Association were elated. Certain misguided policies, they said, were in the past. Now, the profession, and the country, could return to less flamboyant strategies that might meet with more success.

title: HEAD OF JUVENILE JUSTICE
description: If you cannot write straight, Herbert Sturz decided, you cannot think straight. So, when he was one of New York City's deputy mayors, he would assign an essay topic or two to every job applicant. ''Come back with it in a couple of days,'' he would say.

title: LOS ANGELES INQUIRY ON MARILYN MONROE RULES OUT MURDER
description: Marilyn Monroe either killed herself or accidentally took an overdose of barbiturates, the District Attorney said today after a review of the actress's death in 1962.

title: KENYA AND FLORIDA EXCHANGE JOURNALISTS
description: G.C.M. Mutiso and Michael A. Moscardini do not expect their little experiment in swapping skills to change the world. They will be happy, they say, if it simply makes the newspapers they work for a little better, a little more professional, a little more sensitive to the interests and needs of their readers.

title: Japan Balance Of Payments
description: Japan's overall balance of payments swung to a surplus of about $1.61 billion in November from a deficit of $73 million in October, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: PULITZER HEIR WINS CUSTODY OF 2 SONS
description: Herbert Pulitzer Jr., the millionaire publishing heir, won custody of his twin 5-year-old sons today as a Circuit Court judge awarded less than $50,000 in alimony to Mr. Pulitzer's wife, Roxanne.

title: CORRECTION
description: The TV Weekend column last Friday incorrectly identified the director of CBS's ''Kennedy Center Honors: A Celebration of the Performing Arts.'' He was Don Mischer.

title: Israeli Estimates Direct Cost Of Lebanon War at $1.1 Billion
description: The direct cost of Israel's invasion of Lebanon is estimated at $1.1 billion, the military deputy chief of staff said today.

title: THEATER: 'THE BUTTER AND EGG MAN'
description: CELEBRATED for his theatrical collaborations, George S. Kaufman wrote one comedy by himself, ''The Butter and Egg Man.'' A hit on Broadway in 1925, it is an insider's critique of the make-or-break world of backstage Broadway, where checks bounce as curtains fall. The leading target is an opportunistic producer who will do anything to find ''coin.'' He is especially eager to entrap anyone who is rich and unwary, in the slang of the day, a ''butter and egg man'' from out of town.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Smoke and Glitches

title: U.S.O., Show of Shows
description: There's no business like show business, and no greater audience than service men and women.

title: EUROMISSILE MYTHS
description: Is America trying to ram Pershing 2 and cruise missiles down Europeans' throats? That myth, cultivated by Western European foes of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's plans to install medium-range missiles, has begun to spread on this side of the Atlantic.

title: Egypt Reduces Oil Price Again
description: Egypt, which reduced its oil prices on Dec. 1, announced a second reduction today. An official of the Egyptian General Petroleum Company said the price of the key Suez blend would drop 75 cents a barrel on Jan. 1, to $31.

title: JEWISH CHAPEL AT WEST POINT TO END 'WANDERING IN DESERT'
description: For years, Jewish cadets at the United States Military Academy have had to use classrooms, an auditorium or a nondenominational chapel at the post cemetery to hold religious services. There have long been chapels for the Protestants and Roman Catholics, but none for the Jews.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOBBYISTS

title: OKLAHOMA ENERGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes writedown of $3.1 million due to re-evaluation of estimated recoverable oil and gas reserves

title: Bonn Says 2,392 Have Fled From East Germany This Year
description: West Germany said today that 2,392 East Germans fled to the West this year, using methods that ranged from scaling the Berlin wall to crossing the Baltic Sea in rowboats.

title: HOW ABOUT DIM SUM AT DINNER?
description: SAN FRANCISCO IT is this city's newest look in Chinese restaurants, a sleek, white-walled, brass-railed, ivy-hung former furniture showroom. Called Yank Sing, it serves, of all things, those traditional Chinese breakfast dumplings called dim sum for dinner.

title: LASTINGER WINS FOR GEORGIA
description: John Lastinger, the Georgia quarterback, has never lost a game that he started at that position in high school or in college. His counterpart in the 49th Sugar Bowl Saturday night, Todd Blackledge of Penn State, has also been a big winner, with 28 victories and four defeats since he became the Nittany Lions' starting quarterback in 1980.

title: PROPAGANDA WAR RAGES IN U.N. ON DISARMAMENT
description: The flood of disarmament resolutions pouring out of the General Assembly, 60 in the latest session alone, are largely regarded by the United States and the Soviet Union as weapons in a battle for public opinion.

title: Retirement Incentives
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board yesterday approved a draft of a proposal that would require companies that offer a group of employees inducements to retire early to record such payments in the current accounting period, regardless of when they are paid.

title: CUOMO'S BANKING NOMINEE
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would appoint Vincent Tese, a general partner in a Wall Street brokerage house, as the state's Superintendent of Banks.

title: BLIZZARD HITS MIDDLE WEST, ISOLATING CITIES UNDER FOOT OF SNOW
description: A ferocious storm churning its way eastward from the Rockies buried many cities in the Middle West under more than a foot of snow today, sending stranded motorists scurrying for shelter from winds of up to 70 miles an hour.

title: 6 Arrested in MX Protest At Massachusetts Plant
description: Six protesters, including a Roman Catholic priest, were arrested on trespassing charges after pouring blood in the form of a cross outside an electronics plant whose employees were working on the MX missile today.

title: ETHNIC CONFLICT ERUPTS IN ISRAEL
description: Some of the worst ethnic tension in years among Israeli Jews has erupted in the wake of a fatal shooting by policemen in the Tel Aviv slum district of Kfar Shalem.

title: METS' ZACHRY TRADED
description: With the hint of more moves to come, the Mets obtained Jorge Orta, a left-handed-hitting outfielder, from the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday for Pat Zachry, the last survivor of the 1977 trade that sent Tom Seaver to Cincinnati.

title: A MASTER CHEF CREATES A MEMORABLE MEAL
description: OVER the past 20 years or so it has been my good fortune to interview many of the finest chefs from France in my kitchen - Paul Bocuse, Roger Verge, Gaston Lenotre, Jean Troisgros and Alain Chapel, among others - and to watch them cook. Almost without exception the food they have prepared has been faultless. It has ranged from the sensual (Mr. Chapel's mousse of chicken livers with lobster sauce) to the simply sublime (Roger Verge's oysters with orange butter and Jean Troisgros's veal piccata with mustard seeds).

title: ROCK: 3 BANDS ON A SINGLE BILL
description: THE avant-garde Kitchen turned into something like a rock club this week, presenting 12 bands on four triple bills. The opening concert of the series ended shortly after three policemen arrived; the Kitchen's SoHo neighbors, for blocks around, had complained about the noise being made by the Swans.

title: Bridge: Barbara Kachmar's Satire Will Live Long in Memory
description: One of the most entertaining writers in the history of the game was lost to the bridge world recently when Barbara Kachmar died in California.

title: French Train
description: France has set up a company to market its ultramodern ''bullet train,'' the TGV, in the United States, French national railroad officials said. It will open an office in New York early next year in a bid to capture the multibillion-dollar market for high-speed trains developing on the East Coast of the United States, the officials said. The TGV began service at speeds of up to 162 miles an hour in France last year.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan's top economic advisers scaled back their forecast for economic growth in 1983 in preparing the next fiscal year's budget, Administration officials said. The projected increase in the gross national project, after adjustment for inflation, is now below 2 percent for the year; in September a preliminary forecast had put it at 3.1 percent. The new forecast means that revenue will be less than had been anticipated and that spending to help the jobless and needy will be greater. (Page A1.)

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
New Duties for Chief At MGM/UA Home
description: Seymour Leslie started out last April as head of a division of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company. The division has now gone public and Mr. Leslie finds himself in charge of a Big Board company.

title: HEI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr earnings have been restated for a 6-for-5 stock split payable Jan 12, 1983

title: Pepsico Support
description: Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of the Philippines, a subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., said it would immediately receive $40 million from the parent company. A spokesman for the unit said the move was an effort to strengthen its ability to serve customers. The announcement was made by Darrel Agee, Philippine branch president, who replaced Cosme de Aboitiz after Pepsico said that some of its foreign subsidiaries, including the Philippine unit, had overstated profits and understated liabilities.

title: Cures for Car Choking
description: The Mayor of New York is fed up, again, with illegally parked cars in midtown. He proposes, again, to ask the Legislature to raise the maximum fine from $50 to $100. He has suppressed the clinical histories of his previous indigestions, but we hope Mr. Koch recovers less quickly this time.

title: Big East Decides Not to Expand
description: The Big East Conference does not plan to add a 10th team after this basketball season, a decision disappointing to Holy Cross College, an independent that has been seeking league affiliation.

title: ATTEMPTING TO SAVE A STEEL PRODUCER
description: After the McLouth Steel Corporation filed a bankruptcy petition a year ago, nearly everyone thought the Detroitbased supplier to the auto industry would fade away.

title: Shooting Touch And Poetic Touch
description: When Fran Greenberg, the public relations director of the Continental Basketball Association, recently asked Coach Tom Meschery of the Reno Bighorns for some verse that might capture the spirit of the C.B.A., Meschery winced. He would have much preferred to discuss the league's innovative scoring system of awarding 1 point for each quarter won during a game and 3 points for a victory.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $257,000 for the qr and $266,000 for the 6mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $64,000 for the qr and $91,000 for the 6 mos and extraordinary credits of $168,000 for the qr and $220,000for the 6 mos

title: RIOTING IN A BLACK AREA OF MIAMI FOLLOWS A SHOOTING BY THE POLICE
description: At least seven people were reported injured tonight in a two-hour clash between scores of black youths and the police that began when a 21-year-old man was shot and critically wounded by police officers in the predominantly black Overtown section.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including income of $1,369,000 from discontinued operations; the shr earningsgive effect to a 5 percent stock divd paid in November

title: The Campaign for Governor Is Over
description: What's on Trial Is How Best to Pick Judges

title: ORWELL IN WASHINGTON
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The United States believes strongly that the legitimate security interests of Israel should be addressed and satisfied to the maximum extent possible.

title: Ban on Seabrook Unit 2 Lifted
description: The New Hampshire Supreme Court on Monday reversed an order that had indefinitely delayed construction of a second reactor at the $5.12 billion Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: Heart Patient Is Showing Continued Improvement
description: Approaching a New Year no one expected him to see, Dr. Barney B. Clark, the first human to receive a permanent artificial heart, showed continued improvement, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Careers; Air Force Attractive In a Slump
description: THERE is one big business so little affected by the recession that it is still hiring - the Air Force. Brig. Gen. Scott Harpe, 45 years old, a flier who is commander of the Air Force Recruiting Service, says, ''The recession has had a good impact on our recruiting.'' In an interview, he said that not only have more men and women applied to the services but the quality of applicants has also improved. General Harpe has 4,000 people in his recruiting unit worldwide.

title: SETTLEMENT ON O.P.M. REPORTED
description: Five companies associated with O.P.M. Leasing Services Inc. tentatively agreed to settle litigation arising from O.P.M.'s fraudulent activities, lawyers and investment bankers involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Military Analysis
description: The recommissioning of the battleship New Jersey, while satisfying to battleship buffs and military contractors, raises a question basic to the American security posture: Is this a step forward or backward?

title: UNITED OVERTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sprucing Up in Brooklyn

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: People in New York walk as though they know just where they're going: heads up, backs straight. Through the side streets and the avenues they cut a quick swath. Then there are the others, the ones who shuffle away an hour on street corners, or saunter back and forth on one block, or walk slowly and uncertainly, as though they are moving through strange waters.

title: Sweden Cites Intrusion By More Than One Sub
description: Sweden has information showing that more than one submarine lurked on the seabed south of here in October during a monthlong search, a military spokesman said today.

title: GIANTS FIND LAPSES PUZZLING
description: The Giants lost to the St. Louis Cardinals last Sunday on a touchdown with 27 seconds left in the game, after they had taken the lead with 67 seconds left. The week before, they lost to the Washington Redskins on a field goal with four seconds left.

title: A NIGHT OF SLAUGHTER IN MASERU, LESOTHO
description: To the Editor:

title: AS WOMEN'S VERY REAL POWER AT THE POLLS BECOMES VISIBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brass-Craft Manufacturing Co., Detroit, has elected Fred Hyman vice president, manufacturing.

title: Fire Kills 10 in Korean Hotel
description: A fire raced through a six-story tourist hotel today in Taegu, South Korea's third largest city, killing at least 10 people and injuring 15, the police said. Initial reports put the death toll at 11 and indicated that a Japanese was among the victims, but these could not be confirmed.

title: BRIEFING
description: 2 'Old America Hands'

title: FUSION REACTOR AT PRINCETON PASSES FIRST TEST
description: The flagship of American efforts to harness nuclear fusion, the process that makes the sun shine, was officially launched today with an announcement that the giant Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor here had been turned on for the first time and worked as intended.

title: Top Pentagon Aide Joining Sears Unit
description: Frank C. Carlucci, Deputy Defense Secretary, has joined Sears, Roebuck & Company as president and chief operating officer of its new trading unit, Sears World Trade Inc.

title: Youth Held in Fire Killing 25
description: A teen-ager accused of setting a fire in September that killed 25 people pleaded not guilty on Monday to murder and arson charges. The teen-ager, Humberto Diaz de la Torre, 19 years old, was arraigned on 25 counts of murder, three counts of arson and one count of burglary.

title: OILERS WIN, 4-3, FROM RUSSIANS
description: In a game that started slowly but burst into brilliance in the third period, the Edmonton Oilers defeated a Soviet all-star team, 4-3, tonight before a sellout crowd of 17,498 at the Northlands Coliseum.

title: Oil Data Delayed
description: The American Petroleum Institute said today that it will delay its weekly report on fuel production and inventories until Thursday because of the Christmas holiday. The report is normally released on Wednesday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AAR Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., said Synalloy Corp. and its chairman, Barry Cohen, had increased their holdings of AAR common stock to 420,007 shares, or 10.7 percent.

title: STAGE: CARYL CHURCHILL'S 'TOP GIRLS,' AT THE PUBLIC
description: IN the long-running ''Cloud 9,'' her first play to be seen in New York, the English playwright Caryl Churchill turned our usually wellordered theatrical universe topsy-turvy. She sent her cast leaping in and out of two centuries and continents, three genders and even one another's roles. Whatever the effort's flaws, it was always the product of a strikingly original and supple imagination. You could feel the author's bracing determination to liberate both the theater and the audience from every esthetic and sexual shackle in sight.

title: Bonn Says 2,392 Fled East Germany in 1982
description: West Germany said today that 2,392 East Germans fled to the West this year, using methods that ranged from scaling the Berlin wall to crossing the Baltic Sea in rowboats.

title: Salvador Rebels Kill 7 In Attack on Bridge
description: Rebels killed a woman and wounded six soldiers today in an attempt to blow up a key bridge in eastern Usulutan Province, local officials said.

title: AWESOME CHALLENGES REMAIN FOR FUSION SCIENTISTS
description: With the starting up of an advanced fusion energy machine at Princeton University, scientists have reached an important checkpoint in one of the most difficult technological challenges ever undertaken.

title: Billy Joel Serenades the Dark Side
description: ''WHEN I make an album, I usually try to do something totally different,'' Billy Joel said the other day. And true to his word the 33-year-old singer, who will be performing tonight at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., and on New Year's Eve at Madison Square Garden, has indeed shifted gears on his latest album, ''The Nylon Curtain.'' With its use of sound effects, aural montage, exotic orchestration, and thickly overdubbed vocals, ''The Nylon Curtain''is a far cry from the pared-down rock of ''Glass Houses'' and harks back to the late 60's psychedelia of the Beatles.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES RISE A BIT
description: Short-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday, despite an attempt by the Federal Reserve to increase the liquidity of the banking system, a move that usually depresses short-term rates. Prices of long-term fixed-income securities closed essentially unchanged after some weakness early in the day.

title: Mediation Is Reported For P.L.O. and Israelis
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria said today that he was mediating an exchange of prisoners between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization

title: GROUP ASSERTS PICTURE IS OF MODEL, NOT OF ETAN PATZ
description: A recently found photograph that the police have said resembles Etan Patz was published in a 1968 calendar and is not a picture of the boy who disappeared here three years ago, a group called the North American Man-Boy Love Association asserted yesterday.

title: PRIDE SPURS A HAITIAN IN TENNIS
description: Standing on the victory podium at the Central American and Caribbean Games last August, Ronald Agenor heard the national anthem of Haiti bouncing off the walls of the Luano Tennis Club in Cuba. At first they were just notes, he said, and then the notes became a song and the song became his pride. And the pride showed in the corner of his eye, with a tear.

title: Bauer Captures Australian Event
description: Mike Bauer, a 21-year-old Californian, used a strong service to defeat Chris Johnstone today, 4-6, 7-6, 6-2, and win the South Australian Open tennis tournament.

title: JOHN C. WISTER, 95, HORTICULTURIST
description: John C. Wister, one of the nation's most highly honored horticulturists, died yesterday at his home in Swarthmore, Pa. He was 95 years old.

title: PROFESSIONALS FIND CRITICISM COMES WITH POWER
description: Carey P. Modlin, one of the career officials who play a vital backstage role at the Office of Management and Budget, was talking about how the agency curbs spending by the rest of the executive branch of Government, in the name of the President.

title: CANADA, 'IN AND OUT'
description: ''You have a heavy burden in this city, Sondra,'' a friendly socialite called Popsie said. ''Canada is just not chic.''

title: 'Glamour Is What You Make Of It'
description: E ven with a sore throat and only enough strength to perform a few pirouettes and glissades in front of his bench, Lou Carnesecca still has enough energy to prod his players.

title: CHASE LOWERS PRIME RATE TO 11%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, the country's third-largest bank, lowered its prime lending rate yesterday from 11 1/2 percent to 11 percent, the lowest level in more than two years.

title: SEOUL OPPOSITION LEADER ASKS END OF BAN ON 580 POLITICIANS
description: A prominent opposition leader has urged that the South Korean Government lift a ban on some 580 politicians at once to restore ''elementary freedoms and democracy to the people of South Korea.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Wine Without Additives

title: LAW OF THE SEA: THE CORRECT U.S. RESPONSE
description: To the Editor:

title: CHARLES P. LEFFEL
description: Charles P. Leffel, a former president and chief executive officer of the Sunbeam Corporation, died Sunday while vacationing in Mexico.

title: EFFORT TO RAISE DRINKING AGE IN JERSEY UNITES DIVERSE GROUP
description: At first glance, they seemed unlikely confederates - a housewife, a policeman, a dentist and a private investigator. They had small change for a budget, and political experience to match.

title: NBC SHAPES STRATEGY TO KEEP 'ST. ELSEWHERE'
description: Two years ago, NBC defied the rules of prime-time television by staying with a low-rated series about an inner-city police precinct called ''Hill Street Blues.'' The series, highly praised by the critics, went on to win a record eight Emmy awards, and the following year became one of the network's most popular shows.

title: LEBANESE MEET WITH THE ISRAELIS SOUTH OF BEIRUT
description: Lebanese and Israeli negotiators opened talks in this battered seaside town today with Lebanon hoping to achieve the withdrawal of foreign forces from its soil and Israel hoping to pave the way for a peace treaty with its northern neighbor.

title: U. of Mississippi's First Black Is Seeking Job at the School
