description: James Meredith, who broke the color barrier at the University of Mississipi, says he has applied for a teaching or administrative position at the school to carry out his plan for the reunification of black people.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Ground and Air Clashes
description: Iran and Iraq reported heavy ground and air fighting today along their battlefront. Iraq said its forces had killed 111 Iranian soldiers and shot down an Iranian jet fighter.

title: HIT DRAMA 'PLENTY' MOVES UPTOWN TO BROADWAY
description: Three days before ''Plenty'' opened at the Public Theater in October, David Hare, the playwright and director, decided that the star needed a new coat for one scene.

title: MILLER, HENRY S, REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $4,896,411 for the qr and $4,977,820 for the 9 mos, charges for advisor's fees on the sale of real estate of $489,641 for the qr and $497,782 for the 9 mos and a provision of $275,000 for theqr and 9 mos...C-Including gains on the sale of real estate $26,703 for the qr and $807,014 for the 9 mos

title: Loan to Raiders Arouses Concern
description: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors requested today that county officials study the contract between the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission and the football Raiders.

title: No Headline
description: VANDERBILT HANDS MANHATTAN FIRST LOSS

title: Three Navy Fliers Die In Crash of Practice Jet
description: A Navy jet crashed near this Whidbey Island community this afternoon, killing all three fliers aboard. They were practicing touch-and-go landings at an airfield, the authorities said.

title: A Vote of Support
description: Patrick Sullivan, assistant general manager of the New England Patriots and son of the team's owner, William Sullivan, says the club's management supports its rookie coach, Ron Meyer, despite the highly publicized criticism from some of his players. ''I'm having no second thoughts at all,'' the younger Sullivan said of the offseason decision to bring in Meyer from Southern Methodist, ''and I know my father's having no second thoughts. The guy is a really good football coach, and he has his record in taking teams that were losing teams and making them winners.''

title: Coast Jews Bid Vatican Oust West German Aide
description: A Jewish group in Los Angeles is demanding that the Vatican dismiss as a newly appointed financial adviser a prominent West German banker who it says served the Nazis as one of the key banking officials in the Third Reich.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Gentle Tradition

title: No Headline
description: U.C.L.A. WINS ON LATE RALLY

title: Support Gained In Bid for Reade
description: Michael S. Landes and Albert Schwartz, co-chairmen of RKO Century Warner Theaters, said yesterday that Columbia Pictures, a unit of the Coca Cola Company, agreed to support their effort to acquire control of the Walter Reade Organization Inc. Mr. Landes and Mr. Schwartz own 11.1 percent of Reade shares and Columbia holds 30.9 percent.

title: RECONSIDER THE MISSILES
description: Reacting with one of those hostile jerks of the knee so characteristic of its approach toward relations with Moscow, the Reagan Administration last week rejected as ''unacceptable'' Soviet leader Yuri V. Andropov's offer to limit the number of mediumrange missiles that the Kremlin has aimed at Western Europe to the number of British and French missiles aimed at the Soviet Union.

title: THOUGHTS OF ELDERLY BRING CONTRIBUTIONS TO FUND THE NEEDIEST
description: ''Never as much as this year are the elderly needy worthy of increased support, and I would like the enclosed donation to be used for those unfortunates who are grossly neglected,'' Gertrude B. Prins of Manhattan wrote in a letter accompanying a $100 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: News Analysis
description: At midterm, the once-dazzling political momentum of what conservatives enthusiastically called the Reagan Revolution has stalled. In the year ahead, President Reagan faces what his allies and advisers see as the most critical tests of his Presidency both at home and abroad.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.00-11.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Another Changing of the Guards for Nets
description: The most encouraging spell of what has been a frustrating season for Mike O'Koren came to a shattering end Monday night when he went sprawling to the court just before halftime during the Nets' game against Cleveland. Attempting to block a fast-break lay-in by Cleveland's Geoff Huston, O'Koren came down and landed on his right wrist.

title: A WORKING VACATION WEEKEND AT A FRENCH FARM
description: LADORNAC, France DANY DUBOIS opened wide the doors to her rambling, contemporary French farmhouse and called to her noontime arrivals: ''You're just in time for lunch. Come on in and make yourself at home.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Don King, the boxing promoter, announced the scheduling of two fights: Juan LaPorte will defend the World Boxing Council's featherweight championship against Ruben Castillo Feb. 20 at a site to be determined, and Leon Spinks will face Carlos DeLeon March 6, also at an undetermined site. ... Jack Rudnay, the veteran center for the Kansas City Chiefs, confirmed that he would retire after the team's season finale this weekend.

title: HARRY HOROWITZ
description: Harry Horowitz, a former textile manufacturer in Manhattan, died Monday at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: U.S. BOARD ENTERS RAIL WAGE DISPUTE IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The National Mediation Board, in an unexpected move, announced yesterday that it would intervene in the labor dispute involving the commuter rail lines to New York City's northern suburbs.

title: CUOMO REQUESTS GREATER LEEWAY TO SELECT JUDGES
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that he would ask the Legislature to enact changes in the method of selecting judges for the state's highest court.

title: TRADE GAP NARROWED LAST MONTH
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit narrowed to $4.1 billion in November, from $5.3 billion in October, the Government reported today. But for all of 1982, the deficit seems certain to exceed the 1978 record of $42.4 billion.

title: AID IN REBUILDING, NOT DESTABILIZING, CAMBODIA
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: AFGHAN REBELS SAY THEY INFLICTED HEAVY DAMAGE ON AIRPORT

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Insulated Wire Co., Bellmawr, N.J., has appointed Roger Hall executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I intend to go right on living. That may come as a disappointment to some.''

title: New York Fed Picks Directors
description: Alfred Brittain 3d, chairman of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, was elected a director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday, succeeding Gordon T. Wallis, chairman of the Irving Trust Company.

title: Israeli Army Declares A Reporter Unwelcome
description: The office of the Israeli Army spokesman has indicated that the state television's acting military correspondent, Dan Scemama, will not be welcome at a news conference with the retiring commander of the air force, Maj. Gen. David Ivri. In response, other military correspondents told the military command here that they would prefer not to participate in the conference at this time.

title: THE DILEMMA OF EXECUTIVE PRIVILEGE
description: When the House of Representatives formed a committee in 1792 to examine the failure of a military campaign against the Indians and called for the President, George Washington, to supply information, it touched off the first of many disputes over the right of the executive branch to refuse to share its knowledge with Congress.

title: Bridge: A German Expert Depends On the Skill of His Partner
description: There are very few active players who can remember what international tournaments were like before World War II. One of them is B. Jay Becker of New York, who at 78 was the oldest player in the recent world championships in Biarritz, France.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
'BAMA'S BOYS
description: In 1958, Paul ''Bear'' Bryant became head football coach at the University of Alabama, and promised, ''I ain't nothing but a winner.'' That same year, George C. Wallace lost his first gubernatorial election and promised, ''Boys, I'm not going to be outniggered again.'' Both were true to their word.

title: Saudi Talks on I.M.F.
description: The British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Geoffrey Howe, will visit Saudi Arabia on Jan. 8 for talks with Saudi officials on increasing that country's loans to the International Monetary Fund, British officials said here today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BUDDHAS

title: PIONEER WHO CHANGED FACE OF BRITISH GARDENING
description: LONDON ''SMITH'S place is the admiration of all the country; and it was a mere nothing before Repton took it in hand. I think I shall have Repton.'' So declares the rich and eligible bachelor Mr. Rushworth in Jane Austen's ''Mansfield Park,'' in discussing plans for improving Sotherton, his family estate.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-After a loss of $17,000 for the qr and yr...C-After a loss of $129,000 for the qr and a gain of $73,000 for the yr from discontinued operations

title: ALABAMA WINS IN BRYANT FINALE
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant hesitated briefly before entering the blue and white striped tent, studying the sight of dozens of reporters and photographers who had come to chronicle his last game. More than once during the fourth quarter of tonight's Liberty Bowl, Bryant said he realized this was indeed the end, and now the thought had struck him again.

title: Advertising; Executives See Tough First Half
description: AT the end of 1974, a really horrible year, Stanley Tannenbaum, then chairman of Kenyon & Eckhardt, was asked what he was looking for in the coming year. ''Worry beads,'' he answered.

title: Midlantic Banks
description: Midlantic Banks Inc. said its board had agreed in principle to acquire the Greater Jersey Bancorp for $36 a share in cash and stock, creating New Jersey's largest commercial banking corporation, with assets exceeding $5.35 billion. Based on 2,202,000 Greater Jersey shares outstanding, the transaction would be worth $72.8 million.

title: Susan Jenkins Brown, Editor Who Wrote About Hart Crane
description: Susan Jenkins Brown, an author and editor, died yesterday at a nursing home in Highland, N.Y. She was 86 years old. Mrs. Brown, who was born in Pittsburgh, worked as a book editor for many years. She wrote about her memories of Hart Crane and the New York literary circle in ''Robber Rocks,'' published by Wesleyan University Press in 1969.

title: Dennard Comes Back
description: Kenny Dennard says he is ready to return to the Kansas City Kings after a bout with cancer. Dennard, a former Duke star, had a growth removed from his abdomen in September and followed the surgery with radiation treatments.

title: SOLOMON KREITMAN, MEDIATOR WITH STATE'S MEDIATION BOARD
description: Solomon Kreitman, a mediator with the State Mediation Board for the last 13 years, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 72 years old.

title: St. John's Takes Its 6th Holiday Festival
description: Forty-two seconds into the second half last night David Russell scored on a layup from the low post. He went on to score six more baskets in the half to lead St. John's to a 72-65 victory over Wake Forest in the final of the Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.

title: Appointment Is Criticized
description: A Jewish organization said today it had asked that a leading German banker resign his post on a Vatican bank advisory board because of his reported role in the Third Reich.

title: UNION PANEL ADVISES LEGAL AID STRIKERS TO ACCEPT TENTATIVE PACT
description: The executive committee of the union representing Legal Aid Society lawyers in New York City voted yesterday to recommend acceptance of a tentative agreement to end a 10-week strike.

title: JUDGE PUTS TEAMSTER AGENTS IN RECEIVERSHIP
description: A Federal judge today put in receivership and froze the assets of Allen Dorfman and his insurance company, which handles the Central States health and welfare fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: International Recruit
description: Jacek Duda, the 6-foot-10-inch basketball player who slipped away from the touring Polish national team last month to join his parents in Rhode Island, has signed a letter of intent to play with Providence College. Although Duda was a seldom-used reserve with the Polish team, he was recruited by at least 24 college coaches, including Maryland's Lefty Driesell and Marquette's Hank Raymonds. ''From all indications,'' said Coach Joe Mullaney of Providence, ''the young man has some potential and could play for us.''

title: NATIONAL MORTGAGE FUND reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes an extraordinary charge of $13,374 from sale of real estate, a $10,157 gain from purchase of notes and tax credit of $12,000...C-Includes extra credit of $1,317, a gain from purchase of notes of $154,037 and tax credit of $478,000...D-Inc ludes extraordinary charge of $22,903, a $49,178 gain from the purchase of notes and a $85,500 tax credit...E-Includes credit of $10,865 from gain from the sale of real estate, a $154,037 gain from the purchase of notes and a $500,600 tax credit

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Pierson M. Grieve, formerly president and chief executive of the Questor Corporation, was elected chairman and chief executive of Economics Laboratory Inc., a maker of chemical cleaners and sanitizers.

title: China Asks Coal Bids
description: China is inviting foreign businesses to invest in 10 projects to develop coal, China's major source of energy, the New China News Agency said today. The projects are valued at more than $3 billion. The agency noted that an agreement was signed earlier this year between China and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation on a feasibility study for developing a mine in north China's Shanxi province.

title: Topics; 1492, 1982, 1984; Bumping Into America
description: There are days when one is reminded that no adult, however gray or sparse the locks, is ever far from the schoolyard. Such a day was Dec. 21, when the U.N. General Assembly sought to hail 1992 as the 500th anniversary of Columbus's discovery of America.

title: Kean and 7 Mayors Discuss Taxes
description: Governor Kean met with seven urban mayors today to gather support for a tax package to avert $150 million in state budget cuts due to take effect next week.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; U.S. Bars 2 Cubans From Philosophy Talks

title: BELL COMPANY'S EQUIPMENT CHALLENGE
description: The Southern New England Telephone Company, 23 percent owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said it would enter the telecommunications equipment business outside of its home state of Connecticut, a move that will make it the first Bell System company to compete against A.T.& T. in equipment sales.

title: No Headline
description: Forgotten Americans A sign in a Veterans Administration Hospital reads, ''The Price of Freedom Is Visible Here,'' and the U.S.O. has not forgotten the men and women who have fought for the nation. The friendly smile of a volunteer and the red, white and blue U.S.O. banner make the Vietnam veterans in the 12 V.A. hospitals in the metropolitan area as well as the servicemen from World War I and World War II feel that their sacrifices are appreciated.

title: No Headline
description: Hawks Top Oilers

title: Virginia Electric To Sell Part of Unit
description: The Virginia Electric and Power Company said it had signed a final agreement to sell portions of its North Anna nuclear power station to the Old Dominion Electric Cooperative for about $265 million.

title: Telephone Campaign Starts on Bowl Games
description: Three bowl games Saturday will serve to introduce the new advertising campaign for the recently created Business Long Distance unit of American Telephone and Telegraph Long Lines.

title: Millrose Games Sold Out Already
description: Indoor track and field meets may be disappearing at an alarming rate, but the Wanamaker Millrose Games continues to grow in popularity. Yesterday, Howard Schmertz, the Millrose director, reported that all tickets -more than 17,000 - for the Jan. 28 meet at Madison Square Garden had been sold. It was the earliest sellout in Millrose history.

title: Record Insurance On 1984 Olympics
description: The American Broadcasting Companies, which has radio and television rights to the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, has bought a $200 million insurance policy to protect itself from financial losses should the Games be changed in a manner that could affect ratings.

title: Technology; Toxic Waste Disposal
description: AS public fear mounts over industrial waste buried in landfills, and as regulation of the construction of landfills is toughened, many companies are investing heavily in new technologies for waste disposal.

title: NEIGHBORS CAN'T OVERLOOK SOVIET CONSULATE
description: In this city, where the standard joke of real estate agents is that the three things to look for when investing in property are views, views and views, the hasty construction of a ''penthouse'' has angered neighbors living around the Soviet Consulate.

title: MONEY: DEFINITION AND CONTROL
description: Money, according to the master of ceremonies in the musical ''Cabaret,'' is what makes the world go round. Milton Friedman, who has a Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, agrees, at least up to a point.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.00-11.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 'E.T.' Setting Records At British Box Office
description: After a record-breaking run in the United States, ''E.T.'' seems set to become the biggest box-office hit in British film history.

title: Mine Closing In Zimbabwe
description: Zimbabwe's recession-hit mining industry lost 1,180 jobs today when Rio Tinto announced that its Empress Nickel Mine would close at the end of the month.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Allison Rolls On
description: Glenn Allison says he intends to take the American Bowling Congress to court to win approval of the perfect 900 series that he bowled in league play last summer and that the A.B.C. has refused to sanction, contending that the lanes were excessively oiled. Meanwhile, Allison will enter the first Professional Bowlers Association tour event of the season, the $135,000 Miller High Life Classic in Anaheim, Calif., Jan. 12-15.

title: Television Actress Is Robbed And Assaulted, Police Report
description: Diane McBain, the television actress who portrays Foxy Humdinger on the soap opera ''Days of Our Lives,'' was robbed, raped and beaten by two men who assaulted her in her garage on Christmas morning, the police reported.

title: Penney Unit Sold
description: Time Inc.'s Lumberman's Investment Corporation said it had purchased the Great American Reserve Insurance Company from the J.C. Penney Company for $76 million, as part of a program to develop additional financial services. Great American has assets of $215 million and an estimated premium volume of $72 million for 1982.

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After tax credits of $108,950 for the latest qr and $57,977 for the yr-earlier period...C-Including tax credits of $719,200 for the latest yr and $400,700 for the previous yr

title: Peru Is Sending Army Against Andes Rebels
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry today ordered the armed forces to take control of three provinces in the Andes that have been wracked by Maoist guerrilla violence.

title: Agenor Advances
description: Ron Agenor of Haiti, playing with a back problem, won two matches today and reached the boys' 18 quarterfinals of the Rolex international junior championships at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: OFFICE POOL FOR 1983
description: In last year's Office Pool, I was prescient about the rate of unemployment, the comeback of Bert Lance and the split in the Atlantic alliance, but prescient little else.

title: Miss Sheehan's 66 Leads by a Shot
description: Patty Sheehan, among five women competing in the $150,000 Spalding Invitational, posted a five-under-par 66 to take the first-round lead by one shot today.

title: Rainier and ONB Call Off Merger
description: The Rainier Bancorporation and the ONB Corporation have called off a merger that would have produced the second-largest bank in the state after Seafirst, executives of the two holding companies said, because negotiators ''were unable to reach a final, definitive merger agreement acceptable to both parties.''

title: Deukmejian Balks Brown On Appointing 4 Judges
description: California's Governor-elect used his vote on a state commission today to block four appeals court appointments by departing Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. It was the first time since 1940 the panel had rejected a Governor's nominee.

title: CRUISE OPERATORS IN FLORIDA FACING DECLINE IN GROWTH
description: While the number of passengers taking shipboard vacations continues to grow, cruise operators say the industry will have to lure even more vacationers - and more first-time passengers - if the cruise business is to maintain the growth of the last two decades.

title: DREYFUS REVIEW SET
description: The Federal Reserve Board gave notice today that it would review the Dreyfus Corporation's acquisition of a small New Jersey Bank, despite Dreyfus's contention that it has taken Lincoln State of East Orange out of the Fed's jurisdiction.

title: 5 Jets Selected for A.F.C. Pro Bowl Team
description: Five players for the Jets, including Freeman McNeil, the National Football League's leading rusher, have been voted by rival players and coaches onto the American Conference's squad for the Pro Bowl.

title: HERS
description: IREMEMBER how she looked on the TV screen - a perfectly groomed, calm-voiced woman. Her softly Southern tones were controlled and even, betraying no tremor of the internal shock her father's words must have produced in her.

title: DOW INCHES UP 0.73 TO 1,059.60
description: The stock market closed slightly higher yesterday in slower trading as increasing concern over interest rates and the economy kept many investors on the sidelines.

title: New Zealand Seeking More of Lamb Market
description: Annual per capita consumption of lamb in the United States is a pound and a half, compared with 77.2 pounds of beef. Do you think that makes the lamb producers happy?

title: Driver Charged In Robbing Sisters
description: The driver of van has been arrested and charged with robbing two elderly sisters after driving them home from a hospital in the Bronx.

title: WHERE ARE THEY NOW?
description: It was a sensational revelation. During World War II Franklin Roosevelt was in secret and frequent communication with Earl Browder, the Communist leader. A trusted intermediary carried messages back and forth between them. She was Josephine Truslow Adams, a former college art teacher, who in her role met the President nearly 40 times at Hyde Park and the White House.

title: A.T.& T. to Cut Construction Bill
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it planned to cut construction spending 2 percent next year, to $16.8 billion. Among other reasons, it cited a decision by the Federal Communications Commission that shifted responsibility for purchasing and providing new on-premise equipment from the Bell operating companies to American Bell, the new A.T.& T. subsidiary, as of Jan. 1.

title: CAREY'S FAREWELL IS NOT GOODBYE TO SPEAKING OUT
description: Hugh L. Carey bade farewell to the Capitol today with a final slap at the Legislature, some advice for the press and the disclosure of one last bit of self-described political ''mischief.''

title: HOW TO PROTECT A SMALL BUSINESS FROM A GREEDY LANDLORD
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL GALLERY IS GIVEN 9 PAINTINGS
description: The National Gallery of Art has announced the acquisition of nine major American and French paintings, eight of them from the private collection of John Hay Whitney, the late publisher of the now-defunct New York Herald Tribune and former United States Ambassador to Britain.

title: Books Of The Times
description: GENDER. By Ivan Illich. 192 pages. Pantheon. $11.95.

title: SECTOR SEALED OFF
description: After a day of sporadic vandalism, car-burning and stone-throwing, a poor, largely black neighborhood north of downtown was tonight declared ''a restricted area'' by Miami's City Manager.

title: WINDS BLACK OUT BUFFALO AREA
description: A windstorm Tuesday night and early today tore down tree limbs and cut off power to several thousand homes and businesses in the Buffalo area. The winds subsided later in the day.

title: SKIERS AND RESORT OPERATORS RESIGNED TO SNOWLESS HOLIDAY
description: With the New Year weekend approaching and not a flake of snow on the ground, Maurice Dennis decided it was time to do his dance. Mr. Dennis, a 74-year-old Abenaki Indian and a lifelong resident of Old Forge, N.Y., donned headdress, mukluks and other traditional garb and led a large crowd to the Christmas tree in the center of the community, whose economy depends on an annual influx of skiers and snowmobilers, where he called on the Great Spirit.

title: LINEBACKER SHOWS RESPECT
description: NEW ORLEANS T he name has been mentioned so often, and for so long, that when Ken Kelley heard the first reference to Herschel Walker yesterday afternoon, he smiled. It was a sly smile.

title: Barter With East Urged
description: Western companies will have to accept more deals with the Communist world involving payment in goods rather than in cash if East-West trade is to flourish, a senior United Nations official said today.

title: E.P.A. SHORTENS ITS LIST OF COUNTRIES TO BE PUNISHED FOR AIR POLLUTION
description: With a deadline looming for hundreds of counties to meet standards for air quality, the Reagan Administration said today it would let some communities off the hook and not impose sanctions.

title: LAND OF SHRINKING KIN
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: 'BRANDENBERG' SERIES AT Y
description: THE appetite of the American music audience for Baroque basics seems nearly insatiable, to judge from the success of the now-annual year-end cycles of the complete Bach ''Brandenburg'' Concertos offered by Gerard Schwarz and his Y Chamber Symphony. This year's installment includes four presentations of the set of six on successive nights at the 92d Street Y starting Monday, capped by a New Year's Eve concert with champagne obbligato at Alice Tully Hall.

title: El Paso Appealing On Proration Date
description: The El Paso Company said that it was appealing the Delaware Federal District Court's denial of its application to extend the proration period for Burlington Northern's tender offer for El Paso's shares beyond midnight tonight.

title: A TREASURY OF TROLLOPE MSS. AT MORGAN LIBRARY
description: Anthony Trollope, the great Victorian novelist who has been introduced to a wider public in recent years as the original author of ''The Pallisers'' series on television, is getting new attention in glorious black-and-white at the Morgan Library.

title: LEATHER FURNITURE: ITS CARE AND REPAIR
description: AS the classic leather wingback is joined by suites filled with delicate suedes and supple, rich-hued leathers, the question of proper care of leather furniture takes on new importance. New dyes and fine-tuning in the tanning process have yielded soft, textured and even printed leathers that require extra caution to preserve their luxurious looks.

title: White-Collar Cuts by Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company is planning to cut some management-level jobs and downgrade others in product development to save money and improve communications, a spokesman for the auto maker said.

title: POLICE CONFIRM SEIZED PHOTO WAS NOT OF ETAN PATZ
description: A photograph found in Wareham, Mass., that the New York City police had believed resembled Etan Patz, has turned out to be a false clue in the search for the missing SoHo boy, the police said.

title: SUIT FILED AGAINST A.T.&T.
description: The General Dynamics Corporation filed an antitrust suit today against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, charging that A.T.& T. illegally monopolized part of the telephone equipment market.

title: AN ENERGY CHECKLIST FOR PROSPECTIVE HOME BUYERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- James Rosenfield is a researcher at the Energy and Environmental Policy Center, Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University. John Rothchild is author of ''Stop Burning Your Money: The Only Home Energy Book You'll Ever Need,'' published recently in paperback by Penguin Books.

title: Novel Recall: G.M. Calendars
description: The General Motors Corporation has recalled thousands of cars over the years, but its latest recall may be a first - asking that 3,000 calendars be returned because of a problem with some pictures.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL KANSAS CITY (AL) - Announced that P aul Splittorff, free-agent pitcher, agreed t o a two-year contract. BASKETBALL DENVER (NBA) - Announced that it p lans to sign Dwight Alexander, point g uard with Ohio of the Continental Basket- b all Association, to a 10-day contract; p laced Rich Kelley, backup center, on in- j ured reserve.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK
description: IN many concerts of music written before 1700 there is an emphasis on costume and an atmosphere of display and camaraderie that simply doesn't exist elsewhere on the musical scene. A musician might be dressed like a troubadour from the Middle Ages, or sporting a scarlet velvet cape from the Renaissance; some musicians might be sitting at harpsichords decorated with re-creations of French 17th-century painting. The instruments themselves are exotic - the vielle, the rebec, the oud or the shawn.

title: Angolan Rebels Report Killing 404 Soldiers
description: Angola's anti-Marxist rebel movement said today that it killed 404 Angolan Government soldiers and 70 Cubans in a four-day offensive. It added that it had extended its operations for the first time to the country's northern regions.

title: ATHENIANS FIND HOLIDAYS A BIT SPARTAN THIS YEAR
description: It has been one of the balmiest Christmas seasons in years, but Greeks insist it cannot last. The holiday has been generally subdued, with dire warnings of storms ahead, not only from the weather bureau but from the country's political leaders as well.

title: Devine Withdraws
description: It's official. Dan Devine won't be drawing the X's and O's for Temple next season. Gavin White, the university's athletic director, said that Devine had withdrawn his name from the list of candidates seeking the head football coaching job because he had ''had a change of heart about returning to coaching.''

title: POPE CASE REMINDS BRITONS OF UNSOLVED BULGARIAN CRIME
description: On Sept. 7, 1978, a Bulgarian playwright named Georgi I. Markov was walking in the Aldwych, a street near the offices of the BBC World Service, where he worked as a broadcaster.

title: Virginia Found Gloom in Hawaii
description: F rom the pulpit of the First Baptist Church in Charlottesville, Va., last Sunday, the Rev. H. Cowen Ellis addressed his congregation. ''Until Friday,'' he said, ''I thought Chaminade was a fruit drink.'' Mr. Ellis, of course, was pronouncing Chaminade as if it were related to lemonade, but he's absolved. Until last week, Mr. Ellis, like millions of others, probably had no reason to know that it's really pronounced ''Shahmin-ahd.''

title: Lin B. Hickox Married To Ens. A.C. Zigler Jr.
description: Lin Barbara Hickox, daughter of Gertrude E. Hickox of Summit, N.J., and Dean C. Hickox of Long Beach, L.I., was married in Summit yesterday to Ens. Andrew C. Sigler Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sigler of New Canaan, Conn.

title: No Headline
description: INDIANA TRIUMPHS BY 110-62

title: Article 132099 -- No Title
description: Two gunmen held up the Quality Corner Stamp and Coin store in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn yesterday evening and made off with $100,000 in rare coins, the police said. At first the police thought that that a customer had been kidnapped from the store, at 2601 Avenue U, but this proved to be incorrect. The police later concluded that the customer may have in fact been an accomplice in the robbery.

title: DelBello Approves Budget for 1983
description: County Executive Alfred B. DelBello approved a $546 million budget today for running the Westchester County government in 1983.

title: Cairo Confessions Contested
description: Lawyers defending Moslem fundamentalists accused of plotting to overthrow the Egyptian Government asked the court today to ignore their clients' confessions, which they said were extracted under torture. The case involves 300 defendants, 20 of whom are still at large.

title: THRIFT SHOPS: A SELECTION
description: THE thrift shops of the Upper East Side house worthy used furniture and household objects culled primarily from comfortable dwellings. Antiques appear often, so good buys are possible. A sampling of shops follows. Memorial-Sloan Kettering Thrift Shop, 1410 Third Avenue (80th Street), 535-1250; Mon- day through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 4:45 P.M.; closed Dec. 31 and Jan. 1.

title: CHORUS: MUSIC FOR SYNAGOGUE
description: JEWISH liturgy did not generally depend upon choral performance. Indeed, synagogue music in the West has been a combination of traditional and improvisational expressions by the hazan, or cantor, and songs sung by the congregation that often had roots in popular and folk song. In a traditional synagogue, there would never have been a post like the one Bach held in Leipzig; there would not have been a chorus, let alone a resident composer.

title: S.B. Fulweiler Jr. Marries Rena M. Zurn
description: The marriage of Rena Michell Zurn, daughter of Mrs. Lester R. Westphal of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and David Melvin Zurn of Erie, Pa., to Spencer Biddle Fulweiler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fulweiler of New York and Norwalk, Conn., took place last night. Bishop Donald J. Davis of the Episcopal Diocese of Northwestern Pennsylvania, assisted by Canon John Bryson Chane, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Paul in Erie.

title: 1942, 1982, 1984; Good News
description: If dog bites man is not news and man bites dog is news, what is it when nobody bites anybody? Good news, and as the year draws to a close, some of it is worth celebrating.

title: REAGAN HOPEFUL OF ARMS ACCORD
description: President Reagan said today that he was optimistic that some agreement between the Soviet Union and the United States on strategic arms reduction could be reached.

title: NEW YEAR'S MAGIC POWERS': ANOTHER CHANCE FOR US ALL
description: I have nothing against New Year's Eve. I am as accessible as anyone else to the collective giddiness that will take hold of us tomorrow at nightfall and grow more vertiginous as the evening proceeds. New Year's Eve is an occasion unlike any other. At the stroke of midnight tomorrow a new year will come down the pike. Why should not a new life come down with it, and a new self as well? What was ever lost by hoping?

title: Peak Demand For Power Falls
description: The peak demand for electricity last summer dropped for the first time since World War II, leaving utilities with the largest unused reserve capacity ever, according to the Edison Electric Institute, an organization of investor-owned utilities. The decline was 2.7 percent, the institute reported today.

title: REAGAN AND TOP AIDES TALK IN SECRET ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: With his State of the Union address and the submission of his 1984 budget only weeks away, the calendar is pushing President Reagan toward decisions on the politically explosive question of how to restore Social Security to financial good health.

title: IONA DEFEATS GEORGE WASHINGTON, 65-57
description: Rory Grimes, a sophomore guard, scored 6 points in the final four minutes tonight to break a 53-53 tie and help Iona to a 65-57 victory over George Washington (4-3) in the first round of the Shawmut-Worcester County Classic. In the title game Thursday night, Iona will meet Holy Cross, which beat Davidson, 65-62.

title: Study Cites Benefits Of a Coalport for S.I.
description: One thousand permanent jobs would be generated by the proposed Staten Island coalport - 900 of them on Staten Island, the city's Department of Ports and Terminals said yesterday.

title: Frederic S. Mates, 50, Mutual Fund Executive
description: Frederic S. Mates, a major figure in mutual funds in the late 1960's, died Saturday of a heart attack in Olathe, Kan., where he was visiting relatives. He was 50 years old and resided in Manhattan.

title: MANY QUESTIONS BUT FEW ANSWERS FOR PEOPLE OF DIOXIN-PERILED TOWN
description: They came by the hundreds, many in muddied work boots, clutching little children, their faces etched with multiple emotions, worry, resentment, anger, uncertainty. Why didn't anyone realize earlier that their town might be contaminated with toxic dioxin? What is the health danger? What would the Government do for them? Would it buy out their flooded and possibly poisoned houses?

title: JEWISH EXODUS FROM SOVIET REACHED A LOW POINT IN '82
description: The number of Jews allowed to emigrate from the Soviet Union this year was the lowest since 1970, according to figures issued yesterday by the Greater New York Conference on Soviet Jewry and the National Conference on Soviet Jewry.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Theft at the Courthouse

title: DURALITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
REFRIGERATORS REFLECT THE SPIRIT OF A HOUSE
description: BY looking at other people's refrigerators, Judy Waldinger can spot a troubled marriage, a home in need of a top-to-bottom cleaning, a family that pays the bills on time and a household in which the residents are struggling with their self-image and self-esteem.

title: NEW PLANT VARIETIES TO MATCH THE YEAR
description: THE new year will start with a spectacular breakthrough for gardeners: the first yellow-flowered geranium. Called Primrose Yellow, it has ivy-leaved foliage with light yellow semidouble flowers. Not intended as a garden plant, it is for indoor growing only.

title: Early Retirement
description: The retirement of Roger Wehrli, the St. Louis cornerback, has been moved up. Wehrli, scheduled to play his final regular-season game against Washington Sunday after 138 consecutive games with the Cardinals, injured a knee in practice yesterday and will undergo surgery this morning. Wehrli, 35 years old, scored his third career touchdown as the holder on a fake field-goal attempt last Sunday against the Giants.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH there is no shortage of heating fuel, prices are high and in some cases still climbing, so the homeowner still can benefit by reducing consumption.

title: Krupp Signs Soviet Pact
description: Fried. Krupp A.G., the West German steel conglomerate, has signed a technology-sharing agreement with the Soviet Union, Krupp said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anchor Hocking, Lancaster, Ohio, said the Federal Trade Commission had approved its plan to buy 750,000 shares of newly issued Towle Manufacturing Co. common for about $16.9 million.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 2 A.M., tape.

title: WHEN OLD ROCKER IS ROCKY, YOU COULD MAKE IT ROCK AGAIN
description: Curved supports or rockers have appeared on cribs since the Middle Ages; fitting them to the feet of ordinary chairs was an idea born of the 18th century. It is accepted that the rocking chair is indigenous to America, where it became an institution that spread rapidly throughout the world.

title: NEEDIEST CASES INSPIRE DONORS ACROSS THE U.S.
description: Distance is no deterrent to those who want to join the effort to help New York City's poor, distressed or friendless. Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have been visitors to the city, and others are New Yorkers who have long since moved away.

title: K.G.B. Is Said to Search Dissident's Apartment
description: K.G.B. agents this week searched the apartment of Georgi N. Vladimov, leader of the Moscow branch of Amnesty International, Mr. Vladimov told Western reporters today.

title: U.S. Industries Picks Financial Executive
description: Sigurd D. Medhus, the chief financial officer at the American Express Company, has been appointed executive vice president and chief financial officer of U.S. Industries, a diversified maker of energy-related equipment, building materials and furniture.

title: State Panel Urges Ouster of 2 Judges
description: A state panel recommended today that two upstate New York judges be removed from office for what it considered sloppy handling of official funds and records.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * David Jamison Carlyle Corp. said it had completed a one-year $13 million secured financing package with Security Pacific National Bank.

title: UPS AND DOWNS OF JET CORNERBACK
description: Bobby Jackson has a short list of the highs and lows of his football career at Florida State and with the Jets. He plays cornerback on the left side of the defense, and by the isolated nature of the position, the highs and lows easily define themselves.

title: COUPLE ADOPT 67-YEAR-OLD
description: A 67-year-old woman who was born in a home for the retarded has been adopted, and now goes to church on Sunday and swims at the Y.W.C.A. with a childless couple she calls Mom and Dad.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Meese Connection

title: Grant for Chicago Theater
description: For the second consecutive year, Chicago's Goodman Theater has been given a $100,000 programming grant by the Beatrice Foods Company of Chicago. The grant is earmarked for research and development.

title: Klecko Stays On Injured List
description: Joe Klecko, the Jets' regular right defensive end, will not be activated from the injured-reserve list for Sunday's final regular-season game at Kansas City.

title: CHOICE PIECES OF 20's FURNITURE
description: ONE of the partners, Lloyd Macklowe, above right, is ''in Art Nouveau and antique jewelry.'' The other, Barry Friedman, deals in paintings.

title: Kurtz & Tarlow Gets 2 Brands
description: Kurtz & Tarlow has been named agency for two brands from the Lehn & Fink division of Sterling Drug.

title: Hospital Files For Reorganization
description: Officials for the state's largest public hospital said today that they had filed for its reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws and planned to lay off almost 200 workers.

title: DR. WILLIAM H. STEARNS
description: Dr. William Hunter Stearns, a retired physician and teacher at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Monday of cardiac arrest at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 74 years old and resided in Manhattan.

title: TOO MUCH U.S. 'ROPE'
description: Only recently have Americans become aware of the considerable body of Israelis who watch the United States' enormous financial support of our country with growing misgivings. Much of this doubt and resentment is based on purely economic calculations of the costs of depending on another country. But as a career officer and retired general - I served in the army from 1947 to 1969, including a number of years as a member of the General Staff - I must add that America's lavish aid is also having disastrous effects on Israel's Army and its political constitution.

title: ADULTS LURED BACK TO FILMS BY 'E.T.'
description: The summer of ''E.T. - the Extra-Terrestrial,'' ''Rocky III,'' and ''Star Trek II - the Wrath of Khan'' not only reaped record amounts of money at box offices around the country but also helped to increase sharply the number of adults who went to the movies in the last year, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: BANKS HELP MEXICO GET U.S. CROPS
description: The First National Bank of Chicago said today that it and 25 other banks had signed a three-year, $450 million credit agreement with five Mexican banks for the purchase of American farm products.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1982
description: International An Afghan rebel attack on a military airport Dec. 21-22 resulted in the destruction of 10 helicopters and damage to the runway and buildings, according to reports from reliable informants reaching Pakistan. They said 130 Soviet and Afghan army troops had been killed or wounded in the assault. (Page A2, Columns 3-6.) A Times of London dispute widened as management threatened to stop paying all 2,400 employees because of a confrontation involving 92 electricians that kept the newspaper from publishing for a sixth day. (A3:5-6.)

title: FOR DEMOCRATS IN '84, RULES WILL FAVOR BIG NAMES
description: ''There has been a general sense throughout the fall among Democrats,'' Senator Gary Hart observed the other day, ''that there was a bunch of heroes out there that were just going to leap up from the weeds and capture the public imagination.''

title: Busiest Dolphin
description: You will have to excuse Jimmy Cefalo for feeling a little harried these days. In between making key pass receptions as a wide receiver for the Miami Dolphins in recent games against the Jets and the Bills, Cefalo's schedule has included:

title: 4 Senators Call for Halt To Copter Sale to Iraq
description: Four Senate Foreign Relations Committee members urged President Reagan today to halt the sale of 60 American-made helicopters to Iraq immediately to avoid a possible violation of neutrality in the Iran-Iraq war.

title: Walter Reade Sues Columbia Pictures
description: The Walter Reade Organization said yesterday that it had filed suit against Columbia Pictures Industries, a Coca-Cola Company subsidiary that owns 30.9 percent of Reade's stock and has two directors on its board.

title: Swiss Post 2.5% Decline
description: Switzerland's gross domestic product showed an estimated real decline of 2.5 percent in the third quarter of 1982 compared with the 1981 period, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: Spending Cut By Brazil
description: The Government today announced spending cuts aimed at complying with International Monetary Fund guidelines for easing Brazil's financial crisis.

title: ARTHUR BRYANT, BARBECUE MAN
description: Arthur Bryant, who every day barbecued a ton of meat that pleased the palates of working people, food critics and celebrities, including Presidents, collapsed and died Tuesday at his restaurant in Kansas City, Mo. He was 80 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cuomo Sounds a Note Of Frugality

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Holiday Spirit

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Celebration for the Old

title: LET INSTANT TV REPLAY HELP REPAIR BAD CALLS
description: To the Editor:

title: A HOME IS NOT SAFER WITHOUT A GUN
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
PROSECUTOR IN MOON CASE IS PROMOTED
description: Jo Ann Harris, who prosecuted the Rev. Sun Myung Moon for tax fraud, has been promoted to a top administrative post in the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan.

title: Market Place; Tamper-Proof Packaging
description: WHEN the Tylenol poison scare erupted in September, the attention of investors focused initially on the manufacturer, Johnson & Johnson, and on other companies whose over-the-counter analgesics might claim Tylenol's market share. But as the scare spread to other products, talk of tamper-proofing spurred investment interest in the companies that sell packaging.

title: John Paul Is Assailed In a Soviet Magazine
description: The Communist indoctrination monthly magazine Political Self-Instruction attacked Pope John Paul II today as a rigid anti-Communist whose church carries out subversion in Poland.

title: Jack Parisi, 85, Accused Of Links to Murder Inc.
description: Jack Parisi, who has been described by the Pennsylvania Crime Commission and a United States Senate investigator as a gunman for the crime syndicate called Murder Inc. in the 30's, died Monday night at his home here.

title: 2-TERM NEW HAMPSHIRE GOVERNOR
description: Gov. Hugh Gallen of New Hampshire died today of kidney and liver failure in a Boston hospital where he had been undergoing treatment for a blood infection. Mr. Gallen, who was 58 years old, lost his bid for a third two-year term in last month's election and was to leave office next week.

title: DIXICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: B-Including income of $33,000 from discontinued operations

title: Arafat Sees Tunisian
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met with President Habib Bourguiba today, the Tunisian news agency reported. Mr. Arafat and some other P.L.O. leaders have established a provisional headquarters in Tunis.

title: U.S. Asks Court to End Carolina Jail Segregation
description: The Justice Department, accusing North Carolina of segregating prisoners by race at a state prison in Raleigh, today asked a Federal District judge to order the practice halted.

title: Gretzky's Touch
description: Soviet hockey players are celebrated for their mastery of the art of puck control. It includes the almost uncanny ability to hold the puck on the stick as if by magnetic force, despite opponents' attempts to slash it away. But it is also the ability to manipulate the puck with the skates, soccer-style; the ability to feint and shift direction sharply while carrying the puck, and the ability to shoot with precision.

title: REAGAN, ON NEW YEAR'S HOLIDAY, TO CONSULT FOREIGN POLICY AIDES
description: President Reagan today signed five bills, spent some time with his tailor and then flew here from Los Angeles to celebrate the New Year's holiday weekend with old friends and a few senior members of his Administration.

title: Dome Loan Pact
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it had received a two-month extension on a $1.4 billion loan that had been due by Jan. 1. The due date, which had already been extended from Sept. 30 as part of a rescue package by four Canadian banks and the Government, was moved to Feb. 28. As a result of the extension, more than $2 billion of Dome's $8 billion debt will fall due in 1983, a Dome spokesman said.

title: DANCE: JEAN ERDMAN AS A COMEDIAN
description: JEAN ERDMAN has always cut an imposing figure on stage. Who would have thought a deft comedian lurked beneath that heroic surface? But Miss Erdman had her audience laughing hard as she vamped and slinked through ''Portraits From Duke Ellington's Shakespeare Album'' on Tuesday at the Theater of the Open Eye, where Miss Erdman and protegees are offering a Holiday Dance Festival through Jan. 2.

title: LABOR DISPUTE WIDENS AT THE TIMES OF LONDON
description: A labor dispute involving 92 electricians that has kept The Times of London from printing for six days took a turn for the worse today as management threatened to stop paying all 2,400 employees of The Times and The Sunday Times.

title: Oil Insurance, Cheap
description: Three-hour lines at the gas pump ... odd-even day rationing ... stations closed on weekends ... With gasoline available in abundance and the OPEC cartel in disarray, the oil shocks of the 1970's are a fast-receding memory. But the industrialized West remains vulnerable to an interruption of oil supplies - and the Reagan Administration's failure to build up the nation's strategic petroleum reserve quickly is a foolish gamble with disaster.

title: A Governor for Hard Winters
description: Though he sometimes seemed to be trying to hide them, Hugh Leo Carey's great qualities soon became obvious to the people of his state, probably because he reached Albany when the economic climate was icy and New York City's future cheerless. The people found in him inspiration in adversity, ingenuity in answering challenges that aroused his spirit, mastery of subjects that stirred his interest, charm, wit and undaunted courage.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1982; The Economy
description: The merchandise trade gap narrowed to $4.1 billion in November but the deficit for the entire year is expected to surpass the 1978 record of $42.4 billion, the Commerce Department reported. It assumes a December deficit of about $5 billion. Economic weakness among some of America's biggest customers, notably Mexico, and the competitive disadvantage of the strong dollar were blamed for this year's worsening in the balance of trade. (Page D1.)

title: NETS DEFEAT HAWKS FOR FOURTH IN ROW
description: When someone is playing with confidence, things tend to go his way. But he also makes things happen.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: SEVERAL small and handy holders for hanging diverse items are on the market. Super Klip ($1 for a package of four) is a hinged clamp that can hold a variety of items, including keys, tools, pens and washcloths.

title: Dan River Plan To Avoid Icahn
description: Dan River Inc., which is fighting a takeover bid by the Icahn Group, announced a proposal under which its hourly and salaried employees would, in effect, buy the company. David W. Johnston, chairman, said that a corporation to be owned by the employees would pay $22.50 a share in cash for the Dan River stock and then merge the two companies, and that a major bank was willing to provide most of the financing.

title: THE STAGE: MONODRAMA BY KROETZ
description: FRANZ XAVER KROETZ'S innovative monodrama ''Request Concert'' transcends language barriers by the simple fact that it has no dialogue. As in dance, character development and dramatic action are created through movement rather than words. JoAnne Akalaitis's original New York production was a ''translation'' in the sense that the events of the play were moved from Germany to America. At La Mama, Elia Schneider is now presenting a striking Venezuelan version under the title ''A Peticion del Publico,'' a production of Teatro Dramma of Caracas.

title: SOME MANAGERS FOR CITY TO GAIN 8% PAY INCREASE
description: City managers who are not covered by collective-bargaining agreements will get raises averaging 8 percent this fiscal year, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: 500 TO TEST A HERPES VACCINE
description: A vaccine designed to combat herpes, a sexually transmitted disease, will be tested on 500 residents of Seattle beginning next month.

title: 1942, 1982, 1984; Mainframe Fame
description: For the first time, Time magazine's ''Man of the Year'' is neither man, woman nor class of people. It is a machine: the computer.

title: News Analysis
description: Did the Turkish gunman who shot Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square on May 13, 1981, act on the orders of the Bulgarian secret police? If he did, was it at the behest of the

title: SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS ARE HEALTHIER BUT NOW FACE FURTHER CHALLENGES
description: The nation's thrift institutions, which only a year ago were facing the prospect of collapse, are in stronger shape now, thanks largely to the sharp decline in interest rates. But they still face a difficult future as banking practices grow more and more competitive.

title: TAINTED CLAMS MAKE 100 SICK IN THE L.I. AREA
description: Health departments in Suffolk and Nassau Counties were flooded with phone calls today from people who reported they became ill from eating raw clams apparently taken from polluted waters.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY TROUPE PRESENTS ROCK BALLETS
description: THE joint was more or less jumping with rock and ritual in what seemed like youth night at the Joffrey Ballet Tuesday. For its plunge into repertory programming at the City Center, the company offered two rock ballets by Gerald Arpino, Laura Dean's ''Night'' and Jiri Kylian's ''Return to the Strange Land.''

title: No Place Like Home
description: The turf may have seemed greener in other parks, but for Paul Splittorff, the Kansas City Royal left-hander, there really is no place like home. Splittorff signed a new two-year contract with Kansas City yesterday after having been selected by six other clubs in the free-agent draft last month.

title: AN EAR FOR TROUBLED MANUFACTURERS
description: What will it be today? A delegation from Maine railing at cheaper potatoes from Canada? A Texas oil company worried that somebody in Africa is counterfeiting one of its fungicides? The United States footwear industry in a dither about foreign barriers to American shoe exports?

title: Cases on Siding Separated Again
description: A Federal appeals court in an antitrust case voided a lower court's order that lumped together, as one class, all persons who bought aluminum siding from 10 companies in the early 1970's.

title: Japan Planning 'Super Robots'
description: Government researchers will start work next year on developing ''Super Robots'' to take over from human beings in dangerous jobs, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said today.

title: Eye for Talent
description: The hot-stove league is alive with talk of Tom Seaver's return to the Mets, Billy Martin's possible return to the Yankees and Shawon Dunston's promising first season in the Cubs' organization. Dutch Deutsch, a scout for the San Francisco Giants, says the news is heartwarming, but he does not see any new Dunstons turning up next spring.

title: IN ENGLEWOOD, DISPUTE ARISES OVER LIBYANS
description: When the neighbors heard last week that the chief Libyan delegate to the United Nations was moving in, they did not hurry over with homemade pies.

title: WITH HIS FORTUNES
description: Looking out of his office window one evening last year at the snowy shroud of lights encircling Boston's harbor, Mayor Kevin H. White made a pale, ironic joke: ''I kiddingly say I've gone from being bland to being exciting to being corrupt to being senile.''

title: Poland Expects Credits Of $3 Billion in Budget
description: Parliament approved today a 1983 budget that anticipates $3 billion in credits from non-Communist banks. According to Western officials, the credits would take the form of a postponement of $3 billion in debt payments.

title: WHEN MONEY DOESN'T MATTER IN JAPAN
description: The late Kurt Singer, a German sociologist and economist, once observed that the reason Japan was so efficient, so smooth-working ''does not reside in the rationalized perfection of its mammoth organizations, but in the dense tissue of small society relationships.''

title: Soviet Goalie Ailing
description: About 150 people crowded around the baggage claim area at the airport in Quebec yesterday to greet the touring Soviet all-star hockey team, especially its veteran goaltender, Vladislav Tretyak. But Quebec fans almost certainly will not get to see Tretyak play tonight, when the Russians meet the Nordiques in the second of its six games against National Hockey League clubs.

title: Military Analysis
description: Western intelligence sources say there has been a slow but significant expansion of Soviet land, air and sea forces in the West Pacific this year.

title: COMMUNIST-DOMINATED PARTY PULLS OUT OF FINNISH COALITION
description: The four-party coalition Government fell apart today as one of its members, the Communist-dominated Finnish People's Democratic League, opposed a move in Parliament to increase defense spending.

title: Next Trial for Wilson Delayed by the Judge
description: A Federal judge has postponed the trial of Edwin P. Wilson, a convicted weapons dealer accused of smuggling plastic explosives to Libya, because a defense attorney was injured in a skiing accident, a prosecutor in the case said today.

title: LIFE-AND-DEATH ISSUES IN NEED OF THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: GRANDMA LEE'S INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cabby Faults Speed And Method of Justice

title: United Parcel Jets
description: The United Parcel Service, which began next-day air delivery service last fall with two dozen Boeing 727's based in Louisville, Ky., said it had added four more planes to its jet fleet with the $78 million purchase of four McDonnell Douglas DC-8's from Tiger International Inc.'s Flying Tigers, plus spare engines and parts.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES ADVANCE
description: Prices of short- and long-term debt instruments declined yesterday, and rates and yields rose. Treasury securities dealers said the changes were largely technical in nature and linked to year-end balancing of accounts. Indeed, dealers reported very little retail business to test prices.

title: Louisiana-Pacific Fined $4 Million
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation was ordered by United States District Judge James Redden in Portland, Ore., to pay $4 million in civil penalties for violating a 1979 consent order with the Federal Trade Commission, the F.T.C. said. Company officials said they had not seen the order and could not comment.

title: A CONNOISSEUR OF THRIFT SHOPS FURNISHES A HOME
description: JERED HOLMES is an actor, singer, model, photographer - and connoisseur of thrift shops. His apartment in the East 50's is furnished almost exclusively from thrift shops, flea markets and dumpsters on the street.

title: CONCERT: P.D.Q. BACH
description: P.D.Q. BACH returned to Carnegie Hall Monday with music and jokes by and about this mythical son of Johann Sebastian. P.D.Q. Bach is, of course, the creation of Peter Schickele, and Mr. Schickele was on hand to preside, play the piano, conduct singers and musicians, engineer sight gags and take his customary pratfalls.

title: THE DANCE: A DIFFERENT 'NUTCRACKER'
description: SOME stagings of ''The Nutcracker'' try to look lavish -but not the one that was offered Monday night at the 18th Street Playhouse. And while some ''Nutcrackers'' have a cast of hundreds, this one involved only 13 dancers, most of whom kept reappearing in a multitude of guises.

title: Auto Output In U.S. Down
description: United States car production of 5,077,304 units will finish the year 18.8 percent behind 1981, the lowest since 1958, an industry journal said today.

title: Knicks Pull Out Victory; Brown Ejected; Knicks 91 Cavaliers 87
description: The Knicks weathered the ejection of their coach and a technical foul on his assistant tonight, and defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 91-87.

title: No Headline
description: LEBANON AND U.S. STUDY DISCORD OVER AN AGENDA

title: Cyanide Victim's Spouse Named a Suspect in Case
description: The husband of a woman poisoned by cyanide in an Anacin-3 capsule was named a suspect today in the investigation.

title: New G.E. Officer Strong On Strategic Planning
description: Michael A. Carpenter thinks that strategic planning at a lot of companies adds up to little more than paper shuffling. He describes it as ''something they do every September, and then the rest of the time they run the company.''

title: People Express
description: People Express said that from Jan. 10 to Feb. 10 it would reduce its prices on one-way flights from New York and Newark to all its south Florida destinations to $49 off-peak and $69 at peak times. The airline currently flies to Florida for $69 off-peak and $99 peak.

title: 1952 Decree Is Reviewed
description: The Justice Department tentatively agreed today to terminate a 1952 consent decree that settled an antitrust suit against the United Engineering and Foundry Company, a predecessor to Wean United Inc. of Pittsburgh.

title: U.S. Said to Request Mainland Portugal Bases
description: The United States has asked for its first military installations in mainland Portugal in exchange for increased American help in rearming the country's forces, Portuguese officials said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My bathroom gets excessively humid, and as a result a lot of black mold or fungus grows on the paint. I want to get rid of all this growth and then redecorate - preferably by repainting. What steps do you suggest I take?

title: MARKETING MONEY, NOT CROPS
description: As commodity traders look to 1983, they could well conclude that the continued health of the nation's futures markets owes more to the world of finance than the farm.

title: CAREY ENDS 8 YEARS IN OFFICE, HIS RECORD A MIX OF CONTRASTS
description: Governor Carey leaves office today, his record a mix of impressive success and puzzling lapses and his place in New York State's history still uncertain.

title: These Are Not Accidents
description: ''You have to assume that late at night every set of headlights coming at you is being aimed by someone stone drunk.'' So said an Indiana trooper to our colleague, Andrew Malcolm, whose chilling reconstruction of drunk-driving deaths appears today. Mr. Malcolm's report demonstrates that the trooper's assumption is hardly exaggerated.

title: INSURE THE CONSUMER
description: Supply-side economics has failed, and for a reason that is right out of the old-fashioned economics textbooks: Nobody's buying anything.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Free Bank Calendar? Don't Count on It

title: SOLON AUTOMATED SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MYSTIFIED 'MERLIN' CAST IS DAZZLED BY THE MAGIC
description: Doug Henning says things were a bit easier during the early reheasals for ''Merlin,'' when the actors were simply reading lines and adhering to their chalked blocking marks, a period when the magic and illusions were represented simply by large cardboard boxes being shoved about by stagehands. Then came the ideas of what the illusionist calls ''My Magical Think Tank,'' and all that changed.

title: Hong Kong Land Co.
description: The Hong Kong Land Company said today that its purchase of the Bank of Canton building in Hong Kong's central district had been completed and the $77.3 million cost had been paid in full.

title: For one director, New Year means two plays on stage.
description: FOR Robert Allan Ackerman, the new year will bring more joy than most directors could hope for. His name will go up on not one but two Broadway marquees. The first will be ''Extremities,'' William Mastrosimone's drama about rape, starring Susan Sarandon. ''Extremities'' opened Off Broadway last week at the Westside Arts Theater and will move to Broadway, to a theater to be announced, the second week in February.

title: BULLDOZERS, TRAFFIC JAMS AND SMOG DIM LUSTER OF PALM SPRINGS
description: Like President Reagan, Frank Richards, a Chicagoan, arrived in the California desert this week to welcome the New Year and, not incidentally, to find a brief respite from the cold weather that is gripping much of the Middle West.

title: PUBLISHING: '82 SALES OFF AND '83 COULD BE WORSE
description: ''THINGS have been spotty for booksellers all year,'' said G. Roysce Smith, executive director of the American Booksellers Association. ''Right up until November, they were wondering if things were going to pick up.''

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS STUDY IN U.S. COLLEGES
description: Two years ago in the sprawling black township of Soweto in South Africa, Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, met an African employee of the United States Consulate in Johannesburg named Thabo Moeti.

title: GEORGIA AT A GLANCE
description: Offense 20 KEVIN HARRIS; Sophomore split end, 6 feet, 180 pounds. 10 receptions, 166 yards, one touchdown. Started as a safety before move to end. Possibly fastest receiver in this game. 75 JIMMY HARPER: Junior tackle, 6-5, 270. On team with many nicknames, he is The Mountain. Was recruited as defensive lineman. 63 MIKE WEAVER: Sophomore guard, 6-2, 275. Has very quick feet for a big man. Florida state high school shot-put champion in 1979. 55 WAYNE RADLOFF: Senior center, 6-5, 260. Only senior and threeyear starter on interior line. Starting guard in 1980. 68 WARREN GRAY: Junior guard, 6-3, 240. Moved to tackle from guard this year. Missed first six games of season because of ankle injury. 74 GUY McINTYRE: Junior tackle, 6-3, 257. Recruited as tight end but lettered as defensive tackle in 1979. Moved to offensive tackle in 1981. Is line's best blocker, according to coaches. 88 NORRIS BROWN; Senior tight end, 6-3, 215. Three receptions, 46 yards, two toucdowns.

title: HEADED PRODUCTION OF FILMS AT M-G-M
description: Sol C. Siegel, former head of production at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios and producer of such films as ''High Society (1956),'' ''Three Coins in the Fountain (1954),'' ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (1953),'' and ''What Price Glory (1952),'' died of a heart attack Wednesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 79 years old.

title: WALL ST. WINNERS AND LOSERS
description: In a year that produced the strongest sustained stock market rally in a half century and a new high for the Dow Jones industrial average, the biggest percentage gainers were typically small, obscure issues.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
4 Giants Are Named To Pro Bowl Team
description: Lawrence Taylor, Harry Carson, Mark Haynes and Dave Jennings of the Giants were named today to play in the Pro Bowl, all as National Football Conference starters. At the same time, their coach said he thought the voting procedure for the Pro Bowl ''is a farce, to a certain degree.''

title: RUDNAY'S LAST CHANCE AT JETS
description: The end of the National Football League's shortest regular season this Sunday afternoon and Monday night also marks the end of several prominent careers, among them that of Jack Rudnay, the 14th-year center of the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: OVERNIGHT RATES SOAR AGAIN
description: Key overnight lending rates continued to soar yesterday, despite moves by the Federal Reserve to help banks inject more liquidity into the banking system.

title: NEW YEAR'S EVE ROCK PERFORMANCES
description: THE ''harmolodic funk'' invented by the composer and saxophonist Ornette Coleman in the 1970's is a discliplined and dizzying synthesis of jazz, rock and world music. Tonight, New Year's Eve, Mr. Coleman is presenting a ''convention'' of harmolodic bands, including his own Prime Time and the best of its offshoots, Ronald Shannon Jackson and the Decoding Society.

title: U.S. WILL NOT PAY A U.N. ASSESSMENT
description: President Reagan announced today that the United States would not pay a United Nations assessment of as much as $1 million a year. This is the first time, American legal experts said, that Washington has claimed the right to withhold funds.

title: AMERICA'S NONRECOGNITION POLICY IS A NONSTARTER
description: What right-wing European dictator recognized Fidel Castro's Government almost from the day it took power? What conservative Latin-American President recently rebuked President Reagan for blocking Cuban re-entry into the Organization of American States? The answers: Generalissimo Francisco Franco of Spain and Belisario Betancur of Colombia.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Life for an Old Sign A fter seven years of darkness, the familiar Silvercup bakery sign is lighted up again in Long Island City, but with a difference. Under the 36-foot red letters spelling ''Silvercup'' are yellow letters adding ''Studios.''

title: ECONOMIC INDEX RISES BY 0.8%
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: THE WILDLIFE IN ZAMBIA: A KINGDOM UNDER SIEGE
description: A story circulating among conservationists here concerns the big white rhino and the little white rhino, transplants from Zululand, who have not, it seems, found happiness in Zambia.

title: Steel Plant Closing Assessed by Panel
description: An emergency state task force formed to deal with the closing of the Lackawanna plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation held its initial meeting in Buffalo today, and optimism was expesssed by the chairman of the group.

title: Residents in Louisiana Battle Flood Waters
description: The National Weather Service here warned today of the possibility of major Louisiana floods as volunteers stacked sandbags on levees that are barely keeping flood waters from a subdivision at Monroe, in the northern part of the state.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY'S PRESENT DANGER
description: To the Editor:

title: GAS SUPPLIER TO NORTHEAST IS TOLD TO REPAY MILLIONS IN OVERCHARGES
description: In an important policy decision, a Federal official today ordered a pipeline company that supplies natural gas to much of the Northeast to refund $100 million or more to customers that he said had been substantially overcharged.

title: Man Arrested on Coast In Poisoning of Wife
description: A man whose wife nearly died of cyanide poisoning was arrested today on a charge of attempted murder. Four officers arrested Richard Bowen, 29 years old, a newpaper circulation district manager, and booked him into Santa Clara County Jail on charges of attempted murder and poisoning medicine, Police Sgt. Bob Burroughs said.

title: KOCH AND KIDS PLEAD: SAVE WATER
description: Two television veterans joined yesterday to tape a public-service message reminding New Yorkers that there will be a water shortage soon if people do not conserve now.

title: A new entry in nouvelle cuisine.
description: ADOUBLE helping of deja vu is the specialty at Pierre Francois, the insistently nouvelle-cuisine restaurant that opened two-and-ahalf months ago on 58th Street, between First Avenue and Sutton Place. The first where-have-I-seen-this-before feeling comes at the door, with the realization that this is the former home of the nowextinct Dodin-Bouffant restaurant. True, diners are now greeted by a doorman-checkroom attendant comically costumed as a gendarme, a touch that might have come right out of a Jacques Tati farce. But that is hardly enough to overcome the pretentious service and the soporific effect of the small, understated upstairs dining room with its dull pink walls and gloomy lighting.

title: PLAYS TAPES FROM THE UNDERGROUND
description: The Polish Government suspended martial law at midnight Thursday, more than a year after a military crackdown.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: ... For Others, With a Barely Audible Bite

title: WNET LOSING GAMBLE AS AN ANGEL FOR 'ALICE'
description: From the start it was a glamorous gamble. WNET-TV, Channel 13, the metropolitan area's major public television station, decided to raise money in an unconventional manner by investing in a new $2 million Broadway production of ''Alice in Wonderland.''

title: CRUISING INTO NEW YEAR IN A RENTED LIMOUSINE
description: If you want to zip around town in style on New Year's Eve, you might consider renting a limousine. Many renting companies report that they are solidly booked, but many others (some listed below) say they may have a few cars left, and it's worth giving them a call.

title: Army Picks Coach
description: Jim Young, former head football coach at Purdue and Arizona, was named the head football coach at Army today.

title: GAUGING SOVIET ARMS
description: As the fog of war dissipates, it is becoming more and more obvious that Israel's victory over the leading Soviet allies in the Middle East - Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization - has done a great service for the United States. (Whether Israel was wise in paying the price in blood, treasure and repute for America's benefit is another matter.) But the war in Lebanon could eventually turn out to be something of a disaster if its results are interpreted to mean that Soviet weapons are grossly inferior to our own, thus giving rise to dangerous delusions about the worldwide military balance, particularly in Europe.

title: P.D.Q. Finale Sunday
description: P.D.Q. Bach, the musicocomical brainchild of Prof. Peter Schickele, will take the stage at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. for the last of four performances.

title: JAPAN JOINS THE ATLANTIC ALLIES IN SPURNING SOVIET ARMS PLAN
description: Japan has joined the United States, Britain and France in terming the Soviet Union's latest proposal for reducing its missiles in Europe unacceptable, Japanese officials said today.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Woman Is Killed As Crane Collapses
description: A 250-foot crane snapped in half and collapsed at a construction site two blocks from the downtown district this morning, killing a woman who had accompanied her husband on a delivery of steel to the site.

title: Randy Jones at Palace
description: Randy Jones, an alumnus of the rock group the Village People, will make his first solo appearance tonight at 2 A.M. at the Palace, 110 East 14th Street.

title: ETHNIC 'BRUNCHES' FOR THE MORNING AFTER
description: ''THERE may be some perfectly nice people who use the word 'brunch,' '' the late Heywood Broun is reported to have said, ''but I prefer not to know about them.'' However you may feel about the word, brunch probably conjures up generally expensive meals for which reservations must be made and special clothes (at least, casually elegant) must be worn. As pleasant as such a meal can be, after a week of holiday celebrations topped by New Year's Eve, a more relaxed and less self-conscious version of brunch might be just the thing for New Year's Day. Relaxed and generally inexpensive breakfast-lunches can be had in a number of the city's ethnic restaurants, few of which require reservations, nor do they inspire serious attention to dress. The varied and savory Chinese dumplings that comprise a dim sum breakfast make a diverting and soul-satisfying first meal for the New Year. There are several dependable Chinatown meccas for dim sum that will be open tomorrow. Among the best are Hong Gung, 30 Pell Street (571-0545), serving dim sum from 9 A.M. to 3:30 P.M.; Hee Seung Fung (H.S.F.), 46 Bowery (374-1319), with dim sum from 8:30 A.M. to 5 P.M., and the Imperial Inn, 23 Pell Street (233-1014), where dim sum can be ordered from the menu between noon and 3 P.M. Menus at kosher dairy-vegetarian restaurants offer wide choices that are suitable for a brunch. Thick and steaming vegetable soups, omelets or scrambled eggs with smoked salmon and onions, bagels, lox and cream cheese, assorted herrings and blintzes are foremost among such choices.

title: Nortek Is Sued
description: Nortek Inc. said it is the object of a class action lawsuit in Delaware following its agreement to acquire a 30 percent stake in Monogram Industries from three of its officers and directors. Nortek agreed to purchase the holdings of Martin Stone, Harvey L. Karp and George H. Levine, who are also named in the suit, for $35.4 million. The plaintiffs, whose names were not disclosed, seek an injunction against the stock sale and contend the sale constitutes a breach of fiduciary duty to the remaining Monogram shareholders.

title: Decision File; Airline Fined On Smoking Complaints
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board recently imposed a $12,000 fine on American Airlines for refusing to provide sufficient seating in the no-smoking sections of its airplanes.

title: Time And Reality
