description: Tradition gives the end of a year a sense of completion, and imbues a new date with rising hopes. People make lists of what was good and bad, a way of relegating things to the past, and lists of better intentions that always belong to a receding future.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Keep New York wet. Save water.'' - Mayor Koch, in TV commercial.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: No Purchase Necessary

title: A Quiet Evening For Steinbrenner
description: Ever since George Steinbrenner signed Catfish Hunter on New Year's Eve eight years ago, Yankee watchers have waited for a repeat performance. So when Steinbrenner jokingly said several weeks ago that he might name his 1983 manager this New Year's Eve, some people took him seriously and, in recent days, began to fear that their party plans would be wrecked.

title: REFLECTIONS OF A LOSING CONGRESSMAN
description: In 1980, Ronald Reagan won 117,043 votes in Connecticut's Third Congressional District on his way to becoming President of the United States, and Lawrence J. DeNardis won 117,024 votes to take a seat in the House of Representatives.

title: OPEC Special Meeting
description: A four-nation committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in January to discuss OPEC production quotas, Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, said today. Sheik Otaiba, the chairman of the OPEC committee, also rejected suggestions that OPEC is about to collapse as a result of sagging oil sales, increased competition from other oil exporters and internal dissension.

title: TOYO KOGYO CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
ONCE-PROUD STORE HAS ITS LAST CHRISTMAS
description: They have been coming, bringing cameras and children, from suburbs not even dreamed of when J.L. Hudson's was new. For a few brief days, the stately old department store and Detroit's battered downtown are humming again.

title: ART: DRAWINGS OF SCHIELE AND MATISSE, A CHANCE TO COMPARE AND CONTRAST
description: EGON SCHIELE (1890-1918) and Henri Matisse (1869-1954) were two of the most wildly differing draftsmen who ever put pen to paper - Schiele a Viennese, whose nervous, intense Expressionist style gave a close account of his emotional life; Matisse a Frenchman of calmly classical outlook, whose suave, spare line dealt equably with the world that existed outside of him. Both were sensuous rather than cerebral in their approach, but Matisse believed in ''an art of balance, of purity and serenity, devoid of troubling or depressing subject matter,'' while Schiele's often erotic work was raw and tortured and vividly ''psychological,'' reflecting not only his own inner turmoil, but also the avant-garde angst of pre-World War I Vienna.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.00-11.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Advertising; Good News In Travel Accounts
description: RARE is the ad agency president who as the lid is placed on the coffin of 1982 can say, ''None of my clients cut their ad budgets this year.''

title: 5 KEY STATE APPOINTMENTS ARE ANNOUNCED BY CUOMO
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo yesterday announced the appointment of Cesar A. Perales, president and general counsel of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, as Director of Social Services for New York State.

title: CO-OP BANK HEAD NOT REHIRED
description: The National Consumer Cooperative Bank announced today that it would not rehire its president, Carol S. Greenwald, when her contract expires on Jan. 31. The bank's action has been expected since last November, when Mrs. Greenwald took a ''sabbatical'' that coincided precisely with the last three months of her contract.

title: Pan Am Funds
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation has agreed to lend $37.6 million to Pan American World Airways, the airline said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Frontier Exploration Inc. of Denver said it had agreed to acquire a subsidiary of the privately held Southwest Energy Corp. for five million American common shares; the acquired unit owns an interest in various leases and completed wells.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Football Vanderbilt vs. Air Force, Hall of Fame Bowl, at Birmingham, Ala. Vanderbilt, the favorite, has a potent passing combination in Whit Taylor, the quarterback, and Allama Matthews, who has 61 receptions this season.

title: JAZZ: HOLLEY DUO IS AT GRIFF'S
description: THE MAJOR HOLLEY DUO is a changeable ensemble whose one constant is Mr. Holley, a bassist who shares with Slam Stewart top honors in the field of bassists who hum while they bow. The variable in the Duo is the pianist.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,336,000 for the latest yr and $353,000 for the previous yr

title: Sagging Roof Falls At the Metrodome
description: The fiberglass-and-Teflon roof of the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome ruptured and collapsed today as workers attempted to clear away ice and snow.

title: Touche Ross Unit
description: Touche Ross & Company said its German Treuverkehr A.G. subsidiary would merge with two concerns, Dr. Ratsch of Dusseldorf and Mulheim's Westdeutsche Industrie-Treuhand, on Jan 1. It said the merged companies would have a fee volume of more than $25 million.

title: GORSUCH CONTEMPT CASE EVOKES A COUNTERPUNCH
description: The question put today to the Federal District Court here was this: Can one branch of the Federal Government, styling itself the United States, sue a second branch of the Government and ask the third branch to judge the issue?

title: Rockland to Raise Taxes 10 to 17%
description: The Rockland County Legislature has approved property-tax increases of 10 to 17 percent to pay for the county's $162 million budget. The difference in the increase results from varying tax rates in each of Rockland's five towns.

title: Latest Art Holography
description: The Museum of Holography is celebrating its sixth anniversary with ''Contemporary Art Holography,'' an exhibition of works done in the last year.

title: 2 NETWORKS OFFER TOASTS ON THE EVE OF NEW YEAR
description: TWO of the three commercial networks have special programs for tonight's New Year's Eve celebrations. At 11:30, CBS-TV is offering ''Happy New Year, America,'' a collection of festivities from three locations, with Donny Osmond as anchor. At New York's Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Mr. Osmond will be joined by cast members of Broadway's ''Sophisticated Ladies'' and Jerry Lee Lewis, the countryrock singer. From Las Vegas, Les Brown and his Band of Renown have a musical salute to American cities, while Leo Sayre and Susan Anton will sing for the cameras. And, in a segment taped earlier in the month, Gladys Knight and the Pips will be among the performers at Florida's Walt Disney World.

title: AN ISLAND FIT FOR A RESOURCE RECOVERY PLANT
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDROPOV SAYS TALK WITH REAGAN COULD AID TIES
description: Yuri V. Andropov was quoted today as saying that a meeting with President Reagan could be a ''very effective'' way of improving relations between Moscow and Washington but that the success of any meeting would depend on ''good preparatory work.''

title: REAGAN IS SAID TO SELECT SCOWCROFT TO HEAD BROAD STUDY ON MISSILES
description: From now until spring, the search by President Reagan, Congress and a Presidential commission for a way to base the MX missile will drive them well beyond that issue to delve into the fundamental shape of the nuclear deterrent.

title: WATT TO HALT ENERGY LEASING IN FEDERAL WILDERNESS AREAS
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, apparently ending one of his bitterest disputes with environmentalists, said today that he would issue no more leases for oil and gas drilling in Federal wilderness areas.

title: THEATER: 'WHODUNNIT,' COMIC THRILLER, OPENS
description: SUPPOSE a man at a party offers to tell you a joke with a hilarious punch line. You'd want to hear it, right? But suppose the man then says that the story that sets up that punch line takes an hour to tell and is exceedingly boring. Would you still want to hear the joke? If your answer to that question is yes, then there's a passing chance you may get some pleasure out of Anthony Shaffer's ''Whodunnit,'' the putative comic thriller that opened at the Biltmore last night.

title: Eastern Air Lines
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said it was prepared to defy a ruling by the Civil Aeronautics Board and cut prices of its tickets sold through travel agents if other airlines begin selling their tickets through nonagency discounters. The board, as part of its airline deregulation move, ruled that ticket sales could be made only by trade assocation-accredited travel agents, thus paving the way for discounters to enter the travel business.

title: Not Fit to Be Tied
description: Art Modell, the owner of the Cleveland Browns, has asked the National Football League to order that Sunday's game between the Buffalo Bills and the New England Patriots be played to a conclusion in the event of a tie, no matter how many overtime periods it might take. But such a suspension of the rules would require the approval of all 28 teams, and no meeting even to consider the idea is planned.

title: Postcards From 1982
description: S ports reporters don't win games and they don't lose games; their challenge comes in witnessing events in different corners of the world. Some of this year's highlights - and low lights - were worth a postcard home:

title: SORE POINT: CONGRESS'S CUTS IN FOREIGN MILITARY AID
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz returns from his holiday Monday he will find a number of key issues demanding early decision. Some are obvious, such as whether to compromise on the American arms control proposals with the Russians or whether to reconsider lifting some of the sanctions against Poland in response to the formal ending of martial law.

title: ISRAELI TOWN JOYFUL HOST TO PEACE TALKS
description: The second session of Israeli-Lebanese negotiations took place today in this northern Israeli border town, which became a symbol of the suffering of Israeli civilians in years of Palestinian terrorist attacks from southern Lebanon.

title: Iona Loses, 66-65, In Last 2 Seconds
description: Champs Godbolt made a free throw with two seconds left to give Holy Cross a 66 - 65 upset victory over Iona for the championship of the Shawmut-Worcester County Classic tonight.

title: JAMES G. FITZGERALD
description: James G. Fitzgerald, president of Woodward, Baldwin & Company, a textile sales concern in Garden City, L.I., died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 64 years old.

title: Steel Imports Up Last Month
description: Steel imports in November totaled 1.26 million tons, an increase of 9 percent from October, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported today. The imports accounted for 23.8 percent of the steel supply in the United States last month.

title: PRICES CLIMB
description: Spurred by declining interest rates, sales of new single-family houses jumped 12 percent in November to the highest level in two years, according to Government figures released today.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Mr. Volcker as Matador
description: Deep inside the monstrous lame-duck appropriations bill that is now the nation's budget for fiscal 1983, there's a message from Congress to Paul Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. It says: ''Cut Interest Rates.'' Its history also says something about monetary politics.

title: Tender Bid by Mesa Is Oversubscribed
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company today won the first round in its battle to take over the General American Oil Company of Texas.

title: Italy Plans Tax Increases
description: Italy's month-old coalition Government agreed today on steep tax increases to reduce public spending and warned of further austerity measures to deal with the country's deepening economic problems.

title: Clarion Turns To Marsteller
description: The Clarion Corporation of America, owned by a Japanese maker of automotive stereo parts, has selected Marsteller to do its promotion. The account bills around $3 million.

title: Miller Sets Layoffs
description: The Miller Brewing Company said it would put 116 hourly workers on indefinate layoff Monday, bringing to 222 the number of its employees on layoff. Bob Bertini, a Miller spokesman, attributed the layoffs to ''the continuing recessionary economy'' and seasonal adjustments. Miller employs about 1,600 hourly workers at its brewery here.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY BRINGS BACK ITS 'FAUNE'
description: VASLAV NIJINSKY'S ''L'Apres-midi d'un Faune,'' one of the most strangely beautiful ballets of our century, returned to the Joffrey Ballet's repertory on Wednesday night at the City Center. As in 1979, when the Joffrey first performed the piece, Leon Bakst's original decor and costumes were lovingly restored by Ralph Holmes and the choreography was reconstructed by Elizabeth Schooling and William Chappell.

title: UNITED REALTY INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Margaret Megaw Weds Stephen Monas
description: Margaret M. Megaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neill Megaw of Austin, Tex., formerly of Williamstown, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen Sidney Monas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Monas of Austin. Justice of the Peace Guy Herman performed the ceremony at the Travis County Courthouse in Austin.

title: Con Ed Refund Begins in '83
description: The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it would refund $20 million to its natural gas customers beginning Jan. 1 through credits in January, February and March.

title: U.S. Files Bid On World Cup
description: The United States Soccer Federation sent a cable to the Federation Internationale de Football Association yesterday formally bidding for the 1986 World Cup soccer tournament.

title: 2 Bands at Peppermint
description: The Peppermint Lounge, 100 Fifth Avenue, at 15th Street, will feature two top New York bands, the Fleshtones and the Individuals, tomorrow night. Admission is $5 before 11, $10 after. The number for information is 989-9505.

title: HEDBERG EXCELS AS RANGERS WIN
description: The Rangers defeated the New Jersey Devils, 5-2, before a sellout crowd of 19,023 at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight although the New Yorkers were outshot and yielded a short-handed goal.

title: ELEANOR C. BRERETON
description: Eleanor Collins Brereton, a former member of the New York Council on the Arts, died of a heart ailment last Saturday at her home in Canandaigua, N.Y. She was 73 years old.

title: Clampett in Lead
description: Bobby Clampett shot a fiveunder-par 67 before a hometown gallery to take the second-round lead and Craig Stadler moved into contention with a 66 today in the $150,000 Spalding Invitation golf tournament. Clampett, 22 years old and a native of the Monterey Peninsula, had a 36-hole total of 136 and a two-stroke lead in the nontour event. He won this tournament three years ago as an amateur.

title: People
description: * Philip J. Titolo has been appointed publisher of Health magazine.

title: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Wells Fargo Gain
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it would have a pretax gain of about $20 million from a San Francisco land sale, but a special addition to its loan loss allowance will partly offset the gain.

title: PIANIST: TONY RAICO AT LA CAMELLIA
description: MOST restaurant pianists offer a standardized format. They play popular tunes and requests and try not to disturb the diners. Tony Raico, who is playing at La Camellia, 225 East 58th Street, manages simultaneously to fall into that format and to defy it.

title: 2.8% Avoid Paying, Transit Chief Says
description: John D. Simpson, the president of New York City's Transit Authority, said yesterday that about three of every 100 riders entered the subway system without paying.

title: Friday; DEJA VU AT THE THALIA
description: The seventh Surrealist Film Festival is on today and tomorrow at the Thalia Theater, 95th Street at Broadway. It consists of one feature-length film, ''Dreams That Money Can Buy'' (1946) - by Hans Richter, in collaboration with Alexander Calder, John Cage, Man Ray, Max Ernst, Marcel Duchamp, Fernand Leger and Darius Milhaud - and nine shorts. They include ''Un Chien Andalou'' (1928) by Salvador Dali and Luis Bunuel, Man Ray's ''Return to Reason'' (1928) and Marcel Duchamp's ''Anemic Cinema'' (1925). Admission is $4 ($2 for children and the elderly before 5 P.M.). Information: 222-3370. BRONX CHRISTMAS TREES

title: Missing Boy, 13, Found in Midtown
description: A 13-year-old New Jersey boy believed to have been abducted last month was found yesterday, apparently unharmed, in the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown, the police said.

title: MIAMI CALMS AND OFFICIALS QUESTION POLICE PROCEDURE
description: As a tentative calm began to return to Miami's Overtown neighborhood, officials turned their attention today to the procedures and performance of police officers involved in the disturbance.

title: Georgia Game Is Paterno's 'Poll Bowl' A 'Poll Bowl' for Penn State
description: Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State has long advocated a major-college football playoff to determine a national championship team. ''Until there is such a playoff,'' he said today, ''this Sugar Bowl game will suffice. Georgia is No.1 and we're No.2, so the winner is it for this year.''

title: WEINBERGER SAYS PENTAGON BUDGET CANNOT BE REDUCED WITHOUT RISK
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, resisting growing pressures for reductions in military spending, insisted today that deeper cuts could not be made in the Defense Department's budget ''without risk to our national security.''

title: DOCTOR IS SLAIN IN HIS PENTHOUSE ON WEST 70TH ST.
description: A 51-year-old physician was found stabbed to death yesterday afternoon in his penthouse apartment on the Upper West Side, the police said.

title: BRAZILIANS WILL NOT PAY PRINCIPAL DUE IN JANUARY
description: Brazil has notified its foreign creditors that it will not make the $446 million of principal payments that come due in January on its huge foreign debt.

title: Getting Out of the M.T.A.'s Way
description: For one day, the National Mediation Board was ready to intervene against a possible strike on commuter lines. That would have derailed the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's chances of putting New York's suburban network in order. Yesterday the Mediation Board got out of the way, raising hopes the M.T.A. can run its own railroads.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For Some, New Year Will Begin With a Bang ...

title: NIELSEN, A C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bowl Rematches
description: Michigan and U.C.L.A. will meet in the Rose Bowl on Saturday afternoon in a rematch of their Sept. 25 game at Ann Arbor, which the Bruins won, 31-27. But the recent history of bowl rematches favors the Wolverines.

title: Communists Left Out Of New Finnish Coalition
description: Prime Minister Kalevi Sorsa reconstituted his coalition Government today by leaving out the Communist-dominated partner that caused it to collapse on Wednesday.

title: CABARETS, JAZZ CLUBS GIVE REVELERS WIDE CHOICE
description: NEW YEAR'S revelers are offered a wide choice in price and musical point of view by New York's cabarets and jazz clubs tonight. Though some clubs may be sold out by now, it is still possible to make reservations at many others where distinctive musical fare is planned.

title: INTERPROVINCIAL STEEL & PIPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AN ECONOMIC FAITH PRESSED ON AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: MCI'S STOCK LEADS IN '82 VOLUME
description: The MCI Communications Corporation is still a gnat in the longdistance telephone business compared with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. But on the stock market, MCI appears to have beaten A.T.& T. and other industrial giants to become the most actively traded stock in 1982.

title: Books Of The Times
description: A BETTER WORLD. The Great Schism: Stalinism and the American Intellectu- als. By William L. O'Neill. 447 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Festive Displays Mark Holiday at the Cloisters
description: The Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum's medieval branch in Fort Tryon Park, is celebrating the holiday season with festive displays. The Romanesque Cloister of St.-Guilhem-le-Desert has been transformed into an indoor garden with a ground cover of creeping fig and fern and an assortment of flowering plants.

title: BRYANT STARTS THE QUIET LIFE
description: For all the times he had talked about retiring, Paul (Bear) Bryant never really gave the matter serious thought until this season. As long as he had his health, he often said, and the University of Alabama still wanted him, he would continue to make coaching his occupation. Even when a state law requiring mandatory retirement at 70 years old was upheld in court, Bryant's fans said that the Bear would get around it by volunteering his services to the football team.

title: J.M.B. Realty
description: The J.M.B. Realty Corporation, a leading Chicago real estate investment concern, said that two commingled pension fund trusts it manages had acquired a 50 percent interest in four Chicagoarea shopping centers from the Urban Investment and Development Company, a subsidiary of the Aetna Life and Casulty Company of Hartford. The value of the transaction, which will add almost $34 million in after-tax profits to Aetna's fourth-quarter earnings, is in excess of $120 million.

title: FARMERS' PRICES OFF 1.6%
description: The prices farmers get for raw products dropped 1.6 percent in December, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: BALLET: NEUBERT TROUPE'S 'PRINCE AND PAUPER'
description: THE Neubert Ballet Company and Children's Ballet Theater undertook quite a task on Wednesday afternoon in the Fashion Institute of Technology auditorium. That task was the retelling of Mark Twain's ''The Prince and the Pauper.'' Choreographed by Christine Neubert to an ''audiomontage,'' as the program notes put it, ''The Prince and the Pauper'' begins with a scene called ''Blessings of Riches, Curse of Poverty.'' The ballet ended, 48 vignettes later, with a grand finale that brings the entire cast on stage, from lowliest little beggar to the most elegant court lady.

title: U.S. BOARD DECIDES NOT TO TAKE ROLE IN M.T.A.'S DISPUTE
description: The National Mediation Board abruptly withdrew from the commuter railroad dispute in the New York area yesterday, a day after it announced that it would intervene. The reversal cleared the way for intensified negotiations between the unions and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: COMEDIANS WELCOMING 1983 WITH LAUGHTER
description: FIVE out of four New York comedians recommend welcoming the New Year tonight at a club that offers comedy. They counsel revelers to forget the MX missle, the Middle East and the economy, and welcome 1983 with a laugh.

title: HOW NEW YORK STATE PURSUES THE POISONERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Flo and Eddie on 'Tour'
description: Flo and Eddie, alias Howard Kaylan and Mark Volman, were members of the Turtles and later of Frank Zappa's Mothers of Invention.

title: JERSEY CONSIDERS TAX COMPROMISE TO RAISE FUNDS
description: TRENTON Dec. 30 - The New Jersey Legislature today took up a compromise package of sales- and income-tax increases to raise $180 million by June 30. The proposals were intended to close a projected deficit in the current budget.

title: INCREASE IN BROKER RATE PUSHES DOW DOWN 12.23
description: The stock market, responding to an increase in the interest rates charged to brokerage firms by several major banks, fell sharply yesterday afternoon in moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.23 points, to close at 1,047.37.

title: Rebels Said to Attack Another Afghan Airfield
description: Moslem guerrillas attacked a second major airfield in Afghanistan last week, at Bagram, after Soviet soldiers from the Moslem republic of Uzbekistan guarding the base helped by showing the way through minefields, according to Western diplomats.

title: Forum Full of Muppets
description: Big Bird, the Cookie Monster, Prairie Dawn and other Muppet characters are in town this weekend in the three-week run of the ''Sesame Street Country Jamboree'' at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: WESTPHAL IS SPARK IN KNICKS' VICTORY
description: Once Paul Westphal was an all-star and one of the finest shooters in the National Basketball Association. Now, at 32 years old, Westphal waits for precious playing minutes with the Knicks, hoping to prove that he can still perform well.

title: UNUSUAL, INEXPENSIVE AND FREE CELEBRATIONS
description: YOU don't have to spend a fortune, have reservations booked since July or wear funny hats to have a good time this New Year's Eve. The city tonight abounds with ways to celebrate that are reasonable or free and that are still available at this late hour. Last-minute revelers can enjoy, for instance, Purcell and mulled wine or ''Iolanthe'' and champagne; can join in folk or English country dancing; can attend two drama marathons; can watch fireworks, or observe coins traveling up someone's sleeve.

title: TWO SHORTCUTS TO SEATS AT THE MOVIES
description: To the Editor:

title: The case of the lost statue.
description: A3,000-year-old Egyptian statue from the reign of Ramses II, which was found in an abandoned trolley station in Chautauqua, N.Y., may sell for more than $100,000 on May 11, when it is auctioned at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: Last and Least
description: How important is the 12th man on National Basketball Association rosters? Apparently, not too important, judging by the numbers. Before Wednesday night's game against the Atlanta Hawks, Eddie Phillips, the Nets' top draft choice and No. 12 man, had not played for 16 consecutive games and was averaging just eight minutes a game.

title: Nehemiah Is Blocked
description: For a day falling amid a holiday season that is supposed to exemplify a sense of hope and new beginnings, yesterday certainly had its share of disappointments for athletes in a number of sports. In track, Renaldo Nehemiah, the star hurdler turned San Francisco 49er receiver, learned that the International Amateur Athletic Federation had turned down his request that, despite his standing as a football professional, he be ruled eligible for future meets.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Wednesday about Drew Lewis's resignation as Secretary of Transportation incorrectly reported a view of Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority in New York. Mr. Ravitch said the elimination of Federal operating subsidies could cause fare increases for some transit systems, but he has not criticized Mr. Lewis for advocating it.

title: Belle Epoque in Photos
description: A selection of 150 photographs from ''La Belle Epoque'' Paris of 1900 to 1918, by Harry C. Ellis, are on view through Jan. 28 in the gallery of the French Institute-Alliance Fran,caise, 22 East 60th Street.

title: Minimum Pay Up in Mexico
description: Minimum wages for Mexican workers will rise about 25 percent Jan.1, the Government announced, benefiting about one-third of the nation's salaried workers.

title: FIDELITY MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: Hart Building Praised

title: LAND RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including a gain of $395,000 from the sale of property

title: Shift by Whittaker
description: The Whittaker Corporation said it had agreed not to increase its holdings in Smith International Inc. stock beyond the 8.3 percent it acquired on Dec. 10.

title: Insurer Income Offsets Losses
description: The nation's property-casualty insurance industry had record underwriting losses in 1982, an industry group said yesterday, but they were offset by record income from investments.

title: W.B. Pressey Is Dead at 88; Held Position at Dartmouth
description: W. Benfield Pressey, a former chairman of the English department at Dartmouth College, died Saturday at his home in Hanover, N.H., after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Gene Moskowitz Dead; Variety Film Critic, 61
description: Gene Moskowitz, the longtime Paris correspondent and film critic of the show-business publication Variety, died of leukemia Wednesday at St. Louis Hospital in Paris. He was 61 years old and lived in Paris.

title: Harvester Loan
description: The City of Rock Island, Ill., said that it planned to withdraw its offer to provide a loan to the International Harvester Company. Rock Island planned to raise $6.97 million in revenue bonds and lend the funds to the maker of farm equipment and trucks to help offset $13 million in costs that will be incurred by Harvester in its move of its axle and transmission production operations to Rock Island from Louisville, Ky. Harvester had originally agreed to use its automated warehouse in Rock Island as collateral for the loan, but later withdrew the offer.

title: DRINKING AND DRIVING: NEW YEAR'S EVE, 1981
description: It was cold, with 1982 less than an hour away. And it was dark, no stars, no moon, just the winter clouds hanging low over the frozen farm fields of southern Indiana along the Ohio River.

title: Lehrman Aide Seeks Charge Against Carey
description: The treasurer of Lewis E. Lehrman's campaign for Governor today asked the Albany County District Attorney to prosecute Governor Carey on charges of official misconduct.

title: CAPITAL AWAITS D'OYLY CARTE COMEDIAN AND HIS WIGS
description: The tears had hardly stopped streaming from the eyes of those in the cast and in the audience at the last performance of the D'Oyly Carte Company in London earlier this year when Martin Feinstein, the general director of the Washington Opera, got on the phone.

title: Markets Today
description: Stock exchanges and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will be open today.

title: Queen Honors Britons In Her New Year's List
description: Entertainers, politicians, athletes and businessmen were among nearly 700 people rewarded today in Queen Elizabeth's list of New Year's honors.

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1982; Companies
description: A company that supplies natural gas to much of the Northeast was ordered to refund perhaps $100 million to customers who were overcharged. A Federal administrative law judge said the Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation had been guilty of ''abuse'' in buying excessive quantities of high-priced gas while reducing its purchases of cheaper gas that was available to it. (Page A1.)

title: Peru Sets Out to Crush Guerrilla Organization
description: About 1,500 soldiers and police rangers began a sweep through southern Peru today on a mission to crush a Maoist guerrilla group.

title: RELATED REFLECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Midland Bank Picks U.S. Branch Officer
description: The Midland Bank of London has named Harry P. Abplanalp executive vice president and chief manager of a New York branch of the bank that opens Monday.

title: Oil and Coal Gain in U.S.
description: Production of crude oil and coal in the United States increased slightly this year despite a decline in energy consumption, according to industry estimates published today.

title: Olin Settlement
description: The Justice Department announced today a tentative settlement of a soil and water pollution suit against the Olin Mathieson Corporation that requires the chemical maker to pay $24 million to settle the claims of private citizens. The clean-up agreement would resolve a suit the Government filed against Olin in December 1980, as a result of its manufacture of the chemical pesticide DDT in Huntsville, Ala., from 1947 to 1970.

title: TWO DANCERS FOR JOFFREY CONNOISSEURS
description: THE Joffrey Ballet has its razzle-dazzlers. There's a fresh influx every year from the apprentice Joffrey II. But for connoisseurs of the company, there's nothing quite like the dancing of Beatriz Rodriguez and Mark Goldweber, who will dance this weekend at City Center, where the Joffrey appears through Jan. 16. (The company performs today at 2 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 and 7:30. Tickets are $10 to $40 tonight, a celebration of New Year's Eve, which includes champagne, and $5 to $30 for other performances. Information: 246-8989. Chargit: 944-9300.)

title: SOVIET DEFEATS NORDIQUES, 3-0
description: The second game of the series between the Soviet national all-stars and National Hockey League teams was far different from the first.

title: Of ethics, sex and religion.
description: ONE of today's more visible and articulate younger artists is Alain Kirili, a 36-year-old French sculptor who left what he calls the ''monolithic society'' of Paris in 1975 to settle in New York. Since then, Mr. Kirili has had one-man exhibitions at the Sonnabend Gallery in New York and participated in group shows at the Museum of Modern Art, the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington and last summer at the Jewish Museum. Three of his recent sculptures will be on display in the sculpture garden of the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at 92d Street, until mid-May.

title: A VISIT TO THE BROOKLYN OF 'SOPHIE'S CHOICE'
description: HE was 22 years old, Southern and new to New York: Brooklyn might as well have been an exotic foreign land. When he got off the subway at the Church Avenue station and took his first ''intoxicating breaths of the pickle-fragrant air of Flatbush,'' Stingo was beginning a cultural as well as a geographical odyssey.

title: United Airlines Hijacking Foiled by Pilot's Trick
description: The pilot of a United Airlines 727 with 80 passengers told a would-be hijacker that the plane was running out of fuel and that he had to land at Greater Pittsburgh International Airport, the authorities said. A man was taken into custody on suspicion of trying to hijack the plane to Washington.

title: Market Place; Investing Overseas
description: DESPITE political uncertainties, economic upheavals, language problems, currency difficulties, monetary controls and dozens of other headaches in many foreign countries, American corporations have searched the globe for years for new places to build factories or set up shop. Why? Because they can often make far higher profits abroad than they can in this country.

title: Legal Aid Lawyers Ratify New Pact
description: Lawyers for the Legal Aid Society voted yesterday to accept a new contract and end their 10-week-old strike. The vote, at a closed meeting, was 298 to 108, according to Gary Sloman, a spokesman for the lawyers' union, the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys. Mr. Sloman said the lawyers, who represent indigent defendants in criminal cases in New York City, would be back on the job Monday.

title: Real Estate; Sites Sold For Large L.I. Homes
description: ABOUT three years ago Daniele D. Bodini took a call from an attorney. The 160-acre estate of the late Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Manufacturers Trust Company from the 1930's to the early 1950's, was for sale, the lawyer said. Was Mr. Bodini's firm, American Continental Properties Inc., interested?

title: AMADAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
DORFMAN ASSETS CURB UPHELD
description: A three-judge Federal appeals panel today refused to stay an order by District Judge Nicholas Bua to place in receivership the assets of four businesses owned by Allen M. Dorfman, who was convicted in the teamsters bribery conspiracy trial.

title: Funds Down $6.5 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds dropped $6.5 billion, to $210.9 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, marking the fourth consecutive week of declines, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Adams Resources
description: Adams Resources and Energy Inc. said its creditors had waived until March 31, 1983, the technical default that arose Sept. 30 under its loan agreement.

title: 6 ARE SELECTED BY O'NEILL TO BE DEPARTMENT HEADS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, ending eight weeks of speculation about appointments to cabinet posts for his first full term, today selected six new department heads and said he would renominate 16 other commissioners already holding state office.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Net loss includes a net loss of $220,000 on the repossession of stores previously sold

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IF you didn't happen to be an International Debutante, it was, by a ll reports, a poor week for partying. But the debutante whirl was d izzying indeed - parties at the Metropolitan Club, Regine's and D oubles - for the 57 young women whose week peaked on Wednesday e vening in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom, where they were p resented to society at the International Debutante Ball. Since the e vening benefited the Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Club, the g uests paid $150 a head for the privilege.

title: VATICAN COUNTERS ATTACK BY SOVIET
description: The Vatican reacted sternly today to a sharp personal attack by the Soviet Union on Pope John Paul II. The response was as unusual as the attack itself. The Soviet Union has not in many years directed strong public criticism against a pope, and the Vatican rarely dignifies political attacks with a reply.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Laser Photonics Inc. filed with the S.E.C. for an initial offering of 800,000 shares, through D.H. Blair & Co.

title: Jean Jagels Wed To Peter Vaughn
description: Jean Elise Jagels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Daniel Jagels of San Marino, Calif., was married yesterday to Peter Graham Vaughn, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Hurd Vaughn of New York and Lakeville, Conn. The Rev. Michael Boyle of Phoenix performed the ceremony in St. Phillip's Roman Catholic Church in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Samuel Mellitz, Judge And University Trustee
description: Samuel Mellitz, former associate justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors, died last Sunday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 91 years old, and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: NATHAN NATHANSON
description: Nathan Nathanson, former chief assistant appraiser of the United States Customs Service, died Tuesday of respiratory failure at his home in Manhattan.

title: SCHWEIKER PROPOSES TO RELAX FEDERAL REGULATION OF SMALL HOSPITALS
description: The Reagan Administration proposed today to curtail Federal regulation of smaller hospitals. The Department of Health and Human Services formally proposed to relax or repeal many of the detailed requirements that hospitals must satisfy as a condition of participating in Medicare and Medicaid, the Federal programs for the elderly and the poor.

title: Gator Bowl Won By Florida State
description: Billy Allen scored on a 95-yard kickoff return and Greg Allen, the nation's scoring leader, scored twice as Florida State overpowered West Virginia, 31-12, in the Gator Bowl tonight.

title: TENANTS FIGHT TO SAVE 'MODEL' WEST SIDE TENEMENTS
description: Residents of an 80-year-old housing complex near Lincoln Center that was designed to be a model for tenements were joined by elected officials yesterday in calling for major renovations to the nowdilapidated, largely abandoned buildings.

title: Georgia Scouting Report
description: Georgia is an incredibly talented team, perhaps a better team than the one that was ranked No. 1 in 1980. The thing you don't realize until you scout them is that they can beat you in so many ways.

title: Bear, Stearns In Revere Deal
description: Asarco Inc. said it had accepted an offer from Bear, Stearns & Company to buy its entire interest in Revere Copper and Brass Inc. for $17 million in cash. The interest comprises 1.9 million shares of Revere common stock and $22.8 million principal amount of revere's 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Dr. Cooley Praises Physicians In Artificial Heart Operation
description: Dr. Denton Cooley, the heart transplant specialist, complimented doctors who implanted the permanent artificial heart in Dr. Barney Clark five weeks ago.

title: Capitals 4, Whalers 4
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Chris Valentine, in his first N.H.L. game this season, scored a disputed goal at 7:41 of the third period and gave Washington a tie.

title: Economic Scene; How to Make 1983 Happier
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE is a time for nostalgia and looking ahead. But the nostalgia over 1982 is curdled: The year turned out much worse than expected. Last February, the President's Council of Economic Advisers said in its annual report: ''The current recession is expected to end early in 1982.'' It has still not ended. And a major worry for the coming year is that unemployment, now close to 11 percent, will hang on near that level as employers continue to keep payrolls lean in an effort to operate profitably.

title: 'Staying Alive' with a couple of tough guys.
description: NEXT Monday, Sylvester Stallone begins his new job, directing John Travolta in the sequel to ''Saturday Night Fever,'' which is called ''Staying Alive.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: The light-heavyweight unification bout between Michael Spinks, the W.B.A. champion, and Dwight Muhammad Qawi, the World Boxing Council titleholder, will be held March 4 in either Atlantic City or Caracas, Venezuela. Each fighter, said Butch Lewis, the promoter, will earn $2.1 million. ... The Philadelphia Stars of the United States Football League have settled their lawsuit against Michigan State that stemmed from the university's hiring away George Perles, the Stars' coach.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1982
description: International Key foreign policy experts will serve on the commission that will evaluate options for basing the MX missile, White House officials reported. They said that President Reagan planned to appoint as chairmen Brent Scowcroft, a former White House national security adviser, and that the panel members would include former Defense Secretary Harold Brown and former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. (Page A1, Column 3.) No static, undefended land base would be totally secure from Soviet nuclear destruction, advocates of the MX missile acknowledge. As a result, the quest for a way to base the missile will prompt a scrutiny of small mobile missiles, air and sea basing schemes and the present components of the nation's nuclear deterrent. (A1:4.)

title: JAPANESE CABINET APPROVES BUDGET INCREASING ARMS OUTLAY 6.5%
description: ThePrime Minister and his Cabinet approved an austere budget today that covers the fiscal year beginning April 1. It provides for cuts in allocations for education and many other services but, in response to American urging, would increase military spending.

title: Happy Mercedonius
description: In ancient Rome, every two years there was an extra month, called Mercedonius, because calendars of the time were too short. The Romans' 12 months added up to only 355 days, which any schoolboy knows is 10.25 days fewer than it takes Earth to make it around the sun. Then Julius Caesar commanded his astronomers to end the chaos, and they came up with a year of 365 days plus an extra day every fourth year. Over a stretch of years this turned out to be a little too long, so Pope Gregory's astronomers knocked out the extra day when it fell in a year divisible by 400. Hence 1900 was a leap year but 2000 won't be. That's the calendar we use today, and it's time to acknowledge that it's gotten too short again.

title: Memorial Service Set Today For New Hampshire Governor
description: A memorial service will be held Friday afternoon at the New Hampshire Statehouse for Gov. Hugh Gallen, 58 years old, who died Wednesday of liver and kidney failure.

title: Excuse It, Please
description: As has long been known, there are lies, damn lies, statistics and reporters' errors. Thus, an annual column of confession, while it may be good neither for the soul nor for the digestion, is necessary to clear the record and answer the mail.

title: Bridge: Four Outstanding Figures In New York Died in 1982
description: During 1982, the bridge world lost four New York experts, each of whom has a special claim to be remembered: David Mason, as a calm and efficient administrator; Abe Goldstein, as an outstanding teacher; Barbara Kachmar, as a highly entertaining writer, and Augusta Cantor, as an enthusiast with a virtually perfect record of tournament attendance.

title: WALTER READE PRESIDENT 'ANGRY' AT PLANNED OFFER
description: Sheldon Gunsberg is 62 but says he feels like ''2 million.'' His mood can be easily described: ''I think 'angry' is the correct word.''

title: Penn State Scouting Report
description: Penn State has moved into a position to be the No. 1 team in the country for three reasons. Its offense can hurt you badly both running and passing; its rebuilt offensive line has done the job, and the defense, especially at linebacker, is as strong as ever.

title: PENN STATE AT A GLANCE
description: Offense 19 GREGG GARRITY: Senior split end, 5 feet 10 inches, 170 pounds; 32 receptions, 509 yards, three touchdowns. Son of a former Penn State end, Jim Garrity (1952-1954). A defensive back before becoming a regular receiver in 1981. 78 RON HELLER: Junior tackle, 6-6, 248. A tight end and defensive end for two seasons until moved to offensive tackle last August. Was 1980 New York State heavyweight wrestling champion at Farmingdale (L.I.) High School. 56 PETE SPEROS: Senior guard, 6-2, 253. An offensive co-captain. Was a starting tackle last year but moved to guard as replacement for 1981 all-American, Sean Farrell. 59 MARK BATTAGLIA: Senior center, 6-2, 243. Does well despite not being as big as some major college centers. 54 DICK MAGINNIS: Junior guard, 6-2, 250. Doubtful starter because of pulled hamstring muscle. Defensive end and defensive tackle in 1979; moved to offense in 1981. Will be replaced by Dave Laube if unable to start. 79 BILL CONTZ: Senior tackle, 6-6, 252. Strong and reliable. Only returning starter at current position from outstanding line of 1981. 81 MIKE McCLOSKEY: Senior tight end, 6-5, 240. 18 receptions; 227 yards; one touchdown. Latest of fine Lion tight ends that include Ted Kwalick, Bob Parsons and Mickey Shuler. 14 TODD BLACKLEDGE: Junior quarterback, 6-4, 219. 292 passes, 161 completions, 2,218 yards, 22 touchdowns, 14 interceptions.

title: Mitsubishi Prices
description: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc., based in Fountain Valley, Calif., has dropped prices on three 1983 models of light-duty trucks. The new suggested retail price of the Mighty Max truck is $5,749, down $240. The two-wheel-drive version of the 2.3-liter turbo-diesel truck is $7,879, a drop of $180, and the four-wheel-drive version is $9,839, down $240.

title: 9.5% Jobless Rate In New York State
description: New York State's unemployment rate last month continued up, to 9.5 percent, the State Labor Department reported today.

title: U.S. AIDES ASSERT A BREAKTHROUGH ON ARMS DOESN'T SEEM IMMINENT
description: Administration officials cautioned today that President Reagan's recently expressed optimism about the future of Soviet-American arms talks did not mean that a breakthrough was imminent, or that there were any plans for a meeting soon with Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet leader.

title: Talks on Loan To Argentina
description: The 11 international banks in charge of assembling a $1.1 billion bridge loan for Argentina are expected to meet this afternoon at Citibank headquarters in New York to sign the deal, according to bankers.

title: IF A DRIVER'S PHOTO WERE ON THE LICENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Icahn Extension
description: The Icahn Group said it is extending to Jan. 5 its tender offer for up to two million shares of Dan River Inc. at $18 a share.

title: Blackledge Ponders Pros
description: Todd Blackledge, Penn State's quarterback, said today that he would turn professional next year instead of playing one more season for Penn State if he were to be selected in either the first or second round of the National Football League draft in April.

title: Debra R. Maloy and John G. Walsh Wed in Albany
description: Debra Ruth Maloy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Maloy of Loudonville, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Gaynor Walsh 3d, son of Mrs. Walsh Jr., of Albany and the late Mr. Walsh. Bishop Edwin B. Broderick, the executive director of Catholic Relief Services, and Msgr.

title: POP BANDS: AFRICAN CONNECTION AND KONK
description: AFRICAN CONNECTION and Konk played for a houseful of happy dancers on Wednesday at the Underground. African Connection, now based in Brooklyn, has members from Ghana, Nigeria, Surinam and Liberia, and may well be the only African pop band in New York.

title: John Carroll, 71, Dead; Expert on Photography
description: John S. Carroll, author and senior technical editor of the 14-volume Encyclopedia of Practical Photography, died Dec. 23 from injuries suffered in a fall at his home in Emlenton, Pa. He was 71 years old.

title: PACT REACHED AT TIMES OF LONDON
description: Management and union officials of The Times of London reached a tentative agreement early today that could lead to the reappearance of the newspaper on Monday if approved by striking electricians, the newpaper's management said.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Signed a free a gent, Jim Smith, forward, to a 10-day c ontract.

title: Comalco's Showa Stake
description: Comalco Ltd., an integrated aluminium maker, said today that it had completed its purchase of a 50 percent stake in Showa Aluminium Industries of Japan for about $10.7 million. The other 50 percent is owned by Showa Denko.

title: Holders Tender 50% Of El Paso
description: Burlington Northern Inc. said early today that its tender offer for stock in the El Paso Company had attracted 24.83 million shares by the deadline of midnight last night. This preliminary count put the total tendered at ''approximately 50 percent'' of El Paso common, a spokesman for the company said.

title: Article 133209 -- No Title
description: The 71st annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received a total of $1,037,274.62 in contributions. It is the 13th year in a row that the fund has surpassed the million-dollar mark, and the amount raised the prospect of another record in donations.

title: 10 Nations Join African Bank
description: Ten non-African countries today joined the African Development Bank, allowing it to raise lending for development projects.

title: G.& W. Sells Holding
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that under the terms of a previously announced agreement it had sold its entire holding of 3.33 million common shares of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company to Pilkington Brothers P.L.C. for $106 million in cash.

title: BIG 3 LIKELY TO EXTEND CAR-FINANCING RATE CUT
description: The Big Three auto makers are expected to announce extensions of their interest-rate incentive programs, which had been scheduled to expire Friday.

title: TWO SHORTCUTS TO SEATS AT THE MOVIES
description: To the Editor:

title: LILLIAN GISH, AT 83, TRANSCENDS STYLE
description: Lillian Gish has never cared more than a small hoot about fashion, but she's always loved clothes. The result is that the legendary actress is still wearing some of the things she bought three, four and five decades ago, and outshining most of the current crop of fashion strivers whenever she appears at gala events. Whether it's at Radio City Music Hall or the White House, Miss Gish looks so right that there are incredulous glances when she says that she honestly can't remember how many years the dress has been in her closet and, in fact, whether it originally belonged to her or to her late sister, Dorothy.

title: Hockey Odyssey
description: It was supposed to be a nice winter-vacation trip for the Colgate University hockey team, with a game against Denver University last Monday and then a two-day holiday tournament at the Broadmoor Hotel in Colorado Springs.

title: MUSIC: SCHNEIDER'S STRINGS
description: EACH year for the last 14 years, the violinist Alexander Schneider has led a seminar in New York for young string players. During the Christmas holidays, students from music schools and colleges around the country study chamber and orchestral performance, and perform in concerts at Carnegie Hall and at the Kennedy Center in Washington.
